column2: WASHINGTON, April 28 -- For the first time since the country went to war, no soldier patrolled up and down in front of the White House on Pennsylvania Avenue today.

Sinclair dealers' servicing for prolonging car life, and Sinclair's part in the war effort, will be the features in its new advertising campaign starting the week of May 15. About 100 newspapers in seventy-three cities will be contracted for 10,000 lines each, and 70 per cent of the linage will be used in the first three months.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, April 29 (U.P.) -- Roaring in over the Wewak, Dagua, Borm and But airdromes Thursday morning, Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney's big Liberator bombers dumped 2,000-pound bombs on every runway, spreading fires throughout the area.

The report of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago for the first three months of this year, issued yesterday by Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, shows a net income, after expenses, taxes and other charges, of $5,864 484. This was equal to 46 cents a share on the company's outstanding capital stock, and compares with a net of 155,766,980, or 54 cents a share, in the three months to March 31, 1943.

"Sol Over Klara" ("Sun Over Klara"), a Swedish importation, will have its local premiere today at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. The picture, starring Edward Persson, is a comedy of artists' life, set in the Bohemian quarter of Stockholm. The film is equipped with English titles and is slatted to be shown through Sunday, May 14.

Hitting at what he claimed were "enemy attempts to foment distrust and misunderstanding between Japan and the Soviet Union" through "wild, fantastic stories," Sadao Iguchi, spokesman for the Japanese Board of Information, declared yesterday that Japan "will place implicit faith and trust in the Soviet Union's integrity, sincerity and respect for international agreements," the Japanese Domei agency reported in an English-language wireless dispatch to Europe.

The work of restoring to their places in City Hall the eighty-four valuable portraits removed to safe shelter soon after Dec. 7, 1941, began yesterday when fourteen of these works of art were brought back under supervision of the Municipal Art Commission.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 28 -- Dr. Sam Black of Spartanburg, S.C., had the satisfaction today of riding the Dutchess County Hills behind his 2-year-old white, liver and ticked pointer dog and hear later the announcement that the judges had awarded the first trophy to his Sam's Souvenir.

Apprentice Jockey Bobby Permane, the boy wonder of the Florida racing season, was at it again at Jamaica yesterday when he booted home the two winners of the split Laurelton which, together with the Lynbrook, topped a card that lured 22,938 persons to the track.

NAPLES, April 28 (U.P.) -- Patrol activities on all Italian fronts rose to a new aggressive pitch today as opposing armies sparred for an advantage along the deadlocked battle lines from Anzio to the Adriatic.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- Concern is felt here about the possible danger to the security of the Allies' plans created by the presence in Washington of an accredited Finnish diplomatic mission, it was learned today.

Imitation Mexican jade, in reality dyed calcite, is causing considerable trouble in the jewelry field throughout this country, it was disclosed yesterday at the international wartime conference of the American Gem Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The perennial fight in Congress over the high taxes on colored margarine is drawing more attention throughout the nation this year than ever before because of the shortage of fats and the rising cost of living.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- The Braves continued to feature pitching today, as Nate Andrews went the route in an eleven-inning 2-to-1 victory over the Phillies. He allowed seven hits.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Effective May 1 and until July 31 lightweight newsprint manufactured outside the United States may be bought by United States consumers at ceiling prices not in excess of $4 a ton above maximum prices for standard weight newsprint, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- After a hearing in Federal District Court today, Judge William H. Holly deferred until Monday further hearings on the petition of Montgomery Ward Co. to dissolve a temporary injunction restraining the chairman, Sewell L. Avery, and other company officials from interfering with Government operation of the concern's Chicago properties.

lVfost of the perpetual trophies in the Metropolitan Miami winter fishing tournament, now through 'with its ninety-nine-day run, were taken by New Yorrc City anglers, according to the final compilation of results.

UNITED STATES HEAVY BOMBER HEADQUARTERS, in England, April 28 (AP) -- The Eighth Air Force is taking steps to eliminate "overly enthusiastic" reports of crewmen from news stories dealing with American bombing raids.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 28 (AP) -- Because of the Government's legal proceedings against Sydney newspapers on charges of censorship violations, the National Broadcasting Company station here suddenly canceled today a transcribed address by Kent Cooper, Executive Director and General Manager of The Associated Press, on Freedom of the Press.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, April 29 (UP) -- A communique:

DETROIT, April 28 (AP) -- Mel Harder, 34-year-old curve-baller, whose goal is 200 American League pitching victories, racked up his 198th today by spacing ten hits to give the Indians a 2-to-1 decision over the Tigers in the opener of their series. Cleveland thus ended a four-game losing streak.

IT used to be said that if you scratched a Russian you'd find a Tartar. But nowadays if you scratch a Russian you find a Russian. Even anti-Communist emigres such as Prof. Pitirim A. Sorokin of Harvard have been caught up in the emotional swell caused by reaction to the Nazi invasion, of Mother Russia's holy soil. Consequently it is no great surprise to come upon "Frossia: A Novel of Russia,"* by E.M. Almedingen.

LONDON, April 28 -- Maj. Gen. Paul R. Hawley, chief surgeon for the United States forces in the European Theatre of Operations, indicated today that the hospital program for the invasion is about complete and that a physically fit Army, with men bigger in stature than in World War I, will go into the field with medical facilities better than any other army ever had.

PITTSBURGH, April 28 -- Further experimental tests offered as evidence in support of his hypothesis that "not only electric currents but also magnetic currents flow through the universe" were described here today at the meeting of the American Physical Society, at the Mellon Institute, by Dr. Felix Ehrenhaft, Professor of Physics at the University of Vienna in the pre-Nazi era.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 -- A reassuring picture of the extent of Army preparedness for caring for the wounded was given here today by Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, who disclosed that the Army already had provided in its sixty- three general hospitals throughout the country sufficient beds for all casualties anticipated in the European invasion.

RICHMOND, Va., April 28 -- Patents on an improved orange tree and a couple of electronic microscopes illustrate the broad range covered by the 475 listed as issued in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

Eight-year-old Mike Moran rescued a small "poodle" from the frozen Harlem River last winter and yesterday, on his ninth birthday, his heroism was recognized when he received a certificate of award issued by the American Humane Society upon recommendation of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today announced plans for filming the Army life story of Sgt. Charles E. (Commando) Kelly, who recently received the Congressional Medal for heroic exploits in Italy. It is understood that Sergeant Kelly will be paid $25,000 for the film rights and a like amount by The Saturday Evening Post for rights to serialization, which will precede picture production.

LONDON, April 28 -- Signalizing the close of the most important Anglo-American diplomatic talks since the Teheran conference, the Foreign Office issued tonight a joint communique expressing "great satisfaction" with the results of the visit of Edward R. Stettinius Jr., United States Under-Secretary of State, and his mission of experts to discuss immediate and long-term problems of war and peace.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Prospects are good, it was learned today, for calling a conference of Allied and associated countries in May to discuss stabilization of world currencies on the basis of the $8,000,000,000 monetary fund accepted in principle by the countries' experts.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- In a letter today to Representative Emanuel Celler of New York, Jan Ciechanowski, the Polish Ambassador, said that his Government and nation were "decidedly not anti-Semitic," but were "actively working to save the Jewish people."

KEARNY, N.J., April 28 -- The unrest among members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations unions at the Kearny and Port Newark plants of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company flared this afternoon in a wildcat walkout of a small group at the latter plant.

Turkey's abrupt suspension of shipments of chrome ore to the Reich seems to have come as a terrific shock to the trusting Nazis. What hurts, apparently, is not so much the loss of the ore, badly needed and already paid for, as the thought of betrayal by a trusted friend. Officially, up to a late hour yesterday, Berlin had not taken notice of the heartless act, but a military spokesman could not contain his feelings.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Declaring that the International Labor Organization simply could not function for any length of time without the affiliation of the Soviet Union, Walter Nash, president of the International Labor Conference, delivered a strong plea today for Russia to come back into the ILO.

CINCINNATI, April 28 (AP) -- The Reds continued their low-scoring but winning ways today by defeating Pittsburgh, 2 -- 0, behind Ed Heusser's seven-hit hurling. The triumph gave them a second- place tie with the idle Cardinals.

That a shortage of manpower threatens disruption of the country's retail food distribution system is indicated in a nation-wide survey made by the Supermarket Institute, revealing the loss of 10,881 employes to the armed forces and war industries out of a total personnel of 14,599, M. M. Zimmerman, director of the institute declared yesterday.

It seemed to me that this vivid glimpse of English literary folk rescuing their libraries was worth sharing. The following excerpts are from a letter written by Mrs. E. Thornton Cook, author of "Justly Dear," "Royal Elizabeths" and other books from London, where she holds a position in the Ministry of Information:

The old brownstone mansion at 579 Fifth Avenue, at the northeast corner of Forty-seventh Street, which was acquired by the late Jay Gould at the height of his career as a railroad financier, has been sold, it became known last night.

Readers continue to lay their language grievances on our doorstep. This time a reader from Albany worries about Bishop Arthur Moore, who said in Kansas City that the world's 8,000,000 Methodists "must rise up and demand an international organization."

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- General chairmen of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen will vote tomorrow in favor of the issuance of a strike ballot to 12,000 members employed on twenty-six Southeastern railroads, it was learned tonight.

Three suits for an aggregate of $1,540,540 have been flied against the New York Curb Exchange by former partners in the former Curb Exchange firm of Avery Co., which was forced to suspend business as the result of disciplinary action by the Exchange against two of the partners, the Exchange revealed yesterday.

The Government never can equal or supplant private philanthropic enterprise in the care of the physically handicapped, Governor Dewey declared last night as he presented two awards at the twenty-seventh annual exercises of the Institute for Crippled and Disabled, 400 First Avenue, and heard himself characterized, at least inferentially, as a future President of the United States.

Erich Kleiber, the eminent Austrian conductor, has returned to this city after an absence of twelve years to direct four performances of Mozart's "The Abduction from the Seraglio" for the Juilliard School of Music, the first of which was presented last night in the Juilliard Concert Hall.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 28 -- At commencement exercises today at Sarah Lawrence College here a Bachelor of Arts degree was awarded to the wife of a lieutenant colonel, who has two children attending the college's nursery school, is herself a trustee of the college and in the autumn will join the social science faculty as an economics instructor.
Charles C. Ort has sold his property in Washington Township, Morris County, known as the Braeuning estate, to Peter Pasini and Pierre Girando, for occupancy.

SEAT OF THE ITALIAN GOVERNMENT, April 28 -- The statement of policy along democratic lines which followed the first meeting yesterday of the new government of liberated Italy has found general approval among the Allied powers, and it is equally evident that the Italian people, as far as anyone can judge, reserve, as one of the first benefits under the new, liberal regime, the right to be indifferent to it.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Domestic stocks of wheat, corn and oats declined about 26 per cent during the year ended on April 1, reflecting heavy use of grain for livestock feed and industrial purposes, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

VVASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -The last fight of Private Bob Booker, 22, had more of gallantry and devotion than the Army knew at first. He died at Fondouk in Tunisia on April 9, 1943. Part of the story was told and the Army presented the Distinguished Service Cross to his widow.

LONDON, Saturday, April 29 -- Seemingly endless fleets of heavy, medium and fighter bombers maintained the offensive against German defenses, air fields and communications in northern France yesterday, with at least 2,000 war planes of all types participating in the continuing invasion air onslaught.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Three questions which were represented as "causing uneasiness" in Great Britain, each concerning a possible change in the United States Administration from Democratic to Republican were answered tonight by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, a Republican member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee assigned to study post-war peace enforcement collaboration programs with Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

United States Attorney James B.M. McNally warned yesterday that he would continue the vigorous prosecution of black market operators that already has caused price gougers to look about for safer places than the Southern Federal District of New York for their operations.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Under-Secretary James V. Forrestal, for the Navy, reflected today a "show me" attitude toward the merits of the proposal for unification of the armed services and opposed any suggestion that it might be attempted before the close of the war.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York's Free Synagogue was greeted by leaders of Chicago's Christian clergy today as American Jewry's foremost spokesman and the country's "great humanitarian who is capacious enough to be an inspiration to the thought and ideals of all mankind."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, April 28 -- One hundred missionaries, including forty nuns, have been rescued from the Japanese in the Hollandia area, Gen. Douglas MacArthur personally announced tonight with the remark that this appears "an especially beneficient act of providence."

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- Solomon Freedman, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that a type of refinancing proposed by Northern Indiana Public Service Company would "undermine the purpose of competitive bidding."

Reynolds Co. started out yesterday morning to make a special offering of 4,000 shares of Reed Roller Bit Company common stock on the New York Curb Exchange at 22 1/4. It succeeded, but at the close of the day the company found itself owning 2,600 shares of the stock as the result of a combination of such misadventures as lies in wait for any special offering.

Joseph Sweat, National Maritime Union political action director, led a delegation of 55 NMU seamen and eight women of the auxiliary from union headquarters at 346 West Seventeenth Street to the State War Ballot Commission, 80 Center Street, yesterday morning to demand simplification of war ballots for members of the merchant marine.

LONDON, April 28 -- A good volume of business was reported for today's stock markets, which still were under the influences of the favorable impression made by the Government budget and of reinvestment of the 5 per cent Conversion Loan money to be paid on next Monday.

Denial of charges made against him by the Cincinnati Musicians Union, American Federation of Labor, for which a fine of $1,250 and a three-month suspension of membership were imposed, was made yesterday by Eugene Goossens, conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra.

These were not the Bow bells ringing in London town, they were the bells of Trinity Church at Broadway and Wall Street that 10-year-old Ronald Finnegan heard at noon yesterday and they might well have said. "Turn again, Finnegan, thrice Mayor of New York Town," even as legend has them saying to little Dick, later Sir Richard, Whittington.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- An attempt to give a legislative definition of "small business," which has defied the efforts of members of Congress to date, will be made Monday at an executive session of the Senate's special committee named to study the problems of small business enterprises.

There is appearing now in the daytime dress departments in leading stores throughout the country a collection of dresses in size eight. The new size is keyed to the mature figures of women who desire sophisticated fashions and heretofore have been obliged to incur expensive alterations that have not always been successful.
BOSTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Athletics broke a 5-5 deadlock in the sixteenth inning today as Woody Wheaton singled with the bases loaded to drive home two runs for a 7-5 triumph over the Red Sox.

Warnings that the peace treaty will be a "compromise" and less than an ideal settlement were issued here yesterday by two educators addressing an institute of the National Peace Conference in the auditorium of the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association, 600 Lexington Avenue.

Winning the longest game, in ninety moves, from Lewis J. Isaacs of Chicago in the United States chess championship at the Manhattan Club, where tenth-round matches were played off, Albert S. Pinkus of Brooklyn last night tied for second place with Reuben Fine of Washington.

Just Seven Words Every important bank and foreign-exchange dealer in the nation has been obliged to set aside a sizable filing cabinet for the exclusive purpose of keeping the numerous rules, and amendments and interpretations thereof, issued by the Foreign Funds Control Department of the Treasury.

Mrs. Gertrude Berg, creator of the radio series "The Goldbergs," has completed the first act of a stage dramatization of her characters, it was learned yesterday. Mrs. Berg, who has a contract with John Golden to produce the play when it is ready, has read the act to Mr. Golden, who describes it as "very good."

ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP) -- A minority stockholders' fight against the Alleghany Corporation for control of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company was disclosed today with solicitation of proxies by a committee composed of F. Douglass Wilson of Plainfield, Ill., and Andrew W. Comstock of Evanston, Ill.

The principles that bind the peoples of the English-speaking nations should serve to organize the world for prosperity and peace, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday at a luncheon given by the Pilgrims of the United Sta in honor of the Archbishop of York, Primate of England, at the Hotel Biltmore.
A communique broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHUNGKING, China, April 28 (AP) -- Chinese defenders have driven the Japanese troops from strategic Hulao Pass, gateway to Loyang, annihilating a large portion of them, the Chinese High Command said tonight in announcing that successes both east and southeast of Loyang had eased threats to the city.
FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., April 28 -- Nineteen persons were killed in the crash of a Navy transport plane in the rugged country thirty miles southeast of here early today.

In a presentment handed yesterday to County Judge Nathan R. Sobel, a Kings County grand jury recommended formation of a citizens committee to help stamp out organized crime in Brooklyn and the legalization of horse race betting outside of race tracks as well as inside.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, died at his home here this afternoon at the age of 70. The Navy was in mourning for its vigorous leader, who in his four years of office directed the unprecedented development of the United States fleet from an inadequate, undermanned organization to the mightiest navy afloat.

LONDON, April 28 -- This has been a week of conferences. There have been conferences on diplomatic affairs, conferences on vital military matters and preliminary talks on Empire affairs. And in one little corner of central London today there was a conference devoted to the welfare of Britain's housewives and the mothers of this country's future generations.

The apartment house for twenty families at 2525 Frisby Avenue, in the Bronx, was sold by Sandor and Etel Bede to Sophia Bugen for cash over a first mortgage of $41,483 through F.M. Weiss Co., brokers.

Fears that Congress will be unable to recapture the extraordinary powers it has delegated to the Executive branch of the Government to wage and win the war, although widely held, are groundless, Senator Alben W. Barkley, majority leader of the Senate, told The Kentuckians last night at their fortieth anniversary dinner at the Lotos Club, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street.

BUFFALO, April 28 -- Women of the Buffalo-Niagara area are leaving war plants at a rate which, since they form the only worker reserve available, is alarming, and are entering non essential jobs, according to the area War Manpower Committee.

LONDON, Saturday, April 29 -- A general feeling of sorrow in this country over the death of Secretary Knox was reflected today in all London morning newspapers, which devote considerable space on their front pages to the news from Washington.

The eleventh annual $1,250 prize of the Julia Ellsworth Ford Foundation for Children's Literature has been awarded to Laura Newbold for her biography for young people, "Raymond L. Ditmars: His Exciting Career with Reptiles, Insects and Animals."
After opening with overnight losses of 3 to 5 points, the cotton market turned barely steady and closed virtually at the lows of the day, 13 to 17 points net lower on active months.

LONDON, Saturday, April 29 (AP) -- Red Army troops killed 800 Germans and Hungarians in repulsing attacks southeast of Stanislav in Poland yesterday, and Soviet long-range aircraft touched off fires and explosions Thursday night in a mass attack on Lwow, sixty-five miles northwest of Stanislav, a Moscow communique said early today in announcing "no substantial changes" on the land front.

CHICAGO April 28 -- Buyers for several large wet corn processing plants expressed themselves today as much pleased with the response by farmers to the Government's program designed to stimulate the movement of surplus grains from five Central Western States.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY ON THE GARIGLIANO FRONT, April 28 -- There is an American regimental combat team here with one battalion of 105-mm. howitzer men who had not had a casualty until German gunners firing from mountains on both sides laid down a surprise barrage the other day, killing two and wounding eight others.

Yesterday's TIMES carried a finely nostalgic editorial on "Stovepipe Cleaning." I was concerned, however, to notice a dangerous omission from this important account. Years of boyhood experience as an assisting priest at this spring ritual of the stovepipe taught me that if pipe and chimney fires are to be avoided the soot must be burned out of each length and elbow while the pipe is on the ground outdoors.

PEARL HARBOR, April 28 (U.P.) -- Army and Navy fliers, extending the power of four-engined land-based bombers 1,100 miles beyond the Marshalls, bombed Guam, Japanese-occupied former United States naval station, on Monday, it was announced today.

Long before the present war it had become fashionable to talk about the decline and growing disintegration of the British Empire. So prevalent was the notion that "England's day is done," not only among the Empire's enemies but even among some British intellectuals, that it gave rise to speculation as to who would inherit the pieces.

LONDON, April 28 -- The gathering of British Commonwealth Prime Ministers for their first joint conference of the war was four-fifths completed today when a sprightly man of 73 stepped out of a big Spitfire-escorted transport plane near London at dawn.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- W.L. Clayton, Surplus War Property Administrator, today announced a program of "aggressive action" designed to expedite the movement back into production of property left in the hands of private producers by the termination of war contracts.

The Clergy Committee of Washington Heights, which includes pastors of Roman Catholic churches, rabbis of synagogues and ministers of Protestant churches, will call upon congregations of all faiths to assemble at 8 P.M. on D-Day, or Invasion Day for prayer and worship.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- The Society for the Advancement of Management, delving into the problems of reabsorbing and relocating service men and war workers, heard a forecast today that the real work of the post-war period would be in placement rather than reabsorption, and an intimation by a returned veteran that while he wanted job security, he also wanted a change in the type of work.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Miss Anna Lord Strauss of New York City was elected president of the National League of Women Voters today over the official candidate of the nominating committee, Miss Ruth H. Mitchell of St. Cloud, Minn.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from James F. Brownlee, Deputy Administrator for OPA. Mr. Brownlee argues that the Government cannot fix the price of necessities without being compelled also to fix the price of practically all luxuries. His argument is that if you fix the price only of necessities the relative profit from the production of necessities falls.

The Seamen's Bank for Savings has sold to Benjamin Winter the fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 544 East Eighty-sixth Street, in the Carl Schurz Park section, in his first purchase of a large housing property in ten years.

OTTAWA, April 28 (Canadian Press) -- Group Capt. Denton Massey, Progressive Conservative Member of Parliament for Toronto, a tall young man in Royal Canadian Air Force uniform, stood in a hushed House of Commons this afternoon and said that, to a man from overseas, Canada appeared to be a nation enjoying the greatest prosperity in history rather than a nation motivated by a "full-out" war effort.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- United States production of munitions in March rose 3 per cent above the February level, ending a three-month expected down trend, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said today.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- The Browns tied a modern major league opening-season record today when they defeated the White Sox, 3 to 1, for their ninth successive victory since the start of the campaign.

Because margarine will be reduced from six to two points a pound beginning tomorrow, and shortening and oils have already been removed from rationing, we are able to have more meat than usual in the menus for next week. Seven-and-a-half-pounds will be used by our family of two sedentary adults and a school-age child, plus two pounds of fish and one pound of bacon.
The death of Secretary Knox was characterized by civic and political spokesmen as a tragic loss to the nation.

While overseas operations of the United Service Organizations, Inc., have doubled during the last year, the agency program has been amplified so that every military hospital within this country is now serviced by its nearest USO unit, it was revealed yesterday at the first meeting of the group's national council held in agency headquarters at the Empire State Building.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, April 29 (AP) -- American Army and Navy fliers, seeking to forestall any attempt by the Japanese to bolster their crippled air arm on New Guinea, poured more than 300 tons of bombs on enemy airdromes from the western tip of the huge island to Rabaul and Kavieng in the east.

Will you allow me to take exception to a statement in your editorial on "Minority Parties," Saturday, April 8? You asked us to recall that "European democracy collapsed because it was unable to produce effective and responsible government."

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Having refrained from an official expression on the subject of a temporary release from war production for the output of beverage spirits, the Distilled Spirits Institute today broke its silence and said that "the industry would welcome the opportunity to return to its normal beverage producing business even on a partial and temporary basis."
SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, April 28 (AP) -- A communique:

Federal excise tax receipts on domestic and imported distilled spirits during March, 1944, of $77.6 millions, compared with $78.4 millions for the like month of 1943, a decrease of 1 per cent, marked the first time that withdrawals dropped off in a month preceding a tax rise, industry spokesmen observed yesterday in discussing figures released by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 28 -- Two hundred newspaper publishers visited the General Electric Company's television studios here today and were told that it would be feasible for even the smallest video stations soon after the war to televise spot news events, such as fires, basketball games, accidents and meetings, within an hour after their occurrence.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 28 -- A virulent food poisoning affecting at least 100 school children and teachers upset two schools and taxed the resources of the Monmouth Memorial Hospital this afternoon. At 9 o'clock tonight, seven hours after the first child became ill, sixty-two youngsters had been rushed to the Monmouth and four others to the smaller Hazard Hospital and more were expected.

The Mississippi River, swollen to a stage which may equal a ninety-nine-year record at some places for the second time in a year, spilled over crumbilng levees today to flood new acres of Illinois and Missouri farmlands, but with less disastrous results than in 1943.
LONDON, April 28 (AP) -- A broadcast communique:...

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Eight vegetables now rationed will be added to the point-free list of processed foods Sunday for the period through June 30 as the result of of expected large supplies, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

ALGIERS, April 28 -- Sitting at a rustic table under pine trees, the writer has just lunched and talked with representatives of the younger generation of Frenchmen upon whom the revival of the wounded, weakened and impoverished nation will largely depend.

The latest shoe-buying spree, under way for a week, was attributed yesterday by shoe retailers to the expiration of Coupon 18 in War Ration Book 1 tomorrow at midnight. Airplane stamp 1 in War Ration Book 3 still is good for one pair of shoes, and airplane stamp 2 will become valid on Monday.

Despite bad weather, retail trade here was active this week. Department store gains ranged from 15 to 18 per cent over 1943. Comparison, however, was against the week immediately after Easter last year.

As a member of the newspaper profession, a soldier in two wars, a leader of the Republican party -- its Vice Presidential candidate in 1936 -- and as Secretary of the Navy in President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Cabinet, Colonel Knox had a brilliant career.

Your editorial of Friday, April 7, on the subject of "Price of Luxuries" raises the fundamental question as to whether prices of "luxuries" should be regulated under the Price Control Act. The editorial indicates that you are very strongly of the opinion that prices of "luxuries" should not be regulated.

Charles F. Noyes yesterday confirmed the fact that he had purchased the two fourteen-story apartment houses at 9-11 East Seventy-ninth Street and 898 Park Avenue, corner of Seventy-ninth Street, as reported yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

With the nation approaching "the bottom of the alien barrel" after the naturalization of a record number of foreign born last year, Earl G. Harrison, Commissioner of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, disclosed yesterday that his department had formulated a bill designed to assist an estimated 3,100,000 persons to become citizens.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Sewell L. Avery went before his shareholders today and won their almost unanimous approval of his policies. About 350 shareholders in Montgomery Ward Co. crowded into the Crystal Room of the Blackstone Hotel, applauded repeatedly and re-elected him by casting 3,786,972 votes for him and an approximately equal number for the twelve other directors who had supported their chairman in his clash with the Administration.

BALTIMORE, April 28 (AP) -- Ten Kentucky Derby eligibles were named today for tomorrow's $25,000-added Chesapeake Stakes, but Pukka Gin was not among them -- and he probably will not run in the Derby on May 6.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- While both wings of the Capitol resounded with denunciations and defense of the Government's move against Montgomery Ward Co., introduction by Senator Harry F. Byrd, Virginia Democrat, of a resolution for a Judiciary Committee investigation of the seizure of the Chicago plant put the upper house a lap ahead of the lower today in prospective action.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Michigan, Dartmouth and New York University came through as expected in the three big college races on the opening day of the fiftieth annual Penn Relay Carnival today at Franklin Field.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, April 28 -- The powerfully reinforced defenders of Kohima, Allied base in Eastern India, have smashed into Japanese positions west of the mile-high town and captured a number of enemy strongpoints, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee agreed unanimously today to a war contract termination bill which harmonized with recommendations of Bernard M. Baruch, appeared to set a record in nonpolitical approach to one of the most vexing problems of post-war conversion.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 28 (AP) -- University and college track coaches tonight voted to ignore an Amateur Athletic Union decision barring Cadet Bob Steuber of the Iowa Naval Pre-Flight School from participating tomorrow in the Drake Relays because he is a former professional football player.
THE London stage has become richer, since I last wrote, by two pieces of old fashioned, big scale acting, one by a woman, one by a man.

Little by little the technique of special offerings of securities is being refined. Two more helpful changes in the rules were approved last week by the Securities and Exchange Commission and have taken effect in the New York Stock and New York Curb Exchanges.

BALTIMORE, April 29 -- The Kentucky Derby picture was further scrambled today as Mrs. A.J. Abel's Gramps Image, who had been rated only a slim chance to start in the Blue Grass classic, defeated at least three highly regarded Derby eligibles in the twenty-fourth running of the Chesapeake Stakes at Pimlico.

The University of Odessa, according to a recent dispatch from the Soviet Union, will be ready to open for the fall term. Driven from Odessa by advancing German and Rumanian troops in 1941 and from Maikop in 1942, it finally found safe refuge in Bairen-Alia in central Asia. Nikolai Savchuk, university director and Professor of Biology, has just returned by airplane and truck from central Asia to find two main university buildings intact.
Miss Florence Schmitt of the Women's Swimming Association annexed the women's senior metropolitan A.A.U. 300-yard individual medley swimming championship last night at the New York A.C.

TWO years ago in May we were approaching the darkest hour of the war. Bataan had just fallen, the onrushing Japanese had conquered the Netherlands East Indies and controlled all of New Guinea except Port Moresby. Australia appeared to be next. Rommel had launched his big drive in Libya and the British were falling back toward El Alamein.

MOSCOW, April 29 (AP) -- Flags flying from every official building and thousands of apartment houses literally wrapped Moscow in red today as the Russians prepared to celebrate the happiest May Day since the war started.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 29 -- Claiming Red Wheeler as his fourteenth strike-out victim to end a dangerous Princeton rally, Dick Ames hurled Columbia to a 3-to-1 victory over the Tigers in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest today.
SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, April 29 (AP) -- A communique:

NEW DELHI, India, April 29 (AP) -- R.G. Casey, Bengal Governor, told a press conference today that British commanders were confident of allied ability to blunt the present Japanese drive on Assam, and eventually to throw the invaders back beyond points whence the campaign against India was launched.

A liquor dealer described by Government agents as also a stage producer and four others were named as conspirators to violate OPA ceiling prices in sealed indictments, filed by a special Federal grand jury impaneled two weeks ago to investigate black market conditions, which were opened yesterday by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEAD-QUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, April 30 (AP) --

Brooks Atkinson, in Chungking, reports that his English words for things can always get a laugh from his Chinese messenger, Chang. "What is that?" asks Chang, pointing, and hastens forth to regale his fellows with the answer.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The names of thirty-five winners of purchase prizes in the second national Pennel Fund exhibition of prints were announced today by Dr. Luther H. Evans, Acting Librarian of Congress.

THE bomb which sheared the Willards' house in two one quiet October day was not an undiluted catastrophe. In their imperturbable English fashion the Willards moved into a borrowed cottage in the country and -- plop -- into a mystery.

I AM one of 270,000 British evacuees living in the United States today. Like runny of these I sought refuge here in the autumn of 1940 as the "Blitz" reached its height. At the time I landed, I was only 14. I had my birthday on the boat coming over -- an event I celebrated by being sick throughout the day.

Economists have developed the idea of the "inflationary gap" as a framework of reference to describe the pressures in a war economy. They have not held that the presence of excess purchasing power automatically resulted in higher prices. Recommendations for public policy have been designed to limit expenditures so that there would be reduced pressure for price increases.

THERE were sixty-seven cars in that freight train as she rolled toward the seaboard. Don't ask where it started from, or you'll have us all in the hands of the censor; and don't be too inquisitive about its destination. Just take it for granted that the ultimate destination for all that load was the front line, up where the shooting is going on.

LONDON, April 29 -- A new drug that may well play an important role in checking invasion casualties and reducing the death toll has been developed in London laboratories. The drug, known as vivicillin 1/8 is a development of penicillin and can be produced in large quantities at comparatively low cost.

GARRETT MAYNARD was the head of the Military Intelligence in America for the Free Nations Supply Mission. Before Pearl Harbor the function of the mission was to supply the "ghost armies" of occupied Europe with weapons, ammunition and motor vehicles.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 -- There is growing concern on the West Coast over racial problems produced by the war. That communities are alive to the potential dangers is indicated by surveys completed or in progress, dealing especially with the role, present and future, of the many thousands of Negro migrants, and by reactions to suggestions by Gov. John Bricker of Ohio and Secretary Ickes concerning the return of evacuated Japanese-Americans to the Coast.

With Senator Robert F. Wagner as honorary chairman, New York's observance of "Housing Week" will begin May 21, under the sponsorship of the Citizens Housing Council and with the assistance of more than forty realty, religious and civic and welfare agencies, Loula D. Lasker, chairman for the week, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Under-Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal, who became Acting Secretary yesterday upon the death of Secretary Frank Knox, was favored in speculation in the capital today as a logical successor to his late superior.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- In its current state of mind concerning executive interference or usurpation of the prerogatives of the legislative branch of the Government, Congress has gone "gunning" for executive agencies in general and has selected the Office of Price Administration, War Labor Board, Fair Employment Practices Committee and the War Food Administration as its particular "clay pigeons."

IF a Pulitzer prize were awarded for the roughest literary manhandling of the year, I doubt whether a stronger entry will be made than the one offered by Sinclair Lewis in his article, "Fools, Liars, and Mr. De Voto: A Reply to "The Literary Fallacy,'" which heads the Spring Book Number of the Saturday Review of Literature.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The past week was packed with events on the home front which, because of their domestic and international implications, will likely furnish grist for the national political mill for many days to come.
WAR is awful for men, but it is not too good for women.

THIS (so far as this writer knows) is the second book dealing creatively with the forthcoming trial of Adolf Hitler. It is assumed that the Fuehrer won't have a chance to swallow a pill and that he will be caught and tried and get his desserts.

Conducted as a scientific experiment, a deliberate attempt by a Royal Canadian Navy medical officer to sham insanity was exposed unerringly in a big Canadian Naval hospital in Newfoundland during a test of the validity of one of five different intelligence checks used by the Canadian Navy.

ALTHOUGH large households are getting along reasonably well under the point system, small families, even after a year of rationing, are still finding it difficult to manage with their limited stamp allotments. Roasts and large cuts of meat are out of the question, and often the smaller cuts to which those families are accustomed are too expensive both in price and points.

Enforcement of price controls has improved during the past year to the extent that the black market in food is on the wane, Government and industry spokesmen said yesterday at an all-day conference at City Hall on the cost of living.

The New York Mandolin Symphony Orchestra, Ignace Strasfogel conductor, gave in Town Hall last night its twentieth annual concert. The organization of fifty amateurs was assisted by the New York Jewish People's Philharmonic Choral Society.
BOSTON, April 29 -- Now that a reluctant spring has peered around the corner, New England, the East's greatest playground, has started weighing her chances for summer tourist business.

OTTAWA, April 29 (U.P.) -- The proposal of the Wartime Labor Relations Board for settlement of the ten-day strike of 14,000 employes of the Ford Motor Company at Windsor, has been accepted by both company and union, M.M. MacLean, executive officer of the board, announced tonight.
AN ADVANCED BASE IN THE ALEUTIANS, April 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- They were ninety miles off Attu in a storm, six young naval aviators in two rubber rafts, and death was very close.

John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York, announced yesterday that the fund here had raised $21,200,000, or 10.6 per cent of the national goal of $200,000,000. He added that the New York total would be "substantially increased" as a result of planned benefits and other events.

Deliveries of fine chinaware are now running from fifteen months to about two years behind demand, with some factories already refusing to take more orders, a survey revealed yesterday. Deliveries of cheaper types of chinaware, however, have improved somewhat, due chiefly to the fact that some smaller factories making this price range have not been used for war work and the materials situation has improved somewhat.
THE quarrel between authors and reviewers is as old as Euripides, and gets the authors nowhere. They are galled jades who wince, while the reviewers' withers are unwrung.
" WHAT has given great vogue to nationalism in modern times?" asked Prof. (now Ambassador) Carlton J.H. Hayes in 1931 in his Historical Evolution of Modern Nationalism. "We really do not know.

MELBOURNE, April 29 -- Although the remustering of Australia's manpower necessitated the reduction of her army strength, the expansion of the Australian Air Force continues to be sustained and substantial, and its contribution to the United Nations war effort is probably proportionately the greatest of any of the Allied Nations.

CAMDEN, ME. -- A fleet of seven old-time American sailing vessels is being made ready for summer cruises along the Maine coast. The schooner Lois M. Candage will start the season May 29, when she leaves Camden Harbor with a group of tired War workers bound for a week's tour of Penobscot and Bluehill Bays and adjacent waters.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- The announcement by Gen. Douglas MacArthur that he does "not covet" the office of President and would not accept it was disappointing to Joseph P. Savage, chairman of the MacArthur National Association of MacArthur-for-President Clubs.

HOLLANDIA, New Guinea, April 29 (U.P.) -- Twelve American missionaries and nuns, held captive by the Japanese in New Guinea for more than fourteen months, have been rescued by United States Army forces in the Hollandia area, it was disclosed tonight.

Plans for establishment of twenty-two technical junior colleges in New York State as part of the post-war program have advanced to the point where the ]Board of Regents is expected to acquire sites, valued at $250,000, within two or three weeks, Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, Deputy Commissioner of Education, disclosed yesterday.

IN these days of haste without waste, the spoon-fed rock plant and the five-spray perennial have gone the way of extra pats of butter and nylon hose. But the dependable annual of generous disposition and obliging nature has come richly into its own.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Yankees were so confounded by a triple play of which they were the victims today that they made a botch of their first visit of the 1944 campaign to Griffith Stadium.

A TELEPHONE chat with Eddie Cantor the other forenoon revealed that William A. Drake has completed sixty pages of the Cantor project, "Brown Derby," planned for next season. The man with the eyes testified that this is a "true story about Hollywood," with the locale being five or six booths in the film colony's celebrated dining room.

THESE tales of Old Mexico, told in simple, friendly fashion, have genuine atmosphere. Most of the stories are folk tales, but one or two are based on Mexican history. All of them have grown out of the life and imagination of simple country people, for they deal with faithful animals, fiestas, journeys on foot, enchantments and spells, princes and emperors in disguise.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Ration-free sale of children's low-priced shoes in specified size ranges at a maximum retail price of $1.60 a pair will begin on Monday and last through May 20.

Confidence in the election of a Republican President was expressed yesterday by W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Suffolk County Republican Committee, in an address at the spring luncheon of the Kings County Republican Women at the Hotel Bossert. About 250 attended.

LONDON, Sunday, April 30 -- The sinking of four more Axis ships, three of them transports, trying to save the German-Rumanian garrison of besieged Sevastopol in the Crimea was announced by Moscow last night in a communique that repeated the week-old phrase, "No essential changes" on the land front.

LONDON, April 29 -- The aerial offensive has now reached the phase of steady, almost monotonous, assault upon German defenses, communications and supply depots in western Europe -- a phase which will produce no such crushing victories as those which illuminated the strategic bombing of German industry or the offensive against the Luftwaffe.

Initiation of a sweeping survey to determine extent of the public's misconceptions about business so that advertising can be directed to correct erroneous impressions of industry's activities will be proposed by the Association of National Advertisers to its members this week, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- The soldiers who seized the Chicago properties of Montgomery Ward Co. late Wednesday on orders from President Roosevelt were withdrawn at noon today at the request of Wayne C. Taylor, Undersecretary of Commerce and the Government's operating manager.

IT is a lucky thing for our literature that America is not a "melting pot." More often than we realize, it is the heterogeneous types, attitudes and milieus of American fiction which give it its particular flavor and all-encompassing sweep. One group alone -- the Armenians -- has recently added a measure of interest and novelty.

LONDON, April 29 -- In one of the most severe and concentrated attacks on Berlin during the war 1,000 Flying Fortresses and Liberators, escorted by as many or more fighters, gave the Reich capital today a blasting comparable to any ever before delivered and probably set a record for sustained bombing on a single target.

The Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Tammany organization choice for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the new Twenty- second Congressional District, who said recently he would "represent the Negro people first and after that the rest of the American people," revised this statement yesterday.
A total of $18,866,717 has been sent to China through the United China Relief, Inc., since the organization's inception in 1941, Dr. James L. McConaughy, president, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Plans for full military honors for Frank Knox, who died suddenly yesterday were completed today by the Navy.

DETROIT, April 29 (AP) -- The Indians overcame an early five-run Tiger lead today and then won a 7-to-6 decision in the twelfth inning when Russ Peters and Mickey Rocco combined doubles to give Joe Heving, one of nine hurlers in action, the pitching victory.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The international currency problem to which the joint effort of the United Nations is directed flows from the differences in currencies and values employed by the nations of the world. Just as an international political institutional arrangement is designed to compensate for differences in language and nationalistic aims, so the proposed international stabilization fund would attempt to reconcile differences in money and economic systems.

Representative Samuel Dickstein, in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday that a dispatch by A.C. Sedgwick in THE TIMES of the same date "gives a lucid picture of conditions in Italy today and shows how our military and civilian leaders have not lived up to the expectations of the Italian people."

ONE publishing house has decided that it must ration its detective story writers. Sold mainly to libraries, it is a rare thriller that earns its author enough to live on for a year, so the writers turn out two, three or four books annually, often using pen names.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, April 30 (U.P.) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's airmen carried on their sweeping offensive against Japanese bases in northern New Guinea, the Carolines and the Bismarck archipelago with heavy attacks on enemy airfields and supply installations, it was announced today.

ARTISTS to the number of a hundred are represented in the new group exhibition at the American British Art Center. British and American, celebrity and newcomer, they are represented by oils, water-colors, sculpture or drawings, ranging from academism of the right to academism of the left, in one of the most diverse shows of the season.

LONDON, April 29 -- An inter-Allied committee, composed of representatives of the eight exiled European governments and the French Committee of National Liberation, has drafted a drastic plan for the economic and financial disarmament of Germany, which would make it impossible for that country ever to wage war again, the United Press learned tonight.

Despite "regimentation" and Government attempts at control, farm food prices and factory earnings have risen as much in this war as in the first World War, Dr. Frank A. Pearson and Dr. William I. Myers, agricultural economists, find from statistical comparison of these prices and wages in New York State during the two wars.
SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, April 29 (AP) -- The text of the Southeast Asia Headquarters statement follows:

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Michigan's hopes of carrying off the lion's share of the honors in the Penn Relays were checkmated by Army, Dartmouth and a costly decision today as the fiftieth annual carnival ended on sun-drenched Franklin Field with the Wolverines, New York University, Dartmouth and Army each claiming two major relay championships.

WHAT happens to a community when its leading citizen is murdered? Danfield is a small Illinois town surrounded by farms, and its little skyline makes the usual pattern of court house, church, grain elevator, creamery, and shade trees hiding the roof lines of the houses.

Thomas W. Lamont's letter in the April 23 issue of THE TIMES recalls the crisis of Fiume after the last war. Unless a reasonable solution is devised beforehand, the problem of Fiume will cause serious difficulties after this war too.

President Roosevelt's wartime powers seemed headed for major test in both Congress and the courts last week. The larger issue at stake was his general power to support the agencies set up to carry on the nation's wartime programs. The particular issue at stake was his right to seize the Chicago plants of Montgomery Ward Co., the country's second largest merchandising organization, for refusing to obey an order of the War Labor Board.
For the second successive week Saturday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange was the second dullest of the year. Stocks drifted narrowly and closed mixed, up fractions and down fractions.

Last week Bernard Baruch announced that he would give $1,100,000 to various medical institutions to train specialists in physical medicine and to conduct research. The effect is bound to be far-reaching. A discipline that has depended not so much on science as on "we'll try this and see how it works" is now to be placed on a much firmer foundation.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- The seizure by troops on Wednesday of the Chicago units of Montgomery Ward Co., second largest of the country's merchandising corporations, has raised a Central West storm of criticism of President Roosevelt's action among business and industrial leaders and the usual Republican denouncers of the national Administration.

In his first interview since his recent election to the presidency of the United Seamen's Service, William S. Newell declared yesterday afternoon that he welcomed the opportunity to serve merchant seamen upon whom the success of our war effort has depended so heavily, that he was fortunate to join an organization that has compiled such a remarkable record in establishing wartime services for seamen.
CINCINNATI, April 29 (AP) -- The Pirates climbed all over Bob Ferguson, rookie Cincinnati pitcher, in the seventh inning today and beat the Reds, 7 to 3.

THE player of duplicate bridge must keep his eye on the vulnerability conditions far more closely than does the rubber-bridge player. In particular, a player whose side is vulnerable in duplicate bridge must avoid doubling non-vulnerable opponents until his side has exhausted its own game-going possibilities. Consider this hand:
BOSTON, April 29 (AP) -- With Joe Bowman allowing four hits and knocking in two of the runs, the Red Sox shut out the Athletics today, 7 to 0.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The adoption by the International Labor Organization of the "Philadelphia charter" as an outline of the social and economic rights of man throughout the world became assured today when the ILO conference placed the proposed text in the hands of a drafting committee.

IN "They All Had Glamour" Mr. Marks writes of the American stage and opera in the mid-eighteenth century -- an era which was as distinguished for its vulgarity as for its talents; as cherished for its naivete as for its striking innovations.

THE recent sale of some WPA easel paintings and mural sketches (by the Procurement Division of the United States Treasury) as surplus property has evoked comment in some periodicals which we, the undersigned artists, feel misrepresents the purpose and achievements of the WPA Art Projects.

In a plea for unity on the home-front, Rabbi Louis I. Newman in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, said yesterday, "The sight of intransigence in the conduct of disagreements between labor and capital and Government is disheartening to all who have the welfare of their country at heart.

AN entente cordiale has been reached by the studios and the Screen Actors Guild in regard to so-called "pressure" pictures -- films in which charitable or patriotic organizations share in the profits -- following the withdrawal of the Warner Brothers' suits against the talent group in the controversy over "guest actor" salaries for "Hollywood Canteen."

ENGLAND, London promises "round-the-clock hourly news broadcasts and special actuality transmissions covering the invasion of western Europe." Station GRX, 9.69 megacycles, busy all day in the BBC European service, now turns toward America, 5:15 to 12:45 evenings.

BRIGHT lights will blaze along the Jersey coast this summer, are already blazing, in fact, as blackout curtains, black paint, disfiguring screens and other impedimenta, scarifying alike to amusement entrepreneur and householder, disappear from the scene.

The War Food Administration has begun a nation-wide survey to determine the extent of its food surpluses. The check is designed to separate good from "over-age" supplies and to expedite the return of excess foods to normal trade channels with least disturbance to the markets, it was learned yesterday.

SINCE neither time nor help is apt to be over-abundant during the coming months, a good part of this year's spring cleaning efforts might well be directed toward streamlining the upkeep job for summer. Housewives doing their own work for the first time might start out by investigating the myriad gadgets and cleaning preparations designed to save labor.

A U.S. BOMBER STATION IN ENGLAND, April 29 (U.P.) -- "Yes, sir," Lieut. John M. Gibbons of Jefferson City, Mo., said, "I am the only pilot in my formation who came back from Berlin -- and a dead German nearly got me."

The Federal Telephone and Radio Corporation announced yesterday that a hundred vessels of Canada's newly constructed Liberty Fleet already have been equipped with American-made marine radio units and direction finders.

The daily double betting record went by the boards with a crash yesterday when the third largest crowd of the Jamaica meeting took advantage of the summery weather. A total of 40,819 fans crammed their way through the turnstiles, most of them in time to send $162,310 through the mutuel windows in pursuit of the daily double bubble.

FORUMS on American composition, and also on the new Music in Hospitals program of the National Federation of Music Clubs, will be features of the convention of the New York Federation of Music Clubs, to be held Thursday through next Sunday in this city, with headquarters at the Hotel Biltmore.

THE scene of F. Millard Smyth's second adventure in detection is Alaska, just as it was in "Murder Breaks Trail." Smyth is a groceryman, a timid soul with no apparent qualifications for sleuthing unless it be his passion for detective stories. He has come to Harding Lake to decide whether or not he wants to buy a grocery store in Fairbanks, and almost immediately he becomes involved in a murder mystery.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., played a gallant and heroic part in the anti-slavery struggle. The town was a hotbed of abolitionism; Samuel May was one of its leading citizens; Gerrit Smith lived near by, and Frederick Douglass often visited there on his way to and from his headquarters in Rochester.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 29 -- Frank Leahy, who coached Notre Dame to a mythical national football championship last fall, disclosed tonight he would be commissioned a Navy lieutenant on Monday. He received his notice from the Navy today.

Ten years ago today, 1,000 gallons of 100-octane gasoline, the first ever to be produced in commercial quantities, was delivered by the Shell Oil Company to the Army Air Corps at Wright Field. The company commemorates that anniversary by opening its new twin catalYtic*cracking plant for the manufacture of hlgh-octane gasoline at Wood River, Ill, and the Petroleum Administrator for War, the Ainy and t:he Navy will inaugurate tomorrow the national celebration of 100-O'crane Week.

With the losers making more errors than assists, a rarity in any league, the N.Y.U. baseball team overwhelmed Brooklyn College, 8 -- 1, before a handful of spectators at Ohio Field yesterday. This Metropolitan Collegiate Conference meeting found the Kingsmen charged with nine misplays, three in the opening inning, when the Violets counted twice and discovered, as the game progressed, that they didn't need any more.

JERRY FRANKLIN, who has been invalided out of the Army because of a wound, is trying to find out what is troubling his friend and prospective brother-in-law, Alan Cameron, who is evidently in a jam of some sort. While thus engaged, Jerry finds the body of a man who has been murdered and he fears that Alan may be involved.

The shade of Mark Twain hovered over Manhattan Center yesterday, keeping an eye on tailless leaping amphibians of the genus Rana in the sort of Contest he made famous in his early humorous story "The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County."

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, told the American Society of International Law tonight that a peace without forceful backing would not be durable. And if the nations fail after this war to make the most of their opportunities to forge a lasting peace, he added, "the human race may come perilously near self-extermination."

Educators, political and civic leaders joined yesterday in support of a program of post-war adult education that would supplement the existing provisions made by the State, at a meeting under the auspices of the New York Adult Education Council in the Hotel Roosevelt.

THE racket in radio repairs, never as limited in scope as some would have the set owner believe, is flourishing in full glory these days, judging by a survey in recent weeks. All the old tricks of the unscrupulous service man are being worked overtime in many parts of the city, with the public remaining in its usual suspicious if helpless position.

Fourteen outstanding gardens, planted in backyards or on penthouse terraces in fashionable East Side residential districts, will be opened to the public on the afternoons of May 9 and 16 for the annual two-day pilgrimage of the City Gardens Club.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Industry members of the National War Labor Board, in a strongly dissenting opinion flatly rejecting a majority decision of public and labor members granting union employes a maintenance-of-membership provision, today called for a judicial review of the board's authority to grant union security.

Fuel oil allotments to domestic consumers for the third year of wartime rationing will remain virtually unchanged, Daniel P. Woolley, head of the regional Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday. Mr. Woolley also disclosed that simple application forms for next season's fuel oil rations would be mailed to consumers tomorrow by local rationing boards.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 29 -- Regardless of the pressure being brought against them by their own political organization, the five Cabinet members of the Radical party will continue to serve in President Juan Antonio Rio's Government family, it was reliably reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Following is the text of the proposed declaration of the International Labor Organization:

Seven out of ten fire insurance policies, issued by capital stock companies throughout the nation, will be increased liberally in value without payment of extra premium by the new simple, easy-to-read dwelling-house policy form, covering all parts of the country, approved last week by underwriters' associations.

Cotton futures closed yesterday in the New York Cotton Exchange unchanged to 5 points lower than on Friday after having sold off moderately early in the session. Price-fixing orders near the last and a let-up in pressure brought about a very steady tone at the close.

OMAHA, Neb., April 29 -- Every once in a while this agricultural country gets to feeling pretty satisfied with itself and the way in which it is supporting war, especially in contrast to the way in which labor acts. Then it gets a jolt from Mars that shocks its complacency and jars its back teeth loose.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP) -- Timely hitting in the pinches gave the Phillies a 6-3 triumph over the Braves today, evening the series at a game apiece and giving Ken Raffensberger his second victory of the season.

FILM rights to books currently are bringing all-time high prices, with A.J. Cronin holding the record at $200,000 for his as yet unpublished novel, "The Green Years." Metro, which had considerable success with an earlier Cronin novel, "The Citadel," snapped up the new one while still in manuscript form.

You are on firm ground when you say that "the most practical method of assuring international monetary cooperation is through sound economic, budgetary, credit and currency policies within each nation." However, one would wish that you had stressed more than you did the economic policies.

Swift renascence of merchandise standards and consumer informative labeling in the post-war period was foreseen in trade circles here last week as both manufacturers and retailers pushed plans to meet what is expected to be a major trend shortly after the guns cease firing.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- The St. Louis Browns' bid for a new modern major league record for consecutive victories since the start of a season failed today when the Chicago White Sox rallied in the late innings to score a 4-to-3 victory.

THIS is an attempt to let Germany state her own case in her own words. It is a selection of German writings from the last three decades, fiction and non-fiction, by over forty German authors -- some famous, some not so famous -- always with a heavy, occasionally clumsy political accent.

The National Science Fund announces two Charles L. Mayer Awards for contributions submitted before Jan. 1, 1946, on the nature of light. A prize of $2,000 is offered for an outstanding contribution to our basic understanding of the nature of light and other electromagnetic phenomena, which are now described in terms of either waves or particles and which call for unification.

An epidemic of youthful crime is disturbing our national complacency. Commentators, editors, social and religious workers are viewing with increasing alarm this shocking rise in juvenile delinquency. The fact that these children are soon to be citizens and that their training and conduct represent a powerful and decisive influence in coming events is for the first time filtering into the consciousness of our people.

FOOD FOR THOUGHT: The popular notion that political convention are devoted to caucuses and speechmaking was slightly modified last week. . researcher has found that Republican and Democratic poHt/cian meeting in the Chicago Stadium next June and July will probably consume 150,000 hot dogs, 250,000 bottles of pop, 200,000 bottles of beer, 40,000 hara sandwiches, 150,000 ice-cream bars, 500,000 bags of peanuts and 300,000 cups of coffee.

MRS. SIMS has subtitled her stimulating, provocative, amusing little book, "The Art of 'Psychic Living.'" The term is a bit deceptive. There is nothing "psychic" in Mrs. Sims' scheme of living in any sense that the word is commonly understood.

Women should cooperate with men rather than compete with them through underselling if they want to "do well for themselves as well as for society" in the post-war world, Dr. Ruth C. Wright, dean of students at City College, declared yesterday in commenting on reports that the placement bureaus of the four municipal colleges had found employment for 3,000 women students over the past half year.

This week, for the first time in more than ten years, the volume of money in circulation will exceed the total of the nation's monetary gold stock. In other words, the end of the period in which the currency has had the unprecedented backing of more than dollar-for-dollar in gold has come to a close.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, April 29 -- The Japanese are unable to resist, in the outlying areas of their secondary defenses, the overwhelming strength the American Navy, Army and Air Force are able to hurl against them.

WHEN Brig. Gen. Frank Merrill arrived on the north Burma front with his detachment of American infantry early this year he went to see Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell for final orders. Members of General Stilwell's staff were present in a jungle-shrouded bamboo "basha" that served as headquarters.

IT seems incredible -- but there is proof enough in this book -- that less than a hundred years ago an army went into battle with no other provision for the care of the wounded than a few surgeons. In spite of the well-known findings of Florence Nightingale in the Crimean War, no changes had been made by the beginning of our Civil War.

MELBOURNE, Australia. A WELCOME innovation in the musical season of 1944 will be the visit, under the auspices of the United States OWI, of Eugene Ormandy, who is expected to arrive early in May and remain until the end of July.

LAKELAND, Fla., April 29 -- The New Deal has projected itself as the major issue in Florida's Senatorial campaign, in which four candidates are seeking to unseat Senator Pepper, with the Democratic primary set for Tuesday.

MOST terms used in architectural history are misnomers, but eventually the original and more or less false connotations of a term are forgotten and a style name, however misapplied, comes with the passage of generations to specify merely the style to which it was given.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy Ceylon, April 29 -- Allied forces mopping up the Japanese invasion of India have overrun further enemy strong points around Kohima, Allied headquarters announced today coincident with a special statement declaring that the invasion had failed to delay completion of the Ledo road or disrupt the overall Allied strategic plan in Southeast Asia.

THE Achimenes are among the most neglected, though most generous blooming, of summer-flowering bulbs. This Nut Orchid or Spoon Orchid, as it is sometimes called, has proved very successful for many summers in the writer's garden.

LONDON, April 29 -- Britons finally received this morning the facts and figures to prove what their sense of taste has been telling them since 1941 -- that their wartime diet is as thin as the "joint," dull as the cabbage and as monotonous as the potatoes that make up their national dinner of "meat and two vegetables."

THE purpose of this book is to guide economists, statisticians, accountants, engineers, editors and writers in presenting tabular material in statistical form. The author wisely assumes that tabular presentation is not a science but a group of flexible rules.

A going back to the humanities, a vastly expanded program of adult education and greater school opportunities for returning service men will mark the post-war educational period, college presidents representing all sections of the country predict. In most instances, the colleges and universities indicate that they will revert to the pre-war pattern of higher education.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Central Pacific, April 29 (AP) -- A new furlough-leave of absence plan, making a percentage of officers and men eligible for trips to the mainland after two years of service in the Central Pacific, will become effective on May 1, the Army announced today.
Sooner or later time and the Dodgers were bound to catch up with the Giants, and when the appointed hour arrived it cannot be said that the Flatbush Flock failed to do a thorough job of it.

THE only flaw in Thunder's life was that he hadn't a proper tail. Not that he was vain, but even the smartest Siamese kitten can't chase a furry round ball, and when his brother Lightnin' played madly with his long crooked tail Thunder felt left out of things.

With an inspiring "Good luck and good hunting" to wish her well, the Bon Homme Richard, 27,100 tons of bad news for the Axis, slid down the ways at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn at 4 P.M. yesterday, the thirteenth aircraft carrier of the Essex Class built since America's entry into the war.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- A check of electrical industry sources here today indicated that there is very little chance of early reconversion in the big producing plants now devoted to war work, and that the first marked easing of restrictions on civilian goods is likely to come in repair parts and lighting.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Sunday, April 30 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur, back from an invasion which carried him 500 miles nearer his cherished goal of returning to the Philippines, stated unequivocally today that he neither desired nor would accept nomination for President of the United States.

In anticipation of the Presidential election, State laws governing absentee voting by members of the armed services and, in some cases, by attached civilians, have been substantially liberalized in most States.

THESE two volumes, the first of the new "Religion and Civilization Series," are stimulating symposia of discussions of current domestic and international problems; they supplement each other admirably. Their purpose is apparent; it is not only to clarify the political, social, religious and economic issues which rack the war-ridden world today but also to help in their solution.

THOSE without knowledge of the tangled highways and arabesque byways of the Near East will find Dr. Byng's "The World of the Arabs" an able and useful guide. Even experienced political observers, who wistfully discourse on the role of the Near East in the twentieth century and who know the difference between the Kislah Wotania and the Wafd, will find a reading of this book not without rewards.

LONDON, April 29 (AP) -- The Allied war of nerves kept Germany tensely expectant of momentary landings on the Continent today, and Berlin itself said "the invasion air force is now actually in the fight."

LUCKY is the gardener who has an impregnable fence around his Victory garden. For him rabbits are no problem. However, the fence should have basal reinforcement, for otherwise there is no sure proof against rabbits outside who will easily burrow their way to the feast within.
DES MOINES, April 29 -- Illinois' sensational 17-year-old freshman, Claude (Buddy) Young, became the workhorse of the Drake Relays today by engaging in four smashing triumphs.

LONDON, April 29 (U.P.) -- British Labor Minister Bevin, speaking to the Transport and General Workers Union in Bristol, said the day and hour for the invasion had been agreed upon by President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin.

THE exhibition pace can hardly be said to have slackened. The week just concluded might, with some measure of justification, be called Portrait Week, although much of the material newly placed on view does not, of course, come within that category.

LONDON, April 29 -- Louis Marin, the old French politician who barely a month ago was intriguing in Vichy against Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain and the Germans, was engaged in the same patriotic task today in a London hotel bedroom, hungrily gathering news of the Allied world at war after almost four years in German-isolated France.

DUDLEY DIGGES is that contradiction in terms, a modest player. He struts and frets his hour upon the stage, then, to the interviewer's hard affliction, is heard no more. After four decades in the New York theatre, he still shuns personal tub-thumping, shies from disclosing to the public eye the things that happen to him after he leaves the stage door and turns homeward to Sixty-fourth Street and domestic quiet.

With the granting of a charter to the Educational Foundation by the Board of Regents at its recent meeting, plans for the formation of the first two-year technical institute in New York City were advanced. The foundation, consisting of members of the apparel trades, will assist the Board of Education in conducting the garment college, which will be known as the Fashion Institute of Technology and Design.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Congressional investigation into the propriety of the Administration's action in seizing Montgomery Ward Co. and ejecting its board chairman, Sewell Avery, by force for defiance of a War Labor Board ruling was carried forward here tonight with the delivery of the War Labor Board's files in the case on a subpoena from the Senate's Judiciary Committee.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 29 (AP) -- Dr. W.I. Lunt's Valdina Punch saved enough ground along the rail today to win the $5,000 added Brisol Handicap by a length, as a crowd of approximately 30,000 exceeded the million-dollar mark in betting for the fourth time at the Narragansett Park meeting.
