LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 29 (AP) -- Enrique Baldivieso, Bolivian Foreign Minister, tonight named Mauricio Hochschild, wealthy tin mine owner, as a principal conspirator in an unsuccessful "revolutionary plot," and added that all principals were under arrest.

Turkey's decision to withhold chromium ore from Germany may prove to be as telling as the blows that have been delivered from the air on factories and railway junctions. Some chromium ore still trickles into Germany from Yugoslavia. If Tito's appeal to the miners in his country is heeded, Germany will be completely cut off from all major sources of supply.

A SMALL town in Kentucky is the background for this quietly charming and sensitively told first novel. In it you will find no julep-drinking colonels, no lengthy descriptions of blue grass. You will find instead a real and moving account of the Tarnols and the Merrils -- neighbors bound by bitterness instead of friendship.

As the War Food Administration in Washington yesterday fixed the amount of butter set aside for direct war requirements at 40 per cent of production in May and 50 per cent in June, local dairy trade representatives debated the effect on civilian consumption.

Seven times in six days last week the Allied air forces in Britain sent fleets of nearly 1,000 heavy bombers against Hitler's Europe. In one twenty-four-hour period they struck with more than 5,000 planes of all types with bomb loads totaling an estimated 11,000 to 12,000 tons.

LONDON, April 29 (Canadian Press) -- Blackpool's Eph Dodds booted two goals in the last six minutes today to beat Aston Villa by 2 -- 1 in the first game of the English League North Soccer Cup final at Blackpool before a crowd of nearly 30,000.

No one has to be reminded that these are hours and days of growing strain. Those of us who have something to do with gathering, presenting and interpreting the news are particularly caught up in the meshes of suspense. Five o'clock, six o'clock, seven o'clock. Tomorrow, next week, next month.
Here's your sou'wester, April. Pardon us if we just sit here and ooze and relax while you put on your rubbers. Yes, that's a sigh of relief. May's coming.

DETROIT, April 29 (U.P.) -- War production in the Chrysler tank arsenal and five plants of the Briggs Manufacturing Company was threatened tonight by strikes involving an estimated 1,700 workers. At the arsenal, a strike, which began late yesterday, spread to include about 1,000 Negro maintenance men and jitney operators.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, England, April 29 (U.P.) -- The room in which the invasion of western Europe is being planned is small and bare and looks like a typical classroom.

LONDON, April 29 -- It is almost exactly a year since the Soviet Union severed diplomatic relations with Poland. Since that time both Britain and the United States have sought by all means at their disposal to heal the breach between two of their allies, but to no avail.

MOSCOW, April 29 (AP) -- Moscow's official press, today accorded to the visit of the Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski, American Catholic priest, a coverage usually reserved for the world's most prominent leaders, and the gray-haired clergyman termed "excellent" the results of his unprecedented conference yesterday with Premier Joseph Stalin.

The feat of replacing an animal's heart by the heart of another animal through a transplantation operation has been accomplished by Prof. N.P. Sinitsin of the Gorky Medical Institute, Moscow. The experimental animals were frogs.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 29 -- Two New Zealand Venturas teamed with American Catalinas in one of the most dramatic air-sea rescues of the war, the Air Department said today. The Venturas sighted flames 150 feet high off Ballale and found an American Ventura had been hit by flak over Kahili and had crashed four miles from the coast.

LONDON, April 29 (UP) -- Two British-manned Flying Fortresses collaborated with another aircraft of the Coastal Command and a frigate of the Royal Navy in the recent destruction of a U-boat, the Air Ministry announced today.

The tenth annual inventory of migratory waterfowl, conducted by the Fish and Wildlife Service in cooperation with many Federal and State agencies, showed that the game species of these birds had increased nearly 400 per cent in the last nine years.

VICTOR WHITE'S first novel is an impressive attempt to dramatize the problem of the civilized personality in modern times. How is the individual to endure a multitude of pressures, including every variety of insecurity and fear, and yet emerge into this maturity with an unimpaired will?

LONDON, April 29 (U.P.) -- The American heavy bombers blasted an aerial path to Berlin today through swarms of German fighters that met the attackers west of the River Elbe and fought with desperate fury against the flood of destruction heading for their capital.

WHO killed James Paradine? Was it one of the ten persons, all related to him in one way or another, who dined with him a few hours before his death? That is what Miss Maud Silver is trying to find out. Her methods are quiet and unspectacular, but there is little that escapes her notice.

Declaring that "unless we curb juvenile delinquency, America faces a post-war crime wave too horrible to contemplate," Dr. Lewis E. Lawes, chief business consultant of the prison war program branch of the War Production Board, advocated yesterday establishment of special schools to help train parents in methods of dealing with wayward children.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Office of War Information said today it had had no part in the decision of Australian radio authorities to postpone the broadcasting of a transcribed address by Kent Cooper, executive director and general manager of The Associated Press.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 29 -- Dr. Samuel Black of Spartanburg, S.C., this afternoon completed an unprecedented victory record in the annual meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club when he gained first place in the amateur all-age stake, leading event of the thirty-third anniversary fixture of that organization.

ALGIERS, April 29 -- Members of the French Committee of National Liberation said today that they had no confirmation of reports from London that Brig. Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had made an agreement regarding the French and the Allies in France.

MOUNTAINS of books -- good books, including classics, current best sellers, history, biography, science and poetry -- are being distributed among our fighting men overseas by a novel publishing arrangement between American book publishers and the Army and Navy.

A DANGEROUS illusion exists today in many parts of the world with regard to post-war employment. "Jobs for all" is the most frequent and successful of present-day rallying cries, but the three words harbor an important fallacy. Jobs, central though they may be in any blueprint for tomorrow, are not an end in themselves.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Following is the text of the speech prepared by Lora Halifax British Ambassador to the United States, for delivery at the annual dinner of the American Society of International Law here tonight:

CHICAGO in 1843 was a hustling, bustling boom town -- even more exciting to Dorinda, when she first saw it, than she had pictured it back on her father's Indiana farm. She had come up to spend her seventeenth winter with her aunt and to go to school, but before she ever set foot in Miss Elliott's seminary she found that there were many things for a country girl to learn.

LONDON, April 29 -- A warning to the more than 500,000 women and 9,000,000 men of the British Empire now under arms that they could expect only a few days' respite after the defeat of Germany before they concentrated on Japan was given today by Capt. Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production.

More than 400,000 personal consultations with men, women, adolescents and children in trouble were given by social workers of the eight private family service agencies in 1943, according to the first joint report of the welfare organizations, made public yesterday.

THERE are no peanuts and pink lemonade and not enough animals, but Moscow's circus is still a smashing wartime success, drawing a full house nightly -- a crowd representative of a good cross-section of Russia, with a heavy predominance of Red Army uniforms. It is the most uninhibited entertainment in Russia and from many points of view the most satisfactory.

CHUNGKING, China, April 29 (AP) -- Chinese troops beating against the southern claw of a Japanese pincers threatening the rail city of Loyang in northern Honan Province have fought their way back to the outskirts of Mihsien, twenty miles southwest of Chengchow, a communique said today.

WHAT kind of a President do we need? What qualities make a strong President? What qualities make a great President? The questions Mr. Milton poses but does not directly answer. Instead he shows us what light the record of the first 155 years of the Presidency sheds upon the traits and qualities that "America's Number One Man" ought to have.

LONDON, April 29 -- Prime Minister Churchill's decision to gather all dominion Prime Ministers in the Empire's capital and their immediate response to his invitation at this critical time are regarded here as proof at the outset that there is nothing wrong with the British Commonwealth system.

THE Drama Critics Circle held its annual spring meeting early last week at Mr. Case's Algonquin Hotel. As they used to say with a similar air of surprise about Union Square parades, the meeting was orderly and the police were not needed.

GUIDO ROSA, commercial artist turned author, went to Mexico with a camera to record faces and a notebook to hold phrases. He had enough money to buy a dilapidated small car, enough Spanish to understand what was said, enough knowledge of the country to comprehend what he was seeing -- and not enough to make the everyday seem commonplace.

Arnold S. Denker, Manhattan Chess Club ruler, continued to hold first place in the men's United States title tournament, in progress at the Park Central Hotel as a result of his victory in the eleventh round yesterday.

Fresh fuel was added last week to the controversy between Soviet Russia and the Polish Government-in-exile. The Moscow newspaper Pravda declared that White Russian and Ukrainian soldiers of the Polish Army in Scotland had been tortured after they tried to quit Polish forces and enter the British Army.

Floor covering distributors will add furniture to their already extensive lines in the post-war period to increase sales volume and meet the threat posed by the steadily increasing trend toward direct distribution of rugs, carpets and hard surface items, a spokesman for one of the nation's leading distributors disclosed yesterday.

Declaring that simple national problems had been obscured in a "mystic maze" through "academic theorizing and inexperienced guessing" by the Administration, William M. Jeffers held last night that "this trial-and-error method, if persisted in, may wreck the American nation."

RICHMOND, Va., April 29 -- Thousands of parents, wives and sweethearts of Southern fighting men are tensely awaiting the signal for the European invasion. As the bombing of the Continent reaches a higher and higher crescendo they know that "D-Day" is drawing nearer and nearer.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, April 29 -- About noon yesterday, while shells cracked back and forth in the valley between Minturno and Castelforte, some Fifth Army infantrymen shepherded two men, three women and an infant to a prisoner-of-war collection station that was simply a deserted farmhouse taken over by Sgt. Victor Lewis of Rochester and four other M.P.'s.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Seduction competed with sedition in Washington this week, and seduction won.

HIS photograph was in the papers, a handsome youngster with an engaging grin, when the story of his overseas exploits inspired a long-distance call from a city desk to the editor of a home-town newspaper. "Don't talk to me about that rascal," sputtered the editor's irascible voice over the wire: "he was the worst boy in town!"

STIMULATION, say the experts in the beauty field, is an excellent means of keeping the skin young and attractive. Its results may be only temporary, but it does give the skin a fresh, glowing appearance to match the it's-so-wonderful-to-be-alive feeling of these days of spring.

Brooklyn's Brownsville section was the scene yesterday of two muggings, one committed within 100 yards of the Liberty Avenue police station. As a result of tallying descriptions by the victims, police were searching for two Negroes, one dressed in an Army uniform and the other in dark civilian clothes.

THE author of this book is an earnest young woman from Illinois who first saw Europe when she went to Geneva on a summer scholarship to the International Students Union in 1934. Fresh out of the University of Chicago, where she majored in political science, Helen Hiett went to Europe to see internationalism in practice.

WHY, in the midst of a major war, should one take the time to read a long account of the life of William Hazlitt (1778-1830), English critic and essayist, sometime associate of Wordsworth, Coleridge and Keats, and close friend of that lovable antiquarian, Charles Lamb?

A half century of friendly service by the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association to underprivileged families of the middle East Side will be reviewed next Sunday night at a fiftieth anniversary celebration, to be presented by the organization in the Hunter College auditorium, at Park Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street. The program formally will commemorate the founding of the association in 1894 by the Associate Alumnae of Hunter College.

If Dr. I. Newton Kugelmass, attending pediatrician of half a dozen New York hospitals, had his way more attention would be paid to the wartime need of protective foods. In an article which appears in the American Journal of Digestive Diseases he points out that "the consumption of energy-yielding foods, i.e., bread, cereals, potatoes, sugar and fats, milk, eggs, fruits and green vegetables is far from adequate."

Main floor, accessory, cotton shop and dress departments were active in retail trade in the major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

With more than 8,000 entertainers out of work lasts night, at the end of the first month of the new 30 per cent cabaret tax, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, expressed the fear that the effect of the tax "will not only throw thousands of performers out of work but will also cost the Government millions of dollars."

Thompson Products, Inc., maker largely of parts for automotive and other engines and machines, and its subsidiaries, including the Thompson Aircraft Products Company, had a net profit of $798,006 in the first three months of this year

LONDON, April 29 (AP) -- Two thousand United States warplanes smashing through box-like stacks of hundreds of German fighters in the greatest daylight battle of the war cast a 2,500-ton torrent of exploding steel and incendiaries on invasion-jittery Berlin today.

TILLY LOSCH, internationally famous dancer, has just made public her second career. Her first one-man show of paintings recently opened at the Bignou Gallery. Audiences who remember her on stage or screen will recognize the dancer in the painter.
MEMPHIS, April 29 (AP) -- Seven persons were killed -- including two women and a 20-month-old infant -- when a twin-engine Army bomber crashed on a dwelling in the city today.

Mrs. Thomas W. Armitage has been elected president of the Junior League of New York, succeeding Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr., who has just completed two years of service in that office, it was announced by the league yesterday. Mrs. Armitage, the former Miss Frances Auchincloss, has in the past held the following posts: vice president of the organization, member of the ways and means committee and vice chairman of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

THIS is the story of Spalato, the ancient city of the Adriatic coast, of its beautiful, enchanted world which Hitler's Europe nearly destroyed. It is the story of a people who had lived in the past so long that the present had lost its reality.

J. S. Bache Co., New York brokerage firm, was ordered yesterday by the regional War Labor Board to bargain collectively with the American Federation of Office Employes. At the same time the board dismissed the company's contention that the WLB lacks jurisdiction in the case.

WORKING alternately in a somewhat flatly mural vein with figures and in an open-air, deep-space manner, Howard Claney is showing recent paintings at the Norlyst Gallery. "Song of the River," with its looping design of bridge and waterfront, is his most ambitious picture thus far.

LONDON, April 29 -- As German invasion tension continued to mount today, reports reaching London from the Continent told of secret "second front" orders being issued to German military police throughout France and of supposed Nazi evacuations from districts in France where Allied landings might be expected.
ST. LOUIS, April 29 (AP) The Cardinals doubled their way to victory over the Cubs today, 4 to 2, and moved into first place in the National League.

More than 525,000 Polish children are in desperate need of food and clothing, according to a report from the Polish underground published in booklet form by the Polish Government Information Center, 745 Fifth Avenue, and made public yesterday.

LONDON, April 29 (UP) -- Amphibious Yugoslav forces, in their most ambitious operations so far, have captured the strategically important Dalmatian island of Meleda, a Partisan headquarters communique announced today. It appeared that other invasion units were mopping up on Curzola, nineteen miles to the northwest.

It would appear from the War Manpower Commission's recent announcement, to the effect that 2,955 physicians have been relocated in areas where they are badly needed, that the Procurement and Assignment Service is making notable progress in solving one of the major problems of the war.

THE startling resemblance of three beautiful girls to each other drives the Los Angeles Police Department completely gaga. They are triplets and their names are Faith, Hope and Charity. Murder and other crimes follow in their wake and Lieut. Steve McCord finds himself in the doghouse because of them or, possibly, because he is getting uncomfortably close to the truth about a certain influential person.

CLEVELAND, April 29 -- One of the largest spring grain movements in the history of the Great Lakes is in full swing and elevators at lower lake ports are having difficulty unloading a steady parade of freighters from Duluth-Superior and Fort William-Port Arthur, shippers said today.

IT is said that youth, and youth alone, has the power to make time tremble. That being so, Joan Leslie is going about the task with an easy indifference calculated to horrify the time-fearing citizen. As example, in these days when any given twenty-four hours could well plot a new progress curve in the world we know, young Miss Leslie calmly and confidently talks of things she plans "after a while."

THE compost pile -- a bank account of soil vitality that the Victory gardener was advised to start last spring -- is now a year old. He is beginning to wonder just how his balance stands and how he can invest it to good advantage.

On April 24, Robert L. Doughton, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives, introduced a tax-simplification bill which, on the same day, was referred to the Committee of the Whole House. As its title implies, "Individual Income Tax Act of 1944," the bill deals with the income tax of individuals.

There was at least one famous exile, still well remembered, who at a distance from his native land had a much clearer understanding of the temper of his countrymen and of the march of events than practically everybody living at home in the midst of things.

The complete rout of the Communist party in the recent elections of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union was applauded yesterday by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, with which the union is affiliated.

University of Cincinnatians will celebrate the 125th anniversary of the institution's founding at an Alumni Association sponsored banquet Thursday evening in Cincinnati and at similar affairs the same night throughout the country. On May 4, 1819, Cincinnati College opened its doors to mark the beginning of 125 years of continuous higher education.

A NEW American chamber opera by Bernard Wagenaar, composer, and Edward Eager, librettist, will have its first public performances on May 9 through May 13 at the Brander Matthews Theatre of Columbia University.

IF by any chance you have been planning to forget dancing for the nonce and start catching up on your reading, beginning about next week some time, just relax. Things are not going to calm down choreographically for quite a while yet.

MOSCOW, April 29 -- In modern mobile warfare on terrain which offers such opportunities for maneuver as Western Russia, it must always be the aim of armies who intend to attack to obtain possession of springboards before seasonal changes temporarily halt operations.

Declining sales of canned foods in independent retail grocery stores since the cancellation of expiration dates of blue ration stamps, announced by the Office of Price Administration March 26, indicate what is likely to happen under OPA's order of further reductions, it was reported in the trade yesterday.
WITH the national political conventions and the vacation season approaching to harry further the overburdened railroads, reports that travel rationing is imminent are again being heard in the land.

IN our frequent comments on idea-pictures as opposed to straight fiction films -- on a type which is coming increasingly into significant use -- we have sometimes neglected to mention a factor important in this line. That is the sort of distribution which is given these blossoming "think films."

The work of the War Refugee Board created by President Roosevelt was commended but declared inadequate by speakers appearing at Carnegie Hall last night before a rally sponsored by the Emergency Committee to Save the Jewwish People of Europe.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29 (AP) -- With Lou Sakas turning in an effective relief performance after Bill Emmerick weakened in the sixth, the Rochester Red Wings soared to a 6-2 victory over the Newark Bears today. The defeat was the fourth in five starts for the Newarkers.

ORANGE, Text, April 29 (U.P.) -- Chairman Martin Dies instructed the New York office of his House Committee on Un-American Activities today to subpoena all financial records of the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

MOSCOW, April 29 -- Ten years of uninterrupted ministration to Moscow's Roman Catholics is the record of the Rev. Leopold Braun of the Augustinian Order of the Assumption. The 40-year-old native of Massachusetts is priest of the Saint Louis des Francais Church, built on land granted to the French Catholics of Moscow by Catherine II in the eighteenth century.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Minor relexations in the designs and manufacture of certain types of women's wearing apparel were announced today by the War Production Board in amendments to conservation order L-85. Women's and misses' box coats between thirty-three and thirty-six inches long may now be manufactured with the same sweep as that designated for fitted coats and slacks, shorts and ski pants may be manufactured with belt loops under the amendment.

Ultra-violet solariums installed by mining companies in north Sweden resulted in a marked reduction of absences caused by illness, according to Dr. William T. Anderson Jr. in Archives of Physical Therapy. Swedish miners gained 134 additional working days per hundred workers during the first year the solariums were operated.

A proposal, originated in the American Legion, to unite veterans of both world wars in demanding equitable representation on a world peace commission, was accepted yesterday afternoon at the annual State convention of Catholic War Veterans at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

THE first American to write anything about New Zealand was Benjamin Franklin. In 1771 -- two years after Captain Cook had circumnavigated the islands and supplemented Tasman's vague discoverer's report of 1642 with some reasonably precise knowledge -- Franklin, then living in London, collaborated with Alexander Dalrymple on a disquisition entitled "Scheme of a Voyage to Convey the Conveniences of Life, Domestic Animals, Corn, Iron, etc., to New Zealand."

" I NOTICED that you mentioned Bugs Raymond the other day," said gentle Connie Mack in his soft voice. "But, goodness gracious, he couldn't hold a candle to Rube Waddell. No one ever did as many foolish things as the Rube. By golly, he was peculiar.

THE first successful sight and sound broadcast held in Uruguay, and perhaps the first in all South America, has gained for a young radio amateur of Montevideo recognition as the leading television pioneer south of the Caribbean.

In reply to many requests for help in eliminating and controlling caterpillars that are destroying fruit and shade trees on private property, the Park Department advised property owners yesterday to spray trees when the leaves appear with a solution of one pound of arsenate of lead to twenty-five gallons of water and to repeat this spray on May 15, June 1, June 15, July 10 and Aug. 1.

LONDON, April 29 -- Polish circles in London today continued warily watching Soviet activities that seemed to be aimed at further discrediting the Polish Government here and enhancing the reputation of the Union of Polish Patriots in Moscow and pro-Russian Partisans inside the country.
OTTAWA, April 29 (Canadian Press) -- Ray Atherton, United States Ambassador to Canada, said today that the "strongest prejudice" of the American people "is a prejudice in favor of freedom."

The impending invasion has evoked some signs of caution on the part of buyers in the wholesale markets, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. It adds, however, that this does not apply to merchandise in ample supply.

A corps of 15,000 volunteers trained through weeks of preparation will begin today the twenty-fifth annual house-to-house canvass of Roman Catholic families in the Archdiocese of New York, comprising 374 parishes, to solicit contributions for the work of archdiocesan charities, according to Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, secretary for charities to Archibishop Francis J. Spellman.

TO be sure, it is a little late in the history of radio and "The Goldbergs" to be marveling at it, but after nearly fifteen years there it is: a program which, at its inception, you might have deemed too local in its appeal to catch the fancy of a coast-to-coast audience.

CHICAGO. THE news about Victor Payne-Jennings' production of "Rebecca" at the Selwyn Theatre is that Bramwell Fletcher and Diana Barrymore get the publicity and that Florence Reed and Clarence Derwent carry the mail.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 29 -- The lead of Governor Dewey as first preference of Republican voters in the civilian population for the Presidential nomination has been increased from 45 per cent in February to 55 per cent today.

Fred C. De Wolfe is the only circus treasurer in the land who "ever slept in the White House." And if that isn't a distinction, the gentleman in question witnessed perhaps about a half dozen circus performances in his entire life. Mr. De Wolfe is show treasurer of Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey Circus and has held that job for the last forty years.

MUCH of the action of this story takes place on a steamer crossing Lake Titicaca from Peru to Bolivia, the rest of it in Bolivia itself. Mrs. Symington Foster, a self-appointed ambassador of good-will, is a passenger until the boat reaches the middle of the lake.

LOWERING of ration-point values on various foods, as announced at the close of the week, may mean a cheek to sagging sales in this trade although on some previous occasions the opposite effect has been noted. In the merchandise lines, clearance prices manifested some sharp reductions.

Admiral Ernest J. King, commander in chief of the United States Fleet, reported last week on the war at sea, a report concerned largely with the struggle in the Pacific. In that theatre, he declared, we are in the offensive phase. The period started, he said, when "our advance bases were no longer seriously threatened and we became able to attack the enemy at places of our own choosing."

NAPLES, April 29 -- For the fifth time during the war, the French naval base of Toulon was bombed from this theatre when heavy bombers of the United States Fifteenth Air Force made a concentrated attack on shipping and harbor installations today.

THE great invasion of Europe is expected to coincide with a general uprising of the oppressed peoples. This development is taken almost for granted. But the mechanism of the uprising, the methods by which invisible forces direct, inform, arm, feed and coordinate millions of potential warriors, has long been the subject of speculation.

CURRENTLY in "The New Leader" a writer goes for Shostakovich, and this from a point of orientation which is not that of the Soviets. The piece has its measure of argument, considerable inaccuracy, and obvious political bias.
HAVING made Stalin "his horse" (page 166), Mr. Duranty insists on making Trotsky mine, but I am not, nor have I ever been, a Trotskyite. So much for the ad hominem; now for the ad rem:

RAHWAY, N.J., April 29 -- Sgt. Elmer Truax, furloughed from the South Pacific through the intercession of President Roosevelt, returned to his home at 215 East Milton Avenue this morning to see his 18-month-old daughter, Therese, who is ill of leukemia, a usually fatal blood disease.

KANSAS CITY, April 29 (AP) -- A proposal for a Methodist youth army -- an army in which each member would give at least a year of service to "the church and to humanity" -- has been presented to the Quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Church.

IT has been said regarding postal paper that designs thereon often are purposely selected to symbolize the aspirations of the nation issuing the stamps. In 1940 Germany compelled Rumania to cede most of Transylvania to Hungary.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The designation of two duplicating Federal arbitration tribunals to Settle the same question, affecting the four railroad brotherhoods and the Switchmen's Union of North America, proved today to be an embarrassment to President Roosevelt and some of his associates.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 29 -- Dartmouth administered the first defeat of the season to the Army nine today, winning a loosely played game by 6 -- 4.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 29 -- Pointed condemnation of those persons who raise the "spurious issues" of "white supremacy" and "social equality" in current political campaigns was included in resolutions adopted at a meeting of the board of directors of the Southern Regional Council, Inc., and released here today by Dr. Howard W. Odum, president of the council and chairman of the board.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 29 -- Evidencing Britain's more active interest in Balkan and Middle Eastern affairs Prime Minister Churchill sent a message to Greek Premier George Papandreou today, pledging Britain's full support in the liberation of Greece and suggesting that Greek political differences be set aside until after the war.

LONDON, April 29 -- Lack of ferro-alloys has brought Germany to the verge of what may well be one of her most serious crises of the war. To understand the value to the Germans of these metals, wolfram, chrome and the like, which are essential for hardening steel, one must for a moment place himself in their position.

Hunter College graduates are not filling war jobs, Miss Lottie E. Bardach, director of the graduate division of the college's Bureau of Occupations, declared yesterday, because of an overemphasis on post-war security and disinterest in out-of-town positions.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 29 -- This section of the South is tiring of too many elections. Politics has been a disturbing element for years in this part of the country. In Louisiana the Gubernatorial fight usually means three election days.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Heavy evening-up operations in May rye took place today on the Board of Trade, with strong professional traders aggressive buyers which more than offset commission-house selling and also undoing of spreads with Winnipeg.
LONDON, Sunday, April 30 (UP) -A supplement to the Russian Saturday midnight communique, broadcast from Moscow

THE U.S. S. R.'s promised 30kopecs and 60k stamps in commemoration of the 125th anniversary of the birth of Ivan S. Turgeneff have been received by J. PL Stolow. Presenting a portrait of the novelist, poet and dramatist, they bear a Soviet inscription translated as "Great, tremendous, just and free Russian language."

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York was introduced as a modern prophet of Israel tonight at one of the largest dinners ever held in a Chicago hotel. The occasion was the recognition of his seventieth birthday and the fiftieth year of service in the rabbinate.

Six network radio programs, a regional program, a local station program and Bob Hope, comedian, are the 1943 winners of the George Foster Peabody radio awards, it was announced yesterday by Edward Weeks, editor of The Atlantic Monthly and chairman of the Peabody Award, and John E. Drewry, dean of the Henry W. Grady School of Journalism of the University of Georgia.

Plans for a committee to oppose participation by the United States in international affairs after the war, and inferentially to exert influence to that end in the forthcoming national political campaign, were announced last night at a meeting of more than 2,500 persons, many of them representing former isolationist or anti-war groups, in Columbus Club Ballroom, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

The Twentieth Century Fund has commissioned six economists to formulate their individual views on how this country can best manage its post-war financial affairs in connection with broad economic measures to achieve and maintain general prosperity, Evans Clark, executive secretary, announced yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, April 30 -- Japanese troops have started a second spring drive in Anhwei Province, about 200 miles southeast of the Chengchow fighting zone, along the Hwai River west of the Tientsin-Pukow railroad and south of the east-west Lung-Hai line, a Chinese communiqu revealed tonight.

The Homestead Grays made matters extremely unpleasant for the New York Black Yankees yesterday. The local nine, opening its home season in the National Negro Baseball League at the Yankee Stadium, was set down twice, each time by a decisive margin, while a crowd of 15,000 fans looked on.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Two additional six-man panels will be appointed to handle disputes involving about 400 companies whose collective bargaining agreements with the CIO United Steel Workers of America have expired and whose cases are before the National War Labor Board.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- Government loans on 1943 cash wheat stored in warehouses and 1942 crop grain held in farm storage will mature at midnight tonight, but how much grain will be turned over to the Commodity Credit Corporation is not expected to be known for several weeks.

LONDON, April 30 (U.P.) -- An intensified Nazi offensive is exerting heavy pressure on Marshal Tito's troops throughout Yugoslavia, with the greatest threat in Bosnia, where the Germans have entrenched themselves within five miles of Partisan headquarters, a communique disclosed today.
WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, April 30 -- Canol, the $130,000,000 American-financed oil project in northern Canada, is ready to begin delivering fuel for the Allied war machine.

LONDON, April 30 -- From a wealth of evidence gathered in London during the past two months it is clear that the operations of the United States Eighth Air Force against the German aircraft industry on Feb. 20, 22, 24 and 25 constituted one of the most striking victories of the war, a triumph that will profoundly affect not only the invasion but the course of the war with Germany on every front.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 30 -- While her mother was in White Plains consulting an attorney on plans to file a marital suit, attractive Gwendolyn Tidwell, 17 years old, took her life this afternoon by inhaling illuminating gas in the kitchen of her mother's apartment at the Esplanade Gardens, 531 East Lincoln Avenue here.

Doubting correspondents in Chungking last winter suggested that China, in her seventh year of war, might be too tired to fight much longer. The Battle of the Yellow River, now at its height in northern Honan, does not look like it. The Japanese spring drive, launched there in heavy force two weeks ago, has been checked on both its wings.

NORFOLK, Neb., April 30 (AP) -- Representative A.L. Miller said today that General MacArthur's announcement that he would not accept the Presidential nomination "should be final" but added, "I am wondering how much pressure the Administration used to force the general out of the race."

One of the world's widespread misconception is concerned with the married man whose wife has gone away on a visit and left him to fend for himself. He is immediately the central figure in office jokes which cast him in the role of a rake.

The Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society released yesterday a story of the persecution, horrors and "deportation" to extermination camps in Poland of the largest Jewish community in Greece, based on information received from underground sources in Greece, and conveyed to the headquarters of the Hias-Ica Emigration Association in Lisbon, Portugal.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 30 -- This afternoon the Tom O'Donohue Trophy passed out of competition and into the permanent possession of Eric A. Thomee, president of the Orange County Field Trial Club. This was the chief prize in the Orange County stake, the final event of the three-day program of this popular club.
Nine new films will arrive at midtown theatres during the week. The openings follow:

More than a score of exhibitions are scheduled to open this week here in the art galleries. Included on the week's agenda are a double show -- one of paintings, one of drawings -- by Andre Masson; two shows of nineteenth century American paintings and work by a number of well-known contemporary artists.

Another of the realty holdings of William Randolph Hearst and associates has passed into new hands. The fourteen-story apartment house at 471 Park Avenue, at the southeast corner of Fifty-eighth Street, has been sold by Hearst Magazines to the R.F.B. Realty Corporation of 565 Fifth Avenue for an indicated consideration of $60,000 above a mortgage of $165,000.

LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- Laboring men of the United Nations, free to toil for the overthrow of the German hold on Europe, celebrated May Day today as the dusk of German rule while Berlin mouthpieces sought to bolster morale at home and among the conquered peoples and German satellites to meet the coming invasion.

Major league baseball enjoyed a banner day yesterday with a total of 214,974 spectators coming out to see the eight double-headers played in both circuits. At the Polo Grounds, a throng of 58,068 saw the Giants oppose the Dodgers, with an estimated 20,000 turned away.

La Guardia Field, airport for 500 transatlantic crossings made by cargo and passenger planes during a recent month between New York and the United Kingdom and Africa, has become a key center in the war air transportation system, Maj. Gen. Harold L. George, commanding general of the Army's Air Transport Command, disclosed yesterday in announcing a change of command at the field.

Webster aptly defines fishing as "to attempt to catch" and "to seek to obtain by artifice." But Webster does not go into the intangibles, and the true fisherman is concerned with more than frying-pan evidence. There are those who forthrightly say that a man goes fishing for the same reason he plays golf, that is, to get away from the work which supports his family.

LONDON, April 30 -- Apart from satisfactory current earnings and a more generous dividend policy on the part of the boards of numerous industrial companies, post-war prospects again are coming in for favorable discussion. One hears much less nowadays about the so-called dangers of peace where industry is concerned.

LONDON, April 30 -- Four more privileged men will soon hear the secrets of the invasion plans behind closed doors of the British Empire's "family council of war," which will hold its first session in London tomorrow.

Preceded by a parade of 2,500 persons, the annual St. George day service of the American Order of the Sons of St. George, American Independent Order of the Daughters of St. George, and the Daughters of St. George was held yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Numerous associated societies took part in the service, which was attended by 6,000.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Office of Price Administration today brought softwood lumber imported from Russia under the provisions of its northeastern softwood lumber price regulation. The action was taken, the agency said, to provide "more uniform and equitable" prices for this variety of lumber.

Unanimously re-elected for the third straight time as president of the Council of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations of the Federation of Jewish Charities, Judge Jonah J. Goldstein of the Court of General Sessions urged 250 delegates at the council's annual convention yesterday at the Hotel Commodore to prepare to meet the challenge of the home front's post-war needs.

Thirty-five carloads of new potatoes from Florida were rejected last week by local consignees because of rot, one carload of them being dumped, it was learned yesterday. Major dealers warned that the recent abundance might readily shift to scarcity.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- A material enlargement in the movement of cash corn from farms to market is anticipated this week as the result of a Government program, which results in shelling and delivering the farmers' cash grain to country elevators in 125 designated counties in five States.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- The Browns suffered their season's second defeat today, 6 to 5, in ten innings, in the opener of a double-header with the White Sox, but they came back in the nightcap to record their tenth success, 5 to 4. A crowd of 6,602 saw the games in Comiskey Park.

KANSAS CITY, April 30 (AP) -- A challenge was brought to the Methodists of America from Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek tonight to help rebuild a China in which 70,000,000 persons had been driven from their homes in the greatest migration in the history of the world.

A sharp increase in flotations of stock that lifted the total above that of bonds and to the highest monthly figure since May, 1941, featured new financing here in April. Offerings of bonds, on the other hand, were the smallest for any month since September.

Leroy A. Lincoln, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, has been nominated for president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, to succeed Frederick E. Hasler, who has served the limit of two consecutive one-year terms, Richard W. Lawrence, chairman of the nominating committee, announced yesterday. The election will be held on Thursday.
Let me congratulate you on your publishing such sensible letters on discipline.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Several new child care services have been started under Lanham Act funds to meet an increased need for care of children of working mothers developing as the result of the drafting of fathers, according to an Office of War Information report on child care.

The Citizens Union protested yesterday, in a letter to Mayor La Guardia, against his objection to the free admission of loyal Japanese-Americans from relocation camps to this city, asserting that "we Americans have prided ourselves on our readiness to accord equal rights and opportunities to all regardless of their race, color or national origin."

Not to be outdone by the energetic waste paper salvage work of Brooklyn schools, the 450 students of Holy Trinity Parochial School, 212 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday reported April collections of 25,000 pounds.

The present period of limited ground operations on all the world's battlefronts is due to be broken before many weeks have passed, it is now obvious, by the greatest assaults in which American forces have ever participated.

Following your inspiring editorial "The Battle of the Ghetto" we have just received from the Jewish labor underground in Poland a report dated Nov. 15, 1943, telling us what has been happening in Poland since those fateful days in April and May of last year when the martyrs of Warsaw gave their lives in rebellion against the Nazi tyrant.

Early wartime restrictions on all kinds of metals turned many craftsmen who formerly worked with these materials to designing tableware of wood. Although lumber is one of the most critical of war materials and its scarcity is a serious problem for furniture makers, the comparatively small amounts of wood needed for items of this new tableware permit continued production on a limited scale.

Advertising has played an "exceptionally forceful" role in the home-front battle against inflation, President Roosevelt is quoted as saying in a letter released yesterday by the War Advertising Council. The President said that in the year elapsed since he signed the "hold the line order" the cost-of-living index has declined.

Tomorrow there is to be a meeting and debate on these premises of authors of detective and mystery stories. These subjects are of high interest to the public, which, however, will hardly expect that the writers will disclose much of the secrets of their craft. We don't know how to estimate, if it can be estimated, the popularity of each branch.

The volume of sales of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., last year was the highest in the company's history, amounting to $60,473,821, against $32,338,870 in 1942, an increase of 87 per cent, according to the annual report to stockholders, released yesterday by Walter E. Poor, president.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) -- With the score tied at 2 -- 2, the second game of today's, double-header between the Phillies and the Boston Braves was called at the end of the ninth because of a city curfew. The Phillies won the opener, 2 -- 1, in 14 innings.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The visit of the Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski of Springfield, Mass., to Russia and his audience with Premier Joseph Stalin is "a political burlesque, staged and directed by capable Soviet agents" for propaganda purposes, the Right Rev. Mgr. Michael J. Ready, general secretary of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, said here today.

Good buyer representation in the New York market was noted last week, with interest shown in items for Mother's Day and Father's Day promotions. Many types of dresses were wanted, including graduation numbers, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying officers.

The Mississippi River stage at St. Louis remained stationary for several hours yesterday after reaching a crest of 39.1 feet, nearly 2 inches above the level reached last year (May 24) and about 2 feet less than the record high of 41.39 feet established in 1844.

" POLITICS," says Charles Michelson, "is a game for keeps." It is a rabbit-punching, kidney-kicking, eye-gouging, waterfront-riot kind of game. "Nobody has ever been able to formulate a political code of ethics." And yet bitter political enemies, men who belabor each other in public with violent abuse, often maintain friendly personal relations.

Stockholders of the Virginia Electric Power Company and the Virginia Public Service Company will on May 17 vote upon the merger of their two companies. With the approval on Saturday by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell of the sale by General Gas Electric Corporation, a subsidiary of the Associated Gas Electric System, of its entire interest in Virginia Public Service most of the important details leading to the merger have been approved.
LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

ALGIERS, April 30 -- That the French people are still republican, while desiring a new kind of republic, a stronger government and different leaders, is one conclusion of a lengthy survey of public opinion in France that is being studied here.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Current and post-war problems and activities of Federal, State and local governments will be discussed this week at the annual meetings of officials of the American Society of Planning and of the National Association of Housing.

LONDON, April 30 -- Outright nationalization of Britain's fuel and power has been recommended again by the Labor party directorate in a report prepared for submission to the party's annual conference.

Elisabeth Rethberg, who had not been heard in this city for two years, gave a recital last night at Town Hall, where she was welcomed with a warmth that attested to her firm hold on the esteem and affection of the large audience present.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices registered a drop from 112.82 to 112.69. Despite unusually heavy marketings of livestock that have been forced by a relatively tight feed situation, the prices have been generally upward until a few weeks ago.
LONDON, April 30 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

" Veterans" of last summer's Woman's Land Army yesterday heard a farmer express his satisfaction with their work in harvesting and then declare that the committee of farmers he represented was not satisfied with what it had done for the city girls in return.

LONDON, Monday, May 1 -- Marshal Joseph Stalin in a May Day order of the day today called for a combined Russian-American-British blow to crush Germany completely and advised the peoples of Rumania, Hungary, Bulgaria and Finland to overthrow their governments and seek Allied mercy.
KANDY, Ceylon, April 30 (UP) -- A communique:

ON THE KOHIMA FRONT IN INDIA, April 27 (delayed) -- A many-sided British counter-attack is menacing the whole Japanese position in the Kohima area of North Manipur. British forces now hold wedges deep in between the Japanese pockets of resistance and attacks are under way from several directions against Japanese strong points.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 30 -- A military agreement between the British and Marshal Tito, providing for the formation of a Yugoslav Partisan air force to operate within the Royal Air Force, was announced here today in a special Middle East air communique.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- Kathryn Grayson and June Allyson will be starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "Brighton Beach," a musical to be based on a story by Miles Connolly concerning the New York resort at the turn of the century.
NEWARK, N.J., April 30 (AP) -- The Bears shaded the Red Wings today in both ends of a double bill before 4,338 fans by 6 -- 4 and 4 -- 3 scores. Both contests were decided in extra frames.
LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

A code to govern the behavior of the junior high school students in New York City, prepared by the youngsters themselves, has been adopted by a majority vote of the eighty-three junior high schools, representing a student population of 100,000, and is to go into effect at once, Dr. Elias Lieberman, associate superintendent, announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 30 -- The wide publicity accorded to the Father Orlemanski's reception by Premier Stalin has given the event greater significance than a showing of the Soviet leader's desire for the latest information about the state of Polish opinion in the United States.

Police Commissioner Louis J. Valentine's efforts to recruit Negroes for the Police Department, which he said were "not generally known," were renewed by him yesterday morning at a police communion breakfast with an invitation urging Negroes to take civil service examinations for posts as patrolmen. He said he had been trying to get them to do this for more than nine years.
Leases to a Well-known Presbyterian minister, to the Consul General of Venezuela, and to Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, were among the contracts for apartments reported yesterday.

BOSTON, April 30 (AP) -- The dinkiest kind of a scratch hit was the only safe blow in a seventh-inning three-run outburst which gave the Philadelphia Athletics a 3-to-1 verdict over the Boston Red Sox today in the second game of a double-header.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Sage old Art Fletcher turned magician at Griffith Stadium today and cashed gratifying dividends on his fancy tricks, to the dismay of 31,057 fans, the largest crowd to see the Yankees this season.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, May 1 -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- How the traditional "dope wagon" grows into a cafeteria in Southern textile mills and how shipyard workers learn to eat in a way to take the dread from the "afternoon accident hour" was described by Miss Gladys Knight of Atlanta, Ga., Federal industrial feeding specialist.

After an improvement in values in the earlier half of last week, cotton prices turned downward and closed the period with small irregular changes. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed changes ranging from a net advance of 6 points to a decline of 3 points.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 30 -- Fearing increased sabotage by many of the 15,000,000 conscript foreign workers in the Reich May Day, tomorrow, reinforcements of Storm Troopers have been dispatched to concentration points throughout Germany and Austria following the discovery by the Gestapo of an alleged plot to "bring the Reich's war production to a complete standstill for twenty-four hours," according to information received here this afternoon from a reliable source in Germany.

Large quantities of the American drug surplus anticipated at the war's end by the industry will be absorbed by China, according to the China-America Council of Commerce and Industry, which points out that the industry has expanded rather than converted for war production.
In the second round of the Lewis Cup soccer game at Starlight Park on a baked field yesterday, Brookhattan took the measure of the Kearny Scots, 7 to 5.

Ending a policy of drift and vacillation that had become the breeding ground of mutiny and civil war, Prime Minister Churchill has just addressed a firm message to the new Greek Premier, Mr. Papandreou, which must be accepted as a clarification of the British position not only toward Greece but also toward other Balkan countries, and possibly toward all nations still under the Nazi heel.
JERSEY CITY, April 30 (AP) -- Jersey City made it three in a row over Buffalo before 4,550 fans today by defeating the Bisons in both ends of a double-header, 5 -- 0 and 6 -- 4.
The Women's Military Services Club marked yesterday its first year at a luncheon in the ballroom of the clubhouse, the historic Whitelaw Reid mansion at 451 Madison Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 30 -- A "nation-wide crusade" of Northern Baptists to win support in Congress for establishment after the war of "a more Christian world order" was started here today by Donald B. Cloward, executive secretary of the Council on Christian Social Progress, at services in the First Baptist Church.
ST. LOUIS, April 30 (AP) -- The Cardinals retained their National League lead with a double victory, 5 -- 0 and 7 -- 5, over the Cubs today.

With the celebration of solemn pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday Archbishop Francis J. Spellman officially opened the 1944 annual parish appeal of New York Catholic Charities, which was started by the late Cardinal Hayes a quarter of a century ago.

MOSCOW, April 30 -- Andrey J. Vyshinsky, Soviet Vice Commissar of Foreign Affairs, announced tonight details of a proposed new Russian-Czechoslovak treaty covering the entrance of Soviet troops and other Allied forces into Czechoslovakia.

The return to the American Federation of Labor of the International Typographical Union, now an independent organization, and of other unions that left the AFL to help form the Congress of Industrial Organizations eight years ago, was predicted yesterday by William Green, president of the AFL.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 -- Spurred by demands for steel, which were growing heavier, and despite shortages of manpower which appeared at some plants, the steel industry reached last week a new peak in output. The rate advanced 1 1/2 points to 99.5 per cent of rated capacity.
Several properties in West Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets have just passed into new ownerships.

Ruth Soskind, young American pianist, made her debut at the New York Times Hall yesterday, providing an afternoon of very creditable playing. Miss Soskind has a clean technique and an intelligent way of approaching the works she plays, and though she has not yet achieved the authority and full expression of the mature artist, her playing displayed sound musicianship and a sturdy talent.

Encircled by the season's largest baseball crowd, a gathering of 58,068, the Giants and Dodgers put on a variety show at the Polo Grounds yesterday that staggered the imagination and well-nigh prostrated contestants and on-lookers alike.

A call for a State-wide convention to form a new Liberal party was issued yesterday by Dean Alfange, chairman of the Liberal and Labor Committee, and Prof. John L. Childs, chairman of its platform and program committee.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Clear weather has resulted in a resumption of seeding of oats over a wide area in the Central West, but reports indicate there is little possibility of the acreage goal being attained, and brokers express the belief that the official returns in July will show around 41,000,000 acres seeded, or in line with the 1933-42 average.

WOOD RIVER, Ill., April 30 (U.P.) -Speaking today at the dedication of the Shell Oil Company's twin-catalytic cracking units here, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, mentioned the rise in the output of 100-octane gasoline in three years from 40,000 to 400,000 barrels a day and predicted a progressive stepping up of the Allied aerial offensive.

With business estimated to be off 50 per cent, hundreds of taverns in this city and outlying sections that formerly featured dancing and entertainment will be forced to close soon unless the 30 per cent cabaret tax is reduced by Congress, Joseph Maguire, president of the United Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association, said last night.

It seems to me that, regardless of the merits of the controversy between any citizen, corporate or individual, and the Commander in Chief, it is incumbent upon every loyal citizen to obey the orders and directives of the Commander in Chief in time of war, and if, after so obeying, the citizen feels aggrieved, to then appeal to the courts for redress.

Mayor La Guardia took a thirty-minute stroll yesterday through the maze of maps, charts, graphs and models comprising the $90,000 exhibit of post-war city projects, developed by the City Planning Commission and housed in the former home of the Board of Education at Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, In Italy, April 30 -- The combined influx of Italian refugees who remember German pistols, and of sullen Germans who have fired their last shots for a long time, might be expected to keep Sgt. Victor Lewis and his four colleagues at a dangerously exposed prisoner-of-war collection station busy enough.

Walter D. Smith of Tulsa, Okla., has been appointed commercial vice president of Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation. For the past four years Mr. Smith has been manager of Worthington's Tulsa district office as well as Southwestern manager of the engine sales division.

MOSCOW, April 30 -- Pravda, Communist party newspaper, reported today that many in England and America, observing the intensive preparations of the Anglo-American military forces, had for a long time been asking with amazement what was delaying the development of the operation for an invasion of the Continent.

The checkered history of May Day, celebrated in Europe since 1899 as the international festival of labor, reads like a barometer not only of the vicissitudes of the trades-union movement but of the rise and fall of popular government. This year the barometer rises.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The executive committee of the American Legion, in one of its first statements on the role of aviation and air traffic in the post-war world, today called for "full freedom of the air" for the United States, its allies and "other freedom-loving nations."

Acting in behalf of 225,000 members in forty-six cities, the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced yesterday that the union would submit its demand for a general increase of 17 cents an hour, to the War Labor Board.

Net assets of $4,340,113 as of Jan. 31 were shown in a financial report made public yesterday by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America. The audit was made by S.D. Leidesdorf Co., certified public accountants.
CINCINNATI, April 30 (AP) -- The Reds saved the second half of a double-header with the Pirates today behind Bucky Walters' pitching, winning by 4 to 1 after losing the first game, 7 to 1.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, April 30 -- The statement of Gen. Douglas MacArthur that he would not accept a nomination for President did not surprise anyone here.

Mrs. Harper Sibley, member of the committee on strategy and policy of the Protestant Episcopal Church, was the guest speaker yesterday morning at All Angels Protestant Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street, at a service planned primarily for women.

A concert in honor of Russia, the last of three "Concert Salutes," was given at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Congregation Emanu-El, its choir committee and the University Women's Chorus. The event was under the direction of Lazare Saminsky.

LONDON, Monday, May 1 (U.P.) -- Soviet warships have attacked and sunk two German transports west of besieged Sevastopol, a broadcast Moscow communique said today, and reports from the Russian capital told of widespread Soviet air activity concentrated on the central front, where it was described as a "softening up campaign" presaging a drive toward East Prussia and the Baltic Sea.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in April dropped to the smallest of any month in more than a year or since November, 1942, and was only slightly more than one-third the business for the corresponding month in 1943.
LONDON, Monday, May 1 (U.P.) -- Text of Marshal Joseph, Stalin's May Day order of the day broadcast early today by the Moscow radio:

" The work done by various agencies of Government in combating inflation has been ably supported by the exceptionally forceful advertisements prepared by the War Advertising Council," President Roosevelt declared in a letter to the council.

Governor Dewey paid tribute yesterday to the Jews who resisted Nazi troops for forty-two days in the Warsaw ghetto and were killed. In a message read at a mass memorial meeting in Manhattan Center, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, held under the auspices of the American Committee of Jewish Writers, Artists and Scientists, the Governor wrote:

The Manhattan Savings Bank sold the house on a plot 63.9 by 100 feet at 47 Faneuil Place, in New Rochelle, Westchester County, to Mary R. Menzie through See Sullivan, Inc., broker. The assessed valuation is $10,750

LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- More than 1,300 German fighters have been knocked out by American fighters and bomber gunners during the April heavy bomber missions of the United States Eighth Air Force, Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle, its commander, said tonight.

CLEVELAND, April 30 (AP) -- The Federal Government through the War Production Board, "is preparing to limit steel allocations for claimant agencies of the Government for the third quarter," says the magazine Steel.

Three expert safe cracksmen broke into the quarters of the Office of Price Administration at 288 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning and stole ration coupons and certificates that would have diverted a large share of the borough's scarce goods.

A Slavic Center is being planned by the Library of Congress to foster the inter-exchange of American and Russian books and literature, it has been announced by Archibald MacLeish. The library is now administering a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation to determine the extent to which Russian materials are now available in American libraries.
LONDON, April 30 -- Damage totaling millions of pounds has been done to works of art in England by German bombs, it was said today by restorers who are now salvaging what they can of these treasures.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., April 30 -- Irate at customs guards for closing the Rainbow Bridge while he waited patiently in line for a local bus ahead to be cleared, Roy Bradenburg, a Canadian banker of Niagara Falls, Ont., drove his automobile through the heavy wooden barrier at 12:01 o'clock this morning and sped safely into Canada although his car was slightly damaged.
I salute Sewell Avery and Montgomery Ward Co.

LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's new Air Ministry building in the heart of Berlin received direct hits in yesterday's American heavy bombing attack, leaving the south wing burning fiercely, the United States Strategic Air Forces announced today.

Mayor La Guardia submitted for public discussion yesterday his plan for a voluntary all-inclusive health insurance plan for all persons, including city employes, who live or work in New York City and earn up to $5,000 a year.

LONDON, April 30 -- The City's first reactions toward the new budget were favorable while second thoughts strengthened this impression. What there is about a budget that maintains the income tax at 50 per cent and the excess profits tax at 100 per cent that commends itself to financial judgment is difficult to fathom.
LONDON, Monday, May 1 -- A force of 3,000 Allied planes that included about 1,000 American heavy bombers and their fighter escorts attacked German anti-invasion targets in France yesterday.

On financial markets last week transactions were again relatively small; on one day, in the middle of the week, business in stocks fell below 500,000 shares. Averages for stocks were little changed, but declined slightly at the start. Domestic bond averages were somewhat lower, though still not far below the high price of 1944, the week before.

Gen. Douglas MacArthur's statement withdrawing his name from consideration for the Republican nomination for President is blunt and unequivocal: "I request that no action be taken that would link my name in any way with the nomination. I do not covet it nor would I accept it."
The parks and beaches in the metropolitan area played host to record crowds yesterday as the first warm, sunny Sunday of spring made a belated appearance. It was the warmest day thus far in 1944.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Heavy receipts of hogs at leading Western packing points and a slow lend-lease demand for pork products have weakened the markets for hogs, swine selling last week at the lowest prices in recent weeks and loose-lard dropping to $12.30 a hundredweight, or 50 cents under the ceiling, in an effort of packers to make room for new products.

BOSTON, April 30 -- The young women of America should influence returning soldiers to continue their education instead of immediately seeking employment, Judah J. Shapiro, director of the Hillel Foundation in Boston, said today in an address to the district convention of B'nai B'rith girls, when he asserted that woman is the power behind the throne and that she will have a responsibility for the destiny of service men when the war is over.

DETROIT, April 30 (AP) -- Before 38,940 spectators, second largest crowd in two years at Briggs Stadium, the Detroit Tigers won the nightcap, 4 to 2, to divide a double-header today with the Cleveland Indians, who took the opener, 2 to 1.

PEARL HARBOR, April 30 (U.P.) -- For the thirty-fifth time in less than ninety days, Army Liberators attacked Truk atoll in the heart of the Carolines Friday night, dropping forty-one tons of bombs, as other bombers and fighters pounded Ponape Island and Marshall island bases, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced tonight.

The Government and the people of the United States will face the possibility of universal bankruptcy if there is no relief from the menace of war, Dr. James T. Shotwell, director of the division of economics and history of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, declared in the annual report of the division made public yesterday.

LONDON, April 30 -- The United States inaugurated its pre-invasion broadcasts, to Europe from troop-jammed Britain today with a message to the conquered people that their day of liberation is "not far distant" and that the Germans soon will "really learn what overwhelming force can be."

LONDON, April 30 -- A German destroyer was driven ashore by shell fire and left a target for repeated attacks by Typhoon fighter-bombers, and the Canadian destroyer Athabaskan was sunk in a sharp action between the Athabaskan and another Canadian destroyer, the Haida, and two German destroyers, in the vicinity of Ile de Beirge, near Ushant, early Saturday, the Admiralty announced tonight.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, May 1 (U.P.) -- United States naval units teamed up with Fifth Air Force heavy and medium bombers Saturday and Sunday to pour 126 tons of explosives into the Wakde Island area and the Sarmi coastal sector 110 miles west of Hollandia, Netherland New Guinea, Gen. Douglas McArthur's communique today reported.

APPARENTLY there is nothing the matter with baseball that warm weather and an inviting day cannot cure. The tremendous outpouring at the Polo Grounds yesterday -- an awe-inspiring gathering of 58,068 -- was the finest testimonial the sport could have had proffered it. This crowd was a wholesome tonic which should silence forever these critical sharpshooters who have been reading obituary notices on the diamond game.

With an eye on the post-war market the Columbia Broadcasting System advises the radio industry to abandon present television frequencies of 50-84 megacycles for wider bands above 200 megacycles. Translated into ordinary language, this means better television images than we have ever had.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 -- From the prospects of the biggest field since War Admiral defeated nineteen rivals in 1937 and the most wide open race in recent years, the field of the seventieth running of the Kentucky Derby Saturday had been reduced to fifteen probable starters today, with Stir Up labeled as the standout for the $75,000 race at Churchill Downs.

NAPLES, April 30 (AP) -- The Allies' air fleets topped off forty-eight hours of blows at southern European U-boat and surface craft nests last night, bombing the Italian harbors of Genoa, La Spezia and Leghorn after a daylight smash at Toulon, headquarters announced today.

SEATTLE, April 30 (AP) -- More than a score of persons were arrested in King County last night in a follow-up of the drive against juvenile delinquency which, last week, resulted in the disclosure of "wolf pack" gangs or youths banded together to drink and carouse with teen-age girls.

NEW ORLEANS, April 30 -- Uncertainties over the war, political movements in Washington and liquidation in May cotton contracts following first notice today combined late last week to carry cotton futures downward on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange after earlier small upturns on continued unfavorable crop reports, price fixations, covering in the near months and some transferring to the distant deliveries.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor, which will open its spring meeting here tomorrow, will face the problem of deciding on John L. Lewis' year-old application for readmission of the United Mine Workers of America.
Step by step the forces striving to communize us become more and more audacious. The war and its accompanying usurpation of power plays into the hands of these un-American and dictatorial forces.
STOCKHOLM, April 30 -- A Japanese deserter gave a full story about present conditions in Germany today.

CHARLESTON, West Va., May 1 -- A realistic adjustment of postwar shipping fleets of the United States and Britain was advocated tonight by Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, speaking before the Charleston Chamber of Commerce.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 1 -- The Middle East governments are emerging from the war with their currencies fully backed by gold or foreign-exchange assets and there has been no significant flight of capital or depreciation in exchange rates, it was stated today in resolutions adopted by delegates attending the Middle East financial conference.

High fame in letters caught up rather slowly with Martin Flavin. He is in his sixty-first year now, a rugged, beetle-browed man with two sons in the service and with some twenty plays and several novels to his credit. He taught playwriting for one seminar at Stanford University, has turned out countless short stories, written for the motion pictures and at the same time achieved success as a well-to-do executive in the wallpaper industry.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Immediate legislation to prevent further expansion of bank holding companies or creation of new ones was recommended today by the Federal Reserve Board.

Are we to treat loyal citizens or residents of Japanese blood more harshly than we treat those of German blood? This question came up immediately after Pearl Harbor. It is still with us, judging by opposition shown in this and other cities to the resettlement of Pacific Coast Japanese in the East.

CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- The heaviest runs of hogs since late in February were unloaded today at livestock markets throughout the Midwest, causing many head to remain unsold at the end of trading, the War Food Administration reported.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 1 -- The chartered banks of Canada would lose on Jan. 1, 1945, their right to issue their own banknotes, and by 1950 they would be required to redeem all outstanding notes, under a bill introduced in Commons today by Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 1 -- A warning that to return to a period of "trial and error" in price control might bring a backfire of inflation was made by Representative A.S. Monroney in addressing the war problems conference of the National Retail Furniture Association at the Claridge Hotel here today.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 2 (AP) -- Soviet long-range bombers heralded the advent of May Day Sunday night with a mass raid on Brest-Litovsk, touching off nearly a score of fires amid Axis troop trains in that old Polish fortress city, which the Germans captured only two days after they had launched their 1941 invasion, Moscow announced Monday night.

CONNIE MACK had been saying that Rube Waddell had been baseball's prize screwball of all time and that Bugs Raymond, another notorious wack, "couldn't hold a candle to him." This brought a mild dissent from a veteran baseball writer, who stoutly claimed that between the two "It was at least a tie score." Be that as it may, however, the Rube was a most peculiar creature.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Three hundred members of the American Society of Planning Officials, organization of technical experts in Federal, State and local planning, were told at their annual meeting today that post-war public works and relief should be paid for by the States and municipalities as much as possible, and by the Federal Government only where absolutely necessary.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:...

In comprehensiveness no health insurance plan thus far carried out approaches that outlined by the Mayor in his broadcast on Sunday. Every approved diagnostic and therapeutic service, every "extra" usually charged for separately, is included. If any member of an insured family up to the age of 18 needed specialists, surgeons and nursing care in the home or the hospital he would get it.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 -- The Kentucky Derby fever, an epidemic that annually hits this horse-loving country, rose suddenly today as one of the home town candidates turned in a sensational workout, three more eligibles arrived from the East, Trainer Ben Jones wired that Pensive would be on hand and seven horses were named for tomorrow's Derby trial.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The administration, of course, is presenting a common front behind the President in the Montgomery Ward case. Director Byrnes of the Office of War Mobilization, Secretary of Commerce Jones and Under-Secretary of Commerce Chatfield Taylor are faithfully following the instructions of Attorney General Biddle as to procedure.

CHUNGKING, China, May 1 (U.P.) -- Two Japanese armies, attacking savagely in coordinated spring drives, have captured the strategically valuable Hulao Pass, west of Chengchow in Honan Province, and the important highway junction of Yingshang in Anhwei Province to the southeast, a Chinese communique admitted tonight.

Earnings of the Coca-Cola Company in the first three months of this year amounted to $9,478,067 before taxes, against $9,790,622 on the same basis last year, the company's operating statement disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Army has taken "necessary disciplinary action" against salvage officers responsible for the improper sale at a nominal sum of 100,000 dry-cell batteries that when new had cost the Government $200,000, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, assured Representative John J. Cochran, Democrat of Missouri, today.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Manufacture of another 193,625 electric flatirons this year was assured by the War Production Board today as it announced production quotas totaling that many irons had been assigned to three manufacturers of electrical appliances.
PEARL HARBOR, May 1 -- Neutralization raids on enemy bases in the Central Pacific are steadily mounting to new peaks of frequency and weight with once powerful Truk bearing the brunt of the damage.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A decision likely to be of considerable importance in connection with the war production program was handed down by the Supreme Court today when it held by 7 to 2 that States cannot constitutionally assess real property taxes against Federally owned machinery and equipment in war plants.
Price changes on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were small. The close was steady, 3 to 6 points lower than Saturday's final figures.
