LONDON, May 1 -- The stock markets here opened the week cheerfully today, brokers reporting an increase in orders received over the week-end. With buyers active and shares in short supply, many increases in prices were seen.
CHICAGO, May 1 -- Jimmy Wilson threw in the sponge as manager of the Chicago Cubs today.

For the forty-second consecutive year the Big Show went to Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning. It was seventy minutes of unbridled joy for a record-breaking assemblage of 5,000 patients, doctors, nurses and, of course, the usual quota of hookey players. All agreed that this year's visit was something long to remember.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A gain of 14 per cent in March sales of independent retailers, as compared with March, 1943, was reported today by the Bureau of the Census. March sales were up 24 per cent as compared with February.

The effectiveness of newspaper advertising to combat war plant absenteeism, attract new employes and increase company prestige in the community has been demonstrated by the results of the Casco Products Corporation campaign, the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association stated yesterday.
LONDON, May 1 -- Romance triumphed over the British budget when fifty wedding gowns sent from America for use by British girls in the services were shown today for the first time.

Two exhibitions of work by the French artist, r4mdr hasson, opened yesterday. Oils are shown at the Rosenberg Gallery, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, and drawings at the Bucb_holz, in the next block at No. 32. They were arranged in collaboration and will continue through 1Vfay 20.

Back in 1938 Johnny Vander Meer made history at Ebbets Field when he pitched his second successive no-hitter. History, it has been said, has a way of repeating itself, and so today, when the Braves drop into the Flathush ball park, Leo Durocher and his men will have their fingers crossed.
CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) -- A seven-run uprising in the eighth inning produced a 9-to-3 triumph for the Indians today in the opener of a four-game series with the White Sox.

The Jalda Holding Corporation has purchased for investment the two-story taxpayer on a plot 100 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of 212th Street and White Plains Avenue, in the Bronx, from the North Side Savings Bank, which took back a purchase money mortgage of $27,000. The Grenell Realty Agency was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $63,500.

The annual concert of new American orchestral music, from which Music Critics Circle of New York will choose the season's "best," will be broadcast over the NBC network for the second consecutive year with Frank Black and the NBC Symphony Orchestra playing three works nominated for the award.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres today. At the Paramount, beginning at 5:15 P.M., "Going My Way," a Paramount picture starring Bing Crosby, will have its premiere. Directed by Leo McCarey, the film's featured cast includes Rise Stevens, the Metropolitan Opera star; Barry Fitzgerald, James Brown, Jean Heather and Frank McHugh. . . . .

Robert E. Sherwood did not give away any secrets when he opened his ABSIE program on Sunday with the warning that the Continent will be attacked from the south as well as the east and west. The Italian campaign, already under way, is an attack from the south.

The tremendous importance of airpower in this war has never been illustrated more dramatically than at the present moment, when the air arm alone is engaged in major operations. After an almost continuous advance from the Volga to the Beresina and from the foothills of the Caucasus to the Carpathians, the Russian offensive has ground to a temporary halt while the Red armies regroup for fresh attack.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- The right of employers to express personal views on labor unions to employes was upheld today by Judge Charles Alvin Jones of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals. He declared that "to stop a man from expressing himself would be a denial of the right of free speech."

In his fourth purchase of a large apartment building in Manhattan, Henry Leeds of Plainfield, N.J., has acquired the fourteen-story and penthouse building at 108 East Eighty-sixth Street from the Franklin Savings Bank. Assessed at $415,000, the property is 50.7 by 102.2 feet and contains twenty-three apartments renting for more than $40,000 a year.

While refurbishment of the Manhattan Towers Hotel, 2162 Broadway, was being rushed, almost 200 Waves moved into rooms yesterday on the four "decks" of the twenty-four-story building that already have been refitted. The hotel, at Seventy-sixth Street, taken over last month by the Navy for conversion into a women's reserve barracks, eventually will be occupied by 1,000 Waves stationed in the Third Naval District.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Office of Price Administration said today that rationing of new cars would have to get "tighter and tighter" until new production was in sight.

CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) -- The M.A. Hanna Company, Cleveland coal, iron ore and shipping concern, announced today that a special meeting of stockholders will be held on May 17 to approve a proposed new issue of 100,000 shares of $4.25 preferred stock, for which a registration statement was filed Saturday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

One of the last official acts of the late Frank Knox, as Secretary of the Navy, was to ask the United States Steel Corporation and the General Motors Corporation to assist the Navy Department in problems of distribution of combat equipment, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the steel company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Hoboken, N.J.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 26, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Can't something be done about these super-emotional last good-bys to service men at the station? If some fond mothers only knew what these "scenes" take out of us who leave for the front I'm sure they would try harder to deny themselves this last teary indulgence.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Congress should amend the Price Control Act to make it "quite clear" that the function of the Office of Price Administration is to control prices, not profits, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York declared today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 1 -- Harry Leyser, Cherry Valley, and Jack Mallon, pro of the home club. combined to score 33, 35 -- 68, and win the opening one-day amateurpro tourney of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Garden City Coun- try Club today.

The nation-wide history survey conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES among 7,000 college freshmen in thirty-six colleges and universities revealed a striking ignorance of even the most elementary aspects of United States history.

A sentence of three months in the workhouse and $1,700 in fines, or an additional 170 days in jail if the fines are not paid, were imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on Harry Craig Cooper on the first conviction under the new city law against the black market in railroad passenger reservations.

Two riders just about monopolized matters at the Jamaica racetrack yesterday. The veteran Johnny Longden and the apprentice Bobby Permane virtually cornered the winner's market, each coming home ahead of the pack three times on the seven-race card.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Government's mass trial of thirty men and women on charges of seditious conspiracy was thrown back two weeks today when the judge called a hearing for tomorrow on a contempt of court proceeding against one of about twenty defense attorneys in the case and levied a $20 contempt fine against another.

A preview of Oct. 1, New York's traditional moving day, was flashed along city streets yesterday as householders and business concerns with leases expiring April 30 bustled to get their belongings transported to new quarters. Every kind of vehicle from pushcart to taxicab was called to the assistance of the moving van, short these days of both manpower and gasoline.

"Sholom Aleichem," by Maurice Samuel, has received the Anisfield Prize as the best book on racial relations of 1943. Mr. Samuel's new book, "Harvest in the Desert," concerning the national awakening of the Jews in Palestine, will be published by Knopf late in the fall.

NAPLES, Italy, May 1 -- Col. Stephen Galatti, haed of the American Field Service, who on the invitation of the British War Office, is touring the theatres where his men are operating, said today that units of 260 ambulances in Italy alone had covered distances amounting to 1,000,000 miles and had transported many thousands of casualties.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world, offers a partial list of free amusements available today. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue for tickets.

On a reformed and chastened first of May the Morningside jury has brought in its verdict. The public can dissent or assent on individual judgments, as it pleases. One of the benefits of these awards, in our opinion, is the stimulus which they give to criticism. Martin Flavin's "Journey in the Dark" is the prize novel.

KANSAS CITY, May 1 (AP) -- It has taken a war to make the nation realize the excellent work that is being done by foreign missionaries, Ralph E. Diffendorfer, executive secretary of the Methodist Foreign Missions Board, said today.

LONDON, May 1 -- What is being sought more than anything else in the conference of British Dominion Premiers that began here today is a general agreement among all five on the line of policy to be followed in dealing with other nations in the discussion of world security.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 1 -- A plan for carving Westchester County into six new Assembly Districts, in accordance with the State reapportionment laws, was submitted today to the County Board of Supervisors by a special reapportionment committee headed by Supervisor E. Percy Barrett of Bedford.
Keith W. Shearman is with J.R. Williston Co. in their research department.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 1 (U.P.) -- Bishops, educators and leading layment of the Methodist Church joined tonight in tribute to Bishop Francis J. McConnell, Episcopal head of the New York area since 1928, who retired at the June jurisdictional conference.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 2 -- Heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force again paced the giant Anglo-American invasion offensive yesterday. Flying Fortresses and Liberators made two heavy assaults during the day, hammering the Germans' defenses in Pas-de-Calais in the morning and six railway yards in France and Belgium in the afternoon.

Albert Margolies, returned yesterday from Hollywood, revealed that he had closed his deal with Whitfield Cook for the latter's dramatization of his "Violet" stories which have appeared in Redbook Magazine. Mr. Cook, currently working for Metro, is expected to have a finished script for rehearsals, which are slated to start the second week in August. Patricia Hitchcock, signed for the lead, will arrive here a week earlier.
LONDON, May 1 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Selecting "Journey in the Dark" by Martin Flavin as the most distinguished American novel of 1943, the trustees of Columbia University announced yesterday the winners of nine Pulitzer prizes in journalism, five in letters, and one in music.

The Dooley-Stapleton Corporation of Brooklyn sold the two six-room houses at 47-35 and 47-37 198th Street, in Flushing, L.I., through the Halleran Agency, which also sold for John Reilly to F.E. Jockers a seven-room house on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 206-12 Thirty-fourth Avenue, in Bayside.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 1 (AP) -- Premier Per Albin Hansson, in a May Day speech delivered in an atmosphere of alertness, said today Sweden had "continuously and rapidly" strengthened her military forces as a bulwark to neutrality and the time had not yet arrived when she could neglect preparedness.

The Tuesday issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES carries a story, with a Naples dateline, to the effect that the members of the new Italian Cabinet have been sworn in and have dutifully kissed the hand of the King, according to the prevailing Italian tradition.

The editorial "Technicians Under 26," appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 25, along with other articles on drafting technically trained men under 26 reveals an apparent misunderstanding of War Department policy which, because of the importance of the subject, should be cleared up.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- An attempt by proponents of Marshal Tito's Committee of National Liberation in Yugoslavia to prevent the seating of delegates named by King Peter's government to represent that nation at the International Labor Conference failed today.
LONDON, May 1 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The New York City Department of Health, in cooperation with other interested agencies, sponsored Child Health Day celebrated yesterday in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx. A series of similar events for the next two weeks has been planned at centers in all the boroughs, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Commissioner of Health, reported.

The Department of Justice moved in Federal court yesterday to obtain an injunction against what it described as a forty-three-year-old world-wide cartel in the match industry. The anti-trust division of the department filed a civil complaint under the anti-trust laws, naming as defendants the Diamond Match Company and seven other American concerns, the Swedish Match Company (Svenska Tandsticks Aktiebolaget), two English concerns, a Canadian organization, and six individuals.

LONDON, May 1 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisan forces have struck ten miles inside the pre-war southwestern Austrian frontier toward the key railroad junction of Villach, but are waging a desperate battle in western Bosnia, where Nazi armored columns have smashed to within three miles of Jajce, headquarters of Marshal Tito, it was announced today.

A.L.M. Wiggins, president of the American Bankers Association, gave here yesterday further details on the association's plan to establish a "network of credit pools" by banks throughout the country to take care of post-war needs of industry.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- With the Senate Judiciary Committee scheduled to start closed hearings Wednesday in its investigation of the Montgomery Ward seizure, legislative proposals for inquiries made little advance today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a rise of 17 per cent during the week ended April 29, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank reported a decline of 3 per cent.
Mrs. Virginia Romano knew her husband, Frank, knew that triplets were expected along about now in the Romano household at 136 Boerum Street, Brooklyn.

Scores of additional cocktail lounges, cafes and night clubs closed down last night following a month's trial of the 30 per cent cabaret tax, Matt Shelvey, national administrative director of the American Guild of Variety Artists, announced.

California's 1943 harvest of 40,000,000 pounds of avocados makes it the largest commercial producer of this fruit in the world. Though the season there is year-'round, from 60 to 70 per cent of the total output is marketed between mid-November and mid-May.
D-day, the day of invasion of western Europe, the day that will settle the course and duration of the war, is approaching.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- An annual reduction of about 72,000,000 tons in the production of aluminum was ordered by the War Production Board today in an action described by the agency's authorized spokesman as "another step to bring aluminum-metal production more closely in line with consumption."

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor issued today "an invasion eve" pronouncement to all AFL affiliates, calling upon them to strive for new production records and emphasizing that "above all, this is no time to strike."

New York City food retailers reported yesterday that the temporary elimination of ration points on eight additional canned vegetables and the reduction of ration points on butter had failed to start any buying rush.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 1 -- In the interest of re-employment and a sound post-war economy, lend-lease should be abandoned as soon as possible after the war is won, according to Alexander N. Gentes, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, New York, who spoke on "Financial Aspects of Future World Trade" at the Midwestern controllers' conference of the Controllers Institute of America, now being held here at the Hotel Jefferson.

NEWARK, N.J., May 1 -- Three of nine war plants operated in this area by Breeze Corporations, Inc., closed down today when hundreds of members of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, refused to work because, according to a union spokesman, the company had made "a last-minute appeal" of a wage award handed down by the Regional War Labor Board in New York.

Mayor La Guardia advocated yesterday as a post-war program for the nation an expanded Social Security plan, including a uniform unemployment insurance law for all States and a national system of health insurance; a "rounded program" of public works, stabilization of employment, a shorter work week and an annual wage.

Disturbed over comments on the War Department's new policy for pricing in textile contracts and their exemption from renegotiation, Maj. Gen. C.L. Corbin, Army Service Forces, declared in a letter made public yesterday that various contracts already had been exempted and that "with the cooperation of contractors" the program would continue.

Clovers, butterflies, bees and roses enliven a series of fashions developed by Pauline Granichstadten and sold in New York by Lord Taylor. Mrs. Granichstadten and twelve young artists whom she employs work in a large rambling house in Weston, Mass., and paint the motifs on fabrics that are used in stockings, sweaters, girdles, beach coats and tablecloths.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 -- Humphrey Bogart has been named by Warner Brothers for the lead in "God Is My Co-Pilot," the screen version of Col. Robert Lee Scott's story of his adventures with Maj. Gen. Chennault's China Air Force. The picture will be directed by Robert Florey and produced by Robert Buckner.

After four hours of listless trading, the stock market suddenly sprang to life in the final period yesterday and, in a sudden wave of buying which consumed no more than thirty minutes, prices were bid up from fractions to more than a point.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- The old-line isolationists who used to rule the roost out this way and who still have undoubted influence in the councils of local Republicanism are beginning to feel themselves nevertheless isolated in their own ranks after the speech of Governor Dewey in New York last week and the disavowal of Gen. Douglas MacArthur of any Presidential aspirations.

Probably the most disturbing aspect of the President's seizure of Montgomery Ward Co. has been the arguments of Attorney General Biddle to justify it. In his original opinion Mr. Biddle went to great lengths to try to prove that Montgomery Ward was a war industry in the sense contemplated by the War Labor Disputes Act.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- In the presence of admirals and blue-jackets, statesmen and citizens, Col. William Franklin Knox, Secretary of the Navy, was buried this afternoon in Arlington National Cemetery with the full military honors he had earned through a long career of service and devotion to his country.

AFTER reading hundreds of books over the years on both a professional and amateur basis, it is a strange thing to look back and see what sticks in your mind. Of Garet Garrett's "The Driver," which I read more than fifteen years ago, no critic would argue that it is even a good second-rate novel. Its characterization is sketchy, its psychology is one-sided.

Disguised as subway track walkers, two Brooklyn detectives pursued and captured a purse snatcher yesterday morning after a dangerous chase through the dimly lighted tubes of the Independent Eighth Avenue-Fulton Street line near the Nostrand Avenue Station.

The City Center Opera Company opened its spring season at the City Center last night with a performance of Bizet's "Carmen" which featured Dusolina Giannini singing the title role for the first time in this city. A capacity audience was on hand to welcome the company back.

If the nation's business and industry is to convert from a war status to a peacetime basis with a minimum of dislocation and delay, the tax structure must be revised to remove impediments to the free flow of short-term credit and long-term capital, "the life blood of progress in this country," according to Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., May 1 -- Governor Dewey's administration of the State Government was contrasted tonight with the methods followed by President Roosevelt in a speech that Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of New York State and New York County Republican chairman, delivered before the Valley Stream Republican Club.

Possible return of football to the sports calendar of New York University was seen yesterday in the call for candidates issued by Al Nixon, graduate manager of athletics, with the full blessing of the university board of athletic control, The Associated Press reveals.

NAPLES, May 1 (U.P.) -- Huge squadrons of the Royal Air Force's night attackers bombed four Italian harbors before dawn today, extending into three days a day-and-night obliteration bombardment of Mediteranean targets.

Your story in THE TIMES, April 14 that there is a contemplated program to give youths 17 years old military training before going into the Army proper. I wish to bring to you attention that this is not a new scheme. The State Guards have been doing just that for the past three years and have been doing a grand job of it.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York issued yesterday its retail credit survey covering 1943, on the basis of nearly 300 leading retail merchants canvassed, representing various lines of merchandising in the Second Federal Reserve District.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1 -- The newspaper Prensa reappeared today at the expiration of the five-day suspension imposed on it by a Presidential decree last week. It complies with the Government demand and prints on its editorial page without comment a long reply of the public health authorities to statements that it made last Tuesday, statements that officially motivated the paper's suspension.

RYE, N.Y., May 1 -- This country is on the edge of the greatest marketing era in its history, and "with advertising the most important tool in the creation of markets it must become a vital factor in top management," Clarence Francis, chairman of the board of the General Foods Corporation, said at the opening today of the spring meeting of the Association of National Advertisers at the Westchester Country Club here.

The question of how to use the scrap metal, wood and paper that countless campaigns have taught householders should be doing something better than lying around in attics and yards was solved in 250 ways by the 250 youngsters who took part yesterday in the "Something for Nothing" contest that was the main feature of the opening session of the four-day convention of the Boys Clubs of America.
Sales of commercial and residential properties contributed to the activity of the New Jersey realty market yesterday.

BOSTON, May 1 (AP) -- Second Baseman George Myatt's perfect day -- six hits in as many trips to the plate -- spearheaded a twenty-wallop attack by the Senators today as they overwhelmed the Red Sox, 11 to 4, before a slim crowd at Fenway Park.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, May 2 (U.P.) -- American infantrymen have counted a total of 677 Japanese dead in the Hollandia, Netherland New Guinea, sector in eight days since the first landings, and are pushing into the hills north of Lake Sentani to reduce isolated enemy positions, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (U.P.) -- Charging that "only Hitler and Mussolini" could match the attitude of Rexford Guy Tugwell, the Governor of Puerto Rico, Bolivar Pagan, Resident Commissioner, asserted late today that the island's people would have revolted long ago if they had not been under the American flag.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP) -- United Gas Improvement Company's stockholders approved today at the annual meeting a plan to reclassify the company's capital stock by reducing the number of authorized shares from 35,000,000 with no par value to 3,500,000 with a $13.50 par value.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 1 -- A May Day crowd estimated at more than 50,000 in the industrial center of Sao Paulo heard President Getulio Vargas pledge that after the war a bright future awaited Brazilian labor. In his international labor day address, Senhor Vargas said that greater equality would be obtained by labor with respect to the position held by capital.

NEWARK, N.J., May 1 (AP) -- Making good use of sixteen bases on balls and ten hits off two Newark pitchers, the Rochester Red Wings registered an 11-to-4 victory over the Newark Bears today to square the current series at two games apiece.

LONDON, May 1 (U.P.) -- British submarines prowling in the Mediterranean and Aegean Seas have sunk twenty-two enemy merchant ships, including two medium-sized supply vessels, and damaged seven others in recent patrols, the Admiralty announced tonight.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Defending President Roosevelt's war-time powers in the seizure last week of the Chicago facilities of Montgomery Ward Co., Attorney General Francis Biddle asserted in Federal Court today that "no business or property is immune to a Presidential order."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The War Labor Board, denying union contentions that a musicians' strike against a radio station had no effect upon the war program, today ordered locals of the American Federation of Musicians to end work stoppages immediately at WJJD, Chicago, and KSTP, Minneapolis-St. Paul.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, Ceylon, May 1 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's invasion army, reinforced by a crack formation of American-operated medium tanks, is smashing the Japanese steadily back in northern Burma and may capture the enemy railroad city of Mogaung before the monsoon rains pour down about May 15.

Another two weeks should determine the fate of the faltering Japanese invasion of India. Some time this month the monsoon is due. It will flood the fighting terrain. If the invaders are able to secure a base of operations they can probably maintain themselves in hostile territory through the rainy season.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 1 -- A May Day crowd estimated at more than 50,000 in the industrial center of Sao Paulo heard President Getulio Vargas pledge that after the war a bright future awaited Brazilian labor. In his international labor day address, Senhor Vargas said that greater equality would be obtained by labor with respect to the position held by capital.

NEWARK, N.J., May 1 (AP) -- Making good use of sixteen bases on balls and ten hits off two Newark pitchers, the Rochester Red Wings registered an 11-to-4 victory over the Newark Bears today to square the current series at two games apiece.

LONDON, May 1 (U.P.) -- British submarines prowling in the Mediterranean and Aegean Seas have sunk twenty-two enemy merchant ships, including two medium-sized supply vessels, and damaged seven others in recent patrols, the Admiralty announced tonight.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Defending President Roosevelt's war-time powers in the seizure last week of the Chicago facilities of Montgomery Ward Co., Attorney General Francis Biddle asserted in Federal Court today that "no business or property is immune to a Presidential order."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The War Labor Board, denying union contentions that a musicians' strike against a radio station had no effect upon the war program, today ordered locals of the American Federation of Musicians to end work stoppages immediately at WJJD, Chicago, and KSTP, Minneapolis-St. Paul.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 1 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Gordon Bennett retired from the Australian Army today and promptly handed newspaper men a signed statement asserting he had been forced out and attacking Gen. Sir Thomas A. Blamey, Commander in Chief.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 1 -- Berlin observed a colorless May Day, dispensing with the customary rhetorical pronouncements and proclamations. Only plants engaged in war production remained in operation.

Six mulberry trees, a backyard, and 150 silkworm eggs might in two months' time add up to one pair of pure silk stockings, according to sericulture experts now presiding at a display on American silk production in the Sky Greenhouse at Bloomingdale's.
BALTIMORE, May 1 -- United States Senator Millard E. Tydings and five of the State's six Representatives apparently won renomination in today's Maryland primaries.

Severing its sixteen-year affiliation with Columbia University, Bard College at Annandale-on-Hudson will become an independent, coeducational institution, it was announced yesterday by Ward Melville, chairman of the college's board of trustees, after Columbia trustees had approved the move.

Reuben Fine of Washington, D.C., American international ace and acknowledged speed champion of the country, made the most of his opportunity in the thirteenth round of the tournament for the United States chess championship at the Hotel Park Central last night, by adding a point to his total, thereby reaching 11 1/2.

Those who have a nostalgic fondness for done-over furniture of the more or less antique variety and are partial to the "amusing" type of decorative conversation piece will find some new twists to this style of decor among the second edition of the "Restoration Drama" groupings that went on display at Macy's corner shop yesterday.

A large audience, including many prominent musicians, which gathered last night in Town Hall to hear Nikolai and Joanna Graudan give a program of duets for 'cello and piano, heard one of the most satisfying concerts of the season. Mr. and Mrs. Graudan are artists of unusual intelligence and skill and their performance was of exceptional interest.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 1 (UP) -- A communique:

With almost every well known variety of narcissus on display, the Horticultural Society of New York yesterday opened its annual Narcissus Show at its headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue. The exhibition, which is free to the public, will continue today, its last day, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- This country will have to work hard and fast to reach a standard as good as Great Britain's on well-baby clinics, Dr. Katherine Bain, director of the Division of Child Development, Children's Bureau, ruefully said today in a "May Day-Child Health Day" report.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Americanism Commission of the American Legion today refused to act on a resolution from Puerto Rican legionnaires opposing independence for the island.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A program designed to provide small business with a way of using its expanded production capacity in the reconversion from war to peacetime enterprise is being studied by the Smaller War Plants Corporation for possible recommendation to Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and to whatever reconversion unit may be set up by the WPB.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, April 30 (Delayed) -- One of the best bomber pilots in the southwest Pacific is Lieut. Col. John P. Henebry, Irish and 26, whose record of 118 combat missions puts him among the most experienced American bomber pilots anywhere.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 1 -- The policy of both Britain and the Soviet Union in eastern European Allied countries is now crystallizing, according to diplomatic observers here.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A program designed to provide small business with a way of using its expanded production capacity in the reconversion from war to peacetime enterprise is being studied by the Smaller War Plants Corporation for possible recommendation to Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and to whatever reconversion unit may be set up by the WPB.

Initial steps were taken here yesterday in what was expected to become a national program to return public housing in the United States exclusively to the low-income families for which the vast Federal low-rent system originally was devised.

Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, which has been in the forefront of the struggle against cancer since 1884, will begin Saturday a month-long observance of its sixtieth anniversary, Isaac F. Marcosson, chairman of the anniversary committee of the hospital's board of managers, announced yesterday.

Senator Lister Hill won renomination in Alabama and a major victory for the Administration, and Senator Claude Pepper was safely leading in Florida on the basis of returns early today from Democratic primaries in the two States.

AN EIGHTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER BASE, in England, May 2 (AP) -- A Mustang group commanded by Col. Don Blakeslee of Fairport Harbor, Ohio, which has become the first in the European theatre to top 500 kills, was congratulated today by Maj. Gen. William E. Kepner, commander of the Eighth Air Force Fighter Command, for setting a record "in the history of aerial warfare."

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- Reverberations from the recent debate in the House of Commons on equal pay for British women school teachers were heard today at the International Labor Office Conference in discussion of social policies in dependent territories.

LONDON, May 2 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisan "flying columns," in their deepest penetration of the war inside Italy, are attacking German communications near Trieste, with some units operating inside the Adriatic port city, a communique from Marshal Tito's headquarters announced today.

Frederick Heizer Wright, 40year-old newspaper copy editor, was placed on trial yesterday in Federal court for serving as an unregistered propaganda agent of the Japanese prior to Pearl Harbor, and for conspiracy to violate the 1917 law that requires registration of such agents.

PEARL HARBOR, May 2 -- Powerful naval task forces comparable to those that assaulted Palau a month ago have laid waste the enemy's big Truk base in the heaviest attack we have yet staged in that area.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 2 --- At Montpellier last night, according to news received here, all cinemas were raided by the police and all young men were arrested. Anxious parents were notified today by posters that information could be obtained at the local offices of the German labor service.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 3 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill, welcoming Empire Premiers to 10 Downing Street, told them they were here "in the most deadly climax in the conflict of the nations, at a time when, although we need no longer fear defeat, we are making the most intense efforts to compel an early victory."

BUENOS AIRES, May 2 -- Two of the vacancies in the Argentine Cabinet were filled tonight. Gen. Orlando Peluffo was appointed Foreign Minister, replacing Gen. Diego I. Mason, who since Feb. 17 had been acting Foreign Minister though still retaining his post as Minister of Agriculture.

The board of directors of Schenley Distillers Corporation voted yesterday to split up the common stock on the basis of three shares for two and to institute a stock purchase plan "for employes who have shown outstanding ability and who have made significant contributions to the business."

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Japan, who has been performing various duties as a special assistant to Secretary Hull, has been appointed director of the Office of Far Eastern Affairs in the State Department.
GOSHEN, N.Y., May 2 -- Representative Hamilton Fish unanimously was endorsed for renomination tonight at a meeting of the Orange County Republican Committee.

Leonard Ginsberg, president of Hearn Department Stores, Inc., will serve as chairman of the department stores division in the current campaign of the Greater New York Fund, John S. Burke, head of B. Altman Co., and Jack I. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., who are co-chairmen of the merchandising and apparel trades section of the drive, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- A portrait of the late Dr. George Washington Carver, noted Negro scientist, was given to the Smithsonian Institution today. Vice President Wallace made the presentation.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, May 2 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today pinned the Distinguished Service Medal on the shirt of Major Gen. William H. Rupertus, commander of the First Marine Division, which captured Cape Gloucester and then drove the Japanese out of three-quarters of New Britain.
Since Hildegarde is acknowledged as a potent fashion influence, the gowns she wore at her opening last night in the Persian Room tat the Plaza evoked almost as much comment as her singing.
Mervyn B. Stitzer is with Shields Co. in their institutional bond department

A fighting ship lost in combat usually goes under with guns blazing and sailors at their battle stations. But the soldiers who go down with a troopship are men denied by fate their right to fight. It is their tragic lot to strike no last blow at the enemy. That is the risk which every army in transport on the sea most dreads.

Formation of a Council for a Democratic Germany, including leaders among German refugees representing the important German political groups from the former Catholic Center party to the far left, was announced yesterday by Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr in behalf of a group of Americans sponsoring the new German organization.

Major Rowan T. Thomas, who has described his globe-girdling adventures in an American bomber in "Born in Battle," which will be published shortly by Winston, has been made director of flying training at Peterson Field, Colorado. There he is responsible for the training of 2,000 Army fliers.

For the first time since the establishment of the Pulitzer traveling scholarships at Columbia Graduate School of Journalism in 1917, two of the three awards have been won by women, Dean Carl W. Ackerman announced yesterday. The awards, amounting to $1,500 each, have been awarded for 1944 by the trustees of Columbia University to Robert Weil of Los Angeles, Lena Louise Dickinson of Columbia, Mo., and K. Jane Bedell of Manhasset, L.I.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, May 2 (AP) -- Gen. Sir Thomas Blarney, Australian Commander in Chief, commenting today upon a statement by Lieut. Gen. Gordon Bennett that General Blamey had forced him out the Australian Army, said General Bennett was placed on the reserve officers' list at his own request.

Differences between months in cotton futures narrowed in yesterday's local market, where, although steady early, prices moved slightly higher on new crops, and slightly lower on old crops, and closed barely steady 3 points lower to 8 points higher.

ON THE KOHIMA FRONT, April 30 (Delayed) -- Developments of the last week on this front indicate the process of clearing the Japanese from Manipur in India will be a long, costly and arduous task. It is not likely that the job will be completed before the monsoon begins.

A wintry chill came to Brooklyn, "No-Hit" Jim Tobin and the Braves at the same time yesterday. Tobin's highly publicized bid to emulate Johnny Vander Meer's two consecutive no-hitters of 1938 ended on Jim's second pitch of the game when Frenchy Bordagaray singled cleanly to left, and the Dodgers went on to win the game, 7 -- 6.

With 3,000 persons watching, the Knickerbocker Greys held their annual spring review and reception in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon. One hundred and forty cadets, averaging 10 years of age, went through intricate drill formations on the armory floor and received medals and promotions for their work in the last year.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The late Secretary of the Navy, Frank Knox, may attain his highest, historical rating for an original proposal whereby to maintain world peace in the period between the end of hostilities and the establishment of a durable international structure.

JERUSALEM, May 2 -- British communications and Anglo-American oil are expected by impartial observers here to determine Palestine's fate at the peace conference. They point out that the major issue no longer is the rivalry of the Jewish and Arab peoples.

Congressional authorization of permanent Fair Employment Practices Committee was advocated last night by Senator Robert F. Wagner during ceremonies at Carnegie Hall honoring A. Philip Randolph, Negro union leader.

EDDIE ARCARO heads for the Kentucky Derby today and for what he hopes is a date with destiny. Little Eddie is riding highly favored Stir Up in the Run for the Roses and victory for him would bring him even with Earle Sande and Isaac Murphy as the only jockeys to pilot three winners in the classic. Everyone knows, of course, that Arcaro missed the boat in 1942.

NEWARK, N.J., May 2 -- More than half of the 2,700 employes of the Breeze Corporations, Inc., makers of aerial armor plate and other vital war materials, meeting in an emergency session tonight at the Labor Lyceum here, voted unanimously to return to work.

Murder of the most delightful variety, the kind manufactured by detective story writers, stalked through The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, for several hours last night to the evident enjoyment of 300 not-at-all bloodthirsty persons.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The trial of the twenty-eight men and two women whom the United States links in a seditious conspiracy to corrupt the armed forces will not be resumed until after the United States District Court here has finished its contempt trial of James J. Laughlin, one of the twenty-sixth defense attorneys.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 2 -- A pocket edition of the Miami School for Aviation Mechanics was inaugurated by President Getulio Vargas today at Sao Paulo. Temporarily the school will operate in the old Immigration Building in Sao Paulo city, but work already has commenced at Cumbica, Sao Paulo, for a modern school to house 2,000 students.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 2 (AP) -- Methodists argued hotly today over whether the church should change its position of 1940, when it voted that it would "not officially endorse, support or participate in war."
LONDON, May 2 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

LANSING, Mich., May 2 (AP) -- A grand jury investigating charges of graft in Michigan's Legislature today accused fourteen persons of conspiracy to corrupt the 1939 session. A similar indictment, of twenty-six individuals was handed up last Jan. 22.
Perhaps he wanted to "dig up some Japs" again or it might have been just plain wanderlust, but 3-year-old Roger La Garde disappeared yesterday for the third time in four months.

The Office of Price Administration's power to enforce "suspension orders" cutting off a dealer's right to receive rationed commodities was upheld by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here yesterday in a decision by Judges Harrie B. Chase, Charles E. Clark and Jerome N. Frank.

Today is the Polish Fourth of July. That is, it is the anniversary of the Constitution of 1791, long celebrated as Poland's national holiday. Until the country is permanently free the day will have a bitter meaning for the Poles, as well as a proud one. Old Poland was partitioned for the second time two years after the Constitution was adopted, and partitioned out of existence two years after that.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 2 -- The drastic censorship now being applied to discussion of Greek affairs and of the recent armed mutiny by Greek forces in the Middle East was protested in a memorandum submitted today by the Allied war correspondents to the British and American military commanders and Ministers here.

NAPLES, May 2 (U.P.) -- German troops have launched a sudden attack against the British left flank of the Anzio beachhead and made a slight advance, it was disclosed today as Royal Air Force pre-dawn bombers opened the fourth consecutive day of heavy assaults on German communications in Italy.

NAPLES, April 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- Almost alone, Pfc. William J. Johnston had smashed a German attack, then, single-handed, had covered one withdrawal of his platoon. But the Germans were coming in again and the doctor said that he was dying, so he had to be left behind.

LONDON, May 2 -- For the past two days the discussions at meetings of the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers have been almost entirely concerned with the conduct of the war in the east as well as in the west.

Judge Charles Alvin Jones of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals has upheld the right of employers to express their personal views to employes on labor unions, provided such expression of opinion does not involve threats or the use of intimidation.

Consolidated net income of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., for 1943 was $7,484,214 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, compared with a net of $6,834,364 in 1942, Curtis E. Calder, the president, reported yesterday. Gross operating revenues increased to $72,414,900 from $64,384,946, a gain of 12.5 per cent.

A reply to readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES who urged three significant modifications in the rationing system, as reported in this column on April 20, has been received from Walter F. Straub, director of the Office of Price Administration's food rationing division.

ALGIERS, May 2 -- If the Americans should meddle in French administrative affairs there would be "grave disorders," in the opinion of Edmond-Jean Louveau, who left France last month. He spoke to French and Allied correspondents today under the auspices of the Commissioner for Information.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- "Prospects are that conditions in the post-war period will favor the continuance of low long-term interest rates," the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System states in its annual report, made public today.

Outlining broad achievements in the communications field, particularly in the application of electronics to the war effort, Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, informed stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting that RCA now is manufacturing 150 new electron tubes and some 300 types of apparatus not manufactured by anyone before the war.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 3 (U.P.) -- Soviet bombers, in their fifth major air attack in as many nights, left thirty fires raging among German troop and supply trains Monday night after an attack on the Polish rail junction of Lwow, while seventy miles to the southeast, in the Stanislav area, units of the First Ukrainian Front Army yesterday killed about 2,000 Germans trying to find weak spots in the Russian lines, Moscow announced early today.

Young Eric Guerin, who's been so successful helping players win the daily double by booting home a winner in either the first or second races during the Jamaica meeting, made things easier for them yesterday when he got both his daily double mounts, Free Double and King Dorsett, under the wire in front.

Those attending last night's preview of the "Jardin d'Et" at the headquarters of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, Inc., 457 Madison Avenue, entered rooms filled with a profusion of fruits and vegetables "in paint and porcelain."
A communique as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commision:

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- James P. McGranery and Maynard Smith, for the Department of Justice, reported to the Senate Committee on Campaign Practices in a closed session today that the National Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organization had done nothing, so far, which violated the Hatch "clean politics" act or the Smith-Connally amendments to the Corrupt Practices Act.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- The Yankees introduced a bit of larceny with some fancy 5-hit flipping by Bill Zuber to make a rousing success of their first visit to Shibe Park today. Before 6,228 fans, the champions downed the Athletics, 4 to 1, in Zuber's first pitching effort of the campaign, even though Willie was not there at the finish.

The effect of emotional problems on the health of children as discussed yesterday by Dr. Flanders Dunbar at a lecture sponsored by the Child Study Association of America, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street. Dr. Dunbar is a member of the Department of Medicine and Psychiatry at Columbia University Medical School.

Encouraged by the unexpectedly large attendance and the enthusiasm of the visitors, the New York Horticultural Society closed its annual two-day narcissus show yesterday with the announcement that it would hold a special one-day show on May 17 devoted to flower arrangements, with competitive displays and featuring any varieties of spring flowers that suggest a popular poem.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- In an effort to distribute the supply of rayon yarns more equitably among hosiery manufacturers, the War Production Board today permitted the manufacture of full-fashioned and seamless hosiery of 100 and finer denier rayon yarns on machines of coarser gauges.

NEWARK, N.J., May 2 (AP)--Although outhit, Rochester hung up a 7-to-3 victory over Newark today to take the rubber match of a five-game series. The winners collected eight safeties to Newark's 12. A two-run homer by Jack Sturdy in the fifth was the victors' heaviest blow.

What the American people think of the Red Cross is shown in the reports on the recent campaign. The national organization asked for $200,000,000, and National Campaign Chairman Leon Fraser has announced a total, so far, of $211,000,000 received. In this city $21,200,000 has been contributed this year, or nearly $7,000,000 above last year's total.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The text of the State Department's announcement of the agreement with Spain:

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Speed and more speed must dominate the dissolution of war contracts and reconversion of industries to civilian production as peace arrives or disaster will result, Eric A. Johnston told the House Committee on Post-War Economic Policy today.

WITH STILWELL FORCES, in the Mogaung Valley, May 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph Stilwell's forces in northern Burma have not reached the top of the league, "but we're getting there," he said today, two years after he admitted to "'one hell of a beating" in the Burma retreat.

Robert H. Patchin criticizes as a misleading generalization my statement that Cordell Hull's trade-agreement program was unsuited to post-war needs because it "committed nobody to anything," and he points to thirty-one agreements signed under the program committing twenty-seven nations to numerous tariff reductions.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- The American Federation of Labor's executive council criticized the military authorities today for their "apparently haphazard and contradictory policies" on inductions and proposed a four-point program for most effective use of the nation's manpower.
LONDON, May 2 -- Business in today's stock markets was on a smaller scale, but recent advances were well held.

Shortage of newsprint and an early Easter forced a loss in April advertising linage in New York daily newspapers, the first in three months, according to figures compiled from Media Records. Total advertising was 8,464,427 agate lines as against 9,536,881 for the corresponding month last year, a decrease of 11.25 per cent.
LONDON, May 2 -- The arrival of a military mission from the Partisan headquarters of Marshal Tito was regarded today as presaging plans for intensified guerrilla activities in Yugoslavia.

With the announcement yesterday by the nation's railroads that they would consent to the suspension for another six months of the increase in freight rates granted in 1942, it now appears probable that the Interstate Commerce Commission will order an extension in the suspension to Jan. 1, 1945.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- An important source of supply of the strategic mineral wolfram, used in hardening steel, has been substantially denied to the German war machine through an agreement with Spain, announced simultaneously today here and in London.
PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP) -- The Pirates wrecked a beautifully pitched game by Al Jurisich with a five-hit, three-run barrage in the eighth and defeated the Cardinals, 3 to 1 today.

The Branscombe Choral, Gena Branscombe conductor, gave its tenth annual spring concert last night in Town Hall before an audience that filled the house. Walter Olltzkt, Metropolitan Opera baritone, was the assisting artist

DEDHAM, Mass., May 2 (AP) -Bobby Dickey, 5, was just another little boy when his mother Mrs. Everett Dickey went out to do some shopping this morning, but by the time she got back he was just as much a hero as any grown man.

It's a bit early to predict that fishing for fun is in for a wartime boom, but the season now fully launched is going to be a big one. The deduction is made from the hordes that turned out over the week-end, the first that offered really fine weather.

ANZIO BEACHHEAD, May 2 (AP) -- Daniel de Luce, Associated Press war correspondent, was typing a story today when he was informed that he had won the 1943 Pulitzer Prize for distinguished telegraphic reporting on international affairs.

CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -%Vith the flood of hogs coming Into Midwestern markets, the handling of the over-supply is almost as serious as it was last winter when the marketward movement was at Its peak. Some of the more seriously congested markets have placed embargoes on incoming supplies and Derlnit sYstems are effective at other points.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Charges that President Roosevelt ignored the Bill of Rights and arrogated to himself "despotic powers" and that he relied solely upon the opinion given him by Attorney General Francis Biddle in the seizure last week of Montgomery Ward Co.'s Chicago properties marked the final argument by company counsel today in the Government's injunction suit in Federal Judge William H. Holly's court.

The stock market maintained yesterday the range of Monday but with some difficulty toward the close, when pressure appeared in the rails and liquors. The confident undertone that prevailed in the industrials brought comment from some financial quarters that the market showed less and less apprehension over the coming invasion of the Hitler fortress.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (U.P.) -The War Department disclosed tonight that for the last two years lend-lease planes from the United States have been flown to Russia by Red Army pilots over a northern air route, presumably via Alaska.

The City Council, with many dull meetings behind it, stirred with new life for a short time yesterday when a Democratic member requested that a bill on the soldier vote, sponsored by the two Communist members, be read before being placed on the calendar of the next meeting "lest it contain someCommunist theory we might not want to have anything to do with."

LONDON, May 2 -- All records for aerial bombing were shattered during April when the Royal Air Force Bomber Command and the United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe joined to rain 81,400 tons of bombs on Germany and German-occupied Europe.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,023, compared with 1,270 in the preceding week and 1,428 in the like period of 1943, according to the lists appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP) -- Bill Dietrich pitched five-hit ball for the White Sox today and topped it off by scoring the winning run in the tenth as the Indians lost, 3 to 2.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 (AP) -Broadcloth, bearing the red and white silks of Mrs. George Poulson of Los Angeles, moved up among the leading contenders for the seventieth Kentucky Derby when he made a show of five other eligibles in the Derby Trial Stakes at Churchill Downs today.
Geographical location and terrain are major factors that will influence the coming invasion of western Europe.

A large post-war apartment project was revealed yesterday with the announcement by Robert W. Dowling, as president of the City Investing Company, that his company had acquired the vacant plot with 94 feet frontage on the south side of Eighty-ninth Street adjoining the Fifth Avenue corner site recently acquired by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation for the new Guggenheim Art Museum.

Community service panels on city-wide, borough and neighborhood levels will be set up soon to "convert" every consumer into "an informed and cooperating part of the Office of Price Administration program," Daniel P. Woolley, OPA regional administrator, announced yesterday to representatives of 101 groups invited to a special meeting at the Hotel McAlpin.

LONDON, May 2 -- The prospect of coordinated military action by the Anglo-American invasion forces in the west and the Russian armies in the east is now a major concern of German military writers and spokesmen.

MONTEVIDEO, May 2 -- Leaflets accusing the newspaper Prensa of accepting bribes from United States officials to defend American interests to the detriment of British ones were distributed in Buenos Aires yesterday among persons who gathered to hear the acting War Minister, Col. Juan D. Peron, read a radio address to Argentine workers.

Parke, Davis Co., domestic manufacturers of drugs, including a widely diversified line of chemicals and pharmaceuticals, reported yesterday for the quarter ended on March 31 consolidated net earnings of $1,938,793, after $2,750,000 Federal taxes, equal to 40 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Spokesmen of business, industry, finance, agriculture and transportation in the twenty-one American republics, including Argentina and Bolivia, will meet in New York Tuesday to draw up a program designed to solve economic problems of the hemisphere.

An investing client of Douglas Gibbons Co., brokers, has acquired from the Greenwich Savings Bank the thirteen-story and penthouse apartment buildings at 990 Fifth Avenue, corner of Eightieth Street. The building, which occupies the land where the Frank W. Woolworth mansion formerly stood, consists entirely of large duplex apartments. In the same block are the residences of several well-known New Yorkers.

The New York City Department of Health has traced seventy-four cases of food poisoning in one charitable institution to evaporated milk released to hospitals, schools and other institutions by the Federal Government from its 45,000,000-pound oversupply.

Gert Hans von Gontard, active figure in cafe society and heir to a large part of the Busch brewery fortune, is confronted with charges of having conspired to evade the draft, not because he made such an attempt, but because of his former secretary's "vindictiveness and viciousness," defense counsel contended as the trial of the 37year-old German-born baron opened yesterday before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert.
West Side properties came in for a major share of attention in the realty transactions reported yesterday, giving further evidence of the upturn in the market in Manhattan.

James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, announced yesterday his opposition to any move to freeze television standards at their present level and excoriated manufacturers of sets for hoping "to sell a lot of stuff" that would not give the best possible service.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 3 -- The Allies' tactical air offensive against railroads that would support the German Army in operations in western Europe continued with no fewer than fourteen separate assaults against junctions, freight yards and bridges in France and Belgium in the twenty-four hours up to last evening.

LOS ANGELES, May 2 (AP) -L solemn legal language, Superior Judge Henry 1. Willis undertook today to explain what makes a jitterbug that way as he awarded $8,170 damages to Florida Edwards, radio actress, for injuries received when she was sent into a spin by a "jive-maddened marine.''
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, May 3 -- communique:

TRENTON, May 2 -- New Jersey's draft boards, heretofore engaged solely in sending men off to war, were asked today by Lieut. Col. Edgar N. Bloomer, State Selective Service director, to assist in recruiting members for the Women's Army Corps by furnishing names of prospective Wacs to recruiting authorities.

"The Adventures of Mark Twain," Warner Brothers' screen biography of the American humorist, will have its premiere today at the Hollywood Theatre. Fredric March is starred in the title role, with Alexis Smith, who plays the author's wife, Donald Crisp, Alan Hale, C. Aubrey Smith, John Carradine, Walter Hampden, Robert Barrat, Joyce Reynolds and Bill Henry among the featured players.
Preoccupied as we are with fighting the war, we still have time to think about the future, and, since we spend much of our lives indoors, housing is often in our minds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will star Dorothy McGuire in "White Collar Girl," a story by Anita Loos about a young married woman who takes over her-husband's business when he goes to war. The picture will be produced by William Perlberg and may precede the proposed "Claudia and David" on the actress's schedule.

Andrew Asaro, 32-year-old Brooklyn fireman, was identified yesterday as the mysterious "assistant to the stork" who drove Mrs. Frank Romano to Swedish Hospital while she gave birth to two of three babies in his car.

LONDON, May 2 -- Spain has agreed to put her promised neutrality into practice. Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden informed the House of Commons today that the Anglo-American negotiations with the Franco government had at last borne fruit.

A well-proportioned young right-hander, Charley Schanz, may develop into the chief nemesis of the Giants. If that is his ambition, it must be said that the bespectacled hurler is off to a nice start, because yesterday at the Polo Grounds Schanz made it two straight over the Giants, this time augmenting his one-hit mound work with a game-winning triple in the four-run ninth as the Phillies triumphed, 5-2.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of free amusements available today. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue for tickets.

Only in a few places was the first of May remembered on the old-time scale as a day of demonstration or of celebration by workers. For a long time on the Continent it was awaited with a certain amount of anxiety by Governments and was pretty sure to bring clashes between the police and the marchers.

Net income of the Kennecott Copper Corporation in the first quarter of this year was equivalent to $1.02 a capital share on the basis of present 95 per cent excess profits taxes and 40 per cent normal income tax rate and after a contingency reserve of $1,000,000, E.T. Stannard, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.
ATLANTA, May 2 (AP) -- Negroes voted, unchallenged, at several polls in Democratic primary elections in Alabama and Florida today, but ballots were refused to them in at least two cities.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 -- During a discussion of the post-war problems of the furniture industry Charles Shaughnessy of R.H. Macy Co., New York, told the War Problems Conference of the National Retail Furniture Association here today that manufacturers and dealers alike were too complacent about the decline in the quality of the products turned out under wartime restrictions.

A vacant plot of 32,500 square feet on the East River Drive at Forty-sixth Street, east of the Grand Central zone, has just been sold by the Robert W. Goelet Estate, which had held it for forty-six years.

A new issue of $1,440,000 of various purpose bonds, dated May 1, 1944, and due serially from May 1, 1945 to 1974, was awarded yesterday by Alleghany County, Pa., to a syndicate comprising Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.; the Peoples-Pittsburgh Trust Company; Graham, Parsons Co.; W.H. Newbold's Sons Co., and Singer, Deane Scribner.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- In a number of revisions to the regulation establishing ceiling prices for distilled spirits and wines, the Office of Price Administration tightened today its controls over sales of packaged liquors.

Yielding to both pressure and to conviction regarding the way the war will end, the Spain of Generalissimo Franco, which had already modified its official position from one of "moral belligerency" backed by military action on the Axis side to one of "strict neutrality" toward all sides, has now gone a step further in adjusting itself to the new realities of the war.

BUFFALO, May 2 -- Joseph D. Canty, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, this afternoon told members of the area war manpower committee that some urgent solution must be reached quickly to halt the exodus of women from local war plants.

FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, Italy, April 16 (Delayed) -- British troops have captured another of Adolf Hitler's secret weapons -- a radio-controlled explosives carrier which is more gruesome in name than in action.
ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP) -- In the first defeat for a St. Louis team at home this season, the Browns lost to the Tigers today, 4 to 3, but remained at the top of the American League.

CHUNKING, China, May 2 (U.P.) -- Striking at Japanese armies on both sides of the Peiping-Hankow railway, the Chinese have killed or wounded more than 800 in the Mihsien sector and have retaken Yushih, a Chinese communique reported tonight.
Sports leaders, writers and broadcasters were enlisted yesterday by the War Finance Committee of the Treasury Department to help in the Fifth War Loan Drive next month.

The city of Edmonton, Alberta, has sold a new issue of $9,150,000 of debentures due from May 15, 1948, to 1964, to a banking group headed by the First Boston Corporation and the Dominion Securities Corporation, according to a statement issued yesterday on behalf of the bankers.

Although David Feinberg, 54 years old, a former druggist, was released last September from Sing Sing, after serving seven years on a General Sessions sentence in 1936 as a criminal receiver in a burglary, Judge Jonah J. Goldstein, who imposed the sentence, yesterday dismissed the indictment and vacated the conviction.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Nineteen manufacturers and converters of asbestos insulating materials were ordered by the Federal Trade Commission today to dissolve a price-fixing conspiracy in which the commission said they were engaged under supervision of Donald Tulloch Jr., Philadelphia promoter of a patent licensing system and merchandising plan.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Association of American Railroads consented today to a six-month extension of the lower freight rates that have prevailed since the Interstate Commerce Commission suspended, as of April 6, 1943, the higher rates formerly in effect.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission instituted today proceedings to integrate the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and its forty-two subsidiaries and to simplify the system's corporate structure in compliance with the Holding Company Act.

ALBANY, May 2 (AP) -- Governor Dewey's legal department began court action today to oust Albany's Water Commissioner, Frank J. Cassidy, on the ground that he had refused to waive immunity when called before the grand jury which is investigating crime in Albany County.
LISBON, Portugal, May 2 (AP) -- Nazi authorities have launched a fear campaign throughout Europe in an effort to keep civilians from reading propaganda leaflets dropped by Allied raiders.

If Gen. Giulio Douhet were alive you would doubtless permit him to comment in your columns on your reference to him in the editorial "Five Years of Air Power." In it you state that the theory advanced by General Douhet in 1921 that air supremacy alone could win a war has not been sustained.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- The time for talking about post-war planning is past, and the moment has come for action to make sure that public works are ready to fill the employment gap in the period of industrial reconversion from war to peace with real jobs, not leaf-raking, and with community projects of lasting value.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The "Sample Fair" which opens on June 10 at Barcelona -- a sort of abbreviated world's fair conducted by the Spanish Government -- will afford the United States an excellent opportunity to present the American way of life to the Spanish people, Harold Ballou, chief of the Iberian Section of the Overseas Branch of the Office of War Information, said today.
LONDON, May 8 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, May 1 (Delayed) -- On this sector of the Garigliano River front, only one road was open today, running across a smoke-covered bridge that the Germans kept trying to knock out. But it led right to Pvt. Lucien Thibodeau, who, at every command post from here to the sea, was the man of the hour.

Despite all the efforts of professional social workers the problem of halting the warttime spread of juvenile delinquency will never "receive more than a scratch upon its surface" unless residents of troubled neighborhoods are aroused to decisive action, Edgar W. Baird Jr., treasurer of Philadelphia and vice chairman of the Crime Prevention Association, declared yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, May 3 (AP) -- Allied planes and PT boats have smashed twenty supply barges fleeing the isolated Japanese base of Wewak and other marooned enemy points near Aitape, headquarters announced today.

LONDON, May 2 -- The sinking of one Japanese destroyer and four cargo vessels and the damaging of two other supply ships by three British submarines operating in Far Eastern waters were announced by the Admiralty today.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Failure of the Government to provide for prompt and final settlement of war contracts once cut-backs and cancellations of such agreements begin to become a factor in the economy could well breed a period of confusion and chaos, Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today.
May we point out that your editorial on "Television" in today's issue misrepresents the CBS position and the policy we advocate in more than one important and controlling point.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- United States submarines operating against the Japanese Navy and merchant shipping in the Pacific and Far East have added three warships, a naval auxiliary and eight supply vessels to their toll of ships sunk, bringing to 695 the total number of Japanese vessels sunk or damaged by American submarines, the Navy Department announced today.

The State Department is at pains to announce that in working out the arrangement just concluded with Spain the American Government accepted a compromise at the "urgent request" of the British. Evidently Washington held out for a flat embargo on the delivery of wolfram to Germany and London was ready to allow a token shipment in return for other substantial concessions to Allied demands to which Madrid has agreed.

JAMES RONALD is a Scotsman and a natural and effective story teller. In "The Night Is Ending"* he has spun a long yarn and a continuously entertaining one. It is a novel that without making any pretensions to being art or literature packs a dramatic wallop. If it is a galloping plot crackling with action, suspense, surprise and sentiment you want, look no further.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 2 -Adolph Hitler's special anti-Maquis detachments from Savoy have been fought to a standstill near Verona in northern Italy, according to a special communique tonight from the headquarters of the Italian resistance movement.

NEWARK, N.J., May 2 -- Four indictments returned in Federal court here today against three corporations, including the Schenley Distillers Corporation of New York, and seventeen individuals charge conspiracy to deal in black market operations in liquor and to sell above Office of Price Administration ceiling prices.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The executive committee of the American Legion adopted without dissent today a report by a special subcommittee clearing Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., New York Republican, of charges that he misused the franking privilege to disseminate anti-American propaganda, as was charged in a resolution by the national convention of the Legion last year.

RYE, N.Y., May 2 -- Warning that the advertising executives' responsibility will be at peak when the war ends, while available creative personnel will be at a new low, Cameron Hawley, director of advertising and promotion of the Armstrong Cork Company, urged yesterday that advertising prepare itself for the "tornado" of activity that will hit it when V Day comes.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 2 -- War contractors will be subject to even greater scrutiny by renegotiation boards than prevailed during the past year, according to Comdr. E.H. Wagner Jr., member of the Navy Price Adjustment Board and assistant to the chairman of the New York division.

PEARL HARBOR, May 2 (AP) -- The attack on Truk was the second of the war by United States carrier forces. In the first, last Feb. 16-17, twenty-three Japanese ships were sunk and probably six more, and 201 enemy aircraft destroyed.

Mrs. Charles S. Freeman, Manhattan salvage chairman of the American Women's Voluntary Services, with the cooperation of the Fourth Avenue Booksellers Association, is collecting unsalable volumes to swell the harvest of the waste-paper drive this week.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- The United States Government submitted to the international labor conference today a plan of action for putting into effect the social objectives of the Atlantic Charter through measures designed to win for all improved labor standards, economic development and social security.

Resuming play with forces in a position the nature of which presaged a draw, Arnold S. Denker, Manhattan Chess Club champion, nevertheless succeeded last night in winning his adjourned game with Albert S. Pinkus of Brooklyn at the Manhattan Club.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 2 -- Allied glider-borne Chindits have smashed a fourth desperate Japanese attempt to break their grip on the north Burma railroad, dealing out ten casualties for each of their own, and have seized new positions on that enemy lifeline on a twenty-five-mile front, dispatches revealed tonight.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- While no "wild upsurge" in prices is expected after the war, a general consumer price level one-third to one-half above that of 1940 is to be expected, according to Frank D. Newbury, in an address before the ninth annual Westinghouse machine tool electrification forum at the Hotel William Penn.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- Navy communique 518:...

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The National Labor Relations Board, acting far ahead of its expected schedule, ordered today that an election be held within seven days to permit employes of the Chicago facilities of Montgomery Ward Co., now under Government operation, to determine whether they want to be represented in collective bargaining with the management by the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes Union, CIO.

LONDON, May 2 -- At a meeting tomorrow that promises to be a stormy one, the Administrative Committee of the Parliamentary Labor party will make its first move to throw Aneurin Bevan out of the party for inspiring a rebellion in the House of Commons last week over the Government edict laying down severe penalties for strike agitators.

Business men of Manhattan are ready to join in the program of post-war re-employment for service men and war workers sponsored by the Committee for Economic Development, former Gov. Alfred E. Smith, the city chairman, announced yesterday.

With a gesture of renunciation, the King and Queen gave up their crowns and scepters yesterday to the war. Bound by court custom to follow the royal example, the Duke and Duchess and the Prince and Princess unhappily tossed their coronets upon the scrap heap.

Failure of the President's War Relief Control Board to authorize a campaign by the American Committee for Italian Democracy for voluntary contributions to relieve distress in the liberated parts of Italy is denounced in an editorial in today's issue of the Progreso Italo-Americano, an Italian-language daily of which Generoso Pope is publisher.

Net sales of Standard Brands, Inc., were $55,800,000 in the first quarter of 1944, a third more than the $41,800,000 reported for the same period in 1943, James S. Adams, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Reflecting a reduction in military requirements for all combat aircraft needed to support the invasion of Europe and "strike the enemy," plane production during April took a drop to 8,343 craft of all types, Charles E. Wilson, chairman of the Aircraft Production Board, reported today.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Selling of July wheat attributed to professional traders gave the market for that grain on the Board of Trade an easy undertone today, but with May wanted at ceiling prices, there was comparatively little pressure and buying of July and September by brokers who frequently act for cash interests held prices within relatively narrow limits.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Tentative agreements between American and British experts on a set of principles to govern the development and distribution of the world's oil resources were reported today at the conclusion of exploratory talks started April 18.

ON THE KOHIMA FRONT IN INDIA, April 29 (Delayed) -- In spite of the constant possibility of enemy attack, American Army operators during recent months have kept trains moving in record numbers along the section of the Bengal-Assam railway threatened by the Japanese invasion of north Manipur.

Supreme Court Justice Isidore Wasservogel granted yesterday the petition of the seventeen justices of the Supreme Court in the First and Second Departments for the restoration of $2,500 a year ordered cut from their pay by the Board of Estimate on Nov. 2, 1939.

ALBANY, May 3 -- Paul C. Lockwood, secretary to Governor Dewey, put the responsibility for delay in calling special elections to fill Congressional vacancies in the Fourth and Eleventh Districts, New York City, upon the County Clerk of Richmond County.

Paulette Goddard, screen actress just returned from an eleven-week tour of front lines in India, Burma and China, reported in an interview yesterday that the privations of her trip had resulted in increasing her weight by eight pounds.

CHUNGKING, China, May 3 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have launched a new drive northward from Sinyang in southern Honan Province, apparently aimed at a junction with other enemy forces pushing down the Chinese-held midsection of the Peiping-Hankow railway, it was disclosed today.
