WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A "task committee," comprising representatives of three Government agencies concerned with the production of cotton textiles has recommended that the Office of Price Administration adjust price ceilings when it appears necessary to get an increase in certain critically short items, it was learned today.

LONDON, May 3 (U.P.) -- Germany has been forced to resort to salvaging parts from destroyed American and British aircraft in a desperate effort to compensate for her shattered industrial production capacity, information reaching here revealed tonight.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 3 (U.P.) -- British armored columns, attacking in four directions, have captured a number of Japanese strong points around Kohima and other Imperial units are smashing north from Imphal in a drive to link the two bases and deal a knockout blow to the invasion of eastern India, dispatches said tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 3 -- Invoking accusations of "leaders of the black market," "disseminators of defeatist propaganda" and "traitors who are on the point of selling the country's possibilities of resistance against the Bolshevist menace to the Anglo-Saxon powers," the Hungarian Government, assisted by the Gestapo, has virtually liquidated the affairs of more than 160,000 Jewish families since the German occupation, according to information received from Budapest tonight.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- There was no pressure today on the wheat market on the Board of Trade and a little buying attributed to commercial interests and shorts, combined with strength in rye, was sufficient to cause a moderate upturn. Closing trades were at gains of 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 3 -- Within the past month 909 Jewish refugees arrived here by sea from Rumania en route to Palestine. The number includes passengers on the last two ships, which arrived this week, the forty-one-ton Belasitsa, carrying 152, and the eighty-ton Milka with 272 aboard.

TRENTON, N.J., May 3 -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper appointed today Miss Grace J. Ford of South Orange as an assistant attorney general at $5,500 a year. She is the first woman to hold that position in New Jersey. Recently Gov. Walter E. Edge named Mrs. Pearl Bridegum of Hainesport as the first woman member of the State Civil Service Commission.
PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- Plans for a world labor conference in London have been abandoned.

BALTIMORE, May 3 (AP) -- The showdown on an attempt to oust the present management of the Certain-teed Products Corporation was deferred today at least twenty-four hours when officials of the company declined to produce their proxies and declared there was no quorum of stockholders for a meeting.

A consecutive triple by Ted Atkinson, a double by Trainer Andy Schuttinger and an impressive triumph by Jeep, Col. C.V. Whitney's promising colt, in the Youthful Stakes were witnessed by the 25,179 persons who paid a visit to the Jamaica track yesterday and sent $2,167,507 jingling through the mutuel windows.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A prediction that Negroes would vote for Franklin D. Roosevelt for President rather than for Thomas E. Dewey, was made today at a press conference by Judge William H. Hastie, chairman of the legal committee of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and Thurgood Marshall, special counsel of the organization.

Counterfeit ration coupons for almost 250,000 pounds of sugar were seized and four men arrested here yesterday in the first instance of the use of spurious sugar stamps to come to light in the New York area, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, announced last night.

The imposing old Union Club building and the adjoining Vanderbilt mansion -- landmarks at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, opposite St. Patrick's Cathedral -- will come down along with the house at 3 East Fifty-first Street to make way for "an imposing edifice" of undisclosed type which is expected to be one of the major post-war projects of private enterprise in that district.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers won, yesterday, the award of various blocks of bonds of Providence, R.I., aggregating $2,000,000. The securities had been held in the city's sinking fund and the transaction did not represent new financing.

Walter J. Dockerill, regional representative of the Solid Fuels Administration for War, informed Dr. William A. Holla, Westchester County Health Commissioner in a better made public yesterday that there was no truth to reports that the SFAW had deferred the organization of advisory committees to expedite the filling of fuel orders.
NAPLES, May 3 (UP) -- Apparently as a defensive measure, the Germans have flooded large sections of the Pontine Marshes between the Anzio and Cassino fronts, it was disclosed today.

Once again the New York Curb Exchange is looking for a paid president. Fred C. Morfatt, acting president, has indicated that he would not continue beyond the end of his present term -- March 1, 1945 -- and that he would be glad to quit at any earlier date.

"Pick-Up Girl," which opened last evening at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, is another of those plays in which the practice falls considerably short of the intention. On the face of it, Elsa Shelley's drama should be an important addition to the serious side of the waning season, for it deals with a current problem, juvenile delinquency.

Stressing the indispensability of President Roosevelt as the nation's leader in the war and in the task of making a just and enduring peace, the convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, adopted a resolution at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday urging the President's re-election for a fourth term.

A collection of letters from enlisted men and non-commissioned officers entitled "Going Home" is announced for June 8 by Little, Brown. The book is edited by Mina Curtiss, former associate professor of English at Smith College, who has recently been working on overseas radio scripts for the Office of War Information.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Spokesmen for the packing industry cheered the elimination of ration points on pork, lamb, veal, and some of the cheaper grades of beef, but said they could not estimate the increase in meats moved into consumer channels until the new setup had been tested in practice.

Speaking for the Army Service Forces, which he commands, Lieutenant General Somervell tells the American Legion that the Army's greatest demand on the country's manpower is still to come. There will be a "terrific" problem, he believes, when we try to take 1,400,000 more men from the factories and farms and still try to maintain production at a high enough level to beat Germany and Japan.

AFTER Munich Georges Bernanos, a French Catholic writer who is deeply imbued with the Christian humanism of Jacques Maritain, quit Europe in sorrow and disgust. Settling down in Brazil, on the edge of one of the last remaining wilderness frontiers, he let his mind play over the tragedy of his country and his continent.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 3 -- Ethiopia's long dormant natural resources, virtually untapped under Italian rule and unscratched since the country was restored to its people, will become the subject of an exhaustive preliminary study by an American technical mission that has just arrived at Addis Ababa at the invitation of the Ethiopian Government.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, May 4 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today that bombers and fighters have heavily raked the Rabaul, New Britain, area, at a cost of two planes.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3 -- The total synthesis of quinine for the first time, culminating the efforts of nearly 100 years to produce this most desirable anti-malaria chemical by artificial means, has at last been achieved, it was announced here today by the Polaroid Corporation.

Paving the way for peacetime plans and development, formation on the Norden Laboratories Corporation with headquarters in this city was announced yesterday, with Carl L. Norden, inventor of the precision bombsight and the automatic pilot, as president.

Despite the marked betterment of the financial outlook of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad the management believes a further contraction of debt should be made before dividends are resumed. This view was expressed in a statement in behalf of the management read yesterday by W.H. Wenneman, assistant to the president, at the annual stockholders' meeting in Cleveland.

A special prayer suggested to be offered in the churches on "Invasion Day" was issued yesterday by the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church and president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.
LONDON, May 3 -- The stock markets were again in a cheerful mood today and a fair amount of business was reported, chiefly consisting of fresh investment support for industrials.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Capitol the attraction will be "Gaslight," a Metro screen version of the English play by Patrick Hamilton starring Ingrid Bergman and Charles Boyer. Directed by George Cukor, the melodrama's featured cast includes Joseph Cotten, Dame May Whitty, Angela Lansbury and Barbara Everest.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 3 (UP) -- A communique:

Doing without a maid has been the inspiration for many new trends in serving and table settings. Round dining tables, for instance, after being shunned as dowdy for so many years, have returned to favor because they make it so much easier to pass the butter.

The natural difficulties of landing from the sea on an open coast -- difficulties of wind, weather and hydrographic formation -- are enhanced, in western Europe, by formidable defenses that the Germans have erected along large sections of the shoreline.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 3 -- In the substantial diplomatic victory of the United Nations over Germany diplomatic circles here measure the series of advantages that Spain has conceded, including the reduction of wolfram shipments but specially in expelling Axis agents from Tangier and from the Spanish mainland.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 3 (AP) -- Gov. Rexford Guy Tugwell today characterized charges of dictatorship made against his administration Monday by Bolivar Pagan, Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico in Washington, as "irresponsible talk" whose "extravagance indicated well enough its lack of truth."

LONDON, May 3 -- Across western France and the Low Countries to Germany in a coastal zone roughly 100 miles wide from the shores of the Bay of Biscay to Cologne, Allied air attacks have blasted every railroad yard worthy of the name, an expert on European communications for the British Ministry of Economic Warfare said today.

Stocks of major oil products in the United States declined last week, with the greatest drop in heavy fuel oil supplies, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period, gasoline stocks amounted to 88,462,000 barrels, a decline of 267,000 from the 88,729,000 a week earlier.

"What is our production?" THE TIMES asks in an editorial on April 17 referring specifically to production in industry -- at factories and mines. The answer suggested, on the basis of Geoffrey Moore's recent study for the National Bureau of Economic Research, is that the level of industrial production may be something quite different as compared with the pre-war period from what the Federal Reserve index shows.

Extensive expansion of Canadian business during the war period will be dwarfed by even greater progress in the post-war era, with capital from this country expected to play an important part, Gladstone Murray declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York.

Pvt. Raoul N. Maradini, 37 years old, was committed to the Tombs in default of $50,000 bail after a hearing in Felony Court yesterday, charged with having been one of the three gunmen who robbed the Latin Quarter, a Broadway night club, a year ago and escaped with $5,900.

In the light of protests against the establishment of the New York Relocation Hostel, readers of THE TIMES should be informed of the following facts. I speak out of very close connection with the Relocation Hostel in Chicago, with which I was associated last year. It is this same hostel which is moving to 168 Clinton Street, Brooklyn 2, New York.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The Texas New Orleans Railroad Company, a subsidiary of the Southern Pacific Railway system, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue $16,178,000 in 4 1/2 per cent first and refunding bonds to be exchanged at par for a similar amount of its bonds now held by the Southern Pacific.

LONDON, May 3 -- Lord Vansittart declared in the House of Lords today that Sweden's behavior in this war had not conformed to any known standard of neutrality and charged that Portugal's persistence in supplying half of the wolfram needed for Germany's war industry had reduced an "alliance of centuries to a farce," and not a very pleasant one at that.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- Oscar Heiremans Brockmann, Chilean employers' delegate to the International Labor Conference, and Dr. Abdelmeguid Ramzi, Egyptian Government delegate, died of heart attacks within a few hours of one another today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Spirited exchanges between committee members and organized labor representatives over the Government's seizure of the Montgomery Ward Company last week, marked today's hearing by the House Banking and Currency Committee on legislation to extend the price control and wage stabilization acts beyond June 30.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 3 (U.P.) -- Francis M. Forde, Army Minister and Acting Prime Minister, announced today that there would be no more releases of men from the armed services for essential industry beyond the 20,000 previously agreed upon, although there was a demand for 40,000 persons for industry.

LONDON, Thursday, May 4 -- Relatively small forces of American Liberator "heavies" and Thunderbolt fighter-bombers and British Mitchell and Mosquito bombers maintained the tactical offensive over northern France yesterday. No allied plane was lost. Deterioration of the weather over northwestern Europe curbed the Allied air assault for the first time in two weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A broadening of the Senate Judiciary Committee's pending investigation into Government seizure of the Chicago facilities of Montgomery Ward Co. to include an inquiry into the use of troops in taking over the plant and forcibly evicting Sewell L. Avery, board chairman, was approved without opposition by the Senate late today.

Alfred Bloomingdale has decided to terminate the brief career of his musical comedy production, "Allah Be Praised!" after Saturday night's performance, it was announced yesterday. The show, repsenting an initial investment of more than $100,000, opened at the Adelphi Theatre on April 20 and will have been seen for only twenty performances.

NEWARK, N.J., May 3 -- The United States lost the peace after the first World War because President Wilson was old and ill, former Representative Bruce Barton declared here today and contended that a Republican victory at the election in November would give the country a President and Vice President who would be "young and strong and clear-headed and untired.

Part one of the James McHenry papers was sold at auction yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for $18,980. James McHenry was aide de camp and private secretary to George Washington, aide de camp to the Marquis de Lafayette, Secretary of War under Washington, 1796-97, and under John Adams, 1797-1800. His papers were sold by order of the heirs.

New skyscrapers are to join Rockefeller Center's towering spires of steel and stone after the war. The vast midtown commercial and amusement project, occupying most of the three blocks from Forty-eighth to Fifty-first Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, probably will spread out when peace comes to take in several strategic corners and big sites in the adjoining blocks, it became known yesterday.
Felix N. Williams, production manager of the phosphate division of Monsanto Chemical Company, has been named general manager of the company's plastics division at Springfield, Mass.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Senate approved the Byrd resolution broadening a Judiciary Committee investigation of the Montgomery Ward seizure to include use of troops and also the company's labor relations. Senator Vandenberg urged immediate consideration of the Murray-George war contract termination bill, with Senator Kilgore withdrawing his efforts to delay it until next week.

Seemingly still dreaming of their day of grandeur when they exploded 26 runs in one contest, the Giants continued to perform at the Polo Grounds yesterday like men who couldn't be bothered with inconsequential matters of the present.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Congressional investigation of the sedition trial would trespass on the constitutional powers of the American courts, Senator Pat McCarran, chairman of the Committee on the Judiciary, told the Senate today as he predicted his committee would accept the recommendation of three of its members to deny the petition of defense counsel, Albert W. Dilling.

Last year Congress passed a bill to buy the birthplace of George Washington Carver, near Diamond Grove, Mo., and make it a national monument. Through the good offices of persons engaged in that project a portrait of Dr. Carver was presented Tuesday to the Smithsonian Institution.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, May 2 (Delayed) -- The Garigliano River front was "quiet" again today. No ground was gained or lost. Yet, possibly because of this very lull, this deceptive peace-within-war, the contrasts between the spring weather and the war's destruction were all the more melancholy.

Still pursued by Reuben Fine, Arnold S. Denker maintained his victorious course through the fourteenth round of the United States chess championship at the Hotel Park Central last night by defeating Louis Persinger. Denker continued in first place with a score of 13 1/2 -- 1/2, with Fine still second at 12 1/2 -- 1 1/2.

A syndicate of builders has purchased for investment the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 969 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Seventy-eighth Street, from the Seamen's Bank for Savings and will alter it into smaller suites when the materials are available.

William H. Winters of Port Henry is the new district game protector for the New York City area and is established in the Conservation Department's offices in Center Street. He replaces the late William G. Jacquemin.

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- The Cubs, opening a twenty-game home stand under Acting Manager Roy Johnson, didn't have the pitching to stop a seventeen-hit Cincinnati assault today, and the Reds pounded three hurlers, including the veteran Claude Passeau, making his first appearance in a relief role, for a 10-to-4 victory.

LONDON, May 3 -- The meeting of British dominion Prime Ministers at what Prime Minister Churchill described on Monday as "the most deadly climax of the conflict" has already reached the point of intimate collaboration of a team working together with a single aim.

Two Army trucks, one loaded with three military prisoners and the other with 367 sacks of parcels and papers for delivery overseas, collided at 7:30 A.M. yesterday at Lexington Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. Seven persons were injured, one seriously.

The Barricini chain of candy stores will occupy a large store mezzanine in the Union Carbide Building at Forty-second Street and Madison Avenue as the result of a lease just closed through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., and Cushman Wakefield.

An article critical of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, written by Walter Lucas, a Britisher, accredited war correspondent in Australia of The Daily Express of London for eighteen months, was barred from publication in Harper's Magazine by the War Department "on the grounds of security," it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, May 3 -- A meeting of 3,000 persons to celebrate the Polish national holiday commemorating the adoption of the Constitution of 1791 provided the setting this afternoon for two rather remarkable addresses. The speakers were Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk and Ernest Bevin, British Minister of Labor.

The good news that all meat except beef steaks and beef roasts is now ration-free prompted us to thumb through our file of NEW YORK TIMES-tested recipes for formulas that would take advantage of the Office of Price Administration order.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- Embargoes on Incoming shipments of hogs at several Mid,Vestern markets caused receipts at the twelve major terminals tO drop today 45.000 head belOW those o! a week ago. Total arrivals this week were 1.l.700 head more than in the first three days o! last week.

On the theory that steel will have an important place in pre-fabricated housing wherever it meets the requirements of design, utility and cost, the United States Steel Corporation has arranged to purchase a substantial interest in the Gunnison Housing Corporation of New Albany, Ind., it was announced yesterday by Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the former.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- Acting on direct request of the White House, the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor today adopted a vigorous statement supporting the Roosevelt Administration in its action on the Montgomery Ward case.

BOSTON, May 3 (AP) -- Revamping his line-up, Manager Joe Cronin put himself at first base today and played a major role as the Red Sox snapped a three-game losing streak by defeating the Senators, 11 to 10.

The proposal of the Columbia Broadcasting System to clamp down in effect on the production of television sets after the war until the higher-frequency channels are explored, and means for making the most of them have been invented, has stirred up a controversy that ought to be settled now because of the economic and technical issues raised.

The stock market braced itself yesterday for further recovery. Demand enlarged on a fairly broad scale and gains of a point or more were scattered generously through the list, although the average addition remained fractional. There appeared to be a reluctance in brokerage circles to talk-up too bullish a market for fear that a return to the peaks of March before the Allied invasion of Hitler's Europe would bring out profit-taking.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that the State Department has no position with regard to the visit of the Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski of Springfield, Mass., and Professor Oscar Lange of Chicago University to Moscow except that they went there as private citizens and were not in any way whatever representing this Government.

Camp and city recreational facilities for underprivileged children will be at least as extensive this Summer as in previous years, it was agreed yesterday by speakers at a meeting of the committee on information services of the Welfare Council of New York City.

As a result of the disclosure that seventy-four cases of food poisoning in a private charitable institution had been due to evaporated milk from the War Food Administration's surplus, Westchester County health officials placed an embargo yesterday on all the remaining milk of a 1,500-case shipment distributed last month among twenty institutions in that county.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The New Deal legal theory of Presidential powers has expanded steadily as more and more "emergencies" were proclaimed and with the advent of war. As recently developed by the Attorney General in the Montgomery Ward case, however, it has attained record-breaking breadth and depth.

Charles Walzer, operator, has bought the two six-story apartment houses at 1730 and 1750 Montgomery Avenue, in the Bronx, for cash above a first mortgage of $428,000. Each building occupies a plot 150 by 100 feet, and the aggregate annual rental is reported to be about $68,000.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Apartment buildings and converted houses figured in many of the deals reported yesterday on the west side of Manhattan. Several of the new owners expect to improve their buildings after the war.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A plea that small business be allowed now, through grants of materials, financial aid and priorities, be allowed to resume or increase the production of from 600 to 700 smaller items of civilian supply was made today by Maury Maverick at his first press conference as chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation.

Patriotic and religious services marked Poland Day throughout New York yesterday as the city's Polish community, which numbers some 500,000 persons, celebrated the 153d anniversary of the signing of the Polish Constitution. The day was dedicated to the martyred and persecuted millions of Poland.

CLEVELAND, May 3 (AP) -- Melm Harder recorded his 199th major league victory today as the Indians walloped the White Sex, 9 to 4. Harder, who will be 35 next October, allowed seven hits. This is his seventeenth year with the Tribe,

Phyllis Mencher, 13 years old, of 25 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, thanked Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, in the Empire State Building, yesterday, for saving her and her classmates 25 cents apiece on their class photographs and for giving them the opportunity to "see price control in action."

Until the invasion of Europe is launched and appraisal of its prospects become possible, major policy decisions by business concerns in the United States for the most part will have to be deferred, according to the National City Bank in its monthly bank letter released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (U.P.) -- Biting denunciation of the Soviet Union for its adamant stand in the Polish-Russian boundary dispute was voiced by opponents of the Administration's foreign policy today as Congress observed the 153d anniversary of Poland's Constitution.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Senate gave tentative approval today to the long-awaited war contract termination bill which has been harmonized with the recommendations of Bernard M. Baruch, but withheld final action until tomorrow because of efforts, backed by organized labor groups, to expand the measure into a complete post-war reconversion program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3 -- Joan Leslie will replace Ann Sheridan in "Hollywood Canteen" when production of the picture is renewed at Warners about June 1. The dispute between the studio and the Actors Guild over player salaries in the film was settled recently.

TRENTON, May 3 -- A fire that already had swept through 4,000 acres of pine, spruce and cedar forest and fields was still unchecked tonight six miles north of Hammonton, in Atlantic County, but more than 400 fire fighters were on the job, including 100 sailors from the Navy air field at Pomona and forty members of the motorized cavalry unit from Port Republic, near Atlantic City.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- In sharp contrast to the early days of the New Deal, when Federal officials were often criticized for infringing upon local autonomy with grandoise and radical schemes for rebuilding America, John B. Blandford Jr., administrator of the National Housing Agency, declared today that Washington intended to exercise restraint, caution and sober appreciation of existing values in its approach to the problems of planning for post-war community housing.

A continuing decline in the quantity of waste paper picked up in the regular Wednesday collections by Department of Sanitation trucks was offset again yesterday, Deputy Commissioner William J. Powell said, by continued improvement in the quality of the total tonnage salvaged.
PEARL HARBOR, May 3 -- We are listening to the overture of a dramatic period in the Pacific war in which new and spectacular blows against the enemy will fall heavier and nearer the heart of Japan.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., May 3 (AP) -- Mass inter-faith conferences here and at Camp Wood in near-by Eatontown were attended by 6,000 soldiers today.

IT is a mighty lucky thing for the Amateur Athletic Union that its destinies are guided by one with the personal charm of the highly esteemed Dan Ferris. The so-called "brass hats" of the A.A.U. are regularly flailed by press-box tenants at the drop of a hat. As a matter of fact some of them don't even wait for the hat to drop.
PITTSBURGH, May 3 (AP) -- Two home runs by George (Whitey) Kurowski, third baseman, paced the Cardinals to a 5-1 triumph over the Pirates in the second game of their series today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The individual income tax simplification bill reached the floor of the House today, and two days of debate was opened with indications that the measure would be adopted by an overwhelming vote despite objections to its treatment of deductions for religious and charitable contributions.

RYE, N.Y., May 3 -- The tide of public opinion is now running with industry instead of against it, with business stronger in the public's estimation than is generally recognized, according to the "pilot survey" just completed for the Association of National Advertisers and disclosed today at the conclusion of its spring meeting at the Westchester Country Club.

Ceiling prices on meats, cheese and butter will be strictly enforced in the face of any run on those products that may result from the removal of ration points from all meats except beefsteaks and beef roasts, Mayor La Guardia and Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, May 3 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today proclaimed D-day, the day Europe is invaded, as one of prayer "to Almighty God for the success of our armed forces and the safety of our valiant fighting men."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 (AP) -- Stall walking started in earnest at Churchill Downs today as time grew short for the eighteen 3-year-olds expected to match strides in the $75,000 added Kentucky Derby on Saturday.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP) -- Pounding out five runs in the fourth inning, the Browns batted their way to a 7-to-4 victory over the Tigers today. Jack Kramer received credit for his fourth consecutive triumph against no defeats, the best record in either league, but the St. Louis ace wasn't around for the finish.
Several investment deals involving loft buildings in Manhattan were announced yesterday.

When the idea of "free ports" in this country for war refugees was brought up in Washington recently there seemed to be two possible objections to it, one good and one bad. The first objection was that it would be inhuman to establish what might be regarded as concentration camps for refugees we were not willing to admit.

Bolder, more resolute and more convincing plans than any yet proposed are needed if a third World War is to be prevented, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, champion of peace for half a century, told the first convention of the Women's Action Committee for Victory and Lasting Peace yesterday.

LONDON, May 3 -- Sixty-nine German divisions -- approximately 760,000 soldiers -- are now arrayed in the coastal defenses of western Europe or concentrated in reserve formations poised for counter-offensives against the Anglo-American invasion forces, according to the most reliable estimate available here.

My attention has been called to the letter of the United Committee of South Slav Americans, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 26. Attacking me personally, the committee, in its letter, questioned my right to tell the American public about what is going on on the battlefields of Yugoslavia.

Navy procurement orders for chambray shirts and denim dungarees during the last half of the year will carry the year's total purchases by that branch of the armed services to well over 100 per cent more than those of 1943, it was learned in the work clothing market yesterday.

A consolidated net income of $7,822,607 was reported yesterday by the Standard Oil Company of California for the first quarter of this year, the largest amount for any similar period since 1937, when about $7,900,000 was earned.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- In the face of a concerted attack by a number of smaller nations against the proposal of the United States to the International Labor Conference for the post-war lifting of standards for world labor, the British Government threw its full support today behind the American plan.

LONDON, May 3 -- In "probably the most brilliant feat of low-level precision bombing of the war," RAF Mosquitos of the Second Tactical Air Force pinpointed a designated house in The Hague, the Netherlands, so accurately that "the bombs went in the front door," and destroyed the house, along with many thousands of documents of paramount importance to German authorities, the British Air Ministry revealed tonight.

WINDSOR, Ont., May 3 (Canadian Press) -- Strong picket lines set up by Local 200 of the United Automobile Workers of America (CIO) were in operation at the Ford Motor Company of Canada today, barring the entrance to all but a few of the 14,000 employes and forcing Wallace R. Campbell, president of the company, and other officials to remain away from their offices.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Here are the foods, together with their point values a pound, which still require red ration points:

RENO, Nev., May 3 (AP) -- Alice Whitehouse Harjes of New York said today that her complaint for divorce from John Frederick Harjes, witness in the Wayne Lonergan murder case, would be filed here tomorrow. She said the complaint would allege extreme cruelty.

The admitted sale of 6,919 cases of oranges at over-ceiling prices last July -- when oranges were being doled out for as much as $1 a dozen -- brought a joint fine of $10,000 yesterday to Peter Martori's Sons, Inc., of 338 Washington Street, and Stephen Martori, its treasurer.

The Down Town Glee Club in its Spring Concert in Carnegie Hall last night under the direction of George Mead gave a program of unusual merit, well chosen and well arranged. Lucius Metz, tenor, was the assisting artist, singing numbers by Handel, Samuel Barber and Michael Head.

DETROIT, May 3 (UP) -- Strikes at seventeen plants with war contracts in the Detroit area took approximately 8,000 workers from their jobs tonight in defiance of orders by the War Labor Board for many of the plants to resume production.

MONTEVIDEO, May 3 -- The new Argentine Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Gen. Orlando L. Peluffo, and of Justice and Public Instruction, Dr. Alberto Baldrich, took the oath of office this morning and shortly afterward were placed in possession of the ministries entrusted to them.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The celebrated case of 400,000 pairs of $1 and $1.50 shoes for children, which were bought for shipment to liberated regions when consumers would not part with their precious shoe coupons except for $3 or $4 pairs, might be considered typical of purchases of "distressed stocks" hunted down by the Foreign Economic Administration for distribution by the Army during military occupation.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, May 4 -- Two United States planes and two PT-boats were destroyed Saturday in the Southwest Pacific when American forces failed to recognize identification signals and fired on each other, Gen. Douglas MacArthur revealed today.

MADRID, May 3 (AP) -- The Vichy regime has put the finishing touches on its preparations to meet the expected Allied western offensive by telling Frenchmen that they are bound by the armistice with Germany to treat the Allies as invaders.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Senators Burton K. Wheeler, Demcrat, of Montana, and Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, urged in the Senate today that the State Department continue efforts to seek a solution of the difficulties between Russia and Finland so that Finland might get out of the war.
Isidor V. Wolfsohn, "the Wolf" of the Consolidated Edison Company, was caught yesterday after a chase that the police said lasted twenty years.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Angry protests were being voiced today by leaders of the United Mail Order, Warehouse and Retail Employes' Union (CIO) against the setting of Tuesday for the holding of an election to determine a collective, bargaining unit at the Ward establishment here.

NEWARK, N.J., May 3 (AP) -- William Wyer, chief executive officer of the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey, said today he had telegraphed the Association of American Railroads that the line "does not acquiesce" to another six months' suspension of the 1942 freight rate increases.

Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel was elected Grand Master of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York at the 163d annual communication of the lodge held here yesterday in Masonic Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

With the score tied, bases filled and one away in the ninth inning, Lloyd Waner was sent up to pinch-hit for Bill Hart. Red Barrett, successor to Nate Andrews, who had been blasted out by Augie Galan's rousing two-bagger, deadlocking the issue, threw a fast ball and Little Poison swung hard and missed, but that was only a decoy.

LONDON, May 3 -- Negotiations regarding the civil administration of liberated areas of France are proceeding between the Allies' command and Brig. Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig, head of the military mission sent here by the French Committee of National Liberation, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today in the House of Commons.

India has concluded arrangements with Great Britain whereby all dollar exchange acquired by India through exports will be earmarked for future use by that country rather than converted immediately into sterling, it was disclosed yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Cotton futures ruled steady all yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and closed 4 to 9 points higher on the day. They were influenced by continued price-fixing in near-month contracts and scattered outside buying of new-crop months.

Senator Claude Pepper, Administration leader, kept well out in front in late returns last night from Florida's Democratic primary although his margin over the combined opposition of four other candidates slipped as the count neared an end.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Newspaper publishers in this country who have ordered more than 100 tons of the experimental thirty-pound newsprint for May were told today by the War Production Board they would have to reduce their orders from Canadian mills by 10 per cent to balance Canadian production of that type paper in the first month of the sixty-day test period.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Despite statements by Administration leaders that inflation is under control, Government economists are expressing alarm over the striking parallel between the current inflationary trend in farm real estate and that which occurred during the period 1918-20.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 3 -- Tuesday's primary election results in Florida, Alabama and South Dakota came as a distinct stimulant to many Democratic leaders who already had started rationalizing the possibility of losing their national and State tickets in this section of the country next fall.

The Government produced three major witnesses in Federal court yesterday to testify to Frederick Heizer Wright's contacts with Japanese for ten years prior to Pearl Harbor, during which he is accused of having served Japan as an unregistered propagandist.

LONDON, May 3 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden announced in the House of Commons today that the British Government had signed an agreement with the Chinese Government yesterday granting a loan of 50,000,000 "to finance the goods and services required by China in the sterling area for purposes arising out of the war."

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- Luke Hamlin, now of the Athletics, may have been a "hot potato" in his days on the Flatbush frontier, but to all practical purposes he was just another guy named Joe today so far as the Yankees were concerned.

LONDON, Thursday, May 4 (U.P.) -- Berlin claimed last night that the Red Army, breaking a three- week lull on the Rumanian front, had opened an offensive along the middle Siret River, but Moscow's broadcast bulletins, reporting no changes on any fronts, told only of smashing Soviet air attacks during which 114 German planes were destroyed Tuesday and yesterday.
NAPLES, May 3 -- Wellingtons bombed three Italian ports of vital importance to the enemy in supplying the troops on the Italian battlefields -- Genoa, Leghorn and La Spezia -- early today.

The use of 75 denier yarn on 42-gauge hosiery machines will increase the proportion of sheer hose, according to hosiery machinery men yesterday. They predict, however, that the yarn on 300-needle seamless machines will produce hose with a baggier ankle.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- All meat except steaks and roasts of beef was made free of ration points today by the Office of Price Administration in a move to channel to consumers the vast supplies of pork, veal, lamb and mutton piling up in the country's stockyards and slaughterhouses.

A new pancake flour package, backed by a nation-wide sales campaign and increased advertising in newspapers, magazines and on the radio to celebrate Pillsbury's seventy-fifth anniversary, June 1, was described by Alec Parsons, vice president of Pillsbury Flour Mills Company, at a sales meeting at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

Sherman K. Ellis, chairman of the advertising and professional section of the Greater New York Fund campaign, announced yesterday that Larry Bennett, vice president of McCann Erickson, Inc., advertising agency, has accepted the chairmanship of the advertising and publishing group.

The Bank of Savings, a venerable savings institution in this city, has presented a "contender" in the lists for the title of the oldest savings account in this country. The account was started in 1819, the year in which the bank was established, with $10 deposited for John S. Thorne, at his birth.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- After fifteen days of executive sessions, the World War Veterans Committee of the House reported favorably this afternoon on the "G.I. Bill of Rights," although amending it in a number of instances. The major alteration was made on the unemployment compensation feature, which was reduced 50 per cent from the maximum approved by the upper House.

Public hearings looking toward revocation of the so-called "5 per cent spread rule" of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., are demanded in a petition to the Securities and Exchange Commission served yesterday by "the Securities Dealers Committee."

Prime Minister Churchill of the United Kingdom has been conferring with four other Prime Ministers -- Mackenzie King of Canada, Smuts of South Africa, Curtin of Australia and Fraser of New Zealand. In receiving his colleagues Mr. Churchill referred to "the Commonwealth and the Empire," making note of a distinction which is clear in constitutional law but perhaps not as clear in American minds as it ought to be.

Because any economically inferior and unskilled group is a national liability, Negroes should receive training for leadership and accomplishment through better educational opportunity, Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor and national campaign chairman of the United Negro College Fund, declared yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in launching the fund's first annual drive.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (AP) -H.D. Collier, president of the Standard Oil Company of California, told stockholders today at their annual meeting that he hoped the proposed transarabian pipeline would be pushed through to "early completion."

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Elmer J. Garner, 80-year-old defendant in the Government's sedition trial of thirty persons, was found dead in bed this afternoon in his rooming house. O. John Rogge, the Government's prosecutor, said that the death would have "no effect" on the United States' case.

The American housewife, who had taken meat rationing in her shopping stride for more than thirteen months, walked to her neighborhood meat market yesterday -the first day that most meats became ration free -- and bought no more than her usual amount.
CHUNGKING, China, May 4 -- A Chinese Government spokesman at a press conference today announced the long-awaited arrival of the Communist negotiator Lin Chu-an.

Arnold S. Denker retained the lead in the United States chess championship at the Hotel Park Central last night, when he defeated Irving Chernev on the black side of a queen's pawn opening after 38 moves. With two more rounds to go, tomorrow and Sunday, the Manhattan Chess Club titleholder has a clear lead over the field with a score of 14 1/2 -- 1/2.

Harold M. Winters, associated with the Radio Corporation of America since 1926, has been appointed manager of the newly created sales region of the RCA Victor division covering the eastern central States with headquarters in Cleveland.

An increasing trend among a number of Latin-American countries toward nationalistic trade practices emerged yesterday as one of the principal concerns of United States business men as the second plenary session of the Permanent Council of American Associations of Commerce and Production opened at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Average prices for commodities in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent during the last week of April as a result of higher prices for apples, potatoes and meats, and Office of Price Administration action in allowing increases of not more than 20 cents a barrel in prices for cement in the Northeastern area.

LONDON, Friday, May 5 (AP) -A merciless night attack by Russian bombers on the German-Rumanian garrison jammed into surrounded Sevastopol was announced last night in a Soviet communique, which said bombing and strafing had silenced many enemy batteries, started at least ten large fires and caused many explosions.

Hope that the work of the Boys Clubs of America could be extended to cover "another 1,000,000 less-privileged boys" in our cities was expressed last night by Herbert Hoover, who presided at the annual dinner of the Wartime Conference of the Boys Clubs at the Hotel Commodore.

The United States is a country divided against itself because education here has evaded the responsibility of creating citizens who know how to practice the art of living with each other in harmony, Dr. Elias Lieberman, associate superintendent of schools, declared yesterday at Charter Day exercises commemorating the ninety-seventh anniversary of the founding of City College and of the municipal system of higher education.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The War Production Board notified the cotton textile trade today that consideration would be given to applications by plants for priority assistance in obtaining limited quantities of cotton yarn for the manufacture of certain types of cotton tape products during the current quarter.

Jewelry blossoms forth in flower motifs and the mediums that designers are using lend themselves to this expression with charming effect. Although wartime restrictions have curtailed the supply of metals, there is a limited amount available and the remainder of the picture is filled with costume jewelry interpreted in glass and ceramics.

LONDON, May 4 -- Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia laid his argument in favor of closer empire organization before the world press today in a question-and-answer interview. What he was anxious to insure, he said, was that the close cooperation that has been established during war should not be permitted to slip back into the casual relationship of pre-war days.
America's play-for-pay golfers will be in there pitching and putting for more than $200,000 in war bonds this year.

LONDON, Friday, May 5 -- The United States Eighth and Ninth Air Forces and the British Second Tactical Air Force pressed the assault on the Wehrmacht in France and the Low Countries yesterday. About fifty Fortresses led the attack with a smashing blow at a Luftwaffe base in the Netherlands.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -Officials of the two agencies handling the Government's large supply of wool remain unconvinced of the necessity for consolidating the two stockpiles for sale through one channel as proposed by growers, Representative Granger, Democrat, of Utah, Chairman of a House Agriculture subcommittee, said today.
CLEVELAND, May 4 (AP) -- The White Sox won a 2-to-1 decision behind the southpaw pitching of Rookie Eddie Lopat today to tie a series with the Indians at two games apiece.

Mayor La Guardia summoned representatives of the wholesale produce trade to City Hall yesterday and directed them to resume six-day operation of their business at once. They have been operating on a five-day week basis, remaining closed on Saturdays, since Feb. 14.

Frederick Milzoff, seven months old, afflicted with an unusual variety of bronchitis, was still fighting for his life last night. His condition had been helped somewhat by the use of helium obtained after his mother had appealed to the police.

KANDY, Ceylon, May 4 (U.P.) -- British-led Kachin tribesmen have driven within thirty-four miles of Myitkyina, and the Japanese, faced with a major strategic defeat in north Burma, have launched fierce but fruitless counter-attacks against the Kachins and Chinese troops striking for Mogaung to the west, it was disclosed tonight.
North Carolina Democrats endorsed a fourth term for President Roosevelt yesterday and lined up thirty more national convention delegates behind him.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A decentralization of government in the Netherlands West Indies to give more autonomy to each of the six islands that compose them is being discussed by the Curacao Legislative Assembly as one of the first steps toward the transformation of the Netherland Empire into a commonwealth, it was learned here today.

"All relevant theoretical plans and practical attempts at international organization from earliest times to the present" are summarized and outlined in "Searchlight on Peace Plans: Choose Your Road to World Government," edited by Edith Wynner and Georgia Lloyd, which Dutton will publish next Friday.

BERNE, Switzerland, May4 -- Today's communique from the Italian National Committee of Resistance reported without details that "a vast operation undertaken by Fascist guards in the Province of Coni has ended with complete disaster for the Axis."

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The War Department favors continuation of its corps of women fliers and militarization of their organization, known as the Wasp, including regular commision in the Army of the United States, Secretary Stimson said today in response to a question asked at his news conference.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Proposals for allocating a small percentage of the nation's daily alcohol production to beverage purposes are now before War Production Board officials for study, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the war agency, told a Senate committee investigating the liquor industry today.

Frederick Brown announced yesterday his purchase of two apartment properties in the Marble Hill section of Manhattan. He bought the building containing fifty suites and occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet at 15-19 Jacobus Place, corner of Van Corlear Place, and the forty-seven-family house on a plot 85 by 100 feet at 10 Adrian Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Federal Trade Commission today announced "dismissal without prejudice" of a complaint against the Lambert Pharmacal Company of St. Louis, which had been charged by FTC with misleading representations in the sale of its Listerine antiseptic. Such action is rarely taken by the FTC.

The Hotel Association of New York City joined yesterday in the demand for a reduction in the tax on cabarets, charging that the present 30 per cent tax had resulted last month in a business decline in the entertainment rooms of hotels of 40 to 70 per cent under a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The United States and Britain tightened their economic blockade of Germany today with a warning to neutral European businesses not to assist the enemy in its final struggle for existence. The warning was based on a policy statement for 15,000 business concerns and individuals which had been blacklisted because of their cooperation or trade with the Axis.

A small, attractive airline secretary, victim of a "mugging" attack on First Avenue at Forty-ninth Street at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, fought her assailant and chased him two blocks into a tenement house, where he was captured by two policemen.

There is a touch of irony in the news that the Germans in Italy have flooded large sections of the Pontine Marshes. The reclamation of the malarial swamps south of Rome, drained at immense cost and turned into agricultural colonies, was one of the most grandiose accomplishments of the Fascist Era.

NAPLES, May 4 (AP) -- The Allied command said that the Germans made considerable movements both on the Adriatic sector and the Cassino front in Italy yesterday, and a small-scale Nazi attack was driven off by Indian troops of the Eighth Army.

ALBANY, May 4 -- The State Government formally affirmed its support of Office of Price Administration price ceilings today when the War Council, with Governor Dewey presiding, unanimously extended until June 30, 1945, its resolution giving Federal prices, rules and regulations the effect of State law.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Edward Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, returned from his series of conferences in London and North Africa today and immediately reported to Secretary Cordell Hull on his mission.
Life began anew yesterday for old Olympus, who came out of retirement to show his four rivals how they did it in the days of yore.

A few minutes might be usefully employed in looking back through the dictionary of memorable events for the purpose of testing a statement by Senator Robert F. Wagner. He was speaking the other night in Carnegie Hall about how to wage a successful campaign for Negro rights now unjustly withheld.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Strand, the attraction will be "Between Two Worlds," Warner Brothers' remake of the Sutton Vane play "Outward Bound." John Garfield, Paul Henreid, Eleanor Parker, Sydney Greenstreet, Dennis King, George Coulouris, Faye Emerson, Sara Allgood, Isobel Elsom and George Tobias are among the featured players.

Manufacturers of margarine and food dealers paid $12,812,090 in special Federal taxes and license fees last year for the privilege of making and selling the product that medical authorities have endorsed as being as healthful and nutritious as butter, a study of Internal Revenue figures disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- More than 1,000 hospitals in the United States have been selected by the War Production Board to serve as depot hospitals for limited civilian distribution of penicillin. The distribution of the new curative product, which was recently announced could be made available to civilians as well as the armed services, will be handled by a WPB branch in Chicago.
LONDON, May 4 -- Again today there was good support on the stock markets here for all classes of securities. Some profit-taking was seen, but this was well absorbed by new buying.

Samuel Gelland, 49 years old, of 62-59 Ellwell Crescent, Forest Hills, Queens, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Special Sessions to a grand jury "information" alleging he conspired to violate the penal law by obtaining money under false benevolent pretenses in his Overseas Cigarette Service at 226 West Forty-second Street to send cigarettes to persons in the armed services.

LONDON, May 4 -- With one of the most important military operations of the war hanging fire and the course of world history still to be determined, a harried House of Commons took time out today to discuss at length that problem of problems that has beset many householders in time of war as well as peace -- the servant question.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The problems of peacetime readjustment facing the country's war-strained cities are being discussed jointly by officials of the Federal Government and of leading municipalities, the War Production Board disclosed today after an advisory council to its Government Division met and took "initial steps" toward developing a program.

In what industry spokesmen described as a "unique" case, the $100,000,000 asphalt roofing industry is seeking the rescinding of a 10 per cent price roll-back ordered by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply in 1941 and an additional increase sufficient to cover raw material cost rises which occurred after the finished product was placed under price control, it was learned yesterday.

In connection with the criticism in Wednesday's Il Progresso, Italian-language daily, of the failure of the President's War Relief Control Board to authorize the American Committee for Italian Democracy to collect funds for relief in liberated Italy, Luigi Criscuolo, chairman of the Council of Americans of Italian Origin, 50 Broadway, urged yesterday the retirement of Myron C. Taylor as head of the American Relief for Italy Committee.

Following their recent purchase of the apartment building at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street from the Union Dime Savings Bank, A. Ruth Sons, operators and builders, have purchased the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment at 17 East Ninety-sixth Street from the East River Savings Bank.

The dearth of baby nurses is being felt keenly in the home of the Bachant triplets, who were born March 30 at the Sloane Hospital for Women. Yesterday, in her three-room apartment at 1627 University Avenue, the Bronx, which she shares with her mother, Mrs. Muriel Bachant, 21-year-old mother of three girls, sighed wearily as she told of having so little sleep while trying to care for the babies herself.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEAD-QUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Friday, May 5 (UP) -- A communique:

Two police radio patrol cars chased a stolen automobile for three miles through Greenwich Village and the lower West Side last night and after the exchange of a score of pistol shots, the three occupants, two of them critically wounded, were arrested on charges of felonious assault, robbery and violation of the Sullivan law.

One of the stirring sagas of the war in far-off places was told for the first time here yesterday at the offices of the North Atlantic Division of the Army Corps of Engineers, coincident with the announcement that the great American base in Greenland had been completed after years of heroic struggle against the Arctic elements.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Senate; by unanimous vote, passed and sent to the House today the George-Murray bill to establish a formula for settling terminated war contracts as the first step in the legislative program for gradual re-conversion of industry to civilian production.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Appointment of a five-man subcommittee to make the study of international communications authorized by the Senate under Resolution 187 was announced today by Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, chairman of the Committee on Interstate Commerce.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 29 were 17 per cent above sales in the croresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. The following table shows percentage changes from like periods of 1943:

Pointing up the increasing gravity of the shortage of fabrics for children's low cost dresses, a buyer for a leading chain store organization said yesterday that he is unable to buy more than 10 per cent of requirements for the fall.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- A broad program for world-wide economic reconversion, reconstruction and expansion following the war was put before the International Labor Conference today by American industry.

Yesterday was the hottest May 4 in the records of the local Weather Bureau and the hottest day this year. The official thermometer atop the Whitehall Building went to 83.3 degrees at 3:35 P.M., breaking the record for the year which was established last Monday at 83.2 degrees.

The New York City Center Opera Company gave its first performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" last night at the City Center. Irma Gonzalez, Mexican soprano, made her debut with the organization as the Mimi of the cast. The presentation also marked the return to the local opera stage of Natalie Bodanya, who assumed the role of Musetta.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Legislation which would subject to induction for assignment to special work units an estimated 1,000,000 4-F draft registrants and men 38 to 45 years of age who have quit or failed to obtain essential war jobs was endorsed today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War; Ralph A. Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, and Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of the Selective Service System.

A far-reaching reorganization within the State Labor Department, affecting the enforcement of social legislation as well as factory inspection, was announced yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Edward F. Corsi, who heads the department.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 4-When Baron von Knyphausen, Helsinki correspondent of the Hamburger Fremdenblatt until he deserted the Nazi regime last month, boarded a Helsinki train en route to Sweden he was stopped by Finnish police and compelled to stay in Finland, an eyewitness said on his arrival in Stockholm yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Those who hoped or wishfully believed that the issue of "white supremacy," or resentment against the New Deal, or both, could bring down the President's political standard in the South can find no comfort in the Florida and Alabama Democratic primaries.

Termination of the European phase of the war will be followed by a brief psychological reaction, which will in time give way to an upswing with the end of the war in the Pacific, A.W. Zelomek, economist for Fairchild Publications, said yesterday at the meeting of chain store and resident buying executives in the Hotel McAlpin to aid the United Jewish Appeal.

LONDON, May 4 -- Grave concern is felt both in the United States and Britain over the great need for coal in both countries and on the Continent of Europe during the coming year. The difficulties posed by the problem of transporting such a commodity are aggravated by the shortage of supply, particularly in this country.

MOSCOW, May 4 -- The Soviet newspaper Izvestia reported today that American press reaction to Wendell L. Willkie's defeat and to General MacArthur's withdrawal from the Presidential contest demonstrated that President Roosevelt had increased his chances for a fourth term.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 (AP) -- After wavering in the first inning to allow three runs, big Max Butcher settled down behind excellent support today and pitched a 6-3 victory that enabled the Pirates to win the series from the Cardinals, two games to one.

Black market operations at the retail level have become widespread on work clothing not only in New York but in all sections of the country, it was reported yesterday by manufacturing executives in the field. Garments described as being particularly affected are chambray work shirts and denim overalls and dungarees.

OPA has shown a commendable tendency in recent weeks to ease rationing restrictions wherever possible. The action now taken with regard to meats will prove to be the most welcome of all those to date. The reduction in the requirements of the armed forces and lend-lease, heavy slaughtering and inadequate warehouse facilities have resulted in a sufficient increase in supplies to warrant the present move.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -Proposing legislation which would allow banks and savings and loan associations to carry war bonds on their books at par rather than current market value, Senator Thomas of Oklahoma said today that the end of the war might bring a huge liquidation of these securities and a "dangerous" drop in their market price.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Short covering was on today in May rye on the Chicago Board of Trade, and with a lack of aggressive selling the price of that delivery advanced 1 3/8 cents a bushel over yesterday's finish to the highest mark since early February.

Studies of bacterial and other factors responsible for the spoilage of home-canned foods have revealed that file time generally employed in processing foods of low acid content by the boiling water bath method is not long enough to destroy some of the harmful bacteria present, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Society of American Bacteriologists at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 4 -Despite the doubling of rations to spur morale, defeatism is spreading in the German Navy in Norwegian waters, according to a Belgian engineer who for more than a year has been working with the land constructions section of the German Navy and is now in Stockholm following a successful escape.

Filing of a petition with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the hitherto unknown Security Dealers Committee emphasizes the need for a clarification of powers in the so-called "5 per cent mark-up rule" of the executive committee of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc.

The trend toward recovery in the stock market, well sustained for a week and a half, ran into difficulty yesterday, but more because of a slackened demand than outright pressure. It was a slow-down born primarily of caution on the part of recently active traders and increasing evidence of the nearness of the Allied invasion of the European continent.

Branch Rickey announced yesterday that several members of the Brooklyn Dodgers had been assigned to minor league teams. Heading the list of those sent down on option was Gene Mauch, much spoken of through the Spring as the regular shortstop of the team for 1944.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- A vast housing and public works construction program to provide jobs for several million workers must be ready for the millions who will be released from war industries and from the armed forces, according to recommendations adopted today by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor.

Means of aiding efforts of the nation's retailers to make more effective the War Production Board's declaration of policy relating to conservation of textiles and related products were discussed yesterday by the war activities committee of the National Association of Better Business Bureaus and M.C. Harris of the Office of Civilian Requirements of the WPB, at a meeting in the Hotel Lexington.

LONDON, May 4 -- When the time comes for the Red Army to enter that part of Poland west of the old Curzon Line in pursuit of the Germans, the Russians have no intention of consulting the Polish Government in London about civil administration, any more than they have already in the eastern territory they claim as their own.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 4 -- One of the first things that the new Argentine Foreign Minister, Gen. Orlando L. Peluffo, did after taking charge of his post yesterday was to call at the Brazilian Embassy to inquire after the health of Ambassador Jose de Paula Rodriguez Alves, who a few hours before had been stricken with a cerebral hemorrhage.

Discovery that certain bacteria secrete a substance that destroys penicillin, and studies shedding light for the first time on the mechanism by which penicillin exerts its destructive effect on bacteria were reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Society of American Bacteriologists at the Pennsylvania.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

It will be forty-four years tomorrow since her marriage. The stroke is cruel. The long "bright day is done." The survivor's sole consolation is the deep religious faith and hope that are his as they were his wife's. Because he is the best-beloved citizen of New York, because his wife won the affection of many friends, this is a public sorrow and we may speak of it.

Eighteen child-care centers will be established in various sections of the State to care for children of migrant farm and canning factory workers when the harvest season begins in July, Mrs. Mebane Hunt Martensen, field worker for the State Child Care Committee of the State War Council, announced yesterday.

A prediction that payments to American holders of Brazilian bonds would probably start by June 1 as a result of an agreement reached several months ago between representatives of American and British bondholders and the Government of Brazil was made last night by Dr. Valentim F. Boucas, special representative of the Brazilian Government, at a press conference in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Those of us who hope for a cooperative world were disappointed in your editorial "A World Monetary Plan." As you point out, each nation must keep its house in order. But it is just as true that no nation can do this if other nations adopt unwise and selfish domestic policies.

In THE TIMES for April 18 a dispatch on the coming invasion says: "The enemy is becoming increasingly worried by the possibility that the Allies may also achieve a strategic surprise by landing in an area for which defensive plans have not been drawn up and where coastal defenses are rudimentary."

The chemical analysis now being made by the War Food Administration of samples of all its surplus stocks of canned evaporated milk will prevent a recurrence of conditions that led recently to the illness of seventyfour persons from milk given by the Government to a priva charitable institution in this city, Francis E. Robinson, chief of the marketing reports division of the WFA'S Office of Food Distribution here, said yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 4 -- Army officers' winter uniforms have been completely redesigned by the Quartermaster Corps with a view to increasing comfort and improving their appearance, while retaining their present basic style, the War Department announced today.

PEARL HARBOR, May 4 (AP) -Far-flying Army Liberator bombers followed up the mauling of Truk by carrier task forces with one of the heaviest land-based serial attacks on the crippled Japanese bastion in the central Pacific, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.
LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, discussing the predicament of the Chinese in the face of new Japanese pressure in Honan and Anhwei Provinces, pledged today, "We shall use every means to hasten the day when the flow of supplies and war materials to these Allies of ours will give them much more of the resources needed to drive out the invader."

E. Braum Co., importers of linens, have leased an entire floor in 669 Fifth Avenue, consisting of 5,000 square feet, through the Harold C. Samuels Company and Clark T. Chambers. The Samuels company also leased a floor in 23 West Fifty-seventh Street to Marion Valle, milliner.

SUPPOSE you were an author trying to dream up a heroine who would incorporate in her person all the most romantic, glamorous and seductive attributes imaginable. You might begin by endowing her with the grace of a swan. No one could object to that as long as you made it perfectly clear that it was a swan swimming that you meant and not one waddling on dry land.

RAHWAY, N.J., May 4 -- Therese Truax, 18-month-old daughter of Sgt. Elmer Truax and Mrs. Truax of 215 East Milton Avenue here, died late this afternoon of leukemia and complications, six days after the arrival of her father from the South Pacific on a furlough obtained through the intercession of President Roosevelt, to whom Mrs. Truax had appealed.

Most of us see spring tripping in as a young girl clad in a green mantle. For the poets, too, she moves in a green haze, though they do twine rosebuds in her hair and scatter violets and arbutus at her feet. But spring comes to the artist with a rainbow round her shoulder.

BALTIMORE, May 4 (AP) -- F.W. Hooper's favored Alabama won the $5,000-added Ral Parr Stakes before 13,000 persons at Pimlico today, nosing out the long shot, Don Chance, after a stride-for-stride duel down the stretch. The victory was worth $6,150.

The Federal Open Market Committee, acting on behalf of the twelve regional Federal Reserve Banks, came to the rescue of the member banks of the Reserve System during the week ended Wednesday, by purchasing a total of $294,354,000 of Government securities, mostly Treasury bills, from the banks. Otherwise, reserve
Crown Princess Martha of Norway, accompanied by Mme. Ragni Ostgaard, has arrived from her home in Bethesda, Md., and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A Festival of Polish Music was presented at Carnegie Hall last night by the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America. The concert, which commemorated the Polish Constitution of May, 1791, featured eighty members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony under the direction of Gregor Fittelberg.

ST. LOUIS, May 4 (AP) -- Nelson Potter limited the Tigers to five singles, only two of them in one inning, as the Browns held their top perch in the American League with a 2-to-0 triumph today. It was St. Louis' twelfth victory in fifteen starts and Potter's third against one loss.

All galleries and the members' penthouse will close on Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art in preparation for the fifteenth anniversary exhibition, "Art in Progress," which is to open on May 24. The whole museum space will be devoted to this exhibition.

Commissioner John McKenzie of the city Department of Marine and Aviation, under whose jurisdiction the General Anderson Airport at Idlewild, Queens, is being constructed, visited yesterday two homes in the area near the airport known as Cedar Gardens and inspected the cellars.

It seems altogether probable that the House today will overwhelmingly approve the bill to simplify taxes. The measure was adopted unanimously by the Ways and Means Committee and has the blessing of the Treasury. Congressional and Treasury experts have worked in harmony to draft it.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Newspapers and magazines will be distributed to soldiers here and overseas on basis of the soldiers' preference, the War Department said today in announcing that it has sent instructions to all commanders that "a policy of strict impartiality in the dissemination of political information" must be followed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -Barbara Britton, who recently finished a co-starring lead with Ray Milland in Paramount's "Till We Meet Again," has been lent by the studio to Bing Crosby's production company for the second feminine lead in "The Great John L." She will portray the childhood sweetheart and second wife of the Boston pugilist.

The German defense of western Europe is based upon a very stiff and difficult system of shoreline defenses, manned continuously by coastal defense divisions, backed up by flexible mobile reservoirs. Farther inland, there are other prepared zones of defense -- but whether they are equal in strength to those along the coast only future operations can tell.

Although the taking of black bass doesn't become legal in New York State until July 1, with some local exceptions, you can fish a section of the Schoharie River and its tributaries up in Greene County now and take all of them you want.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee directed Government agencies today to give Congress regular reports on the volume of reverse lend-lease from countries receiving United States aid.
AT A FRENCH BIVOUAC, on the Fifth Army Front, May 4 -- Twice a week copies of the Patrie, the French newspaper published in Naples, reach this camp, built around a monastery in an olive grove.

In nine months of 1940 and 1941, according to evidence produced yesterday at his trial in Federal court, Frederick Heizer Wright banked a total of $2,448.10 more than he received in salary and loans. Wright, a copy editor for The New York Daily News, is accused of serving the Japanese as an unregistered propaganda agent for ten years before Pearl Harbor.

Asserting that under proper development and safeguards against deterioration of social and economic standards, Australia could support a population of from 150,000,000 to 200,000,000 people, Percy J. Clarey, president of the Australasian Council of Trade Unions, declared yesterday that the Commonwealth probably would reconsider her prevailing policy of strict control of immigration when the war ends.

A gloomy post-war future for Puerto Rico was forecast by Rafael Carrion, executive vice president of the Banco Popular de Puerto Rico, at the annual meeting yesterday afternoon of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

"Do not try to imitate the rooms of a well-known decorator," warned Miss Phyllis Costello, head of the interior decorating department of John Wanamaker's, addressing women students of personality development at the New York University School of Commerce yesterday.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to have increased during the week to new high records.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and United States marshals entered the dispute between the Government and Montgomery Ward Co. today when they seized Paul D. Sowell, assistant to the operating manager, after he had removed a notice that had been posted by Government agents in the company's retail plant.

CHUNGKING, China, May 4 -The Japanese have cleared all but a sixty-five-mile stretch of the Peiping-Hankow railroad and are spreading west of the line in a multi-pronged drive that threatens to engulf central Honan's rich coal fields, a Chinese communique admitted tonight.

LONDON, May 4 (U.P.) -- German and Croat Ustashi garrisons in the Adriatic port of Spalato have been cut off completely from supplies by Yugoslav Partisan attacks against interior rail lines and occupation of islands guarding the port's sea approaches, Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) announced today.

CHUNGKING, May 4 (AP) -- Throwing in air support, the Japanese reopened their push aimed at Loyang, sixty-five miles west of Chengchow. They advanced within nine miles of Tengfeng, thirty miles southeast of Loyang, the Chinese communique said today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -Workers' delegates and Government representatives at the International Labor Office conference rose today in support of women workers. They defeated, 72 to 30, an employers group resolution to omit from ILO recommendations a section prepared to protect women's post-war employment.

NAPLES, May 4 -- In a statement issued today Premier Pietro Badoglio expressed confidence "in the loyalty and patriotism of farmers throughout liberated Italy" in support of the coordinated grain distribution plan by which every man, woman and child in the area would receive "a just amount of bread and pasta."
