Accentuating the decline in plastics material prices, E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. announced yesterday substantial price reductions on "Lucite" methyl methcrylate resin in clear, transparent sheets. The reductions, following closely upon a 10 per cent cut announced on Wednesday by the Rohm Haas Company in the price of Plexiglas acrylic sheets, range from 4.5 per cent for the thinnest type of sheeting to 10.8 per cent for thicker sheets.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- From the country's largest cities as well as from rural areas, witnesses brought testimony today to a Senate Agriculture subcommittee that the Federal School Lunch Program fully justified expansion, as well as retention as a permanent service to the rising generation.

BALTIMORE, May 4 (AP) -- In a brief but stormy session, stockholders of the Certain-teed Products Corporation seeking to oust the present management succeeded today in adjourning the annual meeting to May 12 after expressing confidence that they could produce a quorum.

A syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,814,800 Minneapolis (Minn.) refunding and hospital bonds, due serially from June 1, 1945 to 1954. The bankers bid 100.3323 for the bonds as 1.10 per cents.

Eddie Dowling's first production early next season will be a new play entitled "Men to the Sea," it was learned yesterday. It is the work of Herbert Kubly, who is on the editorial staff of The Herald Tribune. Mr. Dowling plans to start rehearsals a month hence.

Awards for engineering construction throughout the country amounted to $145,040,000 last month, or an average of $36,260,000 a week for the four-week period. The average is 3 per cent higher than the weekly average for the five weeks of March.

All of us are becoming more conscious of the discrepancies between our ideals of democracy and our performance of them. In Springfield, Mass., something is being done about this, and I think New York would do well to study their practice to see what steps we too can take in our educational system and employment practices in order to begin to make real and true the aims for which we profess to be fighting.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 19 was 851,857 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,903 cars, or 1.4 per cent more than for the preceding week; 63,068 cars, or 8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 7,054 cars, or 0.8 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, May 4 -- Thirty-seven-year-old Gen. Vladimir Velebit, leader of Marshal Tito's military mission in London, said today that small forces of American troops were operating beside Yugoslav Partisans in Yugoslavia. In addition, he said that Partisan troops had rescued numerous United States airmen who crashed in Yugoslavia after operating against Axis supply lines and troop concentrations.

A committee of leading architects, enlisted from the American Institute of Architects, the New York State Association of Architects, architectural magazines and public agencies, has been set up to spur this year's participation by the profession in The Greater New York Fund's current campaign, it was announced yesterday by Daniel P. Higgins, chairman of the division.

The Crucible Steel Company of America and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in a statement of operations covering the first quarter this year a net profit of $1,279,302 after all charges including provision of $5,967,093 for income and excess profits taxes, equal to $1.97 a share of common stock.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4 (AP) -- Dr. Melvin H. Knisely of Chicago said today he had discovered a way to test the effectiveness of anti-malaria drugs and predicted the method eventually would be used to measure the value of other disease treatments.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Five hundred members of the National Association of Housing Officials at their annual meeting heard a report today of its committee on post-war housing, approved by the board of governors. It recommended that some resumption of non-war housing construction be permitted before the end of the war if the materials and manpower situation permit.

The war has brought forth many a wonder of research but none more wonderful than the success of Drs. Robert B. Woodward and William E. Doering in synthesizing quinine. Behind this outstanding achievement stands nearly a century of vain effort -- vain partly because organic chemistry had not developed the conceptions and techniques required.

Sir Walter Citrine, general secretary of the British Trades Union Congress and president of the International Federation of Trade Unions, declared in an address last night that cooperation between the labor unions of the Western democracies and the unions of Soviet Russia was necessary to international labor unity and the task of post-war reconstruction.

Fluctuations in prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were again within a very narrow range, and quotations closed unchanged to 4 points higher than on Wednesday, with a steady undertone.

JIM DURFEE was mentioned in most casual fashion in this corner last week, and that is no way to treat a football official as distinctive as he was. When the coaches of the National Football League were re]axing one night after the strain of their lengthy meetings a week ago, one conversational topic they explored rather fully was this same Durfee.

President Roosevelt named no date in his request to Congress yesterday for authority to turn over $450,000,000 in cash and $350,000,000 in lend-lease supplies to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration. The White House statement did refer to "impending military operations" and said that "the beginning of fuller relief operations by UNRRA may be accompanied by a decline in military and lend-lease requirements for operations in the European theatre."
LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- Nazi propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels fed the Germans soothing syrup for their nerves today with the promise of "trump cards up our sleeves" when the invasion strikes!

LONDON, May 4 -- Soviet Russia's intentions to expand vastly her purchasing of consumer goods and capital equipment from private firms, both in the United States and Great Britain, became known here today in diplomatic circles.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Gehrig, parents of the late Lou Gehrig, Yankee star first baseman, and Efrem Kurtz, permanent conductor of the Kansas City Philharmonic Orchestra, and his wife, became United States citizens yesterday, when they took the oath before Federal Judge John C. Knox.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for an initial appropriation of $450,000,000 toward the total United States commitment of $1,350,000,000 for participation in the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- American troops storming into Europe will have newly developed ordnance, "the finest artillery, small arms with performances better than anything the enemy has used and ammunition with higher explosive charges," Brig. Gen. Henry Sayler said today.

LONDON, May 4 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden met the Empire Prime Ministers today and besought their approval of Britain's policy in her dealings with foreign countries. As members of the British family of nations, the Dominion representatives have already been made privy to the military secrets of the War Cabinet.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 -Owners of the horses nominated for the seventieth Kentucky Derby must decide by noon tomorrow whether they want to put up $500 each to enter their 3-year-olds in the $75,000 added classic at Churchill Downs on Saturday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, May 5 (U.P.) -- American forces in Netherland New Guinea, meeting very light opposition, have expanded their holdings westward along the coast in the Humboldt Bay area, with new landings at Torare Bay and Demta, where they are mopping up small bands of the enemy, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -Steamship rates and values have been "drastically" reduced since the outbreak of war "in the face of an upward inflationary trend of our economic system and contrary to all past experiences in wartime," the War Shipping Administration said today.
LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- Note circulation established a new high record of 1,129,170,000 in the week ended yesterday, an increase of 4,697,000 in the week, as reported today by the Bank of England.
KANSAS CITY, May 5 (AP) -- The Methodists voted today to support the war because "God Himself has a stake in the struggle."

BOSTON, May 4 -- Incredible as it sounds, our Giants, who only last Sunday had shattered an imposing Yankee-Cardinal record by belting twenty-six runs across the plate, continued to wander aimlessly today. They lost the opening clash of a five-game series to the Braves, 8 to 4, for their fourth straight defeat since that memorable drubbing of the Dodgers and as a result fell into a fourth-place tie with their idle Brooklyn victims.
MONTREAL, May 4 (AP) -- Newark spoiled the home opening of the Royals today by combing four pitchers for eighteen hits and swamping them, 17 -- 8.

College and university presidents debated the relative merits of ac-celebration in academic curriculums at an open discussion last night, sponsored by the Women's University Club at the Hotel Biltmore.

The largest annual volume of sales in the history of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., a strong financial position and larger earnings were reported by Bernard F. Gimbel, president, in the annual statement to stockholders released for publication today.

BOSTON, May 5 -- Our urbane Melvin Ott lost some of his patience today as he gave his faltering Giant line-up a bit of a shaking. Ace Adams lost his status as a starting pitcher and went back to his old chore as a relief worker. Mel even retired himself for a pinch runner in the ninth.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, expressed the opinion at a press conference today in the light of his mission to London that the British and Americans were going to stick together through thick and thin.

Governor Thomas E. Dewey yesterday set June 6 as the date for special elections in the Fourth and Eleventh Congressional districts to fill the vacancies caused by the deaths of Representatives Thomas H. Cullen and James A. O'Leary, both Democrats.

A letter from Vice Admiral R.R. Waesche, commandant of the United States Coast Guard, made public yesterday by Freeholder A. Paul King of Ocean County, N.J., raised hopes that the move to relax the Coast Guard regulations governing off-shore party boat fishing was a step nearer realization.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Chairman Donald M. Nelson and Executive Vice Chairman Charles E. Wilson of the War Production Board told THE NEW YORK TIMES in a joint interview tonight that there was "not the slightest foundation" for widespread rumors that they were at loggerheads over basic policies.

BOSTON, May 5 (AP) -- Sal Bartolo, Boston featherweight, made his first defense of his National Boxing Association title tonight by defeating Phil Terranova in a fifteen-round fight before 7,673 spectators at Boston Garden. The champion weighed 126, while Terranova scaled 125 1/2 pounds.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, May 6 (U.P.) -- Half-starved and dejected Japanese troops are surrendering to American forces in the Hollandia and Aitape areas of northern New Guinea, while Allied bombers, fighters and P-T boats have blasted by-passed enemy positions, and sinking or damaging at least twenty barges along the coast, it was announced today.

LONDON, May 5 -- In a striking review of great Britain's achievements in transport services by land and sea, Philip J. Noel-Baker, Parliamentary Secretary in the Ministry of War Transport, told the House of Commons today that since war began, his Ministry had built up an instrument that would stand the strain of forthcoming invasion operations and make its contribution to the victory that lies ahead.

Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, sitting in Brooklyn, yesterday dismissed a writ of habeas corpus in behalf of Private Ignacio Aberanturi, who sought his discharge from the Army on the ground that he was a citizen of Spain, a neutral country.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- Betty Hutton will be starred by Paramount in "Torch Song," a melodrama with music, to be based on a story by Milton Holmes, former manager of the Los Angeles Tennis Club who wrote the Cary Grant picture "Mr. Lucky" and the forthcoming Paramount film "Sally O'Rourke."

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has sold 206 Fifth Avenue, a five-story store and loft building running through to 1126 Broadway, between Twenty-fifth and Twenty-sixth Streets, to an investing client of Herbert Charles Co. The property is assessed at $165,000 and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $100,000 for ten years.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee voted today to recommend an eighteen-month instead of a one-year extension of the Price Control Act, which will expire June 30.
LONDON, May 5 (AP) -- A correspondent with the Red Army said the Russians were "burning and squeezing the enemy out of nearly impregnable stone nests."

SYDNEY, Australia, May 5 (U.P.) -- Chief Justice Sir John Latham of the Commonwealth High Court today recommended that Australian newspapers and censorship authorities attempt to settle their recent differences out of court.

LONDON, May 5 -- Seventy-four year-old Mohandas K. Gandhi, whose followers in 1942 proposed to yield India to the Japanese without a fight, will be released tomorrow from his seventh term of political imprisonment.

The Republic Steel Corporation has provided for refunding of its entire $71,076,000 funded debt through the sale of $50,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent series bonds due in 1964 to eleven insurance companies and through loans of $24,500,000 from its regular commercial banks.

One faithful reader of this column is pleased to see life's permanent interests assert themselves amidst the din of war. He writes to us about it: "It was around midnight. The avenue was dim, and, as usual at that hour nowadays, not many people were abroad.

The virtual suppression of a story about Japanese war moves a week before Pearl Harbor was attributed yesterday to Frederick Heizer Wright at his trial in Federal court on charges of serving the Japanese secretly as a propaganda agent.

With the decision yesterday by Jacques Chambrun to end the run of "Sheppey," starring Edmund Gwenn, after tonight's performance, the total of Broadway casualties for the week rose to four. The other closings are "The Merry Widow" ( 321 performances), "Mrs. January Mr. Ex" (43) and "Allah, Be Praised!" (20).

ALGIERS, May 5 -- An echo of Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud's dismissal was heard in the Consultative Assembly today during a debate on the war effort when Etienne Fajon, a Communist, expressed regret that the office of Commander in Chief had been abolished and presented the Giraudist argument that the separation of political and military powers had been reaffirmed last year.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 -Nineteen 3-year-old horses, one of them a filly that never has started, today accepted the issue for the seventieth Kentucky Derby -- America's mile and a quarter turf classic that is expected to draw upward of 60,000 fans to Churchill Downs tomorrow and to be run over a muddy track for the first time in fifteen years.

NAPLES, May 5 -- Allied dive-bombers breached the great Pescara dam near Italy's Adriatic coast this afternoon, unloosing a great volume of water that may result in serious consequences to the enemy, who used the dam's hydroelectric service.

Eugene Francis O'Brien, one of three men arrested Thursday night after a seventy-mile-an-hour automobile chase through the lower West Side, and accused of two robberies in barrooms, told the police at the line-up yesterday that he slept through the pursuit and the fusillade of pistol shots fired by the police. He said he knew nothing of the hold-ups.

The Music School Settlement celebrated its fiftieth anniversary with a dinner given last night at the Town Hall Club, which was followed by the organization's annual spring concert in Town Hall. The dinner was attended by 180 persons, and among the honored guests was Emily Wagner, who founded the school and for many years headed it.
NAPLES, May 5 (U.P.) -- The Allied fliers who breached the Pescara Dam broke it in three places with delayed action bombs that burst under water against the base of the structure.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Some relief in the lumber shortage was seen today in a War Production Board announcement reporting greater success "than had been anticipated" in cutting back 1944 construction activity.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 5 -- At a service of solemn evensong in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the Eastchester section of this city Sunday at 4 P.M. there will be blessed a sanctuary lamp and a pair of branch candlesticks. The church, which dates to 1665, is known as "the National Shrine of the Bill of Rights."

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 5 -- British troops have launched a general counter-offensive on the Kohima front and are making "satisfactory progress," while in north Burma Chinese troops led by American tanks have captured Inkagahtawng and trapped its Japanese garrison of 1,000 men, it was announced tonight.

Food stores throughout the metropolitan area reported yesterday that there was "not too much meat" to supply the enormous potential demand created by the Office of Price Administration on Thursday, when it freed 85 per cent of meat cuts from point rationing.

March installment accounts receivable of household appliance stores showed no decrease from the February level, the Federal Reserve Bank reported yesterday. This, it is said, is the first time in more than two years that there was no decrease from the preceding month.

An investing group purchased the six-story self-service elevator apartment house at 299-305 Adelphi Street, in the Hill section of Brooklyn from A.J. Septoff. The house contains suites for seventy-one families, occupying a plot 91 by 126 feet.

Resolutions recommending that Government authorities inform the public of the probable lapse of time before goods will be available when releasing frozen materials, and that safeguards be set up now regarding the disposition of surplus products following the war were adopted yesterday by the war activities committee of the National Association of Better Business Bureaus at the Hotel Lexington.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A "most emphatic protest," claimed to be made in the name of 6,000,000 Americans of Polish descent, was sent to Secretary of State Cordell Hull today against the Government's action making possible the visit to Moscow of the Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski, a Catholic priest of Springfield, Mass.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP) -With the score 8 to 8 at the end of the eighth inning, Stan Spence and Joe Kuhel pounded homers over the right-field wall in the ninth as the Senators gained an 11-to-8 triumph over the Athletics in the first game of a series today.

" Production, Jobs and Taxes," by Harold M. Groves, will be the first in a series of studies sponsored by the Committee for Economic Development devoted to the problems involved in the transition from war to peace. McGraw-Hill will publish it June 5.

" The Hitler Gang," Paramount's picturization of the genesis and growth of the Nazi party, will have its local premiere this morning at the Globe. Robert Watson plays Hitler, with Roman Bohnen as Capt. Ernst Roehm, Martin Kosleck as Goebbels, Victor Varconi as Hess, Luis Van Rooten as Heinrich Himmler, Alexander Pope as Goering and Alexander Granach as Julius Streicher.

Sam Silver is a short and not overly pugnacious person, but when a pair of hold-up men tried to strong-arm him early yesterday morning in his stationery store at 4805 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, he quickly proved that appearances may be deceiving.

NAPLES, May 5 -- Intense flak met the United States Fifteenth Air Force heavy bombers as they attacked railyards and oil refineries at Ploesti today. The attack was the fifth on the all important center of Rumania.

To take the gospel into war areas, Army camps and summer resorts a "Trailer Chapel" will be sent out next week under the auspices of the Atlantic District of the Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and other States. It will be on exhibition tomorrow from 3 P.M. to 9 P.M. on the campus of Concordia Collegiate Lutheran Institute, Bronxville, N.Y.

Topics of The Times mentions that it is difficult to justify the arch form of the municipal asphalt plant's main unit, and likens it to a great proscenium. In the first place, it is not a proscenium shape; second, the cross-section of the machinery almost exactly fills this arch form.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Judge William H. Holly of the Federal district is expected to rule tomorrow whether there is need to extend the ten-day temporary injunction restraining officials of Montgomery Ward Co. from interfering with the Government's operation of the concern's Chicago properties.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY ON THE ANZIO BEACHHEAD, May 5 -- On the eighty square miles of this beachhead there is not one square inch of this flat pleasant wedge of Italy that is not vulnerable to German shell fire twentyfour hours daily.

Government adoption of food industry recommendations to limit future purchases so as to ease the problem of surplus disposal at the end of the war, as indicated by Lee Marshall, director of distribution of the War Food Administration, was welcomed yesterday by Francis L. Whitmarsh, president of Francis H. Leggett Co., and industry chairman of the Food Industry Advisory Committee.

Memories of nine years spent as secretary, literary aide and general factotum to Gert Hans von Gontard were recounted in Federal court yesterday by Mrs. Gertrude Zenzes, who is not his secretary any more. Her story, eked out by occasional references to a meticulously kept diary, was told in Federal court, where von Gontard and three other men are on trial for conspiracy to evade the draft.

The Eastern college rowing season will be launched today on the Harlem with Columbia. Cornell and Navy meeting in a two-race regatta for varsity and junior varsity crews. The junior varsity boats will get away at 5 o'clock and the varsity at 6.

ON THE KOHIMA FRONT, in India, May 2 (Delayed) -- The plight of the Japanese in north Manipur is getting increasingly difficult and they are beginning to realize that their chances of victory on this front are growing slimmer.

PEARL HARBOR, May 5 (U.P.) -- United States Army and Navy planes, sweeping the far reaches of Japan's Pacific Empire, struck Wednesday and Thursday at Paramushiru in the Kuriles, and hit Nauru Island, on the southern flank of the Carolines, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.
RENO, May 5 -- Mrs. Mary P. Weightman O'Brien filed suit and obtained a divorce today from Esmond P. O'Brien of New York. They had been separated for three years.

A simple suit in trespass, mentioned as a possible step in the Montgomery Ward affair, may be the means of obtaining answers to two far-reaching and unsettled questions in our scheme of constitutional government. The questions are: What is the extent of the power of the President to impose his will on private individuals? and What part is the Supreme Court going to take in determining the limits to that power?
An indignant woman stomped up to a hotel desk yesterday morning and demanded to see the manager.
KANSAS CITY, May 5 (AP) -- Methodists moved today for "ultimate elimination" of racial discrimination in their church.

An emergency resolution "vigorously protesting" the recent Montgomery Ward seizure and branding it as "totalitarian procedure in violation of its citizens' constitutional prerogative as set forth in the Bill of Rights," was adopted unanimously yesterday at the 124th convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor.

A merger of the Van Camp Milk Company of Fort Wayne, Ind., into the Pet Milk Company of St. Louis, Mo., will be acted upon at a special meeting of stockholders of Pet Milk in St. Louis on May 24, that company announced yesterday.

A THIRTEEN-YEAR-OLD boy stood tip-toe on the tailboard of a grocery wagon and watched Aristides win the first Kentucky Derby. He will watch some other horse capture the Run for the Roses at Churchill Downs today just as he has witnessed every Derby since Aristides romped home a winner in 1875. Yes, this will be the seventieth consecutive classic for Col. Matt Winn, a remarkably vigorous young fellow of 83.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Four new constructions of Army cloth, still in the development stage, have been exempted from price control, OPA announced today. The new constructions are wind-resistant water-repellent oxford fabrics made wholly of combed cotton yarns, and are designed for use by the armed forces for sleeping bags and shelter tents.

LONDON, May 5 -- Until bad weather closed in on targets four hours after dawn today Allied air forces in Britain struck five times. While a small force of Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force bombed German military installations in the Pas-de-Calais area, waves of British Mitchells and Bostons and American Thunderbolt fighter bombers hammered rail yards at Valenciennes, Somain, Cambrai and one unspecified spot.

To the article of Alexander Porhownik which appeared in the April 11 issue under the heading "Letters to THE TIMES" and headlined "Using Alien Physicians" I submit a rebuttal to his entire trend of thought regarding the idea that State board examinations are unnecessary for European doctors residing in the State of New York.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- Gag-throwing, banjo-playing Charlie Grimm had two baseball clubs on his hands today.
Count that day lost whose low descending sun views no old record toppled when the seventh race is run.

A trickle of the vast restless reserve of unemployed funds found its way yesterday into the stock market and produced the widest recovery move in almost two months. Although gains of 1 to 3 points were reserved generally for a selected list of issues, the upsweep proved to be broad and returned the composite price to the levels of mid-April.

Including $7,397,000 of short-term notes by several local housing authorities on Wednesday, new municipal financing scheduled to be done next week will total $8,818,000, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's total of $7,233,566, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $15,506,198.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 5 -- The position of the Communist party was established today with a three-point statement issued after a quarrel between President Juan Antonio Rios, on the one hand firmly refusing to change his Cabinet, and "Alianza Democratica," a combination of parties headed by the Radical party, employing its utmost efforts to obtain the removal of all rightists and the adoption of a number of points approved at a recent convention.

Last night's performance by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was perhaps the most brilliant of the season thus far, consisting as it did of "Gisele" with Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin, Jerome Robbins and his youthful colleague in "Fancy Free," and Antony Tudor's "Gala Performance."

The Senate Committee on Appropriations has directed Government agencies to give Congress regular reports of the volume of "reverse lend-lease" received from countries to which American supplies are going. It is proper that such reports should be made from time to time and that the transactions which they reveal should be taken into consideration when a final settlement is made.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The House, by a vote of 300 to 60, approved today the naming of its own special committee to investigate the seizure of the Chicago facilities of Montgomery Ward Co., with 116 Democrats supporting the inquiry and fifty-nine opposing it.

The celebration of the Memorial Hospital's sixtieth anniversary calls for congratulations and a review of the progress made in controlling cancer, and this for the reason that Memorial has been so conspicuous in conducting research, training specialists and alleviating suffering from a dreadful affliction.

Company surveys, cross-checked by independent research organizations, indicate that Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., will have a market for 500,000 washing machines in the first post-war year, J. S. Sayre, president of the company, stated yesterday. In the company's best pre-war year it manufactured 125,000 washers.

The Monsanto Chemical Company and its American subsidiaries had a net income in the first quarter of this year totaling $1,141,733, equal to 73 cents a common share, according to a report issued yesterday. In the corresponding three months of 1943 the net income amounted to $1,348,711, or 92 cents a share of common stock.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A new plan under which officers and enlisted men whose jobs make them "in a measure indispensable" in overseas theatres may be granted "non-emergency leaves and furloughs'' to visit their homes in the United States and then return to their assignments overseas, was announced today by the War Department.

Favored by fine weather, retail trade here gave a good account of itself this week. Department-store sales were estimated as about 10 per cent ahead of the like week last year, with specialty shops showing an even larger increase.

With about 2,000 bartenders, waiters and kitchen workers in the city already out of work as a result of the 30 per cent cabaret tax, the joint board of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Union, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, announced last night that it had called a special emergency meeting for next Friday at 3 P.M. in the Hotel Astor to "crystallize protest against the tax."
The Sons of Indiana of New York in session at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, last night awarded to Ernie Pyle, Scripps-Howard war correspondent, a scroll as the outstanding Hoosier of 1944.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Women must be included in all plans for post-war employment, Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Retraining and Re-employment, today told the Institute of Women's Professional Relations.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bulletin said today "reports from various sources show that the rejection of the Soviet peace terms has contributed to a growing lack of confidence in the Finnish Government among large sections of the population of Finland."

The Navy's number one flying ace, 24-year-old Lieut. (j.g.) Ira Kepford, who has sixteen confirmed and eight probables to his credit, termed "pure bunk" yesterday any reports or rumors that the quality of Japanese pilots is deteriorating. He declared that the Japanese was a tricky flier in tricky planes, that he was a good shot, that he must not be underestimated for a minute or a pilot "finds his pants shot off."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Several defense attorneys in the Government's trial of twenty-nine alleged Nazi seditionists, revealed today that they believed that the Roosevelt Administration "conspired" to give the case to a judge who was prejudiced against the defendants.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- A joint committee of seven national organizations interested in State and city planning has been set up to act on post-war urban redevelopment as a result of this week's conferences of the National Association of Housing Officials and the American Society of Planning Officials, it was announced after today's closing sessions.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Military plans for rush production of newly developed, highly secret rocket weapons were disclosed today and Congressional leaders promised speedy action to provide the necessary funds.

RICHMOND, Va., May 5 -- Patents covering a Vitamin K preparation and a way to treat wood to speed up the "aging" of whisky are among the 543 inventions reported in this week's issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- Holding that if the Cities Service Company "desires to retain its oil business it cannot remain in the utility business," the Securities and Exchange Commission gave the big holding company a choice today of disposing of either its utility interests or its "vast and complex" oil enterprises and other non-utility units.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today the request of the Northern Indiana Public Service Company for exemption from the rule of the commission for competitive bidding in the issuance of $22,007,800 of new cumulative 5 per cent dividend preferred stock, $100 par value, which would be exchanged for three series of preferred shares now outstanding.
LONDON, May 5 -- Discussions of armistice terms for Germany and immediate post-war organization of Europe have occupied the conference of Dominion Prime Ministers during the last two days.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 5 -- When the Allies land on the European continent it is conceded now that they cannot possibly take the Germans by surprise. But competent observers are wondering today whether the surprise may not be sprung by the Germans.

LONDON, May 5 -- Another Allied officer has arrived in London from the phantom armies of Yugoslavia to participate in military conversations which observers here believe may result in an offensive by Yugoslav guerrillas to be timed with the 1944 attack on the European fortress from the east and west.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A revised agreement among the War Department, the Canadian Government and the Imperial Oil Company will reduce the cost to the United States of crude oil from the Canol project in northwestern Canada from $1.25 a barrel plus production costs to 20 cents, plus such costs, it was announced today.

Post-war transportation issues assumed a dominant role in discussions yesterday before the Permanent Council of American Associations of Commerce and Production, which represents the principal business associations of the twenty-two American nations.

As a further step in its post-war retail expansion program, Bond Stores, Inc., has leased the Francis M. Newman property at the corner of Fulton Street and Gallatin Place, in Brooklyn, measuring 95 by 100 feet.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- The consuming desire of Republicans to sweep the Middle West in next fall's election, and their belief that conditions are moving toward that end, have put many party leaders in this section on the alert against any issues or clashes of personalities which might divide the ranks.

Mrs. Velvalee Dickinson, the diminutive doll dealer who fought furiously on Jan. 21 when she was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, was brought into Federal court yesterday under new charges which, if proved, could cost her her life. Originally indicted for violation of the censorship code, she was newly accused yesterday of espionage, conspiracy to commit espionage, secret service as an agent of the Japanese, and the censorship violation.

Repeated appeals by jam and jelly preservers of New York to the War Food Administration for reduction of the spread between the price of 15 cents per pound which is the limit they are permitted to pay growers for berries and other small fruits and the price of 30 cents at which growers are allowed to sell in produce markets, have to date brought no response, the New York Preserves Association reported yesterday.

LONDON, May 5 -- A detailed photographic mosaic of the defenses of Festung Europa is now available to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and his staff as a result of six months' work by Royal Air Force pilots who have photographed 3,000 miles of the European coastline.

In a 10,000-word report that winds up the testimony the Office of Price Administration will use in ruling on the plea of New York landlords for a 10 per cent blanket increase in residential rents here, Mayor La Guardia has challenged the accuracy of most of the data presented by the realty men and has urged strongly that the rise be denied on the ground that it would not be in the public interest.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, May 6 (U.P.) -- Air-supported Japanese troops, advancing north from Sinyang in a north-south push to clear the Peiping-Hankow railway in central Honan Province, have captured Kioshan, leaving only a fifty-three-mile stretch of the line in Chinese hands, while to the northwest enemy spearheads are fighting nearer Loyang, a Chinese communique disclosed today.

LONDON, Saturday, May 6 -- Warships and planes of the Soviet Black Sea Fleet, maintaining a tight blockade around besieged Sevastopol, sank eleven more enemy vessels, including five troop transports totaling 13,000 tons, in day and night attacks Wednesday off the southwestern Crimea, Moscow announced last night as the lull on the eastern ground front passed through its second week.
MONTREAL, May 5 (AP) -- Newark again beat the Montreal Royals today, 3 -- 0, as Frank Hiller scattered seven hits, walked none and fanned eight, including the side in the third inning.
Everything went sour for Columbia from the opening inning at Baker Field yesterday and the Lions lost-their first game in five starts as Colgate won, 14 -- 4.

The present speed restrictions on motor vehicles should be retained after the war and not changed until highways have been improved and new automobiles have replaced old cars, Inspector Robert V. Annett, commanding traffic, New York State police, declared yesterday before the Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators, at its spring meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.

Janie Pizzo, a 4-year-old contestant dressed in pink organdy, had difficulty walking past the table of prizes yesterday afternoon at the annual Little Sister Show of the Boys Club of New York. It had been some time since Janie possessed a doll and there were six of them, just sitting there.

Broken in health and spirit, middle-aged Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, partner of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, recently put to death at Sing Sing, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to fifteen years to life imprisonment. In their reign of terror in the garment and other industries of the city a dozen years ago they extorted more than $2,000,000.

Admiral Mineichi Koga, commander of the combined Japanese fleet, was killed in action on an undisclosed front in March, the second Japanese fleet chief to die in action within a year, and has been succeeded by Admiral Soemu Toyoda, the Tokyo High Command announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 5 -- Profit-taking before the week-end caused a subdued tone in today's stock markets. Realizing was heaviest in the Orange Free State group of Kaffir mining shares and many small declines were seen.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- The United States Government made it clear to the International Labor Conference today that it was the settled policy of this country that the United Nations, throughout the peace settlement, should include appropriate provisions for world-wide standards for labor.

LONDON, May 5 -- Although the Soviet Government has no intention of treating with the Mikolajczyk government in London either now or after the liberation of western Poland, it does not intend to use the Union of Polish Patriots in Moscow as a puppet to establish a government there, according to the best information available here.

LONDON, May 5 (AP) -- It was expected in London tonight that Portugal soon would fall in line behind Turkey and Spain in curtailing metals shipments to Germany as Britain, backed by the United States, put pressure on her oldest ally to halt or reduce wolfram exports to the Reich.

In any debate over censorship the censor has the advantage because in suppressing the story he also suppresses the evidence. One can't tell whether or not the War Department was in the right in refusing permission to Harper's Magazine to publish an article discussing General MacArthur as a Presidential candidate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 5 -- Republican leaders of Westchester County met here this afternoon with Livingston Platt, county chairman, to consider candidates for the November election. Mr. Platt later reported unanimity on ten proposed nominations and decision reserved until May 15 on three others.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 5 (AP) -- Edmund A. Gullion, United States charge d'affaires Helsinki, will come to Stockhom Monday "to renew contacts and have talks," an official of the American Legation in Stockholm disclosed today.

Dr. Beverly L. Clarke, head of the analytical department of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., was elected chairman of the New York section of the American Chemical Society at the annual meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A day-care center for thirty pre-school children in Sidney, N.Y., will be the first nursery to receive funds from a special appropriation of $100,000 for rent, repairs and equipment of centers, under the new provisions for the use of funds of the State War Council, it was reported yesterday by Miss Elsie Bond, chairman of the Child Care Division of the State War Council.

No amount of warning will make people plant their Victory gardens again this year unless they are convinced that they are really needed. They are and badly. One ton of food per year is the stockpile allotment for each soldier, and this quantity is doubled or trebled when he goes overseas.

Under the auspices of the Artists League of America, an auction of paintings, silk screen prints and black-and-white prints will be conducted tomorrow afternoon at the RoKo Gallery, 51 Greenwich Avenue, from 3 to 6 o'clock Proceeds from the sale will go to the Red Cross. Robert Gwathmey and Ladislas Segy will auction off the work.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The tax simplification bill, designed to relieve three-fifths of the country's individual income tax payers of the need to compute annual returns and to lessen greatly the task for the other two-fifths, was passed by the House today.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Eric A. Johnston of Spokane, Wash., was re-elected president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States for a third term today, the fourth man to serve beyond two terms.

The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association will present findings on readership habits for newspapers at an advertising clinic to be featured at the annual convention of the Proprietary Association of America at the Hotel Biltmore May 15-17.

An official Soviet investigating commission has issued a report charging German occupation forces with the "premeditated destruction of the ancient Russian town of Novgorod and its monuments of world renown, the mass killing of Soviet civilians and prisoners of war, and the deportation of Soviet citizens to slavery in Germany," the Russian Tass agency said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor reaffirmed today its willingness to readmit the United Mine Workers of America with the jurisdiction over coal miners which the union had when its connection with the federation was severed seven years ago.

After a quiet session, cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange finished yesterday 3 points higher to 2 points lower than on Thursday, with the market lacking a definite trend, and seemingly marking time pending developments in Washington and Europe.

The War Food Administration, which has just announced that more ice cream and milk sherbet will be available in May and June than had been expected, estimates that the extra quantity will amount to 15,000,000 gallons. Compared with what we have been receiving throughout the country as a whole this increase is slight, according to the Association of Ice Cream Manufacturers of New York.

I want to congratulate you for your calm, fair editorial on the Montgomery Ward situation. With one Chicago newspaper calling for impeachment of the President and many New York newspapers overly hysterical in their denunciation, it is refreshing to have a paper like yours preserve an equanimity in the matter.
PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (U.P.) -- Delegates to the conference of the International Labor Organization tonight elected a new governing body, to serve until the next regular session of the conference.

LONDON, May 5 (U.P.) -- Dis patches to Stockholm from Berlin said tonight that German military authorities were almost certain that the invasion of western Europe would start this month and the Germans seemed increasingly to fear that it would be timed with smashing blows along the Mediterranean.

The Dollar Savings Bank sold the three-story house for three families on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 2975 Briggs Avenue, in the Bronx, through Taylor Co. The bank also sold the one-family house on a lot 31.7 by 75 feet at 982 Jackson Avenue through J. William Johnson, broker, and the six-story apartment house containing three stores and twenty-seven suites on a plot 47 by 90 feet at 1367 Brook Avenue.

Production of sufficient lowprice cost-of-living apparel to take care of minimum consumer needs this year has become the No. 1 problem among the war agencies in Washington, according to industry observers yesterday. Pointing to growing aggravation among manufacturers as to unprofitable operations on these items and the shortage of materials and labor, they declare very little has been done to date to encourage output of critically needed merchandise.

A dramatic series of four battles against bacterial invaders that threatened to destroy a $500,000 Government war plant in Puerto Rico for the manufacture of butyl alcohol was described yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Society of American Bacteriologists.

While New York experienced yesterday its second successive day of heat unusual in May, snow fell in the Middle West. The highest temperature recorded by the Weather Bureau here was 82 degrees at 1:35 P.M., but in Chadron, Neb., and Mobridge, S.D., the thermometer stood at 18 and temperatures below freezing extended over Iowa, Nebraska, the Dakotas, Minnesota and most of Wisconsin and Upper Michigan, The Associated Press said.

RAHWAY, N.J., May 5 -- The housing problem of Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Compton and eleven of their twelve children, who were evicted yesterday afternoon from their one-room home at 938 St. George Avenue here, was solved temporarily this afternoon when police and welfare agencies made arrangements to quarter the Comptons in the Salvation Army Home at Newark until Mr. Compton can find another place.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, May 6 (AP) -- Netherland New Guinea soon may become a scene of major air combat in pre-invasion battles for the Philippines.

The unanimous passage in the House yesterday of the bill to simplify taxes will be welcomed by everyone. It is an excellent bill, which is expected to relieve some 30,000,000 persons of the need for making out an income-tax blank. Credit for its passage must be shared among the Treasury and both parties in Congress.

Marlin G. Geiger, a vice president and director of Westvaco Chlorine Products Corporation, and resident manager of that company's South Charleston plant, has been elected vice president and director of United Chemicals, Inc. He will continue as resident manager of Westvaco's South Charleston plant.

The proposed amendment to MPR 178, establishing dollar and cents "exemption levels" on fur garments was discussed yesterday by officials of the Office of Price Administration with representatives of the industry at the headquarters of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Liquor will receive the status of an essential civilian product eligible for a share of production and distribution just as soon as available supplies of alcohol for military and currently designated essential civilian uses reach a safe level, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told the Senate's special committee to investigate the liquor industry today.

The proposed amendment to MPR 178, establishing dollar and cents "exemption levels" on fur garments was discussed yesterday by officials of the Office of Price Administration with representatives of the industry at the headquarters of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc.

Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told the Senate's special committee to investigate the liquor industry today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Plans, for the formation of an international education organization to help reconstruct the school systems of occupied Europe and China and to raise educational standards in the post-war world were discussed here today by Representative J. William Fulbright, Arkansas Democrat, who was chairman of the American delegation to the Conference of Allied Ministers of Education at London.

Seven adjourned games of the United States chess championship tournament were played at the Manhattan Chess Club last night, but, at the close of play, Arnold S. Denker of Forest Hills was still in the lead, with his remarkable score of 14 1/2 points in fifteen games.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 6 -- Challenging critics who call the Republican party one of isolation, Booth Tarkington has written an open letter to all Republican candidates for Congress calling upon them for "frank and clear public statements" as to how they stand "upon the question of a permanent peace and what you will do when the attempt is made, as it will be, to take such measures as will best serve to prevent international wars."

LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- The incessant hammering of Europe by the Allies' bombers has already begun an invasion whose second phase will be opened by land operations, Britons were told today, while Germans heard from Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel that the invasion "must be reckoned as imminent."

Medical and surgical supplies needed as supplementary equipment by the armed forces of the United States and the Allies and by hospitals and war zone nurseries will be received as the only admission "fee" required for a cocktail dance to be given in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis on May 17 from 5 to 8 P.M.

IN the Congressional elections of 1942 the Republicans gained forty-seven seats in the House of Representatives and ten in the Senate. Since then, whenever a special election has been called to fill a seat vacated by death or resignation, the Republican candidates have been almost uniformly successful.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Nine Republican members of Congress from the West held a meeting here today to discuss the chaos which they say has been caused in the hog and corn markets by "arbitrary and ill-considered actions" of the War Food Administration and the Office of Price Administration.

Under current conditions, when many new brands are to be found in canned goods on grocers' shelves, grade labeling would be of inestimable aid to the consumer, according to Roger Wolcott, managing director of the National Consumer-Retailer Council, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (U.P.) -- Senator Wagner, Democrat of New York, has proposed an amendment to the price control extension bill which would make railroad wage decisions of the National Mediation Board final and not subject to review by Fred M. Vinson, Economic Stabilization Director.

Pointing to the similarity between its case and that of Montgomery Ward, J.S. Bache Co., yesterday filed an appeal with the National War Labor Board from the recent order of the regional WLB directing the company to sign an agreement with Local 20940 of the American Federation of Office Employes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 6 -- Protesting Government seizure of the properties of Montgomery, Ward Co. as a "deliberate purpose to substitute military force for normal methods of law enforcement through the courts," the Manufacturers Association of New Jersey today asked New Jersey Representatives in Congress to help enact legislation to prevent a recurrence.
The Golden Hill Chorus, under George Mead, gave its tenth anniversary concert last night at Town Hall. In the elaborate program presented the chorus was assisted by the Down Town Glee Club.

AS one who has squirmed quite often with embarrassment and chagrin at the sanctimonious ways in which the movies have represented clergymen, this writer is especially pleased this morning to be able to report a new film in which men of God are presented in a human and unaffected light.

METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER apparently is disregarding cost in the production of "The Ziegfeld Follies," which went before the cameras last week under a "ceilingless" budget. Studio executives expect that more than four million dollars (perhaps five) will have been expended on the picture before it reaches the screen.

LONDON, May 6 -- At the heart of the discussion begun this week in London between the Prime Ministers of five self-governing British nations lies a difference of conception that, it was agreed by all, would best be discussed now within the family than later in public controversy.
Plainclothes men attached to the West Fifty-fourth Street Police Station opened yesterday a spring drive on young bootblacks in the Times Square area and rounded up thirty-five of them.

DURING the renascence of American letters, beginning early in the century and running down to the present war, there were two great sources of new endeavor -- the South and the Midwest. Writers in the South wrote as if they expected to appear in the next collection of Southern letters, but writers from the Midwest -- at least, at the outset -- seemed to bristle at the very approach of the regional anthologist.

Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board; J.F. Brownlee, deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration in charge of prices, and Brig. Gem Albert J. Browning, director, Purchases Division, Army Service Forces, will be the principal speakers at the twenty-ninth annual international convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents May 29-31 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Edward James Smythe and Robert Noble, two of the twenty-nine alleged seditionists who are on trial, named jail inmates and "common political gossip" today as the sources for their allegation that the Roosevelt Administration had "conspired" in bringing them to trial.

The War Food Administration is planning no campaign for higher meat consumption to reduce the current surpluses. The agency's Washington representatives made its position clear yesterday when they voiced their surprise at New York City shortages of pork and lamb reported by the retail food trade.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- As a result of the censorship on communications between representatives of Allied and neutral Governments in London and other parts of the world, with the exception of those of the United States, Russia and the British nations, a substantial number of Washington diplomats are twiddling their thumbs and wondering when the war will be over.

WHEN Mrs. Carrie Giles finds a dead body in the shrubbery near her house she does not call the police because she has reason to believe that her grandson, Kent Giles, knows more than he should about the matter.
NAPLES, May 6 -- "We have made some mistakes and learned a lot of things," Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker said yesterday, opening a conference at air headquarters.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull in a letter made public today by Rep. John Lesinski of Michigan, said Father Orlemanski and Prof. Oscar Lange of the University of Chicago were in Russia at that country's request and had no official status with the United States Government.

LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- Allied plans for occupation of Germany and the full liquidation of Nazi control have almost been completed by the European Advisory Commission, with the possibility that final approval will be left to a new meeting of the "big three," it was disclosed today.

William P. Witherow, former president of the National Association of Manufacturers, sought yesterday to dispel the concern of American industry over any future industrialization of Latin America and the fears of businessmen south of the Rio Grande over any thoughts of "Yankee imperialism."

LONDON, Sunday, May 7 -- The Soviet High Command announced last night that Russian fleet and air units had sunk eight more Axis ships off Sevastopol in the Crimea, boosting to nineteen the number of transports and auxiliary vessels destroyed there in two days.

BY day Walter N. Greaza keeps office hours as assistant executive secretary of Actors Equity. By night, as Andrew Linnet, he loudly, if ineffectively rules the erratic family housed at the Cort Theatre in the season's unexpected success, "Wallflower."

CHICAGO, May 6 -- A ten-day temporary injunction issued in Federal Court April 27, restraining officials of Montgomery Ward Co. from interfering with Government operation of the Chicago properties was extended to Wednesday by Judge William H. Holly today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Breaking silence on the problem of what will be done with Italian prisoners of war now that Italy is a cobelligerent of the Allies, the War Department revealed today that the Italians were receiving an opportunity to volunteer for special service units, organized on a military basis, which will aid the American Army in any duties except actual combat.

CLEVELAND, May 6 (AP) -- Roy Cullenbine blasted relief hurler Sigmund Jakucki's first pitch over League Park's right-field screen to break an eighth inning 2-to-2 deadlock as the Indians gained a 3-to-2 victory over the league-leading Browns today in a delayed series opener.

The usual rush for graduation and evening dresses was heavier last week than in previous years, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. The week was also featured by the arrival of a considerable number of buyers to cover late summer and fall requirements.

MEXICO CITY, May 6 -- Foreign military observers were busy today drafting reports to their Governments on the degree of efficiency obtained by the Mexican Army after military maneuvers held in Puebla yesterday.

In connection with National Family Week, which begins today, Rabbi Israel Goldstein in a sermon yesterday in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway, declared that because of the wartime dislocation of family life, schools and churches must do much that formerly devolved upon parents in molding the character of children.
NAPLES, May 6 (AP) -- Gloom spread among the devout in many parts of Naples tonight, after the annual ceremony of "The Liquefaction of the Blood" was held without any sign of Divine manifestation.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, Ceylon, May 6 (AP) -- Pressing a general offensive in the Kohima area, British and Indian troops have knocked the Japanese invaders of northeast India out of a number of important positions and are continuing their advance, Allied headquarters announced today.

In the choppy, wind-whipped water of the Harlem the junior varsity shells of Navy and Columbia foundered yesterday and the only local college rowing regatta of the season came to an abrupt ending with Cornell the lone crew to finish.

NAPLES, May 6 -- Fifth Army GI's had no mint juleps and no blue grass here in Italy today, but they were distinctly Derby conscious on this Kentucky Derby day -- so Derby conscious, in fact, that they had their own bookmaker handle wagers of a quarter or two on their choices.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 (AP) -- The sun didn't shine bright on the old Kentucky Derby today. The weather was not favorable to the cool mint juleps, but the seventieth running of the great American race had much of the color of previous classics.

CONCORD, N. H. -- New Hampshire summer resorts are facing a less restricted vacation time. Last summer's ban on gasoline for motor boats has been lifted, and such hotels as Wentworth-by-the-Sea at Newcastle (closed for two seasons) are opening this year.

Bryan, assistant provost marshal general, United States Army, emphasized today the following policies which the Army follows in administering its Prisoner-of-War Division:
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador to Russia, has returned here on a short visit for "a current exchange of information," the Department of State announced tonight.

The Russian radio quoted an article from the Moscow newspaper Izvestia yesterday saying that the Bulgarian people were "beginning to see for themselves" that their rulers were "servants of Hitler, dragging Bulgaria into disaster."

For three years the British have stabilized their cost-of-living index at a level between 28 and 30 per cent above that in the pre-war period. This achievement was made possible by the combination of a heavy tax program, compulsory and voluntary savings, effective price fixing, extensive rationing of food products, complete control over supplies and comprehensive subsidy payments.

" MIDDLE AMERICA" includes Mexico, Central America (Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Panama) and Cuba, Haiti and the Dominican Republic. This convenient grouping, is, in itself, a clarifying device, enabling us to see our nearest southern neighbors as a compact whole.

WITH an eye for the timely, Decca is releasing an elaborate album of selections from the current Broadway show, Carmen Jones, the Oscar Hammerstein musical play based on Bizet's Carmen (album DA-366, six twelve-inch records).

Penicillin may have a rival in chlorellin, which is found in a green plant able to manufacture its own food out of natural raw materials. All previously discovered compounds of the type, including penicillin, are made by molds, soil bacteria, and other plants that have to be supplied with ready-made foods in the form of glucose solutions or the like.

Sweeping changes in the Emergency Price Control Act as it affects rents, including a proposed provision for a "fair return" to property owners and other safeguards "to remove rent control inequities" are being advocated by the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, it became known yesterday.

With unlimited demands for war materials, the nation's manufacturing production in 1943 rose far above that of any previous year in industrial history, rounding out the first year of total war work. Net sales of some ninety manufacturing groups far exceeded those of the previous year.

Big Ed Levy, all 6-feet-5-inches of him, and husky Bud Metheny collaborated in a popular victory tableau yesterday at the Stadium, as, before 10,957 fans, the Yankees turned back the Red Sox for their sixth victory in a row.

LONDON, May 6 -- While American and British bombers were stepping up their air offensive over occupied Europe this week, the overseas branch of the Office of War Information opened fire with a big new gun with the same immediate purpose, namely, to soften up the German defenses and help clear a path for the invasion.

RICHMOND, Va., May 6 -- Acute concern throughout the Upper South over a loss of thousands of public school teachers to private industry, where they can make two or three times the pay, is reflected this week in the anticipated call of a special session of the Kentucky Legislature and in the campaign addresses of the two Democratic candidates for Governor of North Carolina.

ANYONE to whom well-prepared snap beans are served at the table will find it impossible to distinguish from the flavor whether they are pole beans or bush beans, growing on plants which climb up several feet or stop at about eighteen inches.

MOSCOW, May 6 -- The Army newspaper Red Star gave great prominence today to an article by Alexander Yerusalimsky listing statements by British, French and American miltary leaders in 1918 to the effect that long, determined resistance had to be expected from the German Army, that the Allies should not be in too great a hurry to attack and that the war might go on until 1920.

ALGIERS, May 6 -- Having protested in vain against the British ban on communications in code to and from the United Kingdom, the French Committee of National Liberation decided today that the discussions between the Allies and the French on the administration of liberated areas of France could not be continued while that ban existed. Sex is immaterial. Already 7,000 pet dgs are enrolled in the British Army, and any

SINGLE plantings of pole beans will give continuous, abundant yield from mid-July until frost. No succession planting every two weeks is needed as with bush beans, no preparation of more ground, no shifting of garden space.

LONDON, May 6 -- England defeated Wales by 2 -- 0 in the football international and Aston Villa won the League North Cup from Blackpool, the defending champion, by around score of 5 -- 4, as England's fifth wartime soccer season ended.

Henry J. Kaiser, industrialist and shipbuilder, is scheduled to speak at the first city-wide campaign report luncheon of the Greater New York Fund Thursday in the Hotel Roosevelt. He will describe some of the methods that have been applied to the mass production of liberty and victory ships.

MR. WOODWARD appears before the reading public in a new role. In the present volume the creator of the word "debunk" is no longer concerned with pulling patriots off their pedestals, but rather with satisfying a "growing desire" to tell sympathetically how our people have lived at various times.

LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- Marshal Tito's Yugoslav forces killed more than 900 of the enemy yesterday in extensive operations topped by a strong new German tank and plane offensive in eastern Bosnia, a Partisan communique said today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Saving of almost 330,000,000 miles of travel as compared with 1941 was made during 1943 as the result of reductions by State Governments in automobile traffic, the Office of Price Administration stated today. New York State was not up in upper brackets on mileage saving, as reported by OPA, but New Jersey and Connecticut were.

LONDON, May 6 (U.P.) -- Allied headquarters in Naples announced today, according to word here, that American heavy bombers set new daylight operational records for the Mediterranean theatre Friday during attacks on Ploesti and Turnu Severin and a German troop garrison at Podgorica in Yugoslavia.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Amid jubilation over the removal of all meats, except beefsteaks and roast beef, from the ration lists, Central Westerners are finding time to appraise the national political outlook, with the dilemma of pre-war isolationists, now apparently without a suitable Presidential choice, arousing interest.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, May 7 (AP) -- Allied neutralization raids of New Guinea north coast sectors still in Japanese hands have been made from Hansa Bay to Sarmi, headquarters announced in today's communique.

THE annual quest of the Music Critics Circle of New York for outstanding new works introduced during the season is on. The circle has already nominated works for two concerts -- one orchestral and one chamber music -- from which the final choices will be made.

CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- Hogs sold today at steady quotations on the livestock market here, closing a week which saw prices decline to the lowest level in two years as receipts continued heavy and demand slumped. The top was $13.75 a hundredweight, the Government support price, on offerings weighing 200 to 270 pounds.

THE title of this book is somewhat misleading. A more accurate one would be "Manual of Aircraft Sheet Metal and Assembly Work," since no mention is made of wood airplanes, welding processes or machine work.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, May 6 -- Surrender of more than 150 Japanese in the Hollandia area is creating speculation as to whether the Japanese trapped in Wewak will surrender rather than fight on.

RECENT paintings by B.J.O. Nordfeldt, in his current show at Georgette Passedoit's Gallery, reveal that artist's strength and versatility to the full. Since the death of Marsden Hartley it is not too much to say that no other American artist paints with more power and sweep than Nordfeldt.
MOST, of us grew up on one or another version of "This Little Pig Went to Market," and "Pease porridge hot, Pease porridge cold," and "This Is the Way the Ladies Ride."

After getting off to a shaky start, Ralph Branca, New York University freshman right-hander, settled down and pitched the Violets to a 10-to-5 victory over Colgate yesterday at Ohio Field. The conquest was the fifth in seven starts this season for Branca, who was tapped for seven hits.
MOSCOW, May 6 (AP) -- The text of a statement made today by Father Orlemanski:

THE newest baby of the cosmetic industry is leg make-up. It is now a lusty, thriving infant, vastly different from that of the summer of 1942 when it made its real debut. Cosmetic chemists stress the great improvements in this summer's product which are the result of two years of testing and research.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 6 -- Between inspection of the western defenses of Europe, Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel is breeding rabbits, German propaganda says.

SAN FRACISCO, May 6 -- There has been a disposition on this coast for labor and management to forget their old differences, fight the war together and wait until peace comes before putting on unpadded gloves for a renewal of their spirited bouts.

CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- Lumbering around in the third base coaching box at Wrigley Field tomorrow, his voice booming encouragement across the Cubs' infield, will be the familiar figure of Charlie Grimm, the team's new manager.

For its annual theatre benefit the Protestant Welfare Federation is sponsoring performances of two popular plays -- "The Searching Wind," for the night of May 24 at the Fulton Theatre, and "Jacobowsky and the Colonel" on the night of June 8 at the Martin Beck Theatre.

BALTIMORE, May 6 -- Sun Again turned on a blazing burst of speed to score easily in the fortieth running of the Dixie Handicap at Pimlico today, gaining his third consecutive victory and the fifth 1944 Maryland stakes triumph for the Calumet Farm.

War or no war, the Bank for International Settlements will hold its fourteenth annual meeting on May 22 at its headquarters in Basle, Switzerland. What is more, representatives of the Allied Nations, although they be junior members, will attend the meeting, as well as banking representatives of the Axis Nations.

Emery Reves is right in "A Challenge to the Atlantic Charter." In this new world, made over by science and technology, absolute irresponsible national sovereignty is an explosive anacrhonism. Woodrow Wilson's principle of national self-determination led to a rash of economically and politically weak nationalisms in a more thoroughly Balkanized Europe, and to World War II.

MUSIC enters far more extensively than is generally realized into war activities as well as those of peace. There is an urgent demand for the art back of the lines as well as at the front which extends in this war over most of the habitable portions of the globe.

LONDON, May 6 -- Allied policy toward those countries which this summer's grand scale offensives are intended to liberate is in principle simple and completely straightforward. The pattern for it is plainly drawn in the treaty between the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia, which Andrey Vishinsky, Deputy Commissar for Foreign Affairs, announced on Monday.

Johnny Tripp had a double anniversary yesterday -- his sixty-fifth birthday and his forty-sixth anniversary with Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey Circus. Johnny observed both anniversaries in the sawdust arena of Madison Square Garden, cloaked in a blazing red uniform, doing his regular clown routines at both performances of the circus, and was rewarded with the laughter of the happy crowds.
Good weather aided retail trade here last week. Main floor, accessory and apparel departments were busy. Estimates put department store volume at about 10 per cent ahead of the like week last year.

In Hitler's Europe last week the explosion of demolition bombs, falling at the rate of two tons every minute of day and night, raining down on railroads, airfields, troop concentration points and coastal defenses, marked the quickening pace of Allied preparation for D-Day.

COMES now the season for placing bay leaves on the modest brows of people and programs, and as usual cheers and jeers rise in the pleasant vernal air. It is an old notion of this column that the awards, as such, seldom prove much but are worth while because they provoke a certain amount of discussion and therefore stimulate interest in the quality of radio, which needs it.

SOMETHING of a sequel to the current "Chicken Every Sunday," based on the Rosemary Taylor autobiography, probably will be seen on Broadway next season. Edward Gross, producer of "Chicken," has informed us of his acquisition of the dramatization rights to a story by Mrs. Taylor and her husband, Major Winchcomb Taylor.

PINE PLAINS, N.Y., May 6 (AP) -- Henry Sherwood, master of the State Grange, predicted today a falling off of farm production in New York this year, because, he said, farmers were 'confused" by the labor situation.

Graduate schools throughout the country, in an unprecedented decline as a result of the war, now maintain a student body of approximately 30,000, compared to a normal enrollment of 100,000 prior to Pearl Harbor. Graduate students number 4 per cent of the total college attendance, instead of the 7 per cent found in 1939-40.

NEW DELHI, India, May 6 (AP) -- Widespread satisfaction greeted the release today of Mohandas K. Gandhi, Indian Nationalist leader detained for twenty-one months as a political prisoner in Aga Khan's summer palace in Poona, but intimates feared it marked a new crisis in the illness of the frail disciple of India's masses.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- A hands-off attitude toward the administrations to be set up by the United Nations for Germany and the other totalitarian countries of Europe was adopted by a special subcommittee of the International Labor Conference today in a tumultuous session, with the absence of Russian representation acting as a factor in the decision.

LONDON, May 6 -- One of the gravest political matters before the Dominion Prime Ministers conference is the extent to which they can commit their countries to any policy of post-war occupation of Germany and police work in any future world security organization.

The National Jewish Hospital at Denver stands as "an American beacon of mercy, a haven of refuge where the tubercular poor, regardless of creed, may find renewed health and new hope," Reagan P. Connally, president of Interstate Department Stores, declared last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria marking the forty-fifth anniversary of the hospital.

VICTORY gardeners are asked to produce 10,000,000 tons of fruits and vegetables in 1944, according to the Office of War Information. This vast amount is needed in view of increasing demands from the armed forces, lend-lease, Red Cross, and so on. In fact, the over-all requirements for this year are greater than they have ever been, which means that every family able to do so must preserve food at home.

This pre-invasion battering of the Luftwaffe and Nazi communications far behind the outer ramparts of Hitler's Fortress Europe has already placed a terrific burden upon the RAF and the United States Strategic Air Force in Europe, but the climax has not yet been reached.

Should the rebid be two spades or a raise to three hearts? Some advise bidding two spades, reserving the three-heart raise (which is a more encouraging rebid) for stronger hands.

DETROIT, May 6 -- Six months ago the problems of reconverting the automobile industry from a war to a peace economy began to trouble leaders of the industry in the Detroit area as their plants began to reach the top limit of war output.

AN exhibition of unique books, pamphlets and broadsides is currently on display at the Grolier Club, 47 East Sixtieth Street, and will continue until May 10. Considering that the collection is drawn wholly from the libraries of the members of the club it is an impressive and exciting show.

The Solid South had apparently decided last week to remain solid in its Democratic loyalty and to forget the talk of anti-fourth term revolt and anti-New Dealers. That was the conclusion being read into the election returns from Alabama and Florida primaries.

THE radio world, never given to prolonged quiet, burst forth last week with as lively and complicated an argument as it ever had. The topic under debate was when and under what standards post-war television should make its bow.

In the last year, the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division completed fifty-three major conversions of vessels into Army and Navy fleet auxiliaries, in addition to constructing 380 ocean-going fighting and cargo ships, it was disclosed yesterday.

THE recent season of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center was definitely a financial success, having taken in something in excess of $90,000 in three weeks, with the highest-priced tickets costing only $2 plus tax.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (U.P.) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce prepared tonight to sound out its members on a series of resolutions, including one demanding that the Government stay out of the oil business, but support private enterprise in foreign petroleum projects.

To assure the discovery and efficient use of petroleum, the Standard Oil Company (N.J.) proposed yesterday that the United States and Great Britain, the leading oil finders and producers, adopt a "comprehensive and enlightened world oil policy."

Total war production has reached a leveling-off period, "with red lights flashing on many schedules," according to Lawrence A. Appley, executive director of the War Manpower Commission. He declared yesterday that the next phase in the manpower picture would be a "partial demobilization."

OMAHA, Neb., May 6 -- Woodrow Wilson's phrase, "Watchful waiting," has acquired new meaning in these farm States as people have stood by expecting momentarily to learn that D-Day has dawned. There is a tension to this kind of waiting that is quite without its parallel on the eve of other anticipated events.

WHAT lends this refugee story a special quality is the personality of the author. Margaret Vail is an American woman who found herself on her own with a baby girl in fallen France, her French husband a prisoner of war, and her fate in that dreadful year, to say nothing of the fate of her child, depending entirely on her wit, her ability to improvise and her courage.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 6 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Surgeon General Thomas Parran and Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, administrator of the Federal Works Agency, were speakers this afternoon at the dedication of two dormitories to house 200 of the 308 students of the United States Cadet Nurse Corps of Adelphi College here.

CLEVELAND, May 6 -- Bulk freighters that have been hauling grain since the opening of the season have been ordered into the ore trade by the Office of Defense Transportation and the ruling insures a minimum movement of 11,000,000 tons of the raw mineral this month, shippers said today.
