Although touched for eleven blows, Herm Neuberger tightened sufficiently in the clutches as he pitched and batted C. C. N. Y. to an easy 13-5 victory over Brooklyn College yesterday in a Metropolitan Conference game on the Kingsmen's diamond.

RELIGIOUS cults such as Father Divine's Movement, the "Black Jews" and the sect led by the self-named and self-anointed "Bishop Grace" have been growing in importance in Northern cities. That they have made such headway among largely unassimilated Negro migrants is the subject of a valuable study published by the Philadelphia Anthropological Society.

ALL over the country today people are dreaming of the new homes they will build after current restrictions are lifted. To help them translate their wartime daydreams into concrete plans for saving and building a series of organized home-planning projects have sprung up simultaneously from New York to California.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $751,364,040 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on April 29 was $32.59, compared with $33.12 at the end of March.
I have read with great apprehension your editorial of April 29 "India Stands Fast."
SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 6 (AP) -- A communique:

NEW ORLEANS, May 6 -- Seizure of the Montgomery Ward Co. plant in Chicago has crystallized sentiment in the Deep South against Government seizure and control, even during wartimes, of private enterprises. Seldom has this section of the country been more aroused than it is at present over the action of the Government in forcibly taking over this concern.

LOUISVILLE, May 6 (AP) -- Little Conn McCreary figured last Monday at Pimlico that Pensive would win today's Kentucky Derby and he asked to go along for the ride. That's all he had to do to win -- just ride.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The tax simplification bill passed unanimously by the House yesterday repeals the Victory Tax and sets up a new system of normal and surtaxes which may be computed as follows:

Termination of the war with Germany which might result from a successful invasion of continental Europe in the next few months will not loosen the civilian supply of cotton textiles to any great extent, according to Worth Street textile men yesterday.

The contribution of Memorial Hospital to cancer treatment and research throughout the world was praised yesterday by leaders in Government and surgery at a celebration of the sixtieth anniversary of the institution at Sixty-eighth Street and York Avenue.

NANCY MARTIN, who regularly lifts her voice in song on behalf of the Blue network, might still be teaching eighth grade in the Hatfield-McCoy feudin' country of West Virginia if she hadn't been afraid of her students.

FIVE floors up, mighty near the ceiling of the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, Pvt. Herman Kantor and a squad of G.I. electricians manipulate the huge switchboards that feed the juice for the lighting effects for "Winged Victory." Kantor used to be the stage manager at Radio City Music Hall.

PEARL HARBOR, May 6 (AP) -- Seventh Army Air Force Liberators dropped eighty-seven tons of bombs on Ponape island Thursday, three days after that explosion-battered satellite of Truk had been raked by a protracted battleship shelling, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

ANY reader who may have imagined -- as any reader might be forgiven for doing -- that English novelists have somehow lost the trick of telling a story will have James Ronald to reckon with henceforward. "The Night Is Ending" partakes of the vast energy and invention which are in the classic tradition of the English novel.

FIGURES that have now come through on retail trade in April disclose that the expected setback failed to materialize and a small gain was accomplished in the month. Earlier predictions took account of the variation in the date of Easter and indicated that sales might fall under those of last year.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., had combined consolidated earnings of $16,140,821 for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 1 after all charges, including taxes and $2,000,000 additional reserve for contingencies, Barney Balaban, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

From the Polaroid laboratories came last week an announcement of the highest medical importance. Dr. Robert B. Woodward (Harvard) and Dr. William E. Doering (Columbia) have synthesized quinine and solved a problem that has baffled chemists for nearly a century.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 6 -- Conditions in Bolivia are rapidly leading up to a state of chaos, according to a report published here today by the Hora newspaper from its correspondent in Arica. The correspondent reported holding interviews with deported Bolivian leaders and travelers in Chile's northernmost port.
ROCHESTER. SIX new compositions were given for the first time anywhere at the recent fourteenth annual Festival of American Music of the Eastman School of Music, University of Rochester.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (U.P.) -- Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, said tonight that he favored immediate resumption of the manufacture of civilian goods -- but only in cases where use of facilities, materials and labor would not affect the output of munitions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 6 -- As D-day draws closer the war of nerves is reaching its point of culmination, and from the Nazi side this week came Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels' contribution to it -- dark hints about the unpleasant surprises allegedly in store for the Allied invasion troops.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, May 7 (AP) -- A communique:

THE last twenty pages of our copy of Charles Michelson's book, "The Ghost Talks," are missing. Whether this can be laid to the paper shortage or whether the fellow who turned out this particular volume was too discouraged to carry on, we don't know.

The Pantagon -- also variously known as the "Hellangon" (because of its distance from Washington), "Washington's Mammoth Cave," the "Pantygone" (because "you walk your pants off in it") and lots more -- marked its second birthday last week.

At last week's exercises in commemoration of the 125th anniversary of the University of Cincinnati the principal address was delivered by Dr. Tom D. Spies, noted for his clinical researches in pellagra and other diseases caused by a deficiency of some vitamin. He gave his hearers not only a summary of what bad eating habits can do to any man or woman but also the cure.
BOSTON, May 6 -- The downward plunge of the Giants from their once lofty position in the National League's 1944 flag race apparently is only beginning to gain full momentum.

MONTREAL, May 6 (AP) -- A home run by Chuck Stevens in the eighth inning with one on base enabled the Montreal Royals to win from the Newark Bears today, 11 -- 10. Stevens also hit a home run in the fifth with two on to drive in a total of five runs.

Horace M. (Harry) Harrison, for more than forty years the officials "ship spotter" for this harbor, has returned to the retirement from which the war had summoned him. In 1938, after having completed forty years of service he climbed down from his observation tower at the Quarantine Station at Rosebank, S.I.

I AM very glad indeed that I, speaking on behalf of the British Army, should have this opportunity of paying tribute to the American Army. You know it wasn't always like that, and 170 years ago we made a sad hash of our relations.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose yesterday to the best Saturday figure in a month but stocks moved irregularly and closed without disclosing a trend. The final prices were mixed.

Well intentioned tax legislation sometimes proves to be complex and obscure after its enactment. Such a law was enacted on April 1 by the State of New York as Chapter 510 of the Laws of 1944, dealing with the treatment of excessive profits from renegotiation of war contracts for State tax purposes.

Brig. Gen. Edward R. Kerby Sr., USA, who had been on duty in the South Pacific for the last three years, was killed in action on April 29, it was learned yesterday through his son, Ensign Edward R. Kerby Jr., of the Merchant Marine, honorably discharged for medical reasons.

BOSTON, May 6 -- New England housewives reacted cautiously to the biggest home front news of the week -- the removal of many meats from the ration list. Anticipated buying rushes failed to materialize, butchers stated, wondering whether large surplus stocks on hand would move readily.

A new organization of war veterans, dedicated to liberal ideas at home and a post-war internationalism to preserve the peace, is being formed by men and women taking part in the present war, it was revealed yesterday by Ensign William Burke, who addressed the annual convention of the United States Student Assembly.

ABOARD A CARRIER FLAGSHIP IN THE CAROLINES, May 1 (Delayed) -- Powerful guns of the newest American battleships and cruisers brought to a climax today a three-day attack on Japanese bases in the Carolines.

NAPLES, May 6 -- Implying that an early Allied attack might be expected in Italy, Maj. Gen. John K. Cannon announced today that the Tactical Air Force had knocked out all Italian railway yards below Florence and, "when large-scale fighting resumes, the enemy's reserves will soon be exhausted."

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Allied invasion of Europe, Chairman Cannon of the House Appropriations Committee declared today, holds the answer to whether Congressional appropriations will begin to decline.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP) -- The Cardinals, opening their first long stand at home, were shut out by the challenging Reds today, 2 to 0, and yielded their National League lead to the visitors on Bucky Walters' four-hit pitching.

Acting on "widespread complaints" from prospective tenants that they were charged anywhere from $10 to $100 for the privilege of moving into a vacant apartment, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, warned landlords and agents yesterday that it was illegal for them to accept bonuses for renting flats.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- General liquidation developed today in May rye on the Board of Trade and the price broke 2 5/8 cents a bushel, more than wiping out an advance made early in the week. The selling was accompanied by reports that a large holding of rye owned by a food concern had been sold to an elevator interest, with intimations that the grain would be delivered on May contracts.

SOMERSET MAUGHAM, in one of his mellow Saturday Evening Post moments, has said that most English humor depends on irony, most American humor on exaggeration. The pages of "A Treasury of American Folklore," coming from Crown publishers on May 15, offers abundant testimony on this point.

Arnold S. Denker extended his undefeated record in the United States chess championship event at the Hotel Park Central yesterday by drawing with Herman Steiner of Los Angeles in the sixteenth round. The half point thus gained gave him a total score of 15 -- 1 and placed him in a strong position for the final round today, when he meets Benjamin Altman of Flushing.

LONDON, May 6 -- So many hopes and fears are wrapped up in the Anglo-American opening of a second front that the part the first front in the east will play in the final campaigns in Europe has been overlooked.

THE Coordinating Council for French Relief Societies' "Jardin d'Ete" may stand as a symbol for the week's profusion, and, within the realm of fruits and vegetables to which it is confined, for the week's variety also -- an opulent spring salad.

DETROIT, May 6 (AP) -- The White Sox, blanked for twenty innings by Detroit pitching this season, exploded for four runs in the ninth inning today to defeat the Tigers, 4 to 2, thus dropping Detroit deeper into the American League cellar.

THIS little tone poem of the air reaches the ear of all of us. Some will have the faith to enter into the fullness of its meaning at a time when hearts are heavy with foreboding. All will be impressed by a prelate who is able to divest himself of his robes, commune with his inner self and mingle freely with his fellow-men.
Many buyers representing stores all over the country will begin to arrive in the wholesale markets here during the next two weeks to place fall orders.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 6 -- A criticism voiced by many soldiers returning from battlefronts is that the civilian population of the United States does not take the war seriously enough.

THE current interest in American nineteenth and early twentieth century painting should be further enhanced by two of the new group shows. The Babcock Gallery has opened one which ranges from Eakins, Homer and Ryder to Luks, Lawson and Bellows, with excellent representation of a score of well-known artists.

Declaring that the American people "are madder than the proverbial 'wet hen'" at Government seizure of the Montgomery Ward plant, Representative Winifred C. Stanley of New York reported yesterday that New York State voters by the thousands had sent telegrams and letters to Washington protesting the action.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Surplus commodities held by the Government and in new condition, except food and commodities originally purchased for resale, may be sold by any Government agency at a ceiling price not exceeding cost of acquisition, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

Denial of deferments for pre-theological students as of July 1, recently announced by Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, National Selective Service director, has met with opposition from the Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive director of the National Lutheran Council it became known yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., May 6 -- One of the most popular show dogs in present-day competition added further laurels to his many triumphs of the recent past in the final event of the annual all-breed fixture of the Delaware Valley Kennel Club, held on the grounds of the 112th Field Artillery today.

ALBANY, May 6 -- Edward W. Scully, Special Assistant Attorney General in charge of the investigation of bribery of the State Police, formally ended his inquiry today with a report that, while the bribery was "extensive and involved many truck owners," the evidence had disclosed that only one trooper was directly involved.

SINCE 1777, when Maurice Morgann published his "Essay on the Dramatic Character of Sir John Falstaff," the criticism of Shakespeare's greatest history play. "Henry IV," has labored in the toils of the fallacies Morgann propounded.

MIGNONETTE was once grown mainly for its fragrance, but during recent years hybridizers have improved the formerly unimpressive blossoms. Today we may enjoy larger flowers as well as the delicious perfume.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -- The Senators blanked the Athletics, 5 -- 0, today, with Milt Haefner, southpaw knuckle baller, limiting Philadelphia to four hits. Stan Spence, whose home run had licked the A's yesterday, drove another, with two on base.

IT is a strange thing that there should be a perpetual mild feud between people who are fond of cats and those who are fond of dogs. In a bluff, off-hand manner, aficionados of dogs take it for granted that their pets are far, far superior to cats.

LONDON, April 1 (Delayed). GABRIEL PASCAL, to whom George Bernard Shaw has entrusted his motion picture destiny, is ready now to start shooting on "Caesar and Cleopatra" at Denham, and is waiting for Claude Rains' arrival from Hollywood to set the exact date.

German steel production, which may have been cut by as much as 50 per cent by bombings and manpower shortages, is due for still ther reductions in both quantity and quality, according to an Associated Press survey.

LONDON, May 6 (U.P.) -- The British Commonwealth of Nations appears to be prepared to emerge from the war with the greatest active unanimity of purpose that it has ever achieved, if the results of the first week of the Empire conference set an accepted pattern for the future.

Members of the Association of Reform Rabbis will not only take part in prayer services when the announcement of the invasion comes, but will begin now, at every service, with a special prayer for the Allied men and armies, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel announced yesterday in his capacity as president of the association.

The papers run a picture of an English boy of 5 who has known no home but a cave deep in the white cliffs of Dover, out of reach of the German shells from Calais. We are not going to weep over the little chap. Think of the sights he can see from the door of his hideaway; the gleaming airmadas streaming, hour after hour, overhead.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Nine internment camps for persons moved from the West Coast, including both Japanese aliens and citizens of Japanese extraction, have been sending forth dribbles of internees who now approach a total of 22,000.

Hal Gregg, 22-year-old Dodger fireball pitcher, knocked on the door of baseball's hall of fame for six and one-third innings yesterday at Ebbet's Field only to have it slammed in his face when Ted Cieslak, the ex-service man who plays third base for the Phillies, got the first hit on a pop fly to center field.

The national Commissions of Inter-American Development, corresponding to the countries that form the Pan American Union, will hold their first conference "to chart a course for further practical and mutually beneficial use of hemisphere resources" at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel beginning on Tuesday and extending through May 18, it was announced yesterday.

A MAN whose workaday fortunes are geared to the rise or fall of Adolf Hitler could well be bucking an occupational hazard. A case in point is Robert Watson, who plays the title role in "The Hitler Gang." Through applied odiousness he has gained a cinema stature, the loftiness or durability of which only time and the human equation will solve.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, May 6 -- The single dominant factor in the life of the Allies' beachhead here -- a twenty-four-hour vulnerability to shells and bombs -- applies just as much to the hospitals as to the front-line installations.

Passenger ships will again cruise the Great Lakes this summer. Among those scheduled for June sailings are the S.S. North American and the S.S. South American of the Georgian Bay Line, leaving Chicago and Buffalo, respectively, on June 17.

The United States Military Academy at West Point observes today the 150th anniversary of the passage of a Congressional act creating the grade of cadet in the Army. That act was the real beginning of the West Point of the present, though the act creating the Academy itself had to wait eight years.

Behind the lines in Italy last week the Allied armies, according to reports, were moving into position for a new all-out offensive which would probably coincide with invasion of Europe from the west and Red Army drives from the east. The German radio chattered the same reports.

Treble damage actions voluntary contributions and other fines collected by the Office of Price Administration from September, 1943, through April, 1944, for price ceiling violations have resulted in settlements amounting to $2,272,155, Regional Director Daniel P. Woolley disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, May 6 -- Sir Samuel Hoare, British Ambassador to

TO those of us who have suffered vicariously the long journey from Double Eagle to Red Flag through a spate of Russian Revolution-born novels, this book offers a revelation of tranquillity. Its author draws no color line in her picture of post-revolution Petrograd.

There was a time when Germany thought that her U-boats would win the war. Happily for us that time seems definitely to have passed. We never placed an equal dependence on our own submarines; but in the Pacific they are proving a more effective weapon than even the most optimistic dared to hope.

The mass production of inexpensive concrete houses which are fire, weather and vermin proof has now been made possible, after thirty-five years of research, as the result of a contract between Yale University and the War Production Board.

THERE are, according to Mr. Heard, three levels of prayer. The first is the egocentric level in which the self seeks to bend divine and ultimate forces to its purpose. In its simplest form this level of prayer is an expression of magic rather than religion.

DR. HALVDAN KOHT, Professor of Norwegian History at the University of Oslo, was Minister of Affairs in Norway's Labor Government from 1935-1941 -- that is, during the rise of the German menace and the invasion of Norway.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The income tax simplification bill passed by the House will be reported out by the Finance Committee of the Senate in practically the same form, Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, and chairman of the committee, stated at a press conference today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 -- Pensive, the horse that almost didn't get to the Kentucky Derby, struck from behind in the final eighth of a mile today to win the seventieth and richest of all Derbies at Churchill Downs in the silks of Warren Wright's Calumet Farm.

The meeting of British Dominion Prime Ministers in London has again directed attention to the nature and construction of what Mr. Churchill has designated as the "British Empire and Commonwealth." A constant object of envy or attack, it has weathered all vicissitudes and survived every crisis, including, it is now assured, the latest and gravest crisis in its existence -- the present war.

Urging the drafting of President Roosevelt for another term, the State executive committee of the American Labor party adopted yesterday a national platform, calling for participation of the United States in an international organization to maintain peace and promote trade and the formation of a permanent National Planning Board to prepare a program to insure full employment after the war.

FOR a number of desperate years Broadway looked upon the Pulitzer committee as a particularly large mountain, whose labors resulted in a train of minute models of tiny mice. As the prizes came down from Morningside Heights on the first Monday of each May they were greeted by the thinking people of Times Square with howls of rage and a feeling of personal affront.

Allow me to protest the injustice done the South in C.P. Trussell's report from Washington on the poll-tax issue in THE TIMES of April 16. The injustice is quite too commonplace in the press generally and results from the readiness of correspondents -- and of editorial writers -- to accept the voices of some Southern Congressmen, particularly Senators, as the voice of the South.

Accused by the police of possessing two home-made .22 caliber rifles, a large butcher knife, a heavy metal club and a sawed-off rifle, eight boys ranging from 16 to 18 years old, were each held in $7,500 bail for a hearing next Wednesday, when arrainged yesterday before Magistrate Raphael M. Koenig in the Felony Court on charges of violation of the Sullivan law.

A GARDEN above ground is a far different proposition from terra firma gardening, as many city dwellers who are now eagerly considering the possibilities will confirm. Those fortunate enough to possess terrace or roof space, however restricted, can create a garden of charm and interest, and a place for relaxation.
MANY years ago, before the first World War, E. Boyd Smith made his first picture books for children. Ever since then his books have been cherished and returned to again and again by young and old.

WHEN Martha Graham gets her eight-day repertory season under way at the National Theatre tonight, it will be the first time since the days of Anna Pavlova twenty years ago that a dance company built around a single star has undertaken so extensive an engagement.

Fifty years ago a group of women led by Mrs. Solomon R. Guggenheim opened a day nursery in two small room on Sheriff Street on New York's lower East Side and welcomed its first child -- an 11-day-old baby of a working mother.
WHEN some old-fashioned characters and their love affairs get mixed up with an oil boom, the start of a new State and the ever-continuing Civil War, the result is bound to be a confused melodrama.

CHUNGKING, China, May 6 (U.P.) -- Two mechanized Japanese columns were reported battering at the gates of Loyang in west-central Honan Province tonight and front dispatches indicated that the city, headquatrers of the Chinese Army in that province, may already have fallen to the invaders.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- With penicillin made available for limited civilian use, the War Production Board made public today, for the guidance of physicians, a summary of a survey on the use of the drug.
More than 1,000 Americans have been interned in Swiss and Swedish resort hotels as crew members of United States bombers forced down in neutral territory, The United Press reports.
KANSAS CITY, May 6 (AP) -- The General Conference of the Methodist Church adjourned today, finishing in ten days procedure which normally takes at least twenty-one.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A revised blacklist of pro-Axis firms with which trading will not be permitted was issued today by the State Department and contained for the first time the names of companies and individuals in Eire. Thirty-eight such firms and individuals were listed. had Italian names such as Berni's Cafe and Restaurant. Nearly all were in Dublin.

Dr. J.E. Markee, professor in the Duke University School of Medicine, is transplanting bits of organic tissue into the eyes of animals with every prospect of obtaining information urgently needed to develop better methods for treating disease. His technique is based on the discovery that tissue from another part of the body will retain its original characteristics when transplanted into the eye.
Mrs. A. Wentworth Erickson Boston has returned from Nassau, the Bahamas, and is at the Savoy-Plaza.

PLAIN obstinacy is the trait that leads John Letherton into the strange adventures recorded in this book. By nature he is a dreamer rather than a man of action, but he finds, to his own astonishment, that when strangers tell him where he must not go their opposition makes him all the more determined.

LIEUT. GEN. OMAR NELSON BRADLEY, who will command the American ground forces in the coming invasion of Europe, is a soldier "made in America" -- a man who, were it not for three silver stars on his shoulders, would be outwardly indistinguishable from the millions of other Americans who live in the great heartland of the Missouri and Mississippi Valleys.

FOR her latest novel Margaret Mackay has chosen a timely subject which a good many people are probably thinking about these days. It is the difficult problem caused by the necessary separation of married couples in wartime.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 -- A new jurisdictional dispute between two American Federation of Labor unions delayed construction and repair work at the General Engineering and Dry Dock Company's shipyard in Alameda today, while the Bay Area awaited possible intervention by President Roosevelt in a wage controversy which has prevented completion of two dry-docked Navy vessels in San Francisco and Oakland yards this week.

The annual report of the Seaman's Church Institute of New York, made public on Friday by the Rev. Dr. Harold H. Kelley, the director, disclosed that last year 366,864 lodgings and 1,193,630 meals were provided for active merchant seamen of all nationalities and creeds at the institute's headquarters, 25 South Street.
CHICAGO, May 6 -- A new type of torpedo known as the "Mark 15" for use by destroyers is in production and is expected to play an important part in Pacific battles against Japan.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for $3,564,316,000 for foreign economic operations in the year ending June 30, 1945. Of the total, $3,450,570,000 would be a direct lend-lease appropriation.

Only slight changes were registered yesterday in cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange as trading remained rather light, reflecting a slow demand for spot cotton and continued apathy on the part of mills to contract ahead more than about two months. Final prices were 2 points higher to 1 point lower than on Friday.

Mrs. George E. Ruppert will give a reception this afternoon at her home, 1115 Fifth Avenue, for Mrs. Hugh A. Drum, Mrs. George Grunert and Mrs. Thomas A. Terry, members of the sponsoring committee for the auction in aid of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy to be held early next month at the Plaza Art Galleries.

Joseph Mayer, a well-known New York business man who retired from the retail field in 1939 to devote himself to writing, is the author of a book, "The Impolite Mirror," published last week. It is a collection of original aphorisms, epigrams and reflections.

Brown thrashers are back in our woods again, acting as though they owned them, and towhees are flitting through the underbrush and scratching in the leaves. It's May, all right, and the chorus of warblers is beginning. Some of them are already flitting past the casual observer, and there must be many more that are not so bold, for the mornings are full of song.

The "vacillating tactics" of the House Ways and Means Committee in delaying action on the Knutson resolution reducing the Federal cabaret tax from 30 per cent to 10 has already cost 15,000 performers their jobs, Matt Shelvey, national director of the American Guild of Variety Artists, declared last night.

An extensive radio program, to supplement the regular classroom work of the teacher, has been inaugurated in the Chicago public schools. The programs are in many instances closely geared to the courses of study as set up by the Bureau of Curriculum.

Wilson College students of French who wish to aid in the reconstruction of France are studying the essentials of such a task in a course that stresses understanding of the average French family's post-war problems. The Wilsonians are learning everything from basic principles of nutrition to correct terms of farming machinery.
Horses came into their own on Jamaica's closing program yesterday when Mrs. Ed Mulrenan's First Fiddle equaled a 20-year-old track record to win the $15,000 added Grey Lag Handicap.

Opening the four-day triennial convention of B'nai B'rith at the Hotel New Yorker last night, Henry Monsky of Omaha, Neb., its president, reported that the organization had spent $1,000,000 on war service activities in addition to contributions of $200,000 toward its national war service projects.

NEWARK, N.J., May 6 -- Six agents of the Treasury Department, accompanied by three Newark detectives, seized this afternoon an alcohol still with a daily capacity of 1,000 gallons and equipment they valued at $50,000 after forcing their way into a three-story extension in the rear of a building at 82 Congress Street here.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The National War Labor Board was confronted today with a labor defiance case close upon the heels of the Montgomery Ward case, in which management defied the board, and it began to move toward plant seizure.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Details of the Army's new Information and Historical Service, which the Army likens to a "metropolitan newspaper" set up to gather and disseminate facts about ground troops at the front, were disclosed by the War Department.

THE possessive woman -- wife or mother -- is no stranger to fiction, but the war has added quirks to the problem she presents. She is as much of a menace as ever, but the menace takes new forms -- witness the heroine of "These Are the Times."

HOTCAPS are becoming increasingly popular devices for protecting any early crops from frost and wind, and especially the seeds that could not otherwise be started until the weather is really warm. They also give protection early in the season against the ravages of insect enemies.
A proposed twenty-four-word amendment to the Constitution is now stirring widespread debate. The amendment, now before Congress, reads:
IN this symposium my part is only to sit in silence. To express one's feelings as the end draws near is too intimate a task.

LONDON, Sunday, May 7 (U.P.) -- The regular German war bulletin reported Saturday that the Russians had thrown powerful forces of infantry, artillery and warplanes against Sevastopol. It said that the Russian assault, the first major one since the Red Army had thrown a twenty-one-mile-siege arc halfway around the city on April 18, had been preceded by a violent artillery barrage and attacks by warplanes swooping in on the Nazi positions "in consecutive waves."

DANVILLE, Va., May 6 -- The Virginia State Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today was on record in a resolution condemning the remarks of service men who at a recent State convention of the labor organization said there was no time and a half for hours spent in foxholes and no absenteeism from battle on account of headaches.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 6 -- The miracles of war production, brought about by management and labor were praised in a report submitted today to the thirty-second annual meeting of the Manufacturers Association of New Jersey. The report was made by Michael J. Hickey, assistant secretary.

DURING the first World War Winston Churchill wrote an article for a London publication in which he stated that if England failed to make the fullest use of the services of a Dominion statesman who had just arrived there, she deserved to go under.

A big eighth inning which netted four runs enabled the Columbia baseball team to down Pennsylvania in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at Baker Field yesterday. The four-run inning saw the Lions break a 3-3 tie and go ahead by 7 to 3, a score they retained until the end of the proceedings.

It was listed as the third annual P.S.A.L. Relay Carnival, but the one-mile run, open to all schools, captured the spotlight at Randalls Island yesterday, as William McGuire of George Washington took the measure of New Utrecht's Walter Soltow in 4:37.9. Armand Osterberg of Stuyvesant was third.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- More than a quarter century ago, in the midst of another world war, Charles Evans Hughes pointed out the way in which Congressional legislation greatly augments the wartime powers of a President, outside of his broad authority as Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Thirteen United States generals, eight flag officers of the Navy and two Marine generals have been killed, become missing or died during operations directly related to the war. Four are listed as killed in action and six are carried on the missing list.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Dates for hearings on the Bailey-Brewster bill to freeze 18-to-45-year-old workers who have been rejected for military service in their war jobs will be set by the Senate's Military Affairs Committee at a meeeting Tuesday.

MOUNTING public interest in television and its controversies has prompted an unprecedented interest in the engineering aspects of the current and future video art. A report of progress in this line, submitted to but not yet approved by the main Radio Technical Planning Board, came to light here recently.

The annual spring bridge benefit for the Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys at Millington, N.J., will take place on May 24. Invitations have been sent by local hostesses to prospective guests in many communities throughout northern New Jersey.

ONE of the constructive results of the college training of soldier students may well be a permanent stimulation of interest in geography, with special emphasis on the economic aspects of this subject. The book under review is a reflection of this interest.

LONDON, Sunday, May 7 -- While Hitler's Atlantic wall suffered from Allied air attack on only a restricted scale yesterday because of weather conditions, his southeastern defense lines received one of the severest poundings of the war when United States heavy bombers operating from Italy blasted five railway targets in Rumania northwest and west of Bucharest.

MOSCOW, May 6 -- Summing up his twelve-day visit to the Soviet Union as he departed for the United States, the Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski, pro-Soviet priest of Springfield, Mass., said today that he had found Premier Joseph Stalin friendly toward the Roman Catholic Church, and predicted that Poland would retain her religion after her liberation.

IT is high time what has now happened should have happened. A "commercial" publisher, presumably interested in the dissemination of his product, has taken on the Selected Poems of Robert Penn Warren, one of the important poets of our generation.

This year's Pulitzer award to THE NEW YORK TIMES for its survey on American history is particularly gratifying inasmuch as many of the recommendations made in the study have been adopted by educational leaders. Reports from various sections of the country indicate that interest in American history is greater now than it has ever been in the past.

BRITAIN as a base for invasion is bracing herself to become a battlefield. Neither the Allied Supreme Command nor the people of Britain regard the great assault on Europe as strictly a one-way affair. On the contrary. Engaged in the vital and difficult but fascinating task which confronts every commander of a big army in war -- to study the enemy -- General Eisenhower has had to anticipate Hitler's answer to invasion.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Thirteen months, almost to the day, after meat rationing was clamped down on the American people, Government officials achieved a major relaxation in the program this week by cutting all meats but beef steaks and roasts of beef free from ration-point restrictions.
Capt. T. Stewart Hamilton, Medical Corps, USA, and Mrs. Hamilton have come to Hampshire House from Detroit.
NAPLES, May 7 (AP) -- United States heavy bombers blasted Bucharest by daylight today in the steady, sledgehammer pounding of Rumania, Allied headquarters announced.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 7 -- Thousands of Arabs in the southern sector of the Arabian peninsula who were near death from famine are getting regular meals and medical attention through facilities rushed in by British planes, it was announced today.

Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the Russian War Relief clothing campaign in New York City, revealed Sunday that he had received an eyewitness account of Nazi atrocities in the recently liberated Sarny region. The report was received from the Rev. Georgii Alexeivich Parli, vicar of the Pochaevo-Bogoroditskaya Church in Sarny.

LONDON, May 7 (AP) -- More than 102,000 civilians and prisoners of war were murdered by the Germans in the Rovno region of Poland, a Soviet extraordinary commission for investigation of German atrocities charged today, as it named the alleged perpetrators of the crimes.

Tanned, refreshed and vigorous, President Roosevelt is back at his desk in Washington. We can all be glad that he has had a chance to enjoy a month of rest and relaxation from the almost overwhelming burdens which his office forces him to carry.

Problems faced by the teaching staff and the student body of a vocational high school are set forth in "Hickory Stick," which Marjorie Ewing and Marie Louise Elkins will present tonight at the Mansfield. Miss Ewing, who is formally entering the managerial ranks with this offering, is no newcomer to show business, having been financially interested in other local shows.

LONDON, May 7 -- The six day and night attacks on Berlin in March by American and British heavy bombers damaged seventy-four factories in the city area, according to a report tonight by the British Air Ministry. Among these were several vital Nazi war plants virtually wiped out.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Senator Ellender, Democrat, of Louisiana, chairman of a special Senate Agriculture subcommittee, announced today that hearings on the Smith bill to remove certain restrictions on the manufacture and distribution of margarine and to regulate the same would begin June 6 and would probably continue for about a week.

In last Sunday's TIMES there appeared an interesting news item regarding the efforts on the part of the Peruvian Government to rebuild and restore its great National Library, which was destroyed by fire last year.

A political week which will see Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio move unchallenged into second place in delegate strength for the Republican Presidential nomination gets under way with action today in Missouri and Wyoming.

ALTRUISM is a word which generally is found only in the dictionary. Occasionally, though, some altruistic soul will perform an unselfish deed merely for the love of it. Motives such as these impelled Nat Fleischer of Ring Magazine to compile his first monumental "All-Time Ring Record Book" three years ago. Now he has his third (and last) edition off the presses, and even at $5 per copy it is a rare bargain.

MONTREAL, May 7 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals defeated the Jersey City Giants, 2 -- 1, in the first game of a scheduled double-header today. The game was halted at the end of six innings by rain and the second game postponed.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, May 8 (AP) -- A communique:
Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.68, practically unchanged from the previous week's level of 112.69.

All the mortgages of the Home Owners Learn Corporation in the Hawaiian Islands have been sold to savings and loan associations there, John H. Fahey, Commissioner of the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration, announced in Washington yesterday.

ALGIERS, May 7 -- Speaking in Tunis today at a celebration of that city's liberation a year ago by the British, French and Americans, Gen. Charles de Gaulle seized the occasion to protest once more against what he called the "interruption in communications between the French Government and its diplomatic and military representatives in London."

BOSTON, May 7 -- Melvin Ott, visibly shaken by a full week of misadventures, gave his Giants another strenuous shaking today. He benched himself to rest a sore leg; he called upon his veteran captain. Billy Jurges, to make his first appearance of the year at third base; he moved Hal Luby over to second, and for a time this seemed to be exactly what the occasion demanded.

Fewer buyers were in the New York market last week. Interest in the coat and suit trade was shown in boys' coats. Sun back dresses were one of the fashion hits and party dresses for graduation were in unprecedented demand, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying officers.
You can hardly read a newspaper these days without running across a criticism of the State Department, that it has no foreign policy.

PROCESSED FOODS (vegetables, soups, fruits and fruit juices, dried beans, jam, jelly, canned and bottled baby foods and certain other special products). Only blue stamps and blue tokens can be used in buying processed foods. Blue stamps A8 through Q8 in War Book 4 are good indefinitely, at 10 points each. Five additional blue stamps become valid the first of each month. Frozen fruits and vegetables and dried foods are now point-free.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

There still seems to be no distinction in the public mind between Gerald L.K. Smith's so-called "America First" party and the long-disbanded America First Committee. General Wood, the former national chairman of the disbanded organization, has several times tried to get publicity for a statement disavowing the Smith groups.

NEW DELHI, India, May 7 (AP) -- A meeting between Mohandas K. Gandhi and the Viceroy of India at the earliest possible moment, with the objective of marshaling India's potentially vast military strength in the struggle against Japan, was envisioned today by Indian political leaders and among those closest to the Indian Nationalist leader.

Peace with justice will come only if we "let God rule our lives," Mgr. Joseph A. Flannelly declared yesterday at the sixth annual communion breakfast of the New York City Department of Public Works branch of the Holy Name Society, attended by 700 at the Hotel Roosevelt.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 7--Management and labor .must have faith in each other to achieve an economy of abundance and conquer temporary unemployment after the war, it was agreed today by Philip Murray, president of the CIO, and Paul Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation.
CHUNGKING, China, May 7 (UP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Fear that the coming Presidential election might result in a "minority" vote of the nation unless the people take action and see that everyone who is able votes, was expressed yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 7 (AP) -- British and Indian troops have withdrawn from the western Burma base of Buthedaung during "a readjustment of our positions," but have beaten off new Japanese attacks on the Indian frontier base of Kohima, headquarters announced today.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- A Government program designed to obtain cash corn for essential industries has been in effect for a little over a week and has been decidedly successful. Sufficient corn was obtained in Illinois and Iowa to permit a majority of closed industries to resume operations and with the bulk of the corn now moving going to the processors the latter are expected to operate at capacity for the balance of the season.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY ANZIO BEACHHEAD, May 7 -- The road signs say "Roma -- 58 kilometers." but it is not nearly that far to "Gusville." All you have to do is to give your jeep its head and sooner or later some one will say:

March shipments of all types of hosiery dropped 6.5 per cent under the like month a year previously, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. March, 1944, shipments were 13,589,865 dozen pairs, compared with 14,533,545 dozen pairs for the 1943 month.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 7 (UP) -- A communique:

Mayor La Guardia congratulated New York City consumers yesterday on their refusal to be stampeded into meat-buying by the Office of Price Administration's removal of ration points on all meats except beefsteaks and roasts last Thursday.

PITTSBURGH, May 7 -- An expansion in the volume of steel orders, a continuation of a high level in steel-ingot output and a further tightening in steel supplies featured news of the steel industry last week.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 7 -- Summer's long stretch of racing started today at the Larchmont Yacht Club with the annual tune-up regatta. Only seven sloops started and they were of the International Class, the winner among them being Corny Shields' Aileen.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 7 -- In one of the biggest executions ever carried out by the Gestapo in occupied territory a great number of Hungarians were shot in the cellar of the National Bank in Budapest last week, according to reports reaching Stockholm today.

To help the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, complete on time its record quota of 21,000,000 surgical dressings for the Army, skilled cutters of Amalgamated Clothing Workers Local 4, who by day cut garments in the city's men's clothing industry, have volunteered to work nights, it was announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. Robert C. Davis, chapter executive director.

LONDON, May 7 -- Vivicillin, a development of the much-talked-about drug penicillin, although still in its scientific infancy, was first tested by a co-discoverer on himself before it was permitted to be administered to another human being.

The vast scope and many-sided issues of this war are again bringing to the fore in this country a problem which is inherent in the nature and processes of the American melting pot. That is the problem of the loyalties, sympathies and political leanings of Americans of foreign birth or extraction whom the melting pot has as yet been unable to amalgamate completely.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Calculations based on data obtained from the Department of Justice indicated today that during his eleven years of office President Roosevelt had made 296 judicial appointments, or virtually as many as the total number of places on the Federal bench.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 7 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bisons snapped a losing streak of five straight this afternoon to whip the Newark Bears, 9 to 3.
Only three new films are scheduled at the moment to arrive on Broadway this week. The openings follow:

Four hundred troops of the Manhattan units of the Fifty-first Regiment of the New York Guard paraded through the rain yesterday afternoon to the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, to attend memorial services for members of Squadron A, the predecessor of the participating outfits.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Roosevelt came back to Washington today from a month's vacation on the plantation coast of South Carolina, tanned, rested and described by his physician as in "excellent shape."

HARRISBURGH, Pa., May 7 (U.P.) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, Republican Presidential nomination possibilities, will address the opening Session of the thirty-sixth annual Governors' conference to be held here May 28- 31.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 7 -- The ball bearing question, outstanding between Sweden and the Allies, produced yet another development today when William Waring, assistant commercial attache and steel expert at the British Legation in Stockholm, left here for London to report on the ball bearing matter.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, announcing yesterday the annual award of medals to members of the Police Department for acts of conspicuous bravery in 1943, listed three recipients of the Departmental Medal of Honor, the most treasured distinction in the department.

LONDON, Monday, May 8 (AP) -- Russian planes, in a possible prelude to a final Red Army land drive against Sevastopol, destroyed twenty-two German planes, blew up four ammunition dumps, damaged several ships, silenced artillery batteries and inflicted heavy losses on German and Rumanian troops in attacks at the besieged Crimean port, Moscow announced last night.
LONDON, May 7 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics salvaged one game of their four-game series with the Washington Senators, winning the second half of today's double header, 7 -- 3, after losing the first, 2 -- 1.
The ports of western Europe once again are about to play a major role in history.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- The Soviet publication, War and the Working Class, asserted today that the Atlantic Charter and the Moscow declaration of Foreign Ministers were not sufficiently precise instruments for settling the complicated problems of world war and peace in 1944.

NAPLES, May 7 (U.P.) -- Allied troops have thrown back a sharp German attack at the center of the Anzio beachhead and countered with a raking artillery barrage while enemy thrusts on the southern Italian front below Cassino have been repelled with a number of casualties for both sides, official reports said today.

The appetizing aroma of chocolate that is being melted pervades the factory of the Kopper Company at 18 Waverly Place, where candies in the European style are manufactured for sale in retail stores in many sections of the country. The confections, with which we first became acquainted at Altman's, are of twenty varieties that the firm used to make in Germany before its establishment in this country in 1938.

People are continually being told that the best way to lead a long and healthy life is not to worry. Most doctors agree that mental strain plays a part in the development of the conditions that lead to illness, so intelligent people will henceforth worry no more.

According to the reporters who have seen him, the President comes back to Washington bronzed, rested and fit from the most complete vacation he has had since he took office more than eleven years ago. This is good news for the American people, for the country no less than Mr. Roosevelt will need all the strength, serenity and fortitude of spirit he can muster to face the burdens of this year.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- A big trade was on in rye futures last week on the Board of Trade. Heavy deliveries of cash grain on May contracts failed to relieve congestion and the price advanced around 3 cents a bushel at one time to the highest level since early in February, before heavy profit-taking and closing of spreads with wheat checked the upturn and caused a sharp reaction.

Reporting on operations last year of the American Export Lines, William H. Coverdale, president, informed stockholders in the annual statement released today, that the net income for 1943, after $1,380,600 provision for taxes, was $1,449,563, equal to $3 a share.

TRENTON, N.J., May 7 -- For the first time in a considerable period, a Bedlington terrier has gained the highest distinction in Eastern dog shows. That honor today was awarded to the dog, Champion Rock Ridge Driftwood, at the twelfth annual exhibition of the Trenton Kennel Club, held on the grounds of the 112th Field Artillery.
In reading your editorial comment of May 1 on Prime Minister Churchill's message to Premier Papandreou A. came to the conclusion that certain fundamental facts are being overlooked.

The five-story loft building at 670-74 Broadway, northwest Corner of Bond Street, has been sold by Nessa Sears and Jeannette Epstein to an investing client of Julian Lewis 1Vfarko, attorney, for cash over. a mortgage Of $86,680. It is on a plot 85 by 130 feet and was sold through M. W. Suffern Co., brokers, iVIorris Leight represented the sellers.

SHEFFIELD, England, May 7 -- The United States, Britain and the rest of the British Empire turned out planes in 1943 at a clip of fourteen and one-half every hour -- 127,000 for the year -- A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, disclosed today.

A campaign to see that women workers get a "fair employment deal" after the war has been started by the National Women's Trade Union League of America, with league members and all working women urged to rally to support of a post-war job program, it was announced yesterday by Rose Schneiderman, president of the New York Women's Trade Union League.

CHUNGKING, China, May 7 -- The Chinese High Command announced today that its troops defending the key city of Loyang in northwestern Honan Province had repulsed a reinforced Japanese attack nine and one-half miles south of the city as Maj. Gen. Claire Chennault's Fourteenth Air Force fighters and bombers were thrown against the enemy.

The National Peanut Council has adopted a resolution to assess its members on a poundage basis to raise a fund for advertising and publicity. The Peanut and Nut Salters Association, Peanut Butter Manufacturers Association and the National Confectioners Association, members of the council, announced that similar resolutions had been passed.

MADRID, May 7 (AP) -- Chief of State Generalissimo Francisco Franco referred to what he called victorious "battles of peace" in a ceremony at Seville today, and the press made it clear that one of those victories was renewed United States oil shipments in return for Spanish restriction on ore exports to Germany.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7 -- A Gutenberg Bible dating from about 1455 will be presented to President James B. Conant and the fellows of Harvard College in a ceremony tomorrow in the Harry Elkins Widener Memorial Room of the Widener Library.
ST. LOUIS, May 7 (AP) -- Six-hit pitching by both Max Lanier and Al Jurisich gave the Cardinals a 5-1, 1-0 double victory over the Reds today and placed St. Louis firmly in the National League lead.

Early last week, the price level, whether of stocks or bonds, hardly changed. Daily transactions in stocks averaged between 500,000 and 600,00 shares, and on one day transactions in bonds were the smallest thus far in 1944. At the week-end the stock market became more active, and prices rose moderately.

LONDON, May 7 -- Owing to a rise in certain foodstuffs and textiles, notably cotton, the Economist's index of commodity prices on April 25 reached a new wartime high at 117.3. This compares with 115.2 three weeks before, 114.6 a year ago, and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

The Society of Independent Artists, which seeks to encourage new and unrecognized artistic talent, opened yesterday its twenty-eighth annual exhibition at the American Fine Arts Society Galleries, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. A thousand invited guests saw the exhibition, which will be open to the public beginning today and through May 28.

NEW ORLEANS, May 7 -- While crop news continued to be mainly unfavorable, accounting for sharp narrowing of the premiums of near over new-crop positions, cotton futures on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange were narrower last week than for some time.

NAPLES, May 7 -- Probably never before has an army been as aware of its responsibilities to a nation it has entered as this army of the Allies which, while able and equipped to cause utmost destruction, holds off in literally hundreds of cases for it fully realizes that damage done to treasures of art, culture and religion is damage not only to Italy but to the civilized world as well.

LONDON, May 7 (Overseas News Agency) -- An internal crisis in the Free German Committee here has come into the open with the designation of the old German Liberal leader August Weber and intimations by two Social Democratic members, Victor Schiff and Fritz Wolf, that they also may leave.

James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman, declared yesterday that Governor Dewey had hoped to escape calling special elections in the Fourth and Eleventh Congressional Districts, which the Governor set last week for June 6 after a request from Mr. Farley.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Removal of pork from the list of rationed foods resulted last week in a much better demand for that meat, especially for fresh pork, and packers express the belief that there will be a sustained call so that some of the accumulation of stocks in cold storage can be worked off to advantage.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved the issuance by the New Jersey Power and Light Company of $9,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due 1974, and $3,000,000 of $100 par cumulative preferred stock.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- Even the presence of Charlie Grimm, who took over again today as manager of the Cubs, couldn't snap the Bruins out of their losing streak, which was extended to twelve straight by two extra-inning defeats at the hands of the Pirates.

Even losing pari-mutuel tickets at local race tracks are lengthening the odds against the Axis by helping to step-up the War Production Board's waste paper salvage drive, it was disclosed yesterday by Pierre L. Barbey, the board's Brooklyn representative.

The inspiration that early American handcrafts offer to the home decorator of today was commented on by speakers at the first Institute of Early American Folk Arts, which closed at the Folk Arts Center yesterday afternoon.
Martha Graham last night opened her first extended season of performances at the National Theatre, assisted by her company of dancers and with Louis Horst conducting a small orchestra in the pit.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- A shortage of domestic cash wheat is developing rapidly and feed interests and distillers are reported to be encountering difficulty in obtaining sufficient supplies of desirable grades of that grain. Large orders are said to have come into the market last week, but relatively little business was transacted owing to the inability of elevator men to buy grain.

The colorful interiors of war plants developed to increase the efficiency of the workers are likely to have an effect on post-war homes, Faber Birren, an industrial color consultant, declared yesterday. "Color on walls and equipment in factories, while introduced primarily to prevent eye strain, to offset any feeling of monotony and to stimulate activity, can be adapted to the home with good results," he said.

LONDON, May 7 -- Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia disclosed tonight that the conference of Empire Prime Ministers here had agreed that a stalemate must be prevented in the Pacific war while the European conflict was being fought to a conclusion.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 7 -- A pair of eight-branch brass candlesticks and a pewter sanctuary lamp, presented by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Mrs. Sulzberger, were blessed at a service of solemn evensong late this afternoon in St. Paul's Church, Eastchester, national shrine of the Bill of Rights and officially dedicated to freedom of the press, on the Eastchester village green here.

Just what are we to make of Dr. Gallup's finding, published in this newspaper yesterday, that two-thirds of the American people are convinced that "most people in this country do not take the war seriously enough"?

Warning that unless an increasing trend of delinquency and an "alarming" spread of immorality is not checked quickly, existing facilities, private and public, will prove unequal to the task of administering guidance to those in need, William R. Bayes, Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions, declared last night that the trend must be halted if the future of the country is to be safeguarded.

PEARL HARBOR, May 7 (U.P.) -- Japanese positions in the Kurile Islands of the north Pacific were bombed for the thirty-sixth time Friday by Navy Ventura search planes winging their way to Paramushiru and Shemushu from Aleutian bases, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

The downpour of yesterday completely washed out plans for the first Sunday double-header in the Yankee Stadium, as well as at Ebbets Field. Until 3 o'clock the decision to postpone was delayed in each case, as President Ed Barrow waited patiently in the hope that the storm clouds would pass, and President Branch Rickey did the same thing in Flatbush.

The Emergency Price Control Act and the Stabilization Act expire June 30. Many changes have been proposed to Congress. Some recommendations have been designed to strengthen the controls over prices, others would greatly weaken them. Any such weakening would represent a serious defeat in the battle against price inflation.

Cotton prices held generally steady last week in quiet trading. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed the period at net changes ranging from a decline of 2 points to an advance of 13 points.

MOSCOW, May 7 (AP) -- The Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski, pro-Soviet priest from Springfield, Mass., is on his way to the United States by plane after a twelve-day visit in Russia, it was disclosed today.

New England's stone walls make a patchwork-quilt pattern of the landscape. They are the weather-grayed, lichen-covered threads which run along country roads, climb upland pastures and meander over brows of low mountains. They encompass small mowing fields and circle fertile meadows.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Sales of used tires and tubes in bulk quantities must be segregated from other items of scrap rubber if they are to be eligible to bring ceiling prices, the Office of Price Administration ruled today.

The fiftieth anniversary of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, founded in 1894 by the Associated Alumnae of Hunter College to serve underprivileged families of the East Side, was observed last night in Hunter College.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- The last time limits for the Allied invasion of western Europe have been reached, all preparations completed and the Germans "have to await any day now crushing blows," War and the Working Class said today in conjunction with a sharp attack on "advocates of German fascism in the Anglo-Saxon countries," who, it said, are feverishly speculating on the number of casualties British and United States forces will suffer in landing attempts.

Arnold S. Denker, 30-year-old champion of the Manhattan Club, one-time N.Y.U. star and former champion of New York State, capped his chess career yesterday when he drew his last game with Benjamin Altman of Flushing, champion of the Queens Club, and thereby won the national tournament at the Hotel Park Central.

Your editorial in today's issue concerning freedom of speech for employers seems to me based on a misunderstanding of the essential problem involved. There are many situations in which an individual comes into conflict with the law because of words he has spoken or written.

Belmont Park will be the scene of New York's horse racing activities for the next month. The spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association will start there today and will continue through Saturday, June 3.

The official heads of twenty-three Protestant denominations with a combined membership of 25,000,000 persons have protested to Selective Service against the recent ruling canceling the draft deferment of pre-theological students, it was announced yesterday.

The pronunciation of 12,000 words and names, battle fields and air force objectives of the last two years, likely places of future attacks and places that may figure in peace-making and future air lines, will be given in "World Words: Recommended Pronunciations,'' by W. Cabell Greet, to be published by Columbia University Press on May 25.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, May 8 (AP) -- Naval Catalina flying boats on routine patrol over the island-dotted. Netherlands East Indies damaged a 5,000-ton Japanese freighter in intercepting an eight-ship enemy convoy off Celebes Island late Friday, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

MONTREAL, May 7 (AP) -- Ray Atherton, United States Ambassador to Canada, said today that "the post-war world must achieve internationalism or go down into the chaos of darker ages than we have yet known."

Renewal of "the forgotten devotion" to the Holy Ghost was urged yesterday as a preparation for peace by the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Archbishop Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 7 -Until economic reconstruction is effected, forms, types and creeds of government in the liberated countries are likely to be of only transient consequence, Prof. Wesley A. Sturges, who was appointed to coordinate and direct American economic aid in liberated Sicily, said in a radio address tonight.

Not so long ago a committee of American and British physicians visited Russian hospitals, schools and medical laboratories and reported in terms of the highest praise on what they had seen. That Soviet Russia also stands high in the physical sciences Raymond Stevens made clear at the meeting of the American Chemical Society.

CHUNGKING, China, May 7 -- If the rapid advance of the Japanese forces to eliminate the Chinese-held center stretch of the Peiping-Hankow Railway and the accompanying thrust westward from the railway toward Loyang is beginning a new active phase in the China war, breaking the military stalemate since 1939, it is likely that the political stalemate, which has done much to paralyze China during this period, may also be broken.

Niles Trammell, president of the National Broadcasting Company, in his first statement on the present controversy over television, came out yesterday against "non-technical people" who were trying to evaluate the video art now.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- With the Soviet Union, simply by not being represented, apparently exerting as much, or more, effect upon the functions of the International Labor Conference as would have been possible if a Russian delegation were in attendance, a movement began to develop among the workers' delegates today to determine whether their policies had been controverted, directly or indirectly, through the influence of Moscow.

CLEVELAND, May 7 -- The Indians split a twin bill with the league-leading Browns today, dropping the opener, 7 to 4, as Jack Kramer hurled his fifth straight triumph without a defeat, and winning the nightcap, 3 to 2, on Allie Reynolds' seven-hit performance.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (U.P.) -- The birth-rate, already past its wartime peak, is rapidly declining and will fall until the war ends, perhaps reducing the 1943 record births of 3,000,000 babies to about 2,100,000 yearly, according to Wilson H. Grabill, analyist for the Bureau of the Census.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Nazis have turned their weapons of propaganda toward the network of patriots working underground in occupied nations in an effort to expose and destroy this potentially powerful ally of the invaders, the Office of War Information revealed today.

ROSEBURG, Ore., May 7 (AP) -- Senator Rufus Holman, Republican, of Oregon, declared yesterday that the Pearl Harbor catastrophe was caused by Admiral Husband E. Kimmel through countermanding defense orders and failing to supply new ones.

Congratulations on completion of one year abroad will be sent this week to "Mount Sinai Overseas" by the trustees and medical staff of the hospital here, it was announced yesterday. Although no official connection exists between Mount Sinai Hospital and the contingent of its doctors and nurses serving with the Army in North Africa, there is said to be a strong sentimental bond constantly reinforced with letters and packages.
LONDON, May 7 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe announcement:
LONDON, May 7 -- The buoyancy and activity of the London stock markets in the past week have surprised even the most optimistic traders.

HEADQUARTERS, SEVENTH AIR FORCE, May 6 (U.P.) -- Fifteen officers and men, including special observers, were lost when an Army Liberator bomber failed to return from a strike against the Kurile Islands April 26, it was announced here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 -- Lee Bowman, who recently signed a term contract with Columbia, will have the male lead in the forthcoming "Tonight and Every Night," an adaptation of Lesley Storm's "Heart of a City," for which Rita Hayworth, Janet Blair and Marc Platt already have been named.

Employment in the New York region, which includes New Jersey north of Trenton and Fairfield County in Connecticut as well as all of New York State, has about reached its peak and has become relatively stable, Carl H. Hendrikson Jr., regional business consultant for the Department of Commerce, reported yesterday in a study covering manpower problems of the region for the first quarter of 1944.
GEORGETOWN, S.C., May 7 -- (AP) -- President Roosevelt selected the flat, easy-going plantation country of South Carolina for a two weeks' vacation and liked it so much he stayed four.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period April 29 to May 5 are given in the appended tabulation:

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Senate expects to clear the stage tomorrow for the opening Tuesday of what is expected to be the bitterest fight of the session -- a battle over the repeal of the poll tax in eight Southern States.

A double bill composed of Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavalla's "Pagliacci" was given by the City Center Opera Company last night at the City Center. In the Mascagni work Regina Resnik assumed the role of Santuzza, which afforded her her first opportunity to disclose the real nature of her talents, which proved to be of outstanding worth.

LONDON, May 7 -- The greatest landing of paratroops and glider-borne infantrymen ever made at night was successfully concluded yesterday when British and American air-borne units combined to hold day and night exercises somewhere in Britain.

LONDON, Monday, May 8 -- The greatest air offensive in history was resumed yesterday in vaster weight than ever. Up to 2,000 American heavy bombers and escort fighters made Berlin one of the principal targets, while probably 1,500 more Allied war planes swept over France and Belgium, blasting rail yards, bridges and other military objectives necessary to Hitler's defense against land invasion.
DETROIT, May 7 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox took both ends of a double-header from the Detroit Tigers, 4 to 1 and 4 to 2, before 25,151 spectators today to sweep a three-game series.

Although 9,000 children are being cared for by foster parents, 3,000 other young boys and girls in New York City are waiting to get into foster homes, Harry W. Marsh, Acting Commissioner of Welfare of New York City, said yesterday at a luncheon given by the Foster Homes for Children, at the Hotel Commodore.

With the addition yesterday of two film newcomers, the week's openings now number five. On Wednesday, the new attraction at the Victoria will be "The Hour Before Dawn," Paramount's adaptation of a novel by W. Somerset Maugham.

Descriptions of Bernard W. Baruch's South Carolina plantation, Hobcaw Barony, scene of the President's recent vacation, revive old longings in many a city heart. The farm mansion, we read, contains a library, a gunroom and bedrooms no end, and all the rooms have fireplaces.

The Soviet magazine, War and the Working Class, takes to task people in England and the United States whom it accuses of attempting to "use" the Atlantic Charter to bolster the "conqueror's pretensions of the so-called Polish Government toward territories in the Ukraine and White Russia."

In an attempt to give New York City public school students a start in assembling their own libraries, the Board of Education is considering a plan to purchase inexpensive paperbound textbooks for classroom use in place of clothbound books, it was revealed yesterday by James Marshall, board member, who introduced the recommendation.
Ohio voters are expected to put Governor Bricker in second place in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination today.
Still expanding its information, the 1944 edition of the city's directory, popularly known as "The Green Book," is now on sale, Stephen G. Kelley, supervisor of The City Record, announced yesterday.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, May 8 (AP) -- President Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez, for thirteen years head of this little coffee-growing Central American republic, resigned today, a little more than a month after a revolt against his government was bloodily suppressed.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A joint committee of manufacturers, dealers and Government officials to assist in the task of distributing surplus equipment and machinery was recommended by the used equipment and machinery industry advisory committee of the War Production Board today as the group explored ways for the Government "to get the most benefit out of its holdings and insure protection of the democratic economy."

A UNITED STATES AIR EVACUATION HOSPITAL, in the Marshall Islands, April 25 (delayed) (U.P.) -- Ten United States Army airmen, suffering from sun-blistered faces and salt water sores, told today of six nights and five days spent on life rafts in the Pacific after they had been forced down while protecting a damaged Navy bomber.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Rye turned sharply upward today on the Board of Trade after a small fractional decline at the opening. Later in the day the General Foods Corporation sent a telegram to P.R. O'Brien, president of the exchange, saying: "There is no foundation to a report that we sold rye to elevator interests or other sources."

The Halstead Apartments, a six-story building with suites for seventy-eight families at 234-54 Martime Avenue, in White Plains, Westchester County, has been sold by David S. Meister to a syndicate of investors. The property, which is 250 by 100 feet, is between Mamaroneck Avenue and South Broadway and is assessed at $310,000.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The National War Labor Board moved today to discourage appeals from decisions of its commissions and regional boards by pointing out that "unnecessary delays in the disposition of labor disputes are an important cause of labor unrest which may be harmful to the war effort."

Determination of final selling prices on fur garments for the coming season continued unsettled in many instances yesterday, as lack of decisive action last week by the Office of Price Administration on the long-awaited amendment to MPR 178 impeded fall preparations by manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers, it was reported in the industry here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Attorney General, according to Chicago dispatches, availed himself of the undisputed privilege of an advocate to modify in his brief a legal proposition advanced to the court in his oral statement.

The War Food Administration is offering to the highest bidder 700,000 pounds of off-grade cheddar cheese in storage in California and Oregon, it was learned yesterday. Most of the cheese is said to have been in storage for more than six months and is part of the hoard piled up by the Federal Government under set-aside orders.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Representative Ramspeck of Georgia, majority whip, was named by Speaker Rayburn today as chairman of a committee of seven to investigate the seizure of the Montgomery Ward Co. plant in Chicago.

The Radio Technical Planning Board's sub-committee on proposed new television standards has recommended post-war assignment of ultra-high frequencies for experiments in transmitting more detailed images and pictures in color, it became known yesterday.

IPSWICH, England, May 8 -- The Rev. Harold Godfrey Green, vicar of St. Nicholas Church and chaplain to British forces, said today he had verified "quite definitely" the story of hundreds of Ipswich residents who said they saw a vision of Jesus on a cross in the sky during an April 27 air raid alert.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 3: Decreases of $107,000,000 in total loans, $208,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills and $541,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and an increase of $125,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

The first "eye bank" in the United States and possibly in the world has been established at the New York Hospital, according to a joint announcement yesterday by Stanley Resor, president of the Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital, and Langdon P. Marvin, president of the New York Hospital.
ABOARD AN LST EN ROUTE FROM THE ANZIO BEACHHEAD, May 8 -- The men all looked small. They were bedded in, two deep, in litters supported on arms folding in from the sides of the tank deck.

All was quiet on the local baseball front yesterday, the only activity being confined to the Yankee invasion of West Point and the departure of the Dodgers, who headed westward early last night to keep tomorrow's initial date with the Cardinals.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 8 (UP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Tuesday, May 9 -Germany's waning fighter forces suffered a major defeat yesterday when 119 enemy planes were destroyed by the guns of about 2,000 American warplanes that for the second day in succession blasted Berlin and also attacked Brunswick, a German aircraft factory center and rail junction.

Conceding that "the Dewey bandwagon is pretty far up the road," Victor H. Johnston, eastern campaign manager for the forces backing Lieut. Comdr. Harold E.
