Stassen for the Republican nomination for President, said yesterday that former Governor Stassen would have many friends at the Republican convention, and that the nomination is by no means "in the bag" for the Dewey forces.

A membership increase of 4,000 over last year's total of 15,000 was reported yesterday at the opening of the two-day emergency conference of the Lower New York Region of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, at the Hotel Park Central.

LONDON, May 8 -- Britain's "gloomy dean," the Very Rev. W.R. Inge, former dean of St. Paul's Cathedral, predicted today that film stars, prizefighters, labor leaders and purveyors of popular luxuries would be among the few persons who will have any money after the war is over.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 7 (Delayed) -- So ineffective has been the Luftwaffe in checking American air attacks in the Balkans that the Germans have resorte to desperate psychological warfare to counter this offensive. Through their control of all Balkan radio stations and news services the Germans are repeatedly telling the people of satellite countries that American airmen are callous and ignorant murderers who indiscriminately slaughter the civilian population.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Roosevelt devoted to Congressional and foreign affairs his first day of work in the White House since his return from his four weeks' vacation in South Carolina. His associates reported that they found him "looking fine."

NAPLES, May 8 (U.P.) -- Showing increasing nervousness on the southern Italian front, German forces have been carrying out large-scale movements south and west of Cassino, screening them behind a heavy barrage and a raid in force against our upper Garigliano bridgehead, which was beaten back in an hour's battle, it was reported tonight.

The Tokyo radio said yesterday that the Japanese Government had declared its readiness to dispatch a vessel to Vladivostok to pick up supplies sent from the United States for the relief of American war prisoners and civilian internees in Japanese hands.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 8 -- First official estimates of destruction inflicted during the bombardment of Schaffhausen by American bombers on April 1 indicated today that material damage alone would amount to roughly $8,500,000.

John A. Coleman was elected yesterday chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange for a second term of one year, when a total of 842 votes were cast, substantially more than the vote of 703 in 1943 and balloting by only 446 members in 1942.

A new and decentralized system for the examination of municipal fiscal affairs will enable the State Controller's office to complete 1,700 examinations this year as compared to 113 throughout 1942, Frank C. Moore, Controller of the State of New York, reported last night before a meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Sculptors Guild has moved indoors. For several seasons this energetic American organization has exhibited under the open sky: in a delightfully arranged space on Park Avenue at Thirty-ninth Street, then down in Greenwich Village and after that on the seventh-floor terrace of International Building, Rockefeller Center.

The question of how to treat Germany after the Allied victory is being debated with animation, not to say acrimony and violence, by people who want the same thing. Shall Germany be politically dismembered or shall it remain a post-war Reich of eighty million people speaking the German language?

LONDON, Tuesday, May 9 -- Red Army forces, ending an eighteen-day lull on the Crimean ground front, have smashed the main German defense belt around besieged Sevastopol after two days of violent fighting through a maze of steel and concrete fortifications, and are now engaging the enemy on the "closest approaches" to the Black Sea naval base, Moscow announced last night.
Arthur Eckstein Inc. was the broker in the recent purchase by the Bing syndicate of the eleven-story store and loft building at 714 Broadway from the Leopold Sinsheimer estate.
LONDON, May 8 (AP) -- The text of an announcement issued simultaneously tonight in Moscow and London by the Soviet and Czechoslovak Governments:

To insure the post-war purchasing power of the Western Hemisphere it will be necessary to industrialize Latin America considerably through the pooling of foreign and native capital, it was declared yesterday by several delegates to the ten-day Inter-American Development Commission Conference starting today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A bill to increase the statutory limit of the public debt from $210,000,000,000 to $240,000,000,000 was reported by the Ways and Means Committee today after the Administration had yielded to Republican demands for a slash of $20,000,000,000 from the originally proposed new ceiling.

Warning that the success of the Fair Employment Practices Committee's work against discrimination in industry requires the support of the entire community, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday that no Government agency could force business to do what the public doesn't want done.
The Board of Estimate has received a bid of $25,000 from Coty, Inc., for the "exclusive privilege" of broadcasting Mayor La Guardia's Sunday radio talks to the people, it was learned yesterday.

Women doctors in the armed forces have a wide range of duties, from the performing of pre-induction physical examinations to the treating of men who have returned to this country with tropical diseases, it was reported yesterday by Lieut. Comdrs Marion Josephi and Achsa Bean of the Navy and Capt. Elizabeth Howe of the Army Medical Corps.

The recovery in the stock market stalled yesterday when buying contracted sharply, although interest in a long list of specialties, principally the liquor shares, kept closing prices from being worse than mixed. So neglected were the pivotal issues that only scattered sales in the afternoon shaded values, with technical considerations rather than basic news or corporate developments at the base of the irregular movements.

The Monticello Drug Company has sold the six-story business building on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 52-56 West Houston Street, southeast corner of Wooster Street, to Benjamin Winter. The building was erected originally for the New York Telephone Company, which occupied it for a number of years.

The audience that filled Town Hall last night to hear Egon Petri, Dutch pianist, play a program of Scarlatti, Bach, Beethoven, Brahms and Chopin was rewarded with one of the best performances by one of the world's greatest artists.

Production of steel in April was moderately below the record output of 7,820,226 net tons of steel produced in March, but was the highest for any thirty-day month on record, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The institute placed the output last month at 7,568,530 tons.

RICHMOND, Va., May 10 (Science Service) -- The finding of the largest diamond ever unearthed in the eastern States was revealed today at the annual meeting of the Virginia Academy of Science by Dr. Roy J. Holden, head of the Geology Department of Virginia Polytechnic Institute.
LONDON, May 8 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

On May 2, 1944, you carried a front-page article on a case argued on May 1 before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia which involved a proceeding brought by the National Labor Relations Board against Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company and its president for allegedly violating a decree of that court enforcing an order of the board.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- The amount of bituminous coal in consumer storage on April 1 was the lowest since the start of the war, Secreteary Ickes reported today.
Opening days seem to suit Devil Diver right down to a T, for when he won the Toboggan Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park's curtain-raiser for 1944 he merely followed his own precedent.

Edward McGrath of St. Augustine School, Linton Baldwin of Poly Prep and Herbert Gruber of Dwight came through to the singles semi-finals of the twenty-ninth annual interscholastic tennis championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools, which began on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

In a speech made in Tunis to celebrate that city's liberation a year ago by British and American troops General de Gaulle seems to define the conditions under which he will accept the liberation of France at the hands of the British and Americans. The task of the British and American forces when landing in France, he declared, "should remain exclusively strategic."

Although there was yesterday somewhat heavier liquidation in May contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange, a slightly better demand for new crop months brought about a steadier market in the late trading and prices at the close were unchanged to 5 points higher than on Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- In the most moving address yet delivered at the international labor conference, Jan Masaryk, deputy prime minister of Czechoslovakia, called today for the imposition of peace terms so harsh as to convince the German and Japanese peoples for all time of the futility of aggression.

LONDON, May 8 -- Under hurried, almost frantic, German orders, western Europe is moving toward a state of siege while Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's reputation as a soldier and his patriotic oratory are being employed to bolster confidence in the Wehrmacht's ability to meet and defeat the invasion.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A Senate subcommittee dismissed today charges that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had exerted undue influence in the reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad and commended Jesse H. Jones, head of the RFC, for his "diligence in protecting" a $10,000,000 loan which the RFC had made to the railroad.
The naval support of the invasion of western Europe will include all types of vessels from battleships and aircraft carriers to small landing craft fitted with rocket launchers.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Rejecting company assertions that issuance of a press release by the New York regional director invalidated an election Dec. 15 at the Botany Worsted Mills of Passaic, N.J., the National Labor Relations Board certified the Textile Workers Union, CIO, today as bargaining agent, saying that it had won by 1,797 to 1,545 votes.

The British radio declared yesterday that Spain had not yet fulfilled "one of the most important pledges" made in concluding her recent agreement with Great Britain and the United States -- "the closing of the German consulate at Tangier."

With the recent changes in rationing, it may be possible for some consumers to use a few red points for the purchase of cheese, which has been neglected recently in favor of meat. Three varieties in relatively good supply are Muenster, Camembert and Limburger, all made by the Kraft Company and all unprocessed.

Despite a 5 per cent rise in attendance during the last season, and commercial sponsorship for its Sunday broadcast-concerts, the Philharmonic-Symphony Society had a deficit of almost $20,000 for the year, according to Marshall Field, chairman of the society's board of directors.

Martha Graham and her dance company chose for the second performance of their repertory season at the National Theatre last night a rich and rewarding program, containing every color from the exquisite tragedy of "Letter to the World" to the merciless foolishness of "Every Soul Is a Circus."

The Good Neighbor policy must be based upon the "solid foundation" of a good business policy that permits the freer exchange of goods and services between peoples and reduces governmental restrictions to a minimum, Erie A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, told industrialists from twenty-two Western Hemisphere nations at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A dining and dancing dress for the Wacs was modeled by Lieut. Robin Elliott today at Col. Oveta Culp Hobby's press conference.

Philip Tanawitzky, 33 years old, of 557 Timpson Place, the Bronx, was killed at 7 o'clock last night, and two other persons were injured when a three-ton truck ran wild for fifteen blocks up Tenth Avenue.
LONDON, May 8 -- After its recent spurt of activity the stock market here started the week today in a quieter vein. The general tone, however, was firm.
LONDON, Tuesday, May 9 (UP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by The United Press:

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- Hogs poured into Midwestern markets today in larger numbers than at any time since midwinter. Serious congestion resulted at several major terminals. At twelve Midwestern markets today's receipts totaled 188,400, compared with 164,800 last Monday.

ALTHOUGH it is conventional for Englishmen (and Americans, too) to be aloof, snobbish, superior and supercilious about other peoples, called "natives," there have always been plenty of exceptions. Among them few are more distinctive and distinguished than that strange succession of eccentric, gifted, eloquent individuals who lived for long periods among the Arabs, who loved the Arabs, who understood the Arabs and who wrote about them with such earnest enthusiasm.

With taut nerves and hearts that beat the higher the closer they are to the battlerront, vast armies around the rim of Hitler's fortress stand ready for the crisis of this war. But for tens of thousands of Allied soldiers D-day is every day and has been for more than three weeks.
Enrique A. Jimenez, Ambassador from Panama, and Senora de Jimenez have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

AN AIR TRANSPORT COMMAND BASE in India, May 7 (Delayed) -- Japanese threats to Assam notwithstanding, planes of the American Air Transport Command ferrying cargo to China during April flew a record amount of air freight per airplane assigned and showed the lowest loss of planes' crews in the history of ATC "hump" operations, Brig. Gen. Thomas Hardin announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared tonight that the AFL executive council wished very much that an understanding could be reached through which the United Mine Workers could become reaffiliated with the AFL.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, May 8 -- The great bomber attack on the Japanese in the Pacific from Paramushiru to the Netherlands East Indies may be the prelude to the next step in the Army-Navy offensive that began with the Hollandia landings.

American Relief for Italy, Inc., has received assurances of cooperation from almost all important groups of Italo-Americans, Justice Juvenal Marchisio, the executive vice president, declared yesterday. The organization, headed by Myron C. Taylor, plans to collect clothing for the destitute and homeless in liberated Italy.

PEARL HARBOR, May 8 -- Army and Navy heavy bombers flying a roundtrip of more than 2,000 miles made the second land-based air attack of the war on Guam on Saturday, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, announced today.

MILWAUKEE, May 8 -- A series of political events, culminating at the week-end in the apparent crack-up of the twelve-year-old marriage between the New Deal and the La Follette Progressives, largely over international policies, left little doubt in the minds of observers here that a nationalist movement of the first rank was shaping in Wisconsin.

The trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric system disclosed yesterday that the next step in the complicated proceedings from the top holding companies in the A.G. E. set-up will be the holding of hearings on June 12 before Judge Vincent L. Leibell in the Federal District Court here.

NAPLES, May 8 -- Production of the Rumanian Ploesti refining system, said to have been capable of an annual oil output of 9,600,000 tons, which was furnishing Germany with more than 30 per cent of her war needs, has been reduced to less than one-quarter of normal by the heavy Allied bombings, according to a statement by Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, commander of the Mediterranean Allied Air Force.

The emergency sales tax division of the Controller's office of the City of New York, which will leave 350 Broadway on June 1 to make room for the Veterans Administration, has leased large quarters in 74 Trinity Place from Trinity Church, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- In one of the most sweeping antitrust decrees of recent years, a special three-judge Federal court ordered Pullman, Inc., today to separate "completely and perpetually" its railroad-car building business from its sleeping-car enterprise.

At least two major banking groups are expected to bid for the new issue of $56,000,000 San Francisco-Oakland Toll Bridge revenue refunding bonds scheduled last Saturday by the California Toll Bridge Authority for award on May 22, consisting of $36,000,000 due Sept. 1, 1945 to 1959, and $20,000,000 due Sept. 1, 1962.

The House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York, which opened its 138th annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, voted approval of a new organization, known as United Medical Services, Inc., established to provide prepaid medical insurance for the lower and middle income groups of the seventeen lower counties of New York State.

The first shipment of special envelopes to be used in mailing war ballots to voters in the armed services and in returning them was received yesterday by the Board of Elections. The mailing out will start Sept. 7 and will continue through Oct. 16 as requests are received.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (U.P.) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the decision of a three-judge New York Special Federal Court in the Government's anti-trust suit against The Associated Press.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE IN ENGLAND, May 8 (U.P.) -- Capt. Robert S. Johnson, 24-year-old Thunderbolt pilot from Lawton, Okla., closed his tour of active duty today in a blaze of glory, destroying two enemy planes to become one of America's two top fighter aces with a total of twenty-seven shot down, one better than the record set by Capt. Edward Rickenbacker in the first World War.

LONDON, May 8 (U.P.) -- An agreement placing Czechoslovak territory under the supreme authority of the Soviet (Allied) military commander as it is liberated by Russian armies, with a Czech administration to take over when the area becomes no longer a fighting zone, was signed today in London, the Czech Government announced tonight.

CLEVELAND, May 8 -- A guaranteed weekly and annual wage is in the forefront of the goals toward which the Congress of Industrial Organizations is working, according to Philip Murray, president of the CIO.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Answering statements that his firm had collected excessive fees from the Navy for services in the shipbuilding program, William Francis Gibbs, vice president of Gibbs Cox, ship designers with offices at 21 West Street, New York City, submitted for the record today comparative figures of his own concern and Stone Webster, indicating a greater return to the latter in the last three years.

The City's Center's first production of Verdi's "La Traviata" last night was a performance of great charm, color and spirit, with a high standard of vocal excellence. Major roles were allotted to singers who had never appeared at the Center before.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, May 9 (AP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, May 9 (U.P.) -- American casualties have been only twenty-eight killed and ninety-five wounded to date in the Hollandia, Netherland New Guinea, area where troops swarmed ashore ten days ago in the greatest Allied offensive of the war in the southwest Pacific, it was disclosed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 -- In spite of a War Labor Board order and telegrams from their own international officers urging compliance, machinists of the San Francisco Bay area made no evident move today to return to work on two drydocked ships which they have refused to complete for Navy service at the rate of $1.20 an hour for "new shipbuilding."

More than 1,400 of New Jersey's bankers are expected to attend the annual meeting and war-time conference of the New Jersey Bankers Association to be held on Friday and Saturday in the Hotel Pennsylvania here, Joseph G. Parr, president of the association, said yesterday in announcing the program for the meeting.

Presentation of the Government's case against Frederick Heizer Wright, who is on trial in Federal court charged with serving as an unregistered propaganda agent for the Japanese, was completed yesterday by John F.X. McGohey, chief assistant United States attorney.

The spring theatre is being governed by good intentions, To the list of those earlier plays deserving the phrase there now can be added "Hickory Stick," which opened last evening at the Mansfield. Unfortunately, it is not only the intention which counts on the streets near Times Square, and like a good many others the drama by Frederick Stephani and Murray Burnett does not equal its high hopes.

The tremendous blasting of western Europe from the air has emphasized the lull on the Russian front. But there is one place on that front where there is no lull. At Sevastopol the remnants of two German armies are being ground to bits methodically by land, air and sea.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- John L. Lewis withdrew today the yearold application of the United Mine Workers of America for reaffiliation with the American Federation of Labor and, in an angry letter to William Green, AFL president, asked for immediate return of a $60,000 check deposited for the first year's dues.

CHUNGKING, China, May 8 (U.P.) -- The Chinese defenders of Honan Province have checked the Japanese drive on the key city of Loyang, Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's High Command announced tonight, but the invaders have scored new gains along the Peiping-Hankow Railroad, narrowing the Chinese-held gap in that sector to about twenty miles.

A set of standards for non-profit day nurseries has been developed by the membership and standards committee of the New York Association of Day Nurseries and will be distributed today to twenty-seven member agencies, Mrs. Broderick Haskell, president of the association, announced yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 8 -- New York's world champion Yankees made their annual trip to the United States Military Academy today. With big Floyd Bevens, Kansas City right-hander, giving a masterful exhibition, the American Leaguers ran rough shod over the Army combination, 14 -- 0.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 8 -- Reports this morning of British and American commando raids on the Ligurian coast of Italy said that one of the most important of these raids was carried out Saturday morning just south of Genoa. A dispatch from Chiasso said that a large majority of the forces engaged had succeeded in leaving after gathering important information on the condition of the Todt organization defenses there.

Designed to promote post-war sales in a market estimated to require 6,900,000 gas ranges for replacement, 4,500,000 ranges for war brides and 1,500,000 ranges for new homes to be built during the first six months of peace the American Stove Company is launching its new advertising campaign in national magazines this month.

ONE of the most rugged assignments ever undertaken by any football coach is the one just given to Herb Kopf. From the standpoint of sheer difficulty it ranks slightly ahead of the labors of Hercules, that of handling the destinies of the newly formed Boston Yankees of the National Football League. About all Herb has is a franchise and boundless energy.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 8 -- The death on Saturday of the Brazilian Ambassador in Argentina, Jose de Paula Rodrigues Alves, has led to what the Argentine Government regards as an implicit recognition by the Brazilian Government of the regime of President Edelmiro Farrell.

LONDON, May 8 -- Carrier-borne Barracudas of the Fleet Air Arm, protected by naval Hellcat fighters and a formidable escort of warships of the Home Fleet, swung into action against two enemy convoys off the Norwegian coast at dawn yesterday and sank two heavily laden supply ships and damaged three other vessels.

I would like to take this opportunity of applauding the courage of THE NEW YORK TIMES for its position concerning the television situation. This whole matter has been too long a question of industry argument, and you are performing a great public service in putting this matter before the readers of your publication.

LONDON, May 8 (AP) -- German forces have launched strong drives throughout Yugoslavia in an apparent effort to crush the Yugoslav Partisan army during the temporary lull on other Allied fronts, headquarters of Marshal Tito announced today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 15 per cent last week over the like week of 1943, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain of 19 per cent in sales.

After several years of practical deadlock the pattern of the war in China is perhaps about to change. The Japanese seem to be working at two plans, each of strategic importance. One is to open up railroad communication between Peiping and Hankow by occupying the stretch of line from Chengchow, on the Yellow River, southward.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- A supplemental brief prepared by Attorney General Biddle stating that the "power" involved in the Presidential seizure of the Chicago properties of Montgomery Ward Co. is "the power of requisition" was filed today with Federal Judge William H. Holly.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, and Alben W. Barkley, Senate majority leader, fired the opening shots last night in the campaign to elect Franklin D. Roosevelt President for a fourth term. Speaking here at the annual $50-a-plate Jefferson Day dinner at the Hotel Commodore, they hailed the leadership of the President, accepted Governor Dewey as his Republican opponent and criticized Mr. Dewey for his views on foreign affairs.

Business-like disposition of foods manufactured and packed according to war specifications and bearing the names of nationally known manufacturers is the most important unsettled problem now disturbing food manufacturers, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, declared yesterday in commending the program of the War Food Administration announced last Thursday by Lee Marshall, director of food distribution.

ALGIERS, May 8 -- In connection with Gen. Charles de Gaulle's statement in his Tunis speech yesterday that the French desired to be permanent allies of Russia it was learned today that after General de Gaulle's speech March 18, advocating a "western grouping of nations," Alexander E. Bogomloff, Russian Ambassador here, asked him what he meant.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Supervisory employes, or foremen, cannot be discharged or otherwise discriminated against because they belong to an independent foremen's union, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today.

Plans for the reorganization of the Federation of Crippled and Disabled, Inc., 163 West Fifty-seventh Street, were discussed yesterday by Assistant Attorney General Theodore D. Ostrow and Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel.
LONDON, May 8 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The Parker Pen Company and its Canadian subsidiary reported yesterday in the annual statement covering the fiscal year ended on Feb. 29, a net profit of $1,105,139 after charges and taxes totaling $3,106,961 and allowing for post-war refund of excess profits taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The wisdom of increasing tax burdens, an acknowledged effect of the tax-simplification bill, was questioned by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan today as Finance Committee hearings opened on the measure. Not long afterward Representative McLean of New Jersey declared on the floor of the House that the bill would raise "upward of $2,000,000,000" of new revenue.

Russia has cleared most of her land of the Hitlerite hordes, but the story of her suffering does not end there. Millions of her people today are even more destitute of the simplest material aids to living than they were after the German assault, before the Red Army's heroic westward drive from Stalingrad began.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Senate, by a vote of 63 to 1, passed today the House-approved bill to extend the lend-lease program for another year, after several hours of debate.

With the singular exception as to relief matters, our State Department's position in the Balkans has at best been only that of an "honest broker" in adjusting, as C.H. Sulzberger puts it, "any contradictory points between the Soviet Union and Britain."

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 8 -- The Japanese have launched a general offensive in the Manipur Hills of eastern India but are being hammered back with appalling losses, while at some points British Imperial troops have extended their own recent gains, it was disclosed tonight.

C. George Niebank, president of the Bank of Jamestown, Jamestown, N.Y., has been elected president of the New York State Bankers Association. The ballot was taken by mail because the association held no convention this year.

A new book by Charles and Mary Beard, "The Beards' Basic History of the United States," will appear Ang. 1 in a 69-cent edition put out by the publishers of The New Home Library (Garden City Publishing Company). Late next winter an enlarged and more fully illustrated edition will be distributed as a Book-of-the-Month-Club dividend.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- The recreation section of the War Production Board today turned down the Cubs' application to install night baseball facilities at Wrigley Field, Chicago, this season, but invited the Cubs to resubmit their request with a view to construction for 1945.

Confusion had free rein for a while yesterday at the Broadhurst, where the long-run musical comedy "Early to Bed" is current. It seems that Producer Richard Kollmar's office didn't notify the theatre of its intention to close the show Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The mass trial of twenty-nine alleged Nazi conspirators was reconvened after almost a week's recess today solely to adjourn until tomorrow when the separate hearing of the Federal District Court here against James J. Laughlin, one of the twenty-six defense attorneys, is expected to end.

LONDON, May 8 -- The British Empire Prime Ministers began the second week of their conferences today with a program now directed toward the discussion of problems of a more specifically Commonwealth character. These will include such matters as currency, commercial preference, migration and the machinery of empire consultation.

Associate Justice Frank Murphy of the United States Supreme Court called yesterday for mobilized action in combating the growth of undemocratic forces in America, and warned against the divisive and disruptive forces seeking political control here through a technique similar to that used in the early days by the Nazis in Germany.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 8 -- Measures to protect and support the level of prices and wages, which will be the peace-time counterpart of our war-time ceilings, should be planned now to keep our economy functioning properly after the war, Chester Bowles, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, declared here today.

Being one of the "experts on penicillin" referred to in the letter from Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 2, I am emboldened to emphasize some important points which he did not cover.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The stage was set today for the opening tomorrow of the Senate's much-postponed fight over repeal of poll taxes in Federal elections, with last-minute plans indicating a possibility that a test vote might be taken on the House-approved measure within a week.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8 -- Veronica Lake has been named by Paramount for one of the three co-starring parts with Eddie Bracken and Diana Lynn in "Out of This World," a musical to be put into production May 22. Miss Lynn will have the singing part, previously earmarked for Betty Hutton.

LONDON, May 9 -- The Spanish Government did not bow in defeat when it yielded to British-American pressure in signing an agreement by which valuable mineral exports were denied to Germany, the Earl of Selborne, Minister of Economic Warfare, explained in Parliament today.

Clifton Fadiman, editor, book critic and master of ceremonies for the "Information Please" radio program, has been made a member of the editorial board of the Book-of-the-Month Club, it was announced yesterday. His appointment is the first addition to the board of editors since the organization was launched eighteen years ago with Dorothy Canfield, Christopher Morley, Henry Seidel Canby, the late Heywood Broun and the late William Allen White.

Declaring that the Anglo-American oil conferences that have been going on in Washington for two weeks have resulted in "highly pleasing conversations," Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and Petroleum Administrator for War, revealed last night at a dinner of the Economic Club of New York at the Hotel Astor, that thus far they have been on what he described as a "high technical level."

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- The proposed text of the Philadelphia charter, comprising an international bill of social and economic rights for the common man, was reported out unanimously by a special five-man committee at the International Labor Organization conference today, with only one minor change.

The $2,000,000 the Lepke-Gurrah gang got from the garment and other industries in this city ten or more years ago were not extortions, Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, the middle-aged co-chief of the gang, declared yesterday. They merely were remunerations for "favors" conferred by the late Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and himself.

An amendment to the administrative code of the city to provide for the enforcement of Office of Price Administration's regulations by punishing any person who buys or sells a rationed commodity without giving or taking the required stamps, coupons or certificates, was introduced in the City Council yesterday by Michael J. Quill, Bronx Independent.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a series of transactions designed to liquidate and dissolve the Connecticut River Conservation Company, Boston, a subsidiary of the New England Power Association.

We first heard of an eye bank for New York last December. Now the bank is to become a reality with the establishment in New York Hospital of one which is to receive eyes that have been donated by will or from those whose sight is gone because of some defect of the optic nerve.

Eleven years ago tonight Berlin and a number of other German university cities saw a sight almost as obsolete as witch-burning. After long search and preparation great quantities of "un-German" books were burned. Joyous students bearing torches set logs afire and threw the volumes called traitors to "the German spirit" into the flames.

In a tragic letter from his 80-year-old sister, Anna Bach, in the Soviet Union, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony, has learned that his brother, Nicholas, died in Leningrad in 1941 "at the hands of the Fascist butchers," it was learned yesterday.

In the presence of five teachers and 150 pupils in the ground floor gymnasium of Public School 119, at 257 West 133d Street, a 9-year-old girl was fatally stabbed yesterday by one of two masked girl students of the same school because she had told a teacher that the two had stolen school property.

Marshal Rommel is wandering up and down the coasts of Europe like an uneasy spirit. Today he is said to be inspecting the fortifications along the deeply indented shore line of Italy, which must be improvised and full of holes and in recent days has admittedly been breached by commando raids.

Rear Admiral Luther Sheldon Jr., Assistant Chief of the Navy Bureau of Medicine and Surgery, told the House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York at its annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday that "the danger of tropical diseases for our armed forces has been overcome to a large extent," and that Navy medical officers felt that they "have the problem licked."
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor ended its spring meeting today by closing the door more tightly on readmission of the United Mine Workers.

Two hundred veterans of the first World War, members of Canadian Legion Post 120 of New York and of the Newfoundland War Veterans Association, gave a pint of blood each yesterday to the blood and plasma exchange bank of the New York Medical Society, in a mass donation on the floor of the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Twenty-fourth Street and Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, May 9 (U.P.) -- Fifteen speedy blockade runners loaded with thousands of tons of vital cargoes en route to German or Japanese war industry have been sunk by Allied naval and air forces, it was disclosed in the House of Lords today by the Earl of Selborne, Minister of Economic Warfare.
Wolfgang Rosenberg, 21-year-old Seabee serving in the Pacific and son of a former member of the German Reichstag, yesterday became the first recipient of the Monroe D. Franklin Medal at City College.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, May 10 (U.P.) -- A total of 871 Japanese were killed in the American conquest of Hollandia, Netherland New Guinea, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

J.J. Hasley and H.E. Barnes were elected yesterday directors of The Fair, Chicago, at the annual meeting of stockholders in that city. They succeed J.S. Schoff, former president of the department store, and H.J. Schwartz, who resigned.

Bishop William T. Manning appealed yesterday for cooperation among the United Nations as the hope of world peace for future generations. He spoke at the 161st annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Criticism turned into commendation for Gibbs Cox, New York marine architects, as the House Naval Affairs Committee absolved the firm today of accusations that it had collected excessive fees for work on Navy contracts.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow at 12:30 o'clock this morning, Moscow time, to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A new issue of $500,000 of temporary loan notes was scheduled yesterday by Quincy, Mass., for award tomorrow. The issue will be dated May 12, with one-half payable on Dec. 11 and the balance on Dec. 18, 1944.

KANSAS CITY, May 9 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Kansas City Southern Railroad elected today a slate of eighteen directors selected by a Midwestern and Southern group whose announced purpose was to bring control of the road to the area that it serves.

PEARL HARBOR, May 9 (AP) -- Army bombers encountered only moderate anti-aircraft fire when they bombed airfields on Ponape Island, Japanese base between Truk and the Marshalls, on Sunday, the Navy reported today.

Edward McGrath of St. Augustine's and Linton Baldwin of Poly Prep, the two top-seeded players, gained the final round of the annual tennis tournament of the Athletic Association of Private Schools yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

A FEW years ago the Dodgers opened their season with nine straight victories and, horror of horrors! lost the next game. Thereupon a disheartened Brooklyn fan remarked gloomily, "I knew they'd never be able to keep it up." Perhaps similar emotions filled the breasts of the followers of the St. Louis Browns who ripped off their first nine games, but the fact remains that the Brownies are leading the American League as of this moment.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Following are the texts of Secretary Jones' statement announcing the Government's return of Montgomery Ward Co.'s Chicago properties to the management and Iris order ending possession, and the text of a letter to Sewell L. Avery, company chairman:

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose last month from 1,028,489 to 1,090,581 shares, but the number of stocks with short interests declined from 664 to 624. Neither figure includes short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which were 34,923 shares at the end of March and 37,357 shares at the end of April.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., May 9 -Claimed for $3,000 about two weeks ago, Ray Daniels' Onecbill scored his third consecutive triumph in allowance races today when he won the $2,000 Bonnet Shores Purse at Narragansett Park.

We are fighting this war for certain ideals, among them the right of all peoples to choose their own forms of government and to be protected in them against external aggression. These are good ideals, especially when we hear them expounded after a good lunch or a good dinner.

Some days ago my former very excellent and intelligent Finnish-born laundress called on me, as she does a couple of times a year, to compare the doings of our boys in the service. We each have two. Naturally we talked of the Finnish question also. I told her how gratified I was that THE TIMES had published very fair editorials on the subject.
LONDON, May 9 -- Business on today's stock markets generally was quiet, but the tone was firm in all sections.

The work of the War Service Committee of St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square, will be advanced by proceeds from a concert of Gilbert and Sullivan music to be given Friday night in the main hall of the parish Memorial House, 207 East Sixteenth Street, by members of the Blue Hill Troupe, one of New York's best-known companies of amateur Savoyards.

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad has made considerable progress toward the merger of its leased lines, William White, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting held here yesterday. He said that the consolidation of these lines on terms already agreed upon would reduce the fixed charges of the carrier by around $1,100,000 a year.

Rare Chinese porcelains that belonged to William Cecil, Lord Burghley, lord treasurer under Queen Elizabeth and one of the most powerful figures in the England of the Tudors, have been bought by the Metropolitan Museum of Art from the estate of J.P. Morgan.

Plans for a network of permanent entertainment committees in cities where veterans' hospitals are situated were announced yesterday by Ginny Simms, radio and motion picture singer, at her Waldorf-Astoria Towers apartment. Miss Simms said that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has accepted honorary membership in the "Lest We Forget Program" started recently when a veteran of the first World War told the singer: "It has taken another war to get some entertainment in our hospital."
Johnny Longden was the big show at Belmont Park yesterday. The veteran jockey came close to a perfect score. He had mounts in four races, was first in three of them and second in the other.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 10 -- Premier Joseph Stalin announced early today the Soviet capture of Sevastopol, the great Crimean Black Sea naval base, whose 250-day defense by the Russians in 1941 and 1942 was one of the epic stands of the present war.

At the break of dawn four years ago today the earth of Western Europe seemed suddenly to split apart and to spew forth a monstrous juggernaut of conquest. The ground shook under the tramp of marching hordes of German soldiers and the air was filled with planes from which came death and destruction in the shape of bombs and the even deadlier parachute troops.

An exhibition of camera work entitled "Pacific Report," by W. Eugene Smith, 25-year-old war photographer, opens today at the Photography Center of the Museum of Modern Art, 9 West Fifty-fourth Street. The pictures were made in the battle areas of the Pacific from which the young photographer has just returned after eight months.

Through operation of the "bulk indent" system that controls pharmaceutical and chemical imports to Egypt, United States exports to that market have been limited to approximately 25 per cent of all permitted Egyptian importations, it was learned yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., May 9 -- Two sisters, who have been detained on Ellis Island since their arrival with other European refugees on the Gripsholm last March 15, were ordered arrested today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges of attempting to bring hidden messages into the United States.

Aviation will play a tremendous part in the post-war development of economic cooperation between the United States and the other American nations, Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commanding general of the Army Air Forces, predicted last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, opening the first Conference of Commissions of Inter-American Development.

Red Cross staff assistants who have done volunteer clerical work at war price and rationing boards here and women who have just completed the Red Cross dietitian's aide course were honored in ceremonies yesterday afternoon and evening in the New York chapter house, 315 Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Army increased its strength from 513,410 on Nov. 1, 1940, to 7,481,925 on Jan. 1 of this year.

NAPLES, Italy, May 9 -- The Germans have withdrawn abruptly from the east-central sector of the main Italian front and Allied troops, pouring into the breach for gains up to eleven miles, have driven within twelve miles of the big rail and highway junction of Sulmona, it was announced today.

FRANCIS OSBERT SACHEVERELL SITWELL, author of many poems, plays, novels and essays, brother of two other writers (Edith and Sacheverell), fifth Baronet, proprietor of Renishaw Hall and some 2,000 acres, a relative of a large percentage of the British peerage, finds his childhood as fascinating as do many authors of humbler connections.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 9 -- In France all nerves are on edge in expectation of major events. Sabotage increases on the railroads, and passenger trains are curtailed again. French and German courts are trying patriots everywhere and sending them before firing squads. Militiamen are being shot down in all parts of the country.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 7 (Delayed) -- Although it may sound unbelievable, it as a fact that Hungary, where Jewish citizens were comparatively well treated until March 19, is now preparing for the annihilation of Hungarian Jews by the most fiendish methods.

" La Traviata," City Center, 8:15 o'clock; "Pieces of Eight," opera by Bernard Wagenaar, Brander Matthews Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; two-piano recital, Josef and Rosina Lhevinne, Bronx House Music School benefit, Town Hall, 8:30; recital, Thelma Laurens, soprano, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30; program of portraits in song, Bartalini, Times Hall, 8:30.

Congress legislation was called for in a resolution adopted yesterday by the American Institute of Accountants providing that procurement agencies of the Government have full responsibility for settlement of terminated war contracts, with the Controller General to have no participation in the program.

BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) -- Pensive, looking fit and ready to run after his long and lucrative train ride to Louisville and back, arrived at Pimlico today to assume the favorite's role for Saturday's fifty-fourth running of the $50,000 added Preakness Stakes.

NOW the political hyphenates are beginning to sound off in Congress. The real object of their oratorical flights is simply to oblige the Government and people of the United States to mobilize their diplomatic and military forces, if need be, in support of some non-American people -- or else.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Moving to end the strike of foremen which is hampering war production in Midwest automotive plants, the National War Labor Board notified the strikers today that it would attempt to settle their disputes with employers over recognition of their union.

First Sgt. Edward F. Martin of the Signal Corps, who is 61 years old, has requested foreign duty and hopes to repeat his performance in World War I, the Army made known yesterday. On Nov. 11, 1918, he sent by telegraph in France a message from Marshal Ferdinand Foch, commander of the Allied armies, to Gen. John J. Pershing, commander of the American Expeditionary Force.

CLEVELAND, May 9 -- Endorsement of President Roosevelt for a fourth term by the convention of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, was forecast today when Philip Murray, president of both organizations, took the unusual course this morning of asking the delegates to consider his written request for such an endorsement. A formal committee report will be made during the convention, which will last through the week.

Three new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Roxy the new attraction will be "Pin Up Girl," a musical produced by Twentieth Century-Fox starring Betty Grable. Martha Raye, Joe E. Brown, John Harvey and Eugene Pallette are featured in the Technicolor film. . . .
Would you like to catch a nice whale? There's one in Long Island Sound, or at least a creature believed to be a whale spent the week-end in the western end of that unlikely body of water.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Proposals for poll tax repeal, which were prevented by filibuster from reaching the Senate floor in 1942, were taken under formal consideration there today, with Southern opponents of the legislation, apparently confident that they could muster sufficient votes to defeat closure, offering only a token resistance.

CHUNGKING, May 9 -- The fighting in Honan Province for the last three weeks is different from the spring and autumn reconnaissances in force and expeditious for looting and devastation that have been typical of Japanese military action in China during the last four or five years of the military stalemate.

Of one thing we may be certain about John L. Lewis. No ghost writer does his letters and speeches for him. The authentic beetle-browed touch is in everything he puts his name to. Teachers of rhetoric and literature who want to show their students the difference between style which is personal and genuine and style which is glib and machine made can find their text in two adjoining columns on our first page yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Three top admirals met in San Francisco last week-end in a conference that offered full opportunity for planning even heavier blows at Japan, the Navy disclosed today.

The fourteen-story store and apartment building at 200-10 West Fifty-seventh Street, at the corner of Seventh Avenue, with a one-story extension business floor and penthouse, has been sold by the Greenwich Savings Bank to the Sipal Realty Corporation for an indicated consideration of $110,000 above a mortgage of $530,000. The assessed value is $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Three opportunities were given to President Roosevelt at his press conference this afternoon to discuss the fourth term question, but he rejected them all. One questioner reminded him that it was "only seventy-one days until the Democratic National Convention."

The Petroleum Administration for War stands ready to allocate 25,000,000 gallons of gasoline in exchange for Cuban industrial alcohol, suggested by the liquor industry as a means of replenishing stocks and smashing the black market, if the War Production Board should see fit to make the request, according to Ralph Davies, deputy PAW administrator.

Magicians will hold court at this season's final "Fun With Book People" meeting, to be held on Saturday morning at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, under the sponsorship of THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the Association of Children's Book Editors and Junior Programs, Inc.

AT A NINTH AIR FORCE MEDIUM BOMBER STATION, Somewhere in Britain, May 9 -- As proud and peppy as on the day she made her first mission, the Mild and Bitter, a Ninth Air Force Martin Marauder, touched her wheels on the runway of this airfield at dusk last evening to complete her 100th mission against the enemy and set a record for any bomber based on these islands.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9 (AP) -- Yale University announced today it would play eight football games between Sept. 30 and Nov. 25 and that the latter date would be left open until Princeton University decides whether or not to continue the sport this fall.

After one year, ten months and six days, counting from July 3, 1942, when the last resistance ceased, the Russians are back in Sevastopol. The Germans, with their Rumanian allies, took the city after a siege of eight months. The Russians have retaken it in a matter of weeks.

Twelve hundred high-school students will assemble next Wednesday afternoon at the Ambassador Theatre to see a special performance of "Decision." The admission price for all seats will be 5 cents. The New York City School Theatre Program is sponsoring the event, the first of the season and the thirteenth of the series, with the cooperation of Edward Choate, producer of the Edward Chodorov play.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (U.P.) -- Representative Louis E. Miller, Republican, of Missouri, charged today that Chairman James L. Fly of the Federal Communications Commission used "threats and intimidation" to prevent The Reader's Digest from publishing an article criticizing the FCC.

The twelve central Federal Reserve Banks are required by law to maintain reserves of 40 per cent against currency and 35 per cent against their deposits. Prior to the outbreak of war this "weighted" ratio, taking account of both items, was above 90 per cent.

Increased price-fixing in July, and buying of new-crop months by commission houses on unfavorable rains in the Cotton Belt, carried prices slowly upward yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The tone at the close was steady and prices were 6 to 8 points net higher.

New and different trends, certain to develop in the post-war period, must command attention in industry planning at this time, Alexander Printz, chairman of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, said yesterday at the opening at the Hotel Astor of the three-day annual meeting of the executive committee of the organization.

Some ten pounds lighter and a month older since the last time he saw his ball club, Joe McCarthy, manager of the Yankees, returned to this city yesterday, ready, willing and most certainly able to resume operations. This means that Joe will be at the helm this afternoon when the New Yorkers engage the Tigers, first of the Western teams to invade the Bronx, at the Stadium.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Pressure from houses with Eastern connections disclosed today a lack of aggressive support in May rye on the Chicago Board of Trade and the price broke 1 7/8 cents a bushel from yesterday's final quotation before buying by professionals and shorts stemmed the tide.

HOLLYWOOD, May 9 (U.P.) -- Charles H. Carr, Federal District Attorney, said today that Justice Department officials had indicated that charges against Charles Chaplin, film comedian, and three others of violating the civil rights of Joan Barry, former protegee of Mr. Chaplin, should be dropped and probably will be after he receives written instructions from Attorney General Francis Biddle.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, May 9 -- This is a story about two pairs of brothers and how the elder in each case went to find the younger on the Anzio beachhead. It is a story without real names because sometimes names hurt more than they help.
Because of my anxiety to cooperate in every way with the regulations of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association and other interested organizations, have meticulously been "curbing" my dog.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Government abruptly terminated its possession of the Chicago plants and facilities of Montgomery Ward Co. today at 7 P.M., Central war time.

CHUNGKING, China, May 9 (U.P.) -- Pounded relentlessly by Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's Fourteenth United States Air Force, Japanese troops have been hurled back from the immediate approaches to Loyang, their key objective in Honan Province, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 9 (UP) -- A communique:

A relish prepared entirely from fruits and seasonings -- with not a trace of the tomatoes, cucumbers or other vegetables found in many such condiments -- is the novel product being introduced this week by Burt Co., a concern known for its delicious mint chutney and mint dressing.

Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, who came to this city years ago with the intention of becoming a singer, declared yesterday in connection with the observance of Music Week that the opportunity to hear good music at a cost within the means of the people had become a necessity among all civilized nations.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 10 -- The invasion bombing of western Europe went on at peak strength yesterday when more than 4,000 Allied planes from Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force to Seafire fighters of the British Fleet Air Arm swept over northern France and the Low Countries and blasted Nazi airfields, communications and coastal defenses from the Atlantic to Luxembourg and the borders of Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- A union of radio technicians who sit in a little glass booth and control the technical angles of broadcasting has served notice it will strike if the American Federation of Musicians receives a contract to operate record playing equipment on the air.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- By a voice vote the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill authorizing an estimated $807,953,270 of post-war appropriations for 112 flood-control projects on streams al lover the United States.

The Board of Education unanimously elected Miss Mary E. Dillon, Brooklyn member for the last two years and chairman of the finance committee, to be its first woman president at its regular meeting yesterday. Miss Dillon succeeds Ellsworth B. Buck, who was president two years.

MEXICO CITY, May 9 -- An agreement establishing diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and the Republic of Costa Rica has been signed by Constantine A. Oumansky, Soviet Ambassador, and Carlos Jinesta Munoz, Costa Rican Ambassador here, it was learned in diplomatic circles today.
Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff have returned from Palm Beach and will be at 860 Park Avenue until early next month, when they will go to their new home in Southampton, L.I.

LONDON, May 9 -- "Floating hedgehogs," which appear to be batteries of field and anti-aircraft guns mounted on obsolete naval vessels, have been added to the invasion defenses in the English Channel and the North Sea, according to the German High Command weekly Militaerische Korrespondenz aus Deutschland.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The War Production Board disclosed today that it was embarking on another program aimed at increasing production of essential articles of infants' and children's wearing apparel.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday were 1,118, compared with 1,023 in the preceding week and 1,724 in the similar period of 1943, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 528 against 441 last Tuesday.

Peggy Guggenheim opened her second Spring Salon for Young Artists yesterday at Art of This Century, 30 West Fifty-seventh Street. Twenty-four artists are represented by as many paintings, drawings and pieces of sculpture. These works were selected from about 300 entries by a jury composed of James Johnson Sweeney, Marcel Duchamp, Alfred H. Barr Jr., James Thrall Soby, Kenneth Macpherson, Miss Guggenheim and Howard Putzel.
The Metropolitan Golf Association has arranged a large schedule of one-day tournaments along with its championship which is being renewed after a lapse of two years.

Fellow-newspapermen, including his 79-year-old father, testified as defense witnesses at the trial of Frederick Heizer Wright in Federal Court yesterday, after Judge John Bright had overruled motions for dismissal of the indictment accusing him of failure to register with the State Department as a propaganda agent of the Japanese Government.

Ellsworth B. Buck, retiring president of the Board of Education has been nominated as the Republican candidate for Congress from the Eleventh New York district to run for the post vacated by the death of James A. O'Leary, Democrat.

Lindsay Bradford, president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, yesterday was unanimously elected president of the New York War Fund at a meeting of the board of directors of the fund at its headquarters, 57 William Street.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- When the President at his press conference today completed his summary of the facts and issues in the Montgomery Ward Co. case as they appear to him, two conclusions were possible. One is that the President is aware that the handling of the situation by the War Labor Board and the Attorney General was at least maladroit, has aroused much hostile public opinion and requires a drastic modification of policy.

Miss Jean Libbe, a stenographer, of 158-03 Selover Road, St. Albans, Queens, was acquitted yesterday in Queens County Court on a charge of criminal negligence in driving of an automobile that caused the death of Robert Stark, 10, of 120-29 178th Street, St. Albans, on June 3, 1943.

Elsa Baklor, soprano, made her debut at the New York Times Hall last night in a program of Russian, German, French, Hungarian and Spanish songs. Miss Baklor has a somewhat small, though well-trained voice which she uses not unintelligently.

At the opening of an exhibit on Underground Europe at Freedom House, 5 West Fifty-fourth Street, Jan Masaryk, deputy Prime Minister of Czechoslovakia, predicted last night that open rebellion would break out in Europe soon. In his country, he declared, "the people are ready for the orders to march."

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 9 -- A deposition by Mrs. Eva R. Stotesbury of Palm Beach, widow of Edward S. Stotesbury, the banker, was presented in Chancery Court here today when Advisory Master Douglas Herr began hearings on the action by Mrs. Stotesbury's son, James H.R. Cromwell, former United States Minister to Canada, to nullify a Nevada divorce obtained last December by his heiress wife, Doris Duke Cromwell, on a cruelty charge.
LONDON, May 9 -- The Dominion Prime Ministers went back today to what Prime Minister Churchill recently described as the "common building up of thought" on post-war security.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- A few hours after the Government returned to private management the Chicago properties of Montgomery Ward Co. which were seized two weeks ago on President Roosevelt's order, the United Mail Order, Warehouse and Retail Employees' Union (CIO) again established that it represented a majority of company employes in the plants here.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Members of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers concluded their annual meeting today with a forecast of better appliances, due to research, and of unlimited supplies of liquefied petroleum gas in the post-war era and applauded an attack on the Office of Price Administration for its efforts to control profits as well as prices.
LONDON, May 9 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Partisan forces of Marshal Tito have recaptured Berane, in Montenegro, after stubborn fighting, a broadcast communique said today.

LONDON, May 9 (AP) -- Staff Sgt. Joe Louis, heavyweight champion of the world, surprised American soldiers and others -- before whom he has appeared almost nightly in exhibitions -- by naming Max Baer today as the toughest opponent he ever had met.

Voting 13 to 1, the City Council adopted yesterday a resolution severely criticizing the State soldier vote bill and petitioning Governor Dewey to call a special session of the Legislature to correct, amend and liberalize the law and to make it conform as far as practicable with the Federal vote law for service men.

A leading broadcasting network asserts that purchasers should be told not to buy the present type of television receiver and to wait until pictures richer in detail can be received at higher frequencies, the possibilities of which should be explored for at least a year by a dozen radio laboratories.

Eight bullets were fired yesterday by two Brooklyn policemen in a chase at Eugene Agres, 27 years old, a paroled convict, after he had clubbed John Pereira, 65 years old, drug store owner at 316 Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Roosevelt said at his press conference today that the Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski of Springfield, Mass., had received a passport for his trip to Russia as a private citizen after it had been decided that there were sufficient reasons why the passport should be issued to him.

MEXICO CITY, May 9 -- The United States will allot additional weapons and equipment to the Mexican Army, Maj. Gen. Guy V. Henry was quoted in today's press as saying at a luncheon of high American and Mexican officers.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 (AP) -American President Lines, Ltd., issued today a supplement to the annual report, indicating earnings of about $829,635 for 1943, compared with $1,139,584 in 1942. Subsidy returns to the Government under the agreement with the Maritime Commission fell to $169,985 from $1,115,485.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries, in a report for the March quarter, issued for publication today, showed a net income of $17,242,862, equal to $1.38 a share, as compared with $14,739,314 or $1.16 a share, a rise of about 17 per cent in the corresponding three months of last year.

Closely following the recent large transactions which have brought the Journal Square section to the fore in Jersey City's realty activity, another important deal was closed there yesterday in the purchase by the Jersey City Stationers Corporation of the former Hudson County Buick showroom and service station at 870 Bergen Avenue, corner of Smith Street.
The main effort in the invasion of Western Europe undoubtedly must be made by amphibious troops in direct assault against the German coastal fortifications.

Edward McGoldrick, formerly a practicing attorney in Manhattan, has been devoting all his time for a year as a city employe operating a bureau to help alcoholics regain control of themselves, it was disclosed yesterday. His efforts, with the aid and encouragement of Mayor La Guardia, have achieved results sufficiently successful to cause the Mayor to approve plans to house this bureau in a building of its own, Mr. McGoldrick said.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -- Machinists affiliated with both major branches of organized labor ignored appeals today from national leaders and refused to resume work on two Navy ships awaiting completion at San Francisco Bay dry docks.

A new treatment which promises to safeguard against a serious form of heart disease by the use of penicillin in oral surgery was described for the first time last night before a staff meeting of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. The report was by Dr. Matthew D. Levin, who developed the new technique in collaboration with Dr. Leo Loewe of the hospital.

Further obstacles to recovery were encountered yesterday by the stock market as a mixed and narrow course again prevailed, broken only by activity in some specialties and strength in the low-priced motor issues. Although on balance there were more stocks on the higher side than in the losing column at the close, the moderate heaviness in an assortment of pivotal issues kept the composite price index from moving forward.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 9 (AP) -- Former Senator Rush D. Holt dropped behind tonight in early returns on his effort to make a political comeback by winning the Democratic nomination for Governor.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 -Philip Dorn, on loan from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, will go into the lead of "Stranger in Our Midst," the remake of "Petrified Forest," at Warners. He replaces Zachary Scott, who was named for the part when Paul Lukas withdrew.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 9 (AP) -- Two Mayors, Frank J. Lausche, Democrat, of Cleveland, and James G. Stewart, Republican, of Cincinnati, ran ahead tonight in contests for their respective party's nomination for Governor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- The overruling of precedents by the courts is following an "unmistakable" trend which is in general due to the personal attitudes of judges, but is traceable also to more impersonal forces, Associate Justice Robert J. Jackson told the American Law Institute today.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, Ceylon, May 9 (U.P.) -- British imperial troops have liquidated half of the recent Japanese besiegers of Kohima in eastern India, killing as many as 750 in two days, and are pressing an annihilation offensive against the rest, crushing them in their mountainside bunkers under tanks and the fire of massed artillery, official reports said tonight.

The Democratic State Convention in North Carolina a few days ago adopted a platform one plank of which called for an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide for ratification of treaties by majority vote of both branches of Congress instead of by a two-thirds vote of the Senate alone.

Mayor La Guardia was chided last night by Allen Wardwell, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, for failing to consult with bar associations and interested civic groups in the selection of city magistrates. Justices of the City Court were criticized also for failing to name lawyers as their clerks instead of political workers of the parties responsible for their nominations.

MADISON, Wis., May 9 -- The New Deal stands today in real danger of reaping some bitter harvests from the political partnership which it has carried on with the Progressives in Wisconsin for ten of the last twelve years.

Branding Mayor La Guardia as unsympathetic toward farmers and the Office of Price Administration as "Public Enemy No. 1" of the same group, W.H. Allen, New Jersey State Secretary of Agriculture, yesterday urged the formation of a council to protect the $2,000,000,000 farming industry in the Northeastern States.

As the Office of Price Administration last week freed from ration points 85 per cent of all meat cuts, to increase consumption, New York City's meat receipts dropped 2.2 per cent from the total of the preceding week. Beef sagged one-half of 1 per cent, pork fell off 1.6 per cent and lamb and mutton slumped 5 per cent, according to the weekly meat report yesterday by the War Food Administration, 150 Broadway.

The Germans have broken the long stalemate on the Italian chessboard. Unexpectedly, they are moving backward. They have withdrawn their fighting line ten miles from the outposts of the British Eighth Army on the central Italian front, and there are indications that the movement will extend all the way from Castel de Sangro to Casoli, twenty-four miles to the northeast.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Rural and urban women conferring on common problems were told today by Edward O'Neal, president of the Farm Bureau Federation, that relaxation of rationing by no means solved the food problem and they should turn to their victory gardens and canning activities with renewed zeal.

The Delia Austrian Medal, given annually by the Drama League of New York for the most "distinguished performance" of the season, was presented yesterday afternoon to Elisabeth Bergner, star of "The Two Mrs. Carrolls," now playing at the Booth Theatre.

LONDON, May 9 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, on the eve of the fourth anniversary of the German invasion of her country, broadcast a message of sympathy and hope to the mothers and other women of that nation tonight.

With a per capita effective buying income of $1,509 in 1943, New York City ranks sixty-first in the nation, according to the annual survey of buying power made by Sales Management Magazine. However, the income figure is $406 higher than the national per capita of $1,103, and represents a gain of $261 over the city's 1942 average.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that unconditional surrender was still the policy of this Government, as far as he knew.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Victor V. Boatner, a director of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad, today asked for an investigation by the full Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce of his assertion that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had exer cised "unreasonable and improper" influence in the road's affairs, and asked the setting aside of a subcommittee report that found no basis for the allegation.

The Germans have broken the long stalemate on the Italian chessboard. Unexpectedly, they are moving backward. They have withdrawn their fighting line ten miles from the outposts of the British Eighth Army on the central Italian front, and there are indications that the movement will extend all the way from Castel de Sangro to Casoli, twenty-four miles to the northeast.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Rural and urban women conferring on common problems were told today by Edward O'Neal, president of the Farm Bureau Federation, that relaxation of rationing by no means solved the food problem and they should turn to their victory gardens and canning activities with renewed zeal.

The Delia Austrian Medal, given annually by the Drama League of New York for the most "distinguished performance" of the season, was presented yesterday afternoon to Elisabeth Bergner, star of "The Two Mrs. Carrolls," now playing at the Booth Theatre.

LONDON, May 10 -- Members of the House of Commons went on record today in favor of continuance of currency fund discussions at Washington but did so on principle and with some lingering doubts about it all.

LONDON, May 10 -- Agreements' between the United States and British Governments on one hand and the Netherlands, Belgium and Norway on the other as to how the civil affairs of the three German-occupied countries are to be administered when the enemy is driven out soon will be signed here, it was understood today on the fourth anniversary of the Nazi invasion of the Low Countries.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 10 -- That the Swedes have a mind to settle with the Allies, on a compromise basis, the question of their export of ball bearings to Germany was hinted at tonight by a source that can well be considered highly initiated.

Lower Manhattan's "largest industrial center" will rise on the four-acre site of the old St. John's Park Freight Terminal on Varick Street under a post-war construction plan announced yesterday by private builders.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Acting Secretary James Vincent Forrestal, chief lieutenant of the late Frank Knox in the building of America's war-time fleet, was nominated today by President Roosevelt to be Secretary of the Navy.

A collection of American art which will be available for loan to museums, universities, schools and even industrial plants has been formed by the Encyclopaedia Britannica, E.H. Powell, president, announced yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, May 10 -- The death of the Brazilian Ambassador in Buenos Aires, Jose de Paula Rodrigues Alves, and the marked Pan-American character that the Argentine Government gave to his funeral have brought about a noticeable lessening of tension in the relations between Argentina and those countries on this continent that have not recognized Gen. Edelmiro Farrell as the lawful successor of Gen. Pedro P. Ramirez in the Presidency.

DUBLIN, May 10 -- When Prime Minister Eamon de Valera faced the Dail Eireann today for the brief adjournment session before the Deputies quit for the election campaign he had to face angry criticism from all Opposition parties for his precipitate action in decreeing a second general election within a year.

Because of the growing practice of cloak manufacturers in branding their products, the fair trade practice committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board is considering modification, in connection with branded merchandise, of the trade regulation prohibiting subsidy payments by members for retailers' advertising.

Michael Schaap, chairman of the board of directors of Bloomingdale's, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt attended by 300 department store executives. The occasion opened the drive of the department stores and specialty shops division of the United Jewish Appeal, of which Leonard Ginsberg is chairman.

Disclosing the sale of the company's roofing plant at Madison, Ill., as of April 1, T. Rieber, president of Barber Asphalt Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders at Barber, N.J., yesterday that the company has now withdrawn entirely from the roofing business, which could not have been continued without modernizing the plants and entering the building supply business with a complete line of materials.

Depending on what phases of the question one looks at, both the Government and the management of Montgomery Ward Co. may be said to have won a sort of victory and both to have suffered a defeat. The victory of the union in the election disposes of the company's claim that the union no longer represented a majority of its employes.

Although the War Department has issued a ruling which would permit contracting officers in dealing with terminated contracts to pay little attention to inventory limitations set by the War Production Board, industry representatives stated yesterday that sufficient controls remain to prevent abuse of inventory regulations for the purpose of building up material stocks for post-war production.

The City Council's 13-to-1 resolution for a special legislative session to improve the State service vote law is not likely to make a great impression in Albany. The law we now have was passed after some deliberation by the legislative majorities and Governor Dewey is on record as believing it to be a good law.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP) -- A compromise reorganization plan for the Midland System was assailed by a security holders' group today as "scarcely more than a reprehensible attempt to whitewash the Insull manipulations."

In his letter published in THE TIMES on May 8 Osmund Fraenkel opposed any specific reservation of freedom of speech for employers in NLRB disputes. Those who deny all possibility of improvement in NLRA (Mr. Fraenkel among them) oppose even so broad an amendment as: "Nothing in this act shall be construed to be in violation of the First Amendment to the Constitution."

The board of directors of E.P. Dutton Co. has elected Elliott B. Macrae as president, John Macrae Jr. chairman of the board and John Holwell, assistant secretary and assistant treasurer. On June 1, Nicholas Wredon will join the company.

" La Boheme" will be presented by the City Center Opera Company at 8:15 o'clock tonight at the City Center, with Irma Gonzalez, Natalie Bodanya, Mario Berini, John De Surra, Eduardo Rael and Ralph Leonard. Laszlo Halasz will conduct.

Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein dismissed yesterday a burglary indictment against Alonzo Gedney, 47 years old, of 712-A Monroe Street, Brooklyn, so the defendant would be free to attend ceremonies tomorrow at Fort Jay, Governors Island, at which his son, the late Corp. John Gedney, will receive posthumous awards for bravery in action.
