Although the number of Assembly districts in New York County has been reduced from twenty-three to sixteen by reapportionment, the number of Tammany Assembly district leaders and co-leaders will be increased from sixty-six to seventy-two.

TULSA, Okla., May 10 (AP) -- Importance of systematic maintenance to keep pipelines in operation in the present period of material and labor shortages has been stressed by speakers at the oil and gas conference of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

MOSCOW, May 10 -- The strategic relation of the Soviet ground forces' campaign in Rumania and the Anglo-American attacks on Rumania, Hungary and Austria was pointed up in an article today in Red Star, the Red Army paper. It said the three countries, led by Rumania, now supplied about 50 per cent of the liquid fuel badly needed by the Wehrmacht, which already had lost its Russian oil fields.

Five young volunteer dental assistants, for whom the dentist's chair has lost its terror, proudly received the press yesterday at the Children's Aid Society's Lower West Side Center and passed around certificates they had received for training in this field.
LONDON, May 10 (Reuter) -- Sir John Anderson, Chancellor of the Exchequer, made made it clear in the House of Commons today that the British Government did not intend going back to the gold standard.
Operations of the Electrolux Corporation in the three months ended on March 31 resulted in a net profit of $77,297 after all charges and taxes, according to the report issued for publication today.

NAPLES, May 10 (U.P.) -- Allied troops, driving onto the rugged Maiella plateau in central Italy, have swept through three villages in the wake of retreating enemy forces, while in the Fifth Army sector the Germans are hurriedly building fortifications south of Cassino, front reports said today.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Al Gerheauser pitched his second victory today as the Phillies handed the Cubs their thirteenth consecutive whipping, 7 to 1. The Phils hammered four pitchers for thirteen hits, with Jim Wasdell and Ray Hamrick each contributing three.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- A new deadlock in the affairs of Montgomery Ward Co. was threatened tonight as executives of the mail order house and union representatives both expressed dissatisfaction with the Government's seizure of the Chicago properties and their subsequent return to the company after a National Labor Relations Board election.

One hundred young women were sworn into the Army in Times Square yesterday. Noonday traffic was stopped and the sun beat down on 10,000 motionless witnesses as Col. Sumner Waite, chief of staff for the Second Service Command, ordered, through a loud speaker: "All applicants raise their right hands and repeat after me."

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., has virtually completed negotiations for the purchase of all the common stock of the Colonial Radio Corporation for about $3, 250,000, payable 60 per cent in cash and the balance in its own common stock, it became known yesterday when a special meeting of stockholders was called for May 18 to approve an increase in authorized common stock from 905,000 to 1,200,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Associate Justice Jennings Bailey today pronounced James J. Laughlin, one of the twenty-six defense lawyers in the sedition trial, guilty of contempt of court and fixed his punishment at $150 fine.

Detailed proposals for post-war economic and social cooperation among the American republics to promote industry, trade and employment, raise standards of living, and safeguard private enterprise, individual rights and world peace, will be presented by the United States delegation to the first Conference of Commissions of Inter-American Development, now in session at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Mr. and Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont of Far Hills, N.J., and Palm Beach have come to Mayfair House for a stay of several weeks.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 -- The Dodgers' opening engagement of their Western tour with the Cardinals and John Whitlow Wyatt's first start since April 21 against the Giants both were marked by singular lack of success today. Billy Southworth's league champions won, 4 -- 2, with Mort Cooper pitching his first triumph and first complete game in four starts.

The first hostel for Japanese-Americans in the New York area was opened yesterday, a week ahead of schedule, with the arrival at 168 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, of a family of three, father, daughter and son, from the relocation center at Gila River, Ariz.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Office of Price Administration today permitted manufacturers of household furniture whose operations are "unprofitable" chiefly as a result of increased wages ordered by the War Labor Board to apply for adjustments to their own price ceilings.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Principles which will govern disposal by the Treasury's new Surplus Consumer Commodity Disposal Division of Government-owned surpluses of consumer goods were outlined at a press conference today by Ernest L. Olrichs, who will head the division.

BOSTON, May 10 (AP) -- Although driven to the showers by an eighth inning uprising, Mel Harder was credited with his 200th major league victory today as the Indians beat the Red Sox, 5 to 4. Harder allowed four hits until the eighth, when Leon Culberson's safe bunt toward third started things rolling.

LONDON, Thursday, May 11 -- The assault on the Germans' defenses and communications in western Europe was maintained yesterday with methodical ferocity. From dawn to dusk more than 2,000 medium and light bombers, fighter-bombers and fighters of the Allied Expeditionary Air Forces attacked armed points and railway yards, airfields and bridges in France and Belgium.

The trustees of the New York Public Library announced yesterday an important gift of rare books and manuscripts from Dr. Albert A. Berg of this city. They will be added to the valuable collection of great works of English literature that Dr. Berg already had presented to the library in memory of his brother, Dr. Henry W. Berg, who died in 1938.

A protest to Price Administrator Bowles against the pricing amendment covering raw furs, asking its modifiaction or suspension, was sent last night by the Fur Brokers Association of America, Inc. The amendment was recently issued by the OPA and becomes effective June 23.

In a formal statement issued yesterday in the name of the Military Ordinariate, Catholic clergymen protested against what they described as two misstatements of fact and an unwarranted implication in the protest of twenty-three heads of Protestant denominations against a Selective Service ruling that would cancel draft deferments for pre-theological students.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, a Democrat long identified with isolationism, called on President Roosevelt today for the first time since 1938 and stayed about forty-five minutes.

Howard Butcher Jr., senior partner in Butcher Sherrerd, investment brokers, and a former president of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, has been elected a director of the Land Title Bank and Trust Company of Philadelphia.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 10 (UP) -- A communique

LONDON, May 10 -- While Britain and the United States have been mobilizing their forces of men and machines in this island base for their joint attack on Europe from the west, their preparations have not been permitted to interrupt the help they have been giving Russia.

Who Goes There, the George D. Widener colt that had spread-eagled his field in his first outing last week at Jamaica, was made a 3-to-5 choice in yesterday's forty-fourth Swift Stakes at Belmont Park, but apparently forgot the countersign.

Stockholders of the International Paper Company defeated yesterday by a wide margin at their annual meeting in this city a resolution enclosed in the proxy statement under a rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission calling for an immediate re-examination of accounts for several past years by independent engineers or accountants.
The ever vigilant Earle Doucette, chronicler of matters piscatorial in the State of Maine, wired from Down East yesterday:

CLEVELAND, May 10 -- The convention of the United Steel Workers' of America, CIO, adopted a resolution today reaffirming its no-strike pledge. The vote was overwhelmingly in favor of the action, but several speakers opposed it and a few negative votes kept it from being unanimous.

CHUNGKING, China, May 10 (U.P.) -- Minister of Information Liang Han-chao today announced that a meeting is now in progress at Sian, capital of Shensi Province, between representatives of the Communist "border zone" government and the Chungking regime.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The 1,630-ton United States destroyer Lansdale was sunk in the Mediterranean April 20 by German torpedo planes, which blasted her nearly in two, the Navy revealed today. Lieut. Robert Morris Morgenthau, 24 years old, son of Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., was one of the survivors.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The report of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, Inc., announced yesterday, shows for the three months ended on April 1 a net profit of $252,268, equal to 67 cents a common share. This does not include any refund on Federal taxes which the company will be entitled to receive, the statement declares.
consultations to be initiated by the British with the United States and Russia, it was learned in informed circles here today.

The day of the "hot" copywriter who worked as an individualist is over, Vernon M. Welsh, vice president and copy director of Geyer, Cornell Newell, Inc., said yesterday before the copy-testing group of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

CINCINNATI, May 10 -- They showered Bucky Walters with baskets of flowers tonight commemorating his 200th starting assignment as a pitcher and the Giants, bent on ruining the program for a crowd of 15,311, showered Bucky with a total of ten base hits.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Nobody can blame the President for trying to dismiss from the continuing record and the public mind those administrative acts and policies which have aroused strong national opposition. The country is engaged in total war; this is the eve of the great invasion of Europe; Mr. Roosevelt is the responsible leader of the nation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- In an action which overshadowed the unanimous adoption of the Philadelphia Charter by the International Labor Conference, the United States Government made known today and succeeded in having adopted by the United Nations Committee the social principles it would seek to have included in the peace settlement.

Basing his estimate on salvage records supplied by the Salvation Army, American Legion, Catholic Charities, American Women's Voluntary Services and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, Borough President James A. Burke said yesterday that total waste paper collections in Queens amount to nearly 1,000 tons every week or about twice as much as is picked up on Wednesdays by Department of Sanitation trucks in all five boroughs.

At this critical moment in the prosecution of the war the elevation of James V. Forrestal from Under-Secretary to Secretary of the Navy in succession to his late chief, Frank Knox, comes as welcome news. It is a well-deserved promotion. It should insure continuance of Navy administration on an even keel.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- J.C. James, vice president and general manager of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad has answered the Interstate Commerce Commission's query as to what services Morgan Stanley Co. of New York, investment bankers, performed for the Burlington to earn the $75,000 fee specified in the Burlington's application to issue $30,000,000 of collateral trust bonds and $10,000,000 serial notes.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Railroad securities must be sold under competitive bidding, the Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today in ending a long and bitter fight over the problem. Commissioners Claude R. Porter and Carroll Miller dissented, while Commissioner William E. Lee was absent and did not participate.

CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, May 11 (AP) -- A Japanese force from Shansi Province forced a crossing to the south bank of the Yellow River Tuesday and is attacking heavily northwest of Loyang, in an apparent attempt to put a pincers on that strategic railway city in Honan Province, the Chinese Command disclosed today.
PITTSBURGH, May 10 (AP) -- Outfielder Jim Russell's two-base hit in the eighth scored Johnny Barrett and Frank Zak to give Pittsburgh a 4 -- 2 victory over Boston tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for approval of an Army budget of $49,283,916,500 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, of which $15,676,652,700 would be new appropriations.

Concerned over the recent regulations of China's Ministry of Education governing the "thinking and actions" of students from that nation in this country, American colleges and universities are becoming reluctant to admit more Chinese students until these rules have been removed, it became known yesterday. Several institutions are making freedom from interference a condition for admission.
LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

CHARLESTON, W.Va., May 10 (AP) -- Rush D. Holt, former "boy Senator," conceded tonight that Judge Clarence W. Meadows of Beckley had spiked his attempt at a political comeback when he sought the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination in yesterday's primaries.

COLUMBUS, May 10 (AP) -- Mayor James G. Stewart of Cincinnati won the Republican nomination for Governor of Ohio, complete unofficial returns from yesterday's primary showed tonight, but the possibility of a recount was immediately raised.

Award of new issues of notes, aggregating $7,397,000, were made yesterday by twelve local housing authorities in various parts of the country. Salomon Bros. Hutzler obtained the award of $3,348,000; Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., $1,940,000; the Capital National Bank of Sacramento, Calif., '$1,624,000; and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, $485,000.

" The White Cliffs of Dover," Metro's adaptation of the poem, "The White Cliffs," by Alice Duer Miller, will have its local premiere this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Irene Dunne and Alan Marshal are co-starred in the drama, which was directed by Clarence Brown and produced by Sidney Franklin.

MOSCOW, May 10 -- All Russia celebrated today the liberation of Sevastopol, mighty fortress and former main base of the Soviet Black Sea Fleet, whose recapture took three days' fierce battles compared with 250 days required by German and Rumanian troops to overcome the resistance of the Russians when the city was under siege in 1941 and 1942.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 10 -- Advisory Master Dougal Herr of the New Jersey Chancery Court ruled today that the Nevada divorce obtained by Doris Duke Cromwell from James H.R. Cromwell, former United States Minister to Canada, was invalid in this State on all the grounds presented by Mr. Cromwell, who contended that the tobacco heiress was not a legal resident of Nevada when the divorce decree was granted in Reno last December.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 10 -- Frank Laboon, the first Army twirler to go the route this season, shut out Columbia, 8 -- 0, with five scattered hits on Doubleday Field today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that April weather brought a 60,000,000-bushel increase in the winter wheat crop, but said this was offset largely by delays in planting of spring crops caused by one of the wettest and coldest spring seasons in years.

ABOARD A U.S. CARRIER, off Truk, May 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- One after another, two American torpedo planes, a dive bomber and two fighters were shot down by Japanese anti-aircraft fire yesterday and crashed into the Pacific Ocean off the eastern reef of Truk atoll.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- May rye declined 5/8 cent a bushel at the opening today on the Board of Trade to sell at the lowest price in about two months, but professional support appeared and a rally of 1 3/8 cents from the bottom followed with the close showing a net gain of 5/8 cent.
After starting unchanged to 1 point higher yesterday, the cotton market turned and closed at 8 to 14 points net down, at the lows of the day for active months.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 10 -- Foreboding caused in Bulgaria by news of the fall of Sevastopol and the arrival of elite German shock-troop reinforcements was increased today when the Bulgarian Cabinet and Regency Council met in joint session to consider a mysterious German communication presented to the Bulgarian Foreign Minister by the German representative in Sofia, according to a report to the Swiss press received here tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- In the midst of the second day of the Senate's fight over repeal of poll taxes in Federal elections, with prospects for a forced limitation of debate concededly slender, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called on Governor Dewey today, because of his "strategic position in the Republican party," to urge all Republican Senators to vote to invoke closure Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Vice Admiral F.J. Horne, Vice Chief of Naval Operations, and Vice Admiral Randall Jacobs, Chief of Naval Personnel, voiced opposition before the House Committee on Post-war Military Policy, today to any movement toward unification of the armed forces until the war was over, and expressed grave doubts of its value at any time.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The National War Labor Board set the stage today for another possible encounter between President Roosevelt and Montgomery Ward Co. by referring to him the refusal of a Springfield, Ill., subsidiary of the mail-order house to comply with a board directive for union maintenance of membership.

" Pieces of Eight," a new operatic comedy in two acts by Bernard Wagenaar, received its premiere last night at the Brander Matthews Theatre, where it was presented by the Columbia Theatre Associates and the Department of Music of Columbia University.

A garden of 3,000 tulips blooming on a third-story terrace of Rockefeller Plaza was dedicated yesterday in tribute to Holland, invaded four years ago by the Nazis. The ceremonies, attended by a number of refugees, as well as prominent members of the Dutch colony in the city, were held in the library of the Holland House Corporation of the Netherlands, whose windows look out on rows of flowers developed from stock originating in the Netherlands.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has named Gregory Peck and Gene Tierney for the leads in "Dragonwyck," the Anya Seton novel of up-State New York, which will be produced by Ernst Lubitsch and directed by Joseph Mankiewicz.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Observers of the livestock market commented again today that many hogs are being unloaded at markets now because of a misunderstanding among producers regarding the announced change in ceiling prices.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday for the first three months of this year a net income of $1,781,314, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges. The net compared with $1,233,465 in the three months ended on March 31, 1943. Gross revenues were $46,162,676, against $34,968,252, a gain of 32 per cent.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week reached a new high of 4,518,550 barrels daily, an increase of 87,250 over the 4,431,200 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The previous peak was in the week ended on Nov. 13, 1943, when production averaged 4,436,450 barrels daily.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, May 11 -- American troops rescued 707 Allied prisoners when they stormed ashore at Hollandia and Aitape, on the northwestern coast of New Guinea, Gen. Douglas MacArthur disclosed today in a communique that set Japanese losses for the operation so far at 1,502 killed and 290 captured.

Letters mailed to United Nations prisoners of war, detained or interned civilians, and belligerents held in a neutral country are exempt from all postal charges and are acceptable for mailing even though the regular mail service to the destination may be suspended, according to instructions just issued from Washington, it was announced yesterday by Albert Goldman, postmaster of New York. However, if air-mail service is desired, postage must be prepaid.

The Musicians Emergency Fund, between last Sept. 1 and March 1, provided engagements through which musicians earned $433,595. Mrs. Lytle Hull, president, in reporting the fund's activities at the annual meeting yesterday afternoon in The Cottage of Hampshire House, said this sum was nearly one-third of all the employment obtained for musicians from 1932, when the fund was organized, through Aug. 31, 1943.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 10 -- The Brazilian press today stresses Argentine's action in declaring three days' mourning in memory of Jose de Paula Rodrigues Alves, late Brazilian Ambassador in Buenos Aires, which some observers here interpret as aimed to place Brazil on the spot by seeking some sign of recognition of the Farrell regime.

That planned double-barreled celebration to honor the return of their manager and the seventy-sixth birthday of their president backfired on the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium. And, if Joe McCarthy suffered a relapse and Ed Barrow left the grounds in a hurry, neither could be blamed.

DETROIT, May 10 -- The question whether union leaders are to be allowed to unionize management and take over control of war production was declared today by the Automotive Council for War Production to be the real issue in the strike by foremen in twelve plants of major war producers in the Detroit region.

Endeavoring to correct the impression gained from reports of airline companys that they had given up one-half of their equipment to further the war program, Col. Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, declared yesterday that the industry actually had given up four times the number of planes operated at this time last year, which was 166.

The facts about tea -- how much is available in comparison with peacetime years, what varieties are on hand in city stores, what kinds are not, etc. -- were presented to us yesterday by the Tea Bureau It said that stocks, now 75 per cent of normal, are coming from India and Ceylon, which have increased production remarkably to make up for the loss of pre-war sources -- China, Java, Sumatra, Formosa and Japan.

Frederick Heizer Wright was working under assignment by The New York Daily News when he sought information on lend-lease aid to China in May, 1941, according to testimony introduced yesterday in Federal Court. Wright is on trial on charges of serving as an unregistered propaganda agent of the Japanese for ten years prior to Pearl Harbor.

A sweeping order commanding all detectives and other plainclothes policemen to visit every city cabaret, dance hall, pool parlor, bowling alley and bar and grill twice nightly, and four times on holidays, to look for minors, was issued last night by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

Sustained by demand for low-priced issues and an assortment of specialties, the stock market continued yesterday to drift over an irregular course, although it veered to the higher side. A better front was presented also by some of the pivotal stocks in the heavy industrial section, which proved a bolstering influence, but bids remained on the conservative side on the New York Stock Exchange.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, announced yesterday that Mrs. Sara Pelham Speaks, Negro social welfare worker and former teacher, had been designated for the Republican nomination for Representative in the new Twenty-second Congressional District.

First shipments of penicillin, powerful disease-fighting chemical are being received by the sixty-one hospitals in the city designated as distributors under the new system of allocation to civilians, it was learned yesterday.

MONTREAL, May 10 (AP) -- A four-run rally in the ninth fell one run short for Jersey City today and Montreal won, 7 -- 6. The Little Giants used three pitchers, with the loss charged against Harry Palmer, who started. Gabbard was credited with the victory.

Orders relating to the procedures and duties of 111 temporary wartime patrolmen who have been accepted and trained by the Police Department for service until six months after the war were issued yesterday by Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

What moves me to write this letter is a paragraph in the opinion of the United States Supreme Court in a case very recently decided (Yakus v. United States, 64 Supreme Court Rep. p. 664). The defendants in that case were charged with violating a regulation of the Price Administrator which fixed a maximum price for beef.

Through the Army Exchange Service, mail-ordered Mother's Day gifts are being sent from service men and women stationed all over the world. The civilian staff at the exchange service has been too busy this week to compile figures on the volume of its business, but it was learned yesterday that orders for flowers alone totaled 365,000, while last year only 115,000 requests for flowers were received for both Easter and Mother's Day.

For the third time since the country went to war Congress is now acting on a bill to lift the legal limit on the national debt. The figure today stands at $210,000,000,000. The Administration proposed recently that it be raised to $260,000,000,000. The Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee forced a compromise which proposes to set the figure at $240,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- By a voice vote the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill increasing the national debt limite from $210,000,000,000 to $240,000,000,000.

The annual report of the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., issued yesterday to stockholders by Leonard Ginsberg, president, disclosed an increase in sales to the second largest Volume on record. The total, including $201,846 from licensed departments, was $21,835,632 for the year ended on Jan. 31, compared with $20,687,207 in the preceding fiscal year.

Richard Kollmar yesterday revised his plans for the local presentation of "Dream With Music," the musical comedy in which Vera Zorina, Ronald Graham and Joy Hodges are starred. The opening has been advanced from May 26 to next Thursday night and the production will be installed in the Majestic rather than the previously announced Forty-fourth Street.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, May 11 (AP) -- Japanese atrocities, including nailing Chinese to palm trees by driving iron spikes through their foreheads, were made public today simultaneously with the release of a headquarters report that the American invaders of Hollandia and Aitape had freed 707 Allied prisoners.

Herman Wallenda, a member of the famed Wallenda troupe, the high-wire act in the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, yesterday afternoon gave an audience of 10,000 persons in Madison Square Garden an unexpected thrill when he attempted a double back flip on the high wire, fifty feet above the arena, missed, then caught the wire by one hand.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 10 -- Spearheaded by fifty American tanks, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's Chinese troops have smashed through to open country in an all-out drive to reach Mogaung before the monsoon, while airborne Chindits have attacked Japanese positions south of the vital Burma base, bringing it under a two-way assault, dispatches revealed tonight.

Industry representatives will meet in Washington today with OPA officials to discuss the work clothing situation. Matters to be brought up will include the profit-and-loss statements of representative manufacturers, which industry executives declare show substantial dollar losses on production of low-end garments.
According to an editorial in THE TIMES of May 5, you feel that everybody will consider the new simplified tax bill an excellent one.

ALGIERS, May 10 -- Vice Admiral Edmond Derrien, who surrendered Bizerte and the French naval vessels there to the Germans in November, 1942, went on trial for his life on charges of treason here today.
The contribution that better lighting may make to the homes of tomorrow was discussed yesterday at the regional home service conference of the Edison Electric Institute in the Hotel Belmont Plaza.

Inflation is not likely to occur at the end of the war, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance of New York University, told the American Spice Trade Association yesterday at its meeting in the Hotel Astor. The end of hostilities will witness a material reduction in output of war materials and an increase in the number of unemployed. People out of work do not indulge in a spending spree, Dr. Nadler said.

THE TIMES of May 7 contains the results of two Gallup polls. The question asked in one was: "Do you think the Government did the right thing in taking over the Montgomery Ward plants, or was it a mistake?" Sixty-one per cent thought it was a mistake.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- Following is the text of the Philadelphia Charter as adopted today by the International Labor Conference:

An epidemic of ringworm of the scalp in New York City involving "several thousand children" has been spreading for more than a year, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York, at the Hotel Pennsylvania, by a committee of five physicians appointed by the Association of Dermatosyphilologists of Greater New York.

SEATTLE, May 10 (U.P.) -- The Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski, Polish-American priest, returned to the United States tonight after a twelve-day stay in Russia, but refused to comment on his talks with Premier Joseph Stalin concerning the Polish Catholic Church.

The Office of Price Administration announced yesterday its first arrests of distributors of an improved type of counterfeit gasoline ration coupon. These counterfeits, while not good enough to pass Government tests, had succeeded in fooling dishonest operators of gasoline stations who thought they were buying stolen genuine coupons.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, May 11 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, May 10 -- About 1,400,000 German civilians have been trained to use rifles and revolvers in defense of the Reich, according to an announcement on the German radio today. Thus almost exactly four years after the formation of the British Home Guard in the face of the threat of a German invasion the enemy is belatedly instructing civilians to meet a similar onslaught from the base of Britain.

LONDON, May 10 (U.P.) -- Forty thousand Bulgarian guerrillas are fighting beside Marshal Tito's Partisans on the Yugoslavia-Bulgaria frontier, a communique broadcast by the Free Yugoslavia radio said tonight.

BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- Most of the 3-year-old stakes are still to be run, but the championship of the division is likely to be decided over Pimlico's ancient racing strip Saturday when Warren Wright's Pensive, the Kentucky Derby winner, tangles with Platter in the richest of the fifty-four runnings of the Preakness Stakes.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP) -- Luke (Hot Potato) Hamlin was really hot today as he pitched the Athletics to a five-hit 9-to-0 victory over the White Sox.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 (AP) -- An agreement to settle claims of William G. Heiner, trustee for the Pittsburgh Terminal Coal Company, against several other companies for $1,803,319 in cash and $400,000 in property was reached today at a meeting of representatives of the defendants, Samuel Kaufman, attorney for the trustee, said.
LONDON, May 10 -- The stock markets here generally were firm today with a fair amount of business transacted. Rubber shares showed further all-around advances in a narrow range.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- This tatement was issued today by Sewell L. Avery, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co.:

ONE of the strangest fights in the history of the ring ended with dramatic abruptness forty-four years ago today, and old-timers still talk of it in tones of awe. It was the bout at Coney Island between Jim Jeffries and Jim Corbett for the world heavyweight championship. Even at this late date it seems worth a backward glance.

A group of new rooms defined as an exhibition of architecture and decoration was previewed at Lord Tayolr's yesterday afternoon. Thee six rooms, comprising a house set in a background of tropical vegetation, will be open for public inspection today. Early Empire elegance is the decorative theme of the whole house. Some of the furniture is antique, some of it specially designed along early nineteenth century lines.

In the fourth performance of her repertory season at the National Theatre last night, Martha Graham revived three of her most famous solos from earlier programs of her career. Among them, as a matter of course, were "Frontier" and "Lamentation," the latter the oldest work in her current repertoire, and the former so popular over the last few years as to be virtually her trade-mark.

All is in readiness for the much-discussed auction sale of paintings and sculptural works from the Museum of Modern Art's collection. The sale will take place this evening at 8:15 in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, where the assembled material has been on public view since Saturday.

LONDON, May 10 -- About 1,400,000 German civilians have been trained to use rifles and revolvers in defense of the Reich, according to an announcement on the German radio today. Thus almost exactly four years after the formation of the British Home Guard in the face of the threat of a German invasion the enemy is belatedly instructing civilians to meet a similar onslaught from the base of Britain.

LONDON, May 10 (U.P.) -- Forty thousand Bulgarian guerrillas are fighting beside Marshal Tito's Partisans on the Yugoslavia-Bulgaria frontier, a communique broadcast by the Free Yugoslavia radio said tonight.

BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- Most of the 3-year-old stakes are still to be run, but the championship of the division is likely to be decided over Pimlico's ancient racing strip Saturday when Warren Wright's Pensive, the Kentucky Derby winner, tangles with Platter in the richest of the fifty-four runnings of the Preakness Stakes.

BALTIMORE, May 11 (AP) -When Ben Jones sends Pensive to the post in the fifty-fourth Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Saturday he'll be seeking not only the second leg on the turf's triple crown for the Kentucky Derby winner but a continuation of a record that has other trainers wondering whether the Missourian can make a mistake.

Party-boat owners in this area who have been clamoring for Coast Guard permission to take their vessels off shore may have their wishes fulfilled soon. A call to the Third Naval District headquarters here yesterday developed the fact that, while not ready yet, plans for relaxing the regulations are well advanced.

NAPLES, May 11 (AP) -- Heavy mortar and artillery assault on Allied positions in the Cassino area and an exceptionally concentrated artillery barrage against the central sector of the Allied beachhead perimeter were announced today by Allied headquarters.

Increased participation by organized labor in post-war economic planning and development throughout the western hemisphere was asked by representatives of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations at yesterday's meeting of the Conference on Inter-American Development at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Office of Price Administration placed specific dollars-and-cents price ceilings today over all wholesale and retail sales of cotton, Jersey leather-palm work gloves, and at the same time revised the specific prices fixed in January at the manufacturing level.

Operations of the Celanese Corporation of America in the first three months of this year resulted in a consolidated net profit of $1,850,101 after provision of $3,166,000 for Federal taxes on income, Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president, reported to stockholders in a quarterly statement to be released today.

A total of 8,165 inquiries on facilities for children available here were answered during 1943 by the information bureau of the Children's Welfare Federation at 435 Ninth Avenue, it was revealed yesterday at the thirty-second annual meeting of the federation at St. Mary's Hospital, 405 West Thirty-fourth Street.

Continued improvement in Cotton Belt weather reports and weaker grain markets were factors yesterday in price movements on the New York Cotton Exchange and the market closed 1 point higher to 8 points lower than on Wednesday, with new crop months relatively easy.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 11 -- With a twinkle in his eye, former Postmaster General James A. Farley spoke with veneration today of Journal Square as one of the "battlegrounds" in the fight for free speech as he stood in the Hotel Plaza, hard by the place where Mayor Frank Hague's gendarmes used to chase orators having views not to the Mayor's liking.

Fifty French patriots risked their lives to prevent the Germans from scrapping a statue of Lafayette in a little town in France last December, the Society of the Cincinnati was told last night by Henri Hoppenot, delegate of the French Committee of National Liberation.

KALININ, Russia, May 11 (AP) -A glimpse of the future of postwar Russia was given to correspondents at Kalinin. It is a scene of smart young men with military bearing and elegant manners in a city that was devastated by war but which already has returned to something like normal life.

War production of the International Harvester Company is declining, making it difficult for the company to obtain and hold sufficient manpower, but the company expects to make some 20,000 trucks for civilian use this year, for the first time since early in 1942.

A drive in the women's garment industry that already had realized more than 430,000 pounds of clothing for families in recaptured Soviet areas were brought to a climax yesterday afternoon when 7,000 workers and employers in the industry held an open-air rally in Thirty-sixth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

The stock market was steady yesterday and there was a continuation of activity in recent favorites, but no definite trend appeared. Price fluctuations again were minor except in a few situations. Final quotations were firmer than those in the early hours, when irregularity followed a firm start.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a complaint in the Federal court at Baltimore today seeking a mandatory injunction and final judgment to compel the management of Certain-teed Products Corporation to vote at a reconvened stockholders' meeting scheduled for tomorrow, proxies obtained prior to April 12.

Gert Hans von Gontard proved a big disappointment when he ventured into the business world in 1941, according to testimony yesterday at his trial in Federal court. He is accused with three other men, also on trial, of conspiracy to evade the draft.

Martha Graham last night revived her "Primitive Mysteries" in her repertory season at the National Theatre and proved it to be what most of us have known it was for years, a genuine masterpiece. In its first presentation back in 1931 the audience gave it a memorable demonstration, and this was before the days when audiences began to shout bravo as a matter of course at the drop of a pirouette.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- The Cubs, aided by the seven-hit pitching of Eddie Hanyzewski, snapped a thirteen-game losing streak today by defeating the Phillies, 5 to 3, for their first victory since the opening day of the season, more than three weeks ago.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have decreased $43,017,000 during the week, while note circulation for the system as a whole increased $95,084,000 to a new high record.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The War Department gave details today of the pattern it has set up for "streamlined" separation centers to be established throughout the country, modeled on the first installation at Fort Dix, where the process of discharging and orienting soldiers for return to civilian life has been cut down from a period of "three weeks or more" to forty-eight hours.

Your editorial of May 7 which sets forth the very real dangers and confusion of divided loyalties among American citizens of foreign extraction does Father Orlemanski an injustice in considering him a "spectacular illustration."
LONDON, May 11 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Testimony of high Army and Navy officials on consolidation of the armed forces before the House Committee on Post-War Military Policy, lapsed today into a perfunctory phase which seems destined to continue until the invasion of Europe is under way.
Seapower and airpower will play major roles in transporting and supporting the amphibious invasion of western Europe.

NEWARK, N.J., May 11 -Four men, including two officials of this city, and a corporation were indicted by the Essex County grand jury this afternoon on a charge of conspiracy to defraud the city. The indictments resulted from a month's investigation into the City Commission's authorization and later cancellation of the purchase of land at Port Newark for $264,000.

One hundred and twenty-four years ago today Florence Nightingale was born in the city after which she was named. Nearly sixty years later Benjamin Jowett, her friend for a generation, told her that there were thousands of girls between 18 and 23 named after her.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The War and Navy Departments called on the Foremen's Association of America tonight to end a strike which has tied up munitions production at thirteen plants in the Detroit area.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The committee which the House created to investigate the Government's seizure of Montgomery Ward Co. voted today to seek a $10,000 appropriation from the House Accounts Committee with which to pursue its inquiry.

PITTSBURGH, May 11 (AP) -- Big Jim Tobin's "flutter ball" baffled Pittsburgh today while his mates collected eighteen hits off two Pirate pitchers to give the Braves a 7-2 victory and even their current series at one game each.

New York Stock Exchange member firms were notified yesterday that beginning on next Monday they must ask for deposits in "when issued" and "when distributed" deals equivalent 'to Stock Exchange margins for an issued security.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Applying the brakes to the draft as a result of decreased Army and Navy demands, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, issued orders today staying the induction of most men of 26 through 29 years for at least six months and deferring older men for an indefinite period, possibly permanently.

LONDON, May 11 (U.P.) -- Huge forces of German tanks and infantry are attacking the Soviet bridgehead on the west bank of the Dniester River above Tiraspol, but so far the Red Army has thrown them back with grave losses in men and material, Moscow reported tonight.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 11 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- There is bound to be more government in our lives after the war than there was before the war, Miss Anna Lord Strauss, new president of the National League of Women Voters, told a press conference at national headquarters today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, May 12 (AP) -- Liberator bombers from the Solomons set fires on Truk Wednesday and other bombers cratered the runway of Woleai in the western Carolines Tuesday, headquarters reported today.

The availability of a new community health service for persons of low income, providing hospitalization with ward accommodations, was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, president of the Associated Hospital Service, New York's Blue Cross Plan, who revealed that 127 hospitals in the metropolitan area have agreed to participate in the plan.

Recent arrivals from Algiers describe the resentment felt in French official circles when it became known that all diplomatic privileges, concerning coded telegrams, couriers, etc., had been suspended by the British Government as a measure of security prior to the invasion of the Continent.

Although the excess reserves of all member banks of the Federal Reserve System remained unchanged in the fiscal week ended Wednesday at $800,000,000, the New York City member banks continued to show a reserve deficiency, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

LONDON, May 11 -- Russian forces neither have asked nor been invited to "occupy" Norway, it was stated on indisputable authority here today. This mistaken impression arose when it became known that Moscow was studying a separate draft of an agreement concerning control of Norwegian civil affairs during the period of liberation.

On the basis of an announcement by the French Committee of National Liberation the first United Nations troops are already in France. They cannot be described as part of the invasion. In fact, when they think of invasion they must think of the Nazis.

CHUNGKING, China, Friday, May 12 -- The Japanese invaders of Honan Province have won control of the entire length of the important Peiping-Hankow Railway and, in swift gains over a wide area, have trapped several groups of Chinese troops, the Chinese High Command acknowledged today.

Henry J. Kaiser, shipbuilder and a native of this State, praised the efforts of the Greater New York Fund in behalf of 403 voluntary hospitals, health and welfare agencies yesterday at the first report luncheon of the current campaign in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Paradise Court, a six-story apartment building for sixty-one families at 2040 Grand Concourse, southeast corner of 200th Street, has been resold by Isadore Silverman after an owenrship of three weeks to a client of Darling McDonald, brokers.

ST. LOUIS, May 11 -- Thanks to the skillful pitching of Curt Davis, with some timely hitting and near-brilliant playing by the much-maligned shortstop, Bill Hart, the Dodgers today won a nip-and-tuck, battle from the Cards, 2 -- 1, to even the series.

Testifying at his trial in Federal court, Frederick Heizer Wright denied completely and specifically yesterday the Government's charges that he had served the Japanese for ten years prior to Pearl Harbor as an unregistered propaganda agent.

In a recent speech Gov. Thomas E. Dewey blamed the failure to obtain world peace after World War I on the illness of President Woodrow Wilson. The same statement was made more recently by former Representative Bruce Barton.

William Martin Singer, 35 years old, an ex-convict, who said he had sold $250,000 in insurance yearly as vice president and treasurer of the concern at 123 William Street headed by his mother, pleaded not guilty yesterday in General Sessions on an indictment accusing him of $28,000 in forgeries and thefts through discounting fraudulent notes.

CINCINNATI, May 11 -- The Giants' efforts to establish a beach-head on the western front of the National League again met with disaster today as the Reds, wrenching three runs from Rube Fischer on doubles by Estel Crabtree and Steve Mesner in the eighth inning, upset Mel Ott's men for the second successive day, 4 to 3.

Both the winter and spring wheat crops are making good progress and indications are that there will be no shortage of that cereal for the next twelve months. On the basis of Wednesday's forecast by the Department of Agriculture, the 1944 grain harvest in the United States will be around 940,000,000 bushels, probably higher.

A teacher and four girl students in Brooklyn High School for Homemaking at 901 Classon Avenue were injured in a luncheon-recess disturbance between two groups yesterday. Crockery was thrown, chairs were used as weapons and combatants clawed and kicked for twenty minutes before police from two precincts restored order.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 11 -- After months of vacillation on the part of Bulgaria in the Axis war effort, the joint session of the Council of Regents and the Cabinet during its emergency session decreed general mobilization, according to authenticated reports from Sofia tonight.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 11 - A 32-to-1 shot won the second race at Narragansett Park today and the resulting daily double pay-off was $1,017, the largest at this meeting. F.T. Sahakian's Canterup was the long shot. The winner of the first race was Mike Salvia's Dark Mischief.

LONDON, May 11 (U.P.) -- Western hemisphere bases, leased by Britain to the United States in exchange for fifty American destroyers, were leased only for military purposes and may not be used for civil aviation without British consent, Lord Beaverbrook told the House of Lords today.

Amid an atmosphere of mock seriousness and outright levity, mixed with embarrassment, the Board of Estimate rejected yesterday the offer by Coty, Inc., perfume manufacturers, to pay $25,000 for an exclusive contract to sponsor Mayor La Guardia's weekly radio "Talk to the People" in a series of twenty-five broadcasts from an unnamed commercial station.
CHUNGKING, China, May 11 (AP) -- A communique:

James Work, chairman of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation when the Navy took possession of the plants and properties on April 20, 1942, and whose large holdings were placed in a voting trust as one of the Navy's conditions for restoring the company to a private management of its own choice, yesterday presented a slate of directors to be acted upon at the annual meeting n6xt Wednesday.

LONDON, Friday, May 12 -- The railroads on which Field Marshal Gens. Erwin Rommel and Karl von Runstedt depend for reinforcement and supply of the Atlantic Wall have been subjected to the heaviest attacks of the tactical air campaign in the last twenty-four hours.

General Eaker estimates that the output of the Ploesti refineries, on which Germany depends for 30 per cent of her war needs, has been cut to a quarter of normal by the attacks of our heavy bombers. This estimate is based on the observations of returning fliers and the study of reconnaissance photographs.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Rialto the attraction will he "Bermuda Mystery," a Twentieth Century-Fox melodrama featuring Preston Foster, Ann Rutherford, Charles Butterworth, Jean Howard and Richard Lane. . . .

Reporting on operations for the March quarter, W.A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, declared yesterday that lower passenger-express rates, plus increased operating expenses, tended to offset the earnings effect of substantial traffic gains in the first three months this year.

A program of "Music of Four Centuries" will be given in Carnegie Hall tonight at 8:45. Yella Pessl, harpsichordist; Teddy Wilson, pianist; Mitchell Miller, oboist, and a string quartet will present the program.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Paul D. Sowell, assistant to the operating manager of Montgomery Ward Co., who was arrested for removing a Government poster during the thirteen days of Federal control of the company's Chicago properties, was exonerated today in a hearing before Edwin K. Walker, United States Commissioner, and the Government agent who started the prosecution was rebuked.

LONDON, May 11 -- Relations between Russia and Poland remain the prime political problem for their allies. The efforts of Great Britain and the United States to bring the two countries together have failed completely so far. Mutual distrust is at the heart of Russia's and Poland's failure to get along.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, May 11 (AP) -- Firecrackers popped and sirens screamed today as opponents of former President Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez celebrated news that he had left the country and was "through with politics."

A contribution of $23,000 this year to the educational foundation of the Fashion Institute of Technology and Design was authorized yesterday by the executive committee of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board at the conclusion of its three-day meeting at the Hotel Astor.

The report that 1,400,000 civilians have been trained to defend the Reich reminds the British that it is almost exactly four years since the Home Guard was recruited to face the threat of invasion. Until now the Germans never really expected that enemy armies would march into the Fatherland.

If Steve O'Neill never sees another bunt, he'll be a mighty satisfied manager. The Tiger pilot sat helplessly in his dugout at the Stadium yesterday and saw the Yankees bedevil his team with three exasperating short singles in inning, during which the one-time Bombers scored four runs. They made another run in a later session, won handily, 5 to 2, and seized first place when the Browns lost last night.

A sentence of three and one-half to seven years in State prison was imposed in General Sessions yesterday on William L. Meissel, 50 years old, head of an insurance brokerage concern at 25 Pine Street, who recently pleaded guilty to having forged an endorsement on a $10,000 insurance company check last December.

Sir John Anderson, Chancellor of the Exchequer, declares in the House of Commons that the British Government will never go back to the gold standard. "I believe," he declared in debate, "there is in fact no foundation for the view that this [international monetary] scheme in any way involves a return to the gold standard.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP) -- First baseman Hal Trosky stole home today with the winning run in the White Sox' 4-to-2 victory over the Athletics in sixteen innings.

PLANDOME, L.I., May 11 -- It was Pete Ladislaw day in the opening amateur best-ball tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Plandome Golf Club today, the home club player winning the low net and low gross awards.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- During the week ended May 10, member bank reserve balances increased $39,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from an increase of $5,000,000 in Treasury currency and decreases of $15,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks and $148,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by a decrease of $17,000,000 in Reserve bank credit and an increase of $111,000,000 in money in circulation.

ON THE MANIPUR FRONT, in India, May 9 (Delayed) -- British forces are slowly gaining ground in their counter-attacks against the Japanese in the Manipur in the north as Kohima assault by infantry and tanks, supported by concentrations of artillery, have won back several enemy strong points.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 11 (AP) -- The Red Wings won their sixth straight game today as they swept the opening game of the series from the Bears, 5 -- 2.

LONDON, May 11 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans of Marshal Tito are pouring into Serbia to threaten some of the most important railroads in the country, a Partisan communique said today, after two and one-half years of operations in Croatia, Bosnia, Herzegovina and Montenegro to the west.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- Recommendations for equality in job opportunities for women and safeguards on employment of young people were included in resolutions on post-war employment and policy for dependent territories passed today without dissenting votes at the International Labor Office conference.
BOSTON, May 11 (AP) -- In a two-and-a-half-hour contest, the Indians defeated the Red Sex, 7 to 6, today.

Due to increased imports and decreased military demands for platinum the War Production Board has informed members of the platinum group metals producers and distributors advisory committee that it is holding in "abeyance" its program to requisition idle platinum, it was learned yesterday.

Divided sects among Protestants share the responsibility with homes broken up by divorces for difficulties encountered in providing religious instruction for children, declared the Roy. Dr. George A. Buttrick of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, in a National Family Week luncheon address for Protestant clergymen of the metropolitan area yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The texts of the Selective Service headquarters announcement accompanying its draft memorandum to local boards, and of the memorandum itslef, were as follows:

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- Despite efforts to cut down the shipments of swine to market, a generous number of hogs moved today into markets throughout the Midwest and further aggravated the congested situation. At twelve markets receipts were 83,500 head, plus about 75,000 farmer-owned hogs held over from Wednesday.

The Museum of Modern Art realized $64,070 last night at an auction sale of forty-six lots from its collection at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. The proceeds, the museum announced, will be used "to provide funds for the purchase of paintings and sculpture, particularly by living artists."

BERNE, Switzerland, May 11 -- The systematic bombings of key points in France are producing their effect, although official reports today would make it appear that only civilian homes are hit with great loss of life. Occasionally it is admitted that railroad tracks are destroyed, but they are claimed to be repaired "so rapidly that one wonders why the Anglo-Americans insist."

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Whether baseball players 30 years of age and older stand a better chance of draft deferment under the newly liberalized deferment policies is entirely up to the local boards, a Selective Service spokesman said today. But it's not likely that many local boards will ease up on professional athletes, the spokesman added.

A row of four four-story brownstone dwellings at 30 to 36 West Fifty-second Street has been sold for cash by T.J. Oakley Rhinelander and Philip Rhinelander 2d to the Eastmanton Corporation, represented by Harris Berlack, attorney.

Two local housing authorities, those of Memphis, Tenn., and Chattanooga, Tenn., announced yesterday new issues of refunding bonds, aggregating $8,365,000 and $3,310,000, respectively, for award on May 23. In addition to stipulating the interest rates, bidders are asked to bid their preferences in serial maturities.
LONDON, May 11 -- Lord Rothermere, publisher of The London Daily Mail, declared today that a free press was a better safeguard for world peace than treaties.

To maintain and expand the nation's economy above the current $200,000,000 level, Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat, of West Virginia, yesterday set the nation's post-war export goal at $25,000,000,000 annually. Pointing out that exports can be paid for only by means of imports, the Senator indicated that he favored an import program of equal volume by adding that "in the long run imports and exports should finally balance."

Reviewing methods used by the newly established Bureau of Broadcast Measurement in Canada to study potential radio audiences, Glenn Vannerman, president of the Canadian Association of Broadcasters, said yesterday that costs of radio coverage in Canada can now be determined to a degree comparable to that of media costs for publications through audited circulation figures.

Purchase of Lincoln School, the experimental unit of Teachers College, Columbia University, is being considered by the Board of Education, it became known yesterday. A request for an estimated $1,202,000 for the Teachers College building at 425 West 123d Street has been filed with the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -Charges that Puerto Rico is being used by United States supervisors as a "guinea pig" for social and economic experiments looking toward socialism, have no foundation in fact, Secretary Ickes told a House Insular Affairs subcommittee today.

Wartime rededication of the American people to the ideals of inter-racial, inter-religious and international unity as the only way to achieve vietory over Hitler in the spiritual as well as the material realm was urged yesterday by speakers representing religious faiths and the Negro people at a City College unity rally.

It will be noted that in President Roosevelt's opinion the fault lies both with the press and the radio. They should not have left the American people uninformed on the subject of Montgomery Ward. Once upon a time it was the press of the country that was sadly recreant in its duty.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- Paulette Goddard, who returned this week from an Army camp tour in the China-Burma-India theatre of war, will be co-starred by Paramount with Arturo de Cordova in a comedy with music, "Masquerade in Mexico," after her forthcoming picture, "Kitty."

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11 -- Striking evidence that the Democratic party is not only a one-man party but that without Franklin D. Roosevelt at the head of the ticket the Democrats would almost certainly lose the election is revealed in a survey just completed by the institute.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Department store sales for the week ended May 6 were 8 per cent above sales in the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Dr. Anthony Renda, 56 years old, a physician in Italy and this country for thirty-three years, and author of three books on obstetrics, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to a Sing Sing term of three and one-half to seven years on a recent manslaughter conviction in an abortion.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A Japanese reply to the American protest of last February over the treatment by the Japanese of our prisoners of war and civilian internees has been received, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today, but it contains conditions that require close study.

John J. Rooney is slated to become the Democratic candidate for the House of Representatives from the Fourth Brooklyn District when the members of the county committee within the Congressional area meet tonight at the Third Assembly District Democratic Club, 314 Clinton Street, Brooklyn.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 11 -- Opening his final pre-convention bid for the Republican nomination for President, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio declared here today that the New Deal had resorted to "picking" courts to try its cases in an effort to sustain the "philosophy of absolutism" which, he said, it is trying to spread throughout American society.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The War Production Board does not dare relax its demands for industrial alcohol at present because this major ingredient of poison gas must be adequate for retaliation if Germany should use poison gas against the invasion forces of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The housewife sweating over a hot stove, farmers whose cows refuse to give milk by the clock, and little children trudging to school in early darkness were advanced before a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee today as reasons for repeal of war time.

The 4,000 residents of the community of Broad Channel, Queens, occupying 1,260 homes privately built on city-owned land, won a preliminary victory yesterday in their battle to prevent the city from ousting them by April 30, 1948, under conditions that would cause their dwellings to pass into city ownership.

LONDON, May 11 -- In the first public statement he has made in five years, former Minister of the French Republic Louis Marin, who recently escaped from France, today replied to some of the questions that he said had been asked of him by newspaper men since he arrived in London.

J. E. May, vice president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Inc., formerly in charge of the company's operations at Los Angeles, Calif., has returned to Akron, Ohio, as head of the tire sales division responsible for all activities pertaining to that field.
LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

CHICAGO, May 11 -- The Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski of Springfield, Mass., whose mysterious trip to Russia drew protests from some Polish groups, was in Chicago last night, the reputed bearer of documents promising cooperation of Premier Stalin with the Catholic Church.

Harry A. Augenblick, a member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Augenblick Kohn of Newark, N. J., was elected a director of the Pacific Coast Company at the annual meeting held in Flemington, N.J., on Wednesday, which lasted late into the evening after a three-hour suspension had been taken for tabulation of proxies.

LONDON, May 11 -- The British frigate Spey, which has had considerable success in the North Atlantic while guarding convoys against U-boats, has scored two more sinkings and picked up sixty-one survivors, four of whom died and were buried at sea.

Loomis J. Grossman, operator, bought the six-story apartment house with self-service elevator at 100 Parkway Road, Bronxville, Westchester County, from the Bronxville Improvement Corporation, represented by Proskauer, Rose Paskus, attorneys.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -Terming proposed increases of 5 to 20 per cent in the salaries of postmasters "fantastic" and unjustified, Senator Clyde M. Reed, Republican, Kansas, today called on Postmaster General Frank C. Walker to investigate the payment of overtime wages to postal workers during the last year.

KANDY, Ceylon, May 11 (U.P.) -- Japan has lost more than 23,000 men killed in the Southeast Asia campaign, it was estimated tonight, as Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's columns in North Burma closed within artillery range of Kamaing from two directions.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- Soviet war correspondents reported today the story of the survivors of battered Sevastopol, who described the final German atrocity -- loading the surviving young men of the city on barges, which were towed to the middle of the harbor and then sunk only a few days before the Red Army stormed the fortress.

ALGIERS, May 11 -- Rene Massigli, Commissioner of Foreign Affairs, is expected to make a frank review of foreign affairs tomorrow to the Assembly. He also is expected to discuss the present difficulties regarding communications with London, as well as longer-range problems that extend to the post-war period.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Browns threw away a ball game as the Senators took their second-in-a-row from St. Louis, 4 to 2, tonight before 11,200 fans. The setback cost the visitors first place, the Yankees moving ahead.
A galaxy of cottons for mothers, daughters and sisters marked the show given yesterday at the Hotel Plaza by Mary Lewis to celebrate the opening of her new shop at 746 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Although prices for certain agricultural commodities and building materials continued to move upward at a moderate rate, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' composite index of nearly 900 price series remained unchanged at 103.7 per cent of the 1926 average during the first week of May.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, May 11 -- G-5, that heterogeneous group of civil affairs specialists who will move into enemy and occupied territory with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Allied Expeditionary Force, is ready to roll when the D-day signal is given.

LONDON, May 11 (U.P.) -- Capt. Robert Johnson of Lawton, Okla., who recently shot down his twenty-sixth and twenty-seventh German planes to break the record of Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker and tie Capt. Richard Bong as America's leading ace, has received the Distinguished Service Cross.
LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- The Bank of England weekly condition statement issued today reported an increase of 53,000 in note circulation, lifting the total to a new high record of 1,129,223,000.

PEARL HARBOR, May 11 -- Far flying central Pacific air forces are battering key enemy defenses in the Marshalls and Caroline Islands areas without permitting the dizzy enemy a day of rest from the sight and sound of American planes.

Twenty-one American republics, including Argentina and Bolivia, are represented at the conference of the Inter-American Development Commission, in session here this week. As a whole these nations, as President Roosevelt said in his message to the conference, "have mobilized their resources against the common enemy" -- some, of course, more eagerly and completely than others.

BUFFALO, May 11 (AP) -- Buffalo defeated Jersey City, 7 -- 1, tonight, and the victory, coupled with Baltimore's loss to Toronto, sent the Bisons into second place. Hank Oana allowed four hits and fanned six besides rapping out three singles and driving in a pair of runs.
As usual, the arrival of warmer weather takes its toll of Broadway shows and decreases the "To Be Continued" listing. Last week there were four closings; tomorrow night there will be three more.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Chief Justice Edward C. Eicher held in contempt of court today Ira Chase Koehne, the third defense lawyer so cited in the Government's sedition trial. Other defense counsel asked the court to hold Martin Popper, secretary of the National Lawyers Guild, in contempt.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- George Pabst Jr., vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, signed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a statement in which he said that a fee of $87,500 paid to Kuhn, Loeb Co. of New York, investment bankers, for the issuance and marketing of $35,000,000 of notes of the Pennsylvania Company was less expensive than competitive bidding would have been.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The official "list of essential activities" as drawn up by the War Manpower Commission and covering thirty-five broad occupational fields to be used as a guide in granting deferments is as follows under these general headings:

Investigations providing the first definite clues to the solution of the mystery of lysozyme, powerful bacteria-dissolving substance found in egg white, tears, saliva and many other plant and animal secretions, the nature of which has been a major biological puzzle for more than twenty years, are described in the current issue, of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The College Art Association has announced the awards of Grants-in-Aid for research in the fine arts to four young graduate students of the History of Art who are completing their work at New York University for Ph.D. degrees. The awards are as follows: $400 to Creighton E. Gilbert; $300 each to Gertrude Achenbach and Jane Costello, and $200 to Phyllis Pray Bober.

LONDON, May 11 -- As a result of a statement by Col. Oliver Stanley, Colonial Secretary, that production of copper should be maintained so far as possible, there was a fresh advance today in Rhodesian copper shares on the stock markets.
LONDON, May 11 (UP) -- The Russian Thursday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A closure petition, signed by twenty-nine Senators and seeking a two-thirds majority vote to force limitation of debate on the Marcantonio bill to repeal poll taxes in Federal elections, was filed in the Senate today by Senator Alben W. Barkley, majority leader.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, May 12 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Civilian consumers and distributors of fuel oil on the East Coast must fill their storage tanks this summer if they are to have enough to carry through next winter, Secretary Ickes said today.

A permanent organization composed of associations in the shoe, leather and allied industries may develop as a result of an informal gathering last week of officers and executives of several groups, it was learned yesterday. While no plans have been made as yet to form such a formal over-all group, it was said that several men who attended the initial gathering believe such a body will be developed.

KEARNY, N.J., May 11 -- The U.S.S. Diphda was launched today by the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here, the ninth naval combat-cargo ship to be sent down the ways to the Hackensack River. The vessel was sponsored by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission in New York State.

Before 22,698 racegoers Caddie, the Rokeby Stable's 6-year-old brown gelding, yesterday proved his consistency as a jumper when he gained his third triumph of the year in the $4,000 added International Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park.

The season for fresh ducks, which starts in March and reaches its peak in June, is well under way, and more birds are coming in from Long Island than we've had in many weeks, representatives of the trade report. Because of shipping conditions, fewer than usual are being sent out to other parts of the country, and this, coupled with a slow demand, has resulted in a good supply in city markets.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The global importance of American air power was emphasized today by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, who, in commenting on the Pacific-Asiatic war, revealed that nearly 5,000 Japanese planes had been destroyed by the Army.
CLEVELAND, May 11 -- The convention of the United Steel Workers of America approved today the union's wage policy objective which calls for revision of the Little Steel formula.

New York City has the best budget this year it has ever had, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, told 200 educators and civic leaders attending the annual meeting of the Public Education Association yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Back in this country, "to learn all about gunnery," Maj. Richard I. Bong, ace fighter of the Southwest Pacific, deprecated his verified record of twenty-seven Japanese planes shot down in aerial combat by maintaining that he probably was one of the worst shots in the Air Forces and that he must have scared some of his victims to death.

There is no doubt that the basic idea of an all-inclusive health insurance plan as published by Mayor La Guardia is sound and progressive. The fact that private insurance companies in increasing numbers have been underwriting group health insurance of late is a proof of the actual necessity and popularity of such protection at this time.

LONDON, May 11 -- The British Government gave Portugal clear warning today that unless she ceased supplying Germany freely with wolfram the British might halve the shipments of coal that they have been sending to Portugal regularly during the past six months despite the losses in coal production caused by strikes.

Who's news -- and why -- may be found in "Contemporary Biography," just published by H.W. Wilson Company. This reference book contains the life stories of 380 persons prominent in public life or the professions -- from movie stars to naval chiefs -- with a listing of many others.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- In response to a question as to why there was an urgent need of more members for the Women's Army Corps, Secretary Stimson gave detailed reasons today why neither the 1-A's nor the 4-F's were the answer to the Army's "behind the lines" problems.

When the Russians enter Czechoslovak territory they will encounter many of the same problems that the United Nations forces under Genera Eisenhower will meet in France. On the face of a treaty signed this week with the Czech Government in London they mean to solve them, as General Eisenhower does, with as much regard for civilian rights as is consistent with military security.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- Moving toward adjournment tomorrow, the International Labor Conference by overwhelming votes today adopted for recommendation to the member governments broad programs providing for cradle-to-grave socialized medicine, minimum social standards for dependent territories, and proposals designed to cushion the effect upon employment of demobilization and reconversion after the war.

LONDON, Friday, May 12 -- The Germans are bolstering their coast defenses in Norway and holding a series of anti-invasion maneuvers, for the German General Staff appears to believe the Allies may land a considerable force in Norway on a diversionary operation while the main invasion thrust is made elsewhere.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses declared yesterday that work made available by New York City's postwar planning program might have to be accelerated because of unemployment after the war. An "enormous" amount of money has been spent on detailed plans so the program will be ready, he said.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- A controversy over educational provisions of the "G.I. Bill of Rights" split the House into two groups today, each accusing the other of seeking to impose bureaucratic control from Washington over State and private schools.
In this war no one's job is too insignificant to the successful prosecution of our national duties. And one's work, however lowly in another's eyes, is just as important and productive of some good.

SPARKILL, N.Y., May 11 -- Miss Betty Miller of Staten Island, a niece, has filed suit to upset the will of Miss Elizabeth M. Miller, who died in 1942 leaving an estate now valued at more than $200,000 and instructions to use the income to care for an aging dachshund and a cheetah in her seven-room home at Monsey, N.Y.

LONDON, Friday, May 12 (AP) -- Russia and other nations attacked by the Nazis would be justified in demanding German "reparation in labor," the national executive committee of the British Labor party said today, but added that "we should want none here."

The letter of Under-Secretary of War Patterson in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 2 commenting on your editorial "Technicians Under 26" speaks of the close cooperation of the War Department with the Office of Scientific Research and Development. Here there seems to be a lack of follow-through.

Expressing a belief that local price and rationing boards should place many more women in responsible positions in their organizations, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administrator, announced yesterday the appointment of thirteen women, representatives of consumer groups, as members of the New York City Advisory Committee of Community Service.

Almost half the radio programs sponsored by New York retailers attract fewer than 1 per cent of the sets in the local area, and two-thirds of the advertisers could not be identified in a single one of the radio homes interviewed in the metropolitan area, according to one of the most comprehensive analyses ever made of retail store advertising in newspapers and radio, which has just been completed by the newspapers of New York City.

MONTREAL, May 12 (AP) -- Mervyn (Red) Dutton was tendered the presidency of the National Hockey League today at the annual meeting of the loop here, but he declared he could not accept the position until he consulted with his business partners in the West.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, May 13 (AP) -- A com;uniqud:

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Under the system of direct loans of Federal funds to veterans of this war, which is proposed in the Senate version of the GI Bin of Rights, the Government would become the largest and most powerful loan agency in the history of the country, Representative Paul Cunningham of Iowa, Republican, told the House today as debate continued on the measure.

Public offering of 50,000 shares of $10 par common stock of the McQuay - Norris Manufacturing Company was made yesterday at $16.50 a share by Shields Co. The offering, which does not represent new financing by the company, was oversubscribed by the close of business, the bankers announced.
