LONDON, Saturday, May 13 -- Red Army forces liquidated the last center of enemy resistance in the Crimea yesterday and completed a thirty-five-day campaign that cost the Germans and Rumanians more than 111,000 men killed or captured, Moscow announced last night.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 12 -Piled on a city dump at the foot of Duncan Avenue, bordering the Hackensack River here, are several tons of turnips that were dumped there by trucks of the city garbage removal contractor in the last three days.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, Ceylon, May 12 (AP) -- Allied air forces sent unprecedented swarms of bombers and fighters to the direct support of ground troops today in a smash at Japanese on the edge of India's Imphal plain.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- A new effort to force a court-martial of the men in command at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, was begun in Congress today, accompanied by an implied threat of impeachment against Cabinet members.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A total of 2,461,943 women were trained for war work under Federal programs between July, 1940, and April, 1944, according to the War Manpower Commission.

Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday that, beginning today, there would be available free at the General Postoffice and its stations new special standard air-mail letter cards for exclusive use in sending messages by air mail to prisoners of war and detained or interned civilians in Germany and German-occupied countries.
The Appellate Division in a unanimous decision yesterday upheld the claim of Doctors Hospital, East End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, that it is exempt from New York City real estate taxes.

A miniature black market was broken up yesterday with the arrest of two men charged with stealing butter from the Concord Hoffman Cafeteria, 1535 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, and then selling it without ration points to private individuals, mainly housewives, for 44 cents a pound.

The Greenwich Savings Bank has sold the five-story apartment house on a plot 35 by 100 feet at 258-60 West Ninety-first Street, 100 feet west of Broadway, through Francis E. Martin and the Wood, Dolson Company, brokers. The property, which has sixteen apartments, is assessed at $50,000, of which $31,000 is land value.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NAPLES, Italy, May 12 -- Gen. Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander, Commander of the Allied Forces in Italy, and Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, Commander of the Fifth Army, both promised in orders of the day today that the Allies would destroy the German armies in Italy.
Jockey Ted Atkinson proved the factor between victory and defeat for Grant Thorn's speedy chestnut filly Leaving in the feature at Belmont Park yesterday.

LONDON, Saturday, May 13 -- Five synthetic oil plants in the heart of Europe were successfully bombed by nearly 1,000 Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force yesterday. This dramatic switch from tactical targets to long-range strategic ones produced a series of violent air combats in which 150 enemy interceptors were destroyed by the bombers and their escort of Mustangs, Lightnings and Thunderbolts.

OROVILLE, Calif., May 12 (AP) -- An early morning fire in the Union Hotel killed at least four persons and injured a score here today. A hundred soldiers were searching the ruins tonight for other bodies and city fire officials said that seven persons were missing.

CLEVELAND, May 12 -- Henry S. Kaiser, shipbuilder and industrialist, laid before the convention of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, today a blueprint for a prosperous post-war era which he based largely on the airplane and the automobile.
Bob Holmes of the Putnam County Fish and Game Association comes through with a summary of what has been taking place in the fishing waters around his baliwick, to wit:

BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP) -- Attorneys for stockholders battling to throw out the management of The Certain-Teed Products Corporation agreed today with company lawyers to confine business at a thrice- postponed annual meeting merely to submitting of proxies.

The appropriations of New York State for the care of children of working mothers will be increased from $250,000 spent in 1943 to almost $1,000,000 for the coming year, Oswald D. Heck, chairman of the sub-committee on child care of the State War Council, said yesterday at the annual luncheon meeting of the New York State Association of Secretaries of Chambers of Commerce, held at the Hotel New Yorker.

Literary Troubles Know Your Exchange, the weekly news sheet of the New York Curb Exchange, celebrates its third anniversary with the current number and confesses somewhat lugubriously to the troubles that have vexed literary men since the first hieroglyphics appeared on a tomb.

An over-all reduction of 25 per cent in the enrollment of 70,000 students under the Navy's V-12 program on Nov. 1 was announced yesterday by Vice Admiral Randall Jacobs, Chief of Naval Personnel. The action affects the fifth class of officer candidates for the Navy and Marine Corps scheduled for training at 131 colleges and universities throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Twelve thousand members of the Industrial Marine and Shipbuilding Workers Union, CIO, at the Kearny and Newark (N.J.) shipyards, who are behind in their dues, were directed today by the War Labor Board to pay up under a union security provision of the 1942 contract.

SOMWHERE IN ENGLAND, May 12 (AP) -- Four Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth of Nations -- Winston Churchill of Britain, W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada, Jan Christiaan Smuts of South Africa, and Sir Godfrey Huggins of Southern Rhodesia -- saw new, modern and terribly lethal invasion weapons today in a visit to British troops in this great military area.

LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler has placed a tank specialist, a man rated as the German's best artillery general and a veteran of the Russian front, in command of three armies along the West Wall coast of Europe to meet the Allied invasion.

Three hours after the New York County grand jury handed up an indictment yesterday afternoon accusing Herman G. Brock, 53 years old, a former vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, of thefts of $9,800 from the bank last Dec. 16, Brock surrendered at District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office. Brock, an expert on Latin-American banking, was employed at the bank's main office at 140 Broadway.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- A transcript of major remarks by Father Orlemanski at a press conference today follows:

CHICAGO, May 12 -- The concluding phase of the Montgomery Ward Co. case in the Federal courts was written off today when Judge William H. Holly dismissed without prejudice the Government's injunction suit against the company.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Senator James E. Murray of Montana filed a bill today to prevent "big business" from gaining possession of most of the $15,500,000,000 of Government-owned war plants when peace comes.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- By announcing that it would consider a new regulation permitting employers to challenge the status of unions certified as collective bargaining agents, the National Labor Relations Board today held out the prospect of a distinct concession to industrialists.

Forty-two men, who are alleged to have conspired to operate fourteen bootleg stills in Brooklyn, Queens and elsewhere on Long Island, were indicted yesterday by the Federal Grand Jury in Brooklyn. The indictment charged the defendants had defrauded the Federal Government out of $1,141,224 in alcohol taxes.

The Germans can draw only one conclusion from the attack which the Eighth and Fifth Armies have just opened on their lines in Italy. This is no local engagement to gain a few miles of ground. It is no mere resumption of our earlier offensive on the Mediterranean front.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The four Axis satellites -- Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Finland -- received today so stern a warning to get out of the war and thus cease aiding Germany that it had the force of an ultimatum from the Big Three powers -- the United States, Great Britain and the Soviet Union.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 12 -- Princeton will not engage "in a formal schedule of intercollegiate football games next fall," President Harold W. Dodds of the university stated tonight and announced that the continuation of intercollegiate participation in other sports was now being reviewed.

The single-family house at 1380 East Twenty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold for the Margaret and Sarah Switzer Foundation for Girls through Realty Management, a division of the Realty Mortgagee Corporation. Frederick G. Hess is the buyer.

AT A FIFTH ARMY OBSERVATION POST, Overlooking the Garigliano Valley, May 11 (Delayed) -- There was a tree out in front. It was a solitary umbrella pine and its canopy of branches stood out blackly against the soft sky.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Confidential reports by British and American officials in Moscow that Premier Joseph Stalin plans to exact a retribution for German crimes against occupied Russia that may shock the sensibilities of the Western World received some confirmation today from the Soviet Embassy Information Bulletin.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 12 (AP) -- With Bill Trotter hurling three-hit ball the Red Wings swept to their seventh straight victory by downing the Newark Bears, 8 -- 1, today.

A telegraphic appeal to the Office of Price Administration for an extension from June 15 to Aug. 1, representing a "bailing-out" period in which to liquidate stocks on hand under the amended handbag pricing regulation, was made yesterday by the National Handbag and Accessories Salesmen's Association, Inc.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 12 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today scheduled for Syracuse on June 15 the first of a series of hearings to determine and allocate costs of several railroad grade crossing eliminations completed in recent years.

The Association for the Aid of Crippled Children needs volunteer workers to help with the summer camp program. The association has more than 2,000 crippled boys and girls on its case list. Many of these children need vacations in summer camps. Volunteer workers can do much of the work involved in registering children, interviewing mothers, taking children to trains and buses and keeping clerical records in the association offices at 580 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON, May 12 (U.P.) -- Major Partisan strongholds in Bosnia are under German assault from both the east and west, with some of the heaviest fighting of the Yugoslav campaign raging around the eastern Bosnian town of Vlasenica, which has changed hands several times in the past seventy-two hours, it was announced today.

Without benefit of a preliminary out-of-town showing, Lodewick Vroom will open J.C. Nugent's comedy, "That Old Devil," at the Playhouse on June 5, it was announced yesterday. This is a play about a retired business man who manages to turn the tables on a group of tattle-tale artists.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Members of the House burst into applause today in tribute to an appeal for more aid for disabled veterans by Representative John J. Cochran of Missouri, Democrat, a disabled legislator.

ALBANY, May 12 -- The most effective factors contributing to the total drop in employment and payrolls from March to the middle of April were the seasonal slump in the apparel industry and the curtailment in various war plants.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The American Democratic National Committee, which has been opposing a fourth term, announced through its chairman today that it was prepared to support Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio if he was the Republican nominee opposing President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Declarations by Premier Joseph Stalin of the Soviet Union that cooperation with Pope Pius XII was possible "in the matter of struggle against coercion and persecution of the Catholic Church" and that he is "an advocate of freedom of conscience and of worship" were made public today by the Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski of Springfield, Mass.

ALGIERS, May 12 -- Describing an agreement between the French and the Allies regarding the landing in France as an "urgent and absolute necessity," and expressing his conviction that the Allies know this and that the way out of the present diplomatic deadlock must be found, Rene Massigli, Algiers Commissioner of Foreign Affairs, gave today a frank review of foreign relations in a speech to the Assembly.

Comment in some quarters suggests that the local medical societies are not prepared to accept in its entirety the Mayor's plan to render complete medical and hospital service to families whose heads earn up to $5,000 a year, the cost of 4 per cent to be shared equally by employes and employers.

THE Holly family were somebody once. If Gramp hadn't given away most all his money back in the Eighteen Nineties to help feed the starving Indians they might still be. They still lived in the big house in Portsound across the bay from Seattle, but Pop only worked in the company store and the Adamses and the Markses, who owned the great lumber mill that dominated the town, were inclined to be patronizing and superior.

All the coquetry of Scarlett O'Hara is prevalent in the new cotton evening dresses sold in junior departments throughout the city. Tiny waists are emphasized by means of voluminous skirts and bodices, which are fitted and abbreviated.

The Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit in the quarter ended on March 31 of $3,954,573 after all charges including $1,264,585 provision for Federal taxes on income, according to the report announced yesterday.

The Democratic majority in the City Council is prepared to cut $6,000,000 to $7,000,000 from the 1944-45 city budget of $737,400,923, recently approved by the Board of Estimate, it was indicated yesterday at a public hearing of the Council's finance committee at City Hall.

The Japanese Vice Minister of Finance, in a domestic Tokyo radio broadcast reported by United States Government monitors yesterday, told the Japanese people that they had saved 30,988,000,000 yen in 1943. This, he said, was 3,988,000,000 yen greater than the national savings goal of 27,000, 000,000 yen for last year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- Pamela Britton of the Chicago "Oklahoma!" company will have within two weeks for her first screen part under a recently signed Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer term contract. She will have a singing and dancing part in "Anchors Aweigh," the forthcoming Frank Sinatra-Kathryn Grayson-Gene Kelly musical. George Sidney has been assigned to direct the film.

OMAHA, May 12 (AP) -- Gov. John Bricker of Ohio, Republican Presidential candidate, tonight described the New Deal as "wasteful, careless and politically selfish" and called for Government economy in money, manpower and paper.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Bus service over certain routes between New York City and Chicago will remain suspended until Sept. 1 under an amendment issued today by the Office of Defense Transportation.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12 -- Mayor Vincent J. Murphy and two of his fellow city commissioners, John A. Brady and Joseph B. Keenan, defended in statements today their parts in the $264,000 abortive meadowland deal which yesterday resulted in the indictment of Corporation Counsel Philip J. Schotland, Deputy Director of Public Works Theodore S. Miller Jr., two other men and a corpora tion on charges of conspiracy to defraud the city.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York told the Senate on the last day of debate on the anti-poll tax bill before the closure vote is taken that the fight for final passage of the measure must go on even if efforts to thwart a filibuster against it should fail.

Assuming that 1947 will be the first post-war year, S. Morris Livingston, chief of the national economics unit, Department of Commerce, estimated yesterday that production capacity in that year will be 40 to 50 per cent more than actual output of 1940 and between 70 and 80 per cent above that of the 1935-39 period.

Dr. Max M. Furter, tenant in the house at 38 The Fairway, in Upper Montclair, N.J., has purchased the property from Bert S. Fuller for whom it was erected in 1937. The Simpson-Merritt Company was the broker.
BALTIMORE, May 12 -- Except for the black-eyed susans, which dash it all, are not yet in bloom, everything is set for the fifty-fourth Preakness Stakes at Pimlico tomorrow.

A charge that Edward V. Loughlin, leader of Tammany, was seeking to "pack" its executive committee to strengthen his control of the organization and to perpetuate his "unholy alliance" with Representative Vito Marcantonio, New York County Chairman of the American Labor Party, was made yesterday by two West Side district leaders.
CINCINNATI, May 12 -- Mel Ott, determined to snap his Giants out of their doldrums, gave his club another violent shaking today.

WASHINGTON, New Zealand, May 12 -- Shot through the head by a Japanese 25-caliber bullet on Bougainville, Esivorosi Kete of the Fiji scouts demonstrated the toughness of these South Pacific commandos and today is recovering in a hospital after an ordeal that few white men would survive.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Naples, May 12 -- Here is the new line-up of Allied troops after regrouping in Italy for the all-out offensive:
Perhaps you will permit some comment on the editorial in your issue of April 17 regarding "Approval of Treaties."

Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation and chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, said yesterday that approximately $10,000,000,000 in new investments will be needed to provide the six to seven million additional jobs required to maintain production and employment at the level necessary for post-war prosperity in the United States.

Prof. John Hanna in his interesting reply to my comments (and those of Peter B. Olney, whose views I am not fortunate enough to know) on his proposal of a minimal program for a postwar organization asks for a more precise analysis of the term "International Police Force."

CAIRO, Egypt, May 12 -- Analyzing American foreign policy trends as reflected in the recently reported British-United States agreement on the Arabian oil pipeline, Al Mussawar, the leading Arabic weekly, predicts that American interests in this part of the world will be greatly stepped up after the war.

"America's Town Meeting of the Air," produced by Town Hall, Inc., is scheduled to be sponsored commercially next fall by The Reader's Digest, it was announced yesterday. The board of trustees of Town Hall will meet next Tuesday to pass on a contract that would make the "Town Meeting" the first major radio forum to be presented by an advertiser.

An Associated Press dispatch, the first interview given the American press by the Yugoslav Partisan leader, Marshal Tito [Josip Broz], has been stopped by censors of the Allied Mediterranean Command in Algiers despite official assurances that political censorship would not be imposed in the Mediterranean theatre.
LONDON, May 12 -- The stock markets finished the week on a quiet note, the general disposition being to await events.

ALGIERS, May 12 -- Vice Admiral Edmond Derrien was convicted today by a military court of having been responsible for the acquisition by the Germans of a score of French naval vessels at Bizerte on Dec. 8, 1942, and sentenced -- in view of his 61 years -- to solitary confinement for life.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, Ceylon, May 12 May 12 (U.P.) -- The Japanese are sending their newest type of fighters into the Burma area to regain the air supremacy they lost more than a year ago, but without success.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 12 -The Hudson County grand jury's investigation into the Jersey City Tax Department is directed at assessment practices that are alleged to be criminal and affect the financial position of the municipality, it became known today as the result of a hearing before Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan.
PITTSBURGH, May 12 (AP) -- Behind the superb pitching of Nate Andrews, the Braves pounded out 12 hits, including two home runs, for a 10-3 conquest of the Pirates today.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Representative Martin Dies of Texas bowed himself out of the political arena today and his withdrawal is expected to mean the end of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, which he piloted through six stormy years.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Browns blasted fifteen hits to defeat Washington, 6 to 4, tonight and regain first place from the Yankees in the American League.

Greater activity occurred this week in the market for new investments here, following the dullness of last week, but the improvement was chiefly in the volume of issues awarded to bankers, particularly of municipal and housing securities, rather than in offerings of new bonds and shares for public subscription.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Truk atoll, Japan's once powerful citadel in the Carolines, was struck again Thursday by Army Liberator bombers which dumped sixty-two tons of bombs, hitting airfields and causing fires.

With the approach of Mother's Day serving as a stimulating factor, retail trade here this week was active. Estimates put department store gains at 15 per cent or more over the like week last year. Weather conditions spurred demand for summer apparel and accessories.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The text of the declaration by the United States, Great Britain and the Soviet Union to the Axis satellites:

Warning of the danger of religious or racial groups voting as such in the Presidential election, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of the Free Synagogue, in a sermon last night in the Synagogue House, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street, declared that Jews should vote as Americans and not as partisans.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 -- Facing the Cardinals in the first night game of the season in Sportsman's Park tonight the Dodgers donned their gaudy new circus suits of "jockey" satin and, unkind though it be to say so, their play was distinctly on the clownish side.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- With the launching at Savannah today of the Juliette Low, named after the founder of the Girl Scouts, a total of 101 Liberty ships, bearing the names of American women, will have slid into the water.

Reflecting lower volume of the mail order and shoe groups, sales of leading chain and mail order companies declined 0.6 per cent in April under the like month of last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A correspondent with the British Eighth Army reported that the "Rapido River has been forced on an eight-mile front between the range of Cassino and the Liri," the British radio said last night in a broadcast recorded at the Columbia Broadcasting System short-wave listening station.

The speech of Mr. Mackenzie King before the British Parliament on Wednesday is likely to be drowned out by the thunderous prelude to invasion reverberating in Italy and on the Channel coast. This is a pity, because the statement of the Canadian Prime Minister has an important bearing on a vitally important development.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, May 13 (U.P.) -- Eight Japanese planes were destroyed and two others were probably knocked out at Dublon and Eten Islands in Truk Atoll on Wednesday when Liberator bombers fought off thirty enemy interceptors to batter the islands' enemy airdromes and installations with ninety-six tons of bombs, it was announced today.

Choice by the Board of Education of Miss Mary E. Dillon as its President is no chivalrous compliment to its only woman member. It is recognition of the high ability she has shown in the last two years as Brooklyn member and chairman of the Finance Committee.

Presentation of evidence at the trial of Frederick Heizer Wright in Federal court was completed yesterday by both prosecution and defense and the case will go to the jury Monday after summings-up by counsel and a charge to the jury by Judge John Bright.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce declared in an address tonight before the Union League Club that the United States was in the war before Dec. 7, 1941, and that the attack on Pearl Harbor was in consonance with that fact.

Although Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, announced early this week that the agency had inaugurated a policy for the resumption or increase of production by small plants in cases where it would not interfere with war output, Lewis S. Greenleaf Jr., regional director of WPB, indicated yesterday that no substantial increase in such output win be authorized for some time.

In recognition "for outstanding services to American music," the National Association for American Composers and Conductors at its annual reception at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night awarded the Henry Hadley Medal to Mayor La Guardia.

RICHMOND, Va., May 12 -- Outstanding among the 518 patents listed as granted in the current issue of The Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office is one on a method of manufacturing cellulose derivatives so that they will retain dye.
BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Red Sox today shelled Vernon Kennedy from the mound in the third inning and went on to a 10-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians at Fenway Park.

DETROIT, May 12 (AP) -- As one major war production factory quit operations, the strike of 3,300 Detroit war plant foremen remained at a deadlock tonight with the War Labor Board cool toward a strikers' demand for job protection.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., May 12 -- Following is the text of the resolution adopted today by the International Labor Conference dealing with the social provisions in the peace settlement:

The Silver Star for gallantry in action was awarded posthumously yesterday to Corp. John Gedney of the Army, in a ceremony on the parade field of Fort Jay, Governors Island, while his father, Alonzo, watched after having been freed of a charge of burglary in Brooklyn so he could attend and also keep clear his son's good name.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- The proxy fight for the control of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad ended peacefully today when V.V. Boatner, a director opposing the management, withdrew his slate of directors and voted his proxies for the directors recommended by the management.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The possibility of 19,000,000 persons becoming unemployed immediately on the close of the war was suggested by a Senate Military Affairs subcommittee today in a report emphasizing the necessity of all-inclusive legislation to govern policies of reconversion to peace.

City Markets Commissioner Henry M. Brundage announced yesterday that the Bronx and Brooklyn Terminal Markets, both city owned, would remain open today because a substantial number of wholesale produce dealers had signified their intention to operate six days a week as ordered by Mayor La Guardia.

PEARL HARBOR, May 12 -- During the last eight months Pacific Fleet carrier pilots attacking Japanese bases throughout the South and Central Pacific areas have established aerial superiority over a Japanese in a ratio of more than 7 to 1 in planes lost.

Asserting that the responsibility of teachers did not end in the classroom, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, urged yesterday the support of the 40,000 employes of the New York public school system for the current campaign of the Greater New York Fund.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 12 -The first large contingent of Wacs to reach the Southern Pacific area has arrived in this city, renowned from Pearl Harbor to Hollandia, New Guinea, as the Paris of the Pacific.
LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- A Strategic Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Several changes in methods of determining maximum prices for new kinds of merchandise under the General Maximum Price Regulation were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

The National Confectioners' Association has authorized an advertising campaign of $1,000,000 to correct popular misinformation that candy is fattening and causes tooth decay, it was learned yesterday. The action resulted from publication of the results of the recent survey undertaken by Leo Burnett Company, Inc., Chicago advertising agency, for the Council on Candy.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Generalissimo of China, received today the annual award of merit. It was made by the council's president, Dr. Robert Sibley of the University of California, at the annual meeting.

The shadow of the coming invasion of Hitler's European fortress, emphasized by the Allied push in Italy, produced yesterday fresh nervousness in the stock market and lower prices in the late trading. Scattered losses of a point and more showed in the closing list, although the general retreats held within a fractional range.

WITH THE ALLIED ARMIES IN ITALY, May 12 -- The Allied spring offensive in Italy began at 11 last night when hundreds of guns from Cassino to the Tyrrhenian Sea and from American and British ships off shore opened a thunderous chorus, their fire sweeping the lower Gustav Line.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today that the Shawrout Association, a Massachusetts trust holding bank shares and other investments, must obtain its shareholders' consent as a condition to withdrawal from listing and registration on the Boston Stock Exchange.

A new film-producing partnership has been formed by Hal Wallis and Joseph Hazen, who until a few weeks ago had been associated with Warner Brothers for many years, it was learned yesterday. They now are discussing a distribution deal with a major studio and also are conducting negotiations both with the Theatre Guild and Herman Shumlin, producers of Lillian Hellman's new play, "The Searching Wind."

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, commander of the United States Fifth Army in Italy, conferred recently in this country with President Roosevelt, Gen. George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, and other military officials, it was learned here today.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- The Cubs, who yesterday broke a string of thirteen straight defeats, returned to their losing ways today when the Phillies pounced on Paul Derringer for four runs in the first inning, then went on to a 9-to-3 victory.

Probably no member of either house of Congress has been the center of more controversy in the last six years than Representative Martin Dies. A comparatively obscure member of the House from Texas, he was catapulted into national prominence in 1938 when he became chairman of a recess committee appointed to Investigate un-American activities.

A 33-year-old welding foreman in a war plant and a member of the New York City Patrol waited nearly a month to catch up with the veteran pickpocket who took his empty wallet and 50 cents in change on April 15 while riding in the IRT subway.

For the Nazi satellites, Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Finland, twelve o'clock is about to strike. They can get out of the war now or take the consequences. This is the meaning, as stern as it is just and necessary, of the warning issued yesterday by the Governments of the United States, Britain and Russia.

OTTAWA, May 12 -- The Dominion Minister of National Health and the Provincial Ministers closed a three-day conference today and agreed on the major principles of public health service and national health insurance.

Isaac W. Roberts, president of the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society, oldest mutual savings bank in the United States, was elected president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks at the concluding session yesterday of the association's twenty-fourth annual meeting, held in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Continuing their warfare against strained Japanese communication lines, United States submarines in the Pacific and Far East have sunk fourteen more ships, including a destroyer, raising to 709 the number of enemy vessels reported sunk or damaged since the beginning of the war.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, outlined tonight four "important" questions, including the establishment of a better relationship between labor and management, which he said the American people should start thinking about in the immediate post-war period.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Chairman Howard W. Smith of a special House committee which sponsored amendments to the Price Control and Wage Stabilization laws, now up for renewal, appeared before the Banking and Currency Committee today to defend the recommendations. He denied that the amendments would disrupt price control and contended that they would make the laws more efficient and equitable.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The tax simplification bill, passed by the House a week ago, was informally approved today by the Senate Finance Committee, with only technical changes, and Chairman Walter F. George said it would be reported to the Senate on Tuesday.

A resolution calling for the immediate rescue of victims of Nazism, signed by the worker- delegates from twenty-four countries to the conference of the International Labor Organization in Philadelphia, was made public yesterday by the Jewish Labor Committee, 175 East Broadway.

With hospitals and public health officials speaking in support of her views, Miss Hilda M. Torrop reported yesterday to the National Association of Practical Nurse Education that practical nursing has emerged now as a recognized vocation and an indispensable part of post-war nursing.

Indications are increasing that the Japanese invasion of India may fail as dismally on the military front as it has already failed on the political front. There is no evidence that enemy penetration of Manipur ever produced a ripple of revolt in India. Meanwhile the invaders have lacked the strength to take a single one of their objectives.

Mrs. Sara Pelham Speaks, designated Wednesday for the Republican nomination for Representative in the new Twenty-second Congressional District, announced yesterday that she also intends to enter her name in the Democratic primary this August.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Liquidation was on again today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and for the second consecutive session prices declined rather sensationally. Selling pressure was especially severe in rye, prices breaking 2 1/4 to 3 cents a bushel at one time and May showing a loss of 9 7/8 cents from the high of last week.

Demanding a relaxation of Federal regulation of the nation's farms, spokesman for agricultural groups in the northeastern States asked yesterday that control of agriculture be returned to community and State supervision.

Charging that the use of the Army by the Government in taking over the Chicago offices of Montgomery Ward Co. is "dictatorship and the end of private enterprise," Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, told members of the New Jersey Bankers Association at their annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania that unless a change is made, "our American way of life is nailed to the cross of bureaucracy."

He is 23. He comes from a Wisconsin county that hugs the border of Minnesota and from the village of Poplar with a population of 461. He used to knock down ninepins as neatly as he knocks down Japanese planes. He can drive a jeep sixty miles an hour, never less than forty around a curve.

With a barrage of seventeen hits, including two homers and a double, the Tigers yesterday spoiled Bill Zuber's second start of the season for the Yankees at the Stadium. Zuber disappeared in the six-run seventh inning, bringing Floyd Bevens into bold relief before a Bronx crowd for the first time.

The American Federation of Labor, through Matthew Woll, vice president, declared yesterday that the 30 per cent cabaret tax was "confiscatory" and urged waiters and culinary workers to protest to Congress against the tax.

LONDON, May 12 -- The Polish Government today made the ultimate concession to the public out-cry against the imprisonment of soldiers who deserted the Polish Army to escape what they said was racial discrimination, and granted amnesty to all the convicted men.

LONDON, May 12 -- During today's air battles First Lieut. Robert J. Rankin of Washington, D.C., destroyed five enemy fighters, equaling the American-European record for the greatest number of enemy aircraft destroyed in a single day.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan consented yesterday to a motion by Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks of the State of New York in charge of The Bank of United States in liquidation, for an order approving a final accounting covering the period from Oct. 1, 1942, to April 30, 1944, and virtually ending the career of that institution.

British-American psychological warfare against Germany on the subject of invasion has "completely achieved its aim" and built a "psychosis" among the Nazi leaders, according to an article in the Geneva newspaper Suisse reported yesterday to the Office of War Information.

New Yorkers more than 30 years old, who are employed in essential occupations probably never will be drafted, Col. Arthur V. McDermott, City Director of Selective Service said yesterday. He hastily added, however, that their continued deferment from military service would depend on "the fortunes of war."

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Only 150,000 to 200,000 men 26 and over need be drafted for the rest of this year, Government officials estimated tonight. Selective Service was reported to be apprehensive that too many older men might be taken despite a new deferment policy.

When news of the invasion of Europe is announced the famous Bow Bells and bells from several other vanished churches will ring again in the Times Square area. They will be sounded from the tower of St. Luke's Lutheran Gothic edifice, 316 West Forty-sixth Street.

The thirty-second annual meeting of the Children's Welfare Federation reminds us again that the existence of the Federation is a basic fact in the well-being of New York childhood. At this time when the thoughts of most of us are on faraway battlefields it is well to recall that orderly and intelligent care of thousands of children of the city would hardly be possible but for the activities of this devoted organization.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (U.P.) -- Representative Fred Crawford, Republican, of Michigan, charged tonight that the War Production Board was "parceling out" the production of farm machinery to favored manufacturers at the expense of the country's farmers and vital food production.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- The twenty-sixth International Labor Conference adjourned tonight after adopting unanimously the social provision suggested by the United States for inclusion in the peace treaty and sending a strong message to the enslaved peoples of the occupied countries of Europe that their day of deliverance was not far off.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 12 -- War workers in general spend their earnings so freely that the State has to help protect them against their own carelessness, Assistant Superintendent Joseph G. Rogers of the State Department of Weights and Measures said today.

It has long been assumed that American book-reading habits are in part shaped by the difference in production costs between paper-bound books and cloth-bound books, and this spread is considerable one.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, March 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Fifth Army said farewell today to the Cassino stronghold on the road to Rome which it tried to crush and failed, and set off to try again on another sector.
If the college football rules are changed this year, they'll have to change the chairman of the rules committee first.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12 -- Lack of funds to back regulatory food and drug laws is hampering officials endeavoring to control sanitation in production and handling of the food supply, Jacob W. Forbes of New Orleans, president of the Association of Food and Drug Officials of the United States, charged tonight at the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the Central Atlantic States Association of Food Drug Officials.

Starting one minute after another Army plane of the same model and making a stop of 6 minutes 25 seconds in Kansas City, Kan., Col. Clair Peterson, Army Air Force, flew from California to New York in 6 hours 31 1/2 minutes, arriving at La Guardia Field yesterday just seven minutes before Lieut. Col. Jack Carter, AAF.

WITH THE AMERICAN AIR FORCE IN ITALY, May 12 (AP) -- Along the actual combat lines of the Fifth and Eighth Army battle fronts, the weather again played the German game today as it has repeatedly in major engagements of the past few months by shielding enemy strong points from bombing and strafing during the pinches.

Summer vacation jobs for teenage students won the approval of a juvenile audience at New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, last night when the final youth panel meeting in a series sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES was held with "Vacations: A Challenge to Youth in Wartime" as the topic.

Cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday continued their slow decline, finishing 5 to 8 points net lower. The market was influenced by the weakness in grains, continued favorable weather in the South and uncertainty regarding war developments in Europe.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Effective Monday, the Government will extend the support brackets to include good and choice 180 to 200-pound hogs. On the same date the ceiling on hogs over 240 pounds will be lowered 75 cents to $14 a hundredweight. Receipts at the twelve major midwestern markets to date this week have been 58.490 head heavier than for the same period last week and price declines have resulted throughout the circuit.

CHUNGKING, China, May 12 (AP) -- Japanese invaders sweeping into northwestern Honan from Shansi Province have cut the eastwest Lung-Hai railway forty-eight miles west of Loyang, severing a main retreat line for several hundred thousand Chinese troops, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Rear Admiral Joseph R. Redman, director of naval communications, told the House Committee on Post-War Military Policy today that there had been long standing differences of opinion between military authorities and the Federal Communications Commission over the latter's jurisdiction in the assigning of radio frequencies.

Governor Dewey, now regarded as the leading possibility for the Republican Presidential nomination, and the daily press of the nation were criticized last night at a "draft-Roosevelt" dinner at the Hotel Commodore sponsored by the Kings County section of the American Labor party.

BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- An enlisted man died of burns and sixteen others were reported missing as the result of an explosion and fire on a Navy lighter while its crew was dumping old and condemned ammunition yesterday afternoon about fourteen miles northeast of Boston Harbor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- Recommendations passed by the International Labor Conference on social and economic problems of women and young people present a sound and stable basis for future action in all countries, Secretary Frances Perkins, United States Government delegate to the conference, said tonight.

Mother's Day will be celebrated tomorrow in churches of all faiths and today in synagogues. Mary's Day will be commemorated today in Roman Catholic churches in honor of Mary, the Mother of Jesus Christ. In all houses of worship the mothers who have sons and daughters in the armed forces will receive special honor as asked by President Roosevelt in a proclamation last month.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Bill Lee, pitching star of the Chicago Cubs' 1935 and 1938 pennant drives, held his old team to seven hits today to hurl the Philadelphia Phillies to a 6-to-2 triumph. The loss was the Cubs' fifteenth in their last sixteen games.

The first major labor agreement to be reached in the martime industry since the outbreak of the war without previous recourse to the National War Labor Board was signed on Friday by representatives of eight tank ship companies and Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations.

LONDON, Sunday, May 14 -- Striking deep within Germany at vital points that must be protected by the Luftwaffe at the expense of air power badly needed in the enemy's Italian defensive, Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force battered objectives from the Ruhr to the Baltic yesterday.

Maj. Gen. Auguste Marie Brossin de St. Didier, chief of the French Military Mission to the United States, paid an official visit to Governors Island yesterday afternoon. He was received by Lieut. Gen. George Grunert, commanding officer of the Eastern Defense Command; Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commanding the Second Service Command, and Col. George S. Beurket, in command at Fort Jay.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 13 -- Argentina is planning to bring 1,000,000 boys and girls, presumably orphans, from Europe after the war to establish them in national territory and make them Argentine citizens, it was revealed today in statements made by Carlos Barrales, who recently returned from Buenos Aires.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 13 (AP) -- Glenn Gardner made his pitching debut of the season for the Rochester Red Wings today by hurling them to a 11-0 victory over the Newark Bears. It was the eighth straight victory for the Wings and it gave them a clean sweep of the Newark series.

CHUNGKING, China, May 13 -- Japanese troops, using about 200 tanks, have driven to within two miles of Loyang, the Chinese command acknowledged tonight, and Chinese hopes of holding the ancient Honan Province citadel faded rapidly.
SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 13 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Sunday, May 14 (AP) -- The Soviet High Command announced last night that Russian bombers attacking German military trains and stores at Dvinsk in Latvia and Tartu in Estonia had touched off violent explosions and fires Friday night.

The International Labor Conference, meeting at Philadelphia, has produced a charter of human rights which, if it could be generally adopted, would usher in the millennium. The charter affirms that "all human beings, irrespective of race, creed or sex, have the right to pursuit of both their material well-being and their spiritual development in conditions of freedom and dignity, of economic security and equal opportunity."

FRENCH LICK, Ind., May 13 (AP) -- An optimistic report on probable future discoveries of natural gas reserves was presented to the spring conference of the American Gas Association here last night by Lyon F. Terry, second vice president of the Chase National Bank of New York.

As the struggle in Europe rises to a climax of invasion and Allied forces in the Pacific strike harder at the Japanese, the people of the American republics are able to report progress in rendering strategic and economic support to the war.

FRED WARING and his Pennsylvanians, who for the past five years have been on the air five nights a week, have come to the parting of the ways with their sponsor and, beginning June 12, will be replaced by Johnny Mercer, the song writer and orchestra conductor, and a new band.

ANNUAL asters in the not too distant past were the most popular flowers of their class in American gardens, but these aristocratic beauties have fallen into disfavor during the past fifteen years or so. In spite of the fact that they are relatively easy to grow from seed, and that plants ready to purchase and set in the ground are plentiful in May, many gardeners have shied away from them.

MR. VILLARD, always an interesting journalist and pamphleteer, has revised in this volume his earlier studies of newspapers and brought his general survey up to date under war conditions. The title, "The Disappearing Daily" probably is intended to be a shocker.

LONDON, May 13 -- Germany's Nazi leaders are desperate, but they still think they have a chance to stave off complete defeat. This is the theme that runs through much of their propaganda. It shows, too, in some of the plans they are known to be making for conserving assets, such as their own manpower and industrial plants in occupied countries.
BOSTON, May 13 -- Although birds are singing, flowers blooming and heat waves starting, New England had sharp reminders this week of next winter's blizzards.

Scarce merchandise items currently average from 15 to 20 per cent of over-all retail stocks with this potential loss in volume, however, overcome by higher unit sales of available goods, recourse to substitute types and, in some instances, aggressive canvassing of the markets for spot purchases to pull up depleted inventories.

CLEVELAND, May 13 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steel Workers Union, CIO, today pledged that there would be no strikes while the union's case for revising the "little steel" formula was before the War Labor Board.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12 (Delayed) -- The informal conversations between representatives of political and guerrilla factions of occupied Greece and emigre political leaders, including Prime Minister George Papandreou, are proceeding in what has so far been a surprising atmosphere of harmony.

EVIDENTLY they weren't kidding this time. Guthrie McClintic commences rehearsals of "Mr. Tutt" about Aug. 25 and the venerable barrister should be seen on Broadway the week of Oct. 30 after four weeks out of town.

LOS ANGELES. The custom collections of the West Coast designers this season are marked with elegance. Evening clothes have been brilliant in detail and in the choice of fabrics. Adrian features suits in bright colors, always contrasted in some way with piping, insets or appliqued designs.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 13 -- Until today the principal criticism of Father Stanislaus Orlemanski's activities expressed by any one in Springfield had come from members of the Polish National Catholic Church, a sect which broke with the Roman Catholic Church forty-eight years ago.
CHICAGO, May 13 -- Probabilities are that the end of the German phase of the war will not mean any marked easing in the hardwood lumber situation for some months thereafter.

IT is good to welcome Catherine Littlefield to the ranks of American choreographers represented in the repertoire of the Ballet Theatre. She is one of the mere handful of people who have done most to prepare the field for the existence of a native ballet art.
It is indeed a hopeful augury for the post-war settlement that the leaders of both great parties appear to be in agreement that our foreign relations must be raised above all partisan considerations.

THE rarest and most desirable quality in books about Russia is grass-roots authenticity. Amid the flood of books about Russia in recent years it is surprising how few tell a simple, straightforward story of how Russians live and raise families; how they are housed; what they eat and wear; how they think and feel and amuse themselves; how their children are educated.

Prof. Boyd H. Bode will retire this year from the faculty of the College of Education at Ohio State University, having served on it since 1921. Prior to that time Professor Bode taught philosophy at the University of Illinois and the University of Wisconsin. His colleagues will honor him on May 26 with an educational conference in which the meaning of his philosophy will be explored.

LONDON, May 13 -- A political crisis developed in the Polish National Council today as a result of the recent charges of anti-Semitism in the Polish Army when two Socialist members of the council demanded the resignation of the Minister of Defense, Lieut. Gen. Marjan Kukiel.

WEARING its hair shirt as jauntily as possible under the circumstances, the theatre this season has stood accused of almost every crime on the artistic calendar. It has been blamed for behaving with the frivolity of a summer grasshopper and for hawking wares that weep with maudlin sentimentality.

A CLOUD with a solid platinum lining, still no bigger than an agent's hand, looms in the Urgent West. Hollywood (MGM, to be exact) is making a demarche on Publishers Row, in Hollywood's best Lorelei manner -- and, if the metaphor is not already too strained, the ground-bait may be hard to refuse.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- A story of how Staff Sgt. Raymond H. Rooke of Detroit, his body riddled by mortar and grenade fragments, used the last of his strength to pour one final, deadly burst of machine-gun fire into a Japanese pillbox before he died is told by a companion in his squad.

MOSCOW, May 13 -- How Gen. Rodion Y. Malinovsky's military council consulted a 95-year-old Ukrainian beekeeper on weather prognostication during the freak spring last February was told today by Vasili Grossman, Red Star war correspondent.

A FLOCK of new plants may be started from the handsome hydrangea, which is such a popular flower gift during spring. That is, if one has a window garden or sun room spacious enough to accommodate several of these sizable plants next winter.

WASHINGTON, May l3 -- The War Production Board announced today the placing of controls on all production, sales and distribution of work gloves in order to meet requirements of essential war industry workers and farmers.

NAPLES, May 11 (Delayed) -- The Yugoslavs announced today the beginning of an Allied onslaught against Hitler's southern European strongholds with all-out attacks by the forces of Marshal Tito on the Vardar and Ibar Valleys -- the two main German communication routes from Serbia into Greece.

Words and their meaning, at home and abroad. Here at home it is the problem of "smear." It is now a dozen years old. It came in with the 1932 Presidential campaign and has since made its regular quadrennial reappearance in the vocabulary of the old war horses.

ATLANTA, May 13 -- Completion of a campaign begun in 1939 to raise $7,500,000 toward the development of a university center in Georgia was announced here today. When this plan was proposed it was heralded as "the most forward step ever undertaken for Southern education."

Hailed by leaders of both sides as forerunner of the invasion of the Continent, the Allied attack in Italy from Cassino to the sea is of prime military importance; it is of large political import as well. The drive is developing and it is too soon to predict what it will accomplish.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The Third Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that the constitutional guarantee of free speech protected employer and employe alike, and that the Wagner Labor Relations Act did not purport to authorize "a restraint upon the freedom of speech in any circumstances."

The Women's Organization for The American Merchant Marine, Inc., will mark on Wednesday its fourth anniversary of war relief activity with the sponsoring of a Liberty ship at the Bethlehem-Fairfield yard in Baltimore. The vessel, the Samtorch, will be the 336th Liberty launched by the yard and is intended for operation by the British.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., May 13 (AP) -- Battling heavy seas and a high wind, a Navy blimp, a destroyer and a Catalina flying boat joined forces in a dramatic but unsuccessful attempt to save the life of Lieut. Hugh F. O'Neil of Akron, Ohio, pilot, whose plane crashed into the ocean off San Diego.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- The 1944 convention and war conference of the National Association of Retail Grocers will feature chiefly Government and industry speakers on operating and supply problems during the last half of the year, it was announced here today.

STEPS to speed up distribution of the United Newsreel, through which a representative pictorial account of America's participation in the war is brought to the people of Allied and neutral nations in every corner of the world, have been initiated within the past few weeks.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 13 -- The medalists, Alex Antonio and Frank Kringle of Sunnyfield, defeated Walter Pease and Sam Kinder of Plainfield, 3 and 2, in the opening round of match play in the New Jersey State amateur-pro best-ball golf championship at the Glen Ridge Country Club today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- A committee of nine, including three representatives of the United States, was named tonight by the governing body of the International Labor Organization to stand ready at all times to present the social viewpoint of the ILO at any international meetings prior to the next International Labor Conference.

TOURISTS who make their headquarters in Mexico City are becoming increasingly familiar with the motor highway through Morelia to Guadalajara. It winds through forests, over hills and around lakes that possess a strange, wild beauty.

TO understand the type of warfare in northern Burma you must understand the nature of the country. Picture it as a triangle. Across the northern apex of this triangle runs our hop, or air route, to China. In this apex General Stilwell and his Chinese troops are pushing the Japanese very, very hard. On the eastern side of the triangle are high mountains along the Salween River; the western side is the Imphal area.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Many Cabinet officials, members of Congress, high-ranking Army and Navy officers and industrial and labor leaders attended the premiere at the National Theatre here tonight of "The Forgotten Factor," a drama based on the industrial program of the moral rearmament movement, started by Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman.

Running the fastest local schoolboy mile of the season and cracking the meet record, one of eight new marks accounted for during the long program, Bill McGuire of George Washington again took the measure of New Utrecht's Walter Soltow in the featured test of the sixth annual Boys High track meet at Randalls Island yesterday.

On April 30 you published an article cabled from London by Raymond Daniell. I recently arrived here from London for the International Labor Office conference and have devoted most of my time to problems relating to the conference cannot, however, allow this extremely harmful statement of your correspondent to go unchallenged.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 13 -- The Army nine triumphed over N.Y.U. by 3 -- 2 in the tenth today. The cadets used two pitchers, Kinney lasting until the eighth, then giving way to Laboon. Branca went the route for the Violets, but received ragged support in the pinches.

THE great majority of American sailors go through what is perhaps the most exasperating experience of war -- to be under fire, in dangerous action, without being able to see what is happening. There is a vast degree of difference, in the Navy, between seeing action and actually seeing action.

LANGUAGES grow and change. New words spring up, out of new needs, new inventions, historical events. The German language -- in the last ten years -- is a case in point. New words have spread far and wide under the Nazis' Third Reich.

Challenging the entire structure upon which the Securities and Exchange Commission has formulated its reorganization program for public utility holding companies, Otis Co. of Cleveland, investment bankers, last week took the SEC before the Supreme Court of the United States in a determined attempt to overthrow a commission-approved plan for dissolution of the United Light and Power Company in conformance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

WITH THE ALLIED ARMIES IN ITALY, May 11 (Delayed) -- The great highways that have been the pride of Italy since the days of the Romans have been transformed by Gen. Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander's polyglot forces into international trade routes dealing in the substance of war.

THE versatility of the city's parks will again be tested as the sun grows hot and the public takes to malls and sports fields. The parks should be able to stand the test. For from barber shop quartets to championship swims, from tennis and track meets to picnics round the open fireplace at Talapoosa Point, they annually offer a choice of fun and recreation free to the people of the five boroughs.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- With the California primary election only three days away, a controversy was caused in Republican ranks today by the mailing of letters by Thomas M. Carlson of Richmond, a delegate to the Republican National Convention, endorsing the candidacy of Senator Sheridan Downey, Democrat.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The draft situation changed again this week, this time reflecting a decrease in the armed forces' manpower requirements for the first time since Pearl Harbor.

Although some key furniture men believe that production will be increased in the near future they are seeking the answers to several questions that have been bothering them for some time before venturing any opinions as to the extent of this rise, a survey of the market disclosed last week.
NAPLES, May 13 -- The fighting was bitter today as the Fifth and Eighth Armies assaulted thirty miles of the German line extending from slightly east of Cassino to the mouth of the Garigliano River.
LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- A broadcast communique:

TO the thousands of Americans who once were newsboys Harry E. Burroughs must seem to have all the earmarks of a guardian angel. In the general sense of the word Mr. Burroughs is a philanthropist, but, unlike most philanthropists, he has not been content to contribute money and then sit around and pat himself on the back.

Although retail business remains good, the tendency is toward conservatism, particularly in the purchasing of merchandise that is in fair supply, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

One-third of all New Yorkers ngage in black-market buying as a regular practice and up to 70 per cent violate Office of Price Administration regulations "at one time or another," it was revealed yesterday in a city-wide survey by the City College Social Research Laboratory.
CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

THE urge to cut some of the tulips that are blooming so riotously in many gardens this week is apt to be too strong to resist. Tulips are blooms with a dramatic quality. Their plastic form, their porcelain-like texture and sleek, smooth stems suggest an arrangement in glass.

ASBURY PARK, N. J. -- An accelerated tempo to life hereabouts indicates that all will be ready for the official opening of the summer season on Memorial Day. For the first time in the modern history of the resort, all hotels will be open on that date, and municipal officials have ready the new program for civic and sports activities.

CLEVELAND, May 13 -- John L. Lewis has suffered one of his rare defeats. By rejecting his terms for readmission of the United Mine Workers to the American Federation of Labor, the federation's council has forced Mr. Lewis to play a lone hand in the labor movement.

ABOUT three years ago special short courses in explosives and in other "defense subjects" were started at many colleges and universities as part of what later became the Engineering, Science and Management War Training Program.

THE Talking Books, which from their long-playing phonograph disks read themselves to blind people, celebrated their tenth birthday as a free service the other day. On May 9, 1934, President Roosevelt signed the bill authorizing Talking Books to travel free through the mails.

THERE is a lot of talk these days about international problems. Editors, columnists, commentators, policy makers, and forum leaders discuss the pros and cons of a post-war organization of nations, a world-wide police force, air bases, the extension of reciprocal trade treaties, the continuation of lend-lease and the like.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A bill increasing the national debt limit from $210,000,000,000 to $240,000,000,000, was passed this week in the House by a voice vote. There is no reason to expect that the Senate will make any more ado about it, although it is admitted that next April another enlargement of the debt total will almost certainly be necessary.

The world premiere of Max Brand's scenic oratorio, "The Gate," on the night of May 23 at the Metropolitan Opera House will be presented to raise funds for the children of India. The proceeds will be turned over to the India Famine Relief Committee, Inc. Mrs. Charles H. Goddard has been appointed chairman of the committee of sponsors for the benefit.

AT A FORTRESS BASE in England, May 13 -- The big Fortress in the next group had exploded in flames. We knew it was out of the fight, but then we saw the blazing wreck swerve and, in a kind of tragic billiard shot, collide with the next Fort.

Political leaders of liberal thought extolled the principles recently enunciated by the International Labor Organization as beneficial to better understanding among the people of the world at a luncheon yesterday in honor of Walter Nash, New Zealand Minister to the United States, sponsored by the League for Industrial Democracy.

ALGIERS, May 13 -- It was expected today that Andre Le Trocquer would soon go to London for negotiations with the Allies' command regarding the civil and military Government of the liberated regions of France. Some informed quarters thought it likely that Gen. Charles de Gaulle would be persuaded to go later.

CHINESE who come to this country now are, or profess to be, surprised at the concern felt here over internal dissension in China, meaning, of course, the latent conflict between the Government at Chungking and the Communists, now immured in the northwest behind an unofficial blockade.

In Britain last week final preparations for military invasion of the Continent were accompanied by final preparations to take over local government in the enemy and occupied lands. That will be the job of the new G-5 section of the Allied General Staff, working under SHEAF -- Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Expeditionary Force.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Red Sox bunched five hits in the fourth inning to score three runs and followed with another in the sixth today to take the opener of a three-game series from the Tigers, 4 to 2.

FOR some hours last Sunday night at the Hotel Astor they were saying a lot of nice things about the little man with the popping eyes who was celebrating his thirty-fifth anniversary in the show business; and, in the argot of the banquet hall, the compliments were no more than a just tribute to one who . . . etc., etc.

A husband and wife who asked for cancellation of their citizenship because they were completely pro-German and detested American democracy were accommodated by Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday. As a result of their sentiments and the denaturalization proceedings, the couple, William and Meta Z. Sebert of 4256 Barnes Avenue, the Bronx, face internment and deportation at the end of the war.

THE world's greatest harbor swarms with the greatest merchant fleets in world history. In natural light by day, In searchlights' glare by night, thousands of brawny men on the New York City waterfront toil and sweat to fill these ships with tanks, guns, ammunition, planes, trucks and food destined for distant battle zones.

LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- German troops in fierce fighting along the entire Croatian front have penetrated into liberated territory, but in Slavonia Yugoslav troops have taken the initiative, Marshal Tito's communique said today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The case of the Government vs. Montgomery Ward Co., kept moving at furious pace by acts and counter-actions since the April 26 seizure and threatening new explosions momentarily, has offered little opportunity for orientation of long-range conclusions, but the repercussions which have set in promise to leave lasting marks.

Dr. Willard H. Dow, president of the Dow Chemical Company, whom received the annual medal of the American Institute of Chemists last night for his contribution to the war in the large-scale production of magnesium and styrene, charged that a "control mania" was rampant in Washington and had struck the sciences.

SWEET potatoes have every quality that makes for approval among Victory gardeners. Plants are cheap to buy or they may be grown at home and set out when the weather is warm. Last season we paid 35 cents for fifty plants and dug out more than a bushel of good potatoes in October.

The field service of the War Shipping Administration, a unit designed to control costs of ship repairs, was ordered on March 5 of this year to make "no further personnel expansions" and to cut its operating staff to 200 men by the end of this month, according to testimony given yesterday by David A. Richardson, chief of the field service section of the maintenance and repair division of the WSA.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 13 -- In a thrilling finish between two beautifully stroking crews, the Navy varsity eight barely got home ahead of M.I.T. by a foot today to sweep the Severn in the two-race regatta.

The first National Challenge Cup soccer final to be played in fourteen years at the Polo Grounds is scheduled this afternoon with Brooklyn Hispano, the titleholder, opposing the Morgan Strassers of Pittsburgh. A crowd of 15,000 is expected to be on hand for the kick-off at 3:30 o'clock.

AT A PARTISAN HOSPITAL IN ITALY, May 8 (AP) (Delayed) -- Djuro Miljusevic, 31-year-old Yugoslav partisan who faced a German firing squad and stopped twenty-five bullets including one through his face, can almost handle a rifle again.
Steadiness prevailed yesterday in the cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices on active months were 3 points lower to 3 points higher than on Friday.

MOSCOW, May 13 -- Behind the 2,000-mile Russian front there was no rest last week, no lull, despite the temporary cessation of large-scale forward movement of the Soviet forces which had been moving westward in one sector of the front or another almost constantly since last summer.

NAPOLEON THE GREAT is credited with the statement: "Whoever is master of the Dardanelles is Europe's master." The Germans might have become the Old World's masters if they had been able to conquer the Straits.

TORONTO, May 13 (AP) -- Nearly half the newsprint orders placed in Canada for May specified 30-pound or "lightweight" paper, and 60 per cent of June orders are expected to ask the lighter paper, the Toronto Financial Post said in an article from its Montreal bureau.

WILKES-BARRE, May 13 -- Rejecting an order of the War Labor Board to return to work, 3,350 striking employes of the Duplan Silk Corporation voted unanimously today to remain idle until written assurances are received that the board will assume jurisdiction and rule on demands for wage increases and paid vacations.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Roger Wolff, a knuckle-baller, limited the White Sox to seven hits tonight while the Senators pounded out nineteen off three pitchers for a 12-to-2 triumph. Wolff held Chicago scoreless until the ninth.

Students of Fairleigh Dickinson Junior College at Rutherford, N. J., have joined their parents, town officials and the Committee for Economic Development to go over the findings of the survey recently completed of the town by the college students.

Devil Diver maintained his mastery of the racing scene at Belmont Park yesterday. The Greentree Stable's 5-year-old, winner of the Paumonok and Toboggan Handicaps earlier in the season, stepped down in front in the fifty-first running of the one-mile Metropolitan Handicap and in so doing gave strong evidence that he was one of the top candidates for the handicap championship.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Allied invasion forces will take with them to Europe millions of dollars worth of occupation money -- francs, guilders and other western European currencies. Preparations for the issues were recently completed in agreement with the countries concerned.

An event of more than usual moment in the fishing line will take place on Tuesday, when the use of shrimp for chumming becomes legal on Peconic Bay, in Long Island. Thus the lads who go after weakfish there will be able to take these fish from near the surface.
ORDINARILY these articles have dealt with a single theme on each occasion; I hope I may be pardoned if today I touch upon two subjects which are quite unrelated.

MANY gardeners who planted strawberries for the first time last year are now looking forward to gathering their own vine-ripened fruit. Proper spring care of the strawberry bed, although fairly simple, is important. Since the groundwork was done the first season, a good bed now means that nine-tenths of the work is done.

LONDON, Sunday, May 14 (AP) -- The formations of United States heavy bombers that struck in Germany yesterday were part of a total of about 5,000 American and British planes that hurled 8,000 tons of explosives on Nazi targets in Europe in two-way attacks from Britain and Italy during the day.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- At a time when normally the trend of West Coast thinking would be toward political candidates and issues, one question comes into sharp focus wherever one travels up or down this Pacific slope. It is not "Who will win these Senatorial primaries in California, Oregon and Washington?", but "When is D-Day?"

NAPLES, May 13 -- Allied troops on the offensive in Italy smashed deeper tonight into the heavily fortified Gustav Line, increasing the gains of two miles or more that they had recorded during the day but encountering grim resistance from the Germans in strong mountain positions.

THERE were special reasons for the celebration of Mother's Day this year and this was made manifest during the week in the surge of gift purchasing for today's occasion. From overseas came remembrances which no doubt are most fondly cherished.

RUSSELL SAGE was monumentally wrong. When New York was debating some forty-five years ago the advisability of digging its first subway, he spoke up with all the authority of one of the city's First Citizens.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (U.P.) -- The youngest major generals in the United States and German Armies -- the American eight years his enemy's senior -- are pitted against each other in the air war that is the prelude to the Allied invasion of western Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (U.P.) -- American fighting men held prisoner by the Japanese are doing without most of the mail-borne comforts from home -- such as letters, parcels and books -- that are reaching Americans in German prisoner-of-war camps, an analysis of American Red Cross reports showed tonight.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 13 -- The South Carolina Democratic convention will be held Wednesday, with anti-New Dealers professedly in the saddle and expecting to nominate an anti-Roosevelt delegation to the Chicago convention.

POETRY indeed seems to me more physical than intellectual. A year or two ago, in common with others, I received from America a request that I would define poetry. I replied that I could no more define poetry than a terrier can define a rat, but that I thought we both recognized the object by the symptoms which it evokes in us.

More than 4,000 veterans have availed themselves of the community service established a month ago at 10 East Fortieth Street by the War Manpower Commission and the Selective Service of New York City, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the WMC, said yesterday in reporting on the effectiveness of the Veterans Service Center as a clearing house for solving the problems of discharged service men and women.

FROM J. Madden, Deputy Director General of New Zealand's Postal Administration, comes information regarding new stamps. Remainders of the 1940 Centennial 1 1/2-pence have been overprinted "Tenpence" in black block letters, the original value being obliterated by a decorative cross-shaped design; the provisional is "primarily for use in prepaying the fee on civilian air-graph messages."

Dr. H.E. Enoch and Dr. W.K.S. Wallersteiner report in Nature that they have put part of the mold from which penicillin is made right in a wound with no harmful effects. Within three or four hours fever dropped and pain was relieved in test animals. Good results have been obtained in human cases of pneumonia that failed to respond to sulfa drugs, and in acute staphylococcal, streptococcal and other infections.
LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force communique:

THE conscience of Ireland is her women. Her freedom was won by her men, but through the darkness of 400 years until victory was achieved the purity of the race was a sacred flame kept burning by the women.

With a brisk demand reported for Mother's Day items, retail trade was active here last week. Gains ranging up to 15 per cent or more over the like week last year were reported for department stores. Favorable weather conditions spurred the call for summer apparel and accessories.

MR. WISH EGAN is a tall, stately gentleman with patrician bearing and fatherly mannerisms. Although he has been scouting for the Detroit Tigers for some thirty years, he can better be described as the new type of talent searcher. The minor leagues were combed so thoroughly just before the war that few clubs bothered to send their eagle-eyed operatives looking for hitherto hidden nuggets.

The first American eye bank is to be established, with New York Hospital acting as the distributor of donated eyes collected from nineteen other hospitals. Not whole eyes but just the corneas are to be transplanted, and the corneas are to come from living donors whose sight is doomed or lost or from benefactors who dispose of their eyes in their wills.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 13 -- A uniform system of State legislation for food and drug laws was demanded today by the Central Atlantic States Association of Food and Drug officials in convention at the Claridge Hotel.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 13 -- A tense ringside crowd awaited the final award this evening in the second annual show of the Plainfield Kennel Club, held on the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club. Nearly 700 dogs had been in competition through a long day of judging. Some of the greatest canine specimens in the East had been battling through their breeds and groups.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 13 -- While Vichy propaganda is concentrating on Allied "terrorism from the air," private letters from France indicate that though bombings are dreaded, they are accepted stoically in the hope that the higher tempo heralds "the great day."

A War Department telegram and an orchid notified Mrs. Jack J. Seifter of 176 West Eighty-seventh Street, that her son, Second Lieut. Morton Seifter of the Army Air Forces, reported missing in action over Germany, was a prisoner of war, she said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May, 13 -- The Southern Coal Producers' Association told the War Labor Board today that, in view of the record of operations under the Ickes-Lewis formula, it could not approve the pending wage agreement between coal producers and workers based on that formula without "a clear repudiation" and violation of the stabilization program.

THE Postoffice Department made available last week a photograph of the 3-cent purple stamp which will be issued on May 22, National Maritime Day, to commemorate the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the first American steam-propelled vessel to venture across the Atlantic.

Working closely with the Surplus War Property Administration, which has already set "floor" prices on Government-held surplus materials, the Office of Price Administration is preparing a comprehensive price order which will establish ceilings and pricing methods for Government agencies, it was learned yesterday.
