The expanding advance in cancer control through education and the necessity for cooperation between the layman and the physician in combating the disease were stressed by speakers in the second group of Memorial Hospital's sixtieth anniversary lectures yesterday in the hospital auditorium, 444 East Sixty-eighth Street.

SENATOR JAMES M. MEAD of New York was one of the five globe-girdling Senators whose remarks caused a furor when they returned from their inspection of global battlefronts last autumn. They were scolded by many sections of the press, chided by President Roosevelt, spanked by Winston Churchill.

Plans for an International Office of Education, in which the United States would play an important role, began to take shape last week with the return from London of the American delegation to the Conference of Allied Ministers of Education. It appeared certain that some form of emergency program would be adopted to help rebuild the destroyed school systems of Europe and China.

NATIONAL unity was at its lowest ebb in Italy during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. What was left of the glitter and magnificence of the Renaissance had not been long in wearing off under the burden of Spanish and Austrian oppression.
BALTIMORE, May 13 -- It was Pensive again today in the Preakness just as it was last Saturday in the Kentucky Derby.

With forebodings of the invasion of western Europe by the armies of the United Nations still hanging over the market, trading on the New York Stock Exchange dropped yesterday to the smallest figure in eight months -- 220,110 shares -- but prices were moderately firmer.

Ormsby McHarg, chairman of the MacArthur National Associates, said yesterday that nothing short of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's personal appearance in this country and his personal veto when made familiar with the facts would prevent presentation of his name as a candidate for President at the Republican National Convention.

THE first client to engage the services of Sam Booker and Jimmy Webb, who have just opened a detective agency, wants the two detectives to find his wife, who has deserted him. This they do quite easily and are well paid for their work.

VISCOUNT CRANBORNE, British Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs, who has served as stage manager of the conference of Commonwealth Prime Ministers in London and looms as a potential future British Foreign Minister, is the complete English aristocrat.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 -- Although playing in their sedate daytime uniforms instead of the bizarre theatrical costumes they wore last night, the Dodgers still were just as full of "ham" as they closed out the series with the Cards by losing their third game in four starts, 8 -- 4.

ONE day during the Tunisian campaign, about a year ago, Capt. Albert Wharfield and Lieut. Charles Batson of the communications and public relations staff of Allied Force Headquarters in Algiers negotiated with the British Broadcasting Corporation for the indefinite use of a mobile unit.

IT is good old-fashioned Presbyterian doctrine that man is born to meet his time. Therefore, when a Scot sets forth to picture the personality of a subject, President or peasant, what is more natural than framing the man to his time?

DES MOINES, May 13 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio does not concede that Governor Dewey has the Republican nomination for President in the "bag" and intends stepping up his own campaign right up to convention day, say Buckeye State friends who accompanied him here on his delegate-getting mission.

Frank D. Abell, president of the First National Bank of Morristown, N.J., was elected yesterday president of the New Jersey Bankers Association at the final session of the forty-first annual meeting of the association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BOTH Twentieth Century-Fox's "Thunderhead" and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Son of Lassie," going into production within a month, will be photographed, interiors as well as exteriors, entirely by the newly disclosed Technicolor Monopack process.

CITIES like St. Louis have gone into show business to provide their citizens with summer entertainment at popular prices, says Harry Friedgut, managing director of Mayor La Guardia's City Center, so why shouldn't New York?

PITTSBURGH, May 13 (AP) -- Those unpredictable Boston Braves maintained their hitting mood for the third straight day and blasted three Pittsburgh Pirate pitchers for twenty-three hits as they hammered out a 16-to-2 victory to take the series, 3 to 1.

Eight members of the war veterans' organizations were arrested in midtown Manhattan yesterday afternoon and accused of selling poppies without holding proper permits from the Department of Welfare. All were convicted in Night Court of having solicited contributions illegally, but sentences were suspended.

UP to the summer of 1942 the older boys of Four Corners might take their girls to nearby towns for movies, dancing, skating or bowling, but the activities of young people centered mostly around the churches, the homes and the school. Athletic teams exchanged visits with teams of neighboring towns.

THE rollicking spirit of Waldo Peirce has never been infused into his painting to better effect than in the work currently shown at the Midtown Gallery. The work has more substance and, too, there is a greater variety of subject matter than in many of his shows in the past.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 13 -- Scoring heavily in the field, Princeton's track team defeated Pennsylvania and Columbia in a triangular meet at Palmer Stadium today. The final score gave the Tigers 70 1/2 points to 49 1/2 for Penn, the Lions trailing with 45.

THE title of this little book explains the scope of Sir Osbert Sitwell's inquiry. According to the palmists, the lines of the left hand outline one's birthright, the lines of the right hand are modified by one's own actions and the character we develop.

IN your article "Politics Versus Symphonies" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 30, in which you discussed my analysis of Shostakovich in The New Leader of April 22, there were a few remarks which may have given the wrong impression of my opinion on the subject.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 13 (AP) -- Dr. W.I. Lunt's keen sprinter Valdina Punch scored his third straight triumph today as he won the $5,000 added Blackstone Valley Handicap on the closing day of the spring meeting at Narragansett Park.

READERS of "The Seventh Cross" will begin this book with hope, and finish it (if they can bear its vagaries that long) with a complete sense of let-down. Frau Seghers' first novel, despite its turgidity and its Teutonic tendency to moon, was good melodrama, lashed by the whips of an evil older than history.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 13 -- The Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski came home today from his twenty-six-day pilgrimage to Moscow to find himself embroiled with his church superiors.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 13 (AP) -- Bolivian mines producing wolfram, antimony and copper are threatened with a serious curtailment of production as a result of the expiration of contracts with the United States, the Minister of Economy, Gustavo Chacon, said today.

THERE is no product on the market today that gives 100 per cent protection against moths. Such was the unanimous pronouncement of the chemical and textile experts who answered homemakers' questions at a recent "Conservation Please" forum held by the Greater New York Chapter of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

Feats in magic drew laughter and awe from children yesterday morning as the season's final "Fun With Book People" meeting was held at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, under the sponsorship of THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the Association of Children's Book Editors and Junior Programs, Inc.

Jack-in-the-pulpit stands tall in the moist lowlands, its twin three-lobed leaves almost tropical and its purple-striped spathe with the hood flapped over making one think of some little grandmother with a shawl around her shoulders and one corner up over her head.

LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- American-British-Russian plans for acceptance of Germany's surrender are nearly completed, and call for complete destruction of the Prussian-built army, a reliable informant disclosed tonight.

MANY women are too busy today to afford the weekly two hours at the hairdresser, and so are forced to shampoo, set and style their own hair. Some of the outstanding New York hairdressers were asked to give tips to help these women solve their hairdressing problems. Here are the suggestions of those hairdressers.

Obviously embarrassed by the attention focused upon her, Mrs. Barbara Johnson, wife of Capt. Robert S. Johnson, the leading air ace of the European theatre, said yesterday that they would spend his leave enjoying the things her husband likes to do.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13 -- Gov. Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts, lean and fit in Harvard rowing togs, today stepped into an eight-oared shell and rowed as bow in an exhibition half-mile that marked a reunion of a Harvard college crew that thirty years ago won the Grand Challenge Cup in the Henley Regatta on the Thames River in London.

MOSCOW, May 13 -- The official Soviet newspaper Izvestia followed up the joint statement of the United States, the U.S.S.R and Great Britain with a warning today to Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Finland that delay now in ending their collaboration with Germany "is really the same as death."

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP) -- The Athletics knocked the Browns out of first place today when they pounded four pitchers for 17 hits and an 8-3 victory in the first game of a series before a crowd of 6,125.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- More than 74,000 veterans of the present war were put in civilian jobs in February and March through the United States Employment Service, the War Manpower Commission reported today.

The first blow in the all-out Battle of Europe was struck last week. Allied armies in Italy, after extensive regrouping and bringing up a great weight of weapons, launched the most ambitious offensive yet in the peninsula. They hit hard at the German Gustav Line, between Cassino and the Tyrrhenian Sea.

JASPER, Tex., May 13 (AP) -- Representative Martin Dies, resting today at his lodge here after his announcement of withdrawal from the Congressional race yesterday, said "from the beginning of my service in Congress my opposition to immigration has made me a number of powerful enemies."

Pressing a drive to bring the prices of clothing, notably work clothes, down to ceilings, the regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that it had filed in Federal courts injunction proceedings against forty-five retailers of work clothes in New York City.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, May 14 (U.P.) -- American forces in the Hollandia and Aitape areas of northern New Guinea, systematically wiping out Japanese forces which fled inland in the face of United States landings three weeks ago, have killed a total of 1,716 enemy soldiers and captured 354, it was announced today.

THE recent excursions by Hollywood into the field of international politics with such seemingly factual pictures as "Mission to Moscow" and the current "The Hitler Gang" have brought up some vital questions regarding the capacity and aims of entertainment-minded film producers as political analysts.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (U.P.) -- Semi-official sources said tonight that this Government was still hopeful that Sweden could be persuaded to stop ball bearing shipments to Germany but was prepared to apply economic sanctions if current Swedish-American negotiations broke down.

PEARL HARBOR, May 13 (U.P.) -- A slender Texan told a great success story of the Pacific war today in describing how his air group had shot down ninety-six Japanese planes while losing only one to enemy aircraft.

ENGLAND, London's "Newspaper on the Air," extended service to North America on May 7 by adding a 7:30 evening broadcast, admittedly as a pre-invasion move. "Radio Newsreel" is also on at 11 P.M. Arthur Mann, Mutual's commentator in London, in inaugurating the service, promised listeners throughout this continent a faithful night by night account of events when action begins across the Channel.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Father Orlemanski's assertion in a letter to Bishop O'Leary that he was no longer under the Bishop's jurisdiction but under that of the Apostolic Delegate was denied today by the Delegate, the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani.

ONE afternoon several months ago Phil Moore, who writes background music for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, was sitting opposite the torch singer Lena Horne. Rehearsal had gone badly and Lena was, as Moore put it, "full of grief." She dabbed at her eyes. Then she gave up and began to weep frankly. Moore had to do something.

Dr. Carlos Davila, former provisional President of Chile, warned the United Nations yesterday against excess post-war "economic demobilization." Dr. Davila, who is a member of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, spoke at an Inter-American Institute program at Brooklyn College under the auspices of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Out-side Castelforte, May 13 -- On the dusty road curving up to the newly won village of Santi Cosmo e Damiano, a German Mark IV tank lay atilt in a ditch. Its main gun was snapped off jaggedly near the turret and through the front slit one could see one German.

FROM time to time we have engaged in speculation concerning problematical postwar trends in art and possible new fields that the reconstruction period may open to artists sufficiently on their toes to take advantage of opportunities thus offered.

OMAHA, Neb., May 13 -- The people in this great food factory, of which this point of observation is a center, see, in last week's meat-ration dividend, a testimonial to the performance of an important job well done. It is the kind of result which is recognized by the ceremonial hoisting of E flags over war production industrial plants.

Tall, right-handed Dick Ames, who used to pitch for Yale, turned back his old team-mates on Baker Field yesterday and enabled Columbia to triumph 4 to 3. Ames' ability to tighten in the pinches balked the Elis.

LONDON, May 13 -- The Allies' offensive in Italy, launched in the midst of the tremendous air assault on targets of tactical importance in western Europe, has raised German pre-invasion forebodings to a painful new peak. German official statements and military comments, together with news percolating from Germany and occupied countries, show the Germans are anxiously contemplating the imminent possibility of several invasions striking them at once.

At yesterday's meeting of the Acoustical Society Miss Claire Benedict presented a convincing argument for regarding the human sound-producing mechanism as an organ-pipe, much like the one that produces vox humana effects in church. Her work is the result of years of study.

LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- The Berlin radio admitted tonight that the power of the Allies' offensive in Italy had driven breaches into the German defenses and forced the evacuation of Castelforte and nearby territory on the Fifth Army's front.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- In eloquently simple terms, Jack J. Zurofsky, a Brooklyn corporal, told of his stake in the war and won first prize, a $100 war bond, in an essay contest sponsored by the War Department.

THE annual exhibition of both pay-time and play-time work by members of the Society of Illustrators -- always a large and lively event -- is no disappointment this year although many of the members are in military service. If the visitor does not inquire too closely it will not be easy for him always to distinguish which is work done for illustration and advertising and which is avocational.

ALGIERS, May 13 -- Twice this week there has been striking public expression of French apprehensions regarding the future of France in relation to her present Allies. Misunderstandings between Algiers and Allied capitals -- which lately have been not far from the maximum -- might diminish if the Allied world took sympathetic account of French fears, even though they are not always expressed in dulcet tones.

THREE annuals became current last week: The Sculptors Guild, at the American British Art Center; the Society of Independent Artists, at the American Fine Arts Galleries, and the Spring Salon for Young Artists, at Art of This Century.

President Roosevelt came back to Washington last week from Hobcaw Barony, Bernard M. Baruch's 23,000-acre estate stretching across a peninsula from the Atlantic Ocean to Winyah Bay on the South Carolina coast. For a solid month he had slept twelve hours a night and spent his days in the sun, fishing a little and cruising about the near-by waterways and highways.

CINCINNATI, May 13 -- The Giants, who suddenly seem to have stumbled upon the right course, continued to dash gaily in the direction of the National League's first division today as they thrashed the Reds for the second successive afternoon.

THE Forty-fifth Division has been making history in a big way, and it deserves to have a lot of books written about it. Every one of us war correspondents has his favorite division, generally one of those with which he has "served," and that no doubt induces some bias, but this correspondent's admiration for the Forty-fifth, which he watched in action in Sicily and Italy, is shared by everybody who followed those campaigns.

A study by five leading specialists of the managers of industry and agriculture in the Soviet Union and of the operation of Russian managements, made public yesterday, indicates that Soviet production has overcome or is dealing effectively with many of the managerial problems that formerly promoted inefficiency or chaos.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- The War Labor Board reported today that work would be resumed on Monday by machinists in the San Francisco Bay area on two Navy ships in drydock. Completion of work on the vessels has been delayed more than a week by a wage dispute, but a union spokesman called the announcement by the WLB "a bit premature."

Federal Government reports showed yesterday that 1944 meat production would break all previous records, but consumers of New York City and elsewhere continued to encounter shortages of many meat cuts recently freed by the Office of Price Administration from ration points.

HAVING given the critics and Broadway's patrons of the light operetta something to cheer about in the presentation of "Rosalinda," "Merry Widow" and "Helen Goes to Troy," the New Opera Company, with Felix Brentano at the helm as producer and director, tonight offers two items in the opera buffa medium.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Destruction of the Liberty ship William M. Welch in a storm off the coast of Scotland a few weeks ago with the loss of about sixty men was reported today by the War Shipping Administration.

Todd Shipyards Corporation reports the development of an improved type of ship's gangway, with an all-steel frame that is lighter, safer and more flexible than the usual gangplank. The company's engineers have already installed one at the Hoboken yards after it successfully met all stringent tests.

A DOCUMENTARY film about France, one of a new series of full-length pictures produced under the supervision of the Office of War Information for exhibition in occupied countries immediately upon liberation, is in the final cutting stage and is expected to be completed within a week.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., May 13 -- Marking the second anniversary of their organization, several hundred Wacs stationed here paraded in review today before Maj. Gen. Frank O.D. Hunter, commander of the First Army Air Force.

" Officers at Home," a fete offering a varied program of entertainment, will be given by the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, of which Mrs. Junius S. Morgan is chairman, on Thursday night in the clubhouse for officers of the armed services, which the sponsoring group maintains at 28 East Thirty-sixth Street.
WHILE authorities agree that the longer of two biddable suits should usually be bid first, they are equally unanimous on the following type of exception:

Dr. Samuel Belkin, Talmudist and scholar, will be inducted as second president of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, which includes Yeshiva College, 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on May 23, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Samuel Levy, chairman of the board of directors.

WINDOW boxes in city and suburb are being decked for the summer. Few plantings are more conspicuous than they all season long. There is all the more reason, therefore, to create about them an indisputable air of well-being by preparing the soil and selecting the plants for them with discrimination.

AREQUIPA, Peru, May 13 (AP) -- Former President Enrique Penaranda of Bolivia, now living in exile here, said last night that political prisoners were being tortured by the present Bolivian Government. He appealed to the International Red Cross to investigate "the outrages of the Hitlerist regime now established in my country."

Lightning struck an Army artillery observation tower in Garfield, N.J., last night during an electrical storm that ended a day of unseasonable warmth, and touched off a barrage of 40-mm. shells. Explosions, the police said, continued for sixteen minutes and one shell crashed into a near-by house at 51 Malcolm Avenue, but the Army reported that there were neither military nor civilian casualties.

HANOVER, N.H, May 13 -- Dartmouth took both ends of a double-header today from Princeton 8 -- 4 and 2 -- 1. Carl Meurn held the Tigers to five hits in the opener, and Art Young, moving over from third, scattered seven hits in the nightcap.

THESE fourteen chapters which describe the life and ways of woodchucks, field crickets, garter snakes, cottontail rabbits, squirrels, skunks, turtles, swallows, chickadees, juncos and other small outdoor creatures are simply written and full of accurate information.

THE young woman, Tor Sigmund, who is the heroine and narrator of this story, is also the chief suspect in the murder of her next-door neighbor, Martin Linder. The evidence against her is purely circumstantial and not nearly so convincing as the other characters in the book, including her own father and the man she loves, seem to think.

Although the Japanese have allowed occupied Indo-China to retain the technical status of a Vichy dependency, recent domestic broadcasts by the Saigon and Tokyo radios have disclosed that the invaders have looted the country to such an extent that serious shortages of food, clothing and medicine have developed, the Office of War Information said today.

BLEND a town meeting with a dramatic production. Tinge with liberalism. Sprinkle freely with stooges. And you have the flavor of a performance by Stage for Action, the new theatre group that dramatizes home-front issues of today.

NAPLES, May 13 -- Heavy bombers of the Fifteenth United States Army Air Force attacked vital areas in northern Italy again today in what was officially described as the "climactic phase in the Allied air power's plan to destroy supply lines through which Hitler feeds forces resisting the new offensive of the Fifth and Eighth Armies."

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- An assertion that Republican members of the Senate, if they voted in a solid group, had the power to shut off debate and force a vote on the anti-poll tax bill, when the motion for closure comes up for a vote Monday, was made today by Senator H.M. Kilgore, Democrat, of West Virginia.

The practice of submitting income tax disputes to the United States Tax Court upon stipulations of the facts, agreed upon by the attorneys for the Government and the taxpayer, is not at all unusual. Whether this is good practice so far as the taxpayer is concerned depends upon the nature of the case and the thoroughness with which the stipulation is prepared.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The "David and Goliath" story of how the Choctaw, a 1,600-ton tug, raced out from Bermuda in February to tow into port the disabled 10,200-ton tanker Murfreesboro, laden with 4,500,000 gallons of aviation gasoline, after a twenty-four-day struggle described as "the longest towing job of the war," was told today by the Navy.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 13 (AP) -- The issue of cutting timber on State-owned lands has been revived by the lumber shortage.

Predicting that the United States would face a tremendous problem of unemployment after the war, James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, asserted last night that government and industry "should be working together now" to make plans for reconversion.

RICHMOND, Va., May 13 -- It seems to be generally assumed in this part of the South that the Marcantonio poll-tax repeal bill cannot pass the Senate, hence there is relatively little excitement. Yet even though the bill will probably be beaten, there remains the possibility that both the national party platforms this summer will incorporate poll-tax repeal planks, with all that this implies.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Negotiations for a bargaining contract between Montgomery Ward Co. and employes of CIO Local 20 of the United Retail Wholesale and Department Store Employes will be opened early next week, spokesmen for the company and for the union said today.

DETROIT, May 13 -- Telegraphed assurance that they would not be discriminated against if they returned to work failed tonight to end a strike of more than 3,300 foremen in war plants of six Detroit manufacturing firms.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 13 -- A new Allied offensive has been launched against the north Burma Japanese bases at Kamaing, Mogaung and Myitkyina by Chinese forces, which stormed a two-mile front with tank, dive-bomber and artillery support, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

Contrary to published reports, the cotton textile industry in Great Britain has not presented plans calling for permanent government control, nor was a proposal made to restrict expansion of the industry, it was learned yesterday from an authoritative source.

SOMEWHERE IN THE MIDDLE EAST, May 13 -- At long last, as the Allied offensives prepare to engulf the peripheries of the Balkan Peninsula and perhaps seek a passage through Germany's back door while Adolf Hitler is occupied in defending his front portal, Britain is trying to do something definite about unscrambling some of the mess that has tragically developed within the occupied territories of her small United Nations partners, Greece and Yugoslavia.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, May 14 (AP) --A communique:

THE "Frontiers in Chemistry Series" is an interesting improvement in the pedagogy of science and technology. It has been conceived because of a twofold need -- the need of graduate students of chemistry whose professors are not expert in all branches, and the need of practicing research chemists who tend to become narrow specialist and who require books to inform them about recent advances.

" THE EDUCATION OF T.C. MITS" is a delightful book that is both chastening and stimulating. I enjoyed it enormously, although the reason for the book's charm is hard to analyze. It might lie in the good-humored style, its total lack of condescension to the reader or in its fundamental faith in the human mind.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- John D.M. Hamilton, former chairman of the Republican National Committee, defended today the record of Republican administrations prior to 1933 and asserted that New Deal orators during the coming months would seek to induce voters to believe the lack of military preparedness before Pearl Harbor was the fault of Republican administrations between 1921 and 1932.

The foreign policy of the United States in the post-war period must be based upon the good-neighbor policy, Assistant Secretary of State Adolf A. Berle Jr. declared at yesterday's meeting of the Conference of Commissions of Inter-American Development at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Montgomery Ward Co. may not be engaged in war production, as it has been contended in the imbroglio with the Government in Chicago, but Central Westerners are agreed that it is manufacturing what may prove to be heavy ammunition in the Republicans' campaign to establish a bridgehead in the country's capital this fall.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A suggestion that the House create a standing committee on Un-American Activities, backed up by "a highly trained and permanent staff," was advanced today by Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, and ranking minority member of the committee which Representative Dies of Texas now heads.

MILWAUKEE, May 13 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, declared today that world peace could come only through cooperative effort of all the nations, with the United States assuming leadership.

MONTEVIDEO, May 13 -- The "interventor" or federal commissioner for the Argentine Province of Entre Rios today expropriated the Compania de Electricidad del Este Argentino [East Argentine Electricity Company], a subsidiary of the American and Foreign Power Company.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Liquidation of rye futures on the Board of Trade was on again today for the third consecutive session, but the volume of business was materially less than yesterday's record turnover of 22,868,000 bushels. At no time were prices above yesterday's close, and pressure on the market on all upturns was exerted by professionals and commission houses.

DDAY -- the day of invasion, the day of the war's greatest crisis -- is at hand. Invasion of western Europe will be the consummation of years of planning and months of effort; it will shape the course, duration and outcome of the war; it will justify -- or negate -- all the strategy, all the planning, all the fighting that has gone before.

Only half the boys and less than half the girls in the last two years of high school are now receiving organized instruction in physical education, according to a survey conducted by the United States Office of Education, made public last week. This means that about 1,100,000 juniors and seniors in high school are not receiving instruction in physical fitness.

MAC GARDNER (a woman) has written a fine first novel, a family story, brilliantly alive, with a keenly humorous slant. It is a Harper "find," and freshness is its outstanding quality. It is laid in the Puget Sound country in a big-mill, small-town setting.

IF this were a deliberate satire on mysticism -- and the character of sainthood in general -- it would be one of the most audacious books ever written. But as an unconscious record -- the artless revelations of a novelist extolling her own mystic "secret" -- it is terrifying enough.

CATHERINE MACDONALD MACLEAN has said goodby to the fictional Highland home in which she housed her "wee bairns" from the Scottish Lowlands, from London and from other parts of England, for the duration.

A large committee headed by Mrs. William C. Breed and comprised of many other women prominent in society, including patrons of music, is assisting with plans for the gala concert to be given May 25 at Madison Square Garden to raise funds for the American Red Cross.

THE pleasure boat owner will find little joy in making out a fuel application at his local ration board. OPA restrictions remain rigid -- a maximum of twenty gallons, which must last three months for an outboard motor, and only 125 gallons for the largest inboard craft during the same period.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Hope that "the women of America will respond to the present call for a large and urgently necessary increase in the strength" of the Women's Army Corps was expressed tonight by Gen. George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, on the eve of the second birthday of the organization.

Discussion of post-war controls is now becoming more widespread. After the last war most controls were quickly removed and there was a sharp price rise, followed by the collapse in 1920-21. It has been assumed that many controls must be continued after the cessation of hostilities to prevent a repetition of these developments.
HOLLYWOOD. THE "Claudia touch" has profoundly affected the careers of three young ladies, one who thought she should portray Claudia on the stage and two who did.
Evidently Left-handed Joseph Francis Page Jr., from Springdale, Pa., is a firm believer in the adage "try, try again."

The man on the flying trapeze, discovered yesterday afternoon in his dressing room at Madison Square Garden wiping off a small rivulet from his face, had a lot to say about this business of "flying through the air with the greatest of ease."

Vladimir Heifetz, conductor of the Yiddish Culture Chorus, was honored last night on the occasion of his tenth anniversary as leader of the organization by a Jubilee Concert at Town Hall at which only compositions or arrangements by Mr. Heifetz were sung by the chorus.

ONE of the more ambitious undertakings of the waning music season will be the presentation at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday evening of what its composer, Max Brand, calls a "scenic oratorio" entitled "The Gate."

The American Business Congress yesterday called upon the city Government to take action against street photographers said to be collecting "dollar bills" from service men for pictures they never receive. Harold M. Schwab, executive director of the ABC, lodged the protest with the city.

JUHU, India, May 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- Intimates of Mohandas K. Gandhi said today that his physical condition had deteriorated sharply and his mental powers had apparently been affected, causing him frequently to fade into a state resembling a coma.

Retail trade was generally active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floor departments had brisk business, with all types of accessories selling.

AS Carl Sandburg says in his introduction, "there have been small collections of folklore, we might say, but this one is a big shot." It is big in volume and it ought to be big in scholarship, for Mr. Botkin has been specializing in folklore for a couple of decades or so, looks after the interests of folksong in the Library of Congress, and this year is president of the American Folklore Society.

A new method for treating measles is revealed by Dr. Francis G. Blake, president of the Board for the Investigation and Control of Influenza and Other Epidemic Diseases in the Army. The material, which comes from blood plasma, is the protein known as gamma globulin.

MISS COATSWORTH includes in all her stories satisfying possibilities for imaginative fun. What child (or what adult, for that matter) who has read "The Littlest House" will ever forget the charm of that tiny, real dwelling and the actual housekeeping which three children did there one summer?

Our condolences to the Petersburg Society for the Preservation of Antiquity. No longer can it pay taxes on the Golden Ball Tavern, much less restore it. So it is being torn down. It is a frame building with brick ends and dormer windows and a gambrel roof, pentless and in its last open days a lunchroom.
LONDON, May 13 -- The aerial assault upon the material resources with which the enemy hopes to fight a defensive campaign against the invasion of western Europe is slowly nearing its climax.

" WHEN I depart for other regions," wrote Carl Engel in the last January's issue of The Musical Quarterly, in an article entitled "Introducing Mr. Brown," I expect to leave behind a lot of what belongs under the head of unfinished business.

Ninety-nine Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M., evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

The eyes of the world are fixed on Italy, where the first guns of the Battle of Europe have opened their drumfire. So far little can be seen beneath the smoke and dust of that twenty-five-mile front. On its third day our offensive is officially described as "progressing," while Berlin reports fighting of "increasing violence."

The New York City market is swamped with eggs. As unprecedented production continues, some trade members estimated yesterday that 50,000 cases were begging storage space. Shipments are reported held in railroad warehouses. In one instance they are said to have been held here without refrigeration since the first of the month.

LONDON, May 14 (U.P.) -- The German-controlled Vichy and Paris radios broadcast today an appeal by three French Cardinals and the Archbishop of Cambrai to the Cardinals and Archbishops of the Catholic Church in the United States and the British Empire to intervene with their Governments in an effort to spare the civilian populations of France and Europe "as much as possible" from Allied aerial bombings.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- For more than five hours this afternoon 33,366 persons, Wrigley Field's largest crowd of the season, watched the Dodgers and Cubs embroiled in an activity that the National League schedule had listed as two games of baseball, but so far as many of the bizarre happenings are concerned any resemblance to baseball was purely coincidental.

Cotton prices last week generally were slightly lower, but the volume of trading was higher than in the preceding week. At the close on Saturday, active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 3 to 11 points, with the greater recession in the new crop positions.

Felony complaints decreased 4.6 per cent in New York City last year, the annual report of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine disclosed yesterday. Decreases were shown in every category of major crime except burglary, where a sharp rise was attributed to the disturbances in Harlem on Aug. 1 and 2.
LONDON, May 14 -- King George VI has just concluded a four-day visit to the British Home Fleet and bidden his ships, his captains and his men godspeed before the battle.

Three members of a Brooklyn family lost their lives at 4:30 A.M. yesterday in a two-alarm fire that destroyed their home, a three-story frame house at 119 Nassau Avenue, at Eckford Street, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

A concert of unusual interest, consisting of an entire program of chamber music by Bedrich Smetana and most of this music little known to our public, was given yesterday afternoon in New York Times Hall under the auspices of an Masaryk, Czechslovak Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Franklin F. Hopper, director of the New York Public Library.

LONDON, May 14 (U.P.) -- Great Britain's Home Guard was warned officially and forcefully today that the Germans might attack this country simultaneously with the Allies' invasion of western Europe, and King George personally emphasized the warnings by reviewing "spare time army" men on the occasion of the fourth birthday of their corps.
Supporters of Governor Dewey have become increasingly confident of his nomination for President on the first ballot at the Republican National Convention, it was learned yesterday.
Drew L. Hines has been appointed manager of transportation and supplies, Eastern division of Tide Water Associated Oil Company, with headquarters in New York.

More than 1,000 persons -- some 500 of them unable to get inside -- attended a funeral service yesterday morning in Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, for Joseph Willon, superintendent of delivery of the New York Postoffice.

Last week's activities in the wholesale markets included many demands for Mother's Day items. Lines for immediate and fall deliveries also were wanted. Cotton dresses were in demand for National Cotton Week promotions, but new merchandise was not available, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP) -Despite the greatest material prosperity the United States has ever experienced, the nation has entered a period of business hesitation and restricted speculation, Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, declared today in his monthly report.

Senator Robert F. Wagner and Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick will head the list of speakers at the opening session of the organizing convention of the new political party now being formed by the Liberal and Labor Committee, Dean Alfange, chairman, announced yesterday.
It was a beautiful day at the Stadium yesterday, and everything came the Yankees' way.

NYACK, N.Y., May 14 (AP) -- Helen Hayes and Representative Hamilton Fish continued their political controversy today when Mr. Fish issued a statement, saying that Miss Hayes was not enrolled in the Republican party.

LONDON, May 14 -- Reinvestment of Government money released by the repayment of the 5 per cent conversion loan having ceased, and the cheering implications of the budget speech abated, business on the stock markets has become much quieter.

PITTSBURGH, May 14 -- Steel industry tempo last week was reaching new heights owing in no small measure to the shell program. According to reliable sources this program may be larger than was thought a few weeks ago. It is believed that the shell casings output in the next several months will be of such magnitude that other products may have to be cut back.

ST. LOUIS, May 14 -- Despite preoccupation with the war, the people of Missouri are beginning to turn eyes to a political battle in which Bennett Champ Clark appears certain to be warmly opposed for the seat he has held in the United States Senate for nearly twelve years.

BOSTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers swept both ends of a double-header with the Boston Red Sox today as Johnny Gorsica pitched three-hit ball in the second game for a 9-0 victory after Detroit triumphed in the opener, 6 -- 1.
LONDON, May 14 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin:

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 112.91 from the previous week's level of 112.6. This increase of 0.2 per cent brought the index close to the all-time high of 112.96, reached the week ending April 14, 1944.

The City Center Opera Company ended its spring season at the City Center last night with Puccini's "Tosca" before a capacity audience that showed its appreciation of the fine performance by generous applause throughout, and gave an ovation to Dusolina Giannini, who sang the title role, after her rendition of the "Vissi d'arte" aria in the second act.

MOSCOW, May 14 -- Soviet newspapers printed today the statement regarding the Catholic Church and the possibilities of closer relations between it and the Kremlin as given out in Chicago by Father Orlemanski, but none of the papers commented editorially.

Berkley Associates. Inc., resold the fie-story apartment house with two stores and sixteen suites on a lot 32 by 120 feet at 2708 Broadway to Ada Wagner for cash over a mortgage of $45,000 through Ralph P. Obedin Co. The property, a 103d Street, is assessed at $95,009.

NEW ORLEANS, May 14 -- "Pre-Invasion jitters" brought about last week a narrower and quieter cotton futures market on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange. Also holding many traders to the sidelines were delays in decisions by the Office of Price Administration on new price schedules for cotton textiles, which in turn caused uncer tainties in the textile field as production continued to fall further behind huge calls for military and lend-lease needs.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 14(AP) -- Jersey City and Buffalo divided their double-header before 6,733 fans today. The Little Giants garnered two runs in the seventh and final frame of the nightcap for a 5 to 4 victory, after the locals galloped off with the regulation opener, 5 to 1.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES in Southwest China, May 14 (U.P.) -- United States Army officers, stressing offense and aiming at rejuvenation of China's southwest armies, have established a general staff school patterned after the general staff school at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., for Chinese generals and field officers.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (U.P.) -The proposed merger of the Army and Navy into a single department will be shelved until fall and may not be revived until the war is no longer a factor, according to reports here tonight.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- Allied troops in Burma now are "inflicting on the Japanese a number of casualties which proportionately is rapidly nearing a higher point than any reached in any other theatre where the Japanese are engaged," is was announced today in a Southeast Asia Command statement issued through the Ministry of Information.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $10,110,907.

Representing the mothers throughout the world whose sons are fighting for freedom, four mothers were honored yesterday on the Mall in Central Park at the Salvation Army's third annual Mother's Day celebration.

HOLLYWOOD Calif., May 14 -- After his recent outstanding characterization as the elderly priest in the Bing Crosby picture, "Going My Way," Barry Fitzgerald has been signed to a five-year optional contract by Paramount. The deal calls for character roles in two pictures a year at a reported $20,000 a picture.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) -- Frankie Hayes hit a homer into the left-field stands with one on in the eighth inning of the second game of a double-header with the Browns at Shibe Park today to clinch the contest for the Athletics, 2 -- 0, before 27,795 fans.

Rejecting a petition of the National Labor Relations. Board to have a company and its president adjudged in contempt of court for writing a letter to its workers after the company had been ordered to dissolve an alleged company union, the Third Circuit Court of Appeals at Philadelphia has unanimously ruled that the constitutional guarantee of free speech protects employer and employe alike.

It takes a day or two of time in a busy season of year, but there's something about mending pasture fences that appeals to a man. The foundation of a pasture fence here in the Northeast is often a stone wall. Built generations ago, the weather-grayed, lichenetched stones are heaved by frost and undermined by spring rains.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 14 (AP) -- The Syracuse Chiefs stretched their winning streak to four straight and ran Newark's losing string to seven in a row by sweeping a double-header from the Bears today, 4 to 2 and 3 to 1.

The setting up of free ports in the United Nations for refugees of all faiths from Nazi-dominated countries was urged in a resolution adopted yesterday afternoon at the fifth annual convention of the Brooklyn Jewish Community Council at the Brooklyn Jewish Center, 667 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

Many a news dispatch telling of the current political troubles of Argentina has a Montevideo dateline, as readers may have noted. The fact bears witness that the democratic spirit of little Uruguay is still dynamic and determined. The Uruguayans have had their share of the woes of the time.

The Newbery Award, for the year's best children's book, has been given to Esther Forbes for her story of colonial Boston, "Johnny Tremain." The award, which is twenty-three years old this spring, was first presented to the late Hendrik Willem van Loon for "The Story of Mankind."

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 14 -- Business should be divorced from Federal Government control as soon as possible after the war is won, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and James F. Lincoln, president of the Lincoln Electric Company of Cleveland, told a Toledo audience today.

NAPLES, May 14 -- The Allies' troops have blasted a wedge five miles wide and a mile deep in the Gustav Line above the Rapido River and tonight French forces reported that they had cut the Cassino-Formia road, a vital lateral highway connecting German bases on two main roads to Rome.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- The Government program designed to ob tain cash corn for essential industries has been in operation for about three weeks and has met with striking success. Farmers have pledged more than 46,000,000 bushels of corn so far, and it is reported officially that the order that froze farmers' grain in 125 counties in five Central Western States may be lifted in a few days.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 14 -- A German military spokesman in a series of grim forecasts tonight about the "colossal" invasion blows the Allies were planning from Britain declared that "British and American parachutists may try to land on the soil of Germany itself."

SHORTLY after he assumed his fourteenth post and his fourth diplomatic mission, Ambassador Joseph Clark Grew wrote in his diary in Tokyo in 1932: "This is a terrible life." He was referring particularly to all the speeches he had to make; but he also had in mind the sixty-four diplomatic calls he could not avoid, all the formal entertaining for which he was responsible and the ridiculous ritual of dress, "that all-important element of diplomacy."

PROCESSED FOODS (vegetables, soups, fruits and fruit juices, dried beans, jam, jelly, canned and bottled baby foods and certain other special products). Only blue stamps and blue tokens can be used in buying processed foods. Blue stamps A8 through Q8 in War Book 4 are good indefinitely, at 10 points each. Five additional blue stamps become valid the first of each month. Frozen fruits and vegetables and dried foods are now point-free.
FOLKESTONE, England, May 14 (AP) -- Bald, merry-eyed Charlie Uden drew off another row of beers Saturday and chuckled at the way his ancient pub, the British Lion, was shaking.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- About half the combat fliers who crack under strain are being restored so fully that they can return to duty.

LONDON, May 14 -- Unfavorable flying conditions gave the Germans a respite last night and most of today from the furious, sustained Allied air assault of the past month that has left Hitler's continental fortress smoldering from the Balkans to the Baltic.

Price Control Week will be marked throughout the city beginning on Wednesday at rallies and street meetings under the sponsorship of the sixty-eight groups that make up the New York City Consumer Council.
Will you please allow me to say few words in reply to your editorial of May 9 entitled "French Realities"?

PERHAPS it was only a coincidence. The letter arrived just a day or two before Lieut. Col. William J. Bingham of Harvard, the chairman of the Football Rules Committee, flatly stated that the gridiron code would remain unaltered this year and, quoting the Associated Press story, "if the college football rules are changed this year, they'll have to change the chairman of the rules committee first."
Flashing an effective passing attack in the second half, the Brooklyn Hispanos conquered the Morgan Strasser eleven in the National Challenge Cup soccer final at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Broadway will see only one film opening this week. This will be "Cobra Woman," a Universal adventure story starring Jon Hall, Maria Montez and Sabu, which will arrive at Loew's Criterion on Wednesday. The technicolor picture, which has a mythical South Seas locale, includes Lon Chaney Jr., Lois Collier, Edgar Barrier, Mary Nash and Samuel S. Hinds among its supporting players.

At the week-end, vigorous attack by Allies occurred on the Italian front. Both violence of the movement and predictions of victory by Allied commanders gave the impression that the general invasion of the Continent had begun. Nevertheless, the stock market hardly stirred.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 14 -- In the first prize racing of the season, eleven International Class sloops competed today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and Arthur Davis, last year's class champion, sailed Patricia to a fifteen-second victory over Albert Marx's Alberta after ten miles of about as perfect going as any skipper could ask for.

Out of each dollar spent by the city for education, 85.2 cents goes to cover the cost of instruction, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast. He cited as his authority the report of Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, covering the school year 1942-43 and supplemented with figures bringing the financial data down to last March.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, May 15 (AP) -- A communique:

CASTELFORTE, Italy, May 14 -- This was a town of 8,000 inhabitants. In its cracked and tower-less town hall is a marble plaque inscribed: "Per le future generazioni [for future generations]." It was erected in memory of the heroic Castelfortesi who defended their liberty at Eastertide, 1799.

PEARL HARBOR, May 14 (U.P.) -- Seventh Army Air Force Mitchell bombers attacked Nauru Island, southwest of the American-held Gilberts, Friday morning, hitting the island's rich phosphate works, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz reported today.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 14 (AP) -- With Miss Jacqueline Sehling scoring half of her team's goals, Philadelphia today trounced Boston, 8 to 3, to capture the National Women's lacrosse title for the eleventh time in twelve years.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Santa Maria Infante, May 14 (AP) -- American artillery tore this bloody stumbling-block on a hill apart, piece by piece, and then American infantry and tanks moved in for a showdown with the Germans after two miles of murderous and desperate battling up the important road across the lower Ausenti Valley.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Naples, May 14 (U.P.) -- The Silver Star, third highest decoration for gallantry, has been awarded to Tech. Sgt. Charles E. (Commando) Kelly for a hitherto unrevealed feat of heroism during seventy days of action from Salerno to Cassino.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Experiments are being made at Walter Reed Hospital to find whether a patient will get well faster if a band plays his favorite tune or a soprano sings his favorite hymn.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- Mobilization of the 14,000,000 members of organized labor for the election this year of a President and Congress who will continue the policies of the Roosevelt Administration is urged in the report of the general executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, which is to be presented to the national convention when it opens here tomorrow.

LONDON, May 14 -- Firm application of the mechanics of economic warfare, developed to high degree in the present conflict, may forestall another war, if it is made an integral part of a nation's foreign policy, the British believe today. For that reason the Foreign Office, traditional stronghold of formal diplomacy, is adopting new methods to gain lasting results in the post-war world.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 14 -- A 30-foot chip for a birdie on the 18th green by Alexander Antonio of the Sunnyfield Golf Club, Linden, gave him and his pro partner, Frank Kringle, a 2-up victory in the final of the ninth annual New Jersey pro-amateur best-ball match-play tournament at the Glen Ridge Country Club today.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 14 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's forces have smashed to within eleven miles of the Japanese northern Burma base of Kamaing, while on the Indian frontier Allied troops have nearly captured Porsangbam, village outpost of Bishenpur on the road to Tiddim, Allied Headquarters announced today.

Declaring he had received 1,800 letters urging him to keep on with his weekly Sunday broadcasts from WNYC, the municipal radio station, as against only fourteen recommending their discontinuance, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday he planned to proceed "for some time" with the talks he started Dec. 7, 1941.

Twenty-one national organizations, representing 5,000,000 members, have endorsed a campaign to work for immediate formation of a United Nations Council, the Women's Action Committee for Victory and Lasting Peace announced yesterday. Thursday, May 18, has been designated "United Nations Council Day" to mark the opening of a nation-wide drive to mobilize public opinion in support of the idea.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (U.P.) -- Twelve State conventions will be held and primary elections in California, Montana, Oregon and New Jersey will take place this week, with a prospect that Governor Dewey of New York will obtain a sufficient number of delegates to assure of the Republican Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON. May 14 -- The Office of Price Administration outlined today conditions under which manufacturers of certain articles of men's and boys' underwear may apply for individual price adjustments on ceilings which can be demonstrated to be out of line with those of competitors or result in a loss for the producer.

Continental Can Company, Inc., has acquired the Reynolds Molded Plmtics division, Cambridge, Ohio, of the Reynolds Spring Company, it is announced by Carle C. Company, chairman of the board and president of Continental. The division is the third largest custom plastics molding concern in the United States and provides the company with complete facilities for the production of all forms of molded plastics, Mr. Conway said.

CHUNGKING, China, Monday, May 15 -- Chinese troops have opened a powerful counter-drive along the Peiping-Hankow railway and have captured the city of Suiping after routing enemy forces west of the railroad, a Chinese communique announced early today. At Loyang, on the Lung-Hai railway, the Japanese broke through to the city wall from the west, northwest and east, but the Chinese are fighting strongly, it was announced.

Post-war cellophane packages for fresh meats, coffee, sugar and a variety of other foods, developed by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., are now being shown at a private exhibit in the New York City offices of the company. R.M. MacDonald, in charge of the collection, explained the idea behind the designs, most of which are entirely different from anything on grocery shelves at present.

A two-story taxpayer on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 35 to 43 West 125th Street was sold by Dexter Associates, Inc., Sidney Levine, president, to Mayfair Equities, Inc., a client of Sehack Schack, for cash over a first mortgage of $87,525, due in October, 1952, and held by the Greenwich Savings Bank.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- The governing body of the International Labor Organization created today a tripartite committee of eighteen to wage a world-wide fight against unemployment in concert with other agencies that have been or are to be set up by the United Nations.

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisans have smashed through an enemy ring in Macedonia, inflicting heavy casualties on the Germans, and in Slovenia have defeated a strong group of several thousand Nazi officers and men, Marshal Tito declared today.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 14 (UP) -- A communique:

LONDON, May 14 -- Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Polish Prime Minister, said in an exclusive interview today that he was not worried over Russia's reported plans to create a rival regime on Polish soil. Any such scheme would be frustrated, he said, by the strength and loyalty of his underground political and military organization, which embraces the entire country.

Taylor Holmes is the new lead in "A Strange Play," Joseph Macaulay having bowed out. The change was made because Mr. Macaulay is retaining his role for the subway circuit tour of "Early to Bed," the musical which ended a long Broadway run on Saturday night.

The hope of lasting peace in the world after the war depends upon the cooperation of the United States, Great Britain and Russia, in fellowship with China and all peace-loving countries, Bishop William T. Manning asserted last night in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass, May 14 -- The Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski has decided to accept his instructions from Bishop Thomas O'Leary to leave his parish for an indefinite period and retire to a monastery, according to an announcement made today by the Rev. George A. Shea, Chancellor of the Springfield Diocese.
NAPLES, May 14 -- United States Fifteenth Air Force heavy bombers attacked many points along the main railways in the Po Valley today.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- Weakness in the prices for rye and wheat had some effect last week on oats and barley on the Board of Trade, and despite prospects that the acreage for oats will be 10 per cent or more short of the March 1 forecast, prices for that grain ranged lower, with December oats selling at a new seasonal low.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Office of Price Administration, in renewing fuel-oil rations for next winter, will allow consumers generally about the same gallonage they received last year.
Landing craft and the specialized amphibious tactics built around then will play major roles in the invasion of western Europe.

CINCINNATI, May 14 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds exchanged whitewash jobs today in a double-header with the Boston Braves, winning the opener, 4 to 0, behind near-perfect pitching by Buck Walters, who gave but one hit, and losing the nightcap, 6 to 0.
Impressive ceremonies that followed a parade of 45,000 persons marked the annual celebration yesterday of the Diocesan Union of the Holy Name Society of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (U.P.) -- Stanton Griffis special representative in Sweden of the Foreign Economic Administration, has been vested with authority to purchase all ball bearings produced by the giant Swedish SKF works in a move to cut off shipments to Germany, it was disclosed tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 14 -- A Swedish sailor who returned after working in German-organized convoys said today that the British Navy now has a new type of mine that "can be dropped without a parachute from any height to any depth in the sea."

"These are difficult times when we have to do without the things our parents never had." Thus, with considerable truth, remarks a philosopher of the hour. Many of the things the war obliges us to do without were scarce, if not unknown, in the days of our parents, or, at least, of our grandparents.

Ballet Theatre last night presented Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin in "Giselle" for what will probably be the last time for several seasons, since these artists will leave the company at the close of the present season to dance on Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (U.P.) -- The Congress of Women's Auxiliaries of the CIO urged tonight a Justice Department investigation of four women's organizations for alleged collaboration with Fascists and for distributing literature asserting that President Roosevelt was of "Jewish ancestry."

As the decisive battle of Europe gets under way with the thundering assaults of the Allied air armadas and the all-out offensive in Italy, the European Advisory Commission created by the Moscow Conference is completing the draft of the Allied victory terms which provide a grim background to a struggle that has still to reach its climax.

WASHINGTON May 14 (AP) -- The White Sox came from behind in the ninth inning today to win the nightcap of a double-header from Washington, 6 to 4, after dropping the first game to the Senators by 4 to 0.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 14 -That Brazil is ready to place orders in the United States for an amount near $100,000,000 to buy machinery and tools has been divulged here officially. The greatest percentage amount is for textile machinery, looms, etc., but Brazil also needs a large amount of machinery for manufacture of small hardware, other steel products and tools in varied amounts.

Communists will support President Roosevelt for re-election "as the surest way to bring together all forces for winning the war," Israel Amter, State chairman, declared yesterday at the State convention of the Communist party at Manhattan Center. A thousand regular and fraternal delegates attended.

New York City had 660,899 registrants between the ages of 18 and 38 serving in the armed forces on May 1, Col. Arthur V. McDermott, New York City director of Selective Service, disclosed yesterday. This is in addition to an undetermined number, estimated at 40,000, who were already in the National Guard, the Army and the Navy before registration began on Oct. 16, 1940.
Unless the world organizes as a cooperative community, there is little hope for it in the future, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in his sermon at Riverside Church.

ST. LOUIS, May 14 (AP) -- The champion Cardinals stretched their National League lead to three and one-half games today -- their longest margin of the season -- as they defeated the second-place Phillies twice, 6 to 3 and 1 to 0.

Pergolesi's "La Serva Padrona" and Wolf-Ferrari's "The Secret of Suzanne" formed the double bill presented by the New Opera Company last night at the Alvin Theatre. Both operas, given in English, were produced by Felix Brentano, who was responsible for the many novel details and alterations figuring in their performance.

The great aerial offensive against Fortress Europe now under way means different things to different military specialists, depending on their specialty. For airmen the effort represents strategic action pure and simple, aiming to disarm Germany by destroying her means to wage war.

A vacant plot, 100 by 100 feet, at the southeast corner of Jerome Avenue and 171st Street, in the Bronx, has been sold by Vincent Astor to Matthew Forelli, owner of the adjoining property. It is assessed at $32,500 and was sold for cash through John J. Reynolds, broker.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, May 15 (U.P.) -- The blazing rocket guns of American fighter planes and dive-bombers destroyed forty enemy barges at the isolated and neutralized Japanese base at Rabaul, New Britain, last Friday in one of the most damaging attacks against enemy light shipping in two months, it was announced today.

LONDON, Monday, May 15 -- Fleets of long-range Russian bombers, striking along a 600-mile front, raided key German rail depots in Poland, Estonia and White Russia Saturday night, while Red Army forces yesterday threw back fresh German attacks against the Soviet bridgehead on the west bank of the lower Dniester River, Moscow announced early today.

PITTSBURGH, May 14 -- With Frank Frisch, the graying Arctic explorer and petunia grower of New Rochelle, still boiling in a rage over the humiliating defeat his Pirates had suffered at the hands of the Braves yesterday, the Giants made a rather untimely entry in the lair of the Corsairs today and soon paid dearly for the oversight.

LONDON, May 14 -- King Peter of Yugoslavia, who has been working quietly for several weeks to recast his country's provisional government, will hold a general conference of Yugoslav politicians tomorrow morning at his official residence.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, declared yesterday in his sermon that there was "every indication" that the demobilization of ten or eleven million of the armed forces would give added impetus to the work of the church.

Richard W. Lawrence, former president of the Chamber of Commerce, State of New York,' discussed post-war industrial problems and current campaigns to publicize the desirability of New York Oity as a' place to do business.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Nearly 2,000 persons, including Cabinet members, members of Congress, high Army and Navy officials and leaders in industry and labor, filled the National Theatre tonight for the Washington premiere of "The Forgotten Factor," a drama which the Moral Rearmament Group presented to portray national teamwork.

The other day THE TIMES reported a speech by P.J. Clarey in which he asserted that Australia under certain conditions could support from 150,000,000 to 200,000,000 persons. This was to students of Australian affairs a startling echo from the distant past, or the period before Prof. Griffith Taylor began his systematic, critical reassessment of Australian resources and population specialists got their ideas of the continent's probable optimum population in line with reality.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (U.P.) -- The bill of rights committee of the American Bar Association voiced its opposition tonight to a measure now before the House Judiciary Committee which proposes to circumvent a Supreme Court ruling, calling for prompt arraignment of persons arrested in Federal criminal prosecutions.
Mrs. Francis L.V. Hoppin will return from Palm Beach this week and will be at Mayfair House until she goes to Newport for the summer.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Comdr. Edward H. (Butch) O'Hare, who is missing in action, was revealed tonight to have received an award, the third of his flying career.

The New York Foundation, 61 Broadway, has agreed to underwrite $150,000 of the $250,000 required to start Mayor La Guardia's plan for health and medical insurance for all persons living or working in New York City and earning up to $5,000 a year, the Mayor announced yesterday in his weekly radio talk, broadcast from his home at Gracie Mansion.

DETROIT, May 14 (AP) -- While foremen of the Ford Motor Company approved today with praise their new contract with the concern covering about 9,000 men, representatives of 3,300 striking foremen in other plants showed no willingness to give ground in their prolonged dispute.

RYE, N.Y., May 14 -- Ensign Robert W. Craig of Old Westbury, L.I., did not have the satisfaction this afternoon of seeing his fox terrier, Champion Full Measure of Wissaboo, gain the highest award in the seventy-fourth specialty show of the American Fox Terrier Club on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, May 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- One of the biggest gripes of the average combat soldier in Italy is the growing total of strict regulations he runs into as soon as he crawls out of his front-line foxhole and heads to the rear for a shave and bath and a little fun, if possible.

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- American Wacs paraded in London today in observance of the second anniversary of their organization and received a tribute from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who cabled Col. Oveta Culp Hobby, Wac leader, that he and his men were proud of the women in khaki and urged: "Keep up the good work."

The Pipes of Pan are heard these earth-stirring days on country roads and rural lanes. A boy and his dog going for the cows are accompanied by a series of shrilly plaintive blasts, for the month of May is willow-whistle season.

Two persons were killed and six persons were injured at the height of the home-bound rush of motorists from Long Island last night when an eastbound automobile, swerving from the roadway in which it had been traveling, was involved in a collision with two other private cars and a bus of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.

MARSHAL TITO'S HEADQUARTERS in the Yugoslav Mountains, May 10 (Delayed) -- High up in the Yugoslav mountains, less than twenty miles from where the Partisans are putting up a magnificent fight against the Germans, Marshal Tito has the most impregnable headquarters of any commanding general in the world.

WITH STILWELL'S ARMY, In North Burma, May 13 (Delayed) -- The Japanese here are fighting with their backs to the wall. They are waging a dogged delaying action in the desperate hope that the monsoon will save them.

The report for 1943 of the United States Lines Company, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net profit of $1,518,882 after charges and taxes. Of the total profit, $438,865 was transferred to capital surplus, this being the amount attributable to the five months of the year preceding the merger.

Disallowances on advertising expense in income tax returns of large corporations are infrequent, individual reviewers of the Internal Revenue Department report. Very few instances of disallowance were noted by reviewers in this district in the returns for 1941 and 1942, recently completed.

NAPLES, May 15 (U.P.) -- British heavy and medium bombers last night smashed two vital rail points northwest of Venice on lines leading to Germany in the climax to American daylight attacks by 750 heavy bombers that included Venice and rail targets in the Po Valley.
Women war workers are thinking seriously about post-war layoffs and unemployment, according to a report, based on interviews with 250 working women, issued yesterday by the State Department of Labor.

Plans for a Manhattan crosstown express highway have been submitted to the post-war committee of the Board of Estimate and the Borough Advisory Planning Board, Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Manhattan Borough President announced yesterday.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 16 -- Unhampered by the German air force, formations of American heavy and medium bombers blasted Hitler's sprawling coastal defense system yesterday, carrying the invasion air offensive from Britain into the twenty-ninth consecutive day.

LONDON, May 15 -- Twin sweeps by the Luftwaffe over the south and southeast coats of Britain last night, during which fifteen German planes were shot down, now appear to have been for the purpose of reconnaissance rather than attack. And it is thought here that such reconnaissance sweeps may become more and more frequent as D-Day draws nearer.

Public offering will be made today of $9,150,000 of debentures of Edmonton, Alberta, by a banking group headed by the First Boston Corporation and the Dominion Securities Corporation. The issue of the provincial capital will mature on May 15, 1948 to 1964.

Budgetary cuts in City College's 1944-45 appropriation have caused the curtailment of its summer session from the twelve weeks required by the school's accelerated program to eight weeks, with $20,000 still lacking for even a full eight-week program, it was learned yesterday.

Smart fashions in decorative draperies occupied the housewife's mind in colonial days as well as today, a newly installed four-poster bed and curtained windows at the Brooklyn Museum attest. Museum experts say that the rusty red printed chintz is almost 200 years old and the green-painted four-poster-is even older.

A Rockefeller Foundation grant of $100,000 to be used for the purchase of books of permanent value for future shipment to libraries in war areas has been made to the American Library Association, it has been announced by Carl H. Milan, executive secretary of the association.

UNITED STATES HEADQUARTERS ON THE SALWEEN FRONT, May 5 (Delayed) -- After two years Chinese armies were going back down the Burma Road to push the Japanese out of the Salween country. For more than a year Americans of an operations staff have been helping them get ready.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration announced today specific dollars-and-cents wholesale and retail prices for new standard radio replacement tubes for civilian radios and phonographs.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 -- All Federal criminal charges pending against Charles Chaplin were dismissed today while the State Supreme Court at the same time cleared the way for Joan Berry's paternity suit against the film comedian.
CINCINNATI, May 15 (AP) -- Clyde Shoun spun the no-hit bottle today as the Reds downed the Braves, 1 to 0.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 15 (AP) -- Thumping five Jersey City pitchers for sixteen hits, including a home run and two triples by Otis Davis, the Rochester Red Wings romped to a 20-10 decision over the Junior Giants in the opener of a three-game series today.
AT THE EIGHTH EVACUATION HOSPITAL, Fifth Army Front, Italy, May 15 (AP) -- This is the shock ward of an emergency hospital where blood plasma is stacked like cordwood.

LONDON, May 15 -- The Socialist members of the Polish National Council vigorously pursued today their campaign to wrest control of the Polish forces from the right-wing military group and place it in the hands of the civilian government.

"Attack!" subtitled "The Battle of New Britain," a feature-length documentary picture about that campaign in the South Pacific filmed for the War Department by the Signal Corps in collaboration with the Air Forces, has been tentatively scheduled for general theatrical release next month, simultaneous with the Fifth War Loan Drive.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 -- Two Australian war brides eager to join their American Army Air Corps husbands stowed away on a ship bound for this country, were discovered by ship's officers during the voyage and are held here by immigration authorities to face a charge of false entry, it was disclosed today.

The report of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation for the twelve months ended on March 31, filed yesterday in Federal District Court by the trustees in reorganization of the company, showed a balance of consolidated income, after operating expenses and taxes, of $10,243,158.

Reflecting heavy buying for Mother's Day, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 30 per cent over 1943, the Federal Reserve Bank announced yesterday. Comparison, however, was with the week after Mother's Day, as that day last year came on May 9.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 15 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's main forces, striking for the Japanese base of Kamaing in northern Burma, were reported less than ten miles north of that premonsoon objective tonight after Chinese troops, advancing down the Mogaung Valley, joined up with other Allied units.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP) -- Frankie Hayes smashed his second homer in as many days and led the Athletics to a 6-2 victory over the Tigers at Shibe Park today before 5,921 fans.

UNITED STATES HEADQUARTERS ON THE SALWEEN FRONT, May 8 (Delayed) -- Not many G.I.'s have rolled into this Chinese town deep in the Burma Road country. But already the impact of their presence has made an impression.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, On the Lower Garigliano, May 15 -- In Santa Maria Infante yesterday an American infantryman lay dead where he had fallen. He was on his stomach, feet spread and eyes looking dead ahead over the sights of the shattered rifle still in his hands.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Rejections by selective service on the grounds of psychosomatic disease, i.e., originating in a combination of mental and physical factors, have doubled since Pearl Harbor, it was reported today at the opening sessions of the centennial anniversary meeting of the American Psychiatric Association by Col. Leonard G. Rowntree, chief of the medical division of the selective service system.

Most of the fun of camping out will be available for 3,000 city girls between 7 and 18 at seven day-camps to be operated by the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York in city parks beginning July 3. For the third year girls, both Scouts and non-Scouts, will learn to cook in the open, do handicrafts, and take nature hikes under supervision of trained counselors.

NORWICH, Conn., May 15 (AP) -- No criminal negligence was involved in the deaths of five infants at Lawrence and Memorial Hospital, New London, from boric acid mistakenly administered as dextrose, Coroner Edward G. McKay reported today.
