SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 15 -- The Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski was disclosed tonight to have been confined to his bed in the Rectory of the Church of Our Lady of the Rosary, suffering what his physician termed a "nervously upset" condition.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Artemus L. Gates, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, injected today into Congressional studies of possible consolidation of all armed forces of this country the suggestion that, if such a merger should be effected, the Navy was the service to absorb the others, including the Army ground and air forces.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- Prices on good and choice 180 to 200 pound hogs advanced 50 cents to $1.00 today, the first day of their inclusion in the price support program. Other weights remained steady with Friday's close, topping at $13.75. Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

Ephraim Tutt, stovepipe-hatted "Yankee Lawyer" of fiction fame, was labeled as a "fraud" yesterday in a suit filed in Supreme Court by Lewis R. Linet, an "out-of-town lawyer," who seeks a rebate from Arthur Train, author and creator of Mr. Tutt, on the ground that while Train actually wrote "Yankee Lawyer: The Autobiography of Ephraim Tutt," the natural inference is that it is the work of Mr. Tutt.

BALTIMORE, May 15 (AP) -- An estimate that the stockholders attempting to oust the management of Certain-teed Products Corporation held a 90,000-vote majority over the company's officers as of April 12 was made today at the opening of a hearing on a court move to force an election.

PRESTER JOHN, that legendary Oriental Christian king, was one of the great dreams of the Middle Ages. Somewhere beyond all those fierce paynim hosts who shouted their faith in Allah and his prophet while threatening Europe from Hungary to Navarre, lay his mighty kingdom. There was no king on earth like Prester John. "His robes were washed in fire and woven by the salamander.

The decision to close "A Highland Fling" at the Plymouth this coming Saturday night was confirmed yesterday by the George Abbott office. The Scottish fantasy by Margaret Curtis, in which Ralph Forbes and the author enact the leading roles, will have been performed twenty-seven times.

CLEVELAND, May 15 -- An estimated 1,200 members of Gerald L.K. Smith's America First party, gathered in Music Hall here tonight voted unanimously and uproariously to give Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York one more chance to get in line with their "nationalist" movement before being stricken from their list of possibilities to unseat Franklin D. Roosevelt from the Presidential chair in the fall election.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 16 (U.P.) -- Soviet long-range bombers, in their fourth successive night attack on German troop and supply concentrations, bombed four Polish rail centers and a similar target in Latvia Sunday night, while Red Army ground forces yesterday killed approximately 1,000 German troops in destroying an enemy bridgehead on the east bank of the lower Dniester River, Moscow announced early today.

On May 11 you ran an article, "Mail to Prisoners of War Sent Free," quoting a statement by Postmaster Goldman that "One package of books weighing not more than five pounds and measuring not more than eighteen inches in length and forty-two inches in girth and length combined will be forwarded every thirty days."

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP) -- Clarence U. Carruth Jr., of New York, representing holders of Midland Utilities Company's 6 and 7 per cent prior lien preferred stock, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that the Midland United-Midland Utilities joint plan of reorganization is "not a true compromise, but more in the nature of a conspiracy."

Ferried on American-made rubber rafts, a Chinese army swarming across the Salween River has struck into northern Burma on a 100-mile front. This major movement is evidently aimed at a junction with General Stilwell's forces.

Rodney E. Boone has sold his residence of eleven rooms and five baths at 191 Elderfield Road, Manhasset, L.I., reports Previews, Inc., to Ralph Pulitzer. It is on a one-acre plot. David Wile acted as broker.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., May 15 -- Mrs. Austen Fox Riggs of Stockbridge was re-elected president of the Austen Riggs Foundation, Inc., on Saturday at the twenty-fifth annual meeting here of the organization. The foundation is a philanthropic institution for the treatment of psychoneurotic patients and was founded by Mrs. Riggs' husband, the late Dr. Riggs, a psychiatrist.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- With a dozen Dodgers stepping to the plate in the sixth inning, eight of them hitting safely and seven scoring, Lippy Leo Durocher's angry athletes partially erased the memory of yesterday's second-game debacle by trouncing Cholly Grimm's Cubs, 14 to 3, today for their seventeenth setback in twenty games.
LONDON, May 15 -- The first and final official communique on the British Dominion Prime Ministers' conference will be issued tomorrow.

Describing the Office of Price Administration's action giving price relief to manufacturers of men's and boys' heavy underwear as incompatible with the profit system because no business can continue to operate by meeting costs, Roy A. Cheney, president of the Underwear Institute, voiced the hope yesterday that a "practicable" solution will be worked out in the next two weeks to give more substantial relief to those mills now losing money.

Late covering in May futures and prospects of Spain accepting offers today for about 80,000 bales, gave the cotton market a steady tone yesterday and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 7 points higher to 1 point lower than Saturday's close.

UNITED STATES HEADQUARTERS ON THE SALWEEN FRONT, May 6 (Delayed) -- In the morning it was raining hard at Tali, on the Burma Road, where armies are moving. Our topless jeep was filled with water, and after tying a shelter half over our heads we started the second lap of the journey to United States field headquarters near the front.
TORONTO, May 15 (Canadian Press) -- A rally by the Toronto Maple Leafs in the last half of the eleventh inning fell short tonight and the Newark Bears took the first of a three-game series, 4 -- 3.
LONDON, May 15 -- Stimulated by war news from Italy, the stock markets here opened the week today on a cheerful note. Industrials were the brightest section in a generally firm session.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Supreme Court today ordered reargument next fall of the anti-monopoly suit against the Hartford Empire Company and the Glass Container Association of America, but, by a five-to-four division, took drastic action against the Hartford Empire Company in two cases involving patent frauds.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Legislation to authorize Federal Reserve Banks to guarantee upward of $500,000,000 in loans by private financial institutions to business for reconversion to civilian production was introduced today in the House and Senate.

WITH THE CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, on the Salween Front, May 13 (Delayed) -- More than 20,000 Chinese troops crossed the Salween River on a 100-mile front the night of Wednesday-Thursday in the first stage of a campaign to drive the Japanese from north Burma and eventually open land communications with India.

A 134-acre farm with twelve-room dwelling on the Holmdel-Bradevelt Road, in Holmdel, N.J., has been purchased by William R. Jones of Scotch Plains from Lawrence A. Holtgren. It formerly was known as the Dan Taylor farm and is on both sides of the road, west of Route 34 and adjoining the farm of Joseph Parr.

BOSTON, May 15 -- Under a well-judged stretch ride by veteran Willie Duffy, H.H. Miller's Incoming scored a neck triumph today in the $2,500 Inaugural Handicap as 21,700 thronged Suffolk Downs for the opening of the track's sixty-day race meeting.

A new gallery under the direction of Patrick O'Connor, portrait painter and sculptor, will open this afternoon with a preview party at 35 Jane Street. The gallery plans a price range from $50 to $250 for work which may be purchased outright, on the installment plan or rented.

The Silver jubilee of three Christian brothers, members of the Institute of the Brothers of Christian Schools, was marked yesterday at Manhattan College by a luncheon in the college dining room following a pontifical mass of thanksgiving at 10 A.M. in the college chapel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 15 -- Warner Brothers will remake the Oscar Hammerstein-Jerome Kern musical, "Sweet Adeline," which the company filmed in 1935 with Irene Dunne and Donald Woods co-starred. In the new version, to be produced by Alex Gottlieb, Patrice Munsel, the 18-year-old Metropolitan Opera soprano recently signed to a term contract, will have the feminine singing lead.

Latin America already has acquired $2,500,000,000 in dollar balances as a result of the war and the consequent demand for her products, and thus should be able to finance a large part of her proposed post-war industrialization without calling on foreign capital, W.W. Cumberland, partner of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Wellington Co., said yesterday.
ALGIERS, May 15 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle said today that the Darlan-Clark agreements, on which the Allies' military authority in North Africa rests, were not binding, in the eyes of France.

Robert Shaw and his excellently trained chorus, the Collegiate Chorale, held forth last night in Town Hall in a program of special interest. It traversed Brahms, Hindemith and Lukas Foss, in, it is true, a rather queer combination of material. Thus the Six Chansons of Paul Hindemith.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by tire Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Representative O'Brien, Republican of New York, lauded he record of Frank Gannett, publisher of New York State, in the House today, asserting that "he cannot in any way be termed a Fascist."

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Another extension of the civilian production program which aims at providing consumers with 2,000,000 electric irons by the end of the year was announced by the War Production Board today, when it disclosed production quotas for another 376,768 irons had been assigned to eight new companies.

Frederick Heizer Wright, 41-year-old copy editor for The New York Daily News, was acquitted yesterday of having acted as an unregistered agent of the Japanese Government. The verdict, which Judge John Bright said was justified, was returned at 8:10 P.M. The jury had received the case at 3:22 P.M.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 15 (UP) -- A communique:

NAPLES, May 15 -- French troops of the Fifth Army have cored a triumph that ranks with the heroic stand at Bir Hacheim, it was disclosed today as the Allies continued to score steady gains in their offensive against the Gustav Line.

An ordinary card headed by a Class D handicap failed to keep the players away from Belmont Park yesterday. Nor did it deter them from wagering with the briskness that has become customary at local racing enclosures this season.

With emphasis again placed on timely deliveries, fall buying of women's apparel got under way here yesterday. Many buyers, representing stores all over the country, arrived, with the number expected to increase steadily until early in June.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan of the Electric Power and Light Company to acquire any or all of the 65,167 shares of publicly-held $6 first preferred stock of the Mississippi Power and Light Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 15 -- First prize in today's one-day pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. at the Westchester Hills Golf Club was taken by the team of Jack Sabol, pro at the home club, and C.W. Benedict of Mount Kisco, who carded a best-ball score of 32, 31 -- 63, seven under par.

Every humane person must deplore bombing from the air just as every humane person deplores war itself. To that extent we must all sympathize with the appeal of four eminent members of the French clergy that "the civilian populations of France and Europe be spared as much as possible," and that care also be taken to avoid hitting churches, schools, hospitals and "humble dwellings in neighborhoods sheltering women and children."

Three acreage properties with dwellings in the North Stamford, Conn., area have been sold through the Samuel H. Silberman brokerage agency. The largest of the transactions was the fifteen-acre farm with a seven-room residence on Cascade Road, sold to a client for Marion B. Hill, with David L. Davis cooperating.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate rejected today a closure petition which would have limited further debate on the anti-poll tax bill to a maximum of ninety-six hours. (Two-thirds approval was needed to carry the petition.)

In yesterday's TIMES a dispatch from Folkestone in Kent referred to an inn there, the British Lion, said to have been opened for business in 1460. In it, we are told, Dickens wrote "Our Mutual Friend." This, if a fact, we have been unable to verify from any life of Dickens, but it is good enough to be true.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 15 -- Royal Air Force craft based in the Middle East roamed throughout the southern Eagean Sea from dawn to dusk yesterday in search of enemy vessels that are still being smuggled through the island-dotted waters to supply hard pressed German garrisons.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (U.P.) -- The defending champion New York University team heads a list of more than thirty colleges and 403 athletes competing in the sixty-eighth annual IC-4A track and field championships at Franklin Field Saturday.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 15 (U.P.) -- Oklahoma Democrats, after hearing a prediction that President Roosevelt would accept a fourth-term nomination "when he weighs the national security against his personal feelings," instructed tonight the State's delegation of twenty-two to the national convention to support the fourth-term drive.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Because her mail has convinced her that a great many women in different parts of the country do not know they are entitled to the maternity care given free to the wives of men in the four lowest grades in the armed services, Mrs. Roosevelt today held a special press conference on that subject.

Three large garage properties in Brooklyn were sold through the Brevoort Management Company as brokers. One transaction involved the former Borden garages at 242-52 Herkimer Street, a plot 255 by 200 feet, sold to the Bilt Well Steel Products for use as a steel fabricating plant.

Leonard Bernstein's "Jeremiah" Symphony No. 1 was voted the outstanding orchestral work by an American composer introduced in New York concert halls during the season just ended, by the Music Critics Circle of New York, at a meeting yesterday afternoon.

Notwithstanding the publicity regarding the regular Wednesday collections of waste paper by Department of Sanitation trucks, many residents in widely scattered sections of the city -- especially where large numbers of foreign-born families are grouped -- were found last week to know nothing about the weekly salvage and its wartime importance.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- John J. McCloy, Assistant Secretary of War, disclosed today that France, as well as other "friendly" nations, would receive less strict military governorship than Italy when the Allied armies marched in. Also, he put out a cautious hint that to Frenchmen, possibly through General de Gaulle's National Liberation Committee, there may be accorded much latitude in the way of self-rule.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 15 -- Convinced that air attacks will become more and more frequent as the Allied plan for invasion matures, the authorities in France are enforcing existing regulations to the letter and issuing new ones when required.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Senate, by a vote of 36 to 44, refused today to invoke closure to forestall a threatened "months- long" filibuster to prevent enactment of the Marcantonio bill which would repeal poll taxes in Federal elections.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (U.P.) -- Hillis Layne's single to left in the eleventh inning scoring Mike Guerra gave the Senators a 4-3 victory over the Indians tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court upheld three State taxes in decisions on disputed levies today and in a fourth opinion sustained the Supreme Court of another State in finding that out-of-State firms were not liable for payment of a sales tax.
OTTAWA, May 15 -- The Canadian people, despite an unprecedented burden of taxes, have over-subscribed their sixth Victory Loan of $1,200,000,000 by $200,000,000.

If, as James Joseph Dykes would have us believe, Joseph Vincent McCarthy is a push-button manager, the pilot of the Yankees needed only to make one move yesterday at the Stadium and the White Sox were licked. That happened in the fourth inning, when the Yankees had just scored a run to tie the game, Bud Metheny was on first, two were out and Don Savage at the plate.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., May 15 -- A mother duck, proudly escorting thirteen newly hatched ducklings through the business section of Fisher Avenue here today, unwittingly trod on a sewer grating and saw eight of her brood slip into the stygian depths below. She had been transferring the ducklings from a quarry to the near-by Bronx River.

RENO, Nev., May 15 -- Virginia R. Ridder obtained a divorce today from Herman H. Ridder, St. Paul, Minn., newspaper publisher. They had made an agreement for the support and custody of their year-old daughter.

Taking a lead from the experience of previous military operations, national and local advertisers have made their preparations for D-Day, it was learned yesterday. Numerous ads are in the hands of metropolitan newspapers with orders insert in the first available issue after the invasion starts.

WITH THE POLISH ARMY IN ITALY, May 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- Polish troops, who have waited four years to battle the Germans on a big scale, again were thrown against their old-time enemies at the opening of the offensive against the Gustav Line last Thursday night and have been in the thick of the fighting ever since.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Plans for a drive for the re-election of President Roosevelt will be completed by the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations when it meets here tomorrow under the chairmanship of Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, May 16 (AP) -- A communique:

The fight against the poll tax has come to grief again on the question of cloture -- that is, of limiting debate in order to reach an early vote. A majority of the Senators would probably have voted against the poll tax if the measure had been presented to them, but less than a majority yesterday were willing to vote for cloture.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The railroads must continue to carry freight at present rates for another six-month period beginning July 1, the Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today. The order also denied a request of the American Trucking Association Inc., calling for an increase in rates on less than carload lots.

I read with interest the letter of Henry Waldman, published on May 11, calling attention to the inadequacy of notice of the provisions of governmental regulations and directives to the persons affected through the medium of publication in the Federal Register.

The National Association of Manufacturers announced yesterday that it had formed a "Government spending" committee of sixty-three manufacturers who would attempt "to sweat down the nation's overspending." Lewis A. Dibble, president of the Eastern Malleable Iron Company of Naugatuck, Conn., is the chairman.

Antony Tudor's "Dark Elegies" had its second and final performance of the season by the Ballet Theatre last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. This deeply impressive peasant ritual on the "Kindertotenlieder" of Mahler, though it may not be everybody's meat, is an important work and deserves to be kept alive if only for an occasional presentation each season.

COMMAND POST NEAR CASSINO, May 15 -- A rumor went around that the Germans were about to evacuate Cassino for fear of being outflanked, but by a simple test performed in "Spandau Alley" a British Tommy was able to report today that the Jerries were still very much in evidence.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 15 -- Unless the problem of competing production throughout the American countries after the war is taken care of before the war ends, Chileans will not feel too optimistic regarding the practical results of the convention of the inter-American Development Commissions meeting in New York, according to leading articles in the press.
Purchase by operators of housing properties featured realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, spoke last night at the Hotel Astor to some 400 musicians on proposals for an extensive program of musical interchange between the United States and the Soviet Union. The meeting was held under the auspices of the music committee, of which Dr. Koussevitzky is chairman, of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship.
CHUNGKING, China, May 15 (UP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

CHICAGO, May 15 -- General liquidation developed in the grain markets today. December wheat, oats and rye sold at new seasonal lows on the Board of Trade here and a majority of the active and near-by months went into new ground since late last year.

The Richfield Oil Corporation, in its March quarter report released for today, shows a net income after all charges of $886,281, equal to approximately 22 cents each on the 4,010,000 shares of capital stock outstanding. In the corresponding three months of last year the company earned $654,596, or about 16 cents a share.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 -- Frankie Frisch, the venerable horticulturist of New Rochelle, saw his Pirates sprout five runs as they uprooted Rube Fischer of the Giants in the second inning today and forthwith settled back into a deep reverie.

ST. LOUIS, May 15 (AP) -- Breaking away for their biggest single inning of the season, the Cardinals today scored nine runs in the first off Dick Barrett and Chet Covington and won, 11 to 6, from the Phillies.

Some folks are always hard to please. They will now ask if the recently dissolved Communist party of America could not have picked out a better new name for itself than the American Communist Association.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 10: Increases of $283,000,000 in demand deposits -- adjusted and $140,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $504,000,000 in United States Goverment deposits.

For several weeks a special committee of the House of Representatives has been holding hearings on a proposal to merge the Army and Navy into a single defense department. On two points there has been a large measure of agreement. First, that this is not the moment for such a change; in the midst of war the advantages of such a plan would be more than offset by its resulting complications.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Some meats now being sold point free will most certainly be returned to the list of rationed items, perhaps in "thirty, in sixty or ninety days or maybe in next January or Febuary," Price Administrator Chester Bowles said today.

The Associated Press dispatch from the Eighth Army Italian front, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 13, speaks of Polish troops in Italy as "fighting their first major battle since the conquest of Poland in 1939."

The City Council passed a local law yesterday designed to prohibit discrimination because of race, color or creed against any person seeking to become a resident or business tenant of any future housing project built by private capital with tax exemption under the Urban Redevelopment Law.

Gregory Osterman, 29-year-old first-class private, who enlisted in the Army three years ago, returned last Thursday to his home at 870 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, on a week's furlough after his father, Solomon, had written two weeks earlier that Snowflake, his 7-year-old Eskimo spitz dog, was pining for his master and refused to eat.

In the most limited session in more than eight months, the stock market operated yesterday at an irregular and mixed pace. Special situations come in for marked attention, and usually at higher prices, but the lack of interest in the main list argued against anything more than fractional changes.
The Delaware Hudson Company announced yesterday a move to divorce the Boston Maine Railroad from control by the New Haven Railroad, but denied any intent to acquire control itself.
LONDON, May 15 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
WITH GENERAL STILWELL'S FORCES, Mogaung Valley, Burma, May 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's forces have made amazing progress in the Mogaung Valley during the last five weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The sedition trial jury was near to selection today as all peremptory challenges were exercised, except the defense's last. Nine prospective jurors were excused. Among those challenged on behalf of the twenty-nine defendants accused of conspiring to overthrow the Government by demoralizing the armed forces by such means as racial propaganda, were four Negroes and a Jew.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Supreme Court ruled today by 5 to 4 that a State might assess personal property taxes against the entire fleet of airplanes operated by an airline with its home port of operations within that State.

The Yugoslav Partisan Army -- potentially 600,000 strong -- already has freed one-half of Yugoslavia and will open a general counter-offensive against the Germans when Europe is invaded from the west, Marshal Tito has declared in interviews with two correspondents representing the combined Allied press.
The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus presented yesterday morning the special annual performance for 14,500 underprivileged children of the city in Madison Square Garden.

Why do we grow old? Degeneration describes what happens, but it does not explain causes. So long as this mystery remains so long will men seek the Fountain of Youth either outside the body, as they once did, or inside, as modern biologists do. Not until the function of the ductless or endocrine glands was discovered was there any hope that old age might be staved off.
JIMMY DYKES was thumbing through his mail, thus giving the lie to the Chicago correspondents who had insisted all along that the Little Round Man was unable to read.

Within a matter of hours yesterday it was disclosed that the Post Office Department had barred "Strange Fruit," by Lillian Smith, a new best-selling novel dealing with the race problem and moral dry-rot in a small Georgia town, from the United States mails and had subsequently lifted the ban to the extent of accepting the book for mailing "at the publisher's risk."

Stockholders of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York engaged the management in lively discussion yesterday at their annual meeting over pensions paid top ranking officials. When votes were tabulated, however, a proposal to limit pensions to $6,000 annually was defeated, 7,339,406 to 852,257.

Asserting that the dollars and cents price ceilings set by the Office of Price Administration on fresh vegetables have taken away their profits, many retail grocers threaten to discontinue selling such produce, A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the New York State Food Merchants Association, disclosed yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 15 -- Stocks of meat in storage on May 1 were the largest for that date since 1920 and lard stocks were the largest in history, the War Food Administration reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Ruling that the "sole purpose of the journey was to provide innocent recreation and a holiday," the Supreme Court held by 5 to 4 today that Hans P. Mortensen and Lorraine Mortensen of Grand Island, Neb., could not be prosecuted under the Mann act for transporting two prostitutes across State lines on a two-week vacation trip.
NAPLES, May 15 (AP) -- A communique:

Enforcement of price-ceiling regulations by the Office of Price Administration has been followed by the shutting down of virtually the entire smoked fish industry of New York City. Processors of smoked fish, which is an important item in the diet of millions of New Yorkers, declared yesterday that they could not continue to turn out their product at 1942 prices as required by OPA.

Rich and spicy is a so-called cinnamon fruit roll just put on the market by the General Baking Company under the trade name of Bond. Actually, it is a bread, a first cousin to the company's cinnamon raisin loaf, but differing from the latter in that it is made with more shortening and sugar and with the addition of candied orange peel, lemon peel and citron.

BUSTLETON, Pa., May 15 -- The flying version of the Conestoga wagon, the first stainless steel cargo plane, is in mass production at a huge new plant near this small community on the outskirts of Philadelphia, the Navy disclosed today.

Shipments of steel plates in March and the first quarter of 1944 topped all previous records, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, which placed deliveries at 1,204,368 net tons for the month and at 3,452,871 tons for the quarter.

Commendation and reciprocal courtesy are merited by the statement reported in your May 7 issue of Ensign William Burke as favoring a new organization of veterans after the present war. You quote him as saying: "I see no reason why veterans can't join both the American Legion and our group.
ALGIERS, May 15 -- For the first time in French Parliamentary history a woman member addressed the French Consultative Assembly today.

BALTIMORE, May 15 (AP) -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad reported today a 1943 net income of $30,509,480, a drop of $14,814,116 from 1942, and attributed the decilne to higher wages, increased taxes and loss due to suspension of freight rate increases.

Howard Hughes, aviator and film producer, announced yesterday that his television company did not concur in the recent statement of the Television Broadcasters Association opposing the policy of the Columbia Broadcasting System on post-war television.

According to his letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 11 Henry Waldman's sense of justice and fairness is shocked by the fact that the Supreme Court in the case of Yakus vs. United States applied the familiar rule of law that publication in the Federal Register constitutes constructive notice of the contents of a regulation.

With the clearing of the North African coastal areas and the opening of Mediterranean traffic the supply problem on medicinal drugs has passed its critical peak, Dr. E.C. Merrill, assistant vice president of the United Drug Company, Boston, said yesterday at the opening of the three-day annual convention of the Proprietary Association of America at the Hotel Roosevelt.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 15 (U.P.) -- Negotiations of Stanton Griffis, American economic expert, with Swedish industrialists to stop the export of ball bearings to Germany are virtually complete, the newspaper Goeteborgs-Posten said today.

War and violence have replaced love and springtime as the topics to which the city's junior poets devote their talents, it was revealed yesterday at the annual inter-high school poetry contest, held in Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place.

A great invasion of the department-store field is planned by the mail-order and chain-store companies for the post-war period, which will require independent retailers to gird themselves to meet this competitive expansion, Franklin J. Bradley, president of the Mutual Buying Syndicate, representing stores with an annual volume in excess of $200,000,000, said yesterday.

Psychologists, writers and foreign-language experts working under Government supervision have been busy preparing the greatest barrage of printed facts and figures and instructions in history to accompany the Allied invasion of the European Continent.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Tuesday, May 16 (AP) -- Allied airmen, pressing their drive to immobilize Japanese airpower on the path to the Philippines, have lashed Wakde Island, off the northwest coast of Netherlands New Guinea, with 220 more tons of bombs, headquarters announced today.

Tammany Hall, once monarch of all it surveyed, suffered last night the indignity of having a scheduled meeting of its county committee prohibited by court order. The order was obtained by two members of Tammany's own executive committee and was signed by a Supreme Court justice placed on the bench by Tammany as recently as the last election.

CHUNGKING, China, May 15 (UP) -- Fighting furiously to stem the four-week-old Japanese offensive in Honan Province, Chinese troops have hurled back the invaders from the gates of the key stronghold of Loyang, a Chinese communique, announced tonight.

PEARL HARBOR, May 15 (U.P.) -- United States Army and Navy bombers, striking Japanese bases from the heavily battered Truk atoll to the Kuriles, north of the Japanese mainland, Saturday, opened their seventh month of a sustained aerial offensive that has spearheaded the steady American advance in the Pacific, it was announced today.

Award winners selected by the professional jury in the twenty-third annual exhibit of the Art Directors Club of New York were announced last night at the club's dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Winners selected by the consumer jury will be announced tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock at the exhibit, which is free to the public and is open daily from today to June 5.
Short coats and jackets that combine dressy fabrics with casual lines abound in the stores for summer wear.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the conviction of Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, former national leader of the German-American Bund, and twenty-three other officials of the organization on charges of conspiring to advise evasion and resistance to the Selective Service Act.

WITH UNITED STATES TROOPS AT HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, April 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- The official records will show that Pvt. Artie Bracknell, "above and beyond the call of duty, gave his life to keep his platoon from being annihilated."
Bids will be opened on May 30 by the State Board of Administration of Florida on four new issues of refunding bonds of Florida counties. The new issues are as follows:

LONDON, May 15 -- The Germans have lost another round in the Battle of the Atlantic. The enemy's submarines, somewhat fewer in number than a year ago, are still cruising the Atlantic, but the U-boat blockade that once threatened the United Nations has been broken.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 15 -- A rift developed today within the entrenched Republican organization of Westchester County after Livingston Platt, County Chairman, had requested Assemblywoman Jane H. Todd of Tarrytown to withdraw as a candidate for Representative from the new Twenty-seventh Congressional District and arranged for the nomination of Ralph W. Gwinn of Bronxville.
Short coats and jackets that combine dressy fabrics with casual lines abound in the stores for summer wear.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the conviction of Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, former national leader of the German-American Bund, and twenty-three other officials of the organization on charges of conspiring to advise evasion and resistance to the Selective Service Act.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Senators and a State Department representative alike expressed surprise today over London dispatches quoting statements of Lord Beaverbrook, Lord Privy Seal, last week to the House of Lords, as to post-war aviation agreements with this country.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today bills increasing pensions of disabled veterans of the first and second World Wars from $100 to $115 a month, where disability is service-connected, and from $40 to $50 monthly in case of non-service-connected disability.

As buying returned yesterday to a more normal pitch after the lifeless performance of Monday, the stock market improved moderately to an irregularly higher closing on the New York Stock Exchange. Specialties again were the center of attraction, with pivotal issues still relegated to the background.
LOS ANGELES, May 16 -- The Navy now has more than 1,200 fighting ships in its fleet.

An Associated Press interview with Marshal Tito, submitted to censorship of the Allied Mediterranean Command April 30, still is refused clearance largely because of a paragraph in which the Yugoslav Partisan leader refers to his rival, Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,464, against 1,118 in the preceding week and 1,814 in the like period a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals were 839, which compared with 528 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- A new medical weapon for preventing measles epidemics has been developed from a substance extracted from blood plasma given by volunteer donors in the Red Cross program, the War Department disclosed today.

LONDON, May 16 -- The protocol signed by Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark and the late Admiral Jean-Francois Darlan in November, 1942, is regarded here as legally binding on the French Committee of National Liberation notwithstanding Gen. Charles de Gaulle's statement to the contrary.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -- William L. Batt, president of SKF Industries, Inc., told employes of three of the company's plants here today that he believed Sweden should end shipments of ball bearings to Germany.

An event that many fishermen consider to be a dress rehearsal for the popular bass season will take place in New Jersey on Saturday when the State's season for pike and pickerel opens for a period of six months and ten days. The taking of bass becomes legal on June 15.

Sunshine flooded the Central Park sheep meadow yesterday afternoon and flushed the cheeks of 1,800 little girls welcoming spring with a program of folk dances. But even the proud mothers circling the green at Sixty-sixth Street agreed that the star of the fete, sponsored annually by the Public Schools Athletic League, was Vincie, a papier-mache sailor.

WITH EIGHTH EVACUATION HOSPITAL, Fifth Army Front, Italy, May 16 I;P) -- Frederick Faust, who thrilled millions with his fiction of adventure under the name of Max Brand, died in the forefront of battle within thirty minutes after the Allied offensive opened last Thursday night, the seventeenth American correspondi ent to be killed in the war.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 16 -- George K. Batt, vice president and treasurer of Dugan Brothers, bakers, was elected Mayor of Montclair today when the Town Commission held its organization meeting. He succeeds Mayor Bayard H. Faulkner, who had served by appointment since the resignation of William E. Speers last Jan. 1 to become a Bergen County Freeholder.

Yesterday in Chicago Alf M. Landon made a courageous appeal to his fellow-Republicans to revise their traditional attitude on the tariff. "No territorial redistribution of the world," he declared, "can equalize opportunities for all nations. But we can make the differences less irritating and burdensome by facilitating international trade.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 16 (UP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Delegates to the Republican National Convention who have been selected by delegates from each State and Territory as members of the Resolutions Committee, subject to approval of the convention, will meet in Chicago on June 19 to begin preliminary work on the 1944 platform.

BOGOTA, Columbia, May 16 (U.P.) -- The political crisis that had engulfed Colombia for the past six months ended tonight when President Alfonso Lopez, who had been on a leave of absence since November, announced his decision to resume the Presidency.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Navy has ordered a reduction in over-all production of fighter planes because its losses in fighters have been only two-thirds as great as were estimated earlier this year.

To take Time by the forelock is a useful habit, especially in a responsible public employe. But it does seem like a pretty long tuft or tress on the brow of Father Time when Price Administrator Chester Bowles says that renewed meat rationing may be with us in a month, two months or three months, "or maybe in next January or February."

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The sedition trial jury, including two women and only one government worker, was completed today and sworn to deliver a true verdict between the United States and twenty-nine defendants. Immediately afterward, many of their attorneys presented delaying motions over Prosecutor O. John Rogge's protest:

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Lieut. Col. Martha J. Rose Clement, a week and a day from Australia as the bomber flies, said today that more than 3,000 Army nurses under her direction in the South Pacific theatre were as good for jungle-fighting men as a morale-factor as they were as a medical factor.

MIAMI, Fla., May 16 (AP) -- The new chief of China's military mission to the United States said in an interview today that his country would not be knocked out of the war but warned that heavy weapons were needed if the Chinese were to drive out the invading Japanese.
CHUNGKING, China, May 16 (AP) -- Chinese forces have thrown the Japanese out of a second town on the vital Peiping-Hankow railway in Central China, the Chinese High Command announced today.

Cancer kills more than two million people each year, and 158,000 of these are in the United States. To date the country has spent some four and a half million dollars in the war for each death in our armed forces. Naturally, no one begrudges this, but it is a lot of money contrasted with $4.50, which represents the sum spent here on cancer research for each cancer death.

Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the Zionist Organization of America and of the Synagogue Council of America, will be honored on the occasion of his twenty-fifth anniversary as rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street, with a four-day celebration beginning next Saturday, it was announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 16 (AP) -- Assignment of double-header and night games for the American League's National War Fund and Red Cross benefit program was announced today by Will Harridge, league president.

The composite New York team upset expectations and the Fencers Club representatives last night to win the women's national team title as the United States championships got under way on the strips of the Fencers Club on East Fifty-third Street, under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America.

ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP) -- The Phillies were leading the Cardinals, 6 to 4, tonight when their game was called after seven innings to allow the Phillies to catch a train. The game will be completed during Philadelphia's next series here, starting June 28.

If proof were needed that the Russian-Polish dispute casts a long shadow on the future, it is to be found in the lightening of the atmosphere that comes with the first signs that Moscow and the Polish Government in London may be at least on whispering terms. The relief caused by reports that both sides are receding a little from their original positions demonstrates how deeply troubling is this division in the Allied ranks.

Representatives of the lamps and shades industry entered the Greater New York Fund campaign yesterday with an organization and assignment luncheon at the Aldine Club. The meeting was called by David Fingerhut, president of David Fingerhut, Inc., and Morris Thau of the Mutual Sunset Lamp Manufacturing Company, co-chairman of the division.

SPIGNO, Italy, May 16 (U.P.) -- Civilians, looted of their food and clothing by the Germans, straggled back into Spigno last night and tearfully kissed the hands of the American troops who marched into this almost ruined town early yesterday.

LONDON, May 16 (AP) -- The British today were clearing their calendar for whatever may come and whenever it may come. Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, announcing a secret session of the House of Commons Thursday to consider the next sitting dates, told the House:

The two stores at 1454 Broadway, adjoining the I. Miller shoe store on the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-sixth Street, have been leased by Cye Bernard, Inc., haberdashers, through David A. Bernstein Son. This is the sixth store in the metropolitan area and the second store in the Times Square area for this chain. Other business leases follow:

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- "Mental x-rays" of American fliers overseas suffering from war neuroses have revealed that "the successful American soldier is pushed by a complex combination of fear, anxiety and love, but that only love makes him a good saldier," according to a report made today at the meeting of the American Psychiatric Association by Lieut. Col. Roy R. Grinker and Maj. John P. Spiegel of the Army Air Forces Medical Corps.
CINCINNATI, May 16 (AP) -- The Braves evened their shut-out series with the Reds today, taking the fourth game, 1 to 0, to leave each team with a pair of whitewash jobs.

Election of thirty-six members of the Board of Directors of the Welfare Council of New York City was the chief order of business last night at the first meeting of the recently organized Delegate Body of the council held at the McAlpin Hotel.

PEARL HARBOR, May 16 -- The largest tonnage of bombs ever dropped by land-based planes of our central Pacific Air Forces in a single day's operation blasted Japanese positions on Jaluit Atoll in the Marshall Islands Sunday and early Monday, United States Pacific Fleet Headquarters disclosed this morning.

THE condition of the world being as it is a deposed czar has practically no chance of reclaiming his throne. But one czar who is impatiently waiting to be restored to his old position is Dr. C. Guyer Kelly, who reigned from 1921 to 1939 as the Judge Landis of North Africa, a title now held (by right of conquest) by the ebullient Zeke Bonura.

ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP) -- Stan Musial the Cardinals' hard-hitting outfielder, passed his pre-induction physical examination today and joined his team-mate, Danny Litwhiler, in awaiting call to report for service in the Navy.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 16 -- The Right Rev. James P. De Wolfe, Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, approved the bombing of Rome if the Eternal City is held as a military fortress in his address to the seventy-sixth convention of the diocese in Cathedral House here today.
"Cobra Woman," a romantic adventure story produced in Technicolor by Universal, will open this morning at Loew's Criterion. Maria Montez, Jon Hall and Sabu play the lead roles.
CHUNGKING, China, May 16 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Using a novel nomenclature instead of the usual terms for financial operations, Davis S. Roswell of New York, an economic consultant, told a panel of the National War Labor Board today that the result of granting a wage increase of 17 cents an hour wage demanded by the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, would be the "confiscation" of the industry's "tools of production" with nobody gaining anything.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Disclosing that "a great backlog of terminations" involving more than $500,000,000, has piled up and is due contractors because of "the confusion brought on by a multiplicity of termination forms," the War Department announced today that it had "cut through a morass of red tape" by issuing simplified standard contract termination forms for future use.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, May 17, (AP) -- A communique:

The United States will engage in post-war foreign trade "on a scale never before imagined," without private interests joining any foreign cartels, Wendell Berge, Assistant Attorney General of the United States in charge of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, declared yesterday.

The Brooklyn Appellate Division unanimously reversed yesterday the conviction of Christel Schulz, an Astoria, Queens, delicatessen store owner, for the sale of a bottle of beer for off-premises consumption before 1 P.M. Sunday, in violation of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 16 -- Six officers and four enlisted men were killed instantly and one enlisted man was injured critically here this afternoon in the crash of a Navy patrol-type training airship. The eleven men formed the craft's entire crew.

Establishment of inter-American investment banks in all the Latin-American countries to promote post-war foreign trade, industrialization and other economic development on a hemispheric scale was recommended here yesterday by the Committee on Investments of the Conference of Commissions of Inter-American Development.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The resolution sponsored by Representative Charles S. Dewey, Republican, of Illinois, proposing "a central reconstruction fund" of $500, 000,000 to make foreign reconstruction loans and otherwise contribute to post-war rehabilitation and currency stabilization was attacked today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee by Dr. Harry White, monetary adviser to Secretary Morgenthau, as wholly inadequate to meet those problems.

The International Paper Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $2,116,706 in the March quarter after all charges, including $6,673,843 provision for income and excess profits taxes, according to the report of Richard J. Cullen, chairman, mailed to stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The announcement today of the signing of agreements with the exile Governments of Norway, the Netherlands and Belgium was regarded as another indication of the imminence of the impending invasion. It followed closely the recent warning of the United States, Great Britain and the Soviet Union to Finland, Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria to quit the war or take the full consequences of remaining in alliance with Germany.

Held to three singles the last time the Violets faced him, New York University routed Herman Neuberger, City College right-hander, yesterday, raking his offerings for thirteen of their sixteen hits, and registering a 15-to-2 victory over the Beavers in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Ohio Field.

Department of Sanitation officials expressed the opinion yesterday that housewives still were not aware of the importance of saving for the Wednesday paper collections all small scraps that fill their wastebaskets, as well as old newspapers and magazines.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 16 (AP) -- One of two diplomatic exchange ships carrying about 1,600 Allied and German war prisoners and civilians arrived off Barcelona tonight, nearly twelve hours ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Roosevelt summarized for his news conference this afternoon the requests to Congress for appropriations and contract authorization for the new fiscal year starting July 1. So far as the Army, Navy and War Shipping Administration were concerned, they were $8,300, 000,000 less than his original budget estimates in January.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- An oversold condition was disclosed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade when shorts tried to cover. Liquidation was less in evidence and at no time were wheat and rye prices below yesterday's close.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 16 (AP) -- Japanese troops have stabbed close to the borders of India in a new thrust far to the southwest of Imphal, Allied headquarters disclosed today.

Not very long ago we used to hear a great deal from the President and other members of his Administration about what was then described as the evil of "split" decisions in the Supreme Court. The President's chief legal officer, the Attorney General, went before a committee of the Senate in 1937 to denounce this practice.

BRISTOL, Pa., May 16 -- The development of a new chemical compound and of a novel method of administering it to plants so as to render them immune to both insect and fungi destruction was announced today by the Rohm Haas Company, Philadelphia chemical concern, at its laboratories here.
CHUNGKING, China, May 16 -- Chinese troops have scored general advances in their new offensive in western Yunnan Province, it was announced tonight.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Speaking in the name of 5,000,000 members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the CIO Political Action Committee, meeting here concurrently with the convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers formally endorsed President Roosevelt for re-election today as "the only man in public life today qualified to lead the nation during the next four years."

By unanimous vote, the Proprietary Association of America yesterday adopted a thirteen-point revised code of advertising practices at its annual convention at the Hotel Biltmore. Included in the code were five new stipulations designed to raise the standard of proprietary advertising, the five original standards of ethical practices adopted in 1934, and three stipulations on membership requirements formerly a part of the by-laws.

About three-quarters of a million young men from this city, or about one in ten of our population, have gone into the armed services, according to Col. Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service Director. It is as if nearly the whole population of Boston or more than the whole population of San Francisco (at the time of the 1940 census) had been sent to war.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Basing its decision on the right of management to discipline employes who strike in violation of a contract, the War Labor Board punished forty-one former employes tod, by refusing to order their reinstatement with back pay, but ruled that any of them may apply for re-employment as individuals.

NAPLES, May 16 -- The Allies' gains in Italy have been swifter and their losses have been smaller than had been anticipated, it was officially announced today. Three thousand prisoners have been taken since the attack began.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $9,000,000 New Jersey Power and Light Company first mortgage 3 per cent bonds, due 1974, and 30,000 shares of the company's 4 per cent cumulative preferred stock, by a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation.

The New York State Racing Commission, through Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope, has suggested to the Westchester Racing Association, which conducts Belmont Park, or to the track in operation at the time, that if there is a formal announcement of the invasion of Europe racing should be abandoned for that day.

Senator Elbert D. Thomas, Utah Democrat, declared last night that the United States must pay a stiff price still for victory but that "thanks to the sacrifices of the Russian people, that toll will be smaller than it might otherwise have been."

Upward revisions in estimated military needs for cotton goods, continued heavy calls for lend-lease shipments, and tightness of May futures at noon yesterday, when it expired at 21.21 cents a pound, brought about a moderate upturn in quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 16 -- Smith College, at its commencement today, gave four honorary degrees, Doctor of Laws to Capt. Mildred H. McAfee, president of Wellesley College and commander of the Waves, and to Mrs. Vera Micheles Dean of the Foreign Policy Association; Doctor of Music to Miss Marian Anderson, singer, and Doctor of Science to Miss Sophie Satin, research associate at the Smith College Genetics Experiment Station.

The board of directors of the Celanese Corporation of America authorized yesterday a dividend on the common stock of one share of common for each seventy held, payable on June 30. A similar stock dividend was distributed on March 31 last.

In a cabled appeal to Marshal Joseph Stalin sent yesterday by the Emergency Committee to Save the Jewish people of Europe, Russia was asked to come to the rescue of the million Jews in Hungary whose lives are now endangered, and to reaffirm its intention to punish all "war criminals" convicted of persecution.

Your account of the disturbingly nationalistic atmosphere which hung like a cloud over the Republican and Progressive meetings here last week confirms the observations of many of our citizens. But some observers would be inclined to think that your analysis of the Wisconsin isolationist spirit, accurate and true as far as it goes, fails fully to account for the phenomenon.

Skilled medical personnel, trained in the shortest possible time, was ranked yesterday as China's major need by Lieut. Gen. Robert K.S. Lim, chief of the supervisory and planning commission of the Chinese Army Medical Administration.

Liquor package store owners have done a good job during the whisky shortage period in serving the public equitably, except during the very peak of the excessive demands, according to association spokesmen yesterday. This view, as expressed at a luncheon sponsored by Allied Liquor Industries at the Hotel Roosevelt, at which the latter group presented a new program to eliminate criticism of the industry arising from unethical practices in a small minority of liquor stores.

LONDON, May 16 -- The long-awaited signing of agreements between Britain and the United States, on the one hand, and the exiled Governments of Norway, the Netherlands and Belgium, on the other, governing control of civil affairs in those countries during the period of liberation took place here today.
Miss Ella Widener's Iron Shot yesterday annexed the Charles L. Appleton Steeplechase at Belmont Park.

The Chalfonte, a fifteen-story and penthouse apartment hotel at 200 West Seventieth Street, southwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue, was sold by the Prudential Insurance Company of America to a syndicate of investors represented by Netter Netter, attorneys. It is on a plot 125 by 100.5 feet and contains 205 apartments, with stores on the ground floor.

As was suggested on this page yesterday, the best strategy for enemies of the poll tax now is to push a constitutional amendment to abolish it. A resolution calling for such an amendment has been introduced by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming. On Tuesday, just before the Senate dropped the poll tax bill, the Judiciary Committee voted six to five not to take up the O'Mahoney resolution.

Revoking an earlier decision, the Hunter College elections board announced yesterday that last week's elections for student officers have been declared invalid because of illegal voting procedures. In view of testimony that there had been double voting and electioneering near the polls, both violations of election regulations, a new vote has been scheduled for tomorrow and Friday.

Rehabilitated refugees who have "gone through the fire and who know the value of freedom" were called the "people of the future" by I.A. Hirschmann, special representative of the War Refugee Board, who spoke yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Palestine Lighthouse in the Plaza Hotel.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 16 (AP) -- On receipt today of a letter of apology, the Most Rev. Thomas H. O'Leary, bishop of Spingfield, lifted the suspension of the Rev. Stanislaus Orlemanski, who recently visited Marshal Stalin.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 17 (U.P.) -- Red Army tank forces killed more than 400 Germans yesterday in turning back attacks against the Soviet bridgehead on the west bank of the lower Dniester River, and Monday night Russian bombers blasted the enemy base of Polotsk in northwestern White Russia, Moscow announced today.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- Cloud Light, owned by Ray Metcalf and Jim Carr, and Ruth Daniels' Onecbill captured the two divisions of the Winthrop Purse, six-furlong sprints for Grade D 3-year-olds at Suffolk Downs today.

LONDON, May 16 -- The Royal Air Force's speedy Mosquito bombers dropped two-ton blockbusters on the German chemical center of Ludwigshafen and attacked objectives in northwestern Germany and a Luftwaffe base in France last night.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Federal investigation in progress for the last two weeks into the SKF Industries, Inc., Philadelphia, and the SKF Steel, Inc., New York, was undertaken for the purpose of determining ownership and control of the Swedish company and should not be interpreted as any reflection upon either the management or employes of the two companies, the Treasury Department and the Alien Property Custodian said tonight in a joint statement.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the issuance and sale under competitive bidding by the West Penn Power Company, Pittsburgh, of $12,500,000 principal amount of Series L, 3 per cent, first mortgage bonds, due 1974.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 --David Loew and Robert Hakin have formed a partnership to produce George Sessions Perry's novel, "Hold Autumn in Your Hand," for United Artists. The story of a modern Texas pioneer family will be directed by Jean Renoir. Joel McCrea and Frances Dee have been signed for the co-starring leads.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Lippy Leo Durocher's display of a slight bit of overconfidence in Ol' Dan'l Boone Davis, coupled with the resurgent bat of Bad Bill Nicholson, today cost the Dodgers the finale of the series with the Cubs by a 7-6 score, the winning run crossing in the ninth inning.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 16 -- On the defensive diplomatically as well as militarily, Berlin is bringing to bear all possible pressure on the Balkans to prevent wavering in the support of the German war effort, following the Allied warning, according to information in diplomatic quarters.

Tammany's executive committee upheld last evening, with plenty of votes to spare, the moves planned by Leader Edward V. Loughlin and his supporters designed to strengthen their control of the governing organization of the Democratic party in New York County.

Richard Wright, Ira Wolfert Edita Norris and Oscar Williams are among the better-known writers appearing in "Cross-Section," a new collection of American novelettes, short stories, plays and poetry, edited by Edwin Seaver, to be published by L.B. Fischer on May 29.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 16 -- The Allied push into the Gustav Line, coupled with bombings and partisan sabotage, has disrupted food deliveries and thrown Italy into the greatest confusion since the days following Benito Mussolini's ouster, it was reported today.

WITH THE CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE ON THE SALWEEN FRONT, May 16 (AP) -- The big object of the current Chinese offensive across the Salween River is to win a land route to bring in heavy war equipment that will permit a military showdown with Japan, a Chinese military leader said today.

DETROIT, May 16 -- The Briggs Manufacturing Company closed its Mack Avenue plant, where nearly 10,000 persons are employed on all shifts, with the announcement tonight that the Navy's Bureau of Aeronautics had refused to accept any more of its output.

Vincent Petrocelli, 12 years old, a member of the West Side Children's Center Boys Club, 409 West Thirty-eighth Street, won the George Lane Nichols Memorial Medal yesterday because his sense of "fairness and good sportsmanship" was deemed by the Children's Aid Society to be the most outstanding among 15,000 New York City boys.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Senators made three runs in the first inning to defeat the Indians, 3 to 2, tonight behind Southpaw Mickey Haefner's six-hit hurling.

New Jersey and California Democrats put eighty-six more delegates in President Roosevelt's column in primary voting yesterday and pushed his total far above the required majority for another nomination two months in advance of the party's national convention.

The organization Republican slate of seven delegates-at-large to the national convention, headed by Governor Walter E. Edge and H. Alexander Smith of Princeton, former chairman of the Republican State Committee, regular party candidate for United States Senator, were elected last night over an insurgent opposition in New Jersey's primary election.

Does Germany enjoy "tactical advantage" over us in the present air battle over Europe? A suggestion that it does, made recently in those dispatches, has been challenged from some directions. We are evidently winning the Battle of Germany, it is said, the implication being that we would not do so if the Germans had a tactical edge.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Treasury Department advised today against any reduction at this time in the 30 per cent wartime tax on night club checks, which became effective April 1.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, On the Garigliano Front, May 16 -- Frederick Faust, whose pen name was Max Brand and who wrote much action and adventure fiction, was buried here this morning in a soldier's grave. He was killed "about May 12" near Santa Maria Infante, which at that time was still in German hands.

TRENTON, May 16 (AP) -- Harry A. Walsh, a veteran of seventeen years service in the New Jersey Attorney General's office, announced today his dismissal as an aide to Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper and said he was told the action was "purely political."

As the attack in Italy nears the end of its first week one cannot help thinking of the situation four years ago. By May 17, 1940, after seven days of fighting, the Germans had forced the surrender of the Netherlands, had taken Brussels and were about to take Antwerp, and had broken the "hinge" of the French line at Sedan.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -- Jojo White's single in the last half of the tenth inning with two men on and two out gave the Athletics their second consecutive victory over the Tigers, 4 -- 3, today.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16 -- In pursuance of a War Department policy to hospitalize wounded members of the armed services as close to their homes as possible, 203 patients of the Halloran General Hospital on Staten Island were evacuated by air today from the Newark Airport to institutions in Cleveland, Indianapolis, Battle Creek, Boston and Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Secretary Hull denied at a press conference today that an agreement on post-war aviation had been reached by A.A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, during his recent conversations in London.
CHICAGO, May 16 -- Following is the statement issued today by the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations endorsing President Roosevelt for a fourth term:

This is Norway's Independence Day, her Frihestag, the 130th anniversary of the promulgation of her Eidsvold Constitution; a day dear to the hearts of her people the world over, and doubly dear to those in the homeland. In invaded Norway on this Freedom Day there will be no chiming of church bells, no choral singing in the village squares, no processions of happy children.

Vincent Guy Calfapietra, 31-year-old first grade fireman attached to Hook and Ladder Company 5, was dismissed yesterday from the Fire Department by Commissioner Patrick Walsh for holding a job outside the department.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- With the threat of a Senate filibuster apparently ended by yesterday's displacement of the anti-poll tax bill, Congress renewed its drive today for a convention and campaign recess to begin about June 20.

Wholesale produce dealers in New York City abandoned the five-day week yesterday and agreed to keep open for business six days weekly. The Consolidated Committee of the Fruit and Vegetable Association voted to remain open on Saturdays, commencing this week, in response to the demand of city, State and Federal authorities.

FEW young men have seen more of Americans fighting in this war than 26-year-old Howard Hunt. He was graduated from Brown University in 1940 and, being able to see which way the wind was blowing, joined the Naval Reserve and was commissioned an ensign at the Naval Academy in 1941. He served a long spell of convoy duty in the North Atlantic on the destroyer Mayo.

LONDON, May 16 (AP) -- Marshal Tito said tonight his Partisan troops had routed an enemy column of several thousand men in Prijoj, eastern Bosnia, and that "violent battles" were raging all along the Yugoslav front as the Germans strove to clear threatened communication lines.

Wayne T. Lonergan, who was convicted of the second-degree murder of his estranged wife, Mrs. Patricia Burton Lonergan, heiress of the Bernheimer brewing fortune, in their Beckman Hill home on Oct. 24, and who subsequently was sentenced to serve thirty-five years to life imprisonment, filed a right of election in Surrogate's Court yesterday, which if upheld would entitle him to an intestate share in her estate.
"A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" -- as the novelist Betty Smith says in her book title -- and Magistrate J. Roland Sala took action yesterday to insure that it will keep on growing.

In its issue of May 12 THE TIMES printed a story about Secretary Ickes having urged Congress to recognize that the people of Puerto Rico are United States citizens. Mr. Ickes was also reported to have suggested transferring the island's surplus population to Central and South American countries.

Free admission to local major league baseball games may now be obtained by service men and women directly at the Yankee Stadium, Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field, it was announced yesterday. A special booth will be opened at each park, making it more convenient for those who are desirous of attending a game.

Stressing a large decline in attendance at church schools in the last decade, the annual report of the four district superintendents in the New York area of the Methodist Church yesterday condemned parental lethargy as "one of the greatest dangers to the future welfare of America."

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The income tax simplification bill was reported favorably by the Senate Finance Committee today. Senator Walter F. George, chairman, said that it would be taken up Friday in the Senate.

The ninth annual Catholic School Music Festival, under the auspices of the Music Education League, began yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The festival is chiefly a competition among choirs and choruses from churches and schools. The opening program was given by church boys' choirs, intermediate choirs of schools and elementary school choruses.

HARRISON, N.J., May 16 -- Approximately 3,000 employes of three war plants of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation, two of which are in Newark, N.J., and the other here, went on strike today in protest over the company's alleged failure to extend a contract that expired yesterday with the United Steel Workers Union, CIO.

Arthur Krock's dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 7 relative to the right of an elector to exercise his own judgment in voting in the Electoral College for President and Vice President recalls the situation in which James Russell Lowell found himself in connection with the disputed Presidential election of 1876.

Abraham A. Fishman, 33 years old, of 975 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, one of eight men indicted last January in an alleged racket through which they obtained $275,000 in subscriptions for blood bank, fat salvage and war bond drive advertising in a bogus newspaper, was permitted to enter a guilty plea to conspiracy in General Sessions yesterday to cover thirteen other grand larceny counts.

More strenuous efforts than ever made heretofore will be developed in the post-war period by the floor coverings industry to acquaint the public with what the products of the industry can do to beautify and make homes more comfortable and livable, it was revealed yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Floor Covering Advertising Club at the Hotel Biltmore.

The large residence on the corner of MacCulloch Avenue and Miller Road, Morristown, N.J., occupied by the cartoonist, Thomas Nast for many years during his lifetime, has been sold for the estate of Helen B. Darcy by Horace C. Jeffers and the Morristown Trust Company, executors, reports Eugene V. Welsh, broker in the transaction.

A project for "horticultural rehabilitation" of veterans at the Cushing General Hospital in Framingham, Mass., received the Founders Fund award of $1,200 yesterday at the annual meeting of the Garden Club of America.

The City Center's festival of musical shows starts tonight with "The New Moon." With a cast headed by Dorothy Kirsten, Johnny Morgan and Earl Wrightson, the operetta revival will continue until June 4, with the possibility of the run being extended.

RICHMOND, Va., May 16 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Southern Railway Company at their annual meeting today authorized the company, at the discretion of its directors, to simplify its corporate set-up by acquiring all franchises, rights and properties of four subsidiaries.

LONDON, May 16 -- Contact between the Polish underground forces and the Red Army has been broken by a German counter-attack at the only point in Poland where cooperation had been formally established on a large scale, Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk reported today at a press conference held by three important underground delegates who recently came here to report.

CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP) -- Directors of the Alleghany Corporation, top holding company of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway system, today authorized an application to the Interstate Commerce Commission for an order designed to clear the way for eventual merger of the C. O., the New York, St. Louis Chicago (Nickel Plate) and the Pere Marquette roads.

Although he criticized it as evidencing distrust of the courts' New York Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins yesterday declared constitutional Sections 61A and 61B of the General Corporation Law, legislation recently enacted in Albany limiting the scope of stockholders' derivative actions, and held that it applies to actions now pending in the courts.

Eight directors were elected yesterday at the forty-seventh annual meeting of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York. Neal Dow Becker, president of the Intertype Corporation, and association president, in announcing the election said that three of the directors are new to the group's board, while five succeed themselves.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Because of larger food requirements and a tighter labor market, the Women's Land Army is planning to recruit 800,000 workers this year, as against 600,000 in 1943, Miss Florence Hall, director of the stated today.

Reports that have reached this country leave no doubt that the European Advisory Council, at work for some months on the terms of the eventual German armistice, conforms to the rigorous policy that President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill had in mind when they coined the formula of "unconditional surrender."

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Merchant Marine has lost one of its most colorful skippers in the death at sea of Capt. Levi J. Plesner of New Orleans, it was announced today by the War Shipping Administration. He was 50 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The present is an opportune time to "expand and make more adequate the whole social security program," George E. Bigge, a member of the Social Security Board, told the Senate's Special Committee on Post-War Economic Policy and Planning today.
NAPLES, May 16 (UP) -- A communique:

Stockholders of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation at their annual meeting here yesterday approved a resolution setting aside 140,000 shares of common stock to be optioned to certain executive employes for sale by installments spread over five years.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- After missing a chance to win over the regulation distance, Virgil Johnson of the Red Sox blew high and handsome in the twelfth inning today, presenting the Browns with a four-run cluster and a 7-to-3 triumph.

The New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs opened its golden jubilee convention last night at the Hotel New Yorker, initiating a program in which members' war services will be stressed. Mrs. Charles S. Maddock Jr. of Trenton, president, welcomed delegates from 300 clubs to the sessions, which will continue through Friday noon.

LONDON, May 16 -- The stock markets here were subdued today and prices in some sections were lower. The main interest centered in the shipping section, where the Anchor Line was prominent as a result of support by investment buyers.

LONDON, May 16 -- Under cover of bad weather, which is hindering the full development of the Allied air offensive, the Germans are believed to be concentrating aircraft and men-of-war in northwestern Europe to attack Allied invasion forces when they concentrate and when they are en route to the Continent.

Readers of this newspaper have long been familiar with the qualities of Brooks Atkinson as a critic of the drama. Certainly he never had a more dramatic story to unfold than that of his return to the Burma Road. When he left it a year ago it was a valley of despair. Now his vivid dispatches reveal the majestic backdrop, the off-stage effects and the motive power behind a reborn Chinese Army advancing to battle.

The reorganization of several high schools to meet problems caused by the drop in enrollment is now under consideration by the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday by Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade.
