A banking group headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and the Hibernia National Bank in New Orleans won yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,180,000 Orleans Levee District, La., refunding bonds, dated June 1, 1944, and due serially from June 1, 1947 to 1962, and callable beginning June 1, 1954.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Elimination of arbitrary freight rate differentials and a new approach to regulation of transportation based on cost and service were recommended today in the first report of the Board of Investigation and Research established under the Transportation Act of 1940.

ALGIERS, May 16 -- The French Committee announced tonight that it had decided that it would soon formally proclaim itself the Provisional Government of the French Republic, as the Assembly suggested in a resolution adopted yesterday with General de Gaulle's approval.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, declared at a press conference today that the strike of the Associated Foremen of America, at Detroit, was the most serious to-date during this war, because of the effect it was having on plane production.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, England, May 16 (AP) -- They're putting up the big-scale battle maps on the newly painted walls of the long conference room of invasion press headquarters -- and if the German command could look them over, they would be just as worried as they are now and not one bit better informed.

CHUNGKING, China, May 17 (AP) -- Hope for at least a provisional agreement between the Communist and Central Governments, enabling China to throw greater strength against Japan, was stimulated today by the arrival of Lin Tso-han, Communist administration chairman, to confer with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

Three meet records were broken as Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School captured the point trophy in the open events of the sixth annual Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades track and field meet yesterday at McCarren Park, Brooklyn. Loughlin compiled 22 points, while De Witt Clinton, winner a year ago, tied for second with George Washington at 8.

John J. Kenney has been appointed manager of the post-war planning department of the International Business Machines Corporation and J. Walter Dickson Jr., special representative, with headquarters in Los Angeles.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, May 18 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur disclosed today that invasion forces that have been at Aitape, New Guinea, since April 22 now are engaged with a Japanese force in that sector.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- President Roosevelt likened the Philadelphia declaration of the International Labor Organization's conference to the Declaration of Independence and said today that its statement, "poverty anywhere constitutes a danger to prosperity everywhere," represented a principle which "is a guide to all of our international economic deliberations."
TORONTO, May 17 (AP) -- Newark cut loose with a six-run blast in the seventh inning against Toronto tonight, but the Maple Leafs collected three runs in the eighth to beat the Bears, 11 -- 10.

The retirement of the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin as president of the faculty of Union Theological Seminary in June, next year, and the election of the Rev. Dr. Henry Pitney Van Dusen to succeed him were announced last night at the annual graduation exercises in James Chapel at the seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.
THE mail continues to pile up on a variety of subjects as the indefatigable letter-writers take pen in hand and go to work. So here are a few which have been received within the past fortnight or so.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Piecemeal amendment of the educational section of the "GI Bill of Rights" brought the House of Representatives this afternoon to a point where Representative Barden of North Carolina, chairman of the Education Committee, announced that he would not ask for a vote on his group's proposal, known as the Barden bill.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Senate, by a vote of 42 to 24, divided closely on party lines, defeated today a proposal that salaries be denied to any employes of the Department of Agriculture, here or in the field who engaged in political activities.

One of this country's modern generation of ship masters, Capt. Morgan A. Maxey, 27 years old, a native of Rusk, Tex., yesterday received the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal for rescuing a French destroyer. Rear Admiral Albert B. Randall, commandant of the United States Maritime Service, presented the award in the offices of Walter W. Schwenk, Atlantic Coast director, War Shipping Administration, 45 Broadway.

I have no doubt that many of your readers felt as I did that your editorial of May 9, "French Realities," laid stress upon a vital point, namely, that while it is in the clutches of the most cruel of enemies, none should discount the will of the French people in the selection of its government until it is able at last to exercise that will.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The President signed the lend-lease extension act. His appointments today were with a group of ILO conference delegates headed by Secretary of Labor Perkins, with a group of members of the foreign service, and with W. Averell Harriman and Secretary of War Stimson.

ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP) -- The Braves opened up against three pitchers for five extra base hits in a total of eleven and won the initial contest of a three-game series with the Cardinals, 5 to 1, today.

NAPLES, May 17 (U.P.) -- British and Polish columns opened a powerful, two-way attack to encircle Cassino today and by nightfall they had closed the Germans' shell-torn lifeline to the city to less than two miles as French and American forces, slashing through the last broken Gustav Line forts, reached the Adolf Hitler Line.

LONDON, May 17 -- Business on today's stock markets here again was on a small scale, but support was given to a few industrial issues.

A former champion came back after an interlude of thirteen years to win the national title with the epee last night and a 63-year-old veteran carried off second place honors as the United States fencing championships continued at the Fencers Club under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America.

Representative Emanuel Celler threatened yesterday to seek "economic sanctions" against four New York title insurance companies unless State Insurance Superintendent Robert E. Dineen causes their compliance with War Labor Board directives to negotiate contracts with Local 16 of the United Office and Professional Workers of America.
Unless adults assume a greater responsibility toward the teen-age boy, juvenile delinquency will increase to an even greater extent, Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Cries of continuing deterioration in quality rise above complaints of scarcities in a twenty-eight State summary of a second survey of the low-cost clothing field, issued today by the American Home Economics Association.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Treasury experts told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that Dr. Benjamin H. Beckhart, economist of the Chase National Bank, had made important errors in testimony regarding the joint statement of principles on currency stabilization of the United and Associated Nations.

George Ade was fortunate in attaining success and ease early, but he couldn't get more than he deserved. Fame never went to his head. He was unspoiled. After a little rough going he made himself one of the best of reporters. The selective and retentive eye and ear were his.

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY, South of Cassino, Italy, May 17 -- The squeeze is on the road to Rome behind Cassino and once again the Battle of Italy is tending to be synonymous with the battle for the bombed and blasted town at the foot of Monastery Hill.

LONDON, May 17 (UP) -- Mustang fighters of the Royal Air Force's Second Tactical Command, in the only announced Britain-based activity by daylight today over storm-swept Western Europe, carried out offensive sweeps over Denmark.

Richard and Irene Richie, 5-year-old twins -- one of four pairs born to Mrs. Helen Richie of 327 East Eighty-ninth Street -- were believed to have drowned in the East River near Ninety-second Street yesterday afternoon.

Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, last night urged immediate action by this country to encourage Latin-American industrialization as a stimulus both for war output and post-war foreign trade, and as "a sustained expression of the Good Neighbor policy in terms of healthy industrial development."

LONDON, May 17 -- Based on carriers that steamed within sight of the Norwegian coast, aircraft of the Royal Navy have struck another sharp blow at German shipping in Norwegian fjords and at shore installations there, the Admiralty announced tonight.

The Excelsior Savings Bank announced yesterday that it had sold the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 590 West End Avenue, southeast corner of Eighty-ninth Street, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $440,000.

Repeated protests by Cuban pineapple canners to the Office of Price Administration in Washington and by the American Ambassador, Spruille Braden, in Havana, to the State Department have brought no relief from the sharp reduction recently made in ceiling pric Denis Figeroux, director of the Cuban Pineapple Canners Association, declared yesterday.

LONDON, May 17 (U.P.) -- King Haakon and Premier Johann Nygaardsvold, in speeches broadcast to the people of Norway today on the anniversary of their independence, said that their liberation is near and that drastic punishment is being readied for Quislings.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- Isolationists and extreme nationalists who believe that it is possible to surround these United States with a Chinese Wall are in this respect "as fanatical and fantastic" as the "psychological isolationists" known to psychiatrists as "schizophrenics," Prof. Edward A. Strecker of the University of Pennsylvania told the American Psychiatric Association today.

LONDON, Thursday, May 18 -- The Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth of Nations announced today that they had decided at their London conference that after the war there should be a new world organization with "the necessary power and authority to prevent aggression and violence."

Operations of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries in the three months ended with March resulted in a net profit of $6,911,311 after all charges and taxes, it was announced yesterday by Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president.

Dr. Joao Barros Barreto, director of the National Health Department of Brazil, who attended the fifth Pan American conference for public health officials, which has just closed in Washington, advocated yesterday a complete understanding of the common sanitary problems of all the American republics in preparation for a successful post-war program in this field.

TRENTON, N.J., May 17 -- On the basis of unofficial returns Gov. Walter E. Edge of New Jersey and the ticket he led against "Republican against executive dictatorship" forces today won a better than five-to-one majority over his opponents in the State primaries for the Republican United States Senate and convention delegate-at-large nominations.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Foremen's Association of America (independent) ordered an end today of the strike of its members in thirteen Detroit war plants which has made idle 60,000 employes working on Army and Navy planes.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Disposition of Col. Frank Knox's controlling interest in The Chicago Daily News, Inc., was placed in the hands of three executors under the terms of the will of the late Secretary of the Navy filed in Probate Court today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 17 -- Mrs. J.B. Balding of the Cedar Creek Club led the way in the opening one-day tourney of the Women's Long Island Golf Association with a 44, 45 -- 89 at the Nassau Country Club today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 17 -- The first act in a program of mass extermination of Jews in Hungary is over, and 80,000 Jews of the Carpathian provinces have already disappeared. They have been sent to murder camps in Poland. This action was ordered by the Sztojay government and carried out by the newly appointed Governor of those provinces, Field Marshal Andreas Vincze.

New York University's hard-hitting baseball team assured itself of at least a tie for the Metropolitan Baseball Conference championship yesterday by defeating Brooklyn College, 17 to 5, on the loser's diamond.

The five-story brownstone business building at the southwest corner of Trinity Place and Liberty Street, through to Cedar Street, has been sold by the Irving Trust Company to an investing client of Irwin Colvin, broker. It fronts fify-three feet on Trinity Place, twenty-nine feet on Liberty Street and nineteen feet on Cedar Street, in a busy downtown retail store area.

Unless educators turn their attention to the post-war problems of youth as well as to the needs of returning war veterans, America will find itself with a new "lost generation on its doorstep," Prof. Howard Y. McClusky of the University of Michigan warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Nothing that was said to the striking Detroit foremen at the War Labor Board hearing today was new. They had been told before, and precisely, of the effect of their strike on the production of airplane engines in a category now more critical than ever.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- The Athletics, trying for a seventh straight victory before a crowd of 28,535 tonight, lost a 2-to-1 decision to the Tigers when Irv Hall booted Joe Hoover's roller with the bases filled and two out in the eighth. Both Detroit runs crossed on the error.

The fourth paragraph of your leading editorial on May 11 begins "The Ward election establishes that the union, contrary to the company's claim, still has a majority of the employes." Your issue of May 10 gives the following figures for unit No. 1: Employes eligible. 4,737; voted for CIO, 2,340.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 17 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants clubbed four Rochester hurlers for 18 hits to score a 10 -- 5 victory over the Red Wings today. Ken Miller, who relieved Andy Hansen in the fourth, turned in a sparkling relief job, holding the Wings to three hits in five and one-third innings. Andreas Fleitas led the Jersey attack with four hits.

With Orval Grove pitching a five-hitter and escaping from the few tight spots in which he found himself, the Yankees were blanked for the first time this year by the White Sox at the Stadium yesterday. The Chicagoans took advantage of Joe Page's early wildness to record a 4-0 victory that made it two straight for Jimmy Dykes' merry men from the Midway.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Several months in preparation, a "simplified" price regulation for sales of packaged dry groceries by processors, repackers, primary distributors and intermediate dealers will be forthcoming "in the near future," the Office of Price Administration reported today.

ALGIERS, May 17 -- Authoritative French quarters explained today that both Gen. The person who fostered the idea that college youths were a tradition-breaking, disrespectful, cynical lot has been proved wrong by this year's senior class at City College, it became known yesterday. The revolt in Tammany ended yesterday and the group supporting Edward V. The third, the crowning magnum opus of his life, "The Condition of Man,"* is published today.

Owing to a shortage of teaching personnel, a number of classes in the city's public school system are without teachers, either regular or substitute, Miss Mary E. Dillon, president of the Board of Education, revealed yesterday. In her first official action in her new post Miss Dillon declared that the dismissal of any large number of teachers at this time would be "disastrous."

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 17 -- The Humble Oil Company is legally entitled to the State reward of $50,000 and free oil leases on 40,000 acres of land for bringing in Florida's first commercial well, Attorney General Tom Watson has ruled.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat, of Montana, told the Senate today that "much information" on European political matters "is being withheld from the American people."

" Dream With Music," a musical comedy said to have cost $175,000, will have its premiere tonight at the Majestic. A large cast is headed by Vera Zorina, Ronald Graham and Joy Hodges. Among other principals are Robert Brink, Betty Allen, Leonard Elliott, Ralph Bunker.

Juan D. Peron, War Minister, in his capacity as Secretary of the Labor Department, ordered it to draw up "after necessary study a draft scheme for the organization of special labor courts."

An extensive property at the southwest corner of George and Albany Streets in New Brunswick, N.J., has been sold for cash above an existing mortgage of $209,945 by the Romipa Realty Corporation of Newark to the Lomil Realty Corporation of Jersey City.

Described in its foreword by Gen. H. H. Arnold, Commanding General of the Army Air Forces, as a "useful, accurate guide to our operations,'' "AAF -- The Official Guide to the Army Air Forces" will be published by Simon Schuster on July 1. The body of Miss Valsa Anna Matthai, 21-year-old student of Columbia University, who disappeared from her home at International House at 500 Riverside Drive during a snowstorm on March 20, was found in the Hudson River off Yonkers last evening.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 17 -- German propaganda boasts of indefinite possibilities of resistance on the southern Italian front finally gave way to military reality in today's communique.

LONDON, May 17 -- The German High Command is making a desperate effort to bring its defenses in the Reich as well as in France and the Low Countries to maximum strength for the Allied invasion, which, according to Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel, "will begin at any moment now."

ALBANY, May 17 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission has ordered a $4,704,045 write-off of original property cost by the Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company in the first original cost determination for a large operating company in the Niagara Hudson Power system.

PEARL HARBOR, May 17 -- In the shadow of Pacific Fleet submarine headquarters two days ago the United States submarine Tang, Lieut. Comdr. Richard Hetherington O'Kane commanding, slid up to the dock and ended the most dramatic and produc tive cruise of her career. Crowded into her with the normal crew were twenty-two flight officers and enlisted airmen rescued during the two-day task force strike on Truk April 29 and 30.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The first draft of a critical article on the Federal Communications Commission in preparation for the Reader's Digest, which was "warned" by James Lawrence Fly, FCC chairman, not to print it, was read today into the record of the Special House Committee investigating the FCC, together with a letter from Mr. Fly to DeWitt Wallace, editor of the Digest, protesting its proposed publication.

PITTSBURGH, May 17 -- Two storms, one of Pirate base hits and the other from rain-filled clouds over Forbes Field, tonight were too much for the Dodgers and their 18-year-old Choctaw-Irish rookie, Calvin McLish, who essayed his first professional baseball mound start tonight.

The procedure for restoring civil administration under national authority is established in the three agreements concluded in London with the exiled Governments of Norway, Belgium and the Netherlands. The protective committee for holders of Childs Company debentures headed by George J. Wise has informed the debenture holders that "substantial additional progress has been made" in working out the company's real estate problems.

Retail sales of furniture and home furnishings by independent dealers during the first quarter of this year decreased 2.1 per cent, compared with last year, Arthur Fertig Co. revealed yesterday. Department store sales, however, increased 7 per cent, due chiefly to a spurt in March, when sales were 20 per cent above those during the same month of last year, while sales by independent dealers declined 3 per cent.

Price Control Week began yesterday with a proclamation from Mayor La Guardia urging all citizens of New York to obey the rulings of the Office of Price Administration. Nation-wide observance of the week has been planned by consumer organizations to encourage housewives to write to their representatives in Congress demanding renewal of the Price Control Act.

LONDON, May 17 -- Pursuing the efforts they describe as a democratizing of the Polish Government here within the framework of Poland's authoritarian constitution, the members of the Polish National Council voted unanimously today to ask President Wladislaw Raczkiewicz to divest the Commander in Chief, the rightist Gen. Kasimierz Sosnkowski, of his political appointment as successor to the Presidency.

Although they represented only a small percentage of 35,767 original contestants, Government employes were disclosed yesterday to have captured ten of the seventeen prizes in a national essay contest on post-war employment problems sponsored by the Pabst Brewing Company.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Secretary James V. Forrestal, holding his first press conference as the new head of the Navy Department, declared today that American ability to operate at will 1,500 miles within enemy territory in the Pacific Ocean had reduced Japan's so-called outer defense bastions to a "nominal perimeter."

A plot of vacant land, 82 by 65 feet, at the northeast corner of Love Lane and College Place, in Brooklyn, has been sold by William H. Nicholls Co. to a client of the David Jaret Company for improvement after the war. It is assessed at $35,000.

Advances in quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange were checked yesterday by continued favorable weather in the cotton belt, and final prices were 1 to 3 points lower than on Tuesday with a steady undertone.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 17 (AP) -- The F.W. Woolworth Company's sales for the first four months of 1944 were $132,712,072, or 1.44 per cent above the same period a year ago, E.C. Mauchly, vice president and a director, told stockholders today at their annual meeting.

Owens-Illinois Glass Company has launched a six-week summer campaign on behalf of glass vacuum packed coffee. Full page ads featuring the glass coffee container will appear in national magazines during the period of the campaign and a five-day-a-week radio show has begun over a national network.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- In a statement issued here tonight, Mrs. Gretta Palmer said:

N. Peter Rathvon, president of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, reported yesterday in the annual statement covering 1943 a consolidated net profit of $6,965,005 after all charges including provision for income and excess profits taxes. Consolidated net profit the year before was $736,241.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- A 50 per cent over-all tax reduction when the war ends was set up today as the goal of the Republican Post-War Tax Study Committee. After a committee meeting, Chairman Daniel A. Reed of New York, issued a statement which said:
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- President Roosevelt signed the third extension of the Lend-Lease Act today and hailed the program as the symbol of Allied unity which will hasten the day of victory.

Thirteen resolutions on international trade and seven on transportation, all designed to increase post-war commerce between the United States and Latin America, among the Latin-American republics, and with the world at large, were adopted yesterday at committee meetings of the Conference of Commissions of Inter-American Development.

Our question has reference to here at home. This country's interest in the Russo-Polish dispute is basically determined by the American people's hopes and fears about the post-war world. But there is the special factor of our own large population of Polish descent.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Permanent long-range planning of the country's economy for the attainment of maximum prosperity after the war was urged in a resolution adopted today by the convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Realty trading in the Bronx yesterday was featured by sales of business buildings, one of which will be displaced by an apartment house after the war.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Vernon Kennedy limited Washington to four blows tonight as the Indians beat the Senators, 4 to 2, before 12,100 fans.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 17 (AP) -- The diplomatic exchange ships Gripsholm and Gradisca docked here today and the transfer of some 900 American and British prisoners of war for 900 German prisoners and civilians began immediately.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The heroism of an American airman, who, wounded and facing death as his crippled bomber plunged toward the sea, read from his pocket Bible to his wounded and dying mates, was revealed today with the War Department's posthumous award of the Distinguished Service Cross to Staff Sgt. Howard G. Collett of Thompsonville, Conn.

Business must be on guard against continued attempts by a group in the Office of Price Administration "to destroy the American system of brand names and trade marks" and to standardize products, Dr. Frederick J. Cullen, executive vice president of the Proprietary Association of America, said yesterday at the conclusion of the annual convention of the organization at the Hotel Biltmore.

Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee that investigated the Municipal Civil Service Commission and Paul J. Kern, its former president, received a verdict of $111,910 from a jury in Supreme Court yesterday after a two-week trial before Justice David K. Peck.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- An increase of 30 per cent during the last three months in child care facilities financed through funds provided under the Lanham act was reported today by Mrs. Florence Kerr, director of war public services of the Federal Works Agency.

An exhibition of 155 paintings and drawings by eighty-eight merchant seamen will be a feature of the National Maritime Day ceremonies on Monday afternoon at the National Maritime Union, 346 West Seventeenth Street. The work to be shown was done in the informal art classes inaugurated last July and conducted twice a week at the Union Hall by Alzira Peirce.

A canvass of taverns and package stores in behalf of the Greater New York Fund's 1944 campaign was decided upon yesterday by sales managers, distilling executives and liquor trade press editors at a meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 17 -- Army won easily from Penn today, 9 to 3. The cadets scored five runs in the first inning, when Jack Hennessey hit a home run to deep left field with one on base. Bechtel, starting pitcher for Penn, gave way to Ludwig after the fourth.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company announced yesterday plans for the refunding of its entire outstanding debt of $48,000,000. A special meeting of stockholders to approve the financing has been set for June 15. Under the proposed program the company would issue $30,000,000 of new mortgage bonds and $12,000,000 of sinking-fund debentures to replace the present debt, which carries interest rates of 5 and 6 per cent.
LONDON, Thursday, May 18 -- The German DNB agency said today that Cassino had been evacuated by the Germans.

NEWMARKET, England, May 17 (AP) -- Garden Path, favored at 5 to 1, won the classic 2,000 Guineas race before about 7,000 fans today, the first filly to capture the traditional Derby trial in forty-two years. Growing Confidence was second and Tehran third.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Amid a tumult raised by defendants and their lawyers, O. John Rogge, the prosecutor, today outlined the Government's sedition case to the jury, declaring he would link the defendants to the Nazi conspiracy to destroy democracy here and throughout the world.

Households continue to be slightly less productive each week as sources of waste paper for salvage, but the city's 1,400 office buildings and various commercial and industrial plants are more than making up the difference, officials of the War Production Board and Department of Sanitation reported yesterday. Increases in the tonnage totals of the weekly paper collections consequently have been maintained.

Having given New Yorkers a taste of almost all other forms of the theatre, from ballet to opera, the City Center last evening turned its attention to the romantic operetta. As the first of what it hopes will be a full summer season, it chose a revival of "The New Moon," the Romberg-Hammerstein-Mandel-Schwab hit of 1928.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 17 -- Opposition to the New Deal collapsed today in the South Carolina Democratic Convention, which chose an overwhelmingly pro-Roosevelt delegation to go to the national convention and by a fifty-vote margin defeated Eugene S. Blease of Newberry, anti-New Deal leader, in a race for chairman of the State executive committee.

The Queens School, a parents' cooperative undertaking to provide greater facilities for nursery and elementary schooling in central Queens, has obtained an option to lease the former clubhouse of the Queens Valley Golf Club on Union Turnpike, Kew Gardens, it was announced last night at an organization meeting in the parish house of Grace Church, Jamaica.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 17 (AP) -- Allied forces rolled the Japanese back east and west of the big enemy base of Myitkyina in north Burma today and a headquarters spokesman declared with optimism tonight that the Japanese on the eve of the monsoon period had been thrown on the defensive generally throughout the Indo-Burma theatre.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, who will make the principal speech at tonight's meeting of the New York County Republican Committee at the Central Commercial High School, disclosed yesterday the committee's new campaign song, "Yankee Dewey Dandy," written to the tune of "Yankee Doodle Dandy."

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., heads an underwriting group of sale of $10,000,000 of Quaker Oats Company twenty-year 2 5/8 per cent debentures, it was announced yesterday. The company has arranged also to sell $5,000,000 of one-to-ten-year 1 7/8 per cent serial notes to the First National Bank of Chicago and the Northern Trust Company of Chicago.

CHUNGKING, China, May 17 (AP) -- Japanese forces have swept sixty-five miles to the southwest of embattled Loyang in what appeared today to be a gigantic trap for Chinese forces clinging stubbornly to that Honan Province city despite furious infantry assaults.
BOSTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Red Sox today toppled the Browns, 5 -- 1, behind four-hit pitching by Tex Hughson but, in a wild second game of a double-header, the Sox were defeated, 12 -- 8.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Josephus Daniels, Secretary of the Navy during the Wilson Administration, endorsed unification of the armed forces before the House Committee on Post-War Military Policy today as a modernization movement which was years overdue.

The Continental Oil Company announced yesterday the declaration of a 30-cent dividend payable to common shareholders on June 26. Including the March 27 payment, dividends for the first half of this year total 60 cents a share, or 10 cents more than the amount disbursed in the corresponding period last year.

OMAHA, Neb., May 17 -- Major Lue Lozier, Washington, D.C., of the legal section, contract termination branch, Office of the Chief of Engineers, declared at the meetings of the National Association of Credit men here today that legislation on terminations will be necessary to dispel contractors' fears.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- To the list of activities for which irre placeable key men under 26 years of age may be granted occupational deferments on approval of State draft directors these additions were made today by Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service:

CHICAGO, May 17 -- So long as the fixed debt of the Illinois Central Railroad is at its present substantial size -- about $292,500,000 -- there will be no dividends on the common stock, J.L. Beven, president, told stockholders today at the annual meeting in the company's offices.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- President Roosevelt followed an easier routine of official duties today on the advice of his physician, Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, to keep the physical gain made during his South Carolina vacation.

Your leading editorial today is part of the material that will make certain a third World War. You hold out hope for the survival of Germany as a nation. You will not face the unpleasant fact that while Germany so survives there can never be permanent peace in the world.

STOCKHOLM, May 17 (Reuter) -- Denying a Swedish press report that a satisfactory settlement had been reached on the question of Swedish ballbearing exports, William Waring, commercial attache at the British Legation here, tonight said that Sweden's export of ballbearings to Germany broke the spirit of a decree passed in 1937 for preventing the export of war materials.

CLEVELAND, May 17 -- President Roosevelt called upon communities throughout the country today to give all possible encouragement to the home-front morale job of social workers in a message to the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare, which opened its annual session here tonight.

LONDON, May 17 -- Spain has ordered German and Japanese agents out of Tangier, across the strait from Gibraltar, and measures to limit the export of Spanish wolfram to Germany will soon be put into effect, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today.
CINCINNATI, May 17 (AP) -- Bucky Walters delivered a pinch double in the eighth today to give the Reds a 6-5 victory over the Phils, and the game was called a moment later on account of a heavy rain.

The fur market here has continued unsettled because of the recent proposed OPA regulations and only a limited amount of business has been done since the first of the month, according to the market bulletin of the United Fur Brokers.

After a lively discussion, the stockholders of the Sinclair Oil Corporation approved yesterday at their annual meeting the sale to H.F. Sinclair, president, of 150,000 shares of the company's stock at $13.25 a share. The vote on the resolution to sell the stock was 7,648,244 shares for and 835,959 against.

Cooking a complete dinner all in one pot, including dessert, may sound like a housewife's dream of Utopia but it proved a reality yesterday when Miss Betty Stafford, staff nutritionist of the New York State Emergency Food Commission's Westchester branch, gave a demonstration of "Big Nutrition -- Little Time" at the last in a series of Wednesday morning classes conducted by the commission's Wartime School for Housewives.

Gasoline stocks in the United States at the close of last week amounted to 87,623,000 barrels, a decline of 444,000 from the stock of 88,267,000 barrels that existed a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago they were 87,011,000 barrels.

LONDON, Thursday, May 18 (UP) -- Russian bombers, striking along a 255-mile front in their sixth successive night assault on enemy bases, attacked the White Russian capital of Minsk and two rail junctions in Eastern Poland Tuesday night.

Five men, four of them former civilian employes of the Brooklyn Army Base, pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn to a charge of stealing Government property. They were alleged to have taken 1,368 ship valves worth $5,000 on Jan. 19.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 16 (Delayed) -- The new Argentine Foreign Minister, Gen. Orlando L. Peluffo, today received the heads of all the foreign diplomatic missions that continue to maintain relations with the present Argentine Government.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 17 -- Lieut. McCain Smith, 28 years old, of Beachwood, N.J., and formerly of Washington, D.C., a nephew of Vice Admiral John S. McCain, Deputy Chief of Naval Operations for Air, was among the six officers and four enlisted men killed here yesterday in the crash of a training airship, according to an announcement by the Navy today. Lieutenant Smith leaves a wife.

Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran reported yesterday that twenty-five of the 375 employes under his jurisdiction held outside jobs, with his permission. Some of these, he said, worked only one hour a week on the extra jobs, while others worked only one night a week.

Only a slight relaxation of admission requirements for war veterans was advocated yesterday by Dr. Young B. Smith, dean of the Columbia University Law School, in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

Challenging the contention that mass production methods can be used to lower alleged high distribution costs, Q.F. Walker, economist for R.H. Macy Co., Inc., declared last night that the assembly-line technique is not feasible in the field of retailing.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Selective Service authorized tonight the deferment of students preparing for the ministry regardless of whether they are attending theological or divinity schools.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17 -- RKO will star Dorothy McGuire, on loan from David O. Selznick, in "The Enchanted Cottage," an adaptation by De Witt Bodeen of Sir Arthur Wing Pinero's English play of that title. The locale of the picture story, to be produced by Harriet Parsons, has been shifted to Salem, Mass.

AT A POLISH BIVOUAC ON EIGHTH ARMY FRONT, Italy, May 16 (Delayed) -- Northwest of Cassino, contained by the mountainous arc from Belmonte through the mighty Mount Cairo and on to Piedimonte, the men who remember what happened to Warsaw in September, 1939, are fighting one of the grimmest phases of the resurgent battle of Italy.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, May 17 -- The Allies are now strong enough to undertake major offensives in the Pacific and Atlantic simultaneously. There are strong indications that blows at widely separated points in the Pacific will be timed with the opening of the offensive against western Europe.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, May 17 -- The Allies are now strong enough to undertake major offensives in the Pacific and Atlantic simultaneously. There are strong indications that blows at widely separated points in the Pacific will be timed with the opening of the offensive against western Europe.

Twentieth Century-Fox has acquired the screen rights to "Leave Her to Heaven," a forthcoming novel by Ben Ames Williams, for a reported $100,000. The sale was negotiated here through the author's agent, Annie Laurie Williams.
A suggestion that may interest fishermen with spare gear lying around is made by S.G.H. It is that they put it to work by selling it, because reels, especially, are at a premium now.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Jolly Cholly Grimm, who a few days ago was driving nails in the heels of his shoes to bring luck to his Cubs, was all for driving a few into the heads of his hapless helpers today to bring an end to his miseries as his club crashed down to another defeat.

At last we have reached a stage of the war in which the United Nations communiques cannot keep up with the achievements of the advancing troops. The map changes hourly. Bloody Cassino is cut off and falls. Esperia and Formia, but lately brought under fire, are in our hands.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- To treat mental breakdowns at their very inception on the battlefield, the Navy has established a large neuro-psychiatric hospital in one of our operating theatres "to receive the man who breaks down in combat circumstances in the shortest possible time," Rear Admiral Ross T. McIntire, Surgeon General, informed the closing sessions of the American Psychiatric Association today.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Department store sales for the week ended May 13 were 31 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of 1943, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WITH THE POLISH FORCES, Northwest of Cassino, May 18 -Polish troops who took the monastery between 10 and 10:30 this morning, and thus share with the British the honor of cracking the Cassino nut once and for all, attained their objective in two nights and a day of fighting whose savagery can only be attested by a tour of the mountain battlefield.

New officers were elected yesterday at the five-day conference of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The conference terminates today. Miss Cecil Lester Jones of Washington was elected president of the association to succeed Mrs. Linville K. Martin of Winston-Salem, N.C.

LONDON, May 18 -- It is now possible to describe from here the part the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces played in depriving the German commander of supplies to meet the land assault on Cassino, the fortress that had delayed the Allies' progress so long.

A seven-point program to cover disposition of surplus American automotive equipment located overseas after the war was announced yesterday by the Overseas Automotive Club. The plan, believed to be the first presented to prevent disruption of export markets, will be forwarded to the Foreign Economic Administration and other Governmental agencies.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The War Labor Board, carrying out its promise to the Foremen's Association of America, decided today to name a panel to hear grievances of the men whose dispute jeopardized the Army and Navy aircraft construction program by halting the work of nearly 60,000 employes in Detroit factories.

Pronouncements of its committee on world peace and its social service committee condemning fascism at home and abroad were adopted yesterday by the New York East Methodist Conference, which ended its annual sessions at Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, at St. Felix Street. Brooklyn.
CHUNGKING, China, May 18 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Sewell L. Avery, chairman of the board of Montgomery Ward Co., filed suit in Federal District Court today for a $1,000,000 judgment against Marshall Field, charging malicious publication of an untrue and defamatory article in his Chicago Sun.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., May 18 -- The Times-Leader-Evening News will resume publication tomorrow afternoon, and The Wilkes-Barre Record on Saturday morning, it was announced by the Wilkes-Barre Publishing Company tonight after an agreement was reached with printers terminating a strike which began May 8 over a contract dispute.

TULSA, Okla., May 18 (AP) -- The bulk of primary power generated at the Denison Dam will be sold to the Texas Power and Light Company for the duration of the war under a contract announced today by Douglas G. Wright, Southwestern Power Administrator.

Although the New York County Committee adopted no resolution endorsing Governor Dewey for the Republican nomination for President at its meeting last evening in the Commercial High School, 214 East Forty-second Street, most of the speakers assumed that the Governor's nomination was certain.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE IN ENGLAND, May 18 (AP) -- Honors were showered today on a Flying Fortress group commanded by Col. Harry Leber Jr. of 159 Riverside Drive, New York City, which recently passed the 100mission mark.

On three dates this summer all-night sailing will be permitted on Long Island Sound. The Coast Guard has been considering the move for some time and yesterday confirmed a decision to permit sunset-to-sunrise use of the waters between the Westchester and Connecticut shores on the one hand and Long Island on the other on the nights of June 17, July 8 and Aug. 5.

LONDON, May 19 (Reuter) -- So efficient has the spy system of the Dutch patriots become that Quislings no longer dare denounce underground workers to the Germans, it was revealed in Vrij Nederland, Dutch newspaper published here.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Fourteen household articles, mostly novelties and bric-a-brac, were removed from price control today by the Office of Price Administration.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 18 (AP) -- Allied invasion of Adolf Hitler's fortress may give the Finnish Opposition to Premier Edwin Linkomies' Cabinet the lever needed to oust it in favor of a Government willing to make peace with Russia, an Opposition leader said today.
BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Red Sox slapped three St. Louis pitchers for fifteen hits and a decisive 12-to-1 victory today, gaining an even split in the four-game series.

Gertrude Lawrence, who now is definitely under contract to star in "Errand for Bernice," has left these shores and is in England, it became known yesterday. She went there to help out ENSA (Entertainment National Service Association), the British Government agency providing fun for the fighting services and defense workers.

ABOARD THE GRIPSHOLM at Barcelona, Spain, May 18 (AP) -Nazi Germany, apparently expecting the Allies to smash through the Atlantic wall defenses, is concentrating on completion of a second great system of fortifications deep in France, and has told her soldiers that the line must be held "until the last man."

On the first three business days of next week, the Treasury made known late yesterday, it will make substantial withdrawals from Government war-loan accounts in the principal commercial banks of the nation. The withdrawals in the aggregate, will be equivalent to 6 1/2 per cent of the war loan accounts in these banks as of the close of business on Tuesday of this week.

The American people, who have "too long been afflicted with provincialism," must become international in their thinking if they want to participate in post-war adult education on an international basis, speakers agreed yesterday at the closing meeting of a two-day annual conference of the American Association for Adult Education at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The resignation of Louis R. Glavis as chief investigator for a Senate subcommittee investigating the Rural Electrification Administration was reported late today after the subcommittee heard that Mr. Glavis had produced evidence which was challenged as not authentic.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that results of the investigation of affairs in Bolivia now being made by Avra M. Warren, United States Ambassador to Panama, would be communicated to the other American republics in line with their agreement to keep one another informed of their information and views concerning that country.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Directors of the International Harvester Company increased today the quarterly dividend rate from 50 to 65 cents a share "to restore normal balance in the interests of stockholders, employes and customers."

ATLANTA, May 18 -- Four thousand messengers at the Baptist convention adopted a recommendchurches work for "the defense and churches work for the defense and protection of all the civil rights of Negroes."
LONDON, May 18 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Warning that reliance upon a four-power military alliance to safeguard the peace of the future would involve the United States in a policy of imperialism that would culminate in a third World War, Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, appealed last night for this country to take the lead in the formation of a truly international organization for peace.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- At the close of a day of debate which was stormy at times, the House passed its own version of the G.I. Bill of Rights this afternoon, 387 to 0.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The War Production Board, in an effort to achieve maximum output of a critical item, directed producers of cotton duck yarns today to manufacture and deliver as much yarn each week, beginning May 21, as they did in their week of greatest production so far this year.

The revived recovery in stocks took on fresh momentum yesterday mostly because of a demand for low-priced issues. Some of the recent speculative favorites quieted down under the pressure of profit-taking and again there appeared considerable reluctance by long-term investors to venture into the pivotal stocks.

An increase of 150 per cent in its advertising and promotional budget for the last six months of 1944 was announced, by CP gas range manufacturers through Lloyd C. Ginn, chairman of the executive committee. The larger budget will allow wider coverage of architects, builders, furniture, hardware, department store and other appliance dealers.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The War Department announced today a tentative list of sixty-four sick or wounded American soldiers, who have been prisoners of Germany, who are being repatriated aboard the exchange ship Gripsholm due to arrive in the United States early next month.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Queen Elizabeth of England, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek of China and Mme. Vyacheslaff Molotoff of Russia will join in a radio appeal backing the $16,000,000,000 Fifth United States War Loan drive which starts June 12, Ted R. Gamble, National War Finance Director, said today.
CHUNGKING, China, May 18 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

A wider variety of fresh fruit, which has been limited so far this season, is beginning to come to market. Shoppers this week-end should find a better choice than heretofore, even though prices still remain high for the most part.

NEWARK, N.J., May 18 -- After thirty-three hours' deliberation yesterday and today, a jury of eight women and four men in Federal court here returned tonight guilty verdicts against nine defendants, including two corporations, accused of conspiracy to avoid registration with the State Department as agents of the Nazi government; acquitted five other individuals and disagreed on the guilt or innocence of three more.
James J. Farrelly, formerly chief clerk of the Public National Bank and Trust Company of New York, has been promoted to assistant cashier.
Robert F. de Graff of Pocket Books, Inc., has a few words to say on our own few words about James Marshall's recent plan for paper-bound textbooks in the schools. Mr. de Graff writes:

One of the most interesting sidelights of the ILO convention at Philadelphia was found in a recent news item published in THE TIMES in which Vicente Lombardo Toledano, Mexico's delegate, voiced several serious charges anent the recent attempt upon the life of President Camacho.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- In an unfurnished thirty-room mansion on Massachusetts Avenue's "Embassy Row," a "Hebrew Committee for National Liberation" set up today what it called an "unofficial embassy" for a proposed "really independent Hebrew Nation in Palestine," and announced plans for seeking a "co-belligerent status" with the United Nations in fighting the Axis powers.

New York's public school system has not only successfully adjusted itself to the demands imposed by global war, but is already hard at work preparing its students to become better citizens in the post-war world, Dr. John E. Wade, superintendent of schools, declared yesterday in his annual report.

Three key men in the American war effort appeared before a committee of the Senate yesterday to discuss the problem of manpower as that problem shapes itself today, on the eve of the invasion of Western Europe and the launching of new and greater offensives in the Pacific.

A pleasant contribution to fishing literature makes its United States bow today with the publication of John D. Robins' "The Incomplete Anglers" (Duell, Sloan Pearce, Inc., $3). It appeared first in Canada and won considerable applause.

One of the saddest features of the martyrdom of Europe's Jews is that it is taking place in some areas that were once places of refuge. In the long ages of sporadic persecution the Jews went where they were allowed to work and survive. Hence the large Jewish population of Poland.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 18 -Leon Koslowski, who was Premier of Poland during the Pilsudski regime, died in Berlin on May 11, it was announced today, after injuries suffered in an Allied air raid that destroyed his hotel.

Reporting on operations of the Bendix Aviation Corporation in the fiscal year ended with last September, Ernest R. Breech, president, informed stockholders yesterday that the company doubled its output of the previous year. Consolidated gross sales, royalties and other operating income, less discounts, returns and allowances, rose to $918,753,465 from $465,980,768 for the previous fiscal year.

The American Standards Association announced yesterday that it had adopted a new building code standard for use by cities and towns throughout the country. Its purpose is to provide a suitable form of organization for building departments, and for efficient administration of building code work.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, May 18 (Netherland News Agency) -- A Roman Catholic Bishop and fifty-nine other missionaries were killed or fatally injured when Allied planes strafed a Japanese prison ship off the New Guinea coast, it was said here today by a Dutch priest, the Very Rev. Willem Van Baar, Superior in Australia of the Society of the Divine Word.

The ten-story apartment house at 3770-78 Broadway, southeast corner of 157th Street, has been purchased by Charles Walzer, operator, through Herman A. Acker, broker. It is on a plot 125 by 100 feet and is assessed at $410,000. Goodman Mabel were the attorneys for the buyer of the property, which contains four stores and seventy-four apartments of three to seven rooms each.
For the second successive year, Warren A. Dow of the New York Athletic Club and Alfred Snyder of the home club met in a fence-off for the national foil championship last night at the Fencers Club.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -An abundant supply of most foods for civilians during the next few months was predicted by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics today. The bureau cautioned that a tighter situation might develop later in the year.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to have increased during the week to new high records.

Mount St. Michael demonstrated its superiority in the senior division of the Bronx-Manhattan-Westchester C.H.S.A.A. track and field championships for the third straight year yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. Ernie Hjertherg's lads amassed 51 1/2 points to 40 1/2 for their nearest rival, La Salle Academy.

IN Mississippi's rich black-earth country between the forks of the Big and Little Deer Rivers in the Eighteen Thirties the cotton bloomed with ripe luxuriance. The great homes of the plantation aristocracy were centers of good food, good times and good living. Hospitality was fresh and gracious, courtesy and kindness were habitual and gregarious sociability was taken for granted.

PEARL HARBOR, May 18 (AP) -Far-reaching American warplanes pounded Wake Island in a daylight raid and probably sank two sizable Japanese ships in Truk harbor, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation yesterday designating Monday as National Maritime Day and calling upon all citizens to observe one minute of silence, starting at 11 A.M., to honor merchant seamen lost through enemy action and pray for the safety of those still in service.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Liquidation of a large line of July rye that brokers attributed to a professional trader who had been operating on the bull side carried the nearby future of that grain off to a new low on the current movement and December to a new seasonal low in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.

LONDON, May 18 -- Gen. Karl Rudolf Gerd von Rundstedt, veteran of the Polish, French and Russian fronts, has been named supreme commander of Germany's anti-invasion forces in the West, the German Transocean News Agency announced tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 18 -- An amazing story of how a patrol of British officers captured Maj. Gen. Karl Heinrich Kreipe, commander of the Twenty-second Panzer Grenadier Division, within gunshot of his headquarters at Candia, in Crete, and spirited him away from the island was told today after his arrival in Cairo.

President Roosevelt, Vice President Henry A. Wallace and Senator Robert F. Wagner are scheduled for renomination at tomorrow's session of the State Convention of the Liberal party at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A preinvasion warning to the American people, the press and the radio to be particularly wary of enemy propaganda during this "tense" period when the War Department cannot even hint as to its plans was issued today by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson.
ST. LOUIS, May 18 (AP) -- Scoring two runs on one of their only two hits, the Cardinals defeated the Braves, 2 to 0, tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -Leonard Warren, Metropolitan Opera baritone, and Blanche Thebom, Canton (Ohio) mezzo soprano, have been signed by Twentieth Century-Fox for "Irish Eyes Are Smiling," the musical based on the life of the late Ernest Ball.

PITTSBURGH, May 18 -- The Dodgers' machine, in common with other civilian vehicles, can't operate successfully without replacements, and never was that fact more forcibly demonstrated than in Forbes Field today.

Concerned over living conditions of migrant workers in their State, the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs approved yesterday a resolution asking the Governor to obtain an interpretation of laws applying to this group, in order to define responsibility for regulation and management of migrant settlements.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A summary of legal requirements for voting by soldiers in party primaries to be held in nineteen States in July and August was made public today by the War Department. It has been forwarded to all Army posts, camps and stations for the information of servicemen who desire to participate in these elections.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Seasonal declines in prices for fresh fruits and vegetables together with lower ceiling prices for heavy hogs were largely responsible for a decline of 0.1 per cent in commodity prices in primary markets during the week ended last Saturday.

N.S. Timasheff, Professor of Sociology at Fordham University, predicted yesterday in an article that an eventual rapprochement between the Vatican and the Soviet Government was possible if the Roman Catholic Church received the same rights now held by the Russian Orthodox Church.
Joseph B. Ely, former Governor of Massachusetts, and Mrs. Ely have arrived from their home in Westfield and are at the Biltmore.

Late yesterday afternoon neighbors kept pushing open the door of the Richies' ground-floor flat in the tenement at 327 East Eightyninth Street to ask about the twins. Irene and Richard Richie, 5 years old, had been drowned in the East River off Ninety-second Street on Wednesday.

Extensive courses in radio for New York City high school teachers and students will be started next fall by the Board of Education in cooperation with the National Broadcasting Company, it was announced yesterday by Dr. James Rowland Angell, NBC public service counselor and president emeritus of Yale University.

Selling of government securities, in anticipation of the Fifth War Loan drive, much of which came from commercial banks in connection with adjustments of reserve positions, required the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System to buy $559,521,000 of United States Government securities in the open market in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, May 19 (AP) -- General MacArthur, announcing the one-two strike today, forecast the early fall of the remaining Netherlands New Guinea territory between him and his avowed return to the Philippines.

Reiterating his denial that he had suggested to Mrs. Gretta Palmer that she write for The Reader's Digest a critical article on the Federal Communications Commission, Wendell Willkie revealed yesterday that on legal grounds he had advised several radio companies not to fight the commission's rules directed against monopoly in chain broadcasting.

Directors of the Southern Pacific Company at a meeting held here yesterday authorized the redemption at par and accrued interest on Dec. 1, next, of all the company's Central Pacific stock collateral 4 per cent bonds, due Aug. 1, 1949.

NO branch of our huge Army and Navy has placed a greater premium on sports as the perfect physical conditioner than naval aviation. When Comdr. Tom Hamilton set up his Pre-Flight program a couple of years ago, he remarked that it would take considerable time for his theories to be confirmed by actual statistics.

LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- Seven Royal Air Force fliers, participants in some of the RAF's most spectacular operations, including the Battle of Britain, were shot trying to escape from their German prison camp near Dresden on March 25, it was learned here today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission today extended until May 24 the period in which the American Utilities Service Corporation may complete the transfer of its interest in the Northwestern Illinois Utilities to Fred D. Ellis and Edmund J. Haugh for $840,000.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Constantine Ponlos and Charles Olson of the Office of War Infor'mation's Foreign Language SecJ tion resigned today with the assertion that George W. Healy Jr., OWI domestic director, had "hamstrung" the activities of their division. Mr. Healy quickly issued aI statement declaring the claim untrue.

The first Conference of Commissions of Inter-American Development closed its ten-day meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday with unanimous ratification by the delegations from all twenty-one American republics of forty-three resolutions designed to expand post-war hemispheric trade and industry, but with assurances to the rest of the world that no exclusive regional bloc is contemplated which might arouse economic rivalries and sow the seeds of a third world war.

A syndicate of investors represented by Robert Netter, attorney, bought the six-story apartment house at 2770-80 Kingsbridge Terrace, in the Bronx, from the East River Savings Bank. Assessed at $235,000, the property is 150 by 112.5 feet and has suites for seventy-two families.

Prices of cotton for future delivery lost 5 to 8 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, influenced by increasing likelihood that Congress will pass the Price Control Act without amendments to lift the ceilings on cotton goods and on the continued favorable weather in the Cotton Belt.

The Henry Hadley medal "for outstanding services to American music" was presented to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by the National Association of American Composers and Conductors at a ceremony held in the Mayor's office at City Hall. Sigmund Spaeth, president of the association, made the presentation.

LONDON, May 18 -- Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia denied today all "implications" that Australians were drifting away from the British Empire. He spoke at a luncheon where he was a guest of honor and in the presence of Prime Minister Churchill and the Duke of Gloucester, brother of King George VI, who is Governor General designate of Australia.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Roosevelt discussed domestic and international post-war plans with two groups today and heard reports from John G. Winant, Ambassador to Great Britain, who returned here a few days ago.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Three national war leaders, James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, Robert P. Patterson, Undersecretary of War, and Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, strongly urged the Senate Military Affairs Committee today to report to the Senate work-or-fight legislation to meet war labor requirements.

Chief City Magistrate Henry H. Curran told Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine in a letter yesterday those "pestilential sidewalk photographers" that have been defrauding servicemen under the guise of taking their pictures -- and pocketing $1 from each without a return -- should be arrested and sent to the lock-up for a week or two as roustabouts."

Ninety-nine Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson predicted today that the real fight in Italy would come when the Allies hit the Adolf Hitler Line in the fortified mountains behind the present front.

DETROIT, May 15 (AP) -- A short-lived strike of 10,000 interstate and intrastate truck drivers was called off tonight following a three-way conference of regional War Labor Board officials and spokesmen for rival AFL and CIO unions. The parley also averted a threat of a general strike of the city's 35,000 drivers.
NAPLES, May 18 (AP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, May 18 -- After leap-frogging another 125 miles closer to the Philippines, United States infantry have seized the smaller of the two islands in the Wakde group after an amphibious operation that established a beachhead on the near-by New Guinea coast west of Hollandia.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 18 -- The Buenos Aires police have arrested five men -- including Dr. Frederico Pinedo, former Minister of Finance -- who are presumed to be the ringleaders of a plan to stage a silent protest against the Argentine Government on the first anniversary of the June Fourth revolution.

Alex Barth, the Millbrook Stable's dark bay gelding that used to scamper around in sprint races under the name of Poacher, was easily best of the four that ran in the $5,000 added Stromboli Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.
CINCINNATI, May 18 (AP) -- Ken Raffensberger outpitched Bucky Walters tonight as the Phillies blanked the Reds, 2 to 0.

ALGIERS, May 18 -- In Algiers, where there is perhaps a more realistic appreciation of the French situation than elsewhere, there is a marked disposition today in official and informed quarters on both the French and the Allied sides to agree on these propositions:

Declaring that the anticipated high level of business activity in the United States in the post-war period will make for a sharp increase in international trade, H.B. McCoy, chief of the industrial economy division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, said yesterday that both small and large producers should regard exports as an important factor in their post-war planning.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Senators bunched their blows to defeat Cleveland, 4 to 2, tonight behind Dutch Leonard's effective hurling. The victory was Washington's third in the four-game series and placed the Senators only 9 percentage points behind the first-place Yankees.

CHUNGKING, China, May 18 (AP) -- Chinese troops have hurled back determined Japanese counterattacks in the sweeping Salween River offensive aimed at juncture with Chinese-American forces in Burma, and have tightened the prongs of a pincers threatening an enemy-held stretch of the Burma Road, the High Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- American Army planes have destroyed or damaged 32,149 enemy planes in the air and on the ground -- of which 20,174 were definitely destroyed -- since Dec. 7, 1941; our losses from enemy action for the period through May 15, 1944, were 6,154 planes, General Henry H. Arnold, commander of the United States Army Air Forces, said today.
Ira A. Harap has resigned as manager of the paint department of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, Brooklyn, to become sales manager of trade sales for the Far-boil Paint Company, Inc., Baltimore.

Frank C. Moore, New York State Controller, sold yesterday, through competitive bidding, $7,076,920 of various blocks of New York State municipal bonds held by a number of the State's sinking funds. Of the total offering about $4,715,000 consisted of New York City serial bonds and corporate stock, most of which went to the Chase National Bank, the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and the First Boston Corporation, bidding separately.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Directors of the Continental Can Company, Inc., have approved a "model" group insurance plan featuring comprehensive coverages at low cost to employes, Carle C. Conway, president and chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Sugar rations for industrial users were increased today for the second quarter of this year to 80 per cent of their consumption in the second quarter of 1941, as compared with the present 70 per cent.

Like a thoroughbred in a stake race, the White Sox roared down the stretch at the Stadium yesterday and came from virtually nowhere to inflict a third straight setback upon the Yankees, 8 to 4. Going into the eighth inning, the visitors trailed, 4 -- 1, even though they had been hitting Tiny Bonham consistently, but presently they pulled even and then unevened the situation with a four-run outburst in the tenth.

LONDON, Friday, May 19 (AP) -The Russians announced today the capture of "a height of considerable importance" southeast of Stanislav in Poland, and the slaughter of 600 Germans who had made an abortive counter-attack in the lower Dniester campaign northwest of Tiraspol.
LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended May 17 reported a decrease in note circulation of 2,932,000.

WITH THE CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES ATTACKING MYITKYINA, Burma, May 17 (Delayed) -- Into the little jungle headquarters of Brig. Gen. Frank Merrill in the hills above Myitkyina today came the laconic message "cafeteria lunch," a prearranged code phrase that announced the capture of the main airdrome of Myitkyina.

LONDON, Friday, May 19 (U.P.) -- King Peter of Yugoslavia has dismissed his Yugoslav Government in Exile and has invited Dr. Ivan Subasitch, recently returned from the United States, to form a new Ministry in an attempt to end the war-long dissension that has led patriot forces in Yugoslavia to fight each other as well as the Germans, usually reliable sources said early today.

Bernard M. Baruch, adviser to the Office of War Mobilization, will receive the 1944 gold medal of the National Institute of Social Sciences "for distinguished service to humanity and the nation," it was announced yesterday by C.M. Chester, president of the institute.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 18 (U.P.) -- Arthur Yencken, British Minister to Madrid, was reported killed today when his plane crashed in a mountain village near Zaragoza, 165 miles northwest of here, according to official information. He was 49 years old.

LONDON, May 18 -- Martial law was imposed at Istanbul today because of unconstitutional activities of the Turkish pro-Nazi organization, "Pan-Turanian," which caused public demonstrations, said an Ankara broadcast tonight recorded by the British Ministry of Information.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP) -- Rufe Gentry pitched shut-out ball and batted across the only run as the Tigers made it two in a row over the Athletics, with a 1-0 victory before a ladies' day crowd of 10,621 today.
OTTAWA, May 18 -- Relaxation of foreign exchange regulations for Canadian visiting the United States were announced today by Hon. J.L. Ilsley, Minister of Finance.

The Fort Hamilton Arena, oldest outdoor boxing club in the city from the standpoint of continuous operation, opened another season last night with a program witnessed by a crowd of 4,000 fans. Cleo Shans, Los Angeles, headlined the card, and he defeated Leo Dulmaine of Worcester in the eight-round feature.
LONDON, May 18 -- Although today's stock market business again was on a small scale, the tone throughout generally was firm.

The second meeting of the National Post-war Conference, consisting of leaders and policy-makers of twenty-two organizations, including major business, labor and farm groups, will be held at the St. Moritz Hotel today and tomorrow, with morning, noon and night sessions. The first meeting was held last February in Atlantic City, N.J.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he expected to confer with representatives of the medical societies of the five boroughs before establishing his health insurance plan for individuals living or working in New York and earning up to $5,000 annually.

CLEVELAND, May 18 -- Surveys made in the last two years in twenty-one American cities emphasized the need for revision of social welfare, youth and educational programs, delegates to the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare were told today.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 18 (AP) -- Merger of the Virginia Public Service Company with the Virginia Electric and Power Company virtually appeared assured today, after the announcement by William E. Wood of Alexandria, president of the VPS, that common shares had been voted 100 per cent and preferred, slightly more than 86 per cent, in favor of the plan.

CHUNGKING, China, Friday May 19 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced today that it had inflicted heavy casualties on a Japanese armored column closing a trap on large Chinese forces in western Honan Province, while the threatened defenders to the east were last reported holding grimly to the ancient city of Loyang.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 18 (AP) -- Settlement of the censorship dispute between the Commonwealth Government and six major Australian newspapers was announced tonight by acting Prime Minister Francis E. Forde.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Dr. Hazel K. Stiebeling was appointed today chief of the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture, effective June 30, to succeed Dr. Henry C. Sherman, who will return to Columbia University.

A proposal to condemn an additional 1,350 acres at Idlewild, Queens, to expand to 4,500 acres the site for the huge municipal airport now under construction there, will come before the Board of Estimate for public hearing next Thursday, it was disclosed yesterday.

OMAHA, Neb., May 18 -- The price stabilization policy has been reasonably successful "in holding the line," Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, Washington, D.C., told the National Association of Creditmen at their concluding session today.

Charging that full responsibility for the huge black market in gasoline rested solely on Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Administrator, and Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, James A. Moffett, veteran oil executive and former Housing Administrator, said yesterday at a press conference here that the control of the oil industry should be returned to its executives and that they could "clean it up" in a few weeks if permitted to do so.
The following is the text of Sumner Welles' address on "The Shaping of the Future," delivered last evening in the New York Times Hall:

To The Club of Queer Trades founded by Chesterton, which Dickens was perhaps better entitled to found, should be added that of professional dried-egg taster. This is the foundation of an article in The Statesman and Nation of London. Or shouldn't such tasting be classified as a fine art rather than a trade? To differentiate one brand, class or state of powdered eggs from another must call for a supersensitive, almost an over-educated taste.

It is obvious that when Richard Kollmar decides to put on a show, he does so with an open checkbook and a liberal pen. His "Dream With Music," which came last evening to the Majestic, has settings and costumes which must have cost a fortune -- and look like it.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 18 (AP) -- The Delaware Racing Commission approved today Delaware Park's request for permission to abolish the daily double, with the commission reserving the right "to reinstate the daily double pool in the event that the interest of the public and the State revenue make it advisable."

NAPLES, May 18 -- Cassino and its dominating feature, Monastery Hill, fell to the Eighth Army this forenoon. Thus the last strong-hold of the Gustav Line and the point on which the formidable German bastion was anchored crumbled, and with a speed that only the most optimistic would have thought possible when the attack started six days ago.

Spokesmen for labor and industry agreed last night on the need for the nation to set its sights for a post-war level of employment of 50,000,000 to 55,000,000 persons to maintain peacetime production and consumption on the scale developed in wartime.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 13 were 868,309 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 31,331 cars, or 3.7 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 19,277 cars, or 2.3 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 29,255 cars, or 3.5 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two yeasr ago.

George Horne's story in yesterday's TIMES of the rescue of our Navy fliers off Truk last April by the submarine Tang is only one of its kind, although one of the most thrilling, that has come out of the Pacific over the last two and a half years. Time and again our fliers and Navy personnel have risked their planes, their ships and their lives on such rescue missions.

LONDON, May 18 -- Specially prepared rations of hard candy, chewy candy, gumdrops and chewing gum are being issued to United States airmen before they take off on long flights over Europe, because it has been proved that they enable bomber crews to fight off fatigue and bitterly cold temperatures prevailing at high altitudes.

LONDON, Friday, May 19 (U.P.) -Powerful Italy-based United States air armadas, totaling up to 1,500 heavy bombers and fighters, blasted the Rumanian oil and rail center of Ploesti and freight assembly yards at Belgrade and Nish in Yugoslavia yesterday in a new blow to cripple the Nazis' Balkan communications.
LONDON, May 18 -- Two new types of warplanes, so unorthodox in wing design as to give the impression they are flying backward, have been produced here, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -President Harvey N. Davis of the Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, N.J., said today that he wished to devote his full time to the institute and had submitted his resignation as director of the War Production Board's Office of Production and Research, although told in advance that the WPB chairman, Donald M. Nelson, was unwilling to accept it.

AT THE ABBEY OF MOUNT CASSINO, May 18 -- This monastery, the retreat that Saint Benedict first established long centuries ago, is dead, like so much of Italy these days. It has been gutted and cracked and only one corner, the northeast, has an intact perpendicular.

Plans for celebrating the one hundredth anniversary of Congregation Emanu-El in the fall of 1944 and the spring of 1945 were formulated last night by a "Committee of One Hundred" meeting at the Community House of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, under the chairmanship of Roger W. Straus.

Consolidated net income of Pullman, Inc., for the first quarter of this year was $2,251,209 or 70 cents a share, David A. Crawford, president, reported in the statement of operations issued for publication today.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- Hogs outside the Government's support brackets showed gains of 15 cents in moderately active trade today. The report of the War Food Administration follows:
