HEADQUARTERS OF THE CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, Salween Front, May 18 -After five days of fighting Tatangtzu, a small town west of the Salween River and twenty-one miles from Tengyueh, a Burma road objective of the present Chinese drive, remains the most fiercely contested point on the 100-mile Yunman-Burma border offensive front.

JERUSALEM, May 18 -- Marshal Joseph Stalin has just won a minor tactical victory in Palestine that will undoubtedly have much spiritual importance among religion-conscious Russians as the outcome of an agreement by a small group of orthodox monks and nuns here to recognize the authority of the Metropolitan of Moscow and to accept official Russian administration of highly valuable religious property inside Jerusalem.

DETROIT, May 18 -- Plans to give 50,000 Michigan civilians free blood plasma each year have been worked out through a joint project of the American Red Cross and the State Department of Health. Distribution is already under way and treatment has been accorded to 299 adults and 47 infants.

Accused of conducting a loan business in which interest at the rate of 365 per cent a year was charged, Samuel Jacobs, 47 years old, who operates the Rex Trading Corporation at 1400 Broadway, mostly as a check-cashing concern, was released in $5,000 bail and his bookkeeper, Mildred Korman, 25, of 1413 Rosedale Avenue, the Bronx, in $500 bail yesterday by Justice Bernard Kozicke for trial on June 20 in Special Sessions.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The status on May 1 of the country's 22,216,809 selective service registrants 18 through 37 years old was disclosed as follows today by the Selective Service system at the Senate Military Affairs Committee hearing on work-or-fight legislation:

Seeking to encourage 10 per cent more New Yorkers to plant victory gardens this year than last season, the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office already has helped start 527 "allotment gardens" in all five boroughs, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Members of the Biscuit and Cracker Manufacturers Association, holding their annual meeting here, were warned today by J.T. McCarthy, president of the American Bakers Association, that efforts by segments in the industry to obtain special treatment on rationed items would disrupt the unity of effort shown during the last three years.

Initial reports yesterday on the autopsy performed on the body of Miss Valsa Anna Matthai, whose body was found in the Hudson River off Yonkers on Wednesday, indicated death by drowning. The Medical Examiner said a final report will not be made until chemical analysis of vital organs is completed.
FORT DIX, N.J., May 18 (AP) -Fort Dix revealed today that it was conducting a little recruiting campaign of its own -- for men and women willing to work for the Army and still remain civilians.

With their eyes twinkling in anticipation, two little women sat up straight in their chairs in a two-room suite in the Hotel Woodstock, 127 West Forty-third Street, at 8 o'clock last night, all dressed up with some place to go.

NEWARK, N.J., May 18 -Only four husbands in the country are getting War Department dependency benefits because of wives enlisted in the Wac, Brig. Gen. H.N. Gilbert, Office of Dependency Benefits director, said today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The official activities of James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, have long been a source of suspicion and perplexity to those in public life who believe that no other administration has played power politics as ruthlessly as Mr. Roosevelt's and that Mr. Fly is one of the most effective players.

With production of Army tanks by the company virtually completed the American Locomotive Company has on its books orders for "several hundred" steam locomotives for Russia which may be increased substantially in the near future, William C. Dickerman, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday.

Announcing that he had not yet read "The First Lady Chatterley," D.H. Lawrence's novel that is charged by the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice with being "obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, indecent and disgusting," Magistrate Charles G. Keutgen yesterday reserved decision in the Yorkville Court until Monday, May 29, on the charges brought by John S. Sumner, secretary of the society.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Lawrence Dennis, "authority" on Fascism and one of the twenty-nine alleged seditionists on trial here attacked today the government's charge that the accused had conspired with the Nazi party to demoralize the armed forces as "cockeyed nonsense."

Paramount Pictures, Inc., in its report for the first quarter ended on April 1, estimated earnings at $3,814,000 after interest and all charges, including provision for Federal normal and excess profits taxes.

Because of limited seating capacity, service men desirous of free admission to Ebbets Field night, Sunday and holiday games must make such application two weeks in advance and the requests must be made by service organizations or camp groups, John F. Collins, business manager of the Dodgers, said yesterday.

The scope and content of statistical information which the Government might make available to business was discussed at an exploratory meeting yesterday in the office of the National Electric Manufacturers Association, 155 East Forty-fourth Street, and attended by twenty-eight economists.

While a hundred of her new neighbors cheered, Mrs. Helene Zwilling, 25-year-old mother, took possession yesterday of the three-room apartment at 1254 Evergreen Avenue, the Bronx, from which she had been barred previously by the landlord because of her 2-year-old son, Brian.

The Roman Catholic population of the United States, Alaska and the Hawaiian Islands is 23,419,701, an increase of 474,454 over last year, according to the Official Catholic Directory for 1944, to be issued today by P.J. Kenedy , Sons, publishers.

A Mexican concern and its New York agent, who had brought 2,240 waterproof Swiss watches into this country, were restrained yesterday in Federal court from selling them at prices in excess of Office of Price Administration ceilings.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 19 -- The thirty-seventh Bach festival at Bethlehem opened this afternoon in Packer Memorial Chapel at Lehigh University with the nave and transepts well filled with listeners from more than twenty States and 150 cities and towns whose enthusiasm for Bach was not dampened by the war.

A total of nearly 170,000 families have received information on wartime food problems through the metropolitan area division of the New York State Emergency Food Commission, Mrs. Roger W. Straus, metropolitan commissioner, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Heavy professional selling of July wheat late in the session today on the Chicago Board of Trade disclosed a lack of support and prices dipped around 2 cents a bushel from the early top and closed around the bottom. Net-losses were 7/8 to 1 3/8 cents.

Permanent injunctions against forty additional restaurants in the New York metropolitan area accused of increasing prices in violation of the Restaurant Maximum Price Regulation have been obtained in Federal courts by the Regional Office of Price Administration, Daniel P. Woolley, regional OPA administrator, announced yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., May 19 -- Gustave Schmidt, one of the seven individual defendants convicted last night in the Nazi propaganda conspiracy trial, received today a suspended sentence and was placed on probation for five years by Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney. Schmidt's case was isolated from the others in view of the serious condition of his health.

THE race track folk are strange people. The way business is booming one would get the impression that they would relish to the full these three-million-dollar days and be looking forward with keen anticipation to the inevitable afternoon when a cool four million will be poured through the mutuel windows. But nothing is farther from the truth.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers and chairman of the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared at the final session of the union's convention today that the CIO committee was ready to open its books and records "to any properly authorized committee" of Congress desiring to investigate its activities and financial sources.

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange in cotton futures was not very active yesterday and the market lacked a trend, closing 2 to 4 points lower than on Thursday on active months. Early price-fixing brought about a slight advance, but profit-taking and wee-kend liquidation caused prices to slip a few points in the later trading.

WASHINGTON, Way 19 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, urged today that labor and management make plans immediately to give needed vacations this summer to war workers in such a manner as would not curtail production.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Spokesmen for organized labor expressed fear today that a proposed rule widening the right of employers to file petitions with the National Labor Relations Board would result in "chaos," industrial conflict, an increase of strikes in war production plants and disruption of peaceful labor-management relationships.

JERUSALEM, May 18 (Delayed) -- Swift action by the Allies could save up to 1,500,000 Jews in Hungary and Rumania, in the opinion of Isaac Gruenbaum, chairman of the United Rescue Committee for European Jews.
Mr. and Mrs. Edwin G. Merrill have left the Beekman for their summer home in Bedford Hills.

Shylock's classic demand for a pound of flesh to settle a court case finally was surpassed yesterday when Magistrate J. Roland Sala evolved a novel plan for the disposition of minor litigation by having all the participants give up a pint of blood.

The name of the Atlantic Rayon Corporation has been changed officially to Textron, Inc., Royal Little, president, announced yesterday. The company's wholly owned subsidiary, Textron, Inc., will cease to function July 1, and all transactions with the retail trade will be handled directly by the parent company, Mr. Little declared.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Twenty-five years after the first World War the House of Representatives passed by a voice vote today a bill providing compensation in the form of pensions for the widows and orphans of veterans of that conflict.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Practical advice given by the Government's Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture is based on experiments at Beltsville, Md., the research center of the Department of Agriculture.

Adoption of an Army food conservation program last July is now resulting in a daily saving of $50,000 on the food bills of the Second Service Command alone, Lieut. Col. Charles G. Stewart Jr., director of food service in area embracing New York, New Jersey and Delaware, disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- The Cubs, whose victories this year can still be counted on the fingers of one hand, recorded their fifth triumph today before a shivering Ladies' Day crowd of 4,626, and under circumstances quite extraordinary.

KANSAS CITY, May 19 (AP) -- Generalissimo and Mme. Chiang Kai-shek declared today that help from the United Nations had changed China's outlook from one of little hope as she stood alone, to that of a comrade-in-arms in "the greatest potential power existent."

Vincent Perino, 25 years old, of 140 Mulberry Street, was sentenced to Elmira Reformatory yesterday in General Sessions for a term that may last ten years and Vincent (Mundo) Walsh, 26, of 357 West Twenty-third Street got off with a suspended sentence for criminally receiving 700 cases of liquor worth $30,000, stolen last Sept. 27, from a hijacked truck at Broadway and 127th Street.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Secretary Hull called on American businessmen today to turn this country's tremendous war-developed productive capacity to industries which will not call for heavy tariff protection or subsidies when peace comes.

Martin Dies is the subject of a new biography by William Gellerman, author of "The American Legion Educator," entitled "Martin Dies, to be published by John Day on June 8. This analysis of the political career and utterances of the former chairman of the House Committee on un-American activities charges Mr. Dies with spearheading a native reactionary movement by failing to expose real un-American forces at work in the country.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The War Manpower Commission authorized its regional directors today to prohibit all male workers in any age groups which they may designate from accepting jobs in essential or non-essential industries unless they receive clearance to take such jobs from the United States Employment Service or such agencies as that organization may appoint.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- Joan Bennett has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for a co-starring role with Fred MacMurray in the forthcoming musical "Nob Hill," a story of San Francisco's political and social life in the early Nineteen Hundreds.

It will be a miracle if the production of synthetic tires in 1944 reaches the advertised goal of 18,000,000, Theodore E. Allen, secretary of the contest board of the American Automobile Association, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Advertising and promotion expenditures of the Tea Bureau at pre-war levels will be resumed as soon as post-war conditions permit, and as a preparatory move the bureau's minimum wartime budget will be doubled for the fiscal year beginning October 1, 1944, Benjamin Wood, managing director, announced last night at the spring dinner of the Tea Association of the United States in the Biltmore Hotel at which he was the honor guest.

Because of inadequate planning the people of this city do not have the best hospital care, to which they are entitled, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Greater New York Hospital Association, in the Hotel McAlpin.

LONDON, May 19 -- The Germans shot and killed forty-seven officers of the British Dominions and Allied air forces after they and twenty-nine other prisoners of war attempted to escape from a German prison camp designated as Stalag Luft 3, near Dresden, on March 22, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today in the House of Commons.

New issues of municipal bonds scheduled for award next week aggregate $93,372,128, largest weekly total thus far this year. According to The Daily Bond Buyer this compares with this week's revised total of $11,781,020, and with the weekly average for 1944 to date of $15,363,029.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 19 -- The Federal Public Roads Administration made public today a 15,000-word criticism of New York State's "obsolete land acquisition policy," already abandoned under a program initiated by Governor Dewey in January and enacted into a law on April 7.

LONDON, May 19 -- The light shower of British propaganda leaflets that the Royal Air Force loosed over Germany on the first night of this war is now a cloudburst that delivers more than 55,000,000 copies of leaflets, booklets, pocket magazines and newspapers monthly to the Germans and citizens of occupied European countries.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The War Labor Board, after more than a year of controversy and four general coal strikes, approved today by a vote of 10 to 2 an agreement submitted to it five months ago by the United Mine Workers and bituminous coal operators representing 70 per cent of the country's soft coal tonnage.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Tigers backed up Johnny Gorsica's tight hurling with an effective attack to defeat Washington tonight, 4 to 1, tumbling the Senators into third place.
NAPLES, May 19 -- Allied troops are pressing against the Hitler Line at many points.

On Tuesday of next week Eire will hold a general election, the second within a year. This was precipitated by Prime Minister Eamon de Valera following the defeat of the Government's transport bill by the narrow vote of 64 to 63. Mr. de Valera's opponents charge him with having forced this election on a trivial issue.

NAPLES, May 19 (AP) -- American troops pressing forward near the coast were reported poised before Itri. A breakthrough at Itri would cut the last good escape route in the area and probably would compel the Germans to pull back into positions in a mountain range extending from Fondi southwestward to the sea near Terracina.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The meat and vegetable hash for the Army has been discontinued and the Quartermaster Corps has expanded the original three meat units in the "C" ration to these: meat and beans; meat and vegetable stew; meat and spaghetti; ham, eggs and potatoes; beef and noodles; meat and rice, and frankfurters and beans.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19 -- A plan for reducing the purely military instruction for Army units not directly engaged in combat operations in favor of a program of non-military training was disclosed here tonight by Maj. Gen. Joe N. Dalton, director of personnel, Army Service Forces.

LONDON, May 19 (U.P.) -- Swedish reports tonight said all leaves for German troops in the Netherlands had been suspended and that garrisons along the French Mediterranean coast were on the alert for a possible Allied drive from Corsica.

LONDON, May 19 (U.P.) -- The German radio claimed today that American, British and Yugoslav Partisan forces had invaded the strategic Dalmatian island of Sulet, athwart the important Nazi Adriatic supply port of Spalato, ten miles to the east, and that bloody fighting raged on the beaches.

One popular tradition about pioneers and discoverers and inventors was shattered by the Boer farmer Jacobus Jonker, whose death is reported from Johannesburg. Ten years ago, after twenty years of fruitless prospecting in the Transvaal mineral fields, he found the fourth largest diamond in the world, weighing 726 carats uncut.

At the Provincetown Playhouse, where a good number of ambitious bearers of the drama's torch have lingered on their way to distinction or obscurity, the Modern Play Productions, Inc., presented last night Oskar Gens' "Spring Production.''
WITH THE ALLIED ARMIES IN ITALY, May 19 -- The Allied offensive in Italy went into its second week last night with gained ground already nearly twice the area of the Anzio Beachhead below Rome.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 19 (AP) -- President Ismet Inonu, addressing a throng of 50,000 at a National Youth Day celebration, declared today that a plot had been uncovered against the Turkish Republic and voiced the suspicion that it had been engineered by "foreigners."

The vast area of land and water which the Japanese blacked out in their first mad rush in late 1941 and early 1942 is shrinking under the equatorial sun. The pace of the United Nations advance has increased since the first ghastly struggles in Guadalcanal and New Guinea.
Miss Madeline Dalton of New York is the new women's foil champion of the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today the merger of properties of the New York, Lackawanna Western Railway Company into the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company.

LONDON, Saturday, May 20 (AP) -- The pre-invasion tempo quickened last night as Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower returned to supreme headquarters from an inspection of troops massed in Britain. A curt announcement said the Allied Commander in Chief had completed "a quick visit to air and ground troops in England and northern Ireland."
SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 19 (AP) -- A Communique:

The huge Cities Service Company, in a petition filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, notified the Government agency that it would retain its oil, wholesale natural gas, real estate and other nonutility enterprises, and would dispose of its utility interests "to the extent necessary to relieve it from regulation under the Holding Company Act."

A newspaper campaign has been launched by Kaufman-Straus Company, department store in Louisville, Ky., calling attention to savings effected by the Office of Price Administration in World War II compared to inflationary prices of World War I, and urging consumers to buy war bonds with such savings.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Fred M. Vinson, Economic Stabilization Director, told Congress today the Administration was confident that, through a new program, the country could avoid the rationing of low-cost clothing and provide enough goods to meet essential needs.

War touches the schools, as it does every other phase of American life. Two thousand New York City teachers are now in the armed forces. Five have died in service. Half a million of their former pupils are in uniform. As Superintendent John E. Wade says in his annual report, just released, "the boys who played in the Manual-Erasmus game on Election Day in 1940 were in the mountains near Cassino in March, 1944."

CINCINNATI, May 19 (AP) -- Clyde Shoun, who on Monday had hurled a no-hitter against Boston, found it tough going today as the Reds withstood a three-run ninth-inning rally to defeat the Phillies, 7 -- 5.

Patrolman John C. Cowart, 46 years old, attached to the Elizabeth Street Station, was killed late yesterday afternoon in a gas explosion that wrecked and set fire to his three-room apartment on the second floor of a six-story apartment house at 48-56 Forty-fourth Street, Woodside, Queens.

NAPLES, May 19 -- German defenses along two-thirds of the blazing Hitler Line battleground from the Liri River to the Tyrrhenian Sea crumbled before American and French attacks today, and Gaeta was occupied by the Allies as a disorganized Nazi retreat approached the proportions of a rout.
A communique broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- Army and Navy coaches have been pointing at each other all spring whenever the discussion turned to the favorite's role in tomorrow's Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track meet, but the cadets moved in front today on some pointing out by the Middies' doctor.

TRENTON, N.J., May 19 -- The State of New Jersey refused late today to allow three boys, sentenced to life imprisonment for murder in Camden, to associate with the hardened criminals in State Prison here.

French troops supported by American tanks are now reported to have pierced the Hitler Line at Sant' Oliva, one of its strongest points. The tricolor of France, waving once more in the very forefront of victory on the mountains of Italy, can be seen from every quarter of the earth.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 19 -- George Mabie, 60 years old, a member of a pioneer Bergen County family, was arrested and turned over to Federal authorities today on a charge of embezzling $25,813 from the Hackensack Trust Company, of which he is assistant secretary and assistant treasurer.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 19 (AP) -- While Syracuse made the most of seven hits, eleven walks and one hit batsman by three Newark pitchers, Hod Lisenbee hurled the Chiefs to a four-hit 5-0 victory over the Bears tonight. It was the Chiefs' sixth straight triumph.

LONDON, May 19 -- Although business generally was not active, today's stock markets were cheerful as a result of the war news from Italy. In addition, good dividend announcements were made by several industrial companies. Shipping, radio, brewery and rayon issues all benefited where changed.
CHUNGKING, China, May 19 (AP) -- A commnunique:

CAIRO, Egypt, May 19 -- A bombshell has been tossed into the higher circles of the Egyptian Coptic Church with the revelation here today that Emperor Haile Selassie has authorized the Ethiopian Government to declare that the next Archbishop of Ethiopia must be an Ethiopian rather than an Egyptian.

The formation of parish committees in the Archdiocese of New York in connection with the Clothing Campaign for Italy collection from May 28 to June 11 has been authorized by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre, Chancellor of the Archdiocese, has announced in a letter to be read tomorrow in every church at each mass.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Four changes in the regulations establishing manufacturers' ceilings for coated and combined fabrics were announced by the Office of Price Administration today.

With some men's and boy's shirt and pajama manufacturers already having opened their fall line, and with others scheduled to make formal showings during the next two or three weeks, the supply situation is viewed as being highly unsatisfactory.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 18 (Delayed) -- Suspicions and internal difficulties still beset any thought of the permanent resolution of the Levant problem, although since the completion of the North African campaign a year ago these can largely be considered as of a post-war nature.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday May 20 (AP) -- A communique:

"National Maritime Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in the churches at the request of President Roosevelt who has proclaimed Monday as "National Maritime Day." The Commission on Worship of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America issued yesterday a prayer for suggested use.

ALBANY, May 19 (AP) -- Two Cohoes officials were arraigned today on sealed indictments handed up by a special grand jury in the investigation of crime in Albany County which was ordered by Governor Dewey.
ST. LOUIS, May 19 (AP) -- Mort Cooper retired with a sore elbow after pitching two trying innings today as the Braves defeated the Cardinals. 4 to 3.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- The American people may be confident of the ultimate results when major invasions start but "we will do our fighting men a great injustice if we overlook the tremendous difficulties involved and expect an overnight miracle," Lieut. Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the board of directors of the Radio Corporation of America, declared here today.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY BEFORE SANT' OLIVA, Italy, May 19 -- This northern anchor of the "Hitler line" has been pierced by French poilus riding on the backs of American tanks.
Gottesman Co., Inc., wood-pulp agents, importers and exporters, have been appointed sole selling agents for groundwood pulp made by Halifax Power and Pulp Company, Ltd., Nova Scotia.
A new Swedish comedy importation, "Vi Hemmslavinnor" (We Domestic Slaves), will open today at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. Dagmar Ebbesen is starred in the picture, which Las English titles.

Overwhelmed with a flood of invitations from hospitable New Yorkers who hung out the welcome sign in a big way yesterday when they heard that Mrs. Flora Dampier and Mrs. Emily Brown of North Adams, Mass., were in town; that both were past 60 and that neither had seen a ship, nor a skyscraper nor a subway in all their lives, the pair had the time of their lives yesterday "doing the town."
TRENTON, N.J., May 19 -- Party fishing boats operating from points in Monmouth, Ocean, Atlantic and Cape May Counties will not receive extra gasoline rations, OPA executives said today.
The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, has announced that it will reopen for next season in September with a continuous program of exhibitions throughout the winter and spring.

AT THE DNIEPER DAM at Zapapozhye, May 15 (Delayed) -- The partially destroyed, world-famed Dnieper Dam was seen today by non-Axis foreigners for the first time since the Russians blew up a section of it as part of their scorched earth policy during their 1941 retreat to the East.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Alleghany Corporation asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to find that its control of the Chesapeake Ohio, the Pere Marquette, the New York, Chicago St. Louis Nickel Plate and other railroads was not in violation of the Interstate Commerce Act.

A market deluged with potato alcohol for public consumption, while millions of gallons of grain alcohol continue to be "poured into automobile radiators in the guise of anti-freeze" was foreseen yesterday by the liquor industry in view of a ruling made Wednesday by the War Production Board that permitted a small New Hampshire plant to turn out beverage alcohol from Maine potatoes.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, CEYLON, May 19 -- Chinese and American jungle fighters drove into the outskirts of Myitkyina yesterday after taking the main Japanese airdrome two miles to the south, and two other elements of a three-pronged drive converged on the big Japanese North Burma headquarters from the west and the north, the Allied Command announced today.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 19 -- South Pacific air targets are becoming more difficult to locate as the Japanese are forced by our bombing offensive to disperse and camouflage their key points more elaborately, the Air Department said today.

The stock market adhered yesterday to a steady course with the accent in trading reserved for the specialties and the pivotal issues relegated again to the background. Fluctuations in prices were generally narrow and final quotations were above the previous close by a hairline.

LONDON, May 19 -- Reports that King Peter of Yugoslavia had dissolved the Cabinet that included Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch as Minister of War were somewhat premature. They seem to have mistaken the will for the deed.

In the largest weekly total since the end of March, offerings of new bonds for public subscription here this week were quite diversified and amounted to $28,830,000 for four issues, compared with $3,946,000 for three issues in the preceding week and $4,439,000 for three small flotations in this week a year ago.
PITTSBURGH, May 19 -- President Branch Rickey joined his Dodgers at long last today and what he witnessed from a seat well back in the stands probably made him wish he had "stood in Brooklyn."

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The War Labor Board announced today its program for dealing with the problems of unions which are not affiliated with the AFL or the CIO, but the Confederated Unions of America rejected it as an unacceptable substitute for its demand for full representation on the board.
In Washington and in London the protracted governmental deliberation on French affairs is about to be concluded. It has now become a question of days and perhaps of hours.

BOSTON, May 19 -- Volume of orders received by Massachusetts manufacturers during April declined about 16 per cent under the preceding month, the Associated Industries of Massachusetts reported today, in announcing preliminary figures for the month.

LONDON, Saturday, May 20 (AP) -- Moscow announced early today that the Red Army was attacking in the Vitebsk area of White Russia and had captured a fortified Nazi stronghold in that vicinity falter a fierce two-hour battle.

LONDON, May 19 -- The Polish National Council discussed at length today a motion of nonconfidence in Minister of War Marjan Kukiel, then postponed a vote pending the report of the committee investigating charges of anti-Semitism in the Polish Army.

A newcomer in the Fulton Fish Market these days is the blowfish or swellfish, a variety that used to be scorned through a whim of custom that deemed it inedible. So far this season it has been arriving in limited amounts in the form of triangular-shaped pieces, four to six inches in length, which include the portion of the body that tapers into the tail.

LONDON, May 19 -- The issue of the battle for Europe will not be decided by attack from the west alone, Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Prime Minister of South Africa, told an audience at Birmingham today where he was made freeman of the city.

Assurance was given the toilet goods industry yesterday by Col. R.P. Kuhn that there will be no dumping of branded merchandise by Post Exchange or "PX" stores which would ruin markets manufacturers have developed over a long period of time.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- After pitching three hitless innings in relief, Mike Ryba came to bat with the bases loaded in the twelfth inning and singled home the winning run today in the Red Sox' 3-to-2 victory over the White Sox.

Frank D. March, salvage director of the War Production office here, reported yesterday that the effort to "bring out dormant paper from files and storerooms continues to bring impressive results." He declared that office, loft and apartment buildings are being systematically emptied of old records and scrap paper by the real estate management executives and employes who are cooperating wholeheartedly with the wastepaper salvage drive.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Roosevelt nominated Ambrose O'Connell of New York today to be a judge of the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals.

With any sort of help from the weather man, the $4,000,000 betting day that seemed so brash when first predicted may arrive today at Belmont Park, where one of the best cards of the season will be served up to racegoers, with the ancient Withers Stakes, first run in 1874, as the piece de resistance, despite the absence of the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, Pensive.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- The Sears, Roebuck Co. midsummer flyer catalog was in the mails today with a bigger percentage of new merchandise offerings than normally but with a plentiful sprinkling of price cuts nevertheless.

Raymond Rubicam on July 1 will resign as chairman of the board of Young Rubicam, Inc., and will retire from active participation in the advertising agency business at that time, he announced yesterday. Mr. Rubicam will dispose of his holdings to the company, of which he was a co-founder in 1923, and they will be made available to members or the organization over a period of time.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- The Indians knocked Luke Hamlin out of the box with eight hits and four runs in two innings and defeated the Athletics, 9 -- 1, today. Al Smith scattered nine hits along the route to record his first victory.

IN the second Latin-American Literary Prize Competition the first prize for non-fiction went to "Enriqueta and I,"* by Argentina Diaz Lozano, an autobiographical account of childhood in Honduras. Mrs. Lozano was born in 1909. Her mother, whom she calls Enriqueta, was a widow who supported herself and her child by teaching in a series of village schools

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 19 -- After the arrest by the Buenos Aires police Wednesday of five men believed to be the organizers of a "civil disobedience campaign" in protest against the present military government, a wave of arrests spread over Argentina yesterday and today.

Applauding announcement of the Office of Price Administration in Washington that there would soon be issued simplified regulations of packaged dry groceries, Clarence Francis, chairman of the board of General Foods Corporation, said yesterday that this showed a trend toward clarification and speeding up of decisions.

CHUNGKING, China, May (AP) -- Counter- attacking Chinese forces have driven to within ten miles of the big Japanese base of Sinyang in southern Honan Province with a surprise thrust from the south, the Chinese command announced tonight.

LONDON, Saturday, May 20 -- Targets in Berlin and the Brunswick area were heavily attacked and 125 German fighters were destroyed yesterday in large-scale resumption of the American air assault on the Reich.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 19 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York tonight added Oregon's fifteen Republican National Convention votes to the advancing total pledged to him for the party's nomination for President.

Your editorial "Due Warning" of May 13 asserts that "the peoples of the four countries -- Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Finland -- may not be equally guilty." May I draw your attention to some contradictions and inaccuracies in it?

On May 15 the City Council passed a resolution which declared that since "five infants, all children of United States Navy men, died in agony when boric acid was substituted for dextrose in their feeding formulas at a hospital in New London," the city and State Boards of Health be asked to label all boric acid containers "Caution -- Poison."

JERUSALEM, May 18 (Delayed) -- Eight men wearing khaki uniforms and speaking Hebrew are officially reported to have penetrated around midnight Wednesday into the Palestine wireless transmitting station at Ramallah, a small town about eight miles to the north of Jerusalem, and failing in an attempt to give an illegal broadcast, damaged part of the station apparatus before escaping.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., May 19 -- With the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs prepared to pass a resolution endorsing Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican nomination for President at its convention, which opened today, there was a split on the question of endorsing a candidate for vice president.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Petroleum production in June, as approved today by the Petroleum Administration for War, is expected to hit a record rate of 4,879,100 barrels daily, an increase of 60,600 barrels daily over May.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had filed a complaint in the Federal Court in Boston charging seven trustees and officers of the Aldred Investment Trust with gross misconduct and gross abuse of trust.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Thirty-three of the thirty-seven Republicans in the Senate joined today in sponsoring a resolution which seeks to abolish by constitutional amendment the payment of poll taxes as a prerequisite to voting in Federal elections. The four other Republicans, who were in their home States, were expected to back the resolution.

LONDON, May 19 -- Through Arctic gales, heavy, murderous seas and pitch-black sub-zero nights, one of the largest convoys ever sent to Russia ran the gantlet of submarine attacks and aerial dog-fights without the loss of a single merchant ship, but only after the Fleet Air Arm and escort sank two U-boats, probably sank two others and damaged several more.

To assist the educational work of historic St. Paul's Episcopal Church at East Chester, Mount Vernon, N.Y., a national shrine for the Bill of Rights, the Society of the Friends of that church was formed yesterday by its rector, wardens and vestrymen at a tea at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PEARL HARBOR, May 19 (AP) -- In their second daring daylight raid on Wake Island in two days, American fliers heavily bombed Peale Island and Heel Point on Wednesday despite intense anti-aircraft fire, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

Mr. and Mrs. William Richie of 327 East Eighty-ninth Street waited in vain yesterday for word that the police had found the body of their daughter, Irene, 5 years old, in the East River off Ninety-second Street. The body of Irene's twin, Richard, was brough up with grappling hooks on Thursday.

The aircraft industry is trying to prepare in realistic fashion for the difficult problems which it must face with the termination of war contracts. Unity of purpose and active participation of the top men in this now giant industry have been achieved at recent meetings of the Aircraft War Production Councils, East and West Coasts, in Los Angeles.

The new duck stamp to be issued for the 1944 45 hunting season will be available on July 1 and will be from a drawing by Walter A. Weber, wildlife artist, according to an announcement from the Fish and Wildlife Service. Mr. Weber, who is assistant curator of birds in the National Museum, Washington, D.C., chose for his subject three white-fronted geese, part of a flight coming in.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, May 20 -- Bombers and carrier planes of the commands of Admiral Louis Mountbatten, Gen. Douglas MacArthur and Admiral Chester W. Nimitz jointly carried out a heavy raid against Surabaya, Java, from dawn to midnight Wednesday, a special communique announced today.

RICHMOND, Va., May 19 -- A simple method of protecting potatoes against decay, a process for treating glass to lower its reflectance and a device for determining the level of a liquid in a closed container are among the inventions covered by the 528 patents listed as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

Terming the recent sale of surplus materials conducted by aircraft manufacturers a "flop" as far as small manufacturers are concerned, H.M. Polhemus, regional director of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, stated yesterday that the agency is seeking simplification of procedures governing appeals from War Production Board material limitation and conservation orders.

Retail trade continued active here this week. Seasonal apparel and accessories were in brisk demand. Estimates indicated department store volume ran ahead of the like week last year by 15 per cent or more.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Army said today that the hours decided upon for issuing communiques in London after the invasion represented a compromise between conflicting desires of American and British newspapers.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The War Department is making a country-wide survey to determine the practicability of substituting two ten-hour work shifts a day in place of three eight-hour shifts now generally used in war plants, Senator Clyde M. Reed, Republican, of Kansas, said today.

As Secretary Stimson has reminded us, the Nazis are doing their best to "confuse the people of the United States and of the Allied Nations" about the invasion. But behind their obvious lying there is at least one manifest truth. They don't know any more than we do about the invasion plans.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- After the most lavish war expenditures in history, public reaction will probably be prompt and drastic against the military forces when peace returns, Representative James W. Wadsworth, Republican, of New York, warned Army and Navy leaders today.

My buddies and I are infantrymen. We don't wear wings and we don't have diplomas; we don't live in hotels and we don't have serge blouses, and when Hollywood actors get drafted, we're not the outfit they join.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- Richard Townsend, as trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, revoked today the privileges of limited participation held by Samuel Okin of New York, lawyer and self-styled "protector" of investors in the Electric Bond and Share Company, in the commission's proceedings involving the American Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Forty-one Democratic Senators naming their choices for the party's Vice Presidential nomination in an Associated Press poll today gave twelve votes to Henry A. Wallace and split the rest among ten other possible candidates.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Serious consideration is being given to a complete blacklisting of all Swedish concerns having American connections unless Sweden cuts off ball-bearing supplies to Germany, it was learned tonight.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- Forced to the extreme outside at the head of the stretch when the leaders went wide, H. Guy Bedwell's Undulator ran down his field to score by a head today at Suffolk Downs in the $2,500 Village Green purse, six-furlong Grade C dash.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 -- A many-faceted "stealthy political invasion" of the United States is under way in wartime as part of a Nazi program for "winning the peace," Norman M. Littell, Assistant Attorney General, told the Commonwealth Club today. Execution of wartime sabotage plans had been frustrated, he said, but America was destined to be a fifth-column battle ground in the postwar period.
ALGIERS, May 19 -- General de Gaulle's associates predicted today that he would go to London only if he received assurance in advance that the outcome would be an accord that he could accept.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The War Department announced today that it had been informed that Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten, Supreme Allied Commander in southeast Asia, had issued the following order of the day to Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, United States Army, in connection with the success in capturing Myitkyina airfield:

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY, at the Hitler Line, Italy, May 19 -- A Polish bugler, standing before the grim ruins of Monte Cassino Abbey, sounded Poland's famous Hejnal call today as the battle for Italy moved into a new phase.
LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- An Air and Home Security communique: Last night there was slight enemy activity over northern Scotland. No bombs were dropped.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 19 -- Rushing last-minute preparations for counter-measures against expected Allied landings along the west coast of Italy north of Rome, the German High Command has ordered the total evacuation of civilian populations from large sections of the country around La Spezia and Genoa by tomorrow noon, according to reports received from the Italian frontier tonight.

The General Sessions trial of Albert Horowitz, 39 years old, an ex-convict and his wife, Ruth, 32, charged with a series of burglaries in rooms in midtown and West Side hotels, had reached its fourth day yesterday, when both suddenly announced they were ready to plead guilty.

Fourteen - year - old Princess Rangnhild, eldest daughter of Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway, will make her first official appearance when she sponsors the tanker Karsten Wang at its launching today at the Sun Shipbuilding Company's yard in Chester, Pa.

MOUNT CASSINO ABBEY, Italy, May 19 (U.P.) -- Maj. Norman Newton of Cambridge, Mass., former Harvard professor and now monuments and fine arts officer for the Allied Military Government attached to the British Eighth Army, predicted today that reconstruction of the entire abbey here was possible, "although most of it now is only a heap of pulverized rubble and dust."

The American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters held their annual joint ceremonial yesterday afternoon, inducting new members and making awards and grants to writers, artists and musicians.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- Miss Edith D. Gwinn, special assistant to the director, division of pupil personnel and counseling of the Philadelphia Board of Education, says that the comic strip "Little Orphan Annie" is "a vicious example to hold up before children who read her adventures religiously."

SEVASTOPOL, May 17 (Delayed) -- Foreign correspondents today toured the Crimean battlefield and the ruins of this once beautiful Black Sea naval base and inspected the battlefield scene of the Chersonese Cape, where the trapped Germans, under a terrible hail of Soviet bombs and artillery shells, looked vainly toward the sea on May 12 for their promised evacuation ships in a disaster that one German prisoner described as "worse than Dunkerque."

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Construction of another million tons of landing craft was approved in the House today and Representative Fish, Republican, of New York promptly demanded that Gen. Douglas MacArthur receive most of the new attack barges to carry the war "into the heart of Japan."

The final curtain will ring down on two Broadway attractions tonight, "Winged Victory" and "A Highland Fling." The Air Forces show, one of the outstanding hits of the season, closes at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre after a total of 212 performances.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Destroying enemy planes on the ground is twice as hazardous as knocking them down in aerial combat, though it requires less flying skill, Capt. Don S. Gentile of Piqua, Ohio, one of the top aces of the European theatre, and his "wing man," Capt. John T. Godfrey of Woonsocket, R.I., declared today.
The New York Stock Exchange firm of Ball, Burge Co. was formed on Monday by Peter Ball, John D. Burge, Burton T. Reid, W.C. Allen and T.C. Wellsted, all of Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The income tax simplification bill was stalled in the Senate today by Senator William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota, who had urged unsuccessfully that consideration of the measure be postponed until Monday to permit Senators to study its contents.

Election of officers ended the four-day Golden Jubilee convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, attended by 700 members. Mrs. Stephen J. Francisco of Little Falls was elected president to succeed Mrs. Charles S. Maddock Jr., who presided.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, May 20 -- American infantry are in complete control of the air strip on Insumar, largest of the Wakde Islands, and have driven the Japanese defenders into a trap in a half-mile-square area at the northeast end of the island, where the enemy is making a determined last stand.
The Yankees caught up with the unpredictable Browns yesterday at the Stadium and to say the experience was disappointing would be understatement.

Despite the enormous volume of freight which is being moved for war purposes, loadings of revenue freight by the nation's railroads have shown no startling gain. From the beginning of this year through May 6 they have amounted to 14,996,727 cars, an increase of 594,227 over the 14,402,500 cars in the similar period of 1943.

On the premise that the Democratic and Republican parties have ceased filling their real functions and are now mere election machines, a new Liberal party was started last night at the Hotel Roosevelt by about 1,100 delegates claiming to represent upward of 475,000 voters in New York State.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19 -- Evidence that the majority of people in Australia are looking to the United States for armed aid in future years as well as during this war is revealed in a survey just completed by Australian Public Opinion Polls.
The Olympic Games may be resumed as early as 1948, President Avery Brundage of the American Olympic Committee predicted last night, according to The United Press.
Deft handling of mere wisps of material characterizes one of this summer's hat fashions.

GUADALCANAL, May 19 (U.P.) -- Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., commander in the South Pacific war theatre, said today that "with the announcement of the virtual completion of the South Pacific campaign, except for mopping up and starving out operations," he wanted to tell his men they were members of the greatest fighting team ever put together.

Philadelphia, May 19 -- The Army lifted the veil of secrecy today from the first of its sea-going harbor house-cleaners, a former merchant ship packed with all types of machinery needed to render an enemy-wrecked port fit as speedily as possible for the rapid landing of troops and supplies.

The National Post-War Conference, consisting of twenty-two major business, industrial, financial, labor, agricultural and civic organizations, opened a two-day meeting at the St. Moritz Hotel yesterday in an attempt to bring conflicting viewpoints together in a program of joint action to insure "a balanced and equitable post-war economy."

IF, in the summer of 1941, you had chosen to go on an automobile tour of the summer theatres, you could have traveled for quite a few weeks seeing a play every night except Sunday in a different rural playhouse without finding yourself more than a few hundred miles from New York City.

Though I find myself in thorough agreement with the spirit of Mr. Kantorowicz's article, "The Burned Books Still Live," in THE TIMES MAGAZINE, I should like to point out an unfortunate lapse from good scholarship in his discussion of one great artist whom the Nazis still tolerate.

Faced with the curtailment of the Army Specialized Training Program and a drastic reduction in the aviation corps, colleges and universities are now confronted with a 25 per cent cut in their V-12 units when the November terms begin. The Navy recently warned the colleges that the 70,000 men now under the V-12 auspices would be reduced by one-fourth this fall.

THE crew of a fishing trawler not far from port in the North Sea foul their net in something they fear is a mine. Such a catch, only recently, had not only threatened to blow them to kingdom come, but had cost them the gear they had to cut loose, as well.

ALGIERS, May 20 -- Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, Supreme Allied Commander here, and other high Allied officials and Allied correspondents climbed aboard the Swedish liner Gripsholm in Algiers harbor today to welcome 1,043 Allied soldiers, sailors and aviators who had just come from German prisons in exchange for 900 Germans sent home from the United States.

BOSTON, May 20 -- New Englanders, fearful of Government control, turned sympathetic eyes this week to rock-ribbed Vermont's fight against the Federal effort to foist a $30,000,000 flood-control dam upon farmers in the West River Valley.

THE take-out double has been used for nearly thirty years as a strong bid. Its primary purpose is to ask partner to show his best suit when the opponents have opened the bidding and a defender has a strong hand, one which can support any of the un-bid suits.

LONDON, Sunday, May 21 (U.P.) -- The lull on the eastern battlefront remained unbroken yesterday for the twenty-ninth consecutive day, but Moscow announced in a supplementary communique today that more than 1,200 Nazis had been killed in a series of abortive, localized attacks on Red Army positions in Bessarabia, southeastern Poland and White Russia.

THE testimonial dinner tendered Dr. Koussevitzky by American composers last Tuesday night was far more than a conventional gesture of recognition for the completion of his twenty years in the country of his adoption as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

Repeating with minor variations a previous propaganda tactic, Nazi propagandists flirted with a fake invasion story yesterday in a broadcast beamed to North America. The broadcast had no substantiation in fact.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -Senators Taft of Ohio and Green! of Rhode Island were hosts todayI at a Capitol luncheon honoring I two famous constituents, Capt. ,Don Gentile of Piqua, Ohio, and :Capt. John T. Godfrey of North Smithfield, R. I., Army aces.

The home team, with an imposing total of 1,092, captured the John Payne Whitney P.S.A.L. championship trophy at the first title competition of the newly organized New York Public and High Schools Rifle League held yesterday on the Abraham Lincoln High range.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Heeding pleas by Secretary Ickes, the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended today that the appropriation bill for the Interior Department for 1945 be increased by $35,976,765 over the $87,652,580 previously approved by the House and also knocked out a House amendment aimed at canceling most draft deferments for employes of the department between 19 and 30.

THE finest type of broccoli is produced from seed sown during May. This planting will mature in late summer and early fall, and the cooler temperatures at that time will increase its flavor considerably.
