ITHACA, N.Y., May 20 -- The United States Naval Academy's precision-stroked crews swept Cayuga Lake in the annual spring day regatta today, meeting the challenges of three other boats in both the varsity and jayvee two-mile races.

THE American army of invasion is in every respect the greatest army the United States has ever put into the field -- in training and in management no less than in numbers and equipment. It will be the shootingest army that ever squeezed a trigger.

William T. Hedlund, president of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, with plants in Union, N.J., and Lincoln, Neb., yesterday denied that the company was an affiliate of the Svenska A.B. Gasaccumulator.

PEARL HARBOR, May 20 (U.P.) -- Aleutians-based bombers resumed their attacks on powerfully-fortified Kurile Islands Thursday, bombing the enemy base of Paramushiru in a night raid following a day attack on shipping, Pacific Fleet headquarters announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Heavy duty floor maintenance machines currently required in war industries and by military claimants may again be produced in limited quantities, WPB announced today.
Following is an official digest of the platform of the new Liberal party, adopted yesterday at an organizing convention at the Hotel Roosevelt. The digest was issued by the new party:

To the extent permitted by shipping conditions, the recruitment and manning organization of the War Shipping Administration is urging experienced ordinary seamen temporarily to forego assignment to vessels in favor of enrollment at the nearest able seaman upgrading school, Craig S. Vincent, Atlantic Coast representative of the RMO, revealed last week.
NAPLES, May 20 -- A paragraph in a copy of an order of the day found on a German prisoner and addressed to soldiers of the German Fourteenth Panzer Corps follows:

News reaches this department from London that British engineers are now experimenting with creeper treads which are to facilitate the landing of post-war airplanes. If the promise of ultimate success is realized it will be possible to operate heavily loaded planes more readily than at present because of the increased contact with the ground in landing.

A suggestion that the Treasury consider consolidating the national debt while interest rates remain as low as they now are, eliminating maturity dadtes on the new bonds and making them redeemable at the option of the Government, is maded by Louis Guenther, publisher of The Financial World, in the currenet issue of his paper.

SOME fifteen years ago a young woman, who has since become one of the formidable great ladies of American fiction, published a first novel in which she identified one of her characters as being an immigrant to Boston from "some weird State in the middling West." No one, not even a resident of Beacon Street, ever actually used the phrase "middling West" to define a region of the United States.

Despite their great war loss of personnel, voluntary hospitals here are in a position to "meet any crises likely to arise," Roy E. Larsen, president of the United Hospital Fund, advised J. Stewart Baker, general chairman of the 1944 campaign of the Greater New York Fund, in a letter made public yesterday.

Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Finland, you wrote today, "can get out of the war now or take the consequences." Would it not be more correct to say "and take the consequences"? Concerning Hungary, even this would miss the point, because she has taken the consequences of her attempt to withdraw during the last seven weeks.

Every branch of social welfare service administered in New York by 205 agencies through the Protestant Welfare Federation will be aided by the double springtime theatre party arranged by the federation for the near future. The two performances are "The Searching Wind," on Wednesday night at the Fulton Theatre and "Jacobowsky and the Colonel" for the night of June 8 at the Martin Beck Theatre.

During the war, even though a large section of the Russian oil industry had to be evacuated rapidly from areas menaced by German assaults, Russia has undertaken to modernize her petroleum production and refining processes by "a radical reorganization," according to a report on the industry by L. Sedin, Soviet Oil Commissar, now available here.

To stimulate activity among United States citizens in the interest of a united policy on world problems and call for action by political and Government leaders in a letter-writing drive, a "World Order Compact" will be signed today in some 1,100 Congregational Christian Churches across the country, patterned after and carried out in the spirit of the original, historic compact signed aboard the Mayflower in 1620 by the Pilgrims.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 20 -- The Bumble Bee, owned by William H. Stanley and sailed by Arthur Knapp, stung the others of the International Class sloops today by taking the second Sparkman Trophy race off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Liquidation and bear pressure sent May and July rye futures off 5 cents a bushel, the permissible limit for one day's trading, on the Board of Trade today. Trading was extremely heavy, and although there was short covering on the way down, this was more than offset by selling on stop-loss orders and the close was at the bottom.

The 2,200-ton super-destroyer Shea, named in honor of Comdr. John J. Shea, who lost his life Sept. 15, 1942, when the aircraft carrier Wasp was torpedoed in the Pacific, was launched last night at the Bethlehem Steel and Shipbuilding Company's yard at Mariners Harbor, S.I., in the presence of 500 persons.

Founders of the New School for Social Research will be honored at a dinner celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the school tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria. More than 1,500 persons, including many prominent figures in educational, scientific and governmental circles, are sponsoring the event.

PIQUA, Ohio, May 20 (AP) -- Capt. Don S. Gentile came home tonight to a hero's welcome that developed into such unrestrained fervor that women ripped pieces from his uniform and tore the captain's bars from his shoulders.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Chairman Harry S. Truman, Democrat of Missouri, said today the Senate War Investigating Committee would "act immediately" on a request by Senator Gerald P. Nye, North Dakota Republican, for an inquiry into the operations of SKF, Swedish ball-bearing firm.

Fifteen members of a Harlem gang eight of then juveniles, were accused before Magistrate Raphael R. Murphy in the Felony Court yesterday of violating the Sullivan Law because of the possession of seven shotguns, several home made, and three knives.

In what is probably the only school of its kind in the world, a group of carefully selected men and women have returned to the classroom for a concentrated eight weeks' program dealing with the salvaging of human lives. The school, located on the peaceful University of Maryland campus, is the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration Training Center.

A FEW weeks ago, in speaking of the writers who meant most to me during my adolescent years, I said that what I chiefly got from Thomas Carlyle was a quickened sense of the exhilaration that goes with struggle and an understanding that conflict is a condition of life.

The directors of the Kansas City Southern Railway Company at their organization meeting held here yesterday elected M. Livingston Delafield, a partner in the law firm of Delafield Delafield of New York, as chairman of the board.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 -- Two Australian brides of American soldiers, who stowed away on a merchant ship to join their husbands in this country, pleaded guilty today to violating the immigration laws and were reprimanded by Federal Judge A.F. St. Sure, who put them on six months' probation.
TRADITIONALISTS favor the importance of heredity in art. They believe that new designs are merely developments of the work of former generations.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The War Shipping Administration has received Maritime Day tributes to the merchant marine and the nation's shipbuilders from Army, Navy and production leaders.
SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, Ceylon, May 20 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Because of the necessity for acting on important legislative measures, Congress has little chance of taking a summer recess this year, Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, chairman of the Finance Committee, said today.

An apparatus for transfusing whole blood within battle lines has been devised by Majs. Charles Emerson and Richard Ebert, two Harvard Medical School specialists, in England. It weighs only thirty-five pounds and can be used to draw blood from a healthy donor and to inject a pint into the veins of a desperately wounded soldier in five minutes.

CHESTER, Pa., May 20 -- With Princess Ragnhild Alexandra, 14-year-old daughter of Crown Prince Olav and Crown Pricess Martha of Norway, as sponsor, the 16,000-ton tanker Karsten Wang was launched today at the south yard of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

Gallantly and irresistibly, the Allied armies continue to forge ahead in Italy; but the one certainty of that campaign is that, despite local withdrawals, occasionally in some disorder, the Germans are not giving up a single position except under immense pressure. Every move back, no matter how insignificant, represents a defeat not only for their arms but for their policy.

Declaring that no nation should control post-war commerce of the world, Senator George L. Radcliffe of Maryland urged international cooperation for both sea and air trade in the coming peace "to spare much ruinous competition." He spoke at the twenty-second annual dinner of the Port of New York division of the Propeller Club of the United States, held also in observance of National Maritime Day, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

STOCKHOLM, May 20 -- In the week's operations on the nerve-war front, as viewed from this vantage point, the Allies have had one big advantage -- the successful offensive in Italy. That offensive certainly has lent emphasis to the Allied nerve-war output, impressing the Germans far more than the Allies could have been impressed by anything Goebbels has produced lately.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, NEW GUINEA, Sunday, May 21 (AP) -- A communique:

AN airmail cover received from Stockholm last week bears as postage two unheralded stamps, 5-ore green and 60o red-violet, picturing a seventeenth century maritime map and inscribed "Sveriges Sjokarta 300 Ar" (Sweden's Marine Chart 300 Years).

To make the Surplus Consumer Commodity Disposition Division of the Treasury Department "a number one source of supply" for the goods assigned to it for disposal the agency is reorganizing its facilities to tap as wide a market as possible, it was learned yesterday.

Scoring in every event, the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School track and field team annexed the Private Schools Athletic Association senior championship at Baker Field yesterday, amassing a record total of 99 1/2 points. It was a gala day for Coach George Eastment's athletes, who also triumphed in the junior division, a feat they have been achieving for seventeen years in a row, and captured third place in the midget division.

SENSITIVE regard for difficult material and a considerable skill in dramatic narrative mark this latest novel about Jesus and his circle. Traveling a well-trodden road, but observing freshly, Dorothy Clarke Wilson has brought something arresting to her portrait of James, "the brother of our Lord."

THE "pigeon," whose name is Valerie Bright, has every reason to be frightened. She is trying to smuggle out of occupied France a diary which is filled with potential dynamite. It is not her own diary; it has been stolen from a German general who has written in it his frank opinion of Hitler and other Nazi leaders.

WHY was the Emmaline Quincy abandoned in mid-ocean, and what became of Captain Angel and the crew? Johnny Angel, the captain's grandson, wants the answers to those questions in order that he may spike the rumor that his grandfather has stolen the secret cargo that the ship is supposed to have carried.

ANY country resident who has ever put a porch rocker in motion -- by direct contact or by gossip -- will recognize the slightly delirious carrying on in "Mrs. Applegate's Affair." The action takes place in a Vermont village replete with natives and the usual summer colony; and Lucy Applegate, the heroine in Frederic F. Van de Water's latest novel, is decidedly of the scatterbrain type with a highly charged capacity for attracting complications.

The Communist party of the United States, after an embattled quarter century on the political scene, dissolved itself yesterday as a political party and was immediately reconstituted as a non-party organization with a political mission.

NEW DELHI, India, May 20 (Reuter) -- Twelve Indian soldiers, selected by the Japanese from among prisoners captured in Malaya to work as spies, were landed in India by submarine but immediately gave up to the Allies' authorities.

MARTHA GRAHAM'S recent experiment in giving a solid week of repertory was a curiously enlightening experience even for some of us in her audience who have followed her career virtually from its beginning with the most intense and convinced concentration.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 20 (AP) -- Despite a four-run rally in the ninth, Syracuse dropped from first to second place tonight as Newark squeezed out a 9-8 victory which ended the Chiefs' six-game winning streak. Frank Dunlap paced the Bears' thirteen-hit attack with two triples.

LONDON, May 20 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, India's modern messiah, is free again to resume his life-long role as champion of Indian freedom, but the thought in London has been that the drama of his life will never reach its intended denouement.

Henry J. Kaiser's plan for the creation of a non-profit corporation for the establishment of 3,000 to 5,000 terminals for personal airplane operations in the six months immediately after the war, at a cost of $150,000,000 for the smaller number, is intended to provide employment for 4,500,000 persons and to create an immediate market for private airplane manufacturers, who might otherwise find their growth slow and consequently their prices high.

Walter Dubiel, the husky from Hartford, who came out of the minors with the distinction of a couple of no-hitters in his last two years down below, strong-armed the Yankees back into the American League lead yesterday before 14,271 palpitating fans at the Stadium.

RICHMOND, May 20 -- Action of the North Carolina Democratic Convention in adopting a resolution urging a "more democratic" constitutional process for the ratification of treaties is seen as evidence that sentiment is rising in the Upper South against the requirement that treaties must be approved by two-thirds of the Senate.

The article by Gerald Johnson entitled "Is There a Trend to the Right?" contains an assertion so typical of so-called "liberals" or New Dealers. In speaking of the public's dislike of certain Presidential appointees he says that since the days of Van Buren and Jackson, "no President's appointees have been so bitterly excoriated without proof or even serious charge of financial dishonesty as have those of Mr. Roosevelt."

MOST men who reach the battlefronts have little actual fear of death. In donning the uniform they face (and put aside) the fact that they may not return to wear civilian clothes again. Most of them, however, do have a horror of being wounded.

IN "McGraw of the Giants" one of the ablest of sports writers, Frank Graham, has set down the life and works of one of the greatest of baseball managers, and any discussion of it might as well begin with the flat statement that no fan -- no Giant fan, particularly -- can think of going without it.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A strike of a comparatively small number of foremen in Detroit war plants in the last three weeks has proved to be a near-calamity, according to Gen. Henry H. Arnold, Chief of the Army Air Forces.

MORTON GOULD, one of America's sauciest composers, rarely produces music that is intellectually impressive, but neither does he write with a pen dipped in boredom. His "Latin-American" Symphonette No. 4, which is on the new Victor list (Album DM-964, three twelve-inch records), is not a work calculated to arouse veneration but it is a workmanlike, deft piece which is thoroughly enjoyable if approached in the proper mood.

Restoration of industrial sugar quotas to 80 per cent of manufacturers' 1941 consumption was attributed yesterday by Lamborn Co., sugar brokers, to the government's correction of its error of judgment in reducing the allotment to 70 per cent contrary to trade advice and to a miscalculation of the Cuban crop and the availability of shipping space.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange were firm yesterday and the close revealed small changes in either direction. Volume was the best for a two-hour session since April 8, for 361,570 shares were traded, against 220,110 a week earlier.

THE report that reached us from the Fifth Army recently, regarding the discovery of a priceless cache of Renaissance books and manuscripts in a ruined church abandoned by the Nazis, is heartening for more than one reason.

LONDON, May 20 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisan attacks have forced the Germans to suspend service on a section of the important Venice-Vienna railroad, one of two alternate lines between Italy and Austria on which the Germans rely heavily for supplying their Italian fronts, it was announced today.

THE prolific and tireless ants can turn a thriving garden or well-kept lawn into a wilderness unless they are exterminated as soon as detected. Not only do these persistent insects spoil the appearance and interfere with the growth of plants above ground, but their extensive tunneling under the surface often prevents healthy development of roots.

PHILADELPHIA May 20 (AP) -- The Indians pounded out twelve hits against Luman Harris while Mel Harder held the Athletics to three for a 5-0 shut-out in his 201st major league victory today. Cleveland clinched the game in the fourth when Pat Seerey hit a home run on top of the left field stands with one on base.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Bob Bilgrav's four-hit pitching and a two-run ninth-inning rally enabled Princeton to defeat Penn in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game today, 2 to 1, for the Tigers' first circuit victory in four starts.

THIS book is much more than its title would imply. The reviewer expected a dull catalogue of facts and figures, instead of which Dr. Rosinski, himself a German, has given us a fascinating study of the German Army from its beginnings under Frederick the Great until today.

MEXICAN tulip poppy is a deserving but neglected annual worth a trial in some inconspicuous flower bed. The common name indicates the origin, form and type of this plant usually listed as Hunnemannia. It comes from the hot, dry regions of Mexico and resembles the familiar California poppy, except that the bloom is larger and more cup-like.

PARENTS ask, "Did I do something wrong?" or they ask if poor eyesight or some other physical cause could have accounted for a child's poor learning performance. They blame themselves or "heredity" or the school. The premium put on high intellectual attainment in our society makes a lower-than-average I.Q. in the family very hard to take.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Prospects of early settlement of the century-old border dispute between Ecuador and Peru, brought messages of congratulation today from President Roosevelt to Presidents Prado of Peru and Arroyo of Ecuador. In identical messages President Roosevelt congratulated both Chief Executives tonight on the agreement.

AS expected, the board of trustees of the Town Hall last week approved a contract whereby The Reader's Digest next fall will sponsor "America's Town Meeting of the Air" over the Blue. It is the first major discussion program to be offered on a commercial basis, having been a sustaining show for the past nine years.

MONTREAT, N.C., May 20 (AP) -- Problems of post-war readjustment and a demand that the Sabbath be observed even by war production industries during the conflict will come before the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States at its meeting beginning here Thursday night.

THE blurbist announces, somewhat sensationally, that "The Malfreys," by Catherine Whitcomb is "sophisticated and fantastic." It is a lot better than that. Its author possesses the sensible, clear-eyed innocence of the little boy in the fairy tale who was not taken in by the emperor's non-existent new clothes.

Wholesale and chain buyers who appeared in large numbers in the Worth Street market last week expressed deep concern over the increasing difficulty in meeting immediate and fall needs in low end merchandise. In the case of piece goods and certain types of underwear, buyers met with little success.

BUFFALO, May 20 (AP) -- Myron Sulzberger of New York City, president of District Grand Lodge No. 1, B'nai B'rith, called upon members of the order tonight to carry "the banner of democracy" and identify themselves "with all groups united in their devotion to democratic ideals."

ST. LOUIS, May 20 -- Max Lanier, ace left-hander of the Cardinals, blanked the Giants on three hits tonight while Billy Southworth's pace-setting champions hammered the ears off four of Mel Ott's hurlers to win the opener of a three-game series, 10 to 0.

Ground will be broken at 10 A.M. tomorrow on the site of the former Madison Square Garden bowl, in Sunnyside, Queens, for a new building for New York's Postal Concentration Center, it was announced yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman.

WEATHER conditions returned as a factor in retail trade results for the week, following the spurt in sales due to observance of Mother's Day. Where warm temperatures prevailed retailers reported a heavy run on beachwear and other summer items.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Southpaw Frank Overmire scattered Washington ten blows as the Tigers downed the Senators, 6 to 2, tonight for their second consecutive victory of the current series.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Plans for rallying the labor vote behind President Roosevelt next November, should he be a candidate for a fourth term, were completed at a meeting held here this week by the CIO Political Action Committee after it had formally endorsed the President for re-election and called upon him to make the race as a matter of public duty.

" THE outstanding flowering tree in the whole of the temperate part of the world" does not seem an exaggerated description of the dogwood to these who have been enjoying its blossoms. Whether this distinguished native is a thousand strong along the edges of our woodlands or in such places as Valley Forge Park, or a single tree on our own front lawn, it seems to outlive all other flowering trees.

We have now seen two films about Japan, "Behind the Rising Sun" and "The Purple Heart," which give the American public a distorted view of the Japanese people. The false mysticism of Japanese "Bushido" chivalry they present does not exist in Japan.
Many buyers were in the market placing fall commitments last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.
GAETA, Italy, May 20 (AP) -- This Italian seacoast town lay in ruins today. The war had torn it apart stone by stone and then smashed the stones into pebbles.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 20 (U.P.) -- Fifteen polygamists were convicted today of unlawful cohabitation with fifty-five plural wives and faced a maximum sentence of five years imprisonment, a decision they said they had "prayed for" because they want the case to go to the Supreme Court and get it settled once and for all.

The Japanese Domei agency disclosed yesterday that Rear Admiral Torajiro Sato, "the pride of the submarine units," and Rear Admiral Tomejiro Tamagi headed a list of eighty-four naval officers who had been killed in action and were to receive posthumous awards for distinguished service.

THAT the Army, which has frequently been a headache to the radio industry with its necessarily rigorous military censorship of news and its heavy priority demands on manpower, can also be a blessing to radio stations, especially smaller ones, is vividly demonstrated in this bustling Carolina community (population 32,000 at the last census).

The fragrance of lilacs is strong on the May morning, and a bouquet of their blooms will scent a whole house. They make one glad to be around and to have a sense of smell. There's but one thing wrong with lilacs; they are so insistent that they sometimes overshadow May's other fragrances.

FOR some unknown reason, the American public can't resist polls of any description. Exhibit A is the Gallup Poll. Another and much lesser known one is the consensus which the Sporting News, baseball's Bible, has taken among the press box tenants. It sought opinions on managers in five distinct categories and here are the leaders:

The American Society for the Advancement of the Hebrew Institute of Technology in Haifa, Palestine, last night held its annual dinner-dance at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to mark the opening of a $500,000 drive. The money will be used for the building of laboratories for industrial and electrical engineering as a memorial to Brig. Gen. Frederick H. Kisch, late chief engineer of the British Eighth Army and a trustee of the Haifa Institute.

Pointing out that there are 360,000 adults in New York City who have never gone to school, Harold Fields, a member of the Board of Examiners, recommended yesterday establishment of institutes for adults who sought education. The time was ripe, he said, for a broad program in adult education that would help men and women to understand the principles of democracy.

The Opportunity Shop at 46 West Forty-seventh Street, a thrift mart operated as a permanent activity of the Community Service Society, yesterday initiated its annual appeal for "anything and everything" in the way of clothing, furniture, books and household furnishings.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Breaking the meet record of 71 1/2 points set by Southern California at Randalls Island, New York, in 1939, the athletes of the United States Naval Academy ran away with the sixty-eighth annual I.C. 4-A track and field cham pionships on Franklin Field today, piling up 81 points to leave the favored Army cadets far behind in second place with 35 1/2.

I HAVE been thinking about islands, those explosions of apparently uncharacteristic experience that occur in certain lives. Most of the people we know are terribly afraid of such islands. They see one looming ahead and they hurriedly steer off in another direction.

WHEN Adolf Hitler stood on the coast of France in 1940 and looked westward to this small, inadequately armed island he probably felt certain of at least two things: (1) That the RAF was numerically no match for his Luftwaffe; (2) that even if by some miracle it should prove to be, the number of airfields which it could operate was limited by the size of the British Isles.

WE know shockingly little about the stars -- we, the ordinary man, woman and child. We shall not, I believe, know more until the names of the stars are changed. What is wrong with the old names which have served the stars so long? They are, for the most part, inept, unfitting, unworthy of the stars and the human race -- and therefore do not excite our interest as they should.

NAPLES, May 20 -- American and French troops, smashing through the crumbling German defenses, pounded back the whole southern half of the German front today in a wide swing toward a new wall anchored at Terracina, only twenty-five miles from the Anzio beachhead.
NAPLES, May 20 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, May 20 -- Little more than three years ago the cocksure Luftwaffe, then the world's largest and most terrifying air force, launched swarms of bombers and fighters against Britain from air bases along the northern coast of western Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Leslie M. Merill, president of the American Gas Accumulator Company, an American affiliate of one of the Swedish concerns that THE NEW YORK TIMES reported this morning might be placed on the official blacklist unless Sweden cut off its ball-bearing exports to Germany, said today that his company was engaged in production for the United Nations war program. His statement follows:

BERNE, Switzerland, May 20 -- When France has been liberated and the Committee of National Liberation comes forward with its plans for what it calls "the Fourth Republic," the attitude of the French in France, to judge from reliable information seeping through, may bring surprises.

THE spy story is coming to be more and more the Anglo-Saxon prose vehicle for modest writers who have a message or a moral to propagate, who want to make some money -- or, shall we say, reach a wide audience -- and who apparently know their own creative limitations better than many aspirants to the serious novel.

Who Goes There, George D. Widener's bay 3-year-old, supplied the answer to that question yesterday when he won the sixty-ninth running of the $15,000 added Withers Mile that attracted 40,732 to Belmont Park for the twelfth day of the Westchester Racing Association's spring meeting.

CONCORD, N.H. -- This summer there will be no dimout along New Hampshire's short coastline, where some resorts open officially on Memorial Day. This is the traditional planting date for most of the State's upland commuities. Colonists plan bigger and better Victory gardens this year.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 20 -- Iowa State's team strength today overcame the individual brilliance of Kansas performers and the Cyclones took their first Big Six outdoor track and field outdoor championship with 67 points to 56 1/2 for the Kansans.
A 375-foot home run by Howie Sarath with one out in the last half of the ninth inning gave the New York University baseball team a 4-to-3 victory over Columbia yesterday at Ohio Field.

CASSINO, May 19 (Delayed) -- Tonight I walked through Cassino alone. It was that indefinable time when day is dead but night is not quite born. The light was blue-gray and the mountain was vague and dark, but, at the crest the broken abbey stood out in clear anguish against the sky.

Engineering plans for a $150,000,000 irrigation and hydro-electric development in Palestine, to be known as the Jordan Valley Authority, are being prepared here, with preliminary surveys already completed, it was announced yesterday.
Three ceremonies which have recently taken place in England, and of which I have seen no account in American newspapers, will, I think, be of interest to many of your readers.

LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- For the first time in a year, the western Allies are believed by military men in Britain to have a good chance to destroy a German army, thanks to Adolf Hitler's reported "fight-and-die" orders to German troops in Italy.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Faced for the first time with problems of surplus in a few categories, the Combined Raw Materials Board, in its second annual report, said that "a more lenient consumption policy could, for the time being, be justified by the easier raw materials position providing no other limiting factor arises."

The legislative and not the executive branch of the Federal Government should have ultimate control over the machinery for the reconversion of the American economic system from war to peace, it was held yesterday in a public statement adopted by the closing session of a two-day meeting of the National Post-war Conference, which consists of twenty-two representative business, industrial, financial, labor, agricultural and civic organizations.

BEDTIME STORY: A year ago the British Board of Trade (equivalent of the Department of Commerce), which regulates and allocates civilian supplies, warned travelers to take their own towels along. For exhibition at inland hotels -- since June, 1940, most East and South coastal areas have been restricted for defense reasons -- the board issued some 15,000 notices: "Bring your own towel."

CLEVELAND, May 20 -- Beneath many surface indications that life is going on relatively as usual in the Middle West these days, there is discernible a definite and growing tension traceable directly to an awareness that this section, along with the rest of the country and the world, is standing on the threshold of great and terrible events.

PITTSBURGH, May 20 (AP) -- Nick Strincevich limited the Phillies to seven hits, as the Pirates eked out a 4 -- 3 victory today in the first of a three-game series. As a result, Pittsburgh rose to second place, replacing the Reds.

CINCINNATI, May 20 -- With President Branch Rickey again watching from the stands the Durocher Dodgers found surcease from sorrow here today as they ended their losing streak at four games by beating Deacon Bill McKechnie's Reds 6 -- 1.

DOROTHY WHIPPLE established herself as an English author suitable for American consumption, when at the age of 12 she sold her first short story to The Buffalo Courier. Since then a steadily growing audience in this country has acclaimed her an excellent novelist of English country life.

" WHEN Arthur Hopkins 'presents,'" Brooks Atkinson wrote in this newspaper fourteen years ago, "that hackneyed old verb musters up a dignity. His goods are worth looking at." The general title of the series of dramas now being broadcast over WEAF-NBC on Wednesday nights at 11:30 is "Arthur Hopkins Presents," and again his goods are worth -- not looking at, because on the radio you do not see them, but mighty well worth hearing.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Vice President Wallace left today on the trip which will take him not only to China but to Siberia as a "messenger" for President Roosevelt, who stressed the importance of his mission in a statement issued from the White House.

FOR a man with so many irons in the fire Billy Rose should be pushing buttons, dictating memos, dashing hither and yon and maybe thinking seriously about a nervous breakdown. Au contraire, Mr. Rose, in his Beekman Place splendor, is placid, unruffled and unhurried.

ROBERT RISKIN, chief of the Overseas Motion Picture Bureau of the Office of War Information, who is here to plan with studio executives the production of twelve documentaries, expects that eventually all OWI film production will be transferred from New York to Hollywood.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20 (AP) -- Nine race horses and one pony were destroyed early today when fire razed one of the barns at historic Churchill Downs.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Central Westerners, who held ringside seats at the recent unfinished battle between the Government and Montgomery Ward Co., were not surprised this week when Sewell L. Avery, Ward's chairman, dragged into the fray Marshall Field, editor and publisher of the pro-Roosevelt Chicago Sun.

WITH CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES ATTACKING MYITKYINA IN BURMA, May 19 (Delayed) -- Brig. Gen. Frank Merrill's overland forces moved against Myitkyina across the wild, rugged 8,000-foot mountain barrier between the Hukawng Valley and the valley of the upper Irrawaddy.

CLEVELAND, May 20 (U.P.) -- Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, warning that another war might start with an attack on the United States, called upon all Americans tonight to support post-war organization to prevent such an event.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Capt. Lewis L. Strauss, USNR, is given credit today for the inception of the Army-Navy production award, under which almost three thousand plants fly the "E" flag, with official summaries of the award program being inserted in the Congressional Record.

The Regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that 1,200 motorists in its jurisdiction, including 104 in the New York Metropolitan area, are facing charges that they illegally used their gasoline rations to drive to Florida and other southern resorts last winter.

LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- Two new versions of the A-20 Havoc light bomber, each capable of carrying a ton of high explosives, are now flying against the Germans from British bases, Lieut. Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, commander of the United States Ninth Air Force, announced today.

If you were to ask Dr. Albert W. Hull of the General Electric Laboratories about the future of research in industry he would tell you that its possibilities are limitless. From an address which he delivered recently before the American Physical Society we gather that any imaginative, energetic physicist has only to look around him to discover enough to improve.

Youth everywhere should work together to create a world where people can live in a security that will assure them freedom from want and fear, four teen-agers agreed yesterday, speaking to each other across the Atlantic Ocean.

The City Council adopted yesterday, by a vote of 10 to 6, a budget of $731,973,092 for 1944-45, lopping $5,427,851 from the budget of $737,400,923 approved by the Board of Estimate on May 1. Its action was in accordance with recommendations submitted by its Finance Committee, whose report was approved by the same vote margin.

In the usual procedure of taking out stones from kidneys with forceps, the surgeon finds it almost impossible not to injure the sensitive tissues. Sometimes the stones crumble or break in the forceps, so that it is hard to pick out all the fragments.

NAPLES, May 20 -- American infantry and artillery, supported by tanks and followed by engineers, have seized Itri, three miles inland in the coastal sector. They had advanced from Formia along the Appian Way. As a result, the Germans can no longer count on the important lateral link between the forces in the coastal sector and those in the Liri Valley.
A program of American and Russian music, including songs by Stephen Foster and Jerome Kern, will be broadcast by the Russian radio today, the Office of War Information was informed last night.

Miller (United States Marine Hospital, Ellis Island) told the American Psychiatric Association last week. Six of Dr. Miller's patients were marines who could not sleep and six had been morphine addicts.

A MAN on his way to work in a Washington street car one morning in May, 1940, was murmuring "Pipe dream, pipe dream" as he read his newspaper. What drew his protest was a call by President Roosevelt for American production of 50,000 airplanes a year.

The Catholic Center for the Blind will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Career Angel," a new comedy by Gerard M. Murray, on the night of June 1 at the National Theatre. Mrs. William F. Cogswell is president of the board of managers of the organization, and Miss Ada Semmes Clarke, honorary president.

LONDON, May 20 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower delivered to underground patriots in occupied Europe by radio today the first of a series of "operational orders" to govern the part they will play in the coming invasion. The supreme commander's instruc tions were read first in English this afternoon over the British Broadcasting Corporation's radio and the Office of War Information's new propaganda station, ABSIE.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Combined Production and Resources Board, representing the war production agencies of the United States and Britain, soon will send to Britain an American coal mission composed of technical and economic experts to confer with British Government and mining officials, the combined board announced today.

MOSCOW, May 20 (AP) -- Maj. Alexander Pokryshkino, easy-going Siberian who is Russia's leading ace, is worried for fear the Germans will make him swellheaded. He is credited with shooting down fifty-three German planes.

QUIETLY, without the usual fanfare attending the production of commerce films, the Overseas Motion Picture Bureau of the Office of War Information has been plugging away for going on two years on its project of making special movies to elevate America abroad.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 20 -- A capacity audience thronged the Packer Memorial Chapel on Lehigh University campus for the second day this afternoon to hear the Mass in B minor, concluding the thirty-seventh Bethelehem Bach Festival.

The Federal Government is racing against time to move its huge egg purchases into cold storage before hot weather further complicates a glutted market. As thousands of cases of eggs purchased under the Government's price support program piled up here and as far west as Portland, Ore., the War Food Administration discussed the emergency yesterday at a special meeting in Washington.

Unprecedented significance will be given this year to National Maritime Day, celebrated tomorrow by a nation that has come to appreciate the all-important part our American Merchant Marine has played thus far in the prosecution of a war with battlefronts scattered all over the world.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 20 -- To 129 wounded and sick soldiers who came today to England General Hospital here the news of the fall of Cassino was nothing short of unbelievable. The steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral will be gay with many varieties of spring flowers on Tuesday when the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, Inc., holds its ninth annual flower mart. PRINCETON, N.J., May 20 (AP) -- Army defeated Navy in an extra hole play-off today to win the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Championship. Dartmouth, Princeton, Cornell and Penn State trailed in that order at the end of the thirty-six holes of medal play over the Springdale course.

The extent of our victory, therefore, may be measured historically by the durability of the peace that is to be fashioned by the United Nations' leaders when the fighting is over.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 20 -- Dartmouth's baseball team made it four straight in Eastern Intercollegiate League competition today with 8-1 and 11-3 victories over Cornell. The games went seven innings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 20 -- Army maintained its prestige as one of the outstanding college baseball teams of the East by defeating Yale today in twelve innings, 7 to 6, before 1,800 spectators. It was the seventh straight victory for the cadets, who have won ten of their eleven starts this season.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Senator Maybank of South Carolina, declared today that southern Democrats were prepared to carry their battle for "white supremacy" to the party's national convention, adding that "anything can happen" if they lost.

I have just finished reading "Thanks America -- And Good-by" by Anselm Acker in THE NEW YORK TIMES MAGAZINE. I, too, am one of the British evacuees in this country. To me, this article seemed to express thoughts and feelings that I could not put into words.

FORT RILEY, Kan. THE New York music lover, accustomed to the easy accessibility of concert and opera halls and the record collections of himself and friends, has a rude shock in store for him when he is inducted into the service and has to adapt his musical m enthusiasms to new conditions

Establishment of a Jewish Commonwealth in Palestine was urged yesterday by Rabbi Israel Goldstein, president of the Zionist Organization of America and Synagogue Council of America, in his twenty-fifth anniversary sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The rare occasion when a book that has attracted wide attention comes under the ban of the Post-office Department, as in the recent case of the novel "Strange Fruit," may give the impression that such action is exceptional. On the contrary, the department reportedly bans "several thousand" publications a year.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 20 -- Whether the present political strength of the Republican and Democratic parties be appraised by scientific sampling polls or by an analysis of the special Congressional elections in recent months, the answer is virtually the same.
CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:
Mrs. Roger Welles, wife of Major Welles of the Army, has arrived from Washington and is at the Weylin.

THREE years ago Vanport, in Oregon, was a small semi-rural area. Today it is a city of 40,000 people. In the same period the population of San Diego has jumped from 203,000 to about 400,000, excluding the uniformed forces that add many thousands. Portland, Me., is today the center of 150,000 people, as against the pre-war figure of 100,000.

CHUNGKING, China, May 20 (AP) -- Chinese troops clamped a firmer hold on their re-won section of the Peiping-Hankow railway today, capturing the railway city of Kioshan, 110 miles south of Chengchow, the High Command announced.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, May 20 (U.P.) -- American infantrymen completed the three-day conquest of the Wakde Islands Friday by annihilating the last remaining Japanese defenders, who made their final desperate stand behind grounded airplanes and concrete pillboxes, a communique announced today.

Opposition to any legislation that would establish minimum standards of quality, construction and materials for furniture after the removal of wartime controls on the industry as recently proposed in Great Britain was expressed yesterday by a spokesman for furniture manufacturers in this country.

OMAHA, May 20 -- The first fortnight of uninterrupted working weather since the season opened lies behind the Middle Western farmer. Out of it begins to emerge some outline of the shape which another year of food production may take.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 20 -- About 100 persons in the city of Buenos Aires and a like number in the interior of Argentina are being held in jails at the disposal of the political police for their alleged conspiracy against the military government. The majority of them are workers and labor leaders.

GEN. MAX HOFFMANN, the most brilliant German Staff officer on the Eastern Front in the first World War, witnessed the incessant struggle for power and personal advancement among the Kaiser's generals.

FOR the purposes of the novelist there can hardly have been a war like this one since the fall of Troy. The newspapers almost every day release stories which no sober writer before 1939 would have dared to
After fluctuating a few points on each side of the previous closing levels, prices on the Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, having risen 1 to 2 points. The volume of business was small.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 -- The West Coast, harassed since the war's beginning by transportation problems and told frequently by Government spokesmen that the worst is yet to come, has shouted more than once that it cannot meet its obligations without more trains, more buses, more trucks, more gasoline, more tires, more street cars.

IT is not always easy to convince the authorities that one is a murderer, as Rocky Smith finds to his astonishment. His plan, when he confesses to the murder of Jane Fry in Laurel, Utah, is to remain safely in jail for a few days and then to present evidence to prove his innocence.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- Henry J. Kaiser criticized the Navy Department tonight, saying it had decided to terminate suddenly its plane contracts at the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation's big Long Island City and Johnsville, Pa., plants.

When the United States Supreme Court decided that the salaries of certain employes of the Port of New York Authority were subject to the Federal income tax (Helvering v. Gerhardt, 304 U.S. 405), seed was sown in an attempt to tax also the interest on bonds issued by that corporate entity.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- A warning against a "runaway" price movement in city homes, coupled with inflationary mortgage lending on such property was issued by today by John H. Fahey, commissioner of the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration.

THE wartime separation of families, sweethearts, husbands and wives, according to portrait photographic studios, accounts for the great number of people who are having their pictures taken these days.

Retail trade continued active here last week, with seasonal apparel and accessories in brisk request. Department store volume was estimated as running 15 per cent or more ahead of the like week last year.

SOMEWHERE IN YUGOSLAVIA, May 14 (Delayed) -- The exact names of the fighting forces of which Marshal Tito is supreme commander is the National Liberation Army and the Partisan Detachments of Yugoslavia.

In 1818 Moses Rogers, a Connecticut man who had commanded the Phoenix, a steam vessel of the Hoboken Stevenses running by Sandy Hook and Cape May to the Delaware River, saw under construction in this town a sailing packet intended for service between New York and Havre.

In the military sense victory is not without serious hazards for the victorious countries. Nations that have won wars are always tempted to glorify the methods and weapons that brought success, and therefore to hold on to them long after they have become outmoded.

Failure to buy war bonds out of earnings of $125 a week as a war worker resulted yesterday in a five-day jail term and a $25 fine for one of three persons who pleaded guilty in Brooklyn Week-End Court to charges of disorderly conduct in participating in a boisterous celebration of Norwegian Independence Day.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 21 -- American and Chinese jungle troops have fought their way through one-third of Myitkyina, capturing the railroad station in ferocious street fighting, and all three principal Japanese bases in far northern Burma have been almost completely isolated, it was announced today.
With reference to your editorial on April 17 "What Is Our Production?" and to the letter from Mr. Thomas and Mr. Garfield that appeared May 4, the following comments may help to clarify the issue.

What Russia was yesterday, Italy is today -- the main Allied battlefield. Until invading forces succeed in opening a front on as great a scale elsewhere, the Italian peninsula will remain the focus of the fight for Europe. Even in Moscow the Italian campaign is no longer characterized as a secondary front.

A commemorative dinner and spring folk dance festival will be given tomorrow night at the East Side House Settlement, 540 East Seventy-sixth Street, in celebration of the fifty-third anniversary of the founding of East Side House by the Church Club of New York.

We shall have to work after the war on the problem of growing young men and young women who are better equipped physically. The percentage of rejections in the armed services has been disappointingly high and must have come as a surprise to a good many people who supposed, because of our enthusiasm as a nation for sports, that our youth must be extremely fit.

NEW ORLEANS, May 21 -- Advices from private sources somewhat confirming recent smaller crop ideas and a reported expanding demand for actuals over the South accounted for a sharp upturn in cotton futures the first half of last week here.

CHUNGKING, China, May 21 (AP) -- China found hope and comfort today in the news that Vice President Henry A. Wallace was coming to China and drew a fresh surge of confidence from the belief that he would bring concrete pledges on the nature and extent of American help for improving the economic and military situation here.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Wheat prices continued their downward movement last week as the result of selling indicated by increased offerings of new winter wheat for shipment by June 15 from Texas, favorable weather and crop comments from other areas and in sympathy with weakness in rye. July and September sold at a new low since late last year and December in new seasonal ground.

FOLKESTONE, England, May 21 (U.P.) -- They say you get used to anything if you have lived here. Even the sheep on the Kentish farms, who have caught more shrapnel in their woolly coats than most front-line troops ever dodged, seem to take the constant drone of our bombers and fighter planes in their stride.

LONDON, May 21 -- Word of sharp, new fratricidal fighting in Yugoslavia reached London tonight while that country's politicians in exile were still negotiating for the formation of a new Government that might bring unity among the contending factions.

MOSCOW, May 21 (AP) -- Alexei, 67-year-old Metropolitan of Leningrad and Novgorod, became acting Patriarch of All Russia today with announcement that the Holy Synod of the Russian Orthodox Church had "accepted and fulfilled the last will and testament of the late Holy Patriarch Sergius."
ON THE FIFTH ARMY FRONT, IN ITALY, May 21 (AP) -- A booby trap on an abandoned German anti-tank artillery piece narrowly missed killing Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, Fifth Army commander, this morning.

A proposal that ration points be removed altogether from beef is one of many "suggestions for improving the rationing program" submitted to the Office of Price Administration by the American Meat Institute.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 -Undaunted by the failure of negotiations to reach an understanding with the various parties, President Juan Antonio Rios opened the session of Congress today with a long message, in accordance with the procedure followed every year.
LONDON, May 21 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Limitations on exports of lard to the West Indies and Central America have been eliminated for the time being, and the amount that can be shipped is expected to be limited only by available steamship room. Cuba has been in the market for supplies recently and it is expected that a good business will be done.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, May 22 (UP) -- A communique:

WITH SIXTH ARMY FORCE ON THE WAKDE ISLANDS, May 21 (AP) -- This little 8,000-foot coral island [Insumuar, one of the Wakdes and the center of Japanese resistance] was nothing more than an air strip surrounded by coconut palms, but tonight it is bloody from one extremity to the other after a two-day battle.

H.J. Kenner, general manager of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, declared yesterday in the bureau's twenty-second annual report, which will be sent to members today, that the public's strongest protection from wartime deception in merchandising lies in the integrity of business which consistently "plays fair" in its advertising and selling practices.

AMERICAN and British airmen have crashed or parachuted to earth within the walls of festung Europa in large numbers. A considerable number have escaped, aided by the underground, walking by night, armed with false papers obtained by mysterious means. Their adventures have been romantic, exciting, hair-raising and desperate. Few details have as yet been allowed to be published as to how such escapes are acytually made.

PEARL HARBOR, May 21 -- A lone Liberator, flying from our powerful bases in the Aleutian Islands, has pushed American air power to within 900 miles of Tokyo and 400 of Japan proper to bomb Shimushiri and Ketoi Islands in the Kuriles for the first time.

A plan to expand the junior auxiliary of the American Women's Voluntary Services for post-war work and to train its members for community service will be presented today by Mrs. Alan Kissock, national chairman of the auxiliary, at the opening of the third annual national AWVS convention in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, appealed to advertisers today to avoid commercial exploitation of "D-day" or the actual invasion of Europe.

NAPLES, May 21 (U.P.) -- The Germans have been forced to send six of their twenty-five divisions in Italy to the northern border regions to fight off Italian patriots and Yugoslav Partisans who have opened a major drive against German supply lines to the main Italian front, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -Congressional sources are predicting that the American Legion will become the greatest political force in the country, even greater than labor, as its membership expands with veterans of this war.

In celebration of thirty years of continuous philanthropic service, the Junior Emergency Relief Society will hold its annual luncheon tomorrow in the ballroom of the Biltmore. Mrs. Walter Eyre Lambert, who founded the society in 1914, will preside.

BALTIMOR, May 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told about 5,000 Negroes today that the United States must show other nations "that all peoples should go forward together, and no group can remain disunited without bringing harm to the rest of the world."
LONDON, Monday, May 22 (UP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

LONDON, Monday, May 22 (U.P.) -- Red Army forces killed approximately 800 Germans yesterday in turning back attacks in the Stanislav area of Poland and along the lower Dniester River northwest of Tiraspol, Moscow announced early today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 21 -About 1,350 Jewish orphans, whose parents were murdered by Germans and Rumanians, are waiting hopelessly in Bucharest, Rumania, for the arrival at Constanta of the Turkish steamer Tari to carry them to Palestine.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, May 21 (AP) -- Attorney General Francis Biddle declared here today that thousands of new citizens in this country must give unqualified allegiance to the United States, and that there could be no unity in the land if old-world political conflicts were continued.

With candy in limited supply, the wartime demand for maple sugar has been greater than in other years. Happily, the 1944 production was unusually heavy, according to the United States Department of Agriculture, and a quantity is on hand in city stores.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (U.P.) -- The War Department has issued regulations requiring Army unit commanders to seek a reduction in medical discharges of enlisted men and listing defects which bar overseas duty.

After an early rise, prices of cotton turned easier last week and lost much of their advance. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed gains of 4 to 13 points, with the spot month showing the best advance.

After extreme inactivity at the week's opening, news of Allied advances in Italy changed the picture. Volume of business, before the week-end, nearly doubled. Capture of Cassino, before which the Allies have been held back four months, and further gain of territory afterward, appealed to financial imagination.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations fired another volley tonight at the National Labor Relations Board, accusing it of "retreating from the principles of the Wagner Act."

Last October a Gallup survey revealed that 54 per cent of those asked favored approval of treaties by a simple majority of both the House and Senate, whereas only 25 per cent favored retention of the present system of treaty ratification by two-thirds of the Senate alone.

Techniques for improving collective bargaining within industrial plants rather than through the Government will be studied at a conference on "Management's Stake in Collective Bargaining" sponsored by the American Management Association at the Hotel Astor Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (U.P.) -Shift of two key naval commanders from the South Pacific area -- Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., and Vice Admiral Aubrey W. Fitch -- was believed tonight to presage changes in the Navy's top command.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The National Inventors Council of the Department of Commerce is asking the public to send in ideas for the protection of soldiers against flame-throwers.
DES MOINES, May 21 (AP) -Four persons were drowned in Iowa flood waters today, bringing to nine the death toll from storms and floods of the last four days.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -Philip H. Cohen, 33, was named today director of the powerful new American broadcasting station in Europe, ABSIE, set up by the Office of War Information to beam messages from London to the antiAxis underground.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 21 -- Champion Gessner's Rolf v. Siegzell, a black-and-tan Doberman pinscher dog, today was named for the best-in-show title in the final competition of the forty-second annual all-breed show of the Long Island Kennel Club at the Mineola Fair Grounds.
CHUNGKING, China, May 21 (AP) -- A communique:

Bernard A. Grossman, manager of the men's neckwear, handkerchief and belt departments of R.H. Macy Co., has resigned to join the J.F. Ingals Company, neckwear manufacturers. He will be succeeded by Milton Thiessen, assistant manager of the drug department.

SEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Central Pacific (AP) -- An Army airman with a broken arm and two others with broken legs swam fifty yards through the Pacific Ocean from their wrecked bomber to life rafts.

Style is headed for a season of glamour not experienced since the war began, says Maurice Rentner, one of New York's leading creators of fashion trends. He bases his statement on his knowledge of feminine psychology as well as his study of fashion history.

CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- The cellar-haunting Cubs, heretofore quiet folk at the plate, broke out with the big-inning technique today to rout the Braves twice, 15 to 1 and 14 to 5, before 17,138 fans. The second game was called at the end of seven and one-half innings because of darkness.

The "German Requiem" of Brahms was performed by the Dessoff Choirs, under Paul Boepple, yesterday afternoon at the City Center, under the auspices of that institution. On the program, which was the first to be given by tenants of the Center, was also the "Elegie Francaise" for orchestra by Ernst Levy, Swiss composer.

The city has just broken all records for real estate tax collections, with 91.1 per cent of the current levy paid into its treasury by April 30, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -Michael O'Shea has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox to play the title role in "Commando Kelly," the picture to be based on the life of Sgt. Charles E. Kelly of Pittsburgh, who recently received the Congressional Medal of Honor for heroic action in Italy.

All Japanese operations in northern Burma hinge on Myitkyina. Linked directly to Rangoon both by rail and water, it is at once a natural base of supply and a fortress closing the back door to China. Now Merrill's Marauders are surging through the town, American planes are sinking boatloads of the enemy fleeing down the Irrawaddy and the door to China is swinging open.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus ended last night an engagement of forty-six and one-half days in Madison Square Garden, establishing a new high attendance record of 1,162,000 persons. There were ninety-three performances in that period, the longest engagement of the Big Show at the Garden.
NAPLES, May 21 (AP) -- The following statement was issued to the press today by Allied headquarters in the Mediterranean theatre:

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Following are the texts of President Roosevelt's order directing the seizure of the Hummer Manufacturing Division of Montgomery Ward Co. and the letter of William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, to the President recommending executive action:
Six new films, including two foreign-made importations, are scheduled to arrive in Broadway theatres this week. The openings follow:

Men and women of the armed forces of the United Nations -those in uniform only -- will be able to attend "Oklahoma!" at a reduced-price scale, 60 cents to $2.10, on Tuesday afternoons, beginning June 6. During holiday weeks the Tuesday matinee will be omitted.

NEWARK, N.J., May 21 (AP) -The Bears and the Little Giants swapped shut-out performances today before a crowd of 5,697. The Jerseys bagged the first game, 3 -- 0, and Newark came back with a 1 -- 0 triumph in the nightcap.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The cumulative effect of the war and the increasing impact of Allied military operations have made the 1944-45 food outlook in Europe "by no means favorable to the Axis," the Department of Agriculture's Office of Foreign Agricultural Relations reported today in an analysis of the European food situation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, May 22 (U.P.) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique today reported that a single Solomons-based Liberator of the Thirteenth Army Air Forces, ranging over the Pacific near the Nomol group in the Carolines Friday, damaged a Japanese freighter. Another Liberator bomber attacked Lamotrek, 540 miles west of Nomoi and between Truk and Woleai, Thursday and destroyed nine enemy floating planes and set fire to a fuel dump.

The Communist Political Association, formerly the Communist party of the United States, adopted yesterday a constitution opening its membership to any resident of this country over 18 years old interested in "the advancement and protection of the interests of the nation and its people."

LONDON, May 21 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices in April, based on 1930 as 100, reached a new wartime high at 165.5, comparing with 164.9 in March and 162.8 in April last year. Since August, 1939, the aggregate increase has been 69 per cent, food and tobacco being 75 and industrial materials 65 per cent higher.

LONDON, May 21 (U.P.) -- Intensified fighting between Chetnik and Partisan forces throughout Yugoslavia was reported today by Marshal Tito, who charged that General Mikhailovitch, who has been dropped as Royal Yugoslav War Minister, personally had taken charge of operations against Partisan forces on the Serb-Sanjak border.

An appeal to world youth, issued by the third anti-Fascist meeting of Soviet youth held in Moscow yesterday, pledged Russian young people to "still more powerful blows against the Germans," called on guerillas to "help the advancing Red Army by every possible means" and expressed gratitude for Allied aid.

The demobilization of some 10,000,000 service men at the close of this war will present "a tremendous challenge to the Christian church," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, the pastor, said yesterday morning in a sermon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street. He said hundreds of thousands of them would require guidance and spiritual help.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Progress is reported in obtaining pledges from farmers to sell cash corn to the Commodity Credit Corporation, more than 50,000,000 bushels having been bought so far, or more than 60 per cent of the goal. The remainder of the 80,000,000 bushels estimated to be needed to cover industrial requirements for the rest of the season is expected to be purchased without much trouble.

" DID I ever tell you about the time I went duck-hunting?" asked Stout Steve Owen and never waited for an answer. "Well, sir," he began, "I was down at the Sugar Bowl game in New Orleans one year and a fellow named Pat Moulton suggested that I go up to Mobile Bay with him for a spot of duck-hunting. I told him that no duck had ever gotten away from me in my life.

DETROIT, May 21 (U.P.) -- Members of Local 490, United Automobile Workers (CIO), defied a War Labor Board return-to-work order today and an overwhelming majority voted at a closed mass meeting to continue their strike at six Chrysler Corporation plants.

LONDON, May 21 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's pre-invasion order to the underground armies in Europe by radio yesterday has stirred alarm among the collaborators with Germany at Vichy. Today Philippe Henriot, Vichy Minister of Information, broadcast a warning of bloody reprisals against Frenchmen who aided the liberating forces.

Compulsory allotments from service men's pay to wives believed to have been unfaithful form one of the major problems under the allotment law, according to the annual report of the war committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, which Charles E. Hughes Jr., chairman, made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Although a few unfavorable comments regarding the outlook for winter wheat are coming from some areas, the general situation is regarded as very favorable, and so far there has been nothing to indicate any
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -An April increase of 35 per cent in production of landing craft pushed the 80,000-vessel program 2 per cent ahead of schedule, the War Manpower Commission reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -The Army and Navy should demobilize qualified teachers and guidance specialists somewhat in advance of other service men to staff depleted faculties and assure the veterans educational opportunities when they are discharged, says a research bulletin of the National Education Association.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 21 -- The Bulgarian Regency Council has been "invited" to go to Berchtesgaden tomorrow for consultation with Adolf Hitler, it was reported today. Bulgaria is the object of virtual ultimatums from both the Germans and the Russians. The Germans demand the immediate rupture of diplomatic relations with Moscow and the Russians seek a clarification of Bulgaria's official attitude.
TITO'S HEADQUARTERS, in Yugoslavia (Reuter) -- The British military mission to Marshal Tito's headquarters is one year old this month.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose 0.1 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.91 to the all-time high of 112.97. The raw materials index and the farm products index rose 0.2 per cent and 0.1 per cent respectively as a result of price increases in apples, oranges, cotton and steers.
LONDON, May 21 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force in Europe communique:

CLEVELAND, May 21 -- Dr. Elizabeth Wisner of Tulane University, president of the National Conference on Social Work, invoked the specter of the post-war era of the conflict of 1917-18 to emphasize the acute dislocations of American life today, when she made the opening address at the annual session of the organization tonight.

CINCINNATI, May 21 -- The Dodgers made a lot of frantic and futile gestures on Crosley Field today and the Sunday crowd of 17,319 Rhineland fans wended its homeward way late in the evening chortling happily over a double Red triumph, 5 -- 3 and 6 -- 5, the second in ten innings.
Before baseball's biggest crowd of the year, 59,161 persons, of whom 54,725 paid, the Yankees concluded their home stand with a double victory over the Browns at the Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Following the War Department's announcement that it had created the Army Nurse's Aides, the Red Cross reported today that ninety nurse's aides had been employed in the Eighth Service Command and that 700 more were to be recruited from Certificated Red Cross Volunteer Nurse's Aides.

ST. LOUIS, May 21 -- Melvin Ott seemed literally to lift himself and his faltering Giants up by their bootstraps today as the Polo Grounders brought their Western trip to a close by gaining an even break with the high-flying Cardinals, in a twin bill that gave 11,404 onlookers a variety of entertainment.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP) -The Athletics took the second half of a double-header with the Indians today, 3 to 2, after losing the first game, 5 to 4, in the eleventh, before 28,216 fans at Shibe Park. It was the Indians' third victory of the four-game series.

AT A FIFTH ARMY VETERINARY HOSPITAL, May 21 -- After slogging through the desolation around Cassino, it is good to learn here that not all the mules and horses injured in the mountain campaigning in Italy end their lives hideously wounded and uncared for on the rocky slopes.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -Predictions of a stiff fight on the floor of the House this week over the request of the Office of War Information for an additional $26,000,000 for the fiscal year were made tonight after members of an Appropriations Subcommittee paid a surprise visit to the New York office of the OWL.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (U.P.) -The Senate silver group and some delegations to the coming international monetary conference will demand that any international stabilization scheme be based on silver as well as gold.

CLEVELAND, May 21 -- In response to a message from President Roosevelt to the National Conference of Jewish Welfare, delegates adopted a resolution today offering the resources of the 250 component welfare agencies and 650 individual social workers "toward the end of facilitating the orderly demobilization and reabsorption of returning service men and women into civilian life."

CAREY, Ohio, May 21 (AP) -- In the hush of a church remote from the war he has lived, Capt. Don S. Gentile knelt with his family before a little shrine today and fulfilled once again the vow his mother made when her boy was saved from death in babyhood.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 21 (UP) -- A communique:

New York and Connecticut, pioneering among the States in efforts to develop and strengthen Latin-American business ties after the war, held dinners here last night for business men of Central and South America who will participate in two independently arranged State-wide tours this week.

America has shown the way toward a permanent world peace by the spirit behind its work in the Philippines, Col. Carlos P. Romulo, Secretary of the Department of Information and Public Relations of the Philippine Government, told 1,000 members of the Alumnae and Alumni Associations of Fordham University at their annual corporate communion luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Under an almost cloudless blue sky, with just enough sun and a compensating breeze to make the day ideal, what was officially said to be the largest number of persons ever to assemble at one point in the city's history turned out in Central Park yesterday for the fourth annual celebration of "I Am An American Day."
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -The cost of living rose six-tenths of 1 per cent from March to April, the Labor Department reported today. Part of the rise was attributed to higher excise taxes.

What China faces today and her hopes for the future were discussed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. W. Plumer Mills, for twelve years a Presbyterian missionary there, who returned from the Orient recently on the liner Gripsholm.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -Admiral Ernest J. King deplored today what he said was a tendency to believe "that the end of the war is close at hand, both in the Atlantic and Pacific."

CAIRO, Egypt, May 21 - -Delegates representing all Greek political parties and national resistance groups yesterday closed their four-day congress in Beirut by signing a "national charter," which will serve as the basis for creating a Pan-Hellenic coalition.
LONDON, May 21 -- When D-day comes, the German Luftwaffe will enter the struggle to determine the future fate of Europe depleted in strength but still strong in numbers.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 21 -- The Right Hon. William L. Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of Canada, dropped out of a dark sky at 10:20 o'clock tonight, well satisfied with his British conferences and ready to take up the reins of his Government of Canada, and get on with the war effort again.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY in Fondi, Italy, May 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Walter B. Yeager got the "biggest kick" of his life when he led his battalion in to capture this town today on important Highway 7 to Rome -- thirty airline miles from the Anzio beachhead.

PITTSBURGH, May 21 (AP) -- The Pirates won the first game of a double-header from the Phillies today, 4 to 3, and were behind, 9 to 4, when the second game was called at the end of the eighth inning because of the Pennsylvania 7 P.M. Sunday baseball law.

The People's Chorus of New York will celebrate its twenty-eighth anniversary on Friday night with a Spring Song Festival in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Lorenzo Camilieri, founder and director of the organization, will conduct.

LONDON, Monday, May 22 -- In the most concentrated attack of the war on continental rail lines and yards and other Nazi communication facilities, great fleets of Allied fighters, fighter-bombers and medium bombers fanned out from the Breton Peninsula of France to points well east of Berlin yesterday in an all-out effort to cripple Hitler's battered war transport machine.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Predicting the early defeat of Germany and Japan, but not without a hard, tough fight, Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commander of the American Air Forces, received a thunderous ovation today from 30,000 persons gathered in the rain at Soldier Field for observance of "I Am An American Day."

Recently the Civil Aeronautics Board, of its own motion, simplified the regulations governing private flying and asked suggestions for further simplification of the rules governing safety. The experience of combat aircraft and of the larger combat types used for the transportation of men and goods for war indicates that study might well be made of modification of the airworthiness requirements which will be expected of passenger and cargo planes in the post-war period.

Sixteen Republican women made public yesterday an open letter of protest to Livingston Platt, Republican leader of Westchester, against his refusal to designate Assemblyman Jane H. Todd for Congress in the newly created Twenty-seventh Congressional District, which includes northern Westchester and Putnam.

MOSCOW, May 21 (AP) -- Prof. Oscar Lange of Chicago announced today he had received personal assurances from Premier Stalin that "Poland is going to play a very important role in Europe." The Soviet leader also told the Polish-American visitor, "It is in the interests of the Soviet Union that Poland be strong."

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- To Second Lieut. Robert Craig, who died under the fire of 100 Germans when he sacrificed himself to save his platoon, has been awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor by the War Department.

WITH CHINESE-AMERICAN I FORCES AT MYITKYINA, in Burma, May 17 (Delayed) -- For Brig. Gen. Frank Merrill's American Raider detachment this week's attack on Myitkyina is the climax to four months of marching and combat in Burma jungles.

Of accidents connected with home canning last year, more than 80 per cent resulted from use of the oven canning method, the National Safety Council has discovered from a national survey. About 15 per cent of the accidents causing injuries and property damage occurred in canning with pressure cookers, and these were usually due to failure to follow directions.

Volume buying of the Canadian free dollar last week lifted the value of that currency to 90.93 cents, highest since Sept. 20, 1939. The week's lowest was 90.56 cents, made on Tuesday, while Saturday's closing of 90.82 cents, represented a gain of 1/16 cent over the preceding week.

LONDON, May 21 -- The stock markets have returned practically to normal. That is they have reverted to the condition of quietude prevailing before the introduction of the budget, although not losing the improvement that occurred then.

RYE BEACH, N.Y., May 21 -- Four White Plains high school students, with a fine disdain or whaling procedures, towed a dead 900-pound whale one and one-half miles to shore here yesterday, leaving local police with an odiferous problem they were obliged to pass on to the Coast Guard.

Scientific research in a limited area to measure the actual stages in the operation of prejudices was proposed by Dr. E. George Payne, dean of the New York School of Education and president of the League for National Unity, at a dinner of the league last night in the Park Central Hotel.
