ALGIERS, May 21 -- The explanation given by Allied Mediterranean Force Headquarters for the delay in censoring an Associated Press interview with Marshal Tito, Yugosalv national liberation leader, was regarded today as a historic fact since a military bureaucracy thus took the trouble to defend its censorship policy to correspondents and the public.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -With the Democratic and Republican National Conventions less than two months away, President Roosevelt is overwhelmingly assured of a fourth-term nomination if he wants it and Governor Dewey appears certain of selection as Republican standard bearer, possibly on the first ballot, without lifting a hand.
AURORA, N.Y., May 21 (AP) -Life offers no greater satisfaction than the pursuit and discovery of truth, President W.E. Weld of Wells College declared today in a baccalaureate address.

Book advertising in New York newspapers for the first four months of 1944 totaled 848,119 agate lines, an increase of 5.2 per cent over the corresponding period of last year, according to figures compiled from Media Records. The increase is indicative of the heavy demand for books under wartime conditions which have eliminated automobile touring and decreased participation in sports.

LONDON, Monday, May 22 (AP) -- Three thousand Allied planes, mostly fighters, converted western Europe into a gigantic shooting gallery yesterday, sweeping across Germany, France and the Low Countries in the most colossal ground-strafing onslaught of the war with vast success.

Seventy-five hundred members of the Jewish War Veterans, its auxiliary and other organizations marched yesterday on Fifth Avenue to honor the dead of four wars. To the music of sixteen bands, the marchers went from Ninety-second Street south in Lexington and Fifth Avenues to Temple Emanu-El at Sixty-fifth Street, where the forty-ninth annual memorial services brought a capacity audience of 3,000.

NAPLES, May 21 -- French forces in the central sector of the Italian front pushed generally northwestward yesterday from the area astride the Pontecorvo-Pico highway, and the Adolf Hitler Line was being turned.

Five hundred friends and members of the W.I.V.E.S. Club, organization of service men's wives, anticipated the opening of the Fifth War Loan Drive by holding a rally of their own yesterday afternoon at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel. Twirling a globe of the world and calling for bonds for each battlefront, Lieut. (j.g.) Harold Mantel and Coxswain George McLaughlin sold $23,200 worth of bonds.

A resolution urging the United States Government and Allied nations "to take immediate steps to secure 'free ports' in various countries as a haven for all war refugees" was unanimously passed by delegates at the sixth annual convention of the American ORT, Young Men and Women's Division, held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -J. Edgar Hoover of the Federal Bureau of Investigation thanked foreign-born Americans tonight for their aid in combating Axis agents and said that the dreaded fifth column no longer existed in the United States.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 21 (AP) -- Ten Army representatives took possession of the Hummer Manufacturing Company's plant here today and announced that it would resume operations tomorrow morning after being strikebound since May 5.

A few days ago Magistrate J. Roland Sala disposed of an assault case in his court by a plan under which each of those involved agreed to contribute a pint of blood to the Red Cross. Magistrate Sala suggested that this procedure might be followed in other cases.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The democracy for which the United States now fights a global war is not a formula for achieving a working civilization overnight, but "a bold experiment in freedom" which must be pursued "with conviction and with determination," Associate Justice Felix Frankfurter declared in an "I-Am-anAmerican Day" address today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Foreign Economic Administration in a broad application of its policy to loosen export restrictions when the war situation warrants it, today added 175 items in twelve different groups to the list of commodities which are exportable under the agency's new "BLT" or Blanket Export License.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 9.1 (U.P.) -- The Republican Presidential nomination is wide open, Governor Bricker of Ohio said tonight on his arrival here to make a bid for the forty convention votes of the Texas delegation.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period May 13 to 19 are given in the appended tabulation:

CHUNGKING, China, May 21 (AP) -- Liberators of the United States Fourteenth Air Force on a sea sweep off the southeast China coast attacked a radio station on Pratas Island, about 190 miles southeast of Hong Kong, destroying three buildings and severely damaging another, a communique of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

WELLESLEY, Mass., May 21 -In the presence of Captain Mildred H. McAfee, president of Wellesley College, now on leave as director of the Waves, Vice Admiral Randall Jacobs, chief of Naval Personnel, told the graduating class of Wellesley today of the important part the woman's organization had played in "our expanding Navy."

Four thousand persons thronged the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory at Lexington Avenue and Twentysixth Street yesterday in celebration of Physical Fitness Day. The feature of the program was a festival presented by 1,000 members of the American Sokols of the Eastern States.

PITTSBURGH, May 21 -- The national rate of production of steel ingots declined last week one-half point to 99 per cent of rated capacity of the mills, but there was no decline in the volume of steel orders. The emphasis on the shell steel program was said to be creating a situation which would result soon in the tightest period in the industry since the war began.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from Geoffrey H. Moore of the National Bureau of Economic Research defending his doubts regarding the reliability of the present Federal Reserve index of total industrial production. This index, as well as Mr. Moore's own index of the production of industrial materials, was discussed editorially by this newspaper on April 17.

LONDON, May 21 (;P)--Terming invasion from the west "imminent,'' the Moscow Communist party newspaper Pravda declared today that the break-through of the Hitler Line in Italy had taught the Germans "the Allies are capable of breaking any defense, and possess sufficient forces to do so."

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -The Tigers topped Washington in both ends of a double-header today, edging out the Senators 2 -- 1 in the opener and taking the nightcap, 7 -- 1, with a fifteen-hit assault behind Hal Newhouser's five-blow hurling.

Holding that any position of leadership requires "certain basic equipment," the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, pastor of the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway, discussed in his sermon yesterday morning the most important qualifications for such a role.

Many buyers were in the wholesale markets last week, with interest divided between summer and new fall lines. The reorder trend on seasonal goods held up very well, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

BOSTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Red Sox amassed twelve hits in winning the second game of a double-header, 9 to 2, today against the White Sox after taking the opener by a 4-to-3 score to sweep the four-game series.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Roosevelt ordered Secretary Stimson today to take control of the Hummer Manufacturing Company, a war plant subsidiary of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., at Springfield, Ill., because of failure by the parent company to comply with a National War Labor Board directive of April 14.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 21 -- Opposition to the government of President Anastasio Somoza in Nicaragua is growing, particularly to his plan to change the Constitution to permit his re-election, according to reports received here and stories in the local press.

The tenth annual award of the Catholic War Veterans National Commander's citation was made last night to Eddie Cantor for his Purple Heart circuit to entertain wounded men, to Maurice Pate, director of the prisoner of war relief service of the American Red Cross, and to James Norris, executive director of the National Catholic Community Service.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -"More attention must be given by all educators and educational institutions to a positive program of education in the ways of democracy at home and in the practices of good-neighborliness among nations abroad," Samuel I. Rosenman, legal adviser to President Roosevelt, declared tonight at the Founder's Day celebration of Dropsie College.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., plans to sell to its president, Barney Balaban, $2,000,000 of convertible notes, with stock conversion privileges attached, it was disclosed yesterday in the film concern's proxy statement to stockholders for their annual meeting to be held on June 20.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 21 -- The brothers Manny, who have been sailing boats of various sizes on Long Island Sound for so many moons neither admits to an exact count of them, took out the International Class sloop Grilse today and made pretty much of a show of the Sparkman Trophy.

In your editorial "Old Virginia Taverns" in THE TIMES of May 14 you speak of the Rising Sun Tavern in Fredericksburg, "where in 1777 George Mason, Edmund Pendleton, George Wythe, Thomas Ludwell Lee and Thomas Jefferson met and drew up the outline of the Statute of Virginia for Religious Liberty."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, May 22 -- The Japanese, counter-attacking violently, attempted Saturday to wipe out an American bridgehead on the west side of the Tor River on the Netherland New Guinea mainland near the Wakde Islands. But they were defeated.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 21 (AP) -- Dr. Austin W. Curtis Jr., the young Negro scientist Dr. George W. Carver designated to carry on his research in the realm of peanuts and garden plants, has been dismissed by Tuskegee Institute, Professor Curtis disclosed here today.

The waning art season is not without notable events. On Wednesday the Museum of Modern Art will open to the public its big fifteenth anniversary exhibition, "Art in Progress," a members' preview being scheduled for Tuesday evening.

Continental Overseas Corporation, a separate subsidiary, has been formed by the Continental Can Company to act as agent and representative for the company and its subsidiaries in all foreign countries, except Canada and Cuba. Officers of the new unit are Carle C. Conway, president; Sherlock McKewen, vice president and general manager; Paul E. Pearson, Wendell H. Funderburg and Jacob F. Egenolf, vice presidents; Loren R. Dodson, secretary, and Everett W. Gray, treasurer.

A program of post-war objectives, including an international peace-maintenance organization, legislation to prevent exploitation of children and the underprivileged, and opportunity for returning service men's adjustment to civilian life, was adopted yesterday by the National Congress of Parents and Teachers through its board of managers, meeting in a pre-convention session in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The importance of the church as a divine agency rather than a human organization for worship was stressed yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning, who preached at a confirmation service in the French Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit, 109 East Sixtieth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A Senate liaison committee was reported today to have reached preliminary accord with Secretary Hull on the broad principles of a post-war international peace organization which the "Big Four" of the United Nations would take the lead in forming.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- The bull market in rye that continued from last August until early this month has collapsed in the last two weeks as the result of heavy liquidation and bear pressure. The May and July futures broke 5 cents a bushel yesterday, with May showing a decline of 16 1/8 cents in about two weeks.
Thirty commanderies of the Knights Templar in the metropolitan district held their seventeenth annual service yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

LONDON, May 21 -- A short, stout, middle-aged woman of no style or social pretensions, who once spent six months in jail, will be one of two women candidates opposing Viscountess Astor in Britain's first post-war Parliamentary election.

It has been twenty-five years since Dr. Israel Goldstein, as a young seminary graduate, assumed the rabbinate of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, the second oldest Jewish congregation in this city. Serving in that one pulpit to this day, he has become a spiritual leader of America and a figure in the life and the thought of his co-religionists both here and abroad.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 22 -- Production moved along smoothly today at the Hummer Manufacturing Company plant under Army control, with 428 workers back on the job after a seventeen-day strike shutdown.

CLEVELAND, May 22 -- Public opinion would react in post-war years against employers trying to bar disabled veterans from jobs because of physical standards unconnected with performance, L. Metcalfe Walling of New York told one of the larger sectional meetings of the National Conference on Social Work today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -Henry Armstrong, one of the greatest little fighting men in ring history, proved himself the master of an up-and-coming youngster by stopping Aaron Perry, Washington, in the sixth round of a scheduled ten-round bout tonight.

UNITED STATES FIGHTER-BOMBER BASE, in England, May 22 (U.P.) -- Col. Lance Call, leader of one of the most experienced United States dive-bomber outfits in Britain, said today that he believed his Thunderbolts could completely isolate an enemy area from any rail or road transportation within twenty-four hours.

RYE, N.Y., May 22 -- One-day tournaments of the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association, a wartime casualty in 1943, resumed with a surprising entry of forty-seven starters at the Westchester Country Club today, and it was fitting that Miss Margaret Nichols, the association champion from Hudson River, should win.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- In what is developing into one of the most serious academic rifts on an American campus in recent years, a full-sized revolt has broken out at the University of Chicago. Faculty members accuse Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, dynamic 45-year-old president, of assuming too much power in deciding educational policies and of threatening their academic freedom by a "one-man" rule.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 22 -- "Complete confidence" between the United States and Latin-American Republics was urged by Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin as the basis for close post-war trade relations in a luncheon address here today at the start of an official three-day tour of the State by delegates from Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama and Peru.

AN ALEUTIAN BASE, May 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- The air advance on Tokyo jumped halfway down the Kuriles when an Army Eleventh Air Force mission reached Shimushiri Island, only 900 miles from the Japanese capital.

LONDON, May 22 -- There is still no agreement with the French Committee of National Liberation regarding the administration of civil affairs in liberated France. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has received no specific directive from either the British or the American Government on the extent of recognition of the committee as the civil authority.
CHUNGKING, China, May 22 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States-Air Force communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, May 23 (AP) -- The airstrip of the Wakde Islands has been put into use by Allies, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today. This puts Allied airpower 110 miles toward the Philippines from Hollandia.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 22 -Dr. Albert Einstein, internationally famous scientist who has made Princeton his home for a decade, issued a brief statement today urging the re-election of President Roosevelt for a fourth term. His statement was made in conjunction with a meeting held at the Princeton Inn to form a New Jersey League of Independent Voters to campaign to return the President to office.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 22 -- An amusing illustration of how many Argentines feel about their present military Government is offered by a decree that the Federal Commissioner for the Province of Entre Rios issued yesterday. He forbade all movie theatres and other places of public entertainment to exhibit newsreels showing any provincial or national official of the regime deposed by the revolution June fourth of last year.

LONDON, May 22 -- One of the most important factors in all Allied calculations and preparations for the invasion of Europe -perhaps the most important single factor -- is the weather. The most brilliantly conceived and thoughtfully worked out plans may fail utterly if the weather conditions on D-day, and several days thereafter, should prove unfavorable to the invading forces.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Money and clothing seized in the Chicago home of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Max Haupt by Government agents without a search warrant was suppressed as evidence in Haupt's second treason trial today by Federal Judge John P. Barnes.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department showed an increase last week of 14 per cent over the like week a year ago, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week, in which buying for Mother's Day was a feature, a rise of 30 per cent in sales had been reported by the bank.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 22 -- Bill Goldbeck, Mount Kisco pro, and Leroy L. Franck of Westchester Hills gained top honors in the one-day pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. at Fenway Golf Club this afternoon after matching cards with two other teams in the field of twenty-six which finished with identical scores of 32, 33 -- 65.

Announcement that the forthcoming season of the Metropolitan Opera Association will run for eighteen weeks, two less than during the season recently ended, was made yesterday afternoon by Edward Johnson, its general manager, at the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Opera Guild in the Hotel Pierre.
LONDON, May 23 -- Retaliation swift and sure, on an unprecedented scale, will follow any use of poison gas by the enemy, either against the invasion ports or the Allied armies invading the Continent.

A String Quartet composed by Sgt. Andrew Imbrie yesterday received the award of the New York Music Critics Circle as the best work of chamber music by an American composer heard here during the season. The Circle voted honorable mention in the category of dramatic and choral works to Lukas Foss' cantata for chorus and four solo voices on lines of Carl Sandburg's "The Prairie" "for its musical distinction."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- (AP) OPA said today that maximum prices for certain types of radio tubes range up to $2.85 retail and $1.78 wholesale under the new dollars-and-cents ceiling prices effective May 20.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 22 (AP) -- Colt's Patent Fire Arms Manufacturing Company, in an interim statement being received today by stockholders, shows a net loss of $1,100,580 for the sixteen weeks ended on April 23, in contrast to a net income of $2,705,285 before taxes for the first four months in 1943, which was reduced to $1,326,885 after taxes.

The Tokyo radio told Japanese audiences last night (Tokyo time) that a total of 132 carrier-based planes from a United States naval task force had carried out seven raids during Saturday and Sunday against the Japanese base on Marcus Island by using "decoying tactics."

Harry C. Thompson and C. Shelby Carter, as the committee for holders of preferred stock of the Childs Company, have advised the holders that no definite plan of reorganization can be worked out until the question of the reserve fund for preferred stock is settled.

The theft yesterday morning of a Manhattan housewife's purse by a young woman sent to the home as a part-time domestic uncovered a bureaucratic impasse that prevents both local police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation from ascertaining who the light-fingered maid was and where she lived.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, defended today the board's assumption of jurisdiction in at least twenty-two cases involving Montgomery Ward Co. on the ground that the mail order house with its 600 establishments and 78,000 employes was "engaged in activities directly related to the successful prosecution of the war."

Charles Michelson's cynical opinion about the accuracy and general value of statistical surveys of public opinion is based upon a complete misconception of aim and method, according to Dr. George H. Gallup, conductor of the Gallup poll, which fell chiefly under criticism of the former publicity director of the Democratic National Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A coal shortage so acute that it may plunge the country into another dim-out or even force the curtailment of civilian production is being discussed here by production and fuel officials.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (U.P.) -- A proposal to destroy War Department intelligence records of investigations into espionage, sabotage and other subversive activities was reported tonight to have been injected into Senate consideration of promotions for fourteen generals.
Referring to the editorial of May 17 "Mr. Landon on Tariffs," may I submit the following facts?

Former City Magistrate Thomas A. Cullen will resume his place on the bench this morning after a brief hiatus caused by the absentmindedness of Mayor La Guardia, and remedied by the helpfulness of a reportorial friend. The hiatus was so brief that it will doubtless come as news to most of the magistrate's friends that he has been off the bench at all.
French sailors in town may be easily recognized by the red pompons which crown their caps, but now the broad collars of their light blue shirts are edged with three stripes of thin white braid.

The Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, which for years has been operating workshops to help blind and crippled persons fit themselves for jobs, will soon expand its facilities in a broad program of vocational rehabilitation for discharged service men and other partly disabled persons, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Mary Childs Draper, president.

Two Japanese experts have drawn up a list of conditions to be imposed "after the United States has surrendered" that calls for the complete destruction of American naval power and maritime trade, the abolition of private banking institutions and trade unions and the eventual establishment of a "political authority" in this country subservient to Japan, the Japanese Domei agency said yesterday.

"Career Angel" comes to the National Theatre tonight after two tryouts. Written by Gerard M. Murray, a priest on the staff of Our Lady of Mercy Church, Forest Hills, Queens, the play was first put through its paces by the local Blackfriars Guild last fall and most recently in Boston, for eight days under the auspices of its present sponsors, Andrew Billings, Joseph Dicks and David Shay.

BALTIMORE, May 22 (AP) -- Superior Judge Emory H. Niles, ruling today in an action brought by some stockholders against the present management of the Certain-Teed Products Corporation, said it was up to stockholders to determine the validity of proxies.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUATERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, May 23 (UP) -- A communique.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- The aerial pounding of Hitler-held territory constitutes an invasion "in the deadliest sense of the word," General H.H. Arnold asserted tonight.
An underwriting syndicate headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis will offer today to the public 100,000 shares of common stock of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., at $28.50 a share.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 23 (U.P.) -- Soviet forces again turned back local German attacks in the Stanislav area of Poland and along the lower Dniester River northwest of Tiraspol yesterday as the Eastern Front lull continued, but the Moscow radio said that the Red Army was preparing for "fierce battles that lie ahead."

Where are you, old companions trusty, Long-Legged Bill, Big-Foot Jack, Bully Climchy, mighty whalemen of old? Bunglers and amateurs are trying to do your work. We used to read about your sufferings in slimy fo'castles and with the land sharks that infested you on shore.

NAPLES, May 22 -- Chopping steadily deeper through the Hitler Line, forward elements of the Allies' armies in Italy have pierced its coastal anchor at Terracina, tightened a mountainous pincer around the vital town of Pico and thrust fighting spearheads into both Piedimonte and the outskirts of Pontecorvo, it was announced today.

TRENTON, May 22 -- With Frank S. Farley, Senate majority leader, of Atlantic County, and five other Republicans joining the Democrats in opposition, the Legislature in special session passed three bills today, endorsed by Gov. Walter E. Edge as a sound way of placing municipal policemen's and firemen's pension funds on a firm financial footing.

The Red Cross benefit concert in Madison Square Garden on Thursday evening will bring together two of the greatest of orchestras, the NBC Symphony and the Philharmonic-Symphony, playing as one. Supporting them will be a chorus of 600 young voices augmented by eight glee clubs and four famous soloists.

An official circular issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York confirms statements that although the $16,000,000,000 national sales quota for the Fifth War Loan Drive will be harder to attain than the $14,000,000,000 goal of the last drive, speculative purchases will be frowned on.

Both clubs having failed, with any degree of consistency, to bring down to their own level the stronger Western teams on their late lamented road trips, the Dodgers and Giants will attempt to beat each other tonight under the fights at Ebbets Field.

Lightly regarded by the crowd of 24,100 fans on hand, C.T. Chenery's 4-year-old chestnut, Anthemion, 13-to-1 shot, proved the best of the lot in the Koh-I-Noor Handicap, the feature event on the racing card at Belmont Park yesterday.
CHUNGKING, China, May 22 (AP) -- A communique:

Sex education courses and classes in preparation for marriage and family life should be encouraged in the schools by parents and teachers, Evelyn Millis Duvall, director of the Association for Family Living, Chicago, declared yesterday.

A small group of specialties provided yesterday the only bright spot on the stock market where there was a further noticeable lack of activity among the pivotal issues. Again it was a waiting proposition but with signs of growing impatience on the part of holders of idle cash.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 -Spencer Tracy has been named by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to star in "The Romance of Henry Menafee," a story by Paul Gallico about a State schoolmaster who turns circus clown. Casey Robinson is writing the screen adaptation for production by Cliff Reid.

For the details of our latest task force attack on Marcus Island we must wait until the Navy's radio silence ends. Possibly the bombing of Marcus was not the only task assigned. But according to Berlin it was enough to send a wave of air-raid alarms over all of northern and eastern Japan.

Earl Browder, for many years the directing genius of the Communist party of America, was elected unanimously yesterday as the first president of its successor, the Communist Political Association, at the closing session of a Communist convention at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventy-third Street.

LONDON, May 22 (AP) -- United States Army field commanders in the European Theatre of Operations have received from headquarters a twenty-four-page booklet explaining their relations to war correspondents and urging their full cooperation in aiding the reporters to send an accurate report of the fighting to the folk back home ahead of the German propaganda machine.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set May 29 for a hearing in its New York office on an application by Lehman Brothers of New York for exemption from the Investment Company Act barring service as a joint underwriting manager with Goldman, Sachs Co. in sale of 58,337 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation.

Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, New York City Health Commissioner, ordered more dog catchers to the Bronx yesterday as he disclosed that there had been a further spread of rabies in that borough. Two new cases have been reported in the last ten days, raising to twelve the number of rabid animals discovered in the Bronx since February.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Rocket guns, used only on small craft in the early amphibious warfare, now go forward on 157-foot LCI's (Landing Craft, Infantry) to aid landings in the Southwest Pacific, Rear Admiral Daniel E. Barbey, commander of the amphibious force of the Seventh Fleet, said here today.

The National Academy will open with a preview at 9 o'clock tonight the graphic section of its 118th annual (the painting and sculpture sections, combined, were presented last March). Although the prints and drawings that have now been assembled run to a total of 224, it was not found necessary to use more than the two large galleries on the second floor of the Academy's building at 1083 Fifth Avenue, between Eighty-ninth and Ninetieth Streets.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 22 -- Livingston Platt, Republican chairman of Westchester County, said today in a telegram to Mrs. John T. Pratt, president of the Women's National Republican Club, that his executive committee would still consider Assemblyman Jane H. Todd of Tarrytown for the nomination for Representative in the new Twenty-seventh District of Westchester and Putnam Counties if Miss Todd desires.

The case of the football coaches against the Football Rules Committee will be heard during a two-day session of members of the American Football Coaches Association in this city next Sunday and Monday.

LONDON, May 22 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting is under way throughout western Yugoslavia, with the Germans pouring in fresh reinforcements against the Partisans and supporting their offensives with continuous air attacks, Marshal Tito announced today.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, in England, May 22 -- Capt. Mike Sobanski of 400 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York, led his Mustang squadron beyond Berlin yesterday. It was the day for which he had been waiting almost five years, and he made the most of it.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 23 -- The great German naval base of Kiel, where a large portion of the Nazis' undersea raiders is built, was the target yesterday for large formations of Flying Fortresses escorted by Mustangs, Thunderbolts and Lightnings.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The State Department, indirectly but positively, moved today to stop the efforts by Argentina to build up a synthetic rubber industry with the aid of engineering assistance from the United States.
Brig. Gen. Clifford W. Gaylord, USA, and Mrs. Gaylord have arrived from St. Louis and are at the Park Lane.

Twentieth Century-Fox has acquired screen rights to "The Rebirth of Flower McRoy," a short story by Ann Chidester, which appeared in the April issue of The Woman's Home Companion. The story is a romance, with gambling on the Mississippi River as a background.

Industrial alcohol production in the post-war years will range from 250,000,000 to 300,000,000 gallons a year, almost three times normal pre-war output, after emergency alcohol sources such as beverage distilleries are returned to their normal uses, Milton F. Martin, of United States Industrial Chemicals, Inc., stated yesterday.

Two hundred inspectors of the War Shipping Administration, most of them veterans of the present war, met yesterday on Pier 86, North River, at Forty-sixth Street, to protest their dismissal by the WSA scheduled for May 31. A committee headed by James A. King was chosen to confer with authorities on cancellation of the order.

Swedish press dispatches reported to the Office of War Information yesterday revealed that two Danish patriots had been executed, four others sentenced to death and twenty-one more arrested as a consequence of continued waves of anti-Nazi activity in Denmark.

CHUNGKING, China, May 22 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have recaptured a fifth town on the Peiping-Hankow railroad in southern Honan Province, broadening the gap in the Japanese-held line to sixty miles, but to the northwest a strong enemy column has driven to within about fifteen miles of the Shensi Province border, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's High Command announced tonight.

First reports of spoilage of some of the nation's unprecedented abundance of eggs, which is still begging cold storage, were current in the trade yesterday. Concern for tens of thousands of cases lacking refrigeration mounted with the arrival of the month's second heat wave.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Presidential power to issue through the Office of Price Administration suspension orders against business concerns which have violated rationing regulations was upheld by the Supreme Court today.

LONDON, May 22 -- Encouraging war news from Italy had a stimulating effect on today's stock market here. Although business was on the small side many sections recorded small gains where prices changed.

Six strikes, involving only 303 workers, were before the New York State Board of Mediation during the month of April, Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the board, reported yesterday, and all but one, involving twenty-two workers, were settled before the end of the month.

Samuel F.B. Morse's invention of the electro-magnetic telegraph virtually terminated the art of personal diplomacy by speeding world communication, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday. Eliminating the necessity for lengthy and tedious transatlantic missions, the telegraph enabled Ambassadors to remain in home offices under public scrutiny, he said.

The appeal to advertisers not to exploit D-day by Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, was believed to have resulted from promotion of special editions by some newspapers in smaller communities, it was learned from authoritative sources in the advertising field yesterday.

LONDON, May 22 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, supreme Allied commander, gave his second operational order to the underground armies of occupied Europe today to guide them in the help they will give when Allied forces land on the Continent.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 22 -- Accused of using more electricity in their home than the meter indicated because of alleged "tampering" with the meter, H. Richard Panzer, New York and Westchester County real estate operator, and his wife Elinor heard a Supreme Court jury's verdict here today denying an order to compel the Westchester Lighting Company to restore service in their home at 39 Walbrooke Road, Greenburgh.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE on the Salween Front, May 17 (Delayed) -- Although the Japanese are well equipped in southwestern Yunnan they are frightened, according to an agent who returned today after a forty-seven day reconnaissance trip on the other side of the river.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- There are people who earn a decent journalistic income by furnishing a syndicated series of astrological charts, foretelling future events or, at least, indicating -- by the position of the stars and planets -- what are the prospects of persons born under the relative position of the heavenly bodies.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 22 -Jean Dupuy, 34-year-old member of the famous French newspaper and magazine publishing family and a champion outboard motor boat racer, and Miss Geraldine Spreckels, 25, of the sugar refining family, were seriously injured here at 11 o'clock last Friday night when the motorcycle on which they were riding collided with an automobile, it was learned today.

The officially stated policy of the Allied Supreme Command in the Mediterranean theatre to censor news dispatches only for reasons of military security, thereby removing any implication of political censorship, "achieves an objective of paramount importance," Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The manpower shortage has hit the political parties, too, and women are coming to the front, Mrs. Charles W. Tillett, assistant chairman of the Democratic National Committee, told a luncheon meeting of the Women's National Democratic Club today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- An amendment which would bring barber shop and beauty parlor services under price control has been drafted by the Office of Price Administration and sent to the House Banking and Currency Committee at the latter's request.

President Roosevelt used the familiar British phrase in transmitting his fifteenth Lend-Lease report to Congress yesterday. In the narrower sense "combined operations" are those in which several service arms take part. In the broader meaning they are operations for which, in the President's words, "the fighting men of many nations have been banded together."

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Liquidation was on again today in May rye on the Chicago Board of Trade and an opening break carried the price down 4 1/2 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish. This, however, proved to be the low point of the day as cash and elevator interests took the May and sold the deferred deliveries, buying the former at a full carrying charge discount under July.

National Maritime Day was celebrated yesterday in the city, as it was throughout the nation in accordance with President Roosevelt's proclamation, with awards of Mariner's Medals to next of kin of the 5,000 merchant seamen who gave their lives in getting supplies to our fighting forces, with the casting of the traditional wreaths on the waters in their memory, and with gatherings honoring the 150,000 men now afloat with the merchant marine.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) -- The majority of holders of refunding first mortgage bonds and debentures and general creditors of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company have accepted the amended reorganization plan
KANDY, Ceylon, May 22 (UP) -- A communique:

The first-hand account of a flying psychiatrist on how the crew of a Flying Fortress behaved on a mission "during which the plane and the crew received such severe damage that survival seemed impossible" was presented last night at the meeting of the Medical Society of the County of New York at the New York Academy of Medicine.
SAVANNAH, Ga., May 22 (AP) -- There will be no surplus merchant ship graveyards after this war such as followed the first World War, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land told a Maritime Day audience tonight.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

On the theory that desperate conditions call for desperate remedies, Leo Durocher, bad thumb, extra poundage and all, has decided that he is the best available Brooklyn shortstop. Leo may take over the job tonight against the Giants at Ebbets Field, although his mind may change, once the first heat of his anger and disgust about Sunday's double debacle has cooled.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (En Route With Giants) -- Determined not to break up a "winning combination," Manager Mel Ott said today as he sped eastward with his Giants to keep an appointment with the Dodgers at Ebbets Field tomorrow night that he would continue to play third base.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 22 (AP) -- About one hundred machine hands at No. 6 shop of the Bethlehem Steel Company walked off their jobs today in what was described by John Posivak, representative of the United Steel Workers of America, a CIO unit, as a "protest over contract-slip changes."

HOUSTON, Tex., May 22 (AP) -Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio told Texas Republicans tonight that "we have been reliably informed that the CIO Political Action Committee is prepared to spend $5,000,000" to re-elect President Roosevelt and "to take us down the road toward state socialism."

A nation-wide syndicate of 236 banking houses headed by Blyth Co., Inc.; the Mellon Securities Corporation, Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers won yesterday the award of a new issue of $56,000,000 of California Toll Bridge Authority refunding bonds of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge.

Everyone who loves growing things enjoys a garden room, even though the "garden" is only a collection of potted greenery that brings the outdoors into a city apartment. A garden room scheme offers possibilities for arranging a summery corner in the living room or for fixing up a maid's room that is idle.
Saratoga's month-long racing program again will be run on the Belmont track this summer and the Empire City events will be decided on the Jamaica course.

NAPLES, May 22 (U.P.) -- The Allied High Command has divided all of German-occupied Italy into six operational zones and has flashed word to the Italian underground operating in those areas to "prepare for the day of action," it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Twenty-five additional industrial plants have been selected as follows to receive the Army-Navy "E" award in recognition of outstanding performance on war work:
CAMP ANZA, Calif., May 22 (AP) -- Lieut. Beaufott G. Swancutt prefaced a fusillade from his service pistol, Lieut. Harry J. Light testified today, with the word:

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The State Department added thirtyeight Swedish firms tonight to those already under blacklist by the Interdepartmental Proclaimed List Committee, in extension of the policy of taking punitive steps against "firms in neutral countries who have assisted the Axis by engaging in trade with enemy territory to an unusual extent or in other ways."

NEWARK, N.J., May 22 -- Cast in the same pattern set by the foremen's strike in Detroit, a dispute involving supervisory employes and the management of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Kearny resulted today in the failure of 100 sheet metal department lead men to report for work in the company's Port Newark yards.

Multiple rates of exchange created by control devices of foreign governments and used in connection with transactions involving importations into the United States were ruled out yesterday in a final disposition of customs litigation which has been carried on for more than four years.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Announcing today that it would save $180,000,000 through its recently announced cut-back in fighter-plane production, the Navy revealed that the principal reduction would be in Corsair fighters and that the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation's contract to make this type of plane would be terminated.

All-American symbols and emblems by good thinking and common consent should be kept all-American and not made factional or partisan. Miss Liberty is not only a symbol for all America but bids fair to be the symbol of all democracy the world over, having already appeared on United Nations posters.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- An appeal for more instructors to train increasing numbers of young women for essential nursing service was made today by Dr. Thomas Parran, the Surgeon General, in announcing a wide range of scholarships that are available under the Bolton Act.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Lend-lease aid to the United Nations contributed by the United States for "greater offensives now impending" reached on March 31, 1944, a total of $24,224,806,000, President Roosevelt notified Congress today in transmitting the fifteenth report on the progress of this part of the American war program.

BOSTON, May 22 -- The United States needs a 10,000,000-ton merchant fleet of fast, long-range vessels of quality construction for its part in post-war world trade, Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, said here tonight.

Tonight's events: "The Gate," scenic oratorio by Max Brand, Jean Paul Morel conductor, benefit for children of India, Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 o'clock; guitar recital by Rey de la Torre, Town Hall, 8:30; Commencement Concert, Music School of Henry Street Settlement, The Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, 8:15; concert by the Tudor Group of eight young women singers, assisted by Patricia Yates, harpist, the Barbizon, 8:30.

In the effort to forestall the booking by manufacturers of fur garments of orders from retailers at conditional prices pending clarification of the forthcoming Office of Price Administration regulations, Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers has adopted a resolution opposing the acceptance of such orders, it was learned here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- The Alleghany Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $30,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent secured convertible notes due on April 15, 1954, proceeds from sale of which will be applied to redemption of more than $40,000,000 of convertible bonds of the company.

Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal declared yesterday that the armed power of this nation, as typified by a strong Navy, must be the basis of any plan for international peace. He spoke at a luncheon opening the third annual convention of the American Women's Voluntary Services at the Waldorf-Astoria.
ALBANY, May 22 -- Governor Dewey appointed today twelve members to the temporary State commission on municipal revenues and the reduction of real estate taxes.

Big league baseball is heading toward its second million in paid attendance with the first fifth of the season showing an approximate turnstile count of 1,660,544 admissions, The Associated Press reveals.

President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey paid tribute to the New School for Social Research when it marked its twenty-fifth anniversary in honor of the founders of the institution with a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night, attended by a thousand friends and associates of the school.
Following consultation between the New York Racing Commission and officials of the New York racing associations, the following plans have been completed for racing on D-day:

According to reports from Europe, the Regency Council of Bulgaria has refused an "invitation" from Adolf Hitler to come to his mountain home of Berchtesgaden for "consultations" on the war situation. The reports vary as to whether this refusal was outright or by indirection, but they agree that the Bulgarian answer was No -- and this despite the presence of German troops on Bulgarian soil.

All materials not required for war should be released immediately for production of needed civilian goods "to lessen the danger of inflation from suppressed buying power," Senator Harry S. Truman, chairman of the Senate War Investigating Committee, declared yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
The high mark of New York racing's contribution to the sale of war bonds in 1944 will come on Saturday, June 24, at Aqueduct.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 22 -- A detailed account of the tragic events in the German prison camp, Stalag Luft 3, near Dresden, in which forty-seven Royal Air Force officers were murdered on March 22 has been received here from British pilots who were among a number of prisoners who succeeded in escaping.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 22 -- Heavy monsoon rains breaking suddenly over north Burma have transformed the battleground at the encircled Japanese stronghold of Myitkyina into a slogging sea of mud, but as the Allies prepared for the final assault on the city, already one-third captured, Chinese troops stabbed to the north and seized a strategic road junction, it was announced today.

ALBANY, May 22 -- Appointment of Alfred J. Worsdell Jr., executive manager of the New York State Council of Retail Merchants, as deputy State commissioner of commerce, was announced today by Commissioner M.P. Catherwood.

Paper salvage officials of the Department of Sanitation and the War Production Board here yesterday attributed the steady falling off during recent weeks in the tonnage totals collected by the city's trucks on Wednesdays to the fact that the carts of junk dealers, Boy Scouts and volunteer workers for welfare agencies get out earlier in the mornings and now pick up almost 50 per cent of the waste paper placed on curbs.

Your editorial of May 14 on the International Labor Conference hit the nail on the head. The drafting of some very general humanitarian resolutions expressing not one new idea took up all its time and attention. The delegates comforted themselves by resolving that man-stripped Poland should have full employment and starving Greece should raise its standard of living.

It is impressive what a change of scene will sometimes accomplish. The new Communist Political Association, which was the Communist party of the United States until only the other day, has been holding its national convention on West Seventy-third Street. From the walls of the hall in which it met immense portraits of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, as well as of Marshal Stalin, looked down on its deliberations.
HOUSTON, Texas, May 22 (AP) -- A $20,000,000 boxing gate is in view here June 21.

Two hundred Harlem women have organized a non partisan committee to elect Mrs. Sara Pelham Speaks, Republican, as Representative to Congress from the new Twenty-second Congressional District, it was learned yesterday. The women's group has undertaken its first task -- the getting of signatures from 750 registered Democrats on a petition to enter Mrs. Speaks' name in the Democratic primary in August.

LONDON, May 22 -- Despite the reverse administered to the Allies at Terracina by German reserves hastily thrown into the battle, German propagandists were carefully preparing their public today for the shock of further withdrawals.

CHICAGO, May 22 (U.P.) -- Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister to Washington, told the Rotary International Convention today that the United States was an enigma to the British "possibly because you have not yet pulled out your choke to adjust your mixture between realism and idealism."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Office of Price Administration outlined today a new method for figuring maximum prices which exporters of iron and steel products will use to determine ceilings for products known as "excess stock."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Justice Edward C. Eicher fined Henry H. Klein, one of the twenty-six sedition trial attorneys, and Ellis O. Jones, one of the twenty-nine defendants, $200 and $100, respectively, for contempt of court today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 22 (AP) -- Midshipman Benjamin S. Martin of Prospect Park, Pa., today was announced the winner of the Thompson trophy cup, presented to the midshipman who has done the most during the year for the promotion of athletics at the United States Naval Academy.

WALTHAM, Mass., May 22 (U.P.) -- Interests represented by Frederic C. Dumaine of Boston have agreed to sell their majority stock in the Waltham Watch Company to the Union Securities Corporation of New York City, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Supreme Court today held, 6 to 3, that ballot-box stuffing is punishable as a Federal offense under criminal statutes controlling the voting right.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, the market lacking trend and closing 4 points lower to 3 points higher than on Saturday.

WASHINGTON. May 22 -- Proposed compromises through which a part of the Bailey-Brewster "work or be drafted" bill might be saved from pigeonholing were brought out today as organized labor opened its fight upon the measure before the Senate Military Affairs Committee.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 22 -- Second Lieut. Gertrude V. Meade, 20 years old, of Little Falls, N.Y., an Army nurse stationed at Camp Kilmer near here, was killed and three other second lieutenants, including another nurse, were injured last night when they were struck by a reconnaissance truck driven by an Army private.

Harry Brown, creator of "Artie Greengroin," the fictional Pfc. in Yank, will have a new novel entitled "A Walk in the Sun" published by Knopf, June 26. Mr. Brown has resigned from the staff of Yank's London office to write an overseas motion-picture project sponsored by the Office of War Information

BASLE, Switzerland, May 22 -- Behind closed doors in the gloomy offices of the Bank for International Settlements in Basle today seven executive officers of the bank, including an American, a German, a Frenchman, a Swede and an Italian, met under the presidency of the Swiss chairman, Dr. Ernst Weber of the directorium of the Swiss National Bank, in the fourteenth annual assembly of the institution.

It is, or rather was, the Gustav Line. It will soon be over with the Adolf Hitler Line. Beyond it other fortified lines with a capital letter may turn up, most probably north of Rome. In the last war it was the Hindenburg Line and the Siegfried Line and the Wotan Line and others that may easily come to memory.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Lower retail prices for watermelons and some kinds of cheeses were promised by the Office of Price Administration today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Under a proposed set of standards for allocation of newsprint to newspapers the War Production Board is planning full publicity on all appeals in hardship cases, Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, told members of the Truman Committee today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A final decision on the reorganization of the War Production Board to shape it to the task of turning industry from war to peacetime manufacture is expected to be reached tomorrow at a meeting of high board officials.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 24 -- Allied air power struck a series of swift and heavy blows at German supply lines and airfields in the western Reich, the Low Countries and northern and central France yesterday, with about 600 Liberators and Flying Fortresses of the United States Eighth Air Force leading the onslaught.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Stone Webster and Blod-get, Inc. will offer publicly today $23,000,000 of first mortgage and refunding bonds of the Virginia Electric and Power Company at 103 1/4 and accrued interest. The bonds, carrying a 3 per cent interest rate, mature in 1974.

Even a drizzle yesterday could not dampen spirits at the annual flower mart of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rockefeller Center lilac bushes nearby added neighborly color and American Legion poppy vendors gave selling tips to the association's basket-laden flower girls.

Quiet strength prevailed yesterday through the greater part of the stock market and the list made its best gain in more than two weeks. Most interest appeared again in specialties, with pivotal issues still in the background. Under the leadership of the liquors, sugars, department stores and the rails, values were improved from fractions to a point or more.
The Giants, Yankees and Dodgers all will take part in a novel threecornered baseball game as one of the feature promotions of the Fifth War Loan Sports Committee to help the sale of war bonds.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 23 -- For the first time in recent history, Texas today had two rival, irreconcilable Democratic conventions. The party split sharply on whether or not to send a delegation to the national convention instructed for the re-nomination of President Roosevelt.

Brother Jones, H.E. Talbott's accomplished 8-year-old jumper, yesterday took up where he had left off just before snow flew late last Autumn. Winner of the Grand National last October, the bay gelding, in his first start of the year, proved his superiority over six rivals in the $4,000 added Corinthian Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Without objection the House today accepted Senate amendment to its individual income tax simplification bill and sent the measure to the White House.

MEXICO CITY, May 23 -- The good neighbor feeling that Washington has been painstakingly building in Mexico has received a minor setback, according to today's press, because of what it termed Leopold Stokowski's "arrogant behavior" toward Manuel M. Ponce, most famous of Mexican composers.
CHUNGKING, Wednesday, May 24 (AP) -- A communique:

Purchase of a block front on Jackson Avenue, between Queens Boulevard and West Street, at the Queensboro Bridge Plaza, Long Island City, was announced yesterday through the Herbert Callman Company, brokers, by Nierenberg Brothers for improvement after the war, with a large building covering the entire site.

With the launching of a new Allied offensive from the Anzio beachhead under the personal command of Lieutenant General Clark, the long-drawn-out battle for Rome has now entered a new and possibly decisive phase. For the new offensive puts into effect at last the grand Allied strategy for this battle, which aims not only at the capture of the Italian capital but also at the destruction of the bulk of the German army in Italy.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Commercial sponsorship of news broadcasts and radio commentators would be forbidden, and such programs thereby put on a "sustaining" basis under the proposed revision of the 1934 Communications Act, as presented today to the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee by Chairman Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat, of Montana.

While the United States and Great Britain are agreed upon the need for "absolute undiscriminatory treatment between nations and for general action to lower or remove trade barriers," some disagreement exists on British policies which would continue Government bulk purchasing after the war, Don C. Bliss Jr., commercial attache to the American Embassy in London, declared yesterday.

LONDON, May 23 -- Lord Keynes, British economist and one of the authors of the Anglo-American plan for international currency control, made his first detailed defense of it today in debate in the House of Lords on the motion, carried with little opposition, that the United Nations monetary talks be continued.

Declaring that the essence of socialization lay in subsidies, Herbert B. Dorau, Professor of Public Utilities and Transportation at New York University, yesterday told business men to shun Governmental largess if they desired to retain their independence and security.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 17, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Citing four cases in which the National Labor Relations Board had found Montgomery Ward Co. guilty of unfair labor practices, Gerard D. Reilly, NLRB member, charged today that the company's actions in the dispute before the National War Labor Board had played a large part in causing the members of the Retail Clerks Union to strike in Chicago.
Two apartment houses, a group of small industrial buildings and small residences figured in realty transactions reported yesterday in the Bronx.

The Blackfriars Guild, which for several years has been in contented communication with the muses on Fifty-seventh Street, last evening saw one of its shows move downtown. Since the Guild works very hard at tryouts, it would be a pleasure to report this morning that "Career Angel" had turned out to be the glittering diamond it must have seemed uptown.

CHUNGKING, China, May 23 -- Chinese forces on the offensive along the Salween River have cut the Burma Road at Chefang, blocking the principal source of supplies for the Japanese forces in Yunnan Province in southwest China, the Chinese Command announced today.

Beyond any question one of the great and continuing problem of the postwar years will be the care of disabled veterans and the support of the families of those men in the armed forces who have given their lives for their country. We must make sure that measures of this kind are prompt and as adequate as a fair and generous policy on the Government's part can make them.

Life, laughter and the pursuit of baseballs returned to Ebbets Field last night. Amid frigid, hostile surroundings, Bill Voiselle, rookie right-hander of the Giants, gave one of the most remarkable exhibitions of clutch pitching against the Dodgers witnessed all season in the first all-arclight encounter here since 1941, but when it was all finished, Voiselie, his head hanging low, walked slowly to the dugout a beaten man.
LONDON, May 23 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berin and recorded by The United Press:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 23 -- Frank Dietrich, 62 years old, proprietor of the Alpine Inn beside the Eastern State Parkway at Shrub Oak, and Elmer Losee, 37, were indicted here today by a Westchester County grand jury on a charge of using saltpeter to damage three stately trees that hindered motorists from seeing the inn.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 23 -- In his keynote address as president at the opening session of the Northern Baptist Convention here today, the Rev. Dr. Joseph Chandler Robbins appealed to the liberal and newly organized fundamentalist factions to "maintain our unity" and not to "allow this fellowship to be broken."

SYDNEY, Australia, May 22 (Reuter) -- London and Washington will soon be able to see a film showing the Netherlands Indies scorched-earth policy applied to the Surabaya naval base in March, 1942. The film, shown here privately today, is one of the most remarkable of the war.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The War Production Board authorized today the manufacture of 157,100 more electric irons, bringing the total to 926,438 and approaching the half-way mark in the 2,000,000 iron program.

A Federal warrant was issued yesterday for the arrest of Thomas Gorman, 43-year-old liquor salesman, "Broadway playboy" and reputed backer of theatrical enterprises, according to United States Attorney James B.M. McNally. Gorman was described as having collected $500,000 in premiums from liquor dealers to whom he deigned to sell whisky.

FOR forty-seven years Joe Barry has been living on borrowed time. Next week this tall, straight, white-haired and lovable old man retires as the traveling secretary of the Chicago White Sox to spend the rest of his life in quiet and contentment -- no more train tickets to buy, no more hotel bills to pay, no more baggage to check and no more baseball writers to ride herd on.

Louis Hollander, organizer and president of Local 21313 of the Theatrical Costume Workers Union, who on June 15, 1942, accepted $3,000 in the lobby of the local's headquarters at 19 West Forty-ninth Street to call off a strike, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to an extortion from two members of the Theatrical Costumers Association, Inc.
CLEVELAND, May 23 -- Social progress of the smallest State in the union was the biggest single topic of discussion at the national conference of social work here today.

An outdoor poster symbolizing the mutual effort and common cause of the various religious denominations in the war was unveiled yesterday in Times Square by Mayor La Guardia, who described it as "a most telling poster, reminding the people of this city that we are all Americans."

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A program consisting of three recommendations aimed at improving price control over apparel and yard goods was proposed to Chester Bowles. Price Administrator, today by the OPA Consumer Advisory Committee.

LONDON, May 23 -- The recent lull in U-boat activities generally is interpreted here as meaning the Germans have recalled most of their undersea craft to bases along the French coast of the Bay of Biscay and the northern coast of France and the Low Countries and are holding them for use on D-day.

The large three-story reinforced concrete building at 578-582 Market Street, Newark, N. J., has been purchased by the Supreme Laboratory to provide larger quarters due to the increasing business in recent years in filling war orders. For eight years the laboratory has been at 667 Garfield Avenue, Jersey City.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- With Leo Treadway's third homer of the season, with one aboard in the seventh featuring a nine-hit attack, Jersey City registered a 5-to-2 decision over Newark tonight in the first full-fledged arc-light contest played at the local stadium in almost two years.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Peter Gissibl, an organizer of the German-American Bund in the United States and one-time leader of its Chicago unit, testified in the sedition trial today as the Government's first witness. Now a tailor living near Chicago, he is a brother of Fritz Gissibl, Elite Guard officer, one of the Nazi leaders with whom the twenty-nine defendants are accused of conspiring.

CHUNGKING, China, Wednesday, May 24 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have opened counter-offensives over wide areas of northern Honan Province where they are driving the Japanese before them at all key points, the Chinese High Command announced today.

Sixty-odd private organizations and eight public organizations have cooperated with the Citizens' Housing Council of New York to observe Housing Week. Architects, college faculties, neighborhood clubs, labor unions, settlement houses, the clergy, tenants' associations, real estate men, builders and almost every other phase of our life that has any conceivable connection with housing, all are represented.

A number of solutions to meet the problem of "the forgotton man of housing" -- the individual earning more than is permitted for residence in public housing units and too little to afford adequate accommodations in private projects -- were advanced yesterday at the Conference on Housing the Post-War Metropolis, sponsored by the Citizens Housing Council at the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East Sixty-fifth Street.

" Taxi to Heaven," a Soviet importation featuring Ludmila Tselikovskaya, will have its local premiere this morning at the Stanley. The comedy-musical was produced under the supervision of Frederick Ermler.

America is the most powerful nation in the world and has the strength to make the future whatever the American people will it to be, Bernard Baruch said last night in accepting The Churchman Award for 1944 at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MYITKYINA AIRDROME, May 21 (Delayed) -- The battle for Myitkyina continues this morning in a drizzling rain. The American and Chinese troops have started new drives to oust the Japanese from a point two miles northeast of here. The Japanese are not many but they are dug into their usual underground, strongly built defenses, and getting them out is tough going.

Japanese radio and press reports yesterday said that Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu had appointed two new advisers to the Foreign Office "to strengthen Japanese foreign policy" -- Toyotaro Yuki, member of the House of Peers and former governor of the Bank of Japan, and Kumatoro Hondo, former Ambassador to Germany and China.

PEARL HARBOR, May 23 (AP) -- American land-based bombers unleashed a 230-ton bombardment Sunday on Wotje atoll, in the eastern Marshall Islands, the heaviest daylight air attack of the war on a single target in the central Pacific.

A poll of veterans of this war conducted by Iron Age, steel trade publication, to determine what employment and economic demands returning service men may make, revealed that 73 per cent of the veterans questioned insisted they were entitled to job preference.

AN ADVANCED COMMAND POST OF THE CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, on the Salween Front, May 15 (Delayed) -- On the cres tof a mountain 3,000 feet above the Salween River Maj. Laurence W. Beilenson of Los Angeles, Calif., formerly an attorney for the Screen Actors Guild, was sitting on a log overlooking enemy positions across the river.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- The grain markets made a firm start today on the Board of Trade, but the bulge brought a resumption of liquidation and a professional selling and prices dropped rapidly, with numerous stop-loss orders uncovered in wheat and rye on the way down.

LONDON, May 23 -- The stock markets here generally were firmer today, with the chief interest being shown in shipping and cotton textile issues. Further gains were recorded, but the best levels were not maintained owing to profit taking.

On Nov. 16, 1832, a man stepped off the packet Sully and in bidding good-by cockily declared: "Well, Captain, should you hear of the telegraph one of these days as the wonder of the world, remember the discovery was made on board the Sully." The man was Samuel F.B. Morse, the most distinguished American painter of his time, founder of the National Academy of Design, friend of Lafayette, Aragon, Humboldt, Bryant and other celebrities.
The Cuban guitarist, Rey de la Torre, gave his first recital here in more than two years last night in Town Hall, presenting a program of historical and musical interest with fine art.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Faculty members at the University of Chicago have divided into two opposing factions, as the aftermath of the passage by the university senate yesterday of a "bill of rights" which attacked President Robert M. Hutchins and accused him of initiating education policies harmful to the institution.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 24 (AP) -- Heavy shellfire from British and German batteries shook the starlit Strait of Dover for a half hour early today. Big British guns opened a barrage -- probably aimed at a German convoy trying to break through the Channel -- and drew a sporadic response.

Staff Sergeant Gerard M. Kenny of 646 Hudson Street, former copyboy for THE NEW YORK TIMES, came home this week for a respite from the war, bearing five decorations won in combat over Europe as a member of the Eighth Air Force.
PITTSBURGH, May 23 (AP) -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation was cleared today of charges of falsifying steel-test records on war orders to meet Government specifications.

An advertising campaign exceeding $125,000 to promote consumption of tea will be started Oct. 1, Benjamin Wood, managing director of the Tea Bureau, Inc., announced yesterday at the close of a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club in the Hotel Roosevelt, at which he was the principal speaker.

Anyone not devoid of a sense of justice has to agree with Franz Klein, who, in your issue of May 21, objects to the arbitrary discrimination between Axis satellites and other collaborationists. Less fortunate, however, was Mr. Klein in choosing not the Hungarian people but Admiral Horthy in support of his thesis.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 23 -- Professor S. Sakimura, first Japanese official to attempt to desert the Axis cause, returned to Berlin this morning. He made the trip in a regular Swedish airliner.

The City Council of Cleveland has just adopted an ordinance calling for a reduction of $1,200,000 annually in electric rates of the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company. The new rates, if made effective, would replace those now in effect which had been provided for in a four-year agreement expiring on July 7.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Reports from Europe saying that Great Britain and Russia might be disposed to give a greater degree of recognition to the French Committee of National Liberation under Gen. Charles de Gaulle find no echoing support in American policy.
The issues of "progressive education" and "children's freedom" are now being reviewed by many parents and educators.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, May 24 (AP) -- A communique:
Several sales and resales of apartment and business properties on West Fifty-fifth, Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets enlivened trading in the midtown section yesterday.

A U.S. FLYING FORTRESS BASE IN BRITAIN, May 23 -- Sergeant Raymond Allen, 21 years of age, of Penns Grove, N.J., a radioman on a Flying Fortress, swung by his legs for nine minutes in an open bomb bay door today and held the spinning arming vane on a bomb to prevent it from exploding prematurely.

The plans of Tammany Leader Edward V. Loughlin to strengthen his hold on the Tammany organization by increasing the appointive membership on the executive committee received final approval last night at a meeting of the New York County Democratic Committee. The meeting, attended by 1,000 of the faithful, was held at the Manhattan Center.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The State Department announced today that the Japanese had given approval for the purchase of $25,000 of relief supplies monthly for civilian internees and prisoners of war in the Philippine Islands.

Atlantis Assets, Inc., sold to the Ten Security Corporation of Brooklyn the apartment house and garages on a plot 334 by 192 feet at 180 Hilton Avenue, in Hempstead, L.I. The property is assessed at $180,650 and was bought subject to a mortgage of $127,500.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 23 -- State Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale, who will be considered for endorsement for re-election at a meeting tomorrow of Westchester County Republican leaders, said today that his acceptance of a $4,600 legal fee from the State involved no impropriety.

Earl Browder, making his first public appearance as president of the new Communist Political Association -- successor to the Communist party -- last night proposed an Anglo-American economic agreement that would guarantee Britain a share of world markets in which it would not be subject to "free competition" from America's unlimited resources and mass production.

" The Gate," a scenic oratorio with music by Max Brand, was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night by the music and theatre wing of the Caravan of East and West for the benefit of the children of India through the India Famine Relief Committee.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- A sudden about-face by the leadership of Local 490 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, acting under pressure from highest authorities of the international union, brought an end today to the week-old Chrysler Corporation strike.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Enough clothing to provide more than 100,000,000 persons with complete outfits will be required in the relief period immediately after the re-conquest of Europe, according to estimates made public here today by the National Planning Association.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Following is a special communique issued May 20 by Allied Headquarters in the southwest Pacific area, which apparently through inadventure was not transmitted to the press in this country at the time:
KANDY, Ceylon, May 23 (UP) -- A communique:
The battle to get the Congressional nomination on the Republican ticket in Westchester and Putnam for Miss Jane H. Todd, vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, continued yesterday.

The Phillips Packing Company, Inc., announced yesterday in its report for the fiscal year ended with March a net profit of $774,689 after all charges, including provision of $2,510,000 for taxes and renegotiation refund.
LONDON, May 23 (Reuter) -- In his fifth Empire Day message of the war, King George told the people of his colonies:

HOUSTON, Texas, May 23 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, addressing the Republican State convention, declared today that "if no business in this country is immune from seizure, then we no longer have a constitutional President -- we have a dictator."

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Contending that the new 30 per cent cabaret tax had proved during its first month of operation to be a failure as a revenue producer, Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, introduced in the Senate today an amendment which would reduce that levy to 10 per cent.

In a first step designed to crystalize post-war planning of tobacco wholesalers, the National Association of Tobacco Distributors yesterday sent out its "operation program" to members. The program, covering nine major factors and the wholesaler's present and postwar relation to them, will enable comprehensive analysis at the local level.

Suppose that in 1919-1920, when the Versailles Treaty was up for ratification in Washington, we were living under a different Constitution. Suppose that the practice then was to ratify treaties by a majority vote in the Senate and in the House of Representatives instead of a two-thirds majority in the Senate only.

Four women were taken to St. Vincent's Hospital at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon as a result of injuries received when the subway escalator they and sixteen other persons were using at Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street suddenly went into reverse.

Formal offering was made yesterday of the new issue of $56,000,000 California Toll Bridge Authority, San-Francisco-Oakland Bank Toll Bridge revenue refunding bonds, by the nation-wide banking group of 236 investment firms headed by Blyth Co., Inc.; the Mellon Securities Corporation, Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers, which won the award of the bonds on Monday.

The Museum of Modern Art was founded in 1929 and thus is celebrating this year its fifteenth anniversary. To mark the event an exhibition illustrating all phases of the museum's development has been arranged. It opened with a preview last evening, and from now on, through the summer, the many-sided report ought to prove a genuine source of public enjoyment and profit.

For at least four or five years after the war American textile exports will be greater than they ever have been, William C. Planz, president of the Textile Export Association, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the association at the Arkwright Club.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- A German convoy of six ships loaded with ammunition and gasoline was destroyed in the Mediterranean by a British-American force after two American PT boats lured a pair of German destroyers from their protective position, the Navy disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted authority to the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company to issue certain securities, as follows:

The Health Department's drive to rid Bronx streets of stray dogs and thus curb the spread of rabies has incensed so many dog owners that agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals are getting police protection, it became known yesterday.

Lieut. Lester N. Hofheimer, killed four days before his twenty-eighth birthday in a plane crash last Dec. 12 while en route to China from India in an Army plane, left the bulk of his estate, approximating $1,000,000, to philanthropic enterprises, it was disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- First Lieut. Cordelia E. Cook has become the first woman to wear the Bronze Star for "meritorious service" recently authorized by the War Department. She had previously won the Purple Heart for wounds when her field hospital was bombed in the Presenzano sector of the Italian front, and she thus has become the first American woman to win two decorations in the present war.

TRENTON, May 23 -- President Roosevelt's domestic and post-war policies were denounced at the opening session of the Republican State convention here today and his Administration as stoutly defended at the Democratic State convention.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
