LONDON, Wednesday, May 24 (U.P.) -- Red Army forces scored local gains in the Stanislav area of southeastern Poland and along the lower Dniester River northwest of Tiraspol yesterday, killing about 400 Germans, Moscow announced today.

It was not luck but careful timing that brought General Stilwell's campaign in northern Burma to its present line just as the monsoon rains begin to fall. For the most part our forces have crossed the valleys which are certain to be flooded. They now stand on higher ground before our main objectives.

Founded in 1919 to "assist the intelligent adult toward educating himself to a better understanding of a rapidly changing world," the New School for Social Research this week has celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary. It began in protest against the use of class credits and grades as currency, against the policies of unimaginative and often reactionary boards of trustees, and against undue influence by alumni bodies which had become too set in their ways.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- While supporting free competition in all parts of the world after the war, Ralph W. Gallagher, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, warned a Senate subcommittee today that the realities of foreign trade as conducted before the war required, sometimes, that American corporations enter restrictive agreements if they would do business under the laws and customs of foreign governments.

A1 (Bummy) Davis of Williamsburg knocked out Charley Sabatelle of Scranton, Pa., in 1:13 of the third round last night on the season's final card at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn. Davis weighed 142 pounds and Sabatelle 145 1/4.

MOSCOW, May 23 -- The State Symphony Orchestra of 100 and a choir of 125, with one of the Soviet Union's leading lyric tenors performed Sunday night in honor of Soviet-American friendship before the heads of Moscow diplomatic missions and a large representative Russian audience in Tchaikovsky Concert Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Truman Defense Investigating Committee of the Senate today brought forth evidence which members held to show that the Printing and Publishing Division of the War Production Board has shown partiality in allocating additional newsprint supplies to magazine and book publishers.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. LST 141, May 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- For six days the "Anzio highway" -- as the United States Navy's tank landing ship men describe their flotilla on this job -- has been worked at the highest pressure since the beachhead was stormed four months ago.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Legion of Merit to Maj. Samuel R. Peterson, 609 West 173d Street, New York, and Second Lieut. Martin J.A. Schwarzschild, Rutherford Observatory, Columbia University.

On May 24 100 years ago Samuel Morse was able, after many discouragements and Congressional delays, to send a telegraphic message over the completed line from Washington to Baltimore. The message, a verse from the twenty-third chapter of Numbers, was "What God Hath Wrought."

LONDON, Wednesday, May 24 (AP) -- The pro-Russian National Council of Poland has sent representatives to Moscow from German-occupied Polish territory, the Moscow radio announced today, raising the possibility that the Soviet Union might recognize the council as the legal government of Poland.

LONDON, May 23 -- The recent agreement between Norway and the Allies regarding civil administration of that country after its liberation from the Germans has been seized upon by the Quisling government in an effort to drive a wedge between Norwegians and their exiled King and Government.

various faiths aid radio stations in preparing such prayers in advance and that once the invasion started prayers be offered daily thereafter at a certain hour, with a request that all citizens join in.

Nine hundred churchmen and friends honored Bishop Francis J. McConnell, Resident Bishop of the New York area of the Methodist Church, at a dinner last night in the Hotel Commodore. He will retire from active service next month after having completed thirty-two years in the episcopacy, sixteen of which were spent here.
THE TIMES of May 17 tells of the case of two boys brought before Magistrate J. Roland Sala. They had been maliciously breaking branches from a tree.

Mayor La Guardia enthusiastically declared yesterday afternoon that the New York City Center of Music and Drama was "no longer an experiment" after announcement was made that the city's venture in the show business had shown a profit of $844.77 on its initial year of operation.

A communique covering the activities of Italian guerrillas behind the German lines, issued yesterday at Allied headquarters in Italy, disclosed that the Italian patriots were "cooperating with the French patriots of Haute-Savoie" and now control the Little St. Bernard Pass leading from Italy to France.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 23 -- The principal Stock Exchanges and chief newspapers of Canada are renewing strong protests to the Government against certain clauses in the new extradition treaty between Canada and the United States.

The man who would relax for a day without making too extensive a trip during this period of travel difficulty can do worse than try his hand at flounder fishing in Long Island Sound. It's about as exciting as extracting bullheads from a pond, but you will get a good outing and even some fish.

Simple, brief directions on home canning that are followed with care often result in the most satisfactory products, according to the New York State Emergency Food Commission. It says that long explanations, replete with a discussion of the kinds of spoilage organisms and how and why they must be destroyed, are bewildering to the many women who lack the time to study them painstakingly.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday were 1,478, compared with 1,464 in the preceding week and 1,414 in the similar period last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 638, against 839 last Tuesday.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 -- Work in the sheet metal department of the Federal Dry Dock and Shipbuilding Company at Port Newark was seriously curtailed today as the result of the continued strike of the lead men. Eighty went on strike early Sunday morning, reporting themselves "sick"; twenty others left their jobs today, notwithstanding a plea to return to work by William F. Cann, United States Labor Department conciliator.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -Samuel Okin of New York, perennial thorn in the side of the Electric Bond and Share Company, was escorted today from a hearing at the Securities and Exchange Commission by a policeman who had been summoned at the climax of one of Mr. Okin's frequent brushes with Richard Townsend, a trial examiner.

The chestnut wig that the noted ballerina, Alicia Markova, wore in flowing braids in her role of Juliet in the ballet "Romeo and Juliet" at the Metropolitan Opera House, will become "Exhibit A" next Monday when Francisco Xavier, 25 years old, Mexican member of the corps de ballet of the Ballet Theatre, Inc., appears in Special Sessions for trial on a charge of stealing it.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Whether or not the Children's Bureau can cope with the rising tide of illegal child labor depends in a large part on the fate of a proposed $144,222 increase in enforcement funds, Mrs. Elizabeth Coleman of the bureau's industrial division said today.

During the twelve months ended March 31 last, farm land prices in the United States rose 15 per cent and the average price now is 38 per cent above the average levels of 1935-39, the agricultural commission of the American Bankers Association reported yesterday.

American GI's overseas go strongest for Hollywood movies (when they're not on war themes), radio programs, including those beamed at them by the Axis, and for athletics, according to Special Service officers freshly returned from Iceland, Asia and the South Pacific.

The band of the Cardinal Hayes High School won the Group B silver cup in the final session of the ninth annual Catholic School Music Festival, according to an announcement made yesterday. The festival closed at Town Hall Sunday afternoon.
BOSTON, May 23 (AP) -- Apprentice Ken Scawthorn from Pawtucket, R.I., accepted only five mounts on today's card at Suffolk Downs and rode each of them into the winner's circle.

LONDON, May 23 -- The enemy today tried to prove that the Allies' air attacks on the French railroad system have been successful when Robert de Beauplan. Paris radio commentator, declared, "the French railway system is in complete chaos," and said British and American planes "have successfully pulverized into rubble whole marshaling yards" and destroyed "countless locomotives and made scores of railway stations unusable."

SOUTHEND-ON-SEA, England, May 23 -- England's second set of quadruplets in less than three months was born early today to Mrs. Daisy Moxham, 38-year-old wife of an RAF flying officer and mother of five other children.

WASHINGTON, MAY 23 -- War plant workers should honor the heroic dead on Memorial Day next Tuesday by making it a day of full scale production, Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, said today in appealing to all war plants to operate full schedule on the holiday.
The address of Bernard M. Baruch in accepting the Churchman Award at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night follows:

To check an inflationary trend now in evidence in Venezuela, growing out of a surplus of dollar exchange, the Creole Petroleum Corporation has agreed to borrow up to 30,000,000 bolivars from the Central Bank of that country for six months at 3 per cent interest, pending completion of a plan to borrow from the public, C.H. Lieb, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting held here yesterday.

LONDON, May 23 (AP) -- German People's Courts will try Allied pilots shot down during fighter-plane attacks on trains and communications in Germany, a Reich broadcast quoted by the Stockholm newspaper Svenska Dagbladet said today.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, at a press conference here today said he would favor President Roosevelt for re-election in 1948 "in the event there is a comparable emergency and the Republicans have a candidate of comparably little experience."

A court order, served at 7:30 o'clock last night on Sergeant Frank J. Rowland Jr. of the Asbury Park police in the office of Mayor Vincent P. Keuper of Asbury Park, brought one step closer to a grand jury investigation the belief of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan that the Jersey policeman, for seven years, had furnished pistols to notorious gangsters, at least one of which was used in a well-known gambler's murder.

" Abracadabra" will be the title of that "magical-musical comedy" Dick Himber, band leader and legerdemain artist, intends to produce. Mr. Himber has gone to the Coast to urge Orson Welles, a sleight-of-hand expert himself, to appear in the show as well as co-produce it.

Knowing radio voices is going to be very important to the populations of occupied Europe and to Allied plans to use the underground armies to aid the invading forces. In the name of General Eisenhower advance instructions are being issued over the air in French, Norwegian, Danish, Dutch and Flemish, and one reason these orders are serialized is to familiarize the listeners with the voices of the broadcasters.

Huge quantities of lard moved out of cold storage in the New York City area yesterday to make room for eggs bought by the Federal Government in its price-support program. The exact amount of lard evacuated from needed storage space was not divulged on the ground that it might have strategic significance.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Responding to the intra-party demand that he jettison Henry A. Wallace as a running mate in the national election, President Roosevelt has saddled the Vice President's opponents with the job of finding a substitute.

Diplomas and collegiate awards were presented to 107 gTaduates -of Manhattanqlle College of the Sacred Heart by Archbishop Francis J. Spenman at commencenent exercises held yesterday in the college symnasium, 133d Street and Convent Avenue.
LONDON, May 23 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Estimates by the United States Steel Corporation, presented today to the National War Labor Board steel panel, indicated that higher wages requested by the United Steel Workers, CIO, combined with a request for guaranteed maintenance of wages, would involve a loss of more than $500,000,000 a year, if business returned to the level of 1937.

LONDON, May 23 (U.P.) -- The Air Ministry today branded as "without foundation" a report published in The London Daily Express that forty-seven Royal Air Force officers were massacred in a German prison camp by guards who "lost their heads."

Renewed demand for cotton for export, agitation in Washington for higher cotton loans and higher textile ceilings and a firmer spot basis in the South, brought about yesterday a steady tone in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, which closed 1 to 4 points higher than on Monday.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, May 23 -- Heavy fighting began this morning as American tanks and infantry rolled forward after a half hour of intensive artillery preparation and naval shelling. The Air Force turned out to do as much damage as possible to selected enemy objectives under bad weather conditions.

Pressure by the armed services for additional quantities of wool seamless knitted gloves will mean indefinite delays in shipments to the civilian trade, it was learned yesterday. Manufacturers, who started booking fall and winter lines last December on an "as ready" basis, declared that heavy new requirements of procurement agencies also point to losses of 25 per cent and more in deliveries during the season on orders already booked.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Killing Japanese with any weapon that comes to hand is a specialty of Pfc. Edward J. Gordon of Waukegan, Ill. He accounted for twenty-two dead and an uncounted number of wounded on March 10.

ALBANY, May 23 (AP) -- Farmers' referenda on proposed increases of fluid milk prices beyond OPA ceilings were initiated in two additional marketing areas today by the State, which presently is restrained by court order from enforcing an above-ceiling price in the Hudson-Mohawk area.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- As invasion approaches, the new and once-nebulous program of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration has been reduced to the realism of a minimum staff of highly trained specialists; and a boiled-down budget to be used primarily for buying a lot for a little in basic foods, clothing and medical supplies.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Senator Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, told the Senate today he had been informed that a United States cruiser had been transferred to Russia, and he demanded to know the truth of such a report.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A prospect loomed that the United States might reconsider its non-recognition attitude toward the revolutionary regime in Bolivia in view of a report made to the State Department today by Avra Warren, American Ambassador to Panama, who has just completed a special investigation of the situation in the South American country.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Two Congressional committees today turned down demands for specific inquiries into the CIO Political Action Committee and how it is operating in this election year.

Chief Justice Harlan Fiske Stone, participating in ceremonies inaugurating Dr. Samuel Belkin as president of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary and Yeshiva College, called yesterday upon Americans to preserve their "capacity for moral indignation against cruelty and injustice" as the surest safeguard of peace and happiness in the post-war world.
Universay military training for youth was urged as part of the post-war educational program yesterday by Brig. Gen. Walter L. Weible, director of military training, Army Service Forces.

LONDON, May 23 (AP) -- Yugoslavia's patriot army is attacking in Dalmatia and Croatia and has destroyed thirteen troop and supply trains in blows at the German lifelines, Marshal Tito's headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- By a standing vote of 236 to 16 the House passed today and sent to the Senate legislation repealing "land grant" rail rate schedules under which the Government has a 50 per cent discount on shipments of men and supplies of the armed forces.

" Our Heritage," published by Putnam, is a collection of the addresses and writings of Representative Sol Bloom, including an interpretation of George Washington's carreer. As director of the George Washington Bicentennial celebrations in 1932, Mr. Bloom had access to all the historical material in the possession of the Government, and was aided in his research by a corps of historians.

PEARL HARBOR, May 23 (AP) -- Rear Admiral J.J. Gaffney, head of the Navy's vast supply system in the Pacific, declared today that "the turnover and volume of supplies handled here are seven times greater than on this area last year."

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- The University of Chicago, which quit intercollegiate football in 1939, today withdrew from all athletic competition in the Western Conference through 1945 because of manpower shortage.

NAPLES, May 23 -- The long pent-up power of the Allies' beachhead forces was hurled into the battle of Italy early today in conjunction with a renewed attack by the British Eighth Army against the rain-swept remnants of the Hitler Line and a relentless continued push by the Fifth Army deep into the mountains northeast of Terracina.

While the War Manpower Commission remained adamant in its refusal to supply to the police here information vital to the solution of a series of crimes, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that he had proposed to War Manpower Commissioner Paul V. McNutt on May 2, a modification of regulations imposed on the United States Employment Service, which have prohibited the revelation of names and addresses of dishonest domestics supplied to housewives by the USES.

With a preview for members and their guests, the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, last night opened its fifteenth anniversary exhibition, called "Art in Progress." The exhibition, filling all of the galleries, opens to the public today and will run through the summer.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Criminal penalties for those in Government departments and agencies who permit the making public of excerpts censored from mail or other communications entering or leaving this country were advocated today by Byron Price, Director of Censorship.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- June Allyson has been chosen for the ingenue lead of "Music for Millions," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical, which was put into production today with Jimmy Durante, Margaret O'Brien and Jose Iturbi also featured.

Plans for the post-war re-establishment of Judaism in France, its colonies and possessions have been completed and have been filed by a committee with the Secretary of State in Albany, it was learned yesterday. A certificate of incorporation has been approved by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan.
A police drive to rid the city's sidewalks of "photographic fakers" who accept money for photographing people but do not deliver pictures has been ordered by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

At the special meeting of R.H. Macy Co. yesterday stockholders approved the recommendation of the directors to authorize the issuance of 500,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock. A record of 81 per cent of the outstanding common stock of the corporation voted in favor of the recommendation.

Major league and Pacific Coast League baseball parks will be kept open on D-Day, but International League plants will shut down for the day at the announcement that the Allies have begun their invasion of Europe, The Associated Press learned yesterday.

Photography will be taught to returned war veterans by members of the American Women's Voluntary Services in a rehabilitation course that will be developed on a national scale, Mrs. Alice T. McLean, president, told the group's national convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 23 (AP) -- Iceland's referendum to decide whether she shall sever her ties with Denmark and become an independent republic ended today after two days of balloting that brought out 100 per cent of the qualified voters in some districts.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Wednesday, May 24 (AP) -- American Sixth Army forces, pressing toward two northern New Guinea airfields, have expanded their bridgehead at the mouth of the Tor River opposite the captured Wakde Islands, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Rabbi Israel Goldstein, president of the Zionist Organization of America and of the Synagogue Council of America, received many tributes last night at a dinner tendered him on his twenty-fifth anniversary as rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, second oldest Jewish congregation in New York.

Edward F. McSorley, principal of Public School 53, at Findlay and Teller Avenues, the Bronx, said yesterday that an entertainment program arranged by students there to aid their weekly waste paper collection had been so successful that repeat performances were under consideration.
LONDON, May 23 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
Residential properties figured in most of the East Side realty transactions reported yesterday, the sales involving a home in East Sixty-sixth Street, an old Yorkville holding and other parcels.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, May 23 (AP) -- American tanks and infantry smashed today at the smoke-shrouded German line guarding the Appian Way to Rome in the Allies' greatest attack from the beachhead since they landed on Jan. 22.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23 (AP) -- Howard Mumford Jones, dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Arts, demands that the study of American civilization receive its rightful place in American colleges.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Donald R. Richberg, former administrator of the old National Recovery Administration, defended the "administrative discretion" of the Securities and Exchange Commission in a brief filed today with the United States Supreme Court urging denial of a petition by Otis Co. of Cleveland, investment bankers, to upset decisions of lower courts approving the SEC's reorganization of the United Light Power Company.

The four-story, forty-family apartment building at 37-43 Mitchell Place, in White Plains, assessed at $104,900 and reported to have an annual rent roll of about $22,000, has been sold by the Manhattan Savings Bank to Bud A. Lipman and associates, of Spencer-Adams, Inc., for cash above a mortgage of $76,000.
LONDON, May 24 -- The rich beauty of England in the Spring provides a strange backdrop for impending drama.
Miss Rae Hirshorn, 24 years old, died in an automobile accident yesterday in Brooklyn while rushing a physician to her dying mother at 2401 Sixty-fourth Street, Brooklyn.

With the closing of entries for the meet, 255 nominations have been attracted for the sixteen events in the twelfth annual Metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships, it was announced yesterday by the meet director, Ralph Furey of Columbia.
LONDON, May 24 -- Here are the most important targets of the many attacked today with thousands of tons of American and British bombs:
LONDON, Thursday, May 25 (AP) -- German spot raiders were over the southeast coast and East Anglia again last night. Bombs were dropped at one place, but no damage or casualties were reported.

Almost every woman golf star in this vicinity, including all champions of recent years, has entered the women's division of the Red Cross week of golf at the Wykagyl Country Club, New Rochelle, June 12 and 13 for the Greater New York 1944 Red Cross War Fund.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -Senator Hernan Videla, head of the Chilean conference of the InterAmerican Development Commission in New York, declared today that the Chilean Government is using normal diplomatic channels as an effort to influence Argentina into joining the other countries of this hemisphere in a common policy of continental solidarity.

DETROIT, May 24 (AP) -- Frank Hayes belted his sixth homer of the season and his second with the bases loaded to give the Athletics an 8-to-4 victory over the Tigers today, ending Detroit's six-game winning streak. The Athletics thus replaced Detroit in the American League's first division.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24 -- Navy scored a 2-to-1, ten-inning baseball victory over Columbia University today in preparation for the final game of the season with Army here on Saturday. Third Baseman Rabbit Curry broke up the fray with a single, scoring Conway Taylor, the Midshipmen's third pitcher. The box score:

CLEVELAND, May 24 -- Unless America maintains her prosperity in the post-war world, not only the country but also the world will suffer, the National Conference on Social Work was told today by Alvin H. Hansen, Littauer Professor of Economics at Harvard.

A new issue of $11,000,000 of refunding bonds of the Chicago, Ill., Board of Education was awarded yesterday to a banking group headed by the Illinois Company of Chicago. The bonds are dated Aug. 1, 1944, and will mature on Aug. 1, 1954, and are callable beginning Aug. 1, 1945. The winning bid was 100.306 for the bonds as a 1 1/4 per cent issue.

Rain yesterday washed away both local major league games. The schedule called for the Dodgers to clash with the Cardinals in daylight at Ebbets Field and for the Giants to launch their night campaign at the Polo Grounds against the Reds, until old Jupe Pluvius made his presence felt.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- (AP) -- Harrison E. Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that an assertion by Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National chairman, made it clear that "this Administration and its cohorts are seeking to destroy America's republican form of government."
CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- American planes under naval command sped into action against the Japanese 2,005 times in the last week, Navy Secretary James V. Forrestal reported today. He gave the total number of sorties -- a sortie is one flight by one plane -- in reviewing the war in the Pacific for the week of May 16 to May 23.
DETROIT, May 24 -- Ernest G. Liebold, personal secretary to Henry Ford and a power among the executives of the Ford Motor Company for more than thirty years, has been discharged.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A long legal controversy between the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Federal Government came to a showdown today when James E. Markham, Alien Property Custodian, ordered the company to surrender physically possession of certain securities and patents formerly owned by I.G. Farbenindustrie, the German chemical trust.

Paintings by old and modern masters, owned by the estate of Anne Depew Paulding, Mrs. J. Macy Willets and others, were sold at auction last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, for a total of $66,555.

After more than fifty years of joint operation the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service is being separated from the Henry Street Settlement and different boards of directors have been named to manage the two organizations, it was announced yesterday by George W. Alger, for many years chairman of the organization's board and a lifelong friend of the late Lillian D. Wald, founder of both organizations.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A nonpartisan picture of the coming Presidential campaign will be presented to foreign audiences by the Office of War Information, Elmer Davis, Director, promised today.

LONDON, Thursday, May 25 -- Anti-fascist and left-wing opinion recoiled in alarm today from the "kindly words about Spain" spoken in the House of Commons yesterday by Prime Minister Churchill, who declared that the war "has become less ideological in character."
ST. LOUIS, May 24 (AP) -- Jack Kramer pitched his sixth victory of the season tonight as the Browns opened a long home stay by defeating the Red Sox, 7 to 3. Each club made seven hits.

Office and store space in the midtown Manhattan district continue to attract many business concerns. New rentals have just been made to retailers, publishers, advertising firms, artists and contractors. Several deals for commercial space also were reported yesterday in the Wall Street district.

Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday that he would recommend to the Board of Health a modification of its regulation to destroy stray dogs in the Bronx if the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals could set up a shelter to care for the animals for six months. The regulation was put into effect to curb the spread of rabies.

PEARL HARBOR, May 24 (U.P.) -- Navy Aleutians-based search planes made three pre-dawn attacks on the Japanese bases of Paramushiru and Shimushu in the Kurile Islands on Sunday and yesterday, while Mitchell bombers dealt new blows to the enemy's battered Carolines outpost of Ponape, Pacific Fleet Headquarters announced today.
The Office of Price Administration got ready for the summer yesterday by setting up flat dollars-and-cents ceiling prices on artificial ice in this city for the first time.

CATSKILL, N.Y., May 24 -- Staff Sgt. Paul Johnson, 23 years old, who was reported shot down over Austria on March 29, returned to his home in Halcott Center this morning. He will spend his twenty- one-day furlough at the home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roy Johnson, Halcott Center.

Lee Savold and Joe Baksi, who meet in a twelve-round return bout in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, ended their intensive training yesterday. Savold weighed 197 1/2 pounds after boxing four rounds at Stillman's, while Baksi was 208 1/2 after five at Summit, N. J. Baksi promised to shave today a three-week growth of beard that aroused the displeasure of the State Athletic Commission.

MOSCOW, May 24 -- Ferapont Golovaty, beekeeper of Saratov, today for the second year in succession, donated 100,000 rubles to Premier Joseph Stalin for the purchase of a latest-model Soviet fighter plane for presentation to Guards Major Yeremin, who in Mr. Golovaty's first plane fought the Germans at Stalingrad, Rostov, Taganrog, Melitopol and in the Crimea.

Don Meade, stormy petrel of racing, whose career has been on the on-and-off order, was reinstated as a rider yesterday by the stewards of the Jockey Club. Announcement of the lifting of the ban that has been on the veteran jockey since October, 1942, was made at Belmont Park in the afternoon, following the stewards' meeting in the New York offices of the Jockey Club during the morning.
LONDON, Thursday, May 25--From the Alps to the Baltic, from the gun-studded Channel coast to Berlin, Allied air power was supreme over Hitler's European fortress yesterday.

While purchasing officers at the Jersey City Quartermaster Depot of the Army were stressing the importance of saving waste paper with the announcement that $18,000,000 was spent on paper products for military needs during the first quarter of 1944, Commissioner William F. Carey reported last evening that his Department of Sanitation trucks salvaged twenty-two tons of paper less than on the previous Wednesday.

The recent broadening of the scope of the War Production Board's limitation order, L-13-A, which controls the production of metal furniture and fixtures, will seriously affect the production of school furniture, theatre seats and swivel chairs, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday.

An old town house in the Murray Hill section passed to new control with the announcement yesterday that a contract had been signed for the sale by the estate of Grace R. Rogers of the six-story residence at 58 Park Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets.

Fighting with a dash and courage that have never been surpassed, the Allied armies in Italy are continuing to score advances. Out of the smoke and the thunder of the battle there is already rising the pattern of a victory. On every side the German lines appear to be crumbling, and over the broken ruins of their fortifications rush the waves of Allied might to crush the remaining enemy resistance.

The old Hammerstein Theatre and fourteen-story office building at 1697 Broadway, near Fifty-third Street, passed into new hands yesterday with the completion of a deal whereby Howard S. Cullman, Cullman Brothers and associates acquired the property from the Manufacturers Trust Company.

China is now waging effective war on two widely separated fronts. While her offensive in northern Burma still forges ahead she has launched a counter-offensive against the Japanese in Honan Province. A nation that can find strength after seven years of exhausting war to support two such major movements at once is not staggering toward collapse.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 24 -- The executive committee of the Westchester County Republican organization met here this afternoon with Livingston Platt, county chairman, and designated nine State legislative candidates, including Senator Pliny W. Williamson, but again failed to endorse Assemblywoman Jane H. Tood for Representative.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Alien E. Norman told the Senate War Investigating Committee today he thought it would be "quite inappropriate" that he continue as assistant director of the War Production Board's printing and publishing division and chief of the magazine section.

As principal of the Baptist Wayland Academy of Hangchow, China, Dr. E.H. Clayton, author of "Heaven Below," to be published by Prentice-Hall on June 12, has lived through the Chinese revolution, the founding of the republic, the Sino-Japanese War and the conversion of his school into a refuge for thousands of women and children.
NAPLES, May 24 (AP) -- A communique:

Announcing itself as an organization formed to support the principles and objectives of the Hebrew Committee of National Liberation, the American League for a Free Palestine held its first meeting yesterday at the home of Maj. and Mrs. Harvey L. Schwamm, 1046 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy Forrestal announced today that Vice Admiral Aubrey W. Fitch, who recently returned from four years' duty in the Pacific, will become Deputy Chief of Naval Operations for Air.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Orders have gone out to about 100 producers of cotton textiles instructing them to set aside specific quantities of their output of certain fabrics which are to be delivered under orders bearing preference ratings to manufacturers of children's wearing apparel, the War Production Board announced today.

BALTIMORE, May 24 (AP) -- Bobo Palica held Jersey City to six hits tonight while Baltimore rapped Bob Barthelson and Mike Mellis for nine safeties to score an 8-1 victory. The Jersey City run was a homer by Lockman in the opening inning.

A news photograph shows Winston Churchill inspecting an outfit of camouflaged invasion troops wearing headdresses of loose foliage, which the picture caption very happily designates as bird nests. From the enemy's scouting planes and from the remoter observation posts these camouflaged warriors in repose are a sleeping forest.

Though Bernard Baruch, to whom has just been given another honor, has won his eminence by his own efforts and genius, it is natural to think of him as fortunate because he enjoys general respect and gratitude. Burke's definition of public life as "a situation of power and energy" is incomplete.

LONDON, May 24 -- For the conclusion and peroration of his speech in the House of Commons today on Britain's foreign policy, Prime Minister Churchill sketched in roughly a picture of a world insured against war by the combined might of the victors in this conflict through a world-controlling council and an assembly to include other powers.

DES MOINES, May 24 (AP) -- With more than $30,000,000 damage in their wake flood waters which have been racing through Iowa for a week continued their rampage in the southeastern part of the State today, forcing hundreds to flee their homes.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- General Shang Chen, new chief of the Chinese Military Mission to the United States, predicted today that China might be receiving munitions over the Ledo-Burma Road six months after the fall of Myitkyina, in Burma, which he declared was certain.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 24 (UP) -- A communique:

ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, May 24 (AP) -- A veteran American armored formation smashed through the German flank on the Rome side of Cisterna today, pouring a threatening steel avalanche closer on that fortress town astride the Appian Way to Rome.

Official word is that the directors of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., may vote tomorrow to call 195,576 shares of $10 par 6 per cent convertible preferred stock for retirement at the call price of $10.50 a share and accrued dividends.

DETROIT, May 24 -- International executives of the United Automobile Workers (CIO) ousted fifteen officers of a rebellious Detroit chapter tonight for their part in a wildcat strike against the Chrysler Corporation, while the strike-ridden area was threatened by another walkout which would cut the city's bread supply.

Four strong pillars -- spiritual, educational, economic and military -- support our American life and must be kept standing if we are to continue our pursuit of happiness under freedom, Bernard M. Baruch said last night at the annual dinner of the National Institute of Social Sciences at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The majority of 600 graduating seniors at City College want President Roosevelt for a fourth term, believe that he is the "greatest living man in the world" and expect another world war in twenty-five years, according to the results of an annual poll made public yesterday.
LONDON, May 24 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast by the Nazi DNB agency:

The nation's stocks of major oil products increased moderately last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week gasoline stocks amounted to 87,962,000 barrels, an increase of 139,000 over the 87,823,000 at the end of the previous week. A year ago they were 85,649,000 barrels.

Fishermen who have returned from Peconic Bay on Long Island with enthusiastic reports of the abundance of weakfish there this season but who have been somewhat disappointed with their size will be interested in an announcement from George Ruppert of a big one taken in the surf off New Jersey.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
Lucky Draw, eliminated from the Kentucky Derby by an attack of colic on the eve of the Run for the Roses, won the Peter Pan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday with practically no effort whatsoever.

The high levels reached by the stock market in March were tested successfully yesterday as idle funds were poured by impatient investors into a wide variety of issues. The upward movement encountered some minor stumbling blocks toward the close which prevented prices from ending at the highs of the day.

Continued price fixing credited to tire factories and Southern mills lifted cotton futures prices again yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and the market closed at about the best levels of the day, or 11 to 12 points higher on active months than on Tuesday.

CAMP ANZA, Calif., May 24 (AP) -- A court-martial in the case of Lieut. Beaufort G. Swancutt today held that he was sane last March 5 when, the Army charges, he fatally shot four persons and wounded four others.
LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

SOMERVILLE, N.J., May 24 -- A verdict of first-degree murder coupled with a recommendation for life imprisonment at hard labor, was returned at 6 o'clock tonight against Scott Wolfe Farland, 36 years old, a gunner's mate in the Navy, in his trial for the knife slaying of James Manchester, 61, of 10 Monroe Street, New York, last Jan. 23 at 8 Allen Place, North Plainfield.

Stockholders of the American Distilling Company put up an aggregate of about $96,600,000, including excise taxes, for the purchase of some 4,347,000 cases of blended and bonded whisky under the company's distribution plan which ended on Saturday, according to the latest check of purchase orders.

Three Government agencies joined here yesterday in opening a vigorous drive to recruit civilians into various home-front jobs held up to now by soldiers who are being rapidly transferred abroad to combat duty.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A triple play by Mrs. Anna Higgins, Mayor La Guardia and Police Lieut. Andrew Ryan supplied the tenants of a large apartment house at 47-32 Forty-fifth Street, Sunnyside, Queens, with hot water yesterday, to the satisfaction of all concerned, including the apartment house superintendent, who got out of some legal hot water in Long Island City Magistrates Court.

LONDON, Thursday, May 25 (AP) -- Possibly signaling a big new offensive on the Eastern Front, the Moscow radio said in a broadcast to the Army today: "Soon you will be called on to accomplish the liberation of Soviet territory and also to liberate other European nations from the German fascist oppressor."

ALGIERS, May 24 -- The Russian Government has approved President Roosevelt's directive to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on the civil rule of liberated France, it was understood tonight. The directive empowers General Eisenhewer to use his own discretion in dealing with the Committee of National Liberation or any other groups or persons.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 24 -- An explosion below decks in the tanker S.S. Petersburg in the East Coast Shipyards, Inc., at Constable Hook killed one man and injured thirteen others at 9 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee, after three days of sworn-to-secrecy inquiry into reports that the War Department purposed to destroy records of military intelligence investigations into espionage, sabotage and other subversive activities, received today and accepted as satisfactory assurances from Secretary Stimson that no such records had been done away with and that none would be.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Terracina, May 24 (AP) -- American infantrymen smashed through deep-dug German defenses in the tombs and crypts of Cemetery Hill before Terracina despite heavy mortar and machine-gun fire and captured this large coastal highway town today in the climax of a three-day battle.

LONDON, May 24--The terrible raking and hammering of a wide variety of military targets in Germany and Western Europe during the last four days by thousands of American and Allied fighters and fighter-bombers is only a foretaste of the terror that D-day holds for the Germans.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 24 -Further to dominate the French press Vichy has revised all wage scales so that a cub reporter earns 4,000 francs a month. With the purchasing value of the franc ever diminishing, this is no princely pay but it is far better than pre-war standards.

Republic has allocated $17,750,000, the highest budget in the history of the company, to the sixty-eight films on its 1944-45 production program, it was announced yesterday. Heading the schedule are eight super de luxe productions.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Prime Minister Per Albin Hansson of Sweden conceded before his own party in convention at Stockholm on Monday that Sweden had "not succeeded in keeping strict neutrality in all respects," and, putting Swedish neutrality on a realistic basis that "considers actual situation and risks," he observed that "there is a limit also to concessions which can't be exceeded."

Tonight's events: Red Cross Benefit Concert, Arturo Toscanini conducting Philharmonic-Symphony and NBC Orchestras with chorus, glee clubs and soloists in Wagner-Verdi program, Madison Square Garden, 8:30 o'clock; recital of Hungarian and gypsy folk lore and songs by Louise Fernald Rice, Barbizon-Plaza Concert Hall, 8:30, concert of New York College of Music, with Anne Roselle, soprano, Ruth Kisch-Arndt, contralto, Otto Herz, pianist, Rahel Ginsburg, narrator, and Siegfried Landau, conductor, Community Center, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street, 8:15.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 23 -- The Princeton University Gynasium, which was the largest collegiate gynasium in the United States when it was built in 1903, was destroyed by fire early this morning. Many athletic trophies, including the football used in the first Yale-Princeton game in 1873, and the Childs Cup, oldest collegiate rowing trophy in this country, were lost.

Jan Masaryk, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Czechoslovakia, the guest of honor last night at a dinner given by the Czechoslovak Committee of the United Jewish Appeal at the Hotel Roosevelt, emphasized that it was the duty of the United Nations to deal with the problem of Jewish minorities "thoroughly and for all time."

When the Germans assert that the weather must be good before the Channel can be crossed and the most stupendous landing operations in military history are undertaken they are right. They are probably also right in holding that there have been recent periods of good invasion weather.

The letter of Charles Davila, former Rumanian Minister to the United States, carries an implication which needs correction. Finland has not been an aggressor in the second Russian-Finnish War, which started in June, 1941.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Hollywood, the attraction will be "Mr. Skeffington," a Warner Brothers adaptation of the novel by Elizabeth, starring Bette Davis. Featured in the drama are Claude Rains, who plays the title role; Marjorie Riordan, Walter Abel and George Coulouris. . . .
LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- The Foreign Office and the Air Ministry said tonight that they were still awaiting details of the shooting of forty-seven Allied airmen in a German prison camp.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The chairman of the committee on credentials at a national party convention must be a gifted politician and an ingenious lawyer, even in peaceful times. For upon him devolves the delicate task of deciding which group of delegates shall represent a State or district where there is a contest, and then he must provide the convention with as good a legal case for his decision as he can.

Asserting that most of the "eloquent lip service" being paid to free enterprise is accompanied by plans which embody some element of Federal or State compulsion or some element of state socialism, John M. Hancock, co-author of the Baruch-Hancock report on war and post-war adjustment policies, declared last night that in seeking wide post-war employment "we have to abandon that habit of mind which induces whole groups to lean on Washington."

Dr. Irwin R. Harris, a dentist prominent in Hudson County, N.J., was arrested with another man yesterday by city police and Office of Price Administration agents, who reported finding gasoline ration coupons for 15,000 gallons in their possession.

CHUNGKING, Thursday, May 25 (AP) -- The Japanese forces besieging Loyang in northwestern Honan Province attacked the ancient city fiercely from all sides Tuesday but were repulsed and more than 1,000 of their troops killed, the Chinese High Command announced today.
New York City and most of the metropolitan district were blacked out from 9:30 to 9:40 o'clock last night in 1944's second quarterly drill.

Two young members of a gang that for two years had carried on a reign of terror on the West Side as the "Forty-Thieves," perpetrating hundreds of burglaries, robberies and "muggings" of service men in the streets, were sentenced yesterday by Special Sessions Justices Irving Ben Cooper, Frank F. Doyle and Frank Oliver.
BALTIMORE, May 24 (AP) -- An entire new board of directors of the Certain-teed Products Corporation was elected tonight at the annual stockholders' meeting, originally scheduled for April 12.

BUENOS AIRES, May 24 (U.P.)--The United States ranks second in both imports and exports among all countries trading with Argentina, according to official statistics published by the Argentine Ministry of Finance last night.

A suggestion that New York State take over the existing tuberculosis hospitals and facilities for the large-scale work that will come as a result of the development of mass X-raying was made yesterday by Homer Folks, secretary of the State Charities Aid Association.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-secretary of State, said in comment today on Prime Minister Churchill's speech that lend-lease aid to Turkey had been stopped for some time. However, Turkey may still obtain American civilian goods for cash.

Iceland's decision to renounce her allegiance to King Christian of Denmark and set up as an independent republic comes at a time when it will sadden many Danes. Yet the recent link between Iceland and Denmark, expressed in this allegiance to a royal personage, has been hardly more than a symbol.

Various associations in charge of golf in the Metropolitan area have arranged a fair-sized schedule this year, according to the list of events compiled by the Metropolitan Golf Association and released yesterday. Starting this week-end, scarcely a week will go by between now and fall without an event of one kind or another.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, May 25 (AP) -- A communique:

Public offering of $12,500,000 of the West Penn Power Company's first mortgage 3 per cent bonds, series L, due on May 1, 1974, will be made today by a group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at 104 1/2 and accrued interest. Net proceeds of the offering, with additional corporate bonds, will be used to redeem $12,500,000 of first mortgage 5s, series E, on Sept. 1, at 105 and accrued interest.

All the requisites for a welldressed summer were on view yesterday at the showing of "Jeune Fille" fashions by Hattie Carnegie. The presentation, which took place on the Starlight Roof at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, abounded in clothes for country and town that were notable for their good taste, versatility and budget appeal.
LONDON, May 24 (U.P.) -- The text of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's address in the House of Commons today:

Double taxation must be abolished and business given an opportunity to earn a fair profit without an obbligato of sneers, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared last night at a dinner given for him in Cleveland by Stock Exchange member firms.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Regional Director of the War Manpower Commission, announced last night in a written statement that she had asked the United States Employment Service to reveal the name of a domestic worker to the woman employer from whom she is alleged to have stolen $18 last Monday.

Two new booklets on child care, designed especially to help "teenage mothers whose husbands have never seen their babies, mothers doubling up in temporary homes, and service men's wives settling near army camps," have just been issued by the Child Study Association of America, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Hugh Grant Straus Jr., who presided at the annual meeting of the group at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Japanese occupation authorities, in an increasing number of Chinese cities, are refusing to allot food to children under 6 years of age and to men and women past 60, Miss Tsai Kwel, executive director of the Young Women's Christian Association of China, declared here yesterday.

Directors of the Duplan Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock, payable Aug. 1, or 10 cents more than the July 31 disbursement last year. The corporation also announced that it has called for redemption on Aug. 15 the outstanding 8 per cent cumulative preferred stock at $115 a share plus accrued dividends thereon of $3 a share to the redemption date.

DETROIT, May 24 (UP) -- The slashed and mutilated body of Mrs. Jean Long, 40, ministerial secretary, was found today in the red- carpeted aisle of the Twelfth Street Evangelical Church by the Rev. Newell C. Liesemer, church pastor.

The Italian bishops of Piedmont and Venice have publicly "deplored" the German policy of transporting Italian men and women workers to Germany and have adopted a "clearly hostile" attitude toward the occupation authorities, the Swiss newspaper Gazette de Lausanne said in an article reported last night to the Office of War Information.

The three-day convention of the American Women's Voluntary Services adjourned yesterday after a final session at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, attended by 200 delegates from units in twenty-two States. At the final session, Mrs. Charles A. Lindley, national director of training courses, urged the importance of keeping the training of volunteers up to standards.

Drew Middleton's London dispatch in THE TIMES of May 21 refers to the recent declaration by the United States, Britain and Russia to Rumania, Hungary, Bulgaria and Finland, and says "three of the four States named in the Allied declaration are in the Balkans."

A new package of rum and brandy fruit cake, designed for mailing to members of the armed forces who are overseas, makes its first appearance today at Abraham Straus in Brooklyn. It weighs five and a half ounces and may be sent abroad to a service man or woman without the letter of request from the intended recipient that is demanded for parcels of more than eight ounces.

Sixteen of the seventeen domestic airlines listed as competitors in the National Safety Council's Air Transport Safety Contest flew 1,225,000,000 passenger-miles without a fatality last year, it was disclosed yesterday by Col. John Stilwell, president of the council, at the eighth annual Transport Safety Award luncheon held in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.

The new 20 per cent excise taxes are having a "bad effect on sales," according to answers to a questionnaire sent out by the Bureau of Smaller Stores, National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday.

To show the need for planned post-war housing, former Gov. Alfred E. Smith conducted yesterday through the lower East Side a tour of old-law tenements and modern housing projects. Because of a misunderstanding among those carrying out the itinerary, the trip was completed by only a third of those who started.

The reorganization of three high schools, designed to solve the problem of declining pupil registrations, was approved yesterday by the Board of Education at its regular meeting, held in the Board's building at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

Matthew J. Merritt, Representative at Large, was denied nomination in his home Congressional district, the Fifth, by the Queens County Executive Committee at a meeting last night at Democratic County Headquarters, 60-19 Roosevelt Avenue, Woodside.

BEFORE he died Stephen Vincent Benet wrote a short, interpretive history of the United States for translation into many languages. The job was undertaken at the behest of the Office of War Information. It is published posthumously as "America."*

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Conditional approval was given today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to a voluntary plan providing for the reorganization of the Laclede Gas Light Company and the dissolution of the Laclede Power and Light Company after the sale of its electric properties to the Union Electric Company of Missouri.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Government's mass sedition trial was bogged down today by long, heated arguments of prosecutors and defense counsel over the procedure for the handling of documentary evidence.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- President Roosevelt sent a letter today to A. N. Williams, president of Western Unuion commemorating the centennial of the telegraph.

The days of isolationism for this country are over, James S. Carson, vice president of the American and Foreign Power Company, and chairman of the current New York Foreign Trade Week Committee, declared last night, adding that "world interdependence, at least in an economic sense, is essential to our very existence."

The experience gained from the wartime medical program should be put to use in peacetime to assure that "never again will 10 per cent of the births have to be without any medical care and a much larger percentage without competent medical and nursing care," Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the United State Department of Labor, declared yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, May 25--gainst heavy Japanese rifle and machine-gun fire and some artillery fire Americans are advancing west of the Tor River toward the Maffin airstrip, three and a quarter miles away, the Allied communique announced today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 24 -President Getulio Vargas bade farewell today to 15,000 Brazilian troops ready to embark overseas.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The centennial of the first public use of the electric telegraph was celebrated here today with ceremonies at the Capitol and a dinner at a hotel at which speakers emphasized the role that the telegraph and its associate means of communicating intelligence have done in narrowing world distances.

Management's stake in collective bargaining is to make it work so that "Government may be forced to the sidelines" when the war is over and the peacetime processes of voluntarism can be resumed, William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, declared last night.

NEWARK, N.J., May 24 -- One strike in a critical war industry in this area was settled temporarily today and another, which appeared to have been settled yesterday after a dispute of several hours, flared into serious proportions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has named June Haver and Vivian Blaine for leads in the Technicolor musical, "Where Do We Go From Here," and has indicated that Michael O'Shea will play the third co-starring part. The picture, for which Ira Gershwin and Kurt Weil have just completed a score, will be produced by William Perlberg.

ALBANY, May 24 (AP) -- State Senator Pliny W. Williamson, Republican, of Westchester, has returned to the State a legal fee of $4,663 which was received by him for representing the Senate before the Court of Appeals in litigation over reapportionment.
LONDON, May 24 -- A firm tone was general today in all sections of the stock markets here.
BOSTON, May 24 (AP) -- Five unearned runs in the first inning with the aid of two errors started the Pirates off today to an 8-to-1 victory over the Braves.

The church's contribution to social change must be based upon its spiritual and moral power for shaping the economic practices, the political institutions and the cultural developments of the community, Dr. George Finger Thomas of Princeton University declared yesterday at the annual commencement of the General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle spent six busy hours today before the Select Committee of the House investigating the Government seizure of Montgomery Ward Co., affirming that President Roosevelt, not only had authority to take over the company's property under the War Labor Disputes Act but under his authority as Commander in Chief of the armed forces as well.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 21 Edwin L. James discusses the all-important problem of a world police force. Although I am not mentioned by name, it is apparent that his critique of "one of the world police force projects receiving no little popular consideration" refers to the quota force method of establishing an international police force, which is one of the basic features of the World Federation Plan.

A considerable quantity of alcohol was found in the brain of Valsa Matthai, 21-year-old Indian heiress and student at Columbia University, whose body was recovered from the Hudson River last week, nearly two months after she had disappeared, Dr. Thomas C. Gonzales, chief medical examiner, announced yesterday.

In an address last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Princess Juliana of the Netherlands denounced the "shameless rapacity" of the Nazis who have looted museums and libraries of the occupied countries.

Mayor La Guardia and several associates in the city administration stressed the value of Manhattan's new municipal asphalt plant, both for its current use and as a part of post-war planning at dedication ceremonies yesterday morning on the site at Ninety-first Street and East River Drive.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Administration spokesmen today declined to confirm but avoided denial of reports that a United States cruiser had been transferred to Russia.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Terracina, May 24 (U.P.) -- When the Americans tried to storm Cemetery Hill yesterday afternoon they were pinned down by German snipers and machine guns. Enemy mortars joining the counter-barrage inflicted heavy casualties on our men.

Indicating that the Axis powers may be stripped of all shipping except that necessary to carry on their coastwise and inter-island transportation needs, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the War Shipping Administration, proposed last night that one-third of the pre-war Axis deadweight tonnage be assigned to the United States, the other two-thirds among the rest of the United Nations.

CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., May 24 -- The first woman Judge Advocate in the history of the Marine Corps took over her duties at this post today. She is Capt. Lily S. Hutcheon of San Francisco, and her present titles include Acting Judge Advocate before the General Court-Martial Board, and Legal Assistance Officer.

LONDON, May 24 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied commander in chief in Britain, sent his third operational order to the underground armies of Europe today. Like preceding ones, it was broadcast by familiar voices in English and in the languages of the occupied countries.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 24 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have smashed desperate Japanese counter-attacks in the western and southern outskirts of Myitkyina and have reached a junction of the main Burma railway with the road leading from the Allied-held airdrome into the city, a Southeast Asia command communique announced today.
Magistrate Abner C. Surpless offered a bargain in justice yesterday to a part-time coal merchant who had pleaded guilty to black market operations.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -The Phillies left eleven men on bases as Paul Erickson of the Cubs pitched a 2-0 victory in his first start of the season tonight.

LONDON, May 24 -- Indications that Bulgaria must stop aiding Adolf Hitler or sacrifice her long-strained friendship with Russia came today as the Germans attempted to soft-pedal an apparent crisis in the Cabinet of the Balkan country. A report reaching Ankara by telegraph said the Soviet Union had handed Bulgaria an ultimatum Monday that relations would be broken unless there was a change in the country's policy, and fixed midnight Thursday as a deadline.

Distribution engineering based on the "end-use" of a manufacturer's product should be a vital factor in lowering distribution costs in the post-war period, particularly in the home building industry, Arthur A. Hood, director of dealer relations of the Johns-Manville Corporation, said yesterday.

A new school list that would make it possible to supplant teachers approaching the retirement age of 70 with "bright, alert and better trained young teachers" was advocated yesterday by City Councilman Stanley Isaacs, who said current school lists dated back to 1932.

ALBANY, May 24 (AP) -- The executions of Gordon Cooke and Winston Arthur Sealy, sentenced to die in Sing Sing prison tomorrow night for a Brooklyn murder, were deferred today by Governor Dewey until June 22. He explained he had been advised by the clerk of the Court of Appeals that pending motions affecting the case might not be determined until the middle of June.

LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- Marshal Tito's Partisans on the offensive along most of Yugoslavia's irregular battleline have killed 500 Germans and satellite troops and have left many more in the wreckage of eleven military trains, a Free Yugoslav communique reported tonight.

The development of oil resources in Mississippi is proving to be greater than had been anticipated and the half-dozen wells that the Gulf Oil Corporation has completed there are showing a satisfactory output, J.F. Drake, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting held in Pittsburgh yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Prospects of early agreement on an omnibus veterans' benefit measure faded perceptibly today when a Senate-House committee trying to work out a compromise decided to abandon meetings for several days.

Anyone who can make a dress can make a slipcover from a pattern, said Miss Kay Hardy, author of books on decoration, in her lecture on slipcovers at John Wanamaker's yesterday evening. And these days, with shortage of labor, she pointed out, making your own may save several weeks of waiting for covers to be finished.

TRENTON, May 24 -- New Jersey's thirty-five delegates will go to the Republican National Convention unpledged and without a unit voting rule, it was decided today at a luncheon conference of the delegation called by Gov. Walter E. Edge, one of the State's seven delegates-at-large.
WOOSTER, Ohio, May 24 (AP) -- Dr. Harold F. Lowry, English Professor at Princeton University, has accepted appointment as president of Wooster College, it was stated today.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 24 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren, keynoter of the Republican National Convention, has sent letters to California's delegates asking "that my name be not presented to the convention as a candidate for any position and that you do not cast your ballots for me," his office announced today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 24 (AP) -- Miss Mary Keys, last of Oklahoma's well known Keys quadruplets to wed, will be married to Sgt. Jack P. Anderson of Piano, Tex., on June 9. Announcement of the engagement was made tonight by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Flake M. Keys.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The War Food Administration has authority to ration liquor under the powers conferred by President Roosevelt under the Second War Powers Act, Grover B. Hill, Assistant WFA Administrator, told the Senate's special committee investigating the liquor industry.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -- William C. Freeman of Chicago, vice president of the Middle West Corporation, said today that a plan of reorganization leading to the liquidation of Commonwealth Light and Power Company and its subsidiary, Inland Power and Light Company, soon will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- The elements thwarted a Yankee plan to wreak vengeance tonight upon the White Sox for three straight beatings in New York. A torrential downpour late this afternoon washed out the inaugural game of the first Yankee Western invasion.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Liquidation was on again today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and July wheat broke 1 7/8 cents a bushel and July rye, 4 7/8 cents below yesterday's closing prices before short covering and commission-house buying developed in sufficient volume to bring about a rally.

LONDON, May 24 -- The creation of a Polish National Council inside Poland has presented a new challenge to the authority of the exiled Polish Government which only last week produced in London three members of the Polish underground government and army who testified to the completeness and popularity of their own movement in the country.

CLEVELAND, May 24 (AP) -Washington batsmen leveled an 11-hit barrage against three Cleveland pitchers today, winning the series opener, 5 to 4. Emil (Dutch) Leonard effectively scattered eight Indian hits and did not issue a single base on balls.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 24 -Less than twenty-four hours after he was called upon to form a new government in Bulgaria, Christo Kalfoff, President of Parliament, admitted failure "owing to the coordinated opposition of all the political parties," whose leaders refused to be involved in a Cabinet that is expected to lead the country into at least a break in diplomatic relations with Russia.

Advertising art might use a Gallup poll or two to find out what the public likes, if the voting of a consumers' jury on the annual Art Directors Club exhibit is any indication. A cross section of seventeen persons drawn from varied walks of life endorsed only one professional award out of the twelve prize winners that the professional jury chose.
Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert will go to the Plaza today to remain a week before going to their summer home in Newport.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday promised an attack on "the sources of juvenile delinquency," which he described as pool halls, bars, bowling alleys and other licensed amusement establishments that cater to or capitalize upon minors.

Arthur Middleton Hill, president of the Atlantic Greyhound Corporation, disclosed yesterday that the bus industry proposes to establish a non-subsidized, multi-scheduled helicopter-bus air service operating between the downtown sections of 1,000 American towns and cities.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 24 -- While a special committee worked behind the scenes to effect a reconciliation with a dissident fundamentalist group, and liberals and fundamentalists were holding closed caucuses, delegates to the Northern Baptist Convention here adopted a resolution assailing the simplified income tax bill's 10 per cent automatic deductions for those earning up to $5,000 a year as "inimical" to the interests of churches and charity.

NEWARK, N.J., May 24 -- Of the many things new under the post-Pearl Harbor sun, the 3,000 acres of runways, factories and plants of the Atlantic Overseas Air Service Command at Port Newark probably have more to the cubic yard than any like area in the country.

BILLY SOUTHWORTH invested in a new straw hat yesterday, which probably was a left-handed attempt to woo spring out of hiding. It didn't work. The day remained dark, dismal and drizzly so that the eager attempt of Billy the Kid to perpetrate some more baseball mayhem on the doleful Dodgers was frustrated in the bud.

Lee Savold will try to make it two in a row at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Des Moines heavyweight will meet Joe Baksi of Kulpmont, Pa., in the star bout of twelve rounds, and he hopes to improve his standing in the division by setting Baksi down again.

Admitting that "it looks like we had a tough job on our hands," Senator Joseph H. Ball said yesterday that he intended to present the name of Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen as a candidate for the nomination for President at the Republican National Convention.

After an ownership of two months, the sixteen-story store and loft building at 330-42 West Thirty-eighth Street, in the garment district, has been resold by Tupton Associates, headed by Irving Brodsky, attorney, to Louis Denberg, operator, for cash over a first mortgage of $695,000.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations, through Philip Murray, president; Lee Pressman, general counsel, and a battery of other spokesmen, attacked the Bailey-Brewster "work or be drafted" bill before the Senate Military Affairs Committee today as a measure built upon a foundation of labor crises such as could and had been solved without resort to legal sanctions.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- American troops who scored a sixty-mile gain in Italy in fourteen days were identified today as new divisions of the Second Corps of the Fifth Army by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, who declared that their "inspiring" performance was due to a new system of "immediate replacements" of battle-worn forces.

I should like to ask Elbert S. Brigham, whose letter appeared in THE TIMES recently relative to margarine, if butter in bulk is not colored also. I was brought up on a farm, and when farmers' wives made the butter, particularly in winter when the butter was almost white, yellow coloring was added.

Continued help for wayward girls that "springs from the heart, not the brain" was asked by Mayor La Guardia at the thirtieth anniversary luncheon of the Florence Crittenton League yesterday at Sherry's. Looking back on his years of acquaintance with the league's work, the Mayor said: "If the board would prefer to change the shelter to a home of detention, I can assign some officers and arrange for payments from the city.

Preparing for the liberation of Czechoslovakia and the eventual resumption of private trade with that country, the American-Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce, Inc., will revive its activities to help "lay the foundations for trade resumption," George Boochever, chairman of the board of directors, announced yesterday.

The stock market encountered yesterday some difficulty in maintaining its advanced position as supporting bids backed away at the least suggestion of pressure. Despite the mixed prices at the close there were several broad movements which produced substantial additions, although emphasis tended to the lower side on balance.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Bearish sentiment in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here was less pronounced today and shorts showed a decided disposition to take advantage of declines in prices to secure liberal profits amassed during the recent break that carried July wheat off 11 cents a bushel and rye 22 3/4 cents from the recent highs.
LONDON, May 25 (U.P.) -- Five German divisions are taking over strategically important points in Bulgaria, Ankara dispatches reported tonight on the basis of Balkan advices.

Excess reserves of all member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $100,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $800,000,000, and in New York City they declined $15,000,000 to $5,000,000, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- For the first time today the Navy revealed that rocket-firing bombers have been in use in the Atlantic as a new and hitherto "secret weapon'' against U-boats. It made this disclosure in telling how two Avenger torpedo planes probably destroyed a huge German U-boat earlier this year in a combination rocket, depth-bomb and machinegun attack.

CAIRO, May 25 -- Details of the mutiny in the First Greek Brigade during early April are now permitted to be released from Cairo following Prime Minister Churchill's brief mention of the way the British Middle East Command handled the extremely difficult situation in the course of his speech on foreign affairs in the House of Commons Wednesday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 25 -- Members of the Westchester County Republican Committee, meeting here tonight, designated Ralph W. Gwinn, New York attorney and president of the National Republican Club, for nomination in the primary as Representative in the new Twenty-seventh Congressional District and thus eliminated Assemblywoman Jane H. Todd, who had failed to win the support of executive leaders as a candidate for the post.
LONDON, May 25 -- The general tendency in all sections of today's stock markets was for share prices to improve where changed.

To provide an atmosphere in which domestic problems can be solved and international trade flourish, the United States should commit its support to an international organization having both the authority and power to enforce the peace, Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican from Minnesota, declared yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN ITALY, May 25 (U.P.) -- Gen. Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander, Allied commander-in-chief in Italy, paid tribute today to the Anzio beachhead force as it made a junction with the main Fifth Army forces.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Six important Navy contractors have paid more than $300,000 in consultant fees to a private engineering and managing corporation of which Comdr. John D. Corrigan, a Navy officer charged with expediting war production, is half owner, the Senate Truman Defense Investigating Committee said today.

Simultaneous raids by Secret Service agents on two downtown printing plants were credited by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally yesterday with the frustration of "one of the largest black market counterfeiting syndicates in the country."

Newspaper advertising in support of the war effort totaled $2,436,567 in February 1944, exclusive of money spent for Fourth War Loan advertising between February 1-15 which was credited to the previous month's figures at the Treasury Department's request, according to the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (U.P.) -- The Navy since early this year has been using aircraft rocket guns capable of direct hits from as far as two miles away in its drive to sweep the German submarine fleet from the seas.

DETROIT, May 25 (AP) -- The Tigers suffered their eleventh defeat in twelve games at Briggs Stadium when Luman Harris pitched a three-hitter and drove in the winning run today in the Athletics' 2-to-0 decision.

LONDON, May 25 -- Denying that Britain had agreed at Moscow, Teheran or anywhere else to give Russia an exclusive sphere of influence in Eastern Europe or had made any secret agreements with anybody, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden declared today that he was basing his hopes for a peaceful world after the war on the armed might of this country, the United States and Russia in continued collaboration.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Under the latest revision of its cargo war risk insurance policy, more than 96 per cent of cargo risk insurance will return to commercial underwriters, the War Shipping Administration announced today.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday the appointment of William B. Herlands, former City Commissioner of Investigation, as a Special Deputy Attorney General to organize a permanent State-wide election frauds bureau.

Westerner by choice, Harold Bell Wright was born up-State. So were two of his didactic predecessors, Timothy Shay Arthur, whose "Ten Nights in a Bar Room" is running yet, and the Rev. Edward Payson Roe, author of seventeen best sellers. Mr. Wright's books had a circulation almost incredible.
MOSCOW, May 25 -- Another attack on the Polish Government in London was launched today by Izvestia, which accused it of shooting not at the Germans but at the Poles who are fighting the Germans.

Direct relations between employers and employes without use of intermediaries, and collective bargaining on a company basis instead of an industry basis, were urged yesterday at the fifty-third general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, guest speaker.
