LONDON, May 25 (Reuter) -- The Archbishop of York, Dr. Cyril Garbett, recently returned from a visit to the United States and Canada, wrote today that, although the United States was heart and soul in the war, he doubted whether it could be taken for granted that it would cooperate with the United Kingdom in the settlement of the post-war world.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Roosevelt is understood to have approved plans for a United Nations monetary conference, which soon will be held. A White House announcement is expected tomorrow.

Some observations on trout fishing made by Ray Forbes in an imaginary letter to the revered Izaak Walton, passed along by the New York County Chapter of the Izaak Walton League of America, are in turn relayed to you, now that the May flies are dancing:
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Membership of the Army-Navy Committee appointed to investigate the feasibility of unifying the armed forces was officially announced today.

LONDON, Friday, May 26 -- The full weight of the five Anglo-American air commands, the greatest concentration of air power yet assembled for a single offensive, blasted and scourged the foundations of German resistance to an invasion in the west in the twenty-four hours ended at midnight last night.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- With the Senate's Banking and Currency Committee still at work on the price control and wage stabilization measures which it is drafting, hope that the committee would be able to report the bills out this week faded here today.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 25 -- George A. Brakeley, vice president and treasurer of Princeton University, said today that the destruction of the university gymnasium by fire early yesterday is "a serious blow, but not a catastrophe that cannot be surmounted."

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Sewell L. Avery, chairman of the board of Montgomery, Ward Co., insisted on actual force being used to evict him from the plant and would not recognize a showing of force such as the presence of United States marshals, Wayne Chatfield Taylor, Under-Secretary of Commerce, told a House Select Committee today.

LONDON, May 25 -- Exiled Spanish republican circles in London today described Prime Minister Churchill's "kindly words about Spain" in the House of Commons yesterday as a new diplomatic success for Generalissimo Francisco Franco that would strengthen the fascist dictator's hold on the country he seized through the aid of Germany and Italy.

Another major post-war building project for Manhattan was revealed yesterday when it was learned that the New York Telephone Company had sold the large parcel it had held for more than a decade on the east side of Second Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets.

The earnings of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., in the first four months of this year were about $13,000,000, compared with $9,500,000 in the similar period of 1943, John A. Brown, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, acting through its finance division, approved today a fee of $87,500 for Kuhn, Loeb Co. of New York, investment bankers, in connection with the issuance of $35,000,000 of secured notes by the Pennsylvania Company, a holding concern controlled by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The election of Joseph A. Broderick, president of the East River Savings Bank, as an alumni member of the New York University Council was announced last night by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase. Mr. Broderick will serve a four-year term under a recently adopted plan designed to broaden alumni participation in managing college affairs.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Employes in coal mines spend an average of 57.29 minutes on the daily round trip from mine portal to work and back to portal, it was reported today by the President's committee on portal-to-portal travel time.

A corporation headed by Herbert Baum has purchased the five-story brick commercial building at the southeast corner of Franklin and Greenwich Streets, in the wholesale butter and egg district. The property is assessed at $36,000 and was sold through Howe-Rowland Inc., broker.

BOSTON, May 25 (AP) -- Only two noses separated the first three finishers in today's $2,500 Dorchester Purse of six furlongs at Suffolk Downs, but the camera settled on William Helis' Sophocles as the winner.

Unable to operate under ceiling prices set by the Office of Price Administration, members of the Cuban Association of Pineapple and Fruit Packers have decided to close their plants, Frank Cody, president of the National Distributors Company, 100 Hudson Street, New York, representing Fruit Industries Cooperative, Inc., of Havana, announced yesterday.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Friday, May 26 (AP) -- United States Sixth Army units have battled their way through stiff Japanese resistance to reach the Maffin Bay airfield in Netherland New Guinea, 120 miles northwest of Hollandia, it was announced today by headquarters.

MOSCOW, May 25 -- Izvestia today published a criticism of United States camp authorities for allegedly coddling German prisoners of war while Soviet, British, American and other Allied war prisoners are killed and mistreated in Germany.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 25 -- The text of the resolution on war adopted by the Northern Baptist Convention follows:

PEARL HARBOR, May 25 -- Marcus and Wake islands, two lonely enemy-held outposts in the Central Pacific, were severely punished by planes from a United States carrier task force that roamed the area over the weekend.
CLEVELAND, May 25 (AP) -- A three-run ninth-inning rally carried Washington to a 4-to-2 victory over the Indians tonight at Municipal Stadium before 18,706.
CHUNGKING, China, May 25 (AP) -- A communique:

A good example of the hidden-hand of diabolist interpretation of history occurs in a recent number of The New Leader. This is a right wing labor weekly which prints much useful and interesting news and discussion, but from time to time stuff that is not so good, as in the present instance.

While the War Production Board has indicated the toilet goods industry may obtain some relief in the tight container situation later this year, it is doubtful whether any easing will come in time for the heavy shipping period for the holiday season, which is about to start, reports in the industry indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The War Production Board was reported today to have ordered producers of worsted weaving yarns using the Bradford and the French systems to make at least 50 per cent of their output available for orders bearing preference ratings.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Fifteen more enemy vessels, including a destroyer, have been sunk in Pacific and Far Eastern waters by the growing United States submarine fleet, which since the first of the year has maintained an average of better than one ship sunk a day, the Navy announced today.

PRINCETON N.J., May 25 -- A political popularity race in New York State, matching Thomas E. Dewey against Franklin D. Roosevelt as candidates for President, shows Governor Dewey holding a slight advantage at this time in terms of civilian votes.
A new issue of $820,000 of refunding 3 per cent bonds, dated July 1, 1944 and due serially from July 1, 1945 to 1977, was announced yesterday by Cocoa, Fla., for award on June 6.

Sales of the National Department Stores Corporation and consolidated subsidiaries increased 15.1 per cent, to $64,234,662, in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, last, as compared with the $55,821,228 volume of the year before, according to the annual report of Harry H. Schwartz, president, released today.

MYTKYINA AIRDROME, May 22 (Delayed) -- The battle for Mytkyina town and plain has now become a slow process of overwhelming strong, long-prepared Japanese fortified areas. Japanese dispositions are becoming steadily clearer as Chinese and American troops press forward, and it is becoming possible to throw our power against centers of Japanese resistance.

NAPLES, May 25 -- Forward elements of the onrushing main Fifth Army forces established contact with beachhead patrols on the coastal highway between Anzio and Terracina early this morning as the Italian offensive neared the end of its second week.

LONDON, May 25 -- The propaganda newspapers and leaflets that the Allies have been showering on Germany and occupied Europe for many months -- and which the German Government has heretofore studiously ignored or deprecated as useless -- apparently are getting on the nerves of Nazi leaders as D-day approaches.

In an effort to save minority groups in Axis-dominated countries from extermination, an appeal, addressed to President Roosevelt and the Governments of all the United Nations, and urging the establishment in this country of temporary havens of refuge, has been signed by seventy-two leading Americans, it was announced yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Once again the Prime Minister of Great Britain has made a public report on the war which is crammed with news the President has not volunteered to the American people. Once again the contrast between Mr. Churchill's war information policy and that of Washington has been strikingly displayed.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 25 -- A solemn Te Deum was sung in the Buenos Aires Cathedral this morning to celebrate the 134th anniversary of Argentine independence and was attended, with the exception of the Mexican Ambassador, by the whole foreign diplomatic corps, including United States Ambassador Norman Armour, British Ambassador Sir David Victor Kelly and representatives of all the other powers that have recognized President Ellmiro Farrell as Gen. Pedro P. Ramirez's lawful successor.

MEMPHIS, May 25 (AP) -- Bringing his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination into the mid-South, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio declared today that President Roosevelt has placed the two-party system in danger through what he described as accumulation of "personal power."

The Mayor has invited criticism of his health insurance plan. Although it includes more services than that of the Associated Hospital Service, neither plan embraces all the people of New York City who would benefit if included in health insurance.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The Board of Investigation and Research said today that "a readjustment of freight rates in relation to the cost of the service will encourage greater production of both raw materials and finished products in the South and West without injuring Eastern production and manufacturing."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 25 (AP) -- A new instruction manual issued by the German High Command, a copy of which was received here today, gives evidence that the German High Command already is preparing for the next war.

Employes of the Field Service Division of the War Shipping Administration, scheduled for "lopping off" by next Tuesday, unfolded yesterday stories of payroll padding, labor overloading and general loafing in ship repair yards here and at Boston.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- Ralph Y. Cooper, chief of the knit goods branch of the War Production Board, told 200 manufacturers at a war conference of the Underwear Institute today that disciplinary measures would be taken soon as a result of field investigations of the use of allocated yarn.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 20, were 871,105 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,796 cars or 0.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 27,263 cars or 3.2 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 33,429 cars or 4.0 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WICHITA, Kan., May 25 (AP) -- Base running in reverse -- an idea advocated by Ray Dumont, president of the National Semi-Pro-Baseball Congress -- will receive its initial test in an exhibition game here Aug. 11, opening night of the tenth annual national championship semi-pro tournament.

ESME DAVIS, nee Esmeralda Consuela Maria Holland, is a handsome and muscular young woman who now lives in New York City, where she distills rare perfumes for profit and swings on a flying trapeze installed upon the roof of her house for fun and the delight of her neighbors. She is part Irish and part Spanish and part gypsy.

Several hundred civilians appeared yesterday at the Army civilian employment center at 2 West Forty-third Street in response to an appeal by military and War Manpower Commission authorities for 2,500 men and women to replace soldiers in the New York area of the Second Service Command.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets rose 0.2 cent during the week ended May 20 principally because of higher quotations for livestock, fruits and vegetables, cotton and naval stores. At 103.8 per cent of the 1926 average, the all-commodity index has risen 0.2 per cent in the last four weeks to the level of this time last year.

A resolution opposing the drafting of 17-year-old boys for military service "until more effective use is made of available man and woman power." was adopted yesterday by the Board of Managers of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

Hal B. Wallis and Joseph H. Hazen, former Warner Brothers executives, yesterday announced the formation of their new producing company, Hal Wallis Productions, Inc., and the completion of a distribution agreement with Paramount Pictures.

Albany, May 25 (AP) -- Disbarment of the former New York City Magistrate, Hulon Capshaw, was affirmed today by the Court of Appeals. Five of the court's seven judges concurred in the decision. Judges Harlan W. Rippey and Thomas D. Thacher did not participate.

" Make Your Own Bed," a comedy produced by Warner Brothers and starring Jack Carson, Jane Wyman and Irene Manning, will open this morning at the Strand. The film, which deals with the servant problem, includes Alan Hale, George Tobias, Tala Birell, Ricardo Cortez and Robert Shayne among its supporting players.

Legislation now pending in Congress which states that the antitrust act does not apply to the business of insurance was praised yesterday by John M. Thomas, president of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, at its seventy-eighth annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

S. Stroock Co., manufacturers of fabrics, have called for June 21 a special meeting of stockholders to vote on a proposed change in the company's certificate of incorporation to permit an increase in the amount of authorized no-par capital stock from 100,000 to 300,000 shares.

WASHINGTON May 25 -- The Administration has drafted a peace plan similar to the world order outlined by Prime Minister Churchill in the House of Commons yesterday and will make it public in the near future, it was learned today.
LONDON, May 25 -- The greatest air assault in history continued today to "soften up" Hitler's Europe in preparation for the invasion.

In recent weeks it has been usual for the Treasury to make withdrawals on the first three business days of each week from government war-loan accounts in the principal commercial banks of the nation. As next Tuesday is a holiday, the Treasury will take up the slack by increasing the amounts of the withdrawals on Monday and Wednesday.

ALBANY, May 25 -- Governor Dewey, looking ahead to the time when deep-freeze plants will be as common in homes as refrigerators are now, said today that he had directed the State Emergency Food Commission to prepare a program designed "to improve the standard of living on our farms, and to better the diets of our city people."

Two American soldiers met at 7:31 yesterday morning on an Italian coastal road five miles south of the Mussolini Canal and in typical soldier language which eschews all heroics for heroic deeds gave history an event which thrilled the Allied world. For their meeting signalized the junction of the main Allied armies pushing up from the south with the flanking army entrenched on the Anzio beachhead.

First Fiddle, Mrs. Edward Mulrenan's gray 5-year-old, made it four straight at fog-bound Belmont Park yesterday when he took the $5,000 added Ballot Handicap, feature of the drizzling day that kept the attendance down to 16,547.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Friday, May 26 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- Navy communique 521:

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 24 (AP) (Delayed) -- One of the oldest democracies in the world has decided to become the world's youngest republic, the people of Iceland, with probably the largest participation in a referendum ever recorded in any democratic country, having voted to sever all its ties with the Danish crown.

Sales of the Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended with January rose 19.3 per cent to a new high of $203,718,739 from the $170,828,164 volume of the previous year, B. Earl Puckett, president, announced yesterday in the annual report to stockholders.

CHUNGKING, China, May 25 (U.P.) -- Japanese broadcasts recorded here asserted tonight that Loyang, on the Lung-Hai railroad in Honan Province, had fallen after a twenty-day battle, but a Chinese communique asserted that the Chinese still held out against a savage enemy attack.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 25 (UP) -- A communique:

PEARL HARBOR, May 25 -- An explosion and fire which could be heard in Waikiki, fifteen miles away, rocked Pearl Harbor Navy Yard Sunday while ammunition was being unloaded from one of the group of landing craft.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Western Conference football coaches today reached a gentlemen's agreement to abolish deliberate out-of-bounds kick-offs, while the basketball coaches sought an agreement to make games next season more gentlemanly.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Artemus L. Gates, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, revealed tonight that the Navy now has sixty-five aircraft carriers in active service and that its air fleet will soon total 37,700 planes.

ANZIO, May 25 -- The Fifth Army's beachhead no longer exists, for it is now fused with the rest of the Allied front in Italy. The strategic tactical advantages gained thereby are of far-reaching importance. The daring venture, carried out at great risk just over four months ago when the Allied forces landed and fought their way to the possession of ninety square miles, is now vindicated.

LONDON, May 25 -- Prime Minister Churchill's foreign affairs speech yesterday, which means to the Royal Yugoslav Government nothing less than an Allied ultimatum to drop Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch as Minister of War and accept the military leadership of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz), fell like a blockbuster in the midst of negotiations for a new Yugoslav Cabinet.

Herbert Hoover, who frequently has been mentioned as an adviser of Governor Dewey, announced yesterday that he would take no part in the selection of a Republican nominee for President. In a statement issued from his suite in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel the former President said:

A crowd estimated at nearly 18,000 packed Madison Square Garden last night to hear Arturo Toscanini conduct a gigantic Red Cross benefit concert that netted well over $100,000 for that organization. An additional $11,000 was contributed by Mrs. James P. Donahue, who bid that amount for the specially made thirty-six-inch baton the maestro used when it was auctioned off by Mayor La Guardia during the intermission.

CLEVELAND, May 25 -- Towns and villages that set up the loudest civic groaning when war pressures first disturbed the patterns of their communities have decided now that they would like nothing better than more of the same, a sectional gathering of the National Conference of Social Work heard this afternoon from Perry Hall of New York, who reported that planning boards to hold these gains were springing up in many areas.

The extension of human rights under the auspices of the United Nations, with the establishment of a Human Rights Commission as a permanent international appeals body, was advocated by leaders of a wide range of civic and cultural interests in a report issued yesterday by the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- Bob Muncrief won his second game of the year today in a pitcher's duel with Tex Hughson as the Browns beat the Red Sox, 3 to 2. Each gave seven hits, although Mike Ryba, relief pitcher, held the Browns hitless for the last three innings.

Due at the Broadhurst on June 10, a postponement from June 7, is "Take a Bow," Lou Walters' vaudeville revue formerly called "Slap Happy." Prominent in the cast are Chico Marx, Jay C. Flippen, Cross Dunn, Gene Sheldon, Pat Rooney, the Murtah Sisters and the Whitson Brothers.

It may be that the weather man still was weeping about that terrible ninth inning finish at Ebbets Field in which the Dodgers beat the Giants on Tuesday night. At any rate the dripping skies yesterday make it impossible for the Giants and Brooklyn to go through with their scheduled night contests against, respectively, the Reds and the Cardinals.

A Bronx motorist who failed to answer an Office of Price Administration summons to explain to his rationing board how he managed to drive to Florida on his basic gasoline ration was deprived yesterday of all gasoline rations until further notice.

After traveling 5,000,000 miles and never missing a day's work, James A. Ware, a dining car waiter for the Pennsylvania Railroad, retired yesterday after fifty years of continuous service. He received the company's fifty-year gold service button from George LeBoutillier, vice president of the New York Zone of the railroad.

On a previous occasion I recommended that the ratio of our losses should be watched as the surest index to how the all-important Battle of Germany, in the skies over Fortress Europe, is going. On the basis of this index, using the cost in machines and men as a barometer of success or failure, I believe there is no longer any doubt that the tide of the aerial battle is running strongly in our favor.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- Paramount will star Bob Hope in "Girls' Town," a story about a factory worker in a war-manufacturing town where the women outnumber the men 100 to 1. The comedian is now making "The Princess and the Pirate" for Samuel Goldwyn.

Veterans of the last war anxious to get back into uniform during the present conflict were urged yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Hugh S. Drum, United States Army, retired, to join the New York State Guard, which needs thousands of men before starting its summer training season in three weeks.

CHICAGO. May 25 -- The 156th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America elected today as its Moderator the Rev. Dr. Roy Ewing Vale of Indianapolis, succeeding the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary in New York.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Selective Service provided a guide tonight for the re-employment of war veterans in their former jobs.

LONDON, May 25 -- Thousands of British families have canceled plans for the traditional Whitsun holiday week-end travel under the stern warning that train service is subject to stoppage without notice as the hour for the invasion of Europe nears.

Tonight's events: "Music of Four Centuries," with Ray Lev, pianist, and Sterling Hunkins, 'cellist, Carnegie Music Hall, 8:40 o'clock; P.M.; concert by People's Chorus of New York, Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, 8:30; operetta, "Prince of Eisenach," presented by the High School of Music and Art, Hunter College Auditorium, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 20 were 15 per cent higher than sales of the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following table shows percentage changes from corresponding periods of 1943:

Atlantic County, New Jersey, which includes Atlantic City, will be placed under rent control as of June 1, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday. The maximum rent date, on which the control would be based, he said, would be Sept. 1, 1943.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to have increased during the week to new high records.
With the arrival of locally grown vegetables in increasing quantities the cost of most varieties has moderated, the War Food Administration reports.

In these columns several weeks ago James F. Brownlee, Deputy Price Administrator, protested against our criticism of price-fixing for luxury products. At that time he pointed out that "if the least important products were freed from such restriction" the effect on the psychology of the American people would be "unquestionably very bad for the total war effort."
BALTIMORE, May 25 (AP) -- Jersey City laid down a barrage of thirteen hits against a quartet of Baltimore pitchers tonight to win an 11-4 International League decision.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 25 (AP) -- Japanese troops, battling desperately to maintain their slipping grip on the north Burma stronghold of Myitkyina, have attacked the Allied-held airdrome two miles south of the city and have been repulsed, and enemy assaults on many Allied positions both in Burma and in India have been thrown back with heavy losses to the attackers, an Allied communique announced today.

Francis A. Adams, in THE NEW YORK TIMES, May 23, presents views on tariffs which seem typical of Republicanism. He not only approves of the twelve-billion-dollar excess of exports over imports in the twenty years ending in 1941 but he feels that "the present strength of industrial America is based upon a fifty-year period of tariff protection."

ANKARA, Turkey, May 22 (Delayed) -- There is every indication that Turkey not only is not yet prepared to enter the war on the Allied side but that, barring unforeseeable developments, this country will not be ready to assume a belligerent status before autumn.

The August selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club will be "The Time for Decision" by Summer Welles, to be published by Harper July 19. Another major literary effort by a prominent political figure will "Democracy Reborn" by Vice President Henry Wallace, which is said to be far more than a "mere collection of speeches and papers."

An estimated 32,000 lumber workers in the Pacific Northwest are remaining away from their jobs. But it is a "wildcat" strike and the union leaders disown it. This is in accordance with precedent since the Connally-Smith Act was passed.

LONDON, May 25 -- Shades of World War I, when stories of German brutality were on everyone's lips, crept into the House of Lords today when Viscount Cranborne, leader of the House, and Lord Vansittart, hard peace advocate against the Germans, denounced as a massacre the shooting by the Nazis of forty-seven British and Allied air officers in a German prison camp last March.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Protests against the proposed ceilings on beauty parlor prices were brought to the Office of Price Administration and the House Banking and Currency Committee today by spokesmen of the industry.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 25 -- Five days of suspense over whether the Bulgarian Regency Council would send a "suitable delegate" -- Prince Cyril -- to Berchtesgaden in answer to Adolf Hitler's "invitation" last Sunday ended tonight with a "compromise" that former Premier Bogdan Philoff is to proceed to "the Fuehrer's headquarters" late tomorrow for what appear to be purely military talks, according to information received from Balkan sources tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Government, although still fighting a barrage of objections from defense attorneys and defendants which has marked the course of sedition trial, was able today to put in evidence its first documents.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The assurances given by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons today concerning France, coupled with the hopes he expressed that Gen. Charles de Gaulle would meet with success in his forthcoming visit to London, appear to have gone far toward satisfying doubts that had been held in French circles here concerning the future of the French Committee of National Liberation.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Reports that a listening device had been perfected which could pick up human conversation within a distance of three miles, and which had been used by top officials for that purpose, were labeled "fantastic and silly" today by Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board.

The National Geographic Society has taken a laudable step toward simplifying our treatment of foreign place names, and its suggestions have been adopted by many newspapers and radio announcers. The general principle is to reproduce the native spelling of today, except for names long Anglicized, like Cologne for Koln and Florence for Firenze.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 -- Wartime strikes were denounced today as "treason against the nation" by Local 6 of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union (CIO), which declared in a resolution that "any strike for any reason engaged in by any section of labor is a strike directly against all labor."
LONDON, May 25 (AP -- ) -- The Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
The Greater New York Fund has received subscriptions amounting to $2,910,781, it was announced yesterday at the campaign's second report luncheon meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Three executive promotions were announced yesterday by Hanford Main, president of the Loose-Wiles Biscuit Company. Gene Flack was named director of advertising, and also will continue as trade relations counsel of the Sunshine organization, a post he has held for eight years.

Publicity attending the renewed drive in Congress to raise ceiling prices for cotton goods brought in yesterday a broader demand for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, and the market closed at about the best levels of the day, up 5 to 12 points net from Wednesday's closing quotations.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 25 -- The Northern Baptists called a truce today on the dissention in their ranks between Fundamentalists and Conservatives and took a stronger stand on supporting the war than had been taken at previous conventions.

LONDON, May 25 -- Innuendoes that United States military authorities are failing to check misbehavior among troops in Britain are unjustified, Herbert Morrison, the Home Secretary, told the House of Commons today in reply to a question demanding what he proposed to do to make "Grantham and many other towns fit for a woman to walk through unescorted at night."

Private industry and the "every day citizen" must stand in readiness to shoulder new responsibilities after the war is won, Nugent Fallon, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, told delegates of the New Jersey Savings and Loan League assembled in convention here today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The War Department does not want the task of disposing of surplus materials and is convinced the job should be handled by some agency outside the department, Major Gen. L.D. Clay, director of materiel Army services, told the House Military Affairs Committee.

The Board of Estimate failed yesterday, by a margin of three votes, to approve the local law denying tax exemption to private housing corporations organized under the State Urban Redevelopment Law in cases where discrimination because of race, creed or color is displayed against prospective tenants.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Offering an exhibit of three seersucker dresses, one made for Government agencies for relief shipments abroad and two garments of similar material produced for sale to women in this country, Representative Fred A. Hartley, Republican, of New Jersey, told the House today that to Americans is denied the right to purchase good dresses while foreign recipients of relief are "being dressed to kill" for nothing.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Discussions with China and Russia on post-war aviation are being undertaken at this time through separate conversations here, it was said today. The talks follow those recently held with the British through the London mission of Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State.

Private Theodore Price wrote a highly entertaining letter to THE TIMES the other day pointing out the need of an up-to-date infantry song. Within the next few weeks Private Price and the rest of the Army -- and the general public -- will be hearing not one but four new infantry songs which are now in the process of being printed and published and arranged for performance.

Walbridge S. Taft, chairman of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, yesterday announced the full schedule of racing for the youngsters there this summer. Seven trophy events are on the list, and several interclub team races will be added later.
BOSTON, May 25 (AP) -- Alva Javery hurled a three-hit shut-out to gain his first victory of the season today as the Braves nosed out the Pirates, 1 -- 0.

ALGIERS, May 25 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle let it be known today that he was highly pleased by the invitation to go to London, which, as a communique from General de Gaulle's office confirmed, was made and accepted when Alfred Duff Cooper, the British Ambassador, called on the general Tuesday night.

Numbers of European Jews now facing death can be saved if free ports are established here and in the allied countries, Magistrate Charles Solomon said last night at the annual United Jewish Appeal dinner of the Signs and Display Industry in the Hotel McAlpin.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Despite the appeal yesterday by the Chicago Livestock Exchange that further hog shipments be withheld until next Wednesday, about 13,000 salable swine arrived. There were 35,000 hogs on sale, including holdovers, and prospects were that around 20,000 head would go unsold at the close today. The unsold supply probably will be carried over into next week.
LONDON, May 25 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Wartime strikes were condemned and the use against them of "constitutionally armed force where other means fail" was approved "whether this curb is invoked against workers or against employers," at yesterday's session of the 145th meeting of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Church.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Governor Warren of California, keynote speaker for the Republican National Convention, made it clear here today that he must be drafted if he became the party's Vice Presidential nominee at the convention opening in Chicago June 26.

The eradication of syphilis by the use of penicillin is now possible and the time therefore has come for public health authorities to step in and provide the treatment free for all infected persons and their contacts, it was declared yesterday by Col. George Baehr, formed medical director of the Office of Civilian Defense and member of the State Public Health Council.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 25 (U.P.) -- Col. Myron Blalock of Marshall, who was elected Democratic National Committeeman from Texas by both of the rival State Democratic Conventions on Tuesday, said today that he was "hoping when the smoke of battle clears away we will find both sides working and voting in the election for the party nominees."

MOSCOW, May 25 -- The mounting tenseness of relations between the Soviet Union and Bulgaria, only Hitler satellite with which Russia is not at war, was reflected in sharp comments today in the Moscow newspaper Izvestia, which declared the Bulgarians' present leaders were "persistently pushing the country farther along the path leading to national catastrophe."

DETROIT, May 25 (AP) -- CIO unionists striking at plants of Parke, Davis Co. here today challenged the power of the National War Labor Board "to interfere with or prevent negotiation between the union and the company to settle this dispute."

While the United Nations war against the Japanese is making great strides in the Pacific and in Burma there is reason for anxiety as to its course in the Yellow River Valley in northern China. MacArthur's war and Stilwell's war are of the post-Pearl Harbor variety.
NAPLES, May 25 (UP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- A War Department press release telling of the award to Pfc. Alton W. Knappenberger, 20, of the Congressional Medal of Honor calls him a "determined infantryman."
LONDON, May 25 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

The wide distribution of contaminated medicinal supplies was charged yesterday to the Winthrop Chemical Company, Inc., in a criminal information fried in Federal court here by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally. The prosecutor said that, as the result of quick action by the Federal Food and Drug Administration, the Winthrop concern had called in 73,600 ampules of dextrose solution and about 22,000 combination packages containing distilled water and either atabrine, neoarsphenamine or phenarsine.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A sober appraisal of the country's food situation, containing assurances that "the food supply in general is good today" balanced by reminders that good cuts of meat will be even harder to get later in the year, was issued jointly today by the Office of War Information, the War Food Administration and the Office of Price Administration.

Net income of the United Gas Corporation aggregated $7,248,034 in 1943, compared with $7,034,356 during the previous year, according to the annual report to be issued today to stockholders by Joe H. Gill, president. Gross operating revenues of the system totaled $56,696,439, against $56,043,450 in 1942, and the balance carried to consolidated earned surplus after reserves, expenses, taxes, interest and other deductions was $7,604,602.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC AIR BASE, May 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- Marine Ace Maj. Joe Foss, first of the Pacific airmen to down twenty-six enemy fighters in combat, is back in action -- and already has another plane to his credit.

THE elephants have departed from Madison Square Garden and the elephants are ready to return tonight. That is neither a vicious circle, a paradox nor anything quite so fancy. A free translation merely means that the Ringling brand of pachyderms finally has vacated the arena and that Uncle Mike Jacobs is importing his variety of oversized performers.

Wendell Willkie and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt joined last night with 600 citizens and civic leaders of all parties and faiths in paying tribute to Walter White at a dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his service as secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of the Colored People.

The Brooklyn Museum opened with a tea and reception yesterday afternoon an exhibition designed to illustrate the cultural aspects of life in this country for two centuries. All the material has been drawn from the museum's own collections, including a number of recent accessions and many other items not previously exhibited.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The United States should continue propaganda and information work in Europe even after the fighting there stops in order to promote a stable and lasting peace, according to Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information.

Up to the first of March the Government of the United States had transferred to Russia, under Lend-Lease, 8,800 planes, 4,500 tanks, 36,000 jeeps, 190,000 military trucks and 1,450,000 tons of steel. In these circumstances it is a little difficult to understand the excitement of two Republican Senators in Washington over reports that our Government has also transferred to Russia an American cruiser.

BAINBRIDGE, Md., May 25 (AP) -- Ensign Adolph Kiefer of the Bainbridge Naval Training Station unofficially bettered his world's record for the 100-yard backstroke route tonight by swimming the distance in 56.1 seconds, compared with his recognized record of 0:56.8.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 -- The names of twenty-two winners of journalism achievement awards of the National Headliners Club were announced here tonight by Braton R. Gardner, Professor of Journalism at Pennsylvania State College and chairman of the newspaper fraternity's 1944 board of judges.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, May 27 -- Charging that Anglo-American air attacks over Germany were "no longer warfare but murder pure and simple," Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, in a front page editorial in the Voelkischer Beobachter this morning warned that henceforth "it is far too much to ask of us that we call on German soldiers and German police to intervene to protect these murderers from the fate they deserve."

LONDON, May 26 -- In the ninety-day period beginning last March 1 and ending with this month, strafing by American and other Allied fighter planes will have destroyed between 1,300 and 1,500 Luftwaffe planes of all types on German airfields in occupied Europe and Germany.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today a request for exemption from competitive bidding requirements asked by the Capital Transit Company, Washington, D.C.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court unanimously affirmed yesterday a decision of the Supreme Court of New York dismissing a claim by the Mexican Government involving the distribution of about $7,000,000 to holders of defaulted Mexican bonds.

Large numbers of service wives have lost their right to vote in this year's election by closing up their homes and taking temporary quarters in the vicinity of Army camps and naval shore stations so as to be near their husbands, inquiries among election officials disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- A Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled here today that American business men accused of violations of price administration codes might be taken before OPA examining boards in closed sessions and forced to testify without lawyers to represent them or court reporters to record the proceedings.
LONDON, May 26 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast by the Berlin radio:

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- By a four-margin vote of 123 to 119 the House gave the first Congressional recognition this evening to the President's Fair Employment Practices Committee by allowing it $500,000 for maintenance in the $1,033,358,367 War Agencies Appropriation Bill.

MOSCOW, May 26 -- Moscow today hailed the second anniversary of the signing of the Anglo-Soviet treaty of alliance. All papers printed prominently the telegrams exchanged between Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Great Britain and the Soviet Foreign Commissar, Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff.

LONDON, Saturday, May 27 -- While the United States Ninth Air Force sent clouds of fighters and fighter bombers winging over German airfields in northern France, bombing, strafing and generally spreading destruction yesterday, the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces came up from the south to blast German railway and communications lines in southern France over which Germany has been sending supplies to her hard-pressed army below Rome.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Roosevelt today informed the chiefs of the Brotherhoods of Railroad Trainmen and Locomotive Engineers and the nation's railroads that if they were unable to agree on a dispute involving vacations with pay, they were to follow the procedures of the Railway Labor Act.

LONDON, May 26 -- The forthcoming invasion of western Europe has been favorably affected by the succession of Allied victories in Italy, and the German General Staff's plans for defense against attacks from the west, south and east must be reviewed, according to reliable sources here.

Using as its major theme an analogy between problems faced by civilians now and hardships endured by the country's pioneers, Anheuser-Busch, Inc., has launched one of the most extensive home-front campaigns ever undertaken by a national advertiser, according to the War Advertising Council.
While it is not my intention in any way to criticize the report in your paper of yesterday's Steel Institute meeting, I do wish to clarify some of my extemporaneous remarks as reported.

At this distance the campaign in Italy moves with the swiftness and strangeness of a dream. This latest episode in modern war disturbs as it passes the living dust of centuries gone by. Here is Littoria, taken by our troops. Its name will not be found in the older guide books, for it is a new city, dedicated to the glory of Benito Mussolini, reclaimer of the Pontine marshes.

ROOSEVELT RACEWAY will open on Monday for forty-two nights of harness racing, all under lights. Despite the name of the plant, Republicans will be as welcome as Democrats. The only admission requirement is that the visitor have the proper tariff to pay at the gate. If he neglects to bring along with him a sufficient amount of betting money as well, that is his misfortune -- or good fortune, as the case may be.

NAPLES, May 26 -- American troops of Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's beachhead forces captured Cisterna at 4 P.M. yesterday and have pushed ahead six miles against continuing fierce resistance to take Cori and increase the threat to Velletri and Valmontone, in the "Rome Line" running northeast to Avezzano, to which the Germans are now striving to swing back their present defense chain.

NEWARK, N.J., May 26 (AP) -- Banging Syracuse's ace pitcher, Jim Konstanty, for four runs in the first inning and five more in the seventh, the cellar-dwelling Bears carved a 9-to-3 victory tonight and knocked the Chiefs out of first place in the league standings.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, May 27 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney's Fifth Air Force in New Guinea roared across the western part of the large island Thursday in a heavy predawn raid on Manokwari and Biak Island, spreading large explosions and fires along Japanese installations, it was announced today.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 26 -- Turkey's price to enter the war actively on the Allies' side can basically be summarized in terms of material. It is broadly estimated that the key supplies desired by the Turkish Government, prior to becoming a belligerent, are between 400 and 500 Sherman tanks and between 250 and 300 Spitfire pursuit planes, as well as certain relatively minor quantities of other types of equipment.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Labor Department's wage and hour division finds "a high degree" of violations of minimum wage and overtime regulations within the apparel manufacturing plants of New York and New Jersey and intends to check the firms more closely in the coming fiscal year.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from James S. Earley, head economist in the Office of the Economic Adviser to OPA. Mr. Earley's argument, as we understand it, is (1) that the British Government plans to permit a rise in living costs, not because it cannot prevent it, but primarily because it wishes to "warn labor," and (2) that the British policy is probably not very wise.

At a time when we Britishers and you Americans are not quite sure whether we really like one another, there is one thing that is certain; and that is the great bond of friendship that has sprung up between our children and your service men.

As the War Food Administration lifted all restrictions on farm slaughter of livestock to increase the nation's meat supply, point-free meats in New York City continued yesterday to go begging. Food trade spokesmen explained that New Yorkers preferred roasts and steaks, the so-called luxury cuts requiring ration points.

Today's events: "The Prince of Eisenach," presented by the High School of Music and Art, Hunter College Auditorium, matinee and evening; Emma Beldan, soprano, and Phyllis Moss, piano, in Victory Concert, New York Public Library, 5:30 P.M.; Chorus of the Furriers' Joint Council, Town Hall, evening; "La Traviata," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 26 (U.P.) -- The second Japanese attempt in two days to reinforce their virtually trapped garrison at Myitkyina was smashed Wednesday night when Chinese troops intercepted an enemy column west of the north Burma stronghold, inflicting severe casualties, it was announced today.

No portion of Mr. Churchill's report to the House of Commons has stirred up more controversy than his "kindly words about Spain." Among the five European states that have managed so far to sit out the war, Turkey, ally of Britain since 1939, has been generally regarded as the pro-Ally and Spain as the pro-Axis neutral.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (U.P.) -- The Fifth Army plaque and clasp, awarded for outstanding performance and achievement, has been presented to the Field Transportation Corps' military railway service in the Mediterranean theatre for "exceptionally meritorious service in the movement of supplies for the Fifth Army," the War Department said tonight.
CHUNGKING, China, May 26 (AP) -- A Fourtoentl United Btatea Air Force conrnuniqz:

In another effort to match the high levels set last March the stock market edged forward yesterday under a fairly broad buying movement, but the average gains were only fractions. Wall Street in its appraisal of the session's results attached more significance to the employment of idle funds in the top-priced stocks than to the gyrations of certain issues which were swayed by individual corporate developments.

LONDON, May 26 -- A policy shaped to maintain a high and stable level of employment in Britain after the war was published today by the Government in the form of yet another wartime White Paper on the post-war needs of the nation.

Extending its holdings in the Thirty-fourth Street district between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, Webb Knapp, Inc., has bought the twelve-story store and business building at 43-45 West Thirty-fourth Street, running through to 62-64 West Thirty-fifth Street, and expects to lease the property to a retail chain, it was learned yesterday, when details of the recent sale were announced.
DETROIT, May 26 (AP) -- New labor troubles started in Detroit today amid expressions of impatience from union executives.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Roosevelt has called a United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference beginning July 1 at Bretton Woods, N.H., to formulate proposals for an international monetary fund and, possibly, a Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

ANZIO, May 26 -- Following the cutting of the Appian Way, Fifth Army troops pressed on to deprive the enemy not only of the road between Cisterna and Cori but a series of lateral roads to the north, where he does not seem capable of a major effort to hold on.

Joe Baksi had little trouble getting even with Lee Savold at Madison Square Garden last night. Defeated by his blond rival from Des Moines two months ago, Baksi reversed the decision in a twelve-round fight.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The War Department announced today a plan to provide three to nine months of college education for members of the Air Corps Enlisted Reserve before they start air training.

The Amateur Athletic Union has restored the amateur standing of the athletes who competed in the Drake Relays against Bob Steuber, former professional football player, who represented Iowa Naval Pre-Flight School in the Des Moines meet last month.

DETROIT, May 26 (AP) -- The Athletics continued to cool off the once red-hot Tigers, winning 3 to 2, today behind the pitching of Bobo Newsom and Joe Berry for their third straight victory of the series. It was Detroit's twelfth home defeat in thirteen games and their sixth in succession.

In your editorial of May 7, "Living Costs in Britain," you conclude that the decision of the Chancellor of the Exchequer to permit the British cost of living to rise from its 1943 level of 28 to 30 per cent above pre-war months to a new level 30 to 35 per cent above, carries a lesson for the American program of holding down the cost of living with the help of subsidies.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- (AP) The Commodity Credit Corporation announced today that it will allow farmers until Aug. 15 to repay loans and redeem cotton pledged under its 1942 loan program.

Merchant and mill demand for new crop months broadened yesterday in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, and with a fairly heavy volume the market closed steady 1 point lower to 7 points higher than on Thursday on active months.

LONDON, May 26 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, whose word will hurl the full might of an Allied invasion upon the Nazi-bound continent, returned to supreme headquarters today after a swift inspection tour of British land forces under his over-all command, well pleased with the thorough training of the Army that Britain has assembled to avenge the Dunkerque defeat of four years ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- Gregory Peck, Paul Lukas and Hedy Lamarr have been chosen by Radio-Keith-Orpheum for the co-starring roles in the adaptation of Margaret Carpenter's psychological murder mystery novel, "Experiment Perilous.

Increasing military and lend-lease demands for apparel to be delivered this year alone are operating to bring about a progressively tighter situation in the outlook for civilian goods supplies, it was indicated yesterday. Prospects for consumer merchandise at the beginning of the year, which were fairly bright, have shown a reversal indicative of generally more serious shortages than prevailed during 1943.

Activity in the market for new investments here this week increased sharply from that of last week, both awards and flotations of new bonds being the largest for any week in more than a year. Swelled by the largest single flotation of bonds since January, 1943, the week's total of new offerings was $112,337,000, representing nine issues, compared with $28,830,000 for four issues offered for public subscription last week.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Navy Bureau of Yards and Docks was able to eliminate about $226,- 000,000 from its supplementary budget requests in 1943, Vice Admiral Ben Moreell, Bureau Chief, said today, through a widespread conservation program involving salvage, rebuilding of used equipment, simplification or curtailment of projects, substitution of critical materials, reallocation of supplies and other readjustments.

Tomorrow will be a very important day in the history of the Metropolitan Museum. At 1 o'clock in the afternoon the large central block of picture galleries on the second floor will be reopened to the public. In these galleries have been hung approximately 600 paintings, about half of which have not been on view for more than two years.

In a resolution inspired by his retirement next month Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area received a parting tribute yesterday afternoon from the New York Conference of the Methodist Church as he finished presiding at its 145th meeting in Metropolitan-Duane Church, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

After a three-day sit-down strike that led the management to take drastic action yesterday afternoon by closing down the plant of the BH Aircraft Company, Inc., at 27-01 Bridge Plaza North, Long Island City, Queens, engaged in the manufacture of vital airplane engine parts for the Army and Navy, Local 795 of the United Automobile Workers Union at a meeting last night voted to return to work on the midnight shift tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)-Fred M. Vinson, Stabilization Diector, approved today the anthra- cite wage cotract and consequent price adjustments, which will cost the consumer an average of more than 13 cents a ton.

Reflecting higher operating expenses and taxes, the net income of the nation's railroads in April was reduced further. Although some of the smaller roads showed a drop in gross revenues, indications are that the carriers as a whole had a further increase in gross receipts.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The food program of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration will concentrate on basic foods, such as bread grains, fats, meats and milk products, liked by all peoples when prepared according to their own cookery, says Andrew Cairns, chief of the Food Division.

Mr. and Mrs. Maturin Livingston Delafield are at the Savoy-Plaza.

LONDON, May 26 (U.P.) -- Authoritative sources reported today that the Germans had withdrawn troops from Istria to rush them to the threatened southern Italian front and that Marshal Tito's Yugoslav Partisans were attacking along the southwestern Austrian frontier.
The Russian communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
They turned on the lights at the Polo Grounds last night for the first time in two years and for a spell the new bulbs atop the huge grandstand shone very brightly.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 26 -- Fanatical Moslem elements were responsible for disorders in Syria last week-end when an armed rabble broke into a private motion picture showing attended by Moslem women and sought to destroy the building housing the French Officers Club.
Two new films, one of Hollywood origin and the other a Spanish importation, will arrive in Broadway theatres today.

CHUNGKING, China, May 26 (U.P.) -- United States Fourteenth Army Air Force Liberator bombers sank two cargo vessels totaling 3,900 tons off Samah Bay at the southern tip of Hainan Island yesterday, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

With an additional purchase of a "key" Fifty-second Street business property, assembly of the site for the "imposing edifice" planned at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, just across the street from St. Patrick's Cathedral, has been completed, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The House Military Affairs Committee today reported out the second Bolton bill giving "duration-only" rank to members of the Army Nurse Corps, instead of the bill giving them permanent rank which Representative Frances P. Bolton, Republican, of Ohio, also had introduced and championed.
CLEVELAND, May 26 (AP) -- The Senators staged two uprisings, one in the thirteenth inning, to defeat the Indians, 5 to 8, today, chalking up their third consecutive triumph over the last-place Tribe.

When work calls, pupils of the Professional Children's School drop whatever else they are doing to answer. As a matter of fact, several of them did not even turn up to receive their diplomas at commencement exercises held yesterday morning at the New York City Center Theatre, 131 West Fiftyfifth Street.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- The Memorial Day holiday next week influenced local packers today to curtail their buying of cattle, and many steers, mostly medium grade, were taken off the market in the absence of any reliable outlet. The day's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- About 100,000 prisoners of war in the United States will be set to seasonal tasks in urgent work, President Roosevelt announced at his press conference today.

Charges of payroll padding, labor overloading and general loafing on ship repair work done in this area, made Thursday by members of the Field Service Division of the War Shipping Administration, were supported yesterday by Sidney K. Cartwright, head of the service's New York section.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- For all practical purposes the Yankees scared the daylights out of the White Sox at Comiskey Park tonight in this city's first nocturnal major league contest of the season. As a consequence, the champions triumphed, 4 to 0, stretching their winning streak to four games and avenging the shut-out plastered on them by Orval Grove when the Chicagoans visited the Bronx.

Eyelet embroidered cotton dresses, the coolest solution of what to wear in town on those "dog" days, appear in black. In styles as urban as their crepe prototypes, this fabric, heretofore relegated to country dresses or underclothes, has been developed in simple dresses that have budget as well as eye appeal.

LONDON, May 26 -- Sir Samuel Hoare, Ambassador to Spain, delivered a speech to his constituents in Chelsea tonight that must be taken as a sort of extracurricular footnote to the debate that has occupied the House of Commons and the House of Lords for the past three days.
NAPLES, May 26 (AP) -- A communique:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 26 -- A controversy has arisen over the exclusion from the New Rochelle honor roll of the names of merchant marine sailors, with the families of some contending today their sons and husbands were making greater sacrifices in the war than "armchair" members of the armed forces.

Television's first controversy over censorship came to light yesterday after the National Broadcasting Company on Thursday night cut off Eddie Cantor in the midst of his rendition of the song entitled "We're Having a Baby, My Baby and Me."

The report of the Columbia Pictures Corporation announced yesterday for the thirty-nine weeks ended on March 25 shows a net profit of $1,490,000 after all charges, including $3,195,000 provision for Federal income and excess-profits taxes.

LONDON, May 26 (U.P.) -- A Polish Government special commission is investigating charges that Polish Interior Minister Wladyslaw Banaczyk, one of the outstanding Polish leaders in exile, has been in touch with circles connected with the Russian Government, a Polish informant said tonight.

Only three of the eighteen members of the Senate Military Affairs Committee were present at a hearing a few days ago when Secretary of the Navy Forrestal, Under-Secretary of War Patterson and Donald Nelson of the War Production Board came before Congress to urge the enactment of "work-or-fight" legislation to support our armies in the field.

Relaxed regulations governing off-shore fishing by party boats in the Third Naval District, expected in this area for the past few weeks, were made public yesterday by Rear Admiral Stanley V. Parker, United States Coast Guard, Captain of the Port of New York.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder reserved decision yesterday on a motion to dismiss the defense entered by David Sullivan, president of Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, American Federation of Labor, to a suit for an accounting of union funds by him and James J. Bambrick, former president of the local.
