When it comes to choosing fabrics these days, decorators are throwing overboard many of the old conventions that prescribe specific materials for various decorative uses. Since all kinds of fabrics are scarce these days and show signs of becoming scarcer, decorators often have to raid dress goods or linen departments to find the particular shades that fit into their color schemes.
Altered houses and small business and loft buildings on both the East and West Sides of Manhattan figured in realty sales reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A press conference remark by President Roosevelt that he might meet Prime Minister Churchill in an inter-Allied War Conference late next spring, was seized upon here this afternoon as the clearest public indication which the President has given to date that he expects to run for and be elected to a fourth term.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 26 -- Members of the New Jersey Savings and Loan League were urged by Ferdinand Trostel of Guttenberg, who was elected president today, to "continue to build reserves and maintain an adequate degree of liquidity" as the fundamentals of safe operation.
I have read your editorials, which I greatly admire, for about twenty years. I think I can say that I have concurred until I read the one entitled "Price Control Acts" in THE TIMES of May 8.

LONDON, Saturday, May 27 (AP) -- The Russians reported early today that bombers of the Red Fleet Air Force had attacked German troop ships in the Barents Sea, north of Norway, early Friday morning, sinking two transports and a destroyer and damaging three other vessels.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Saturday, May 27 (AP) -- A communique:
Another great day in racing history is at hand today with a program that may bring about some more of those records so commonplace this year.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The American section of the International Federation of University Women awarded today three international research fellowships for 1944-45.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Disclosure that the War Production Board has moved to require the use of not less than 1,000,000 bushels of rye in the production of industrial alcohol was made to a meeting of Senators from the grain States today.

The Seamen's Bank for Savings has sold the one-story brick taxpayer containing seven stores at 1505 to 1505 1/2 Westchester Avenue, in the Bronx, to the Howard Charles Corporation for cash over a purchase-money mortgage of $55,000.
The American Labor party slate in Queens for the Aug. 1 primaries was announced yesterday by Harry Chapman, county chairman, at county headquarters, 92-32 161st Street, Jamaica. It follows:

A three-alarm fire fed by pillows and cushions that gave off billows of heavy, black smoke swept through the three-story brick factory of the Hauptman Feather Company, 16-18 Heyward Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, killing two women and a man and causing damage estimated at $100,000.

A threatening sky failed to discourage artists from bringing their paintings to Washington Square yesterday to open on schedule the twenty-sixth semi-annual outdoor art exhibition. By afternoon hundreds of landscapes, marines and other paintings were displayed on walls and fences, and artists, or their representatives, were watching for possible buyers among the strollers who stopped now and then to look.

A Civil War anecdote has it that Abraham Lincoln once made a disparaging remark about a certain politician. When word reached him that the man was offended he wrote out an apology. "I said yesterday," he conceded, "that I did not believe Mr. A. would steal a red-hot stove.

While shoe manufacturers are pleased that the War Production Board has reduced the quota of manufacturers' bends for the repair trade from 30 per cent to 25 per cent, they still believe that the current allotment, amounting to 350,000 bends a month, actually is far in excess of actual needs of the trade.

The Cities Service Power and Light Company announced yesterday that it had filed with the necessary regulatory bodies applications for the merger of several of its utility properties in Missouri, Kansas and Oklahoma. The company also has requested the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve the public sale of its entire interest in the merged company on completion of the merger in conformity with the requirements of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
BALTIMORE, May 26 (AP) -- Sam Lowry won a mound duel from Ken Miller tonight as Baltimore scored a 4-2 victory over Jersey City to win the odd game of their series.

TULSA, Okla., May 26 (AP) -- J. Edgar Pew of Philadelphia, vice president of the Sun Oil Company, declared today that the Government should begin to make good on what he called its promise of wholly restoring the oil industry to its private owners. He spoke at the Mid-Continent district meeting of the American Petroleum Institute.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 26 (AP) -- A general tie-up of the Northwest lumber industry appeared near today as hundreds of loggers left the woods to join mill and boom workers already off the job in protest against the National WLB denial of wage increases.

ALBANY, May 26 -- Governor Dewey received today nineteen delegates of twelve Latin-American countries to the Inter-American Conference and made a prediction that the barriers of language differences between the United States and the Central and South American nations "will soon dwindle, if not disappear entirely."

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CORI, Italy, May 26 (AP) -- Sherman tanks, firing until the muzzles of their guns were red hot, rained fiery steel on every visible stretch of road before them today, where the Germans were fleeing into the valley between the Alban hills and Lepini ahead of a terrific onslaught of American armor.

Reuters, British news service, said yesterday, according to The Associated Press, than an assertion by Paul H. Alling, deputy director of the State Department's Office of Near Eastern and African Affairs, that the agency had distributed highly editorialized stories cast "a slur upon the British newspapers which own Reuters" and was "an unwarranted attack upon professional newspaper men."

At 33, Dr. Samuel Belkin has been placed at the head of the largest Jewish educational institution in the world. The only college of liberal arts and sciences under Jewish auspices, Yeshiva was founded as a theological seminary in 1897. Under the leadership of the late Dr. Bernard Revel, it expanded to include a seminary, a graduate school, a school for the training of Hebrew teachers and a regular academic high school.

Gerald L.K. Smith, national director of the America First party, said yesterday he would run for President of the United States as the candidate of that party if the Republican National Convention failed to adopt a strong nationalist plank or if the candidate for President nominated by that convention failed to make a sincere bid for America First party support.

The waste paper salvage drive was freshly stimulated yesterday by the efforts of the two groups of volunteer workers who so far have done most to keep the wheels of the continuing campaign rolling -- women and children.

William B. Friedlander is desirous of bringing his production of "Good Morning, Corporal," the play by Milton Herbert Gropper and Joseph Shalleck, to Broadway during the week of June 19 or June 26. The opening is contingent upon the availability of an air-conditioned theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A Senate judiciary subcommittee issued today a sweeping indictment of every agency of the Government involved in the seizure of Montgomery Ward Co.'s Chicago facilities on April 26. Several hours later Attorney General Francis Biddle gave out a statement declaring that the committee conclusions were "absurd" and had been reached "with a complete disregard of the legislative history and language of the War Labor Disputes Ach."

CAMP ANZA, Calif., May 26 (AP) -- An Army court-martial convicted Lieut. Beaufort G. Swancutt of La Crosse, Wis., today on a charge of murdering four persons in a shooting affray and recommended that he be hanged.

RICHMOND, Va., May 26 -- Outstanding among the numerous patents covering medicinal preparations on the list of 563 recorded as issued in this week's number of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office are twelve relating to the recovery of tocopherol, or vitamin E, assigned to Distillation Products, Inc., of Rochester, N.Y.

LOS ANGELES, May 26 (AP) -- Mrs. Barbara Hutton Grant, wife of the movie star, Cary Grant, was directed today to appear in Superior Court June 12 to show cause why she should not be restrained from using "coarse or vulgar language" before her son, Lance Haugwitz-Reventlow, 9 years old.

Federal and State representatives of Government agencies characterized yesterday industrial feeding as a major war weapon at the opening of the fourteenth annual meeting of the New York State Dietetic Association in a two-day conference held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Disclosure was made today that the power to subpoena business men and their records, granted to the Administrator of the Office of Price Administration under the Emergency Price Control Act, had been delegated by him to more than one hundred OPA Regional Administrators and District Office Directors.

CHUNGKING, China, May 26 (AP) -- The Chinese Command announced tonight that contact with Loyang had been cut and an official Army spokesman said that it probably had fallen to strong Japanese forces that have been besieging it for days.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 26 (U.P.) -- Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri, in a keynote address to the State Democratic Convention accused the Republicans tonight of attempting "to turn the crisis of war to their own political purposes,'' and expressed confidence that the present Administration would be "supported and continued.''

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 -- Selecting their officers for the coming year without rival nominations from the fundamentalist faction, the delegates to the Northern Baptist Convention at their closing session today amended the resolution they had adopted overwhelmingly yesterday strengthening the denomination's stand in support of the war.

Retail trade continued active here this week, with pre-holiday buying of seasonal apparel and accessories boosting sales totals. Estimates indicated department store volume is running 15 to 20 per cent ahead of the like week last year.

LAKE CHARLES, La., May 26 -- Complete cooperation between the Federal Government and the oil industry was predicted here today at the formal dedication of one of the nation's largest integrated high-octane gasoline and synthetic rubber plants by Ralph K. Davies, deputy petroleum administrator.

LONDON, May 26 -- The most elaborate arrangements thus far made in this war for the transmission of news dispatches, broadcast reports and photographs to all parts of the world from the land, sea and air fronts have been worked out in finest detail for the invasion of western Europe.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 26 -- Bulgarian communications with the outside world except by radio were cut at noon today. This news blackout is similar to that imposed on Hungary in March just before the Germans occupied that country.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 26 (UP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Rye made a weak start and a strong finish today on the Board of Trade. Announcement that the War Food Administration would require distillers to use 1,000,000 bushels of rye in producing industrial alcohol came as a complete surprize to the grain trade and led to general short covering as well as heavy professional buying of futures.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The War Production Board's aluminum and magnesium division announced today that limited amounts of low-grade "feed material" would be released, as it becomes available, for manufacture of subgrade aluminum for unrestricted or partially restricted use.

Describing the collaboration between the United States and England as a projection into reality of the policy of the English-Speaking Union, Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to this country, presented yesterday to an officer of that organization one of Great Britain's awards in recognition of her work as head of the union's Overseas Children Committee at opening ceremonies of the agency's new national headquarters, 19 East Fifty-fourth Street.

CHUNGKING, China, May 26 (AP) -- The central executive committee of the Kuomintang [China's Government party], pledged at the end of a six-day session tonight to turn all of the country's available strength toward achieving an early victory.

LONDON, May 26 -- The stock markets here were cheerful again today on good war news from Italy. Activity, however, was restricted mainly to industrial issues, support being reported for shipping, textiles and motor shares. Iron and steel shares maintained recent prices.

Lack of lumber and manpower is causing an acute shortage of all kinds of wooden containers for fresh fruits and vegetables, which, if not overcome, will result in a serious waste of those foods, Earl R. French, marketing director of the Atlantic Commission Company, produce-buying subsidiary of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, asserted yesterday.

MYITKYINA AIRDROME, May 21 (delayed) -- A transport plane of the Chinese-American owned China National Aviation Corporation landed at this airfield today, just a little more than two years after the Japanese invasion of northern Burma in 1942 caused the suspension of regular flights by planes of the corporation in and out of Burma.

Industry is increasingly concerned in an equitable solution of the Negro problem, John D. Rockefeller Jr., said last night in a broadcast in which he declared that a solution could be achieved "through mutual understanding, forbearance and progress by agreement, supplemented by law when necessary."

The Board of Health adopted yesterday a resolution modifying its original order to destroy all stray dogs in the Bronx to curb an outbreak of rabies. Effective immediately, unleashed, licensed dogs, picked up by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, will be spared if the owners agree to pay for isolation and quarantine.

LONDON, May 26 -- It was announced today for the first time that historic St. James's Palace, one of the oldest English royal residences from which the accession of many kings has been proclaimed, was damaged in a short but sharp air raid many weeks ago when German bombers scattered high explosive and incendiary bombs on part of London's West End district.

The Park Tilford Company addressed a letter yesterday to holders of 243,976 of its common shares announcing that registered stockholders of record of June 23 may purchase six cases of whisky for each share during a period beginning July 1, 1944, and ending May 15, 1946, subject to all Federal, State and local laws, orders and regulations.

Doubtless Mr. Webster did not have the Northeast in mind when he wrote his definition of a harvest: "The season of gathering grain and fruits; also the gathering of a crop; the product or reward of any exertion." Each spring brings its harvest; the product is the ubiquitous stone pile as a reward of exertion.

BOSTON, May 26 (AP) -- Two pinch-batters came through for Frankie Frisch today and their successful efforts enabled the Pirates to defeat the Braves, 7 to 5, in the rubber contest of a three-game series.

Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel signed an order yesterday directing Acting District Attorney Thomas C. Hughes to prosecute two policemen in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions on Monday on a charge of oppression. The men are Gerald Connolly of 729 Rosedale Avenue, the Bronx, and Charles W. Suckow of 1315 East Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, both of whom are plainclothes men attached to the Brooklyn Borough West Squad.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- The 156th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church suggested in a resolution today that the Protestant Episcopal Church at its general convention in 1946 propose a specific program for the merger of the two churches.

Phantom Ridge rises northwest of Cassino across the valley of death from Monastery Hill. When evening comes wraiths of mist trail over it and the country people whisper that it is haunted. It is haunted now. Thousands of inveterate enemies, Poles and Germans, lie at peace on its slopes.

Magistrate Abner C. Surpless, in Municipal Term Court, Brooklyn, took Mayor La Guardia to task yesterday when he had before him the cases of a wholesaler alleged to have sold and a retailer alleged to have had in his possession some 400 pounds of diseased poultry.

A new plan of cooperation between the New York University School of Retailing and stores in the metropolitan area was announced last night by Provost Rufus D. Smith, acting dean of the school, at graduation exercises for thirty-one graduate students which followed a dinner of students, alumni and faculty at John Wanamaker's, Ninth Street and Broadway.
A biography of Bernard Baruch by Carter Field, a veteran Washington newspaper man, will be published by Whittlesey House late in August. Its title will be "Bernard Baruch: Park Bench Statesman."

Five Navy vessels acquired "godmothers" yesterday when the New York Junior League accepted sponsorship of the new-type LSM's (landing ships, medium) in ceremonies at Pier 42, North River. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mrs. James V. Forrestal, wife of the Secretary of the Navy, and a number of high Naval officers participated in the program at which the women's group promised to keep the ships stocked with records, books, letters and packages.

Bids will be opened next week on new issues of municipal bonds aggregating $52,943,174, of which a single issue will account for $41,533,000, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's revised total of $93,788,128, and with the weekly average of $19,097,557 for the year to date.

ALGIERS, May 26 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle will take with him to London Rene Massigli, Commissioner for Foreign Affairs; Emmanuel de la Vigerie d'Astier, Commissioner for the Interior, and Andre Le Trocquer, Commissioner for Liberated France, the French Committee of National Liberation announced tonight.

Dollar-and-cents ceilings for basic raw furs will replace individual multiple ceilings in the revised regulations which the Office of Price Administration is expected to issue shortly, it was reported in the industry here yesterday. The specific levels will carry through in wholesale and retail prices of garments made from these skins, although manufacturers have not yet abandoned hope that the cost-plus basis which they advocate will be ultimately adopted.

CLEVELAND, May 26 -- Sharp modification of racial antipathies will be necessary in the post-war era if the white man is not to face possible subordination by the overwhelming majority of colored peoples, Edwin R. Embree of Chicago, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, told the National Conference of Social Work tonight.

BOSTON, May 26 (AP) -- In a stunning reversal of form, Dr. Walter I. Lunt's Patches, 2-5 favorite and easy winner of her last two starts, barely saved the show in today's feature at Suffolk Downs before 13,486 as the Marsonia Stable's Paigle scored by half a length.

The Allies in Italy were not proud. If the beachhead would not come to the mountain, then the mountain was perfectly willing to come to the beachhead. Actually it turned out to be the case in Italy as so often in life when pride meets pride and deadlock ensues.

LONDON, May 26 (AP) -- Formation of a tripower "super cabinet" to deal with the international diplomatic problems of Britain, Russia and the United States may be the next development in plans to create, before victory, an international organization to keep the peace.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today the findings concerning conditions in Bolivia, as a result of the recent investigation made by Avra M. Warren, United States Ambassador to Panama, would be transmitted to the other American republics for their consideration.
ALBANY, May 26 (AP) -- An Albany County criminal lawyer and the proprietor of an Albany business concern were indicted today by the grand jury investigating crime in Albany County.

The Dodgers ought to apply for patent rights on the art of blowing ball games. Their young and old men tossed one away to the Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday, 5 -- 3, with three enemy runs unearned because of Brooklyn errors.

Led by Ed Conwell, the I.C. 4-A and A.A.U. sprint champion, the New York University track and field team will defend its title today in the Metropolitan intercollegiate championships at Baker Field, starting at 3 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Navy should immediately court-martial Comdr. John D. Corrigan for disseminating "restricted" Navy information for his own benefit, two members of the Truman Defense Investigating Committee declared today.

MYITKYINA AIRDROME, Burma, May 22 (Delayed) -- After two days of separated and disorganized existence in indifferent slit trenches and revetments alongside the airfield, writers and photographers here have succeeded in establishing airdrome press headquarters inside and underneath the shade-giving and rain-shedding corpse of a shot-up C-47 transport.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) -- The Cubs removed the jinx formerly held over them by Lefty Al Gerheauser in routing the Phillies, 9 to 1, for their sixth successive victory today.

BUFFALO, May 26 (AP) -- The New York State Hospital Association endorsed today expansion of Blue Cross hospitalization service contracts to include X-ray, physical therapy and anesthesia, and urged all hospital boards of trustees and administrators to accept such revised agreements.

NAPLES, May 27 -- As the Germans strove to swing back their unwieldy forty-mile line today and anchor the lower end on the mid-peninsular junction of Avezzano, the Allies on what had been the beachhead pounded twenty-five miles inland and twenty-two miles from Rome, while the main armies smashed deeper into the enemy's receding flank along the general direction of the Via Casilina.

POSSIBLY as a breathing spell from war and "hate Nazi" pictures, Hollywood, temporarily at least, has all but shelved martial projects in favor of films bulging with screams in the night, supercharged criminal phenomena and esthetic murder.

A VAST radio broadcast system has grown up overseas to help make American service men feel at home. Forty-six low-powered transmitters, according to the latest reports, are now operating many hours daily, in cooperation with the British Broadcasting Corporation, from stations scattered throughout Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

NEW ORLEANS, May 27 -- All over the South the feeling grows that this section is being discriminated against in freight rates. The South is further greatly aroused over what it asserts is the violation of States' rights by the National Government. Governors of five or six of our States have been meeting for a year and seeking to obtain what they call "justice for the South."

BLESSED are the pure in heart, for they shall tell all and not even know it. Here is life in Honduras through the eyes of a small female brat who calls herself Elena San Martin, with never a cross word for "my beautiful and unfortunate country*** my poor little country," though all its decently drawn shades are made of clearest cellophane.

THE recent season of the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan was one of its longest and most prosperous, in spite of the increased tax on tickets and strong competition during four of its six weeks. It was not, by the same token, its most brilliant artistically, though to have maintained as high a standard and as strong a company as it has in war times is perhaps no mean achievement.
LONDON, May 27 -- The Allied victories in Italy are a favorable preface to a summer of crises.

DESPITE war conditions, the coming summer will find a profusion of large-scale music festivals and concert series being offered throughout the country. In line with this city's Stadium Concerts and Goldman Band series, already detailed in these columns, music will be presented in a comprehensive manner in many other communities during the summer months.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- As the West Coast basks in the publicity attending its wartime evolution as a brand-new industrial center, it must not be forgotten that here is still one of the nation's great agricultural producing regions.
NAPLES, May 27 -- In the Appian Way town of Fondi the other day, a spindly-legged Italian boy or four looked up wonderingly at a uniformed American who had just filled his hands with candy.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The Yankees spent most of this afternoon at Comiskey Park in a futile pursuit of the White Sox. They caught up with Jimmy Dykes' outfit twice. But they didn't have what it takes to pass the local hosts, and the champions dropped the ball game and, with the same motion, saw a couple of winning streaks smashed. The count was 4 to 3.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Government statistics show that American workers have resorted to strikes increasingly in each of the war years. The man-hours of idleness because of strikes in the first quarter of 1944 were about twice those of the same three months last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- With few exceptions, the 22,000 Japanese-Americans who have left relocation centers have been well received by their new neighbors and have "resumed their normal place in society" in numerous communities away from the West Coast, the War Relocation Authority reported today.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 27 (AP) -- The Northwestern Council of Lumber and Sawmill Workers, AFL, today accused the War Labor Board of "a complete lack of understanding of the lumber situation" which has sent from 25,000 to 30,000 northwest workers on protest walkouts.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 27 (U.P.) -- Repatriated Allied war prisoners and civilians who arrived here today on the exchange ship Gripsholm said they had observed that Berlin was two-thirds ruined when their trains passed through the Reich capital.

Throughout the Soviet territory liberated by the Red Army since the Battle of Stalingrad Soviet doctors have discovered innumerable cases of massacre of civilians by the German invaders, according to a Science Service dispatch received from the Soviet Scientists' Anti-Fascist Committee.

Pre-holiday trade was active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the summary prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were busy and the demand for all accessories was good.

WHEN "Dream With Music" celebrated its lavish New York premiere, it made the thirty-seventh production designed by Stewart Chaney, and his tenth this season. If this would seem to be something of a record even for the theatre, Mr. Chaney would seem to be a craftsman who can take records in his stride.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- With the Republican National Convention in Chicago a month away, Central Westerners reached the conclusion this week that this area's nationalists or pre-Pearl Harbor isolationists have decided they cannot accept Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's views on American foreign policy.

LONDON, May 27 -- On last Thursday when the Fifteenth Air Force bombers based on Italy joined in the tactical offensive directed against German power to resist invasion in the west by hammering the railroad yards at Lyon and Toulon, the "softening-up" process of pre-invasion bombing included the five principal air forces in the Mediterranean and northern European theatres in the same campaign with the same objectives.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The general assembly of the Presbyterian Church adopted a resolution today calling for prayers "for the men who battle, for our leaders, and for those in the United Nations who are thinking and toiling to render their lands worthier of the costly sacrifices being made to safeguard or to regain their liberties."

Thirty-six youthful contestants received prizes of war bonds and war savings stamps at the Museum of Natural History yesterday in a program that was the climax of the city-wide Handcraft Exhibit sponsored by the Department of Parks and the New York Community Trust.

INFORMATION regarding the origin of the three United States 3-cent purple commemoratives issued this month was made available by the Postoffice Department last week. The vignette of the stamp recalling the completion of the first transcontinental railroad seventy-five years ago illustrates a mural by J. McQuarrte, which is in the Union Pacific Railroad Station in Salt Lake City.

LONDON, May 27 -- Prime Minister Churchill's remark in the House of Commons this week that Russo-Polish relations were not as bad as they seemed on the surface set London political observers searching for evidence of improvement.
