THERE is possibly no ship in the American Navy today that is more deserving of having its combat history recorded than that fine carrier, the Enterprise. Like her famous prototype, the "Lucky Little Enterprise" of 1812, she possesses a ship's spirit that is partly the reason for, and partly the result of, the distinction with which she has served in this war.

IN a democracy ordinary men govern. To argue whether or not they are capable is fruitless, because participation by all is here to stay. One thing, however, is certain: the average man must have a good education, an education which will carry on beyond the period of formal schooling, if he is to adjust to the increasing pace and complexity of life and if he is to govern intelligently.

NAPLES, May 27 -- Despite the encouraging and even sensational progress of the Allied armies in Italy in the last fortnight there is one thing to be kept in mind by all those prone to figure out the coming western invasion before the event.

TALL bearded iris now claim the attention of garden lovers everywhere. The great appeal of these irises is undisputed, and with their majestic stalks carrying blossoms of iridescent beauty they readily steal the show from any other plant now flowering in the garden.

THE big film news of the week centered around the distribution deal made by Hal B. Wallis and Joseph H. Hazen, former executives of Warner Brothers, with Paramount Pictures for their newly formed independent producing company, and the report made by Spyros Skouras, president of Twentieth Century-Fox, anent the many-sided agreement he recently completed in England with J. Arthur Rank, the British mill owner and movie tycoon.
FRAMED neatly between a promising prologue and an almost moving epilogue, Charlotte Aiken Yarborough's first novel just falls short of making any serious impact upon the reader.

RECENTLY a window cleaner wrote a letter to the editor urging men to join his profession, now short of hands. He said that he had enjoyed a good wage for many years, raised a nice family and had two boys in service.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- While the manufacture of such smaller consumer goods items as electric irons shows signs of loosening up, trade association circles here report that the reverse seems to be true of some of the bigger items which may require small electric motors or other hard-to-get parts. For these household utilities Washington seems to have developed a sudden aversion to even discussing the possibilities of production later on this year.

The American Business Congress yesterday called upon Mayor La Guardia to exert his influence in Congress to obtain regulation of office and loft building rentals under the Office of Price Administration to protect commercial tenants now being "victimized by rent-gouging landlords."
CHUNGKING, China, May 27 (AP) -- A communique:

The sixty-voice Furriers Chorus of the Joint Council, CIO, Max Helfman, conductor, assisted by Maria Safonoff and Vladimir Heifetz, pianists; Aubrey Pankey, Negro baritone; Kenneth Gordon, violinist, and Amelia Babad, monologist, gave a gala concert before a good-sized audience in Town Hall last night for Russian war relief.

Contrary to popular belief, all vitamins are not easily destroyed and lost during large-scale cooking and food handling, Dr. Paul L. Pavcek, secretary of the committee on food composition of the National Research Council, told 250 members of the New York State Dietetics Association, yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Wild geranium has been dappling the meadows and the edge of park and woodland with bright lavender-pink blossoms that soon will give way to the seed pods from which some call it Cranesbill. And there's a name with poetry in it, the poetry of the woods and fields.

LONDON, May 27 -- In all the rhetoric expended on British foreign policy last week two predominant thoughts emerged. One was that the Anglo-Russian treaty of two years ago must be the cornerstone on which Britain builds her future international relations in Europe.

CLEVELAND, May 27 -- Dean Leonard W. Mayo of Western Reserve University, closing the national conference of social work here this morning urged his colleagues from all parts of the country to focus their energies, in the future, on eradication of causes of social ills, rather than on the treatment of their effects, That, he assured them, is the direction in which welfare is trending.

The patience of Edward Jennings, a court warrant officer, was rewarded yesterday when after a two-year search he found his quarry -- a Queens man accused of practicing law without a license and of obtaining $3,000 in fees from John T. Beatty of Darien, Conn.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

It is widely accepted throughout the country that Mr. Roosevelt will once more be the Presidential nominee of the Democrats and, at this writing, that Mr. Dewey will be the nominee of the Republicans. In these circumstances political speculation has recently been more concerned over the respective nominees of the two parties for the Vice Presidency.

UNION, N.J., May 27 -- Two teams paced a field of twenty after the first round of the thirty-six-hole best-ball member-guest tournament of the Suburban Golf Club today. Michael Cestone of Jumping Brook, the Metropolitan amateur champion, and Frank G. Campbell turned in a 70, one stroke under par, to finish all square with Peter Straub of East Orange and Thomas Kenyon.

The vision of Times Square subway station in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine would be funny if it were not so sad. There isn't any good reason why the arrangement of the platforms and the ends of spur lines or shuttle lines shouldn't at least be a little more convenient.

Approximately 5,000 elementary school principals, one-fifth of the total number throughout the country, have gone into the armed services since Pearl Harbor. As a result, 5 per cent of the elementary schools, mostly those in the rural areas, have been closed. In large metropolitan areas many principals have been forced to supervise two or more schools.

THERE are hundreds of officers now in the Merchant Marine who never expected to be there. Lieutenant Denison lectures to candidates at the USMS Officers School at New London on the traditions of the service they are entering.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 27 -- With communications severed since yesterday, events in Bulgaria appeared to be moving toward a crisis, according to vague reports from the Rumanian frontier to neutral sources tonight. Most of these dealt with the entry into Bulgaria of "immense convoys," an indication that "security operations" were proceeding according to plan.

ALMOST every gardener tries cucumbers, although last year not everyone reported a successful crop. For cucumbers like above all a good circulation of air, an abundance of water and soil with plenty of organic matter high in nitrogen.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- First step in a legislative move to cut the prevailing wartime tax on night club and cabaret checks to 10 per cent from the current 30 per cent is expected Monday when Senators McCarran of Nevada and Downey of California will attach an amendment, providing for the tax cut, to the Senate measure which would authorize an increase in the Federal debt limit.

DESPITE her extensive globetrotting, Ellen Gatti's account of an expedition into the heart of the Belgian Congo is feminine and domestic. She gleaned, or chose to write about, the more light-hearted reactions to a tour through the African jungle.

" THE American public," Mr. Lamott writes, "finds it impossible to think in terms of anything but opposites. Either the Japanese are a nation of toothy generals and admirals and ape-like soldiers, or they are a nation of well-behaved, artistic, civilized people who by some trick of fate are constantly being betrayed by a few dastardly rulers."

Proper care for advanced cancer patients of moderate means was urged yesterday by Julius Jay Perlmutter, president of the newly formed National Foundation for the Care of Advanced Cancer Patients, with temporary headquarters at 450 Seventh Avenue.

RICHMOND, May 27 -- Since South Carolina gave President Roosevelt a better than fifty-five to one majority over Wendell Willkie four years ago, it is incredible that Mr. Roosevelt will fail to carry the State for a fourth term, if he runs.

LONDON, May 1 (Delayed). NOW that Claude Rains has been approved as an appropriate Caesar by no less an authority than George Bernard Shaw himself, it won't be long before the Technicolor cameras start grinding out "Caesar and Cleopatra."

Mr. Churchill's idea of world organization, as outlined in his latest speech, is perhaps less precise than might be expected from the head of a Government which will have enormous influence in deciding the form and scope of any international body set up after the war.

DESPITE the letter written by I. Einstadt recently condemning actresses for writing and acting in their own plays, I am still enthusiastically for it. Last season you published my suggestion that the acting profession remedy the lack of good plays by writing its own.

Through the interest and cooperation of a group of women of society organized as the Stadium Concerts Defense Entertainnment Committee, members of the various branches of the armed forces will be privileged to attend many of the Stadium Concerts during the season opening on June 19.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- It is assumed here that the United States expects to be kept informed of the conversations in London between Prime Minister Churchill and General de Gaulle, in accordance with normal practice among the Allies.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The post-war subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, it was learned today, has accepted the principle of United States participation in a United Nations organization to enforce peace, but a controversy of fundamental importance has arisen over whether the United States should seek to create and support such an organization now or wait until after the end of the European war.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 27 (AP) -- Connecticut Democrats helped to put President Roosevelt's total of pledged or claimed delegates beyond the 900-mark today as they unanimously and noisily adopted at their State convention a resolution instructing their 18-vote delegation to vote as a unit for his nomination.
BOSTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Cubs chalked up their seventh straight victory today with Bill Schuster's ninth-inning double bringing in the run that gave them a 3-to-2 victory over the Braves.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 27 -- Under the strange condition of bright sunshine, fog and a fine southwest breeze that blew the smoke around, the summer regatta season on Long Island Sound was opened today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School's seemingly unbeatable band of track athletes, who missed the century mark by a mere half-point, when they retained the private schools' crown last week, yesterday made certain of going over the top, while successfully defending the Catholic High Schools A.A. title at Randalls Island.

AN impromptu, unofficial, curbside information service is flowering on the sidewalks of New York's Times Square. It has neither booth nor lobby, placard nor telephone. The service is made up of about twenty men stationed at Forty-fifth Street and Broadway, at Forty-third Street and Seventh Avenue, on all the strategic corners.

LONDON, May 27 -- The coast of western Europe runs for thousands of miles past fiords, dunes, rocky inlets and sandy bays, and all of this is potential invasion coast. Here behind fortifications built in four years since the fall of France the Germans face the invaders.

The Japanese celebrated their thirty-ninth Navy Day yesterday with a grim warning by Capt. Etsuzo Kurihara, chief of the naval press section at Imperial Headquarters, that the Allies' advance into the Central and South Pacific areas "has already set fire, so to speak, to one end of Japan and is truly about to reduce Japan to ashes.
Mrs. Peter Augusta Jay will arrive from Washington today and will be at the Plaza until she goes to her summer home at Bar Harbor.

All the trains, including the Seabeach subway, were crowded all day yesterday and until late into the night as the Memorial Day week-end sent city crowds to the beaches and the country while throngs of service men and women as well as war workers from nearby towns came into the city.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Netherland New Guinea, May 27 -- Thrice the A-20 plane whipped low over the beachhead, and from the cockpit we could see the invasion of Biak Island proceeding along a growingly familiar pattern.

It was with a sickening feeling that I read the report of Hadley Cantril -- "What We Don't Know Is Likely to Hurt Us" -- in THE TIMES Magazine. It confirmed an opinion I have formed and have been afraid to face, from attempted discussion of public affairs with adults.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Labor Department's wage and hour division inspectors checked on 4,637 New York establishments from July, 1943, through February, 1944, and found 3,558, or 80 per cent of them violating in some degree fair labor standards or public contract acts.

HERE is a book that on the strength of its title alone will attract a host of readers. There are certain things one has come to expect of a novel named for its heroine. For one thing, it must deal with an exceptional woman and, if the author takes his art at all seriously, it must have something rather exceptional to say.

Specific tasks for the underground forces of Europe were laid down last week. By radio and pamphlet, from agents parachuted or smuggled into Hitler's fortress, the word was being passed to the patriots of all the nations under Hitler's yoke. Allied spokesmen made it plain that the need was for planned and particular activity rather than disorganized uprising.

PEARL HARBOR, May 27 (UP) -- Long-range aerial smashes by Army and Navy bombers Thursday brought the Japanese naval and air base at Shimushu, in the Kurile Islands, under attack for he third straight day, reached within 960 miles of Tokyo by hiting Matsuwa and put new battle scars on hard-hit Ponape, in the Marshalls, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

A handsome young man with flashing teeth and a shy smile stepped out of the lobby of a midtown theatre for a smoke at the intermission yesterday afternoon. He was but one of several officers and service men and neither attracted nor invited attention.

Dr. John Lloyd Newcomb, president of the University of Virginia has announced that the writing of a comprehensive biography of Thomas Jefferson in four volumes by Dr. Dumas Malone, former editor of the Dictionary of American Biography, has been made possible by a grant of $21,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation.

Beginning with the greatest of them all, American humorists of nation-wide and enduring reputation have come out of the country west of the Alleghenies. One might almost say the Mississippi Valley if not for the thought of Mark Twain's actual beginnings on the Pacific Coast.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I. -- The Ketchabonack Club opens the golf and tennis season here this week-end. Known formerly as the Country Club of Westhampton Beach, the new club has been recently reorganized by a group of members of the summer colony.

More than 1,600 women who have taken an active part in the work of twenty-one war-related agencies that are affiliated with the New York War Fund and the National War Fund have been invited to participate in a series of "Come and See" tours to inspect the work of the various agencies, it was announced yesterday.

IN the winter of 1942 the OWI suggested that Stephen Vincent Benet write a short, interpretive history of the United States for translation into many languages. He had already done the ground-work for it in other forms. "John Brown's Body" and "Western Star" are a poet's interpretation of the great mosaic, and a short story like "The Devil and Daniel Webster" belongs with them.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's Chinese jungle fighters have captured the Mogaung Valley stronghold of Warong and are tightening a death trap around Kamaing, twelve miles to the southwest, where the largest Japanese force left in north Burma is encircled, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.
DETROIT, May 27 -- Following is the text of the appeal made tonight by R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, to the members of his union:

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- A new War Manpower Commission program intended to step up the recruiting of workers for priority projects on a national basis has been prepared and probably will be announced within ten days.

Children in tissue-paper party hats yelled and ran and the perspiring speakers shouted helplessly yesterday as the United Tenants League presented a scroll to the Harlem River Houses, 151st Street at the Harlem River. The award was made for outstanding achievement in maintaining the cleanliness and beauty of the project, which is occupied by 577 Negro families.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Criticism of the President and Congress for approving a bill appropriating $1,000,000 to provide seeing-eye dogs for blind war veterans is made in an editorial of the June 3 issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Production of munitions in April was 3 per cent less than had been scheduled, and the total represented a recession of 2 per cent compared with the March level, but most of the individual "must" items kept well abreast of output schedules, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A highly promising odorless, greaseless, non-sticky oil treatment for floors, blankets and bedding that traps germs in hospital wards and barracks, has been developed in researches carried out by medical scientists for the Office of Surgeon General of the Army, the War Department stated today.

LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- Norway will follow a policy of friendship and collaboration with Russia after the war and will resist efforts of any power to make her a buffer against the Soviet Union, a member of the Norwegian Government in Exile said tonight.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, May 28 (AP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, May 28 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur threw American infantry and tanks ashore on Biak Island in the Schoutens, about 900 statute miles from Davao in the Philippines, early Saturday morning against fierce resistance.

CHARLOTTEVILLE, Va., May 27 (AP) -- The writing of a biography of Thomas Jefferson in four volumes by Dr. Dumas Malone, former editor in chief of the Dictionary of American Biography, has been made possible by a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation of $21,000 to be administered by the University of Virginia.

It was lovely at Ebbets Field yesterday and the 11,642 fans who turned out for the opening game between the Reds and Dodgers doubtless enjoyed the warmth and sunshine. That was the only source of pleasure they had, though, because Cincinnati won, 2 -- 0, with Ed Heusser hurling.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- Japanese propagandists, opening a peace campaign to get Australia out of the war, assert "Australia never has and never will be considered our enemy," the Netherlands News Agency, Aneta, reported today in a dispatch from Melbourne.

The path of life has been uphill all the way for Eduard Benes, who is 60 today. There have been no easy intervals of coasting for him. The youngest of a farmer's family, he worked for his schooling. Still young, he worked for Czechoslovak independence and did more than any other man, except only his teacher, Thomas G. Masaryk, to bring the centuries-old plight of the Czechs to the world's attention.

THERE are occasions when one must open a strong three-card suit against a no-trump contract, the bidding having made it clear that in no other suit can enough tricks be established to defeat the contract. In leading from three-card suits even the most experienced players often choose the wrong card to lead.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 27 -- District Court Judge Joseph P. Lebkeucher is convinced that a boycott of Belmont Park by race-goers would prove an effective means of forcing the Westchester Racing Association to reopen that track's parking field.

MOST of the thirteen stories, vignettes and sketches of James T. Farrell's "To Whom It May Concern" make easy and often engaging reading, and none of them provides surprise ammunition for either this author's friends or foes.

Scoring heavily in the sprints and picking up points in every event contested except one, New York University won the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championship for the fourth year in succession and the seventh time in the twelve years' history of the meet yesterday on Columbia's Baker Field.

ANZIO, Italy, May 27 -- The roads over which the enemy was forced to move to elude the Fifth Army's advance elements were in many cases littered with abandoned materials, an indication of disorderly flight and a suggestion that the German units had been ordered to hold their positions until a given moment and then make a rush for it.

A VALUED correspondent, Mr. Elick Budovsky, advances, among other matters of argument, the cause of the so-called "infant prodigy." He represents that the great majority of the celebrated musicians of the past have shown wholly exceptional musical capacities at a very early age.

DETROIT, May 27 (AP) -- Southpaw Hal Newhouser cashed in on a five-hit pitching performance today when Pinky Higgins scored on an infield out in the tenth inning to give the Tigers a 2-to-1 victory over the Athletics, who had won the other three games of the series.

AT a time when all the doctors of modern literature have given up their patient for dead, several signs of health appear simultaneously in these new anthologies. We may even wonder whether the percentage of good writing is any smaller than is usual in slack times; perhaps it is the vast, increasing output of bad-to-mediocre books which now makes this tiny fraction seem so negligible.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Orders of newspaper publishers in the United States for 30-pound newsprint from Canada must be reduced again in the second month of the experimental 60-day period of production in the Dominion, Arthur R. Treanor, director of the War Production Board's printing and publishing division, said today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The War Department announced today that the winners, in their respective classes, of the National Intercollegiate Rifle Team matches for 1944 were Culver Military Academy of Indiana, Bordentown Military Institute of New Jersey and Xavier High School of New York City.

THEY say that 25,000,000 people listen to her every Friday night, and about half that many every noon (except Saturday and Sunday), which must mean that with the exception of Franklin D. Roosevelt's voice, Kate Smith's is as well known as any in the land.

THIS book will delight three sets of readers: lovers of Jane Austen and admirers of either Sheila Kaye-Smith or of G.B. Stern. The authors themselves seek no wider audience than that of confessed "Janeites." Devotees though they are, they have no desire to proselytize.

Touching new high levels despite wartime restrictions and shortages, retail sales last year rose 4.2 per cent, while profits increased 9 per cent over 1942, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES based on the annual reports of fifty-three leading mail order, chain, department store and specialty shop organizations now available.

HOLLYWOOD. ONE of the less publicized activities in Hollywood is the compilation of a film's vital statistics, "vital" statistics on the West's generally sunny steppes including everything from the number of extra and bit players employed to the tons of ice sprayed on a set to "snow it down" for a wintry effect.

THIS year's Newbery Medal for the best children's book has gone to Esther Forbes for her "Johnny Tremain," a story of Revolutionary Boston....The Atlantic Monthly Press is hoping for the arrival of a new James Hilton manuscript this summer, if the author's Hollywood commitments permit.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, announced today a new organization to deal with cut-backs and cancellations in the country's military-production programs and plan for partial industrial reconversion with the advent of what is designated "X-day" -- the date of Germany's collapse.

BOSTON, May 27 -- With thousands of war-revived or war-created shipyards humming merrily from Maine to Connecticut and more than 150,000 persons getting higher wages than ever before in an ancient Yankee craft, a majority of New Englanders have assumed Washington to be right in planning for at least 50,000,000 tons of merchant shipping to handle post-war maritime commerce.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, May 27 (AP) -- Fifth Army combat engineers pulled a fast one on their pals of an advance reconnaissance group -- and thereby participated in the historic handshaking when junction with the Anzio beachhead forces was made two days ago.

THE so-called "capsule theory of life" -- particularly as manifested in literary condensations -- has been much maligned on occasion, sometimes with good reason. New evidence for the defense is supplied by this "Treasury of Modern Best Sellers."

DETROIT, May 27 -- Taking cognizance of the many "wildcat" strikes which have "inflamed public opinion against our union," R.J. Thomas, international president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, appealed today to the membership in a surprise statement to see to it that "the good name of our union is maintained; that the acts of isolated handfuls are not permitted to continue, to the detriment of us all."

THE National Academy's print show is, it strikes me, somewhat above "average" this year. The jury of selection (John Taylor Arms, Ernest D. Roth and Victoria Hutson Huntley) has assembled some 224 examples, choosing these from between 2,000 and 2,500 prints submitted.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Democratic quest for a Vice Presidential candidate to team with Franklin D. Roosevelt in his expected fourth-term bid in November, is compelling wider and wider notice in the political community as time for candidate selection draws inevitably nearer.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- President Roosevelt assured a special Congressional delegation today that an Army order halting construction of twenty-eight airports in seventeen States would be reconsidered. Chairman Randolph of West Virginia said the committee had presented facts about the propects which he indicated had not been put before the President previously.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, announced yesterday that representatives of fifteen high priority war plants would be at the Brewster Aircraft Corporation tomorrow offering employment to workers laid off as a result of the termination of Navy contracts at Brewster.

Strength continued yesterday to seep back into the stock market. On the New York Stock Exchange selected stocks advanced and the list closed irregularly higher on the best volume for a two-hour session since March 25. Turnover was 415,300 shares, against 361,570 a week earlier.

A heart sound detector which picks up the faint echoes of incipient illness in other parts of the body has been devised by Dr. John H. Foulger, director, and Paul E. Smith Jr., physicist, at the du Pont Company's Haskell Laboratory of Industrial Toxicology.

OMAHA, May 27 -- While it watches and waits for the beginning of the grand offensive against Germany, the Midwest occupies itself with post-war planning. Hardly a community with the size and enterprise to maintain a local Chamber of Commerce but has its planning committee.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 27 -- If Vichy's official news agency is to be believed Chief of State Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain has taken a definite stand on aerial bombings -- and his side is the German. Before returning to Vichy from his temporary residence near Paris, Marshal Petain made a tour of eastern France.

THE military policeman is often misunderstood -- especially by civilians. In this area, where no place is ruled "off post," the M.P. has never fired his pistol on patrol. He eschews the use of club or other force. He keeps in mind that, as well as to preserve order and to check passes, dress and, now, salutes of military personnel, his duty is to help and care for G.I. Joe.

After two hours of violent debate, members of the New York Association of Teachers of Social Studies adopted yesterday a resolution favoring free discussion of controversial issues but stipulated that opinions should be labeled as such and not mistaken for facts.

The cellulose sponge, familiar handyman in millions of pre-war households, is now mopping up fires before they start in bombers. When the self-sealing fuel cells in the wings of bombers are punctured by enemy bullets a certain amount of gasoline escapes before the rubber swells to close the holes.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 27 (AP) -- Gov. Ellis Arnall, by executive order, today directed Attorney General T. Grady Head to institute a suit before the United States Supreme Court in the name of the State of Georgia to force equalization of freight rates.

JUST before sitting down to write today's column, this department took note of the news that "Strange Fruit," Lillian Smith's powerful and sensitive novel dealing with the Negro problem, had been barred from the United States mails.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 27 -- The West Point cadets displayed too much hitting power for the Annapolis midshipmen and won the thirty-seventh renewal of the interservice baseball classic before a gallery of more than 4,000 fans on Lawrence Field today.

With pre-holiday buying of Summer apparel and accessories a marked factor, retail trade here continued active last week. Department store volume, it was estimated, ran 15 to 20 per cent ahead of the comparative period of last year.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 27 -- Claude (Buddy) Young of Illinois, trying for his fourth victory of the day -- a feat which would have equaled Jesse Owens' Western Conference sweep for Ohio State in 1935 -- tripped over the last barrier in the 220-yard low hurdles today and fell on a water-filled track to miss his goal.

LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Coastal Command's torpedo and rocket bombers have crippled the enemy's blockade-running feedline in the Bay of Biscay to German war plants, while British Liberators and Wellingtons from Italy again have strewn the lower Danube military waterway with mines to throttle another source of supply, it was announced today.

The consumer's ration purchasing power for meats and other foods still requiring red points has been cut approximately 25 per cent, it is indicated by the first trade survey of the effects of the Office of Price Administration's most important food-rationing change, made this month.

MR. OWEN RUTTER has long been known as a leading writer on naval affairs and in this book on the origins and development of the Fleet air arm he gives us of his best. At the beginning of the war the tactical employment of that weapon was in the experimental stage and, starting from scratch, fliers of the Royal Navy had to learn the brand new art the hard way, by trial and error.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 27 (AP) -- Clyde R. Hoey, former Governor, won the North Carolina Democratic nomination for United States Senator to take the seat now filled by Chairman Robert R. Reynolds of the Military Affairs Committee on the basis of returns from 1,301 of the 1,921 precincts in today's Democratic primary.
LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- A German communique:

LONDON, Sunday, May 28 -- Topping off one of the greatest weeks of destruction in the war, during which more than 13,000 American planes alone scarred the face of Europe, 2,000 Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force and escorting fighters concentrated yesterday on the enemy's vital railway junctions in Germany and eastern France.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, May 27 -- One of our Liberators was forced down by bad weather on a New Guinea combat mission. After wandering around in the interior jungle for weeks the nine crew members recently returned to an American base and told of seeing hundreds of skeletons of Japanese who had died from a combination of starvation and disease in the morass of the hinterland.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 27 (AP) -- A Nazi wave of terror swept Norway and Denmark today, possibly reflecting German fears that the Allies intend to break into fortress Europe through Scandinavia.

A State-wide central buying agency to serve sixteen local groups of retail grocers will be organized at the convention of the New York State Food Merchants Association at Saratoga Springs, Aug 6 to 9, A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the association, announced yesterday.

MONTREAT, N.C., May 27 (AP) -- The General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church heard a plea tonight for more and better candidates for the ministry, linked with a promise of increased salaries for pastors.
NAPLES, May 27 (UP) -- A communique:

A special announcement from the Allies' headquarters in Italy last night promised air support within a few days to Italian patriot fighters in the north who were said to be menaced by columns of German and puppet Fascist forces after the expiration of a May 25 surrender deadline.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 27 -- Navy's midshipmen defeated Army's cadets in their annual track and field meet today by 74 to 52. The middies garnered ten of the fourteen first places, while the cadets picked up substantial points for second and third.

The periodic appeal for fishing tackle to be used by our overseas service men comes from Harlan Major. This time he quotes letters from GI Joes, in about every area of the fighting front stressing the opportunities for fishing if only they had the necessary equipment.

WHISKY stocks are dwindling rapidly. In many liquor stores the sale of well-known brands has stopped. The reason is that distillers "converted" to the war program on Oct. 8, 1942; since then they have made no whisky for the trade.

JERSEY CITY, May 27 (AP) -- Jersey City overcame a 7-1 deficit tonight, winning in the ninth from Syracuse, 9-8, when Mike Schemer stole home. There were 23 bases on balls issued, 13 by the Chiefs' pitchers and 10 by Little Giant hurlers.

AT the end of Moliere's "Alceste," the Misanthropist vows "to seek on earth a place so remote that he could be free to be a man of honor." After Munich, Georges Bernanos, in disgust, fled to the ultimate frontier, the very edge of the sertao in Brazil.

Celebration of the centennial anniversary of the founding of the Young Men's Christian Association by its branches throughout the world, which began May 1, will reach a high point of interest on June 6, the anniversary date, and be continued the rest of the year, the New York City branch announced yesterday.

WHILE all of the country's national parks will be open to people who can get there this summer, there will be practically no sponsored tours. Nor will any of the large hotels within park gates take down their shutters.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Recent and dynamic events on the political front have highlighted the Democratic split over a fourth term for Mr. Roosevelt and cast over the process by which our Chief Executives are selected a deeper shadow than at any time since 1876.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The third large money bill reported in less than a week, a $1,104,972,814 supply measure for independent offices, was used by the House Appropriations Committee today as the medium for a verbal slap at Federal employes who "propagandize" Congress for money.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 27 -- Bob Bilgrav hurled Princeton to easy victories over Cornell in both ends of an Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header today, blanking the Ithacans in the opener, 8 to 0, and coming back to win the nightcap, 7 to 4.

Your belief, expressed editorially, that the poll tax can easily be eliminated from Federal elections by a constitutional amendment, seems to me over-optimistic and based on needless uncertainty as to the power of Congress.

SECOND only to the winning of the war and the establishment of a durable peace, the most important objective of the American people today is post-war economic security -- or, more succinctly, jobs. Every poll of public opinion emphasizes that this completely overshadows all other domestic issues.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., May 27 -- Miss Kathleen Courtney of Great Britain, vice chairman of the League of Nations Union, told the Business and Professional Womens Club in State convention tonight that it was important to be clear about the difference between a union of States, a cooperative organization, and a world federation which would involve world government.

THERE is no one formula for a painless, safe, beautiful tan -- there are many, say the dermatologists, cosmetic chemists and beauty experts. Each individual must work out his or her own formula, cautiously juggling three variable elements -- the type of skin, the type of sun and the type of sun preparation.

THERE has been a plethora of stuff written, mostly for the screen, about English aviators who have been forced to land by plane or parachute in France. Invariably, no matter where one of these intrepid fellows descends, he is immediately welcomed by a committee of the underground, which meets alternate Thursday nights behind the old stone barn.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 27 -- The New York University basball team capitalized on misplays to score a 4-to-1 victory over Stevens Tech on Castle Point Field today. The game was briskly played, with the rival pitchers, Branca of N.Y. U. and Bucalo, performing well.

The only people who have any occasion to shed tears over Twilight Tear, the Calumet Farm's bay filly who reigns as queen in the Warren Wright barn where another 3-year-old with an equally lugubrious name, Pensive, is installed as king, is the Westchester Racing Association.

Adolf Hitler has become owner of the van Eyck masterpiece, "The Adoration of the Lamb," Belgium's greatest art treasure, which was sent to France for safekeeping in 1940 and then handed over to Marshal Hermann Goering.

MANY gardeners who grow large fruiting tomatoes for the bulk of their crop like to include a few of those which produce small fruit so abundantly. In shape and size they resemble cherries, currants, peaches, pears or plums.

CHUNGKING, China, May 27 (AP) -- Fighting has broken out in the neighborhood of Tsungyang, about seventy-five miles south of Hankow, in southern Hupeh Province, a Chinese communique reported, today, and the possibility was being discussed here of a vast pincers against the Chinese rear as a likely Japanese move in central China, aimed eventually at this wartime capital.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 27 -- Governor Dewey's popularity as a Presidential candidate among Republican voters polled from coast to coast by the Institute has gone up ten percentage points in the past month.

New knowledge of the stomach, gained in six years of research at the School of Medicine, Western Reserve University, by Drs. J. Paul Quigley, Margaret R. Read and Bernard Brofman, Lieut. Daniel A. Brody, Capt. Isador Meschan, Lieut. Jake M. Werle, Maj. Herbert Bavor of the Army Medical Corps, and Viola W. Quigley promises to change the present method of treating some gastric disorders.

THAT youthful and very energetic aggregation, the New Opera Company, having sounded the gong for the third straight time with the current "Helen Goes to Troy," is negotiating for the rights to the Oscar Straus operetta, "A Waltz Dream."

IT'S about time for someone to get up and lodge a public complaint against the sort of roles which somebody has been handing Bette Davis recently. As a matter of fact, the indictment might even be stretched a bit and caused to include a general protest against Miss Davis' handling over the years.

ENGLAND, London, announces "special actuality broadcasts in effect as from the officially announced commencement of European invasion." Time and frequency follow: 7:10 A.M., 11.68; 8, 8:20 and 9:45 A.M., 15.31; 3:45 P.M., 15.31 megacycles; 6:55 P.M., 11.93, 9.58, 9.69 megacycles; at 7:30 and 7:45 P.M., same frequencies as 6:55 P.M.; 11 P.M. on additional channels of 6.11, 7.12 and 7.26; midnight, on 9.58, 6.11, 7.26 and 9.69 megacycles.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- For the second time this season, Columbia defeated Penn today in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on River Field. The Lions won, 8 to 2, and moved closer to Dartmouth, both teams being undefeated, but the Hanoverians have played one more game.
DETROIT, May 27 (AP) -- B-24 Liberator bombers will soon be flying away from the Willow Run bomber plant at an average rate of one every hour.

MR. VOORHIS has written a thoughtful and provocative book From the eyrie of his seat in the House of Representatives the California progressive has surveyed the antecedents of World War II and why the world lost its opportunity to build a durable peace after 1918.

OWNERSHIP of pets -- whether a dog, a cat, a squirrel, white mice, rabbits or guinea pigs -- is one of the great joys of childhood. Judging by the questions asked and the hundreds of letters children write to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the dog is the most popular pet.

More than 1,700 Dutch merchant seamen, serving aboard Netherlands flag vessels, have lost their lives due to enemy action since that country entered the war four years ago, according to information disclosed yesterday by Alexander S. Lipsett, economist and maritime labor authority.

GARDNER COWLES Jr., president of The Des Moines Register and Tribune and of Look Magazine, has been one of the busier folk of late in radio. He has engaged T.A.M. Craven, retiring member of the Federal Communications Commission, to be vice president of the Iowa Broadcasting Company, which controls his stations in the Midwest, and also has purchased WHOM, Jersey City, for a reported net figure of $350,000.

THERE are books that in the guise of fiction are persuasive discourses in philosophy. Certain novels are not only pictures of life but commentaries on the issues life poses. "The Return of the Traveller," by Rex Warner (widely known in England, somewhat less widely known here as poet and novelist), is just such a narrative.

MADISON, Wis., May 27 (AP) -- The Capital Times said today that a concerted and organized movement to switch the Progressive party away from an "anti-Roosevelt and isolationist" to a "pro-Roosevelt and interventionist" stand was in progress.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 27 (AP) -- Rear Admiral John R. Beardall, superintendent of the Naval Academy, listed seventy-nine midshipmen from New York State as members of the class to be graduated June 7:

DETROIT, May 27 -- Henry Ford, who has hated war all his life, said today that this war would be just a rehearsal for a more terrible combat, unless greeds are eliminated, disunity in religion overcome and national "boundary barriers" leveled.

Five men died in Brooklyn yesterday between 8 A.M. and 8 P.M. from what police believe to be alcohol poisoning. All lived in the shadow of the Navy Yard, near the waterfront between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges.

LONDON, Sunday, May 28 (AP) -- The great Allied pre-invasion aerial offensive, which sent nearly 6,000 bombers and fighters to loose 6,000 tons of bombs on Hitler's transportation and defense system yesterday, roared on past midnight with alerts sounding in Berlin and the English shores shaking from violent explosions along the French coast.

NAPLES, May 27 (AP) -- German troops massing in northern Bosnia for a new offensive against Marshal Tito's Yugoslav Partisans underwent a disruptive attack by Allied planes today as other formations bombed two enemy airfields.
THE Dionne quintuplets, 10 years old today, have been taken out of the showcase in which they have spent much the greater part of their childhood. They will probably never go on show again.

CHARLES FRANCIS COE is known as "Socker" by his friends and at one time or another has done about everything. He has been, of course, a top-flight historian (in terms of fiction) of the racketeering days of prohibition, a pursuit which led him to know where a good many bodies lie.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 27 (UP) -- A communique:

Fifty-six Hunter College students have been elected to membership in the Nu chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, it was announced yesterday. Initiation ceremonies will take place on June 10 at 8 P.M. in the college auditorium. Prof. Hoxie N. Fairchild of the English Department will be guest speaker.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 27 -- One of the major objectives of the Polish-American Congress, which begins a three-day convention here tomorrow, is to unite all Americans of Polish origin behind a program "to assure the sovereignty of Poland and the integrity of her boundaries."

The National Inventors Council (Department of Commerce, Washington, D.C.) was formed in 1940 to invite inventions or ideas that may contribute to the effectiveness of the armed forces. Up to date about 200,000 proposals have been received. A few of these have been accepted.

LONDON, May 27 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower acted today to forestall the Germans from using panic-stricken civilians to clog roads that will serve the Allied armies when they land on the Continent, as the Germans did in their attack through Belgium and France in 1940.

Prof. John Dewey attacked last night the movement led by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, to separate the teaching of the "intellectual" from the "practical" arts and thereby relegate vocational teaching to special schools.

DESPITE dire warnings by the Office of Defense Transportation of crowded trains, unreliable connections and limited dining facilities, advance inquiries and reservations point to a rise in vacation travel this summer. "Any unessential traveler," says the ODT, "who gets caught in the invasion traffic will have only himself to blame if he is indefinitely stranded or finds his Pullman reservations summarily canceled.

A slightly easier tone developed yesterday in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices showed net losses of 2 to 6 points. The market was influenced by profit-taking and commission-house selling on the calling of 1942 cotton loans by the Commodity Credit Corporation.

Bou SAADA, Algeria. HERE in this ancient "City of Happiness," where the rest camp of American officers and civilians from Algiers has been established, the French Army is conducting an experiment which is a part of its overall program for better Arab relations.

Hundreds of Queens residents found their week-end shopping, their movie going and other activities unexpectedly difficult last night, as a result of a brief work stoppage by bus drivers of the Steinway Omnibus Corporation, serving parts of Astoria, Long Island City, and Elmhurst.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The need for rebuilding and reconditioning automotive vehicles, farm tractors, Diesel and marine engines and industrial engines of all types has induced the War Production Board to relax restrictions on the manufacture of many types of automotive maintenance equipment, that agency announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Two Republican Senators declared today that the Administration had attempted to call off inquiries by the Truman War Investigation Committee in several instances "where it appeared that politically damaging evidence or findings were to be made public."
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 27 -- Hoarding by coffee speculators in Latin-American countries may force the United States to return to coffee rationing, reports here today indicated.

DEVON, Pa., May 27 -- Champion Sirarno's Impertinent Lady, Kerry blue terrier bitch owned by the Sirarno Kennels of Lieut. and Mrs. Arnold L. Rose, of Rye, N.Y., was named best in show in the 24th annual all-breed exhibition of the Bryn Mawr Kennel Club on the Devon Horse Show Grounds.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The National War Labor Board's handling of the case of Montgomery Ward Co. and the consideration of that case by committees of the House and Senate this week have again focused attention on the duties and function of the emergency organization set up to adjust certain labor disputes during the war.

HE is marching (route step) down a lane. Behind him is a stretch of incomparably lovely, peaceful English countryside -- May trees in bloom, dark rich earth, newly plowed, bluebells about the fringes of the woods -- serenity, order, permanence. Before him is the blue sea and beyond that sea is the continent of Europe, which he is going to invade.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The State Department announced today the appointment of new members for the United States National Commission of the Permanent American Aeronautical Commission, which serves all the American nations in planning aeronautical developments.

The prize-winning Percheron draft stallion Olivet, recently purchased by the British Percheron Horse Society from the Fuerst Stock Farm, Pine Plains, N.Y., is the first stallion of any breed to have sailed for the British Isles from this country since the start of the war.
ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) -- The Browns moved back to second place today by defeating the Red Sox, 4 to 2, behind the four-hit pitching of Jack Jakucki.

TWO centuries of living in America are highlighted with the aid of some choice examples from the museum's collection of American paintings in the summer exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum. A tea and reception heralded the event on Thursday afternoon.
A "RETREAD" -- in case you may not know -- is an officer of the last war, recommissioned in the present one. Captain Hough is one of them and he has written a grand book about it.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Navy reported today that Karl J. Larsen, captain of the S.S. Thomas J. Walsh had been killed on April 19 in an exchange of shots with members of the naval gun crew aboard his merchant vessel.

CORPSES of malefactors continue to strew the path of the indestructible Paul Kilgerrin, private detective. He is still recuperating from his experiences in Morocco ("The Fanatic of Fez") when Colonel Matthewson of Army Intelligence begs him to undertake the job of running down a conspiracy to wreck the morale of our Army, Navy and munition workers by supplying dope at cut rates.

Discounting immediate effects of the British and American blacklists on concerns in neutral European countries, foreign traders slated yesterday that Prime Minister Churchill's "kindly words" about Spain in his address before the House of Commons had undone a great part of the work accomplished by economic warfare officials of both countries who have emphasized that sanctions would be carried over to the post-war period.

MEXICO CITY, May 27 -- In an appeal to international public opinion, the Spanish Committe of Liberation, which represents many of the once politically powerful parties in Republican Spain, today termed Prime Minister Churchill's statement last Wednesday supporting the Franco regime an "insult and injustice" to the Spanish people.

BALTIMORE, May 27 (AP) -- Newark won a seesaw game from Baltimore tonight, 7 -- 5. A two-run homer by Gene Corbett of the Bears in the eighth inning tied the count after Ab Tiedemann's two-run homer had sent the Orioles into a 5-3 lead in the seventh.

IN this story of Australia in 1846 the teen-age reader may see the origins of the common traditions of pioneering and democracy which form a bond of understanding between that country and ours. To that vast, mysterious, scarcely touched continent came Hugh Reid and his family, Scottish crofters dispossessed of their Orkney island home by the whim of a selfish laird.

LONDON, May 27 -- The impact of Great Britain's post-war policy for stabilizing employment, published as the Government's White Paper yesterday, was such that the reactions, while general and profuse, were also varied and inconclusive.

LONDON, Sunday, May 28 (AP) -- The Russians continue to hammer at German shipping in northern waters, with last nights Soviet communique announcing the sinking of four more enemy transports in the Gulfs of Riga and of Finland.

FIG trees, which are native to warmer climates and supposed by many Northern gardeners to be among the luxuries they must forego, are actually grown, with precautions, as far north as Long Island. Complete cover-ups in winter are needed, or for best protection the branches should be bent to the ground and covered with earth during cold weather.
ALBANY, May 27 -- Appointment of Richard L. Baltimore Sr., New York Negro attorney, as a workman's compensation referee was announced today by Edward Corsi, Industrial Commissioner.

ALGIERS, May 27 -- The ban on communications in code into and out of Britain will be modified to permit Gen. Charles de Gaulle to remain in touch with the French Committee of National Liberation during his visit to London, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (U.P.) -- Polish Ambassador Jan Ciechanowski told the United Press tonight that the Polish Government in exile was ready to reach an understanding for collaboration with the Soviet Union.

NICHOLAS NEEDLEFOOT, handsome and sleek as he was, brave and fierce though he looked, couldn't, in spite of winning all his battles, become king of the cats because at heart he was a fraidy cat. When, one day, a mean-looking yellow cat stalked him Nicholas began to run, but running wasn't enough.

The full surge of Allied power last week swept up the Italian peninsula -- toward Rome, toward the northern provinces, toward the heart of the Continent. An attack in great strength was inflicting on the Wehrmacht a defeat worse than any it had suffered in this theatre since the disasters of Sicily and Tunisia.

TO James Norman Hall, who found peace in Tahiti after World War I, today's Pacific island conflict is a grim approximation of war in Eden. Even though the Polynesian islands Hall knows and loves best are far from the actual combat zones, he sees in the insatiable reaching out of civilization's war an omen of the end of a way of living that was peaceful and beautiful and enormously pleasant.

THERE'S a tidal wave sweeping the world. A tidal wave of American humor. Maybe it hasn't made a clean sweep of it yet, but it's on its way. I've heard it break against the dry shores of North Africa. I've heard it echo above the roar of bombs in Bizerte and swell above the groans of agony in Sicily.

A social security plan covering 25,000 members of the New York Hotel Trades Council employed in 132 local hotels has been submitted to the Hotel Association of New York City for consideration by its industrial committee this week, the union announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Army Air Forces' Air Transport Command, announced tonight on the eve of its third anniversary tomorrow that it was putting into operation more than 200 new transports to fly additional men and materiel to the war theatres.

Since the adoption of the Federal Social Security Act with its old age assistance provision, there has been a mushroom growth of commercial homes catering to aged persons receiving this type of assistance, according to a report by the Bureau of Public Assistance of the Federal Social Security Board.

NEW BERN, N.C., May 27 -- Promotion of Capt. Fred D. Conderman of New Bern to the rank of major, announced this week by the Marine Corps, recalls how he became "fighting mad" and joined the marines two years ago to avenge his only son, Second Lieut. Robert J. Conderman, a marine aviator who was killed by the Japanese in their attack on Wake Island Dec. 7, 1941.

In a ten-page general order Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine outlined yesterday instructions and specific duties of various officers and members of the Police Department to cope with unusual disorders and disturbances.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Details of the program which the automobile industry may follow in its reconversion from war to peace time production once war demands ease will probably be available in mid-summer, the War Production Board has assured representatives of the automotive parts industry.

LONDON. FOUR new factors have combined to bring it about that this year's Shakespeare Festival at Stratford is unlike all previous wartime festivals -- a new audience, new director, new company, new method.

IF generations of growing boys have been conditioned by the adventures of Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn, one wonders how their female counterparts will be affected by the conduct of one Corliss Archer, age 16. Already, via the radio, her charms and escapades have made good listening. Four companies of "Kiss and Tell." the play version of her merry mix-ups, have met with hilarious response.
LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- A Russian communique as broadcast by Moscow tonight and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 27 -- In commemoration of the centennial celebration of the sending of the first telegraph message, Lehigh University has presented a photo-biography of Samuel F.B. Morse to the Chilean Government. Two alumni, Arthur Ward and Lewis D. Rights, made the presentation to Don Rudolfo Michels, Chilean Ambassador to the United States, at the Embassy in Washington Monday.

Conscious of the far-reaching changes that will probably take place in distribution methods in the post-war era, retail furniture stores already are actively engaged in mapping plans to broaden merchandising methods, a spokesman pointed out yesterday.

LIKE the first of their volumes on the auditory art, "Radio Research, 1942-1943," edited by Paul F. Lazarsfeld and Frank N. Stanton, looks into the great mystery of who listens to the radio and why, and comes back with a variety of carefully documented, utterly serious reports from several fronts.

Evidence of a trend to permit the Federal Government to encroach upon State rights appears in high places. Long standing precedents are brushed aside as presenting no obstacles to the superior rights of the Government.

MARJORIE LAWRENCE, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, is now busily preparing for her first trip home since 1939. Miss Lawrence, you'll remember, is a native of Australia, and on June 3 she leaves for a five or six months' tour of the South Pacific theatre of war, on which Australia will be the first stop.

MRS. GORDON PARROTT (Liz to her friends) does not object to her husband's sleuthing but she does object to his being so mysterious about it. She rather fancies herself as a detective and feels that she could help Gordon if only he would tell her a thing or two.

UNTIL after two years' absence in the country the collections of the Metropolitan were returned to the museum, comparatively few people had realized that some fifteen thousand works of art had been removed to safety and that other less valuable objects had taken their places. Despite the violent dislocation of the galleries, the show went on and the year 1943 closed with the largest attendance record in the museum's history, more than 1,300,000 visitors.

An average reduction of 14 cents a ton in the mine price of Pennsylvania anthracite, authorized on Friday by the Office of Economic Stabilization, will be passed on in its entirety to consumers, it was made known last night. The reductions will be effective to dealers on June 1 and to the public after midnight on June 10.

FOOD eaten out-of-doors -- and almost everyone eats it so at least once during the warm weather -- can be a sophisticated meal on a suburban lawn or city-apartment terrace, with caviar and champagne cocktails, or it can be a hamburger-on-bun snack, consumed on a lonely stretch of sand.

THE effect on trade of "invasion jitters" is not clearly defined because of other influences present such as high earnings and wartime shortages, but the impression in retail quarters is that nervous tension explains in part at least the expansion in sales gains over last year.
Wholesale buying slowed up just a bit last week, influenced by the more cautious attitude of retailers according to the market report prepared exclusively for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

The cut in the inspection force of the Field Service Division of the War Shipping Administration, scheduled to take place on Wednesday, reducing the organization drastically, remains a matter of controversy even after hearings held last Thursday and Friday in the Federal Court Building here by a subcommittee of the House Committee on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries.

LONDON, May 27 (UP) -- Stockholm reports today quoted the Germans as saying that a decision in the battle of Rome would be the signal for the Allied drive in the west, coordinated with a Russian offensive.

CLEVELAND, May 27 (AP) -- With the bases filled, Jeff Heath smacked a 12th-inning single today to shatter a 4-all deadlock and give the Indians a 5-to-4 decision over Washington. The Tribe had lost the first three games of their series.

Your artist's conception of the Times Square subway station brings to mind one hectic morning some twenty-six years ago when the shuttle service from Times Square to Grand Central was opened to the public. A solid mass of humanity was jammed in the Times Square station and it was utterly useless to try and follow red or green lines.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Early agreement between the United Mine Workers and Southern coal operators was expected by spokesmen for both groups today following a conference at which a basis for an accord was said to have been reached.

RUM STORY: The epicure is a person with a long and loving memory. At the drop of a hat he can recall the best moments of his life -- a glass of 1921 champagne, that last bottle of 1865 Chartreuse, the thimbleful of 1821 Napoleonic brandy, and what was probably the oldest rum in the world, a 199-year-old bottle which has had four British owners.

AKRON, Ohio, May 27 -- Charles F. Phillips, new OPA rationing chief, announced this week that "A" card holders can expect their first tires of the war when monthly allocations of synthetic tires climb to 2,000,000 a month from the present 1,400,000. The same day Rubber Director Bradley Dewey's office disclosed that passenger car tire production "may" reach 2,000,000 a month by October, November or December.

In the coming invasion campaign which may start any day now we must face heavy losses. There have already been taken fifty to sixty thousand registered nurses, until almost every hospital has been drained of these heroic and splendidly trained women.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Strict application of the Federal anti-trust laws to the insurance business would bring with it unrestricted competition and would be the "most effective way to drive the small insurance companies out of business," Robert E. Dineen, New York State's Superintendent of Insurance, said today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- A possibility that special solutions of common table salt and other sodium salts may some day be used as substitutes for plasma in treating the wounded and those suffering from burns is suggested by Surgeon Gen. Thomas Parran of the Public Health Service.

Eight alumni groups of Columbia University, including a class of fifty years ago, will celebrate their anniversaries at the university during commencement week, it was announced yesterday. Graduation exercises will be held on June 6.

IRWIN SHAW'S new play asks and answers an academic question. If you were a pregnant young wife in 1915 and were advised by your doctor not to have your child, and if, besides, you could, in a series of prophetic visions, see the course of history for the next twenty-five years, would you risk your life for the life of a child in that world?

Importers up and down the Atlantic seaboard are revising some of their profit expectations not only for 1944 but over a period of the past four years because the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals upset an anticipated tax windfall last week.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Wheat was weak early today on the Board of Trade here, with the deferred deliveries easing around 1 cent a bushel under local selling induced by favorable weather and crop reports, the start of the movement of new grain in southern Oklahoma and reports of an easing in cash wheat premiums.

MARY MARGARET McBRIDE will celebrate her tenth anniversary on the air next Wednesday with a two-hour show at Madison Square Garden, the first hour of which -- 1 to 2 P.M. -- will be carried on WEAF and NBC.

The New York State Athletic Commission, through its chairman, John J. Phelan, yesterday enjoined Promoter Mike Jacobs from advertising the proposed bout between Henry Armstrong and Al Davis, which Jacobs had planned to promote in Madison Square Garden on June 9.

A PATH should be practical and natural-looking. If a crooked or winding path is indicated, beware of pitfalls, such as curving them too much, especially if there is no apparent reason for it. A pretty good rule is not to make a bend unless there is an obstruction, such as a tree or a bush.

ADVANCED MEDITERRANEAN NAVAL HEADQUARTERS, May 27 (AP) -- Admiral Sir John Cunningham, the Allied Mediterranean naval Commander in Chief, said today that the Mediterranean was a vital artery for the Pacific as well as the Italian front and that 11,500,000 tons of Allied shipping had been convoyed through it in one month this year.

NEW YORK CITY youngsters appear to know what they want in a home -- judging from the entries in the recent living room contest for high school freshmen sponsored by the Furniture Stores Guild of New York in cooperation with the art departments of the New York City schools. A taste for livable comfort and a preference for contemporary American informality rather than past-century elegance marked the majority of the designs submitted.

Borough President John J. Lyons of the Bronx announced yesterday that he had obtained a building at the corner of 156th Street and Elton Avenue, the Bronx, as a shelter for stray dogs picked up in the Bronx.

MEXICO CITY, May 27 -- Juan Zurita, National Boxing Association lightweight champion, accidentally shot himself in his left hand today as he was preparing to leave for New York, where he had been scheduled to meet Willie Pep of Hartford, Conn., in a fifteen-round bout on June 16.

HERSHEY, Pa., May 27 -- Dedicated to demonstrating to the world the unity of the United States on the eve of the invasion of Europe, the annual conference of Governors will open here tomorrow with a background of politics linked to the Republican National Convention.

The report of the Electric Boat Company and its subsidiaries for last year, issued by Lawrence Y. Spear, president, for publication today shows sales of $94,501,694 after price reductions amounting to $6,868,845 on certain Navy contracts and after a provision of $1,400,000 for a refund under the War Profits Control Act.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: A light application of any commercial fertilizer should be given to plantings of daffodils now that they have finished blooming, and to narcissus and tulips when their flowers have faded. Water the fertilizer into the soil.... Most house plants can be transferred to summer quarters in the garden now. Repot them in fresh soil if necessary and plunge them into the ground in a protected, partly shaded place.

WHENEVER Debby Weissfinger got that "curly" feeling inside of her she should have stopped right then whatever she was planning, for it always presaged some especially ingenious naughtiness. Not that Debby meant to be bad, but life on her father's farm was too full of wonderful things to do -- most of which her family firmly said she was too young for, even though she was all of 8.

THE Army Air Forces' "Winged Victory" now has moved to the Coast, where the cameras are to take it down for a distribution wider than was possible during its run here. Like its predecessor among service shows, "This Is the Army," the Moss Hart play was eminently successful on Broadway; on two tries, the military earned two smash hits -- which is real producing.

PROFF KOCH of Carolina Playmaker fame was being eulogized. The speaker concluded: "And you, Proff Koch, while still living, have been privileged to witness your own immortality." The next day a newspaper printed the statement as follows: "Last night Proff Koch witnessed his own immorality."

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, South of Rome, May 28 -- New Fifth Army attacks are smashing into German defenses along the coastal routes to Rome, winning back with few casualties the shelltorn ground from which the Allies were driven early in February after they had advanced to points within sixteen miles of the capital.

Twenty-five thousand persons will march up Riverside Drive at 9 A. M. tomorrow from Seventy-second Street to Ninety-fifth Street in Manhattan's third Memorial Day parade since the entry of the United States into World War II. The dead of all the nation's wars will be honored, but for the first time no survivor of the Union Army's men in blue will participate.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- One hundred and fourteen leading Republicans have declared in writing that they will oppose any attempts by a future Republican President to seek a third term.
Honor to fallen war heroes was paid yesterday by 20,000 persons attending pre-Memorial Day services throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- For single-handed destruction of three enemy machine-gun nests, which were inflicting heavy casualties on two platoons of American infantrymen, Corp. James D. Slaton of Gulfport, Miss., who, according to his mother, was "always a scrapper," is to receive the Congressional Medal of Honor, the highest award for valor.

The March quarter report of the Packard Motor Car Company, released for publication today, disclosed that while the company shipped 79 per cent more war engines on only 31 per cent greater sales and billings, earnings declined 9 per cent from the corresponding period last year.

There are those who do not choose to hoe. Unfortunately, those who do not choose to hoe sometimes have no choice. That is where hoeing is different from politics. There are other respects in which hoeing is very similar to the pattern of practical politics. In the last years farmers have learned to cultivate corn and potatoes with horse or motor power; but the farm garden is still a fertile field for the art.

LONDON, May 29 (Reuter) -- The recent escape of seventy-six Allied officers from a German prison camp, as a result of which forty-seven of them were shot by the Germans, was made through a tunnel 450 feet long, which took fifteen months to dig, says Ossian Goulding in a cable from Stockhold to The Daily Telegraph.

Bumper strawberry and cherry crops fast ripening in the Hudson River Valley have prompted an urgent call for recruits in the Women's Land Army and the Farm Cadet Victory Corps, local headquarters of the War Manpower Commission announced yesterday.

Contending that the right to employment without regard to race, creed or color "is an inherent and basic right of man," the Catholic Inter-Racial Council urged yesterday a permanent Fair Employment Practices Act in a resolution adopted at its tenth anniversary meeting at the Carroll Club, Madison Avenue and Thirtieth Street.

A plea for "something more intelligent than fundamentalism and more profound and real than emergency religion" was made yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon at the Riverside Church.
Five persons were drowned in the city and near by waters yesterday.

An episode in which a 6-year-old boy who had been terribly burned and shocked by a 22,000-volt electric current was refused admission to the Hunts Point Hospital, the Bronx, and had to be rushed in a taxicab to another institution, where he died, was brought to light yesterday by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh.

CLEVELAND, May 28 (AP) -- The Indians and the Athletics divided a double-header today, the Tribe losing the opener, 4 to 3, and taking the nightcap, 5 to 3 at Municipal Stadium before 11,807 fans. Jesse Flores and Paul Calvert were the winning pitchers.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- About 60,000 high school students under the age of 17 years and 9 months, as of July 1, passed the Army-Navy qualifying tests held throughout the country March 15 and are eligible to enroll for college training under the new Army specialized reserve program this summer.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 27 -- The spring concerted bombing campaign against railway junctions, marshalling yards and factories in the Balkans and the Danube valley by the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces has considerably upset the economy and the military transportation in this region and has brought about widespread political repercussions, especially in Bulgaria and Rumania.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, in England, May 28 (U.P.) -Led by a "flying cowboy," who wears high-heeled Western boots while piloting his winged war horse, American fighter pilots here have adopted a new ground-strafing maneuver that hurtles them at grass-top height across Europe at speeds of better than 450 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Six air generals, including Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, now commander of the Allied Air Force in the Mediterranean, have received Distinguished Service Medals, the War Department announced today.

On the same day as President Roosevelt called a United Nations Monetary Conference the British Government published a White Paper on post-war plans for maintaining employment. The connection between these two events is closer than it may seem at first sight.

TRENTON, N.J., May 28 -- Sidney Hillman, national chairman of the CIO political action committee, told several hundred delegates to a State-wide rally of the Congress of Industrial Organizations group in Moose Home here today that President Roosevelt must be reelected for a fourth term if the United States was to avoid a repetition of the Twenties with its millions of unemployed and the breadlines.

Mayor La Guardia, whose denunciations of "politics" and "the politicians" have been many and spirted, declared yesterday that when his office-holding days are done he might tackle the job of bringing both the art and its practitioners into good repute with the public.
LONDON, May 28 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

The Feis of Tara, which began centuries ago as an expression of the culture of the Irish, was reenacted again yesterday on the campus of Fordham University when the United Irish Counties Association staged its twelfth annual revival here of Ireland's songs, games, legends and dances.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A medical supply program to take care of the first and most urgent needs of the liberated countries, as well as can be done in the absence of precise information from those countries, already is well under way, Dr. James A. Crabtree of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration revealed today.

Administrative tribunals are so often created as an instrument of humanitarian reform that liberals can easily be led to resent constructive criticism of administrative process. As Justice Brandeis once observed, government needs to be watched most carefully when it is acting for the best of motives.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The proposal that temporary havens or "free ports" be established in this country and other United Nations for the benefit of European war refugees was endorsed today by the National Committee Against Persecution of the Jews.

Nothing is perfect, of course, and the tax simplification bill is no exception. On the whole it is a good thing, but what of the effect on human nature? It provides that persons whose income is not more than $5,000 a year, where income not subject to withholding does not exceed $100, need not compute their taxes next March 15 or thereafter.
LONDON, May 28 (U.P.) -- A forecast of perfect fighting weather this summer on Europe's western front was published in London today.

BOSTON, May 28 -- Support of President Roosevelt for a fourth term and the election of a New Deal Congress is urged in the report of the general executive board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers, an affiliate of the AFL, headed by David Dubinsky.

Allen N. Sears and Howard V. Widdoes have been appointed vice presidents of Remington Rand, Inc., with Mr. Sears, formely sales promotion manager, to act as general manager of the system's division and Mr. Widdoes, previously sales manager of the division, general manager of the typewriter division.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 28 -- Long Island Sound's championship racing season started today with the Echo Bay Yacht Club's regatta and it turned out to be one of the kind that tempts landlubbers to take to the water. With a blazing sun and a fine dry breeze from the northeast there were forty-eight starting craft, thirteen more than were in the opening 1943 title event, and that one was held on Memorial Day.

Activities in the New York wholesale markets held to good levels last week, with buyer demands taking in a diversity of items. Suits and coats were being bought heavily, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

LONDON, May 28 (U.P.) -- President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia said in a broadcast to Europe today that it would take at least three generations before a "sane, progressive" outlook was restored in Germany.
LONDON, May 28 -- The storm clouds of coming operations are gathering in eastern Europe as well as in the west.

"Stovepipe Hat," a musical representing a cost of more than $125,000, abruptly ended a scheduled two-week Boston engagement on Saturday night after playing only five days there to a gross of $8,000. The pre-Broadway tour of "the legend with music," the work of Walter F. Hannan, Edward Heyman and Harold Spina, began May 18 in New Haven.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 28 -- Two Navy planes collided in mid-air over the downtown residential district here today and one, its tail assembly sheared off, crashed with a roaring explosion into a three-story frame house less than 500 feet from the resort's big illiuminating gas storage tanks.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- The Red Sox, hitting behind White Sox errors and passes, continued their mastery of the Chicagoans today by sweeping a double-header, 6 to 4 and 4 to 2, before 24,720. This made it six out of six for Boston over Chicago this year.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Faced with depleted reserves of livestock feed, the War Food Administration is pointing 1945 farm production goals toward a sharp reduction in hogs, poultry, eggs, turkeys and cattle.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Office of Price Administration relaxed somewhat today its controls over ceiling prices for manufacturers of a long list of converted paper products, paper napkins, facial tissues, book paper, writing paper and "other fine papers."

The greatest aerial offensive of all time is now in full swing against Germany. It is of such dimensions that, provided the present tempo is maintained, one may confidently expect that the will of the enemy to resist will be broken.
