ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, May 29 -- American infantrymen on Biak Island were battering their way against strong resistance toward the Mokmer airdrome, eight miles west of the landing beach, while cruisers and destroyers shelled Japanese positions at the airfield and large flights of Fifth Air Force bombers pounded and strafed enemy positions.

SEZZE, Italy, May 28 -- This village atop a hill that dominates others and is dominated by higher ones in an apparently unending series -- all steep and barren except for scrub -- is typical of many places that the Fifth Army has recently taken in its forward sweep.

The United Roofing Contractors Association formally charged the Office of Price Administration yesterday with "using an act of God" to screen "a subtle attack aimed at virtually bankrupting small roofing contractors." More specifically, they described the "act of God" as a Tennessee tornado.

BUFFALO, May 28 -Hitler and Nazi Germany have "only one card left to play -- that is to divide and conquer," Senator James M. Mead, Democrat, of New York, warned tonight in urging the closest unity on the Allied home front. He addressed the Polish-American Congress at the opening of its convention.

QUINCY, Ill., May 28 (U.P.) -- About 28,000 acres of farmland and the business districts of several communities were endangered by flood waters from the Mississippi River which crashed through a levee south of Warsaw, Ill., early today.

Realization of world-wide responsibilities as a way for folks at home to demonstrate what this war is being fought for was suggested in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Joseph Irvine Chapman at Trinity Baptist Church, 179 New York Avenue, Brooklyn.

Three years of unwavering Russian resistance "to the common enemy" were memorialized yesterday afternoon at special services at St. Thomas Episcopal Church. Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. The ceremonies were held in cooperation with Russian War Relief as the first of a series of events in observance of the Soviet Union's entry into the war.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has exempted from competitive bidding requirements the $100,000,000 of first mortgage collateral trust bonds to be issued by United Gas Corporation in connection with its reorganization, it was announced today.
LONDON, May 28 -- French patriot saboteurs are admirably supplementing blows of the Allied air forces against continental railway transport, according to reports reaching London from inside France.

LONDON, May 28 -- To the cheers of the Sunday crowds on Merseyside, a man from Stalag Luft 3, where forty-seven RAF and Allied air officers were shot in connection with a mass escape attempt, came down the gangway of a British repatriation ship at Liverpool today.

Richard S. Childs, chairman of the Citizens Union, said yesterday he had written to members of the City Planning Commission asking that changes contemplated in the proposed rezoning of Manhattan be made known to the public so that they can be studied before final action.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 --Three days after it had given conditional approval to a voluntary plan of reorganization for the Laclede Gas Light Company the Securities and Exchange Commission has approved the plan as amended to provide greater participation for preferred shareholders.

CHUNGKING, China, May 28 -- Japanese troops have launched a drive down the Hankow rail route in northern Hunan Province, the Chinese High Command announced today, in a possible attempt to occupy the entire Canton-Hankow railway and establish a defense against possible American landings on the China coast.

BUFFALO, May 28 -- Buffalo's Area War Manpower Committee, which until a week ago readily acknowledged it was seeking a solution to the Niagara section's acute labor shortage, particularly in reference to women, has become irked by Washington's contradictory views on the labor pool and has announced that until the Army, Navy or WPB proves otherwise, Buffalo no longer has a severe shortage of labor.

In general session for the first time since the close of the 1941 season, some forty members of the American Football Coaches Association convened yesterday at the Hotel Astor for a two-day consideration of current problems and post-war plans.
A Red Cross benefit and two outstanding photography exhibitions are included in the new art attractions due this week.

Interest in advertising and marketing is distinctly on the uptrend among college students even in war-time, according to Prof. George Burton Hotchkiss, chairman of the Department of Marketing, N.Y.U. School of Commerce.
NAPLES, May 28 (UP) -- A communiqud :

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, May 28 -- Netherland guilders instead of American dollars will be used on Wednesday to pay American troops at Hollandia and Wakde and Biak Islands, it was revealed today.

Prices of cotton last week registered their best net gains for any similar period for the last few months. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange on Saturday active futures contracts showed net advances of 13 to 30 points, with the greatest gains in the distant deliveries.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Production of lard continues heavy, but there is a fairly good domestic demand and announcement that the Office of Price Administration has lifted all restrictions on the purchases of lard by interests who have heretofore been restricted to thirty days' supply is expected to result in more rapid shipments, which will relieve the storage situation to some extent.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Navy has awarded the air medal and gold star to Edward J. Fisher of Buffalo, N.Y., aviation ordnance man, 3d Class, missing in action in the South Pacific, for helping to destroy an enemy submarine and a blockade runner.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 -- The most powerful aircraft engine in the world, which will increase the engine power of most single-engine aerial fighters by several hundred horsepower, is now at the service of the Army Air Forces, E. B. Newill, general manager of the Allison Division of General Motors, stated today.

Carrying off seven first places and scoring in all except three of the nineteen events, the New York Pioneer Club annexed the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior track and field championship for the second straight year yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

New York City is now a world fashion center without any near rival and will continue in that position after the war, the West Side Association of Commerce, Inc., declared yesterday in a letter to Mayor La Guardia expressing its disapproval of the proposed World Fashion Center here, as suggested by the Mayor's Committee under the chairmanship of Grover A. Whalen.

Bishop Francis J. McConnell, who next month will retire as Bishop of the New York Methodist Area after having served for sixteen years, was the guest preacher yesterday morning at the Metropolitan-Duane Methodist Church, Seventh Avenue at Thirteenth Street.

More than 50 per cent of women war workers queried by the Post-War Planning Committee of the American Legion Auxiliary are eager to return to their homes when the war ends. Of this number, 25 per cent made the proviso, "if my husband's income is adequate;'' while 20 per cent conditioned their statement by saying their return depended on the ability of their husbands to find jobs.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 28 (U.P.) -- Ten Army fliers were killed soon after midnight last night when their heavy bomber crashed into the wooded slopes of Mount Holyoke.

The publication in your issue of April 23 of Thomas Cochran's letter regarding the post-war possibilities of American shipbuilding industries and American maritime trade is further evidence of the increasing thought which is being devoted to this very important problem.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 28 -- While Louisiana legislators sweltered tonight in the heat of a Southern midsummer, the House of Representatives received a bill to prohibit the wearing of coats and neckties from June 1 to Oct. 1 of each year.

Ninety-nine Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, offers a partial list of free amusements availabIe today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A. M.; evening tickets after 4 P. M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (AP) -- The Phillies pounded out an 8-to-2 victory over the Pirates in the nightcap of a double-header today, after being shut out, 4 to 0, by Rip Sewell in the opener.

A modern miracle has been performed by the Air Transport Command, which celebrates today its third anniversary. A successor to the Ferrying Command, the Air Transport Command has grown from a staff of two officers and a clerk to more than 100,000 officers and men.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Sixty pounds of books a year at the rate of five pounds a month may be sent to each United States prisoner of war or civilian internee held by Germany, the Red Cross announced today.

HERSHEY, Pa., May 28 -- Although Gov. Thomas E. Dewey continued to insist tonight that he was not seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, he said that reports that he would be named on the first ballot had gotten beyond the rumor stage and that he was "doing nothing to stop that kind of talk."

The Irving Savings Bank sold the five-story store and apartment building on a lot 26.6 by 100 feet at 2419 Eighth Avenue, between 129th and 130th Streets, to an investing client of Joseph Schrift, attorney, through Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers, and Alexander J. Clarke, associate broker.

Eight members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, four Democrats and four Republicans, are now holding regular meetings with the Secretary of State to discuss international organization; the fifth session is scheduled for today. The wisdom and value of this new method of approaching the problems of peace are too obvious to need emphasizing.
Seven new films including one importation from France will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The openings follow:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 28 -- In anticipation of the opening of a Russian offensive against the Baltic States, which Berlin considers imminent, the Nazis have launched a terror campaign in Estonia directed principally against intellectuals, according to a trustworthy Finnish traveler who was there the middle of last week.

ALBANY, May 20 -- In response to Governor Dewey's request that agencies serving youth take an increasing part in programs to combat juvenile delinquency, Dr. George D. Stoddard, Commissioner of Education, has sent out a leaflet entitled, "Growing Up in Wartime -- What the Schools Can Do to Prevent Delinquency."
BALTIMORE, May 28 (AP) -- Baltimore took both ends of today's double header from Newark, 13 to 5 and 3 to 1.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped back from the all time high of 112.97 to 112.87. As a result of the same price changes, the major index of raw materials and the sub group index of farm products experienced a decline of 0.3 per cent and 0.4 per cent respectively.

THE first time Bucky Walters started on the mound against a big league tam he instantly drew warm words from Larry MacPhail. Warm? They were so warm they were blistering. The Phillies were playing the Reds at Tampa one spring day in 1935 and third baseman Walters had been sold a bill of goods by Messrs. Jimmy Wilson and Hans Lobert of the Phils that he should try his skill as a pitcher.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Total assets of 5,048 active national banks in the United States and possessions on April 13 amounted to more than $66,000,000,000, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today. This figure was nearly $2,000,000,000 more than the assets reported by 5,046 banks on Dec. 31, last year, and $7,000,000,000 more than the amount reported by 5,066 active banks on June 30 of last year.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 28 (AP) -- The annual report of the trustees to stockholders of the Central Railroad of New Jersey showed that the road handled the greatest volume of freight in its history during 1943.

Unlicensed dogs picked up in the Bronx in the current anti-rabies campaign should have the same facilities for a six-month quarantine as those soon to be available to licensed animals, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- A dilemma looms for Great Britain and the United States in plans of the Polish National Council -- now conferring in Moscow -- to visit both countries to present its views of the underground and bolster a bid for its own recognition in the event a rapprochement with the London Polish Government fails.

LONDON, Monday, May 29 (U.P.) -Red Army forces killed 230 Germans yesterday while turning back enemy attacks on a Russian-held height southeast of the partly surrounded White Russian stronghold of Vitebsk, Moscow announced early today.

The Very Rev. Frederick W. Beekman, dean of the American Episcopal Pro-Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in Paris, delivered yesterday the twenty-seventh annual memorial service for the dead of World War I in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.
CHUNGKING, China May 28 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, May 28 -- The British Roman Catholic hierarchy replied today through British Broadcasting System facilities to an appeal by French cardinals to "spare civilians" in the Allied bombing of France.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 28 (AP) -- Jersey City made it three in a row over Syracuse today, sweeping both ends of a double-header, 5 to 1 and 4 to 2, to climb into the first division, before a crowd of 7,157.

LONDON, May 28 -- Although the tension regarding the opening of the second front continues to restrict Stock Exchange business, the shadow thrown by coming events certainly has not deepened in the past week. Sentiment remains most cheerful and free from worry while, considering all circumstances, including the restrictive influence of the Whitsun holiday, a fair degree of activity has been maintained.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in the Lepini Mountains, Italy, May 28 (AP) -- Many soldiers who started on the Fifth Army's offensive more than two weeks ago got their first real rest today. A high proportion of the Germans they were chasing never got away.

Mrs. W. Barclay Parsons has sold the four-story private house on a lot 40 by 100.5 feet at 121 East Sixty-fifth Street through Pease Elliman. The property is assessed at $100,000 and has a pine room taken from an old colonial home in Massachusetts.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Rejections for educational deficiency by the armed forces are more numerous than battle casualties, according to the Selective Service Bulletin.

Joseph Chinich, operator, sold the six-story elevator apartment house at 114-16 West 238th Street, in the Bronx, to Joseph Schultz, operator, for cash over mortgages amounting to $266,000. Assessed at $355,000, the property is 226 by 215 feet and contains 137 apartments.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 28 -Radio-Keith-Orpheum has signed a contract with George White to produce a screen revue this summer under the title "The George White Scandals of 1945." The Broadway producer's last "Scandals" in films were the editions of 1934 and 1935, made for Twentieth Century-Fox.

Chocolates showing a good deal of originality in design are made from fine quality ingredients at 217 West Eightieth Street in the modest establishment of D. Kopper, Bonbonniere, a concern that is not to be confused with any other candy company of similar name.

Walter Malowan, Mrs. Stuyvesant Wainwright, Wingate Bixby and Mrs. William A. Tucker won the eastern mixed team-of-four contract bridge championship at the Park Central Hotel in two sessions of play yesterday. They scored 29 out of 48 possible points, each deal played representing one point.

PITTSBURGH, May 28 -- Steel output was off slightly last week and orders declined in volume to some extent, but neither of these moves was being regarded as representing a trend. Ingot production for the nation last week went off one-half a point to 98.5 per cent of rated capacity.

A solemn Pentecostal mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral was interrupted briefly at 10:20 o'clock yesterday morning when a middle-aged man rose from a pew in the second row and threw two eggs at Archbishop Francis J. Spellman as the prelate sat on his throne inside the sanctuary rail.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period May 20 to 26 are given in the appended tabulation:

New York City will be called on to produce more than a quarter of the national quota of $16,000,000,000 in the Fifth War Loan drive, according to an announcement yesterday by Nevil Ford, chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York. The share of New York State will be 30 per cent.
NEW ORLEANS, May 28 -- Cotton futures rose here last week. New-crop months made the best gains in spite of better weather over the belt and more favorable war prospects.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Post-war consolidation of the Army, Navy and air services under a "Secretary of the Armed Forces" was proposed tonight by Senator Hill of Alabama, the Democratic whip, who will introduce a bill tomorrow.

Responding to the sweeping Allied victories in Italy, last week's stock market advanced. The rise was only fractional, and did not regain this year's highest. Transactions were large, however, averaging above 800,000 shares per day, with a million shares changing hands on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Continued wet weather has slowed up planting of corn, but a return of favorable conditions later in the week sent farmers into the fields and rapid progress was made in many areas. Another week of good conditions is expected to see a large part of the acreage planted except in the flooded areas in the Central West.

DETROIT, May 28 (AP) -- The Tigers pounded out a 15-to-2 victory over the Senators in the nightcap of a double-header today after Washington had won the opener, 4 to 2, on Johnny Niggeling's tight pitching. Jimmy Outlaw and Rudy York homered for Detroit in the nightcap.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman celebrated the solemn pontifical mass of Pentecost in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. Commemorating the descent of the Holy Ghost upon the Apostles, Pentecost ranks with Christmas and Easter as one of the three great feasts of the church year.

BRUNSWICK, Me., May 28 -- Responsibility for preserving the nation's unity in peace as in war as a duty to those returning from the battlefronts was laid upon the sesquicentennial graduating class of Bowdoin College today by President Kenneth C.M. Sills in his baccalaureate address.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 28 (AP) -- A desperate Japanese night lunge against Naga village, north of Kohima and on the road to the vital Dimapur railhead in India, has been beaten off with heavy enemy losses, Allied headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- There are 16,000 sailors named Smith and 300 of them have the same first name and middle initial -- so the Office of War Information suggested today that home folks spell out all middle names when addressing letters to Navy men.
CALLANDER, Ont., May 28 (AP) -- The Dionne quintuplets were 10 years old today. They received a gift for which they had been wishing for more than a year -- a pony.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, In Italy, May 28 -- The great majority of the American troops who have made the sensational advance from Minturno to Sezze, capturing Itri, Fondi and Terracina en route, are draftees -- members of the new Eighty-fifth and Eighty-eighth Divisions, the first all-selective service outfits to fight in Europe.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Prices of oats followed those of other grains to some extent last week on the Board of Trade, but the market showed considerable resistance to pressure, and all futures held above the seasonal low price.

The largest crowd of the year visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday to see the 600 paintings that had been hidden for two years. Into the large central block of galleries on the second floor walked 11,516 persons, twice as many as visited the Metropolitan the same day last year and 5,500 more than the average Sunday crowd.

ALGIERS, May 28 -The use of the normal judicial process for the trial of those accused of collaborating with the enemy in France is understood to have been decided on by the Committee of National Liberation, which is expected to give effect to its decision in an official ordinance.

While Brooklyn police yesterday reported the deaths of two more men, a total of seven, from poisoned alcohol, Mrs. Sophie Krisuimas, 31-year-old proprietor of a candy store at 48 Hudson Street, Brooklyn, was arraigned in the Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of homicide and held without bail for another hearing June 5.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, May 29 (UP) -- A communique:
CHICAGO, May 28 -- A record trade was on in rye futures last week on the Board of Trade here, sales exceeding 125,000,000 bushels, of which more than 29,000,000 bushels were sold on Wednesday.

The Old Country Trotting Association will open its program of harness racing tonight at the Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I. A card of eight events will be presented, as will be the case all through the forty-two-night spring meeting, which will run until July 15, Sundays excluded.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Sharp reductions have been ordered in air-defense installations within the continental United States, the War Department stated today. This action will release trained soldiers, air-defense guns and detection equipment for service overseas.

A call to the intellectual workers of the United States and other free countries to organize and "to fight for the establishment of a supra-national political force as a protection against fresh wars of aggression" was issued yesterday by Prof.

ST. LOUIS, May 28 -- With two innings of concentrated fire today at Sportsman's Park, the Yanks grabbed both ends of their doubleheader with the Browns and toppled Luke Sewell's gang into third place in the American League race to the dismay of 17,740 rooters.

Adolf Hitler, prophet of the world rule of the German "master race," and General Oshima, prophet of the "divine" world rule of the Japanese Emperor and the letter's Ambassador to Berlin, have just met at Der Fuehrer's headquarters to discuss "acute questions of German-Japanese collaboration in the present stage of the war."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 28 (AP) -- The management and board of directors of Axton-Fisher Tobacco Company voted yesterday to recommend to stockholders that the corporation's $17,485,612 assets be liquidated.

We don't think anything that is actually taught at City College can account for the belief of 54 per cent of this year's 600 seniors, as extracted by the annual opinion poll, that there will be another World War within twenty-five years, with Russia as America's possible opponent.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 28 (U.P.) -Clyde R. Hoey of Shelby, former Governor and member of Congress, scored a decisive victory over four opponents in yesterday's democratic primary and will succeed Sen. Robert Reynolds next year. Mr. Hoey rolled up an indicated majority of more than 100,000 votes over his opposition.

DETROIT, May 28 (U.P.) -- An insurgent union local, described by the International United Automobile Workers, CIO, as "a hot-headed minority threatening the life of the union," voted 3 to 1 tonight to end a second wildcat strike at the Chrysler Highland Park plant.

LONDON, Monday, May 29 -- Central Germany's vitally important synthetic oil plants, which fuel the Nazi war machine, were blasted yesterday by 1,000 Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force with a record escort of more than 1,200 American fighter planes.

It took the Dodgers a long time to play ball for the Ebbets Field folks on a Sunday, but they finally made it yesterday, and it couldn't have been more satisfactory, for the Brooks beat the Reds twice, 8 -- 7 and 3 -- 2, before 29,556 fans, largest home crowd of the season.

The Giants practically scraped the bottom of the National League yesterday as they crashed before the Cardinals in the opener of the afternoon's double-header at the Polo Grounds but then came one of those inspired moments which made the long afternoon more than worth while to a sweltering crowd of 36,238.
The Berlin radio made an explanation of sorts last night concerning the "sensational news" promised for broadcast yesterday.

Louis Corrodo bought from the Home Owners Loan Corporation the single-family house at 2405 Eighty-second Street, in Brooklyn, through the Clark Realty Company. The City Title Insurance Company insured the title in this deal and acted in the same capacity in the sale of the two-family house at 1435 Seventy-eighth Street by Accursio Dominoi to Joseph Coppola.

GENESEO, N.Y., May 28 (AP) -- Sgt. Arthur Hasler, 37, lounged beneath a sugar maple tree in his yard today and had his fill of hot dogs as he and seventy-three relatives celebrated his father's 100th birthday at a picnic.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -The House Roads Committee will consider tomorrow legislation to cut in half the proposed $3,000,000,000 Federal authorization for a post-war highway-building program.

BOSTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Boston Braves today swept a double-header with the Chicago Cubs, taking the second game, 7 -- 4, behind Pitcher Al Japery, although outhit thirteen hits to eight. In the first game, behind Jim Tobin, the Braves won, 7 -- 3.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, pastor of Baptist Temple, who leaves this week for Australia, was described as this "country's spiritual ambassador of good-will" in a letter from President Roosevelt which was read at today's services.

Educators have a special responsibility in guiding mankind toward a better social order, speakers declared last night at the closing session of the Conference on the Scientific Spirit and Democratic Faith, in the meeting house of the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

In Rio de Janeiro 15,000 Brazilian troops are about to sail for Europe and play their part in the war. This is a novel event. It reverses old historical precedents. Fleets and armies have come from Europe to some of the countries south of us. A French adventurer seized Rio de Janeiro in the seventeenth century but was soon driven out.

An American rival to the celebrated British naval reference book, "Jane's Fighting Ships," will be published on June 25 by the Cornell Maritime Press. Called "Warships of the World," it is edited by Roger Kafka and Roy L. Pepperburg and will cost $15.

A lull in holiday travel came yesterday as the railroads, which on Saturday had reported passenger crowds 15 per cent greater than at the start of last year's Memorial Day week-end, were back to normal.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, pastor of Baptist Temple, who leaves this week for Australia, was described as this "country's spiritual ambassador of good-will" in a letter from President Roosevelt which was read at today's services.

Educators have a special responsibility in guiding mankind toward a better social order, speakers declared last night at the closing session of the Conference on the Scientific Spirit and Democratic Faith, in the meeting house of the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Below Rome, May 29 -- The main resistance to the Fifth Army's advance appears to be centered along the main avenues leading to Rome through Velletri, which is on the Appian Way and commands access to many secondary routes, and Valmontone, astride Highway 6, the other main thoroughfare, which is vital to all the enemy's defense system.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -- Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, indicated at a press conference today that he did not blame American Communists for supporting President Roosevelt for re-election. Anyone who looked at the President's record and compared it with that of Republican administrations in the Nineteen Twenties should feel the same way about it, he said.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, May 29 (U.P.) -- The General Assembly of the Church of Scotland today accepted Government pledges that the British bombing policy was directed against enemy military targets, not civilians.

That a wide divergence exists in methods used by furniture manufacturers in accepting orders was denied yesterday by mill representatives here. Nevertheless, from responsible sources, it was learned that because of the war many different means of taking orders have arisen lately.

A scale model of the proposed World Fashion Center here will be unveiled and "the site or the preferred site" for it will be disclosed at a luncheon of the mercantile section of the New York Board of Trade on June 27 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Army is breaking up the powerhouse sports teams at Army posts and sending the soldier-sports luminaries out to buck up morale in combat outfits.
Financial and commodity exchanges throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of Memorial Day. Securities markets in Canada and the Winnipeg Grain Exchange will operate as usual.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 -- The Yankees went into a painful nose dive at Sportsman's Park today by way of celebrating their leave- taking of Luke Sewell's Browns. The champions suffered their worst defeat of the campaign for, with a shower of home runs and sundry other base knocks, the Browns subjected Atley Donald, Steve Roser and Johnny Johnson to a 13-hit barrage and triumphed 11 to 3.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Late this afternoon the Senate Banking and Currency Committee completed its version of the new Stabilization Act. It will print the text tomorrow. Extension of the Emergency Price Control Act to Dec. 31, 1945, and inclusion of the Bankhead amendment tying prices of cotton textiles to the price of cotton are major features.

Though Mr. Dewey's speech last night at the Governors' Conference touched briefly on questions of foreign policy, most of its emphasis was on domestic affairs, and particularly on a subject in which all Governors have a natural and lively interest -- namely, the question of States' rights.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The resolution sponsored by thirty-three of the Senate's thirty-seven Republicans through which abolition of poll taxes is sought by a constitutional amendment ran into a snag in the Senate Judiciary Committee today when Democratic members, outvoting their colleagues, 10 to 7, referred the measure to a subcommittee "for study."

PEARL HARBOR, May 29 -- As we approach nearer the heart of Japan it becomes increasingly easier for the enemy to prepare for our next assault, wherever it may be. Hence the selection of likely and desirable objectives is always narrowing.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 29 (U.P.) -- American and Chinese troops have broken into the southern part of Myitkyina, blocking one of the last escape routes of the Japanese garrison, while enemy reinforcements attempting to reach the north Burma stronghold from the west have been hurled back with heavy losses, it was announced today.

George Krisumas, 50 years old, who was alleged to have sold poisonous liquor in his candy store at 48 Hudson Avenue, Brooklyn, causing an undetermined number of deaths, was booked last night at the Poplar Street Station on a charge of homicide.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy the new attraction will be "The Eve of St. Mark," Twentieth Century-Fox's adaptation of Maxwell Anderson's war drama. Heading the cast of the film are Michael O'Shea, Anne Baxter, William Eythe, Vincent Price, Ruth Nelson, Ray Collins, Stanley Prager and Henry Morgan. . . .

LONDON, May 29 -- An Army Air Force pilot of a Mustang P-51 flew ninety minutes over France while unconscious, yet returned safely to his British base. This experience of Lieut. William B. Overstreet of Clifton Forge, Va., is unique in medical annals.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Saturday, May 30 (AP) -- A communique

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- At the request of Senator White, Republican, of Maine, acting minority leader, the Senate deferred the scheduled confirmation today of thirteen high-ranking Army officers for permanent promotion.

The American Football Coaches Association went unanimously on record yesterday as looking with disfavor upon the intentional kickoff out of bounds and recommended to Lieut. Col. William J. Bingham's Football Rules Committee that it act as soon as possible on two changes in the intercollegiate code.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- The public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission conditionally approved today an amended plan of recapitalization filed by the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.

Declaring that inter-American unity after the war will be as essential as it proved to be after Pearl Harbor, Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, warned the United States last night against seeking to impose her will on the other republics of the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration announced today pricing methods by which stockholders of Park Tilford, Inc., may sell the liquor that the company plans to distribute to its shareholders.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Senator Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, appealed to Congress today to "release the music of school children from the domination of James C. Petrillo."

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Antagonisms toward the Roosevelt Administration which have come into the open in Democratic conventions and primaries in various parts of the South in the last few weeks threaten to flare again at the Mississippi Democratic convention to be held June 7 at Jackson.

The material supplies situation will reach in August or September the "turning point which will enable the long march back to civilian production to get under way," Ben R. Newbery, president of the National Association of Purchasing Agents declared yesterday at the opening session of the association's twenty-ninth annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Applying alike to corporations domiciled within the State and those chartered elsewhere, the Wisconsin Privilege Dividends tax, allowing collection of a 3 per cent levy on dividends on income from business inside the State, was upheld today by the United States Supreme Court.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 29 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Production of more than 2,500,000 articles of children's knit underwear and sleeping garments has "substantially met" the list of requirements set up by the Office of Civilian Requirements of the War Production Board during the first quarter of the program, the agency's apparel, textile and leather products division announced today.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- The first special offering of securities under a plan of the Chicago Stock Exchange designed to facilitate the distribution of large blocks of stocks without disrupting the market was carried out today with a dispatch which is believed to presage more closely knit financial ties with other Midwest cities.
BOMBAY, India, May 29 (U.P.) -- V.S. Srinivasa Sastri, Indian Nationalist leader, today warned the makers of the next peace to beware of any color bar.

A probable line-up of Congressional and legislative representatives for Manhattan has been worked out, it was disclosed yesterday, as a result of the reduced representation for New York County in the House of Representatives, the State Senate and the Assembly, under the reapportionments that go into effect with the November elections.

Dr. Raymond H. Mathews has purchased the house at 43 Maple Avenue, in Morristown, N.J., from John H.B Coriell through Eugene V. Welsh, broker. The house was built in 1864 and is on a plot of one-half acre with frontages on Maple Avenue and Oak Street.

The Civilian Defense Volunteer Office here announced yesterday that enough posters, urging the public to cooperate with the waste paper salvage drive, had been supplied to the Department of Sanitation for each of its 1,000 trucks to bear one on each side when they start out tomorrow morning on their regular weekly paper collection in the five boroughs.

Theeodore Ruskin, 33 years old, former president of the Metropolitan Bronze Manufacturing Corporation at 55 West Forty-second Street, was held in $5,000 bail by Judge John J. Freschi of General Sessions yesterday on an indictment handed up last Friday accusing him of defrauding the Centaur Credit Corporation, 11 West Forty-second Street, of between $40,000 and $50,000 through accounts that were falsified to obtain money for his concern.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 29 -- President Carlos Arroyo del Rio and all members of his Cabinet resigned tonight after a revolutionary junta had seized power in Guayaquil, Ecuador's main commercial city on the Pacific coast.

WITH THE AMERICAN DIVISION, Bougainville, May 27 (delayed) (U.P) -- The veteran American Infantry Division -- the only active combat division in World War II with a name instead of a number -- nominated today a former New York tailor, a former art student and a winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor among its six top-ranking "heroes of Bougainville."

Awards of $50 each were made by the Society of Illustrators to Jacqueline S. Peller of Brooklyn land Concetta Cacciola of Long Island City for work submitted in a competition held at Pratt Institute Art School, Brooklyn. Humbert Monaco of the Bronx and Mildred Zomzely of New Jersey each received $25 awards, and $50 scholarships went to five students.

As a foreign correspondent who had the occasion to watch, from Stockholm, the developments in Scandinavia during the spring of 1941, I must contradict Francis Stuart Campbell when he maintains in your issue of May 25 that "Finland has not been an aggressor in the second Russian-Finnish war."

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, announced tonight in an obviously optimistic mood that he was ready to proceed through international discussions with steps toward formation of a world security program, upon which he has been working for many months.
There were novel contrasts in evidence last night at the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation "stay-in" demonstration that left the police and passersby confused.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 29 -In an endeavor to reduce the Allies' bombings and the resultant civilian casualties, French resistance groups seem to be devoting their chief attention now to railroad sabotage.

Further marked growth in the post-war period of the cooperative movement in Sweden, as a competitor to large-scale private enterprise which might develop monopolistic tendencies, was predicted in an interview here yesterday by Nils Thedin, attached to the Swedish delegation to the recent ILO conference as an expert on cooperatives.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A survey on what is happening to the children of this country, conducted by the Association of Childhood Education here, has brought from Miss Marjorie Craig of the School Health Bureau, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, New York City, a report of a "rootless generation" growing up in the twelve highly urbanized North Atlantic States.
ABOARD A BRITISH ESCORT CARRIER AT SEA, May 19 -- The old customs continue, though war and its imperious necessities have brought a host of changes to His Majesty's Navy.
PEARL HARBOR, May 29 (AP) -- The heaviest aerial assault of the war on Ponape, a major Japanese base 440 miles east of Truk, was announced tonight by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz.

LONDON, May 29 -- Today was Whit-Monday, Britain's traditional springtime holiday. This year it was a circumscribed but none the less welcome holiday, because most people regarded it as the last "breather" before the supreme and final effort to defeat Hitler.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The abundance of eggs and the inadequacy of suitable storage space is forcing the Government to make animal feed from some of the egg surplus, the War Food Administration made known today.

Officials of the Bronx shelter of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals reported yesterday to the Department of Health three more canine rabies cases, bringing to sixteen the number since the department's anti-rabies campaign started in the Bronx March 30.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Overriding protests of Senator Clyde M. Reed, Republican, of Kansas, the Senate approved today salary increases of 5 to 20 per cent for postmasters now receiving up to $8,000 a year.

While American business "by a miracle of production" and a great contribution to the financing of the war effort has made the winning of the war paramount to every other consideration, there is growing realization that serious thought must be given now to the preservation of free enterprise when peace is restored, according to the Guaranty Survey, monthly business review of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

The finer points of floor waxing, mopping and window washing will be demonstrated at Teachers College, Columbia University, for a week beginning on June 19. With dust mops and scrub brushes instead of textbooks, a corps of janitors, custodians and superintendents will "study" the essentials of building service, or Education esp. 229 Ex, as listed in the school's catalogue.

TRENTON, N.J., May 29 -- Gov. Walter E. Edge, Republican, was accused by the Democrats today of plotting the destruction of the open primary law. The charge was made in a plank added to the platform at the closing session of the Democratic State Convention.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Weather conditions over the week-end were regarded today by brokers on the Board of Trade as ideal for rapid development of the grain crop. This brought in scattered commission-house liquidation and also pressure from professional traders.

Trapped by dense smoke from a fire in the hold of a large United Nations freighter almost ready to sail from an east shore Staten Island pier, a fire lieutenant was killed by smoke and eight of his men overcome, three seriously, a little before last midnight.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 29 (AP) -- Jersey City made a clean sweep of its four-game series with Syracuse tonight, winning, 5 to 4, in 13 innings before a crowd of 4,498.
APRILIA, May 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- The red stone Christ looks down from Aprilia's ruined church tonight on fresh blood spilled at this ghastly milestone on the Allied road to Rome.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 29 -- Bearing a five-point program of future Bulgar-German collaboration and containing an expiration date of midnight Thursday, Bogdan Philoff, a Regent, is reported by usually reliable neutral Balkan sources to have returned during the past twenty-four hours to Sofia after a trip to Berchtesgaden.

Seizure of Wakde Island two weeks ago warned the Japanese we were on our way to Biak. Accordingly, they were ready this time to give us a sharp fight and American troops nearing Mokmer, the first of the three inland airfields, are meeting strong opposition. General MacArthur says that for strategic purposes complete conquest of the Schouten group will mark the end of the New Guinea campaign.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., May 29 -- This community's advice to others puzzling over what to do about juvenile delinquency is, "Give the kids a brush and a paint box and turn 'em loose."

Howard Mumford Jones, Dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences of Harvard University and author of "Ideas in America," published on May 17 by the Harvard University Press, has been elected president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, one of the oldest learned societies in the United States.
The War Food Administration yesterday promised the nation's civilian consumers 30,000,000 gallons more of ice cream and other frozen dairy products this summer than they had last summer.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Politicians of all parties and factions have suddenly realized that, under the tutelage of Sidney Hillman, the Congress of Industrial Organizations (CIO) has taken up their trade in a manner often threatened but never realized by the CIO's founder, John L. Lewis.

THIS may be the day. That long-awaited four-million-dollar day for race track wagers may be just around the corner. The corner in question is Belmont Park and the betting fraternity will flock there in startling numbers this afternoon. The probability is that if the magic figure is missed it will be due only to the fact that the lads behind the mutuel windows are unable to sell tickets fast enough.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. May 29 (AP) -- Appointment of "qualified women as delegates to the peace conference" was recommended in a resolution adopted by the New York State Association of Business and Professional Women's Clubs at a three-day conference which ended yesterday.

Business men who "pilfer" city labor by hiring municipal employes for part-time jobs were condemned as "chiselers" by Mayor La Guardia yesterday in a talk before 250 men going to work as the Department of Sanitation's first temporary street cleaners.

Events continue to demonstrate the wisdom of the decision made by the Army Air Forces, long before Pearl Harbor, to encourage the development in this country of liquid-cooled aircraft engines. Now the Allison engine, in a twenty-four cylinder type, has completed tests with an output of no less than 3,000 horsepower.

Consumer demands for men's and boys' summer clothing, including tropical worsteds and gabardines, already have found many stores understocked, with indications that a sold-out position will be reached before long. Buyers in the New York market, as well as clothing manufacturers, agree that the situation this year, "for the average retailer," is more severe than was the case a year ago.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 29 -- Attacking those who criticize our Allies and seek to sow distrust among the people on the home front, Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff today told the graduating class of the College of New Rochelle, "never abandon faith in the things and people near and dear to you."

MERION, Pa., May 29 -- Ch. Warland Warboy, 5 years old last month, came through today to his second best-in-show award when he defeated nearly 500 other dogs to gain the highest award in the first venture of the Quaker City Dog Club.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Below Rome, May 29 -- Against an enemy goaded into using flamethrowers in desperate counter-attacks southeast of Velletri, the Allies' drive toward Rome continued inexorably yesterday as American troops lanced westward across the Anzio-Albano road north of Carroceto and its suburb, Aprilia, both of which the British, driving northward, captured.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Herbert Wechsler of New York, nominated to be an Assistant Attorney General, denied before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today that he was a Communist, had ever been a Communist, or in "any way supported communism as a way of government or way of life."

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP) -- The Third Regional War Labor Board denied today a demand by District 50, United Mine Workers of America, that the Milford (Del.) Ordnance Company be required to provide life, non-occupational accident, and sickness insurance for employes.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 10 per cent last week over the like period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the previous week the bank had reported a rise of 16 per cent in the volume of these stores.

WITH GENERAL STILWELL'S FORCES, May 27 (Delayed) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's Chinese and American troops squeezed their grip still tighter around Myitkyina today by a mile and a half advance from Zigyun forest in a bend of the Irrawaddy River to the southern fringe of the town and a gain of a hundred yards on the eastern outskirts.
HAVANA, May 29 -- Cuban people will go to the polls June 1 to choose the successor to President Fulgencio Batista, who has controlled the island since the 1933 revolution.

BOSTON, May 29 -- With nearly 800 delegates from thirty-two States and four Canadian Provinces in attendance, the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, opened here today with an address by David Dubinsky, president of the ILGWU, in which he called for the re-election of President Roosevelt, and for a post-war reconstruction program which would provide full employment.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday that he was investigating the alleged refusal of the Hunts Point Hospital in the Bronx to admit a 6-year-old boy who was dying from electric burns and shock, but he expressed doubt as to whether the hospital could be held legally responsible.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- The largest general construction program in the country's history was forecast for the first five years after the war by William Muirhead, president of the Associated General Contractors of America, Inc., at the association's governing and advisory board's spring meeting today. Operations in the first postwar year will be at a rate of $12,000,000,000, he estimated.

Sunshine yesterday was expected to continue today and to lure large numbers of New Yorkers to near-by beaches, parks and golf courses as the city celebrates its third wartime Memorial Day. With most war plants operating on normal weekday schedules and the ranks of holiday travelers held down by yesterday's interpolation of a business day into the holiday week-end, it seemed unlikely last night that any travel records would be challenged.

CHUNGKING, China, Monday, May 29 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces advancing behind herds of cattle used to explode mines left by the retreating Japanese have crossed roads above the clouds through the towering Kaolikung Mountains and penetrated the outposts of strong positions now occupied by the Japanese garrison that escaped Tatangtzu on the Salween front, it was announced today.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 30 (AP) -- Softening up enemy air strength in Rumania, the Red Air Force struck airdromes near Roman and Husi Monday and destroyed or disabled at least sixty planes, a Soviet communique announced last night.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Possibly as the result of reports of deterioration in the quality of fabrics, the Department of Agriculture has issued advice on "how to give body and stiffness to sleasy rayon."

BUFFALO, May 29 -- Evidence of a cleavage within the ranks of the Polish-American Congress as to the means of achieving a common goal, the restoration of the Polish Republic, came to the surface today with the adoption of a constitution making the congress a permanent organization without restriction on political action.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, May 30 (AP) -- A headquarters spokesman said the Japanese guessed wrong when deploying troops to combat the American invasion of Biak Saturday. The enemy apparently reasoned that the doughboys would storm ashore in a frontal assault on the Mokmer and Sorido air dromes, both of which are on Biak's south coast.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The National War Labor Board today made public the opinion of its general counsel, Jesse Friedin, on which it based its right to take jurisdiction over disputes involving foremen and supervisory employes. The board excluded bargaining rights and discriminatory discharges from its jurisdiction.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Twenty-five additional firms have won the Army-Navy award for excellence in the manufacture of war materials. They are:

The power of Surrogate Albert H. Henderson of the Bronx to fix the salaries of the employes of his court and of the office of the Commissioner of Records was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John H. McGeehan. The decision will halt temporarily the fight between the Mayor and the Board of Estimate on the one hand, and the Surrogate on the other, over increasing the salaries of forty-eight employes approximately $200 each yearly.

An airtight relief job by Ace Adam, who has answered many a bullpen rush call in the past and undoubtedly will answer many more in the future, brought the Giants their second straight victory over the league-leading Cardinals last night at the Polo Grounds.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, May 27 (delayed) -- Despite the fact that the Salween offensive is going slowly it is regarded by a competent foreign authority as the best military operation the Chinese have performed on the Japanese for a long time -- perhaps in the whole Sino-Japanese war.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- A prediction that "great advances will be made in the field of scientific research" in the post-war period and a warning that "we must expect no miracles" were voiced today by George A. Sloan of New York, president of the Nutrition Foundation, Inc., at the conference of the institute of food technologists.

In a quiet market, cotton futures prices at the close of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were 4 to 8 points higher on active months than Saturday's final quotations. Pre-holiday covering and price fixing were sufficient to give the market a steady tone.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The need for more comprehensive and detailed information on the wages and working and living conditions of employes in the transportation industry was emphasized today in a report of the Board of Investigation and Research set up by the Transportation Act of 1940.
The Texas Pacific Railway Company announced yesterday that J.T. Suggs had been appointed general counsel to succeed S.W. Lancaster, vice president and general counsel, who has retired.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- Letters from the National Women's Council of the Navy League, in New York, have been sent to eighty-four State and local councils of the group, the first step in putting on a national basis the league's convalescent service for men and women of the armed forces.

The fact that 38-year-old Rudolph Beye was a "thorough nuisance so far as Local Draft Board 213 of Brooklyn was concerned, was not sufficient justification for a short-cut in getting him into the Army. This was the decision yesterday of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, when it reversed a ruling by Federal Judge Mortimer T. Byer dismissing Beye's habeas corpus petition.

Christopher Morley, in a letter to this department, is concerned lest people overlook the fact that today, May 30, is two hundred years since the death of Alexander Pope. The thing is just possible, even if Pope for some years now has been emerging from the long eclipse that followed on his long, triumphant reign.
CLEVELAND, May 29 (AP) -- Four runs in each of the fourth and eighth innings, with an added tally in between, gave the Athletics a 9-to-4 triumph over the Indians today before 2,000 fans.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, May 30 -- Supported by Bostons that strafed the Japanese, American troops on Biak Island, off the northwest coast of Netherland New Guinea, advanced to within two miles of the Mokmer airdrome despite sniping from bluffs overlooking the coastal road.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 30 -- The combined strategic and tactical air offensive against German war power from its industrial sources in Poland and Austria to its coastal defenses in France was pressed successfully yesterday by fleets of more than 4,500 Allied planes, 4,000 of them American.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- FiveI types of United States fighter planes are successfully using rocket projectiles in the China-Burma-I llndia and Pacific theatres, the] War Department announced today. ] The planes are the P-40 Warhawk, P-47 Thunderbolt, P-35 Lightning, P-39 Airacobra and the P-51 Mustang.

GUAYAQUIL, May 29 (AP) -- A revolutionary junta seized control of this commercial city after ten hours of bitter street fighting today. The violent uprising was aimed at forestalling a scheduled week-end Presidential election.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHUNGKING, China, May 29 (UP) -- A communique:

In North Africa, in Sicily, in Italy and in the South Seas there are new cemeteries that would not be there if the American people had been willing to permit their country to be an Axis satellite in a slave world. That was the choice and our people made it. The young men who died shared in this choice, though some of many were not old enough to vote when they went overseas.

CONCORD, N. H., May 29 (UJ-Fourteen conscientious objectors working at the New HampshireI State Hospital for the Insane haveI refused institution food for theI past three days in protest over din-I ing room seating arrangements. Dr. Charles H. Dolloff, superintendent, describing the actionasal "childish performance," said that the men had agreed to end the strike tomorrow morning.

Net income of the Food Machinery Corporation for the six months ended with March amounted to $1,483,439, equal to $3.47 a share, Paul L. Davies, president, reported yesterday. For the corresponding previous period the net was $692,864 or $1.62 a share, the 1944 figure representing a rise of 114 per cent.

Bucky Walters, the fellow who seldom loses a night game, burst the Brooklyn bubble, blown up by their double triumph Sunday, when he pitched the Reds to a one-sided 13-4 victory over the Dodgers before a crowd of 27,312 at Ebbets Field last night.

The women of America have been aware of the fact for some time that the stock of ready-made clothing is depleted. We have been somewhat dismayed but not baffled by this reality. Representative Hartley should know that we are a resourceful lot. We've dusted off the old sewing machine and oiled the works.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- New steps toward enactment of a Congressional directive for a war-time court martial of Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel and Major Gen. Walter C. Short, commanders at Pearl Harbor when the Japanese struck Dec. 7, 1941, were taken in both houses today as Admiral Kimmel called urgently for "a free, open and public trial at the earliest practicable date."

NAPLES, May 29 (AP) -- Systematic German uprooting of civic machinery in Italian communities to make restoration of law and order more difficult for the Allies has been found on a wide scale by civil officers in the beachhead area.

The "lessons learned" in the Italian campaign have precipitated a "sudden demand" for new heavy artillery, and the War Production Board for the last month has been allocating facilities and getting machinery installed for turning out guns, ammunition, ammunition cases and containers, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the board, disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Secretary Hull's discussions with the Senate subcommittee were generally frank and as detailed as plans can be at this stage, it was learned tonight. A clear majority of the eight-man group, headed by Chairman Tom Connally, Texas, of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, swung to support of the Secretary's program.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- President Roosevelt reappointed to the sixteen-member United States Tax Court today four judges whose terms expire June 2.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP) -- The Pirates won an overtime contest from the Phillies, 3 to 2, before 14,438 fans tonight when Tom O'Brien tripled to start the eleventh inning and scored on Babe Dahlgren's outfield fly.

WESTBURY, N.Y., May 29 -- The trotters returned to the Roosevelt Raceway tonight after an absence of two years. And the return was a welcome one indeed, attracting, as it did, a crowd of 8,000 fans. These spectators took kindly to the night's activities sending bets rolling merrily into the win, place and show mutuel windows.
DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- After almost a month of major labor disputes, Detroit saw the end of one strike today only to have another develop to take its place.
NAPLES, May 29 (AP) -- A communique:

A Polish-American Congress, consisting of 2,500 delegates who undertake to speak for some 6,000,000 Americans of Polish descent, is now meeting in Buffalo to help promote three causes. These causes are a quick victory for the United Nations; genuine acceptance of the Atlantic Charter, and restoration of the Polish Republic with its pre-war boundaries.

Ninety-nine Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 -- Perneen Productions, in which Pat O'Brien and Phil Ryan are partners, has taken an option on the screen rights to Gene Fowler's newspaper novel "Special Extra," which will be published late in the summer by Viking Press.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 29 -- Four prominent Coptic clergymen, headed by the Bishop of Dakahlia, will leave Egypt tomorrow for Ethiopia to discuss with Emperor Haile Selassie and leaders of the Ethiopian branch of the church their recent demands for greater autonomy.

Eleven teen-age youngsters attended by proud parents and beaming teachers were honored luncheon guests yesterday at the Hotel Ambassador as prize winners were announced in the home decorating contest for high school freshmen sponsored by the Board of Education and the Furniture Stores Guild.

Baton Rouge is "all het up." Sometimes Shreveport and New Orleans admit a dog-day temperature of 100 in the shade. The capital, representing the whole State, might be expected to be more conservative, yet in the Legislature itself a member has made comic confession and protest by bringing in a bill forbidding the wearing of coats and cravats between June 1 and Oct. 1.

Bitterly indignant at the Navy for what they described as its "obviously unfair" action in terminating its contract with the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation for the production of Corsair fighter planes, 8,000 members of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, staged a "stay-in" demonstration last night in the company's plant in Long Island City, Queens.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Supreme Court upheld today an Interstate Commerce Commission order authorizing the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company to charge ten cents cash or eleven tokens for $1 on its tubes, despite protests by Jersey City officials and the Price Administrator that fare increases would be unwarranted and inflationary.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The less coddled the life, the healthier are women, is the conclusion that Major Margaret Janeway of the Army Medical Corps has tentatively reached on the basis of fourteen months in watching over the health of hard working Wacs in Italy and North Africa.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29 -- H. Russell Phillips, area rent director for the Office of Price Administration, who was a sergeant during the First World War, has found a new and suitable apartment here for the family of another Newark sergeant who is serving overseas, thus forestalling the possibility of their becoming homeless.

As the site for a post-war housing development, a tract containing 1,000 lots at East Meadow, in Hempstead, L. I., has been purchased by a syndicate through Harry Leibowitz, president of the Hempstead Land Improvement Company.

New York University's hard-hitting baseball team gained its second straight Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference championship yesterday with a 25-to-6 victory over Brooklyn College on the loser's diamond.
LONDON, May 29 -- Leaders of American and British armed forces and spiritual and lay representatives of various religions will join tomorrow in Memorial Day services.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Below Rome, May 29 (AP) -- Terrific American artillery fire turned the green shoulders of the Alban Hills into blackly smoking infernos today as American tanks attacked German strong points less than sixteen miles from Rome.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- The average 10 per cent tax deduction for contributions in the new Federal law was protested and "corrective legislation" to protect religious and charitable institutions demanded today at the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

In what is said to be the first case to come to the attention of the Office of Price Administration involving the right of a landlord to exclude a tenant who had previously been in possession of an apartment, Federal Judge Vincent Leibell yesterday signed an order temporarily restraining the Stelma Realty Corporation from excluding Janet White from an apartment at 1511 Sheridan Avenue, in the Bronx.

DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- Emil (Dutch) Leonard suffered his first defeat as the Tigers beat the Senators, 2 to 1, on two unearned runs today. Johnny Gorsica of Detroit had to offset five errors to cash in on a five-hitter. Detroit took a 2-1 series edge and its sixth victory in seven starts against Washington.

Much of the talk about war profits has been based upon reports that corporate earnings before taxes have increased from $7,390,000,000 in 1940 to $23,000,000,000 in 1943, while net profits after taxes increased from $4,847,000,000 in 1940 to $8,500,000,000 last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -- Negro employes of the Permanente Corporation and the Kaiser Company, Inc., today lost a fight against what they termed a "Jim Crow" union auxiliary in order to retain their shipyard jobs.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress for its information today a report on the recent conference of the International Labor Organization in Philadelphia.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 29 -- After squirming restlessly on a hard seat in the rear of a courtroom here today while his parents ought for his custody, Lawrence J. Boucher, 5 years old, decided he would be more comfortable on the lap of Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis, who was presiding.

Bids will be opened on June 8 by the State of Mississippi on a new issue of $2,000,000 highway refunding bonds, due on Feb. 1 and Aug. 1 in 1960 and 1961. They will be callable on Aug. 1, 1949. Bidders are asked to name the rate of interest.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 29 -- Repercussions of the coming invasion and a Soviet summer offensive on this country are now beginning to worry the Swedes. They fear that if either has for one of its results the isolation of Col. Gen. Eduard Dietl's Germans in north Finland, Sweden may be drawn into the war after a Berlin ultimatum for passage through Sweden of Nazi troops which the Swedish Government is bound to turn down.

The heirs of the late Charles Dibner, well-known Brooklyn builder and realty operator, have sold the two-family dwelling on a plot 80 by 100 feet at 8118 Twenty-first Avenue, northeast corner of Eighty-second Street, in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, to Dr. Gertrude Wexler and Dr. Hyman A. Asher.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 29 (AP) -- The Northwestern Council of Lumber and Sawmill Workers Union, AFL, called upon all idle workers in the lumber industry tonight to return to work immediately.

IT is not very fashionable, or even very tactful, at the moment to write critical books about the internal affairs of the Soviet Union. Knowing that she is going against the popular current, and deeply appreciative of what the Russians have done to defeat Hitler, Markoosha Fischer, wife of the well-known foreign correspondent Louis Fischer, says she wrote "My Lives in Russia"* with great pain in her heart.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Evidence admitted in a State court can be used to convict a man in a Federal court despite the constitutional language against self-incrimination, the Supreme Court decided today by a narrow and sharp division of four to three in the case of Samuel Feldman of New York.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 30 -- The British Fleet has gunned and bombed its way to what appears to be hands-down mastery of the Arctic Ocean clear to Russia and, for more than 100 days, has been sweeping -- free from enemy attack -- into the very shadows of the Norwegian coast as a prelude to invasion.

LONDON, May 29 (U.P.) -- A convoy carrying the latest Allied invasion weapons and troops to man them arrived in Britain recently from the United States, it was disclosed today as Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower completed an inspection of hard-bitten Canadian troops of his Allied invasion army.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The strike of Pennsylvania Greyhound bus drivers, which halted week-end motor coach travel on the line connecting Washington, Baltimore and Wilkes-Barre, Pa., went before the War Labor Board today as international officers of the striking union ordered the drivers to return to work.

ALGIERS, May 29 -- French officials here, ready to leave for London, were dismayed today by a monitored broadcast quoting a Washington dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES to the effect that the United States would not participate in the London talks between Prime Minister Churchill and Gen. Charles de Gaulle, but would be kept informed about them.

A committee, which said that it represented 278 field examiners of the New York and Boston districts of the War Shipping Administration who have been dismissed effective tomorrow, made public yesterday a petition to President Roosevelt and Congress asking for reinstatement. James A. King is chairman of the committee.
If yesterday was any indication of what is to come, all racing records, both as to attendance and betting, ought to be completely wiped out today at Belmont Park.

CHUNGKING, China, May 29 (AP) -- The new Japanese drive southward from Yochow in the widespread Hunan Province offensive is threatening Siangyin, thirty miles north of the Canton-Hankow railway city of Changsha, Chinese field dispatches said today.
LONDON, May 29 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:
LONDON, May 29 (U.P.) -- Marshal Tito's Partisans were reported today to be engaged in violent battles throughout Bosnia, Croatia, Slovenia, and Hercegovina.
LONDON, May 29 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

A loan exhibition called "Corot to Picasso," held as a benefit for the Red Cross, will open with a private view from 8 to 11 this evening at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street. It opens to the public tomorrow. The admission fee this evening is $1 and thereafter 50 cents. The show remains through June 23. The hours: Weekdays, 10 to 5:30; Sundays, 2 to 5:30.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, May 31 (UP) -- A communique:

BOSTON, May 30 (AP) -- After being blanked 1 -- 0 by Nate Andrews' four-hit pitching in the opener, the pace-setting Cardinals pounded four other Braves' flingers for a 13-3 decision to divide today's doubleheader before 20,707.
CAMPOLEONE STATION, Italy, May 30 (AP) -- German Ferdinands -- self-propelled guns that hit and run -- took a heavy toll of American armor in this sector today.
JERSEY CITY, May 30 (AP) -- Jersey City ran its winning streak to six games today, defeating Newark, 1 -- 0 and 5 -- 4. The victories enabled the Little Giants to take first place from Toronto.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Out of the experiences of all the United Nations in dealing with maternal and child welfare in emergency situations Miss Martha Branscombe, international social service expert lent by the United States Children's Bureau to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, hopes that the UNRRA will be able to distill the methods most useful for the liberated countries.

RYE, N.Y., May 30 -- Scotch Caps, Red Bell Buoy, with its guardian spar off here, was a mecca in the sense of a nautical goal for a canvas spread today with racing craft assembled for the Memorial Day regatta of the American Yacht Club.

Mayor La Guardia spoke yesterday at services honoring the memory of his Fusion predecessor, John Purroy Mitchel, Mayor in 1914-17 and World War aviator killed in a plane crash in 1918. Mr. La Guardia called for "an aviator's peace," a peace requiring "complete and thorough destruction of wrong and evil, so that little boys won't be called into another world war."

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The War Production Board has ordered sharp increases in the quantities of cotton textiles which may be shipped abroad under the Government's export program, it was learned today.

LONDON, May 30 -- Hints that Allied tactical bombing may soon turn to the canals of northwest Europe were seen tonight in an Air Ministry report that drew an encouraging picture of damage and dislocation affecting the German Army's rail and highway traffic.

Twenty-two courses in radio broadcasting and related fields will be presented by Columbia University, in conjunction with the National Broadcasting Company, in the 1944-45 school year and later, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 30 -- Helped by some of the implications of the White Paper on the Government's employment policy, plus an accumulation of orders over the Whitsunday holiday yesterday, the stock markets reopened today on a cheerful note, and a firm tone was evident in most sections.

Bulgaria is the anomaly of the Balkans, and one of the most striking contradictions of the war. Of the southern Slav peoples occupying a great part of that fractious peninsula, the Bulgarians are easily the most sentimentally attached to Russia. The Yugoslavs have no such feeling for "Mother Russia"; the "Tito" of the Pan-Slav movement might have been expected to rise in the land of Stambulisky and Dimitroff instead of in the mountains of Dalmatia.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- President Roosevelt clarified today two statements made at a press conference last Friday that gave rise to varying interpretations. One concerned his prediction that the invasion of Europe would take place this summer; the other, his statement that he anticipated seeing Prime Minister Churchill this summer, next fall or in the late spring of next year.

In addition to facing continued shortages of all types of containers, paper and paperboard products and fuel oil, the nation faces this winter a coal shortage which may call for a general cutback affecting all industry or a possible curtailment of the supply to non-essential industries, Government officials predicted yesterday at the second-day panel meetings of the twenty-ninth annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 31 (AP) -- German forces north of Jassy, Rumania, opened an attack yesterday "with large forces of tanks and infantry," Moscow announced last night, breaking a six-week lull on the main Eastern Front and denting the lines of the Red Army.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Revisions in the Maximum Export Price Regulation which modify the definition of "export sales" and eliminate export premiums for several transactions were ordered today by the Office of Price Administration.

Mayor La Guardia's 15-year-old daughter, Jean Maria, made her first public appearance yesterday before an audience of 5,000 in sponsoring the launching of a 166-foot Navy rescue tug at the Wheeler shipyards at 154th Street and the East River, Whitestone, Queens.

MARYKNOLL, N.Y., May 30 -- Battling against starvation in the Kwangtung Province of south China, Maryknoll Sisters in Kaying are dispensing food daily outside the convent gate to 700 hungry persons with funds provided by the Red Cross, according to word just received here at the Sisters' Motherhouse.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP) -- The Reds took a double-header from the Phillies, 4 to 3 and 7 to 4, today before a crowd of 21,556 at Shibe Park.

MEXICO CITY, May 30 -- North American and Mexican officials began today a series of meetings at the Foreign Office to solve several minor border problems and to study means by which to prevent the clandestine immigration of Mexican laborers to the United States.

BOSTON, May 30 -- Centralization of all Government labor agencies into one over-all organization to eliminate what was described as confusion and overlapping and to promote efficiency is urged in a resolution introduced before the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

Henry Nardone of the Columbia Midshipmen, a former New England titleholder from Rhode Island State, captured the javelin throw of the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships with a toss of 172 feet 4 inches yesterday at Baker Field.

The interior of Public School 53, at 360 East 168th Street, the Bronx, looked yesterday as if it had been swept by a small cyclone. Fire had destroyed a closet in a workshop, water from the sprinkling system was seeping through two floors, seventeen classrooms were marked with pencil and ink stains and the principal's office was ankle-deep in school records strewn over the floor.

ALGIERS, May 30 -- The time and circumstances of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's expected journey to London were surrounded with uncertainty tonight after the French Committee of National Liberation had spent four and a half hours discussing foreign relations in the light of Prime Minister Churchill's invitation and what has followed.
LONDON, May 30 -- American warrior dead of this war and World War I who were buried in Britain were honored here today in Memorial Day services held by Americans and Britons.

In the presence of a record throng of 52,029, A.C. Ernst's Aletern, a brown 5-year-old son of Eternal, won the fifty-eighth running of the Suburban Handicap, one of America's chociest tid-bits, yesterday at Belmont Park under the superb manipulating of Herb Lindberg.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 30 -- The Berlin correspondent of the Stockholm newspaper Aftonbladet reported today a roundabout story that five American airmen had been killed "by agitated people" after having landed by parachute at three unnamed places in central Germany.

With the solemnity of Memorial Day deepened by the universal realization that the United States is on the verge of perhaps its most costly sacrifice for freedom, New York and the nation paid tribute yesterday to the heroic dead of this and the past wars of the republic with parades and other patriotic exercises.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Civilian motorists will get about 200,000 more new synthetic tires in June than in May, but the time when the A-card driver will get any of them is not yet in sight, Col. Bradley Dewey, Rubber Director, said today.

During the latter days of the first World War there were some who regretted the granting of an armistice on the basis of Wilson's Fourteen Points and felt that the Allied armies should have fought on to the capture of Berlin in order to punish the Germans and make them realize the horror of war on their own territory.

We wonder if Dr. A.D. Henderson, president of Antioch College, did not think his words might be softened down a bit when he saw them in cold print. The occasion was the recent Conference on the Scientific Spirit and Democratic Faith here in town.

For the payment of unauthorized bonuses to seasonal employes, Readers Digest Association, Inc., of Pleasantville, N.Y., will be penalized by the disallowance of $50,000 for income tax purposes, Walter Gellhorn, vice chairman of the Regional War Labor Board and chairman of its Enforcement Policy Division, announced yesterday.
