A shortage of medical technicians and office assistants is proving a severe handicap to the already overloaded medical profession, Miriam Bredlow, dean of women of the Eastern School of Physicians Aides, Inc., said yesterday in issuing an appeal to young women graduating from school this year to enter this field.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Lieut. Allen T. Brown, son of Mrs. George C. Marshall, wife of the Army Chief of Staff, was killed yesterday in a tank action near Campoleone, Italy, the War Department announced today.

LONDON, May 30 -- An Irish Royal Air Force officer has just returned from Stalag Luft 3, the German prison camp, from which forty-seven British and Allied officers who attempted a mass escape were shot dead. He asserted today that the men had not been killed while fleeing from the camp itself.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The entire body of Catholic Archbishops and Bishops of the United States today sent a 300-word message to Pope Pius XII in which they expressed confidence that Allied military forces now nearing Rome "will discover a way to victory'' without bringing destruction or further damage to the center of the Catholic Church.

LONDON, May 30 (U.P.) -German and German-controlled radios maintained today for the fifth consecutive day an increasingly hysterical propaganda campaign against American and British air attacks. In a typical German broadcast,

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Instructions to 13,500 workers of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation to end their "stay-in" demonstration against cancellation of the company's contract for Navy planes were telephoned to its Long Island City, Queens, and Johnsville, Pa., plants late today by Richard T. Frankensteen, vice president of the United Automobile Workers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 30 -- Here, where the blood of Civil War fighters tinged the verdant fields with crimson four score and one year ago, the strong hand of them South clenched that of the North today in a symbol of the indissoluble unity of forty-eight States dedicated to the pursuit of victory.
Investment interest in business and apartment-house properties in Manhattan despite the long holiday week-end preceding Memorial Day was shown in the announcement of several large transactions.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 30 (AP) -- An error by a Beulah Park employe cost the management an estimated $36,000 today. When Court Flash, one of two horses entered in the seventh race by Leo Wagner was scratched, the odds board operator posted 3 to 5 against Wise Margaret and 3 to 1 against Sis Wagner, the other half of the Wagner entry.

LONDON, May 30 -- Europe on the eve of invasion is an armed camp, tense, uneasy and expectant. In the west and south the Allies' tremendous bomber offensive continues its systematic attrition of the Germans' air strength and its progressive impairment of the German railway network.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -- With labor members voting with employer and public representatives, the Regional War Labor Board accused Lodge 68 of the International Association of Machinists, AFL, today of endangering the "entire labor-employer relations and the war effort" in three States by its continued defiance of the WLB's regional and national directives.

Hanson Baldwin's account in this newspaper yesterday of life on board a Yankee-made British carrier must have given a good many readers something of the delight they used to get out of Captain Marryat and Clark Russell. You might almost think you were aboard and being waked up by the matin skirl of the bos'n's mate's pipe.

Frankie Frisch and his Pirates could claim extenuating circumstances as an excuse for their double defeat at the hands of the Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field. A crowd of 25,845 would attest to the belief that the visitors virtually slept through the twin bill, which went to the Brooks, 9 -- 3 and 4 -- 3, but therein lies a tale.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, May 31 -- American tanks battled Japanese tanks in the first meeting between metal monsters in the southwest Pacific theatre as elements of the Japanese Thirty-sixth Division launched violent counter-attacks against our positions near Mokmer on Biak Island.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 30 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's forces have cut the Kamaing-Mogaung highway in northern Burma, virtually isolating the large Japanese garrison in Kamaing and other enemy remnants in the Mogaung valley, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

BUFFALO, May 30 -- The Polish American Congress ended its three-day convention today with adoption of a memorial to President Roosevelt endorsing the Administration's policy in recognizing the Polish Government-in-Exile and in refusing to take cognizance of territorial changes brought about by use of force in Europe.

Small homes continue to lead the wartime market in most sections of New Jersey. Involved in the deals reported yesterday were a number of institutional holdings. Union City, Montclair and East Orange were among the active centers.

This week the City-Wide Citizens Committee on Harlem is endeavoring to attract special attention to the problems of those areas in our city where there is a congested Negro population. In such areas, as in most urban districts where housing and related conditions are bad, there is a high rate of crime and juvenile delinquency, a bad health record and a high rate of rejection for military service.

JULIAN HUXLEY, grandson of the great Thomas Henry Huxley, grandnephew of Matthew Arnold, nephew of Mrs. Humphry Ward and brother of Aldous Huxley, is a distinguished biologist, a former secretary of the London Zoological Society and a prolific writer. When he isn't writing technical scientific papers he is fond of writing books of a more popular scientific appeal.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The United States Government will place before the major powers in the United Nations for discussion a tentative form of organization as well as a suggested program for nternational post-war security, one that will not take from this country its integrity, President Roosevelt said today.
HARRISBURG, Pa., May 30 -- Following is the text of the prepared address of Gov. John W. Bricker at the Governors Conference here:
PRINCETON, N.J., May 30 -In the New England and Middle Atlantic States there are today roughly 1,000,000 fewer gardens planted than at about this time last year.

LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- German propagandists poured out stories today of plans to combat invasion by flood and fire, of assigning flying repair squadrons to keep bombed communications open and of salvaging trains from the scrap heap to keep supply lines running.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 30 -- German military comment on the fighting in Italy is already toying with the probability that the Germans may soon be compelled to shorten their entire left wing from the area above Cassino to the Adriatic.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 31 -- The American and Allied air forces kept up their massive invasion pounding of German communications on the Continent yesterday and at the same time landed further telling blows on the Luftwaffe, which will need every plane it can get into the air when D-day comes.

Development of new forms for perfume, made necessary by the 50 per cent cut in cosmetic alcohol supply from 1941 levels, has brought a boom in production of powder perfumes, one of the newer forms recently introduced on the market.

After a night and a day, the "stay-in" at the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation plant in Long Island City, Queens, a demonstration unique in the annals of labor in this country and viewed by both management and labor as a dire portent of things to come in the cutback and reconversion period, came to an end shortly before 6 P.M. yesterday and 5,500 workers left the plant for their homes.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Republican National Committee branded the CIO Political Action Committee activities today as "a flagrant and bold violation" of the Corrupt Practices and Hatch Acts, and asked Attorney General Francis Biddle for an opinion on the immunity from prosecution of anti-Roosevelt groups engaging in like activities.

STANTON, Del., May 30 (AP) -- Max Marmorstein's Best Reward earned a nose victory, decided by the camera, in the Wilmington Handicap today at Delaware Park, where new attendance and betting records were set.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP) -- Although outhit in each game, the Browns took a rain-drenched double-header from the Senators today, 6 to 4 and 4 to 2. The two victories advanced the Browns within half a game of the league-leading Yankees.

The first concert of the season by the Naumburg Orchestra drew a crowd of several thousand persons to the Mall in Central Park last night. Eugene Plotnikoff, former conductor of the City Symphony Orchestra directed, and the guest soloist was Maria Noelte, coloratura soprano.

Slightly disappointing was the report of yesterday's holiday afternoon performances on Broadway. A multitude of factors, such as competition of ball games, the balmy weather, and Memorial Day exercises were given as the contributing causes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30 -- Hedy Lamarr win be starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "Diamond Rock," a novel by the English writer, Alec Waugh. The domestic-triangle story, which has a West Indies locale, will be produced by Edwin Knopf when Miss Lamarr is finished with Warner Brothers' "The Conspirators."

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 30 -- Declaring that the very existence of State and local government was threatened by "an ever-growing centralization of power in Washington," Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio further developed the States' rights philosophy of the thirty-sixth annual Governors' conference tonight by enunciating tax and fiscal proposals to overhaul the whole fiscal structure of the nation.

LONDON, May 30 -- The Manchester Guardian, in an editorial written for tomorrow's edition, describes certain ideas expressed in THE NEW YORK TIMES about Britain's proposed post-war employment policy as "nonsense."

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 24:
LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- The people of Great Britain worked off invasion tenseness over the three-day Whitsuntide holiday by attending sports events in record-breaking numbers.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, NAPLES, May 30 (AP) -- Two veteran Flying Fortress groups of the Fifteenth Air Force received Presidential citations today for combat achievement on the Mediterranean front.

Annual graduation exercises of the College of Mount St. Vincent were held at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the college, Riverdale, the Bronx, when Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided, and presented the collegiate awards as well as diplomas to a graduating class of 105 young women.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today suggested amendments to the Standard Gas and Electric Company's plan of reorganization, filed in March, 1943, and granted the company ninety days in which to make the proposed changes.

An honorary Doctor of Laws degree was conferred upon Harry James Carman, dean of Columbia College, by Dr. Clarence C. Stoughton, president of Wagner Lutheran College, at the annual spring commencement exercises yesterday in the auditorium of the college on Grymes Hill, S.I. The exercises were attended by 400 friends and relatives of the eighteen graduates who received Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science degrees.

Pearl Buck will be one of the speakers at the East and West Association's forum on June 7 at 8 P.M. at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. "The Atlas of Global Geography" by Erwin Raisz, "Look at the World" by Richard Edes Harrison, to be released June 26 by Knopf, and "A War Atlas for Americans," prepared by the Council on Books in Wartime and the Office of War Information, will be discussed.

" The Queen and the Cardinal," a French historical romance set in the seventeenth century, will have its local premiere today at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse. The film, which was directed by Abel Gance, stars Tania Fedor as Anne of Austria, Queen Mother of Louis XIV, and Robert Le Vigan as Cardinal Mazarin.

New York City's custom-slaughtering program has been out of gear since May 3, when the Office of Price Administration freed virtually all meats except beefsteaks and roasts from ration points and cut the red-point allotment by one-half.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The request by Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, renewed in his telegram yesterday to Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan, for an open court-martial to inquire into the causes of the disaster at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, is being echoed in Congress, as it was when previously made.

ALBANY, May 30 (AP) -- An industrial development campaign, the first in the history of the State, was started today by the Commerce Department with a call to action for post-war business expansion aimed at setting a new high mark in peacetime employment.
CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- Backing the steady pitching of Bill Dietrich and Orval Grove, the White Sox checked the Athletics' spurt today by sweeping a double-header, 5 to 1 and 2 to 1, before 15,037.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP) -- A crowd of 34,368 that wagered $1,401,760, the largest handle in Massachusetts racing history, saw Mintlock, a 7-1 shot, score a head decision for Owner Charlie Ruff of Ravenna, Ohio, at Suffolk Downs today, in the Joseph A. Tomasello Handicap, $5,000 added six-furlong feature.

Rex W. Hovey, director of the paper division of the War Production Board, warned civilians yesterday that new orders would reduce still further their use of bags, boxes, containers and many types of paper. Only the limited success of the nation-wide wastepaper salvage campaign, he told the convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, had made as much paper available for civilian use as there had been so far.

Simultaneously with an announcement by President Roosevelt that this country is ready with the first draft of a definite post-war organization for world peace and security, Secretary Hull has issued invitations to Britain, Russia and China to begin as early as possible informal conversations on that subject in Washington.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 30 (AP) -- Gen. Luis Larrea Alba assumed leadership tonight of the military provisional government that took control in Ecuador after revolutionists, in a bloody coup yesterday at Guayaquil, forced the resignation of President Carlos Arroyo del Rio.

One of the largest realty deals for several months in the downtown section of Brooklyn has been closed through the sale by the Dime Savings Bank of the four-story concrete commercial structure at 166-172 Livingston Street to a syndicate known as the 166-172 Livingston Street Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- President Roosevelt signed at 7 o'clock last night the new tax law whereby an estimated 30,000,000 Federal income tax payers will be relieved in future years of filing ax returns supplementing the withholding of payments from their salaries or wages.

MONTREAT, N.C., May 30 (AP) -- A chaplain-veteran of Pearl Harbor, Frederick Volbeda, of Washington, told the general assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church that his own commanding officer once heard him preach repentance and actual punishment and swore he would have "no hell-fire preaching" on his ship.

PEARL HARBOR, May 30 -- The important enemy naval base and staging station on Saipan Island was attacked Sunday by long-range Liberator bombers of the Seventh Army Air Force and the Navy's Fleet Air Wing 2, Fleet Headquarters announced today.

AT GENERAL STILWELL'S HEADQUARTERS in North Burma, May 27 (Delayed) -- The battle for northern Burma is now in its decisive phase. Engagements that will determine, for a time at least, the outcome of the North Burma hostilities are shaping toward a conclusion that may come in a few days.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CLEVELAND, May 30 (AP) -- The seventh-place Indians swept both ends of a Memorial Day double-header from the Red Sox today, winning the nightcap, 4 to 3, behind the seven-hit pitching of Allie Reynolds, after staging a six-run splurge to take the opener, 9 to 3.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- A "noticeable decrease" of absenteeism among workers in the country's war plants has resulted from an industrial plant feeding program developed by the War Food Administration, the annual conference of the Institute of Food Technologists was told today by W.E. Broeg, head of the program.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., May 30 -- About 44,000 miners remained out of the anthracite mines of eastern Pennsylvania today in spite of the pleas of Government and union officials who called upon them to sacrifice their traditional Memorial Day holiday to help relieve the acute coal shortage.
May I add my appeal to the one which appeared recently in your columns, suggesting that the Metropolitan Museum of Art be opened to the public at least one night each week.

CHUNGKING, China, May 30 (AP) -- Japanese forces who landed on the southeastern shore of Lake Tungting have breached the Chinese second line of defense at the Milo River, forty miles north of Changsha, the Chinese High Command acknowledged tonight.

DETROIT, May 30 -- The genial, rotund Steve O'Neill today found the antidote for the peculiar complaint which has been making his Tigers something of a flop at Briggs Stadium. It is a mixture of Dizzy Trout and the left-handed Hal Newhouser, with a touch of the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Net profits after taxes of the 13,274 insured commercial banks in 1943 amounted to $638,000,000, the highest figure reported since the inauguration of deposit insurance, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, announced today.

SAN JUAN, P.R. May 30 -- Lieut. Comdr. Virgil Baker, USN, retired, has filed a claim for compensation in the Federal District Court against the Navy Department for its seizure two years ago of about 36,000 square meters of land which the Navy leased to him in 1921 for 999 years.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Below Rome, May 30 -- As the British and American beachhead forces drove into the fringes of the Alban Hills nearer Velletri and Lanuvio, Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark declared this morning at an American cemetery at Nettuno that the Allies now stood on the threshold of Rome and that, "before many days have passed, we shall have freed this first of the European capitals from Nazi tyranny."

Putting on a tiptop show of old country soccer, notwithstanding lack of regular practice, the eleven from the Royal Air Force Navigation School at Hamilton, Ont., held a powerful All-Star team representing four of the American League clubs to a 3-3 tie yesterday at Starlight Park before 4,000 fans.
NAPLES, May 30 (AP) -- A communique:

Betty Humby Beecham, the pianist, wife of Sir Thomas Beecham, will appear as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at the Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday evening, June 24, it was announced yesterday. Lady Beecham will play the Saint-Saens Concerto No. 2 in G Minor under the direction of Sir Thomas who will conduct during the entire opening week.
I have been thinking about your recent editorial "Minority Parties." I would like you to go further into the subject and write on some such questions as the following:

A powerful offensive has been launched by Japan against Changsha in Hunan Province. The new drive is coordinated with the campaign already under way, farther north in Honan, and is intended to cut China in two by opening the trunk rail line from Canton, on the south coast, all the way through to Peiping and Manchuria.

DETROIT, May 30 (AP) -- Governmental agencies today continued their efforts to stop strikes of drug firm workers and bakery truck drivers as showdowns with the national and regional War Labor Boards approached.

Children's happy voices resounded yesterday through Prospect Park in Brooklyn and older folk, too, wandered across the lawns in peaceful, holiday mood. However, before the gates clattered shut on the crowd of 30,000, many had witnessed the spectacle of two angry deer -- father and son -- fighting in the primitive fashion of the wild, a battle that ended in death.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 30 (UP) -- Acommunique

On this year's Memorial Day many thousands in the metropolitan area evidently discovered the fun of spending a holiday at home, working at an accumulation of odd jobs, and the throngs that did get away traveled only short distances to resorts and beaches.

ANZIO, Italy, May 30 -- The first commemorative service for the Fifth Army's dead in this area was held in the American military cemetery today while the war in which they fought and died rolled on in the near-by hills.

British and American representatives insist in Lisbon that Portugal must entirely suppress all exports of wolfram to Germany and, according to diplomatic sources, an agreement may be expected to mature at an early date.
Carrying on in the face of restrictions and losses of oarsmen to the services, the New York Rowing Association maintained the continuity of its annual Memorial Day regatta yesterday on the Harlem.
LONDON, May 30 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Segregation of Negroes has seriously affected New York public schools, according to a statement issued yesterday by Frank E. Karelsen Jr., chairman of the subcommittee on education of the City-Wide Citizens Committee on Harlem, on behalf of the subcommittee.

Clarence H. Neal, an influential figure in Tammany Hall under the last four Tammany leaders, announced yesterday that he had resigned his district leadership to accept one of the newly created ex officio posts on Tammany's executive committee.

Paced by a trio of homers which Mel Ott thumped into the stands with varying degrees of intensity, the Giants yesterday dealt the Cubs' hopes of elbowing their way out of the National League cellar a couple of damaging blows by tripping Charlie Grimm's Chicagoans in both ends of the double-header at the Polo Grounds.

THE horse players not only needed strong bankrolls at Belmont yesterday. They also needed strong backs and strong muscles. The entire Chicago Bears' football team would have had difficulty in driving a wedge to the mutuel windows, so densely did the record throng congregate. Despite the difficulties imposed on the betting public, it still managed to show what a dauntless person the true lover of the improvement of the breed is.
The Eastern Cooperative Wholesale established a new record volume during 1943 when its sales reached $3,210,810, it was announced yesterday. The volume represented a 19.7 per cent increase over 1942.

This is nice weather for ducks -that is, for buying them -- if we are to judge from the records of the War Food Administration, which show that receipts are heavy at the moment. Last week 970,420 pounds came into the city, compared with 872,148 for the same period a year ago. Since Jan. 1, arrivals have totaled 800,000 more pounds than those chalked up for the first five months of 1943.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, pleaded today for Presbyterian patience in the development of a plan for the merger of the Presbyterian and Episcopal Churches.

Calling attention to the need for post-war business activity to create employment for returning war veterans, the State of New York through the Department of Commerce launches today an advertising campaign on industrial development, the first in its history.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Career Angel," the new comedy by Gerald M. Murray, tomorrow night at the National Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Catholic Center for the Blind.

CHUNGKING, China, May 30 (U.P.) -- Aided by a return of good weather, which opened the way for strong American air support, Chinese troops in western Yunnan Province have captured Lengshuikou, the highest village on the Mamien trail leading across the towering Kaolikung Mountains toward Burma, a Chinese communique said today.

CHUNGKING, China, May 30 (U.P.) -- Spearheaded by crack shock troops brought from Manchuria, 150,000 Japanese have now been thrown into the enemy offensive in the Hunan-Hupeh Provinces border area and the drive already has developed into the biggest in the rice-bowl area since the war started nearly seven years ago, Chinese military authorities said tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- President Roosevelt believes that Spain has been less than satisfactory in her operations as a neutral power, he told a news conference today, thereby indirectly taking issue with Prime Minister Churchill, who paid high compliments to the Franco regime in his recent speech before the British House of Commons.

Night and day the crash of bombs echoes across western Europe while the artillery of our advancing armies in Italy rolls north. Meanwhile, until yesterday, only minor clashes have broken the brooding silence of the eastern front. Now the Russians announce that a heavy German attack north of Jassy in Rumania has driven "an insignificant wedge into our defenses."

Lumber and plywood are today the most critical materials related to the war effort; far more critical than steel, aluminum or copper. For shipping the vast quantities of materials needed to carry on the war and to sustain our men in the various fields of operation, both lumber and plywood are indispensable.

On the authority of Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, speaking as regional director of the War Manpower Commission, there is no lack of jobs for the 8,000 workers who have been thrown out of employment by the Navy's termination of its contract with the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

A nation-wide banking group of fifty-nine investment houses, headed by Smith, Barney Co., Blyth Co., Inc.; the First Boston Corporation, Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers, won yesterday through competitive bidding the award of a new issue of $41,533,000 of refunding revenue bonds of the Consumers Public Power District of Nebraska, due from 1946 to 1972.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York suggested today in a letter to a House subcommittee investigating production in ship repair yards that suppression of "gambling and other chiseling of workers' wages in war plants and shipyards" be turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 31 -- Acting Prime Minister Daniel G. Sullivan laid a wreath on the National War Memorial today in tribute to the American dead in World Wars I and II as New Zealanders held special ceremonials to mark Memorial Day.

Warning that "an impoverished Germany will continue to be a menace to the peace of the world," a group of prominent Protestant ministers and laymen who had been called together by the Commission on a Just and Durable Peace to make an independent study of post-war Europe urged yesterday firm but not vindictive treatment of Germany by the victorious Allies.

ALBANY, May 31 -- Governor Dewey named today eight more members of the twenty-three-member commission on discrimination created by the Legislature to investigate alleged discriminatory practices and recommend legislation to eliminate discrimination due to race, color or creed.

JERSEY CITY, May 31 (AP) -- Newark snapped Jersey City's winning streak at six games tonight, defeating the Little Giants, 10 to 4. As a result the Jerseys dropped from an undisputed lead into a first-place tie with Buffalo.

An underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation will offer today $6,040,000 of Texas Pacific-Missouri Pacific Terminal Railroad of New Orleans 3 3/8 per cent mortgage bonds, series A, due 1974. The price will be 101.95 and accrued interest, to yield about 3.27 per cent to maturity.

The Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury returned yesterday an indictment linking an agent of a Brooklyn concern to one of the most extensive black market liquor operations thus far disclosed by Federal investigators. He is Isidore Fried, 57 years old, who said he lived in the Essex House, Manhattan.

Three physicians were arrested last night on charges of abortion and conspiracy after a raid on the elaborately furnished "clinic" of one of them, Dr. Louis Stanley Barnett, on the ground floor of 3 West Seventy-first Street.

The operators of El Morocco, East Side night club; El Chico, a Greenwich Village resort, and Shine's Restaurant, near Pennsylvania Station on Seventh Avenue, were among ten restaurant proprietors cited in Federal court yesterday by the Office of Price Administration.

Sterling Drug, Inc., announced that acquisition of the assets, business and good-will of Frederick Stearns Co., pharmaceutical manufacturers, was assured when directors of Stearns met in Detroit yesterday and voted to retire that company's preferred stock on June 30 at 105 and accrued dividends.

BOSTON, May 31 -- Elimination of racketeering from the ranks of the American Federation of Labor by means more effective than mere "moral suasion" was demanded today by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers, an AFL affiliate, in an address before the convention of his union.

JOLLY CHOLLY GRIMM is a cheerful gent by nature, and he is not particularly downcast by the present lowly standing of the Chicago Cubs, the team he inherited from Jimmy Wilson a few weeks ago. "We'll get straightened out soon," he said with understandable optimism. "Nobody is hitting much, and that sort of thing can't go on forever."

PEARL HARBOR, May 31 (AP) -Army and Navy planes made their most widespread attack of the war last Monday on Japan's Kurile Islands, striking less than 1,000 miles from Tokyo in battering enemy positions on four islands.

Two films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Capitol the newcomer will be "Tender Comrade," a topical romantic drama produced by RKO and starring Ginger Rogers. Directed by Edward Dmytryk from a story by Dalton Trumbo, the film features Robert Ryan, Ruth Hussey, Patricia Collinge, Jane Darwell, Kim Hunter and Mady Christians. . . .

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Below Rome, May 31 (U.P.) -- Apparently angered at their comrades for surrendering, German machine-gunners and snipers sprayed captured Germans with bullets today as they were being transported to the rear atop American tanks.

WITH SIXTH ARMY FORCES, Mokmer Village, Biak Island, May 29 (delayed) -- The Japanese crouched in limestone caves and thickly forested ridges and waited while American troops pushed along the beach road below.

LONDON, May 31 -- The American Red Cross, which has been conspicuously present in every theatre of the war where American service men have engaged the Axis foe, has completed its plans for the coming invasion and now awaits D-day.

HERSHEY, Pa., May 31 -- A resolutions committee on which the Democrats outnumbered the Republicans, 3 to 2, obtained today the unanimous adoption by the Governors' conference of resolutions demanding the return to the States of powers granted to the Federal Government because of the war emergency and urging Federal consultation with the States in the future concerning projects affecting more than one State.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Ceiling prices for nearly 10,000,000 items of low-cost clothing for men and women, which are proposed as "minimum requirements" for civilians during the third quarter of the year are being set by the Office of Price Administration.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., delivered in the half-year ended on March 31, approximately $112,000,000 worth of war products, an increase of 31 per cent over the corresponding period of the previous year, Ward M. Canaday, president, reported in a statement to stockholders released today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- In the face of a day-long barrage of arguments and objections from attorneys defending the twenty-nine men and women on trial in Federal Court here on charges of seditious conspiracy, the prosecution finally obtained today the "provisional" admission of evidence showing efforts of the pro-Hitler Friends of New Germany to organize in the United States in 1933.

An attempt by Magistrate Abner C. Surpless to influence the policy of an American Federation of Labor union backfired against the magistrate yesterday but won a suspended sentence for a confessed black marketeer in coal.

Two youths were under arrest yesterday on charges of breaking into Public School 53, at 360 East 168th Street, the Bronx, Monday night, setting fire to a clothes closet, stealing $50 worth of carpentry tools and doing extensive damage to seventeen classrooms and the principal's office.

Scoring all its runs in the first two innings Columbia defeated Princeton, 4 -- 3, at Baker Field yesterday for its fourth Eastern. Intercollegiate League victory in as many starts and tying Dartmouth for the lead. The Lions and the Hanoverians will meet in a double-header Saturday, alumni spring reunion day, at Baker Field.

Also Asks Business to Play Greater Role in Surplus Sale to Avert Disaster Over $500,000,000 awaits industry on terminated contracts where no claims have yet been filed with contracting Government agencies, Col. D.N. Hauseman, Director of the Army Service Forces Readjustment Division, War Department, disclosed yesterday before the closing sessions of the twenty-ninth annual meeting of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Hotel Waldorf Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Whenever Prime Minister Churchill has made a radio speech or an address to the House of Commons in which he has given in detail important news for the first time, the President has seemed to be fired by a spirit of emulation. This has usually followed American comment in which the reporting methods of this Government have been unfavorably compared with those of Mr. Churchill's.

The wisdom of Solomon might be a help to Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder in deciding how, if at all, a loan of 50,000 Russian rubles made in 1918 should be repaid. The problem grew out of a suit brought by Mrs. Tatiana Jemtchoujnikov to recover $24,600 on a loan she said was made by her late husband, George Jemtchoujnikov, to Jacques Zolotnitzky in Kiev, Russia, on Nov. 9, 1918.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:...

CHUNGKING, China, May 31 (AP) -- A later communique: in northern un frhtlng south o! the Stnchiang River was transferred to the north bank of the Mllo River on a line east and west of Changlochleh In the evening.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, below Rome, May 31 -- While the Allies' main armies in Italy swept over more ground in a swift surge nearer the Rome battle area, the Germans maintained their desperate though slipping grip on the Lanuvio-Velletri-Valmontone line today, throwing in all available troops to keep the Allies at all costs from gaining a foothold on the Alban Hills, which control the direct approach to Rome.

LONDON, May 31 -- The German Army is completing its preparations for the great dual offensive that it expects in the east and west. In northwestern Europe the field armies, especially the panzer divisions, have been strengthened. A "spoiling attack" has been mounted on the Russian front near Jassy in an attempt to delay the Red Army's general offensive, which Allied observers in Moscow now say is imminent.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP) -- A $1,000,000 capital stock issue was registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Germantown Fire Insurance Company, a "proposed Pennsylvania corporation," to be incorporated by the Mutual Fire Insurance Company of Germantown, whose business and property it will take over.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association and the War Production Board joined yesterday in calling attention to two recent rulings designed to increase the labor supply in the logging and forest industry field, on which the nation's paper supply is dependent.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The War Production Board will send an aircraft expert to the Long Island City, Queens, plant of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation tomorrow to survey the possibilities of using the facilities there to turn out aircraft parts for the Chance-Vought and Goodyear Company-factories now working on the production of Corsair fighter planes.

BOSTON, May 31 (AP) -- Homers by Max Macon and Connie Ryan forced southpaw Max Lanier to accept his first setback in seven starts today as the Braves defeated the pace-setting Cardinals, 5 -- 1, behind right-handed Red Barrett.

The Leopold Schepp Foundation sold to Charles Lehrer the four-story dwelling at 44 West Fifty-fifth Street, near Rockefeller Center, through the Robert R. Rainey Company, broker. The parcel is 20 by 100.5 feet and is assessed at $47,000.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, June 1 -- The position of the American forces on Biak Island, our most advanced position off the northwest coast of New Guinea, is most difficult. It is possible that strong measures will have to be taken to keep it from deteriorating.

Women who join the armed forces will find themselves after the war closer to the men who have been on the fighting fronts, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday, addressing an audience of 18,000 at Madison Square Garden who gathered to celebrate the tenth radio anniversary of Mary Margaret McBride.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 31 (U.P.) -Dr. Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra, exiled leader of the Ecuadorean Democratic Alliance, assumed the Presidency of Ecuador today, receiving the reins of government from the hands of the revolutionary junta that forced President Carlos Arroyo del Rio's resignation Monday.

A Brooklyn plant, which has been working around the clock processing coffee for our armed forces and a Manhattan food company, which has been turning out great amounts of pork mix for the Red Army, soon will fly the War Food Administration's green honor flag, it was announced yesterday by Chester A. Halnan, area supervisor of the WFA's office of distribution.

The growing understanding and friendship between the peoples of the United States and Russia were emphasized yesterday at commemorative ceremonies held on the steps of the Subtreasury Building, Nassau and Wall Streets. This was the first of a series of meetings scheduled for this month, and sponsored by Russian War Relief, to mark the third year of Russia's resistance to Nazi invaders.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Sales of independent retailers showed an almost unchanged dollar volume in April, compared with April last year and a 3 per cent decrease, compared with March, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

LONDON, May 31 -- The offensive in Italy has now reached a critical phase, for, although the main territorial gain -- the occupation of Rome -- seems to be assured, the destruction of the German Tenth and Fourteenth Armies hangs in the balance, for the Germans are making determined efforts to extricate their forces from an extremely difficult position.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -More than 1,000 passengers and members of the crew were rescued today from the Henry Bergh, a Liberty ship bringing more Navy men back from the Pacific war zones, after she went aground in a heavy fog before dawn today on the Farallon Islands, thirty miles west of the Golden Gate.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church closed its week of sessions today with the adoption of a resolution demanding not only full freedom for religious worship, but also freedom "to propagate their faith" anywhere.

The official temperature in the city reached 86.8 degrees at 4:30 P. M. yesterday, making it the hottest day of the year. At La Guardia Field the reading at 5 P. M. was 91, and sprinkler valves in one of the hangars melted, showering an airliner and several mechanics with water.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A revised draft of the George-Murray industrial demobilization bill has been submitted to the Post-War Planning and to the War Contracts Subcommittees of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, Senator James E. Murray reported today.

National advertisers were disappointed to hear the results of the Gallup poll on Victory gardens showing approximately 1,000,000 fewer gardens in the East, it was learned yesterday. From three to four times more space was devoted this year than last on this phase of the home-front fight and advertisers felt that a better showing should have been forthcoming.

MOSCOW, May 31 -- Ukrainian peasants, plowing fields and planting crops sometimes as close as six to ten miles from the firing lines, have exceeded their quota for grain sowing by 1,260,640 acres, it was announced officially today.

LONDON, May 31 -- Gen. Kazimierz Sosnkowski, Polish Commander in Chief, was reported in Polish circles today to be ready to resign as successor-designate to the Presidency as soon as another successor is chosen. President Wladyslaw Raczkiewicz has yielded to anti-militarist sentiment in the Polish National Council and decided to relieve General Sosnkowski of his political office.

WASHINGTON , May 31 -- American aircraft plants produced about 8,700 planes in May, most of them combat craft to support the coming land invasion of Europe, it was learned from aircraft production officials today.

Like Governor Dewey, Governor Bricker is disturbed by "the ever-growing centralization of power in Washington." This was the one subject most strongly emphasized during the Governors' Conference at Hershey, and there can be little doubt that the concern expressed by these two Republican Executives is shared by many thoughtful people, irrespective of party lines.

Thirteen years ago Frank Cassata was speeding along West Side Highway. He received a summons for speeding and another for failing to have a chauffeur's license. Yesterday, he pleaded guilty to both charges and was fined $10 on each.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- The American Democratic National Committee, through its chairman, Dr. Gleason Archer, stated today that it was considering the following steps as mean of defeating the reelection of President Roosevelt:

Thomas Fatone, 44 years old, of 1012 East Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, who is accused of having sold to a Brooklyn storekeeper the poison liquor that caused fourteen deaths since last Saturday, was booked last night at Poplar Street Station, Brooklyn, on a charge of homicide. He will be arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Seven months after he had taken possession of 3,000 bituminous coal mines in the Government's second seizure since May 1, 1943, Secretary Ickes announced today that he was returning to private possession mines producing 60 per cent of the country's tonnage.

The increase in the amount oil Federal Reserve credit required by the member banks of the Federal Reserve System was more than $1,000,000,000 in May, bringing the total increase in the last year to about $8,000,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in the June issue of its monthly review.

An appeal to women to aid Jewish refugees in Europe and to urge all political parties to adopt planks condemning religious or racial prejudice was made yesterday by speakers at the opening session of the biennial convention of the women's division of the American Jewish Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The huge landing craft program for the Navy has surpassed all production estimates by 70 per cent in the last six months, James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, stated today.
Will you grant me space for comment on a great American, Hiram Halle, whose death weighs heavily us on the hearts of all of us who knew him?

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Office of Price Administration ruled today that merchants selling low-priced women's and children's clothing may apply for relief from the provision restricting their sales to price ranges prevailing during the first five months of 1942.

Flotation of the largest block of public authority securities since February, 1940, lifted the total of new bond offerings here in May to $148,728,000 for twenty-one issues, an amount unequaled in any month ' ce January, 1943. It compared ' $55,350,000 for ten emissions in the lreceding month and $135,098,000 for sixteen flotations Ln May, 1943.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Senate, by a voice vote, passed a bill today authorizing the increase of the statutory debt limit from $210,000,000,000 to $260,000,000,000, and with it a rider reducing to 20 per cent the new tax on cabarets.

ALGIERS, May 31 -- Jacques Lemaigre-Dubreuil, formerly chief economic adviser to Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud, who was about to be arrested by order of the French Committee of National Liberation, has escaped from French North Africa to Spanish Morocco, it was revealed today.

Joseph P. Kasper, executive vice president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., will become the new president of the Associated Merchandising Corporation and the Retail Research Association, and will assume his new duties in the near future, it was announced yesterday.

The executive committee of the Queens County Republican Committee adopted last night a resolution calling upon Republican candidates in that county not to accept endorsements or nominations from any minority political party. The meeting was held at county headquarters, 86-15 Lefferts Boulevard, Richmond Hill.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP) -- The Phillies came out of a slump today as Ron Northey, hitless in eleven previous times at bat, singled Jimmy Wasdell across the plate with the run that beat the Reds, 5 to 4.
A midtown office property and a group of stores on upper Broadway were among the Manhattan properties listed yesterday as having passed into new hands.

Last Saturday the venomous little beast who directs Nazi propaganda started a campaign to incite German civilians to murder Allied aviators parachuting to German soil. According to a Stockholm dispatch, partly confirmed by other reports, the campaign has now borne fruit.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 31 (U.P.) -- Mortimer J. Rubin, 21, of 1627 Fifty-third Street, Brooklyn, N.Y., who was a theological student before his induction, won his fight to be discharged from the Navy today when Judge John P. Hartigan ruled in Federal Court that he had been inducted illegally.
CLEVELAND, May 31 (AP) -- The Indians scored five times in the third inning on three hits and an error to trounce Boston, 7 to 4, today, registering their third consecutive victory over the Red Sox.

Only a slight rise in the production of wire frame lamp shades will result from the War Production Board's recently announced amendment to Order L-33, it was reported yesterday. The chief reason for lack of production, it was explained, is scarcity of piece goods such as celanese and rayon at prices that can be afforded by lamp shade manufacturers who cannot sell their finished products at prices higher than those in existence in March, 1942.

MEN fight willingly enough for a variety of reasons. But after the dead have piled up, and the long casualty lists have appeared in the newspapers, the special heart-searchings begin. Why did so many have to die? There must be some reason beyond the abstractions of the orators, the traditional justifications that come so lightly and easily from the top of the mind.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 31 -Synthesis of ordinary commercial sugar, which chemists have been attempting for more than fifty years, has finally been accomplished, the University of California announced today.

MOSCOW, May 31 -- The powerful German attack on Russian positions on the Jijia River north of Jassy probably is intended as a forestalling blow and attempt to gain more room for maneuver around the city, which stands high on the list of objectives of the expected Russian offensive.
LONDON, May 31 -- Helped by the latest war news, today's stock markets here showed fresh strength. There was further buying of industrials, both shipping and textiles being prominent.

A FIGHTER BASE IN ENGLAND, May 31 (AP) -- Lieut. Ralph Hofer, Mustang pilot of Salem, Mo., destroyed three German training planes on the ground today, tying Maj. James Goodson of Toronto, Canada, for the leading ground score of fighter pilots in the European theatre of operations, with fifteen planes destroyed.

Irving Weiss of 1170 Broadway, New York, has purchased the Grand View Home Courts project of 155 two-story houses along Route 6 in the Boroughs of Hasbrouck Heights and Lodi, near the Bendix Airport, Bergen County, N.J.

Ten Democratic votes in the Senate Judiciary Committee have shelved the constitutional amendment to abolish the poll tax. The measure goes to a subcommittee "for study," which may be another way of saying that it will not be heard of again at this session. The responsibility lies entirely with the party which calls itself "Democratic."

Musical compositions of five to seven minutes in length, designed especially for radio broadcasting, have been ordered by the Blue network from composers in the serious and popular music fields, Mark Woods, president of the Blue, announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 31 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

OTTAWA, May 31 -- John Curtin, Prime Minister of Australia, who is in Canada after the imperial conference in London, said today that the initiative had passed to the United Nations in all theatres and the United Nations' commanders had reached the stage that warrants their operating aggressively instead of defensively.

Eugene Endrey will present at the Mansfield Theatre tonight a two-act comedy, "A Strange Play," by Patti Spears, and "According to Law," a curtain raiser by Noel Houston. The first of these is described as a drawing-room play dealing with a modern playwright in quest of a plot.

There was quite a contrast between yesterday at Belmont Park and the day before, when records had tumbled in all directions. With 19,259 racing fans present, there was plenty of room to move yesterday and access to the mutuel windows was so easy that $1,953,749 slid through them with no trouble.

LONDON, Thursday, June 1 (AP) -- Large German forces continued to attack fiercely Russian lines north of Jassy in Rumania yesterday, but were repulsed Without advancing, "even one step" and left "thousands of dead" on the battlefield, Moscow announced early today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to provide $182,252,000 to finance operations of the Office of Price Administration for the 1945 fiscal year. This sum was $12,752,000 above that allowed in the current fiscal year.

DUBLIN, Thursday, June 1 (AP) -- Two-thirds of the votes cast in Tuesday's election have been counted and Prime Minister Eamon de Valera was disclosed today to have been re-elected by a substantial margin. He appeared sure of winning his demand for a clear majority in the Dail Eireann [Parliament].

To prevent this country's economy from pursuing the "twin mirages of self-governing monopoly and Government control of business" following the war, at least eleven steps, including the removal of all Government controls, should be taken as soon as feasible following the peace, Wendell Berge, assistant United States Attorney General in charge of the Anti-Trust Division, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Republican effort to counter or nullify the pro-Roosevelt activities of the CIO Political Action Committee was taken into the Senate today with a demand by Senator Hugh Butler of Nebraska for an investigation of the organization by the Privileges and Elections Committee.

Bonds called for redemption in May before maturity dates aggregated $130,152,000, highest monthly figure since January, when $136,358,000 was retired, and the largest May total since 1941, when $172,193,000 was redeemed. Last month's total compared with $119, 781,000 in the preceding month and $70,222,000 in May, 1943.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 31 -The Bulgarian Regency Council has prepared an affirmative answer to the German "ultimatum" brought back Monday by Bogdan Philoff, former Premier, according to the first direct information from Sofia received here since the severance of communications with the outside world last Friday.

AUCKLAND, N.Z., May 31 (U.P.) -- The Japanese in the South Pacific have suffered an estimated loss of 4,800 planes, 150,000 men and too many ships to count, breaking the backbone of their resistance from New Ireland to New Guinea, Admiral William F. Halsey Jr. asserted today, following his arrival here from a rapid tour of the theatre from which he is retiring as Allied commander.

In ironical contrast to the plight of many Americans searching for relatives missing in the Far Eastern war theatre, a 22-year-old Chinese nurse who escaped from the Japanese to serve with Allied forces has been seeking information about her father, last heard of in this city.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, May 31 (AP) -- The railway feeding Japan's beleaguered north Burma bases is under intense aerial attack that may have blocked the flow of supplies over that vital route, it was announced authoritatively today.

STANTON, Del., May 31 (AP) -The Glasgow Purse, feature at the Delaware Park track, today saw Mrs. P.H. Heighe's Rene B., ridden by L. Knapp, outgame M. Marmorstein's Countess Wise by a neck in a thrilling stretch drive. A claim of foul by Jockey A. Kirkland, who rode Countess Wise, was not allowed.

CHUNGKING, China, May 31 (U.P.) -- Civilians were ordered evacuated today from Changsha, the big Hankow-Canton railroad town eighty miles south of Yochow, as 150,000 Japanese troops advanced in three offensive spearheads, and it was admitted officially here that the outlook for the immediate future was grim.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, May 31 -- Order, after a fashion, is returning to the many hill towns and villages in the area south of Rome, thanks largely to the prompt presence of Allied Military Government officials, whose set task is to take over from the advancing Army elements.

ST. LOUIS, May 31 (AP) -- The Browns jumped into a first-place tie with the Yankees tonight as they won their third straight from the Senators on an unearned run in the eleventh inning. The score was 4 to 3.

Merrill Denison, author of "Klondike Mike, an Alaskan Odyssey," a Book-of-the-Month Club choice, has written the latest Foreign Policy Association Headline book. Called "Canada: Our Dominion Neighbor," it gives, with the aid of graphs and a map, background on the political and economic development of the Dominion.
Less than a month ago Calvin Coolidge McLish was just an Oklahoma City high school lad, whose closest approach to a big league victory was like any other 18-yearold pitcher's -- in a dream.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Another strike against Montgomery Ward Co. of Chicago was threatened today by the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, a CIO affiliate.

Because the Securities and Exchange Commission has found that the common stock of the Standard Gas and Electric Company cannot possibly be entitled to an interest in the reorganized company, the New York Stock Exchange has suspended the stock from dealings.
BOSTON, May 31 -- More than 130 shipyard workers at the Bethlehem-Hingham plant, where vessels are being built for the Navy, were arrested today on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government.

Eight women's organizations which claim a membership of 10,000,000 have united to sponsor a plank for the Republican and Democratic National Conventions asking "equal opportunity to work and equal pay during the post-war period."

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration reduced tonight, by 23 to 38 cents a hundredweight, the ceiling prices on soft wheat bakery flour sold by millers in the Eastern and Central States, and the Defense Supplies Corporation simultaneously announced a compensating increase in the flour subsidy paid to millers.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- The Germans have captured two news correspondents and two photographers who recently reached the headquarters of Marshal Tito, it was announced tonight.

A possible butter shortage in municipal institutions faced City Purchase Commissioner Albert Pleydell yesterday as the Office of Price Administration sought to allay his anxiety over meat supplies for the inmates and staffs of city hospitals and prisons.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 31 -- A German communique said tonight that there had been several cases of lynching of American fliers.

Lured by the reports of excellent weakfishing now on tap in Peconic Bay, a party of fourteen members of the Winfield Anglers made the trip over the holiday week-end. They knew they would be up against a severe boat short-age. How they solved the problem will interest others and is related herewith in the words of J. Arthur Volz, the club's president.

NEWARK, N.J., May 31 -- Robert J. Brennan of 1,599 Crescent Avenue, Hillside, a lineman for the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, faced an unexpected emergency this noon while working atop a telephone pole on Midland Place when he was attacked by two sparrow hawks who mistook his operations for a threat to their nest in an adjacent tree.

LONDON, May 31 -- King Peter of Yugoslavia was reported today to have decided to recognize the military leadership of Marshal Tito and to have given a mandate to Dr. Ivan Subasitch, former Governor of Croatia, to open political negotiations with the Communist commander of the Yugoslav liberation army.
KANDY, Ceylon, May 31 (UP) -- A communique:

DUBLIN, May 31 -- Despite the criticism leveled at the recent transport legislation introduced by the Government, it is evident from the results now available that many constituencies were not enamored of the coalition government plan put forward by Gen. Richard Mulcahy's Fine Gael party.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- The Portuguese refugee ship Serpa Pinto, sailing under a safe-conduct guarantee from the belligerent powers, was stopped by gunfire in midocean early Friday morning by a German submarine which carried off two Americans as prisoners after forcing 385 passengers and crew members to spend nine hours in lifeboats on threat of torpedoing the vessel.

DETROIT, May 31 -- From the deep recesses of the dugout Albert Unser, third-string catcher of Steve O'Neill's Tigers, came today to strike his first home run of the year and his second hit of the campaign in nine games to hand The Yankees their fourth setback in-a-row.

The United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference called by the President will meet a month from today. Its purpose is the highly desirable one of securing stable exchange rates in the post-war world. But the recent proposal for an $8,000,000,000 International Stabilization Fund misconceives the nature of the problem and approaches it from the wrong end.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee voted today to extend for six months, or to Dec. 7, exactly three years after Pearl Harbor, the statute of limitations on the court-martial of Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel and Maj. Gen. Walter C. Short, the commanders at Pearl Harbor when the Japanese struck.

Cotton garment manufacturers, facing an extremely tight fabric supply situation on lower end goods during the last half of the year, declared yesterday that additional export quotas on popular materials, listed in the latest revision to M-317, not only will further aggravate civilian goods conditions, but is reason to wonder whether previously promised relief will be forthcoming.
Members of the Fire Department who criticized it in letters to the newspapers are violating departmental regulations and will be disciplined, Fire Commissioner Walsh announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A strike of broadcast engineers and technicians employed by the National Broadcasting Company, the Blue Network and radio station WOR in Newark which was scheduled for midnight, was apparently averted late today when the National War Labor Board sent telegrams to all concerned to maintain the status quo pending an investigation.

A suit to recover original manuscripts and the autobiographical "Yankee Doodle Dandy" written by George M. Cohan, was discontinued yesterday when Surrogate James A. Foley signed a stipulation terminating the action.

The United States Army's power is being used to "regain Italy for the Italians," while the "insuperable might of our charity will save Italians for Italy and for the world's peace," Archbishop Francis J. Spellman said yesterday in a nation-wide radio appeal for clothing for the destitute war victims of that country, broadcast from WOR.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The United States Government is still dissatisfied with the continued shipments of ferro-alloys from the Iberian peninsula to Germany, and despite Prime Minister Churchill's recent "kindly words for Spain," is continuing to press Generalissimo Francisco Franco for a total embargo on wolfram exports to Germany.

Expectations of fixations against sales of spot cotton to Spain before the end of the week, and continued price fixing against war orders, carried prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday into new high levels for the season, with final prices for the day 10 to 16 points net higher for active months.

Although the volume of business on the New York Stock Exchange in May was higher than in the previous month, it was only half the total for May, 1943. Sales last month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 17,228,380 shares, compared with 13,846,590 in April and 35,051,545 in May, 1943.

The War Finance Committee of announced yesterday the tentative program of major special events for the coming Fifth War Loan drive that includes a pre-campaign rally in Times Square, as well as a State-wide invasion-barge tour and a military parade on Fifth Avenue.

Frank Cist, in his letter published May 26, is right in rejecting the idea that the $12,000,000,000 excess of American exports over imports in the period between the two wars was an achievement. It made us richer in gold, but it deprived other countries of purchasing power, forced their exports down to an exceedingly low level and provoked protective measures as import quotas and currency restrictions.

War is a cruel teacher, but it does teach. Proofs that the human spirit rises to great heights to meet great crises are found day after day in the epics of the battlefield, as glorious and chivalric in the monstrous contests of tanks and bombers as they ever were in the neat little wars of knights in armor.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A campaign in 600 communities for foreign policy platform pledges of international cooperation by both political parties was started today by the National League of Women Voters. In a broadside which had a first distribution of 90,000 copies, the league listed four essentials for platform statements.

The Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation announced yesterday that it had entered into a merger agreement with the management of the Rensselaer Saratoga Railroad Company, which it controls under a perpetual lease. The terms provide for the exchange of general mortgage bonds of the Rensselaer Saratoga for Rensselaer Saratoga 8 per cent stock, par for par.

Among the most plentiful meats at present are cold cuts -- bologna, salami, liver sausage, cervelat and so on. In addition to being served "as is" -- a method that especially commends them in hot weather -they may be converted into many quick and easy hot dishes.

The City Planning Commission discovered yesterday, after four hours of public hearing, that its proposals for comprehensive rezoning of all of Manhattan north of Fourteenth Street were generally acceptable to business, industry and individual property owners "in principle," but quite objectionable as a practical matter in many specific instances and areas.

LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- The German Gestapo pressed a ferocious new wave of terror in France and the Low Countries today with mass shootings and arrests of the patriots on whom Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has called to assist his coming liberation armies.
Wesby R. Parker, formerly with Pillsbury Flour Mills, Inc., has been made sales manager of grocery products specialties under the Swans Down label of General Foods Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Appointment of civilians as officers in the Navy will virtually cease by autumn, and officer strength will be drawn as far as possible from the enlisted ranks, it was stated today. This opportunity for promotion from the enlisted personnel to officer rank was described by Rear Admiral Randall Jacobs, Chief of the Bureau of Personnel, at a press conference held by Secretary Forrestal.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, June 1 (AP) -- A communique:
LONDON, Thursday, June 1 -- Great forces of strongly escorted American heavy bombers slashed again yesterday from west and south at vital knots in Germany's defensive network.

LONDON, May 31 -- To many small nations represented in London the apparent trend of Allied thinking toward control of Europe's machinery for the maintaining of peace by the three great powers is disturbing. Many of them fear that what is taking shape is a reduction of the whole Continent to a gigantic buffer state between the Soviets in the east and an Anglo-American bloc in the west.

An indication that the price-stabilization program is meeting success is shown in the parity prices of May 15 for the principal agricultural products. As announced yesterday by the Department of Agriculture, there was no change from the level of April 15.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -President Roosevelt had appointments with William M. Leiserson, the Chinese Ambassador and General Shang Chen, Governor Johnston of South Carolina and Herbert Lehman, UNRRA Director.

Today, June 1, 1944, five years minus ninety days after the outbreak of the war, begins the month, or at least the season, which must bring the climax in this greatest of all human conflicts. For, as all signs indicate, as the situation itself loudly demands, and as President Roosevelt flatly declared, the great invasion of the European Continent from the west will take place this summer.

Jan Masaryk, Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, warned the United States last night not to become "sentimental about the Boche" and, in an address at a dinner given by the French weekly newspaper France-Amerique at the Hotel Commodore, asserted that "victory this time means our men inside of Germany."
Mrs. Rodgers Denckla of Philadelphia and Hobe Sound, Fla., has come to the Ritz-Carlton.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (U.P.) -A jury of eleven men and a woman, deliberating an hour and four minutes, tonight acquitted Robert I. Miller, 67-year-old criminal lawyer, of first degree murder in the slaying of Dr. John E. Lind, psychiatrist, who Miller charged had stolen the love of his wife.

Councilman Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn, Democratic majority leader, announced yesterday that the Council would meet at 1 P.M. tomorrow to receive Mayor La Guardia's message on the Council's recent elimination of $5,427,923 from the 1944-45 budget of $737,400,923 as approved by the Board of Estimate.

Women interested in learning how to remake their own clothes are urged to register immediately at the Greater New York headquarters of the American Women's Voluntary Services at 11 East Fifty-eighth Street or their local AWVS branch.

I have just read your editorial "The New School," and I could not help linking what you said there with a news item on another page of the same issue of THE TIMES reporting that unhappy conflict between the president and faculty of the University of Chicago.

The Nu-Enamel Corporation, paint and varnish manufacturer which was empowered at a special stockholders' meeting last month to engage in other types of business, announced yesterday that it had brought in its first producing oil well on a tract of 800 acres of land in Montague County, Tex., which it recently leased.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 31 -The Turkish public is awaiting with considerable interest the court-martial trials scheduled to commence soon in Istanbul, which has been under martial law for most of the war.

The hustling example of school children all over the city, especially a very young group in the King's Highway section of Brooklyn that has collected 7,500 pounds of waste paper since May 1, appeared yesterday to be reflected in greater support for the salvage drive from grown ups.

Mendelssohn's "Elijah" was presented by the John Harms Chorus last night in Town Hall for the benefit of Junior American Nurse, Inc. The oratorio was conducted by John Harms, and the exacting music allotted to the singer of the name part was entrusted to John Gurney, the Metropolitan bass-baritone.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

CHICAGO, May 31 -- There was no pressure on the grain markets today on the Board of Trade and short covering and professional buying, combined with a moderate increase in commission-house purchases, advanced wheat and rye around 2 cents a bushel before profit-taking and selling on resting orders checked the upturn.

Bowled over for four runs in the first inning after the first two Cubs had been retired, the Giants, with young Frank Seward on the mound, picked themselves up from the grass at the Polo Grounds yesterday and once again gave what may be styled a miraculous performance.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The mighty United States Navy is carrying on an offensive on all oceans, James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, stated at a news conference today.

MOSCOW, June 1 -- The Germans had little to show but heavy losses in men, armor and especially planes at the close of forty-eight hours' incessant fighting north of Jassy. They were unable to exploit the local successes gained Tuesday, and Red Star reports that all attempts to push farther into the Russian defenses broke down yesterday in the face of grim opposition.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, announced yesterday that guilty pleas were entered in the largest tax evasion ease to be handled by Iris office since he became its head on Jan. 1, 1943. The case involved two officers of the Arch-Bilt Corrugated Products Corporation of 51-18 Grand Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, charged with evasion of taxable income of approximately $250,000.

LISBON, Portugal, June 1 (AP) -- Today is the deadline for removal of all Jews from the Budapest area into designated ghettos. What personal effects any of them may still possess in the new locations, however, is problematical. Recent weeks have been filled with accounts of systematic raids on Jewish homes with the avowed purpose of seizing hidden valuables.
ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP) -- The public transportation system here was paralyzed today as street car and bus operators walked out because of an overtime pay dispute.

The numerous amendments being proposed to the Emergency Price Control Act have one thing in common: practically all of them are designed to break the line at some point or give special favors to some group. An illustration is found in the proposal to give special treatment to milk.

Johnny Barrett picked the best time for himself and the rest of the Pirates yesterday to hit his first home run of the year. With two out and the score tied at 1 -- all, the Pittsburgh right-fielder caught hold of one of Curt Davis' fast ones in the eighth inning and blasted the ball over the right-field wall at Ebbets Field to beat the Dodgers 2 -- 1.

CLEVELAND, June 1 (AP) -- The Red Sox parlayed four first-inning runs with George Metkovich's three-run homer in the ninth to defeat the Indians, 7 to 6, today for their only victory in the four-game series. Boston put together six bases on balls, a single, a wild pitch and a double steal for four first-inning runs.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Heavy buying of wheat futures here and in Kansas City by millers lifted prices 1 3/4 cents a bushel in the early trading today to the highest level on the current movement, and despite profit-taking and reports that new wheat was moving in the far Southwest part of the uptown was maintained.
A new variant on an old "gag" had some night club wags chuckling last night. It went like this:

Post-war discussion that presupposes early or general abandonment of State economic controls of foreign and internal trade in Europe and elsewhere is "unrealistic'' Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor and chairman of its postwar planning committee, declared yesterday before the annual meeting of the Manufacturing Chemists Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Skunk met restricted demand at the auction held yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth. The top was $4.50, with prices slightly easier. Larger sizes of opossum did not meet much buying interest, but the smaller types sold well. The high was $1.18. Civet cat met a fair demand, selling up to $1.72.

Our armed forces in Italy are now among the Alban Hills, a region of ancient fame. Of lava and tufa, rising from a plain covered by volcanic ashes, they are the relics of antique explosions. There is a theory that the first settlers, coming from the north, occupied the Alban, before the Roman, hills.

Howard L. Aller, president of the American Power and Light Company, a $273,000,000 public utility holding company, declared yesterday that the company had decided to seek a Supreme Court review of the recent United States Circuit Court of Appeals decision upholding an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission calling for the company's liquidation under the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

TRENTON, N.J., June 1 -- Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio brought his campaign for the Republican nomination for President into New Jersey today and accused the New Deal of "re-forming its alliances with Tammany, the Hagues, the Kellys, the Sidney Hillmans and the Communist elements in this country."

By choice no one would seek to disagree with so kindly a critic of your recent editorial on the Treasury Department's plan of international currency stabilization as Louis H. Pink. But there is room for fear that if put into operation the plan would lose for American labor, commerce and industry a good deal more than the nation could afford.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 14 Three teams tied at 67, six strokes under par, in the one-day amateur best ball tourney of the Long Island Golf Association at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- Screen rights to Charles Jackson's current best seller, "The Lost Week-End," have been bought by Parambunt, according to an announcement by B.G. De Sylva. The story of three days in the life of a dipsomaniac is scheduled to be produced by Charles Brackett and directed by Billy Wilder.

CHUNGKING, China, June 1 (AP) -- The Japanese, in fierce fighting along a broad 120-mile front, have advanced in three major drives against the Hunan Province city of Changsha, by-passing the Chinese stronghold of Changteh, 100 miles to the northwest, the High Command announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Secretary Stimson reported today that with "the period of decisive action'' at hand, 3,657,000 American soldiers were outside the United States "striking and preparing to strike victory-winning blows" against the enemy.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- Led by Pitcher Dick Barrett, who hit a triple and a double to drive in four runs and score one, the Phillies defeated the Reds, 8 -- 7, today at Shibe Park.

The fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 514 West End Avenue, at the corner of Eighty-fifth Street, has been sold by the 514 West End Holding Corporation to the Avon Amusement Company, Nathan Levy, president, subject to a first mortgage of $185,750.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, June 2 -- The hard-pressed Americans on the Biak Island beachhead have been reinforced, but thus far no greater advance has been made toward the Mokmer airdrome nor has our hold on other areas been substantially increased.

WASHNGTON. June 1 -- A bill to draft unmarried, unemployed women between the ages of 20 and 35, by an amendment to the Selective Service Act, was introduced today by Representative Celler, Democrat of New York, as a means of filling the ranks of women's services.

OTTAWA, June 1 -- Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia, addressing a joint meeting of the Canadian Senate and House of Commons today in the Commons Chamber, called on the United Nations to maintain the unity evidenced in war to solve post-war problems.

Three motorists from this area who drove for pleasure to Florida last winter on gasoline obtained in the black market or issued for occupational driving were penalized yesterday by the revocation of their gasoline rations for the duration.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission stated today that it would consider as violations of the fraud provisions of the securities acts the purchase or sale of common stock of the Standard Gas and Electric Company by a broker or dealer unless the purchaser is reformed that the commission has ruled that the stock is not entitled to participation in a plan of recapitalization.

The entire second floor of 20,000 square feet at 421-35 Hudson Street has been leased by the American Direct Mail Company from the Trinity Operating Company. The move is to allow for expansion and will give the lessee more than four times the area it occupies at present.

A nation-wide study of post-war medical education, designed to develop plans for training future physicians, establish adequate pre-medical standards and provide educational opportunities for returning medical officers has been undertaken by a committee of nineteen educators and specialists in the field, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University, disclosed yesterday.

Although dressed chickens are still scarce because of Government requisitioning, shipments of fowl increased considerably this week and stocks are said to be liberal for the first time in many months. This is because the peak of the egg lay is over and the hens are being killed for market. Supplies of Long Island ducklings are heavy and demand for them has been active. Other market news follows:

Paul Windels, former Corporation Counsel, sent letters yesterday to the Republican county chairmen of New York, Kings, Bronx and Richmond Counties, Thomas J. Curran, John R. Crews, John J. Knewitz and Edward A. Ruppell, urging them to have their respective organizations take action to forbid party candidates from accepting endorsements from the "Communist-controlled" American Labor Party.
