In an expansion move which will provide it with much larger manufacturing space than it now uses at 160 Jay Street, the Howard Clothes Company, manufacturers and chain-store retailers of men's clothing, has purchased from the Sperry Gyroscope Company the eleven-story concrete factory building of the Sperry company at 40 Flatbush Avenue Extension, Brooklyn.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 1 (UP} -- A communique:

STANTON, Del, June 1 (AP) -- The closest finish of the meeting developed in the featured Elk Purse at Delaware Park today when the first three in the field of six were on almost equal terms. The camera convinced the judges Max Marmorstein's Edie Jane was the winner but Cleveland Skinker's Boy Soldier and H.H. Haag's favored Pumpgun were locked in a dead heat for place, only a nose away.

TAPPEN. N.Y., June 1 -- Representative Hamilton Fish, campaigning here tonight for the endorsement of the Rockland County Republican Committee in his contest with Augustus Bennet of Newburgh for the Republican primary nomination in the Twenty- ninth Congressional District, spoke of a recent attack upon him by the American-Labor Party as a boon.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Evidence of efforts of Hitlerite residents to organize all Nazi sympathizers in this country in support of preservation of "Germandom in America" was presented to the jury in the seditious conspiracy trial here today over violent objections of counsel for the twenty- nine defendants charged with cooperation in advancing Nazi propaganda with the object of creating disaffection in American armed forces.

Development of a new thermoplastic, the first ever developed that can hold its shape and strength in boiling water and yet be molded by the fastest, most economical methods, was announced yesterday by Charles Belknap, president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, at a pres conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

THE Belmont Stakes is the American equivalent of the famed English Derby but without either monocle or Oxford accent. It is the Epsom Derby distance of a mile and a half, and the gentlemen who are genuinely interested in the improvement of the breed (not the mutuel manipulators) deem it both the best and truest test of the thoroughbred in these continental United States.

TUNGKWAN, China, May 22 (Delayed) -- Tungkwan, which is at the elbow bend of the Yellow River and the meeting of the frontiers of three Provinces, Shensi, Honan and Shansi, is one of the most important strategic points in all China.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Friday, June 2 (UP) -- A communique:

Reaffirming his determination to prevent city employes from engaging in outside employment, even on their own time, Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday a report by Investigation Commissioner Edgar Bromberger listing the names of 293 men holding outside jobs with concerns doing business along the waterfront.
CHUNGKING, China, June 1 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique :

ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP) -- The Browns were walloped by the Senators today, 11 to 5, but took first place in the American League by 2 percentage points over the Yankees. The slumping world champions, who have played fewer games than St. Louis, slipped out of a tie for the lead by losing again.

The three-story factory building at 35-41 Meadow Street, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, has been sold by the Carwall Realty Corporation through the brokerage agency of Kalmon Dolgin, Inc., to an investing syndicate. The property covers a plot 100 by 100 feet and the building has 35,000 square feet. It is assessed at $52,000.

BOSTON, June 1 -- An eighteen-point program of action to be put into effect at the war's end as steps preliminary to the larger task of transition to a peace economy was offered today by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, at the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers.

THERE is one inescapable conclusion to be drawn from reading Leo Cherne's "The Rest of Your Life"* and that is that the best of your life is past. Mr. Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, is a cool, dispassionate, widely informed and thoroughly pessimistic man. He has digested masses of statistics, studied dreary mountains of data and charted the probable development of various trends now well under way.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- Circulation of petitions will be started soon to win public support for a proposed initiative to regulate labor unions in California.

Six representatives of labor industry and "independent" women have agreed to serve as an advisory committee to help plan administration of New York State's new Equal Pay Law, which will become effective July 1, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi said yesterday at the State Office Building, 80 Center Street.

An estimated 850,000 tons of uncollected wastepaper was left in the basements and attics of households throughout the country in April, including 6,312 tons in Manhattan alone, according to a report received yesterday by the United States Victory Waste Paper Campaign Committee here from the Department of Commerce, after its completion of a nation-wide inventory survey.

The appointment of Col. Rodney H. Smith to succeed Maj. Gen. Sanderford Jarman as commanding officer of the Anti-Aircraft Artillery Command, Eastern Defense Command stretching from Maine to Florida, was announced yesterday by Lieut. Gen. George Grunert, commanding general of the Eastern Defense Command.

Two films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Rialto the new attraction will be "A Night of Adventure," an RKO melodrama featuring Tom Conway. In supporting roles are Audrey Long, Edward Brophy, Louis Borell, Jean Brooks and Nancy Gates. . . . At the Belmont the newcomer will be "En Morenita Clara," a Mexican importation starring Evita Munoz. Dialogue of the musical is Spanish.

CAMP SHELBY, Miss., June 1 (AP) -- Soldiers of the 138th Infantry Regiment, veterans of almost two and a half years in the Aleutians, and builders of at least three airbases, have arrived in Camp Shelby.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A rift between two executive agencies of the Administration appeared for the first time today over the issue of whether the needs of civilians at home or those of the nation's fighting allies abroad should be emphasized in the distribution of cotton textiles for clothing.

As the result of questions raised over the adequacy of the contract termination notification given to the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation and the possibility of other Government agencies having work for Brewster, the Navy Department has issued a statement outlining its position in detail.

Herman G. Brock, 53 years old, of Port Washington, L.I., pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions to an indictment accusing him of the theft of $9,800, through worthless checks, last Dec. 16 from the Guaranty Trust Company's main office at 140 Broadway, where he had been one of its vice presidents for fifteen years.

JOHNSVILLE, Pa., June 1 -- An official of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation who declined to permit the use of his name said today that "in all probability" the union-management contract would be "thrown out the window" if the Navy took over the assembly plant here as a modification center.

The present war has taught Americans that a wrong in any part of the world sooner or later spreads and touches our own country and interests, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday at the national donor luncheon held in connection with the biennial convention of the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress.

Asserting that there is a great need on the part of small business for basic operating information, Quincy Adams, newly appointed chief of the Division of Small Business, Department of Commerce, proposed yesterday a six-point marketing survey program to aid small business firms of the nation in reconversion to a peacetime economy.

After establishing new high levels for the life of the contracts, the cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange sold off yesterday and closed steady, unchanged to 9 points lower than on Wednesday.

LONDON, June 1 -- Strong formations of medium bombers and fighters struck out across the English Channel toward the French invasion coast late this afternoon after a heavy Royal Air Force night assault on three strategic French transportation centers.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- John B. Quinn, eastern manager for the group backing Lieut. Commdr. Harold E. Stassen for the Republican Presidential nomination, charged tonight that many other candidates are conducting a "hush-a-bye contest" in which they avoid discussion of pressing political problems.

The Republic Aviation Corporation announced yesterday production of a new model of the P-47 Thunderbolt fighter-bomber, which it says has come out victor in innumerable dogfights with Hitler's fighting aircraft and chalked up one-sided box scores in smoking out Japanese.

Col. Allan M. Pope, president of the First Boston Corporation, was re-elected president of the Welfare Council of New York City, a federation of more than 600 social and health agencies in the five boroughs, at a meeting of the council's board of directors yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., June 1 (AP) -- Collecting twenty-one safe blows, including four triples, four doubles and a home run, the Baltimore Orioles buried the last place Newark Bears under a 13-4 score tonight for their sixth consecutive triumph.

Declaring that a glut of imported watches can readily cause havoc in the Jewelry trade in this country, T. Albert Potter, president of the Elgin National Watch Company, said yesterday that if necessary "there must be an equalization of imports" to assure American watch makers now engaged in war work, their markets here.
LONDON, June 1 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
LONDON, June 1 -- The French and Belgian highway networks are feeling the thunder of the Allied blitz as the pre-invasion blows against Hitler's Europe approach a new climax.

Greenish-yellow fumes of chlorine gas, leaking from a steel cylinder on a truck that was transporting it, nauseated or overcame perhaps as many as 1,000 men, women and children yesterday afternoon in the area within a radius of half a dozen blocks of Flatbush Avenue Extension and Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn.

BELLE MEAD, N.J., June 1 -- The world's richest "department store" with the largest inventory in history and in which five branches of the Army and lend-lease have accounts was thrown open to the public for the first time here recently during a press tour of the Belle Mead Army Service Forces Depot.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- To Dr. Edwin H. Armstrong, Professor of Electrical Engineering at Columbia University and inventor of frequency modulation in radio reception, was given today the first chief signal officer's certificate of appreciation, awarded by the War Department.

MOSCOW, June 1 -- Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, arrived at Moscow airport this afternoon, traveling in the same Liberator that brought Ambassador W. Averell Harriman back to his post.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The morale of the German soldier is being affected by "the overpowering air domination" of the Allies in Italy, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson declared today in analyzing at his press conference the progress of the renewed Italian campaign.

DETROIT, June 1 -- The Yankees slipped out of the American League lead at Briggs Stadium today as they went down to defeat before the Tigers in their longest game of the season, a sixteen-inning struggle that carried through 3 hours and 28 minutes. The score was 4 to 3.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Henri Hoppenot, representative here of the French Committee of National Liberation, called upon Secretary of State Cordell Hull today for what he described as an exchange of information. He declined to say that he had discussed the forthcoming visit of General Charles de Gaulle to London.

LONDON, June 1 -- The Allies' tactical offensive in the west, which has as its primary objective the immobilization of German reserves and material in northwestern Europe when the invasion begins, produced not only numerous new records in bomb tonnage and planes involved during May but also evidence that the Allies are succeeding to a considerable degree in their preparation for a land invasion.

DANBURY, Conn., June 1 -- A garden rake pulled aimlessly through a sandpile in the cellar of a fire-swept summer cottage on the shore of Candlewood Lake, near here, brought to light the body of a woman who, police said today, had been shot to death more than nine months ago.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Canned carrots and citrus juices go on a ration-free list Sunday and all the meats now unrationed will stay in that category at least through July 1.

HAVANA, June 1 -- Dr. Carlos Saladrigas, Presidential candidate of the Government coalition composed of Liberal, Democratic, ABC and Communist parties, spoke over the radio late this afternoon announcing the victory of the coalition in the election to choose a new President and the greater part of Congress.

Nelson Doubleday, president and chairman of the board of Doubleday, Doran Co., has announced the purchase of the assets and business of the Blakiston Company, publisher of medical and scientific books, of Philadelphia. Horace C. White, president of the Blakiston Company, is now associated with Doubleday, Doran, and the entire personnel of the Blakiston Company is being retained with offices continuing in the old quarters in Philadelphia.

Dairy farmers in the six-State milkshed serving the New York metropolitan area will share in a record pool of $23,000,000 for last month's milk production, it was reported yesterday by Dr. C.J. Blanford, marketing area administrator.

LONDON, June 1 -- Divergences of British and American policy toward Spain and France have put something of a strain upon the otherwise cordial relations that have existed between Washington and London. These conflicting lines of policy have existed just below the surface for some time, but it took Prime Minister Churchill's recent speech, with its enconiums for Generalissimo Francisco Franco, to bring the issue into the open.
WASHINGTON, June 1, (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- A group of Vermonters, bearing the title of Freemen, Inc., stormed the Senate commerce subcommittee on flood control today to voice their opposition to the building of a huge dam which would flood century-old towns and villages in the West River Valley.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have increased $262,020,000 during the week to a new high record. Note circulation for the system as a whole was also at a new high, with an increase of $211,609,000 for the week, while the ratio of reserve declined further.

'In apparent agreement on the .roposition that the civil service ;ystem needs improvement to meet i-Jae pogf-war challenge, civil service ommi.sioners and personnel adiinitrators from about ninety overnmertal agencies in the United States and Canada dis?ussed various suggestions for chievihg ,bi.q end yesterday at [!he oping session of a two-day nference at the Hotel New 'orker

Broadway's second longest-running play, "Arsenic and Old Lace," will terminate its highly successful career at the Hudson Theatre the evening of June 17 after gracing the local stage boards for almost three and a half years, it was learned last night.

Due to the technicality that it was June 1, a new Broadway season opened last evening. Obviously the theatre was mad about something. Reaching down into the pot, it flung a handful of dregs called "A Strange Play" at an audience which hadn't meant any harm going to the Mansfield.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Below Rome, June 1 -- The beginning of the end of the battle for Rome seems to have started.
LONDON, June 1 -- Three British Army medical men reported in the current issue of the weekly medical magazine The Lancet that the new drug vivicillin was not an effective substitute for penicillin.

Protests against the use of their names in literature distributed by the American League for a Free Palestine were registered yesterday by forty-six American rabbis, together with their denunciation of the league as "a denial of Jewish history and a perversion of the fundamental concept of the unity of the Jewish people and of Zionist aims."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

OSSINING, N.Y., June 1 -- Louis Parisi, convicted of the murder of a former friend, was within an hour tonight of the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison when a telephone call from Governor Dewey's counsel, Charles Breitel, notified Warden William E. Snyder that the Governor had granted a fourth reprieve, this one for forty-eight hours.

The United States appropriation for UNRRA -- the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration -- for the coming year still waits final action in Congress. The President asked for a total of $800,000,000, to be expended up to June 30, 1945 -- $450,000,000 in cash and authority to allocate $350, 000,000 as lend-lease.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 1 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's main Chinese forces in northern Burma have captured Malakawng, on the Mogaung Valley road fifteen miles north of Kamaing, wiping out the Japanese garrison, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that the American republics were assembling information covering the facts and circumstances of the revolution in Ecuador. When the information has been assembled and consultations have been completed among the republics, a decision presumably will be reached on recognizing the group in power.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 1 (AP) -- Jersey City stretched the Syracuse Chiefs' losing streak to nine straight tonight as 19-year-old Mike Mellis turned in a neat seven-hit pitching job for a 7-0 victory. Carroll (Whitey) Lockman hit a two-run homer in the first inning and added a brace of singles to pace the thirteen-hit Little Giant attack.

Gasoline stocks in the United States at the close of last week were 86,468,000 barrels, a decline of 1,494,000 from the 87,962,000 at the end of the preceding week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A year ago they were 84,477,000 barrels.

On June 13 the Securities and Exchange Commission will hear arguments whether the National Association of Securities Dealers may enunciate philosophies which have the effect of rules without violating the laws that created it. The point at issue is the "5 per cent mark-up philosophy," widely challenged by over-the-counter security dealers.
Talman Bigelow, Inc., has moved its realty offices to 654 Madison Avenue, at Sixtieth Street.

Realizing entered the stock market yesterday in the final hours but only after the list had pushed into still further high territory for the movement. The development was considered a natural corrective gesture after the sustained advance of the last week, and although values were shaded by this profit-taking, the selling failed to shake the general structure of the market.

READING, Pa., June 1 -- Norman Thomas, perennial Socialist nominee for President, said tonight on arriving at the scene of the party's national convention that he was not a candidate for the nomination this year. When it was suggested that this put him "in a class with President Roosevelt and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey," he insisted that it did not.

There is a shortage of men in the New York Guard. New Federal drafts may reduce the strength of the organization still further. Eligibles are asked to fill the gaps. Here is an opportunity waiting for the man who, though not qualified for overseas duty, would like to be able to say in years to come that he did his bit in a military way in the national emergency.

An exhibition of war murals will be held in New York in October sponsored jointly by the National Society of Mural Painters and Artists for Victory, Inc. Sketches, cartoons and photographs of murals, including triptychs that have been painted since the beginning of the war for various branches of the armed services, hospitals, war industries, etc., are eligible.
WASHINGTON. June 1 (AP) -- The country's railroads have been marshaled for the grimmest task of the invasion -- transportation of the wounded.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., June 1 (AP) -- Seventeen banks in New York, Chicago, Oklahoma City, Tulsa, San Francisco and Los Angeles have underwritten a $75,000,000 revolving credit fund for use of the Douglas Aircraft Company, it was announced today by Ralph V. Hunt, vice president and controller.

LITTORIA, Italy, June 1 -- This utterly synthetic town, built into the northern end of the Pontine Marshes, like the futuristic miniature set in the glass case at the World's Fair in New York, was one of Benito Mussolini's greatest prides.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- The War Manpower Commission, aiming to check labor turnover and channel nonessential workers into war industry, will assume absolute control of all male labor over 17 years of age on July 1, it was learned here today.

The Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., and its domestic subsidiary, had a net profit of $1,087,514 in the nine months ended on April 30, after all charges, including $734, 820 provision for Federal income tax, E.C. Faustmann, president, reported yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 1 -- Twenty-two of Indiana's twenty-nine delegates to the Republican National Convention were chosen in Congressional district caucuses tonight without any instructions as to how they should vote for Presidential nominee.

In connection with the proposed international stabilization fund, your editorial on May 29 takes issue with the decision of the British Government to preserve full employment after the war by maintaining the aggregate spending of the national community at such a level as would assure full employment.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 27 were 11 per cent higher than sales of the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following table shows percentage changes from corresponding changes from 1943.

LONDON, June 1 -- Dr. Ivan Subasitch, who was sworn in today as the new Yugoslav Prime Minister, declared that he was ready to go into German-occupied Yugoslavia if necessary to enter into direct negotiations with Marshal Tito for the creation of a unified Yugoslav government.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Conditions which have led to a glut of eggs on the markets while prices to consumers remain unchanged, have inspired twenty-seven Republican Representatives to form an unofficial committee of inquiry. Reports that as many as fifty carloads a day are being converted into "tankage" or livestock feed have reached the committee.

The history and technique of early American wall and floor stencils and the adaptation of this art to modern home decorating was discussed by Kathleen Cairns at the headquarters of the American Institute of Decorators yesterday afternoon. Miss Cairns' lecture marked the opening of an exhibit of stencil designs that she copied from the walls and floors of old houses, which will remain on view through June 10.
Your editorial "Another War" state that "54 per cent" of City College's 60 seniors expect another world war within twenty-five years, "with Russia as America's possible opponent."

They laughed when Danny Gardella stepped to the plate in the seventh inning of a 3-3 game under the lights at the Polo Grounds last night. But the laughter was ill timed, because the colorful character reached for an outside pitch by Paul Erickson and blasted it against the rightfield facade for a home run that enabled the Giants to defeat the Cubs, 5 to 3.

LONDON, June 1 (AP) -- Marshal Tito, who apparently is slated to supplant Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch as Commander in Chief of the Yugoslav Army, told his troops today to strike immediately against German objectives in his country because "the last blow of the Red Army and the Anglo-American Allied troops is approaching."

Mrs. Roosevelt's knowledge of the public career of Winston Churchill is not nearly as intimate as it might be, if one may judge from her statement. Commenting on the Prime Minister's friendly words for the Franco regime in his recent speech, Mrs. Roosevelt said there is no reason for surprise, since that is the way Mr. Churchill's mind has been working the last sixty years.

WASI'NGTON, June 1 -- Mrs. Guy M Gillette has accepted the[ six-month rotating chairmanship of the Washington Emergency Committee to Save the Jewish People of Europe, which has as its main goal enactment of the resolution introduced Monday by her husband, the Iowa Senator, to receive Jewish and other refugees from Nazi Europe at Ellis Island or other reception centers to be made 'ree ports."

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Charges that UNRRA had bought and was shipping abroad 6,000,000 seer sucker dresses of better quality than are available to the American housewife, made on the floor of the House a week ago by Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jersey, were denied today by Leo T. Crowley, head of the Foreign Economic Administration, in a letter inserted in the Congressional Record by Representative Sol Bloom.
CHICAGO, June 1 -- The Chicago Sun's "Inside Washington" column printed the following this morning:

While Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz was presiding in County Court, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, his home at Coleridge Street and Hampton Avenue, Brooklyn, was robbed of upward of $10,000 worth of valuables during the absence of Mrs. Leibowitz and their daughter, Marjory, 18 years old.

The role of the entertainment industry in the forthcoming Fifth War Loan Drive is not only to "sell" bonds, but to stimulate consciousness of the cause for which bonds are being sold, 100 leaders from all branches of show business were told yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the Toots Shor Restaurant, 51 West Fifty-first Street.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's remarks on liberty as made public by the State Department:

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- William LaVarre, former chief of the Commerce Department's American Republics Division, charged before a Senate Postal subcommittee today that information censored from entering and leaving this country was providing a dangerous competitive weapon that could be used and apparently was being used against American business.

A Soviet aviation officer, Lieutenant General Zhuravleff, recently came out with a blast against the air power theories held by the vast majority of American and British airmen. Writing in the authoritative Moscow journal, War and the Working Class, he denounced our reliance on air power as a "pernicious" idea.

While the Navy may have been making new but undisclosed history yesterday, the New York Historical Society recalled past exploits of this service by opening an extensive permanent exhibition in its galleries at 170 Central Park West.
LONDON, June 1 -- The stock markets here continued to go ahead today, with evidence of fresh buying of equities for both yield and post-war prospects.

LONDON, June 1 -- The Germans are now awaiting the opening of a Russian offensive in the central and southern sectors of the eastern front after the failure of their short-lived attack in the Jassy area, which has produced little but heavy losses in men, armor and aircraft after forty-eight hours of incessant fighting.

Yesterday was important for many New Jersey sports anglers because it was the day that striped bass fishing along the State's shore became legal. New Jersey has a closed Period from March 1 to May 31 during which sportsmen may not take this fish, the law having been passed in 1938.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 -- Ninety-two sick and wounded front-line troops and nine officers and three Army nurses just returned from the battlefields of Cassino and the Anzio beachhead arrived at England General Hospital here today, excited at being home again and happy that the buddies they left behind finally had the Germans on the run in Italy.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Senate recessed after a brief session until noon Monday. The Judiciary Committee approved a resolution extending the statute of limitations in the Pearl Harbor case to June 7, 1945, and calling for an immediate Army Navy investigation into the disaster.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 1 -- What is believed to be the first take-off accomplished by a flying boat from dry land made aerial history when a twenty-six-ton Navy craft took the air from the bed of a dry lake in southeastern Arizona recently and flew 465 miles to the coast at San Diego.

M.M. Freeman Co., Inc., of Philadelphia, was awarded yesterday a new issue of $423,000 Middlesex County, N.J., general improvement bonds, due from June 15, 1945 to 1959. The bankers bid 100.249 for the bonds at 1.10 per cent.

LONDON, June 1 (U.P.) -- King Peter said today that he had asked Premier Subasitch to get in touch with Marshal Tito's representatives before deciding on the final composition of the new Yugoslav Government, adding that the new Premier would be prepared to suggest that one of the Cabinet's Deputy Prime Ministers be a member of the national liberation movement.

After an ownership of only a few days, Henry Goelet, operator, has resold to an investing client of Cuyler Co., brokers, the twelve-story loft building at 164-66 West. Twenty-fifth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, for cash above a mortgage of $120,000.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Below Rome, June 1 -- The luck of the staff of The Stars and Stripes, that remarkable and not altogether appreciated record of soldiering by soldiers, ran out on the afternoon of Monday May 29.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- More war bonds were redeemed in May than in any previous month, the Treasury statement showed today.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP) -- Right-hander George Munger gave only three hits to the Braves, but went out with a dislocated finger during the eighth inning today, as the Cardinals gained an even split in the four-game series with a 4-2 triumph.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- The War Department is preparing to furlough several thousand soldiers who are experienced rubber workers to relieve a critical manpower shortage in the tire industry.
The New York Stock Exchange membership of the late James C. Colgate has been transferred to Chester Apy, and that of William L. Strong Jr. to Robert L. Gill of Mallory, Adee Co.

Tammany turned down yesterday Representative Vito Marcantonio, New York County Chairman of the American Labor party, for designation for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the new Eighteenth Congressional District and designated Representative Martin J. Kennedy, who had been thrown into the same district with Mr. Marcantonio in the Congressional reapportionment.

Disclosing an impending cutback throughout the aircraft industry, Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, of Montana, called last night for immediate Congressional action to forestall any future abrupt contract cancellations in aircraft or other war industries, similar to that at the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation.
In his recent speech Winston Churchill was careful to state that there would be "no dealings with the Vichy government or with any one tainted with that organization."

PEARL HARBOR, June 1 -- Long-range central Pacific Army bombers roamed thousands of miles in the first three days of the week to strike Guam, Truk, Wake, Ponape and the Marshalls bases, fleet headquarters disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- More than 5,200,000 men of this country's armed forces are now on duty abroad or at sea, official announcements revealed tonight. The Navy disclosed that as of April 1 some 1,566,000 Navy, Coast Guard and Marine Corps men were serving afloat or at foreign posts.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY BELOW ROME, June 1 -- Fifth Army Americans broke into the German fortress of Lazio in the hills between Velletri and Valmontone and, swinging sharply to the left, overran an entire ridge to the north of Velletri. The action took place all day yesterday and last night, with consolidation achieved today.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Members of the new board of directors and executive officers of the Chicago North Western railway were elected today. This marked the formal termination of the nine-year-old reorganization proceedings and the return of the property to private management, following the order of Federal Judge John P. Barnes on Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Overriding recommendations of a special subcommittee, the Senate Judiciary Committee reported out today a bill which would extend for another full year the statute of limitations upon courts-martial of Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, Maj. Gen. Walter C. Short or others who allegedly might have been derelict in the defense of Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941.

WASHINGTON June 1 -- Largely as a result of higher prices for agricultural commodities, particularly fruits, vegetables and livestock, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices at the primary market level rose 0.1% cent during the week ended per May 27 to 103.9 per cent of the 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The House of Representatives, which two months ago eliminated the school luncheon program from the agricultural appropriation bill by a vote of 136 to 52, restored the program today in the form of an amendment to a bill for insect and plant disease control. The vote was 133 to 23. The amount allowed was $50,000,000.

Enough butter to meet all rationed demand, including that of the city hospitals, was foreseen yesterday by Francis E. Robinson, chief of the marketing reports devision of the War Food Administration's office of food distribution here.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- Officers and enlisted personnel of the Women's Army Corps will step out this summer in identical dress for dates and recreation in a new one-piece sand-beige rayon shantung uniform designed to specifications by the Quartermaster Corps.

Mayor La Guardia's sealed message to the City Council, presumably his veto of its cut of $5,427,851 in the 1944-45 budget approved by the Board of Estimate, reposed last night in a safe in the office of City Clerk H. Warren Hubbard, who is also the clerk of the City Council.

Out of nothing but water, carbon dioxide and sunlight, plants make sugar. For more than seventy years chemists have been trying to duplicate the process, not in the hope of dispensing with cane and beets, but in the hope of flooding with light one of the more mysterious processes of life.
Mrs. J. Norman Henry and Miss Josephine de N. Henry of Gladwyne, Pa., are at the Plaza.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 1 -- Liquidation of more than 100 Axis firms for an amount estimated between $100,000,000 and $150,000,000 nears completion, it was learned today. Among them are large and small firms covering a wide range of activities, including three banks, one skyscraper, two breweries and two large coffee exporting firms.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- War incomes have raised savings in this country to a total of $128,000,000,000, as compared with peak pre-war savings of $10,000,000,000, A.E. Taylor, a Commerce Department official, testified today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Office of Price Administration today postponed the effective date of producers' ceiling prices for fall and winter outerwear until Sept. 1. The original date, under Maximum Price Regulation 438 which controls prices of those items, was June 1.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 1 -- Stepping in where Dobri Boshiloff and Christo Kalfoff had failed, Ivan Bagrianoff, a minor Naziphile luminary of the Bulgarian Foreign Office, was reported late tonight to have presented a Cabinet list to the Regency Council after less than twenty-four hours of negotiation.

LONDON, Friday, June 2 (AP) -- The Red Army, launching successful counter-attacks yesterday against the German drive north of Jassy in the Moldavian Province of Rumania, killed 800 Nazi soldiers and knocked out eighteen tanks, Moscow announced early today as the battle went into its fourth day.

Tippy Larkin, capable welter-weight from Garfield, N. J., will seek to extend his mastery over his fellow-warrior from the Garden State, Freddie Archer of Newark, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. In two previous meetings with Archer, Larkin had no trouble showing his superiority and he is the 5-9 choice to make it three in a row.

Hustled away fast by Ted Atkinson, Col. C.V. Whitney's fleet-stepping Boojiana yesterday gave 18,056 racing fans one of those thrills they never forget with her triumph in the $11,750 Top Flight Handicap.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The small nations were reassured by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at his press conference today that their rights and position would be safeguarded in the framing of the over-all world security organization that he and President Roosevelt contemplate and that Great Britain, Russia and China have been invited to assist in perfecting.
LONDON, June 1 (AP) -- Note circulation increased 7,732,000 to the new high record of 1,135,539,000, the Bank of England reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Senator McKellar's amendments to the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill, with particular reference to the Tennessee Valley Authority, were rejected in the House today by a standing vote of 138 to 24. The measure went back to conference with a negative vote also registered against another McKellar rider, the provision for Senate confirmation of all Government employes drawing $4,500 or more.

Due mainly to the fact that money in circulation jumped $201,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, which covered the long holiday week-end and also the month-end, member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City and throughout the country lost excess reserves during the week, according to figures released yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- A theory that the German submarine which stopped the Portuguese refugee ship Serpa Pinto in mid-ocean Friday and seized two Americans as prisoners needed a good barber was advanced today by the brother of one of the men taken.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- A proposal by Lehman Brothers of New York, heading a group of underwriters, to purchase as principals 57,337 shares of the 6 per cent preferred stock of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation from the Atlas Corporation for public distribution was exempted today from provisions of the Investment Company Act by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Confidence in the outlook of the independent retailer and wholesaler in the post-war period, although keener competition may be expected, was expressed yesterday at the closing session of the war conference of the National Wholesale Jewelers Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, June 3 (U.P.) -- Reinforced American Sixth Army troops on Biak Island have driven to the top of Mokmer Ridge, where strong Japanese positions blocked approaches to the Mokmer airfield, and already are "mopping up" enemy troops, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today.

IT was no way to treat a distinguished guest. Lieut, Comdr. James H. Crowley was flanked by reporters and photographers for his first press interview since his return from sixteen months in the South Pacific. Then up stepped a Marine officer and caught Sleepy Jim without his short snorter bill, thereby prying a dollar loose from the commander in accordance with tradition.

The chlorine gas that leaked from a tiny hole in a rusted steel cylinder that gave the civilian population in a quarter-mile area of downtown Brooklyn on Thursday a taste of deadly chemical warfare still claimed ninety hospitalized victims late yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP) -- Backed by the three-hit pitching of Bob Muncrief and taking advantage of George Kell's error in the second the Browns defeated the Athletics 3 -- 0, tonight and held on to first place by a fraction of a percentage point.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- British and State Department sources said tonight that they believed the recent delay in receipt of letters in this country from Great Britain was the result of transportation problems and pre-invasion censorship of mail.

NEWARK, N. J., June 2 -- Declaring that the defendants had sacrificed the best interests of the United States to aid a foreign power, Judge Thomas F. Meaney in Federal Court here imposed today maximum prison sentences of two years on six former officials and functionaries of the German-American Vocational League who were convicted May 18 of conspiracy to avoid registering with the State Department as Nazi propaganda agents.

Thousands of New York City's elementary and junior high school students are without teachers, because of the inability of the Board of Education to obtain substitutes for absences that occur daily, with the result that children often are sent home, put with pupils in other classes, or herded into gymnasiums and auditoriums, the New York Teachers Guild charged yesterday.

LONDON, Saturday, June 3 -- The mighty Allied air fleets struck staggering blows Thursday night, yesterday and last night at numerous points on the edges of Hitler's European fortress, hitting railroads, airfields, bridges and radio stations.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Sharp challenges marked the opening of debate in the House today on a $3,920,070,000 appropriation measure submitted for the next fiscal year to cover the Government's foreign economic transactions under Lend-Lease, the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration and the Foreign Economic Administration.
ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP) -- Street cars and buses again were in service today, marking the end of a thirty-seven-hour strike of 3,500 St. Louis Public Service Company operators and maintenance men.

The Regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday a temporary increase in the retail and wholesale ceiling prices of milk in the Catskill and other summer resort areas in the eastern part of New York State. In general, the price of milk to consumers is increased 1 cent and the wholesale price about 1 1/2 cents a quart.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -Production of Warner Brothers' "Hollywood Canteen," which had been halted by the controversy with the Screen Actors Guild over salary rates for "guest" players, will be resumed Monday, under Alex Gottlieb's supervision and Delmar Daves' direction.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 -- A method of providing painless childbirth by anesthetizing the nerves carrying pain fibers as they emerge from the spinal cord was reported today by the University of California.

" Roger Touhy, Gangster," with Preston Foster playing the role of the criminal who now is serving a ninety-nine-year sentence in Stateville Prison, Ill., will begin an engagement today at the Globe. The picture was produced by Twentieth Century-Fox and features Victor McLaglen, Horace MacMahon, Anthony Quinn, Lois Andrews and Trudy Marshall.

An expression that considerations of military security alone should guide the operations of Allied censorship in war theatres was emphasized by President R0osevelt in response to a request from Kent Cooper, Executive Director of The Associated Press, that the President intercede in obtaining release of a recently published interview with Marshal Tito.

Irving Masour, 46 years old, of 580 Empire Boulevard, Brooklyn, the manager of Local 20377 of the Smoked Fish Workers Union, surrendered yesterday in the District Attorney's office on an indictment charging conspiracy and second-degree perjury in grand jury testimony last May 19.

Government war plants in the post-war period should be made available to local communities and the people living in those sections should have every "encouragement and opportunity" to buy and operate the plants and equipment when they can furnish capable management and appropriate equity capital, Jesse H. Jones, Secretary oil Commerce, declared last night at a dinner meeting of the New York Financial Writers Association in the Lexington Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 2 - A special program calling for production of more than 99,275,000 items of Knitted wear for infants and children and men's work socks was announced today by the Textile, Clothing and Leather Bureau of the War Production Board.

The City Council referred to its finance committee yesterday five bills introduced by Council President Newbold Morris, calling for re-enactment of existing special taxes. The taxes, whose renewal for one year was authorized by the 1944 Legislature, are the sales tax, the general business tax, the utilities tax, the conduit tax and the compensating use tax.

EASTERN COMMAND, United States Strategic Airforce Somewhere in the U.S.S.R., June 2 -- Starting a shuttle bombing program, which opens up the possibilities of reaching every target in German-held Europe, huge American Flying Fortresses landed today for the first time at this new American air base in Russia after dropping tons of bombs on enemy targets in eastern Europe.

Full departmental honors were accorded Lieut. Harold J. Curran of Engine Company 16, South Beach, S. I., who was killed while fighting a ship fire on the east shore of Staten Island last Monday night, at a funeral service held yesterday at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in West Brighton.
LONDON, June 2 (AP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin:

The stock market underwent yesterday a further pause for the technical operations of consolidation and correction, while moderate profit-taking in the wake of the sustained advance produced a mixed and irregular close. Selective trading ruled during the session, which witnessed a contraction in volume despite the maintenance of activity in the lower-priced motor issues.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Orders were issued by the War Manpower Commission to its regional directors today to put into effect by July 1 the plan to give industries most important to the war first call on all available male labor.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Transportation Board of Investigation and Research recommended today to the President and Congress that the Interstate Commerce Commission be directed to suspend for the war's duration restrictions which it said hamper the efficiency of motor freight carriers.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Army is considering the possibility of turning one of the training centers no longer needed for soldiers into an asylum for war refugees, pending permanent relocation of these unfortunates, President Roosevelt said at a press conference today.

Paper being scarce, the American people join in the collection drives with patriotic zeal and salvage idle paper by trainloads. But, they are warned, they can be too zealous, too enthusiastic in their paper hunts. Julian P. Boyd, librarian of Princeton University, points out the danger that book publishers and many others, presumably including housekeepers, when cleaning out their files and lofts and attics may scrap irreplaceable records of value to librarians, archivists and historians.

Nine tearful, sea-sick hours spent in a lifeboat after a German U-boat commander had threatened to torpedo the Portuguese refugee ship Serpa Pinto were described yesterday by Miss Maria Dias, 25-year-old survivor who witnessed the death of a 16-month-old baby and herself helped save an exhausted mother from drowning.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 -- Alex F. Csonka, a 29-year-old molder's helper in the Continental Foundry and Machine Company at Coraopolis, stole $11,000 worth of radium, but thought all he had taken was a plumb bob.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The War Production Board today issued further regulations governing the use of cans for paint and several other non-food products.

Eugene P. Connolly, secretary of the New York County committee of the American Labor party, attacked yesterday Edward V. Loughlin, leader of Tammany, for his part in denying designation for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the new Eighteenth Congressional to Representative Vito Marcantonio and in designating Representative Martin J. Kennedy.

Lieut. Col. Harold G. Hoffman, former Governor of New Jersey who is in the Army Transport Command, was the principal speaker last night at the graduation exercises of the Kew-Forest School in the Community House, Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 2 -- Since the Vichy Government is bankrupt, one of the tasks of the Allied command after the invasion will be to control the currency and prevent the franc from tobogganing, it is declared here.

Reaction of the secondary markets to the changes in M-317 was felt in Worth Street yesterday, according to downtown wholesalers, who were concerned chiefly with explaining to out-of-town customers why they would not be able to ship many of the orders taken for June production and also why allotments in the third quarter would be cut drastically.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 2 (AP) -- Americans and Chinese, attacking from three sides, are gaining steadily within and outside the north Burma Japanese bastion of Myitkyina, an Allied communique announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 2 -- Rushing through the motions of pledging support of the Constitution and swearing allegiance to the crown, as represented by the Bulgarian Regency Council, Premier Ivan Bagrianoff's rubber-stamp "yes government," less than three hours after publication of its formation early today met in its first plenary session to "handle important affairs of state," according to information through German channels in Sofia tonight.

Under the leadership of Mrs. Bruce Barton, chairman, and Mrs. Charles H. Higgins, associate chairman, the Woman's Division for the annual fund raising campaign of the Travelers Aid Society of New York today will start a drive for $75,000.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 2 -- Nelson T. Johnson, United States Minister to Australia, in a statement today, issued following a trip to New Guinea, said:

The Congress of Industrial Organizations' Political Action Committee made public yesterday an itemized financial statement of its receipts and disbursements from the date of its organization to May 31, showing total receipts of $669,764, consisting of contributions from trade unions, and disbursements of $189,112.

When Prof. Eugen Steinach died recently in Switzerland at the age of 83 the scientific world of modern medicine lost one of its most courageous and outstanding personalities. As a disciple who aided in introducing his theories and methods in this country I feel it a duty to pay a tribute to him.

For the first time in the sixteen years of its existence the annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, which will open in St. John's Lutheran Church, Albany, N.Y., on Monday, at 8 P.M., and continue through Thursday, will function without a head.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -- The Milwaukee (Wis.) Electric Railway and Transport Company's proposed redemption on June 15 of $100,000 of its 4 per cent first mortgage bonds at par plus interest and its reacquisition of 9,000 of its capital stock shares for $900,000 were approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Cubs and Dodgers drew a crowd of 19,498 fans and Umpire Jocko Conlan drew a shower of pop bottles in a bitter battle under the Ebbets Field lights last night, in which Chicago's cellar dwellers broke their six-game losing streak by beating the Brooks, 2 -- 1.

As Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of Columbia University's School of Medicine, indicates, much good can grow out of the study of post-war medical education now being conducted by a committee of nineteen educators and medical leaders, who are sponsored by the Advisory Council on Medical Education.

Progress in merchandising in the post-war period was predicted by leaders in this field yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at special exercises held by the Laboratory Institute of Merchandising of 45 West Thirty-fourth Street.
ALLIED HEADQUARTER IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, June 3 (UP) -- A communiqu:

A 140-acre farm south of Middletown Village, in Monmouth County, N.J., has been purchased by Morton W. Lieberman of South Orange through the Ray H. Stillman Agency. It was known as the Homestead Farm and for many years was owned by Mrs. F.M. Schad and Geret H. Conover.

SIAN, China, May 20 (Delayed) -- A party of foreign correspondents proceeding to the Chinese Communist areas -- the first such visit in five years -- has spent the last three days in Sian, an important city for the future of China and the future of the Allied continental counter-offensive in Asia.

Public authority securities, for the second consecutive week, featured the new bond offerings here this week. Four issues aggregating $54,013,000 were offered to investors, compared with nine issues for $112,337,000 last week and three amounting to $8,650,000 in this week a year ago.

The Roxane Realty Corporation has sold the sixteen-story store and loft building on a plot 50 by 98.9 feet at 7-9 West Thirty-sixth Street for cash over a mortgage of $247,181. It is assessed at $330,000 and was sold through Magoba Management, Inc., and Adams Co. The buyer is a client of Maxwell Perlman, attorney.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Five New York City newspapers protested at a War Production Board appeals hearing against the granting of 512 extra tons of newsprint to a sixth Manhattan newspaper and asked that the Appeals Board abandon the line of reasoning on which the grant was made.

Prof. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard College Observatory, one of the world's leading explorers of the cosmos, called upon scientists, artists, professional and white-collar workers "not to leave to practical politicians, or to uniformity-producing centralized broadcasters, the shaping of the future, either for the individual or for natural communities."

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz denounced yesterday the action of the March grand jury for handing up a presentment saying that organized bands of criminals operate in Brooklyn and that the alleged condition was due to the failure of law enforcement agencies to do their duties.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- John L. Keeshin, president of the Keeshin Motor Express Company, was accused of violating the Interstate Commerce Act in an indictment returned today by the Federal grand jury before Judge John P. Barnes in District Court. Also named in the indictment were Joseph E. Donovan, vice president and treasurer, and the company itself.
Following is an official translation of the Pope's address to the College of Cardinals yesterday as received in New York by radio and distributed by The Associated Press:

A check at Coast Guard headquarters here yesterday disclosed that forty owners of party boats had received their Captain of the Port departure licenses enabling them to take advantage of the relaxed regulations for off-shore fishing in the Third Naval District and that another forty applications were in the process of being cleared.

For the third consecutive month of sharper paper shortage, total advertising in New York City newspapers showed a loss, according to figures compiled from Media Records. May linage amounting to 8,450,982 agate lines was 7.2 per cent under the corresponding month last year.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 2 (AP) -- Army, with its strength concentrated in the track events, is a heavy favoritie to retain its Heptagonal title in tomorrow's meet that gets under way at 4 P.M. Preliminaries, however, are scheduled to begin at 2:30.

Daniel P. Woolley, regional chief of the Office of Price Administration, expressed concern yesterday over the havoc war has wrought on the "smartness and practicality" of the New York woman's wardrobe and in the next breath offered a solution.

A recent survey conducted by the War Department in one of its Eastern "separation centers" has indicated that 40 per cent of the veterans being discharged from the Army not only do not want their old jobs back, they do not even want to return to their old communities, Fletcher Waller, assistant director of civilian personnel and training for the department, disclosed yesterday.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company reported yesterday a net profit of $22,798,980 for the twelve months ended with March after provision of $76,450,088 for Federal taxes and $6,944,011 for post-war contingencies.

The Battle of the Arctic, almost as vital to Russia as the Battle of the Atlantic was to us, has taken a highly favorable turn. Observers in these chill wastes report that for the past three months Allied convoys have been ferrying munitions and supplies around the North Cape to Murmansk virtually unmolested.

MOSCOW, June 2 -- It was revealed today that the Red Banner award has been conferred on a Ukrainian schoolboy, Kostia Kravchuk, 13 years of age, for saving two regimental standards from the Germans during the Red Army retreat in 1941 and returning them over two years later.

The City Council opened and referred to its Finance Committee yesterday a message from Mayor La Guardia, vetoing its cut of $5,427,851 in the budget for 1944-1945, but promising that "several points" would be added to the ten-point reduction already pledged by him in the basic real estate tax rate.

For the seventh consecutive day the temperature rose yesterday above 80 degrees, and according to the Weather Bureau the "unseasonable warm wave" probably will continue for at least another forty-eight hours.

LONDON, June 2 -- A good week for the stock markets was ended today, with fresh gains seen among leading industrial shares on fresh investment buying. Breweries, tobaccos and motors were wanted, and the only exception to a generally firm trend was the shipping section, where profit-taking caused some declines.

Jenshirl Estates, Inc., sold to a syndicate of investors the apartment house for eighty-four families at 37-16-20 Eighty-third Street, in Jackson Heights, L.I., for cash over a first mortgage of $207,000 held by the Prudence Company and a purchase money mortgage of $25,000 for five years.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Conferences with British spokesmen on development of oil reserves in Arabia owned by British and American interests have resulted in some uncertainty whether a contemplated pipeline, to be financed by the United States Government, will be built, President Roosevelt indicated at a press conference today.

LONDON, June 2 -- The unprecedented destruction visited on Axis Europe in May, which shook the German fortress from the Balkans to the Baltic, was accomplished by more than 118,940 tons of bombs dropped during nearly 94,000 sorties.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A broad ruling that no statute authorized court review of War Labor Board orders came today from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, in a unanimous decision by Associate Justices Justin Miller, Henry W. Edgerton, who wrote the opinion, and Thurman W. Arnold.

Isadore B. Geller, operator, bought the five-story apartment building containing three stores and seventeen suites at 101 West 118th Street, northwest corner of Lenox Avenue, for cash over a first mortgage of $45,500 due Feb. 1, 1948, at 4 per cent.

A drastically revised lumber limitation order which will include specific directions to mills heretofore unaffected by controls will be issued shortly by the War Production Board, it was learned yesterday. At present the order L-335 is confined to modified control over the end-use of lumber by consumers who require more than 50,000 board feet a quarter.

READING, Pa., June 2 -- Only the war enabled the New Deal to end unemployment, Maynard C. Krueger of Chicago declared today in a keynote speech to the Socialist National Convention. He added that Democrats and Republicans were united behind "the outworn formula of a return to free enterprise."
KANDY, Ceylon, June 2 (UP) - A communique:

STANTON, Del., June 2 (AP) -- The Montchannin Handicap featured the racing at Delaware Park today as the first in a series of five races of increasing distance each Friday. O. S. Jennings' Blue Sash won by three lengths from Declared.

NEWARK, N. J., June 2 (AP) -The Baltimore Orioles leaped into a tie with Toronto for second place in the International League tonight by thumping the Newark Bears, 9 -- 7, for their seventh consecutive victory.

FRARMINGHAM, Mass., June 2 -- Ch. Warland Warboy, imported Airedale terrier owned by Mrs. Leonard Smit of Monsey, took his third best of show award today, capturing first honors in the annual fixture of the Ladies Dog Club, held on the Raceland estate of John R. Macomber.

LONDON, June 2 -- Pope Pius declared today that the idea that the war must end in a complete victory or complete destruction was "a stimulant toward prolonging the war." Expressing hope for an early peace he praised "the heralds of wisdom and moderation" as against those "who openly espouse vengeance."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Extension of wartime price and rent controls for another year, with authority for the continuation of the meat, milk, butter and flour subsidy programs, but permitting no others, was voted unanimously today by the House Banking and Currency Committee as it entered its own bill into a race with the recently reported Senate bill.

The increasingly large part that community houses must play in the post-war period was discussed yesterday by 225 settlement house and othe social agency workers at the Spring conference of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York, held in the Town Hall Club 123 West Forty-third Street.

Uncertainty over price legislation and completion of purchases against sales of spot cotton to Spain left the local futures market technically slightly easier yesterday and final prices on the Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 3 to 6 points.

" Skating Vanities," a musical extravaganza on roller-skates, will open tonight at Madison Square Garden and remain through June 11. The proceeds of tonight's performance will go to the newly formed Post-War Blind Aid and Welfare Fund of the Lions Club of New York to aid in the rehabilitation of blind service men.

The double bill of "A Strange Play," a two-act work by Patti Spears, and "According to Law," a one-acter by Noel Houston, which Eugene Endrey opened at the Mansfield Theatre on Thursday evening, failed to give a performance last night, thereby earning the dubious distinction of being the first production in two seasons to close after a single performance.

Isadore B. Geller, operator, resold the five-and-one-half-story apartment house for forty-one families at 86 West 183d Street, southwest corner of University Avenue, in the Bronx, for cash over a first mortgage of $99,900 at 3 per cent.

On the wings of two more home runs that sailed off the magic bat of Melvin Ott, the Giants yesterday extended their winning streak to seven games at the Polo Grounds by upsetting Frankie Frisch's Pirates in the opener of a four game series, 6 to 4.

Wall Street prepared yesterday to battle a Treasury Department ruling that whenever a firm changes a partner, all its stocks are subject to the Federal stock transfer tax. The New York Stock Exchange and the Association of Stock Exchange Firms indicated ithat, if necessary, they will carry the case to the United States Supreme Court to protect their members.

There seems to be a gap between our knowledge of what to feed children and the way we feed them. The result is that large numbers of children develop a rebelliousness against the foods that are good for them.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, June 2 -- The saying is that all good troops must grouse about something but up in the front lines around Velletri and Valmontone where the enemy's fiercest resistance has been encountered, there have been two notable exceptions to the time-honored soldiers' custom.

DETROIT, June 2 (AP) -- Rudy York smashed a two-run homer in the first inning today to provide the runs needed for a 4-to-1 decision over the Red Sox and Detroit's seventh successive victory, the club's longest winning streak in five years.

HAVANA, June 2 -- Wild enthusiasm swept Cuba today as the election returns showed a former Chief Executive, Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, an opposition candidate, had been elected President to succeed General Fulgencio Batista.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -The Cardinals, making their season's debut here before 20,339 fans tonight, shoved five runs across in the eighth inning, after pounding Ken Raffensberger out of the box, for a 9 to 3 victory.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- At least another week will be required to determine whether or not the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation's Long Island City plant can be used for the production of parts for Corsair fighter planes and ship them to the Chance-Vought and Goodyear companes for assembly, T. P. Wright, director of the Aircraft Resources Control Office, advised Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, by telephone from New York tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 2 -- After shadowing an enemy convoy consisting of eleven vessels for more than thirty hours, Middle East Royal Air Force planes late yesterday afternoon struck with skill and precision in the central Aegean, north of Crete, leaving two merchantmen and two escorting warshps burning fiercely and inflicting heavy damage generally on the entire group of ships.

BARI, Italy, May 29 (Delayed) -- German paratroopers, supported by glider-borne infantry, swarmed down and captured the Bosnian headquarters of Marshal Tito on May 25 but failed to catch the wily Yugoslav leader, Partisan sources disclosed today.

In the bright lexicon of youth, as widely studied in recent years in Eire, the outstanding word seems to be Fail; or to be full and precise, Fianna Fail. The word is considerably more popular today than before the general election in which Prime Minister de Valera appealed to the country against a hostile snap vote in the Parliament.

LONDON, June 2 -- The Royal Navy has struck two sharp blows at German coastal shipping whose importance is increasing as the Allied air assaults on continental railroads multiply, it was revealed today.
Some of the most delightful reading that comes my way I find in your occasional editorials on some of the homely chores connected with farm life.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder dismissed yesterday the defense entered by David Sullivan, president of Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, in an action brought by five union members, who charged that Sullivan, James J. Bambrick, deposed president, and George Scalise, imprisoned former president of the international, had conspired to divert $300,000 of the local's funds to their own use.
Small homes were involved in most of the Brooklyn realty deals reported yesterday. Several sales were made by the Home Owners Loan Corporation.

LONDON, Saturday, June 3 (AP) -- German troops, attacking savagely with large forces of tanks and infantry through the fourth day of their battles in Moldavia Province of Rumania, have driven northwest of Jassy, Moscow acknowledged last night.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- An appeal to all war workers to stay on their jobs "at this critical period of the war," was voiced tonight by Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, who declared there was no immediate prospect of susbtantial cutbacks in war goods output.
NAPLES, June 2 (UP) -- A communique:

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's big Venezuelan iron ore development, first disclosed as a prospect a few weeks ago, is now under way. Twenty American engineers and technicians are in charge, with some 600 native Venezuelans, skilled and unskilled, at work on the big project.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- When the invasion of western Europe begins, tactical air power will come into its own. This, however, does not mean that fighter planes and fighter-bombers will be used primarily to strafe and bomb counter-attacking enemy troops or to break up beachhead fortifications, for tactical air power can be used more effectively for other purposes.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 2 (AP) -- Roosevelt supporters were circulating petitions today asking that voters in the Texas Democratic primary be permitted to demand legislation requiring Presidential electors to support their party nominee.

W.E. Woodward, whose recent work, "The Way Our People Lived," chronicles the daily life of ordinary Americans from the seventeenth through the nineteenth century, already has completed a book for publication by Dutton early in 1945. It is a study of Thomas Paine.

BOSTON, Mass., June 2 -- Julius Hochman, general manager of the New York Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers, representing 100,000 organized dressmakers in the New York area, announced today at the convention of the I.L.G.W.U. that his union would take steps to help form a nation-wide employers organization in the dress industry as part of a comprehensive program to preserve high wartime, production and employment m the post-war period.

Dr. Grau San Martin's election came as a result of his second bid for the Presidency since the revolutionary period in 1933, when he served as Chief Executive for several months. In 1940 he was defeated by President Batista, and in his recent campaign he was the candidate of his Cuban Revolujonary party and the newly formed Republican party.

With demand for summer apparel and accessories continuing strong, retail trade here this week again showed substantial gains over the like period a year ago. Estimates put department store volume at 15 to 18 per cent ahead of 1943.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Liquidation was on today in the grain markets and houses with Winnipeg connections were heavy sellers of wheat and rye, adding to the bearish sentiment engendered by excellent weather and crop reports from the Southwest; good showers in many parts of the Northwest and the largest purchases of cash corn for deferred shipment from the country since mid-January.

Recognizing the danger of a breakdown in automotive transportation in this area, the War Manpower Commission designated yesterday the occupation of automotive mechanics as critical in New York City, Long island, Westchester and Rockland Counties, it was announced by the local Office of Defense Transportation.

LONDON, June 2 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace of the United States, en route to China, told a Russian audience that full collaboration among the United States, the Soviet Union and their allies was necessary to insure world peace, the Moscow radio said tonight.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- The White Sox bunched six of their eleven hits into a four-run second inning tonight to beat the Senators, 5 to 2, before 13,286 fans and cilmb out of the cellar into seventh place. Thornton Lee, veteran southpaw, scattered nine Washington hits for his season's first victory after losing his first six decisions.

CLEVELAND, June 2 -- The fivegame losing streak of the champion Yankees ended tonight in the huge Municipal Stadium. The world champions celebrated their season's debut here by turning back the Indians, 5 to 1, in a game delayed ten minutes because of a shower.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The proposal of the National Labor Relations Board to broaden the rights of employers to petition it for a vote of their employes was endorsed today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, with qualifications.
Pensive's "great day" is finally at hand -- the day when a question racegoers have asked time and again after his memorable triumph in the Kentucky Derby finally will be answered.

LONDON, June 22 -- Dr. Ivan Subasitch, the new Yugoslav Premier who intends to go to Bari, Italy, within the next two weeks or so to open unity negotiations with representatives of Marshal Tito, spoke today the first positive words of praise yet heard for the guerrilla leader from the leadership of the Royal Yugoslav Government in London.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 2 -- Further proof of the public's desire to take sterner measures to correct wartime manpower shortages and labor turnover is revealed in the reaction of the country toward the Bailey-Brewster "work or be drafted" bill.

A special meeting of stockholders of Consolidated Laundries Corporation has been called for June 19 to consider proposals to change unissued $7.50 preferred stock into $5 preferred stock, to discontinue cumulative voting in the election of directors, and to permit meetings of stockholders to be held outside the State of Maryland, where the company was incorporated.

Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey announced yesterday that 2,000 additional wire baskets were being placed in the city's streets to help salvage more waste paper, as a result of his having obtained a priority for the necessary metal to repair old Department of Sanitation containers that needed new bottoms.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from the Moscow radio and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Factories have far outstripped business concerns in providing pleasant and comfortable surroundings for women workers, according to the decorator, Majeska, who outlined her ideas for improvement in the planning of women's offices during an interview at her studio at 1 East Fifty-seventh Street yesterday.

The Screen Publicists Guild of New York, a CIO affiliate, has petitioned motion pictures companies not to take part in the International Trade Fair in Barcelona, Spain, it was announced yesterday. The Guild has protested acceptances of invitations by Warner Brothers, Universal and Paramount Pictures, both in letters to the individual companies and to Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc.

BOSTON, June 2 -- President William Green of the American Federation of Labor told the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers today that a joint delegation representing the AFL and the British Trades Union Congress was being sent to Italy to aid in the rebuilding and maintenance of a democratic trade union movement in that country.
BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- In addition to limiting the Reds to three hits, Jim Tobin, the Braves' ace right-hander, knocked in two runs today while pitching his third shutout victory, 4 -- 0.

ALBANY, June 2 -- Crandall Melvin, Syracuse attorney and banker, who was appointed to the State Judicial Council by Governor Dewey last year, charged today that the Legislature, by ignoring major recommendations of the council, had "grossly wasted" the time and effort of that body.

Lieut. Comdr. Jim Crowley, head football coach at Fordham University before he entered the Navy two and a half years ago, signed a contract yesterday to direct a professional eleven. Crowley accented an offer by Ted Collins, president of the Boston Yanks of the National Football League, to direct the Yanks at virtually his own terms.

Mayor La Guardia condemned last night what he said was entirely too much talk, "sometimes from high authoritative places," about the meaning of the Atlantic Charter and voiced his own view that it meant exactly what it said and was issued as a pledge of hope to humanity during democracy's darkest hour.

ALGIERS, June 2 -- In the midst of the apparently confused diplomatic situation that has aroused much indignation here, the French Committee of National Liberation, after five hours of discussion, changed its mind late tonight and decided formally to call itself the Provisional Government of the French Republic.

CHUNGKING, China, June 2 (AP) -- The Japanese have captured two strong points -- east of Changteh and northeast of Changsha-after incessant pounding of the Chinese defenders along a 120-mile front, and new battles have developed for those two major enemy objectives in the Hunan Province offensive, the Chinese High Comm-nd said tonight.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 2 -- Although the Indiana delegates to the Republican National Convention are overwhelmingly in favor of Governor Dewey of New York for the Presidential nomination, the State convention rejected today a proposal to instruct for him.

Starting a campaign of education against black market operations in gasoline, A. Clarke Bedford, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Committee of Rationing of the Petroleum Industry War Council, warned 150 members of the council yesterday that racketeers might get control of the gasoline industry.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Roosevelt said today that the United States had produced more than 175,000 planes between March 11, 1941, when the Lend-Lease Act was passed, and April 1, 1944.

LONDON, June 2 (U.P.) -- The German radio said today that heavy Allied forces are being concentrated in the Middle East and predicted that an Allied invasion of the Balkans will precede the attack in western Europe.

LONDON, June 2 -- The encirclement of Hitler's European Fortress by American air power has been completed. The establishment of American bases in Russia and their use in "shuttle operations" is the "outstanding strategic development of the war in the air" during the last year, according to one high officer of the United States Strategic Air Forces.

David Dubinsky's remarks a day or two ago in Boston belong with the comments of R. J. Thomas in Detroit, earlier in the week, as examples of labor statesmanship. Mr. Dubinsky is the highly efficient president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

Tippy Larkin's right hand served him to better advantage than did his vaunted boxing ability in his scheduled ten-round bout with Freddie Archer of Newark at Madison Square Garden last night. Outpointed in the early rounds, the Garfield (N.J.) welterweight brought the weapon into play to such good effect that he registered an eight-round technical knockout.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The country's four major meat packers -- Swift, Armour, Wilson and Cudahy -- were accused today in suits filed in Federal District Court of violating Office of Price Administration regulations by selling pork cuts containing amounts of fat exceeding OPA rules.

A House vote of 138 to 24 on Thursday blew the fuses on Senator McKellar's latest effort to wreck the Tennessee Valley Authority. The Memphis statesman had succeeded in tacking to the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill a rider requiring TVA to turn in its receipts and come to Congress for its money.

I. Munro Blanchard, Charles W. Snow, John Watts and Richard R. Thomas will organize the New York Stock Exchange firm of Blanchard, Snow Watts on June 19. Mr. Blanchard and Mr. Watts will retire from C.N. Edge Co. on June 17.

Ever since the impending invasion of western Europe by the armies of the United Nations became a market factor, brokers have been paying close attention to the technical position of the stock market. Some declare that the invasion is almost the only factor worth considering at the moment, so dominant has it become in the thinking of investors.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 2 (AP) -The pace-setting Jersey City Giants lengthened the Chiefs' losing streak to ten games with a 5-3 victory tonight. Andy Hansen gave eleven Syracuse hits, including a homer by Al Mele, but fine support helped him out of serious trouble.
In your editorial of May 29, "The Brazilian Division," you speak of "a French adventurer who seized Rio de Janeiro in the seventeenth century."
