In the strained expectancy at the back of all our minds as to when and how the great invasion will happen, we have had an invasion on our own which has taken us almost completely by surprise. We had been warned that we must billet some troops, and with a certain amount of resignation our women-folks had dusted them rooms and given the once-over to stairs and carpet.

The facilities of Cumberland Street Hospital in Brooklyn, already overtaxed with victims of the chlorine gas seepage, were strained further yesterday as a result of two mishaps aboard an Allied Nations freighter tied up for repair and overhauling at Pineapple Street.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Several defendants in the seditious conspiracy trial were linked today with activities of the German-American Bund in the first evidence presented to the jury.

ALBANY, June 2 -- The extraordinary grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany County indicted Albany's 76-year-old temporary Mayor, Frank S. Harris, today on a charge of conspiring to retain in city office an official subject to removal for refusing to testify before the grand jury.
I The election of Richard W.I Lawrence as campaign chain?an of the 1944 fall drive of the lew/ York War Fund was announcedl yesterday by Lindsay Bradford, I president of the Fund.

Executives of various branches of the motion picture industry in the New York area joined yesterday with representatives of the Treasury Department's War Finance staff in a preliminary meeting in behalf of the Fifth War Loan drive for $16,000,000,000, which will begin officially on June 12.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Federal departments and agencies were accused today by the Byrd Joint Economy Committee of having failed to make a "conscientious" effort to reduce to a minimum their use of automobiles and gasoline during the war-shortage period.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Taking issue with the War Labor Board's announced endorsement of maintenance membership and the check-off in the "Little Steel" case, Thomas F. Patton, counsel for the Republic Steel Corporation, urged today the denial of these USW-CIO demands, the purpose and effect of which he declared to be the building up of a slush fund for use in State and national elections.

The full impact of the latest order of Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commissioner, affecting male workers after July 1 probably will not be felt immediately in New York City as it affects ceilings on the number of employes an employer may retain on his payroll, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional WMC director, indicated yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., June 2 -- A chemical, process aimed at increasing the production of nicotinic facial, a frequency modulation receiver and a number of devices in the field of photography are of special interest among the 522 new patents listed in this week's issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.
LONDON, June 2 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Food brokers are not worried by the new Government requirements of canned foods, except in the case of fruits and fish, it was learned in the trade yesterday. There are ample stocks of citrus juices and vegetables of the lower grades now in the hands of distributors generally, brokers reported.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- By unanimous vote, the House Committee on Roads, reported out today a bill providing for the expenditure of $1,500,000,000 at the rate of $500,000,000 a year for three successive post-war years for construction of roads and bridges and elimination of hazards at railroad crossings.

Adolf Hitler, pleasantly incarcerated in the Landsberg Fortress in April, 1924, conceived a plan for making Germany the dominant Power in Europe. His ideas at that time probably did not run to making her the dominant Power in the world. He had not even conquered his own people.

The analysis of the emotional state of the returned soldier as revealed by members of the American Psychiatric Association is not new to those who have had members of their families come home from battle. It needs no great psychical penetration to realize the mixed feelings of relief and, let us call it, regret at' escape that fill the minds and hearts of men who have been for a long time under fire.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY BELOW ROME, June 2 -- The hard-pressed Germans lost the key strongholds of Velletri and Valmontone in their Rome defense line in the past twenty-four hours, leaving the Americans with a clear field for a thrust at the last mountain nucleus between them and the Italian capital.

A resolution urging the appropriation of $500,000 by Congress to implement activities of the Federal Fair Employment Practices Commission was adopted yesterday at the closing session of the three-day conference of the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress.

There's music in the meadows these June mornings. The male bobolinks carol from their perches on tall weeds or strong blades of grass. The female is busy hunting insects for the babies in the grass-lined nest snuggled on the ground. Rarely is it possible to flush Lady Bobolink, because her mate, is an alert watchman.

RICHMOND, Va., June 3 -- With Gregg Cherry, the Democratic nominee for Governor of North Carolina, and Frank C. Patton, the Republican nominee, committed to the advocacy of a referendum on State-wide prohibition, it seems probable that the Legislature will provide for such a vote next year.
Closing prices yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange showed a net loss of 2 to 4 points, but they were somewhat above the lowest levels of the day.

Marking the final stage of summer buying, many buyers were here last week, cleaning out the remnants of seasonal merchandise, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

LONDON, June 3 -- As it becomes apparent that the liberation of Southeastern Europe from Nazi oppression depends more upon Russian than upon Anglo-American arms, the question naturally arises of the Soviets' future intentions in that region.
LONDON, June 3 -- In England this past week there has been an atmosphere of curious unreality. There has been little outward evidence of tension.

Main floor trade was active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Neckwear departments were busy.

The schedule of Commencement Week activities for the graduating class of Hunter College was announced yesterday by Hannah M. Egan, dean of students. A senior dinner, to be held on June 12 at the Park Central Hotel, will open the festivities. On June 14 there will be a theatre party, with groups of students attending either "Oklahoma," "Carmen Jones" or "Othello."

A dispatch received by The United Press here yesterday from Democratic Yugoslavia, the news agency of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, said that three American airmen who parachuted from their plane near the Yugoslav village of Stanci on May 7 had been rescued by General Mikhailovitch's forces after German machine-gun fire had killed two others.

Columbia University's 190th commencement program will begin today at 4 P.M. with a baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel on the campus. Degrees and certificates will be conferred upon 3,081 candidates by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, on Tuesday at an outdoor ceremony on the steps of the Low Memorial Library.

FOUR stars descended on a hot dusty airfield in Africa one day while American forces fought grimly for ground not too far beyond. Had they been stars on a general's shoulder they could have received no more startled glances from the fighting men.

SEATTLE, June 3 (AP) -- A man early today abducted 5-year-old Florence (Susie) Marks, a naval doctor's daughter, from her bed and abandoned her, huddled in a blanket, on a doorstep fourteen blocks from her home.

In a collective action unprecedented in the annals of New York State Workmen's Compensation Law, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi of the State Labor Department dealt a blow yesterday at a widespread "kickback" racket by revoking the licenses of nine Brooklyn physicians to treat compensation cases and suspending 263 others for periods ranging from one month to two years.

EDWARD A. GOLDEN, producer of the phenomenally successful "Hitler's Children," which cost $175,000 and to date has piled up a gross of approximately $4,000,000, is out to try to repeat that spectacular performance with another film about the Nazis.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (U.P.) -- Roy D. Moore, Ohio publisher who is managing Governor Bricker's campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, said tonight:

FOR the final show of the season at the Buchholz Gallery, Curt Valentin has assembled sculpture, oils, watercolors and drawings by a score of modern artists. It is an attractive and highly diverse display, as the sculpture alone would prove.

THE Office of Dependency Benefits at Newark disburses $3,000,000,000 yearly to 5,250,000 soldiers' families, but it is more than a paymaster. To judge from the letters it receives -- and it gets 60,000 a day -- it is also counselor, confidant and friend in need.

Ninety-nine Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

An aptly named colt made racing history yesterday when Bounding Home bounded home in front of Pensive, Platter and Who Goes There, the magic names in the $72,570 Belmont Stakes, feature of the closing day of the spring meeting at Belmont Park and one of the three gems in the triple crown, the other two being the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes.

HERE is a book with a theme fit for a concise psychological novel. A young girl, Augusta, grows up with a sense of frustration so ingrained that it dominates each step of her life, driving her from selfishness to jealousy and from hate to destruction. Out of a warped love for her father springs the fantastic scheme to kill her stepmother.

SELDOM is a country as well served by its official representatives in a foreign country as the United States was served by its diplomatists, its consuls and its attaches in Berlin in the last several years before Pearl Harbor.

AT A CHINESE COMMAND POST ON THE SALWEEN RIVER, May 23 (Delayed) -- On a railroad bench in the mountains above the Salween River two G.I.'s were rigging their "shelter halves" over a field radio set this morning.

If one can judge the reactions of soldiers to motion pictures here a fair sample, then Hollywood has failed dismally in presenting the war. The gate receipts are no more the criterion than is the quantity of local beer (an insipid concoction, I assure you) that is consumed an indication of its popularity.

THE motion picture division of the Office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs is momentarily awaiting Congressional decision on its plan to become an autonomous production corporation under the firm name Hemisphere Films, Inc.

IN June, Mockorange carries on the tradition of pervasively fragrant, lavish, and yet individually beautiful flowers that lilacs have let fall, and that no shrub later in the season can quite attain. With all its charms, it could get away with much more temperament about soil and place in the sun than it does.

LONDON (By Wireless). ON some future tomorrow etymologists still unborn may list and explain many of the colorful words and terms used in this war by the United States Army Air Forces. But the chances are slim that they will ever deal with the most expressive and vigorous of those words.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The issue of whether the tendency of the Federal Government to control and develop the water resources of the country should continue or whether the States should maintain their rights in this field is presented in a referendum now being taken by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States among its member.

METROPOLITAN cyclists tired of urban bicycle paths, are finding Long Island's quiet back roads to their liking. From Brooklyn and Queens they may travel out to the more rustic island spots on their wheels. For residents of other sections of Greater New York the Long Island Railroad is convenient.

Sales of New York grocery chains increased in April, 1944, over a year ago by 13.4 per cent on the average, according to a canvass of the trade last week. Relaxation of rationing, larger and more varied stocks and price reductions to move slow goods were the causes for the increase generally given, rather than any aggressive sales drives.

If the inch worms, tent caterpillars and other voracious, crawling hordes only leave us our fair share of shade and vegetation, June will take care of itself. It will be bright with roses, sweet with strawberries, succulent with fresh green peas. It will bring days touched with the cool breath of early May, nights scorched with the fire of July, and everything between.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -- John B. Kelly Jr., 17-year-old son of the former Olympic and world's champion sculler, won the national interscholastic singles sculling crown today in the tenth annual national interscholastic rowing championship regatta on the Schuylkill River.

With seventy-one persons still hospitalized after inhaling the chlorine gas that escaped from a tank Thursday while being transported on a truck through the Myrtle Avenue section of Brooklyn, Assistant District Attorney Nathan W. Math of Kings County announced yesterday that an investigation to determine whether criminal negligence was involved in the incident will get under full swing tomorrow morning.

Dogs reluctant to submit to a measuring of tails twisted and squirmed and stubbornly sat down, but they and other pets proved willing to display their more general charms yesterday at the Park Department's first playground pet show, held in a drained wading pool at Ninety-seventh Street and Riverside Drive.

THE essays which Julian Huxley has published in this volume fall into two groups; those dealing with his special subject, biology, and those which tackle the question of the meaning of the upheaval of our time. All were composed during the war and all but two have previously been published.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Wartime strike figures are disquieting not only to war procurement authorities but to top-flight union leaders as well. It's news when labor leaders vie with each other to halt walkouts, especially when one union leader's point of view is that labor's no-strike pledge should be continued in the post-war period.

CLEVELAND, June 3 -- Lou Boudreau got his first hit of the local series against the Yankees this afternoon at League Park, and it brought disaster to the champions, as well as the first triumph the Tribe has scored over Joe McCarthy's clan this year.
I have just read A.P. Herbert's "The Sky Renamed," in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine. As an amateur astronomer, I know what great confusion would be brought about by a renaming of the stars.
The motion picture, for all its shortcomings, temporizings and lapses from grace, has an all-important advantage over its parent medium, the stage. It possesses the attributes of permanency.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 -- With the opening of a seven-foot needle valve, water will begin pouring into the Madera Canal in San Joaquin Valley tomorrow afternoon from a reservoir created by Friant the world's fourth largest masonry dam, and one more milestone will be passed in California's long fight for an adequate supply of irrigation water.

AFTER the last war we lost the peace by not persuading the German nation that she was beaten. Sometimes I feel, and I hope I am wrong, that indications of that very dangerous softness are appearing again on the horizon.

THERE'S something of the miller moth in Douglas Leigh's psyche. Even through war's murk, when other post-war visionaries concentrate on graver post-war goals, he strains toward the light -- the brave, new light that will flood Times Square at blackout's end.

LONDON, June 3 -- The battle being fought by the civil fathers of Grantham in Lincolnshire over the alleged immorality of American troops flared up today when a gathering described as a private conference of religious leaders and prominent citizens adopted, with unanimity, a resolution condemning the behavior of the men.
All last week Europe, tense and expectant, prepared for the day of invasion -- D-day and H-hour.

LONDON, June 3 -- To his dwindling assets as chief of the Spanish State, Generalissimo Francisco Franco has gratefully added the "kindly words" spoken about him by Prime Minister Churchill in the House of Commons, but in the opinion of many who have watched the recent course of Spanish politics General Franco has, nevertheless, almost overdrawn his account with the Spanish people already.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The National War Labor Board took final steps today in a "showdown" action to end the refusal of San Francisco machinists to work overtime in 104 shops in defiance of board directives.
CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows

LANUVIO, Italy, June 3 -- Phosphorous shells blasted and burned the Germans out of Lanuvio. They crashed into the elevated fortress one after another and they left their terrible mark upon the dead the Germans left. Two battalions of infantry moved up at 3 o'clock this morning to clean out the diehards but the Germans pulled out, literally shelled beyond endurance.

Steps have been taken to prevent "cracking" in the new Victory ships similar to structural failures encountered in a few of the Liberty type, the American Merchant Marine Institute said yesterday. Discovery that a riveted seam is a good crack stopper has led to the use of this theory in Victory ship construction.

The United States last week took the lead in plans for world peace and security. President Roosevelt announced that this country's tentative outline for a post-war organization was ready. At the same time Secretary of State Cordell Hull issued invitations to the British, Soviet and Chinese Governments to open conversation on the proposals.

Furniture manufacturers are now finding for the first time in months that mahogany, considered by many to be ideally suited to the construction of furniture is the most easily obtainable lumber on the market, it was learned yesterday.

THE exhibition arranged as a benefit for the Red Cross and current now at the American British Art Center is not too large. Let that virtue be cited first. There are only twenty-five pictures, each of which has the proper breathing space on the wall.

OVER at the right a little is the summary of the season of 1943-44, along with the figures which prove whatever figures do. As has been noted now and again, the year just ended has seen the theatre in a fairly prosperous state. It has been rather good -- by quantity.

WHEN an opponent has overcalled partner's opening bid, a bid in the opponent's suit is almost universally recognized as a "cue-bid," promising control of the opponent's suit and implying strong support for partner's suit.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, June 3 -- French Moroccans were pushing fast toward Colle Ferro on the Via Casilina from Montelanico. Another unit took Sgurgola to the east and was also moving on the highway.

IF anyone has lingering doubts that God had his arm around our Alaskan shoulders during the first year of the war this book will dispel them. Here, for the first time, is a detailed record of the appalling muddling, ignorance and waste of men and material that took place between the Alaska Military Highway and the farthest west Aleutians from Pearl Harbor until a few months ago.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Like the minor theme in a great symphony, the internationalist motif recurs throughout the history of our foreign policy, sometimes faint and indistinct and sometimes clear and well defined, but usually dominated by a brassy isolationism, and all too often overwhelmed by the drums of war.

INTERPRETING one's own homeland for the enlightenment of other members of the United Nations entails high responsibilities, since it is only out of the fellowship which comes from understanding that more fruitful cooperation can be developed in the future.

LONDON, June 3 -- The joint parliamentary committee on electoral reform, in a report issued yesterday, placed itself on record favoring a general redistribution of seats in the House of Commons as soon as possible to remove old anomalies.

HOLLYWOOD. CHARLOTTE GREENWOOD will sing in "Life With Charlotte" (WEAF-NBC starting June 13) whenever a song can be worked in naturally She is cast as the keeper of a boarding house in a small city in which she knows everyone.

The Moscow radio, in a domestic broadcast reported by the Federal Communications Commission, quoted the following report, published yesterday morning in the Soviet newspaper Izvestia, on the establishment of "contact and coordination" between the "Red Army Air Force and the Anglo-American air forces":

THE British literary scene is summed up in a trade announcement by that extremely superior firm of publishers, the Hogarth Press, which was founded and directed by Leonard and Virginia Woolf. It is: "Our clients will receive fair treatment and as prompt as circumstances will allow."

ONE of Debussy's less frequently heard works, "En Blanc et Noir" for two pianos, has been recorded by the duo-pianists, Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson (Album X-MX241, two twelve-inch records). Written in 1915, just three years before the composer's death, and when the Germans were dangerously close to Paris, the piece reveals little of the poetic, descriptive Debussy of the better known "La Cathedrale Engloutie," "La Mer" or "Reflets dans L'Eau."

MURDER is done in a crowded bar in Havana, and all the evidence points to Bill Scott, a total stranger to the city and further handicapped by lack of knowledge of the Spanish language. On the way to jail he escapes from the police and finds refuge in Chinatown, where he meets a woman who helps him only because she hates police.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Liquidation of grain futures was on again today on the Board of Trade here, and September, December and May rye and oats sold at the lowest prices of the season, July rye at the inside being 8 1/8 cents a bushel below its high record, made on Thursday.

BOSTON, June 3 -- Further evidence of post-war planning in this canny region comes through a housing survey made by the New England Council for the benefit of myriad citizens who expect better homes in the future. During the ten years after this war about 400,000 new dwelling units must be added to the present number of 2,380,000 units if industrial migrations, family increases and slum clearances are to be handled, according to the survey.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- A vast new program of crop insurance was proposed by the House Agriculture Committee today as a means of making farming "a more sound and profitable occupation."

BALTIMORE, June 3 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested fourteen men and one woman today, accusing them of evading the draft or helping inductees to feign mental ailments in order to obtain deferments.

IT is a former German pillbox, an impregnable little fortress with walls six feet thick and solid concrete. It is shaped somewhat like an igloo, but the men in it have a hotter job than any Eskimo. They are American soldiers who man "smoke pots" providing cover for a vital bridge on the Italian front.

THIS is a story of how men have wanted and tried to organize one of their oldest dreams -- the dream of world peace. A compendium of both private and official proposals, it attempts to create an international government which would prevent international wars.

THE recent record-breaking flight of the Lockheed Constellation from Burbank, Calif., to Washington, D.C., in 6 hours 58 minutes has suddenly brought into sharp reality what hitherto has been, as far as the general public is concerned, mere speculation and prediction about the potentialities of commercial travel on the global skyways of the future.

Changes in the undergraduate curriculum of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to meet special requirements of education in science, engineering and architecture after the war, have been approved by the faculty, Dr. Carl T. Compton, president of the institute announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 3 (U.P.) -- A powerful German attack on Yugoslav partisan mountain strongholds in western Bosnia, which was reported to have resulted in capture of Marshal Tito's headquarters, is still raging after ten days of heavy assaults by Nazi troops, planes and armored forces, it was announced today.

THE time of annual awards for the best this and that is upon us once more, and the one-man committee which makes the selections for this department each year has met, conferred amiably with itself and arrived at easy and obvious decisions.

Characterizing the application of the anti-Jewish Nuremberg laws in Hungary as "cold-blooded murder," the Senate Foreign Relations Committee yesterday caned upon the Hungarian people to resist the orders of their puppet Government, help Jews to escape across the borders and "watch and remember those who are accessories to murder and those who extend mercy" until the approaching time when guilt and innocence will be weighed.

As of last Wednesday, or May 31, the theatrical season of 1943-44 stepped into the pages of history. During the 366 evenings preceding -- the season started June 1 -- Broadway received 55 plays, 11 musical shows, 4 revues, an operetta, 18 revivals and sundry unclassified items, or enough to bring the total to 93 separate and more or less distinct offerings.

NAPLES, June 3 -- With its armies nearing Rome, the Allied command today placed upon the German military the responsibility for making the city a bloody battlefield or withdrawing and sparing it further ravages of war. The Germans countered quickly with an assertion that Rome "can be regarded as a city free from arn3ed forces."

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 3 -- Tennessee Republicans, hoping to capitalize on such anti-New Deal feeling as exists in the State, are eyeing the possible gubernatorial candidacy of Roy Acuff, singer of hillbilly songs and a radio performer.

WHEN American fliers are sent out on a strike at an enemy task force, the first and last order is: "Get the carriers." The Japanese pilots, however it is said in their language, probably hear the same order. "No wonder then that we feel our importance," wrote Lieut. Max Miller, remembering this, as his carrier stood westward from Pearl Harbor. "

LONDON, Sunday, June 4 (AP) -- German forces fighting a bloody battle for a strategic hill position near Stanca, north of Jassy in Rumania, brought up reinforcements and attacked incessantly yesterday for the fifth consecutive day, but were repulsed in every thrust, Moscow said early today.

Strong tendencies arising from world-wide industrialization and the current technological revolution, together with the effects of the war on the different economic regions, are opposing the trend toward an integrated world economy, Dr. Adolph Lowe, research director of the Institute of World Affairs, concludes in a survey of the outlook for international trade made public yesterday.

From time to time this department has reported on the work that Dr. Oswald H. Robertson of the University of Chicago's Medical Department has been doing to disinfect air and thus to kill the disease germs that it always carries. He sprays either the air of a room and floors with propylene or triethylene glycol, or clothes, bedding and hangings.

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- Bill Dietrich and Gordon Maltzberger pitched the seventh-place White Sox to within a half-game of the first division in the closely packed American League field today by beating the Senators, 5 to 3, for the Chicagoans fourth straight victory.

Jolted for home runs by Frank Gustine and Babe Dahlgren and almost upended as they plunged headlong into the season's first triple play in the National League, the Giants for a time still managed to give as good as they were receiving in the second battle of their current series with Frankie Frisch's Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

BOSTON, June 3 -- Speaking before the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers here tonight Justice Ferdinand Pecora of the New York State Supreme Court asserted that the people of Italy had been deprived of relief from the United States as the result of the machinations of fellow travelers with the Communists, led by Representative Vito Marcantonio.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -- Pennsylvania and Cornell, 1943 co-champions of the Eastern Intercollegiate League, split a double-header today as part of the Alumni Day celebration, the Red and Blue taking the first game, 3 to 1, and losing the second, 6 -- 4.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 3 -- In a surprise thrust eastward across the monsoon-swollen Irrawaddy River, British airborne Chindits have sealed the last escape route for the Japanese garrison cornered in the northern half of beleaguered Myitkyina, front dispatches said today.

An appeal to all physically able citizens of the State between the ages of 17 and 55, whose occupations permit, to enlist now in the New York Guard was made last night by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum. He spoke over radio station WJZ.

THE battle against insects, which started weeks ago with cutworms, reaches a high point during June. Although it may seem as though insects in all shapes, sizes and colors are simply waiting for seedlings to reach a promising stage, not every kind attacks at the same time.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- A spokesman said today that the Justice Department would ask dismissal of suits brought by Montgomery Ward Co. to enjoin enforcement of War Labor Board orders against it.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 3 -- The lynching scare regarding Allied airmen landing in France has subsided as quickly as it rose, it appeared today. It did not last more than twenty-four hours and failed to rally public sentiment.

More than 300,000 children are members of the School Safety Patrol, an organization which protects some 8,000,000 boys and girls at crossings every school day in 3,500 communities in all parts of the country. According to a recent national survey made at thousands of crossings, no school child has been killed in a traffic accident for ten years or more, where a Safety Patrol member was on duty.

RICHMOND, Va., June 3 -- President Roosevelt has written Dr. Douglas S. Freeman, editor of The Richmond News-Leader, congratulating him on authoring the term "Liberation" to replace "invasion," in connection with the coming drive into German-occupied territories.

In a Japanese concentration camp outside Shanghai today, two scholastics of the Society of Jesus will be ordained to the Roman Catholic priesthood by the Rev. Augustin Haouisee, Bishop of Shanghai, the Rev. William Masterson, S.J., of the Jesuit Philippine Bureau, announced yesterday.

Yesterday, just nine months and a day after the first Allied landings on the toe of the Italian boot, Allied armies had reached the gates of Rome. An unbroken continuity of attack had brought them far up from the mountains and beachhead and exacted a high toll of the German legions.

LONDON, June 3 -- The formation of Detachment X to set up American bomber bases in Russia for shuttle bombing in eastern Europe and the establishment of the newly revealed Eastern Command of the United States Strategic Air Forces have been two of the best-kept secrets of this war.
NEWARK, N.J., June 3 (AP) -- Although victims of a triple play in the sixth, Baltimore beat last-place Newark today, 7 to 4, for its eighth consecutive triumph.

DDT, the Army's insect powder, which has been used with great effect against the spread of typhus in Europe, was conspicuous in the news last week. The powder kills lice, termites, moths, roaches, bedbugs, fleas, Japanese beetles, corn borers and other insect pests.
ALGIERS, June 3 -- The French situation, as judged here, could hardly be more tragic or bear greater forebodings of further tragedies to come.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Competing a study of the merits of the ten-hour day with two-shift operations compared with the eight-hour day, three-shift schedule, now widely in use in war plants throughout the country, the War Production Board's Office of Manpower Requirements today submitted a report which left the question still open.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- American dissatisfaction with Finland's course in continuing to aid Germany in the war resulted tonight in the blacklisting for the first time of many of her important concerns by the Interdepartmental Proclaimed List Committee.

A NOTABLE thing about the pictures which that great French director Rene Clair, has made during four years in Hollywood has been the successive advances in each toward a closer realization of the old Clair substance and style.

A 16-year-old youth with a passion for snipping the hair of girls while they slept, as well as robbing private homes to keep himself in funds, was captured early yesterday morning in the girls' dormitory of Wagner Lutheran Memorial College, Grymes Hill, S. I.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Visiting golfers are polishing niblicks and mashies for next Saturday's reopening of the Linwood Country Club greens, which have recently been improved. The clubhouse, newly decorated, opens July 4. On Friday and Saturday the Claridge will play host to newsmen here for the Headliners' Frolic sponsored by the local Press Club.

RAYMOND MASSEY is to star in a series based on the lives of famed physicians at 9:30 P.M. Tuesdays over CBS. It will be entitled "The Doctor Fights" and will call attention commercially to penicillin. The program will replace the Morton Gould-Alec Templeton show, effective this week.

SOUFFLES that are skillfully made -- that are, in other words, fluffy and light and flavorful -- are among the most appetizing of dishes. Their chief ingredients are eggs, a food in superabundant supply, thickened milk, and flavoring materials.

VICTORY gardeners looking for a lasting hobby to hold their attention after the war and to relieve the drudgery of hoeing and canning now, will find in the dahlia a perfect solution to their problem. Each year brings forth a crop of novelty dahlias which make their debut at fall shows, fairs and trial gardens.

ABOARD A BRITISH AIRCRAFT CARRIER, in Northern Waters (Delayed) (AP) -- Planes from a British naval task force gliding through Norwegian coastal waters today dive-bombed and strafed a convoy of three German merchantmen aggregating 20,000 tons, leaving all smoking and burning furiously.

MRS. PUCKETTE gives us a salty picture of the Gullahs, the blue-black Negroes of the Sea Islands. She presents them as simple, childlike people, working hard to wring a living from sea and land. Her most interesting angle is their attitude toward the whites.

LAURENCE STALLINGS, who went back to the Marines when this war started, has turned out a play about the corps -- as might have been expected. With Maxwell Anderson, Mr. Stallings hit the bull's eye as a recorder of that other conflict in the film "The Big Parade" and the Broadway production of "What Price Glory?" (remember Sergeant Quirt?).

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Democratic leaders will watch Mississippi next week for a barometric reading on the spread of a Cotton Belt revolt which has raised some doubts about the South's solidity in the November election.

A broad program of "democratic principles for Europe," to be put into effect as soon as the Allied armies invade the continent, was proposed yesterday afternoon at an emergency meeting of the International Free World Association attended by representatives of nineteen European countries.

One factor which makes political and economic discussion so unnecessarily bitter nowadays is the failure of many men of good intentions to understand that those who disagree with them are usually men of equally good intentions, and really differ only regarding the methods most likely to achieve the ends that both are seeking.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 3 -- The make-up and contents of a recent copy of the Berlin Lokal Anzeiger shows two things -- that German morale is now so low that Goebbels attempts to buttress it with as tendentious an interpretation of the news as possible, and second, that the Reich is facing the long-expected textile crisis.

HAVANA, June 3 -- Despite the quick victory of former President Ramon Grau San Martin, Opposition candidate who swept into the Presidency in Thursday's election by a huge majority, the tardiness in completing the official returns left the public today without information concerning the results in the congressional, provincial and municipal voting.

Nothing can prevent this war from being known in history as the World War. It will probably not be called "the Second World War," a designation rejected by President Roosevelt a year or so ago in favor of "the War of Survival"; the historians of the future will perceive even more clearly than we see today that it is the continuation, the second and larger phase, of the struggle that began in 1914.

LONDON, June 3 (AP). -- General De Gaulle was expected in some quarters today to ask Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, soon after his arrival here, for clear-cut recognition of the National Liberation Committee as sole authority for the French to prevent conflict and confusion after D-day.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 1 (Delayed) -- The leaders of the German-abetted Turanian Fascist movement in Turkey, who are now under arrest awaiting court-martial, had hoped eventually to overthrow the Turkish Government and appoint their own committee of four to the posts of President of the Republic, President of a National Assembly, Premier and Chief of the Army Staff, according to official sources.

Mayor La Guardia has disclosed plans for a "municipal circuit" for the opera, orchestra and new dramatic productions of the City Center. How soon it will be possible to get these plans under way the Mayor did not know. The cities under consideration for the "circuit" are New Haven, Hartford, Providence, Jersey City, Newark, Camden, Baltimore and possibly Boston.

READING, Pa., June 3 -- The nomination of Norman Thomas to stand for a fifth time as the Socialist candidate for President appeared a foregone conclusion tonight as he won major personal victories in bringing the national convention over to his views on foreign policy and political collaboration on the home front.

lVfaj. Gen. Robert O. Davis, executive director of the New York chapter of thb American Red Cross, issued yesterday a statemerit warning the public to give no credence to rumors, 'elieved to be enemy-inspired," that "American service men are charged for! Red Cross blood plasma."

WEST POINT, June 3 -- Army won the tenth annual Heptagonal Games title, as expected, today, scoring 82 points to 68 for second-place Dartmouth, but the day's excitement was reserved for the one-mile relay, which the Cadets grabbed by a narrow edge from the Indians.

A letter which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 18 over the signature of Maurice Leon and which purports to discuss the claim of General de Gaulle and the French Committee of National Liberation to recognition as a provisional authority in liberated France throws so little light on the issues involved that I take the liberty of submitting certain observations for the consideration of your readers.

LONDON, June 3 -- Since the first ship carrying lend-lease food from the United States docked here three years ago this week, Britain has received 4,500,000 tons of food from America, Col. J.J. Llewellyn, Food Minister, has announced.

TIME and again some one is writing a premature epitaph on the boss system. Articles like "The Last of the Bosses" or "The End of the Boss Era" can only represent wishful thinking, not reality. The institution of the boss, always assumed to be moribund, persistently refuses to die.

FRAMINGHAM CENTRE, Mass., June 3 -- The dual awards of best in show and best American-bred in the annual fixture of the North Shore Kennel Club today went to the greyhound, Ewhurst Duke of Waterford, owned by Richard S. West, now in active naval service, and handled by his father, George S. West, New England chairman of Dogs for Defense.

From the University of California came the news last week that Drs. Michael Doudoroff, H.A. Barker and W.Z. Hassid have succeeded in syn thesizing sugar and perhaps duplicating the process that takes place in sugar beets and sugar cane.

Hunter College's pocket-sized campus, consisting of a series of stone steps and balustrades edging a small patch of grass and ivy, has been restored to the students after a brief period of restriction, it was revealed yesterday. College authorities had banned use of the campus after complaints of untidiness and excessive noise were received.

THE Fifth War Loan drive, June 12 through July 8, finds the nation's motion picture theatre owners solidly lined up behind the Treasury Department. All of the knowledge learned through trial and error in past bond campaigns is to be put behind the coming drive, in which the theatre people will endeavor to sell more than 11,000,000 bonds, or one for every man and woman in the armed services.

THE National Opera season in Mexico City will open June 14 with Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde." Conductors for the series will include Gaetano Merola, Jean Morel, Jascha Horenstein, Guido Picco, Carl Alwin and Ignacio del Castill.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 1 (delayed) -- German military authorities in Bulgaria have apparently quashed the minor revolt in the Bulgarian Army and have arrested several leading Bulgarian generals, including General Lukash, Army Chief of Staff, it was reliably reported here today.

WITH "Purser's Progress," a seagoing sportswriter, Tom O'Reilly, has written one of the happier books of World War II -- the happier because he takes the war, but not himself, seriously. "Down to the sea with clips and carbons" went Mr. O'Reilly, his equipment for the merchant marine being, apparently, that he was a patriotic fellow and knew how to typewrite.

FITCHBURG, Mass., June 3 -- A plea for better understanding of the part that education and educators play in our national life was made today by President Leonard Carmichael of Tufts College, who also urged that more money be made available for better salaries, for better teachers and for better educational facilities at every level when the war is over.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -- The Cardinals came from behind today after trailing the Phillies 3 to 0 at the end of the sixth to score three runs in the seventh, one in the eighth and another in the ninth, and win the second game of their four-game series, 5 to 3, before 5,843 fans.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 -- Defiance of the War Labor Board by a few West Coast labor unions is becoming increasingly puzzling to the general body of opinion and is giving genuine concern to many union leaders and friends of labor.

Former service men who have returned to the college and university campus are more serious-minded than they were as civilian students, are more interested in technical and vocational courses leading to immediate jobs than they are in the humanities, do not want to be segregated into special schools or departments, and are finding it rather difficult to readjust their lives from the excitement of the cattlefront to the peace and quiet of the classroom.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House approved today and sent to the Senate the $3,920,070,000 appropriation bill covering for the fiscal year 1945 the Government's foreign economic transactions under Lend-Lease, the Foreign Economic Administration and the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.
PANAMA, June 3 -- Unconfirmed reports of travelers from Honduras told today of a declaration of martial law there following a demonstration for amnesty to political prisoners.

AT a recent meeting, radio engineers discussed the vast and growing importance of industrial electronics. They described, for instance, an almost incredible instrument designed to detect chemical and metallurgical irregularities in materials ranging from huge billets of metal to steel balls in airplane-motor bearings.

THIS is the story of a Polish fighter pilot who, after vainly battling the Luftwaffe over his native land, escaped to internment in Rumania; made his way in disguise to France, where he fought again with a Polish squadron during the tragic month of June, 1940, and then fled once more to England, where he became the rear gunner of an RAF bomber, nicknamed by her Polish crew the "G -- for Genevieve."
THE long, strait, narrow and only path to a streamlined figure is exercise. This is the inescapable verdict handed down by the physiotherapists, whose profession it is to know about such matters.

TO encourage the writing of American operas in general, and of short operas in particular, the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University and the Metropolitan Opera Association will award $1,000 to a work, not over seventy-five minutes in length, by a native or naturalized American citizen.

A report issued last week by the Committee on the Harbor and Shipping of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York calls for State handling of unemployment insurance for officers and crews of vessels engaged in interstate operation.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, under the caption of "Men of the Allied Armies" in teresting portraits are reproduced of soldiers of the armies of the United States, Britain, Russia, Canada, Poland, France, Yugoslavia, India, Belgium, the Netherlands, Greece, Czechoslovakia, New Zealand and Australia.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, June 4 -- American troops slipped across to Owi and Wundi atolls, south of Biak Island in the Schouten group, Friday and occupied both coral-necklaced islets without opposition, Allied headquarters announced today. On the same day, Australian forces, relentlessly pushing up New Guinea's north coast toward trapped Wewak, occupied Karkar Island, northeast of Madang and more than 600 miles southeast of the Schouten area.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- If any one practice can be set down as most characteristic of President Roosevelt's attenuated administration, it is the White House press conference. The first such conferences came before 1933, but it remained for President Roosevelt to develop, amplify and rework them into one of the most potent political forces in the history of the White House.

LILLIAN SMITH, by radio and news reel, has deplored the publicity her novel "Strange Fruit" has received as a result of its Boston taboo, its exclusion from the United States mails and its readmission thereto "at the publisher's risk."

Reports on the weakfishing at Peconic Bay continue to drift in. This one is about a party of six Metropolitan Rod and Gun Club fishermen who made the trip, rented two rowboats and proceeded to give the fish a beating. They fished the bottom.

PERCENTAGE gains in retail trade are becoming more moderate after some of the sharp advances which were registered a few weeks ago. Shortages contribute only in part to this contraction, and the opinion is growing among retailers that the consuming public is tending to become more cautious in its spending or, in some cases, falling back on hoarded supplies.

A young British girl teletype operator employed in the London Bureau of The Associated Press punched out a strip of practice tape yesterday and within a matter of moments was responsible for transmission throughout the United States and Latin America of an erroneous announcement that the Allies had landed in France, The Associated Press announced here.
NEW ORLEANS, June 3 -- Public sentiment voiced by thousands of liquor buyers and liquor drinkers in Louisiana has caused a drop in the price of whisky in Mississippi, which is a "dry" State.

LONDON, June 3 (U.P.) -- The Berlin radio tonight began broadcasting reports that "the invasion is nowhere near." Meanwhile, continental dispatches said the Nazis were strengthening their fortifications along the Spanish frontier and transferring thousands of engineers from the East Front to France to repair bomb-sshattered rail lines leading up to the western invasion front.

The Arvid Samuelson A. Capella Singers gave a concert at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night before an audience that filled the house despite the lateness of the season and stayed on at the close of an excellent program to demand encores. The program, given entirely in English, consisted largely of Russian ecclesiastical choral music, Russian folk songs and Negro spirituals.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Through its Services to the Armed Forces, the American National Red Cross during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1943, brought assistance to 2,409,220 service men and women here and overseas, it was disclosed today with publication of its annual report.

WHILE Jones Beach State Park offers a wide area for summer exploration it is the more dramatic appeal of the beach that draws the big crowds. This year practically all beach facilities are open and weekly hegiras to the widely heralded playground are on.

ICHWAN, North Shensi, China, May 25 (Delayed) -- For four days correspondents in the party traveling to the Communist areas in Yenan have been going north from Tunkwan parallel to the Yellow River -- never more than twenty miles from the enemy bank in Shansi.
Perhaps I expect perfection of my favorite Sunday magazine, but when I see pictures of the "Men of the Allied Armies" I expect to see China represented. The Chinese are still our allies.

IN a recent conversation with Dr. Artur Rodzinski the talk turned upon the results of the reading rehearsals of new American scores which he instituted last winter as part of the program of his first season as director of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

The Army required 26.9 per cent of the steel ingots produced in this country last year, compared with 24.3 per cent in 1942, placing it for the second year in a row as the largest steel consumer in the United States, according to data given recently to the American Iron and Steel Institute by Col. John H. Frye of the office of the Chief of Ordnance, War Department.

In hundreds of cities and towns leaders of the Young Men's Christian Association will assemble Tuesday at "Second Century Day" dinners to mark the centennial celebration of that organization, which was started by a dry goods clerk in one room and now operates 10,000 branches in sixty-eight countries.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- A heat wave with temperature in the upper 80's boomed lightweight apparel sales here in both the men's and women's lines. Department stores reported cotton dress and sportswear sales particularly heavy, with women waiting four and five in line for a turn at the fitting rooms.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Sunday, June 4 (AP) -- A communique:

A comprehensive survey of distribution problems and their effect on the nation's over-all economy has been undertaken from an "engineering point of view" by a special committee of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Fenton B. Turck, chairman of the committee, disclosed yesterday.

In his discerning article, "The Case Against Gobbledygook," Maury Maverick presents a common sense argument for the adoption of more simplified English usage. While Government-issued reports are undoubtedly flagrant offenders, there is a tendency in the business world as well toward the use of stilted language.

As Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell signed orders permanently enjoining eleven of the smaller midtown hotels from charging more than ceiling rates for rooms, the Regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that it had started an investigation of rates charged by eighty small hostelries.

With the arrival of June, the main fighting season of the fifth year of the war has begun auspiciously, and the world is waiting for the outcome which this season must bring. It is the season for which the United Nations have been praying, working and planning, in order to be prepared.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 3 -- Post-war work insurance in the form of jobs on a $112,000,000 California works program appeared assured today as legislators prepared to convene on Monday in another extraordinary wartime session.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 3 -- While the Argentine Government is preparing to celebrate the first anniversary of the June Fourth revolution of last year that delivered the nation to the mercies of military governments with dictatorial powers, Argentine nationalists are threatening to hold an anti-Jewish demonstration if the one-day civil disobedience campaign scheduled for next Wednesday is put into effect.

OMAHA, Neb., June 3 -- The War Food Administration announced this week tentative 1945 goals. To the Middle Western farmer, especially in Iowa, hub deep in mud when he ought to be well on his way toward reaching 1944 goals, this may seem like rushing the season.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 3 -- Jack Poinier of Glen Ridge and A.V. Youngman of the home club defeated the medalist team of Ken Burns and Richard A. Henry of Baltusrol, 3 and 1, in the first round of the Montclair Golf Club invitation tournament today.
CHICAGO, June 3 -- Problems of labor and health are confronting Central Westerners, while farmers in their midst are voicing complaints over Federal regulations.

PEARL HARBOR, June 3 -- The future phases of the war in the Pacific, regardless of when and where they are staged, will bring to a supreme test the kind of amphibious warfare that Americans have developed to a high art and on which almost wholly depends the outcome of the war.

" I CAN get along without Broadway," his best known song goes, "but can Broadway get along without me?" You know the answer to that one Neither Broadway nor Jimmy Durante can get along very well, one without the other, for any great length of time.

THE underworld has few secrets from Jigger Moran. He knows who runs which rackets and to which police officers they pay tribute for protection, and he uses his knowledge to extract more information and to enforce cooperation in whatever enterprise he may have in hand.

Maintenance of earnings in the initial quarter of 1944, despite a somewhat lower rate of production and a consequently reduced volume of business, is indicated in a survey of 299 manufacturing companies. The total net income of these companies, representing fifty different industries, increased $10,230,768, or 3 per cent, to $314,020,481 from the net of 303,789,713 for the corresponding three months of last year.

LONDON (By Wireless). WITH the invasion of Europe two of the most remarkable men produced by the second World War, Gen. Sir B Montgomery and Field Marshal Gen Erwin Eugene Johannes Rommel, will resume the tactical duel which began at Elamein. When first they met in September of 1942 the battleground was a sun-baked expanse of desert, the prize the mastery of the Mediterranean.

Splitting a double-header at Baker Field before a spring alumni reunion day gathering yesterday, Columbia and Dartmouth continued in a tie for the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League with five victories and a single defeat each.
BOSTON, June 3 (AP) -- Butch Nieman collected three hits, including two homers, in four trips to the plate and drove in three runs today to lead the Braves to a 5-to-4 victory over the Reds.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., June 3 (AP) -- Freshman Claude (Buddy) Young won three events and ran a lap on the victorious mile relay team today to escort Illinois to its second successive Central Collegiate Conference track and field championship.

IT is a blue leaflet, one of a series called "Parents Keep Posted," and the line-drawing at the top is one to catch a working mother's eye. It depicts Mrs. Brown, laden with groceries, leading Johnny by the hand from a doorway marked "Play School." The caption is "Mrs. Brown is 'tired out,'" and the first paragraph conveys the familiar lamentation of mothers homeward bound from office or factory:

A group of young women of society who will make their debuts next season will act as ushers Thursday night at the benefit performance of "Jacobowsky and the Colonel" at the Martin Beck Theatre. This theatre party is the second of the two sponsored this spring by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies to augment its children's emergency fund.

WITH the words that recently have been appearing in praise of "Arthur Hopkins Presents" it is agreeable to report that most listeners seem to agree. They have had a little something to say, though, about the hour at which that notable dramatic series is broadcast over WEAF-NBC (11:30 P.M. Wednesdays), nor can you blame them for being pretty annoyed.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY BELOW ROME, June 3 -- Nine months ago this morning, Gen. Sir Bernard Montgomery's Eighth Army, now commanded by Gen. Sir Oliver Leese, crossed the Messina Straits and surged north through Calabria with virtually no opposition.

Completing their day's work in the shortest time for an Ebbets Field game this season, the Dodgers yesterday required only an hour and thirty-five minutes to even the series with the Cubs, big Rube Melton shutting out the Bruins, 4 -- 0, on five hits.

CONCESSION: Not since Germany became organized as a republic in 1919 has there been a monarchist paper in the Reich. The closest thing to a pro-monarchist newspaper before Hitler came to power was the conservative Deutscher Allgemeine Zeitung. Last week, according to a London report, monarchists had their own weekly newspaper, "Der Monarchist Im Krieg" ("The Monarchist in War").

The Wa Food Administration soon will offer at public sale what is left of its 1942 pack of evaporated milk. Bidding will be restricted to industrial consumers who may use the product in baking, confectionery or kindred outlets. WFA still has more than 500,000 cases.

Reports from Sweden disclose that, as of April 1, the Swedish merchant marine consisted of 2,097 vessels, representing 1,452,371 gross tons. At the beginning of this year total Swedish war losses amounted to 226 ships of 570,800 gross tons.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Merchant shipbuilders delivered 155 vessels in May, the Maritime Commission reported today, raising the year's total to 719 ships with a deadweight tonnage of 7,247,557.

THE International Ladies Garment Workers Union holds much the same position in the labor field as Harvard University holds in the educational field: both are regarded as respectable old institutions and wholesome influences.

PEARL HARBOR, June 3 -- The dry tone of today's fleet headquarters' press release gave no indication that it was recording one of the most thrilling one-plane feats of the Pacific war. It sounded like someone was playing "Finlandia" with one finger.

CHUNGKING, China, June 3 (AP) -- Japanese troops driving down the eastern side of the Canton-Hankow railway have lunged an additional twelve miles toward Changsha, their major goal in the renewed Hunan Province offensive, a Chinese communiqu admitted tonight as announcement was made that American planes have been thrown into the fight.

SPRING'S first crop doesn't come from the garden. It breaks in fresh leaf from the nation's printing presses in the form of advice to urban dwellers whose hearts and minds are set on ownership of green pastures.

Reading the casualty lists I notice a striking similarity between the eastern and southern European names and the names on the payrolls of large industrial companies. On both of these lists not more than one name out of ten would be classed as of early American origin.

Last Monday, May 29, when the President signed the Individual Income Tax Act of 1944, this measure, also called the Income Tax Simplification Bill, became law. As its title denotes, the act applies only to the taxation of individuals. Income tax amendments of the act apply generally to taxable years beginning after Dec. 31, 1943.

Something has been said in this column, and perhaps more than once, about a missing item in the fascinating technicolor previews of the post-war American kitchen. The ravished eye takes note of the shining chromiums and alloys and stainless steels that spell economy of labor wedded to beauty.

The pulse of the stock market slackened yesterday, for the second successive day, but prices held steady and the week ended with mixed price changes of slight importance. Trading yesterday was the narrowest in two weeks, with a turnover of 385,540 shares for the two-hour session on the Stock Exchange comparing with 415,300 shares traded a week before.

A WORK of exacting and sober scholarship can afford absorbing reading, especially if it deals (as the present book does) with the central problem for the future of peace and liberty in Europe. Dr. Jordan, an English historian, presents a model of impartial and understanding analysis of Franco-British relations regarding the maintenance of the Versailles settlement.

The establishment of sixteen Air I Warden Service Report Centers, to I which members of the service will report instead of to precinct ofrices, was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine at his offices at Police Headquarters.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, South of Rome, June 3 (AP) -- The Germans were in retreat south of Rome tonight, and the skyline of the Eternal City, crowned by the dome of St. Peter's, stood out clearly despite the smoke and dust of battle.

DETROIT, June 3 (AP) -- Rookie James Bucher hit a four-run homer and drove in six runs today as the Red Sox ended a seven-game inning streak of the Tigers with an 11-to-1 victory. Tex Hugson spaced eleven hits for his sixth victory.

STOCKHOLM, June 3 -- From well-informed neutral sources in Berlin, I have received some information that will aid in getting an idea of how the German High Command views the invasion and the means it has at its disposal to meet the onslaught.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 3 -- It was reported from the Balkans tonight that Regent Bogdan Philoff would be accompanied by the new Premier, Ivan Bagrianoff, when he left for Berchtesgaden tomorrow to deliver to Adolf Hitler the Bulgarian Government's acceptance of the German conditions the Regent brought back from his last meeting in Berchtesgaden on Monday.

LONDON, Sunday, June 4 -- The Calais-Boulogne area of the French coast, the most battered section of Hitler's Atlantic wall and daily target of Allied air attack for almost fifty days, received morning and afternoon batterings yesterday from Liberators and Flying Fortresses with strong fighter escort, a total of about 1,000 planes.

THIS is the fifth volume in Mr. Sinclair's Lanny Budd series, and its concluding sentence must contain at least the 1,500,000th word about Lanny and the history of the Western world since 1913. The first of the series appeared in 1940, which means that Mr. Sinclair has been rolling them out at the rate of about 1,000 words a day.

IN Uruguay's Department of Colonia, directly across the River Plata from Buenos Aires, is a district known as Nueva Helvecia, otherwise New Helvetia or New Switzerland, which was legally created a half-century ago as a "Colonia Suiza" or Swiss colony of homes for Swiss settlers and their descendants.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 3 -- A permanent autonomous Council of National Defense, composed of representatives of all branches of the Government dealing with foreign affairs, "to maintain and formulate" the United States' foreign policy, was proposed here today by Hugh Gibson, former Ambassador to Belgium and Brazil, in an address at the Haverford College commencement.

FROM a well-filled storehouse of varied information Mr. Cherne has assembled the pertinent features which will probably have significant bearing on the rest of your life and mine. It's an after-the-war book which outlines many rosy possibilities -- and, with them, probabilities which have a definitely gloomy cast.

NAPLES, June 3 -- American troops raced through Rome's outer approaches from the south and southeast tonight under orders to destroy the retreating German armies, five of whose eighteen divisions already have been practically annihilated and whose defensive lines have been blasted apart.

WASHGTON, June 3 -- The new aggressiveness of Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, marked by an attitude of "never say die" toward his race for the Presidential nomination, put some new life this week into the otherwise prosaic pre-convention Republican campaign.

Latin and Greek, the subjects which made up the first year of study at Colgate University 125 years ago, have become war casualties, but Dr. J. Curtiss Austin, chairman of the Department of Classics, predicts that interest in these languages will be as great as ever after the war.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 3 -- five-hit pitching by Ed Machaj and a pair of home runs by Dick Mathews were the features of Yale's 8-2 victory over the Princeton nine in University Field today. The Elis broke a 1-1 deadlock in the fifth inning and went on to collect thirteen hits from two Tiger hurlers.

Phthalylsulfathiazole, a new sulfa drug rechristened sulfahalidine and said to be the most effective intestinal antiseptic yet discovered, is announced by the Bituminous Coal Institute. The compound will probably prove highly effective in the treatment of such infections as vacillary dysentery, judging from extensive laboratory tests made at the University of Texas Medical School.

BOSTON, June 3 -- In with a feather of 102 pounds, Fred Lansburgh's Bold Salute scored a length-and-three-quarter victory in today's feature at Suffolk Downs, the $5,000 added Paul Revere Handicap of a mile and a sixteenth, before a crowd of 20,558.

LONDON, June 3 -- Details of a slave-labor town that the Germans were building in Poland for 500,000 political military prisoners have been brought to London by a young Pole who escaped after spending three years in concentration camp.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Summing up the work of various services in placing discharged veterans of the present war in jobs, the OWI reports that only 25 per cent of those discharged from hospitals from May 1, 1940, to the present have been returned to places they held before entering the services.

THIS is a remarkable book, all the more so since it emanates from the editorial writer in chief of The Saturday Evening Post in its earlier, unreconstructed days. For in his first twenty chapters Mr. Garet Garrett seems to take as dim a view as Karl Marx of the tendency of profit to disappear in a capitalist machine economy, and even goes far with Oswald Spengler down the occidental road to doom.

A new appeal to Congress to eliminate the "highest price-line limitation" will be made by retailers, following a storm of protest generated by the forthcoming amendment to MPR-330 as announced last week by the Office of Price Administration.

Taking three first places and scoring 40 points, Holy Name School triumphed in the thirty-eighth annual Catholic Schools Athletic League track and field championships at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday. The Manhattan school annexed the senior running broad jump, junior 70-yard dash and midget potato race.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 3 -- There was a spanking, dry nor' easter today for the second special regatta of the Long Island Sound season, with the wind piping up from fourteen to twenty miles an hour in puffs and the bursts coming often over a jump of sea which kept most of the small fry in snug harbor moorings and the fleet down to twenty-nine starters.
HARTFORD, June 3. -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, candidate for the Republican nomination for the Presidency, spent a busy fourteen hours in Connecticut today.

The tense, helmeted young man in the pilot's seat peers to his left and above, watching dozens of similar gliders heading into the same spot, while the co-pilot on his right keeps a sharp lookout to the right.

New figures issued yesterday by the Children's Division of the Domestic Relations Court disclosed a continuing increase in the number of delinquent and neglected children in New York City.

BABYLON, L.I., June 3 -- Mrs. Marion G. Hunt, wife of Frank Carley Hunt of Fairfield, Conn., and daughter of the late Mayor William J. Gaynor of New York, was injured seriously this morning in a grade crossing accident here.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The National Association of Manufacturers put the blame today for recent strikes of foremen and their dissatisfaction on the Salary Stabilization Unit of the Treasury Department and the National War Labor Board.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 3 -- Syracuse University will return to intercollegiate competition in football and basketball this fall, Lewis P. Andreas, director of athletics, announced today. Resumption of other sports will be postponed probably until after the war.

EVERY weekday at noon in London hundreds of civil servants, soldiers and war workers hurry up the steps of the National Gallery overlooking Trafalgar Square. Briefcase in one hand and a sandwich in the other, they file through the splintered glass doors in search of an hour's respite from the weary routine of war.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 3 -- If a Presidential election were held today with Franklin D. Roosevelt heading the Democratic ticket and Thomas E. Dewey the Republican, the Middle West and Rocky Mountain regions as a whole could be counted reasonably sure for Dewey, and virtually the entire South sure for Roosevelt, while the eastern and western seaboard areas would constitute the principal battleground of the election.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- British factories in the United Kingdom turned out 27,000 planes in the twelve months ended in March, the Ministry of Aircraft Production disclosed in a dispatch tonight to the British Information Services here.

THE most diversely talented person in the world is obviously a young woman named Esme Davis who has just written an account of her comparatively short but extremely full life, called "Esme of Paris." Her accomplishments are so numerous and so unusual that one feels that she ought to have a list of them notarized and preserved for posterity.

Pre-meet predictions called for a wide-open struggle for the P.S. A.L. outdoor track and field championship at Randalls Island yesterday with any one of a half-dozen teams given a fair chance to emerge on top and, at the completion of the program, the title belonged to Coach George Wright's Bayside High School athletes who tallied 29 points in a closely fought meet.

The pent-up demand for nylons and the insufficiency of hosiery machines for knitting finer gauges of women's full-fashioned and seamless hosiery will keep their plants busy for three years after the war, machine manufacturers stated yesterday.

KITTENS are likely to be as engaging in books as they are in real life, and small black Lollypop, who arrived with the milkman one morning at the Morrow house, is no exception. As the purringest, friendliest, glossiest of cats with an engaging habit of napping in paper bags, he completely won the hearts of the four Morrow children and their parents.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Candidates for national offices in November will have a potential field of more than 88,600,000 voters in which to contest for support (more than 8,000,000 in excess of what they had four years ago), according to figures released today by the Bureau of the Census in answer to a series of questions on what the war has done to the structure of the voting public.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 3 -- Bonneville and Grand Coulee Dams on the Columbia River in Oregon and Washington -- constructed principally as depression public works to provide jobs and prime the business pump -- have been converted into a wartime asset of major proportion.

Out of the brooding quiet along the Russian front came news last week of a sharp but local Nazi attack in Rumania. German tank and infantry units struck at Soviet lines in the wooded, upland region around the city of Jassy, one of the chief bastions of the Wehrmacht's Rumanian defense system.

HERE is the story of an utterly charming beauty pushing 40 and her son Ned, who has spent most of his 24 years providing a smoke-screen for her escapades and bringing her out of her successive binges. The setting is in a pleasure resort in Switzerland in the ominous days shortly after Munich.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., June 3 (AP) -- Three Liberty ships, named for a distinguished Negro woman, a pioneer Franco-American churchman and a Maine mariner, were launched today by the New England Shipbuilding Corporation.

The British Government has done nothing toward weakening the hold of the American oil companies on their concessions in the Middle East, and indications are that these concessions will be exploited by their present owners without any interference by the British.

To the wonder drugs of war medicine we must now add DDT, by which letters epidemiologists abbreviate dichloro-diphenyl-trichloroethane, a louse-killer which made it possible for the Army to save Naples from the ravages of typhus. Here we have another case of a lag between a discovery and its application.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- An assertion that "the manpower shortage has been caused to a great extent by unfavorable wages and working conditions" in critical industries is made by R.J. Thomas, president of the CIO United Automobile Workers, in a letter sent today to the Senate Military Affairs subcommittee considering the Brewster-Bailey National Service Bill.

Senator Claude D. Pepper, Democrat, of Florida, announced yesterday at the National Wartime Conference at the Hotel Commodore that he would sponsor a bill calling for the establishment of a new Government agency with over-all authority to institute programs for the protection of the health and security of the people.

At the old-fashioned Algerian villa which is Gen. Charles de Gaulle's headquarters there was outward quiet and inward tension last week. Cars came and went past the soldiers posted at the entrance to the courtyard; in the large rooms, aides and secretaries worked, visitors waited in the reception room, much as usual.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- Turning on the power at a stockholders' day game, the American League-leading Browns smashed the Philadelphia Athletics today, 18 to 8, and widened their margin over the second-place New York Yankees.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 4 (AP) -- Harvard and the defending Massachusetts Institute of Technology crews qualified for the finals of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association's McMillian Cup championship in the preliminary series of the 1944 competition on the Thames River today.

ALBANY, June 4 -- Competitive examinations for the 1,200 war service college scholarships established by the 1944 Legislature will be conducted by the State Education Department on Aug. 1. Veterans of both World Wars can compete.

Forty-six couples married fifty years or more ought to know what makes a successful marriage. They were too busy to reveal the formula yesterday, however, at the eighth annual golden wedding party held by the Grand Street Boys Association, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Tentative plans for creating a broad, tree-lined, landscaped boulevard in the Bronx by covering the tracks of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad between 149th Street and Fordham Road, converting that section of Park Avenue into a new-world Champs-Elysees, were announced by Mayor LaGuardia yesterday in his weekly Broadcast from City Hall.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president and founder of the Jewish Institute of Religion, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street, announced yesterday that a summer session of eight and one-half weeks, beginning June 28, would be held for students preparing for the rabbinate.

SHORTY RAY is the original figure filbert. He is a nut on statistics and, since he can juggle those numbers for hours on end without ever dropping a single digit or decimal point, the National Football League has made full use of his talents in the arithmetic department to arrive at the best, the soundest and the most complete set of rules in any sport.

Twenty-five hundred persons, including parents and wives of marines killed in World War II, gathered yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral to honor the memory of marines of all wars at the first Marine Memorial Sunday vesper services sponsored by New York Detachment 1 of the Marine Corps League.
Five films, including importations from Norway and the U.S.S.R., compose the week's list of newcomers arriving in midtown theatres this week. The openings follow:
NAPLES, June 4 -- The Fifth Army captured Rome tonight, liberating for the first time a German-enslaved European capital. German rear guards were fleeing in disorganized retreat to the northwest.

MYITKYINA, Burma, June 1 (Delayed) -- The occupation of parts of the Myitkyina area by Chinese and American troops liberated officials of the Burma Government who for more than two years had been living under the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Prolonged continuation of the present level of taxation "would spell destruction of the American social and political system," the Federal Finance Committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce warned today.

I should like to congratulate you on your recent editorial, "Contempt for Politicians." This contempt is, I believe one that in the past we as a nation have largely ignored. I am firmly convinced that should we continue to ignore it we will do so at great cost and even at great peril to our democratic institutions.

Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel of Jamaica, Queens, who on May 3 was elected Grand Master of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York, announced yesterday his appointments to offices and committees in the lodge for the coming year.

Gunnar Leistikow's letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 30 strengthened me in my conviction of Finland's innocence. If the Germans really had the "run of the country," as it appeared to the correspondents domiciled in Stockholm's Grand Hotel, the Finnish Government must have moved heaven and earth to restrain them for four days from attacking the Soviet Union.

NAPLES, June 4 (AP) -- Besides seizing new strongholds in the Alban Hills, the Fifth Army also advanced north of the Via Casilina toward Highway 5, strategic lateral road running eastward from Rome to the Adriatic coast.

LONDON, June 4 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 117.6 on May 24, compared with 117.7 a fortnight before, 117.3 a month before, 114.8 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

John U. Barr of New Orleans, national chairman of the Draft Byrd for President Campaign, declared yesterday that no New Deal candidate for President, including President Roosevelt, was assured of any of the 124 electoral votes of the formerly "Solid South."

LONDON, June 4 -- The Germans announced tonight in a special communique -- broadcast after the Allies had liberated Rome -- the withdrawal of German troops to the northwest of the city and said that the Allies had received a plan whereby Rome would have been regarded as an "open city."
