AN AMERICAN BOMBER BASE IN RUSSIA, June 4 -- A tow-headed Russian boy, about 5 years of age, with bare feet and a rope holding up his trousers, had the distinction of giving an American Flying Fortress crew member his first lesson in Russian pronunciation.

Questions of far-reaching character were brought up for discussion at the recent "Institute of Transportation -1944," held under the joint sponsorship of the schools of law and commerce of New York University and the Transportation Association of America. This association has a twofold object: the "development of a better public understanding of the transportation problem" and "determination and adoption of a sound national transportation policy."

Aqueduct, the race track nearest the center of town, will take over the turf spotlight today. The Queens County Jockey Club, of which Theodore J. Knapp is president, will conduct a twenty-four-day meeting there, with July 1 the closing date.

T.A. Farrell has been named assistant general sales manager for Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, Detroit, to have supervision of Eastern, Western and Pacific Coast regional managers. Other appointments include E.R. Legg, assistant general sales manager of the commercial and contract division and D.A. Pachard assistant general sales manager to be in charge of sales and merchandising for all household products.

Columbia College seniors were absent yesterday for the first time in years from the university's baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel. Barnard seniors, students from Teachers College and faculty members of the university alone marched from Low Memorial Library to the chapel.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Apparently convinced that the war with Germay will end victoriously within a year, Administration forces are ready to accept a Republican compromise on the food subsidy issue.

ROME, June 4 -- The Allies' troops fought their way into Rome this morning and at nightfall they were still fighting on the outer edges, which the Germans were defending despite all their protestations about considering Rome an open city.

The current issue of International Conciliation, periodical of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, 342 Madison Avenue, contains summaries of reports on problems of peace settlement by the University Committee on Post-War International Problems.

The world premiere of Morton Gould's "Symphony on Marching Tunes," commissioned by the Y.M.C.A. for its 100th anniversary, was given yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall by the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, Vladimir Golschmann conducting, in the regular Sunday afternoon broadcast over the Columbia Network under the sponsorship of the United States Rubber Company.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Pending receipt of final details of the fall of Rome, most Government leaders tonight refrained from direct comment. It was felt that the first official reaction to the Allied victory would come from President Roosevelt in the radio address that the White House announced he would make tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (U.P.) -Fred M. Vinson, Economic Stabilization Director, tonight asked the Senate to reject the Bankhead amendment to the pending Price Control Act and thereby prevent tying textile prices with raw cotton prices. Senate action is scheduled for tomorrow.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 -"Men are at their best when their lives are devoted to a great cause, when their abilities are used on something to live for and not live on," Capt. William N. Thomas, chaplain of the Naval Academy, told the senior midshipmen in a baccalaureate address this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) -- Bill Lee pitched a two-hit shutout as the Phillies stopped the league-leading Cardinals, 1 to 0, in the second game of a double-header today after dropping the opener, 4 to 2. A crowd of 23,313 watched.

This is a particularly good time to go fishing, because fishing is just the right sport for busy people. It slows up the heartbeat, eases the blood pressure, empties the mind, adds color to the skin and restores perspective. People who are not busy have no need for fishing.

Declaring that the nation's railroad facilities, already overtaxed by war requirements, will be strained further when the invasion of Europe begins, Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday to all Americans to spend their vacations at home this summer.

The greatest exhibition of futility in which the frequently futile Dodgers and Cubs have been engaged this year was ended by the umpires shortly after 8 o'clock last night at Ebbets Field when they decided, after three hours and thirteen minutes of the second game of a double-header, that everybody had seen enough.
Award of letters to thirty-eight members of the University of Wisconsin's 1943 football squad has been announced by Harry Stuhldreher, head football coach and athletic director.

While millions of Christians outside the Roman Catholic Church "will heartily agree with Pope Pius XII in opposing a peace dictated by vindictive passions and a spirit of revenge," they will also regard "with serious misgiving his opposition to total victory over the Nazi and Fascist aggressors," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday in his sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 4 (AP) -- Jersey City's league leading Little Giants captured both ends of a double-header from Toronto today, 2-1 and 1-0.
Every good European must be profoundly grateful to Prime Minister Churchill for having proclaimed "the conception of a Europe truly united" as one of the great aims of the war.

Speaking at the commencement exercises at Haverford College over the week-end, former Ambassador Hugh Gibson expressed the opinion that over a long period of years this country will be seriously handicapped in dealing with other nations and in trying to formulate a sound foreign policy unless its citizens are equipped with a better knowledge of history.

BABYLON, L.I., June 4 -- Two dairy farmers, brothers, were found this morning gored and trampled to death on the Ames Farm in North Babylon, victims of their Guernsey bull, which had run wild and scattered their herd of thirty cows over near-by roads.

Opening Brooklyn's observation of the 100th anniversary of the Young Men's Christian Association, Mayor La Guardia yesterday called upon the people of the United States to "take inventory" of the politcal and economic situation of the country with an eye to correcting existing inequalities.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Planting of corn continues to be delayed by wet soil. Some progress is being made but that is because farmers are working day and night between showers in an effort to put in a full acreage. Farmers who have finished planting corn are now putting in soy beans.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4 -Eleven of seventeen academic awards presented at the Military Academy today went to Cadet James F. Scoggin Jr. of State College, Miss., honor man of the graduating class.

ALGIERS, June 4 -- The fall of Rome will add about 2,000,000 persons to those whom the Allies have assumed responsibility of feeding, Allied authorities estimated today. But the Allied Military Government, now operating under the Allied Control Commission, has long prepared for the task and is believed to be ready.
NAPLES, June 4 (U.P.) -- The text of a statement from General Alexander, broadcast to the Romans, follows:

Undeterred by the lateness of the season and the coming of warm weather, a number of art exhibitions of unusual interest are to open this week. Heading the schedule is a large centenary loan exhibition of paintings, drawings and sculpture by Thomas Eakins, which opens today at the Knoedler Galleries, to remain current through July.

IN THE OUTSKIRTS OF ROME, June 4 -- The Fifth Army's entry into the suburbs of Rome was made along Highway 6 -- the Via Casilina -- which runs into Rome at Centocelle, a suburb test known for its airport. But the advance did not mean a simple triumphal procession into the heart of Rome. It meant going in in careful infantry columns along the sides of the road.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Seven members of the Women's Army Corps, three of them from New York State, have been appointed warrant officers (jg), the first women warrant officers in the army.
Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway at the head of Wall Street, observed its titular festival yesterday on Trinity Sunday.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 -- Steel order volume last week was stronger than in the week before and in most cases was in excess of shipments. Consequently there was no change in unfilled order backlogs. Steel ingot output dropped about one-half a point to 98 per cent of rated capacity. There were indications this week that the production rate would be little changed from last week.

Eugene J. Daly and Paul J. Cavanaugh have rightly pointed out in their letter in THE TIMES of May 24 that prayers on the air in connection with D-day should not be presented as a matter of emergency only.

Officers and directors of Pathe Laboratories, Inc., a New Jersey corporation, and Pathe Laboratories, Inc. of California, have approved a plan for their merger into Pathe Industries, Inc., an Ohio corporation. The plan will be submitted to stockholders of the respective corporations for approval at special meetings to be called on June 26.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn made public yesterday plans for that part of the post-war Brooklyn-Queens Connecting Highway that will be built in the downtown section of Brooklyn under the borough approach to Brooklyn Bridge.

Urging tolerance of divergent religious views, the Rev. Karl M. Chworowsky, preaching yesterday at Flatbush Unitarian Church, Brooklyn, said the prospects for a peaceful and orderly world after the war would remain unpromising "until there is more convincing evidence that individuals and groups are able to discuss the differences that separate them without resort to personalities, to anger, to scolding and to insult."

Cotton prices last week advanced into new high ground for the season in the earlier half of the period. Early gains, however, were pared in subsequent dealings. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of only 6 to 9 points.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 4 (AP) -- Results thus far of the Allied Indo-Burma campaigns "can be regarded with satisfaction, though not with complacence," an official headquarters summary said today.

Asserting that the one test in supporting candidates for Congress is support of President Roosevelt and his foreign and domestic policies, Representative Vito Marcantonio and Eugene P. Connolly, chairman and secretary of the New York County Committee of the American Labor party, announced last night the designation of Representative Samuel Dickstein, Democrat, for the Labor party nomination for Representative in the new Nineteenth Congressional District.

KENANPO, Shansi, May 30 (delayed) -- Kenanpo, which means "The Mountain of Conquering Difficulty," is certainly the strangest military headquarters and perhaps the strangest place of any kind in the world.

Mayor La Guardia criticized THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday for what he termed "misleading" headlines and "tricky" reporting in its account of the findings of a survey conducted by the New York Teachers Guild on absenteeism among teachers.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Joint Contract Termination Board announced tonight it has adopted a uniform termination article to be incorporated in all war subcontracts, designed to protect small plants and other subcontractors when war orders are canceled.

Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre denounced twice yesterday as "un- American" passages in a book by Dr. George D. Stoddard, State Commissioner of Education, which he declared, compared "divine revelation with witchery."

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE, Somewhere in the U.S.S.R., June 3 (Delayed) -- Aerial photographs demonstrated today that our Flying Fortresses inflicted heavy blows at six places on the communication lines feeding the Nazi forces opposing the Red Army along the Hungarian-Rumanian front in yesterday's first shuttle-bombing operation that brought the "heavies" of the Fifteenth Air Force from Italy to bases in the Soviet Union.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, June 5 (AP) -- American forces on Biak Island, in the Schouten group, have started a new push on the three airdromes, their main objectives, headquarters announced today.

CHUNGKING, China, June 4 (AP) -- Japanese troops have stabbed six miles beyond Sinshih toward Changsha, while another column in the many-sided Hunan Province offensive has attempted an assault toward Liuyang to the east for an encircling movement against Changsha, the major objective, a Chinese communique announced tonight.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- The shadow of a large crop of winter wheat has fallen over the market for wheat and despite heavy buying early last week by millers against what is said to have been the largest flour business in some months, the undertone was heavy and prices averaged lower, although at one time they were about 4 cents a bushel above the low mark of the previous week.
LONDON, June 4 -- The stock markets here remain in a quietly optimistic mood.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Office of Price Administration today increased ceiling prices for processors of bulk condensed milk doing business in the thirteen Northeastern and Atlantic States and the District of Columbia.
Thousands of war jobs, part and full-time, paid and voluntary, are waiting for women in New York City.

LONDON, Monday, June 5 -- Continuing to pave the way for the Allied invasion of the Continent hundreds of Allied bombers and fighters from Britain scorched a 200-mile stretch of the French coast yesterday and penetrated inland.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Prices of rye fluctuated last week in an extremely nervous manner in the grain market. At the peak on the Chicago Board of Trade July was 8 cents a bushel above the low of the previous week on buying induced by reports that distillers would have to use 10 per cent of rye in their mash for production of industrial alcohol.

There were only two words in the first flash that brought the news into the early-Sunday-afternoon quiet of the city room. "Rome entered" was all it said. The hour was 1:40 and as the first troops crossed the city limit at 6:40 in the morning, allowing for the difference of time we must have heard of the event within an hour of its occurrence.
MOSCOW, June 4 (Reuter) -China's governing circles were charged with half-heartedness in an article in the Soviet magazine War and the Working Class.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- The rampant White Sox pounded out 6-to-5 and 9-to-1 victories over Washington before 20,508 fans today to sweep the four-game series and run their winning streak to six straight. They won the first game in the tenth after overcoming an early 5-0 deficit.

CLEVELAND, June 4 -- The Yankees had to settle for half a loaf in the twin bill against the Indians that brought their first Western trip to a close today at Municipal Stadium before the city's largest crowd of the campaign -- 27,343.

A nation-wide drive to obtain clothing for refugee children abroad, titled Kits for Europe's Children, opens today under the banner of the Save the Children Federation at 1 Madison Avenue, with the Women's Council for Post-War Europe as cooperating agency.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -Corp. Paul B. Huff, whose home is the Tennessee hill country which sent Alvin York to the first World War, is the newest winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor.

Active purchasing of fall lines was noted in the wholesale markets last week, with larger numbers of buyers expected to be in the city this week. Reorders for summer dresses were noted, but manufacturers were not able to take care of all the demands, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Spurred by pleas and statistics from three war agencies, the Office of War Information appealed to housewives today to turn in at least 230,000,000 pounds of waste cooking fats and greases this year to meet a "critical need."

Warren Equities, Inc., a syndicate headed by Walzer Chinich, bought two six-story apartment houses at 1730-50 Montgomery Avenue, near West 176th Street, in the Bronx, from Samuel Knepper. The houses occupy a combined plot of 300 by 100 feet and contain 106 apartments renting for a total of about $67,300 a year.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- With postwar planning receiving the major attention of delegates, a plea for opening employment ranks to returning veterans of World War II rather than perpetuating retail self-service and man-power-saving devices was made here today at the opening of the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers. About 3,000 food merchants from practically all sections of the country are attending the conclave which continues through Wednesday.

The Bank for Savings has sold to a syndicate headed by John S. and Thomas A. Weatherley Jr. the eleven-story and penthouse apartment building at northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street containing twenty-two suites and occupying a plot 60 by 80 feet.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 4 -- Extolling the virtues of Gen. Robert E. Lee and asserting that many of his principles were being applied by present-day commanders, Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, Marine Corps commandant, said tonight that the Allies still had many surprises in store for the enemy.

Authority on salad-making is Mrs. Madge Flavin, nutritionist of the New York State Emergency Food Commission, who recently discussed the subject with this department at some length. Mrs. Flavin talked principally about green salads, of the leafy vegetables that are particularly plentiful now and that furnish appetizing easy-to-get luncheons and suppers during the warm weather.

As the site for an apartment house when materials are available, the southeast corner of Court and State Streets, in Brooklyn, has been purchased by Jacob Freidus from the Brooklyn Savings Bank. The plot fronts 100 feet on Court Street and 125 feet on State Street and is assessed at $123,500, according to Dwight, Voorhis Helmsley, Inc., the broker in the sale.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The farmers of America were urged tonight by Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, to plant at least 67,000,000 acres of wheat for harvest next year and to stretch it to 70,000,000 acres if it could be done without putting the production of other grain crops out of balance with the needs of the war food program.

Asserting that the problems of reconverting industry from war to peacetime work are occupying a steadily growing place in business discussions and in the planning done by Government agencies, the National City Bank in the current issue of its monthly bank letter hastens to add that "reconversion in any general sense is not yet possible."

ATLANTA, June 4 -- The Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, a hooded order which in the early Nineteen Twenties claimed 5,100,000 members, has disbanded as a national group, The Atlanta Journal said last night.

LONDON, June 4 -- Germany's synthetic oil industry, which has become the Wehrmacht's main source of supply since Rumania's Ploesti oil fields were bombed, was crippled in three days of operations in May by the Eighth United States Air Force.

NEWARK, N.J., June 4 (AP) -- The last-place Newark Bears ended a four-game losing streak by taking the nightcap of a twin bill from Montreal today, 3 to 1. The Royals took the opener, 8 to 4, with a five-run spree in the fifth inning. Frank Hiller checked the Royals with two singles in the second game. The box scores:

President Roosevelt was urged to run for a fourth term and 15,000,000 Americans said to be of Slav descent were asked to support him for re-election yesterday in a resolution adopted at the third annual conference of the American Slav Congress of Greater New York in the Bohemian National Hall, 521 East Seventy-third Street.

PEARL HARBOR, June. 4 (U.P.) -Central and northern Pacific aerial forces attacked at least seven targets in the Carolines, Marshalls and the Kuriles from Thursday to Saturday, blasting Japanese installations from Truk to Paramushiru with loads of high explosives, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz reported today.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 4 -The South must develop "a strong opposition party and the sooner the better," Virginius Dabney, editor of The Richmond Times Dispatch, declared in an address today at the commencement exercises of the College of William and Mary.

It is a little less than twenty-one and a half years since Mussolini introduced what he called "the dawn of new history for Italy, and perhaps dawn on a new path of civilization," by his renowned "March on Rome." This lapse of time has been sufficient to permit an imitation of the Mussolinian state to come to monstrous bloom and enter the first stages of decay in the lands of the German tribes.

Two thousand worshipers prayed and Bishop William T. Manning and eleven priests performed the laying-on-of-hands as two priests and two deacons were ordained at the annual Trinity Sunday ceremony yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

MOSCOW, June 4 -- With straight-from-the-shoulder frankness, Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, told 100 Soviet trade leaders yesterday that a gulf separated the economies of the United States and Russia, but that bridges of practical cooperation could be thrown across that gulf.
As a result of pronounced price changes in farm products during the past week, the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices broke through to a new all-time high of 113.03.

The Giants, who seem to have been turned completely around since their gallant seven-game winning splurge, were still dashing at a high rate of speed in the wrong direction yesterday as they dropped both ends of a double-header to Frankie Frisch's Pirates at the Polo Grounds while a crowd of 33,654 looked helplessly on.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -- George Raft has signed a term contract with Twentieth Century- Fox, and will have the lead in the company's forthcoming story of early San Francisco, "Nob Hill." He has the part which had previously been set for Fred MacMurray.
LONDON, June 4 (AP) -- The Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

LONDON, June 4 (AP) -- In today's strikes from Britain Thunderbolt fighter-bombers of the Ninth Air Force attacked two bridges over the Seine at Rouen, pilots reporting one was destroyed and the other substantially weakened. Mustang fighter-bombers swept south of Paris, hitting rail junctions and destroying a Nazi trainer plane.

John J. Floherty received permission from Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. to use illustrations of actual currency in his book, 'Money-Go-Round: The Strange Story of Money," recently published by Lippincott.

What was begun five years ago as a highly experimental plan to give air-mail facilities to off-line communities by unconventional methods has developed into a far-reaching network covering 118 cities and towns in six States in this area. When, in May, 1939, the world's first scheduled air mail pick-up service was inaugurated by the late Richard Du Pont as head of All American Aviation, most public officials and many aviation experts viewed it skeptically.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Immediate action by Government agencies to adjust inequities in the amount of gasoline rationed to civilian car owners was urged today by the American Automobile Association.
LONDON, June 4 (UP) -- A German communique:, as broadcast from Berlin:

Widespread resentment among city employes against Mayor La Guardia's crusade to keep them from holding outside jobs on their own time was intensified yesterday. It became known that Investigation Commissioner Edgar Bromberger, by direction of the Mayor, had asked the 35,000 employes of the unified transit system to make sworn answers to forty questions concerning their own employment and that of all working members of their families.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER-BOMBER BASE, England, June 4 -- Thunderbolt pilots returning from dive-bombing attacks are still amazed at the reception they get from the French, Netherland and Belgian peasants.
CHUNGKING, China, June 4 (AP) -A communique:

LONDON, Monday, June 5 (U.P.) -- Red Army forces turned back large German tank and infantry attacks north and northwest of Jassy, in eastern Rumania, for the sixth successive day, yesterday, inflicting heavy troop and equipment losses on the Germans, Moscow announced early today.

Pierre Laval, chief of the Vichy government, recently tried to transfer $50,000 from Spain to Argentina, the Brazzaville radio said yesterday in a broadcast recorded at the Columbia Broadcasting System's short-wave listening station.

DANBURY, Conn., June 4 (AP) -- Commissioner Edward J. Hickey said today that State police were trying to locate Eudora Atkins, alias Linda Brennan, 19, of Salisbury, in connection with the Lake Candlewood mystery slaying.

The Senate is about to begin consideration of a bill to extend the Emergency Price Control Act. Although the Senate Banking and Currency Committee appropriately has rejected the vast majority of the amendments in the bill reported, there are several proposals for modifications of the original act.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 4 -- Byron Nelson, who won the so-called world golf championship last year by defeating Craig Wood in a 72-hole match, today broke the Essex Fells Country Club course record by ono shot with a four-under-par 66 in capturing the club's pro-member Red Cross benefit tournament.

From a lifetime of experience as an actor and playwright, J.C. Nugent has written himself a tailor-made role in the comedy, "That old Devil," which opens tonight under the auspices of Lodewick Groom at the air-cooled Playhouse. Yesterday Mr. Nugent recalled that he had a hand in the writing of seventeen other plays.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Senators who heard an explanation by Paul V. McNutt of the new manpower program, giving the Federal Employment Service jurisdiction over industrial hiring July 1, were generally in agreement today that the plan was satisfactory, if it would work.

The Second Service Command announced yesterday that the exchange liner Gripsholm, on her way back to this country with repatriated wounded soldiers and also civilians, would dock early tomorrow morning at Pier F, Jersey City.

The statement of Dr. William Y. Elliott, director of the Office of Civilian Requirements, that the smaller demand for durable goods and apppliances was a "tribute" to advertising was appplauded by advertising and market research men, Dr. Elliott's statement was made at a press conference last Thursday when the results of the third nation-wide survey of consumer requirements were made public.

LONDON, June 4 -- The American occupation of Rome is one of the most significant victories of the war in Italy not because of the city's importance as a temporal and spiritual capital but because its capture greatly increases the Allies' chances of destroying the German Tenth and Fourteenth Armies.

NEW ORLEANS, June 4 -- Expectations of a compromise in Washington on the Bankhead amendments to legislation affecting prices of cotton resulted late last week in an advance of quotations for futures on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

Although yesterday's entry of the Allied troops into Rome occurred after the close of last week's markets, it had been fully anticipated. During the week stocks and bonds advanced, making continuous gains of nearly four points in the two past weeks.

The 112th annual commencement program at New York University began yesterday afternoon with a baccalaureate service in the Gould Memorial Library auditorium on the University Heights campus. An overflow crowd of 1,200, several hundred of whom sat on the Mall and listened through loudspeakers, attended the exercises.

Ninety-nine Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at 40th Street) for tickets.

DETROIT, June 4 (AP) -- The Tigers and Red Sox divided a war relief double-header today before 30,000, Detroit taking the opener, 2 to 1, for Paul Trout's seventh victory and Boston winning the nightcap, 5 to 1. Pinky Higgins' homer was the only run off rookie Clem Hausmann in the nightcap.

LONDON, June 4 -- As nearly as can be determined there are more than 350 assorted British and American newspaper, magazine and radio correspondents and photographers in the European theatre of operations now waiting to cover the coming invasion.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., June 4 -- Champion El Wendie of Rockland took best in show and American-bred honors today at the annual exhibition of the Framingham District Kennel Club, which concluded the trio of shows held on the Raceland estate of John R. Macomber.

BOSTON, June 4 -- Total liquid assets of $16,183,692 in general and reserve funds in the treasuries of the International Ladies Garment Workers and affiliates were disclosed in a statistical report made public today by David Dubinsky, president of the union.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Heavy receipts of hogs and lack of storage space room for the products of slaughter is causing an unsettled condition in the market for the latter, and brokers assert that there is no recognized price for lard and other products at the present time.

What a refreshing editorial "Poetry in the Fields"! Like the wild flowers it recalls, that sometimes grow and bloom in a mere crevice of a bare rock, it reared its jaunty head and caught the eye, obliterating the war editorial that take precedence over all.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 4 -- Dr. Stephen G. Lee of Canoe Brook and A.D. Purvis scored a 2-and-1 victory over Jack Poinier of Glen Ridge and A.C. Youngman today to capture the annual Montclair Golf Club member-guest invitation tournament.
READING, Pa., June 4 -- Norman Thomas was nominated by acclamation today at the Socialist national convention to head the party's Presidential ticket for a fifth time.

Columbia will produce forty-four feature films, four action musicals, ten Westerns, twenty-eight two-reel comedies, ninety one-reel subjects and three serials on its 1944-45 program, it was announced yesterday at the company's sales convention, now in session at the Drake Hotel in Chicago.

A Lutheran center for men and women in the armed services was officially opened yesterday in a former residence building at 39 East Fiftieth Street. Two thousand persons stood in the blocked-off street before the new center during the ceremonies, over which Maj. Otto C. Busse, an Army chaplain, presided.

A tradition of 143 years standing has come to an and at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn. Women are now working alongside men at construction work aboard Navy fighting ships. "From shop to ship" describes the progress of several score women welders, electrical and sheet metal workers, moved from shop work and other "land jobs" to help build a $60,000,000 airplane carrier of the Essex class.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- The Shipbuilding Division of the Pullman Standard Car Manufacturing Company of this city has been named winner of the Admiral Land Trophy, the highest award in the Victory Shipbuilding Safety Contest sponsored jointly by the Navy, the Maritime Commission and the National Safety Council.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- With nearly 8,000 persons watching, two submarines, dedicated to the memory of the first Philadelphia police officer to give his life in this war, were launched today at the yards of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 4 -- The report of meteorologists of a mass of polar air moving south may have provided the fine northeast breeze in which the third of the Long Island Sound championships was started today by the 70-year-old Knickerbocker Yacht Club.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP) -- Coming from behind twice, the Browns won the final game of a double-header from the Athletics today, 4 to 3, in ten innings and held their precarious position atop the American League race. Philadelphia won the first contest, 4 to 3.
DES MOINES, June 5 (AP) -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, a Democrat, campaigning for re-election, took a long lead over his opponent, Ernest K. Seemann, in the Iowa primary today.

Columbia University's 190th commencement exercises will take place today at 5 P.M., with Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, conferring 3,075 degrees in course, seven honorary degrees, besides medals and certificates.

The Yankees returned home yesterday, glad to be back breathing the atmosphere of the hospitable East, even if only momentarily, after their first and not altogether satisfactory swing through the West. Dropping eight of the thirteen games in which they clashed with the White Sox, Browns, Tigers and Indians, was not as bad a showing as they made on the first 1943 Western swing, when they lost six of the only seven games they played.

Newspaper advertising people can blame themselves for the ineffective retail advertising appearing in their media, Clyde Bedell, Chicago merchandising and advertising counselor, told members of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association yesterday at their luncheon on the opening day of a three-day convention at the Hotel Commodore.

Production of handmade ceramics by American craftsmen has gained spectacular momentum since the war first put a stop to imports. One corner of the coun try where this trend is markedly evident is Southern California.

There is surprising unanimity of opinion among those concerned that hens have personalities but do not rate high on standard intelligence tests. Therefore rural dwellers tend to smile when they hear the old proverb: "Chickens always come home to roost." In recent years it has sometimes seemed as though the countryside were developing as many social and economic strata as the cities have spawned.

Among several large stock distributions yesterday was a special offering of 42,000 common shares of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., made by Lehman Brothers at 36 5/8 and oversubscribed in two minutes. It was the largest special offering since last August.

One of the first matters of business at the opening of the annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel will be the presentation to the membership for approval of certain amendments to the organization's constitution.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, June 6 (U.P.) -- A War Department report from "a front line town" on the coast of England said today that the jump-off of Allied troops for the invasion of Europe "began in a small way" from that point.
LONDON, June 6 (AP) -- The German DNB commentator, Captain Sertorius, declared in a broadcast early today that the "great contest between the Reich and the Anglo-Americans has begun."

Allied troops, standing at the gates of western Europe today for the first time since the evacuation of Dunkerque in June, 1940, have set up another milestone -- perhaps an almost final one -- on the long road back from 1939, when Adolf Hitler's armored legions and his screaming Stukas crashed into Poland at the start of his attempt to make his "Aryan" Germany the ruler of the world.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A recommendation that recruiting and training for the Women's Air Force Service Pilots be terminated immediately, and that surpluses of experienced pilot personnel be used instead was made in a report to the House today by Representative Robert Ramspeck of Georgia, chairman of the Civil Service Investigating Committee.

In connection with the recent poison gas episode in Brooklyn, it should be noted that the instructions which Fire Department auxiliaries received in reference to war gases contained specific instructions to remove all persons in the immediate neighborhood of the occurrence to the first or second floor of any neighboring buildings, as heavier than air gases rise only to a nominal height above the sidewalk level.

King George VI of Great Britain and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of China paid tribute to the Young Men's Christian Association on the occasion of the hundredth anniversary of its founding, it was announced yesterday by the National Council of the organization.

The season is on for those who like to take time out on a humid afternoon to fill tall glasses with cracked ice and pour out a mixture of something cool. Beverage enthusiasts will find a wide assortment from which to choose already featured in city stores.

Three midtown theatres will present new films this morning. At the Rivoli, the attraction will be "The Story of Dr. Wassell," a Paramount biographical drama dealing with the American Navy physician who evacuated wounded sailors from Java during the Japanese invasion.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Guitars, ukuleles, saxophones, even the handy harmonicas with which soldiers all over the globe might make music are being sought out by Music for the Services, an organization founded by Mrs. Stuart C. Godfrey, wife of Brigadier General Godfrey, former Air Engineer in Office of the Assistant Chief of Air Staff, now overseas.

Leases of space in the thirty-six-story building at 535 Fifth Avenue by three watch dealers were announced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company. Eighth-floor quarters were taken by the Naef Watch Company and the Stona Watch Company, while offices on the seventeenth floor were rented by B. Lipschultz, an importer of watches. Other leases of business premises were reported yesterday as follows:

Harlow Shapley thinks that public taste in America is being vulgarized by the radio companies who have made a "revolting mess" of their job. Perhaps it does no harm to say such things; even if the verdict sounds harsh it may do good.
ROME, June 5 -- The first newspaper to come out in liberated Rome was the Communist journal Voce Operaia [Voice of the Worker], which calls itself "the organ of the Catholic Communist movement.

ALBANY, June 5 -- The State War Council characterized as "an obviously political and useless trip" the visit to Albany today of a group of New York City labor leaders and heads of community organizations for the purpose of demanding $5,000,000 for the establishment of additional centers for the care of children of working mothers.

Enactment of important changes in the New York State corporate franchise tax at the last session of the Legislature this year has wiped out "the arbitrary, narrow distinctions between holding companies, investment trusts and ordinary business corporations," Rollin Browne, president of the State Tax Commission, said yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., at 233 Broadway.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, wheat and rye breaking around 1 1/2 cents a bushel and oats 1 cent, with numerous stop-loss orders uncovered on the way down.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 5 (AP) -- Toronto snapped Jersey City's winning streak at four straight tonight by defeating the Little Giants, 4 -- 2, in the third of a four-game series.

LONDON, June 5 (AP) -- British submarines sank thirty-one Axis ships, twenty-six of them merchantmen and five naval auxiliaries, in recent operations in the Mediterranean and Aegean Seas, the Admiralty announced tonight. Seven other merchantmen were damaged, the communique said.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in a formal notice yesterday to all commercial banks in this district, announced that all such banks that maintain time deposit accounts and savings accounts may subscribe for certain types of Government securities in the Fifth War Loan drive.

Some manufacturing retail confectioners are now reducing their average cost of dipping chocolates from 2.78 cents per pound by the hand dipping method to 1.07 cents by machine dipping, Fred W. Greer of the J.W. Greer Company, Cambridge, Mass., told the members of the Associated Retail Confectioners of the United States at their twenty-seventh annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt.

A "bondmobile," designed to assist in recruitment of volunteer salesmen and to sell war bonds for the Fifth War Bond Drive, was presented yesterday to Nevil Ford, chairman of the New York State War Finance Committee, by Henry J. Cochran, president of the Franklin Savings Bank and chairman of the Bronx, Westchester and Manhattan savings banks groups that joined to make the donation.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The escort carrier Block Island was sunk in the Atlantic during May, the Navy announced tonight. It was the first reported sinking in the Atlantic of any of the "baby flattops" which have been helping to keep the U-boat in check.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The National War Labor Board today furnished Senator Pat McCarran of Nevada its written reply opposing his subcommittee's recent report to the Judiciary Committee on the board's handling of the Montgomery Ward Co. case.

ROME, June 5 -- A "G.I." named John made a speech this morning from Benito Mussolini's pet balcony overlooking the Piazza Venezia. And his audience ate it up. There is the best single incident you can have of how the Americans were received in Rome and of how completely the aura of the big-chinned Duce has been dimmed.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Senate today approved the extension of wartime price, wage and rent controls for another eighteen months, but voted also to permit no subsidy programs after June 30, 1945, which are not financed by direct and specific appropriations by Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- Three stock exchanges received today permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission to strike from listing one issue apiece, while the Chicago Stock Exchange was allowed to strike two.

Lieut. Patty Berg of the United States Marine Corps, women's Western open champion, has entered the women's fifty-four-hole medal play competition in the big New York Red Cross Open to be staged at the Wykagyl Country Club at New Rochelle, starting next Monday and winding up seven days later, it was announced yesterday.
BALDWIN, L.I., June 5 -- Three teams tied for first place in the weekly amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island P.G.A. with three-under-par 68s over the Milburn Club links today.

Counsel for both prosecution and defense completed the presentation of their direct evidence yesterday in Federal court at the trial of Gert Hans von Gontard, Lieut. Francis X. Grottano, Dr. Arnold A. Hutschnecker and Michael Mangano. Only Dr. Hutschnecker and Lieutenant Grottano had testified in their own defense against the charge of conspiracy to help von Gontard to evade the draft.
MEXICO CITY, June 5 -- The fall of Rome was welcomed with deep satisfaction by the Mexican Government and people. All morning newspapers today carried the news under streamers.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Request of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company for permission to increase fares on its downtown line between Jersey City and New York City was granted today by the Supreme Court.

The first eyewitness account of the Allies' invasion of Europe was given in a pool broadcast from London this morning by Wright Bryan of the National Broadcasting Company, who accompanied the airborne troops in their landings.
MOSCOW, June 5 -- Gen. Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander's victory at Rome made a profound and joyful impression here and was hailed as an event of greatest political and strategic significance.

I have seen the letter from Harold Smith, published in the issue of May 31, relative to night hours at the Metropolitan Museum. I should like to take this opportunity of thanking Mr. Smith for his enthusiastic comments about the museum and to reply to the questions which he brought up.

King Haakon of Norway, in a broadcast today to the people of his Nazi-occupied country, called on "all compatriots" to stand at their post and told them that "the Supreme Allied Commander will at all times keep you informed, over the radio and by other means, of what is expected," the British radio reported.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin yesterday declared void a Reno divorce decree obtained by Richard Fondiller, consulting actuary, against Mrs. Elizabeth Fondiller, in October, 1941, and annulled his marriage to Dr. Anna K. Daniels, whom he married six months later in Florida.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 6 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation began its 8 A.M. news bulletin this morning with quotations from a Supreme Headquarters' "urgent warning" to inhabitants of the enemy-occupied countries living near the coast.

A June week with five openings, even though two of them are off Broadway, is considered a rarity. Yet that's the number promised for next week. Should all pass in review, first-nighters will have a busy time. The latest addition to next week's parade is "Slightly Scandalous," in which Janet Beecher, a comparative stranger to Broadway, will return after an absence of a dozen years.

The stock market, having anticipated effectively last week the success of the Allied forces in Italy, followed yesterday an orthodox pattern and suffered reverses on the "good news." Losses of major fractions were sprinkled liberally through the list while the higher-price issues were set back a point and more.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Senator Harley M. Kilgore of West Virginia said today that impending war plant shutdowns threatened to throw "hundreds of thousands of workers" out of employment.

Your editorial of June 2, "The King of the Woods," appropriately likens Mussolini and Hitler to this temporary but doomed Rex of the sacred grove of Diana on the shore of Lake Nemi. But Virgil does not agree with your statement: "It was ancient opinion that this branch was the Golden Bough which the Sibyl bade Aeneas pluck before he began his journey to the land of the dead."
Harry W. Treleaven, formerly assistant manager, has been made manager of the Jersey City steel-service plant of Joseph T. Ryerson Son, Inc.

There was dismay in the insurance field yesterday when the United States Supreme Court, upsetting its previous decisions on the matter, decided that insurance constitutes interstate commerce and therefore comes under the Federal anti-trust laws.

ROME, June 5 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark was a happy man today, but, as he stood on the terrace of the Campidoglio, overlooking the Capitoline Hill, with his chief aides, the man who conquered Rome from the south for the first time in history did not speak loudly or even smile very broadly as he accepted congratulations.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- When the American troops entered Rome the newspaper correspondents who accompanied them were informed by Mr. Tittman, our Minister to the Vatican, that the Pope has constantly observed an attitude of strict neutrality toward the belligerents and will continue to do so.

The dairy industry has appealed to the Office of Price Administration to slash the point value of cream cheese, it was learned yesterday. Offered at 10 points a pound, this perishable product is "backing up," according to the food trade, as consumers ignore cream cheese because they would rather have butter for their precious red points.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- American aircraft plants, responding to the accelerated tempo of bombing assaults over Europe, turned out in May more four-motored bombers -- B-24 Liberators, B-17 Flying Fortresses and the new B-29 "Super-bombers" -- than in any previous month, Charles E. Wilson, chairman of the Aircraft Production Board, reported today.

Without the slightest flurry of excitement, the few New Yorkers who were awake early today to hear the news of the German report of the beginning of the invasion received it, because of its origin, with a "wait-and-see" attitude, but most of them confessed that they were delighted when it was confirmed.

ROME, June 5 -- Into this timeless capital rode today the officers and enlisted men, British and American, faced with the need for getting a quick start on the greatest collective problem ever to confront Allied civil administrators in the history of two world wars.

Sheet and pillowcase distributors who have been getting a reasonably good supply can look for prompt curtailment in their shipments and allotments as a result of the stepped-up jungle cloth procurement program, according to Donald B. Tansill, vice president of the Pepperell Manufaturing Company, writing in the company's monthly publication.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, June 6 (U.P.) -- General Pershing, in a statement headed "American troops have landed in western Europe," said today that he had "every confidence" that the invasion would succeed.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS ALLIED EXPEDITIONARY FORCES, Tuesday, June 6 -- The invasion of Europe from the west has begun.

NAPLES, June 5 -- Victor Emmanuel III stepped aside as King of Italy today, as he previously had said he would do upon the liberation of Rome, and handed to his 39-year-old son, Crown Prince Humbert, all "royal prerogatives." Italian political pressure had been brought to bear against him since the occupation of Naples.

Carl Becker's "How New Will the Better World Be?" has been selected by the Phi Beta Kappa Alumni of New York as its annual award to boys of outstanding scholastic achievement in forty-five New York schools. Awards will be made at graduation exercises. The book was published in March by Knopf.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Supreme Court, by a four-to-three decision today, held that the insurance companies of the country, with assets of $37,000,000,000 and annual premium collections in excess of $6,000,000,000, are in interstate commerce and thus subject to the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

Seven young Negroes, three girls and four boys, arrested for creating a disturbance last Tuesday night aboard a Tompkins Avenue trolley car at Empire Boulevard and New York Avenue, Brooklyn, were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Alfred M. Lindau in Brooklyn Adolescents Court.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (U.P.) -- Flight Officer John L. Coogan, the Jackie Coogan of film roles going back to his early boyhood, told at a press conference here today how he flew British Chindit troops into Burma by glider last March in the first operation of its kind against the Japanese.
Mrs. Homer Cummings, wife of the former United States Attorney General, has arrived from Washington, and is at the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Senate bill to extend the Emergency Price Control Act contains a provision known as the Bankhead Amendment. This amendment is highly inflationary; it is virtually impossible to administer properly, and it would place the cotton textile industry in a favored position as compared with other industries.

Following are the texts of a statement by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower broadcast to the people of western Europe and his Order of the Day to the Allied Expeditionary Force as recorded by The New York Times and the Columbia Broadcasting System:

Belief that Congress might approve loans at 95 per cent of parity on cotton stimulated yesterday a covering movement in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange and prices were carried to new high marks for the life of the contracts, with closing prices 19 to 21 points net higher on the day.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, June 6 -- Washington learned officially of the invasion of Europe at 3:32 A.M. today when the War Department issued the text of the communique issued by the Supreme Headquarters, Allied Expeditionary Forces.

Women planning to make their own clothes this summer may achieve more "professional" results by studying a test of good dressmaking and pointers on how to pass the test, both of which are included in a bulletin issued yesterday by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Westward of the Schouten Islands lie other seas washing Japan's richest conquests. That is why the enemy resists us so desperately on Biak, the most important of the Schouten group. It is the gateway both to the Philippines and to the Netherlands Indies.
Mayor La Guardia, before leaving by plane for Washington yesterday morning, called the Allied capture of Rome "very gratifying."
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, June 6 (AP) -- A communique:

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5 -- Silver wings of pilots in the Army Air Corps were presented today to 171 air cadets of the graduating class of the United States Military Academy in a ceremony held at Battle Monument on historic Trophy Point overlooking the Hudson River.

ROME, June 5 -- Never has there been such a Roman triumph as was this day. Jeeps on the Campidoglio, tanks rolling past St. Peter's almost under the windows of the Pope's office, G.I.'s buying flowers for Roman lassies and excitement everywhere.
CHUNGKING, China, June 5 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Somewhat annoyed over suggestions that the Navy Department is responsible for creating unemployment by terminating its contracts with the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, Navy spokesmen disclosed today that a study had been made of the labor situation in the New York City area, where one Brewster factory is situated.

Net profit of the W.F. Hall Printing Company for the fiscal year ended with March amounted to $1,031,761, equal to $2.66 each on 388,357 common shares, Alfred B. Geiger, president, reported yesterday to stockholders. This compares with $1,102,000, or $2.84 a share, for the preceding fiscal year.

On the fifth "come and see" tour conducted by the women's division of the New York War Fund thirty women observed yesterday branches of the Russian War Relief and the American Women's Voluntary Services.
The following is the text of President Roosevelt's broadcast speech last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

There will be a larger market abroad for machine tools following the war than ever before, W.H. Myer, chief, machinery and motive products unit, Department of Commerce, told the second wartime conference of the Machinery Dealers National Association yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SOMEHOW or other the discussion swung around to curve-ball pitching and it was automatic then that the two main conversationalists, Frank Frisch and Chili Doyle, the veteran Pittsburgh scrivener, should concentrate on Rosy Ryan. The big fellow from Holy Cross College was one of the best curve-ball artists of them all and, if there was anything which delighted John J. McGraw above all else, it was a pitcher who could throw a hook.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 5 (U.P.) -- Chinese and American troops in northern Burma have scored new gains in the battle for Myitkyina and closed a ring of encirclement around the main Japanese base of Kamaing, while on the Manipur front in India British Imperial forces drove the enemy from three hills and a strategic village near Kohima, official reports said today.

A sixteen-point legislative program, designed "to create relationships between Government and people that will make it possible for business and industry to function in such a manner as to provide opportunities for general employment" was outlined yesterday by Dr. Fred I. Kent, chairman of the post-war planning committee of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, at a press conference in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 6 (U.P.) -- The Germans hurled fresh forces of infantry and tanks in fierce battles northwest and north of Jassy, Rumania, yesterday, but for the seventh successive day Red Army troops flung back the enemy and killed more than 600, Moscow announced early today.
LONDON, June 5 -- Examination of evidence from France does not bear out the idea, cherished in some quarters, that the whole population will rise against the Germans when the Allies land.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 5 -- Crowds of excited Brazilians thronged the streets of Rio de Janeiro last night rejoicing on the fall of Rome. After a radio broadcast stated that "General Clark entered Rome," impromptu paraders hailed Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, the United Nations fighters and downed fascism.

CHUNGKING, China, June 5 (AP) -- Six separate Japanese columns, battering their way slowly toward the Hunan provincial capital of Changsha, have achieved new gains at the expense of heavy casualties, and fighting raged on a wide front with American planes ceaselessly harassing the enemy, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

One hundred of the city's office and loft buildings were assigned yesterday to 100 advertising and circulation salesmen for various magazines and periodicals, who will try to enlist every tenant in "housecleaning drives" similar to those recently organized in three midtown skyscrapers, which already have produced several hundred extra tons of wastepaper for conversion into paper containers for war material.

In 1919 the League of Nations was supported by nearly every important educational and religious organization in the United States. The most influential newspapers advocated American adherence. President Wilson and the leaders of his party naturally were actively for the League.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Gen. George C. Marshall, United States Chief of Staff, said tonight "the final action in this terrible European war is now focused on a single battle in which every Allied force will be represented."

After completing the academic requirements while traveling from camp to camp with her soldier husband, Mrs. Sylvia Jaffe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Schnipper, 40-08 Tenth Street, Long Island City, Queens, will receive her Master of Science degree from New York University tomorrow at ceremonies on the Washington Heights campus.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., acting Secretary of State, issued a statement today supplementing oral comments made during his morning press conference, deploring the failure of the House of Representatives on Saturday to authorize transfer of $350,000,000 from lendlease funds to the credit of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation.

STANTON, Del., June 5 (AP) -- J.L. Friedman's Squadron won the mile and seventy yards featured fifth race at Delaware Park today, coasting home three lengths ahead of Mrs. D.B. Miller's Be Calm. H.H. Haag's Pumpgun finished third. Squadron paid $9.80.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Wool industry representatives may ask the Senate to require that wool proposed to be taken from Government-owned stockpiles for foreign relief programs shall be exclusively from reserves of American-grown wools.

LONDON, June 5 -- Prime Minister Mikolajczyk went to Washington on an invitation so urgent as to suggest that President Roosevelt had some proposal to present to him for an eleventh-hour agreement between the estranged Government of Poland and the Soviet Union.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, June 6 (AP) -- Liberator bombers sank a Japanese destroyer and probably destroyed another, headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Loud boos from Republicans and cries of "Shame! Shame!" at Representative J. Bayard Clark, Democrat of North Carolina, marked the open ing today on a joint resolution to extend the statute of limitations to permit court-martial of Maj. Gen. Walter C. Short and Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel in the Pearl Harbor disaster. The Senate had previously passed the measure.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., June 5 -- Bill Goldbeck, veteran Mount Kisco pro, learned today that lightning strikes twice. In the last one-day tournament of the Westchester P.G.A., two weeks ago, Goldbeck and his partner finished in a tie with two other teams for the lead and won the top place on a match of cards.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A House-Senate conference committee agreed today to cut back the cabaret tax from 30 to 20 per cent, but eliminated a provision exempting service men and women from the levy.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- After days of shouted objections from two score lawyers defending twenty-seven men and two women in the trial for seditious conspiracy, now in its eighth week, Presiding Justice Edward C. Eicher adopted a streamlining procedure today to expedite the case.

There is little doubt that, duly cloaked in baggy clothes and charm, J.C. Nugent is one of the great men of the theatre. Baffled, bewildered, blowing through crises like a porpoise, he has a wonderful manner -- as well as all the tricks of vaudeville, which are, after all, the essential tricks of the theatre.

BOSTON, June 5 -- Paul Stark Seeley of Cambridge, Mass., associate editor of The Christian Science Journal, Sentinel and Herald, has been appointed president of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist, here, for the coming year.

At last the supreme moment has come. The months and years of waiting are over. Troops of the United States, the British Isles, the Dominions, contingents from occupied but unconquered countries in Europe are at this moment setting foot on the continental soil. The men who left Dunkerque nearly four years ago are returning.
Prior to the Allied invasion of Western Europe, the most ambitoious such undertaking against those shores was the action at Dieppe on Aug. 19, 1942.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Charges that William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, has done nothing to clean out "racketeers and crooks" from labor leadership and that he has failed to repudiate the spreading of strikes in war industries were made today by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 13 per cent last week over the like period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the previous week the bank had reported a rise of 11 per cent.

ROME, June 5 (U.P.) -- Gen. Roberto Bencivenga, an anti-Fascist imprisoned for many years by Mussolini, installed himself as Civil and Military Commissioner of Rome today to collaborate with the Allied Military Government early, while the capital did one of the greatest political somersaults in its history.

Mayor La Guardia took cognizance yesterday of reported widespread resentment by transit and other city employes against his moves to keep them from holding outside jobs on their own time. He also told of receiving "many complaints that conductors and station masters are irritable and cranky."

PASSAIC, N.J., June 5 (AP) --Six hundred employes of the Botany Worsted Mills of Passaic have been on an unauthorized sit-down strike since Friday morning, threatening to stop all activity by the plant's 5,000 workers and shut off deliveries of cloth for Army and Navy uniforms, the management announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Twenty-seven additional concerns have received the Army-Navy Production Award for excellence in the manufacture of war materials. They are:
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The United States Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision holding constitutional the so-called "death sentence" provision of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

High ranking officers of the nation's fighting forces will attend the first of the special Tuesday matinees of "Oklahoma" this afternoon at the St. James Theatre for service men and women of the United Nations at reduced prices ranging from 60 cents to $2.10 (tax included).

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 5 -- Richard Holden, 59 years old, confessed this afternoon, the District Attorney's office announced, that he killed his wife, Anna, 60, last Wednesday by cutting her throat as she slept in their home at 42 Burling Lane, New Rochelle, to save her from further suffering as a diabetic semi-invalid. He was held on a first-degree murder charge.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 5 -- Dr. Davis A. Lockmiller was chosen today for his third consecutive term as president of the University of Chattanooga. Degrees were awarded members of the fifty-eighth graduating class.

PEARL HARBOR, June 5 (U.P.) -- Army planes attacking the Kuriles hit enemy installations within 400 miles of the Japanese mainland Sunday, and two Central Pacific search planes sank one and possibly two patrol vessels west of Truk Atoll in the Carolines Friday and Saturday, Pacific Fleet Headquarters announced today.

ROME, June 5 -- The Allies' armor and motorized infantry roared through Rome today without pausing, crossed the Tiber River and proceeded with the grim task of destroying two battered German armies fleeing to the north.

Declaring that the Little Steel formula is "obsolete, unfair and unrealistic" and recommending its quick "interment" by the War Labor Board, Emil Rieve, general president of the Textile Workers of America, demanded general wage increases yesterday for the 20,000 employes of the American Woolen Company, on the basis of the company's profit in 1943 of "more than $1,380 on every worker on the payroll."

VATICAN CITY, June 5 -- Pope Pius XII appeared on the balcony of St. Peter's at 6 P.M. today to thank God that Rome had been spared from the ravages of war while before him in the densely packed square of St. Peter's and the new broad Via Della Conciliazione tens of thousands of Romans cheered themselves hoarse.

ANNAPOLIS, June 5 -- Richard Henry Engelmann of Cincinnati will be first honor man of the class of 914 midshipmen to be graduated from the Naval Academy Wednesday, it was stated today by Rear Admiral John R. Beardall, academy superintendent.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Prime Minister Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of Poland arrived here today by invitation of the United States to undertake a series of conversations with President Roosevelt and the State Department. He motored to Washington at noon from Baltimore, where he arrived yesterday, and was quartered at Blair House, the Government's residence for official visitors of the highest rank.

A syndicate sold the five-story loft building on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 162-68 Greene Street to Isidore Britchky for cash over a first mortgage held by the North River Savings Bank. The property, which is fully rented, is assessed at $68,000. Glekel Drimmer were the attorneys for the seller and Irwin Belenken for the buyer.

Following is a list of military terms, both official and of slang derivation, that will undoubtedly be household words during the long-awaited invasion of western Europe. Some of the expressions date back to World War I and before, but most have found their way into military dictionaries and everyday civilian conversation since the invasion of Poland in 1939.

Designed to train 800,000 housewives throughout the country in simple care of sick persons, a new home-nursing course was announced here yesterday by Maj. Gen. Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross.

LONDON, June 5 -- The British Government has protested vigorously to Turkey against the use of the Dardanelles by German warships recently employed in Black Sea operations. By invoking the Montreux Convention at this time, soon after Prime Minister Churchill's blunt words to Turkey, the British Government emphasized anew that it was tired of winking at the oversights of obligations by its Eastern Mediterranean ally.

That some of the prevailing wages paid today will have to be brought down while others are raised following the end of the war was emphasized yesterday by speakers at the twenty-fifth anniversary conference of the National Office Management Association at the New Yorker Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Roosevelt hailed tonight the capture of Rome, first of the three major Axis capitals to fall, as a great achievement on the road toward total conquest of the Axis. Rome, he said, marked "one up and two to go."

City College seniors who are now spending the last few nights of their academic careers on cigarettes and black coffee "cramming" for the final examination ordeals have found a way of taking revenge for their torments and of helping the war at the same time.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 6 (UP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 5 -- Vandalism in city parks and schools and damage to private property has reached such grave proportions in this city that the police have been directed to replace "reasoning with the youngsters" with sterner measures.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The hasty abandonment of Rome sheds more light on a significant German military characteristic, in the opinion of military observers. It now seems incontrovertible that the Nazis have no taste for suicidal, last-ditch stands and that when a situation is clearly stacked against them they retreat or give up.
LONDON, June 5 -- A new phase in the Italian campaign opened today when armored spearheads rumbled out of Rome in an attempt to cut off the retreating German Army.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 -- Donna Reed, who has just completed a role in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "The Picture of Dorian Gray," has been assigned by that company to the feminine lead, opposite Peter Lawford, in "Son of Lassie," under the direction of S. Sylvan Simon and produced by Sam Marx.

The shortage of lanolin is the most serious among the raw materials used for cosmetics, according to a recent Office of War Information release. Other cosmetic ingredients will be adequate for actual needs, with the exception of alcohol.

No mass wedding took place Saturday night in the Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn as incorrectly reported on Sunday in THE NEW YORK TIMES following an erroneous announcement at the hospital. A party was held at the hospital that night for eight couples, among whom were nine physicians associated with the hospital.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, called upon all affiliated unions today to cooperate with the War Manpower Commission in seeking to make effective the program of job priority referrals and employment ceilings.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 6 (UP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 5 -- Vandalism in city parks and schools and damage to private property has reached such grave proportions in this city that the police have been directed to replace "reasoning with the youngsters" with sterner measures.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The hasty abandonment of Rome sheds more light on a significant German military characteristic, in the opinion of military observers. It now seems incontrovertible that the Nazis have no taste for suicidal, last-ditch stands and that when a situation is clearly stacked against them they retreat or give up.
LONDON, June 5 -- A new phase in the Italian campaign opened today when armored spearheads rumbled out of Rome in an attempt to cut off the retreating German Army.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 -- Donna Reed, who has just completed a role in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "The Picture of Dorian Gray," has been assigned by that company to the feminine lead, opposite Peter Lawford, in "Son of Lassie," under the direction of S. Sylvan Simon and produced by Sam Marx.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 5 -- Congress should create an overall agency to handle post-war problems of war plant reconversion, in the opinion of United States Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, of Montana.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 5 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler is conferring with Balkan Quislings at Berchtesgaden at a meeting that may lead to a drastic revision of "the Vienna pact," whereby Transylvania was turned over to Hungary, according to information reaching Balkan diplomatic sources here today.

Although Tammany officially postponed until today the designation of a Congressional candidate in the new Nineteenth Congressional District, in lower Manhattan, indications last night were that a majority of the leaders in the area favored Representative Samuel Dickstein as the organization choice.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 6 -- The German DNB agency's military commentator, Capt. Ludwig Sertorius, said in a broadcast heard here this morning:
Scoring 48 points and taking seven first places, De Witt Clinton successfully defended its Bronx P.S.A.L. track and field championship at the Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday.
Supreme Allied Commander -- Gen. Dwight David Eisenhower, 53 years of age, Texas-born, Kansas-reared; previously Allied commander of the forces in North Africa, Sicily and Italy.

Edward L. Williams, president of the Insurance Executives Association, made up of the presidents or chief executive officers of about 150 capital stock fire insurance companies, declared yesterday that the Supreme Court decision holding that the insurance business was subject to Interstate Commerce was contemplated with trepidation.

Condemning the "liquor people, who want us to clean up the poor old drunks," Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin, president of the State Women's Christian Temperance Union and vice president of the National W.C.T.U., expressed the belief yesterday that "the time is coming very soon when dry organizations will begin an aggressive campaign against the liquor traffic."

LONDON, June 5 (U.P.) -- Enemy admitted today that propaganda the loss of Rome was a serious blow but tried to salvage something from the defeat by claiming that the city had been evacuated to spare its cultural treasures.
First Fiddle, Mrs. E. Mulrenan's 5-year-old gray, proved the standout on the opening day program at Aqueduct yesterday.
LONDON, June 5 -- Good war news from Italy plus buying orders accumulated over the week-end put today's stock markets here in a cheerful mood.

AN EAST COAST PORT, June 5 (U.P.) -- Six men lost their lives when a submarine sank a medium-sized British merchantman in daylight 500 miles off the coast of South America early last month, the Navy disclosed today. It was the first announced sinking of an Allied merchant ship in the Atlantic since December.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 6 -- The main weight of the invasion offensive of the Allied air power fell again yesterday on Nazi targets along the coast of northern France and behind the Atlantic Wall.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The President gave a fifteen-minute radio address tonight on the fall of Rome. During the day he conferred with Prime Minister Curtin of Australia.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 6 -- Early this morning Londoners, who at that time knew nothing of the invasion reports, were watching the sky as hundreds of Allied bombers and fighters roared overhead toward the southeast.

BOSTON, June 5 (AP) -- Mrs. H.P. Bonner's Defense, a stake winner at the recent meeting at Narragansett Park, made his first start at Suffolk Downs a winning one today, scoring by a length and a half in the $2,500 Minute Man purse of six furlongs.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Office of Price Administration instructed processors who buy canned fruits and vegetables from Government agencies today that they must take their ceiling prices from the schedule of maximum levels established for civilian sales of the 1943 pack of the same products if they are to resell their purchases back into civilian markets.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5 (AP) -- In a game that was marred by twenty-one bases on balls, the Montreal Royals pushed across three runs in the ninth tonight for a 6-4 decision over the last-place Newark Bears.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, June 6 -- It can now be revealed that the Allies have been conducting a series of feints in advance of the invasion today.
LONDON, June 5 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press.

Intolerance at home defeats the American and democratic way of life for which we are making unimaginable sacrifices in a world conflict, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, warned last night in urging Americans to shake off "the intolerable shackles of hate toward one another."

BOSTON, June 5 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle, in an address before the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers, today defended the Government's recent seizure of the Montgomery Ward plant in Chicago as having been in the public interest and declared that it would act similarly in any other such labor dispuate.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 6 -- Early this morning Londoners, who at that time knew nothing of the invasion reports, were watching the sky as hundreds of Allied bombers and fighters roared overhead toward the southeast.

BOSTON, June 5 (AP) -- Mrs. H.P. Bonner's Defense, a stake winner at the recent meeting at Narragansett Park, made his first start at Suffolk Downs a winning one today, scoring by a length and a half in the $2,500 Minute Man purse of six furlongs.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Office of Price Administration instructed processors who buy canned fruits and vegetables from Government agencies today that they must take their ceiling prices from the schedule of maximum levels established for civilian sales of the 1943 pack of the same products if they are to resell their purchases back into civilian markets.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5 (AP) -- In a game that was marred by twenty-one bases on balls, the Montreal Royals pushed across three runs in the ninth tonight for a 6-4 decision over the last-place Newark Bears.
CHUNGKING, China, June 5 (AP) -- A communique:

Charging that the Teachers Guild misrepresented facts in its recent report on teacherless classes, Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade said in a statement yesterday that the average number of classes for which substitutes had been unavailable since Feb. 14 was 240 a day, or about 1.4 per cent.

Members of New York's police force have shown themselves expert in varied fields, but Patrolman William Fox has added a new one -- "Equilibrium Relationships Between Fluid Interfaces: the System of Methylene Iodide-Water-Air."

WEST POINT, June 6 -- The American Army began its "tough, grim and bloody march from the shores of the Atlantic to Berlin" equipped with enough of everything and the best of everything obtainable, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell of the Army Supply Forces declared today at the graduation exercises of the military academy.

CINCINNATI, June 6 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today cleared three officials of the National Bronze and Aluminum Foundry Company of Cleveland of a charge of conspiracy to defraud the Government in the manufacture of aluminum castings and ordered the District Court there to grant their motion for a directed acquittal.

Senator Warren R. Austin, Republican of Vermont, speaking at the annual commencement day luncheon of the Columbia University Alumni Federation, called yesterday for the immediate institution of the international organization contemplated by the Four Power Moscow Declaration.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Commenting on the Pacific war at his press conference today, James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, observed that the power of initiative everywhere remained with us, and that American submarines, inflicting the greatest loss on the enemy's merchant and warships, now were sinking five times as many ships as they did at the beginning of the war.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Evidence of the ambitions of the Nazi party to spread its doctrines throughout the world was offered today to the jury in the seditious conspiracy trial.
LONDON, June 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's speech in the House of Commons today:
