LONDON, June 6 -- As the American invasion assault units moved to their assembly points each man was a walking arsenal. Besides his eighty rounds of ammunition he carried three grenades. Some were armed with rifles, some with Springfields which had grenade launchers; others had Browning automatic rifles, flame throwers and TNT pole charges.

D-day meant See-day to Times Square yesterday. From Broadway and Forty-second Street north to Forty-eighth Street every gaze was focused on the news being spelled out in electric light ripples on the Times Tower sign of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Frenchmen, Belgians and Netherlanders now in New York -- members of those nations whose homelands lie directly in the path of the invasion -- learned yesterday of the Allied landings in Europe with mingled hope of victory, fear for their friends and families in the new battle-zone, and relief that the long waiting finally had ended.

PEARL HARBOR, June 6 (U.P.) -Army, Navy and Marine air forces, ranging over a 1,000-mile front in the central Pacific, attacked Truk, Ponape, Nauru and the Marshalls in a series of seven assaults Saturday, Sunday and Monday. A Pacific Fleet announcement said today.
LONDON, June 6 -- This was D-day and it has gone well.

The investment of nearly $100,000,000 in the next few years for the construction of six or seven thousand route miles of coaxial telephone cables, which will be capable of transmitting hundreds of telephone conversations simultaneously over a single pair of conductors and also of transmitting television images, was predicted yesterday by Keith S. McHugh, vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

OTTAWA, June 6 -- Canadian troops taking part in the Allied landing in France "have successfully achieved their first objective land are making good progress," Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King informed the House of Commons this afternoon in making his report on the day's great events.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -Edith K. Gaylord of The Associated Press Washington staff was elected president of the Women's National Press Club tonight.

LONDON, June 6 (U.P.) -- The Allies placed on the alert today -ready for action when needed -- an underground army estimated at 8,000,000 European patriots organized to strike mighty blows for the liberation of their own countries.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- While giving out no fresh information on the progress of the invasion, the reaction of both the War and Navy departments today was that the first phases seemed to be "going well."

Eddie Carnett, the original smiling Irishman from Tulsa, today led the thirteen survivors of baseball's draft along the road to major league stardom with his fancy play and timely hitting as part-time White Sox first baseman, an Associated Press survey reveals.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 6 -The peal of church bells and the roar of guns accompanied the invasion news in Stockholm today. It was coincidence, however, for today was Swedish Flag Day and King Gustav's name day, which is always celebrated with the ringing of church bells and a twenty-one-gun salute.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Members of the government were advised this forenoon that the invasion to liberate Europe was keeping exact pace with General Dwight D. Eisenhower's time-table. They were informed that, up to the moment of this report, men, ships, aircraft and supplies had reached the destinations planned for them to reach today and at the time appointed.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 7 -- The Allied air forces hammered out the paths for yesterday's invasion blow and held a shield over our forces at sea and ashore with an unprecedented power and skill that kept our losses well below the cost Allied commanders had been prepared to pay.

It was never, of course, going to be like this. If Hitler, the man of a thousand certainties, was more certain of one thing than of all the others, it was that he was not going to repeat the monstrous mistake of his predecessors in 1914 and get himself involved simultaneously in a war on two fronts.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -Secretary Forrestal and Under-Secretary Patterson asserted tonight that with "our boys fighting into France," this is no time for strikes or quarrels over profits.

PITSI FERRY ON SALWEEN RIVER, June 1 (delayed) -- In a thatched hut on the beach of the Salween Gen Sung Hsi-lien is watching one of his units crossing the river this afternoon. As a commanding general he said he had had the privilege of riding a horse the day before.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE IN RUSSIA, June 6 -- A large force of American heavy bombers wiped out Nazi air installations at Galati, Rumania, today and returned to their Soviet bases without loss in the first round-trip operation across the Russian-German front.

The cotton market broke on the invasion news to maximum losses of 21 to 23 points, then staged a strong comeback in the afternoon, establishing new highs for the life of the contracts and closing near the best levels, at net gains of 3 to 5 points.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- All the American men and material needed for the invasion of Europe had been convoyed to the United Kingdom by the Atlantic Fleet, and now the fleet's greatly reduced job will be to keep the "expenditures replaced," Admiral Royal E. Ingersoll, Atlantic Fleet commander, declared here today.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -Closeted in his bedroom, President Roosevelt spent the early morning hours of the invasion writing a prayer for victory for the Allied forces of liberation.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- After a brisk battle waged along party lines, the House passed by a roll-call vote of 305 to 35 today a resolution directing the Secretaries of War and of the Navy to start the courts-martial of Maj. Gen. Walter C. Short and Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel within three months.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6 -Joyce Reynolds, who played Emlen Davies in "Mission to Moscow," has been chosen by Warners for the lead in the film version of "Junior Miss," the rights to which the company acquired last week for $425,000. Miss Reynolds recently finished the name role in the studio's adaptation of the play "Janie."

All the major league clubs were idle yesterday, but the day was not without baseball news. The Giants found solace in the return to the fold of the veteran Johnny Allen, 39-year-old right-hander, who met with Mel Ott, agreed to terms and signed a New York contract.

Over 150,000 postcard applications for service men's war ballots have been distributed in house-to-house canvassing by Democratic women workers in forty New York counties, Doris I. Byrne, associate chairman of the State Democratic Committee, said yesterday at party headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (U.P.) -- On the eve of the Allied invasion of France, Portugal agreed to stop all shipments of wolfram to Germany and to shut all her wolfram mines immediately, it was disclosed tonight.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, June 7 -The German Atlantic Wall has been breached.

BUFFALO, June 6 (AP) -- Ninety-two nurses have been decorated for wounds received in action and for acts of heroism in the war, Col. Florence M. Blanchfield of Washington, Superintendent of the Army Nurse Corps, said today.

Two suits contesting the city's right to enforce rules against dual job holding came to light yesterday. A suit in equity to restrain William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, from dismissing Charles Putkowski, a blacksmith, unless he quits a part-time job, was disclosed when the Corporation Counsel's office moved to dismiss the suit on the ground that no legal cause of action was established.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Millions of dollars in profits of cooperatives are escaping taxation, creating "dangerous" and unfair competition for private companies which are being heavily taxed, G. Sherwin Haxton, president of the National Canners Association, asserted at today's sessions here of the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers.

About 100,000,000 pounds of candy will be required for Army rations in 1944, Maj. Gen. Edmund B. Gregory, Quartermaster General, United States Army, told the National Confectioners' Association at their sixty-first annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Sewell L. Avery declared today that he forced his ouster from the Chicago plant of Montgomery Ward Co. by the Army to dramatize "the march of dictatorship" in the United States, and that subsequently he received letters from all parts of the country showing he had succeeded.
ROME, June 6 -- An ugly, four-story yellow stucco house at 145 Via Tasso marks the spot in the crime picture that was Rome until the Allies' entry.

ANNAPOLIS, June 6 -- Presentation of the "colors," national and regimental, most colorful military spectacle during the academic term and the "farewell ball," in honor of the Annapolis graduates, took place this afternoon on the eve of commencement exercises to be held at the Naval Academy tomorrow when 914 Midshipmen will receive commissions and degrees of Bachelor of Science.

ALGIERS, June 6 -- In this temporary capital of France, where a half-million persons or more have relatives in France and thousands have homes there, the invasion, so long and so impatiently awaited, was greeted today with joy tempered by the realization that the beginning of liberation was another ordeal for France.

Federal Judge John C. Knox told 600 men and women admitted to American citizenship yesterday that D-day could be interpreted as a symbol of "Deliverance Day, the day that promises deliverance for the suffering peoples of Europe."

Upton Sinclair's "Wide Is the Gate," the fourth Lanny Budd novel, has won the Commonwealth Club of America medal for the best novel of last year. The fifth book in the series, "Presidential Agent," was published on Friday by Viking, which reports that it had a greater advance sale than any of the others.

STANTON, Del., June 6 (AP) -- Acting on the assumption that by operating on D-Day more and would be supplied to the war effort than by remaining idle, the Delaware Steeplechase and Race Association decided to conduct the sport at Delaware Park today.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 6 (U.P.) -- American and Chinese troops have captured a Japanese position at the northern edge of Myitkyina, in northern Burma, and have destroyed strong defenses south and southwest of the beseiged stronghold, a Southeast Asia Command communique said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, June 7 (U.P.) -- American Sixth Army forces, mopping up Japanese snipers and machine gun nests on the ridge overlooking the coastal approaches to Mokmer airstrip on Biak Island, advanced one-half mile on Monday, but fighting along the coastal route to the field remained static, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 31:

With the conferring of 4,072 degrees and certificates to members of the graduating class, seven honorary degrees to public figures, and five awards to alumni leaders, New York University will celebrate its 112th commencement exercises at Ohio Field on the University Heights campus today at 10:30 A.M.
LONDON, June 6 -- The battle now raging on the beaches of western Europe was fought -- and its planners believe won -- in the war rooms of London and Washington two years ago.
I received, under date of May 15, a V-letter from my son, who is actively engaged in the Southwest Pacific. He was located at the moment of writing in the jungles where things are going on.

May I be permitted to answer part of Gunnar Leistikow's letter "Finland Held an Aggressor," published May 30. He alleges that the "German troops has the run of vast regions months before the attack * * * the Finns cannot therefore plead not guilty so far as the aggression against the Soviet Union of June 22, 1941, is concerned."

Dillon, Read Co. and Hemphill, Noyes Co. head an underwriting group that will offer today $30,000,000 of the Alleghany Corporation's 3 1/4 per cent secured convertible notes due on April 15, 1954, and priced at 102.15. The notes are secured by a first lien on 1,100,000 common shares of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, which are owned by the Alleghany Corporation and pledged as collateral under the indenture.

ABOARD AN AMERICAN PT-BOAT OFF FRANCE, June 6 (U.P.) -- Thousands of vessels arrived safely at their rendezvous off the French coast this morning, and although the operation began in broad daylight yesterday, the Germans were kept so busy by our planes they never knew what was happening.

This dispatch is being written just as the great invasion of western Europe has got under way. Events will move with such dramatic rapidity that the start of the invasion will sound like stale news by the time these words are in print.

LONDON, June 6 -- Alone in his study in Buckingham Palace tonight, King George spoke for six minutes in an empire-wide broadcast urging his subjects everywhere to turn their thoughts to prayer. He spoke with the full dignity of King, Emperor and Defender of the Faith to his people at a time of crisis in their fortunes.
DETROIT, June 6 -- Detroit paused briefly this morning from producing the tools of war to pay tribute to the men of the fighting services taking part in the invasion.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 6 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) declined today for the third consecutive year to restrict their company's operations by a prohibition against foreign production and marketing agreements.

Allocations of millions of pounds of foods to areas liberated by the United Nations were made at the beginning of the year, it was disclosed here yesterday by the local office of the War Food Administration. Butter, cheese and eggs were not included.

For a generation of shoppers brought up on the axiom that "the customer is always right" the trials of shopping in wartime have been a bit hard to take. By and large, however, the average consumer has accepted them with patient understanding, according to the results of a survey published last week by the trade publication, Retailing.

Declaring that the Allied powers "will remain perpetually indicted until fear of poverty and want are banished from every home," Walter Nash, Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand, listed last night freedom from want as the first principle to be worked out at the end of the war.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- President Roosevelt's War Relief Control Board has recommended that the National War Fund grant an application of American Relief for Italy, Inc., for $1,600,000 of privately contributed funds with which to supplement official relief provisions for liberated areas of Italy.

COASTAL AREA SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, June 6 -- Seasoned British troops who left this particular part of the coast on the long-awaited D-day did so with the full knowledge that they were about to take part in one of the most hellish conflicts in the history of the world, but they were glad to get away.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Plans to increase Brazilian exports of cotton textiles "in the interest of the joint war effort" were outlined at a series of meetings between a Brazilian textile mission and members of the Combined Production and Resources Board, it was disclosed today.

Five civil suits asking damages aggregating $34,500,000 were filed in Federal court yesterday against the Corning Glass Works, which was accused in each of monopolizing the manufacture of tubing and jackets for electric lamps. The sums asked represented triple the amount of damages claimed to have been suffered by each defendant, as provided by the Sherman Anti-trust Act.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,743, compared with 613 in the preceding week and 1,726 in the similar period of 1943, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
LONDON, June 6 -- A series of broadcasts carrying advice and appeals for restraint on the part of populace flowed from Britain to the Continent today.

The apartment house accommodating ten families at 5-15 Pierce Street, Newark, N.J., has been bought by the Namset Realty Company for investment, from the Five-Fifteen Pierce Corporation through the J.I. Kislak agency. The house is built on a plot 150 by 163 feet.
The Waukesha Motor Company reported yesterday for the nine months ended on April 30 net profit of $595,789 after all charges and reserve for Federal and State income taxes.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Permission to offer an amendment compelling the Office of Price Administration to reduce prices on cotton goods items where OPA finds they are quoted above "generally fair and equitable" levels, was granted today by the Senate to Senator Bankhead of Alabama.

Scheduled to appear in 103 daily newspapers, 22 national magazines and 12 trade journals, as well as spot announcements and participating programs on 44 radio stations, Don Juan Lipstick has launched its most ambitious advertising campaign, it was announced yesterday.

The Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors will open its fourth annual exhibition with a preview this afternoon from 3 to 6 at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. It opens to the public tomorrow, and will continue through July 1.

Western Hemisphere solidarity must be developed now to build foreign trade that will insure a prosperous post-war economy, William V. Wachtel, president of Calvert Distillers Corporation, said yesterday before the annual conference of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association at the Hotel Commodore.

A painting by Georges Schreiber has been accepted by the Treasury Department from the Abbott Laboratories as the major official poster for the Fifth War Loan drive. The painting depicts action aboard an American submarine and will be captioned "Fire Away."

Forced to resort to a toss of the coin to reach a decision after a "sudden death" overtime period had failed to break the deadlock between the teams, the Brookhattan Soccer Club was declared the winner of the final round game with the Brooklyn Hispanos, United States champions, in the Red Cross benefit exhibitions at the Polo Grounds last night.
Labor controversies kept more than 15,000 workers away from their tasks yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

The fishing reporter who tried to find a subject in his sport that might be of interest yesterday was in the position of a man shadow boxing in a dark room while a rousing brawl was going on outside. The trifling nature of all things piscatorial on D-day was too overwhelming.

LONDON, June 6 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower pressed the button for the invasion of France from a camp set deep in the heart of the sleeping English countryside. There, in a motor trailer, he is directing the first phase of the most gigantic amphibious operation ever conceived.

OTTAWA, June 6 (Canadian Press) -- In the fifteen years from 1929 to 1943 Canadian banks added $10,300,000 to their general contingency, or inner reserves, Finance Minister J. L. Ilsley told the House of Commons Banking Committee today.

Every American housewife who has contributed to the salvage drive has helped the American soldier on D-day, Mrs. Mortimer Hess, associate chairman of the War Production Board-Civilian Defense Volunteer Office salvage committee and national salvage chairman of the American Women's Voluntary Services, said yesterday.
Investors and operators have just acquired several housing properties in Manhattan in a continuation of the active market of recent months.

ALBANY, June 6 -- The State Post-war Public Works Planning Commission announced today that it had allotted $180,000 to the Port of New York Authority for contract plans and specifications for a $9,000,000 Union Midtown Bus Terminal near the Manhattan portal of the Lincoln Tunnel.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June, 6 -- Guns of Allied battleships, monitors and cruisers fought a violent duel with the batteries of coastal guns that stud Adolf Hitler's Atlantic Wall in the early hours today while destroyers and special assault craft crept in to hammer beach defenses and mortar and machine-gun position.

LONDON, June 6 (AP) -- Berlin military spokesmen predicted in broadcasts tonight that further Allied landings would be made in western Europe and suggested apprehensively that there might be a sudden stab for Paris.

Despite the demand for electric power and light under the war production program of the last three years, the power industry has a reserve generating capacity of 8,750,000 kilowatts, or 22 per cent above the peak load of this year, Charles W. Kellogg, president of the Edison Electric Institute, declared yesterday at its annual convention in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

An intensive campaign to extend the showings of war-incentive motion pictures to managers and workers in factories engaged in the production of war materials is being conducted by the Army Industrial Services Division at the suggestion of Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson and Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, head of the Army Service Forces.

With tunes by Leonard Bernstein, young conductor and composer, whose symphony, "Jeremiah," was chosen by New York's music critics as the outstanding orchestral work of the season just ended, a new musical comedy entitled "On the Town" will be placed in rehearsal late in August.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, June 7 (AP) -- A communique:

DETROIT, June 6 -- Greater demands on the automotive industry for equipment will be made by the armed forces as the pace of operations increases in the Pacific war theatre, Rear Admiral H.G. Taylor, superintendent of Navy civil engineering at Chicago told the Society of Automotive Engineers at their national war material meeting tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Secretary of State Hull, vacationing in Hershey, Pa., said today that the Allied invasion armies were "waging the most pivotal battle of all time."

LONDON, June 6 -- As was to be expected, the news of the Allied landing in France had a restricting effect on today's stock markets here. Prices where changed were fractionally lower but the tone hardened before the close.
The text of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's broadcast to France, recorded by the Federal Communications Commission, follows:

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, June 6 -- As the large golden "invasion" moon was sinking this morning and shafts of dawn touched the eastern sky, great fires raged on the northern French coast, where the Allies' armies had established a beachhead.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, June 7 (AP) -- Allied troops swiftly cleared Normandy beaches of the dazed Nazi survivors of a punishing sea and air bombardment, and armor-backed landing parties ranged inland today in a liberation invasion.

LONDON, June 6 -- The Allied grand offensive in the west is proceeding much better than expected and "there already are hopes that an actual tactical surprise has been attained" over the German forces in France, a supremely confident Prime Minister Churchill reported today in two D-day appearances before a cheering House of Commons.

LONDON, June 6 -- American and British soldiers wounded as the first waves of Allied invasion forces surged across the beaches of France today have already been evacuated in special hospital landing craft that penetrated to the shore closely behind the assault troops.
Baseball, racing and boxing in various sections of the country were postponed yesterday in observance of D-day.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 6 (AP) -- A communique:

GENERAL MONTGOMERY'S HEADQUARTERS, June 6 (AP) -Gen. Sir Bernard T. Montgomery, leading Allied armies in the grand assault on France, believes Field Marshal Edwin Rommel -- the Desert Fox he trapped on Africa's sands -- will try at once "to knock us back into the sea."

NAPLES, June 6 (U.P.) -- Premier Pietro Badoglio of Italy has tendered the resignation of his Government to Prince Humbert, newly designated Lieutenant General of the Realm, who accepted it and then instructed Premier Badoglio to form a new government incorporating underground political leaders now in Rome, it was announced officially tonight.

The march into Rome could hardly have been the prearranged signal for the great assault on the Continent, but the sequence of events has the effect of magnificent timing by a master strategist. The fall of the first Fascist capital on the very eve of D-day set the mood for the invasion as nothing else could have done.

Ninety-nine Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- President Roosevelt told a news conference, held thirteen hours after the initial announcement of the invasion of France, that the operation was proceeding according to schedule. He made this statement in a calm, rather low voice, but with obvious satisfaction that his composure did not entirely hide.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The deportation of eighty-one Germans and Japanese irrevocably committed the Bolivian regime of Maj. Gualberto Villarroel to the cause of the United Nations, the State Department told the other American republics in a report openly favorable to recognition of the five-months-old revolutionary government.

JACKSON, Miss., June 6 -- The domestic political reaction to the long-awaited invasion of Europe may have its first practical demonstration tomorrow at the Missisisppi State Democratic convention which, until tonight, had been all set to "read the riot act" to President Roosevelt and the New Deal wing of the party regarding white supremacy, States' rights, the poll tax and Vice President Henry A. Wallace.

LONDON, June 6 -- The United States Coast Guard is in the thick of the operations that began today. It is fulfilling two functions, one the traditional task of aiding ships and men in distress at sea, the other the manning of transports and landing craft that are ferrying men and equipment to the beaches of France.

Britain is determined to increase its exports to the United States, Cecil Smith declared last night in a round-table discussion at the international linen trade dinner of the Linens and Domestics Buyers Club of America at the Advertising Club of New York.

The Brooklyn Savings Bank sold the two-family house with two stores at 862 Flatbush Avenue to Ray S. Kashden. The property is assessed at $50,000 and the deal represented cash over a purchase money mortgage of $27,000. Thomas Kelly acted as broker. The bank also sold the two-family house at 698 Bristol Street to Ethel Javitz. Anna Lapinger acted as broker.

NEWARK, N.J., June 6 -- Twenty-one Army officers and 215 enlisted personnel, including two nurses, who had been returned from Mediterranean war theatres as casualties, were transferred today by ambulance planes to hospitals closer to their homes from the Army air base here.

The Republicans captured a traditionally Democratic Congressional seat in New York City yesterday, as Ellsworth B. Buck, former president of the Board of Education, won in the Eleventh District over Thomas V. Cantwell, nominee of the Democratic and American Labor parties.
After the first spine-tingling thrill of D-day news, New York City's millions turned almost as one yesterday to prayer for a quick victory and speedy return of our fighting men.

Following is the text of a personal message issued to his troops yesterday by Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, commander of the Allied Army group landing in France, as quoted in a broadcast by the London radio and recorded by Federal Communications Commission:

" What Price Italy?" described as a feature-length pictorial account of the Sicilian and Italian invasion, has been booked for its local premiere on Saturday at the Arena Theatre, Eighth Avenue and Forty-first Street. The documentary film was produced by Joseph Plunkett from footage shot by camera men of the Army Signal Corps, the Navy and Air Forces, according to Noel Meadow, the distributor.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 7 (AP) -- The weather, which caused a twenty-four-hour postponement of D-day, still is one of the biggest invasion worries, Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force chiefs disclosed early today.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 6 -France has taken the invasion calmly but with great satisfaction, according to reports. The landing was more of a surprise to the French than to the Germans, whose propaganda in France has insisted that the main Allied attacks would be between Cherbourg and Havre.

CHUNGKING, China, June 6 (U.P.) -- The fourth battle of Changsha opened yesterday as Japanese troops, advancing along several routes, reached the outer defenses of the key Hunan Province stronghold, twenty-two miles away, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

MOSCOW, June 6 -- When news of the Allied landing in France was flashed by the Moscow radio at 1:45 o'clock this afternoon scenes of tremendous excitement occurred in the streets near the public loudspeakers.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES CRUISER. Anchored in a British Port, June 3 (Delayed) -- It was early morning and the leaden light of a cheerless, rainy London day filtered through the dirty window panes of the Admiralty. A young officer sat at a long table in Room 60, where His Majesty's admirals were wont to meet.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 6 -The exchange liner Gripsholm docked at 3:45 P.M. here today, carrying among its passengers fifty-one sick and wounded American soldiers, many of whom smiled and pointed to newspapers which carried banner headlines of the invasion, as they came onto the pier.

BOSTON, June 6 -- The United States "needs to change its economic thinking and must do some original thinking" if it is to keep abreast with world economic trends after the war, Adolph A. Berle Jr., assistant Secretary of State, told the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union today.

President Roosevelt said in his radio address on the capture of Rome, first of the three Axis capitals to fall, that the United Nations are now one up and two to go. We trust it is not hypercritical to suggest that this may be understating the outlook for an Allied victory.

The stock market gave yesterday a salute of confidence to the Allied invasion forces in a buying splurge that pushed volume close to the 2,000,000-share mark, but late profit-taking cut early gains of 1 to 2 points about in half. In the face of all the professional predictions as to how the market would fare on D-day, financial circles labeled the session as highly orderly.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER-BOMBER BASE, in Britain, June 6 (U.P.) -- "It was wonderful. There they were, marching in to die, just as if they were going to a ball game," was the report of the opening of the invasion brought back by First Lieut. Roy L. Saux, 23, of Gretna, La., a Thunderbolt pilot, who watched the drama on the French beaches from 4,000 feet.

THE invasion is under way and sports news of every description suddenly has acquired a most insignificant and inconsequential appearance. It is impossible now to get excited about the pennant races, the way the horses are running or anything else in the world of sports. They just don't count at this precise moment.

ROME, June 6 -- One fact stood out above all others as the Allied authorities who will administer Rome's civil affairs rode in on the heels of the combat troops: In general, the city is in excellent shape. Its apparently splendid condition delighted Brig. Gen. Edgar E. Hume, commander, and the staff of officers who make up the forward echelon of the Fifth Army's Allied Military Government.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (U.P.) -Gen. John J. Pershing, who led American troops to victory over another generation of German aggressors in World War I, called on his countrymen today to share his "every confidence" that American manhood again "will win through to victory" in its second great contest on Western European soil.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Women whose husbands are bearing the brunt of the invasion responsibility shared their D-day thoughts with the women of the country.
Led by President Roosevelt, the entire country joined in solemn prayer yesterday for the success of the United Nations armies of liberation.

Home canners will be interested in the United States Department of Agriculture's newest bulletin called "Home Canning of Fruits and Vegetables" (AWI-93), which is available free of charge by writing to "Home Canning," Washington.

Linton Baldwin of Poly Prep won two matches yesterday to advance into the final of the metropolitan junior championship at the New York Tennis Club. In his quarter-final Baldwin conquered Donald Kramer, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1. Later he defeated Seymour Waldman of Columbia, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.
A BRITISH PORT, June 6 -United States men-of-war and landing craft were trained and prepared for the invasion at American naval stations in the British Isles.

Allied radio stations in the United States, England, North Africa and Italy were coordinated early yesterday morning for an unprecedented propaganda campaign directed at Germany and the occupied countries. At the hour of invasion the broadcasting facilities were linked together in an international chain to insure a maximum audience on the Continent for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's statement to "the people of western Europe."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 7 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons that air-borne heralds of the invasion had been "successful" in the final softening up blow against Hitler's "Western Wall" just before the huge water-borne force surged ashore under naval guns and air bombs.

Several loft buildings in the Broadway district were reported yesterday to have passed into new hands. One of the deals involved the twelve-story "heavy duty" structure at 9-15 Murray Street, known as the Franklin Building, which was acquired in a cash transaction by Richard Lederer as a "permanent investment."
CHUNGKING, China, June 6 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A subcommittee of the Senate's Agriculture Committee began hearings today on the margarine bill introduced by Chairman Ellison D. Smith, which is intended to eliminate alleged discriminatory Federal regulations and taxes governing the production and distribution of oleomargarine.

The National Office Management Association, comprising 4,000 office managers and personnel directors in chapters in sixty-nine cities throughout the country, voted yesterday to cooperate fully in the vast job of post-war rehabilitation program for war veterans.

Sealed bids on forty lots of State and municipal bonds, aggregating $17,565,000, were opened yesterday by the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, which had given notice last week of intention to sell these bonds from its investment portfolio.

FREDERICK, Md., June 6 -- Establishment of an international office of education is even more essential than the forming of a political world-wide body for the future peace of the world, Dr. Alexander Meiklejohn, representing the American Association for Adult Education, declared today at the opening session of the International Education Assembly, meeting on the Hood College campus.

Thousands of city employes joined yesterday in brief periods of silent meditation or prayer for the success of Allied arms in the invasion of Europe. In departmental and borough offices, bureau and sectional offices throughout the city, in courtrooms, fire houses, police stations and hospitals there were simple ceremonies to mark the long-awaited day.

In a quick resale, David S. Meister has disposed of the seventeen-story concrete office, showroom and loft building at 98-102 Gold Street, at the southeast corner of Frankfort Street, to a client of Joseph Howard Katz, lawyer.
MIAMI, Fla., June 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Charlotte Milburn Pickering Cheesborough Wright became a bride for the fourth time here yesterday when she was married to Sergt. Earl H. Mote of the Army Air Forces.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- In the three months of final preparation for the invasion of Europe 3,000 tanks and 90,000 other military motor vehicles were shipped from the United States to Allied forces, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, announced today.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 7 -- Probably within twenty-four to forty-eight hours -- and almost certainly before the end of the week -- Soviet armies will swing their vast power into a synchronized offensive with the British-American western front forces under the master plan of Teheran envisaging the destruction of Germany this year, military observers here believe.
Lieut. J. Richardson Dilworth, USNR, and Mrs. Dilworth have arrived from Washington, and are at the Carlyle.
LONDON, Wednesday, June 7 (UP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
Normal routine of the three major veterans' hospitals in the city was abandoned yesterday morning when news of the Allied invasion of the continent of Europe spread from ward to ward and bed to bed.

It is the strange but noble destiny of France to welcome passionately in secret an army of invaders that must bring more destruction and death upon her, who has suffered so much and so long. It will soon be four years since the armistice with Germany was signed after six disastrous weeks.

PHILADELPHIA June 6 -- The Liberty Bell sounded today from the cradle of liberty to proclaim once again "Liberty throughout the land and unto the inhabitants thereof." It tolled last July 8, 1935, for the death of Chief Justice John Marshall.

The Baron de Hirsch Fund has sold the five-story apartment house at 1551 Hoe Avenue, in the Bronx, containing 134 rooms and occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet, to a client of Bachrach Bachrach, brokers. The sale was made subject to a mortgage of $56,000.
ROME, June 6 -- The Allies swept ahead on a seventy-mile front today to speed the destruction of the German armies routed from Rome.
ROME, June 5 (Delayed) -- At 19 o'clock tonight a newspaper man's newspaper appeared on the streets of Rome bearing the arresting masthead, "Stars and Stripes."

The declining sun gilded 50,000 heads bowed in prayer by the Eternal Light, in and around Madison Square Park, from 5:30 to 6 o'clock last night, as a priest, a minister and a rabbi asked God's grace for the Allied invaders.

The two buildings containing apartment and stores on a plot 50x100 feet on the east side of Jackson Avenue, fifty feet south of West Street, Long Island City, have been sold by Henry Tiedeman to Sadie Rosenstock. The property is in the Bridge Plaza section. The Herbert Callman Company, brokers in the deal, state that negotiations are pending for a resale to a syndicate planning the construction of an industrial building after the war.

Denying that wages paid in the wool textile industry were substandard, as charged by the Textile Workers of America, the American Woolen Company yesterday urged dismissal of demands for increased rates at a hearing before a special panel of the National War Labor Board here.

The President's prayer last night was the nation's prayer. This nation was born in the only revolution in history made in the name of God. It was born of the conception that the rights of man are not conveyed to him by any accident of class or color, race or creed, are not conferred or withheld by any government, but are given him by God as the inalienable birthright of the human being.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Congress was stirred deeply by word that the Allied invasion of continental Europe from the north was on and turned today to prayers for speed and complete victory with a minimum of human losses.

I believe that most of us will agree with the statement of Sumner Welles, as reported in THE TIMES of May 30, that we of the United States should continue to strive to be good neighbors with all the countries of the Western Hemisphere.

Thousands of New Yorkers, anxious to take some active part in D-day swamped blood bank centers in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday in their eagerness to make blood donor appointments. By 8 o'clock last night weary volunteer workers reported a 300 per cent increase in "future bookings" over a normal day.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The President reported on the invassion of Europe at his news conference, and in the evening broadcast his prayer for the success of the Allied forces. During the day he saw General Marshall, Admiral King and General Arnold, and a Texas delegation including Speaker Rayburn, Senator Connally, Amon Carter and Representative Ewing Thomason.

Eleven thousand Allied aircraft supported the sweep of our forces over the rim of the European Continent as the invasion got under way. They were of all types. Many were heavy bombers dropping their 5,000 tons of explosives on German gun emplacements and the Norman road and rail network that leads inland.

The people of New York City received the invasion news calmly. There was no celebration, no outburst of enthusiasm, no sign of fear or depression. The prevailing mood was one of deep solemnity, of sober realization that this was only the beginning, that the road might be hard and bloody and that many might lose sons and brothers before the battle was won.

In shipyards and war plants in the metropolitan area, where the material for the fighting fronts is being turned out, men and women greeted D-day yesterday with solemn pledges to redouble their production efforts to speed victory.
LONDON, June 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of a second statement to the House of Commons today by Prime Minister Churchill:

Invasion interrupted "business as usual" in the department stores of the city yesterday. Some closed at 1 P.M.; many at 4 P.M. All urged employes either to attend prayer services or to return home and devote their thoughts "to the thing uppermost in our minds," as one store put it.

ABOARD A BRITISH DESTROYER, Off Berniere-sur-Mer, June 6 -- Guns are belching flames from more than 600 Allied warships. Thousands of bombers are roaring overhead and fighters are weaving in and out of the clouds as the invasion of Western Europe begins.
LONDON, June 6 (AP) -- Supreme Headquarters, Allied Expeditionary Force communique 2:

LONDON, June 6 -- The greatest air-borne invasion of all time accompanied the Allied assault on Hitler's "Atlantic Wall" today. And tonight, almost twenty-four hours after the first air-borne troops had hit French soil behind the German lines, the operation appears to have been spectacularly successful.

Plans for the $16,000,000,000 Fifth War Loan Drive opening next Monday went forward yesterday, stimulated by the news of the invasion of Europe. Although no official tabulation of the receipts was available, banks, stores, motion-picture houses and other issuing agencies reported increased sales of war bonds and stamps, attributable to the news.

A second recent convention of women's clubs, this time in Massachusetts, has called for a woman delegate to the coming peace conference and has named a desirable candidate. That is all to the good, for it is none too early to discuss and settle this all-important question.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, Thursday, June 8 -- The town of Bayeux, on the main highway and railroad from the Cherbourg Peninsula to Paris, has been stormed and captured by Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's infantry and tanks, and the highway through it, the enemy's principal lateral road in Normandy, has been crossed and severed at several points, according to a special announcement made by Allied Headquarters early today.

LONDON, June 7 (U.P.) -- The Allies' orders to the French underground went out today by plane and radio for the sabotage of German communications and the immediate evacuation of towns about to be bombed.
SUPREME ADVANCE COMMAND POST, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 7 (AP) -- Communique 3:

WITH CANADIAN FORCES LANDING IN FRANCE, June 7 -- Canadian assault forces bounced through the stormy sea in landing craft yesterday and in broad daylight stormed the French beaches and battled their way inland.

The Supreme Court by a four-to-three decision holds that the insurance companies of the country are in interstate commerce, and so subject to the Sherman Anti-Trust Law. The decision upsets precedents which began with a contrary decision by the Court more than seventy-five years ago.

NEWARK, N.J., June 7 -- A strike of 1,200 bottlers and drivers halted today delivery of bottled beer from seven large breweries in this area. The strike started this morning following a vote taken last night by Local 843 of the Bottle Beer Drivers, Warehousemen and Helpers Union, AFL.

Mayor La Guardia will become a radio news reporter on Sunday, covering the Army's "Salute to the Infantry" parade up Fifth Avenue, to be held in the interest of the Fifth War Loan campaign that will open thee next day.

Stocks of all major petroleum products increased last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period the nation's gasoline supplies in storage were 87,084,000 barrels, an increase of 616,000 from the 86,468,000 barrels reported a week earlier. A year ago gasoline stocks were 82,700,000 barrels.

Ninety-nine Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.
SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA (AP) -- Third Bronze Oak Leaf Cluster to the Air Medal to Capt. Joseph J. O'Connor of 168-41 Eighty-ninth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Backing up the War Department with virtually every dollar it requested, the house appropriations committee recommended today a $49,109,002,795 fund to finance the country's far-flung fighting troops during the fiscal year starting July 1.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 7 -- The New Jersey College for Women conferred two honorary degrees here today at the twenty-third annual commencement exercises. The degree of Master of Arts was given to Elizabeth Kenny, Australian nurse noted for her unorthodox treatment of infantile paralysis, and that of Doctor of Laws was conferred upon the commencement speaker, Vera M. Dean, research director of the Foreign Policy Administration.
PEARL HARBOR, June 7 (UP) -- American planes bombed Guam, Nauru, Ponape and Mili in separate attacks over the central Pacific front on Sunday and Monday, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

No particular hedging activities have been shown by store buyers in New York wholesale markets following news of the invasion, it was learned yesterday. Already operating with caution on some fall lines, purchasing programs are being pursued just about as planned previously.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Montgomery Ward Co. will refuse to extend an expired contract with the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, in Chicago as directed yesterday by the War Labor Board, according to statements made today by Sewell L. Avery, chairman of the board, and two associates.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Messages saluting the liberation of Rome and opening of the European invasion are pouring into the White House from Allied Governments and military leaders all over the world.

Formation of a committee to seek the re-education of Nazi prisoners of war was announced yesterday by Gerhart H. Seger, former member of the Reichstag and editor of the Neue Volkszeitung, anti-Nazi publication here.
Gov. Walter E. Edge of New Jersey and Mrs. Edge are at the Ambassador.

The Galerie St. Etienne will open its last exhibition of the season tomorrow afternoon with a memorial show of paintings and drawings by Max Liebermann. Included are some of the artist's most famous works. Thomas Mann has written a foreword to the catalogue.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -- Ike Williams, a 1-to-2 favorite, won a ten-round split decision from Sammy Angott, former lightweight champion, before a crowd of 15,000 at Shibe Park tonight. Williams triumphed on the vote of Referee Irving Kutchner after two judges split.

LONDON, June 7 -- Hundreds of chemists on both sides of the Atlantic are engaged in the search for synthetic penicillin so the production of the new healing drug can be stepped up to meet the demand for it on the fighting fronts, Sir Howard Walter Florey, Oxford pathologist, said here today.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., June 7 (AP) -- Delegates to the five-day Northeastern Jurisdictional Conference of the Methodist Church voted today that the clergyman accepting election as missionary bishop for South Africa must do so with the understanding he is to remain in the post for the duration of his effective ministry.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Maj. Robert Johnson, who is a former boxer and football player and now is America's top fighter ace of the European theatre, was full of regret today that he was missing the "big show."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 7 -- Howie Dobel's fourteen bases or balls handicapped Columbia heavily and decided today's game, 8 to 5 in favor of Yale, reversing the outcome of their New York meeting. Blake Walker of Yale walked five and was derricked in the final inning when the visitors had the tying run on base.

ROME, June 7 -- The villa of the former Metropolitan Opera tenor Beniamino Gigli was sacked last night by Italians who were angered at the singer's alleged friendliness with the Germans during the Nazi occupation.

Forty-four women volunteers who will serve in hospital libraries here by delivering books to patients in wards and private rooms received certificates of graduation yesterday from a training course given by the hospital library bureau of the United Hospital Fund.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs today at midwestern markets were smaller than earlier in the week, due in part to embargoes at some terminals. The outlet, however, remained limited and with she large accumulation from earlier in week, serious congestion continued at several points. Aggregate receipts at twelve markets were 89,000 salable head, compared with 144,000 on last Wednesday.

LONDON, June 7 -- Three destroyers of the German Navy stuck their noses out of the Bay of Biscay last night with a fleet of minesweepers riding ahead, but this threat, if it was a threat, was not great enough to divert even one ship from the Allied force.

The six-story apartment house assessed at $215,000 at 109-01 Seventy-second Road, Forest Hills, L.I., has been sold for a client by Paul P. Zinner, broker, to the Forest Hills Management Corporation for investment. The house occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet and accommodates forty-six families. There are also six stores.

Charles J. Royle, president of the Hudson Wire Company of Ossining, purchased from the assignee of William L. Neissel the nine and one-half acre estate on Somerstown Road, Ossining, N.Y. On the property are a two-story residence, guest house, three-car garage and other buildings. John Yates was the broker in the sale and M. Harworth Hendler represented the seller as attorney.
VATICAN CITY, June 7 -- The Holy See officially announced today its determination to maintain its neutrality, "whoever may be the military authorities actually having control of the city of Rome."

A book might be written about a photograph published on the front page of this newspaper yesterday. The photograph showed the Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Forces talking to a paratrooper. Presumably this man, one of a group with blackened faces, their helmets grotesquely camouflaged, their shoulders bent under the loads they were about to carry on their journey into the enemy's country, was a private soldier.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 7 (AP) -- The State Council of Insured Savings Associations said today it would seek legislation designed to save small home owners "as much as $50,000,000 in needless legal, title search and recording fees in the post-war reconstruction period."

Is Greece also an invasion point? So radio reports of obscure derivation try to make us believe, either to discover our intentions or, as has happened frequently of late, to turn the spotlight on operations the Allied High Command is not ready to make public.

NAPLES, June 7 (AP) -- The Mediterranean Air Force flew more than 2,300 sorties yesterday in operations that carried east to the oil refineries at Ploesti, Rumania, which were attacked by heavy bombers along with Rumanian and Yugoslav rail points.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Bullish enthusiasm in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here vanished overnight and scattered selling at the opening of business today disclosed a lack of support. Wheat and rye broke around 3 cents a bushel, and oats, nearly 2 cents, with liquidation developing on the way down and the finish was about the bottom.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A demand for "immediate cancellation" of all conventions and meetings not connected with the war program and an end to non-essential civilian travel was coupled with a warning by the Office of Defense Transportation today that civilians may soon expect to get "bumped" from reserved seats and other space to make room for war casualties and other military passengers.

Forty-nine wounded, repatriated soldiers of the United States, veterans of the campaigns of North Africa, Sicily and Italy, weathered the ordeal of a press interview yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of Halloran General Hospital, Willowbrook, S.I.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -- Sgt. Vic Ghezzi of the United States Army and Fred Woodruff of Atlantic City, N.J., tied for top honors with Walter Work of Eaglesmere, Pa., and Dr. William Candy of the home club in the pro-amateur handicap division of The Philadelphia Inquirer's $17,500 war bond invitation golf tournament at the Torresdale-Frankford Country Club today.

Reports that plans are afoot to revise the Vinson directive to permit more than the 2 per cent net profit, even if successful, will not operate to increase supplies of cost-of-living apparel, Oscar J. Groebl of Levi Strauss Co., chairman of the International Association of Garment Manufacturers, declared yesterday.

When "Take a Bow" comes to the Broadhurst next Thursday night, Jay C. Flippen will be missing from the roster of the variety bill. He asked producer Lou Walters for his release and it will take effect at the conclusion of the Philadelphia tryout on Saturday night.

ROME, June 7 -- Bruno Buozzi, noted as an Italian Socialist labor leader for the last forty years, was brutally murdered by German Elite Guard men along with thirteen other prisoners last Saturday morning, it was learned today. Peasants found the bodies seven miles from Rome on the Via Cassia.
PITTSBURGH, June 7 (AP) -- Vince DiMaggio singled with the bases full in the eighth inning, scoring two men, to give the Pirates a 4-2 victory over the Reds tonight.
Completion of two deals involving large apartment buildings on Riverside Drive featured the news of West Side realty activity yesterday.

ALBANY, June 7 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the Nassau County Board of Supervisors could not provide for the election of two Assemblymen at large in the new Second Senate District (Long Beach and the town of Hempstead) as was directed by Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley when he declared the division of the town into two Assembly Districts was unconstitutional.

In a joint statement addressed to the American people Secretary of the Navy Forrestal and Under-Secretary of War Patterson emphasize the importance to the troops of our invasion armies of keeping the wheels of American industry turning at top speed. "Our behavior on the home front at this critical hour," their statement says, "will determine whether we can look those boys squarely in the eye when they come home again."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 7 -- To help cities, towns and villages plan for their post-war housing needs, a community development service has been established by the State Division of Housing, Ira S. Robbins, acting State Commissioner of Housing, said today in a speech at the annual conference of Mayors and other municipal officials.

LONDON, June 7 (UP) -- Some of the first American assault troops storming the French beaches went down under a withering German crossfire, but more and more men poured out of the invasion landing craft, a witness said today.

Yesterday originally was an open date for the Dodgers and they would have done much better to have left it open. But they filled in the date by scheduling a postponed game with Freddy Fitzsimmons' Philly-Blue Jays and the results were far from pleasing, either to the Brooks or the crowd of 4,434 fans at Ebbets Field, the Flock bowing, 6 -- 5.

BOSTON, June 7 -- The convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers today indorsed President Roosevelt for a fourth term and called upon the President "to accept the call of the common people of America for re-election."

Establishment in this country of a "cartel commission" with authority to determine the merits of every international business arrangement is suggested as a "practical method to eliminate the evils of the cartel system" of world trade by The Index, quarterly publication of the New York Trust Company.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Celon, June 7 (U.P.) -- Fleeing so rapidly that pursuing Imperial patrols were unable to keep contact with them, shattered Japanese forces are in general retreat east of Kohima, the Southeast Asia Command announced today in a communique that indicated an imminent collapse of the entire enemy position at the northern end of the Manipur front.

ABOARD U.S.S. BARNETT, Transport Area, June 6 (Delayed) -- Lieut. (j.g.) Abraham Condiotti of Brooklyn commanded the first wave of small assault boats that set troops ashore in this section of Europe today.

So much of the meat on the market nowadays is tough that a product known as a "meat tenderizer" should receive a warm reception. This is a pale yellow liquid derived from the papaya, a tropical fruit that grows in Florida. When applied to beef, lamb, veal, pork or poultry the solution softens the connective tissue and muscle fibers with a "tenderizing" effect.

Shoe manufacturers may be expected to make every effort to cooperate with the War Production Board in its request that sole leather be given an oil treatment as a conservation measure. The National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association stated yesterday that it will inaugurate a program seeking to have manufacturers treat every possible sole with oil to add to its useful life.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Robert H. Jackson and William O. Douglas, associate justices of the Supreme Court, have sternly opposed recent suggestions that they be regarded as possibilities for the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination and have said that they would do everything possible to stifle such moves, close friends said today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7 -- Assurance that increased food demands arising from the invasion of Europe and the liberation of conquered peoples would not seriously reduce the civilian supply was given here today by Lee Marshall of Washington, director of distribution of the War Food Administration.

Central Park has become an increasingly necessary refuge to New Yorkers and visitors. The park is very rich in trees, shrubs and flowers of unusual varieties, but people who would like to identify these, in order to appreciate them better, have no adequate mean of so doing.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $2,293,547,652 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on May 31 was $34.14, compared with $32.59 at the end of April.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -- William W. Bodine, chairman of the United Gas Improvement Company, said today that U.G.I. had discarded plans for its complete liquidation as a necessary step in compliance with geographic integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Arthur E. Lehrfeld, disbarred attorney of 6717 Twenty-first Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday tearfully thanked Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions when he received a suspended sentence after pleading guilty to the purchase of seventy-five stolen watches from an ex-convict client last October.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The seditious conspiracy trial took a new slant today as defense attorneys began to clash with each other over questions put by some of them to Peter Gissibl, former head of the Chicago unit of the German-American Bund and chief Government witness so far put on the stand.

Questions about the jobs and wages of working wives, husbands and children of employes of the city's unified transit lines will be stricken from the questionnaire prepared by Investigation Commissioner Edgar Bromberger for submission to the 35,000 employes of the Board of Transportation, it was disclosed yesterday.

James Pipes, author of "Ziba," a collection of Negro folk tales overheard in a Louisiana country store, and published in November, 1943, by the University of Oklahoma Press, has received a Julius Rosenwald Fellowship. The award will aid Mr. Pipes in working on a study of the Negro as a workman.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Maj. Gen. Henry J.F. Miller, former commanding general of the United States Ninth Air Force Service Command in Britain, has been demoted to his permanent rank of lieutenant colonel for having talked carelessly in public about the invasion date, the War Department announced today.

On motion of Assistant District Attorney James A. McGough, County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz dismissed in Brooklyn yesterday a burglary indictment against Patrolman Donald Danielson, 39 years old, of 53 Hale Avenue, Brooklyn.

ALGIERS, June 7 -- The French Committee of National Liberation, or "Provisional Government," studied French political relations with the Allies today as they were reflected in messages from General de Gaulle and a report by Pierre Mendes-France on his negotiations in Washington.

One of the most serious problems facing the electric power and light industry in the post-war period will be utilization of the excess generating capacity installed in the last four years for war production, Kinsey M. Robinson, president of the Washington Water Power Company, declared yesterday at the closing session of the annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Mayor La Guardia spoke yesterday at the dedication and formal opening of the Army's Bronx Area Station Hospital at Mount Eden Avenue and the Grand Concourse. He urged civilian volunteers now helping wounded and disabled service men not to lose interest after the war, because tens of thousands of the men would be under Government care for a long time and their lives could be made happier by the volunteers.
LONDON, June 7 -- It was tough. It was really brutal. I'm speaking now about the invasion of France as I saw it and as everybody else described it.

The War Manpower Commission has just issued another of its autocratic pronouncements by means of which it hopes to control and direct all male workers over 17 years of age; and which it expects to try to put into effect on July 1 next. This appears to be just one more futile effort.

A whale problem was troubling various police, park and conservation authorities in Flushing, Queens, last night. An aquatic monster, identified as a 20-foot whale, passed under the Long Island Railroad drawbridge over Flushing Creek and kept on, being stopped from visiting the scene of the former World's Fair only by the tidal lock gates.
LONDON, June 7 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Net profit of the Childs Company for April was $119,539, comparing with $94,189 in the same month last year, according to an unaudited comparative statement of operations of the company and its subsidiaries presented yesterday in Federal Court by John F.X. Finn, trustee of the company.

ON BOARD A BRITISH WARSHIP, Off the French Invasion Beaches, June 7 -- For four and a half hours this afternoon Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, with Admiral Sir Bertram Home Ramsay, Allied naval commander, cruised to and fro off the invasion beaches and held a series of conferences with his operational commanders.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Contending that Thomas E. Dewey "is in complete ignorance of the major problems that face the nation," Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee, today called upon the New York Governor to make known his views on full post-war employment.

Money in circulation now amounts to more than $22,000,000,000, of which a large percentage constitutes an inflationary threat, if not now, certainly in the postwar era. One of the primary objects of the Fifth War Loan Drive that will start next week, will be to raise at least $6,000,000,000 from individuals, compared with the over-all total of $16,000,000,000 for the drive.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 7 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Pradley -- the "Doughboys' General" who has killed more Germans than any other American general officer -- commands all the American ground forces in the invasion of France, it was announced today.

Arturo Toscanini has objected to sharing with Leopold Stokowski the leadership of the NBC Symphony, with the result that the National Broadcasting Company has not renewed Mr. Stokowski's contract for next season, it became known yesterday.

Protesting a recent ruling by the Office of Price Administration that made no allocation of ration points for prime red meats used in treating persons with gastro-intestinal diseases, the National Gastroenterological Association in convention at the Hotel Astor adopted a resolution yesterday petitioning the OPA to allow red points for such cases.

CHUNGKING, China, June 7 (AP) -- In continued attacks all along the Salween front the Chinese have succeeded in forcing the Japanese to evacuate Chiaotou, and have reached Chiangtso and Watien in their drive toward the Shweli River valley, a Chinese communique said today.
The latest in Army rations is the eight-course meal that fits into a paratrooper's vest pocket.

John J. Hall, formerly vice president, general sales, the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation, has been appointed vice president and general manager of sales of the Richmond Radiator Company with headquarters at 535 Fifth Avenue.
ABOARD ADMIRAL KIRK'S FLAGSHIP, in the Bay of the Seine, June 6 (Delayed) -- The Allied assault upon Adolf Hitler's Festung Europa was made at numerous beaches between Cherbourg and Havre.

The national society, Daughters of the Revolution, closed its convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday after adopting thirteen resolutions. Among them were demands for an early trial for Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel and Maj. Gen. Waiter C. Short, for legislation permitting salary increases for white-collar workers living on subsistence pay, and for expanded military and naval colleges.

President Roosevelt's War Relief Board has allotted $2,250,000 to Polish War Relief activities for fourteen different related projects during the first nine months of this year, the Rev. Dr. Francis Szubinski reported yesterday during a tea given by Mme. Sylwyn Strakacz, wife of the Polish Consul General in this city, at her home.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Among 1,328 Army and 141 Navy casualties announced today by the War and Navy Departments were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

A UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE FIGHTER-BOMBER BASE, June 7 (U.P.) -- Smoke and flames rose 1,500 feet into the air along the invasion coast of France. An ancient French chateau was a roaring furnace. Allied tanks rumbled into a flaming town.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Less than seven hours before expiration of the statute of limitation on courts-martial for Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel and Maj. Gen. Walter C. Short, who were in command at Pearl Harbor, Senate and House differences were compromised and legislation was sent to the White House today to extend the limitation six months.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Arthur R. Treanor, War Production Board Printing and Publishing Division director, told the newspaper industry advisory committee today that permitted consumption quotas of newsprint during the third quarter will continue on the present sliding scale of cuts, barring unforeseen contingencies.

Advertisers object to forced combinations and "plus" charges on split runs, Paul West, president of the Association of National Advertisers, indicated yesterday in an address before the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association at the closing session of its annual conference at the Hotel Commodore.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 -- Some 360 students have passed through the dress design classes of the St. Louis Fine Arts School of Washington University. Sixty have found their way into industry and twenty-five are designing in the junior market of St. Louis.

Asserting that dress manufacturers have been advised of "wholesale cuts" in their cloth allocations due to recent increases in export quotas, Erwin Feldman, director-counsel of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, called yesterday for a Congressional investigation to determine why the decision to increase export quotas was reached.
LONDON, June 7 -- The stock market here reacted favorably today to good invasioin news and with little stock being offered prices moved mainly in favor of holders.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, June 8 (AP) -- A high spot in yesterday's Allied air operations came in a bombing attack on Caen road junctions by 250 to 500 American Flying Fortresses and Liberators to block German reinforcements.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Congress sent to the White House today a bill cutting the night club tax from 30 to 20 per cent and providing, in a reversal of a Senate decision, that men and women in the armed services will have to pay it as civilians do.

The well-known propensity of fishermen to keep the location of where that big one that didn't get away came from is illustrated by Bob Holmes of the Putnam County Fish and Game Association, who says he has seen several brown trout that would tip the scales from 4 to 6 1/2 pounds.

Fifteen-year-old Thomas Bogan was in Bellevue Hospital yesterday, possibly with fractures of both feet and brain injuries, after he had attempted to escape last Tuesday night from the Youth House, 331 East Twelfth Street, by dropping thirty feet from the roof of that building to an adjoining tenement house.

CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE HEADQUARTERS, June 7 -- All sections of the Burma Road hitherto available to Japanese transportation are now cut. Encountering little opposition and maintaining remarkable speed, the Chinese troops who crossed the Salween River a week ago arrived within two miles of Lungling yesterday and cut the road to the north and south.

With unsold butter stocks in this city showing a slight increase over last week, the War Food Administration announced yesterday that the civilian supply was sufficient to meet all rationed demands in the metropolitan area. According to the WFA regional office, unsold butter held by local wholesalers and jobbers amounted to 2,471,472 pounds, compared with 2,363,419 pounds a week ago and 1,322,748 pounds a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Extremely fluid battle lines will prevail in the newly opened French invasion sector during the early phase of the fighting, military observers here believe. A "solid line" defense by the Germans is not expected until a decision has been forced in the early critical stage of the fighting.

LONDON, June 7 -- On Monday evening, just before the signal for the start of the invasion was given, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told correspondents at advanced headquarters that there was complete agreement between him and the French Committee of National Liberation on the military level.

The world now will begin to realize that the Catholic Church, through its international character, will make many contributions to world peace, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham Univesity, told 2,500 persons who attended the ninety-ninth commencement exercises of the university in its gymnasium yesterday.

FREDERICK, Md., June 7 -- Definite steps have been taken to help rebuild the schools of Europe as soon as the liberating armies have freed its peoples, Dr. Ralph E. Turner, assistant chief of the State Department's Education Division, who returned from England last week, reported today to the International Education Assembly, meeting on the Hood College campus.

THE original rules in any sport seem startlingly quaint in the light of present-day codes. That is true of all of them. For instance, baseball began with only one base, a holdover from the famed "one old cat" days, and also ordained that a ball caught on one bounce was out. Basketball permitted as many as forty men on a side, while football once provided, believe it or not, that carrying the ball was illegal.

LONDON, Thursday, June 8 -- Allied air forces laid down a steady curtain of fire yesterday in a great arc extending an average of fifty miles inland from the zones where our troops are battling in France, in an all-out aerial offensive to block German attempts to counterattack in strength.

LONDON, June 7 -- In the midst of the battle for the liberation of Europe the voice of still another small nation was raised today to ask for adequate representation in any future world peace organization. The spokesman was King Haakon of Norway, who told the Foreign Press Association:
PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended today the effectiveness of an order issued on
KANDY, Ceylon, June 7 (AP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, June 8 -- American invasion forces captured the Mokmer airdrome on Biak Island yesterday, eleven days after their landing on the Japanese stronghold in Netherland New Guinea, to give the Allies an airfield within easy bombing distance of the southern Philippine Islands, less than 900 miles away, it was announced today.

With the tension of D-day broken, the stock market began yesterday to adapt itself to a new pattern, the form of which is expected to be dictated by developments in the European theatre of war. In an effort to develop such a pattern, the list encountered some obstacles, not the least of which was the inability of recent buyers to decide on a definite program.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Official concern over delays which are charged both to Capitol Hill and the War Production Board in implementing the Baruch-Hancock report of Feb. 15 on War and Post-War Adjustment Policies has been intensified with the progress of the invasion.

William Thorner, singing teacher of opera stars and film actresses, and once secretary of the great tenor Jean de Reske, was held in $500 bail yesterday in Jefferson Market Court by Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate, charged with maintaining a gambling establishment in his apartment at 152 West Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, June 7 -- The end of the strange episode of Portuguese wolfram in this war, with Lisbon agreeing to send Germany no more of the metal, which is invaluable for the hardening of steels in armaments, was announced to Parliament today by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.

It wasn't hard luck Alva Javery ran up against last night at the Polo Grounds. Rather, it was a barrage of long-distance wallops that brought to the "hard luck" hurler his eighth setback as the Giants romped to a 6-2 victory over the Braves.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Export markets for the capital goods which this country is now equipped to turn out must be found if the nation is to enjoy post-war prosperity, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told the House Post-War Planning Committee today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The order regulating allocation of chemicals and related products was revised by the War Production Board today to establish a new export procedure. The agency also announced that appendices listing materials subject to the order would be reprinted each month to show additions and, at the same time, to save paper work involved in periodic reprints of the entire order.

The eyes of the world remain riveted on the beaches of Normandy, where one of the decisive battles of history is now getting under way. Both sides agree that grim and bitter fighting is raging along a still intermittent and confused, but steadily expanding, front ranging for most of the 100-mile distance between the ports of Le Havre and Cherbourg, with the Caen-Bayeux area as the center of the struggle.

During eight months as a Hitler prisoner of war I have seen Germany from inside and outside her prison camps, have traveled through fortified areas and over her railways from the Brenner Pass to the Polish Corridor, and am convinced that she still expects to win the war.

LONDON, June 7 -- An atmosphere of sober fatalism similar to that of the days just before the fall of France gripped this capital today as the battle for our toehold on the Continent of Europe raged across the Channel.

William D. Kennedy, manager of the big Wright Aeronautical Corporation plant at Lockland, near Cincinnati, Ohio, announced last night that strikers who have hampered production for three days must return to their jobs by tomorrow or be discharged, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Five women's organizations, all of which have been protesting against quality deterioration of clothing and disappearance of low-end items from the market, made a last-minute move today to get a five-agency low-cost clothing program included in legislation extending the Office of Price Administration.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -- Employment of women in the aircraft and shipbuilding industries of California is continuing to taper off. John F. Dalton, chief of the State Division of Labor Statistics and Law Enforcement, reported today.
Sales of two properties in the Bronx for improvement after the war were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- President Roosevelt conferred with Prime Minister Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of Poland today and was his host tonight at a White House dinner attended by Cabinet and diplomatic officers, military and Congressional leaders.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The United States has started rebuilding its European diplomatic service and will soon appoint new Ambassadors to Norway, the Netherlands, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Belgium.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- The board of directors of the Radio Manufacturers Association in a brief meeting elected Raymond C. Cosgrove of Cincinnati president here today. The election brought to a close the twentieth annual membership meeting and third war production conference of the association.

Eastman, Dillon Co. head a syndicate which today will offer $13,000,000 of the Sunray Oil Corporation's 3 3/4 per cent debentures due in 1959 at 103 and interest, priced to yield 3.50 per cent.
