The financing is to provide funds for consummation of Sunray Oil's merger with the Darby Petroleum Company of Tulsa, Okla., which has been approved at special meetings of stockholders, and to retire mortgage debt.

LONDON, Thursday, June 8 (U.P.) -- Red Army forces have killed 10,000 Germans in eight days of fighting north and northwest of the ancient Rumanian city of Jassy, Moscow announced last night as the Allied world waited for the start of an expected Soviet summer offensive timed with Allied operations in western Europe.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- An optimistic picture of the nation's food supply for the coming year, barring unforeseen military contingencies, manpower and container shortages, was painted by speakers here today at the closing session of the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers.

The speed with which war veterans become acclimated to working again in civilian life will depend on the ability of office managers to do a good job of placement, new training and retraining, E.A. Rule, office manager of the Ohio Farm Bureau, Columbus, Ohio, warned 1,400 office managers and personnel directors attending the final day's sessions of the twenty-fifth anniversary conference of the National Office Management Association yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

One very necessary thing today, when people are so much concerned with other nations and other lands, is to keep in mind that the others are other. They are themselves and not ourselves; as, for instance, Americans and Russians in the matter of whistling in the theatre.
The following report comes from an American Red Cross worker in Italy:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 7 -- Wounded British soldiers who returned to an English port today after having taken part in the initial assault on the French beaches yesterday morning reported that the worst obstacles that they had encountered were mortar fire and snipers' bullets.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 (AP) -- A primary post-war concern of bankers will be problems arising from a "tremendous" Government debt, J. Cameron Thomson, president of the Northwest Bancorporation of Minneapolis, told the American Institute of Banking today.

ATLANTA, June 7 (AP) -- Georgia's Democratic party leaders reaffirmed the principle of white supremacy today, and directed county electoral officials to deny Negroes the voting privilege in the State's July 4 Democratic primary.

The torpedoing of an American Liberty ship returning to this country from India with a cargo of tea and jute by a Japanese submarine and its subsequent machine-gunning of the crew who had taken to the vessel's three remaining lifeboats was told yesterday by Arthur McBowman, 19-year-old ordinary seaman, in the National Maritime Union's Headquarters, 346 West Seventeenth Street.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 7 -- Tribute to the American and British navies for maintaining control of the seas, thereby making possible the breaching of Hitler's Atlantic wall was paid today by Secretary James V. Forrestal, at the 104th commencement.

Criticism of Mayor La Guardia for completely dominating the Board of Education and for not meeting the financial problems of the city's school system realistically was made last night by Irwin Steingut, minority leader of the Assembly, at a meeting of 300 teachers sponsored by the New York Teachers Guild.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 7 (AP) -- Members of the American Nurses' Association attending the national biennial nursing convention, voted approval today of expansion of the Blue Cross and other health-insurance plans to provide nursing care in the home.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., won yesterday the award of $3,000,000 of Kanawha County, W. Va., airport bonds on a bid of 100.08 for a combination of coupons, making the net interest cost to the issuer 1.4 per cent.
The regular weekly collection of waste paper throughout the city by Department of Sanitation trucks amounted to 413 tons yesterday, just seven tons less than was picked up on the previous Wednesday.

The Bankers Trust Company has sold to an investing client of Max Ornstein the sixteen-story loft building at 1176-78 Sixth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-sixth Street, for cash over a mortgage of $220,000. It was sold for an indicated consideration of $355,000 and is assessed at $450,000.
CHUNGKING, China, June 7 (AP) -- A communique:

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 -- Edward H. Cashion, counsel to the corporation finance division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, warned today that when-issued trading over the counter in the new common stock of the Laclede Gas Light Company prior to enforcement of its voluntary plan for compliance with the Public Utility Holding Company Act would violate Section 5 of the Securities Act of 1933.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Representative Rankin of Mississippi told the House today he hoped that American soldiers invading Europe "aren't reading the daily papers of America or they'll find Sidney Hillman and his racketeering CIO gang are shaking them down to destroy the Government they're fighting for."

WITH ALLIED EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, 1 P.M., June 7 -- Our forward troops, rested after snatching a few hours sleep last night, are moving steadily forward against undiminished German resistance. We are on the outskirts of Caen and are joining up with the Canadians.

ALGIERS, June 7 (AP) -- Before thousands of his fellow-troopers assembled in Saint Eugene Stadium, 32-year-old Corp. James Slaton of R.F.D. No. 1, Laurel, Miss., today received American and Russian decorations to add to his British military medal.

JACKSON, Miss., June 7 -- The anti-New Deal "rebellion" in Southern Democracy flared anew today when the Mississippi State democratic convention issued a virtual ultimatum to the party on the questions of white supremacy, States' rights, the poll tax and restoration of the two-thirds' rule, and threatened to bolt the national convention's nominees unless their demands are met.
The single-family dwelling at 203 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Brooklyn Savings Bank to Anthony De Maio and Unily W. Batand. H. and D. Agar acted as brokers.

A dual claim, of misunderstanding of us by the British and suspicion of them by us, was raised in a speech before the Rotary International at Chicago by Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister according to a short news notice in THE TIMES of May 23. When both these insidious indictments to strife are present the time has come for the best of friends to look to security of their bonds.

"Since You Went Away," David O. Selznick's first production since the release of "Rebecca," in March, 1940, has been booked for its local premiere at the Capitol following the run of "Two Girls and a Sailor," which is slated to open next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Herbert H. Lehman, Director General of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, today assured the people of Western Europe in a short-wave broadcast that relief would follow the invasion armies.

Continued favorable weather in the Cotton Belt and reports of heavier repossessions from loan stocks in the South led yesterday a freer supply of cotton futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices were 1 to 8 points net lower than on Tuesday after having established new highs for the life of the contracts early in the session.

Valentim F. Boucas and Romero Estellita, representatives of the Brazilian Government, and interested Wall Street bankers formally signed Brazil's debt-adjustment plan with respect to $286,065,645 of dollar bonds yesterday morning in the law offices of Shearman Sterling, 55 Wall Street.

MOSCOW, June 7 (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. M Galaktianoff, writing in the official newspaper Pravda today, analyzed for Russian readers the immense difficulties and perils of the Allies' sea-borne operation across the English Channel and said the Russian people "are watching with sympathy the tense fight on the north coast of France."

LONDON, June 7 -- The second phase of the Allies' gigantic airborne invasion of Europe was successfully carried out late last night and early today when a fifty-mile-long train of transport planes and gliders crossed the Channel to reinforce and resupply the troops put down in the Cherbourg peninsula area early in the morning of D-day.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The House revolted today against its Rules Committee which, it was asserted, had become enabled through a coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats to override the prerogatives of legislative committees and dictate what legislation could or could not go to the floor for consideration and vote.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, June 8 (UP) -- A communique:

Average citizens may yearn for a chicken in every pot, but to Joseph Asaro, 35 years old, of 6121 Twentieth Avenue, Brooklyn, even the idea of "Chicken Every Sunday" is not so desirable. Yesterday in Flatbush Court Magistrate James A. Blanchfield gave him thirteen days in which to eat or otherwise dispose of the twelve fowls that the Health Department contends he houses on the roof of his home in violation of the Sanitary Code.

Sgt. Vic Ghezzi, 1941 P.G.A. champion, and Ensign Neil White, former Western and Southern amateur champion, are among the latest players to send in their entries for the Red Cross open golf tournament to be held at the Wykagyl Country Club, New Rochelle, next week.

Organization of the Second Service Command civilian advisory committee to aid recruiting of the Women's Army Corps and appointment of Mrs. Oswald B. Lord of New York as chairman, were announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. T.A. Terry, commanding general, Second Service Command.

With newsprint shortages still causing marked reductions in advertising space, total advertising linage in all New York daily newspapers for the first five months of 1944 amounting to 40,774,771 agate lines showed a loss of 4.4 per cent from the corresponding period of a year ago, according to figures compiled from Media Records.

Millions of New Yorkers, although their thoughts kept roving to their sons, husbands, brothers and friends fighting on the beaches of Normandy in France, went about their daily activities normally yesterday, but thousands among them offered their blood to the Red Cross or visited churches to pray for the success of the Allied attempt to liberate Europe.

Confectionery sales climbed last year to $575,000,000 from $490,000,000 in 1942, H.B. McCoy, director of the division of industrial economy of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, told the members of the National Confectioners Association yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MOSCOW, June 7 -- Joyous Russians today sought every available bit of detailed information concerning Allied progress on the beachheads of northern France -- a blow at Adolf Hitler that most of them think will speedily seal his fate.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- In the recent decision on the insurance company case, four justices (Black, Douglas, Murphy and Rutledge) concurred in rendering the decision; three justices dissented (Chief Justice Stone, Frankfurter and Jackson) and two justices did not sit (Roberts and Reed).

The Hoboken Bank for Savings sold the three four-story brick flats at 89-93 Washington Street, corner of Newark Street, Hoboken, N.J., to the Winston Realty Company of Hoboken. The parcel is 75 by 100 feet and is assessed at $80,000.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Treasury issued a new regulation today designed to prevent Axis vandals from cashing in on objects of art looted from occupied countries.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 7 (AP) -- The American Ninth Air Force announced thirty-three hours after H-hour that its Troop Carrier Command had completed its first assignment. The sky trains returned to Britain this morning after almost a day and a half of constant movement across the Channel.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- By a vote of 47 to 27 the Senate amended the Emergency Price Control Act today to permit merchants and others sued for violating price regulations to plead as a defense that the violation was "neither willful nor the result of failure to take practicable precautions against the occurrence of the violation."
Lehman Brothers announced yesterday the completion of their offering of 113,333 shares of National Airlines, Inc., common stock.
BOSTON, June 7 (AP) -- Miss Jean Beattie's Aboyne paced a field of seven today as he won the $2,000 feature at Suffolk Downs.
All was confusion for a time yesterday when racing was resumed at Aqueduct after a one-day interlude out of deference to D-day.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations will hold a convention here, June 16-17, to adopt a formal platform for this year, Sidney Hillman, the chairman, said here today.

In a colorful commencement ceremony in which academic gowns and military uniforms were mingled, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, made a strong plea yesterday for a future world order in which the fundamental rights and priviledges of the individual and the advance of mankind toward fuller and better lives would predominate.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- While the armed forces of the United Nations and their commanders, military and civilian, are largely concentrated on the invasion of France, discussion continues of the proposed world peace structure which is one of the great objectives of victory.

ROME, Thursday, June 8 -- Fifth Army troops have captured the port of Civitavecchia, forty miles northwest of Rome on the Italian west coast, after a rapid advance from the Eternal City, Allied headquarters announced today.

LONDON, June 7 -- In the fifteenth honors list of his reign King George VI today celebrated his official birthday by bestowing honors on persons in all walks of life, from the highest to the lowest. For services rendered to their King and country they received decorations ranging from an earldom to the British Empire Medal, awarded to service men and women.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7 -- The England General Hospital here became a regular stop on the Army's new air shuttle transportation system for sick and wounded soldiers with the arrival yesterday of ninety-three patients and the departure of nineteen, it was announced today.

Declaring that the problem of treating mental diseases had outgrown local communities, Dr. Israel Strauss, psychiatrist, called last night for a Federal appropriation of $1,000,000,000 to subsidize nonprofit, nonsectarian institutions handling this phase of rehabilitation.

LONDON, June 7 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans were reported today to have launched violent counterattacks on all sectors, capturing a number of enemy positions. At the same time, a German High Command broadcast communique claimed that Marshal Tito's forces suffered 26,000 losses in killed and captured during May.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Senator David I. Walsh, chairman of the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs, confirmed to members of his committee today the release of a light cruiser of the United States Navy to Russia, which has been a subject of Congressional discussion and comment.

A health program giving particular attention to possible tubercular conditions has been initiated at Cathedral High School for Girls, Fiftieth Street and Lexington Avenue, under the direction of Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, it was announced yesterday by Mgr. William A. Scully, secretary for education in the Catholic Archdiocese of New York.
BOSTON, June 7 -- Regrettable as it is to report, the Yankees' invasion of the New England sector of the American League met with complete failure on this crisp June afternoon.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., June 8 -After electing the Rev. Dr. Fred P. Corson, president of Dickinson College, Carlisle, Pa., to be a Bishop of the Methodist Church, the Northeastern Jurisdictional Conference ran into difficulty today in choosing two other Bishops to fill vacancies in the Eastern seaboard area.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -Universal has named Louise Allbritton and Turhan Bey for the co-starring leads in "A Night in Paradi" a screen fantasy to be based on 'Peacock Feather." a novel by George Hellman. The screen play is being written by Emmett Lavery for production by Walter Wanger.

Eighty-five thousand persons from 300 churches -- most of them children -- marched through the streets of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon in the 115th annual anniversary parade of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union. Sixteen thousand of the paraders were proxy representatives of those in the armed services.

NEWARK, N.J., June 8 (AP) -- The Newark Bears hung up a thirteen-inning victory over the Toronto Leafs tonight, 5 -- 4, after being blanked in the seven-inning twilight opener, for the seventh time this season, 6 -- 0. Alex Mustaikis administered the whitewash.

MEXICO CITY, June 8 -- The miners and metallurgical syndicates today began a general strike that affected directly 70,000 workers in 105 companies and tied up all output of metals. Eighty per cent of the mines' production comes from American and British owned companies.

CHUNGKING, China, June 8 (AP) -- Chinese troops have occupied part of the Burma road stronghold of Lungling, second most important Japanese base in Yunnan Province, and have made advances against the principal enemy base of Tengyueh, the Chinese command announced tonight.

The correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Algiers wrote that the French Committee of National Liberation, headed by Gen. Charles de Gaulle, had decided to call itself the "Provisional Government of the French Republic." This is a misnomer. Although the Government of the French Republic was forced out by Hitler, it is still the Government de facto.

Exceptionally bright kindergarten children who are less than 6 years old will be admitted to the first grade of the city's public schools in September, it was announced yesterday by Associate Superintendent Regina C.M. Burke, in charge of elementary schools.

" Morale boosters" is an apt name for the decorative housecoats that abound in the stores these days. Always feminine, made for coolness and comfort, they are a pleasant diversion from workaday clothes. Gone are the trailing tea-gowns of the past.
DETROIT, June 8 (AP) -- Early appointment of Charles E. Sorensen as president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., is expected.

Five endowment associations composed exclusively of New York City firemen are being liquidated by the State Insurance Department under court orders finding each of them insolvent, it was disclosed yesterday. About half the members of the department are affected by the dissolutions.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets remained unchanged at 103.9 per cent of the 1926 average for the week ended June 3. Average prices for agricultural commodities rose slightly as a result of higher quotations for eggs, new potatoes and onions in Eastern markets.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- In a move which would curtail the publicity privileges of the Yugoslav general, Draja Mikhailovitch, in this country, the Justice Department has asked that the Yugoslav public relations agent in New York be removed from the United Nations preferred list.
NAPLES, June 8 (UP) -- A communique:
PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP) -- The Senators tallied two runs in the eleventh inning for a 7-to-5 victory over the Athletics in their series opener today after a see-saw struggle.

Lewis Mumford's "The Condition of Man" and Leland Stowe's "They Shall Not Sleep" have been selected by the Walt Whitman Society of America for book awards for the period of June, 1943, to June, 1944. Officers of the society for 1944 are Maurice Maeterlinck, Thomas Mann, Will Durant, Robert Nathan, William Rose Benet, Henry Seidel Canby, Fred R. Jones and H.V. Kaltenborn.
CHUNGKING, China, June 8 (AP) -- A communique:
CHUNGKING, China, June 8 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

BOSTON, June 8 (AP) -- About 150 irate bettors stormed Suffolk Downs race track and removed the starting gate today after the racing stewards had disqualified the Oak Tree Stable's Bayport from first position and placed him third for cutting in on Seven Hills, owned by Jim Carr, at the start of the seventh race.

In an effort to adjust itself to the problems posed by the invasion and properly to evaluate post-war prospects, the stock market yesterday went through a session of experimental trading. Weighted down by increasing softness in the rails and limited activity in the prime industrial sections, the share list fell back and closed moderately lower.
CHUNGKING, June 8 (UP) -- On the central China front the Japanese have driven to within less than four miles of the key Hunan Province stronghold of Changsha, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The largest number of women ever employed at one time in the Federal service, 1,010,315 as of April 30, was reported today by the Civil Service Commission. The number of men in the Federal service was 1,662,086.

SHREVEPORT, La., June 8 -- Anti-fourth term Democrats from Mississippi, Arkansas and Texas will meet in Shreveport tomorrow to discuss with Louisiana Democrats action to be taken in the presidential election.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- The University of Chicago's board of trustees moved, today to heal a breach which has developed between the university senate, the policymaking body of the faculty, and the university president, Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins.

The Fifth War Bond campaign will get a head start here at noon today with an elaborate military show in Times Square, designed as a tribute to Army infantrymen. The drive starts officially on Monday. There will be seventy pieces of Army motorized equipment, a battalion of 300 soldiers with full overseas packs, an eighty-piece military band from the 397th Infantry and a delegation of sixty combat war heroes participating in the demonstration.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 8 (AP) -- Communique 5:
Purchases of sites for improvement with apartment houses after the war featured realty deals reported yesterday in Manhattan.

Opportunity after opportunity beckoned the Giants in their clash with the Braves at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Mel Ott's band of athletes blithely ignored these summons when they first appeared, but the beckonings became so urgent that the Giants at length decided to heed them, and in so doing they contrived to win the game, 6 to 4, to give their ace right-hander, Bill Voiselle, his sixth victory of the season.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- The local corn-hog ratio for last week was announced today by the War Food Administration as 11.2, compared with 11.1 the week before and 13.5 a year ago. Today's report of the livestock markets here by the WFA follows.

ROME, June 8 -- In lightning drives of as much as twenty-six miles in twenty-four hours, the Allied Fifth Army today captured Civita Castellana, thirty-two miles north of Rome, after other swift armored units had pounded through Civitavecchia, important seaport thirty-eight miles north-west of the Italian capital.

CINCINNATI, June 8 (AP) -- George Addes, secretary-treasurer of the United Automobile Workers, declared tonight that organizers of District 50 of the United Mine Workers had "agitated, aided and abetted" the four-day strike at Wright Aeronautical Corporation's plant at Lockland, near here.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Roosevelt at 62 is enjoying health that is "excellent in all respects" and better than the average for a man of his age, Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, his personal physician, said today.
Properties repossessed by banks and the Home Owners Loan Corporation figured in realty activity in the Bronx yesterday.

A Philippine plank in the platforms of the Democratic and Republican parties would be logical, timely and useful. Since 1900 the two parties have taken different views on the question, but in 1942 the islands were lost to the Japanese, a fact that must bring the parties together on this subject.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -Presi-I dent Roosevelt today "reluctantly" !accepted the resignation of Dr. W. v[. Leiserson, chairman of the i National Mediation Board and{ ;chairman of the national railwayl {labor panel, but asked him to remain until a successor was named "within a very short time."
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Friday, June 9 (AP) -- A communique:

THE two football players stared open-mouthed like a couple of rubes. On second thought, though, that condition was not too extraordinary because, in effect, there still was a bit of the hayseed protruding from their hair. The big fullback had done some terrific line-plunging that afternoon and the even bigger tackle had been a wildman on defense.

BOSTON, June 8 -- A towering home run clout that streaked through the gloaming just when it looked as though the Yankees and Red Sox would end their twilight game in a deadlock sent Joe McCarthy's bewildered champions down to another stunning defeat today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, June 9 -- British and Canadian infantrymen, supported by strong armored formations, are hacking their way forward on the left of the Allied line in Normandy, while on the right, or west, American forces, including the famous "Fighting First" Infantry Division, are gradually enlarging their beachheads.

The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday its approval of the local law passed on May 15 by the City Council, providing for denial of tax exemption to city-aided housing and redevelopment projects that discriminated against tenants or prospective tenants because of race, color or creed.

Thus far this month anticipated business in the household furniture field has not come up to expectations, it was learned yesterday in the trade. Usually a sharp increase in sales by both manufacturers and retailers is experienced in June following marriages performed or about to be performed in the traditional bridal month.

Perhaps the presence of their new shortstop, Ed Stanky, in the line-up gave the Dodgers a lift in spirit. At any rate they discovered an unexpected resiliency at Ebbets Field yesterday, bounced themselves into a double triumph over the Phils, 6 -- 3 and 8 -- 1, and jumped into fifth place, only a game behind the fourth-place Giants.

John F. O'Connell, chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority, announced yesterday that a fee of $10 has been set for issuing a permit to any one stockholder of Park Tilford, Inc., authorizing him to import eighteen cases of whisky into New York State for his personal consumption.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, June 9 (AP) -- In a sharp sea-air duel off northwestern New Guinea, an American Liberator bomber damaged a Japanese cruiser, sending two 500-pound bombs crashing off her bow, headquarters announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -The State Department, in an article published today in its weekly bulletin, declared that the Spain of Generalissimo Francisco Franco is "a dictatorship under debt to Hitler.''

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- George Meany, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, attacked the Department of Labor and its Bureau of Labor Statistics today, accusing them of subservience to politics and failure to perform their statutory task "to foster, promote and develop wage- earners' welfare."

A tentative agreement has been reached with respect to a revision of the plan for recapitalization of the General Gas and Electric Corporation under Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, now pending before the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was announced yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia's plan to enlarge the present site of the Idlewild Airport in Queens by condemnation of 1,350 acres of adjacent land, struck a snag in the Board of Estimate yesterday, when it received only eleven of the twelve votes needed for its approval.

The House is right in refusing to consider any amendments that are not germane to the renewal of the Emergency Price Control and Stabilization Acts. But nothing could be more germane than amendments clarifying the stabilization policies that the War Labor Board should follow and holding the power of that Board within explicit limits.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Treasury experts will start preparing the agenda for the coming United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference at meetings beginning about June 15, probably at Atlantic City. They will be assisted by experts of United and Associated Nations.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Government price authorities and representatives of producers and feeders of beef cattle reached no agreement today on plans designed to encourage greater marketings this summer of cattle from crowded Western ranges.

Trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet and ended with prices of futures 1 to 2 points lower on the day after holding within a 7-point range all day. Traders awaited Congressional action on the Price Control Bill.

National Carbon Company will be the first national advertiser to use as a major copy theme the newly developed campaign to publicize the role of the infantry, the War Advertising Council announced yesterday. Tying in with Infantry Day on June 15, 1,000-line inserts will appear in newspapers in fifty-nine cities.

A 600 per cent increase in registration of volunteers since D-day was reported yesterday at the Greater New York headquarters of the American Women's Voluntary Services, 11 East Fifty-eighth Street. Yet "disappointment" at the response from women was expressed by AWVS borough chairmen.
PITTSBURGH, June 8 (AP) -- The Cubs pounded four Pittsburgh pitchers for thirteen hits today to break the Pirates' four-game winning streak with a 10-to-6 triumph in the opener of their series.

The first rehabilitation center in a nation-wide veterans' retaining and guidance program will be established this month at City College by the United States Veterans' Administration, as the result of the approval of a contract for use of the school's facilities in the program by the Board of Estimate and the Board of Higher Education, it became known yesterday.
LONDON, Friday, June 9 -- The Allied air assault on enemy rear positions in France reached a new intensity yesterday and drove still deeper into the Nazis' transportation network.

Arthur C. Holden, of the architectural firm of Holden, McLaughlin Associates, was chosen as president of the New York Chapter of this American Institute of Architects at the annual luncheon meeting of the group yesterday at the Architectural League.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 8 (UP) -- A communique:

Resolutions to amend the Price Control Act, to adapt contract termination and reconversion to industry needs and for Congressional reduction of war agencies with due regard for the stability of the national economy, were adopted yesterday at the end of the National Confectioners Association's third wartime conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WITH CANADIAN FORCES, in France, June 8 (AP) -- Canadian infantry and tanks have fought their way forward in a rapid advance through wooded farmlands between Bayeux, captured by the British, and Caen, still strongly held by the Germans.

LONDON, June 8 -- The House of Commons met today and drearily discussed rural water supplies and a sewerage bill, heard complaints that fish prices were too high, and adjourned without learning anything from Prime Minister Churchill about the progress of the battle across the Channel.

Tammany designated yesterday Max Waterman for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the new Seventeenth Congressional District that comprises most of the area of the old Seventeenth Congressional District, now represented by Joseph Clark Baldwin, Republican.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (U.P.) -- The four-man Army-Navy committee which is studying the possible reorganization of national defense was established by the joint Chiefs of Staff only after an earlier committee had failed to produce an agreement in a year of discussion.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A handsome Wac recruiting office and permanent exhibit was opened by Mrs. Roosevelt today in half of the large foyer of the United States Information Center on Pennsylvania Avenue near the Treasury Building.

Fresh fruit supplies were increased this week with the arrival of the first California apricots and plums, and from the same State, the season's initial shipment of cantaloups and honeyball melons. Another "first" was cherries from the Hudson Valley -- one of the leading local areas for this fruit -- which were brought to town on Wednesday.

WITH INVASION FORCES IN FRANCE, June 7 (Delayed) -- While the Allied forces were pushing into France, confounding German defenders at almost every sector, the real heroes of this campaign were resting in the field. They were the assault engineers, the men who cleared the beach fortifications long before the Allied infantry forces swarmed from their landing craft this morning.
Jockey Don Meade, the man without a mount for the past twenty months, returned to competition yesterday at Aqueduct amid assorted cheers and jeers, with the former outnumbering the latter.

It isn't often that a magistrate contributes to the fine imposed on a person charged with a traffic violation, but Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate, in Downtown Traffic Court, broke tradition yesterday.

Saying the pressure of private business made it impossible for him to continue, James A. Farley announced yesterday his resignation as chairman of the Democratic State Committee to take effect on July 11, when a meeting of the committee will be held to elect his successor.
ST. LOUIS, June 8 (AP) -- The Indians, bunching three hits in the fifth inning, defeated the Browns, 4 to 3, tonight.

Two great phases of history are unfolding today on the new Western Front. One is the destruction of the Nazi power. We cannot come to grips with that power today on the soil of Germany itself. We must encounter it first on the soil of France, where if we could avoid it we would not shatter one ancient wall, cut down one tree or trample a single poppy under foot.
LONDON, June 8 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

When Jack Flory, 29-year-old jewelers' messenger, was arrested by detectives and charged with the theft of $10,000 in gems from his employers, Van Cleef Arpels of 744 Fifth Avenue, he presented the novel excuse that his thievery was caused by the "magic spell" cast over him by Emerson Gilbert, self-styled spiritualist, of 404 Riverside Drive.
ABOARD H.M.S. HILARY, OFF THE INVASION BEACHES, June 7 -- "How is the hunting going, sir?"

LONDON, June 8 -- Now that the British, American and Canadian troops battling to oust the Nazis from France are beginning to mingle with the civilian population o liberated territory, some of the problems resulting from the lack of a formal political agreement with any recognized government of France are coming to the fore.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- Government officials said today that there was little if any possibility of an early increase in civilian gasoline supplies despite the belief in some quarters that the black market was thriving on an "apparent surplus."

David Applegate, 21 years old, a sailor in the British merchant marine from Capetown, South Africa, wept yesterday in General Sessions as Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. sentenced him to State prison for seven and one-half to fifteen years on his guilty plea to manslaughter in the stabbing of a cripple while drink-crazed last Jan. 23 outside a bar at 852 Tenth Avenue.

Parents aren't strict enough, in the opinion of teen-age boys and girls. If they were in their parents' shoes they would keep closer tabs on their habits and their friends, judging by majority views expressed by 93,913 junior and senior high school students in a survey conducted recently in all sections of the country by the Institute of Student Opinion, a national polling organization sponsored by Scholastic Magazine.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 8 -- Although official Berlin is most anxious to put on a show of optimism, it is plain that the seriousness of the situation is fully realized, said an informed traveler upon his arrival by air tonight from the Reich capital.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 8 (UP) -- British imperial troops have captured the strategic Aradura Spur, three miles below Kohima, opening the way for a drive down the Manipur road to relieve the long-isolated garrison in Imphal, fifty-seven miles to the south, official reports disclosed today.

LONDON, June 8 -- Exhausted after more than three days without sleep and wearing a four-day growth of beard, Col. Ralph R. Bagby of Evanston, Ill., who parachuted into France with the initial air-borne wave, returned to England today -- the first paratrooper to come back.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- American manufacturers were advised today by the War Production Board not to attempt to fulfill all of their grandiose post-war dreams on V-Day plus one, but, instead, to pick up production on the 1941 scale, with a gradual application of the improvements made possible by military experimentation and development.

Samuel Fields, in 40 Central Pk South; Joyce Ayres, in 333 E 53d St; Charles LaTorre, in 65 Central Pk West; Francis Murphy, in W 55th St, Sig Hindley, in 58 W 58th St; M. Harris, penthouse in 29 Washington Sq West; Irving Rappaport, penthouse in 1 University Pl -- Rose Fabricant, broker.

A married couple whom the police charged with having stolen more than $1,000,000 in jewelry, furs and war bonds in the last five years, mostly in apartment and hotel-room burglaries across the country, were sentenced to State prison yesterday in General Sessions.

My attention has been directed to the May 8 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, wherein your correspondent in Moscow reported an article in War and the Working Class, a Soviet publication, containing the assertion that the Baltic states "joined the U.S.S.R. * * * as a result of a real popular desire of the peoples in * * * Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia."

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP) -- Sam Byrd of Redford, Mich., former Yankee outfielder, batted his way around the tough Torresdale-Frankford Country Club course in 66 strokes today -- five under par -- to take a two-stroke lead for the lion's share of the $17,500 war bond prizes in The Inquirer invitation seventy-two-hole golf tournament.

ROME, June 8 (U.P.) -- Allied Fifth Army forces made an advance of nearly forty miles in three days to capture the port of Civitavecchia, while other units of General Clark's army have pushed thirty-two miles north of Rome along the main highway to Florence to capture the strategic rail and highway junction of Civita Castellano.

For the first time in fourteen weeks the earning assets of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City showed an increase in the week ended Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, at his first post-invasion meeting with the press, today hailed the initial landings as "a great accomplishment" but warned that "we must look for the full fury of savage counter-attacks in force at an early moment."

The Securities and Exchange Commission has reported that, between the ends of 1939 and 1943, the net working capital of American corporations other than banks and insurance companies rose 70 per cent, so that they are in the best shape in their history.

Italian laborers, mechanics, painters, plumbers and Italians of various other skills who were formerly prisoners of war here are now working in the New York Port of Embarkation, the Army announced yesterday.

A move by the United Office and Professional Workers of America to appropriate to its national treasury here approximately $37,400 awarded to an estimated 1,800 insurance agents as part of a retroactive wage increase was challenged yesterday by Jesse Friedin, general counsel of the War Labor Board.

ALGIERS, June 8 -- The French here listened with bated breath today to the radio story of the slowly advancing liberation of their country. All were absorbed by the battle of the beaches and the capture of Bayeux. But few were aware of the perhaps equally historic drama that went forward behind the vast military scene.

ROME, Friday, June 9 -- Former Premier Ivanoe Bonomi was chosen by all parties of both Naples and Rome as candidate for next Premier of Italy, it was learned this morning. His selection followed a day of meetings after the arrival here from Naples of Prince Humbert, former Premier Pietro Badoglio and six leaders of the Committee of National Liberation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 8 -- What Germans claim to be an eyewitness story of the bombardment of Le Havre by a gigantic force of United States and British warships was released by Berlin today. A German combat reporter, Helmuth Berndt, writes:

JACKSON, Miss., June 8 -- The action of the Mississippi State Democratic convention yesterday in naming an uninstructed delegation to the Chicago convention and a footloose slate of electors to cast the State's electoral vote following November's election, was said here today to have been part of a region-wide plan intended to restore the voice of the South in national Democratic party councils.

The Kings County Democratic Executive Committee at a meeting yesterday in county headquarters in the Jefferson Building, designated State Senator Carmine J. Marasco for the vacancy on the Kings County bench caused by the death of Peter J. Brancato. The district leaders also named Assemblyman Charles J. Beckinella for a vacancy on the Municipal Court bench in the First District.

SOMEWHERE IN THE UNITED STATES, June 8 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. G.N. Macready, Commander of the British Army Staff in Washington, today reviewed the first British infantry unit to train on United States soil since before the Revolutionary War.

The Office of Price Administration yesterday revoked the basic gasoline ration of a motorist who bought gasoline in the black market, but allowed him to keep a supplementary ration equivalent to 100 miles of driving a month to permit him to make two trips a week to his farm at Roscoe.

LONDON, Friday, June 9 (AP) -- Two of the toughest, hardest-fighting divisions in the American and English armies -- the famous American First Infantry Division and Britain's renowned Fiftieth Northumbrian Division -- are cracking the Germans again side by side, this time on the fields and beaches of French Normandy.

The board of trustees of the Retirement System of Detroit, Mich., announced yesterday that it will sell on June 19 a total of $847,000 of various blocks of the city's registered bonds now held in the system's investment account.

LONDON, June 8 -- A German battery whose guns commanded a wide strip of the invasion coastline was taken out of action by one of the most coldly calculated and carefully planned air-borne operations of the war, executed by specially selected British air crews, glider pilots and paratroops, it was revealed today.
WITH ALLIED INVADING FORCES, France, June 8 -- Our tanks are rapidly widening a great bulge inside the Atlantic Wall.

At 4:30 this morning I thought mingled thoughts of your lovely editorial, "Meadow Melodies," having been awakened at that unearthly hour by cheery chirping. This happens every morning at the same hour -- and I go to bed at midnight!

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 8 -- The story of the successful conclusion of one of the biggest last-minute rush jobs of the invasion was told here tonight when a spokesman at Supreme Headquarters revealed how the Royal Army Ordnance Corps and British industry combined to waterproof all the Allied tanks and mechanized equipment now fighting in France in one-quarter of the time that normally would be required for such a gigantic task.

The Greater New York Fund has received contributions of $4,023,511, representing 89 per cent of the seventh annual campaign goal of $4,500,000, it was announced yesterday at the Fund's third report luncheon at the Hotel Commodore. The sum is the largest ever announced by the organization at a third report meeting and shows an increase of $421,575 over last year's totals for the same period.

Competition among students of six high schools in the Bronx, who started to collect waste paper on May 22, will end today with the awarding of free admission tickets to a major league baseball game to members of the team that salvaged the largest amount of paper.

The spring run of striped bass is ended along the Long Island shore and those the surf fishermen take from now until the second run begins will be strays. Eddie Aubel was talking about it yesterday and said that although he had tried diligently during the past three weeks, the result was a grand total of one striper.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Use of the country's supply of industrial alcohol in such civilian items as after-shave lotion, anti-freeze, paints and lacquers will be reduced even further next year, the War Production Board disclosed today.
Four of the nation's greatest golfers will be in there "pitching" at the Fifth War Loan sports carnival to be held at the Polo Grounds the night of Saturday, June 17.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 8. -Although President Roosevelt carried Illinois in the last three Presidential elections, that State, with the third largest number of electoral votes, shows a marked trend today toward the Republicans.

Our tense absorption in the tremendous venture in northern France overshadows the continuing and notable gains the Allied forces are winning in Italy. For one jubilant day we thrilled to the story of the capture of Rome, and then the big invasion started, and everything else faded into background.

FREDERICK, Md., June 8 -- A nine-point program designed to raise the standards of school systems in countries throughout the world was adopted by representatives of thirty-two Allied nations attending the international educational assembly at Hood College.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The War Production Board, in an effort to improve facilities for "in-plant" feeding of war workers, announced a program today under which manufacturers of certain cooking and dishwashing equipment may step up their output substantially over their production of last year.

LONDON, June 8 -- The vast operational demands for coal created by the invasion of Europe will be studied closely in the coming week by members of an American mission that arrived in England today and their British counterparts.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP) -- J. Kennard Weaver, Draft Board No. 54 chairman, confirmed today that Danny Litwhiler, outfielder of the Cardinals, has been reclassified 2-A because his board regards baseball as "contributing to public welfare, health and interest."

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The prosecution began a new step in the mass sedition trial today by seeking introduction of evidence which it said would show that Nazi-controlled agencies sent anti-American propaganda to many of the twenty-nine defendants since January, 1941.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Pope Pins XII, answering a recent message of the American Hierarchy expressing confidence that some way could be found to spare Rome, has thanked the Bishops of the United States, the National Catholic Welfare Conference announced today.

Joseph F. Lawless and Charles Schaefer, traffic policemen of the Port of New York Authority, had the distinction yesterday of being the first to receive newly created medals for meritorious service from that body.

The Allied invasion of France has centered interest on the preflight design training exhibit in the lobby of the High School of Music and Art, 135th Street and Convent Avenue, attendants said yesterday. There are maps and models of the world's war areas, schemes for proposed invasions of the continent, camouflage projects of factories and all the paraphernalia usually associated with the headquarters of the combined chiefs of staff.
LONDON, June 8 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England reported a decrease of 74,000 in note circulation.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 8 -- A convention for the avoidance of double succession and estate taxation was signed here today between Canada and the United States, Prime Minister Mackenzie King signed for Canada and Ambassador Ray Atherton for the United States.

BAYEUX, Allied Front Line, Normandy, June 7 (Delayed) -- Allied troops streamed into this historic town at noon today, the first community of France to be freed from the Germans, and its people went wild with joy, crying "On to Paris!"

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Rigid Steel Conduit Association, the National Electrical Wholesalers Association and the Organization Service Corporation, together with their officers and members, to cease operation of a basing-point system for sale of rigid steel conduits which the commission found restrained trade and artificially fixed prices.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The opposing opinions in the insurance cases just decided by a minority of the Supreme Court reveal, on careful inspection, differences in thinking between idealistic and practical reformers, between judges who say that justice must be done at once though the heavens fall and judges who hold that justice, having waited seventy-five years, can wait until steps can be taken to shore up the heavens.
Some folk will take a cocktail before lunch Joe Arcano, a six-foot 200-pound shipping clerk, doesn't. Mr. Arcano swings vigorously fifteen times from the door-jamb instead.

LONDON, June 8 -- Allied High Command broadcasts warned Atlantic shore peoples from France to Norway tonight not to fish in their coastal waters for one week beginning tonight, so they Will "not hinder the operations of the Allied forces." These in structions went out from London and North African stations as the German commentator, Martin von Hallensleben, wrote that the Germans were on the alert for invasions on northern coasts.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee voted today to hear a statement from Sidney Hillman before beginning an inquiry into spending by the CIO Political Action Committee.

WITH THE PARATROOPS BEHIND THE ATLANTIC WALL, June 6 (Delayed) -- Parachuted into Europe at two minutes past 1 o'clock this morning, six and a half hours before our sea-borne forces began their full-blown invasion of Europe, I have seen and done and experienced a lot.

The 257-acre estate of the late J. P. Morgan at Glen Cove, L. I., with a forty-one-room residence and elaborate group of farm buildings, has been sold at a fraction of its original cost and is destined to be devoted to new uses. It was announced here yesterday that the property had been acquired by an unidentified group.

A two-point program designed to help the dress industry meet intensive post-war competition and emphasizing exports and streamlined efficiency in the domestic market was presented yesterday by Henry Silver, president of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, at the annual meeting of the organization at the Hotel Astor.
JERSEY CITY, June 8 (AP) -- Montreal beat Jersey City in a double-header, 8 to 2 and 5 to 2, tonight. As a result the Little Giants dropped from first to second place, back of Buffalo.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 8 -- Marshal Antonescu's resignation as Premier and his replacement by Horia Sima, exiled leader of the Rumanian Iron Guard movement, is forecast as imminent in dispatches from Axis sources received here tonight.

Problems of parenthood, from disciplining the pre-school child to understanding the adolescent, will be discussed in a series of six lectures in a three-day forum, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday at Saks Thirty-fourth Street. Monday's topic will be the pre-school child.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A 28-year-old officer of the Air Forces, who was a second lieutenant less than four years ago, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to become the youngest general in the Army.

BOSTON, June 8 -- Jan Stanczyk, Minister of Labor in the Polish Government-in-Exile, told the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers at its final session today that his Government was anxious for an amicable understanding with Soviet Russia on their territorial differences but still awaited an answer to the Polish Government's proposal for a settlement.

Postmaster General Frank C. Walker is claiming powers that would make him, in effect, the censor of all publications that use the mails in violation of the constitutional guarantee of freedom of the press, the American Newspaper Publishers Association asserted yesterday in a brief it is filing as Amicus Curiae in the Esquire case now before the United States district court for the District of Columbia.
AN INVASION PORT, England, June 8 (U.P.) -- A wounded soldier walked off an LST -- a blood-soaked bandage on one hand and his trousers torn to the knee today.

The Radio Corporation of America and the Columbia Broadcasting System filed a protest yesterday with the National War Labor Board in Washington against what they called an unprecedented delay in rendering a decision on their dispute with the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, on the recording issue.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Legislation to permit the outright transfer of small United States naval vessels to other American republics on a "partial reimbursement" basis was urged on Congress today by James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -Price Administrator Chester Bowles asserted tonight that the Bankhead cotton amendment to the price control bill, was "best calculated to shatter the entire structure of stabilization." But Southern Democrats in the Senate challenged that the proposed new textile price formula would be inflationary.
LONDON, June 8 -- All through southern England, and even in the British capital itself, the wounded, castaways and prisoners have begun to make their appearance.
LONDON, June 8 -- Despite the small volume of business transacted here on today's stock markets, due to investors awaiting further invasion news, a firm tone ruled throughout.
Leases of business space in Manhattan yesterday covered a wide area. Some contracts were made for entire floors.

Two films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Rialto, the newcomer will be "The Invisible Man's Revenge," a melodrama produced by Universal. Jon Hall, Gale Sondergaard, Alan Curtis, Evelyn Ankers, John Carradine and Leon Errol head the film's cast....

Several major real estate transactions involving hotel and residential properties along Madison Avenue were reported near closing yesterday. Investors and estates were said to be about to take additional properties in that section of Manhattan.

ABOARD H.M.S. SCORPION, June 8 -- Strongly reinforced German detachments pinned down advanced Allied units in this area last evening and threw them out of two localities by determined counter-attacks. The Allied position appeared critical.

MOFFETT FIELD, Calif., June 8 -Wind of "double hurricane" velocity, man-made and controlled, roared past a new model scout bomber here today as Dr. Jerome C. Hunsaker of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, pressed a button putting into operation the world's largest wind tunnel.

The real estate pages continue to furnish good texts for one of our favorite discourses. It concerns the peculiar time sense which will announce in one paragraph the sale of a piece of property which has been in the same family for the astounding period of twenty-seven years.

Professor Harlow Shapley's views with regard to vulgarization of public taste by advertisers on the radio, concerning which you express disagreement in Topics of The Times, seem eminently worthy of support.

Coming to the Hudson Theatre on Tuesday night, June 20, is "Love on Leave," described by the management as "a humorous account of two sailors on leave in New York." A.B. Shiffrin is the author of the comedy, which Eugene S. Bryden directed with a cast including Millard Mitchell, Mary Sargent, John Conway, Stanley Bell, Rosemary Rice, Bert Freed, James Dobson and Joann Dolan.

After consultation with former President Herbert Hoover and other speakers scheduled to address a mass meeting Sunday in Carnegie Hall on the plight of Europe's starving youngsters, the program has been indefinitely postponed until the invasion situation "clarifies" itself, Dr. Howard E. Kershner, chairman of the Temporary Council on Food for Europe's Children, sponsoring agency, announced yesterday.

Estrogenic creams that contain female hermones and are said to make the skin look firmer and younger have been proved successful by scientific tests, Dr. Louis Schwartz, Medical Director, Dermatoses Section, United States Public Health Service, said yesterday.

LONDON, June 8 -- Since being driven from his hideout in the Bosnian Hills by a German parachute attack, Marshal Tito has established his headquarters elsewhere in Yugoslavia to continue his campaign against the occupation army, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- From President Roosevelt to the Stage Door Canteen, Maj. Robert Johnson, combat ace of the European theatre, took in the nation's capital today, but he had time to put in a good word with the President for a fellow-Oklahoman and fighter pilot, Capt. Pervis Youree, who faces discharge from the Air Force.

Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican State Chairman, yesterday designated Kenneth S. MacAffer, Albany county chairman, and Miss Mary H. Donlon as the New York members of the Resolutions Committee of the Republican National Convention.
NEWARK, N. J., June 8 -- A threatened shortage of bottled beer intended for the armed services overseas overshadowed today other issues in the strike of beer bottlers and drivers in this area.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, London, Friday, June 9 (U.P.) -- Allied troops, victorious in the first phase of the invasion of France, battled today to within eleven miles of Cherbourg and to the southeast the fall of Caen was reported near.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 8 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared today in a confident appraisal of the first fifty-four hours of the Allied invasion of France that his faith in the sea, air and ground units had been "completely justified" and that the ground forces under Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery were "performing magnificently."

CHICAGO, June 8 -Premier Stalin envisions a large, strong, sovereign Poland after the war, Dr. Oscar Lange, Polish-American Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago, who interviewed the Russian chief of State May 17, said today at a press conference.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle, in his first statement on the insurance decision handed down by the Supreme Court Monday, asserted today that the Department of Justice had "no desire or purpose" to break down regulations of insurance by the States.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Senate and House conferees reported agreement today on educational and rehabilitation loan provisions of "the GI Bill of Rights," the omnibus veterans' aid measure, but remained deadlocked on differing versions dealing with job placement and unemployment compensation.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Wheat fluctuated nervously today on the Board of Trade until late in the session when brokers for millers started to sell contracts, and then with weakness in rye and bearish construction placed on military operations in Europe, the market broke, declining 1 cent or more a bushel, and closing about the bottom with net losses of 1/4 to 7/8 cent.

After consultation with former President Herbert Hoover and other speakers scheduled to address a mass meeting Sunday in Carnegie Hall on the plight of Europe's starving youngsters, the program has been indefinitely postponed until the invasion situation "clarifies" itself, Dr. Howard E. Kershner, chairman of the Temporary Council on Food for Europe's Children, sponsoring agency, announced yesterday.
LONDON, June 8 (UP) -- The French underground patriot army and Vichy's pro-Nazi mercenaries began a fratricidal war to the...

Estrogenic creams that contain female hermones and are said to make the skin look firmer and younger have been proved successful by scientific tests, Dr. Louis Schwartz, Medical Director, Dermatoses Section, United States Public Health Service, said yesterday.

Reductions of 15 cents a ton for householders and 10 cents a ton for industrial consumers in the present heavily-increased maximum ceiling prices of all Pennsylvania anthracite coal beginning tomorrow were announced yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, chief of the Regional Office of Price Administration.

LONDON, June 9 -- The next phase of the assault on Europe, according to a Berlin military spokesman cited by the German news agency DNB today, will probably be an attack by British and Canadian forces in great strength on the Channel coast between Dunkerque and Ostend.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Saturday, June 10 (AP) -- A communique:

The possession of a great port is obviously the initial objective of the Allied forces in France. The reason that Cherbourg was aimed at first, rather than Le Havre or other Channel ports closer to Germany, is probably because the invasion strategists believed it could be taken more quickly.

" What Price Italy," a feature length compilation of newsreel excerpts on the Sicilian and Italian campaigns, will open today at the Arena Theatre, Eighth Avenue and Forty-first Street. The picture, produced by Joseph Plunkett and distributed by Noel Meadow, features detailed accounts of the fighting at, Palermo, Nettuno, Sisterna, Anzio, Battipiglia and ends with the final drive on Cassino.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., June 9--Scoring seven birdies on his own ball, Emery Thomas, home club pro, today paired with George Davidson to take the third New Jersey pro-amateur best-ball tournament at the Forest Hill Field Club with a seven-under-par 64. They had nines of 32, 32--64.

LONDON, June 9 -- Business on the stock markets here today was again limited, operators preferring to await developments in France before taking on more commitments before the week end. The markets, however, were generally firm, with the exception of French stocks, in which profit-taking caused prices to slip to lower levels.
The third of New York racing's ten charity days loomed on the horizon this morning, for today is the day they give the net proceeds away at Aqueduct.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Hans Max Haupt, German-born paper-hanger and father of an executed Nazi saboteur, was convicted a second time today of treason against his adopted country.

Two announcements came from the New Jersey State Fish and Game Commission yesterday, one declaring that the bass season's opening next Thursday would complete all open seasons on the sportsmen's fishing calendar in the State and the other predicting that the current Governor's fishing tournament would surpass its predecessors in popularity because of the relaxation of off-shore restrictions.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Maj. Robert Johnson, America's ace air combat fighter of the European theatre and a Golden Gloves boxer and football player in his school days, went to bat today for competitive sports, declaring that he might not have survived his 102 sorties without an athletic background.

LONDON, June 9 (U.P.) -- A consensus of correspondents at various fronts indicates that for every German who complies with Hitler's demand that he "fight to death" there are sixty or more who willingly throw down their guns and throw up their hands.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Merchandisers' sales plans purporting to give purchasers of rayon and lisle hosiery membership in so-called nylon priority clubs are in violation of the nylon hosiery regulation, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

Reporting on operations last year of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation at Bethpage, L.I., Leroy R. Grumman, president and chairman, informed stockholders in the annual statement released today, that airplane deliveries to the Navy exceeded the schedule each month of 1943.

RICHMOND, Va., June 9 -- Patents relating to improvements in paint, vitamin preparations and the production of pure chemicals stand out among the 653 reported as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.
Led by the strength in July, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange gained yesterday 2 to 6 points in active months.

A diversified list of railroad, public utility, industrial and municipal offerings featured the new bond offering market here this week as investment bankers cleared the decks in preparation for the Fifth War Loan drive, which will open officially on Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Senator Moore, Republican, of Oklahoma, told the Senate today that he had asked Attorney General Biddle for a new ruling on recent activities of the CIO political action committee as well as several other organizations.

The district Office of Price Administration, rationing division, Newark, N.J., advised gasoline dealers throughout northern New Jersey yesterday that they had one month in which to apply to local rationing boards for replacement of gallonage lost by shrinkage, spilling and evaporation since rationing began.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Expenditionary Force, June 9 (AP) -- Communique 7:

A premature raid by one police inspector in Brooklyn in 1942, while another inspector was arranging with the District Attorney's office to eliminate two telephone racing information offices there and in Manhattan, resulted yesterday in the dismissal in General Sessions of an indictment charging nine men with having conspired to aid bookmakers to receive racing information.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Reports of black rust in parts of the Texas Panhandle and eastern Kansas brought in sufficient buying to give the wheat market a firm undertone today on the Board of Trade. Although many brokers expressed skepticism about the prospect of material damage to the winter wheat crop, it was admitted that there still were about thirty days in which unfavorable conditions might lower the prospect.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 9 -William Lees and Dr. O.V. Wibell of Cherry Valley matched par with 38, 35 -- 73 for medal honors among forty-six teams in the annual member-guest tournament of the Hempstead Golf Club. The qualifying round closed today.

Rows of empty and long-idle buildings in a New York war housing project have been transformed into an armed camp in an unusual experiment having the triple aim of utilizing excess emergency living quarters, putting German prisoners of war to useful work, and filling the seasonal demand for additional farm and cannery workers in up-State communities, it became known last night.

LONDON, Saturday, June 10 -The continuous Allied aerial patrol over the battle area of France was broken yesterday for the first time since D-day when low clouds and rain over the Channel and the coast of Normandy made flying impossible for several hours in the morning.

SHREVEPORT, La., June 9 -- Democratic leaders opposed to the New Deal and representing six Southern States met in conference today to begin immediate steps toward molding "rebellious" elements in the South into "a bolting bloc" with which to threaten President Roosevelt's fourth-term management in the national convention and the general election.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate today adopted Senator Bankhead's amendment to price control legislation which would force the OPA to readjust ceilings on cotton textiles:
ALBANY, June 9 -- Governor Dewey has executed a lease, turning over to the War Department the ney $6,600,000 Edgewood State Hospital at Deer Park, L.I., to be used for hospital purposes.

Your recent editorial, "On the Home Front," dealing with the diminishing attractiveness of war industry jobs even before the military efforts abroad approach the conclusive stage and what shall be done now to hold the line against the trend already evident of a civilian inclination to attach itself to jobs safe from sudden "cut-backs" is a most timely statement.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Supplementary pay for various branches of the armed forces occupied the attention of Congress at both ends of the Capitol today. The Senate Military Affairs Committee approved two bills with similar objectives, and the House Military Affairs Committee prepared to hold hearings on the Senate measures. Bills also are pending in the lower house.

LONDON, June 9 -- Supreme Headquarters today made public the English translation of the proclamation of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to the people of France, declaring that "members of the French Military Mission" attached to his headquarters would assist them in providing their own civil administration and promising free, democratic elections when victory is won and France liberated.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The United States Joint Chiefs of Staff -- top commanders of the land, sea and air forces -- arrived in Great Britain today, the White House announced tonight. The commuting commanders are Gen. George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff; Admiral Ernest J. King, Chief of Naval Operations, and Gen. Henry H. Arnold, Commanding General of the Army Air Forces.
A large residential hotel and several other housing properties on the East Side were among the Manhattan parcels listed yesterday as having passed into new control.

LONDON, June 9 (U.P.) -- German occupation authorities in France today blacked-out all civilian activities in the Vichy area while the nation was reported seething under Gestapo mass round-ups in Paris and Lyon, demonstrations smashed by tanks in Marseille, and sabotage outbreaks against vital Nazi communications in the Rhone Valley.

The superiority of our air forces has stemmed in large part from fundamental aerodynamic research. Another step forward in this direction is the dedication of the Ames Aeronautical Laboratory at Moffett Field, near Palo Alto, Calif., which has just been completed by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 9 -- The majority of Americans today do not regard the present conflict as a war that will end all wars.

The proposed economic stabilization advertising program intended for farm papers as outlined by the Office of War Information will tax the ingenuity of advertising writers, informed sources indicated yesterday. The farmer will be asked to reduce his outstanding debts, increase productivity of his land, carry adequate insurance, buy war bonds, adopt a "fair" attitude as to prices on his own produce and refrain from indulging in speculative land buying.

An advance campaign for the Fifth War Loan begun by Mrs. Rae Simon, who is 77 years old, and one of the city's most successful house-to-house canvassers in previous drives, already has resulted in the sale of $4,000 worth of war bonds, it was reported to the War Finance Committee for New York yesterday.

" Mental cruelty" as a cause of divorce keeps adding curiosities to the case-book. A Boston dispatch reveals a peculiarly sensitive Yankee. He got a divorce for cruelty because, as he testified, his wife kept the house "too clean." It is a commonplace remark, whether born of envy or produced as a consolation, that the palaces of plutocrats are like museums and not like homes.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., June 9 -- The Northeastern Jurisdictional Conference of the Methodist Church completed today its task of filling three resident Bishoprics, electing the Rev. Dr. W. Earl Ledden, pastor of Trinity Methodist Church, Albany, N.Y., and the Rev. Dr. Lewis O. Hartman of Boston, editor of Zion's Herald, an independent Methodist weekly published in the Massachusetts city.

The twelve-story loft building at 268-276 Fourth Avenue, northwest corner of Twenty-first Street has been purchased by Samuel Barkin and Samuel Reznick, operators from Herman Herring of the building firm which erected the structure in 1927.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Germans made a colossal mistake in not using their air force to oppose Allied landings on the first day of the invasion in the opinion of United States Army Air Forces chiefs, who were genuinely surprised when immediate air opposition did not develop.
CHUNGKING, China, June 9 (AP) -- A communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters:

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, replying to an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission instituting "death sentence'' proceedings against it, failed today to express a view regarding the properties which it felt constituted its principal integrated holding company system.

Marking the first time in the seven-year existence of the Greater New York Fund that a borough has topped its goal at a final report-meeting, Brooklyn listed $521,840 in contributions, 104 per cent of its quota, yesterday at a Victory Luncheon in the Hotel St. George.
William J. Minsch, G. Leonard Boveroux, Harold S. Smith and John D. Talmage will form on July 1 the New York Stock Exchange firm of Minsch, Monell Co.

" The Protestant Church's Responsibility to Returning Service Men and Women" will be the subject of a conference to be held Tuesday at 2:15 P.M. in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street under the sponsorship of the Service Men's Council, the Protestant Council of the City of New York, the affiliated Federations of Churches, the Y.M.C.A., the Y.W.C.A. and the Salvation Army.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 9 (AP) -- The New York Women's Tennis team, winner of the Sears Cup for the past two years, made a clean sweep of six singles and three doubles matches, today while launching its defense of the trophy against a Philadelphia sextet at Longwood.

Palmero Fazzi, 60 years old, and his son, Peter Fazzi, 26, both of 883 Longfellow Avenue, the Bronx, who were accused of stealing $50,000 worth of food products from a Long Island City plant where the father was employed as stationary engineer, were sentenced to prison by Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, June 9 (AP) -- Jersey City fought a thrilling uphill battle to win in the ninth from Monreal with a two-run rally tonight, 9 to 8.

ALGIERS, June 9 (U.P.) -- French resistance forces played an important part in the success of the Allied landings in Normandy and henceforth will be granted full military status in the French Army as "French Forces of the Interior," it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Four members of the board of the National League of Women Voters and several members of the staff have resigned in a shake-up attributed to administrative changes made by the convention at Chicago in April.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- American bombers, hitting hard at Japanese positions in the Central Pacific, blasted air fields, runways and gun positions on a half dozen islands Wednesday and Thursday, the Navy reported today.

LONDON, June 9 -- Maurice de Jean, London representative of the French Committee of National Liberation, made a demarche to the Allied Governments here calling attention to an ordinance promulgated at Algiers in which the French Committee declared itself to be the Provisional Government of France.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will make "Flat-top," a story of the personnel of an aircraft carrier in dock for repairs. Capt. Harvey S. Haizlip, USN, its author, has written three previous Metro Navy pictures.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, June 10 -- The American wing of the Allied front in Normandy has cut the main highway and railway from Carentan to Cherbourg and is pushing German tactical reserves out of the coastal zone.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Legislation to extend price, wage and rent controls for eighteen months beyond June 30 was adopted by the Senate today with the cotton amendments, which the Office of Price Administration has said will add at least $250,000,000 to the country's, annual clothing bill.

OSWEGO, N.Y., June 9 -- Selection of Fort Ontario as a war refugee camp was a complete surprise to Oswego. Various rumors on possible use of the dismantled military post have been in circulation since the War Department ceased using the fort as a training center three months ago, and the Chamber of Commerce has been trying to interest the Government in reoccupancy of the post.

PERHAPS the deeper implications of the situation will be lost on the casual baseball fan but the Giants play a night game with the Phils at the Polo Grounds tonight. Just in case you didn't bother to glance at the calendar, it had better be added that this is Saturday. A night game in Metropolitan New York on a Saturday? Yes, that's correct. For the first time in history such an event is taking place.

WITH THE INVASION FORCES IN FRANCE, June 8 (Delayed) -British and Canadian troops made their first landings in France in the region of Bernieres-sur-Mer, eleven miles north of Caen and ten miles west of the Orne River, and they are sweeping in from the beaches and cleaning up isolated centers of German resistance.

The City Council, by a vote of 14 to 2, adopted yesterday a resolution criticizing Mayor La Guardia and Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh in connection with the recent transfer of five lieutenants and a fireman to posts remote from their homes because they made public statements assailing the Mayor and Mr. Walsh for establishing the two-platoon system in various sections of the city.

BOSTON, Mass., June 9 -- Although the Yankees are currently in the throes of the worst slump they have known in many years, having dropped nine of their last eleven games, Manager Joe McCarthy indicated today that he plans no changes in his line-up when the champions resume their series with the Red Sox here tomorrow.

An educational campaign among candy distributors to promote freshness of products in modernized stores and continuation of the research being done by the Department of Agriculture to increase the use of agricultural products in confections were authorized yesterday by the board of directors of the National Confectioners' Association at a meeting following the conclusion of the association's convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The American delegation to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference opening July 1 at Bretton Woods, N.H., the composition of which became known here today, will include Edward F. Brown of the First National Bank of Chicago, who is president of the Federal Advisory Council of the Federal Reserve System, and two Republican members of Congress.

BOSTON, June 9 (U.P.) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, warned New England's Governors today that the country's cotton textile supply was "very low" in the face of rising requirements, but he believed that the rationing of cotton goods could be avoided.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- Basing his prediction upon the satisfaction of eight "ifs," Robert E. Freer, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, forecast today a favorable "government climate" 'for business after the war in which they would be so invigorated as to enjoy the rigors of competition.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 9 (UP) -A communique:
