WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Allied air power did more than its scheduled job in softening up Europe for the invasion, it was authoritatively learned tonight. The Allied command had counted on American and British planes based in the United Kingdom to pound the Continent with 130,550 tons of bombs during April and May instead, 166,940 tons were dropped, a surplus of more than 30,000.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 9 -- The following is an Office of War Information translation of a proclamation by General Eisenhower that has been dropped on enemy-held areas in France and posted in areas liberated by the Allied Forces:
PITTSBURGH, June 9 (AP) -- With the score tied at 3 -- 3 the Pittsburgh-Chicago National League game was called in the eleventh inning tonight on account of rain.

DANBURY, Conn., June 9 -- A 17-year-old Bronx (N.Y.) youth was arrested by State police today and charged with the slaying of a former girl schoolmate, also 17, whose body was found May 31 in a shallow grave in the cellar of a burned-out summer cottage on the shores of Candlewood Lake, near here.

Mr. Farley has been a chairman for twenty-six years. He began in 1918 with the Rockland County Democratic Committee. In 1930 he took the chair of the New York State Democratic Committee, which he has just resigned. For eight years he was chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

Defeated in the South Pacific, frustrated in their attempted invasion of India, threatened in Burma, the Japanese are now announcing over the Tokyo radio that they intend to "launch the most formidable offensive" in China, with the purpose of cutting that country in two.

FREDERICK, Md., June 9 -- Relations with the Latin-American countries, especially Brazil, have rapidly deteriorated to the point where the entire good-neighbor policy is endangered and is beginning to backfire, according to Dr. Hernane Tavares, special adviser from Brazil to the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, who addressed delegates of thirty-two Allied Nations attending the International Education Assembly on the Hood College campus.

Supported by a recovery in the rail section, the stock market broke through yesterday to the higher side, but with no improvement in the brand of leadership. Irregular and moderate gains ruled at the close of trading, and, despite the continued heavy turnover in the low-priced motors, business contracted to the smallest in a week.

Failure to show any improvement at the box office has finally induced the management of "Dream With Music" to close the attraction after tonight's performance. It opened at the Majestic Theatre on May 18 and will have given a total of twenty-eight performances.

ALBANY, June 9 -- Charging failure by the District Attorney of Albany County to act, the special grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany handed up indictments today against eight persons, including a veteran captain of railroad police, who are alleged to have constituted a ring which stole $650,000 worth of scrap brass from the New York Central Railroad over a five-year period.

LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- A spokesman for Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery today commended the United States night air force Thunderbolt fighter-bomber groups for constant support to British-American armies on the beaches over the critical sixteen-hour period on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Department store sales in the week ended June 3 were 7 per cent higher than sales of the corresponding week a year age, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following table shows percentage changes from corresponding periods of 1943:

A new program of education and research in the field of restaurant operation, involving a five-year course at the University of Chicago beginning next fall, was announced yesterday at a board of directors meeting of the National Restaurant Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A record wheat crop was forecast today by the Agriculture Department, which said that in spite of a late start, due to unfavorable spring weather, national crop prospects now appeared better than on this date in any of the last ten years except 1942.

The production of steel ingots in May amounted to 7,680,472 tons, the second highest for this year and exceeded only by March, when a record of 7,820,226 tons was produced, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The May total compared with 7,568,530 tons in April and with 7,549,691 in May, last year.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 9 -- County Executive J. Russel Sprague announced today that he would recommend that the Nassau Board of Supervisors take emergency action Monday to set up an Assembly district in the city of Long Beach under the reapportionment act, which increased Nassau's Assembly representation from two to four.

Twenty thousand New Yorkers watched a noonday military demonstration in Times Square yesterday as the motion picture industry staged, amid dramatic settings, its "preview" rally for the Fifth War Loan, which begins officially throughout the nation on Monday.
ROME, June 9 (U.P.) -- Revolver shots, which it was feared were fired at Prince Humbert, interrupted today a demonstration by 5,000 persons who cheered the new Lieutenant General of Italy.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, June 10 (U.P.) -- The first Allied destroyer sunk in invasion operations before dawn on D-day was hit by a German "mystery" weapon that the American ship's skipper is still unable to identify definitely, it was disclosed today.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Broad powers to cancel contracts with employers against whom it strikes were assumed today by the American Federation of Musicians in a resolution adopted by delegates to its convention here. In another resolution, the delegates to its convention here. In another resolution, the delegates reaffirmed the union's constitutional provision denying membership to Communists, Fascists and Nazis.
NEWARK, N.J., June 9 (AP)With Frank Hiller keeping seven safeties well spaced, the last place Bears rolled to an 8-0 victory over Toronto tonight.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 9 -- In the first naval engagement of any moment since invasion day, a force of British, Canadian and Polish warships intercepted four German destroyers about ten miles southwest of Ushant, off the Brittany peninsula, early this morning, and when the smoke of battle cleared, one enemy craft had been blown apart, another left in flames on the beach and the other two escaped after receiving damaging hits.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 9 -- The High Command in its first detailed story disclosed today that United States parachute troops descending on the Ste.-Mere-Eglise sector below Cherbourg Tuesday brilliantly carried out a vital part of history's most successful airborne operation -- a vertical attack far excelling the German sky assault on Crete.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) -Sam Byrd of Detroit added a sub-par 67 today to his opening 66, stretching his lead to three strokes with 133 at the halfway mark in the $17,500 Inquirer 72-hole invitation golf tournament at the Torresdale-Frankford Country Club.
CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, June 10 (AP) -- A communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, June 9 -While the Allied invasion advances methodically Marcel Deat, Philippe Henriot and Joseph Demand are doing their utmost to transform the French official position from collaboration to co-belligerency. They have burned their bridges and are reckless.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Hope for the early fall of Cherbourg was indicated in informed circles today even before the Germans began hinting that they might give up that important port.

ROME, June 9 -- Pursuing the shattered German Fourteenth Army at continued breakneck pace northwest of Rome, Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army forces swept through the communication centers of Viterbo, Vetralla and Tarquinia today as Nazi troops in the Adriatic sector joined the general enemy flight up the Italian peninsula.
LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- A German communique, from a Berlin broadcast:

Comdr. Francis J. Braceland, Medical Corps, USNR, declared yesterday at the thirty-fourth annual meeting of the American Psychopathological Association that the incidence of psychoses in the Navy was far below that of civilian life and did not constitute a major problem in Navy medicine.

The University of Pennsylvania, according to recent news reports, has decided to deny admission to Japanese-Americans. That my own university, one of the oldest and most respected in the country, should take such discriminatory action, which seems to fly in the very face of academic freedom and of the constitutional liberties we are fighting for, came as a shocking surprise.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS IN FRANCE, June 7 (Delayed) -- The Army's communications system set up for correspondents accompanying American troops in the assault on France broke down completely and for more than twenty-eight hours they were unable to get news out on the doughboys in action.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees approached final agreement on a compromise G.I. "Bill of Rights" tonight by settling differences over unemployment compensation provisions.

LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- Violence already has broken out against collaborationists in liberated Bayeux, where a manhunt was under way for suspected traitors, reports from the invasion battlefront said today, but for the most part canny French parrots were biding their time and exercising considerable control.

A six-point program for withholding a percentage of present war production profits to be used to provide an unemployment fund in the post-war reconversion period was outlined yesterday by Col. Willard F. Rockwell, Pittsburgh and Detroit industrialist, at a press luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Roosevelt has granted a request by Gen. Charles de Gaulle that the Chief Executive receive him here, and has indicated dates either late this month or early in July when he will have time for conversations with the leader of the self-styled Provisional Government of the French Republic at Algiers.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The field demotion of a major general at Salerno last September was disclosed today when an Army promotion list showed him heading toward a quick comeback. Now a colonel, he was nominated to be a brigadier general.
NAPLES, June 9 (UP) -- A. communique:

Commercially canned pineapple has been expensive in points since the start of rationing -- at the moment, for example, it is selling for thirty-five points for a No. 2 tin, which contains approximately two-and-a-half cups. Women may find it practical, therefore, to home-can fresh pineapples, which range from 23 to 40 cents, the City Department of Markets reports.

A four-point program to plan and prepare guidance for returning war veterans in need of training and jobs was announced at an annual meeting and luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday by the Vocational Advisory Service.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, June 10 (AP) -- The Japanese are tightening a menacing arc against Changsha, which Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek has ordered defended to the utmost, the Chinese High Command said today. In two other Chinese provinces sudden flare-ups are expected as the enemy masses troops for new thrusts.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Senator Ellender of Louisiana told the Senate today that the Bankhead cotton pricing amendment "is a textile industry amendment and not one to help the cotton farmer."

The volunteer-operated "thrift shops" whose proceeds go to help the poor or disabled, are also doing a good turn today for the "white collar housewife by providing a second-hand source for home furnishings of pre-war make that couldn't be bought elsewhere.

CHUNGKING, China, June 9 (U.P.) -- On the Yunnan front in southwestern China the Burma-bound Chinese offensive is making good progress. Street fighting continued in the Japanese Burma Road base of Lungling, and Gen. Sung Hsi-lien's troops had cut the vital highway west of the city.

Ten students of the Lexington School for the Deaf, 904 Lexington Avenue, have won certificates of merit from the American Women's Voluntary Services for collecting 500 pounds of waste paper, it was announced yesterday by the salvage chairman of the organization's Park East Unit, Miss Augusta Frear.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Less drastic provisions for ending commercial use of the Red Cross name and emblem than those contained in the bill passed by the Senate in April were urged today by Kenneth Perry, vice president of Johnson Johnson of New Brunswick, N.J., at a hearing before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, June 10 (AP) -- Communique 8, announced early today:

LONDON, June 9 -- The chiefs of the United States' three fighting services arrived in Britain today to watch the early progress of the greatest military enterprise in the nation's history, the invasion of Europe by an Allied force under the command of an American general.
The roster of Republican National Convention delegates will be completed today, when a Nevada convention picks a delegation with six votes.

CINCINNATI, June 9 (AP) -- A strike which for four days paralyzed airplane engine production at the Wright Aeronautical Corporation plant simmered out today, fifteen hours before the expiration of a company "work-or-be-fired" ultimatum.

On learning that General de Gaulle is going to visit this country, most people will believe that, as regards the United States and England, the French problem is about to be disposed of and that the long-drawn controversy to which it has given rise is fast changing into harmony.

LONDON, Saturday, June 10 (U.P.) -- Moscow's broadcast war bulletin last night reported "no important changes" on the Eastern Front, and military observers said it was possible the Red Army summer offensive might not start until Anglo-American operations in the West have been developed fully.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 9 (AP) -- A resolution expressing "unbounded faith and confidence" in President Roosevelt was adopted by the Jewish Var Veterans and Ladies Auxiliary, department of New York, at the annual convention which opened at Kiamesha Lake today.

ROME, June 9 (U.P.) -- The swift Allied drive up the Italian peninsula already had cleared the enemy from more than 600 square miles of terrain above Rome in five days and tonight Allied war pilots reported seeing retreating columns of the battered German Tenth Army at points twenty miles north of Viterbo and within eighty miles of Florence.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, June 10 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Mitchell bombers sank four Japanese destroyers off Manokwari, Netherland New Guinea, it was announced today.

LONDON, June 9 -- D-day would not have been possible without the merchant marine. Now that the long-awaited day is history and great Allied forces have been landed in France, it is permitted to indicate the part played by these intrepid civilians, whose deeds for the most part have gone unsung.

The 1,065 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $93,271,754,989 par value as of May 31, had a total market value of $93,849,254,814, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of April 29 there were 1,074 issues, aggregating $95,013,084,742 par value, which had a total market value of $95,305,318,075.

ROME, June 9 -- The new Italian Government, which it is hoped will head the country until the Germans are hurled out, was formed tonight after a last-minute crisis that threatened to upset previous hopes.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES TRANSPORT, Off France, June 8 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Four American gilders landed in a hedge-fringed meadow in France which the Germans had turned into a trap, and twelve hours later only one man -a flight officer -- got out alive.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The British and Chinese Governments have accepted the United States invitation to participate in the exploratory conversations about the formation of a world peace organization, and the Soviet Government has indicated its willingness to take part in the discussions, though the official reply from Moscow has not been received.

Delegates, alternates and attendants at the Republican National Convention may be spared some of the "campaign oratory" customarily used to put a candidate for the Presidential nomination before the convention, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- German broadcasts said today that airborne reinforcements on the invasion front were helping to pack an Allied punch in an increasingly bitter battle of Normandy.

The two-story brick amusement building at 1048-64 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Nicholas Scandore from the Parkville Amusement Corporation. The building occupies a plot 250 by 221 feet and the property is assessed at $110,000.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- President Roosevelt said today that the plan to transfer small United States naval vessels to South American countries was part of an over-all program to build up the Western Hemisphere defenses.

A syndicate of New York investors known as the Centlock Realty Company purchased the two-story commercial building at 215-21 Central Avenue, northeast corner of Lock Street, Newark, N.J., from the New Jersey Title Guarantee Trust Co., in liquidation.

LONDON, June 9 -- Britain has embarked on a four-year food plan in the belief that wartime shortages will extend at least over that period in several important food-stuffs, Col. John J. Llewellin, Minister of Food, told the House of Commons today.

We believe that there will be prompt and generous approval of the President's plan to establish at Fort Ontario, near Oswego, a temporary haven for refugees who may escape from the European nations which are still under Hitler's domination. There is nothing in this proposal that seeks to evade the immigration laws or to disturb existing quotas.
Pitching his second successive five-hit game, young Calvin Coolidge McLish last night hurled the Dodgers to a 3-2 triumph over the Braves at Ebbets Field before 21,163 fervid Flatbush fans.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Legion of Merit medals were presented by the American Government today to Danish members of the Northwest Greenland Sledge Patrol who discovered a German base in Greenland last year and, although attacked by the Germans, reported to the American military authorities, with the result that the base was destroyed.

A syndicate of New York investors known as the Centlock Realty Company purchased the two-story commercial building at 215-21 Central Avenue, northeast corner of Lock Street, Newark, N.J., from the New Jersey Title Guarantee Trust Co., in liquidation.

LONDON, June 9 -- Britain has embarked on a four-year food plan in the belief that wartime shortages will extend at least over that period in several important food-stuffs, Col. John J. Llewellin, Minister of Food, told the House of Commons today.

We believe that there will be prompt and generous approval of the President's plan to establish at Fort Ontario, near Oswego, a temporary haven for refugees who may escape from the European nations which are still under Hitler's domination. There is nothing in this proposal that seeks to evade the immigration laws or to disturb existing quotas.
Pitching his second successive five-hit game, young Calvin Coolidge McLish last night hurled the Dodgers to a 3-2 triumph over the Braves at Ebbets Field before 21,163 fervid Flatbush fans.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Legion of Merit medals were presented by the American Government today to Danish members of the Northwest Greenland Sledge Patrol who discovered a German base in Greenland last year and, although attacked by the Germans, reported to the American military authorities, with the result that the base was destroyed.

The City Council failed yesterday to override Mayor LaGuardia's recent veto of its $5,427,851 cut in the 1944-45 budget, which will therefore stand at $737,400,923, the total approved last month by the Board of Estimate. The new budget, it was estimated, involves a reduction in the basic real estate tax that may be as great as fifteen or sixteen points.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- Naomi Nakano, Japanese-American president of the Women's Student Government Association at the University of Pennsylvania and center of a recent controversy over her right to remain as a postgraduate student, presided today at the first half of the Hey Day ceremonies and, on behalf of her class, presented a silver tray to Dr. Thomas S. Gates, retiring president of the university.

Chiefly because the investment banking fraternity will devote most of its efforts to the Fifth War Loan drive, beginning on Monday, only $2,447,800 of new municipal financing is scheduled to be done next week. This compares with this week's revised total of $37,824,028 and with the weekly average for 1944, thus far, of $21,400,692, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) -- Connie Mack gave a verbal pat on the back today to the local draft board that called baseball "essential,'' while emphasizing that he would not dispute any service group's decisions.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The text of President Roose elt's cablegram to Ambassador Murphy regarding European war refugees and his memorandum to heads of five Federal agencies was as follows:

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Gordon B. Hanlon, president of the Eastern Racing Association, testified today that he interested himself in the affairs of the Aldred Trust in 1928 to protect investors who had purchased trust bonds through his brokerage firm.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The War Labor Board said today the European invasion had resulted in a general clearing up of strikes in this country.

ROME, June 9 -- Two Roman galleys described as of the kind built in the first century A.D., which were salvaged in 1935 when the water in Lake Nemi in central Italy was pumped out in the tremendous enterprise to recover them, were destroyed by fire by the Germans on May 31, according to a reliable report submitted to Allied Military Government officials here.

In this newspaper a Thunderbolt pilot told of American infantrymen whom from the clouds he saw making their way forward on a Norman beach Tuesday morning in the face of mortar fire from Germans hidden in cliffs that faced the beach. "It was wonderful," he writes. "

Warning that it may be next spring before Congress takes vital action on major reconversion problems, Leon Henderson, former Price Administrator and chairman of the board of editors of the Research Institute of America, said last night that the country "is not getting anywhere" in its post-war planning.
A net profit of $5,239,351 for 1943 was reported yesterday by the Briggs Manufacturing Company and its domestic subsidiaries.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 9 (AP) -- Allied forces have punched suddenly forward in all major sectors of the India-Burma front. In the east they seized the northern end of the north Myitkyina airfield; near Kamaing they occupied several villages and routed enemy troops in disorder, and on the India side they pursued Japanese south from Kohima, headquarters announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) -- Early Wynn pitched the Senators to a seven-hit 2-to-1 victory over the Athletics tonight, scoring the winning run himself.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP) -- The Indians made it two straight over the league-leading Browns tonight by winning 4 to 2. Cleveland scored first in the second. Jeff Heath singled, Hockett walked, and after Keltner sacrificed Peters was purposely passed, filling the bases.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 9 -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper, in his capacity as acting prosecutor of Hudson County, struck a blow today at horse-race betting in wire rooms in Hudson County, reputedly a "big business" racket in the bailiwick of Mayor Frank Hague of this city, State Democratic boss, and long the target of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York in his campaign to stamp out off-the-track bookmaking.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, announced yesterday that Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d had been designated for renomination in the Seventeenth Congressional District.

A new plastic, developed for war purposes but which will probably play an important part in the manufacture of post-war products for home and industry, was publicly displayed for the first time yesterday by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company at a press luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria hotel.

More than three hundred entries were announced at the A.A.U. office yesterday for the metropolitan track and field championships to be held this afternoon at Randalls Island. The list includes seventy-one from the New York A.C., the defending champion, which will be represented by forty-seven athletes, several being named for more than one event.

Our beachheads in France are widening, deepening, merging, strengthening. Despite bad weather which held our air fleets back, we have cut the main highway and rail line leading into Cherbourg. The progress in these first few days is greater than most of us had dared to hope.

Your editorial of June 3, "Salvaging Paper," should be taken seriously by all collecting agencies and by individuals who contribute waste paper. Collecting agents should ascertain that highly important letters, documents, account books and the like are not scrapped. Individuals should scan their contributions carefully before disposing of them.

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- In a race marred by a run-out incident near the top of the stretch, Elmer J. Daily's Johnny Jr., 12-1 shot, today won the featured Cohasset Purse at Suffolk Downs, scoring by a length over H. Guy Bedwell's Undulator. The racing was watched by a crowd of 11,194.

According to THE TIMES, a committee announces that it will press the War Department for a program by which Nazi prisoners in this country may be "re-educated" into the ideals of democracy. The claim is that only 25 per cent of the captives here are fanatically Nazi, the implication being that most of the others are therefore ripe for indoctrination, as "good" Germans are supposed to be.

According to THE TIMES, a committee announces that it will press the War Department for a program by which Nazi prisoners in this country may be "re-educated" into the ideals of democracy. The claim is that only 25 per cent of the captives here are fanatically Nazi, the implication being that most of the others are therefore ripe for indoctrination, as "good" Germans are supposed to be.
Babe Ruth, eminent "Sultan of Swat," may be back in baseball as a pinch-hitter before the season is over, The Associated Press revealed yesterday.

Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein of the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street, was elected president of the Synagogue Council of America at the meeting of its delegates in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Wednesday evening, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street.

James A. Farley's resignation as chairman of the Democratic State Committee, of which very few of the party leaders had much advance information, has left the Democratic leaders in the State in a quandary and with no immediate agreement on a successor.

Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio declared last night that while our sons are fighting to crush pagan governments that seek domination over peoples, "it would be a cruel tragedy if, having spilled their blood in this great cause, they were to return to a nation in which the fountainhead of individual freedom and opportunity had run dry."

With the invasion of Europe still in its initial stages, announcement comes of the second biography of the chief of the Allied invasion forces. It is "General Ike" by Alden Hatch and will be released in September by Henry Holt. The first biography is Francis Trevelyan Miller's "Eisenhower: Man and Soldier," published today by Winston.

Max Liebermann long and ably filled the role of leader of the Impressionist School in Germany. On his deathbed (in 1935) Liebermann was notified by the Nazis that "any artistic activity" on his part was henceforth prohibited. In other words, being a Jew and an immediate forerunner of "modernism," he wasn't wanted.

LONDON, June 9 -- The military correspondent of The Times of London today takes issue with the prevalent idea that the Atlantic Wall has proved to be a Nazi bluff. Contending that such a conclusion does less than justice to the Allied troops who penetrated it, he points out there were some beach points on which it was doubtful for a time that the Allies would be able to obtain a footing at all.

Retail trade here showed gains this week after slight early hesitancy reflecting the impact of the invasion. Estimates indicated department store volume for the week would run 3 to 5 per cent above the like week last year. This rate of increase is smaller than in recent weeks, with the dip in volume traced to the earlier closings of stores on D-day and smaller advertising linage.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The President received members of the National Conference of Business Paper Editors, met with his Cabinet, and held his news conference. He also had appointments with Senators Samuel Jackson and Bennett Champ Clark.

Even while we speak of the miracle of American war production we know, of course, that it has not been a miracle, literally. It has been a magnificent effort, but the thing is not a miracle because we know how mighty has been the effort -- more workers, more planners, more directors, longer hours, more sacrifice -- in short, more thought, toil and sweat.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The United States will accept 1,000 refugees from Italy and give them temporary sanctuary at Fort Ontario, N. Y., President Roosevelt announced today. He added that this was the total number of refugees who would be brought to the United States.

CINCINNATI, June 10 -- The Cardinals gave the Reds their lumps today by pounding out the most one-sided shut-out victory in the National League in thirty-eight years. When the firing was done the Cards had won, 18 to 0, on twenty-one hits and fourteen passes.

" THE smith a mighty man is he," might well be applied to labors with the pen as well as at the forge. Today there are two Smiths heading the best-seller lists: Betty Smith, author of "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," and Lillian Smith, author of "Strange Fruit." Here are some other famous literary members of the clan:

ON a black, blustery night during January, 1943, four men, dressed like men from Mars in weird costumes resembling an exaggerated deep-sea diver's outfit, came up out of the sea and stood on the shores of Palermo harbor, which then was still in enemy hands.

The first of six ships being built for the United Mail Steamship Company, a subsidiary of the United Fruit Company, will be launched this morning by the Gulf Shipbuilding Corporation at Mobile, Ala. The vessel, to be christened Fra Berlanga, will be operated in a projected post-war service between American West Coast ports and Europe.

STANTON. Del., June 10 -- O.L. Bonifay's Mouse Hole, neglected in the betting but running in his best form on a sloppy track, paid $27.10 today in winning the first division of the Kent Stakes, featured race on the Delaware Park card.

THESE flights to glory of American aviators in the present war are guaranteed to rock any air-minded youngster back on his heels with excitement and pride. True stories, reported in quick slashing prose by a Life correspondent in the Southwest Pacific, they are records of almost incredible daring, resourcefulness and good American fighting spunk, often against terrific odds.

WHAT kind of Europe are the Allied armies going to discover as they penetrate the areas of German conquests in Western Europe? One may well say "discover" rather than "rediscover," for long years of ordeal have wrought such deep changes that even former visitors to the old Continent won't be able to retrace their steps on once familiar paths.

Allied troops are carrying into France an eloquent tribute -- a movie called "Salute to France". The liberated peoples will see their own story enacted on the screen. This movie was written and produced by the OWI and is also being shown in its English version to millions of American and British soldiers.

Now that the invasion of Western Europe by the forces of the United Nations is under way, the role of the steel industry in the industrial history of this war is about to enter a third phase. If the invasion results in an early collapse of the Nazi war machine there will be tremendous steel inventories which will require months to liquidate.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 10 -- William Lees and Dr. O.V. Wibell of Cherry Valley, the medalists, led the way into the quarter-final round of the annual member-guest tournament of the Hempstead Golf Club today by defeating Charles Lane and Gordon Painter of Plandome, 4 and 2.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 10 (AP) -- Texas pro-Roosevelt forces prepared today to attempt to persuade the State Democratic Executive Committee at Dallas Monday to submit the fourth term issue to the party's voters in the July primary. They had these two specific demands:

LONDON, June 10 -- Brushes with German destroyers, E-boats and other small surface craft have become increasingly frequent off the French coast and Allied naval officers expect the enemy to bring up whatever naval strength he has in an effort to sever the bridge of ships carrying supplies to Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's army.

METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER has hit upon a new method of acquiring story properties and is negotiating with several recognized authors to write novels around ideas suggested by the studio. This "novel-by-assignment" plan is to be along the lines of the deal made last week with Booth Tarkington and contracts previously signed with Carl Sandburg, James Hilton and Rose Franken.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, June 10 -- Five flight nurses, the first American women to serve under enemy fire on the beachhead across the Channel, returned to Britain today with three plane-loads of wounded from the battle area.

BEFORE Pearl Harbor and for some months thereafter, the Army of the United States was not singing. This condition disturbed the High Command because it is a military axiom that a singing army is an army with high morale.

EUROPE is crisscrossed by a web of canals more than 14,000 miles in length. Offering cheap trasportation, the artificial waterways have carried commerce which has brought wealth to Holland, France, Belgium and Germany.

ARGENTINA'S Government is currently holding an official exposition at Buenos Aires in commemoration of the 1943 revolution in which the regime of President Ramon S. Castillo was overthrown by an army group led by Gen. Pedro Pablo Ramirez, who became the republic's President and was ousted in February, 1944.
There is nothing more important to thin country than a complete social security system, which to be complete must be established on a national level, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

The arrival today in Philadelphia of the Flomarcy Line's latest ship, the Sete Cidades, and her docking at the company's new pier, No. 16 South, marks the completion of four years of operation by the organization between Portuguese and American ports, Jose Bensaude, president of the company, said here yesterday.

AS boys and girls always have been, today's youngsters are impatient to grow up, to be in on the worlds' work. It is a normal mood of youth, heightened in wartime when, as Dr. Karl S. Bernhardt puts it, "a boy may be old enough to fight and die for his country but not old enough to vote."

ON the eve of the beginning of its twenty-seventh season of free concerts on the Mall in Central Park, Wednesday night, the Goldman Band, that standby of New York's summer musical life, sends us a few pertinent statistics on its long history.

PARATROOPS and their close allies, the air-borne soldiers who are flown in by gliders or powered airplanes to the air strips that have been conquered by the parachutists, are perhaps the most spectacular military innovation of the war.

CAPT. SIGFRID ERICSSON, master of the Swedish exchange ship Gripsholm, is a kindly, soft-spoken man who likes people, and especially children. He also likes his job, which is shuttling his mercy ship between this country and neutral ports in Europe and Asia in the exchange of nationals of the United Nations and the Axis.

THIS wise and gentle book is a completely engaging account of the misadventures one fortnight in June of John D. Robins, a scholarly man who knows a good deal about how to catch fish in the lakes, creeks and rivers of Algonquin Park, Ontario, but who, with reason, calls himself an "incomplete angler," though occasionally he does have luck with his rod.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 10 (AP) -- Rear guards of Japanese forces fleeing the Kohima area in India fought pursuing Allied troops eight miles southeast of the city as the enemy apparently abandoned villages along the road another six miles to the south, it was disclosed today.

ROME, June 10 -- Prof. A.W. van Buren, acting resident director of the American Academy of Fine Arts, said today that the institution had suffered no damage or theft as a result of the war. For this he paid tribute to the Italian Government for its recognition of the Academy's cultural position and especially to the Swiss Legation for its protection.

Studies which show that American corporations other than banks and insurance companies have increased their working capital by almost 70 per cent since 1939 have been used by the Securities and Exchange Commission as the basis for certain amazing conclusions.

HONOLULU, June 10 (AP) -- The skill and daring with which Rear Admiral John J. Ballentine of Hillsboro, Ohio, commanded his aircraft carrier in recent actions in the Central and South Pacific has won for him the Navy Silver Star and the Legion of Merit.

A new plan of correlated and concentrated study is to begin experimentally at Rockford College this fall. Semesters are to be divided into terms of eight weeks each. Students will take fewer subjects at one time, but will have greater opportunity to concentrate on their program.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 10 -- Under a driving rain, with blasts of thunder and the fog horn on Execution Lighthouse for sound effects, the special regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club was held on Long Island Sound today.

In a recent Magazine of THE NEW YORK TIMES appeared a group of photographs of "Men of the Allied Armies." Conspicuous by its absence was a photograph of a Chinese soldier. As an "old China hand" and a great admirer of the Chinese people, I think that something should be done to correct an obviously unintentional slight to our one ally now on the threshold of its eighth year of warfare.

LONDON, June 10 -- The complete absence of German aerial opposition to the Allied invasion on D-day and the feeble, almost token, resistance since then has naturally brought up again that popular oft-asked $64 question: Where is the Luftwaffe?

IN discussing last week Mr. Edmund Wilson's lament for the departed atmosphere of the Nineteen Twenties, beside which he finds that of our own period so unpropitious for writers, I said that I had no wish to dispute his appreciation of Dorothy Parker's stories and verse, which provided a sort of text for his comments.

VISITING newly opened shows in the galleries was accompanied by peculiar stress of heart and mind. With invasion news turning New York into a community with but a single thought, a single voiced or tacit prayer, it seemed somehow a trivial thing to go about looking as usual at pictures.

The broad woven rayon fabric industry is the first of America's textile producers to be freed from major war obligations and can now see its way clear to devote practically all of its capacity to civilian production, a spokesman for the industry stated yesterday.

LIEUT. (J.G.) CHARLES MERGENDAHL, a Bostonian who entered the Navy in April, 1942, has since that date produced three novels and a half dozen short stories -- all written in between action at Casablanca. Sicily and Tarawa, and none concerned with war.

MOSCOW, June 10 -- The Red Army is believed ready to mount its biggest offensive in three years of warfare, in a final drive to carry out the fervent hope of all the Soviets' people that Hitler can be forced to surrender unconditionally in 1944.

ADD still another project to the Michael Todd schedule. The high-voltaged gentleman now has clinched plans for a production of "And Never Yield." This is the play Betty Smith, author of "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," adapted from the Elinor Pryor historical novel about the Mormons.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- The solemn prayers offered up this week throughout the Central West for the troops assaulting the European coast attest the people's awareness of the cost of the invasion in American casualties and the importance of "full victory" to the United States and other freedomloving nations. Prayer meetings, extensive in number and attendance, were held in houses of worship in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Wisconsin.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, June 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- Allied Headquarters announced today a reduction of malaria fever cases among American officers and men in New Guinea by 95 per cent in 15 months. Military leaders rank the success of the anti-malaria campaign with combat victories.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, June 10 -- The winning of a narrow beachhead along the coast of Normandy by American, British and Canadian soldiers in the first week of the invasion is a victory of the first magnitude and one that, as Allied plans in the west develop, will be recognized as a vital contribution to the grand strategy of the United Nations.
For the first time since 1928 the assessed valuation of taxable real estate and special franchises in New York City has dropped below $16,000,000,000.

IN 1820, when Sydney Smith, with calculated spitefulness, asked his famous question: "Who reads an American book?" there were very few American books worth reading. Then, and as if in answer to his implied challenge, began the long and distinguished period of American writing that was ushered in by Irving, Cooper and Poe and that was ended by the death of Henry James.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Auction of Alaska Sealskins, postponed from April, will be held in St. Louis, Mo., June 19, Harold Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, announced today.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 10 (AP) -- America's "fighting men" must return to find a victorious nation "just as effectively organized for peace as it now is organized for war," State Jewish war veterans were told by the national commander today.

BECAUSE all types of skin are affected by climate and temperature so that in summertime oily skins become more oily and dry skins become less dry, cosmetic authorities suggest a change in routine skin care.

Gov. J. Melville Broughton of North Carolina expressed belief yesterday that differences between the Roosevelt Administration and Southern Democrats now opposed to the re-election of the President would be reconciled. He predicted that President Roosevelt, despite these differences, would receive the electoral votes of all the Southern States and would carry the border States of Kentucky, Oklahoma and West Virginia.

CITY-BRED Janey Lovett, reluctantly arriving to spend a year in the country with her aunt and uncle, felt she deserved something better than the absent-minded welcome she got. But when she saw the cocker spaniel puppies whose simultaneous arrival had caused it her heart softened.
IN these climactic days of this war of the machine age, what are the most important weapons in the armory of Mars? It is an absorbing question and one that is difficult to answer.

MANY women are uncertain whether they should can as much this year as they did last. Their uncertainty, which is reflected in the planting of fewer Victory gardens so far this season, is variously caused. One factor is the "point holiday" affecting several commercially processed foods on account of their current abundance, while another is the left-over stocks of home-preserved products that may still be found in some households.

BLUEPRINTING the post-war world is in the nature of Sunday morning exhilaration. It sets moral standards. It formulates the desirable. It defines ultimate objectives. But it does not prevent the inexorable dawn of Monday morning with its familiar resurgence of unsolved perplexities.

CHUNGKING, China, June 10 (AP) -- Advancing Japanese forces have brought the Hunan Province capital of Changsha under heavy bombardment and are hammering down from the northeast and northwest amid raging battles against this major goal of an all-out offensive, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, June 10 (AP) -- Chinese forces threw a strong road block across the Burma Road south of Mangshih, and twenty-two road-miles to the northeast stormed the northern and eastern gates of Lungling after occupying the southern portion of that second most important base in Yunnan Province, the Chinese communique announced tonight.

The Moscow radio broadcast Saturday night a Tass agency accounting of lend-lease aid to Russia by the United States, Great Britain and Canada, declaring that up to April 30 the United States had sent arms, raw materials, food and equipment of a total value of $5,357,000,000, of which $4,612,000,000 worth had arrived in the Soviet Union.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., June 10 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam was assigned today as resident bishop to supervise the 1,438 Methodist churches in the New York area, succeeding Bishop Francis J. McConnell, who is retiring.

Of all names so far suggested for the present war, the one best liked by the President is "The Tyrants' War." It is at least better than "World War II." But doesn't it glorify the people who started the trouble rather than those who are going to finish it?

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, Before Caen, June 9 (Delayed) -- When Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel inspected this sector of the Atlantic Wall two months ago he remarked: "This is just the ideal spot for an Allied landing. It must be strongly fortified immediately."

In order to prevent a "wave of bankruptcy" in this city and throughout the State, Governor Dewey was urged yesterday by the American Business Congress, national organization of small business men, to call a special session of the Legislature to consider the plight of small merchants being forced to meet "exorbitant rent increases" in office and loft buildings.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 10 -- For the first time since the Federal Council decreed general mobilization in May, 1940, when it looked as if Switzerland might be attacked in an effort to turn the Maginot Line, an official Swiss communique was issued today explaining to the public recent measures that had been adopted to make defensive preparations commensurate with threatened danger.

A plea for immediate attention to the provision of counseling opportunities for men and women as they are demobilized from the armed forces is made in a special report prepared by the American Council on Education.

OF all the apologists for communism writing in English, Harold Laski is the most brilliant and the most plausible. He is a man of wide learning; he is unfailingly eloquent, and coins phrases and epigrams easily; he is master of an impressive oratorical prose; and if you grant his premises, he seems often to move to his conclusions with an unanswerable logic.
THIS is probably a story unique in the annals of experiences of commentators on D-day.

ABOARD THE USS AUGUSTA, Flagship of the Western Task Force in the Bay of the Seine, June 9 (Delayed) -- The American and British beachheads have been joined. Scores of thousands of Allied troops are ashore and more are coming.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the War Food Administration follows:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 10 (AP) -- The Berlin press sought today to answer the question apparently on the lips of most Germans -- "how could the Allies penetrate the Atlantic wall so quickly?"

MILWAUKEE, June 10 -- Claude (Buddy) Young, fleet Illinois freshman, led his team to victory in the twenty-third National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championship tonight -- as advertised -- but even without him the Illini probably would not have had much trouble in winning.

FREDERICK, Md., June 10 -- Minimum essentials for a world-wide educational program, adopted by representatives of thirty-two Allied and Associated Nations attending the International Education Assembly on the Hood College campus this week, are expected to establish the post-war pattern in the rebuilding of school systems in devastated Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Declaring that extracts taken by censors from international mail are "part of the secret files of the war," Byron Price, censorship director, refused today to turn over a file of such intercepts to a Senate investigating committee without a subpoena.

TO the biggest story that had come its way since Pearl Harbor, radio reacted with efficiency, good sense and an honorable respect for its audience. The confusions and the sorry lapses of taste of two and a half years ago were notable for their absence or, at any rate, their very small part in the mighty mass of material that went through the air on D-day.

One of the severest critics of American research in ESP (extrasensory perception) is an English Professor of Mathematics, S.G. Soal. He has swung about-face and reports, along with his colleague, K.M. Goldney, the most thoroughly convincing study of ESP that has ever been made. His outstanding subject is B.S., a London photographer.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 10 -- Columbia won two Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League games from Cornell today, 7 -- 1 and 1 -- 0, for a league record of seven victories and one defeat and clinched no worse than a tie for the championship.

ALGIERS, June 10 -- President Roosevelt's statement yesterday that he might receive a visit from Gen. Charles de Gaulle provided possibly a faint ray of hope for the clarification of relations between the Allies and the body which calls itself the Provisional Government of France.

AN interesting experiment in plumbing popular taste is being made this month at the Ferargil. A dozen New York galleries dealing in American painting have jointly put together a show of small and medium size oils and water-colors, selecting work at low prices -- $150 is the top figure. An even hundred artists are represented.

IF you have recently acquired an apartment that boasts a tiny terrace or a house with a real back yard, and haven't a stick of furniture to make this space livable, don't let this season's price tags on outdoor pieces of cypress and California redwood make you give up in despair.

LIEUT. ANDY BLAKE has a nice, safe desk job in the Pentagon Building in Washington. He also has a wife named Arabella (Arab for short), and she is anything but safe. She wants to win the war all by herself, and she begins by undertaking to smoke out a nest of spies who are gathering stray bits of information, piecing them together and transmitting the results to Berlin.

For weeks before the invasion of France the importance of the weather was dinned into us. Only when the weather was right, and that would be on some day in May or June, could surface and air transports and bombers move on an unprecedented scale, we were told. In May the Germans announced that Eisenhower had missed a perfect chance.

TOUGH PLASTIC -A new plastic, which seals radar and radio parts against harmful moisture, was given its first public showing in New York last week for the benefit of newspaper men. Because it was developed by Newton C. Foster, 29-year-old Westinghouse chemist, the plastic is called Fosterite. It will be especially useful in tropical climates, where the high humidity often causes short-circuiting and breakdowns in service.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The prices of all used passenger automobiles will be brought under Government control starting July 10 in an effort to stop the rise of prices which have gone up 30 per cent in thirty months, Price Administrator Chester Bowles stated today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- Except for the formality of playing an 18-hole round of golf tomorrow, Sam Byrd of Detroit was all set today to pocket $6,700 in war bonds.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (Delayed) -- Striking advances, with results that would have been termed fantastic a few years ago, are being made in the revolutionary fields of rocket warfare and radar by the Navy, which is also making strides in the making of warships, airplanes and ordnance.
LONDON, June 10 -- The Polish government-in-exile broadcast instructions tonight to Polish troops fighting in the German Army.

All of the largest manufacturers of hard surface floor coverings will probably continue to use felt backing for the majority of their products after the war, it was disclosed yesterday in testimony of several witnesses at a Federal Trade Commission hearing involving Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., at the commission's offices at 45 Broadway.

HERE is a legend of the Nativity which in Poland, where it has been told for generations, has no seasonal restrictions. Nor for that matter need it here, for the story of the Christ-child casts a spell which has nothing to do with the calendar.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10 -- A prediction that first-class mail will be carried almost entirely by air in the post-war era was made today by John J. Hart of Chicago, manager of postal service, United Air Lines.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 -- If Thomas E. Dewey is nominated to run for President, he stands to win a higher proportion of the labor union vote than any Republican candidate since 1932.

LONDON, June 10 -- It is not mere rhetoric to say that on the outcome of the battle that has just begun on the shores of Normandy depends the kind of world that will emerge from the struggle between fascism and freedom. It may be true, as Prime Minister Churchill said recently, that the war has become "less ideological in character" as it has progressed, although that is debatable.

The Brooklyn Tigers of the National Football League have acquired three players from the Washington Redskins in an even-up trade, it was announced yesterday. Ray Hare, Courtney Driscoll and George Smith will come to the Brooklyn eleven in exchange for Merlyn Condit, Joe Ungerer and Howard Callinan.

LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- German Channel forces were concentrating their submarine power today against Allied cross-Channel lifelines and American officers expected a crucial struggle in a big German naval effort within the next few days.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, June 11 (U.P.) -- An American and Australian naval task force, looking for a fight with the Japanese Navy in waters 80 miles northwest of Biak Island routed five destroyers in a long-range pursuit Thursday night that smashed the fifth enemy attempt in less than a week to reinforce or evacuate its Biak garrisons.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 10 (AP) -- A communique:

LACEBUGS are making an unwelcome appearance now on rhododendrons and azaleas, and to a lesser extent on some other plants. The injury is usually a general decline in vigor, coupled with unsightly foliage and sometimes dropping of the leaves, rather than sudden death.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- After eight weeks of interminable argument, objections, denials, exceptions and every other conceivable variety of legal legerdemain, the trial here in Federal court of twenty-seven men and two women charged with seditious conspiracy to create disaffection in the armed forces of the United States stands almost where it did when it began on April 17.

For many colleges today the post-war era has already arrived. Thousands of discharged veterans have returned to the classroom and are trying now to go on from where they left off two months or two years ago. A survey covering 1,000 of these ex-service men in eighteen colleges and universities reveals some interesting points.

Last week the Allies struck at western Europe in the greatest invasion the world has ever seen. An armada of 4,000 ships, an air fleet of 11,000 planes, armies from Britain, the United States and Canada, whole divisions of parachute and air-borne troops crossed the English Channel and won a narrow foothold on the coast of France.

THE golf addicts in this neck of the woods have been on extremely short rations ever since Pearl Harbor. They have had mighty few glimpses of their heroes in action because the United States Golf Association hastily closed up shop almost before the reverberations of the first bomb had died away. The professionals have been carrying the torch ever since with a rapidly diminishing membership roll but at least they have kept the sport alive.

AS the nation faces its biggest military campaign on a foreign front, it also faces its largest home-front campaign. The goal of the Fifth War Loan drive which starts tomorrow is $16,000,000,000, of which $6,000,000,000 will come from the pockets of individuals. It represents the largest sum ever asked of a people by their Government.

Allow me to congratulate you on your series of editorials on post-war gold and monetary problems. That of June 1 which highlights the truism that sound currencies can only be established if individual nations are willing to adopt Spartan internal policies essential to such stability is clear and to the point.

LUPINES by the million have run up light blue spikes of bloom in the most unhealthy-looking places along railroad tracks. Yet cultivated members of the same Lupinus polyphyllus as well as the multi-colored Russell hybrids so often tried have an infuriating way of seeming to forget the ease with which the wild forms thrive, nor does any amount of coddling do much good.

Spurred by the Senate's recent rejection of subsidies not financed by Congressional appropriations, after June 30, 1945, food manufacturers, now arriving from all parts of the country to attend the midyear meeting of the Grocery Manufacturers of America on Wednesday and Thursday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, will analyze all war-time food regulations, Paul S. Willis, president of the group, declared yesterday.

THERE is more significance in the title of this book than appears at first giance. Murder, as old Mr. Treves says in the prologue, is not the beginning of a detective story; it is the end -the zero hour. Before that must come the events leading up to the murder and the persons involved in it.

In THE TIMES Magazine two-page spread under the caption "I Am an American: A Creed and a Code," the pledge to the flag, alone among all of the excellent excerpts from speeches, poems and prayers which made up this spread, failed to give the name of the author.

WHEN this war's Erich Maria Remarque, in some future year, attempts to describe the psychological feeling of the German soldier during the terrible spring of 1944 he may very likely write: "At the time of the opening of the Western Front by the Allies, although our Wehrmacht was slowly retreating in both east and south, the Landser still thought we had a chance of winning -- because he believed in miracles."

ATLANTA, Ga., June 10 -- Increase of the authorized common stock of the Coca-Cola Company from 4,000,000 to 5,000,000 no-par shares was recommended today by the board of directors to stockholders of the company, who will pass on the proposal at a special meeting on Aug. 5.

ALL novels about childhood run the risk of seeming slightly childish. There are ways, of course, of circumventing this risk, such as the objectifying technique of "Innocent Voyage," which, by its ironic inversion of the formula, gives us a kind of horror that is characteristic of childhood in at least this sense: that it lies outside the realm of mature decision.

TWO years ago Gallaudet College of Washington, D.C., the only Government-supported college for the deaf, sent its dramatic club down to New York to give a performance of "Arsenic and Old Lace." The pantomimic eloquence of the performers strongly impressed the assembled critics.

With automotive shares leading, the market on the New York Stock Exchange continued yesterday to improve and volume was the second largest of the year for a Saturday. Turnover was 727,170 shares, only thirty shares below the record week-end market of the year, on March 18.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES IN FRANCE, June 9 (Delayed) -- The Germans are fighting guerrilla warfare in a desperate attempt to stop the steady progress of the Americans, and they are making great use of snipers.

LONDON, June 10 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle expressed dissatisfaction today with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's preparations for the administration of liberated French territory. He protested, too, against the Allies' issuance of French currency. It was the first time that the chairman of the French Committee of National Liberation, which prefers to be known as the Provisional Government of France, had publicly expressed his attitude since his arrival here.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Secretary Forrestal has ordered a strict conservation program at all naval shore establishments to conserve fuel of all types. The Navy said today that the Secretary decreed "drastic measures" because of "critical shortages" resulting from increased industrial requirements, movements of increasing quantities of fuel to overseas spheres of war, decrease in pro duction in some regions and, in some cases, insufficient transportation facilities.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Supporters of Governor Dewey were reported yesterday by The Associated Press to have thrown their weight behind Senator Taft of Ohio for the chairmanship of the platform committee of the Republican National Convention.

PORTLAND, Me., June 10 (AP) -- An attempt by organized labor to nominate a Congressional candidate and a three-cornered Republican contest for the nomination of governor are features of the primary campaign in this State.
CHUNGKING, China, June 10 (AP) -- A communique:
THE latest dose of culture in capsule form is Herbert V. Prochnow's "Great Stories From Great Lives," a series of sixty-odd selections extracted from modern biographies.

New York race-goers got their first glimpse of a triple dead-heat to win yesterday among Bossuet, Wait a Bit and Brownie in the Carter Handicap, featured event on Aqueduct's war charity day. The horses were so close together that not even the camera was able to separate them in the 46-year-old race.

CHARLES MORGAN, author of "The Fountain," "Sparkenbroke" and other novels about love and singleness of mind (also, incidentally, drama critic of the London Times), has taken time off to commemorate his publisher's centenary.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 10 (AP) -- A Federal court jury today convicted the Antonelli Fireworks Company and four of its officers on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government, but acquitted them on charges of conspiring to violate the wartime sabotage act.

Last week delegates to the Mississippi Democratic convention at Jackson threatened to bolt the national party if their wishes on several issues were not met next month in Chicago. Conventions in Texas and South Carolina had shown earlier that considerable anti-New Deal and anti-fourth-term sentiment could be found within the party.

I noted with interest your article regarding "I Am an American Day." In this article there appears "A Prayer for Our Country.'' This, you say, "was inspired by the prayer appearing at the end of George Washington's 'Circular to the States,' June 8, 1783."

The acquisition by the United Seamen's Service of a steamship that will serve as a floating residence and club for merchant seamen in the South Pacific area and also as a "mother" ship to the several USS recreational installations in that region was disclosed here yesterday by Douglas L. Baxter director of the overseas operation division of the service.

ROME, Sunday, June 11 (U.P.) -Dr. Vincenzo Azzolini, 64-year-old Governor of the Bank of Italy, was removed from office and placed under house arrest today amid a developing political housecleaning by AMG officials in which Prince Filippo Andrea Doria Pamphili was appointed Mayor of Rome to replace Gen. Roberto Benvivenga.

THERE wasn't one drooling bloodhound in Hinton Rowan Helper's nation-shaking book, nor any floating ice. Perhaps that is why it is now so completely forgotten, although any realistic list of America's Six Most Influential Books must include it.

Special services of prayer for victory and liberation were held in synagogues here yesterday. The spontaneous thronging of places of worship on D-day attested the underlying religious strain of the American people, rabbis declared in sermons.

WITH ALLIED FORCES IN FRANCE, June 10 (AP) -- Allied troops are battling from house to house in the northern outskirts of a village northwest of German-held Caen after experiencing a bitter dose of Nazi trickery.

The rain which deluged the city yesterday washed out a couple of daring experiments at the Polo Grounds. It also washed away a scheduled struggle between the Boston Braves and the Dodgers at Ebbets Field.
LI FU-SUNG, a wealthy Chinese, packed his bags, pocketed a fat checkbook and boarded a C.N.A.C. plane for the south.

WITH THE CANADIAN FORCES IN FRANCE, June 10 -- The third Canadian division has taken more than 1,000 prisoners and a heavy toll of enemy armor since it moved inland from the French beaches and took up positions on the front line of the beachhead between Bayeux and Caen.

LONDON, June 10 -- The thick, low clouds and rain that had deprived the Allied armies fighting in Normandy of close aerial support and cover for about fifteen hours yesterday and probably permitted the Germans to move up reinforcements and supplies, lifted today and the Allied air forces resumed operations with a sharp strategical blow at Berlin and a series of heavy tactical attacks at a wide variety of targets back of the French coast.

AS a participant of the testimonial dinner recently given at New York in honor of Dr. Koussevitzky and as a constant visitor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra's concerts for many years, I have witnessed with admiration the unique and long continued efforts of Dr. Koussevitzky in behalf of American composition.

THE value of liquid fertilizers, as well as their preparation and use, has been on the whole a field unexplored by the average Victory gardener. Closely allied to these fertilizers are starter solutions.

OMAHA, Neb., June 10 -- Reaction of the Middle West to news of the landings in France and the subsequent developments leaves no ground for suspicion of over-optimism or of a failure to appreciate the grim nature of the job which lies ahead. If people view this as the beginning of the final phase of the war in Europe, they show no evidence of believing the end to be near or attainable without costly sacrifice.

A concerted effort to interest the nation's public utilities in an over-all program for the heating of homes electrically is under way and has advanced to the point where a specific method has been developed for the power and light industry's appraisal.

For the first time in five years the House has risen in revolt against its Rules Committee, chiefly on the ground that the committee was "trespassing" on the functions and prerogatives of other legislative committees. One of the rebelling members denounced the Rules Committee for trying to set itself up as "a super-duper committee."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 -- The Princeton Development Coun-individuals and business enter-cil has issued a statement urging prises to prepare immediately plans for improvements to be effected when construction materials once more become available.
ALGIERS, June 10 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle is expected to make a quick journey to some part of liberated Normandy and then return here.

HAVING duly selected Doris Humphrey's "Inquest" as the best new work of the season, this department now proceeds to the next order of business in its time-honored tradition of prize-giving -- namely, the selection of the year's most promising debutante.

KEEP a tight grip on this story if you read it, for it is so light that it might easily blow away. It revolves around the difficulties of a beautiful divorcee and radio singer whose chief object in life is to prevent her 17year-old son from enlisting.

The country is facing a Presidential election in time of war. A Presidential election in the United States divides the country into two principal factions, one of which devotes itself to destroying confidence in the Administration which holds office and is, whether we like it or not, responsible for the framing of public policy and the conduct of public affairs.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, June 11 -- Two fierce tank and infantry battles are now raging around Carentan and Caen, focal towns at the extremities of Allied invasion bridgehead in Normandy, although the Allies continued to gain on the whole Normandy front according to last night's official Allied communique.

No doubt the author was an amateur diplomat, and subsequent events indicated that the possibilities of Polish diplomacy in the Soviet Union were limited.
