LONDON, June 10 -- Disorder is spreading over France, affecting the every-day life of more people in more parts of the country with each hour, according to French radio reports and other more reliable sources of information. Conditions are expected to become critical for the Vichy authorities and the Germans.
LONDON, June 10 (UP) -- Tonight's Soviet communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio:

The Fifth War Loan campaign, which starts tomorrow with the highest quota in history as its goal, will attract approximately $20,000,000 from local sports activities, according to estimates made by officials of the War Finance Committee for New York.

THE library on the war is a long one. High-class correspondents have wandered over the world, hobnobbing with generals and returning to write of them by their first names. Simpler newspaper men have gone into the fighting lines, encountering fewer generals but more GI's.

A battalion of 1,200 infantrymen from three crack regiments, including men recently returned from action in Italy, will parade up Fifth Avenue at noon today as a prelude to the opening in Central Park of a big Weapons of War Exhibit.
LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

With current Congressional hearings being held on bills to eliminate taxes on oleomargarine the Nutrition Foundation, Inc., yesterday revealed the results of certain tests. With carbohydrates substituted for lactose, oleomargarines, both animal and vegetable, show a slight superiority to butterfat according to recent experiments conducted by Professors P.W. Boutwell, Conrad C. Elvehjen and Edwin B. Hart at the University of Wisconsin, it was reported in the June issue of Nutrition Reviews.

MICHIGAN -- Music Divisions Changes in the curriculum of the University of Michigan's School of Music to conform with a revision of fee payments and the "more instruction at less cost to the student" policy approved by the Board of Regents at their last meeting, have been announced by Dr. Earl V. Moore, director.

OMAHA, June 10 (AP) -- James G. Patton, president of the National Farmers Union, charged today that "blind, greedy selfishness rules our food policy" and urged farmers and labor to "get together" to combat 'the stampede back toward scarcity in the post-war period."

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 10 -- The upset defeat of its outstanding player, Mrs. Helen Pedersen Rihbany, who ranks ninth nationally, failed to deter the New York women's tennis team today as it gained its third consecutive Sears Cup by defeating a Boston sextet,

" The voice of maritime labor, which has played such an important role in the successful prosecution of the war, has greatly matured in recent years, and this voice must be accorded a prominent part in the council halls that determine this country's post-war shipping policy," Harry A. Morgan, vice president of the Marine Department of the American Communications Association, declared here yesterday.

FORT WORTH, Tex., June 10 (AP) -- The Army Air Forces Training Command said today that ten screening boards were busy presenting a new program of AAF training to civilian flying instructors. It was stated that the program was "designed to reclaim for the air forces use of these groups:

SUPREME ALLIED ADVANCE COMMAND POST, June 9 (Delayed) -- General Eisenhower, who has directed the first 100 hours of Western invasion operations from a motor caravan bare of maps and documents, could move his command post to the Continent within a few hours.

Denying recent charges made by Dr. Hernane Tavares, Brazilian educator and special advisor to the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs in Washington, that relations between the United States and South American nations are deteriorating rapidly, six Latin-American editors and publishers affirmed yesterday their whole-hearted support of the Good Neighbor policy.

Winning his first championship double, Bill Hulse of the New York A.C. carried off the mile and 880-yard titles yesterday as the wearers of the Winged Foot ran away once again with the team laurels in the metropolitan senior A.A.U. track and field championships in rail-drenched Randalls Island Stadium.

Conscientious objectors have volunteered to serve as human guinea pigs in experiments to test the energy value of food rations issued to soldiers on the fighting fronts, said Ancel B. Keys (University of Minnesota) at a dinner given last week in New York by the Sugar Research Foundation. These volunteers make it possible to study the metabolism of sugar and its relationship to vitamins in the human system.

SACRAMENTO, June 10 -- Bills making available $112,000,000 for post-war State construction are on their way today to Governor Warren for his signature, and legislators, hurrying to complete their special session by Tuesday night, approved by unanimous vote a new pension system for public school teachers.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The correct title of the British Ambassador, since King George VI's recent Honors List, is likely to be the Earl of Halifax, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Ten new hospital ships, converted from former Army transports and cargo vessels, will be commissioned this month and will be used in evacuating wounded troops from the French invasion areas and other combat theatres, the War Department said tonight.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose last month from 1,090,581 shares of 624 issues to 1,181,293 shares of 662 issues, neither figure including short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers. This declined from 37,357 shares between April 28 and May 31.

The long-drawn-out dispute over the status of General de Gaulle and his French Committee of National Liberation may soon be settled and in a definite manner. The Allied invasion of France has begun. When it has liberated a sizable part of French metropolitan territory, the French people themselves may give the answer of the role de Gaulle is to play.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Tickets to the Republican National Convention are being guarded almost as carefully as the time of the European invasion and will be distributed to officials, delegates, reporters and visitors only two or three days before the opening of the convention June 26.

RYE, N.Y., June 10 -- A Kerry Blue terrier, formidable in appearance, stanch in his stance and sound in gait under strict observation, was declared tonight as the best of 1,405 specimens benched in the twenty-first annual exhibition of the North Westchester Kennel Club, held on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -All operations of the Army Air Transport Service within the Continental United States will be taken over by the Air Transport Command before the end of the year, and contract service will be terminated, the War Department made known today.

VAUDEVILLE comedians and radio gagsters have their own peculiar type of "joke session," comparable to the musicians' jam session, whenever they gather to talk shop and trade jokes without benefit of an audience.

NEW ORLEANS, June 10 -- The racial question will not go down as a political issue here in the Deep South. White Democrats of Louisiana are still insistent that a way must be found to keep Negroes from voting in their party's primaries.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 10 -Political unrest in the hitherto Solid South, which has shown itself in the recent Democratic State Conventions of South Carolina and Texas, flared anew this week when the Mississippi party organization jumped to the head of the Southern anti-New Deal forces with a resounding rebel yell.

LONDON (By Wireless). WITH a characteristic broad and crooked smile and a voice so calm as to seem almost superhuman, General Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Kansas boy who has a chance to join history's heroes in the gallery of military greatness, launched the largest amphibious force in history on the invasion of Europe.

THE Carmen (or she-spider) story pattern has always had an unholy fascination for American novelists and dramatists, and many have succumbed to their peril. For, as Somerset Maugham has pointed out in his memoirs, the Carmen story sounds better in French than in English.
THE battle in France belongs to GI Joe, as it has always belonged since war began, for his is the ground to fight on; the ground he takes is the ground that decides the war.

LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- French resistance to the Germans is rising, with sabotage and insurrection all over France, it was learned at Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Expeditionary Force tonight. Every French village, it was said, offers information, medical assistance and any other possible help to the Allies.

The auction committee of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, which has set June 27 as the date for its benefit sale of donated jewelry and art treasures at the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, will meet tomorrow at a "donation tea" at the home of Mrs. David Bandler of 787 Fifth Avenue.

AS our men and their comrades in arms stormed the beaches of Normandy, they went with the prayers of all the nation, but also after months of the most careful planning and detailed preparation. In sorry contrast to this readiness for D-day were the disclosures during the week that business planning for V-day is still confused and lagging.

The Socialist party will not put forward a candidate for United States Senator this year, it was decided by a narrow margin at its State convention yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Their ranks, depleted first by the formation of the American Labor party and then by the recent outcropping of the new Liberal party, the Socialists decided this major issue by a vote of 17 to 16.

RICHMOND, June 10 -- The landings in France are the chief topic of conversation in this region, as elsewhere, but quite a furor has been kicked up in Virginia by the action of Christopher B. Garnett, prominent Fairfax County attorney, and Rixey Smith, long-time secretary to Senator Carter Glass, in forming a committee of 100 to work for the re-election of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -Republican opposition to any commitments on a world currency stabilization program at the United Nations monetary conference flared again today with an assertion by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio that American involvement would he "like pouring money down a sewer."

The New York Diabetes Association, consisting of a number of leading diabetes specialists, announced yesterday that Camp Nyda, its special camp for diabetic boys and girls at Wallkill, N.Y., would open July 3, for its ninth consecutive season.
ONE of the simplest principles governing opening leads, yet one which apparently is very difficult for the bridge student to learn, is this: The lead of a worthless suit cannot directly lose a trick.

FIFTEENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Italy, June 10 -- Squadrons of Lightnings, in the longest fighter-bomber mission ever flown in this theatre, attacked the last major refinery still producing in the Ploesti oil fields today and left the target enveloped in smoke.

Though he was trained as a biologist under Thomas Huxley and others of almost equal stature, H.G. Wells was not a doctor of anything. Now he is. Recently he submitted to the University of London a thesis which earned him his new honor and which bears the learned title "The Quality of Illusion in the Continuity of the Individual Life in the Higher Metazoa, With Particular Reference to Homo Sapiens."

The first important golf tournament to be held in the metropolitan district in a long time will be the Red Cross open championship, which will get under way over the hilly Wykagyl Country Club course, New Rochelle, N.Y., startling tomorrow and continuing through next Sunday.

HARRY HAAG JAMES, hot trumpeter and orchestra leader, would as soon remain just that. His various trips before the camera, each succeeding one giving him additional acting responsibility, isn't stirring in him any of the usual fires of dramatic ambition.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet press release:

DALI's earlier work in prose, his "Secret Life," led one to expect from his first work of fiction -- if not instruction -- at least a mild sort of entertainment at his expense. But now, wishing "to approach the new times of intellectual responsibility which we will enter upon with the end of this war," he has, by no act of logic, written "a long and boring 'true novel.'"

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- S/Sgt. William J. Bordelon of San Antonio, Tex., died on Tarawa, but before his death he demonstrated that a single Marine can in effect operate as a one-man landing force.

A feeling of complacency resulting from temporary food surpluses has lulled the public into a false belief that food problems are over for the duration and as a consequence this has had a direct effect on the farm labor volunteer recruiting program, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, warned yesterday.

Overshadowed by momentous events along the Channel coast, Italy, first of the Axis countries to surrender and now counted "co-belligerent" with the Allies, was trying to solve its political problems last week. King Victor Emmanuel III, keeping a promise made last April, stepped down after almost forty years on the throne when the Allied armies reached Rome.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES in Normandy, June 9 (Delayed) (Reuter) -- Hitler's supposedly invincible Atlantic Wall is a sad spectacle of broken guns and pillboxes and ripped "secret defences."

LONDON, Sunday, June 11 (U.P.) -- The Finnish High Command said yesterday that Red Army forces, breaking a thirty-one-month lull on the Finnish front, had launched a strong general offensive on the narrow Karelian Isthmus above Leningrad, but Moscow failed to confirm the report, saying no changes had occurred on the Eastern Front for the third successive day.

PEARL HARBOR, June 10 (U.P.) -- Hammering at Japanese-held islands from Nauru to Truk, American aircraft staged at least ten attacks in the central Pacific in a three-day period ended Friday. Pacific Fleet Headquarters announced today.

NANTUCKET, June 10 -- To observe life on this island microcosm means to observe New England as whole during these parlous days of invasion. Although thirty miles at sea, basking in a deceptive atmosphere of peace, Nantucket looks at the sign on cobbled Main Street that has said "3,000 miles to France" for any years, and thinks poignantly of the Norman soil where her sons are fighting.

Eli Levenson, 43-year-old former New Yorker, whose aliases, according to authorities, areas numerous as his bail-jumping escapades, once more is in custody, it was announced yesterday by the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

MR. VEINUS, hitherto known as the author of booklets of musical commentary issued with phonograph recordings, has put a vast amount of descriptive and analytical material into this history of the concerto -- with enough biographical and anecdotal seasoning to make the dish palatable.

NINTH AIRFORCE FIGHTER BASE, England, June 10 (U.P.) -- Supplies with which the Germans hoped to hold Caen now lie scattered on roads all over Normandy or are immobilized in railway carriages that are helpless without their engines, Thunderbolt fighter-bomber pilots reported today after returning from one of their most successful missions against German transport.

FATHER FARRELL once held a job as cashier and deckhand on the Rockaway Point ferry. That may not seem like much of an achievement, but it probably explains why he is today the Rev. William J. Farrell, Port Chaplain for the Brooklyn Diocese.

THE hour of the Allied invasion of western Europe found short wave on the fringe of the continental fortress poised and in action within fourteen minutes of the first official announcement of the Normandy and Channel Islands landings.

ADIRONDACKS -- Not since the pre-depression summer of 1929 have the resorts in this area planned such extensive activities to entertain what is expected to be the largest contingent of vacationists in their history. Programs are being keyed to counteract the weariness of war workers and men and women of the services on furlough.

MR. MARITAIN states that he wrote the present essay in 1942 "from hope and from a deliberate will to hope," when the outcome of the war "could still seem very disquieting." The hope was and still is that of showing what direction must be taken if the war is not to prove vain and if democracy is to prevail.

WERE the scepter of the rose, the queen of flowers, to be given to any particular class, the hybrid perpetual would be a strong contender for the honor. Appearing in full bloom right now, this old class of roses under the test of time and the vagaries of climate shows no signs of deterioration.

Spurred by the Senate's action in approving loans on cotton at 95 per cent of parity and the escalator clause for price ceilings on cotton goods, the market on the New York Cotton Exchange opened steady yesterday and closed with advances of 6 to 10 points in active months.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN ITALY, June 10 (AP) -- A communnique:

ROME, June 10 -- The latest round in the fight that the House of Savoy is putting up to save the dynasty ended today in what could at best be called a draw. Prince Humbert returned to Naples with the cheers of thousands of Romans in his ears, but with a distinctly weakened political situation.

The War Food Administration appealed yesterday to housewives to buy extra eggs for storage in family refrigerators to help save 25,000,000 dozen eggs in danger of spoiling and at the same time explained its inability to offer price concessions. Last week WFA's regional office in Chicago announced the sale of seventy carloads of eggs at 5 cents a case to feed-mixers.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- The American Federation of Musicians convention voted unanimously today to sustain the action of the executive board in upholding fines and suspensions imposed by the Cincinnati local against two members of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, Reuben Lawson, violinist and personnel director of the orchestra, and William Morgan Knox, one of the country's better known violinists and chairman of the orchestra's committee.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 10 -- Although often described as the "hourse bourse" of the East, Hudson County today is not the bookmaker's paradise it was up to 3:30 P.M. yesterday, when fifty-four State troopers and the staff of Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper, raided four alleged wire rooms in Union City and one in Hoboken.

Impact of the invasion had little or no adverse effect last week on orders for some $3,000,000,000 or more of merchandise for selling during the second half of the year, which retailers have been placing in local wholesale markets, according to comment in merchandising quarters here.

THE fifty-fifth annual exhibition of American water-colors and drawings opened at the Chicago Art Institute last Thursday and will remain current through Aug. 20. The Watson F. Blair purchase prize of $600 was awarded to Jon Corbino for a charcoal drawing, "Mother and Child," and the Watson F. Blair purchase prize of $400 to Karl Zerbe for a gouache, "Still Life With Mirror."

TO the Thomases who doubt whether Americans are maturing politically, whether they are gaining in world-consciousness, let me suggest -- humbly, of course -- that they compare the number of books published since 1940 on the strategic junction areas of the world with the number published during any previous identical number of years.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Allocation of tantalum, new surgical metal, for first civilian uses was announced today on the eve of the annual meeting of the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The War Department, in a statement declaring the European invasion spearheads had involved the "greatest employment of airborne forces ever known," implied tonight that the equivalent of two airborne divisions had been ferried by air to France early in the Allied assault.

Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Prime Minister of the Polish Government-in-Exile, has arrived in Washington at President Roosevelt's invitation, with the knowledge of the British and Russian Governments. He is welcome, not only as the representative of his country, but because much of his career is what we have almost come to believe peculiarly American.

States' Rights and State pride are not always partisan politics invoked by the Outs against the Ins. Home town parades for the local boy who made good are not always the work of the local realtors and Rotarians.

Private Salvatore Abbate of 2310 East Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, was cited yesterday by the Regional Office of Price Administration for refusing to use black market gasoline while on a recent furlough.

Relief from drastic shortages of sole leather supplies is being looked for by the shoe manufacturing industry during the third quarter of the year through an expected revision of M-310, which will reduce quantities earmarked for the repair trade.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- Archie W. Goldstein, a 36-year-old Philadelphian, dressed in the uniform of a major and wearing the Purple Heart and service ribbons, was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents today, charged with "illegally wearing a uniform of the United States Army." He was held in $2,500 bail for the Federal Grand Jury.

What kind of songs does GI Joe like? Obviously, there is only one way to find out, and that is to approach dogfaces, tankers, paratroopers, gyrenes, pelicans, raiders, R.O.M.'s and o.c.c.'s for first-hand information. And so, with the aid of the War and Navy Departments, I asked literally thousands to send in, or at least name, the songs they and their buddies liked best and sang most often.

Unqualified support of a fourth term for President Roosevelt was voiced yesterday by State Communist leaders at a convention at which the New York party, following the lead of its national organization, formally constituted itself as the Communist Political Association of New York State.

INSPECTOR JIMMY WAGHORN and Superintendent Hanslet are good at digging up facts, but not so good at interpreting them. That is where Dr. Priestley comes in. He listens to what these two detectives tell him about the cases upon which they are engaged and throws out hints to show them where they are wrong.

Two-thirds of the winners of degrees will be absent from City College's ninety-eighth commencement exercises next Saturday night, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college. Degrees and diplomas will be conferred on 400 seniors in cap and gown at Lewisohn Stadium and in absentia to 974 students now in the armed forces or in war industries, a total of 1,374, or 31 per cent less than last year.
CHICAGO, June 10 -- The supply situation has created an exceedingly confused condition in the container trade, a check of trade sources here revealed.

WHAT vigils have these great dunes been keeping through the ages? Slowly, as the sea changes, do these billowing breasts of sand rise and fall and shift their silhouettes so silently, so slowly, that men cannot discern or date their hearings or their hollows.

ADMIRERS of "The Eagle and the Dove," Miss V. Sackville-West's recent study of St. Teresa of Avila and St. Therese of Lisieux, can hardly have expected that the same publishing season which brought that magnificent book would also give them an incisive, and in some ways comparable, study of the great Carmelite poet of the mystic way to whom Miss Sackville-West's "Eagle" served as a spiritual mother.

A price-freezing plan on low-cost clothing and essential home furnishings has been decreed in Argentina following initiative taken by producing organizations and retailers. Prices are roiled back to those of November, 1942, according to Textiles Panamericanos, Spanish-language textile manufacturers' magazine, published in New York.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 10 (AP) -- Declaring that strawberry prices were out of line in many parts of Connecticut, the State Office of Price Administration moved today to correct the situation, which, it said, was caused by a widespread but erroneous impression on the part of growers that the commodity was not under price control.

United States District Court Judge Vincent L. Leibell dismissed yesterday the complaint in an action to recover $1,500,000,000 from John D. Rockefeller Jr. and seven other defendants for alleged patent infringements of a gasoline manufacturing formula.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 10 -- A "commando" raid by a group of civilian scientists, a search through obscure seventeenth-eighteenth-century French manuscripts, months of study of geological reports, experiments with model beaches -- all these were a part of the Allied preparations for the invasion of Normandy that is one of the most remarkable stories of the war.

THE gold bar designates the rank of Nancy Randall, second lieutenant in the Army Nurse Corps. She is assigned to a camp in Texas and there she meets a man whom she has been trying to forget because he is married to another girl. She meets also another man who eventually helps her to forget.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Inductees will be put in a common pool after July 1 to be drawn upon as the needs of the various branches of the armed services develop.

The return of a number of important grass court fixtures which lapsed last year features the surprisingly heavy schedule of tennis events for 1944, released yesterday by the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association.

STOCKHOLM, June 10 -- Dr. Paul Josef Goebbels reacted to D-day exactly as he was expected to by anyone who had studied his propaganda methods. It appears that the Reich Minister for Propaganda and People's Enlightment was well prepared for the invasion.

FOR many years Jack Benny has been the undisputed master of the 7 P.M period on Sundays over the radio. Sponsors of other shows reasoned that there was not much point in competing with the NBC offering at that hour, because the comedian seemed to have a virtual monopoly on the majority of listeners.

LONDON, Sunday, June 11 -- The Nazi-controlled Vichy radio was heard broadcasting an announcement that Allied warships were bombarding the Mediterranean naval base of Toulon early today, soon after Swiss press dispatches reported that Berlin believed an Allied invasion of southern France was imminent.

Michael Lerner, who set all kinds of big game fishing standards before war put an end to that exciting avocation, is the new president of the International Game Fish Association, which is affiliated with the American Museum of Natural History. He succeeds Dr. William K. Gregory, president since the association was organized in 1939.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Premier Stanislas Mikolajczyk of Poland has made such a favorable impression on American officials during a week's visit here that hopes were reported rising for the re-establishing of relations between the Soviet Union and the Polish exiled government.

CLEVELAND, June 10 -- Great Lakes vessel operators are out to make this D-year and, to date, have shattered all existing records for the delivery of ore, coal and grain, statistics compiled by the Lake Carriers Association disclosed today.

DETROIT, June 10 -- The chief responsibility for combating "the moral and social evil of anti-semitism" in this country falls upon the Christian majority, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Detroit, the Most Rev. Edward Mooney, declared here in an address warning against "incipient and ofttimes covert attempts to stir up or to exploit class antagonisms."

A FACT more important to music than the professional relations of two conductors, however distinguished these may be, or whatever the nature of their relations, emerges from the announcement that Stokowski will not be joint conductor with Toscanini of the NBC Symphony concerts given for audiences of the air next season.

PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP) -- Elwin (Preacher) Roe, relief pitcher for Roy Starr, held the Cubs to two hits and no runs for five innings today to win his fourth victory of the season, 9 to 4, and give the second-place Pirates a game and a half lead over Cincinnati in the National League race.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, June 11 -- The Allied air forces, establishing their first bases on the beachheads in France, hammered German concentrations of troops and tanks, big gun positions and airdromes with hundreds of planes of all types yesterday after the weather had cleared and enabled heavy bombers to resume their support of the invasion.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- So many allusions have been made since Monday to "Paul v. Virginia" that some newspaper readers at least are wondering whether a French romantic novel was involved somewhere in the four-to-three Supreme Court ruling holding the $37,000,000,000 insurance business to the rigid controls of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

DURING the week beginning tomorrow, on a great many radio stations in this country, four special half-hour transcriptions will be broadcast. In an air that quivers with such inspiriting transcription - conveyed messages as "The World of the Future Can Be Made Beautiful With Slicksuds," and "We Can Win the War if You Buy Your Second-hand Car From Munificent Murphy," a third of a dozen more recordings may not appear sufficient cause for general excitement.

In an analysis of the Sinarquism movement in Mexico, based on the latest information available from first-hand sources, Edward Skillin Jr., editor of The Commonweal, a weekly magazine edited by Catholic laymen, concludes that it is an authoritarian and highly centralized secret organization led by zealous and high-minded men, one for which "there is some reason for the application of the fascist label."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Administration forces working for re-enactment of price, wage and rent control laws in their present form, were mauled in the House today where test votes carried by overwhelming majorities three proposed amendments which are opposed by the Office of Price Administration.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 10 (UP) -- Communique 9:

RHODE ISLAND, from Westerly to Wickford, is ready for summer vacationists. Beaches covering several hundred miles of shoreline will be open and surf fishing is once more a popular sport. The dimout of the past two seasons is a thing of the past. Again yacht racing will enliven Narragansett Bay, with practically all clubs planning regattas.

WITH Martin Dies' decision not to run for re-election, the Dies committee must cease to exist at the end of the present year. Presumably no other committee can fully replace it -- for this one, as time went on, became more and more suffused with the personality of Mr. Dies.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in Italy, June 10 -- The German forces in Italy, fleeing northward in a rout that, the Allies' Command declared, has become a "catastrophe," turned to make a stand of stubborn but not fully disclosed proprotions late today around a village some miles northeast of Viterbo, which is forty miles above Rome.
BROOKWOOD AMERICAN CEMETERY, England, June 10 (AP) -- The first American dead from the terrible battle across the Channel rested tonight beneath British soil.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (U.P.) -- A Senate Appropriations Subcommittee eliminated today from the War Agencies Appropriation Bill an item for $500,000, which the House had allowed for operations of the Fair Employment Practices Committee for the fiscal year to begin July 1.

LONDON, June 10 -- The indictment of seven high German officials charged with being key figures in the destruction of Lidice has been laid before the United Nations Committee for the Investigation of War Crimes.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 10 -- By use of mobile electric power plants installed in standard railroad, cars, damaged tanks, trucks and other important war equipment can be repaired close behind the fighting line, thereby saving valuable hours, often days in Russia's drive into the Nazi occupied countries.

THE learned medievalist and controversialist here sums up, with undiminished vigor as well as unaccustomed mellowness, what he is inclined to look upon as his two lives. Written by a historian who knows by experience why memoirs are significant, it is far above the common run of reminiscences, both in matter and in manner of presentation.

TWENTY-FIRST ARMY GROUP HEADQUARTERS, in France, June 10 -- To the Royal Canadian Air Force fighter pilots has been assigned the task of constantly protecting United States troops against enemy air attack on the newly established front in western France, and they're doing it with hearty good-will.

A net profit after taxes of 2.9 per cent was realized by the average wood household furniture manufacturer on sales in 1943, according to the twenty-fourth annual report on the furniture industry by Seidman Seidman, accountants. This compares with 3.6 per cent in 1942.

A FIRST-DAY (May 15) cover received from Rio de Janeiro by Stamps Magazine brings two unheralded commemoratives issued by Brazil. One is a l-cruzeiro blue picturing a statue erected in 1943 of the Baron of Rio Branco. This item commemorates the "Inauguracao do Monumento ao Barao do Rio Branco" (Inauguration of Monument to the Baron of Rio Branco).

THE spring fog is gone, and Scotty and Red and that whole outfit are a long way from here. But with Father's Day at hand the boys who are still here are remembering the morning when the fog lifted just long enough to get one ship into the air. Scotty Burke took it up, and the mists closed in again before he had his wheels tucked away.

A slowdown in the used car business, which has had a mushroom growth since the conversion of automobile plants into war factories, was seen yesterday by dealers as a sequel to the imposition by the Office of Price Administration of ceiling prices on used cars, to take effect July 10.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A shortage of track-laying tractors, power cranes and shovels and certain other types of construction equipment for civilian use has developed despite exceptionally heavy production last year, the War Production Board reported yesterday.

IT was a week during which a page turned over and they started another chapter in the history of the world. New York City, like every other small town, clung to its radio and bought newspapers as each edition was carried to the street.
LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- A German communique, from a Berlin broadcast:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -- A lesson in mass psychology, illustrating the ease with which the thoughts of a whole people can be channeled to a new direction, was furnished by the West Coast this week as Allied land operations began in western Europe.

From the fighting now in progress on the coast of France, in the most fateful invasion in history, the pattern of airpower begins to emerge. Thus far our superiority in the air clearly amounts to absolute dominance. It cannot fail to account in great measure for the comparatively light casualties suffered in breaching the "Atlantic Wall," the establishment of beachheads and the holding off of Nazi counter-measures during the all-important first days of our attack.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The State Department accused the Finnish Government of "pro-German sympathies" today as a result of Finland's suppression of a newspaper because of pro-Allied sympathies.

Steady retail trade was noted last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Most stores here closed early on Invasion Day, with one store remaining closed all day.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, June 11 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley summoned his old airborne Eighty-second Division and its flying twin, the 101st, to lead the invasion of Normandy, it was revealed today.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- A joint Congressional committee settled all its differences today and unanimously approved a broad legislative program of benefits for the veterans of this war.

HEADQUARTERS CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, June 9 (Delayed) -- Although Maj. Gen. Sung Hsi-lien's troops have been deployed around Lungling two days, that important Japanese Burma Road base refuses to surrender. Yesterday Chinese penetrated all the outer defenses and took the north gate of the ancient walled city, which is practically demolished after two years of intermittent bombing by American planes.

A JEEP roared down the runway of an American Air Force station in Northern Ireland, screeched to a stop near a group of soldiers, and a tall, 78-year-old matriarch stepped gingerly out.

THE Opera House here is doing something unprecedented this year -- it is valiantly keeping open its doors until the middle of July. Under ordinary circumstances the Algiers theatre season, such as it is, usually comes to a full stop in May, when the hot North African summer settles heavily over the city.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- Charlie Rufi's Mintlock, winner of the Tomasello Handicap here on Memorial Day, came back to win the $5,000 added Plymouth Rock Handicap of six furlongs today at Suffolk Downs before a 19,748 crowd.

Office workers, who for some years, especially since the start of defense and then war work, have been relegated to the background while their fellow-production workers basked in the limelight, are beginning to receive more attention than ever before, it was gleaned from talks and plans laid at the twenty-fifth anniversary conference of the National Office Management Association last week.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- If ever a matriarchate develops in the United States, it may well be that we are closer to it now than ever before, for the Census Bureau has just certified the numerical superiority of women voters. Among potential balloteers in the 1944 election, last week's computation indicated, there are 600,000 more females than males.

A 29-year-old parolee who described himself as Joseph E. McClain of 40 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, was arraigned yesterday afternoon in Stapleton, S.I., on a charge of stabbing Mrs. Elizabeth Boccuzzi, 22 years old, near her home at 6 Coursen Place, Stapleton.

LONDON, June 10 -- A tousle-headed Frenchman, wearing a civilian coat with an armband improvised from a strip of white cloth, came out of hiding in Normandy this week to join Canadian paratroopers in harassing the Germans who are arraying their divisions for a counter-attack against the Allied armies.

Under ordinary circumstances the Algiers theatre season, such as it is, usually comes to a full stop in May, when the hot North African summer settles heavily over the city.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- Charlie Rufi's Mintlock, winner of the Tomasello Handicap here on Memorial Day, came back to win the $5,000 added Plymouth Rock Handicap of six furlongs today at Suffolk Downs before a 19,748 crowd.

FOR half a century the name of Hensley Henson was a household word in England. Outwardly, he was as correct as a clergyman should be. He was swathed in a Bishop's gaiters and apron. He gloried in the silken robes of an academic divinity.

MOSCOW, June 11 -- The increasing collaboration of the peoples of the United States and Russia in the prosecution of the war and plans for preserving world peace was hailed today in editorials in the Russian press on the second anniversary of the master lend-lease agreement.

Universal Pictures will release fifth-five feature films during the 1944-45 season, of which seven will be filmed in Technicolor, it was announced by W.A. Scully, vice president and general sales manager, at a meeting of home office and sales executives at the Hotel Ambassador in Los Angeles.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 11 (AP) -- Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, in a message to his Twenty-first Army Group today on the first four days of the invasion fighting, said the Allies had secured a "good and firm" hold on the French mainland and were in a good position to exploit their success.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, Overlooking Carentan, June 11 (7:45 P.M) -- Hand-to-hand fighting has been raging for hours in the outskirts of Carentan. German paratroopers have turned down an ultimatum to surrender and they continue to fight back from behind concrete pillboxes.

The Republican party in its beginning arose from the people's urge to build a strong national government to offset the disruptive, weakening influence of the States' Rights Doctrine of the Democratic party. Paradoxically, now, in 1944, that same Republican party is urged to dedicate itself to the Doctrine of States' Rights.

LONDON, Monday, June 12 (UP) -- The Soviet offensive, launched by General Govoroff's Leningrad Army, which drove the Germans back from the former Czarist capital during the winter, opened Saturday and through last night had overrun more than eighty towns and settlements, including the coastal city of Terijoki, on the Leningrad-Viborg-Helsinki railroad twenty-eight miles northwest of Leningrad.

LONDON, June 11 (AP) -- The President of the Soviet Union, Mikhail I. Kalinin, in a message to King George VI released today, said the "landings of Allied forces which have begun on the territory of northern France give assurance that the combined blows of the Allies against Hitlerite Germany will be crowned with complete and final victory over our common enemy."

WASHINGTON, June 11 (U.P.) -- The Navy and Marine Corps Medal has been awarded to Lieut. John F. Kennedy, son of Joseph P. Kennedy former United States Ambassador to Great Britain, for "extremely heroic conduct" when his PT boat was cut in two and sunk by a Japanese destroyer, the Navy said tonight.

Many New York City restaurants plan to close shop and take a "vacation" this summer. A holiday ranging from one to two weeks and staggered among the various establishments has been adopted as a partial solution of labor shortages and food rationing difficulties.

Public interest is so absorbed by the overwhelming drama of European invasion that the war elsewhere has seemed to halt. Yet important events are taking place on the other side of the world, too. In China, where fighting is heavier than it has ever been, battles for two cities there underline its growing intensity.

NEW ORLEANS, June ll -- Uncertain crop prospects, a beclouded Washington picture and perplexities caused by the invasion scene combined last week to keep cotton futures on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange in a narrow groove after prices had established new highs for the season prior to the invasion.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- First steps were taken by Senator Robert Reynolds, Democrat, of North Carolina, today toward organizing a bipartisan group known as "the American Nationalists Committee of Independent Voters," which will try to elect persons of their views to Congress and "prevail upon the Democratic and Republican parties to adopt an America First platform in the interest of placing America first in American minds."

WITH UNITED STATES NAVAL FORCES, at Western Beachhead, France. June 8 (Delayed) -- I spent today touring our beachhead here, starting far out in the Bay of the Seine and going ashore and up toward the front and back again to the currently sinister sea.

One important factor which will determine the speed with which reconversion of industry will take place will be the prices that manufacturers are permitted to charge for their products. So far as we know, OPA has not yet decided finally upon its price policy for reconverted goods.
CHICAGO June 11 -- Demand for lard and dry salted meats has been relatively slow. in the last ten days, and some accumulation of these pork products is reported.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Nearly 40,000,000 Americans now have prepaid group medical or hospital care of some sort, the voluntary type as distinguished from the tax-paid, Government-controlled State medicine which the medical profession opposes.

CHUNGKING, China, June 11 -- The complete occupation of Lungling, the second most important Japanese base in Yunnan Province, was announced tonight by the Chinese communique, which called it "he greatest success to date for our troops in the Salween offensive."

Vincent Bendix, who resigned two years ago as chief executive of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, announced yesterday the formation of Bendix Helicopter, Inc., to produce a new type of helicopter carrying two passengers and baggage at a cruising speed of 100 miles an hour, as well as ten-passenger and twenty-passenger models based on the same principles.
Jake (the Ox) Finkel was shot dead yesterday morning in the first fatal flare-up of gang warfare in Brooklyn since Louis (Lepke) Buchalter went to the electric chair early in March.

Prof. Melvin Ott found the antidote for the Philadelphia jinx yesterday at the Polo Grounds. By force of numbers he overwhelmed them and with a flock of home runs he sprayed them, and the Giants bagged both ends of a double-header, to the delight of 23,526 fans who viewed the first victories over the Phillies this year.

CHUNGKING, China, June 11 (U.P.) -- Bitter fighting continued today on the outer defenses northeast of Changsha as the defenders of that Chinese strongpoint repeatedly hurled back attacking Japanese across the Laotao River, last defense line before the city.

One thousand men and women, each of whom had served at least 100 hours as a volunteer worker at the National Catholic Community Service Club and Cathedral Canteen for service men and women, received yesterday merit awards of the United Service Organizations at an open-house ceremony on the third anniversary of the club at 17 East Fifty-first Street.

LONDON, June 11 -- While Gen. Charles de Gaulle has said that he will be "honored" to discuss French problems with President Roosevelt, he has not yet announced which of the alternative dates that the President suggested will suit him better.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 11 (AP) -- The United States Twenty-ninth Division, disclosed today to be operating on the Cherbourg peninsula between Isigny and Trevieres, is called the "Blue and Gray Division" because its fighting men come from both sides of the Mason-Dixon Line.

MOSCOW, June 11 -- Scores of Russia-based Flying Fortresses joined hundreds of United States Fifteenth Air Force heavy bombers from Italy today in attacks by more than 1,000 of our big planes on the ports of Constanta and Giurgiu, Rumania, and Smederevo, Yugoslavia, a rail and oil center on the Danube between Belgrade and the Iron Gate.

PITTSBURGH, June 11 (AP) - The Cubs shut out the Pirates in both ends of a double-header today, 5 to 0 and 1 to 0. Big Paul Erickson let the Bucs down with two hits in the first game. The nightcap was a pitcher's duel, Bob Chipman allowing only five hits and two Pirate hurlers yielding the same.

PEARL HARBOR, June 11 -- Japan's three heavily defended bases in the Marianas Islands, Saipan, Tinian and Guam, were attacked yesterday by a powerful Pacific Fleet task force, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz reported today.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Frank (Stubby) Overmire pitched the Detroit Tigers into third place today by shutting out the White Sox, 1 to 0, on four hits in the second game of a double-header before 23,461 after the Chicagoans had rallied for a 4-2 triumph in the opener.

LONDON, Monday, June 12 -- The non-stop aerial support of the Allied armies in France continued through Saturday night and yesterday along the lines of the three-phase operations developed by American and British air power -- heavy bombing of main Nazi traffic centers and vital defense points, tactical bombings closer to the battle area and far-ranging fighter and fighter-bomber cover.

A plea for "true religious and racial tolerance" was made yesterday morning by Charles H. Tuttle former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. He spoke to 850 persons at the fifth annual communion breakfast of the St. George Society of the Department of Sanitation in the Hotel Commodore.

While voicing disapproval of the retroactive feature of Conservation Order M-317, the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York is urging its members to give the May 29 revision their fullest cooperation, according to W. Ray Bell, president of the organization.

NEWARK, June 11 (AP) -- Effective hurling in the clutches by Ken Holcombe enabled the Newark Bears to take the second game of a twin bill from the Toronto Leafs today, 4-1, and earn an even break before a crowd of 2,497. The Leafs captured the opener easily behind Al Jarlett, 7 to 2.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, on the Lower Cherbourg Peninsula, June 9 (Delayed) -- Forty tough Americans, fifteen of them infantrymen and others paratroopers, talked 120 Germans into surrendering yesterday without firing a shot.

Members of the Republican National Committee, dissatisfied with Harrison E. Spangler as national chairman, look for a change in the chairmanship immediately after the national convention in Chicago, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Great progress has been made by the Army and Navy in reducing the incidence of tuberculosis among their personnel, the annual meeting of the American College of Chest Physicians was told today, and confident expressions were made concerning the home-front situation also.

NAPLES on its lovely bay has inspired a proverbial expression of its beauty, "See Naples and die." Half a world away Hangchow, ringed by hills on which hangs a strangely beautiful purple haze, has prompted the Chinese to create a similar proverbial tribute: "Above is heaven; below, Hangchow." It was in this beautiful city of nearly one million that E.H. Clayton spent the greater part of his thirty years in China.

A German prisoner of war escaped early yesterday morning from Halloran General Hospital on Staten Island and became the quarry in one of the most intensive manhunts ever conducted in the New York metropolitan area.

Any plan of space allotment based on whether advertisers were well established and used space before the war would be detrimental to the advertising industry, according to media men yesterday. "War babies" may be taking up valuable advertising space under paper rationing conditions, but many industries starting in wartime have peacetime potentialities equal or greater to the "old-timers," it was pointed out.

PROCESSED FOODS (vegetables, soups, fruits and fruit juices, some kinds of dried beans, jam, jelly, canned and bottled baby foods and certain other special products). Only blue stamps and blue tokens can be used. Blue stamps A8 through V8 in War Book 4 are good indefinitely, at 10 points each. No additional blue stamps become valid until July 1. Frozen fruits and vegetables and dried foods, except certain kinds of beans, are now point-free.

Large price declines in livestock and apples contributed most to the recession in the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity 'prices, which declined last week from the all-time high of 113.02 to 112.95.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Details, of the caudal analgesia method of "painless childbirth" will be presented on Friday at the convention of the American Medical Association in Chicago by Dr. Robert A. Hingson, one of its originators.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 11 -- Sixty-eight starting yachts, the largest number of the season, competed today in the fourth championship regatta of the Manhasset Bay Club on the Sound. The fleet exceeded by nine the mark of the previous week.

Doubtless Sir Gerald Campbell, whose dry but ready wit seems to cause some hearers to overlook the sound common sense and wisdom of his remarks, could clear up for Albert A. Volk certain of the points he raises in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The battle in Normandy, which enters its seventh day today, continues with mounting fury along the whole Allied front stretching for some sixty miles from Caen to within sixteen miles of the coveted port of Cherbourg. According to the latest Allied communique, it is a mobile battle in which the lines change almost every Lour; but our supreme headquarters now announces that "the phase of securing the bridgehead is nearing a successful end."
PHILADELPHIA, June 11, (AP) -- Sam Byrd, former Yankee outfielder, coasted to victory today in the $17,500 Inquirer invitation golf tournament, and pocketed the first prize of $6,700 in War Bonds.

Your fisherman in Topics of The Times of June 5 states: "The best fishing is done from a small boat." Alas! is his fishing experience limited to dropping a line from a boat -- from an excursion boat crowded with hundreds of others ?

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The House Judiciary Committee today blamed the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Supreme Court for "causing the destruction of hundreds of millions of dollars of railroad securities."

The fact that the Germans thus far have made a remarkably small showing in the air against our invasion has created a wave of optimism. On the whole I share in this optimism. All the same, feel that it is too soon to assume that the Luftwaffe is dead.
LONDON, June 11 (UP) -- German communique as broadcast from Berlin:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 11 -- The first helicopter production line in the world was shown here today to newspaper men at the Sikorsky Aircraft Division of the United Aircraft Corporation as part of an "open house day" for employes and their families.

I Eastern and Western faiths joined yesterday to consecrate the Cathedral of St. Sava, 15 West Twenty-fifth Street, elevated from pro-cathedral to become the first cathedral of the Serbian Orthodox Church in this country.
LONDON, Monday, June 12 (UP) -- The Russia Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Mr. Warren's strictures in your issue of June 8 upon the two recent 4-3 decisions of the United States Supreme Court seem to me to be unfounded in two respects. The century-old precedents he relies on are not relevant. This is not the first time the Supreme Court has decided a constitutional issue by a 4-3 decision.

LONDON, June 11 -- The prospect that if sufficient penicillin becomes available battle wounds might be prevented from becoming infected or, if infected, they might generally be cured in a month was held out today by Sir Alexander Fleming, discoverer of the wonder drug.

ALGIERS, June 11 -- Armed with the authorization of General de Gaulle's statement yesterday, the ultra-nationalist press here gave even fuller rein than usual today to its suspicions of the Allies' motives regarding France.

HEADQUARTERS OF FOURTEENTH UNITED STATES AIR FORCE, June 11 (U.P.) -- The Japanese drives against the Canton-Hankow railway and United States air bases in eastern China represent the most critical battles in China since the enemy capture of Hankow and Canton in 1938, and their outcome may mean a difference of years in the termination of the war in the Far East, Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault said today.

A fervent hope that there will not be another "lost generation" was expressed yesterday afternoon by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York, who presided at the eleventh annual Corpus Christi celebration on the campus of Fordham University.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Liquidation in rye developed last week on the Chicago Board of Trade and July sold within 1/8 cent a bushel of the seasonal low and the deferred months went into new ground. There was, however, a strong rally yesterday as the result of the announcement that the War Production Board had ordered distillers to Use up to 10 per' cent of rye in production of industrial alcohol.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 11 (UP) -- A communique:

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 11 -- A temporary asylum in the United States for Jewish refugees from Nazi Europe, underwritten by American Jews, was proposed today by Herman Hoffman of New York, grandmaster of the Independent Order Brith Abraham at the opening of the order's fifty-seventh annual convention at the Steel Pier.
NAPLES, June 11 (UP) -- A communique:

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) - Staging rallies in the fith inning of each game today, the Athletics swept both ends of a double-header with the Senators, 6 to 1 and 6 to 5, before 18,691 to push the Senators into last place.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES FIGHTING BEYOND BAYEUX, June 10 (Delayed) -- American and British ground, naval and aerial forces have smashed a savage German attempt to cut the Caen-Bayeux road and the Germans are now trying desperately to build a new defense line, with the aid of forced French peasant labor, along the slopes and through the woods and meadows south of the road.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, June 12 (U.P.) -- United States Liberator bombers flying from southwest Pacific bases destroyed twenty-two parked Japanese airplanes in an attack Friday on Palau Island in the western Carolines, while other American airmen on Saturday sank an enemy 1,000-ton freighter, six coastwise vessels and a barge off Netherland New Guinea, it was announced today.

ALBANY, June 11 -- Governor Dewey and legislative leaders have authorized an allocation of $103,350 from the State Emergency Fund to finance a plan to provide more facilities for boys committed for juvenile delinquency to the State Training School at Warwick.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 11 (AP) -- Communique 11:

A day in advance of the official start of the Fifth War Loan Drive, Brooklynites began their drive yesterday to raise the borough's quota of $269,994,000 with a "Salute to the Heroes" rally in Prospect Park.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. AUGUSTA, Flagship of the Western Task Force, in the Bay of the Seine, June 10 (Delayed) -- Today we went with Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley and some of his staff in a PT boat to our western beachhead.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force. Monday, June 12 -- Two American divisions have captured the tiny town of Lison, five miles southeast of Isigny, and have fought their way across the flooded country another six miles to the edge of Foret de Cerisy, where, after a general advance of almost eight miles, they threatened the Germans' hold on St. Lo, chief enemy communications center for the Cherbourg Peninsula south of Carentan.
LONDON, June 11 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe announcement:...

IRUN, Spain, June 11 -- French patriots have occupied strategic centers in the cities of Toulouse, Limoges and Tarbes in southern France and have shot the prefects of police, Mayors and other collaborationist authorities in all three cities, direct dispatches reaching here said today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (delayed) -- A highly significant experiment is being completed at the Naval Proving Ground in Dahlgren, Va., headquarters for testing of Navy ordnance. The marines, who died on Tarawa last year because the Navy's big guns and bombs had not reduced the enemy's concrete and log fortifications, are responsible for it.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- China was revealed tonight to be essentially in agreement with the State Department's post-war aviation objectives of right of innocent passage for international airlines and elimination of unnecessary barriers to the growth of worldwide commercial flying.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 (AP) -- The league-leading St. Louis Browns salvaged the final contest of a four-game series with the Cleveland Indians in the second game of a double-header today, 4 to 2, when Pinch-hitter Gene Moore delivered a grand slam home run with the bases loaded in the last of the seventh inning.

PHILADELPHIA. June 11 -- Electric and gas operating utility companies in the United States earned last year interest on funded debt 3.10 times and fixed charges and preferred dividend requirements 1.81 times, it was shown today in an annual summary prepared by the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BOSTON, June 11 -- To the eminent satisfaction of 23,657 Hub enthusiasts, our sorely beset Yankees went crashing down to two more defeats today as Joe Cronin's Red Sox wrested both ends of the afternoon's double-header from the McCarthymen to score a clean sweep of the four-game series.

CINCINNATI, June 11 (AP) -- The Cardinals gave the Reds a double beating before 24,337 fans today, 3 to 1 and 4 to 1, and at the same time set a National League record for double plays in twin bills with nine.

LONDON, June 11 -- Civil affairs units of the Allied Expeditionary Force were landed in France by gliders with the first airborne detachments on D-day, it was disclosed today. These men, whose job it is to establish normal government in captured towns and to make sure that civil problems do not interfere with tactical operations, were on the spot before any towns had been captured.

Three art exhibitions will open today. Paintings by a group of contemporary American artists will be seen at the Milch Gallery, to continue, with occasional changes, through the summer. A show of oils and water-colors by another contemporary group will open at the Morton Gallery.

THE Fifth War Bond drive opens today. The timing on it was perfect, even if accidental. The only possible improvement would have been to have had the drive for funds coincide precisely with the invasion drive for France. But our boys still are On the invasion beachheads of Normandy and there should be no necessity whatsoever to urge every one of you to purchase bonds to the very limit of your financial endurance.

Hailing the invasion as the dawn of deliverance, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "we are witnessing again the age-old lesson -- that the nation which forgets the eternal distinction between right and wrong goes down to destruction."

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The American Red Cross, whose regular staff numbers 19,098 men and women but whose efforts are aided by an army of 6,500,000 volunteers, gave today a financial account of its stewardship. The report showed the use made of $218,367,- 339 raised in the first and second war fund campaigns of December, 1941, and March, 1943, and other funds.
Six new films, including a Russian documentary and a Mexican -offering, are scheduled to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Prices of cotton for future delivery continued last week to gain ground with active deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange setting new life-of-contract highs. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the Exchange showed for the week net gains of 23 to 30 points.

PITTSBURGH, June 11 -- Invasion news reaching the steel trade last week was expected to renew pressure for deliveries of those steel items needed most at the war theatres. The need for prompt deliveries and the seriousness of any retardation in output were expected also to have some effect upon partially solving such problems as strikes, manpower difficulties and steel scheduling problems.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Amplifying remarks he made before the Cosmetic Division of the Fashion Group in New York last Thursday, Dr. Louis Schwartz, medical director, dermatoses section, United States Public Health Service, declared here last night:

MOSCOW, Monday, June 12 -- The Soviet High Command, through Premier Stalin, announced last night the opening of a new offensive against German and Finnish troops on the Karelian Isthmus, breaking through fortifications on a twenty-five-mile-wide front and driving forward fifteen miles.

RYE, N.Y., June 11 -- Under the slanting rays of a June sun many hundreds of canine enthusiasts stood about the ring on the expansive polo field of the Westchester Country Club this evening to enjoy the final judging in the twelfth annual exhibition of the Longshore Kennel Club.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA. Monday, June 12 (UP) -- A communique:

Parades, dramatic presentations, orations and startling outdoor displays usher in today the Fifth War Loan Drive, in the course of which this nation will be asked to purchase sixteen billion dollars worth of good Government paper, or about $120 worth per capita.

Announcement of the new Russian offensive against Finland drew as much applause yesterday at the convention of the freshly constituted Communist Political Association of New York State as did the election of officers, headed by Gilbert Green of the Bronx.

The 131st annual Grand Conclave of the Grand Commandery, Knights Templar of the State of New York, representing eighty-two commanderies, opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Officers met in executive session in the morning.
WITH AMERICAN AIR-BORNE TROOPS, Somewhere in France (Delayed) -- When Lieuts. Charles Devine and Carl Miller get captured they make it worth while.

The Red Cross open championship -- the first golf tournament of any consequence to be held hereabouts in many a day -- will begin at the Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle today. Play in the event will go on all week, with the concluding matches scheduled for Sunday.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 11 -- Admiral W. F. Halsey, Commander of the South Pacific Force of the United States Pacific Fleet, in a statement made for The Church Congress, urged the church to satisfy "the religious needs of returned fighting men who will seek virile spiritual help during the readjustment period."

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The War Production Board issued to-lay a classification of the entire cotton textile industry which establishes an "urgency rating" for every construction of cotton fabric n terms of military or essential civilian need and the relative shortage of each material, yarn, cordage and twine.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 11 -- Edmund H. Driggs Jr. of Sleepy Hollow, only former M.G.A. title-holder in the field of forty-nine won the medal in the Westchester-Fairfield division qualifying round for the forty-second Metropolitan amateur championship with a 74 over the west course at Winged Foot this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- War workers as a group were accused today by the American Automobile Association of reckless use of the highways, complete disregard for wartime speed regulations and notorious indifference to any and all measures of car conservation.

TWENTY-FIRST ARMY GROUP HEADQUARTERS, June 11 -- How the invasion alarm was flashed along the Atlantic Wall before dawn on D-day was told to American and British officers today by a Polish farmer impressed into the German Army and captured by the Americans after two days' anxious waiting in a trench.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 11 (AP) -- Montreal gained a 3-to-2 edge for its five-game series with Jersey City before 7,045 today by coming back to win the nightcap, 10 to 9, in twelve innings after the Little Giants had captured the opener, 1-0.

If the fall of Rome, which became known on Sunday, June 4, had occurred alone, the phenomenon of "realizing on expected good news" would probably have followed. But Monday, with its loss of ground on the Stock Exchange, was hardly over when the news was broadcast of large-scale Allied invasion of Normandy.

Eight Negro hoodlums, 15 to 17 years old, terrorized more than a hundred passengers on a Brighton Beach Line BMT subway train bound from Coney Island to Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, last night, and when one of the passengers objected they felled him with a blow and, while he was lying prostrated, shot him twice.
A novel by Aldous Huxley called "Time Must Have a Stop" will be published by Harper'8 Aug. 23. This is the f/t book to follow 2Vfr. Huxley "The Art of Seeing," ! which appeared in October, ;1942.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 11 -- Official German quarters announced tonight that the Germans in Paris had ordered the cessation of all private telephone and telegraphic communication throughout the Paris region and inside the city.

These are times when, in the midst of many uncertainties, our thoughts turn toward basic things. Prayer, for instance. In this past week, since the invasion began, one has literally seen prayers everywhere.

ROME, June 11 -- The German rout in Italy spread to all sectors of the front today as the British Eighth Army captured the road junction of Avezzano, forty-eight miles east of Rome, in a drive that threatened the avenues of retreat for German forces fleeing from the Adriatic sector after having abandoned the strongholds of Pescara, Chieti and Sulmona.

Plans to expand the Civil Air Patrol Cadet program for high school students 15 to 18 years old from a force of 1,000 to 20,000 in New York City and to include both boys and girls, were announced yesterday by Major Thomas F. Cooke, commander of the Greater New York Cadet Training Group.

In your editorial of June 8 and in your headline to Professor Warren's article on the recent decision in the insurance company case you seem to imply that the Supreme Court has split 4-3 on a constitutional question, thereby departing from the practice of the court as enunciated by Chief Justice Marshall, not to deliver any judgment on a constitutional question unless a majority of the whole court concur

The Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Ascension, declaring that he owed sole allegiance to his work as chaplain in the Navy, has declined the high office of Bishop Coadjutor of Michigan to which he was elected last month.

With the aid of nostalgic songs from the horse-and-buggy days and a few feats of derring-do, the theatre of a bygone era is spoofed in "Broken Hearts of Broadway," opening tonight at the New York Music Hall, 205 East Sixty-seventh Street, under the auspices of Selected Artists, Inc., in association with Alan Corelli.

LONDON, June 11 -- With the great exodus of Allied troops from Britain to the Continent, London, for several years the play center for servicemen on leave, has almost returned to normal.

The internal row between the adherents of Serbian separatism and the present Yugoslav Government-in-Exile flared up again when Philip Lazo Markovich, former president and afterward secretary of the Serbian National Defense Committee, was arrested yesterday morning amid the congregation of the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava, 15 West Twenty-fifth Street, just before consecration ceremonies.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 11 -- Fighter pilots of the United States Eighth Air Force, who, until six months ago, were concentrating on high-altitude escort of bombers attacking Germany, have spent the past five days skimming housetops and hedges in Normandy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will transfer its filming of Robert Sherwood's Pulitzer Prize play, "There Shall Be No Night," to England so that Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt, now appearing in the play in London, can do the picture.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Considerable improvement is reported in the outlook for the winter wheat crop last month, a Department of Agriculture estimate suggesting a yield of 714,000,000 bushels, a gain of 52,000,000 bushels compared with May 1, and 284,000,000 bushels in excess of the final returns last year.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The value of new construction in the United States fell for the twentieth consecutive month in April to $284,813,000, which was 3 per cent under March. Seasonal increases in May, the War Production Board stated, were expected to reverse this trend for the first time since war construction hit its peak in August, 1942.

Overcoming their own misplays and the relief pitching of Stanley (Klippety) Klopp, the Dodgers yesterday regaled 22,134 Flatbush fans with a tenth inning, 5-4 triumph over the Braves at Ebbets Field. Then, with a deceptive appearance of superiority, they scored four runs in the first frame of the nightcap off Red Barrett, only to blow that contest later by an 8-5 score.

The Morgan Strasser soccer team of Pittsburgh, beaten in the national challenge cup final, was unsuccessful again yesterday. Defending the amateur cup of the U.S. Football Association against the Eintracht eleven of Astoria at Starlight Park, the Bronx, the Western eleven was turned back, 5-2, before 4,500.

Taken over by the Navy fourteen months ago, Harts Island, formerly a city prison, is now the scene of an intensive and successful rehabilitation program for recalcitrant sailors that is restoring 90 per cent of the men involve to usefulness in the fleet.

Winners of gold certificates in the Music Education League's twenty-first season auditions gave their concert in Town Hall yesterday afternoon, followed by presentation of awards to all students registered in the auditions of the league's twentieth season.

Rear Admiral C. E. Rosendahl, the stanchest supporter of lighter-than-air craft in the country, again urges the inclusion of large rigid airships as one factor in the transportation picture of the air age to come. In an article with Kyle Crichton in Collier's Magazine, he makes a persuasive case for the economy and utility of the airship as a commercial carrier.

MUSKEGON, Mich., June 11 (U.P.) -- Paul V. McNutt, head of the War Manpower Commission, warned today that as the greatest struggle in history moved toward a climax thousands of non-essential workers would be asked to fill vital jobs in places other than their own communities.

The number of buyers in the New York wholesale markets reached a very large figure last week, with activities outstanding. There was very little buyer reaction to news of the invasion. A certain amount of caution had been in evidence previously on some fall lines, but the invasion itself caused no additional care in forwad purchasing, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WITH UNITED STATES PARATROOPS N FRANCE, June 8 (Delayed) -- In a duel in which every bullet counted, American paratroops today shot up a force of German paratroops more than double their size, killing several hundred and capturing more than 1,000.

There are a number of pleasant and satisfying aspects about scarecrows. In the first place, they have solid historical tradition. A second major point, entirely compatible with the tenets of democracy, is that the construction of one allows for individuality and initiative.

Four public schools have been selected for an experimental summer program whereby activities of play schools and playgrounds will be combined under one head and operated as one unit, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Adele S. Mossler, director of the Play Schools Association, and Francis Brennan, acting director of the Division of Recreational and Community Activities of the Board of Education.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 11 -- George Jenkin and Frank Graven, Plandone, disposed of the medalists, William Lees and Dr. O.V. Wibell, Cherry Valley, 2 and 1, in the semi-final of the annual Hempstead Golf Club member-guest tournament today.

NAPLES, June 11 -- An unprecedented raid by British, American and Partisan forces, which lasted nearly five days and resulted in wiping out German installations at the port of Bol on the Yugoslav island of Brac, took place between June 1 and 5, it was revealed here today.

The airlines should adopt a more forthright policy in dealing with civilians. The chances of getting through on a trip of any appreciable distance are nil, yet the airlines will say that the trip has been cleared to destination or to a certain city at the time the passenger leaves for the airport.

Two of New York's oldest child caring agencies, the New York Child's Foster Home Service, 121 years old, and the Sheltering Arms, formed during the Civil War, will be merged soon, according to an announcement by Paul Cushman and Thomas M. Peters, presidents, respectively, of the two centers.

Although ice cream can stand alone any day so far as its adherents are concerned, most people concur that it's just that much better when served with a good sauce. A recent investigation revealed that several kinds of prepared sauces are being offered in city stores.

Stalwart American infantrymen -- many of them recent veterans of the fighting in Italy -- swung up Fifth Avenue yesterday between massed crowds of men, women and children estimated by the police to number 550,000, as New York City "jumped the gun" by one day on the rest of the nation in launching the Fifth War Loan drive.

HEADQUARTERS, TWENTY-FIRST ARMY GROUP, in Britain, June 11 -- There was a calm, flat sea today and the ferrying of supplies and their unloading on the French beachhead went forward at the highest rate yet.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Congressional leaders were hoping today that they could get sufficient work out of the legislators in the next fourteen days to assure a vacation of five weeks.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 11 -- Dom Morano of Branch Brook fired a one-over-par 71 at the Montclair Golf Club today to lead a field of thirty-nine in the New Jersey section of the qualifying round for the Metropolitan Amateur Championship.

LONDON, June 12 -- To those who know him the news that Mr. Churchill had visited the invasion beachhead on an inspection tour came as little surprise. It had been suspected that he was harboring some such idea ever since the invasion started, and the suspicion was strengthened when he refused to give assurance in the House of Commons that he would not so risk his life.

DETROIT, June 12 (AP) -- Led by the second-seeded Miss Doris Hart of Miami, Fla., and Billy Talbert of Indianapolis, favorites dominated opening matches of the week-long national clay court championship today at the Detroit Tennis Club.

Last year President Roosevelt set aside the old trappers' rendezvous of Jackson Hole, Teton County, Wyoming, as a national monument -- in effect, a park. He did this under authority of an act passed in 1906 under a Republican President, Theodore Roosevelt, and the public lands thus set aside were free for such disposal because another Republican President, Calvin Coolidge, had withdrawn them from entry.

Those 4,000 vessels that carried and continue to carry troops and supplies to Normandy have done a big enough job to make us appreciate at something like its real value the role of the Merchant Marine. Immense as is this cross-Channel service, it is but a larger chapter in the great book of achievements.
