WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Miss Mary Anderson, who has been director of the Women's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor for twenty-five years, and long an advocate of equal-opportunity, equal-pay principles for men and women work ers, has made known her intention to resign soon.
Led by the strength in the July delivery the cotton futures market here again inched upward yesterday and closed steady, 6 to 9 points higher on active months.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Office of Price Administration, seeking a substitute for its over-all general maximum price regulation at the retail level, will confer soon with a "task committee" of trade executives on a proposed plan for controlling most retail prices under a broad uniform "historic mark-up" procedure.

ROME, June 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Margaret Roosevelt Pallavicini, cousin of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, escaped harm at the hands of the Germans by hiding in a convent in Rome with her 6-year-old daughter, Julia, throughout the German occupation of the capital.

The Senate has passed an inflation bill instead of a measure to extend the Price Stabilization Act. The bill insures a rise in textile prices and a rise in wages for those earning less than $37.50 weekly; it weakens enforcement of price ceilings; it once more increases the loan rate on basic agricultural commodities.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiary companies of the United States Steel Corporation in May amounted to 1,776,934 tons, an increase of 20,137 over the 1,756,797 in April, the corporation announced yesterday. This also was an increase of 70,391 tons over the 1,706,543 shipped in May, last year.

Americans at home command two of the most effective weapons of this war -- money and morale. Today, with the opening of the $16,000,000,000 Fifth War Loan Drive, we will have an opportunity to prove whether we can translate those weapons into the tanks, planes and ammunition our armed forces need on freedom's battlefronts from the English Channel to the Coral Sea.
LONDON, June 12 -- The first American Red Cross girls to go to France landed today at one of the American-held beachheads in Normandy.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 13 (U.P.) -- Red Army tanks and infantry met stiffened Finnish resistance yesterday in the drive that was moving swiftly toward the heart of the Karelian Isthmus.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Roosevelt was reported today as being embarrassed by the injection of "politics" into railway labor disputes by some of those close to him as a result of the wage controversies of last fall and winter.

Effective today will be Brazil's debt refunding plan covering thirty issues of dollar bonds aggregating $286,065,645 face amount, according to representatives of the Brazilian Government now in the United States, Valentim F. Boucas, member of the Council of Economy and Finance, and Claudinor de S. Lemos, Controller General.

Flushing High's baseball team captured the P.S.A.L. tournament final yesterday at Memorial Field, Flushing, as Curtis of Staten Island, defending titleholders, was badly jolted in a 7-0 contest. Sev Laliberte, 17-year-old bespectacled Flushing pitcher, was complete master of the invaders, yielding three hits, fanning five and walking two.

CHUNGKING, China, June 12 (AP) -- Invader troops are pounding incessantly at all sides of besieged Changsha against heroic Chinese resistance and the battle around the outer defenses has reached its "fiercest proportions," a Chinese communique said tonight, indicating virtual encirclement of the Canton-Hankow rail city.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- The wheat market today became weak after a show of strength early, the July delivery being especially heavy, as reports came in of an easier tone at outside cash markets. Minneapolis reported sales of cash wheat at below ceiling levels, and for a time the July delivery there was extremely heavy.

CHICAGO, June 12 (U.P.) -- Joseph P. Kennedy, former Ambassador to Great Britain, predicted tonight at a dinner of the American Gastroenterological Association that the American post-war period would see work for all who wanted it and warned that inflation dangers were not as great as the threat of a national deflation.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, June 13 (AP) -- The twenty 14-inch guns of the United States battleships Texas and Nevada engaged German field batteries in Normandy yesterday in one of the unique duels of this war.

Columbia's "Secret Command," topical melodrama dealing with sabotage on the American waterfront, starring Pat O'Brien and Carole Landis, will open this morning at Loew's Criterion. This is the first picture made by Terneen Productions, the company formed by Mr. O'Brien and Phil Ryan.

WITH ALLIED TROOPS IN FRANCE, June 11 (Delayed) -- High praise was given by Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery to American troops at a press conference tonight, when he revealed that prisoners had included some Japanese and that snipers in action in France included women who had been killed while shooting at Allied soldiers.

The Girard Trust Company of Philadelphia sold the vacant plot, 165 by 110 feet, on the east side of Tremont Avenue, at the corner of 177th Street, in the Bronx, to an in-investing client of the Eugene J. Busher Company. The plot is assessed at $18,000 and was sold for cash.

OVERLOOKING CARENTAN, Normandy, June 12 -- The United States Army infantry took Carentan at bayonet-point at 8:30 A.M. today, moving in from the outskirts under a curtain of white smoke after an infernal night of fighting.

As the battle in Normandy nears the end of its first week, the broad strategic picture of the historic struggle begins to emerge in clearer outlines. It is a grim but also an inspiring picture of the mobilized might of the Western democracies in action -- a picture of vast planning and great daring, of heroic deeds and noblest self-sacrifice, of tremendous accomplishments in the face of overwhelming odds.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, June 13 -- Allied forces extended their hold yesterday on that slender strip of Europe reclaimed from the Nazis after four years of blood and sweat and toil and tears.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 12 -- Frank E. Robinson Jr., 48 years old, a badly disabled veteran of the Royal Air Force of World War I, was found dead at his home at 66 Lockwood Avenue here today. Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester County medical examiner, said the death was suicide by gas.

The Stockholm, Sweden, newspaper Morgontidningen said yesterday that great number of Russian civilian prisoners -- men, women and children seized on Russian territory by retreating German forces -- are now being transported to Norway for slave labor.

LONDON, June 12 (U.P.) -- German broadcasts tonight claimed that twenty-two Allied divisions, almost half-a-million men at full strength, had been thrown into battle along a ninety-three-mile front in Normandy and that Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery had concentrated the bulk of his forces in an effort to shatter the main Nazi defenses between Carentan and Isigny.

Eugene Holman, a vice president of the Standard Oil Company (N.J.) was elected yesterday president to succeed Ralph W. Gallagher, who was made chairman of the board. Frank W. Abrams, a director since 1940, was elected a vice president. James C. Anderson was appointed controller to succeed Thomas C. McCobb, who will continue as a director of the company.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Office of Price Administration today named the three-week period July 10 through July 29 as a rationing "holiday" for limited quantities of "odd-lot" shoes which dealers are unable to move from their stocks under the rationing program.

Stockholders of the Winn Lovett Grocery Company approved yesterday a plan of recapitalization, under which present shares of the 7 per cent cumulative preferred and $2 cumulative class A stocks are to be exchanged on or before July 1 for twenty-year 7 per cent debenture bonds.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Reporting that "we have firm footholds in France with losses lower than expected," President Roosevelt asserted tonight that our policy of smashing Germany first would make it possible to "force the Japanese to unconditional surrender or to national suicide much more rapidly than has been thought possible."

Under the glow of seven-foot class numerals -- 1944 -- emblazoned atop the Gothic spires of City College's buildings and to the strains of "Auld Lang Syne" and the college anthem, "Lavender," the graduating seniors at the school gave themselves a moonlight send-off last night.

ROME, June 12 -- The German Fourteenth Army has been "dispersed to the four winds," Allied headquarters declared today as the Fifth Army, pursuing the disorganized Germans up the Italian west coast, approached Orbetello, seventy-one miles northwest of Rome.
LONDON, June 12 (Reuter) -- The remnants of the Vichy regime are disintegrating rapidly under the blows inflicted by the Allies' armies in the north and the French patriots in the south.

LONDON, June 12 -- Another step to eliminate Serb nationalist influences in the royal Yugoslav government -- dismissal of Ambassador Constantin Fotitch in Washington -- with a view to reaching agreement with Marshal Tito was announced by government headquarters in London today.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Presumably because this is a democracy where "rulers" do not exist, the Supreme Court today changed its language in the now celebrated 8-to-1 decision of April 3, preventing Texas from barring Negro voters in the Democratic primaries.

In Yorkville, at 1577 First Avenue (at Eighty-second Street), there is a delightfully old-fashioned store called H. Roth, where one may procure hard-to-get spices, unusual flours like potato and buckwheat, dried beans of many sorts, shelled nuts, rock candy, coffee and even Hungarian sheep's milk cheese.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The House of Representatives, considering the Emergency Price-Control All, stood firm today against most all efforts to break down price controls on commodities of widely varying types.

LONDON, June 12 (U.P.) -- The German High Command in the west is split over strategy, according to a dispatch today from Leslie Randall, Allied war correspondent at the Twenty-first Army Group headquarters.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- Proceedings were instituted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine whether the registration of the Investment Registry of America, Inc. of Philadelphia as a broker and dealer and as an investment adviser should be suspended or revoked because of alleged violations of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Justice Edward C. Eicher cracked down today on what the prosecution called "deliberate efforts to delay" the mass sedition trial by imposing a three-minute cross-examination limit for the remainder of the day on twenty-eight defense attorneys.

The former Griesenbeck residence fronting on the Shrewsbury River in Middletown, Monmouth County, N.J., has been sold by Harry Jaye, who purchased it a year ago to a client of the Ray Van Horn Agency of Fair Haven. The plot is 100 by 300 feet.

The Hartley amendment to the new Price Control Act banning the "highest price line limitation," which passed the House last Saturday, will not change prices to the consumer and is non-inflationary, according to statements issued here yesterday by retail spokesmen.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 13 -- The Red Army drove forward yesterday along the tortuous forest roads between lakes and swamps in the face of strong defensive fortifications to capture the rail station of Raivola, forty miles below Viborg, as well as thirty other inhabited points on the Karelian Isthmus, the Soviet High Command announced last night.

A new issue of $3,850,000 of industrial waterworks refunding bonds was announced yesterday by Birmingham, Ala., for sale on July 12. The issue will be dated Aug. 1, 1944, will mature on Aug. 1, 1945 to 1970, and will be callable on Aug. 1, 1954. Bidders are asked to name the interest rate at not to exceed 4 per cent.

Louis (Babe) Silvers was held without bail yesterday on a charge of murder in the gang slaying of Jake (the Ox) Finkel, ex-convict, early Sunday morning in front of a cabaret at 1650 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Magistrate James M. Fawcett in Felony Court set his hearing for Thursday.

At a meeting for mothers at Saks-34th Street yesterday, one of a series continuing through Wednesday, Dr. Milton I. Levine, consultant to the Bureau of Child Hygiene, City Department of Health, discussed typical behavior of young children that parents find perplexing.

A unified program for the readjustment of discharged war veterans to civilian life, utilizing the resources of radio, churches, synagogues, civic bodies, employer groups and organized labor, is nearing completion, it was announced last night by spokesmen for the Blue Network Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Under the system of priority referral of male labor to become effective July 1, the demand for women workers will increase not only in war production but in civilian service occupations, the War Manpower Commission predicted today through the Office of War Information.

The blind are doing their bit for the war. Sightless men and women perform vital services in shipyards and aircraft factories, in ammunition, small-arms, radio and precision-tool plants.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Retail prices of fresh fish and seafoods were cut by 1 to 3 cents a pound by changes in price "ceiling" regulations announced tonight by the Office of Price Administration.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 1 per cent in sales last week over the like period of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gain, in face of the impact of invasion news and early closings of stores here, was considered gratifying. For the previous week the bank had reported a rise of 13 per cent.

WASHINGTON, D.C., June 12 -- The down-plunging Yankees went to tremendous lengths tonight to check their precipitous flight from the top to the bottom of the American League flag race as they battled the Senators in the opener of a four-game nocturnal series before a crowd of 12,650.

In the hope that "the success of Pan Americanism will inspire the leaders who gather around the peace table to make Pan Globalism the basis for peace," Frederick E. Two eleven-story loft buildings at 41-43 and 45-51 West Twenty-fifth Street, 125 feet east of Sixth Avenue, have been purchased by Frank Locker, operator, from the Coleman Holding Corporation. They occupy a plot 150 by 100 feet and are operated as one unit, many of the tenants using entire floors for 15,000 square feet or more. The assessed valuation is $390,000.

Three classes of freshmen, a total of 120 pupils, will be the "guinea pigs" in an experimental program attempting to relate the curriculum to life experiences, to be introduced at the Midwood High School, Brooklyn, in September, it was revealed yesterday by Assistant Superintendent David H. Moskowitz.

DALLAS, June 12 (AP) -- Texas' officially constituted Democratic executive committee rejected a proposal today that it submit to the voters names of Presidential electors pledged to vote for the party's nominees.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Senate received from its special Post-War Economic Policy and Planning Committee today a budget of sixteen legislative obligations for Congress to meet without delay in preparing for the impacts of unemployment and readjustment when war production ceases.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Vital supplies have flowed into France behind the invasion forces in a completely satisfactory manner so far and it will be possible to build up supply lines to keep pace with the ever-mounting demands of the new front, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, Commanding General, United States Army Service Forces, said today.

Gert Hans von Gontard, grandson and heir of Adolphus Busch, founder of the Anheuser-Busch Brewery, and Lieut. Francis X. Grottano, Dr. Arnold A. Hutschnecker and Michael Mangano were acquitted at 11:57 o'clock last night by a jury in Federal Court.

Battering the Dodgers to a fare-thee-well yesterday in a rag-tag ball game that revealed twenty-eight assorted hits, including six homers, fourteen passes, three errors and a couple of hit batsmen, Mel Ott's Giants larruped the daylights out of Leo Durocher's pitching staff, walked off with the ball game, 15 to 9, and wound up just half a game back of the Reds in the National League standing.

The re-election of Paul Dullzell as chairman of the executive committee of the Chorus Equity Association was announced yesterday. Ballots were cast at the association's twenty-fifth annual meeting held on Friday at 701 Seventh Avenue.

LONDON, June 12 -- The first civilian government agency to begin operations in France has been established by the United States War Shipping Administration on the Normandy beachhead to handle offshore traffic among American merchantmen and to minister to the men.
CLEVELAND, June 12 (AP) -- A five-run uprising in the fourth inning gave the Indians a 6-to-5 triumph over the Tigers before 16,901 at the Municipal Stadium tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Byron Price, Censorship Director, in response to a subpoena from a Senate Postoffice Subcommittee inquiring into mail intercept leaks, presented today letters which he had previously declined to supply without that formal order because he said they are "part of the secret files of war."

Bear, Stearns Co. have prepared an analysis on the Central Illinois Electric and Gas Company. In February the company was divested from the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company under the integration provisions of the Holding Company Act.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 13 -- The first really good flying weather since the Allied invasion of western Europe began a week ago released 1,400 United States heavy bombers -- the largest number ever dispatched on a single mission -- for attack yesterday on sixteen Nazi air bases and other targets in France, all within a few minutes' flying time of our Normandy beachhead.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 12 -- Prime Minister Churchill set foot on French soil today for the first time since 1940, while General Eisenhower, commander of the Allied invasion forces, led a party of top United States military and naval commanders on a tour of the American-held section of the Normandy battlefront.

Corporations are so usual nowadays that many investors have forgotten that joint stock associations antedated them by some hundreds of years and have many points of pronounced difference. Chief of these is that, because the joint stock association operates on a common-law contract and because time is of the essence in a contract, it must set a date for its termination.

ALGIERS, June 12 -- General de Gaulle hopes that the discussions with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden that will continue after the General leaves London may produce a basis for a three-cornered agreement with which General de Gaulle and Mr. Eden might later go to Washington, it is believed here.

LISBON, Portugal, June 12 (AP) -- Production and export of wolfram, used in the manufacture of armament steel, was halted in Portugal today by official decree.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The story of a 173-foot submarine chaser -- the PC-558 -- that sank two German one-man submarines off Italy this spring and was finally lost as a result of enemy action in the Mediterranean on May 9 was revealed today by the Navy.

Charles E. Hughes Jr., chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Unity, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Dan W. Dodson, assistant professor of educational sociology at New York University, as executive director of the committee. Dr. Dodson is to receive a leave of absence from the university to give full time to the committee's work.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Americans fighting in France and on other battlefields and the seas around the world were virtually assured today of financial help when they return home.

Dwellings in and around Rye, Westchester County, are attracting considerable interest among suburban home buyers, according to the Prince Ripley brokerage office. Recent sales by that agency include the English-type residence on Park Drive South in the Westchester Country Club grounds to Jack Schleman for Benjamin K. Boyce.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The United States Supreme Court today granted a request by Otis Co., Cleveland, investment bankers, that it review a rule announced by the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding the treatment of securities of public utility holding companies forced to liquidate under the Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a union leader cannot withhold records of his union from a grand jury on the plea that such evidence might incriminate him. The finding upset a Third Circuit Court of Appeals decision reversing a contempt of court judgment against Jasper White, assistant supervisor of the local of the International Union of Operating Engineers, AFL, at Mechanicsburg, Pa.

GENERAL MONTGOMERY'S COMMAND POST, June 12 (AP) -- Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery has gained full revenge for the surrender demands that brash Major van der Heydte, German parachute commander, made on an Eighth Army unit less than two months before the Eighth Army's desert victory at El Alamein.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 12 (AP) -- The Japanese lost 21,650 men killed on the India-Burma front since Jan. 1, exclusive of the North Burma front, an Allied officer estimated today.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A new record in destruction of Japanese shipping was attained by our Pacific submarines during the past month, in which an average of two enemy ships a day were sent to the bottom, the Navy revealed today in announcing the sinking of eighteen more Japanese vessels, bringing the total for the May 12-June 12 period to sixty-three.

HEADQUARTERS, CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, June 11 (Delayed) -- The capture of Lungling yesterday by Chinese troops under the personal leadership of Maj. Gen. Sung Hsi-lien was the first major success of the month-old Salween offensive.

Curtin, of 208 Alexander Avenue, New York, who died in service as a flight lieutenant in the Royal Canadian Air Force, is named among nineteen Americans -- six of them dead -- who will be honored here tomorrow by Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, in the name of King George VI.

Parkinson of New York, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee at 99 Park Avenue and affiliated agencies have assisted service men 28,000,000 times, Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler, the co-chairman, reported yesterday to forty members of the women's division of the New York War Fund.
CHICACO, June 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

Scoring 13 points in the two events of the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships which were postponed because of rain last Saturday, the pole vault and the hop, step and jump the Columbia midshipman moved into a second place tie at 33 with the Pioneer Club yesterday at Baker Field.

With its fighting men locked in a death grapple with Nazi panzer divisions in Normandy and Japanese jungle troops in the South Pacific, the nation embarked last night on its newest and greatest financial effort of the war -- the Fifth War Loan drive, which seeks to raise $16,000,000,000 through the sale of war bonds between now and July 8.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 12 (AP) -- Buffalo's Bisons defeated Jersey City's Little Giants tonight, 3 to 0, as veteran Mike Roscoe limited the locals to six hits to hand them their fifth shut-out of the season.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, In England, June 12 -- A squadron of twelve Thunderbolts broke up an attack of twenty Messerschmitt 109's and shot down ten in twenty minutes, at a cost of one Thunderbolt, in the French invasion skies today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Tuesday, June 13 (AP) -- Liberator bombers based in the Admiralty Islands swept over the wide expanse of ocean to the Caroline Islands to blast the Japanese base at Truk for the sixth consecutive day Saturday, General Dougles MacArthur reported today.

Broadway last saw Janet Beecher in the fall of 1932 in "Men Must Fight." Tonight she returns as the star of "Slightly Scandalous," which will have its premiere at the National. Formerly called "Are Fathers Necessary?" and "Love and Learn," the comedy is the work of Frederick Jackson, who makes a program acknowledgment that his material is based on an idea by Roland Bottomley.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The first figures compiled by the Army Nurse Corps on its marriage rate shows an average of about fourteen nurses married per day from January through April in a corps numbering about 40,000.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 12 -- Ninety per cent of the locust swarms breeding in Arabia during the winter of 1943-44 is estimated to have been destroyed following the greatest campaign ever conducted on an international basis and followed through by three mechanized expeditions, it was announced here today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12 -- Increased Brazilian trade with the United States after the war was visualized today by a group of about forty Brazilian and American importers in answering a questionnaire.
CHUNGKING, China, June 12, (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

LONDON, June 12 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle seems to be seeking recognition of the French Committee of National Liberation as the Provisional Government of France from the small nations that feel that they have been left out of things by their bigger Allies.

Tempers exploded on the speakers' platform and in the audience that packed Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, last night as Rex Stout, Mark Van Doren, Louis Fischer and Dorothy Thompson, all writers, argued the question, "What policy toward the defeated Reich offers the best guarantee of a democratic Germany and a peaceful Europe?"

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 12 -- As four more alleged horse race betting rooms in Union City were raided today, the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, in Newark issued a statement saying that records had disclosed that none of the telephones in the places raided had been put in after installation restrictions had been imposed.

MOSCOW, June 12 -- Information recently brought from Poland by a delegation of the "National Council," headed by its vice president, a Mr. Moravsky, revealed a state of affairs that, though at first shocking enough, has also its brighter side.

War Bond linage in New York newspapers yesterday was less than that published on the first day of the previous drive, according to early estimates. This was attributed to the fact that Monday is generally a lighter day for retail advertising than Tuesday, the day on which the Fourth War Loan Drive started.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 12 -- Anne Powell the 14-year-old singer who made her screen debut in the Charles R. Rogers' picture "Song of the Open Road" will be starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which holds her contract, in "Love Makes Me Sick," a comedy with music about a girl who rebels against the romantic inclinations older members of her family.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Two rulings protecting the basic civil liberties of individuals despite strongest Federal Government charges of disloyalty were handed down by the Supreme Court today just before it adjourned for the summer. In both cases, the court said, the Government failed to prove its allegations in instances where persons had the right to use violent or foolish language without being subject to penalties.

A 10 per cent price increase on cellulose acetates, which quietly was put into effect recently by raw material manufacturers producing more than 65 per cent of the industry's output, will have to be absorbed by plastics molders and extruders, industry spokesmen stated yesterday.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 12 (U.P.) -- The American party crossed the Channel in an American destroyer and toured the beachheads to the distant accompaniment of exploding mines and artillery fire. Overhead, flight after flight of Allied bombers and fighters roared inland in the best flying weather the beachhead has so far enjoyed.

ROME, June 12 -- Another highly successful American mission to Russia went into the records with the return to bases in Italy yesterday of our heavy bombers and escort fighters that landed June 2 on airfields in the Soviet Union. The strategic successes of the Fifteenth Air Force's task force were etched in the minds of all who took part by the wonderful reception the Russians gave our fliers, and they have come back enthusiastic.

ALBANY, June 12 -- John T. Delaney, Albany County District Attorney for the past fifteen years, sent his resignation to Governor Dewey tonight in a letter which accompanied the resignation, "effective forthwith." Mr. Delaney said that he had virtually been idle for six months because the Governor had superseded him as the county's prosecuting officer.

Behind the green hedges of its sculpture garden, the Museum of Modern Art held a preview yesterday of a garden canteen for service men. Beginning today, the gates at 10 West Fifty-fourth Street will be open to all in service uniforms, who may bring their friends -- making the center unique among city canteens.

LONDON, June 12 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Myron R. Wood, 51, is commander of the Ninth Air Force Service Command, it was announced today. He succeeds former Maj. Gen. Henry J. F. Miller, who was reduced to the rank of lieutenant colonel and sent back to the United States for loose talk about the Allied invasion date.

The food industry will face the most competitive era the world has ever seen after the war, Clarence Francis, chairman of the board of General Foods Corporation, told more than 300 grocery sales executives who were guests at a luncheon of the Association of Manufacturers' Representatives, New York, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, June 13 (U.P.) -- The fourth battle of Changsha has reached a climax, front dispatches said tonight, as the Chinese defenders of the Hunan province stronghold made a stand to the death against reinforced Japanese columns attacking furiously on three sides.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Conflicting recommendations on post-war disposition of the United States merchant fleet were presented today to the House Merchant Marine Committee, considering a bill setting up a formula for the sale of the war-built fleet to private operators.

BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- It cost the management at Suffolk Downs $4,956.70 in a minus show pool, in addition to the purse of $1,800, to present Frederick W. Hooper's entry of Hoop Jr. and Pry in today's feature, a five-furlong allowance event for 2-year-olds.

A nation-wide "Green Thumb" contest for Victory gardeners was announced yesterday by the National Victory Garden Institute with war bonds to be awarded as prizes to the country's most successful growers of vegetables at the end of the season.

OTTAWA, June 13 -- Canadian naval losses in personnel and ships were "negligible" during the landing in Normandy and the Canadian Navy has added one more to the list of U-boats sunk in the Atlantic, Naval Minister Angus L. Macdonald announced in Parliament today.

In a letter to THE TIMES of June 10 L.J. Rubinstein states that no kind of political education of German prisoners of war can be of value before Germany's surrender. While we agree with Mr. Rubinstein that it is idle to guess at the percentages of Nazis and anti-Nazis among the prisoners, it is nevertheless of the greatest importance to combat the Nazi ideology among the prisoners by both practical and educational methods.

DETROIT, June 13 (U) -- The three-day labor dispute at the Graham-Paige Motor Corporation's amphibious tank plant was deadlocked tonight when 4,000 members of Local 142, United Automobile Workers (CIO), refused to return to work until the company discharged its labor relations director.

At the next meeting of the E.U. (Equine Union) old Iron Shot, owned by Miss Ella Widener, unquestionably will be called to task for his behavior in the $6,000 added Hitchcock Steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday.

We, who are not in Uncle Sam's uniform, can't be with the invasion forces now pushing forward to liberate captive Europe. We can't fire a machine gun from a fox hole in New Guinea. Nor can we man the ships and guns of the Navy now sweeping the seven seas to restore and protect the safety of the world.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 13 -- Three chemical weapons that played important parts in Normandy, Italy and in the southwest Pacific were demonstrated at Chatham, N.J., and at Bayway today by Army and Standard Oil of New Jersey officials who developed them.

LONDON, June 13 -- Although today's stock markets here were less active today, the tone throughout remained cheerful. There was renewed support for various industrial shares but best prices were not held by all.

One of the most stirring chapters in the story of the great invasion belongs to the Allied fleet. Never before in history has there been a land battle in which fighting ships played so large a part. They were expected to support our landing forces, as they did with reckless gallantry.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, June 14 -- Supreme Headquarters announced today that strong enemy pressure continues west of Carentan while in the middle of the beachhead line Allied forces have struck south in the Tilly-sur-Seulles region.

Petain, who calls himself "We, Marshal of France, Chief of the French State," and his begrimed collaborator, otherwise known as "Chief of Government" at Vichy, find themselves discredited today, even in the eyes of their Nazi accomplices. For four years Laval and his henchmen have labored to complete the betrayal of France.
The Welfare Council of New York City, it was disclosed yesterday, has plans under advisement for an elaborate series of community social welfare projects.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Unless post-war planning, particularly with reference to small business, is bold the country "may suffer seriously enough to alter greatly our form of Government," Maury Maverick, head of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, said today -- before a special House committee named to study post-war economic problems.
CINCINNATI, June 13 (AP) -- Three doubles in the fourth inning helped account for three runs today as the Pirates defeated Cincinnati, 3 to 2, in a game stopped by rain and hail after five innings.
PEARL HARBOR, June 13 -- Central Pacific carrier task forces struck a crippling blow in the Marianas Islands Saturday and Sunday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 13 -- Unconfirmed reports reaching Stockholm late tonight indicated that the Russians were supplementing their main drive on the Karelian Isthmus with considerably increased activity in the far north as well as in the center and on the Narva front in Estonia.
CHUNGKING, China, June 13 (AP) -- A communique:

MANCHESTER, N.H., June 13 -- How a medical officer dropped 1,200 feet on his first parachute jump to perform an emergency appendectomy on a civilian at an isolated weather station on Baffin Island was made public today by the Army.

ROME, June 13 (U.P.) -- The Allies' armies in Italy have taken the important road junctions of Valentano, fifty-eight airline miles northwest of Rome, and Popoli, twenty-eight miles southwest of Pescara, it was announced today as Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark officially placed German casualties in the thirty-two-day campaign at 70,000 men.

Erich Kleiber, distinguished Austrian conductor, has been engaged for the forthcoming season of the Metropolitan Opera Association, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Kleiber, formerly a conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony and director of the Berlin State Opera, will replace Bruno Walter, who is taking a year's vacation after completing fifty years on the podium.

Mr. Churchill has just made a visit to France, a country he has always loved. He went in a destroyer. No doubt the former First Lord of the Admiralty was pleased to see his ship bombard German position and steam through the battle fleet pounding at the Norman shore.

One of eight men indicted last winter acccused of illegal solicitation of advertising subscriptions for spurious labor publications on the pretext of supporting war related campaigns turned State's evidence in General Sessions yesterday at the opening trial of three co-defendants.

The Goldman Band will open the season of Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts at 8:30 o'clock tonight on the Mall in Central Park. Edwin Franko Goldman will conduct, and James Burke, cornetist, will be soloist.

MOSCOW, June 13 -- Premier Joseph Stalin declared tonight that the Allied landing in France was a brilliant success and that the history of war did not know any operation so broad in conception, grandiose in scale and masterly in execution.

A consolidated net income of $2,042,658 for the quarter ended with March was reported yesterday by the Greyhound Corporation. The income, which is after all charges and Federal taxes, is equivalent to 72 cents a share on the 2,784,386 shares of common stock outstanding during the period.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Joe McCarthy's Yankees were still vainly clutching at straws tonight as their amazing plunge into the grotto of the American League continued without interruption.

DETROIT, June 13 (AP) -- Topseeded Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles and Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Coral Gables, Fla., won opening victories today in what may be marches to national clay court tennis championships.

A free economy, by its nature, entails a certain amount of fluctuation and risk. As a matter of fact, much of its strength and its very freedoms are directly related to its risks. But one cannot enjoy the freedoms of such a society without a minimum of economic security.

Chatham Manufacturing Company will begin its first consumer campaign on blankets in September, it was announced yesterday. Advertising which was limited to dealer support in former years will appear monthly through December in women's magazines.

After opening steady, 3 points higher to 1 point lower, cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange worked upward to the highest levels in fifteen years, when July touched 21.39 cents a pound. Active price-fixing in the near months, scarcity of offerings and continued heavy call for cotton goods for military purposes, were factors that strengthened the market.
LONDON, June 13 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

j There may be a thin ray qf hope jfor the homemaker who has been looking sadly at her shabby lampshades these many months, in the recent War Production Board order freeing wire for lamp hade productton.

OTTAWA, June 13 (Canadian Press) -- Weather has favored the grain crops in western Canada during the last week, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics said today in the third of its sixteen weekly telegraphic crop reports.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 13 (AP) -- Communique 15:

John J. MacKay, formerly with the City of Paris Dry Goods Company, San Francisco, has been appointed sales manager of the men's divisions, and Dr. Alfred J. Cardall, director of the industrial relations, of the John B. Stetson Company.

CAIRO, June 13 -- The new Greek Government has begun a drastic reorganization of Greek armed forces, both within and without the country, in an effort to unify all military elements for the final fight against the Germans and Bulgarians.

ROME, June 13 (AP) -- Major Robert C. Hendrickson, chief legal officer for Rome under the Allied Military Government, held a class in law today, lecturing to 1,000 members of the Roman bar on the procedure they will have to follow in practicing before Allied military courts.

ROME, June 13 -- For the first time in Rome's long, tormented history, it devolved upon an American today to appoint the Sindaco, or Mayor, of the capital. The ceremony took place on the steps of the old Senate building on the Campidoglio, Rome's ancient political center, where Brig. Gen. Edgar Erskine Hume made the announcement that Prince Filippo Andrea Doria-Pamphilj-Landi, of the Roman branch of the famous Genoese Doria family, is the new Sindaco.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday were 2,086, against 1,743 in the preceding week and 1,536 in the like period of last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TISLES. Yesterday's -arrivals numbered 1,047, compared with 1,104 last Tuesday.

MEDICAL HEADQUARTERS, THE TWENTY-FIRST ARMY GROUP, June 13 -- American and British medical arrangements for treatment of those wounded in the fighting in France, and for their rapid evacuation to hospitals in this country, have proved so efficient that by last night all the beaches had been cleared of casualties with the exception of men so gravely wounded that they were not fit to stand the journey.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 14 -- The Soviet offensive against Finland, now about midway through the old Mannerheim Line positions, continued to develop yesterday against strong resistance and the High Command announced the capture of several strongholds, including Steklyannaya, Kaetraelae, Ronnunkylae, Vehmainen and Sueranmbeki, on the road to Viborg.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Virtually all sellers of domestic and imported fur skins were brought under new and lower price ceilings today as the Office of Price Administration fixed as the ceiling for all sales or deliveries through auction houses or brokers the highest levels charged from Oct. 1, 1941, through April 30, 1942.

LONDON, June 13 -- Within twenty-four hours after the Anglo-American army of liberation swarmed ashore on the beaches of Normandy the Germans carried off Leopold, King of the Belgians, to Germany as a captive, according to information received here today by the Belgian Government from their leaders of the underground resistance.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Women in the Navy's uniform who enviously watch their Wac sisters embark for overseas duty soon may get their chance to do likewise, and the Navy girls who have become attached to their military jobs and dread the moment of parting at the end of the war may yet be able to keep those posts.

Because of a marked increase in the demand by the armed services for beer, the Army Exchange Service is seeking for the first time the cooperation of smaller breweries -- those producing less than 100,000 barrels annually -- it was disclosed yesterday at the second day's sessions of a three-day conference of the Small Brewers Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Today is Flag Day, the 167th anniversary of the adoption of the United States Flag. The anniversary, the third since our entry into the war, will be observed in New York City with a consciousness that our troops, beside their Allies, are fighting for liberty in France and in many other parts of the world.

ADVANCED ALLIED COMMAND POST, June 13 (U.P.) -- A shuddering naval barrage hurtled into the German-held coast below Cherbourg. The British destroyer Kelvin coasted to a stop. A stocky figure went to the rail and trained his binoculars. For ten minutes he studied the effect of the Allied fire, nervously biting on a cigar.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 13 -- Fourteen persons were injured, only one seriously, when a salute bomb exploded prematurely at an air raid precautions demonstration in Union Square here tonight under the direction of the Elizabeth Defense Council.

For the first time since the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the New York Public Library reports an incresaed use of books in its circulation department. According to Miss Esther Johnston, acting chief of the circulation department, 657,595 books were borrowed from the library for home use last month, an increase of 19,864 volumes over the number borrowed in May, 1943.

The Board of Elections appealed yesterday to Arthur D. Patterson, City Budget Director, for an additional appropriation of $22,500 for temporary clerks and typists to handle applications for war ballots from New York City residents in the armed services.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board broke the monopoly on air transportation into Boston by a decision today granting certificates to four more air carriers to operate into the New England metropolis from the south and west, two from New York.

American Kennel Club delegates held a lively quarterly meeting at the club offices in this city yesterday. A long debate followed the introduction of a resolution to the effect that judges of groups must be licensed to judge at least 50 per cent of the breeds in that group.
ALGIERS, June 13 -- The French Committee of National Liberation, acting as the "Provisional Government" of France, appointed military and civilian leaders tonight for freed areas of Normandy.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- All the members of the American Democratic National Committee, each a Democratic party leader opposed to the New Deal, will be present Monday for "pre-convention caucus," according to the national headquarters.

AT UNITED STATES FRONT LINES IN NORMANDY, June 12 (Delayed) -- The handful of hamlets liberated by American troops today were, like all others freed so far, surprisingly prosperous, some inhabitants even living in luxury. Wherever United States troops have been in Normandy during the last seven days they have found French civilians well fed, well clothed and amply supplied with wine, brandy and "applejack."
PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) -- Snapping out of a five-game losing streak, the Phillies defeated the Braves by 8 to 7 in the nightcap of a double-header today, after dropping the opener 2 to 1.

The absence of heavy whipping cream continues to be a problem in so far as the preparation of home-made ice cream is concerned. What made this ingredient so effective was the fact that it acted as a so-called "interfering agent" and prevented the formation of large crystals, which make a grainy, unpleasant texture.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Judge Samuel I. Rosenman and Jonathan W. Daniels will represent President Roosevelt as observers at a White House conference on How Women May Share in Post-War Policy-Making tomorrow in the East Room with representatives of seventy-five women's organizations in attendance.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- For the first time in thirteen years, the Democrats lost today an actual majority of the House membership with the election of a Republican in the Nineteenth Illinois district.

LONDON, June 13 -- At one of the touchiest moments of the war, it still takes an average of only eleven minutes apiece for invasion news dispatches to be read and censored by the three-nation military censorship at Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Expeditionary Force.

As eyewitness accounts help us to see what happened on the beaches of Normandy during the first landings we realize that every man engaged in that tremendous adventure had to take his life in his hands and walk into the trap prepared for him as if he were alone. There is a lot of lonely fighting in this war.

While the eyes of the country have been riveted on the beachheads in France, much less reassuring events have been taking place in the halls of Congress. Many Congressmen of both political parties, instead of devoting their energies to the national interest, have been deserting the principles they professed in the hope of picking up votes from this or that pressure group in the coming election.

In its monthly report on the market for commercial paper, issued yesterday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York states that the volume in the United States at the end of May was $150,700,000. This represented a decline of $20,800,000 or 12 per cent, in the month, the largest decrease for any month in more than ten years.
LONDON, June 13 -- Four exiled European Governments in London have decided to recognize the French Committee of National Liberation as the "Provisional Government of the French Republic."

Bad manners and dirty faces are not the most vital concerns in bringing up children at the ages of 8, 9 and 10; it is far more important to do things with children, to talk with them, and especially to laugh with them, in the opinion of Mrs. Bess B. Lane, educational director of the United Parents Associations of New York City.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 -- Elizabeth Taylor, the 12-year-old actress who made her screen debut in "Lassie Come Home," and now has the lead opposite Mickey Rooney in "National Velvet." will be starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "Hold High the Torch," a story of a child and a war dog by Lionel Houser.

A program calling for allocation of enough raw materials and small motors to permit resumed production of furnace and boiler burners in the fourth quarter of this year will be presented to War Production Board officials today, C. E. Lewis, president of the Oil-Heat Institute of America, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- There will be other openings in the invasion of Europe, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told President Roosevelt in a personal report which the latter made public today at a news conference.

MOSCOW, June 13 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace, speaking in Russian, which he only recently learned, told an overflow audience in Novosibirsk today that "our two great peoples" must work together in peace as well as in war for the reconstruction of devastated areas.

NEWARK, N.J., June 13 -- A repatriated naturalized American citizen, who served as an anti-aircraft gunner in the German Army in the present war, was placed under arrest today at Ellis Island, it was announced by Samuel K. McKee, New Jersey chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, June 14 -- British tanks and American infantry have smashed across the rugged, heavily wooded country south of Bayeux and between the Forest of Cerisy and Tilly-sur-Seulles in the opening of an initially successful offensive in the center of the 85-mile Allied front in Normandy.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Navy has cancelled its contract for about 175 stainless steel Conestoga cargo-carrying planes manufactured by the E.G. Budd Manufacturing Company of Philadelphia. The cutback leaves the company only twenty-five of the original total of 800 planes scheduled to be produced, since the Army recently cancelled its contract for 600 Conestogas.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS IN FRANCE, June 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- On a heavily shelled beach early on D-day, Lieutenant Sam Brightman, Navy public relations officer, did a herculean job getting the invasion news back for transmission to the American press.
CHUNGKING, China, June 13 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

A trio of old-time players familiar to Brooklyn fans will hold a reunion at the ceremonies connected with the War Bond "tri-corner" baseball game among the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers at the Polo Grounds on the night of June 26. They are Zach Wheat, one of the great stars of yesteryear, and the famous battery of Nap Rucker and Otto Miller.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Reports of black rust in wheat in the Texas Panhandle furnished today the incentive for active short-covering on the Board of Trade here and some general commission buying of wheat, which resulted in a sharp advance.

NATURALISTS, like musicians, often embark upon their lifelong careers at a precociously early age. Little boys whose pockets and bureau drawers are. filled with worms, frogs and tarantulas aren't necessarily proper objects of parental wrath. That's the way future Darwins and Beebes start groping for the first rung on the long ladder that leads to scientific eminence.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Theories of an early peace in Europe gripped the stock market again yesterday, and under the urging of another two-million share session, prices shot forward fractions to 3 points. Buying orders ran roughshod over periodic bursts of profit-taking as the list showed the strongest advance yet registered this year and carried quotations almost to the high marks set last July.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Representatives of railroads, shippers and the trucking industry urged today that the Senate pass a House-approved bill repealing land-grant railroad rates which give the Government 50 per cent reductions on war materials and personnel.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS In the Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, June 14 (U.P.) -- Allied aircraft sank seven and possibly eight Japanese vessels in Geelvink Bay Monday in new blows against enemy shipping off Netherland New Guinea while American planes began using the captured Mokmer airfield on Biak Island to support the drive on nearby airdromes, it was announced today.

At least 80 per cent of the total piano manufacturing capacity in this country will be standing idle in the immediate future "waiting for something to do," George Stapely, president of the National Piano Manufacturers Association, reported yesterday at the annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

HOOD RIVER, Ore., June 13 (AP) Pacific Coast Conference Football coaches voted today to throw forward passes anywhere behind the line of scrimmage and to eliminate the oft-attacked intentional kickoff out-of-bounds, beginning with the 1944 schedule.

Three new additions to the Random House Lifetime Library are in preparation. They are a twovolume "Diary of Samuel Pepys," in the Wheatley edition; a twovolume "Basic Writings of St. Thomas Aquinas," edited by Anton C. Pegis, and a three-volume unabridged edition of Thomas Burton's "Arabian Nights."

NEWARK, N.J., June 13 (AP) -- The Newark Bears scored eight runs in the ninth inning after Rochester had tallied six times in the same frame, to eke out a 9-to-8 victory tonight in the second game of a twin bill. The Bears also won the opener, 2 -- 0, with Floyd Bevens yielding four hits.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- A critical shortage in rubber corsets, which might cause many older working women to quit their necessary war jobs, was revealed today by Miss Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

As New York City consumers yesterday found supplies of meat apparently "acutely tight," the War Food Administration, 150 Broadway, reported that meat receipts for the week ended last Saturday showed a gain of 10.9 per cent over receipts for the preceding week.

TRENTON, N.J., June 13 (AP) -- The placing of 150 voting machines in Democratic Hudson County and fifty in Republican Passaic County in time for the Nov. 7 general election was voted today by the State House Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Adopting amendments which were denounced as inflationary and restrictive of price control, the House moved through hours of debate today to the prospect of final action tomorrow on extension of price and wage control legislation.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 13 -- The Bulgarian Cabinet, which admitted the Bulgarian Minister to Madrid, Paravan Draganoff, yesterday as Foreign Minister, is on its way out after a wave of "disaffection" involving several key ministers, German sources reported tonight.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, June 14 (AP) -- A communique:
KANDY, Ceylon, June 13 (UP) -- A communique:...

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee called for open discussion today of a proposal that Italy be recognized as a full ally of the United States with diplomatic ties and entitled to lend-lease aid.

LONDON, June 13 -- Columbia Broadcasting System and Reuter correspondents reported that the remaining inhabitants of Carentan had had no resistance organization and were still Giraudists, deeply puzzled by reports of differences between Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud and General de Gaulle.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, June 14 (U.P.) -- Spearheading attacks by 5,500 Allied planes on German defenses in France, powerful forces of United States Flying Fortresses and Liberators yesterday blasted five front-line enemy airdromes as reconnaissance showed the Luftwaffe had abandoned twenty-seven or more airfields that had proved too hot to hold.

The New, Jersey Council, which sponsors the annual New Jersey Governor's fishing tournament, announces current leaders in the competition. Those who want to know what they have to shoot at may find it of interest. Here are the leaders, their home towns and weights of the fish:

Eluding military and city policemen and civilian searchers, Emanuel Kalytka, a German prisoner of war who escaped from a building of the Halloran General Hospital, Willow Brook, S.I., early Sunday morning, slipped past guards yesterday noon and returned to his place in the prisoner of war dining hall.

Award of a new issue of $716,500 Toledo, Ohio, refunding bonds, due serially from Nov. 1, 1950 to 1955, was made yesterday to a syndicate consisting of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Martin, Burns Corbett, Inc., and Mullaney, Ross Co.

Evoking nostalgic memories of the New York World's Fair among many of the 15,000 spectators, the world's largest cash register was unveiled with appropriate ceremonies in Times Square, at Forty-third Street, during the noon hour yesterday.

LONDON, June 13 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Kurt Dietmar, Berlin military commentator, warned the German people tonight that "we are now in a crisis," as Nazi propaganda broadcasts intensified their alarms that new Allied landings and major operations were imminent.
In your issue of June 8 George Petit Le Brun contests the right of the French Committee of National Liberation call itself "Provisional Government of the French Republic."

LONDON, Wednesday, June 14 -- The strategic attacks by Allied heavy bombers against targets in Germany, along with the aerial offensive over a broad belt of France embracing the Normandy battle area, went on again Monday night and yesterday, without diminishing the pressure of our air power over the invasion beachhead.

Simultaneously, sanity and the Dodgers returned to the Polo Grounds yesterday and, if at times the relationship between the two may be strained, there was nothing eccentric about the Brooks. Nor was there anything crazy about the manner in which the Flatbush outfit contrived to snap the five-game winning streak of the Giants.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 47:

AN ADVANCED FIFTH AIR FORCE BASE, off Netherland New Guinea, June 8 (Delayed) (AP) -- Ten Mitchell medium bombers on reconnaissance high over the Western tip of Netherland New Guinea today sighted the trim outlines and dashing wakes of seven Japanese warships racing eastward toward Biak Island, where the Japanese garrison is in trouble.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The French francs that every soldier in the invasion forces carries were printed only after conferences in London and Washington with French authorities representing General de Gaulle, President Roosevelt announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- What the United States proposes to do in the field of international commercial air operations after the war was revealed today by the Civil Aeronautics Board, as Chairman L. Welch Pogue stood before a world map with a pointer and showed about fifty correspondents lines which would expand the 80,000 route-miles already approved for overseas transport to make a total of 140,000 miles of airlines under American operation.
In your recent editorial summarizing Mr. Churchill's speech you conclude that "the reconciliation of the factions in Greece * * * he credited to the intervention of the King."
ROME, June 13 (AP) -- A communique:

Frederick Jackson is one of the world's most prolific playwrights, who once hired a summer theatre in Westchester and put on nine of his shows, one after another. His most recent offering bobbed up last night at the National under the name of "Slightly Scandalous," and it pretty obviously was one which came from the bottom of his trunk, perhaps even from the false bottom.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today postponed from June 20 to Aug. 22 proceedings on the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company's plan for compliance with the Holding Company Act. The company asked for the postponement to dispose of additional subsidiaries and further reduce its debt.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Here is the list of routes proposed by the Civil Aeronautics Board for commercial operation after the war:

The raids that Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper, in his capacity as acting Prosecutor of Hudson County, has been conducting since Friday on bookmaking establishments in Union City and Hoboken, brought untold grief to the common or garden variety of street-corner bookmaker here yesterday.

During the summer months the voluntary hospitals of New York are facing the very serious problem of providing relief for the much-reduced force of trained professional workers who have been left to carry on. These workers must have some vacation to keep them fit to meet the heavy responsibilities which they now carry.

From a prison camp deep inside Germany Lieut. William J. Cooney of 124-06 Hillside Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, recently is reported to have seized the opportunity while he had a few moments on a short-wave broadcast to urge his mother to buy a War Bond.

The news that Charles A. Lindbergh, who reported recently to Admiral Chester W. Nimitz for duty with the Navy, is teaching American aviators in the Gilbert Islands phases of high-altitude flying deserves comment.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Frank M. Swacker, a New York lawyer, will succeed Dr. W.M. Leiserson as chairman of the National Mediation Board, it was reported tonight. The White House is understood to have tendered him the post today and he accepted. Official announcement will be made in a day or two.

LONDON, June 13 (U.P.) -- Organized sabotage behind the German lines in France, hindering the movement of German reserves to the Normandy front, is spreading across the country from the forested mountain hide-outs near the Swiss frontier to the Paris region, Gen. Charles de Gaulle's headquarters announced today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 13 -- Miss Dorothy Germain of Philadelphia, by adding an 80 to her earlier rounds of 82 and 73 for a 54-hole total of 235, won the Red Cross golf tournament by three strokes over the hilly Wykagyl course today.

There will be many an occasion, while we are driving the Nazis out of France, when the radio newscasters will be in duty bound to mispronounce French place names. They must resist the temptation to win the applause of the cognoscenti by displaying a flawless Parisian accent.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Defense attorneys in the mass sedition trial sought today to inject the Supreme Court reversal yesterday of the conviction of Elmer Hartzel on a charge similar to those facing the twenty-nine sedition defendants, but were able to get nothing more than conversation into the court record.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Telling the House Labor Committee that there is a "real fascist peril in America," Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress, said that failure to establish a permanent Fair Employment Practices Commission would multiply post-war employment difficulties.

ST. LOUIS, June 13 (AP) -- Danny Litwhiler cashed in on four hours of private batting practice with three consecutive doubles and a single which scored three Cardinal runs as St. Louis defeated the Cubs, 8 to 3, tonight.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, June 14 (AP) -- Regular United States Army troops captured the stronghold of Montebourg yesterday and sent patrols into the outskirts of Valognes, ten miles from the prize port of Cherbourg, before German counterattacks left the situation obscure, field reports said.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Senate passed a $3,920,602,200 appropriation bill today for lend-lease and United States participation in the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation (UNRRA) program and to enable the Foreign Economic Administration to continue aiding the warfare against the enemy's economy.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Political Action Committee of the CIO, told the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures today that "we have no 'purge list,' either public or secret, which we seek to impose upon the local members of the CIO from our office in New York."
WITH AMERICAN TROOPS in France, June 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- Tech. Sgt. Alex Stout of Opelousas, La., is still seeing stars.

THERE was a motion picture a few years ago that had as its most memorable scene an extraordinary desk which was operated by the extraordinary W.C. Fields. The desk was jammed to overflowing with letters, papers and the like, but the Hollywood buffoon could find unerringly any item he wanted. With the proper W.C. Fields gestures he would stab into a pile and triumphantly emerge with the scrap of paper he was after.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- While the invasion of France continues to progress satisfactorily, the Germans now face an exceedingly difficult strategic decision, military observers here believe.
BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- Manager Joe Cronin was not charged with a time at bat in four times while his Red Sox were defeating the Athletics, 7 -- 2, tonight in a twilight contest.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Only President Roosevelt's signature was lacking tonight to enact into law the GI Bill of lights, on which Congressional action was completed today with a roll-call vote of 379 to 0 by which the House accepted the conference report on the measure.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 13 (U.P.) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said in a message to his troops tonight, one week after D-day: "Your accomplishments in the first seven days of this campaign have exceeded my brightest hopes."

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 7, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- A ninety-minute barrage of arguments was leveled today against the so-called 5 per cent profit rule of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., by three representatives of over-the-counter dealers appearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, June 13 (U.P.) -- A London Evening Standard correspondent reported today that it was believed that Marshal Rommel had been removed from his post as commander of the German anti-invasion forces.

With the invasion of France under way, the city's school children evidently realize that the need for waste paper salvage will be greater than ever during their summer holidays, as they are planning to carry on until September with the same zeal that has won Mayor La Guardia's "Citation for Merit on the Home Front" for their schools in recent months.

MEMPHIS, June 13 -- The Democratic party high command could stop the Southern anti-New Deal "revolt" in short order if it could give assurance that President Roosevelt would not insist upon the renomination of Henry A. Wallace as Vice President, according to a widely held opinion here in the political barony of Edward H. (Boss) Crump.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 13 (U.P.) -- Smashing Japanese resistance with the aid of flame-throwers and mortar fire, American and Chinese jungle fighters have captured strong enemy positions in the southern part of Myitkyina and have occupied the stubbornly defended rifle range at the northwestern edge of the city, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

ABOARD U.S.S. AUGUSTA, in the Bay of the Seine, June 12 (Delayed) -- Six days after the Allied landings on the coast of Normandy a strip of French coast more than forty miles long and from three to fifteen miles deep has been secured as a beachhead for further operations.

Adoption by retailers of a definite policy of standing behind their apparel orders and avoiding the flood of cancellations which followed the last war was urged yesterday by Herbert O. Bergdahl, general merchandise manager of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, at the luncheon of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

JERSEY CITY, June 13 (AP) -- Jersey City fought an uphill battle to defeat Buffalo, 4 to 3, tonight and regain first place from Baltimore. The Little Giants, after tying the score in the eighth with a two-run rally, won in the ninth when Steve Filipowicz singled Bob Henry home from third after two were out.

WITH AMERICAN FOURTH DIVISION, Near Montebourg, 1:10 P.M., June 13 -- The Germans fought their way back into Montebourg and Carentan this morning, and the infantrymen of the old Fourth Division, which helped write history in France in the last war, are battling them in the streets.

Operations of Bonwit Teller, Inc., in the fiscal year ended with January resulted in new highs for sales and earnings, according to the annual report to stockholders issued for publication today by William M. Holmes, president.

American eyes are centered at this moment upon the Normandy peninsula because the adventure there is new, because it involves large forces and because it is, as we hope and pray, the beginning of the end of the Axis war. The attack on Cherbourg is an attack on Berlin, and the attack on Berlin is an attack on Tokyo.

Acting Police Lieut. John Osnato, whose patience and knowledge of human weaknesses has marked much of his work on seemingly insolvable cases, will retire from the Police Department on June 30 after twenty-eight years of service, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The House Committee on Foreign Affairs will resume hearings tomorrow on a bill which, considering its objective and the nature of its support, has encountered surprising obstructions in a body -- Congress -- which has not hesitated to override similar and much better-grounded objections to other legislation: that vested property rights, acquired through the common law, are disregarded.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 -- If Thomas E. Dewey were the Republican Presidential candidate and Franklin D. Roosevelt the Democratic candidate as of today, Michigan would go into the Dewey column.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- The league-leading Browns turned a White Sox fielding collision into a ninth-inning rally that netted three runs and a 5-to-3 victory today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The House Committee on Foreign Affairs will resume hearings tomorrow on a bill which, considering its objective and the nature of its support, has encountered surprising obstructions in a body -- Congress -- which has not hesitated to override similar and much better-grounded objections to other legislation: that vested property rights, acquired through the common law, are disregarded.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 -- If Thomas E. Dewey were the Republican Presidential candidate and Franklin D. Roosevelt the Democratic candidate as of today, Michigan would go into the Dewey column.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- The league-leading Browns turned a White Sox fielding collision into a ninth-inning rally that netted three runs and a 5-to-3 victory today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- An agreement between the United States, Great Britain and Sweden that would have the effect of "substantially" reducing Swedish ball-bearing shipments to Germany was announced tonight shortly after President Roosevelt told how the United Nations' economic vise is squeezing the Nazi supply of vital alloys essential to the manufacture of steel for munitions.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The widespread indiscriminate use of vitamins was condemned by Dr. Herman L. Kretschmer of Chicago tonight as he took office as president of the American Medical Association. Speaking at the annual convention, he said that impressive advances had been made with vitamins, but he added:

ROME, June 13 -- I have just come back from an ivory tower where George Santayana interviewed me. That is the only way to put it, because the world-famous philosopher, who has strangely become an American best-seller in recent months, has hardly been aware that there is a war on and Rome has been conquered again.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- More doctors are likely to be taken from the cities and elsewhere to meet the needs of war, according to an announcement of the War Manpower Commission, which stated that the "essentiality" of physicians hitherto regarded as overage for military service was being re-examined.
VATICAN CITY, June 14 -- The Vatican, which was a haven for all kinds of people during the German occupation of Italy, gave asylum to nineteen escaped Allied war prisoners, it was learned today.
ST. LOUIS, June 14 (AP) -- Perseverance paid off for the Cardinals, who played it uphill today to shake off the cellar-dwelling Cubs, 10 to 9.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The names of Governors Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma and J. Melville Broughton of North Carolina and Senator Samuel D. Jackson of Indiana will figure prominently in discussions of men to fill key positions in the forthcoming Democratic convention, when party leaders meet here tomorrow to make up a slate of temporary officials.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, June 15 -- Tanks and infantry of four German armored divisions yesterday launched a series of heavy counter-attacks on the two salients that British tanks and American infantry had driven through enemy positions south of Bayeux, Allied Supreme Headquarters revealed last night.

Infantry Day, set aside in honor of the foot soldier, who has been an outstanding factor in past victories and is now spearheading the invasion of western Europe, will be observed today at scores of ceremonies and parades throughout the nation.
Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Warburton have come to the Plaza from Philadelphia.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 14 -- Mrs. Frank Goodyear of Piping Rock took the low net honors with 87 -- 12 -- 75 in the second one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

Federal taxpayers were reminded yesterday by James W. Johnson, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third New York District, that the second quarter deadline for filing amended tax declarations and paying installments on the 1944 Federal tax will be midnight tonight.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Dexter L. Lewis, director of the Central States Drivers Council, announced today 98 per cent of AFL union truck drivers in twelve States who participated in a strike ballot had voted in favor of walking out to bring enforcement of a War Labor Board directive increasing hourly and mileage wage rates.

Today will be observed in the Army as Infantry Day. It is really the infantry's birthday, for on June 15, 1775, George Washington became Commander in Chief of the Continental Army, composed almost wholly of foot soldiers. All Americans will, in their hearts, join in the observance.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Defense objections to the introduction and identification of German-American Bund "commands" to local Bund leaders, directing them to tell their members not to register for the draft, occupied the entire day of the mass sedition trial, with arguments of defense counsel barely started when the day ended.

The Photography Center of the Museum of Modern Art has been temporarily closed until new quarters can be found. It has been located across from the museum's sculpture garden in a remodeled house which has been placed on the market.

HAZLETON, Pa., June 14 -- A fifteen-month fight, marked by four strikes and Government operation of the coal fields, neared an end tonight with the gathering of delegates representing 80,000 members of the United Mine Workers in the anthracite region to ratify an agreement having as its salient feature a 70-cent-a-day wage increase.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Indications that the War Production Board may end its controls over the distribution of all rayon yarn except that required to fill military needs brought a protest today from the hosiery industry, which has heretofore used the yarn only at WPB direction.

Edward Waters, a taxi driver of 361 West Fifty-first Street, found two envelopes in his cab yesterday afternoon containing $27,200 in $50 and $100 bills and fifteen minutes later he had turned the money over to the police, but up to a late hour last night it had not been claimed.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- More than a hundred pages of testimony comprise a report submitted today by the Military Affairs Committee of the House, alleging flagrant misconduct and malfeasance in office of an Army officer whose alleged negligence, it was indicated, might have figured largely in the success of the Japanese attack at Pearl Harbor.

Recent on-the-spot reports from Normandy show that sentiment for de Gaulle there is by no means so vigorous as it is on the editorial page of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Here, then, is a practical demonstration of the realism and wisdom of the Administration in steadfastly refusing to accept de Gaulle's leadership as the over-all will of the French people.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, was disclosed today to have laid down a "tighter editorial control" over the contents of magazines which the OWI publishes for overseas distribution.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, June 15 (U.P.) -- Liberator bombers dropped twenty-three tons of explosives on the airdrome on Palau Island Sunday and shot down or probably destroyed twenty-eight of fifty Japanese interceptors that battled the raiders in their fourth successive day of attacks against the enemy's important Carolines Island base, it was announced today.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- Defending champion Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles rallied magnificently today to defeat 16-year-old Miss Shirley Fry of Akron, 4 -- 6, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 2, thereby reaching the semi-finals of the national clay court championship at the Detroit Tennis Club.
CHUNGKING, China, June 14 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Bob Duffy, headed for the Navy next month, made his final appearance on the mound for St. Peter's a successful one by hurling the Staten Island school to the Division B.C.H.S.A.A. championship over All Hallows, 11 to 4, yesterday at Fordham Field.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Maj. Gen. Norman T. Kirk and Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, Surgeons General respectively of the Army and Navy, told tonight of improved casualty records in the country's armed services.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The recent accidental gassing of several hundred civilians in Brooklyn, N.Y., has given the Army valuable information on the treatment of gas casualties, the War Department reported today.

Halevy's "La Juive" was presented before a large audience last night at Madison Square Garden. The opera, produced under the supervision of Maurice Frank, was preceded by Flag Day ceremonies, and, after the second act, James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, made an address.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Approximately 31,000,000 postcard applications for absentee State ballots, and about 7,600.000 Federal ballots ready for filling out have been sent to soldiers overseas and within the United States.
