An increasing dislocation in supply during the six weeks since most meats were made point free and the prospect of reduced production in the fall were seen yesterday as foreshadowing the return of all or most of the principal cuts of meat to the ration list.

DETROIT, Mich., June 14 -- Current deliveries of war products by the automotive industry are running approximately twice the dollar volume reported in the peak peacetime production year of 1941, the Automotive Council for War Production reported today.

AT FIELD HEADQUARTERS, United States Forces in Cherbourg Peninsula, 6:30 P.M., June 14 (U.P.) -- The United States infantry resumed the offensive today, and the doughboys are moving westward in the direction of St. Sauveur-Le Vicomte, about sixteen miles south of Cherbourg and westward of the blazing Montebourg-Carentan line.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 14 -- With hundreds of merchant ships running troops and supplies between Britain and the Normandy beachhead, so far on the ninth day of the invasion not one American merchant marine seaman is known to have lost his life in the operations, Charles Hogan of the War Shipping Administration said today.

Imposition of stringent peace measures against Japan but under terms that would be conducive to her cooperation in the building and maintenance of a stable world order were advocated in a statement issued yesterday by fifteen religious leaders, members of the Far East Settlement Group called together by the Commission on a Just and Durable peace to make an independent study of post-war problems of the Far East.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Two hundred women, representing seventy-five organizations, voted at a White House conference today on "How Women May Share in Post-War Policy-Making" that "we will take every step within our power to further the active participation of qualified women in positions of responsibility pertaining to the conduct of public affairs, national and international."

PEARL HARBOR, June 14 -- Action against the Japanese in the last few days flamed across thousands of miles in the Pacific from the lower Marianas to the Kuriles, the latter within 600 miles of the home island of Hokkaido, it was disclosed here today.
Electrical power production increased more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index rose to 153.8 from 153.4 in the previous week. The figure for the week ended June 12, 1943, was 149.2.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Refining operations in the oil industry reached a new peak last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The nation's refiners ran to stills an average of 4,670,000 barrels daily of crude oil, an increase of 50,000 over the previous record of 4,620,000 in the preceding week.

A hint when residential construction is resumed it may be on a rationed or priority basis was made by Thomas G. Grace, New York State director of the Federal Housing Administration, at a luncheon meeting of the Long Island Real Estate Board yesterday in the Forest Hills Inn, Forest Hills, Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- After receiving "satisfactory assurances" from the Administration that no agreement for a trans-Arabian pipeline or on any other foreign oil matters would be made "without timely notice to the committee," the Senate Special Oil Resources Committee announced today that it would delay public hearings pending further Anglo-American negotiations on the proposed Saudi Arabia pipeline.

STANTON, Del., June 14 (AP) -John M. Schiff's Shotlo, backed into 9-10 favoritism, accounted for the Spring Maiden Steeplechase, Delaware Park division, today. The first division had been won at Pimlico by G.H. Bostwick's Bridlespur and the second at Belmont Park by Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Chesapeake.

An auction sale of valuable objects of art will be held in the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, on Wednesday, June 28, under the auspices of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Second Region Council, Inc., 36 East Thirty-sixth Street, it was announced yesterday.

Fresh crab meat, a year-'round delicacy that hits its peak during the summer months, is coming into the city in good quantities this year, exceeding supplies of past seasons, according to reports from the Fishery Council and the Fish and Wildlife Service.

American air and sea attacks on a vast arc from the Marianas to the Kuriles have shrunk the Japanese frontier once again. To the north they have carried war to within 600 miles of the home island of Hokkaido.

Andre Labarthe, editor of Tricolor, a magazine, denied yesterday that Normandy was "a land of plenty," and attributed Allied correspondents' dispatches telling of French civilians' living in luxury to a clever Nazi propaganda device.

LONDON, June 14 -- Detailing the reasons for the recent British protest to the Turkish Government on the passage of German naval vessels through the Dardanelles, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that the Turkish President had promised to have the whole matter re-examined.

The three top prize winners in the annual essay contest conducted by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in conjunction with the Board of Education and the Catholic School Boards, defended "Wartime Rationing" in their essays, which they read yesterday at a ceremony held at 65 Liberty Street.
MOSCOW, June 14 (AP) -- An Eastern Command, United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe, communique:
MYITKYINA AIRDROME, Burma, May 21 (Delayed) -- The first refugees from Myitkyina Plain of white blood to turn up at the Chinese-American headquarters came in this afternoon.

Wide fluctuations in prices of cotton futures yesterday on the cotton Exchange here were caused by confusion over legislative developments in Washington. The market, however, closed at about the best levels of the day, up 4 to 5 points net, and at new highs for the life of the contracts.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld yesterday a Federal Tax Court ruling that an author's sale of movie rights to a play did not constitute the sale of a "capital gain," which might be treated specially for income tax purposes.

With experience gained as a successful night-club operator (The Latin Quarter) and as co-producer of two revues ("Artists and Models" didn't last long, but the "Ziegfeld Follies" is now in its second year), Lou Walters is branching into the vaudeville field tonight with the delayed opening of "Take a Bow" at the Broadhurst.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June l4 -- A quartet of potential golf champions, all over 55 in years and under 80 in their scores, led the parade of forty-eight Westchester seniors who started in quest of the association's tenth annual championship at Westchester Hills today.

A provision equivalent to the Bank-head amendment passed by the Senate, which was designed to force an increase in textile prices on the assumption that this would raise the price of raw cotton, was defeated yesterday in the House, after the majority leader warned that the President would veto the measure extending price controls if this amendment was in it.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The discussion over the threatened exercise of independence by Presidential electors, which was evoked by the actions of the Democratic conventions of South Carolina, Texas and Mississippi, started a search of political histories and the statutes which has already unearthed much of interest, and possibly of great importance, with respect to the elections of 1944.

Cost-of-living bonuses totaling $780,000 for 6,450 New York City teachers and administrative employes were voted yesterday by the Board of Education at its regular meeting at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn. Starting July 1 all school employes receiving less than $3,000 yearly are to get increases of $120 a year.
LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
With every prospect of one of the biggest crowds of the year at the Polo Grounds last night, rain came along to wash out the scheduled game between the Giants and the Dodgers.

The Axis forces are retreating everywhere under pressure by men who carry the American flag and do not know the meaning of defeat, Council President Newbold Morris declared yesterday at the twenty-seventh annual Flag Day exercises of the Sons of the American Revolution in the State of New York.

A world-wide reminder of the pledge of the thirty-five free governments of the United Nations to stand together in war and in planning for peace after victory was broadcast yesterday by "The Voice of America" stations of the Office of War Information.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 14 (AP) -- Communique 17:

Referring to the article signed William Stringer in your paper this morning -- entitled "Land of Plenty Described in Normandy" -- we wish to take vigorous exception to the conclusions drawn from the picturesque scene he describes as having discovered in a deserted house there.

New Hampshire's Bob Elliot puts in a friendly word for the pan fisherman, whom he terms "the forgotten man of rod and reel." The dissertation is prompted by the fact that the season for pan fish is now thriving in his State.

WITH THE CHINESE ARMY, on the Salween River, June 13 (Delayed) -- Since a few hundred stubborn Japanese are still holding out in the hills above Lameng, where the Burma Road crosses the Salween River, the Chinese again plastered them with artillery fire today.
LONDON, June 14 (U.P.) -- Pierre Laval may be on the verge of resigning and fleeing France as a result of the upheaval inside the country, official French quarters said tonight.

BOSTON, June 14 -- Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, in an address here today took issue with recent statements by Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, who opposes Federal aid to States and communities for planning post-war public works on the ground that it is unnecessary because the latter are already planning sufficient projects to provide their proper share of employment after the war.

Apparently F. Hugh Herbert is to be the spokesman for the youthful female of the species, somewhat as Booth Tarkington and "Seven-teen" were for the male. A year or so ago he wrote "Kiss and Tell," and he is responsible for Corliss Archer on the radio.

TEXAS CITY, Tex., June 14 -Deputy Petroleum Administrator Ralph K. Davies disclosed today that by July 1 the United Nations would have facilities to produce more than 500,000 barrels daily of 100-octane aviation gasoline -- more than all the oil of all kinds available to Axis Europe.

LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- French authorities in Algiers warned today that if the Germans shot captured members of the resistance movement "the French Provisional Government [Committee of National Liberation] will be forced to take all necessary counter-measures."

American soldiers entering little towns in Normandy have been surprised by finding, in some deserted houses, the evidences of comfortable living. They had heard that the French were starving, but these French seemed to have had meat, cream, butter and wine in abundance.

The new pricing regulation of the Office of Price Administration providing dollar-and-cents exemption levels for eight basic raw furs evoked a favorable reaction here yesterday. The industry, it was stated, now looks forward to issuance of the coordinated order for manufacturers which, when it appears, is expected to revive activity which has been restricted for weeks because of uncertainty about prices.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Allied drive in the vicinity of Caumont and Villers-Bocage, southwest of Caen, on the Normandy front, is of considerable significance, in the opinion of military observers here, because it exposes the Germans to the twin dangers of thrusts either at Caen or St. Lo, both important points in the present fighting.

Your editorial appearing in THE TIMES this morning, which you have titled "Inflation Bill," is a direct, clear and forceful summary of the startling events of the past few weeks in the Senate. We commend your stand and your comprehension of the factors which all thoughtful citizens must know will start a real inflationary spiral.
Yesterday was Ted Atkinson day at Aqueduct, for the little Canadian rode five of his seven mounts to victory, as 21,480 racegoers are now ready to admit, some somewhat reluctantly.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Shipments of hogs to market here continued too heavy for current outlay today and there was no change in the congested condition of the market.

Although supporters of Gov. John W. Bricker are claiming between 250 and 300 votes at the Republican National Convention for the Ohio Governor, supporters of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey continued yesterday to profess confidence in the nomination of the New York Governor on the first ballot.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- The Government commission that is investigating conditions in Odessa during the German-Rumanian occupation today laid charges of murder, robbery and oppression against twenty-one German generals and officers and members of the fifty-four Rumanian military personnel and civilians.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, reaffirmed today his belief that the Republican National Convention would not nominate a candidate on the first ballot.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Mayor La Guardia proposed to the Senate Military Affairs Committee today a seven-point program for handling the unemployment and other problems developing from industry's reconversion to peacetime production.

The stock market was subjected yesterday to periodic thrusts of profit-taking which tended to stem the advance but renewed strength in the final hour kept the list on a firm note. At times it was difficult to separate this selling from actual cashing-in orders or from switching operations.

The International Petroleum Company, Ltd., reported yesterday in its annual statement for 1943 a net profit of $15,973,549, equal to $1.10 a share on the combined preferred and common stocks. This compares with $13,611,825, or 94 cents a share, earned in 1942.

ALBANY, June 14 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed Ernest B. Morris, a Republican and deputy Attorney General, to take the place of Albany County's Democratic District Attorney, John P. Delaney, who resigned Monday night in a letter to the Governor, which said developments in the investigation of crime in the county indicated a design to make him "a political football."

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The President conferred with Robert Hannegan, National Democratic Chairman; Brig. Gen. Joseph C. Mehaffey, Governor of the Canal Zone; the Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Chaplain-Bishop of the Army and Navy, and with the Polish Prime Minister and Polish Ambassador.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 14 -- Preparatory to starting out tomorrow morning in the 72-hole $10,000 Red Cross open tournament, the crack golf professionals of the country joined with the amateurs in the 18-hole best-ball competition today over the course of the Wykagyl Country Club.

To drive home the point that carelessness and waste will lengthen the war, a new series of cartoon style advertisements, some in color and others in black and white, will appear in the June and July overseas issues of national magazines, the War Advertising Council announced yesterday.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has sold to Frederick Brown the thirteen-story apartment house at 258 Riverside Drive, southeast corner of Ninety-eighth Street, on an irregular plot 100 by 108 feet.

Thefts from interstate shipments figured in two Federal court cases yesterday. One involved the taking of nearly 150,000 razor blades from a shipment consigned to British forces abroad, the other the pilfering of $100,000 worth of cotton goods from Pennsylvania Railroad Pier 49, North River.

Assemblyman John A. Devany Jr. of 120 West 183d Street has not been designated as an organization candidate for renomination, it became known yesterday when Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the executive committee of the Bronx County Democratic Committee, announced the list of designees for Democratic nominations in that county.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 -- Skippy Homeier, the 12-year-old actor who created the role of Emil Bruckner, the evil Nazi boy in "Tomorrow the World," will repeat the part in Lester Cowan's film version of the play. Cowan tested a score or more Hollywood boy actors for the part before deciding on young Homeier.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 14 -- A 29-year-old German woman was landed at a British port today, still wearing the bedraggled civilian clothing in which she was captured. Over her arm she carried a deerskin handbag, in which she hid the gun with which she shot and wounded several American soldiers.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Polish Prime Minister, Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, said today that he was confident that "Poland can count on the support and real friendship of the United States," but he added that he had not discussed the Russo-Polish boundary question with President Roosevelt and he did not suggest that any new formula had been found for solving his Government's difficulties with the Soviet Union.

Urging a "rebuilding" of individual character and a full sense of individual responsibility, Senator Albert W. Hawkes of New Jersey addressed yesterday 300 Kiwanis from the metropolitan area at a luncheon given in his honor in the New York City Kiwanis Club at the McAlpin Hotel.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 14 -- That Brazilian trade with the United States will increase after the war is the general opinion here, but to maintain that trade will prove to be a matter bristling with thorns, it is felt.

The title over this paragraph is just as appropriate as the famous chapter heading on Snakes in Ireland. There are no snakes in Ireland. There is no timetable in Mr. Laski's new book, "Faith, Reason and Civilization."

CLEVELAND, June 14 (AP) -- Rufus Gentry's tight pitching and a powerful hitting onslaught gave Detroit a pair of victories over the Indians today. The Tigers took the opener, 3 to 0, and the nightcap, 11 to 3.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The House by a voice vote adopted the bill to continue price, rent and wage controls for a year beyond June 30, after defeating the "cotton amendments" but accepting the Dirksen amendment giving Federal district courts jurisdiction over Office of Price Administration regulations with power to enjoin enforcement.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- The Browns hammered two White Sox pitchers for sixteen hits and a 10-to-3 victory before 24,893 tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The United States naval task force participating in the French invasion was composed of more than 1,300 ships, from men-of-war down to large landing craft, Secretary James Forrestal revealed today in his first detailed report on the Navy's role in the new European operations.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 48:

WITH UNITED STATES TROOPS IN FRANCE, June 14 (AP) -- Tank-supported American infantrymen beat back an attack on Carentan today and then pushed on themselves in hand-to-hand fighting and gained control of high ground south of the strategic town.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The United States should, in its own interest, promote the economic and political freedom of India, the Netherlands Indies and other colonial areas in the Pacific and should help bring a defeated Japan into the ranks of a "free Asia" after the war, Vice President Henry A. Wallace suggests in a pamphlet issued today by the American Council of the Institute of Pacific Relations.

Mayor LaGuardia paid tribute last night to the late Mrs. Daniel Guggenheim at the memorial concert in her honor given by the Goldman Band on the Mall in Central Park as it opened its twenty-seventh open-air season. The concerts are the gift of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation to the people of New York.

LONDON, Thursday, June 15 (UP) -- Four Russian Army columns, backed by artillery firing wheel to wheel, fanned out over the wild Karelian Isthmus on a broadening twenty-eight-mile front yesterday and one unit pushed to within thirty-seven miles southeast of the Finish gateway city of Viborg by capturing the town of Kuuterselkae, on the east side of the Leningrad-Helsinki railroad.

" Man From Frisco," a topical drama about the shipbuilding industry produced by Republic and starring Michael O'Shea and Anne Shirley, will open this morning at Loew's State. Featured are Ray Walker, Gene Lockhart, Dan Duryea and Stephanie Bachelor.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Consideration of the Senate-approved bill to prohibit after July, 1947, all commercial use of the Red Cross insignia or emblem was resumed today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee which will hold another open hearing tomorrow and on Friday go into executive session on the measure.
ISIGNY, France, June 14 (AP) -- When General de Gaulle visited his homeland today Frenchmen lined the streets of beachhead villages shouting his name.

LONDON, Thursday, June 15 (AP) -- The Allies' troops already were moving onto the beaches of Normandy when Gen. Charles de Gaulle withdrew all but a handful of the French officers who had been counted on by the Allies' command to act as liaison officers with the French people and to help take over civil administration, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A program for post-war handling of cartels has been recommended by technical experts of government departments, calling for an international agreement pledging nations to an anti-cartel policy which, however, would recognize that international commercial agreements can serve other than restrictive purposes.

Government orders for what are known in the furniture industry as "non-combatant" articles, have fallen off considerably recently with some factories receiving none at all, it was disclosed yesterday by mill representatives here.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden. June 14 -- The Russian offensive on the Karelian Isthmus may provoke a Cabinet crisis in Finland soon. Leading Finns in favor of peace have again made their voices heard with renewed vigor as a result of Finland's dilemma and have insisted that a new Cabinet be formed by Juho Paasikivi, former envoy to Moscow.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Bernard M. Baruch and John M. Hancock, advisers to the Office of War Mobilization, urged "hurry, hurry, hurry not only in winning the war but in being ready for the peace," in a letter which started reports that the two had threatened to resign because of the delay in acting on their Feb. 15 recommendations.
ALBANY, June 14 (AP) -- An opinion was given today by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein that, for security reasons, the military addresses of service men should not be made public.
The program of sports and entertainment that will make up the Fifth War Loan Sports Carnival at the Polo Grounds on Saturday night continues to grow in length.
BOSTON, June 14 (AP) -- The surging Red Sox extended their winning streak to eight games today by taking a double bill from the Athletics, 6 -- 4 and 5 - 0. Pinky Woods pitched the five-hit shut-out.

Prompt revision of the ceiling-price order on used ears to include rationing, a 15 per cent higher mark-up for dealers than is provided, and elimination of regional price differentials was called for yesterday by C.D. Henderson, manager of the New York State Automobile Dealers, Inc. The used-car ceiling order, which was issued last Saturday, will become effective July 10.

A syndicate represented by Glekel Drimmer has purchased from Goldie Schack a two-story taxpayer building at 35 West 125th Street. The property, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, is assessed at $108,000. It was purchased for cash over a first mortgage of $97,500.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Roosevelt signed today a joint resolution extending until Dec. 7 the time in which Army and Navy officers may be tried by court-martial for the disaster at Pearl Harbor, but qualified his approval with a statement, indicating his belief that such proceedings would not be pressed to the detriment of the war.

Calling for "a complete readaptation of all the varied child-care resources to meet the actual conditions and needs for care as they exist now," Homer Folks, secretary, State Charities Aid, said yesterday that New York City was facing a genuine crisis in child care because of the lack of boarding homes and institutional facilities for dependent children.

Tangible proof that the Fifth War Loan drive has got away to a flying start was provided yesterday by Nevil Ford, chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York State, who made public the first tabulations of sales. They showed that the opening day's sale of E bonds more than doubled those of the first day of the Fourth War Loan.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Five hundred members of the armed forces are being discharged every month because of tuberculosis, Surgeon General Thomas Parran said today.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- A new exhaustion disease, interesting to every one who is putting out extra war effort, was reported to the American Medical Association today by Dr. J.M. Nielsen of Los Angeles. It comes on suddenly, an exhaustion so deep that a person cannot continue any activity for the moment.

After a week of conferences in Washington, Poland's Prime Minister asserts that he will return to London confident that his country "can count on the support and friendship of the United States." To this he adds his belief that feeling between Russia and Poland has been improved by contacts between the Red Army and the Polish underground, and his hope that diplomatic relations with the Soviet Government can be re-established.

The battle in Normandy has now entered into that phase of an amphibious invasion in which the Germans begin to launch determined counter-attacks with steadily increasing strength. Having seen a wide section of their "Atlantic Wall" smashed, their local defense forces overrun, and their tactical reserves pinned down while the Allies organize, develop and reinforce their bridgehead, the German commanders have begun to draw on their reserves in an effort to halt the Allied advance.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 14 (UP) -- A communique:

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES, In the Cherbourg Peninsula, June 13 (Delayed) -- The Germans had fortifications here that theoretically would have been capable of repelling any invasion force with tremendous casualties.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES IN CAEN SECTOR, 12 N., June 14 -- The entire British front line burst into action today, and the earth rocked crazily as Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery opened a "Monty barrage," the mightiest cannonade of the invasion, against the desperately fighting Germans.

In his interesting letter in today's TIMES, in which H.S.B. suggests that Eisenhower is the English for Iron Hewer, he speaks of the Battle of Hastings as the scene of Taillefer's striking the first blow "for a Latin civilization against a relatively primitive Teutonic people."

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Administration announced tonight a lend-lease agreement with India under which 100,000,000 ounces of silver would be supplied to that country by the United States, and at the same time disclosed that total lend-lease shipments of silver to all countries to date amounted to about 4,000 short tons.

CHUNGKING, China, June 14 (UP) -- A reinforced Japanese army battled the defenders of Hunan province across a 100-mile front today and an official spokesman said that the war against Japan might be delayed for years if the enemy succeeded in his attempt to control the Peiping-Hankow and Canton-Hankow railways.

ALGIERS, June 14 -- American troops are battling in France to drive the Germans out. It is almost entirely American material that has enabled the large French Army to strike effective blows against the Germans in Italy. Lend-lease is supplying the French forces in reserve that will form the nucleus of the future army of France.

Tyranny had a hard jolt on this day 729 years ago when surly King John came riding down to Runnymede from Windsor to face his angry barons and agree to restraints upon his royal authority. The barons, themselves tyrants, were thinking of their own rights rather than of the rights of the churl or the serf, the common man of that day.

Public School 116, at 210 East Thirty-third Street, the only school in New York City entitled to boast that not one of its pupils has a single cavity or other dental flaw, was cited yesterday by the Community Service Society for "signal achievement in public health."

Directors of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 15 cents in addition to a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, both payable June 30. On March 31 an extra of 10 cents was distributed.

Myron C. Taylor, personal representative of President Roosevelt to the Vatican, who was asked last week to return to his post as soon as possible, has sold Edge Road, a two-story dwelling on a plot of two and one-half acres at Locust Valley, L.I., to John Walter Wood, airway analyst with the Port of New York Authority.

Stockholders of the White Rock Mineral Springs Company will be asked to vote, at a special meeting to be called soon, on a plan for the National Distillers Products Corporation to acquire the assets, business and good will of White Rock Mineral Springs, approved by directors of the latter company, A.E. Phillips, president, announced yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., June 14 -- Dean W. Mathey of Deerfield Academy out-played Joseph D. Scheerer Jr., of Hill, seeded first, 6 -- 2, 8 -- 6, to reach the semi-final round in the singles championship of the twelfth annual Eastern interscholastic tennis tournament at the Manursing Island Club today.

" The Official Guide to the Army Air Forces," an analysis compiled and written by its members, will be published on June 30 by both Simon Schuster and Pocket Books. It will contain a foreword by Gen. H.H. Arnold, commanding general, Army Air Forces, and photographs, drawings, charts and maps.

Two hardy veterans of ring wars who are beating back along the fistic trail will meet tonight in Madison Square Garden when Henry Armstrong, the Californian who will always be remembered as the only boxer ever to hold three titles at one time, engages Al Davis, Brownsville favorite, in the stellar bout scheduled for ten rounds.
CHUNGKING, China, June 14 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The wheat market rallied sharply in the last half-hour of trading today on the adoption by the House of an amendment to the price-control bill providing that processors must pay parity prices for farm commodities or be penalized for failing to do so by enforcement of lower price ceilings on processed articles.

Affording the first example of an industry objecting to the removal of Government control, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers yesterday registered its protest to the proposed revocation of General Preference Order M-37-d which allocates rayon yarn for the production of women's hosiery.

The advocates of a rise in prices of petroleum in an effort to stimulate further the discovery of new sources of production suffered another setback yesterday when the House of Representatives defeated an amendment to the Price Control Bill which would have increased the price by 35 cents a barrel.

Harold Fields, member of the Board of Examiners of the Board of Education since 1940, was elected chairman of the board for the coming year at the board's annual election yesterday. The examiners receive $11,000 a year.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, June 15 (AP) -- A communique:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, June 15 -- The United States Eighth Air Force put more than 1,500 heavy bombers into an assault on the Nazis from France to the upper Rhineland yesterday -- a number exceeding by at least 100 the previous high mark for "heavies" dispatched in a single operation.

ABOARD U.S.S. AUGUSTA, in the Bay of Seine, June 13 (Delayed) -- Aside from the obvious weaknesses of the Germans in the air and in repelling the initial Allied landings on the coast of Normandy, a week's fighting has brought forth a number of indications that the German Army isn't what it was a year ago.
DETROIT, June 14 -- Based on dollar volume, current deliveries of war products by the automotive industry are running about twice the amount of the peak peacetime production year of 1941.

CINCINNATI, Thursday, June 15 (AP) -- An eleventh-inning rally pulled a ball game out of the fire for the Reds early today as they gained a 3-2 decision over the Pirates. Rain stopped play twice and the contest ended long after midnight.

HAROLD LASKI, the British Socialist and Independent Laborite politician, writes like a dream. Unfortunately, his prose, which is grave and sonorous, has the lack of staying quality that one usually associates with dreams. Like Santayana's style, the Laski sentences fall like a lullaby on the ear, diverting one from any impulse to grapple with what is being said.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during May amounted to 831,889 bales of lint and 120,831 bales of linters, compared with 902,301 bales of lint and 98,586 of linters in May, 1943.
Life is not worth living without liberty. No sacrifice is too great to preserve it.

Monogram will produce forty-seven feature films on its 1944-45 program, it was announced by President W. Ray Johnston, at the thirteenth annual franchise holders' convention at the Hotel Ambassador in Los Angeles. The budget, according to the announcement, "will far exceed anything ever attempted by the company in the past."

Absenteeism in 5,000 war plants employing 5,000,000 wage-earners dropped from 6.06 to 4 per cent after industrial feeding was introduced, Government sources revealed yesterday. This survey was included in the latest group of figures available at the War Food Administration's Office of Distribution in Washington.

Adolescents may be bigger headaches to themselves than they are to their parents, Dr. Lawrence K. Frank of the Institute of Human Development said yesterday at the closing session of the three-day forum on "Raising Your Children," presented by Saks-34th Street.
NAPLES, June 14 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The House passed the price control extension bill today after writing in a provision aimed at guaranteeing parity prices for all farm products by penalizing processors who fail to pay them.
WITH BRITISH SIXTH AIRBORNE DIVISION, France, June 12 (Delayed) -- Paratroop Capt. Charles Bliss had that grin on his face that always means something brewing.

LONDON, June 14 -- The stock markets here were active again today, with the main emphasis on leading industrial, oil and Far Eastern securities. Chinese bonds were prominent on the improved outlook in Burma and Japanese issues showed further gains.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court granted permission today to pro-Roosevelt Democrats to file a mandamus suit to compel the Democratic State Executive Committee to certify for printing on the July 22 primary ballot the names of Presidential electors chosen by the pro-Roosevelt forces in a rump State convention.

TRENTON, N.J., June 14 (P) -- The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, in a split decision, approved today a new and lower schedule of electric rates of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Dr. B.H. Beckhart, Columbia University professor and economic adviser to the Chase National Bank of New York, has filed with the House Foreign Affairs Committee a statement supplementing his testimony of April 27 on intergovernmental currency plans, in which he denies that he changed his views regarding the dangers of the joint currency proposals of United Nations experts.

The American people believe in a life of enterprise and expansion by individual initiative. But all the talk today of a "return" to free enterprise and private initiative is merely an expression of feeling; not a solution of problems. We are not going to return to anything.

Despite the prospect of severe crop shortages in continental Europe and tremendous relief-food needs in liberated countries, the War Food Administration now has enough food reserves for such purposes to enable it to taper off its current stockpiling program, Lee Marshall, director of that agency's office of distribution, disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, June 14 -- That the German Army is not really trying to throw the Allies out of Fortress Europe but merely to make them pay dearly for their breach of its defenses was the new attitude of German commentators today.

Declaring that it had received many complaints regarding poor service and maintenance in the city's subways, the Brooklyn Civic Council, representing more than sixty organizations, announced yesterday it would campaign for the establishment of a New York City Transit Authority by the next session of the State Legislature.

Zoning amendments that would require all new buildings throughout the city, except manufacturing and industrial structures, to comply with more stringent height and area restrictions than those now in force were proposed yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

An issue of $384,000 of refunding bonds which Lodi, N.J., originally planned to sell on June 2 is scheduled now for award on June 23. The issue will mature serially from July 1, 1945 to 1970. The interest rate is to be named by the bidders at not to exceed 3 3/4 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) -- The Republic Service Corporation's application for a year's extension of time in which to comply with "death sentence" provisions of the Holding Company Act was denied today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 14 -- Partly implementing his threat of May 29 to install a German commissioner unless the Regency Council in Bulgaria could appoint a Government "capable of maintaining order," Adolf Hitler today appointed Joseph Neubacher as interim "German delegate to the Bulgarian Regency Council" -- de facto German Commissioner -- Balkan sources reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (U.P.) -- The War Department tonight named three new combat planes: The A-26 Invader, the P-63 King Cobra and the P-39, a jet-propulsion airacomet, and gave out more facts about the new Black Widow night fighter.

ROME, June 14 -- The Allies, in hard fighting, have broken through a hastily established German defense arc above Rome at three vital points and are nearing the important highway hubs of Grosseto, 114 road miles northwest of the capital, and Terni, sixty-two road miles north of it, it was announced today.

LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- The Admiralty announced today the appointment of Vice Admiral Sir Henry R. Moore, many times decorated during his career of forty-two years in fighting ships, as commander of the British Home Fleet.

NEWARK, N.J., June 14 (AP) -Fifth War Loan Bond purchases uy individuals in New Jersey totaled $18,000,000 today, State Administrator John E. Manning said. Series E bonds made up $14,800,000 of the amount.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A combination of circumstances, along with Clark Griffith's renowned perserverance, conspired tonight to give the Yankees, figuratively speaking, the first ray of sunshine they had glimpsed in more than a week.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Navy announced tonight that twenty-seven men were killed, 100 are missing and 380 were wounded in the explosion which destroyed several small landing craft in Pearl Harbor May 21.

A charge that the Board of Education, in granting $120 a year salary increases to school employes earning less than $3,000, ignored the plight of more than 25,000 of its 32,000 employes was made yesterday by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations. At its meeting Wednesday the board voted increases to 6,450 teachers and administrative workers, amounting to $780,000.

Welcoming delegates from many sections of the country to the fifth annual convention of the Negro Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, praised the contribution of members of their race to the war and denied the existence of "a Negro problem" in America.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that the city's school children collected last month 2,083 tons of waste paper, or ninety-five tons a school day, and his Citation for Service on the Home Front was won by 231 schools, where at least eight pounds of paper a student had been turned in.

While food rationing cannot be relaxed completely until Europe has harvested its first complete crop, the Office of Price Administration will relinquish controls as quickly as possible during the interim whenever increased supplies make possible such a policy, Jean Carroll, director of the agency's Food Price Division, declared yesterday.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, June 16 -- Americans, supported by tanks, are advancing on a front of ten miles across the neck of the Cherbourg Peninsula, threatening La Haye du Puits and St. Sauveur-Le Vicomte, two of the most important links in the enemy's chain of communications with Cherbourg.

MADISON, Conn., June 15 (AP) -- Purchase of Shorelands, the twenty-three-acre estate of the late William F. Hoops, candy manufacturer, by John Gunther, author and radio commentator, was announced today by Abraham S. Ullman, attorney for the buyer. The purchase price was given as $25,000.

Seventy-seven graduating seniors will receive prizes, medals, honors and awards at City College's ninety-eighth commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium tomorrow night, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.

Carpets, rugs and linoleum remain items for which new fiber containers cannot be used, it was pointed out yesterday in the floor coverings industry. Some misunderstanding has occurred, it was said, due to the recent War Production Board action concerning Order L-317.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A nation-wide trend toward reductions in utility rates to bring power companies out of the excess profits tax, which experts estimate would cost the Federal Government $200,000,000 in annual revenue if it became universal, was observed today following announcement yesterday of the $5,000,000 annual rate reduction approved by the New Jersey State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.
WITH THE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE TO THE MARIANAS, June 10 (Delayed) -- Pacific operations enter a new phase in this theatre with the attack on Saipan to bring the Marianas Islands under control.

By purchasing $392,036,000 of United States Government securities in the open market during the fiscal week ended Wednesday the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System now hold $15,000,000,000 of these securities, a new record high, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

DETROIT, June 15 (AP) -- Using a borrowed racket, Miss Dorothy May Bundy of Santa Monica, Calif., toppled Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles from her national clay court tennis throne by scoring a decisive 7-5, 6-3 victory today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Almon E. Roth, president of the National Federation of American Shipping, declared today that the American Merchant Marine would be seriously handicapped after the war if the present ban against air operations by steamship lines was continued.

Our own TIMES account of Police Lieut. John Osnato, who is retiring after twenty-eight years of service, called him the ace of city detectives. It attributed his success in clearing up many apparently unsolvable cases to his "patience and knowledge of human weaknesses."

MANY novels about the members of America's plutocracy have a way of falling into one or the other of two classifications: Popular romances for the slick magazines and the rental library trade that emphasize the alleged glamour of silver champagne buckets and a winter home at Palm Beach; and crude mixtures of wild melodramatics and righteous indignation.

ALGIERS, June 15 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has recognized the resistance army inside France as an integral part of the Allies' forces and therefore should insist that the Germans treat them as legitimate military units, not as guerrillas to be shot on capture, Commissioner of the Interior d'Astier said today at a press conference.

The pamphlet report of operations of Remington Rand, Inc., for the year ended with March, mailed to stockholders yesterday, disclosed that output in that period set a new high record and current production is even greater.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 15 -- United States Secretary of State Cordell Hull, who has developed multi-lateralism in trade as opposed to the bilateralism of most European nations, may find one of these days that Russia has adopted the unilateral trade theory, it is considered here.

There are two influences on styles, says Florence Reichman -- one current news, the other art. In the former she finds no inspiration for her millinery offerings; from the latter she has derived the themes that make a thoroughly wearable and pretty collection of hats designed to serve daytime and evening needs.

Kent Cooper, general manager of The Associated Press and a well-known amateur composer, has written a new work called "The Magic of the Violin" that will have its premiere performance by NBC's Stradivari Orchestra on Sunday, July 2, at 12:30 P.M.

HAZLETON, Pa., June 15 -- The press, Federal agencies and Congress were accused today by Thomas Kennedy, secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers of conducting a campaign to render the union impotent by discrediting the leadership of the UMW which is headed by John L. Lewis.

LONDON, June 15 -- There was a slight falling off in business on the stock markets here today and with a tendency toward profit-taking, price movements were somewhat irregular. Setbacks, however, were small and there were fresh buyers for many issues.

HEADQUARTERS OF TWENTY-FIRST ARMY GROUP, Somewhere in England, June 15 (U.P.) -- The Germans are bringing up their E-boats into the English Channel, Admiral Sir Bertram H. Ramsay, Allied Naval Commander in Chief, disclosed today, although he added confidently that the "Channel will soon be completely ours -- as it jolly well ought to be."

The transfer trucks will be busy on Broadway tomorrow night hauling away four attractions. A fifth, which will not be named here, is tottering on the brink. Lest the wrong impression be created from this wholesale number of closings on one night, let it be added hastily that not all were failures.

Stockholders of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company approved yesterday a plan for refinancing of the utility's entire funded debt of $48,000,000 through the issuance of $42,000,000 of new securities and the use of about $6,000,000 from the company's treasury.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 15 -- With a par-shattering 30 for the homecoming nine and seven birdies over the last twelve holes, Sgt. Victor Ghezzi of England General Hospital, Atlantic City, led the field of 110 with a 67 at the end of the first round today in the $10,000 72-hole Red Cross open golf tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club.
ROME, June 15 (U.P.) -- Advancing Allied forces in Italy are within eighty miles of the next major enemy line at Florence, it was announced today.

The Women's Airforces Service Pilots -- Wasps -- have performed valiantly in many types of war service, including ferrying planes, towing targets, carrying out searchlight and radar missions and meteorological flights. They have been supporting the combat services at nearly a hundred different stations.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, June 15 -- The attacks by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's heavy bombers on Palau, 650 miles from Davao, Mindanao, the Philippines, and the raids announced today upon Dublon and Eten of the Truk group, as well as on Woleai in the Carolines, have been made according to a coordinated Pacific war plan to neutralize to the enemy those spots while the Navy landing at Saipan was occurring.
ALBANY, June 15 (AP) -- Thirteen thousand residents of Governor Dewey's native State of Michigan joined today in urging him to become a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 15 -- Bertram T. Blake of St. Andrews, whose championship feats were heretofore limited to the curling rink, captured the title in the tenth annual Westchester Seniors Golf Association tournament at the Westchester Hills course today.

WICHITA, Kan., May 6 -- The United States Army Air Force's new four-engined bomber, the B-29, which can fly so high and so fast it will be seen by enemy ground defenders only as a silver gnat and a vapor trail against the blue infinity of the sky, was presented for inspection during the past three days to American newspaper men at the Boeing plant near Wichita, where it is in quantity production.

The European Advisory Commission is going ahead with the drafting of the armistice convention. Two important issues, over which the American, British and Russian Governments were divided for months, have lately been settled in London, namely, the procedure to be followed for the enforcement of the armistice terms and the treatment to be meted out to the German Army.
SOMEWHERE IN NORMANDY, June 13 (Delayed) (AP) -- A squadron of American combat planes landed on an American airfield in France tonight, refuelled, rearmed and took off again to fight the enemy.
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) -- The Phillies came from behind twice to win from the Braves, 5 to 4, at Shibe Park tonight.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 15 (AP) -- British troops, heavily supported by United States war planes, struck today at Mogaung to wipe out this supporting base of the embattled Japanese garrison in Myitkyina, thirty-one miles east-northeast of Mogaung on the severed Burma railway.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Friday, June 16 (AP) -- A two-day 186-ton bombing attack on Truk -- the heaviest assault by land-based planes against that naval base -- and the war's first Liberator attack on Yap were reported today by headquarters.

The Russell Colgate Distinguished Service citation was awarded yesterday afternoon at a luncheon of the Christian education division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, at the Bankers Club of America, 120 Broadway, to the division chairman, Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney.

Mel Ott blasted his seventeenth home run of the year into the upper right-field balcony in the first inning at the Polo Grounds last night and that big blow, with two on, was enough to beat the Dodgers behind Harry Feldman's pitching and raise the Giants to a third place tie with the Reds.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, June 15 (U.P.) -- A new law protecting the property rights of news has been adopted by the National Assembly and has been signed and promulgated by President Lescot.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- For lack of a quorum, the House Foreign Affairs Committee was unable today to complete hearings on the Senate bill to prohibit after July, 1947, commercial use of the Red Cross insignia and emblem, and will meet again on Monday.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Severe criticism of Sister Elizabeth Kenny and her supporters for claims made for the Kenny treatment of infantile paralysis was made today at the annual convention of the American Medical Assiciation by a committee of seven orthopedic physicians appointed two years ago to investigate the treatment.

Provisions of the city sales tax that are said to place an unjust burden upon coastwise and transatlantic shipping probably will be amended, the finance committee of the City Council indicated last night after a public hearing on the five emergency tax bills that Mayor La Guardia has asked to have reenacted for another year.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The mass sedition trial ended its ninth week today with William Luedtke, former national secretary of the German-American Bund, on the stand and interest at a low mark.

For nearly twenty-five years American women have voted. In that time they have shown intelligence and wide range of capacity. It is notorious that they have not had anything like their fair representation in public office, State, national, municipal, local. Realizing their strength and their power of organization, some 500,000 of them have now formed a Women's Action Committee for Victory and Lasting Peace.

Grover Whalen, chairman-director of New York City Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, and seven women officials of the organization received gold ribbon awards for 5,000 hours of service to the community at a meeting of branch representatives yesterday at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- President Roosevelt advanced a plan today for post-war international security calling for the formation of "a fully representative organization" of peace-loving countries. It would elect a smaller council on which the four major United Nations would be constantly represented with a "suitable" number of smaller countries.

Details of an artillery type rocket projectile weighing fifty pounds, classified heretofore as secret, and used effectively in the invasion of France and on other fronts, were made public yesterday with the permission of the War Department.
West Side apartment houses figured in several of the Manhattan realty purchases announced yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 15 -- A price to farmers of $5 a hundredweight for milk was demanded by the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association in a resolution adopted at its meeting here today. League spokesmen said the average return to farmers for the year ended March 1 was $4 a hundredweight (47 quarts).

In your issue of June 14 Mr. R. Coudenhove-Kalergi states: First, that the last constitutional Government of France was the one to which General de Gaulle belonged; secondly, that General de Gaulle, because he did not resign, is still invested in his functions as a member of the French constitutional Government; and, third, that he thus has transferred his legitimate authority to the Committee of National Liberation in Algiers.

The first battle of France in 1940 was decided by ten German armored divisions which, paced by 1,000 dive bombers and followed by fast-moving motorized infantry, broke through the extended Maginot Line at Sedan, split the Allied armies in two, and precipitated both Dunkerque and the French collapse.

LONDON, June 15 -- Without waiting for an agreement with the United States and Great Britain on the civil administration of France, Gen. Charles de Gaulle has already installed a Commissioner for Civil Affairs in Normandy.
Chairman of the Board, United State Steel Corporation; Member Advisory Committee, Commerce and Industry Division, War Finance Committee for New York

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have increased $392,036,000 during the week to a new high record. Note circulation for the system as a whole was also at a new high, having increased $88,863,000, while the ratio of reserve declined further.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Gov. Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma, an ardent advocate of a fourth term for President Roosevelt, was chosen temporary chairman and keynoter for the Democratic National Convention at a short session of the committee on arrangements of the Democratic National Committee here today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The War Production Board advised the chemical industry today to make preparations for increasing its annual output of phthalic andydride, a chemical essential to a long list of military and civilian articles, by 12,000,000 pounds this year in an effort to bring its total 1944 production to about 138,000,000 pounds.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 15 (UP) -- A communique:

The best market news this week is that the poultry situation has improved considerably. Shoppers should have no difficulty finding fowl or duck, both of which are in good supply, with one large chain store reporting plentiful stocks. Small chickens also are available and shipments are said to be increasing.

LONDON, Friday, June 16 -- Operating even closer than heretofore with invading ground forces, probably more than 7,000 Allied aircraft joined in the battle in the twenty-four hours ended at midnight last night as favorable weather brought a further expansion of the mighty air assault on Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Employment offices who are at work on the job of priority referral after July 1 will question women seeking maids about what they are doing to help win the war, if a recommendation made today by the Women's Advisory Committee of the War Manpower Commission is put into effect.

I am a puzzled housewife. The egg situation outrages me. When I tried to buy eggs on Saturday the prices ranged from 53 to 57 cents a dozen, and the grocers seemed peeved when I asked why the prices were so high, when I understood that eggs were so plentiful.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The War Production Board has created an Office of Labor Advisory Committees which will permit labor a voice in production programs before they are made effective, it was reported today.

LONDON, Friday, June 16 -- Red Army forces have widened their breach in the Finnish lines across the Karelian Isthmus to more than forty-six miles and have pushed to within thirty-three miles of Viborg by capturing the heavily fortified town of Kanneljaervi, near the Leningrad-Helsinki Railroad, Moscow announced last night.

KANSAS CITY, June 15 (AP) -- Peacetime farm production of 50 per cent over pre-war levels is a decided possibility and may pose a serious surplus problem, Secretary of Agriculture Claude Wickard told regional directors of the Farm Credit Administration here today.

Pope Pius XII has elevated four priests of the Archdiocese of New York to the rank of Domestic Prelate with the title of Right Rev. Monsignor, it was announced yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman. The are:

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The combined Allied bombing-blockade program has not yet reduced Axis Europe to the starvation level, but it has greatly lowered the standard of living and forced the Germans to divert five-sixths of their available manpower away from direct munitions production, Dingle MacIntosh Foot, Parliamentary Secretary to the British Ministry of Economic Warfare, said today.

Greater luster was added to the War Bond Sports Carnival at the Polo Grounds tomorrow night with the announcement yesterday by Dan Ferris, track chairman, of a medley relay in which each of the services will be represented. An added starter will be a quartet from the Columbia Midshipmen's School coached by Ollie Hunter.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 15 (AP) -- Rochester and Jersey City divided a double-header before 2,043 tonight, the Little Giants coming back to take the nightcap 4 -- 0, after dropping the opener by 2 -- 0.

With the bombing of the Japanese homeland for the first time by land-based American planes, the giant B-29s, there comes into being, as General Marshall said yesterday, "a new type of offensive." It should help measurably to shorten the time required to accomplish the total defeat of this treacherous and evil enemy.

LONDON, June 15 -- Arguing that if a Quisling sniper had taken deadly aim at Prime Minister Churchill's unmistakable "massive figure complete with cigar," Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as supreme commander would have been blamed for it, Capt. A.S. Cunningham-Reid objected in the House of Commons today to the Prime Minister's recent trip to the Normandy beachhead.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- By a roll call vote of 357 to 0, the House marked the bombing of the Japanese mainland today with the passage of the War Department appropriation bill, totaling $49,109,002,795.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- A United States Army Air Forces communique:

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -The Senate named conferees today to seek agreement on the controversial price control extension bill after hearing a new plea for "the poor devils who have seen their living wages and living standards go down, down, down."

VATICAN CITY, June 15 -- The first official step toward an open break between Hungary and Germany was made known today with the issuance of the text of a message from Baron Gabriele Apor, Hungarian Minister to the Holy See, one of the most noted Hungarian statesmen and diplomats, to the representatives of his country in neutral capitals.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 15 -- Among German voices warning against premature optimism about the war in the west is that of Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the German Propaganda Minister, who, in contrast to his customary practice, prefers to defer judgment for the present.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 -- The official Japanese radio announced today that American warplanes, including B-29 Superfortresses, had bombed Yawata, home of the great Imperial Steel Works; Moji, a communications center, and Kokura in northern Kyushu Island of the Japanese homeland Friday morning, June 16 (Japanese time).

LONDON, June 15 (U.P.) -- Hundreds of German troops have been killed and more than 1,000 captured by French patriots who have fought more than fifty pitched battles in southern France during the past few days and who now control "quite a large number of towns," official French sources said tonight.

The two-story factory building at 455-457 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Equitable Realty Corporation to the Halvaden Association for the manufacture of Diesel engines. The deal was closed through the Bulkley Horton brokerage agency.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A poem chiding Congress for absenteeism and thoughts of a summer recess led today to the "schooling" of a literary editor on the daily life of a legislator, with Senator Taft of Ohio as teacher and guide.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Tokyo and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Re-establishment of point rationing for lamb, veal and all cuts of beef was advocated by members of the New York area consumer committee of the Office of Price Administration, meeting yesterday in regional headquarters in the Empire State Building.
BOSTON, June 15 -- A German submarine invaded the North Atlantic fishing grounds recently, shelled and machine-gunned a Boston trawler and forced all but two of the crew to abandon ship.

CINCINNATI, June 15 (AP) -- A ninth-inning single by Bob Elliott, a force play and Tommy de la Cruz's only walk of the day gave the Pirates a 1-0 victory over Cincinnati today to nullify the lanky Cuban's otherwise brilliant four-hit pitching.
HEADQUARTERS OF CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, June 15 -- After occupying Lungling for five days, Chinese troops holding that important Burma Road city were on the defensive today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Those who have been following the proceedings in Congress on the bill to extend price control might fairly assume that opposition by the OPA and others to the court review amendment of Representative Dirksen of Illinois is bureaucracy run riot.

Martin Krompier, 42 years old, of 1042 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, former henchman of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and one of those eyed by police under Mayor La Guardia's order to harass known gamblers and bookmakers, was freed again yesterday when Magistrate James A. Blanchfield in Rockaway Beach Court, Queens, dismissed a vagrancy charge for lack of evidence.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The War Labor Board ordered the American Federation of Musicians today to end the ban which it put on production of phonograph recordings on Aug. 1, 1942.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was active, and final prices showed gains of 9 to 15 points in active months.

To imagine the Christian world without the Young Men's Christian Association would be hard, as Harry Emerson Fosdick has said. Yet 100 years ago the Association was only an idea, or, in Dr. Fosdick's words, "a faith, a venture in daring spiritual statesmanship." In the 100 years ended this month the "Y" has become one of the great world-wide forces for manliness.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Gen. George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, is "disturbed" about what he thinks is a lack of understanding of the value of combat decorations in sustaining the morale of fighting men.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The air war against the heart of the Japanese Empire has begun, the War Department announced this afternoon. B-29 Superfortresses of the new Twentieth Air Force, which is part of a new "super-air force" under the personal command of Gen. H. H. Arnold, bombed Japan today, a special communique revealed.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 15 -- A tentative plan for compliance with "death sentence" provisions of the Holding Company Act, formulated by the Columbia Gas and Electric Company, was presented today to the Securities and Exchange Commission and was denounced by John J. Burns, counsel for Columbia's parent, the United Corporation.

William L. Batt, vice chairman of the War Production Board and president of SKF Industries, Inc., was re-elected chairman of the board of the American Management Association at the annual business meeting of that organization last night at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

At the suggestion of its minister, the Rev. Adam Clayton Power Jr., the board of deacons of the Abyssinian Baptist Church has gone on record in favor of stronger police measures to curb hoodlumism in Harlem and has promised to support the authorities in the use of "every legal means at their disposal in curbing lawlessness," it was announced yesterday.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 15 (AP) -- Communique 19:
LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

CHICAGO, June 15 -- All wheat and rye futures advanced the full 5-cent limit today, there being much more active general buying because of the passage by the House of the price-control bill with the amendment requiring processors to pay parity prices for farm commodities. Shorts were free buyers also. After hitting the day's price limit there was much profit-taking, prices receding from the top in the late trade.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Noting a recent appeal by French bishops on behalf of civilian victims of bombings, the Administrative Board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference cabled today a message to Luigi Cardinal Maglione, Papal Secretary of State, expressing deep sympathy for the French bishops and the "sufferings of their defenseless flocks."

A worse coal shortage than last winter's awaits New Yorkers unless they begin at once to stock part of their bin space with reclaimed coke and bituminous, according to government officials and the city's coal dealers.

Martin Moorhead has been appointed head of the hotel and club division of the Schenley Import Corporation to fill the vacancy caused by the recent transfer of Albert C. Sondime to the Schenley International Corporation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- Sol Lesser has received War Department approval for a film with a background of the Air Service Command. Preliminary details are now being arranged between the United Artists producer and Maj. Gen. Walter H. Frank, commanding general of the ASC at Patterson Field, Ohio.

New York City's traditional shower of ticker tape, somewhat curtailed because of the paper shortage but none the less warmly spontaneous, floated down from office buildings on lower Broadway yesterday as the city paid tribute to the American infantryman on Infantry Day. There was a parade and a ceremony in City Hall Plaza.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Appointment of four special committees to study specific newspaper and newsprint problems and report to the Wa Production Board's newspaper industry advisory committee on July 11 was announced today by Arthur R. Treanor, director of the WPB printing a d publishing division.
Hammering Henry Armstrong knocked out Al Davis last night in Madison Square Garden before their scheduled ten-round battle had been fairly started.

MOSCOW, June 15 -- Reports from far and wide in the Soviet Union indicate that United Nations Day was celebrated with the most elaborate demonstration of Anglo-Soviet-American solidarity since the war.

The problem of labor today is surcharged with emotion and dangerously sharp cleavages. Men more zealous than wise are trying to label the Democratic party the exclusive friend of labor, and the Republican party its inveterate enemy.

BOSTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Red Sox made all but one of their six hits count today as they gained their ninth victory in a row downing the Athletics, 5 -- 1. The crowd of 770 was the smallest in several years.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra ended its 1943-44 season with a net deficit of $26,486, it was disclosed today by Orville H. Bunitt, president of the Orchestra Association, in a report to the board of directors.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that it will offer for sale on Tuesday, various blocks of municipal bonds aggregating $10,309,000. The offering will comprise twenty-one lots. These bonds have been held in the company's investment portfolio and do not represent new financing.

New York City fighting men purchased war bonds aggregating $4,641,751 in value between June 1 and June 10, it was announced yesterday by Nevil Ford, chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York, who said that their action has helped to lift the city's total sale of E bonds in the Fifth War Loan drive to $19,785,345, or 8.7 per cent of its E bond quota of $227,526,600.

The Cooper Union School of Engineering, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street, held its eighty-fifth commencement last night, awarding baccalaureate degrees in civil, chemical, mechanical and electrical engineering to eighty-five day and evening students.

CHUNGKING, China, June 15 (AP) -- Japanese troops have crossed the Liuyang River, last line of defense before Changsha, by-passed the city on the east and then slashed westward toward the Siang River to cut off the southward line of retreat for the beseiged defenders, the Chinese High Command indicated tonight.
ROME, June 15 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's proposals fori an international organization to maintain peace brought expressions of agreement in principle from many members of Congress today but there were reservations as to details.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, June 15 -- American troops who fought their way ashore on Saipan Island in the Marianas Islands on Wednesday have firmly established their beachheads and are making good progress in an advance inland against heavy opposition, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz said in a communique tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Congressional Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation today directed its experts to begin studies immediately in preparation for a reduction of tax burdens to postwar levels at the earliest practicable date.
ADVANCE ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA. Friday, June 16 (AP) -- A communique:

Extending its vast resources to science, the New York Zoological Society will erect after the war a $200,000 biological and pathological research center at or near the Bronx Zoo, it was announced yesterday by Fairfield Osborn, president of the society, at an informal luncheon meeting of the fellows of the society in the administration building at Bronx Park.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Advancing prices for agricultural commodities, particularly fruits, vegetables and livestock, accounted for a rise of 0.1 point in the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of commodity prices in primary markets during the week ended on June 10.

The Greater New York CIO Council made public yesterday the text of a letter to Mayor La Guardia urging him to reconsider his ban against the holding of outside jobs by city employes in their spare time.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The text of General Marshall's statement on the attack on Japan by B-29 Superfortresses follows:
LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- Note circulation decreased 2,679,000 during week ended yesterday, as reported today in the weekly condition statement of the Bank of England.

Gen. Charles de Gaulle is the hero of France and that country will have him regardless of plots and smear campaigns, Henri Bernstein, playwright and acting president of the French-American Club, said last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in commemoration of the first message of liberation General de Gaulle sent to the French people four years ago.

Interim reports, which will describe the factors upon which renegotiation boards base their decisions in individual cases, will be issued by such agencies whenever contractors request them, Maurice Hirsch, vice chairman of the War Department price adjustment board, told a meeting sponsored by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, yesterday.

A STORY occasionally comes popping out of the Pacific on the magnificent feats accomplished in comparatively small boats by athletes of various descriptions -- the Sound yachtsmen, the football stars, the oarsmen and the track runners, to name only a few. It really is a tremendous list. We accept it with feelings of pride, perhaps, but without any true appreciation of the tasks which are being performed.
Sheridan made one ride in Civil War days that has gone down in history, thanks to a poem that ranks No. 1 in grade school graduation exercise polls.

The Migel Medals "for outstanding service to the blind," were awarded yesterday to Henry Ford for his company's pioneer work in finding satisfactory employment for the handicapped, and to Florrence B. Trader and her late sister and co-worker, Georgia D. Trader, both of Cincinnati.

John Clifford Folger, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, has been nominated by the board of governors for re-election, the association announced yesterday. Since the association was formed in 1912, there have been only three occasions when a president has served more than one year. Mr. Folger is head of Folger, Nolan Co., Inc., of Washington, D.C.

Harper's has announced its twelfth Harper Prize Novel Contest, to end June 1, 1945. The judges will be J. Donald Adams of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Irita Van Doren of The New York Herald Tribune, and Betty Smith, author of "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn."
CHUNGKING, China, June 15 (AP) -- A communuique:

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The President conferred with Secretary Hull, Under-Secretary Stettinius, Dr. Leo Pasvolsky, Dr. Isaiah Bowman and Norman Davis. Other appointments were with Leo T. Crowley and Col. William O'Dwyer, Costa Rican Ambassador, Administrator Bowles and Secretary Ickes.

Lipsticks coming from the cosmetic houses of the country today are better than they have been in a long time. This is the good news reported recently by the Office of War Information. The lipsticks are better because castor oil is once more plentiful enough to permit the War Production Board to relax the severe restrictions that were imposed last year.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 15 (AP) -- Numan Menemencioglu, Turkey's Foreign Minister for the last two years, resigned today in a dispute involving passage of German ships through the Dardanelles, and Premier Shukru Saracoglu, taking over the job, declared that in the future no armed vessels would be permitted to pass through the Straits.

A United States of Europe that includes all the nations of the Old World except the United Kingdom and Soviet Russia was proposed last night by Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat, of Montana, as the best way to lay a foundation for permanent world peace.

Vacations for needy housewives are being studied by a committee of experts appointed by the Swedish Government, according to the American-Swedish News Exchange. A radiogram from Stockholm adds that the experts will prepare a report on the subject on which to base a bill for presentation to the Riksdag next autumn.

ALBANY, June 15 -- Former Solicitor General Henry Epstein, speaking at a Democratic rally tonight, challenged Governor Dewey and the banking department to start an investigation to ascertain whether "the banks of this State are to be used as political weapons against the elected representatives of the people."

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Department store sales in the week ended June 10 were 2 per cent higher than sales of the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following show percentage changes from corresponding periods of 1943:

" America: 1744-1944," the current exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum, presents a panorama of two hundred years of American living. Fanciers of period furniture will find noteworthy specimens dating from the British-influenced colonial styles of the eighteenth cen tury to the florid "Golden Age" of the Eighteen Eighties.

WITH BRITISH ARMY IN CAEN SECTOR, 10 A.M., June 15 -- For forty hours now a battle that marks a new advance in warfare has been going on here south of the Caen-St. Lo line. Both sides have put into this fight all their latest weapons.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 15 (AP) -- Dr. John F. Pohl, medical supervisor of the Kenny Institute, made this comment on the report to the American Medical Association:

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Declaring that a "firm foothold" has been established in the first week of the invasion, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson asserted today that the Allies now "are there to stay until all France is liberated and Germany is defeated."

Vaudeville dropped in again last evening as it does every now and then to hold the franchise, and to deny recurrent rumors that it is dead. This time it is traveling under the title of "Take a Bow," with Lou Walters as the producer and the Broadhurst as the theatre.

ST. LOUIS, June 15 (AP) -- Dr. Walter W. Heller, tax research assistant in the United States Treasury Department, said today that a survey of what he called inter-governmental tax conflicts bad alignment of municipal revenues with municipal responsibilities and the perversity of local finance revealed an urgent need for improved fiscal planning.

Although the New York City department stores and many other merchantile establishments in this city plan to close, generally, on Saturdays in July and August, with few exceptions to this schedule, the banks here are expected to remain open as usual on summer Saturdays.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Harrison E. Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that Wendell L. Willkie, the party standard bearer in 1940, has been invited to attend the convention, opening here June 26.
LONDON, June 15 (UP) -- A United States Tactical Air Force announcement:

Coaches of the 460 athletes from thirty-five States, a record number, figured yesterday that four national records may be broken in the annual A.A.U. games to be held at Randalls Island tomorrow and Sunday. The officials agree with them. Two of the marks are senior ones and two on the junior list.
