A wallet containing $92 and personal papers was recovered yesterday by its owner, Sgt. John E. O'Connell of the Royal Australian Air Force, at the service men's center at 17 East Fifty-first Street of the National Catholic Community Service.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs were cut sharply today after farmers had been advised by the Chicago Livestock Exchange to hold back shipments, but trading was extremely slow and about 23,000 head failed to clear. The day's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:
LONDON, June 15 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The American Federation of Musicians will not comply with the National War Labor Board's order to resume the manufacture of disks for recording subsidiaries of the Radio Corporation of America, the National Broadcasting Company's radio recording division and the Columbia Broadcasting System, it was stated today by James C. Petrillo, president of the union.

The stock market climbed yesterday to the best levels in four years as buying in force was resumed. Gains ranged up to 3 points, with demand more concentrated in favored issues than in recent sessions, and indications that buyers had settled on those stocks most likely to receive the first benefits in the post-war era.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 10 were 874,193 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 63,421 cars, or 7.8 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 19,707 cars, or 2.3 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 41,558 cars, or 5 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

More than $110,800,000 will be spent by the 42,000 Staten Island families for new homes, automobiles, household appliances and on repairs and improvements of their homes after the war, the Committee for Economic Development announced yesterday as it made public figures based on 2,000 returns to questionnaires sent by the committee's survey organization.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Baffled by the tantalizing fluttering of Milt Haefner's left-handed knuckleball the Yankees tonight brought to a close one of their most disastrous road trips by dropping the fourth and final engagement of their all-nocturnal series with the Senators, 3 -- 2.

Store and office space along Madison Avenue and on Broadway figured in many of the business rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Several contracts for space also were listed on Park Avenue. The rentals included:

For the second consecutive year Procter Gamble in 1943 was first in total expenditures among national advertisers, according to data compiled by Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, in its fifth edition of "Expenditures of National Advertisers in Newspapers, Magazines, Farm Journals and Chain Radio."

In reply to Mr. Davila's recent competent and temperate statement which in effect affirmed the guilt of the Government of Finland for its attack on Russia on June 22, 1941, Francis Stewart Campbell opposes a pleasant little fairy story entitled "Finland Not an Aggressor."

ALGIERS, June 15 -- The belief propagated by French Nationalists that Washington's coolness to Gen. Charles de Gaulle implied American designs against French interests has received apparent support from American sources, and through an official American Army publication.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, June 15 (U.P.) -- Official reports from Chungking today said that Brig. Gen. Frank Mierrill's American Marauders broke into the northern part of Myitkyina after advancing down the road from Radhapur four miles to the west.

ROME, June 15 -- Bursting through another line of defenses hastily thrown up by the retreating Germans beyond Rome, Allied forces have captured the large Italian towns of Orvieto, Aquila and Narni in a general advance and were fighting tonight in the outskirts of the important industrial and communications center of Terni, forty-five miles north of the capital.

ROME, June 15 (AP) -- Allied Military Government authorities promised today to press an investigation of the disappearance of Bona de Seta, 22-year-old daughter of a Princess and stepdaughter of Prince Valerio Pignatelli, who was "arrested" yesterday by two men wearing United States Army uniforms and armed with pistols.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a brief supporting its motion in the United States District Court for Eastern Pennsylvania which asked that a complaint filed against it by the Bankers Securties Corporation, Philadelphia, be set aside.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The element of human selfishness will have to be curbed somehow if peace is to be established and postwar employment snags overcome, Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Veterans' Administrator and National Re-employment Director, today told the Women's Advisory Committee of the War Manpower Commission.

CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP) -- The Indians ended their series all even with the Tigers today when a two-bagger by Oris Hockett and a single by Paul O'Dea fashioned a run in the thirteenth inning for a 3-to-2 victory.

Mrs. Lucile Wolfe Burton, mother of the late Patricia Burton Lonergan, was appointed general guardian of her 21-month-old grandson, Wayne William Lonergan, yesterday by Surrogate James A. Delehanty. The child's mother was slain last October by her husband, Wayne T. Lonergan, who is in Sing Sing Prison.

The Surplus War Properties Administration has developed a procedure whereby warranties will be given with many types of government-owned merchandise when it is resold into normal channels of trade, Ernest L. Olrich, director of the agency's Treasury Department division, disclosed yesterday.

Two midtown theatres will present new film attractions today. At the Palace the offering will be RKO'S "Days of Glory," a romantic drama set against a background of Soviet guerrilla fighting. Produced and written for the screen by Casey Robinson, the picture stars the ballerina, Tamara Toumanova, and Gregory Peck, newcomers to the screen.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The "lack of foreign policy" of the Roosevelt Administration was sharply criticized by Senator Ralph O. Brewster of Maine last night before the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

LONDON, June 16 -- German commentators and propagandists boasted today what they would accomplish with "Germany's first secret weapon," the pilotless plane, and made extravagant claims regarding the results already achieved.

Not only is our Troop Carrier Command continuing its invaluable support of the invasion in Normandy by dropping parachutists and glider combat teams in and behind the battle area, but its C-47 transport tow-planes are actively bringing wounded personnel back to Britain. Evacuation of wounded by air is one of the many functions of the command.

CLEVELAND, June 16 -- The "honorable discharge" of industry from wartime regulations as soon as the war ended was urged by T.M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation and the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation, in a talk on "Some Post-War Problems in Industry" today before the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Four B-29 Superfortresses were lost out of the "sizable task force" that carried out yesterday's historic bombing mission against Japan, the new Twentieth Air Force revealed in its first communiques released at its headquarters here today.

RICHMOND, Va., June 16 -- Patents on a wire recording mechanism, developments in frequency modulation, a bottle-labeling adhesive and a method of measuring the thickness of metal were prominent among the 599 reported as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

If after the war the industrial and commercial life of most of the countries of the world is either State-owned or controlled, then the whole problem of the survival of a free economic system, even in the United States, will be complicated.
SUPERFORTRESS BASE IN WESTERN CHINA, June 9 (delayed by censor) -- The building of bases here for American Superfortresses and supporting fighters is a saga of the nameless little people of China.

Corp. James D. Slaton, a 33-year-old former Gulfport, Miss., taxi driver, told yesterday how he had knocked out three German machine gun nests in Italy in a single action. For this feat he received the Congressional Medal of Honor.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- Two Brooklyn scoring innings proved barely enough for Rube Melton to register his fourth victory as the Dodgers beat the Phillies at Shibe Park tonight, 5 -- 4, in the opener of the week-end four-game series.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 16 -- Five under par going to the fourteenth, Byron Nelson faltered a the next two holes and missed is chance for an undisputed lead the seventy-two-hole $10,000 Red Cross open golf tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Senate and House conferees on the price control extension bill agreed today on provisions continuing the present consumer food subsidy program until June 30, 1945, but banning subsidy payments after that unless Congress authorizes them.

A plan for the "adoption" of refugee children in Sweden through donations of $100 annually was approved yesterday as one of the next undertakings of the Save the Children International Union at a luncheon meeting of the war emergency advisory section at the Town Hall Club.

Sales of series E War Bonds in New York City were announced yesterday to have reached a total of $22,661,246 or 10 per cent of the city's quota of $227,526,600 for that issue. The drive received impetus from three major rallies -- in Times Square, the financial district and in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- A check of trade sources today indicated that the summer furniture market opening here July 6 will be largely limited to buying against quotas and to shopping around in the hope of picking up odd pieces and gaining information on the possibilities of improvement in the supply situation.
CHUNGKING, China, June 16 (AP) -- A communique from, Lieut. Gen. Joseph A. Stilwell's headquarters:

To the somewhat long train of attractions departing from the Broadway scene tonight, add still another, "Slightly Scandalous," which raises the week's number of casualties to five. This last, a comedy by Frederick Jackson based on an idea by Roland Bottomley, opened at the National Theatre on Tuesday and will have been seen seven times.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Hebrew Committee of National Liberation, headed by Peter H. Bergson, registered today with the Justice Department as a foreign agent acting for the "Hebrew nation," for which it seeks recognition as an independent state.

ALBANY, June 16 -- The extraordinary grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany County indicted seven persons today on charges of operating a lottery and asserted that Police Chief William J. Fitzpatrick of Albany, Sheriff Decker and former District Attorney John T. Delaney "failed, neglected and refused to take appropriate action."

TRENTON, June 16 -- Former Gov. Charles Edison and Finance Commissioner Frank E. Walsh of Orange, intraparty foes of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, New Jersey's Democratic leader, were among ninety-five persons nominated today by Gov. Walter E. Edge, Republican, for State positions.
CHUNGKING, China , June 16 (AP) -- A communique:
KANDY, Ceylon, June 16 (UP) -- A communique:

ROME, June 16 -- Pursuing disorganized German troops who in many instances were throwing away their equipment and surrendering in droves, Allied forces leaped forward as much as twenty-five miles in the past twenty-four hours in their drive up the Italian peninsula and reached points within less than seventy miles of the enemy's so-called Pisa-Florence-Rimini defense line.

Breaking the handle of a teacup may be a major household tragedy these days, since the job of replacing the cup will probably mean weeks or months of waiting -- if it can be replaced at all. Two local department stores reported yesterday that they didn't have a single cup and saucer in their china departments, and most of the others admitted that these items were the hardest to keep in stock.

CHUNGKING, China, June 16 -- Eleven crewmen and myself assembled near the nose wheel, and Maj. Robinson Billings, our pilot captain, handed out our money belts, first aid kits and language books. It was late afternoon and the take-off time was fifteen minutes away.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The first national conference of the CIO Political Action Committee today urged the people "to draft and elect Franklin Delano Roosevelt for another term in office" and called for the renomination of Vice President Wallace, to whom full support was pledged.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 -- A belief that most of California's fifty delegates to the Republican National Convention favored the nomination of Governor Dewey of New York for President was voiced today by William F. Reichel, Republican national committeeman, on the eve of organization meetings of both major party delegations from this State.

Our correspondent, Herbert Matthews, long inured to war, was interviewing Croce the other day. Croce is an ardent anti-Fascist and liberal. Now Mr. Matthews has interviewed George Santayana, another famous philosopher, who doesn't bother his head about Fascism or Communism and seems to be as remote from contemporary events as if he were a monk of the Thebaid.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, June 17 -- St. Sauveur-le-Vicomte, one of the two vital communications centers in the neck of the Cherbourg peninsula, has fallen to Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley's American infantry in its drive to isolate Cherbourg.

It would be relatively easy for the Treasury to borrow all the money it needed for the prosecution of the war from the commercial banks. In the end, however, excessive borrowing by the Treasury from the commercial banks would dislocate the finances of the United States to a degree that might well result in an uncontrollable wartime price inflation.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN FRANCE, June 16 -- United States troops made a long leap today toward cutting off the Cherbourg Peninsula and brought much nearer the moment when we will have that important French port in our hands.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Saturday, June 17 (AP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, June 17 (U.P.) -- American infantrymen on Biak Island off Netherlands's New Guinea killed 160 Japanese Thursday and destroyed two tanks in repulsing an armored enemy counter-attack west of the Mokmer airdrome, General Douglas MacArthur said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 16 -- In an order of the day to the soldiers of the Swiss Army, General Henri Guisan, Commander in Chief of this country's elite defenders, warned his men that the danger facing Switzerland "might be progressively discernible or could appear quite suddenly," and that in consequence those entrusted with the country's defense had been obliged to call up new forces.

In the past many a pitcher has been batted out of the box and, on occasion, it has happened to Bobo Newsom. At the Stadium yesterday, however, Old Bobo, about whom there must be something different, added a new wrinkle to an old formula when he found himself bunted out of a ball game.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 16 -- While invasion forces pounded inland from their beachheads in the Battle of Saipan, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced this morning that a carrier task force had stabbed deep toward Japan and bombed two air bases in the Bonin Islands, 588 statute miles from Yokohama, and a third air base in the Volcano (or Kazan Retto) Islands.

A sermon whispered in the darkness of her bedroom early yesterday saved a 32-year-old mother of four children, wife of a Navy lieutenant, from a criminal attack by a Negro burglar, who fled after returning money he had taken from her.

The Appellate Division unanimously upheld yesterday a ruling of Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente, who refused to grant an injunction to restrain Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh from continuing his emergency order that abolished the three-platoon system. No opinion accompanied the decision.

LONDON, June 16 -- For the last twenty-four hours parts of England south of a line drawn from Bristol to The Wash have been bombarded intermittently by robots. Most of the night and in daylight these one-ton bombs with wings and engines but no pilots have sailed in to blow up in haphazard fashion.

The American Negro Theatre, which has a somewhat heated headquarters on West 135th Street, last evening turned its attention to the tryout of a new play. It was "Anna Lucasta," by Phillip Yordan, with adaption credits to Abram Hill and Harry Wagstaff Gribble, and the group of players gave it a finished production.

ROBERT PARKER has a background of staid and sober jobs as Associated Press Bureau chief for Eastern Europe and the Balkans and Ankara representative of the Office of War Information. But in his "Headquarters Budapest''* he has coltishly kicked over the traces and run for lush pastures that are seldom cropped in The Associated Press dispatches.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., reported yesterday for the quarter ended on April 30 a consolidated net profit of $479,757, equal to 18 cents a common share, compared with $2,824,371, or $1.50 a common share, for the similar three months of last year.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 16 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches shot a two-over-par 80 at the Montclair Golf Club today to capture the low gross prize in the first New Jersey Women's Golf Association tournament since 1942. Miss Orcutt put together nines of 38 and 42.

Many Government officials observe protocol rigidly when communicating with international leaders such as Prime Minister Winston Churchill, but one 13-year-old American boy does not stand on such ceremony. And as a reward for his directness in sending greetings to the Prime Minister he is now the owner of a prospective historic document bearing the signature of England's foremost statesman, it was learned yesterday.

LIBERTY, N.Y., June 16 -- The Sullivan County Democratic committee at its annual convention unanimously endorsed tonight Augustus W. Bennet, Newburgh Republican, for nomination to Congress from the Twenty-ninth district, duplicating action of the Rockland County Democratic committee on June 9.

Only a trickle of business was done this week in the local market for new investments, as bankers devoted their attention to the sale of bonds in the Fifth War Loan drive. A single issue of municipal bonds for $300,000 was the only new offering of the week, making it the smallest weekly figure since early March.
Yesterday's Soviet communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications:

CHUNGKING, China, June 16 (AP) -- Fighting of the greatest intensity is in progress in the southeastern suburbs of the strategic Hunan Province city of Changsha, the Chinese command announced tonight, but the Chinese garrison is hanging on against the furious Japanese onslaughts in obedience to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's orders to defend Changsha at all costs.

PITTSBURGH, June 16 (AP) -- A picture of shrinking crude oil production at a time when the need for lubricating oils and gasoline is increasing daily was drawn by speakers today at the twenty-first annual meeting of the Pensylvania Grade Crude Oil Association.

Our armed forces in Italy are marching over ancient battlegrounds and past famous cities. They are in the country of the Etruscans, that strange folk of whom so little is known. Orvieto, on its lonely tufa rock, was one of the richest and most powerful cities of the so-called Etruscan Confederation of twelve cities.

City College will hold its ninety-eighth commencement exercises at 8 o'clock tonight in Lewisohn Stadium and will award degrees and diplomas to 1,305 graduates, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.
A surprise was injected yesterday into preparations for Father's Day tomorrow by the revelation that the National Fathers Day Committee had awarded a medal to Kate Smith as a friend of fathers.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Southern Governors contended today before the interstate Commerce Commission that a few large shippers were excepted from the section's higher level of railroad rates on manufactured goods, but that a sweeping downward tariff revision was needed to stimulate further industrial expansion.

The State Department of Labor has leased approximately 15,000 square feet of office space in the Empire State Building. The premises comprise the entire Thirty-fourth Street frontage of the seventh floor and will be used by the Division of Engineering, Industrial Code, Industrial Safety and the Board of Standards and Appeals, now located in the State Building at Centre and Worth Streets.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Russia has rejected a Japanese proposal to pick up relief supplies at Vladivostok for American prisoners, Congress was told today, but has offered the use of "other, equally accessible ports."

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange marked time yesterday pending final action on the price-control bill in Congress, and final prices on active months were unchanged to 4 points lower than on Thursday.

In the crisp phrase "Art is a facet of culture, viewed as a mighty whole," Edward Alden Jewell, in THE TIMES, June 11, touched on a thoughtful theme in his comments upon recent world events in connection with human progress.

A photograph at hand shows a group of people, old and young, strolling in a meadow all carrying canes and some wearing dark-tinted glasses. They are blind people. They do not see the green trees that bank their meadow, the flowers and the grasses beside their path, the blue sky with its drifting white summer clouds overhead.

William Clifford Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., who is associated with the Prudential Insurance Company of Newark, has purchased the fifteen-acre Picket Fence Farm at Colts Neck, N.J., from Mr. and Mrs. Sydney I. Rogers of Washington, D.C.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Hjalmar J. Procope, Minister of Finland, and the three counselors of his legation received their passports from the State Department at 5 o'clock this afternoon and they were directed to leave the country at the earliest possible moment because of activities "inimical to

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A Navy board of investigation reported today Secretary Forrestal that, although hull fractures occurred in 432 of 2,993 welded ships which it examined, "the results in speed and volume of construction which have been accomplished would have been impossible," had welding not been substituted for riveting in the wartime merchant shipbuilding program.
PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 16 (AP) -- The carrier task force that attacked the Bonins made the Pacific Fleet's closest approach of the war to Japan's homeland.

Total newspaper advertising linage in fifty-two cities during May amounted to 117,776,135 agate lines, a loss of 2.7 per cent from the corresponding month of last year, according to a compilation by Media Records. Classified advertising showed the greatest loss with 10.8 per cent, followed by department store advertising with 5.8 per cent, and retail with 1.9 per cent. Automotive gained 9.5 per cent, financial 6.4 per cent and general 4.7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle, in a letter dated May 11 and made public today, informed former Gov. Charles Edison of New Jersey that the Department of Justice had found "no direct evidence" of a conspiracy by Hudson County authorities to "frame" John R. Longo, political foe of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, who is vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

A keener interest in foreign affairs by American Negroes and the expansion of news facilities to make this possible were advocated yesterday at the fifth annual convention of the Negro Newspaper Publishers Association in the Harlem Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, 180 West 135th Street.

In less than nine hours the temperature rose 24 degrees yesterday, reaching its peak at 4:45 P.M., when the thermometer at the Weather Bureau, atop the Whitehall Building, recorded 88 degrees. However, at La Guardia Field, where conditions more closely approximate street temperatures, the mercury was at 92 at that hour.

Events move with a kind of fury these days. All the war fronts explode at once. Super-bombers roar into deadly action over Japan and pilotless planes rip through the skies over southern England. On the road to Cherbourg and on the charred borders of Caen the battle of Normandy mounts to a climax.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Milo Candini blanked the Red Sox with five hits as Washington won, 4 to 0, before 10,256 fans tonight. The defeat snapped Boston's streak of nine straight victories.

The Rev. Dr. John A.F. Maynard, the rector, will conduct an R-day patriotic service tomorrow at 10:45 A.M. in the French Episcopal Church du Saint Esprit, 109 East Sixtieth Street, which will be attended by delegations of French and American patriotic societies. He will preach in French on "The Spirit of Resistance."

With the priority system now working, manufacturers of children's snowsuits, leggings and coats are reasonably optimistic on production for fall, it was reported in the industry here yesterday. Thus far, output compares favorably with a year ago, while orders for better grade merchandise show a gain.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Disclosure of how a peculiar streptococcus outbreak among American naval personnel was halted by the use of sulfadiazine as a preventive was made today by Comdr. Alvin F. Coburn of the bureau of medicine and surgery at a closing session of the American Medical Association.
LONDON, June 16 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast by the Berlin radio:

The cleansing and protective treatment of the brown stone walls Of Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway, at the head of Wall Street, which is 98 years old, will be undertaken this summer "to offset the effects of weathering and the acid-charged atmosphere of New York City." This announcement was made yesterday at the offices of Trinity Parish, 74 Trinity Place.

Your recent editorial on prayer was very timely and to the point. I have long held that our national prosperity and success are the fruits of prayer. We have national days of prayer and thanksgiving. Every session of Congress and the national conventions open with prayer. Our national Constitution, and nearly all the State Constitutions, begin with the acknowledgment of God's supreme power and goodness.

Local representatives of The Daily Telegraph of London point with restrained pride to the fact that copies of their paper dated June 10 were received here in New York on June 13. They think this constitutes a wartime record and especially noteworthy because, as many of us will recall, there was an invasion under way at that time.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Broadened insurance coverage for individuals through private companies rather than through adoption of a "cradle-to-the-grave" program by the Federal Government at this time was advocated today by the social security committee of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners.

ALBANY, June 16 -- The State Banking Department announced today that it had granted permission to the General Electric Credit Corporation of New York to open branches at 378 Stuart Street, Boston, and 700 Antionette Street, Detroit, conditioned upon discontinuance of offices at 581 Boyleston Street, Boston, and 7310 Woodward Avenue, Detroit.

ALBANY, June 16 -- Former Solicitor General Henry Epstein renewed tonight his demand for an investigation by the Governor and the Banking Superintendent of charges that Representative William T. Byrne, Albany Democrat, was forced out of the directorate of the National Commercial Bank and Trust Company of Albany because of his New Deal voting in Congress.
CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP) -- The White Sox bunched four of their six hits in two innings to defeat the Indians, 3--1, before 14,089 fans at Cleveland Stadium tonight.

SUPERFORTRESS AIR BASE, Western China, June 15 (Delayed) -- Squadrons of one of the fastest, hardest-hitting fighter planes made in the United States are based in this area to protect this great bomber base and escort Superfortresses on their missions against the Japanese.

From the New York City Nursing Council for War Service at 645 Madison Avenue came the news yesterday that a cablegram is en route to Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, commanding the British troops in Normandy, telling him all about the United States Cadet Nurse Corps.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 -- Harvey W. Brown, president of the International Association of Machinists (AFL), telegraphed to William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, asking that the board send a longstanding dispute involving Lodge 68 of this city and a group of San Francisco machine shops back to the conference table.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- Warner Brothers will star Bette Davis in the Elisabeth Bergner role in the studio's proposed film version of the current Broadway play "The Two Mrs. Carrolls." The play, for which Warners paid $225,000, is to be produced for the screen by Jesse Lasky late this summer.

Adherents of what is called "the Bible Presbyterian Movement" will meet tomorrow at 4:30 P.M. at 434 West Forty-second Street to organize a congregation. Presiding will be James E. Bennet, chairman of the organization committee, which has issued a cordial invitation to "all who are interested."

Reinforced by a budget of highly favorable war developments and with a turnover that topped any in more than a year, the stock market soared yesterday to the highest marks since May, 1940, with gains ranging from fractions to about 2 points.

ROME, June 16 -- Chief Rabbi Anton Zolli of Rome expressed the Jews' gratitude to the Catholic Church and especially Pope Pius for the aid to Jews persecuted by Nazis and Fascists during the German occupation of Rome.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 16 -- The number of wounded in the invasion of France has been much lower than anticipated, and less than 1 per cent of the American wounded who have reached medical installations have subsequently died.

ROME, June 16 (AP) -- Bona de Sets, daughter of a princess whose whereabouts have been a mystery since her arrest at the home of an American-born baroness is in an apartment in Rome and being treated well, a high Allied source said today.

DETROIT, June 16 (AP) -- Leonard A. Young, president and chairman of the board of the L.A. Young Spring and Wire Corporation, denied today Federal charges that he surreptitiously sold 11,854 shares of the corporation's stock for $281,583 in violation of the Securities Exchange Act.

Retail trade here rebounded sharply this week following the mild letdown noted in the previous week because of the invasion. Department store volume was up 10 to 12 per cent over the like week a year ago, with seasonal merchandise in active demand.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Among 114 casualties announced today by the Navy Department were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

Delinquent girls and neglected children in the Brooklyn Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children Shelter will benefit by an expanded educational program, announced yesterday by the Board of Education for the fall school term. The shelter, now the official detention home for Manhattan and Brooklyn girls remanded by the Domestic Relations Court, has a capacity of 96, with an average of 80 daily, housed at 105 Schermerhorn Street.

The cream of he nation's track and field athletes, many of whom are now in the service and will travel a long distance to be here, will seek national A.A.U. championships today and tomorrow at Randalls Island.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A recommendation that Congress reject Administration proposals for federalizing the standards of unemployment compensation to be paid during the industrial reconversion period was voted unanimously today by the Senate Post-War Economic Policy and Planning Committee.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Roosevelt named Frank P. Douglass of Oklahoma today to succeed Dr. W.M. Leiserson as a member of the National (Railway) Mediation Board.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Passage by the Senate of the $1,027,618,000 War Agencies Appropriation Bill was postponed today until next week as Southern members began their fight against a $500,000 item for maintenance of the Fair Employment Practice Committee.

The Yawata plant of the Japan Iron Manufacturing Company -formerly known as the Imperial Government Steel Works -- is without doubt the most important single element in the Japanese industrial system. Official reports have credited it with 20 per cent of Japan's raw steel output.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 16 -- Golf's most durable whipping boy, old man par, took another beating today as the nation's top-flight club swingers went to work in the second round of the Red Cross open golf tournament. The weather was hot, the course well baked and the scoring low. There has not been so much good golf on display in Westchester since the war began, and the links addicts ate it up avidly.

On Feb. 22 of this year Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons that "the enemy is preparing on the French shore new means to attack this country." Now comes the news that southern England has been attacked with pilotless rocket planes which explode soon after they strike.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- The last obstacle to returning Southern coal mines to private ownership was removed today with the disclosure that Southern Appalachian operators had signed a wage contract with the United Mine Workers.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 16 (UP) -- Fighting in the face of "very adverse" weather and determined opposition, tank-supported British troops have cleared the Japanese road block at Viswema, sixteen miles south of Kohima, and advanced another three miles to occupy Khuzama, it was announced today.

LONDON, Saturday, June 17 (U.P.) -- Red Army forces, pushing along the Karelian Isthmus on an unbroken front curving sixty-five miles from the Gulf of Finland to Lake Ladoga, advanced to within twenty-eight miles southeast of Viborg yesterday by capturing Luonatjoki in a five-mile drive up the Leningrad-Helsinki railroad.

Three Negro boys were injure by missiles and two white youth were arrested as disorderly persons late last night when police reserves quelled an effort by 200 white rowdies to provoke trouble with Negro residents of the Fort Greene Park section in downtown Brooklyn.

DETROIT, June 16 (AP) -- Another upset was tossed into the national clay court tennis championship today as fourth seeded Miss Mary Arnold of Los Angeles defeated second ranking Miss Doris Hart of Miami, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, to advance to the women's singles final tomorrow.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 16 -- Precision bombing by United States Eighth Air Force crews who attacked seven key bridges on the Loire River yesterday resulted in direct hits on all of them, it was learned today after the return of reconnaissance planes. The mission was an important step in the strategic plan to isolate enemy forces in Normandy.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 16 (AP) -- Rochester took a 2-1 lead in its four-game series with Jersey City tonight, defeating the Little Giants, 5 to 4, before a crowd of 3,786.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The question of jurisdiction of the Controller General in adjustment of war contracts at the end of hostilities was debated today in the House, with one group advocating an amendment to the pending contract termination bill to provide for pre-audit of all such accounts before settlement.
BERNE, Switzerland, June 16 -- Germany's "secret weapon" was unveiled for the foreign press in Berlin today in a four-line communique reading:

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A much graver degree of alloy starvation in Germany than was indicated in the report of the Foreign Economic Administrator, made public by President Roosevelt on Tuesday, has been reported by Government experts who studied the situation, it was learned today.

The old Fahnestock mansion at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Fifty-first Street, one of the outstanding examples of the architectural handiwork of the late Stanford White in the residential field, has been sold by the Fahnestock estate and will be used for business purposes after the war, it became known last night.

LONDON, June 16 -- King George VI visited the Normandy beachhead today, lunched at Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's advanced headquarters and held an open-air investiture less than six miles behind the front line where Allied and German troops are locked in a deadly struggle.

DETROIT, June 16 (AP) -- Bob Muncrief gained his fifth successive victory and sixth of the season tonight as the Browns pounded out a 14-to-1 decision over the Tigers in a twilight game before 14,931 fans. Muncrief allowed nine blows.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 16 (AP) -- The Indiana Democratic convention adopted today a resolution urging a fourth term for President Roosevelt. The delegates stood and cheered in a short demonstration after approving the resolution by a voice vote.
ROME, June 16 (U.P.) -- Eighth Army units made a spectacular twenty-five-mile advance to take Todi, east of Lake Bolsena nineteen miles beyond captured Terni, hydroelectric and communications center.

ABOARD JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE FLAGSHIP, Saipan, Saturday, June 17 -- United States assault troops fought their way inland over the green, rolling hills of southern Saipan in the Marianas today after a street-by-street conquest of the town of Charan-Kanoa, where they landed under the heaviest Japanese fire encountered since Tarawa.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Foreign Economic Administration's decentralization procedure so far as exports to Latin-American countries are concerned was modified considerably for thirteen additional countries today. The modifications are effective July 1, and notices were sent to all exporters today notifying them that after that date the decentralization procedure will be lifted except for a relatively few classes of commodities.

Aqueduct blossoms out today with one of the best cards of the meeting. Featured is the $10,000 added Shevlin Stakes, mile and a sixteenth test, which has attracted a field of fifteen that includes some of the smartest steppers in the 3-year-old division.
LONDON, June 16 -- The text of Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's warning to his air force was published here tonight. The warning was found near Fondi, Italy. It said:

NEWARK, N.J., June 16 -- Production in eight breweries in this area, which supply a large proportion of the draught and bottled beer sold in North Jersey and New York City, was halted this afternoon as a result of the strike of 1,600 bottlers and drivers.

HAZLETON, Pa., June 16 -- Delegates of the three anthracite districts of the United Mine Workers of America voted 335 to 15 today to ratify the new work contract after John L. Lewis, international president, had told them that the terms were the best possible in view of "the shabby treatment" of the miners last year "by the President of the United States and his administrative agencies."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically by the Finnish radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

NEWARK, N.J., June 16 (AP) -- Buffalo soared into the International League lead tonight by beating Newark, 4 -- 0 and 4 -- 3. The double defeat shoved the Bears back into the cellar, a half game behind Syracuse.

CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE HEADQUARTERS, June 7 (Delayed) -- One day when Europe was being invaded by means of unprecedented mechanical equipment, Gen. Lu Tzu, Vice Minister of War Services, was discussing the most difficult supply problem that the Chinese Army has ever faced.

Twelve hours after three little girls had found the body of a woman tied up in an olive-green laundry bag in a lot on the south side of East Third Street near Avenue C, the police took into custody a soldier who had been absent without official leave for two years and at 1 A.M. today said he had confessed to the slaying.

NEWMARKET, England, June 16 (AP) -- William Woodward, long a power on the British turf as well as in the United States, won his fourth major race in England today when Hycilla carried the silks of the New Yorker to victory in the classic Oaks.

The Japanese people were told Friday not to become "spiritually depressed" at the bombing of the Japanese mainland by American B-29 Superfortresses and by other attacks on Japan's inner defense lines, while Japanese propaganda for home and for foreign consumption stepped up its efforts to minimize the importance of the attacks.
NEW YORK Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler have left their home at 60 Morningside Drive for Leny Cotrage, their summer place in Southampton, where they expect to remain until mid-September.

Municipal bonds up for award next week will total $15,339,000, compared with this week's revised total of $3,302,800 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $20,646,613, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. One year ago the weekly average stood at $16,237,007.

The United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine reported yesterday that half the $32,000,000 quota of its nation-wide campaign for worldwide rescue and rehabilitation had been raised in the first five month of 1944.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 16 -- Berlin says that never in this war has the Luftwaffe fought under more adverse circumstances than in Normandy.

Just such a report comes from Michael Seaman, a former newspaper man, in a letter to J. Hammond Brown, president of the Outdoor Writers Association of America. CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- A three-run homer by Frank McCormick was the turning point today as the Reds, after surrendering an early lead, came back to pound out a 10-to-5 victory over the cellar-holding Cubs.

Although he asked permission to be absent from his duties as a general law assistant to the Justice of the Supreme Court, First Department, former Municipal Court Justice Edgar Hirschberg received his salary of $5,649 for the period he was absent from his post.

One of the most elaborate and colorful combination sports and entertainment carnivals ever held will be unfolded tonight at the Polo Grounds with the Fifth War Loan expected to be enriched by approximately $6,000,000 worth of "invasion bonds."

Responsibility for the present movement of 2,500,000 gallons of gasoline daily in the black market rests largely with Government agencies that refuse to make this surplus available for legal sales, the Automobile Club of New York charged in a letter yesterday to Chester A. Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Office of Price Administration today modified its "highest-price-line" limitation order to permit retailers and wholesalers of women's and children's outer wear garments to enable those moving to a higher price bracket to take the same percentage mark-up taken on the previous highest price line.

Awaiting clarification of the War Food Administration's announcement of its release of 3,048,000 pounds of beef from Government stocks to the civilian trade, the local branch of that agency disclosed yesterday that poultry was so plentiful in the New York area that it had put the black market out of business.

Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo, sitting in Brooklyn Federal Court, yesterday ordered the revocation of the American citizenship of eight persons of German extraction who had been leaders in the former German-American Bund. For six weeks Judge Abruzzo had listened to testimony in a civil proceeding to prove the defendants had been active in anti-American activities.

Pfaus, area director of the War Manpower Commission, unless the company relaxed a thirty-day probationary restriction for re-employed workers, 1,500 of whom were dismissed from the Port Newark yard of the concern this week.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A great shortage of teachers made more critical by shortages of school nurses, doctors and dentists was reported from the Great Plains and Great Lakes regions in the country-wide symposium of the Association of Childhood Education on "What Is Happening to Our Children.''

LONDON, June 16 -- Some profit-taking was in progress again in today's stock markets before the week-end, particularly in the industrial section, where prices, when changed, were mostly fractionally lower.

WEST CORNWALL, Conn., June 17 -- Mrs. Frances Lee Higginson Jr., wife of the scion of the Boston and New York banking family and great-granddaughter of Henry Ward Beecher, still was unconscious at a late hour today in a Torrington hospital following a mysterious attack upon her Thursday night in her isolated home here.

LONDON (By Wireless). BEHIND the German Westwall, from Norway down to the Riviera, a phantom army of desperate men fights from within the Hitlerian fortress whose gates have been breached again by Allied land, sea and air forces. Compared to the air and seaborne forces which have descended on the Continent from Britain they are scantily armed and few in number.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 17 -- Seeking new worlds to conquer Champion Dictator v. Glenhugel came up from across the Potomac in Arlington, Va., to compete in the annual all-breed fixture of the Mid-Hudson Kennel Club today.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- National political interest will begin to concentrate on Chicago tomorrow as the advance guard begins assembling for the first of the great party conventions which will determine the wartime candidates for President of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull were accused today by Representative Harold Knutson of Minnesota of having-given "the Russians a free hand to invade Finland and wage a war of extermination, which is as savage and barbaric as it is unjustifible."

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Calling high school credits "a broken reed" in measuring the educational level of students, and adopting placement tests to supplant such credits, the University of Chicago broke with another tradition in the American educational system today.
ROME, June 17 -- Last September at the time of the Italian Armistice the inhabitants of Elba rose against the Fascists and Germans and held out until German reinforcements wiped out the partisans.

DALLAS, Tex., June 17 -- The Southwest has high hopes of being able to retain a large part of the sensational industrial gains made under the impetus of war.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade was featured today by strength in the May delivery, in which appeared investment buying by commission houses. Trade in general was largely a matter of evening-up for the week-end, as it was thought definite action on the price-control bill in Washington might by taken by Monday.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- A German broadcast tonight estimated that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had fifty to sixty divisions of 500,000 to 900,000 men waiting for the "second phase of the invasion, which in all probability will be an attack on the French-Belgian coastal area" northeast of the Normandy front.

CLEVELAND, June 17 -- An unprecedented rush of coal up the Lakes, which is expected to result in the setting of a season record, is being handled by fewer vessels and railroad cars than in past years, W.J. McGarry, manager of the Ore and Coal Exchange, disclosed today.

Owing to the passage last week of the so-called "GI Bill of Rights" by both the Senate and House of Representatives, and its almost certain approval by President Roosevelt, colleges and universities look forward to a tremendous influx of veterans in the postwar years.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Passage of the Contract Termination Bill providing for speedy settlement of about $200,000,000,000 of war contracts seemed assured for Monday when the House late today twice voted down proposals by the major opposition.

DESPITE a sharp falling off in the number of exhibitions opening last week, several of the shows were well up to mid-season caliber and brought forward work not previously seen. The Lilienfeld Gallery summer event, for example, includes paintings by old masters and by well-known contemporaries -- work ranging from examples by Cranach and Van Goyen to recent canvases by Feininger and Dan Lutz.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 17 -- Thirty-seven sailing craft were entered for the Riverside Yacht Club's race out around Stratford Shoal Lighthouse and back, which was started tonight.

CAMP days are here again and Junior and his sister are packing their kits ready to take off July 1, when most children's camps open. In response to ODT requests some camps get under way earlier to relieve congestion on railroads at a peak season.

HASSARD SHORT does not know just when he got the idea which, along with the vocal and verbal genius of Messrs. Bizet and Hammerstein, makes "Carmen Jones" one of Broadway's most integral delights. It was all of a dozen years ago, anyway.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- In compliance with the Smith-Connally law prohibiting labor union contributions in connection with elections to Federal office and the requirements of the Hatch act and other legislation dealing with corrupt political practices, the national conference of the CIO Political Action Committee formed a new committee today which will carry on a country-wide campaign for voluntary, individual campaign contributions.

THERE has been some talk recently plans for expanding America's fifty-sixth city after the war. This community, not listed in atlases, gazetteers or postal guides (though it has its own postoffice) has only fourteen buildings, covers only twelve acres, but accommodates 152,000 persons daily, including visitors, and is equipped to provide virtually all human luxuries and necessities.

Conviction that the Office of Price Administration is putting into effect a realistic policy of pricing and rationing of food products is felt by food manufacturers who attended the mid-year meeting of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Paul S. Willis, president of the group, said yesterday.

Establishment of a legislative council with a bipartisan membership to function on a year around basis in preparing a program in advance of the regular sessions of the State Legislature was one of fifteen recommendations made yesterday by the Citizens Union for improving the procedures of the Senate and Assembly.

ROME, June 17 -- A new and strange kind of political crisis has paralyzed the Bonomi Government before it has had a chance to get going, according to reliable information reaching Rome today from the south.

LONDON, June 17 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has set aside a death sentence imposed by a court of seven white and one Negro officers which convicted a Negro corporal recently for rape. General Eisenhower held that the evidence in the case, which British Liberal and Leftist weeklies had been building into an Anglicized version of the Scottsboro case, was "insufficient" to justify the death penalty, but he did not reverse the court's verdict.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Although the weight of statistics and predictions seems to make the possibility a remote one, there is, nevertheless, the lurking, outside chance that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York may have a "run for his money" in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination in the party convention opening here June 26.

CHICAGO, June l7 -- Carrying a radio in the cab for communication by the engineer with the conductor in the caboose, a Santa Fe freight train nearly a mile long is puffing toward Chicago from Bakersfield, Calif., in the first long-distance test of radiophones for intercommunication on a train.

LONDON, June 17 (U.P.) -- Pierre Laval is No. 1 on the French underground's summary execution list, but Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain will be spared for treason trial after the war, an officer of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's secret army of resistance said tonight.

Too much reliance should not be placed on armament control as a means for preventing aggression in the future by Germany or Japan, Stefan T. Possony of Washington, a specialist in military affairs formerly at the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J., warns.

The possibility of a new race track to be built near Flushing after the war became more than a mere dream yesterday when Maj. Louis Beard, who has charge of the Whitney racing interests, received word from Col. John Hay (Jock) Whitney, now with the Eighth Air Force in Italy, that he was in favor of the project.

Man and beast took a fling at record-breaking yesterday at Aqueduct, where 31,162 racegoers enjoyed a sun bath witnessing the seventeenth running of the $10,000 added Shevlin Stakes. Feature of a sparkling card, the Shevlin was won in sparkling fashion by By Jimminy, brown colt owned by Alfred P. Parker, trained by J.W. Smith and ridden by Ted Atkinson, the meeting's foremost rider.

IN five days Humphrey Campbell is to join the Army. He wants to spend those five days in fishing, but he is persuaded to take on the case of Johnny Foster instead. Johnny has been arrested and charged with the murder of Warren Hastings, a junk man who has suddenly become rich.

CHUNGKING, China, June 17 (AP) -- With Changsha virtually isolated and all avenues of retreat closed to the defenders, the Hunan Province fighting has shifted swiftly to the south, with the Japanese threatening Lukow and driving on the southern Hunan rail junction of Hengyang, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

DETROIT, June 17 (AP) -- The league-leading Browns continuedI their mastery over the Tigers today with Sigmund Jakucki hurling a seven-hit shutout as the Browns won, 5 to 0, for their seventh vic!tory in eight games against Detroit this season.

MILLTOWN, N.J., June 17 -- American troops, taking time off from the pursuit of Nazis in Italy to greet their fathers on Father's Day, are using a special V-mail form designed by Sgt. William Gordon of Milltown.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -Reports of growing opposition within party ranks indicated today that Vice President Wallace might face a stiff fight for renomination at the Democratic National Convention even if he carried President Roosevelt's privately given endorsement as he did in 1940.

LONDON, June l7 -- Warnings that the battle for Western Europe, despite its initial success, may yet be long and hard are based on the knowledge that Allied forces so far have gained only the first of a series of progressive objectives.

PEARL HARBOR, June 17 -- American troops have greatly expanded their beachhead on Saipan in the Marianas in fierce fighting that has reached near to the island's prized airfield, one of the main objectives of the invaders.
WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES in France, June 17 -- Fighting ceaselessly all through last night and today American forces had almost completed the cutting of Cherbourg Peninsula this evening.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 17 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker asserted tonight that as this country freed the world from tyranny and cruel might, "we must also free America from arrogant regimentation and domination by bureaucratic government."

WARTIME conditions and wartime urgencies were primarily responsible for the establishment of the Stadium concerts in 1918. CAIRO, Egypt, June 17 -- The worst monetary inflation in European history, with the exception of the one that gripped Germany in the Twenties, is now ruining occupied Greece.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Spurred by the conviction that military events set in motion by successful actions in the European and Pacific theatres of war will bring the war to an end months ahead of the most optimistic predictions of a short time ago, the Government this week speeded up plans for meeting post-war economic problems they see in prospect.

THE first half of this long novel is an exposition of William Morris' ideas and a description of the experiment which put those ideas into practice. The author's framework of fiction, while wordy enough and, in number of characters and scenes, overelaborated, interests him only cursorily.

ALBANY, June 17 (AP) -- Former State Senator Roy M. Page of Binghamton "admitted everything" to the special grand jury which indicted him on grand larceny charges in connection with the inquiry Governor Dewey ordered of legislative spending, Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd asserted today.

HERE is a curious and often arresting story which tells of the last few hours of Tom the Philosopher as he climbs to his death up the sunlit slopes of the Scotch Highlands, "a death so startling that deep in the mind of the countryside the old menacing images would stir and lift their dark heads."

ATLANTA, June 17 (AP) -- A permanent injunction against railroads charging allegedly discriminatory and preferential freight rates in favor of Northern shippers over Georgia shippers was asked in a petition mailed today for filing as an original suit in the United States Supreme Court by the State of Georgia.

The protection of merchant shipping has been improved to a point where losses of ships and personnel have been reduced to negligibility, according to a survey of American merchant marine casualties released here yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

HAZLETON, Pa., June 17 -- A general collapse of the anthracite industry after the war was predicted today by James H. Pierce, president of the East Bear Ridge Coal Company, unless new price levels permitting the building of financial reserves were approved by the Office of Price Administration.

PEARL HARBOR, June 17 -- Admired William S. Halsey, recently relieved of command of the South Pacific area and the South Pacific force has been given command of the Third Fleet, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced this afternoon.

VATICAN CITY, June 17 -- The Pope received Gen. Sir Harold R. L.G. Alexander in private audience today and then met his staff. A brigadier general, commander of the Canadian brigade, also was added today to the long list of Allied commanders to whom the Pontiff has granted private audiences.

OTTAWA, June 17 -- The sweeping victory of the socialistic Cooperative Commonwealth Federation party in the Saskatchewan provincial election has been interpreted here as indicating the way people are thinking, not only in Saskatchewan or in Canada but in many if not all other countries where they are free to think.

CHARLES WERTENBAKER, Time and Life correspondent overseas, is cabling back day-by-day round-ups on the invasion to Appleton-Century, where the cables are being edited and sent to the printer. As the plans now are, Wertenbaker's "Invasion" will be the first book on this subject.

JOHN WILLIAMS, aged nine and a half, gave his German shepherd dog to the Army, though Big Boy was his best friend. RED raspberries are an excellent fruit for the home garden. A hedge from two to three feet wide, well tended, watered and with canes carefully spaced to at least six inches apart, yields a good crop. It is not unusual to pick about two heaping pint baskets from each linear foot of the hedgerow.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- There is no more important item required for the fighting of wars than money. It stands no comparison with the hazard of life by the armed forces, but it is the one staple thing needed to produce the weapons and equipment which these forces use; it pays the men their salaries and allowances and buys the transport to take them to the scenes of battle.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Suspecting a Republican move to put the Democrats "on the spot" on controversial domestic issues, such as race relations, poll taxes, wage and hour control and wartime bureaucracy, some confidants of President Roosevelt are pressing for a "postcard" platform aimed at pitching the campaign broadly on the thesis of winning the war and peace.

Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, last night denied that there was a black market in gasoline, in attacking the proposal of William A. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York, that the value of A coupons be increased from three to four gallons as a means of draining into legitimate channels 2,500,000 gallons of gasoline daily reported to be finding its way into the black market.

Child labor law violations in the State have risen to such serious proportions that a campaign to stem the tide will be started tomorrow, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi of the State Labor Department announced last night.

Breaking a 100-year tradition, the Community Service Society, largest private family welfare agency in the United States, has instituted a voluntary fee payment plan for counseling service to families and individuals seeking help, it was learned yesterday.

Almost four years to the day after he fled before the Wehrmacht, Gen. Charles de Gaulle returned to France last week. HEADQUARTERS OF TWENTIETH BOMBER COMMAND, India, June 9 (Delayed) -- Carefully picked veteran pilots, plane crews and maintenance men and commanders and staff men, who are among the best the American Army Air Force has produced, make the Twentieth Bomber Command and its subordinate units in India and China outstanding in United States military aviation.

THIS corner is bearing no new tidings when it beams that Jimmy Durante has returned. His "comeback" (to use the popular phrasing) has been bruited these past several months, and to radio listeners and nightclub crawlers it is now an accomplished thing.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- War news, marked by triumphs of American arms in many theatres of operations, dominated public discussion this week in the Central West. With Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York viewed as a virtual certainty for the Republican Presidential nomination at the party's Chicago convention late this month, politics was accorded scant attention in the midst of the encouraging military tidings.
ALBANY, June 17 (AP) -- State consumption of taxable gasoline in four months of 1944 increased 32,270,217 gallons over the 308,538,686 gallons used in the same period a year ago.

Under the stimulus of the invasion news the Fifth War Loan drive is off to a good start. A continuation of the early rate of purchases will be necessary, however, to attain the record goal set for the drive. BEGINNING tomorrow, Mrs. Charles Guggenheimer, known to her friends and to the music world as Minnie, will devote her first waking minutes each day to a careful scrutiny of the weather. WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -An inter-American effort will be made to rescue 2,000 racial and political refugees from Germany and German-occupied territory before they are subjected to treatment which may annihilate the group.

WITH THE FRENCH FORCES STORMING ELBA, June 17 (AP) -- French assault troops stormed ashore on the southern coast of this historic island five miles off Italy's west coast today, and by nightfall had won control of one-fifth of the island's eighty-five square miles in stiff fighting that still was in progress against the German garrison.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCES, June 16 (Delayed) -- The swift Japanese drive on Lungling, southwest of Tengyueh, was blocked yesterday by elements of Gen. Sung Hsi-lien's Eleventh Group Army, which took the city June 10.

The earth swings on its trunnions and the summer solstice nears. Time, like the currents of air and ocean, is forever on the move, and there is no end to the cyclic seasons. The violet bursts its pod and scatters its seed. Maple keys which came spiraling down only a few weeks ago strike root and lift eager leaflets toward the sun.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 17 -- Shooting the finest round of golf of the week, Byron Nelson took a five-stroke lead in the 72-hole $10,000 Red Cross golf tournament today as he turned in a six-stroke sub-par 66, one under the Wykagyl course record, for a 54-hole total of 204.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- The Cubs, who had been waiting since opening day to repeat their inaugural victory over Cincinnati, concentrated their waiting in the batter's box today and capitalized on Lefty Arnold Carter's wildness for a 2-to-1 decision in a ten-inning hurlers' duel.

The resignation of Turkish Foreign Minister Numan Menemencioglu probably will meet with favor among the Allies, especially Britain and the Soviet Union, according to European advices received by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Mysterious men, these Presidential electors now emerging from the shadows as the Democratic South seriously discusses another secession, this time not from the Federal Union but from the New Deal.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Driving for the recess of a month, which is to start next Saturday, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a deficiency appropriation bill of $2,595,165,535 -- the last of the year's regular supply measures -- after turning back a listless effort by some members to pare funds for the Office of Price Administration.

THINGVELLIR, Iceland, June 17 (U.P.) -- Sveinn Bjoernsson, regent of the Icelandic Government, was elected the first President of Iceland today by a majority of 30 to 20 after the islands had been proclaimed an independent republic by the Icelandic Parliament.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- With every prospect for one of its busiest summers, Newport is ready for an active season on golf courses and tennis courts, on beaches and at its clubs. The Newport Country Club, which was practically dormant during the last two summers, has taken on new life.

NEW ORLEANS, June 17 -- Anti-Roosevelt, anti-fourth term and anti-New Deal sentiment in Lou isiana, which was expected by its leaders to gain momentum by the visit of James A. Farley to New Orleans this week, failed to materialize, for the New Yorker refused while here to discuss politics, privately or publicly.

The Board of Estimate, at a special meeting called by Mayor La Guardia yesterday for 10 A.M. on Tuesday, is scheduled to authorize immediate condemnation of 1,350 acres in the Idlewild section of Queens to be added to the 3,150 already acquired for use as a gigantic post-war municipal airport.
