In addition to this we've also cornered the market in world records, thus becoming the envy of the athletic universe.

Spurred by Allied invasion successes and Senate passage of an $800,000,000 appropriation for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation, exporters last week turned their attention to methods by which private foreign trade will be restored in the liberated areas.

WASHINGTON, June l7 -- President Roosevelt signed today the bill to permit increased oil production from the Navy's Elk Hills reserve in California, but stated his objections to provisions in the measure which, he contended, would vest the Congress with "what amounts to executive powers over the administration of the naval petroleum reserves."

AWAR once caught Napoleon asleep, but not at the switch. The Little Corporal was snoozing in his famous iron camp bed at midnight, April 10, 1809, when the Austrians opened hostilities against him near Braunau on the Inn, later the birthplace of another little corporal, Adolf Hitler.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Country-wide gasoline consumption 29,000 barrels a day in excess of quotas during May blocked a proposed increase in the "B" ration in the East for the third quarter of the year, Charles F. Phillips, rationing chief of the Office of Price Administration, said today.

IN what appears to be a Presidential election campaign between a Democrat who won't talk and a Republican who says he isn't a candidate, it is at least noteworthy that Vice President Henry A. Wallace is not only ready to discuss some of the issues but has got out a book of his writings and speeches, which furnish plenty of campaign material for both his supporters and opponents.

NOW that the active time of planting and transplanting has ended temporarily, gardeners are eager to keep everything growing vigorously. One of the oldest and best aids for newly set plants is mulching.

LONDON, Sunday, June 18 (U.P.) -- Russian troops, advancing on a sixty-five-mile front, pushed to within twenty-two miles of the Finnish gateway city of Viborg on the Karelian Isthmus yesterday in swift gains reminiscent of the Red Army's winter march across the Ukraine.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Millions of barrels of true petroleum are locked in the sandstone of six coastal California counties, and Federal chemists are trying to develop a commercial extraction process, Secretary Ickes said today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, June 18 -- The village of St. Jacques de Nehou was captured yesterday as American infantrymen of the Eighty-second Airborne Division smashed across the neck of the Cherbourg peninsula, according to reports from the front last night.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Almost 2,000,000 tons of lend-lease military equipment and war production materials were shipped to Soviet Russia along with food for its army in the first four months of 1944, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, stated today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 17 -- Officials of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company declined today to act on the twenty-four-hour ultimatum given them yesterday by George S. Pfaus, area director of the War Manpower Commission, to relax a thirty-day probation period in rehiring procedure at its Kearny yard.

The American Medical Association held its ninety-fourth annual session at Chicago last week and in five days discussed the scientific and social aspects of medicine. Because so many clinicians, biochemists, bacteriologists and surgeons are at the front there were not the usual number of papers of high scientific importance.

Contrary to early forecasts, orders for better fall coats have been large, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell. The report also notes heavy buying of medium price and better dresses for fall. Black, fuchsia and purple are the important tones, with blue dropping in favor and peacock gaining.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
BAYEUX, France, June 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- Except for German bombers overhead and the distant rumble of gunfire, this might be a town on the French Mediterranean coast untouched by battle.

LONDON, June 17 -- German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels has been able to make far better use of Adolf Hitler's secret weapon than Field Marshal Karl von Rundstedt. While propagandists in Berlin showered the German population with claims of what the robot plane could do, more sober military commentators had to caution the people not to expect miracles.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- Bill Lee was breezing along in Shibe Park today with a one-hit shut-out of the Dodgers within three outs of becoming a reality, while a crowd of 4,858 fans watched in mingled tenseness and delight, some of them under the impression that he had allowed no hits.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- If the Republican National Convention at Chicago follows the usual pattern, the selection of a Presidential candidate will be a short and generally harmonious piece of business.

The first American naval officer back from the opening of the second front on the Normandy coast, Lieut. John Mason Brown of New York, declared yesterday in an interview at 90 Church Street that it was "a wonder we got in at all."

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 17 (AP) -- The Chinese Twenty-second Army, after a seven-day siege, has captured Kamaing, principal Japanese supply base in north Burma and key enemy stronghold in the Mogaung Valley, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 17 -- With the arrival several days ago in Addis Ababa of a mission representing the Egyptian Coptic Patriarch Makarius III, negotiations with Emperor Haile Selassie and Ethiopian church dignitaries concerning the dispute over the appointment of an Ethiopian as the next Archbishop of that country are now well under way.

AN assistant director of Hollywood sat on a Central Park bench beneath scowling skies and moodily declared: "You might call the whole thing a long study in frustration." The assistant director, Al Shenberg, had discovered, as had many another Hollywood magic maker before him, that there are certain things in New York which don't bend themselves readily to the will of man.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17 -When the Republican National Convention meets June 26 in Chicago, one of its important tasks -aside from the all-important job of nominating candidates -- will be to adopt a party platform.

Leaders of Hungarian-American organizations and Christian churches, said to represent 500,000 of their countrymen now in this country, convened at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday morning to denounce the extermination campaign being directed against the Jews in Hungary.

WASHINGTON, June l7 -- Ten shipyards now flying the Maritime "M" pennant for meritorious roduction achievement have received gold stars for continuing to maintain or better past records, the Maritime Commission announced today.

Charley Parker, the young sprinter eyed now by the nation as well as by his native Texas, gave some fleeting glimpses of himself during the first phase of the fifty-sixth annual National A.A.U. championship track and field meet at Randalls Island yesterday and raised a question.

OMAHA, June 17 -- In the yellowing wheat fields fast ripening for the sickle, the Midwestern farmer has an excellent object lesson in the error of discounting his chickens before they are hatched. He has had too many disappointments to err on the side of counting them too early.

IN the wake of increasing criticism of some of Hollywood's recent overly heroic, overly dramatic and all-around synthetic war pictures, it is now disclosed that Twentieth Century-Fox is preparing a series of "journalistic features" dealing factually with the war and kindred subjects.

SOMEWHERE IN BRITAIN (By Wireless). SO far the paratroopers and gliderborne infantrymen have received the world the credit they so richly deserve. No one could begrudge them one iota of the tributes or any of the praise they have earned in the invasion of Europe.

" YUKON RIVER CHILDREN" describes the everyday life of Poco, a little Athabascan Indian boy. The author tells how Poco and his family, having made and set their fish wheel, caught salmon and dried them for their winter supply of food; how they went dog sledding and hunting; how they slept and ate and dressed, and how they waited eagerly for mail and supplies.

THE surprising thing about this brief history, originally written in French by a Frenchman for Frenchmen, is that it scarcely betrays its origin. Except for a few slips which a careful editor could have prevented, it might have been written by an American in English for Americans.

TEN years ago a young Welshwoman won a gold medal for the best novel of the year. "The Captain's Wife," Eiluned Lewis' second work of fiction, justifies the enthusiasm aroused by the earlier book -- "Dew on the Grass" -- and fulfills its promise.

Before a world engrossed in World War II President Roosevelt last week laid a plan for preventing World War III. The plan, outlined in a 500-word release handed to newspaper men at the White House, envisaged an assembly of peace-loving nations charged with "promoting and facilitating international cooperation."

Leonard H. Marshall will be 58 years old on Tuesday and on that day he will return to the sea after almost two years on shore as the result of his experience in being aboard a tanker that was torpedoed and set afire, according to word from the Recruitment and Manning Organization of the War Shipping Administration, 37 Broadway.

BOSTON, June 17 -- Having won a long fight for increased transport service to the Boston Airport, which is the aerial hub of all six regional States, New England this week hailed the coming entry of four major airlines into a previously monopolized field as "the big-test transportation event since the Clipper Ships sailed."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 17 -- William H. Stanley's blue-hulled International sloop Bumble Bee, J.N. Halsted's S boat Fidget, Charley Vanderlaan's Atlantic Minkie II and Harold Morse's Handicap Class craft Tzigane were winners today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's regatta, the fourth one of the Long Island Sound special series.

THERE is an almost startling inner kinship among the writings of the three great Yiddish writers of our time -- Sholem Asch, I.J. Singer (lately deceased) and Zalman Shneour. If their novels were issued anonymously it would take a very astute reader to identify the author.

New York University, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the University of Chicago, California Institute of Technology and the University of California at Los Angeles are cooperating with the Weather Bureau in its university training program.

THE readers of historical novels are becoming a specialized order, as set in their ways as detective story fans. Action is, of course, the primary requisite. There must be plenty of blood, thunder, sound, fury. The history itself must be meticulously accurate.

BEFORE Yeats, the fathers of poets were monsters, who wanted their sons to become lawyers or go into business. The influence of such fathers on their sons was perhaps considerable, but it was negative: because the father did one thing, the son did another.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has released a study which shows that the working capital of American industry has increased by $17,000,000,000, or 69 per cent, since the end of 1939. The SEC concludes from this study that industry will be able to finance reconversion to peacetime production and even undertake considerable expansion on the basis of this liquid position.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES in France, June 17 -- American Army casualties totaled 3,283 dead and 12,600 wounded up to midnight last night in the first eleven days of the invasion of France, and the beachhead has become "absolutely secure," the Germans having "lost their last chance to drive us back into the sea," Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley announced today.

THERE is something about Rome which makes one want to be philosophy instead of journalistic. Everyone who has ever come to Rome and lived in it and written about it inevitably succumbs for, after all, it is "the Eternal City" and its atmosphere is redolent of ancient things that somehow never seem to change.

J. Dewey Dorsett, general manager of the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives, asserts in the current issue of The Casualty and Surety Journal that the Workmen's Compensation Law should be changed to aid the handicapped worker.

LINE-UP IN THE HOUSE: The Roosevelt landslide of 1932 elected 313 Democratic Representatives to the Seventy-third Congress and gave the incoming Administration a clear majority which it held unbroken for eleven years. Last week, with the election of a Republican in the Nineteenth District of Illinois, the Democratic party lost its margin in the House.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 17 (UP) -- Communique 23:

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17 -- A pass to Jim Jordan with the bases full in the tenth gave Princeton a 4-3 victory over the Pennsylvania nine today. John McCloskey, who had relieved John Woebse in the eighth, walked Jordan to force Bob Bilgrav in from third.

RING LARDNER began his career in fiction most unpretentiously with "You Know Me Al" and other baseball stories. These pieces are lighter, more gay than his later work. He took the heroes of the sport pages and showed that they were made of anything but the cloth of heroism.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 -- Unveiling of the new Superfortress in a bombing raid on Japan, and the simultaneous invasion of the Marianas, coming so soon after President Roosevelt's prediction that the Japanese would be knocked out earlier than had been expected, have cloaked the West Coast with an air of expectancy, mixed with ennui.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 -- Gov. Earl Warren formally released today all California delegates from their pre-primary pledge to support him for the Republican Presidential nomination and told them that, except for two restrictions they were "just as free as the air they breathed" to follow their own wishes at the Chicago convention.

TRADE gains over last year are shrinking and, as the war bond drive moves toward its goal, retailers would not be surprised to see some sales decreases appear. Bond buying, the invasion, war contract cutbacks, election year and several other influences are mentioned as grounds for believing that trade is leveling off.

FANNIE HURST, the novelist, is to have her own half-hour commercial program at 10 A.M. Saturdays over the Blue and WJZ, beginning July 8. She will act as narrator of the offering, which is expected to make use of dramatizations of some of her own stories.

HOW will Germany crack? At the moment more interest is centered on when, but how is also important. Will the Nazi power break down suddenly, like a strong steel bar that finally has reached the limit of its strength? Or bit by bit? Some people made the mistake of expecting World War II to follow the military patterns set by World War I.

THE traditional June "white sales" that used to offer homemakers the best buys of the year in sheets and towels and table linens have been abandoned by New York stores this year by common agreement. Housewives are asked to buy only what they actually need to cope with today's laundry schedules.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the maritime commission, said today the volume of work in merchant shipyards would be increased very soon and not decreased or cut back.

Five emergency United Seamen's Service centers were opened at various ports in southern England during the pre-invasion period and thus the USS was in a position to care for the needs of merchant seamen who have been shuttling vitally needed supplies to the beachheads established in France during the invasion, it was disclosed here yesterday by Douglas P. Falconer, executive director.

An Army deserter and ex-convict was held without bail yesterday in Felony Court by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney for what was characterized by Assistant District Attorney John A. McAvinue as "the most brutal murder in the annals of the lower East Side."

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The major British and American trade unions appear to be agreed that the United Nations should help trade union men in Germany and Italy to re-establish their organizations.

Disputes over economic and political theories and dogmas may divert the people of this country from entering upon an unprecedented age of building and expansion at the end of the war, David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, warned last night.

I must express my appreciation of your recent editorials concerning the extension by Congress of the Emergency Price Control Act. I am confident that this country will never abandon price stabilization and embark on an inflationary course with its eyes open.

REPOTTING house plants is a chore which should be done this month and the busy Victory gardener is likely to relegate it to some ainy afternoon. For the apartment dweller who is an indoor gardener the year round this annual event affords all the pleasure and anticipation of a spring planting.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The occupation of Iceland by American troops three years ago next month was cited by the Office of War Information today as a "concrete demonstration to other countries throughout the world" of what to expect as new American forces move into Europe.

TO the plaint that radio plays vanish into thin air and seldom return, "Free World Theatre," which puts between covers the 1943 radio series of that name, is a worthy answer. (And, by the way, there aren't many such answers because, by and large, there is shockingly little serious radio writing that is good.)

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Sunday, June 18 (AP) -- More than fifty Mitchell bombers, escorted by a large force of Lightnings, smacked Sorong, on the northwestern tip of Netherland New Guinea, and destroyed more than fifty planes on the ground and in the air, headquarters announced today.

ROME, June 17 -- Veteran French commandos and colonials, supported by American, British and French warships and planes, invaded Napoleon's exile island of Elba early this morning and tonight they were reported charging inland at several points against strong German resistance.

The 150th anniversary of Bowdoin College, alma mater of many famous Americans, will be celebrated at special convocation ceremonies and by alumni luncheons to be held in thirty cities throughout the United States next Saturday. A number of honorary degrees will be awarded to leading American statesmen and educators.

LONDON, June 17 -- The first counter-attack in force against the Allied invasion forces which had landed on the Normandy beaches a week earlier was launched by German defenders of the Atlantic Wall only on Wednesday of this week.

The absent-minded passenger who left $27,200 in a taxicab last Wednesday revealed himself yesterday as Frank Costello, the slot-machine king, ex-convict, judge-maker and one of Mayor La Guardia's pet peeves, when he came to the police property clerk's office to lay claim to the wad of hundred-dollar and fifty-dollar banknotes.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 17 -- Capital from the United States is expected to flow to Brazil after the war in search of new channels of investment and in the belief that Brazil offers attractive possibilities. Some capital, it is felt, also will wish to leave the United States because of the fear of heavy taxation that is expected to follow the war.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- The National Association of Insurance Commissioners recommended today that the insurance supervisory official of each State "request his Attorney General to consider the desirability of cooperating in securing a rehearing of the insurance case before the United States Supreme Court."

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- Finishing in the middle of the track with a tremendous run that carried him from far back, the Brookmeade Stable's Great Rush scored by a neck today in the $5,000 added Bunker Hill Handicap at Suffolk Downs before a holiday throng of 20,952.

PROFESSOR SOWARD of the University of British Columbia has written a clear and interesting outline of the world history of the last twenty-five years. Much of the material was used as a correspondence course for Canadian service men, and the resulting book has lost nothing of the simplicity of approach and narrative skill which would be essential for such a purpose.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- By way of lending credibility to the flat pronouncement of last week that American industry as a whole had so strengthened its working capital structure as to be able to handle the huge task of reconversion without outside financial assistance, the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a series of charts giving the factual basis for its over-all conclusions.

IN making an estimate of the state of the dance on the basis of the recent season's activities, it is difficult to decide whether to hail it with delight or to go in for a bit of viewing with alarm. When all the evidence is in it would seem considerably safer to include at least a generous proportion of the latter course.
LONDON, June 17 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast by the Berlin radio:

HAVING tossed out hints, plans and hopes for the coming season, it was time for the Theatre Guild to pause, reflect and consolidate its positions. Herewith, according to Lawrence Langner and Theresa Helburn, the present Guild "line": Ethel Barrymore and "Embezzled Heaven" should be here in mid-October.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Staggering under the most direct and potentially serious blows she has yet received -- the bombing of her homeland, the invasion of the Marianas and the task force strike against the Bonins only about 600 miles from Tokyo -- Japan this week was driven perilously closer to the possibility of defending herself on her inner lines.

SINCE this book was written General Giraud, already a mere super on the political stage, has retired from the military scene as well. He may justly feel that he has been shabbily treated by Vichy, Algiers and Washington alike.

THOUGH the Berkshire Festival will once again be conspicuous by its absence, there will be musical activity at Tanglewood this summer after all. Dr. Serge Koussevitzky has announced that he will direct a Mozart Festival of four concerts on Saturday evenings, July 29 and Aug. 5 at 8:30 and on Sunday afternoons, July 30 and Aug. 6 at 3:30.

CRAYONS and pencils are better than nothing, but poster paints and clay are much better art materials for children, Jane Cooper Bland said when asked for some suggestions at a preview of New York City Children's Art (on view until June 24 at the Bland Galleries, 45 East Fifty-seventh Street).

From Japan and the Marianas to Normandy and northern Italy the past week has been an awe-inspiring demonstration of the strength of the United States and the British Commonwealth of Nations. The blows struck during these seven days had behind them not only the impact of bold and disciplined fighting men but also the power of management and labor in the democratic countries.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Italy, June 17 (UP) -- A special communique:

In a research study released yesterday, the H.K. Ferguson Company, Cleveland and New York engineering organization, projects a revolutionary "blueprint" of the factory of the future. Combining many novel features, it was said, it will be many years before the transition from present types to the new order is completed.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The War Production Board gave the signal today for industry to lay the groundwork for swift return to peace production.

The smouldering animosity between the United Corporation and the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation flared last week into the open as hearings got under way before the Securities and Exchange Commission at the proceedings for integration and cor porate simplification of the huge Columbia system, a $700,000,000 combined electric and gas enterprise with forty-two subsidiaries operating in seven States extending from New York to Kentucky.

ANNUAL flowers are completely satisfactory in a garden that must be temporary. For example, if a home is rented for only one year or for the summer, and a flower garden is desired, annuals may be counted on to fill the bill without a large expenditure of money or the loss of valuable plants at moving time.

THE business of putting on a radio show has been described at various times as a trade, an art, a racket and a headache, but here at Camp Sibert there is a new wrinkle. Here it is a phase of training for some of the men in the Special Service Training Group.

To praise for the valor of our fighting men on all the war fronts should be added gratitude to the patient, dogged soldiers of supply. Without them there could be no beachheads on the Cherbourg peninsula, no German armies retreating north of Rome, no seizure of the Marshalls, no death traps for the Japanese in the mountains and forests of Burma.

Nine hundred degrees will be conferred in quadrangle exercises at 5 P. M. today in Brooklyn College's third wartime commencement. Thirty-five service men will be candidates for degrees, although few are expected to receive them personally.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- President Roosevelt said today the "best pledge that Poland shall resume her rightful place among the free nations of the world" was to be found in the spirit and determination of her fighting men.

From Japan and the Marianas to Normandy and northern Italy the past week has been an awe-inspiring demonstration of the strength of the United States and the British Commonwealth of Nations. The blows struck during these seven days had behind them not only the impact of bold and disciplined fighting men but also the power of management and labor in the democratic countries.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Italy, June 17 (UP) -- A special communique:

In a research study released yesterday, the H.K. Ferguson Company, Cleveland and New York engineering organization, projects a revolutionary "blueprint" of the factory of the future. Combining many novel features, it was said, it will be many years before the transition from present types to the new order is completed.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The War Production Board gave the signal today for industry to lay the groundwork for swift return to peace production.

The smouldering animosity between the United Corporation and the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation flared last week into the open as hearings got under way before the Securities and Exchange Commission at the proceedings for integration and cor porate simplification of the huge Columbia system, a $700,000,000 combined electric and gas enterprise with forty-two subsidiaries operating in seven States extending from New York to Kentucky.

ANNUAL flowers are completely satisfactory in a garden that must be temporary. For example, if a home is rented for only one year or for the summer, and a flower garden is desired, annuals may be counted on to fill the bill without a large expenditure of money or the loss of valuable plants at moving time.

JOAN CHARLES' first novel is a study of an unbalanced mind which rights itself, of the struggle for sanity in a segment of society which has no ethical standards and no sense of social realities. Ann, the subject of this dilemma, is confined first in a private sanitarium, later in a State asylum.

" GOBBLEDYGOOK," according to Maury Maverick [writing in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine], "means not only big, foolish words" but it is also "talk or writing which is long, pompous, vague, involved, usually with Latinized words." The former Congressman from Texas makes a strong appeal for simple words and blasts the users of five-dollar or four-storied words as well as the ornate verbiage itself.

CITY groceries are well stocked with prepared foods that should appeal to women who want to do just as little "stove" cooking us possible during the hot weather. For the sake of convenience this department has divided these foods into three groups -- first courses, main courses and salads and salad dressings.

With industrial shares near their best levels in four years and railway issues at about their best in seven years, the stock market yesterday ended a week of higher prices on a note of firm optimism. Rails and aircraft led the two-hour session on the New York Stock Exchange.

Last year when German prisoners of war began to come into this country the question was raised whether their presence did not present an admirable opportunity for the beginning of re-education of the German people. Here were these men, fed on lies, indoctrinated against democracy, set down among a free people who knew the facts of the war and were able to speak their minds and make their opinions heard.

THE business of producing a television play is growing up. There has been an air of professionalism recently about a number of the shows, indicating that the programming side of the new art is emerging from what might be called a happy-go-lucky adolescence.

THEODORE WALDECK, whose animal stories are sure fire with young readers, now describes an expedition to Tanganyika to bring back animals for zoos and laboratories. Mr. Waldeck's detailed account of the methods used will delight any boy who has ever longed to be a big game hunter or to explore wild country.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 17 (AP) -- Syracuse University, returning to intercollegiate football after a year's holiday enforced by war conditions, announced today a six-game 1944 schedule capped by the traditional Colgate contest at Syracuse Nov. 18.

ROME, June l7 -- There is a mad scramble going on in Italy and it is the Germans who are doing all the scrambling. On both coasts the Nazis are falling back so fast that as often as not they not only lose contact with us, but lose it with each other.

IN trade circles along Radio Row, which can include anyone even remotely connected with the wireless business, it is reckoned that this summer will be an unprecedented one in the marketplace. For, though many of the big "name" shows will be estivating, as usual, the sages guess that more listeners will be tuning in than ever before in the hot weather.

A Washington dispatch to this newspaper reports that a program for post-war handling of cartels has been recommended by technical experts of Government departments. This program calls for an international agreement pledging nations to an anti-cartel policy which, however, would recognize that international commercial agreements can serve other than restrictive purposes.

LONDON, June 17 -- By disrupting transport and communications and making direct attacks on enemy garrisons, which wrested from them full control of some areas, French resistance forces have "played their assigned role in battle of liberation," according to a special communique issued tonight at Allied headquarters.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The United States and British Governments are reaching the show-down stage in their controversy with each other and with Gem Charles de Gaulle over the recognition of the "French Provisional Government," it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Lord Keynes, economic adviser to the British Treasury, will head the British delegation to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference opening July 1 at Bretton Woods, N.H., the British Information Service stated today.

IN this breezy book radio comedian Bob Hope reveals that vaudeville, which had "folded up into Radio City," has been revived by the war and that "the USO has turned out to be nothing more than Loew's Circuit with foxholes."

MOSCOW, June 17 -- It came as a complete surprise to the public here that the first blow in Premier Stalin's summer offensive should have been struck on the Karelian Isthmus, though, since the breakdown of negotiations with the Finnish Government, it had been taken for a certainty that the next word would be spoken by the Red Army.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (U.P.) -- State officials and representatives of the aviation industry recommended today that the States assume a greater share in control of aviation and that a clear line be drawn between State and Federal regulation of airports, air safety and all other subjects pertaining to air traffic.

THIRTY KOPEC stamps, honoring "four heroic cities in the Great Patriotic War," have been received from the U.S.S.R. by Bamberger's in Newark. One, brown and red, pictures Red Army soldiers with bayonets pointed toward a map of terrain where Nazi troops were annihilated and "Liquidation of German Fascist Army Around Stalingrad" is inscribed. Another, blue, illustrates a statue of Lenin, with the port of Sevastopol in the background.

An incendiary bomb which scatters sticky gobs of burning gasoline jelly on enemy targets was demonstrated for the press last week at Rahway, N.J., by the Chemical Warfare Service of the United States Army. In comparative tests with the magnesium bomb which the Germans dropped by the hundreds of thousands on Great Britain, the effectiveness of the oil-gel incendiary was shown by attacks on typical enemy structures.

HAVING a part score is in many ways a great advantage, but it presents certain pitfalls. Most of these are psychological. The apparent cheapness of game, when it can be made by a contract of two or three in a suit, tempts players to bid unnaturally.

Recently there has been more discussion about the naming of the present war, and a few new names for it have been suggested: "The Tyrants' War," "the War of the Dictators" and so on. However, I don't believe that any such invented names, no matter how poignant they are, will ever be actually used to designate this international struggle.

ALONG Broadway, where all the intelligent people gather every evening, the discussion groups spent most of last season talking about the vagaries of same. Outside the playhouses, and backstage within, there were whining and uncertain noises as producers, actors, managers and reviewers tried to figure out what to say of the state of the theatre.

DETROIT, June 17 -- Smooth-stroking Miss Dorothy May Bundy of Santa Monica, Calif., whose mother and dad both were national tennis champions, captured an American title of her own today by defeating Miss Mary Arnold of Los Angeles, 7-5, 6-4, in the women's final of the National Clay Court Tournament.
LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- The German "dynamite meteors" were disclosed tonight to be a surprisingly simple weapon -- a large steel model of a child's Fourth of July rocket.
NEWARK, N.J., June 17 (AP) -The league-leading Bisons, behind Mike Roscoe's six-hit twirling, took their third straight from the cel-I lar-dwelling Bears, 7 -- 1, today.

THE leaders of the Reformation in sixteenth-century England had somewhat the same sensitivity to the charge of radicalism that some New Dealers have today -- the Anabaptist, not the Communist, figuring in the then-current "fellow-traveler" formula.

Under Title V of the Soldier Vote Act, as interpreted by the Adjutant General of the Army, many distinguished books of general circulation are now forbidden for Army and Navy use, the Council on Books in Wartime, Inc., disclosed yesterday in a resolution describing the restrictions as "an alarming encroachment on freedom."

RICHMOND, June 17 -- In the several Southern States touched by the Tennessee Valley and its tributaries, there is rejoicing over the fact that the assault on TVA started by Senator Kenneth McKellar has failed. The partial face-saver for the Tennessee Senator in the form of a requirement that TVA submit an accounting every four months to both Houses of Congress is not considered objectionable.

THE house of Metro-Goldwyn- Mayer has built up a reputation over the years for doing things in a big way, but it is unlikely that either Nicholas M. Schenck or Louis B. Mayer ever dared, in their fondest dreams, to envision the Metro trade-mark (the roaring lion known as Leo) appearing on practically every motion picture theatre screen in this country and Canada during any given week.

North Carolina last week became the first Southern State to take the final step toward eliminating the differences in salaries of Negro and white public school teachers. At its June meeting the State Board of Education approved plans for equalizing salaries of Negro and white teachers with surplus funds expected to be on hand during the 1944-45 school term, thus fulfilling a pledge made a decade ago to the Negroes of North Carolina.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Expeditionary Force, June 17 (AP) -- The port of Cherbourg, now on the verge of being isolated by the American attack, is a rich prize for the invading armies, comparable on a smaller scale with what the capture of Naples meant to the invasion of Italy.
Yesterday was one to remember for 14-year-old Paul Lindsley Thomas, who finished his course from the Cathedral Choir School of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- "Who is going to support my policies loyally -- Barkley, Rayburn?" the President recently inquired of a visitor who was arguing against the renomination of Vice President Henry A. Wallace in the event the President is a fourth-term candidate.

The current War Bond drive recalls that sportsmen can do a lot in that direction even though they are a heterogeneous group nard to bring together for any concerted effort. By now the ways they can help are well known -- earmarking bonds for the purchase of fishing and hunting equipment not available during the war, awarding contest prizes in bonds and stamps and bidding up desired paraphernalia at War Bond auctions.

Mrs. Francis W. Bliss, who at 54 years of age will be graduated from Hunter College on Wednesday as the oldest member of her class, has another distinction. Within a period of three weeks Mrs. Bliss became the grandmother of two granddaughters as well as the prospective possessor of a Bachelor of Arts degree.

FOR a great runny readers Mrs. Irving Berlin remains the heroine of as glittering a romance as they can ever expect to encounter in fiction, and they might expect a true story here. If so, they are doomed to disappointment, for "Land I Have Chosen" is not even vaguely autobiographical.

RECENTLY the Supreme Court, in holding that fire Insurance is commerce, reversed what had been established constitutional law for seventy-five years. Then it was the insurance companies which unsuccessfully invoked the commerce clause as a shelter against State power.

Ninety-nine Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc., offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at 40th Street) for tickets.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- March and May lard on the Board of Trade here were, respectively, $13.05 and $13 a hundredweight bid, but there were no actual trades.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Senators and Red Sex split a double-header today, with Washington capturing the nightcap, 1 to 0, after dropping the opener, 9 to 6, before a sweltering crowd of 17,494.

The drop of 0.1 per cent which occurred in the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was caused by a large decline in the price of wheat and continued strong declines in the prices of cows and fruit.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 18 -- It is thrilling for a dog owner to win the award of best in show. Nor does the feeling of elation diminish with a recurrence. So Mrs. Leonard Smit of Monsey, N.Y., sat at the ringside on the grounds of the Longshore Club this evening and saw her grand Airedale terrier win tops for the fourth time.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- For a short time on this sweltering afternoon in Shibe Park the Dodgers were at the .500 mark in the National League standing. That great height was reached because of Ed Head's seven-hit pitching and the Brooks' fifteen hits, while downed the Phillies, 7 -- 3, in the first game of a double-header.

The well-educated American "is a formidable fellow because he can work well singly and, on occasion, as a whole team," Dr. George D. Stoddard, Commissioner of Education of the State of New York, told 900 graduates of Brooklyn College yesterday at the ninteenth annual commencement exercises.

Bill Hulse and Johnny Fulton, engaged in a tense duel from the outset, were so concerned about each other that they completely ignored the presence in the 800-meter run of Bob Kelley in the fifty-sixth National Senior A.A.U. track and field championships at Randalls Island yesterday.

Our Superfortress attack on the Yawata steel works marks the beginning of strategic air war over Japan proper. This first flight of the B-29's, damaging as it was, foretells only faintly what is to come. Eventually the skies over Japan will be dark with American planes. But we must not expect the attack to mushroom into anything resembling the terrific pounding Germany has taken for the past year.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- A twelve-man committee of Army, Navy and scientific experts will start work this week on one of the most important proposals for postwar security -- the establishment of a scientific high command ranking with the command staffs of the Army and Navy.

The importance of the American plan of post-war international security, announced by the President last week, has been overshadowed by the sensational developments on the fighting fronts. It may be that the statement sounded low-toned and unemphatic because the action of the war speaks so loudly.

A loan exhibition of chessmen from the collection of Gustavus Pfeiffer will open at the Metropolitan Museum in Gallery H-11 on Wednesday. The sets displayed will indicate the many forms of the pieces used in the game and will remain on view until the end of August.

Mayor La Guardia indicated yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall that his ban against the holding of outside jobs by city employes on their own time would not be generally enforced to the point of discharge from municipal service while the war continues.

ROME, June 18 (AP) -- The impressive Jewish synagogue of the Eternal City has reopened its doors, removing for the first time in nine months of occupation the bars placed upon it by the Nazis, and the first complete service in the temple since it was closed was marked by a fervent prayer of thanks for the deliverance of the Italian capital.

UNITED STATES FIELD HEADQUARTERS ON THE SALWEEN FRONT, June 15 (Delayed) -- While Chinese armies in the east slowly yield to the pressure of the mounting Japanese offensive, the Chinese expeditionary force slowly applies pressure in the Salween River sector in the effort to reopen the Burma Road.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- Two homers by Billy Nicholson and one by Dora Dallessandro enabled the Cubs to gain a thirteen-inning, 6-6 tie in the second game of their double-header with Cincinnati before 40,222 today after Harry Gumbert, in his first appearance for the Reds since his acquisition from the Cardinals, held the Cubs to five hits and beat them, 5 to 2, in the opener.
NEWARK, N. J., June 18 (AP) -- After losing seven straight times to Buffalo, the Bears today beat the Bisons in both ends of a twin bill, 9-7 and 10-1.

Analyzing the results of the first week of the Fifth War Loan drive, Nevil Ford, State chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York, said yesterday that during the first four complete business days of the campaign, E-bond sales averaged $750,000 more a day than during the corresponding period of the Fourth Loan.

If the Wiley amendment in the Senate version of the Price Control Bill is retained in conference it will have the effect of exempting most wages from controls and therefore of bringing about a substantial price rise. The Wiley amendment removes from the control of the War Labor Board the salaries and wages of those earning less than $37.50 a week.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- Calling Bricker-for-President Headquarters in Chicago?. It's Wabash 1944.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Centers for the vocational rehabilitation of disabled war veterans are to be operated at universities and colleges throughout the country, Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, administrator of veterans affairs, announced tonight.

LONDON, June 18 -- If the London stock markets have not exactly taken the bit between the teeth in the last week, they have given expression to buoyant optimism, due to the powerfully stimulating influence of the military success attained in the opening phases of the Allied invasion of Normandy combined with a strong technical position.

ALGIERS, June 18 -- In a chamber decorated with French and Allied flags and flanked by members of the Army, Navy and Air Force, France's Consultative Assembly in ceremonial session observed today an anniversary that doubtless henceforth will be a French national holiday -- the anniversary of the beginning of French resistance when Gen. Charles de Gaulle made his first appeal to France from London four years ago.

The success of the democratic form of government depends upon full utilization of man's instinctive urge to humanize the world, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, declared yesterday in calling or a world state dedicated to purposeful living among its inhabitants.

The establishment of a new department of home economics at Hunter College, to be introduced this fall, was announced yesterday by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, Dr. Gladys Branegan, dean of the division of household and industrial arts at Montana State College, has been granted a year's leave of absence to organize and act as chairman of the new division.
MONTREAL, June 18 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals won both ends of a double-header from the Jersey City Giants today 11-2, 2-0, before 12,000 fans.

Every month the nutrition bureau of the Community Service Society of New York issues to the several thousand families under its guidance a bulletin containing seven dinner menus with appropriate recipes, which are at once attractive, nourishing and low in cost.
NEWARK, N.J., June 18 -- Hot weather and depleted stocks of beer have brought about an acute shortage of that beverage throughout this section of New Jersey.

I like your tribute to the men of the merchant marine in today's TIMES, but some of us did not need to have a London dispatch tell us that the merchant marine 'has the largest rat o of casualties of any branch of the service." And we knew all too well that "some have swum through seas of burning oil," and not too far from our own coast.

CHUNGKING, China, June 18 (AP) -- Three important Chinese strongholds have fallen to swift Japanese advances in Hunan Province, and to the north in Honan Province the enemy also has made serious gains along the Peiping-Hankow railway, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 18 -- Beardsley Ruml, treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., declared at the Tufts College commencement today that the present world war had roused us to the dangers in our past neglect of human freedom and that the doctrines on which it rests had taken on new meaning and new strength everywhere.

Vigorous appeals for unity based on a "common platform," such as that of Professor Perry in THE TIMES of June 11, recall the Crusades, when Christian and Moslem armies met in combat near Jerusalem. Both pursued a purpose which, as each expressed it in his own tongue, meant "Submission to the will of God."

A meeting of the stockholders of Loew's, Inc., has been called for July 18 to elect directors and to approve a retirement plan for the benefit of all employes of the company and its subsidiaries in the United States who have had five or more years of service with the organization, including executives and motion picture talent.
IN YUGOSLAVIA, June 13 (Delayed) -- I believe I am the only Allied correspondent who interviewed and watched the Germans in their own front line and then crossed over to the Allies to report.

CHICAGO, June 18 (U.P.) -- Republicans who will construct the party's 1944 platform were gathering tonight amid indications that at least two major planks, farm and foreign policy, would prove to be a political headache.

ALBANY, June 18 -- Oswald D. Heck, State War Plans Coordinator, outlined today the way in which local war councils can assist Federal and State agencies, already organized with expert personnel, to deal specifically with the problems of returning service men and women.

IT is painful to Have to report it, but the first national champion crowned in sun-baked Randalls Island yesterday was as illegal as 3.2 beer during the era of the noble experiment. Buddy Young was the official winner of the 100-meter title after the strangest succession of mishaps in the long and hitherto honorable history of the A.A.U.

Capt. Don Gentile's account of his combat experiences, "A One-Man Air Force," as told to Ira Wolfert, will be published in August by L.B. Fischer. Mr. Wolfert, author of "Battle for the Solomons," received the story when the Piqua, Ohio, airman was at an air base in England preparatory to returning to this country.

WEST CORNWALL, Conn., June 18 (AP) -- While State policemen, led by their commissioner, searched unsuccessfully for a clue which might unravel the mystery surrounding the assault upon Mrs. Francis Lee Higginson, she was taken in an ambulance today to a Boston hospital.
LONDON, June 18 -- Less than two weeks after the initial Allied landings in Normandy our foothold on the western coast of Europe is almost secure.

One hundred and sixty-five former prisoners of war, now volunteers in the Italian Service Unit on non-combat duty at Camp Shanks, visited New York yesterday as sightseers and enjoyed their first social affair since their capture, a surprise dance.

Coney Island and the Rockaways each estimated its visitors at "more than a million" yesterday as the temperature reached 90 degrees for the first time this year. Another 1,000,000 persons sought relief from the heat in Central Park, and other parks, playgrounds and beaches reported near capacity crowds.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations named today a committee of seven, led by President Philip Murray, to call on the War Labor Board and to present a bill of grievances which include "interminable delays" in board procedure and a charge that the WLB "has almost completely abdicated authority to the Wage Stabilization Division, which arrogantly has assumed final authority over all wage problems."

Store buyers continued to place orders for fall ready-to-wear lines last week, with large numbers being in the market. Bookings for the fall season have been large, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

It is with feelings of anger as well as horror that we read President Roosevelt's announcement to Congress that the Nazis are determined to complete their program of mass extermination of minorities. And the anger is not only against the Nazis, against whom mere anger is futile, but against our own leaders for the picayune and ineffectual measures taken to stop this mass murder.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 18 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 18 (U.P.) -- Waves and women marines are expecting to be sent out of the continental United States in September, despite the objections of Senator David I. Walsh, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, who is fighting all moves to permit the women to serve outside this country.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (U.P.) -- The War Department disclosed tonight that ultra-high speed radio channels kept the Army High Command in Washington and London in instantaneous contact with the fighting on all fronts. Orders can be relayed directly to ships and planes in battle and to mechanized infantry in the front lines.

Alert as ever, but not quite as spry, William Augustin Brady, dean of theatrical producers, will observe his eighty-first birthday today. Asked yesterday how he would spend the day, Mr. Brady, owner of the Playhouse, said it would be the same as any other day as far as he was concerned.

ABOARD AN AMERICAN LANDING CRAFT OFF ELBA, June 17 (Delayed) -- A considerable French force and crowds of small British and American naval craft took part in the amphibious attack on the south coast of Elba at dawn this morning.

LONDON, Monday, June 19 -- The largest strategic bombing mission ever mounted was carried out yesterday by the United States Eighth Air Force when it sent more than 1,300 heavy bombers in an attack on oil refineries and storage depots in northwestern Germany.

In the closing summer of the last war the first Lewisohn Stadium concerts were given. In the years since then these "Concerts Under the Stars" have become one of the great cultural institutions of New York City. It is welcome news that in this year of unexampled stress and strain the sponsors are determined to make the season at hand the most brilliant of all.

Waiting to discover "perfect instruments for world cooperation will play into the hands of the isolationists and the forces making for chaos," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman warned yesterday at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

It took ten innings, but the New York City Police Department baseball team defeated the Fire Department for the first time since 1940, 2 to 1, yesterday at the Polo Grounds before about 16,000 spectators in their annual charity game for the benefit of the two departments' welfare funds.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, June 19 (AP) -- A communique:

The conference committee considering the House and Senate versions of the bill to extend price and wage control has a grave responsibility. It has been presented with two bills which make a farce out of price control. Both bills contain provisions designed to raise certain prices and to weaken the efforts to enforce others.

DETROIT, June 18 (AP) -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura, Ecuador's tennis ambassador, captured his second United States title today by defeating Billy Talbert of Indianapolis, 6 -- 3, 2 -- 6, 7 --5, 6 -- 3, in the final of the national clay court championship at the Detroit Tennis Club.

Names of American airmen forced to abandon damaged planes and now said to be in care of units of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch's forces in Yugoslavia were given out here yesterday by the Yugoslav Information Service, which said it had received the names from a broadcast from General Mikhailovitch's headquarters.
WITH THE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE TO SAIPAN -- The leaflet bombardment in the central Pacific is taking place over Saipan in the Mariana Islands.

LONDON, June 18 -- Dr. Ivan Subasitch, who took office as Yugoslav Prime Minister with the announced intention of going directly into German-occupied Yugoslavia if necessary to reach an agreement with Marshal Tito of the Yugoslav People's Army, has fulfilled that intention.

BOSTON, June 18 -- The Giants polished off the Braves twice this afternoon, and while this bit of refurbishing pleased neither the Braves nor a crowd of 18,836 sympathizers it certainly was hailed with considerable satisfaction by Manager Melvin Ott.

On the fourth anniversary of R- day, signalizing the birth of France's resistance against Nazi conquest, and occupation, delegations from various French and American patriotic societies joined in a special service yesterday morning at the French Episcopal Church of St_ Esprit, 109 East Sixtieth Street, to pay homage to the underground fighters who are aiding the Allied invasion armies in the Battle of France.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 18 (U.P.) -- The partial dispersal of the American Seventh Army, which was led by Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. in the invasion of Sicily, was revealed today with official disclosure that some of its finest troops now were fighting in France under Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley.

The Marathon Paper Mills Company has called a special meeting of stockholders to be held in its office at Rothschild, Wis., on July 6 for authorization to borrow $10,000,000 at a rate of interest not to exceed 3 3/4 per cent and to be evidenced by the company's debentures maturing not later than Dec. 31, 1960.

Waldemar Kaempffert's well-documented and convincing article in Saturday Review of Literature on the faking of antiques, pointing out how widespread is the work of "The World's Most 'Cultured' Criminals," must have left many a reader wondering with queasy doubt whether he too hadn't been robbed.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 (AP) -- The league-leading Cardinals split a double-header with the Pirates today, winning the first game, 12 to 2, then dropping the nightcap, 3 to 1, as its Ostermueller turned in a sparkling three-hit mound performance.
The "hot potato," Luke Hamlin, really was hot yesterday at the Stadium. So was elongated Russ Christopher. So were the Athletics. And the weather was sizzling, too.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 18 (AP) -- Chinese troops have captured the northern approach to the town of Mogaung, and a junction with Allied Chindits east of the town appeared imminent as Maj. Gen. W.D.A. Lentaigne's forces penetrated to within 200 yards of the Mogaung Valley bridge, it was announced tonight.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull, in a message paying tribute to the assistance being rendered by the French underground to the Allied invasion armies, expressed confidence yesterday that the people of France would want their Allied comrades in arms to subordinate everything to the paramount task of defeating the common enemy, thus hastening the day of liberation.

Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, in a broadcast yesterday over the National Broadcasting Company network, paid a strong tribute to the 10,000 American chaplains who have added a "spiritual armament to the fighting forces," adding that "in ministering to the spiritual needs of our fighting forces the church is making a solid contribution and a greatly appreciated contribution to our coming victory."
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- With a month-long recess beginning Saturday as its goal, Congress will step up its legislative machinery this week to dispose of a large number of major measures.

The Hotel Duane, a fifteen-story and penthouse building containing 150 rooms at 237-39 Madison Avenue, has been sold by Harry and Sadie Wells to the Goldron Realty Corporation, Harry Goldman, president, which immediately leased it to the Hotel Duane Operating Company, Joseph Mester, president, for ten years.

Four five-story buildings at 1026 to 1030 Sixth Avenue and 66-68 West Thirty-ninth Street, surrounding the southeast corner, have been sold by the Sperry Realty Company to an investing client of Samuel Brandt, attorney, for cash over a first mortgage of $228,577 held by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- "When our representatives sit around the peace table with those of our gallant Allies, a very definite policy of international responsibility must be adopted as an insurance for continued peace," Governor Edge of New Jersey asserted in the commencement address to a class of 208 at Drexel Institute of Technology today.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Oats failed to rally as quickly as other grains last week but made some response to the Washington news. Buyers are cautious because they expect that new ceiling prices soon will cause a roll-back. The tone of the cash market is easier, and new crop oats from southern areas are now filling some of the urgent demands for feed grains.

CHUNGKING, China, June 18 (AP) -- On the Yunnan Province front in China, where the Salween River offensive already has made its first juncture with Kachin levies from north Burma under Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, a Chungking communique reported continuous heavy fighting around captured Chiaotou since before daylight Friday.

LONDON, June 18 -- The neoblitz on southern England by German winged, powered bombs continued unabated today. Large numbers of the robot planes kept crossing the coast during the day and at night. Those that got through the barrage of anti-aircraft fire and fighter patrols exploded, causing damage and casualties.

DETROIT, June 18 (AP) -- Rudy York smashed a two-run homer in the ninth inning of the nightcap today to give the Detroit Tigers a double victory over the St. Louis Browns, 7 to 3 and 7 to 5, before 27,917 spectators.

LONDON, June 18 -- United States Chief of Staff Gen. George C. Marshall today called the performance of untried American divisions "probably the most reassuring aspect" of the "tremendously impressive" Normandy invasion.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 18 -- Japanese forces, gradually falling back from the American beachhead on Saipan Island, attempted to bring in reinforcements by sea but they were repulsed.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The important role of air transport in moving strategic materials to battle and production fronts was told by the Office of War Information today in a report which said that in three months of this year the total of such cargo was 10,500,000 pounds.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Office of Price Administration, in a move to reduce retail prices for canned fish and sea food, tightened up today a number of loose provisions in the regulations setting ceiling prices for all distributors of certain items except wholesalers and retailers.

The Canadian free dollar was easier last week, the first show of irregularity since early May when the dollar started its climb to a five-year high reached about mid-month. Not a great deal of business was involved on this setback which was due mainly to the falling off in the demand rather than to any pressure of sales.

ON THE SOVIET-FINNISH FRONT, June 17 (Delayed) -- Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, and a group of Allied correspondents were taken beyond Terijoki today on a tour of the Karelian fighting front.

ALGIERS, June 17 (Delayed) -- It is an unmistakable and encouraging sign of the times that the war now raging in France proper has left this pro-tem Paris far behind. In fact, the changes in Algiers since last August have been so great that it is hardly the same city.

The so-called pilotless or robot airplane is the first of the famous secret weapons to be unveiled in action by the enemy in response to the invasion. Though essential details probably are still unknown or uncertain, the device itself is far from a total secret.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 18 -- As a result of persistent German actions, obviously launched to reduce a potential Allied bridgehead in the Balkans, Marshal Tito's Yugoslav Partisan movement now is considerably weakened and has been placed in a delicate position.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 18 -- Breaking par for the fourth successive round despite the fact that his game threatened to fall apart on the outgoing nine, Byron Nelson won the $10,000 Red Cross open golf tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club today with a score of 275.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 18 -- It took only a hoped for fine overhead and breeze to swell the fleet today in the fifth championship regatta out on Long Island Sound to seventy-five. This topped the previous season mark by seven. The breeze was a misnomer after the start though, passed out completely twice and had just enough vitamins left in it to get the craft home.

ROME, June 18 -- The Italian political situation remained snarled today, and as a result Italy has two governments -- one under Marshal Pietro Badoglio, who is still recognized by the Allies; the other under Ivanoe Bonomi, chosen by all six political parties of the liberated regions.

The second annual Festival of Jewish Music -- Ritual, Chassidic, Secular -- sponsored by The Synagogue Light in conjunction with the American Chapter of the Religious Emergency Council of the Chief Rabbi of Great Britain, was given last night in Town Hall.

LONDON, Monday, June 19 -- Red Army tanks and infantry, supported by hundreds of cannon and warplanes, broke through the western side of the new Mannerheim Line yesterday and then pushed on to capture the fortress city of Koivisto in a general fifteen-mile advance that reached a point seventeen miles south of the Finnish gateway city of Viborg.

LONDON, June 18 -- An agreement has been reached between the Czechoslovak and Soviet Governments for printing Czech currency in Russia for use by Czech authorities and the Red Army when it reaches Czech territory. It has been described in a section of the London press as a model of what such agreements should be, in contrast to the unilateral printing by the Allies of French military currency without consultation or control by the French.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Treasury Department has no intention of opposing reductions in utility rates to avert adverse effects on Federal revenues, Secretary Morgenthau declared today. He made the statement, he said, to contradict "an impression created by recent press articles."

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES IN FRANCE, June 18 -- American troops who cut the Cherbourg Peninsula last night spent all today tightening their hold on the western beaches, with a series of bitter little isolated battles with last-ditch German die hards. In-their swift race to the coast yesterday and last night troops of the United States Ninth Division knowingly bypassed many points of enemy resistance.
Four new films will have their local premieres in midtown theatres this week. The programs follows:

CLEVELAND, June 18 (AP) -- Chicago's White Sox swept both ends of a double-header with the Cleveland Indians today, winning the nightcap 7 to 6 on a two-run rally in the ninth inning after Wally Moses tenth-inning home run provided the Sox with a 3 to 2 triumph in the opener.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- United States postal authorities, on orders from the Office of Censorship, seized all copies of the June 17 issue of The Saturday Evening Post which were destined for points outside of the United States and Canada, officials of the Curtis Publishing Company disclosed today.

The six-story apartment building at 3235 Grand Concourse, northwest corner of Van Cortlandt Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Ogden Realty Corporation from the Jacinal Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages of $409,958.

AN EIGHTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER BASE, in England, June 18 -- A "paddle blade," designed to give Thunderbolts a faster rate of climb, was partly responsible for the phenomenal success of these usually high-flying planes in low-level invasion duty.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Contrary to the predictions of some aviation prophets of the past, the North Pole is not destined to become the cross-roads of inter-continental air routes, the Brookings Institution stated today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, June 18 -- An experiment has been tried in Bougainville with such success that it may have an important bearing on the campaign against Japan in its final phases.

PROCESSED FOODS (vegetables, soups, fruits and fruit juices, some kinds of dried beans, jam, jelly, canned and bottled baby foods and certain other special products). Only blue stamps and blue tokens can he used. Blue stamps A8 through V8 in War Book 4 are good indefinitely, at 10 points each. No additional blue stamps become valid until July 1. Frozen fruits and vegetables and dried foods, except certain kinds of beans, are now point-free.

LONDON, June 18 (U.P.) -- Streamlined Spitfire fighters took up the defense of their country again today, swarming over southern England in strength and shooting down a "considerable number" of robot planes.

The unity of family life in many instances is being threatened rather than strengthened by increased war earnings, William Church Osborn, president of the Children's Aid Society, warned in a foreword to the society's ninety-first annual report made public today.

AN ADVANCED BASE OF THE UNITED STATES FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE, Eastern China, June 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- This base is one of the prime objectives of the Japanese drive for control of the Canton-Hankow Railway. Forty minutes away by air, P-40's and P-51's of a Fourteenth Air Force fighter group are killing Japanese by the dozens on barges on Tungting Lake.

The Cotton Textile Institute announces, effective today, E. O. Fitzsimons will transfer from the Charlotte to the Washington office of the institute to enable more effective handling of the increased volume of its Washington office.

JOSEPH KESSEL is a French writer of Russian descent and Argentine birth, At one time he was the youngest doctor of letters at the Paris Sorbonne. In the First World War he was a lieutenant in the French Air Force and received the Croix de Guerre for distinguished conduct in action from the hero of Verdun, a general called Petain.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (U.P.) -- The United States has decided to recognize the revolutionary government of Bolivia, established six months ago by Maj. Gualberto Villarroel.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- A group of anti-fourth-term Democrats, meeting as the American Democratic National Committee, will assemble a subcommittee, headed by former Senator James Reed of Missouri, here tomorrow to draw up a platform of "Jeffersonian principles" to be presented to the regular Democratic convention when it meets here on July 19.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 -- Major Clark Gable, who was placed on the Army inactive list last week, Myrna Loy and Lucille Ball have been named by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as the probable co-starring leads in the forthcoming "Seattle," a comedy drama with music.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, June 19 (AP) -- Mitchell medium bombers sank five Japanese merchantmen in follow-up raid upon Sorong in Netherland New Guinea, headquarters announced today.

The humble people of southern Italy are in need. Tens of thousands of them, their towns and homes destroyed, are actually destitute. The conquering Allied armies come as envoys of a happier day for them, but the world's pity must follow close behind. As Archbishop Spellman has said, "the insuperable might of our charity" is still required to save Italians for Italy and for the world's peace.
SOMEWHERE IN SOUTHERN ENGLAND, June 18 -- have watched two of Germany's vaunted comet bombs burn out their driving force, wing over, plummet and explode -- one less than 200 yards away.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Backers of Gov. Thomes E. Dewey of New York and Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio exchanged claims of support for these leading contenders for the Republican nomination for President as the vanguard of the party convention began arriving today in Chicago.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- There has been a change in the tone of Washington reports in reference to the corn sales under the freeze order. A short time ago it was intimated that the freeze order would be lifted before the end of the sixty-day period, but late advices are that the period may be extended until July 1, as farmers are slow in delivering the grain.
ROME, June 18 (UP) -- A communique:
LONDON, June 18 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and reported by The United Press:

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Bearish sentiment dominated the wheat market early last week, when it was affected mainly by the favorable crop reports and lack of speculative buying interest, but a sudden reversal in the trend came following the House action in passing the price control bill with an amendment obligating processors to pay parity prices for farm commodities.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 18 (AP) -- Communique 25:

SAUGUS, Mass., June 18 (AP) -- A rampage by five small boys between 10 and 14 years of age today reduced the Oaklandvale grammar school to wreckage and inflicted $2,000 in damage, according to Police Capt. Henry P. Wheaton.

Using the slogan, "War Bonds Today Are Job Bonds Tomorrow," Macfadden Publications will launch this week one of its most extensive advertising campaigns in its history. Scheduled for leading newspapers as well as eight Macfadden publications and trade papers, an advertising series will urge wage-earners to purchase war bonds to build a backlog of security so that earnings in the post-war period can be spent without compunction, and thus provide for continuing employment.

A SUPERFORTRESS AIR BASE, in Western China, June 17 -- This has been a day of rest, of assessment of results and of checking over the aircraft at this base, from which the world's largest bombers the night before last blasted the mighty iron and steel works at Yawata, Japan.

LONDON, June 18 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 117.6 on June 6, compared with 117.6 a fortnight before, 117.7 a month before, 114.9 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

BETHANY, W. Va., June 18 (AP) -- The people of the United States are fighting to preserve their own freedom rather than for the four freedoms or democracy or any other ideology, Senator Robert A. Taft declared today in addressing the graduating class of Bethany College. He said:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, June 19 -- Infantrymen of the United States Ninth Division have fought their way to the west coast of the Cherbourg Peninsula and have isolated the great port at its tip in the first outstanding tactical success of the French campaign, Allied communique No. 26 announced last night.

Large transactions and rapid advance in prices occurred last week on the Stock Exchange. European war news was favorable and, toward the week-end, attack on Japan stimulated buyers for the rise. On Friday, 2,517,340 shares were dealt in, largest since May 4, 1943, and exceeded only three times last year.

Thomas E. Dewey's managers in the Republican Presidential contest sent on to Chicago yesterday a message designed to end any lingering doubt there might have been in the minds of some delegates about Mr. Dewey's willingness to yield to a "draft."

LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- Premier Edwin Linkomies of Finland called on his people in a broadcast tonight to fight on to the end against Russia, even as the Red Army reached the old Mannerheim Line whose collapse in the 1939-40 winter war caused Finland's capitulation.

Just as General Eisenhower and General MacArthur have launched great striking forces of men and material for decisive blows against the enemy, the civilians on the home front should buy more war bonds so that our soldiers and sailors will continue to have enough of the best equipment to maintain steady progress toward victory.

A war bond purchased by a newly naturalized couple from Germany "to celebrate the happiest day of our lives," helped to bring sales at the war-bond booth outside the court room at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street, to a new daily high of $3,674 at the end of a court session last week, booth attendants reported yesterday.

Stimulated by developments in price control legislation, all active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange last week established new life-of-contract highs. At the close of trading on Saturday the active contracts on the Exchange showed net gains of 29 to 33 points, following advances of 23 to 30 points in the previous week.

Maj. and Mrs. Jesse Metcalf arrived from Washington at 10:45 P.M. Saturday at the Pennsylvania Station. Their luggage was put into a taxicab, which took them to the Hotel Ritz Tower, Fifty-seventh Street and Park Avenue. When Mrs. Metcalf reached her room she found she had left her handbag, containing a diamond bracelet valued at $40,000, $300 in cash, an unknown amount in victory bonds and eight ration books, in the taxi.

One wouldn't have thought that war would do American colleges much good. In some ways it hasn't, as the report of the Board of Higher Education, made public today, shows. Enrollments have dropped in a year from 20,984 to 17,799. War necessities have upset the curricula.
William Tilden, rated generally as the greatest tennis player of all times, is coming back to the East after an absence of several years to play for the Red Cross.

In connection with the War Bond tri-cornered game in which the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers will engage at the Polo Grounds next Monday night, the Fifth War Loan baseball committee announced yesterday that famous Yankee and Giant players of past years would be on hand.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Senate became embroiled in another heated debate on foreign policy late today. Senator Tom Connally of Texas pleaded for unity and against "sniping behind the lines," and Senators Henrik Shipstead of Minnesota and Burton K. Wheeler of Montana proposed a Senate investigation to determine whether Winston Churchill, before becoming Prime Minister, had obtained assurances of help in the war from President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The prosecution offered new charges today to support Government allegations that the twenty-nine defendants in the mass sedition trial were guilty of inciting disaffection and insubordination in the armed forces of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- War experience has demonstrated the necessity of organizing by States and by communities to bring together all those dealing with the problems of children for unified planning and action, according to Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau.

Congress is rushing toward a recess of a month or more so that its members may attend the Republican or Democratic national convention or take a summer vacation. The spectacle is familiar. In its haste to quit at the end of this week bills are being slapped together and passed with little debate of the improvised compromises.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 7 per cent last week over the like period a year ago, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the previous week the bank had reported a rise of 1 per cent.

Two Brooklyn men and a metal sales company were indicted yesterday by the Kings County Grand Jury on charges of grand larceny and conspiracy in allegedly misrepresenting the sale of 220 tons of black steel sheets and gauges to the First Pan-American Mercantile Corporation, which was acting in behalf of a client in Sao Paulo Brazil.

LONDON, June 19 -- The British Government lifted tonight the ban on diplomatic travel and restrictions on communications which were imposed two months ago to safeguard the secret of the invasion of Europe.

A heavy thunder and lightning storm that circled over the metropolitan area just before 11 A.M. yesterday caused the death of a man near Port Jefferson, L.I., injured two persons and for a few minutes almost turned day into night in the city.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Office buildings throughout the nation are enjoying the highest level of occupancy since the National Association of Building Owners and Managers began its surveys of the rental market twenty years ago, members of the association were informed here today at the opening of their thirty-seventh annual convention.
