YONKERS, N.Y., June 19 -- Mrs. Nancy de Nicholas, 30 years old, a former telephone company supervisor, was shot to death with a rifle early this morning in her apartment at Pine Drive and Central Avenue.

WITH MARINE EXPEDITIONARY FORCES, en route to the Mariana Islands (Delayed) -- The ports had been closed for the night, but in the officers' wardroom there was good lighting and all the seats were taken. Most of the men were engaged in games of chess, cribbage, bridge and pinochle, and some were reading books from the ship's library.

To promote the use of salvaged burlap and cotton bags for agricultural and food products, the National Burlap and Bag Dealers Association soon will begin an adverUsing campaign in trade papers, it was announced yesterday by S. C. Schwartz, president, at the annual meeting of the group at the Hotel Pennsylvania,

Plagued by a steady mounting paper currency circulation and rising prices, the Egyptian Government decided last November to try the experiment of selling gold ingots to hoarders to see if that would reduce the currency circulation and halt the price rise.
PORTLAND, Me., June 19 (AP) -- Rebuffed by his own party, Andrew A. Pettis, a labor-endorsed Republican, tonight won the Democratic nomination in Maine's First Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Male fliers, with more than 2,000 hours in the air, may soon be cleaning windshields and servicing planes for "glamorous women fliers who have only thirty-five hours of flying time," the House was told today by Representative Morrison, Democrat of Louisiana.
CHUNGKING, China, June 19 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- More than one-half of the increase of $8,000,000,000 in demand deposits of individuals in banks during the year was accounted for by owners of unincorporated businesses, a definition which would include most of the smallest "little business men" in the country, according to the analysis published by the Department of Commerce today in its June issue of the "Survey of Current Business."

The four municipal colleges are studying ways of helping returned service men and women who wish to continue college studies, Ordway Tead said in a report as chairman of the Board of Higher Education, which he submitted yesterday to Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A simplified procedure the manufacturers may use to determine ceiling prices for thirteen converted paper products and industrial papers was announced by the Office of Price Administration today. At the same time it provided for an upward adjustment in the maximum prices for gummed kraft sealing tape.

In two weeks the Allied armies in Italy have covered half the distance from Rome to Florence. It took them nine months to hack their way from Salerno to Rome. This gives the measure of the speed of the present advance. General Alexander's troops have destroyed one German army, the Fourteenth, as a fighting force; the Tenth enemy army, sagging dangerously in the middle, seems in imminent peril.

The twenty-eight-story office building at 401 Broadway, northwest corner of Walker Street, has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to a group of investors headed by Kurt Schlesinger and represented by Jesse H. Barkin, attorney.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Representative Gordon Canfield, Republican, of New Jersey, introduced a bill today to make former Presidents voteless members-at-large of the Senate for life.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Trial Production Board and the Office of Price Administration announced today arrangements for special supply of low-priced men's shirts and shorts and women's house dresses and slips, 813,344 dozen cotton garments, to be "produced and put into distribution during the months of July, August and September."
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 56:
WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN FRANCE, June 19 -- An unbelievable transformation has been wrought in this slender crescent of France in the thirteen days since the Allies fought their way ashore.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 19 (AP) -- In the first upset of a verdict in a capital case in Massachusetts for ninety years, Mrs. Beatrice Bouvier of Ware was released today from the custody of the court after a Jury acquitted her on a charge of manslaughter.
LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's address at the Mexican Embassy:

Expressing confidence that the Hartley amendment barring the highest price line limitation will stay in the new Emergency Price Control Act when the joint Senate and House conferees conclude their work on the bill, retailers here yesterday described the action announced by Price Administrator Bowles at the week-end as "another smoke screen."

LONDON, June 19 -- The British Government opened discussions with representatives of the French Committee of National Liberation today in an effort to bridge the gap resulting from the failure to come to political understanding with any French authority before the invasion.

The 3,048,000 pounds of beef that the War Food Administration offered to release last week from its stockpile to the civilian trade of New York City had found "no takers" up to the close of business last night, it was disclosed by the local WFA office at 150 Broadway.

HEADQUARTERS CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, June 17 (delayed) -- Threatened by Japanese encirclement, Gen. Sung Hsilien withdrew his troops from Lungling this morning after holding that important Burma Road city for seven days.

In a comic vein, "Love on Leave," opening tonight at the Hudson, weighs the problems of juvenile delinquency, which has suddenly developed into an absorbing topic on the Broadway stage these days. The A.B. Shiffrin comedy, once called "Spare the Rod," concerns two United States Navy sailors on a three-day leave in New York and several teen-age girls, two of whom are daughters of a writer who specializes in articles on the bringing-up of children.

ROME, June 19 (AP) -- Americans of the Fifth Army, driving up the Italian west coast, ran into some of the stiffest opposition since the capture of Rome as they thrust onto high ground north of Grosseto. The Germans threw reserves of artillery into an effort to check the advance.
CHUNGKING, China, June 19 (AP) -- A communique:

A Japanese Domei agency dispatch broadcast for use in the United States charged yesterday that the B-29 Superfortress attack on the Japanese mainland had been a "mere propaganda stunt," and complained because this country had scored a "scoop" on Domei in first reporting the story of the attack.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES IN FRANCE, June 19 -- United States troops, advancing with unexpected rapidity, got to a point eight miles from Cherbourg today. Artillery followed in close behind the infantry and this afternoon 155-mm, rifles -- 'Long Toms' -- began to shell that important port.

Declaring that Negroes and their votes in the coming election cannot be bought with money paid to party hacks or by pointing to political jobs given to a few individual Negroes, twenty-five representatives of Negro organizations issued here yesterday a program of Negro rights that they called upon the Democratic and Republican National Conventions to recognize.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The National War Labor Board has decided to refer the defiance of a board order by San Francisco Lodge 68 of the International Machinists Union, AFL, to President Roosevelt for action, it was reported today.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- While her 275-pound wrestler-husband lumbered along beside her and added moral support -- if not a bit of color -- with nods of his head, Mrs. Mildred Didrikson Zaharias sent her shots through a high wind today to win the medal in the women's Western open gold tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Ralph A. Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy since February of 1941, was nominated today by President Roosevelt for promotion to Under-Secretary of the Navy. Mr. Bard will succeed James V. Forrestal, who was raised to the Secretary-ship after the recent death of Frank Knox.

MOSCOW, June 19 -- A sharply worded article in War and the Working Class declared today that Japanese imperialists had "deliriously" cast an acquisitive eye on Russia's Far Eastern territory when they thought that their alliance with Germany would lead to victory instead of the defeat that is now inevitable.

Magistrate Abner C. Surpless declared in Jefferson Market Court yesterday that the "peace and health of the citizens of New York is of far greater importance than rushing through V-mail forms for the Armed Forces at all hours of the night and morning."
President, the First Boston Corporation; Member Advisory Committee, Commerce and Industry Division, War Finance Committee for New York.

In view of the persistent Nazi drive for a negotiated peace, the Vatican City telegram of Herbert L. Matthews, published in yesterday's TIMES, calls for a warning comment. Reporting the protest of the Hungarian Minister to the Vatican, Baron Gabriele Apor, against the Quisling Government of Budapest, the dispatch does not make clear the reasons why Baron Apor held his fire so long.

Mayor La Guardia's plan to encourage children to continue collecting waste paper throughout their summer holdays will be put into effect today when pupils representing 254 public and parochial schools will receive from him "citations for service on the home front."

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, June 20 (AP) -- After day and night sessions lasting more than fifteen hours. House and Senate conferees on the price control extension bill deadlocked early today on the Bankhead cotton textile amendment but agreed on other provisions of the measure continuing the Stabilization Act for one year Beyond June 30.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Representative John M. Coffee of Washington, Democrat, introduced in the House today a resolution to break off diplomatic relations with Spain.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 19 -- Finnish Legation circles here predicted tonight an armistics with Russia "within two or three days."

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- The Arkansas-Missouri Power Corporation, in order to cease being a holding company, submitted today to the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan whereby it would sell its holding of all common stock of the East Missouri Power Company to Central States Edison, Inc., for $600,000 in cash, subject to adjustments, and also for $30,000 in cash, an open account indebtedness of East Missouri of a like amount.

ROME, June 19 -- The tide of war rolled yesterday over Assisi, where St. Francis lived and died. The Germans apparently did not fight for it but are, instead, defending in front of the next and even more precious hill town, Perugia, where the British Eighth Army was halted a few miles short of the city limits.

With so much discussion about the use of plastics in airplanes and other mechanical devices, the homemaker is apt to think of plastics primarily as alternatives for metal or wood. Undoubtedly many of the plastic wonders promised for post-war living will be in that category.

Since the founding of this nation the veterans of each succeeding war were allowed to form their own veterans' organization. It is a tradition in our history for those wearing their country's uniform to start an organization to commemorate their participation in each separate conflict in which this nation has been involved.

LONDON, June 19 -- After a dull opening the stock markets here today developed a brighter tone, but business was much less active than of late. There was little selling, however, and later some of the leading industrials rallied.

NEWARK, N.J., June 19 -- Essex County Circuit Court Judge William A. Smith voided today "as contrary to public policy" a contract between the William Steinen Manufacturing Company of this city and Stone Stone, manufacturers' representatives of Washington.
ROME, June 19 -- Italy's unprecedented political crisis ended last night when the sanction of all the Allied powers was conveyed to Premier Ivanoe Bonomi.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 (AP) -- Chester Lake, whose job as field representative for Harry Slattery, Rural Electrification Administrator, will be abolished July 1, wrote President Roosevelt today that he will start a hunger strike protesting what he said was politics in the REA.
ST. JACQUES-DE-NEHOU, France, June 19 -- German prisoners, hanging to fenders and roofs of trucks and packed inside, streamed into the new prison stockade on a farm near this village today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft in a radio address tonight urged Republicans to back the candidacy of Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio for the party's Presidential nomination, asserting that various polls and newspaper stories had not portrayed his true strength.

There were quite a number of exuberant Giant fans in the Ebbets Field crowd of 27,226 that ignored the rain last night to see Mel Ott's men and the Dodgers tangle for the eleventh time this year, and they had reason to be happy, because the Giants flattened Lippy Leo Durocher's satin-suited athletes beneath a 10-2 score and moved within half a game of the second-place Pirates.

Protesting against "abnormal" rent increases in commercial and industrial buildings here, representatives of manufacturing and trade associations at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania last night, voted to ask Congress to extend to them OPA ceiling rent protection.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of the Office of War Mobilization, said today that removal of trade barriers and "prompt revision" of tax laws after the war were the two requisites for maintenance of agricultural prosperity.

CHUNGKING, China, June 19 (U.P.) -- Dispatches from Hunan Province said tonight that Japanese troops pushing southward from besieged Changsha had driven to within fifty miles of Hengyang, at the junction of the Hankow-Canton and Hunan-Kwangsi railroads.

The New York chapter, Military Order of the World War, held its annual dinner meeting in the Sert Room of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night, at which life membership was given to Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the New York guard; Maj. Gen. Irving J. Phillipson of the War Dependency Board; Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commanding the Second Service Command, and Capt. J. Harvey Tomb, USN.

Plans for the presentation this fall of ballets by some of the country's outstanding choreographers were announced yesterday by George de Cuevas, president of the Ballet Institute, recently established for the development of public appreciation in that field.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE TWENTY-FIRST ARMY GROUP, June 19 -- A senior staff officer today praised the work of the United States combat engineer battalions and of the British Army Royal Engineers who have performed numerous feats of gallantry -- often in ways not laid down during their training -- in paving the way for the infantry, armored vehicles and guns to advance into Normandy.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- There was a weak tone in wheat early today on the Board of Trade here, reflecting favorable crop developments, but prices recovered most of the declines as uncertainty about the price-control bill in Washington checked selling.

In China the Japanese invader continues to forge ahead. The key to the fighting on the Yellow River and south of the Yangtze is apparently an attempt to open a through rail route from Peiping to Canton and in so doing to cut off the whole of Eastern China from any aid from the West.
LONDON, June 19 -- The Allies' forces in Normandy have had a mixed reception from the French population but, as the days pass, the Norman peasants are gradually "warming up."

Immediate Congressional repeal or revision of the $5 Federal automobile "use tax" on the ground that it is unfair to auto owners who are limited to A gasoline rations, was urged yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York. The new stamps must be pasted on car windshields by July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Board of the National League of Women Voters, in which ten of twelve members are new as a result of the overturn of a long-established regime at an April convention in Chicago, today opened a week's sessions to "reconsider methods and publications in the light of experience."

On the day after D-day the British newspapers found enough space in their severely curtailed columns to discuss the subject of kitchens and clothes boilers. It is only fair to say at once that it was a theme of considerable national importance.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 19 -- An approach "as dynamic as our approach to the war" is essential to the peace, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared today in seting forth three "priorities for peace" at the annual meeting of Brown University's Associated Alumni. The meeting followed university commencement exercises at which Mr. Sulzberger and two others received honorary degrees.

Efforts of the special mission sent to Peru by the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., to negotiate with the Peruvian Government for resumption of service on Peruvian Government, provincial and municipal bonds aggregating $85,656,500 have been unsuccessful, it was announced last night by the council.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, June 20 (U.P.) -- Big fleets of United States Eighth Air Forces Flying Fortresses and Liberators pounded at least four Nazi airdromes near Bordeaux yesterday.

NEW PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- An important contribution to the war effort of the Allied Nations in the European theatre was disclosed today at a demonstration of a "power house" on wheels designed to restore electric power overnight to the territories retaken from the Axis nations.

LONDON, June 19 -- The plan of campaign adopted in the accord with Russia at Teheran is being steadily unrolled and may bring victory this summer, Prime Minister Churchill said Thursday in a speech to diplomats, the text of which was released today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Efforts to recover waste paper and to recruit farmers for off-season labor in the forests must be continued if the nation's paper production is to be held at its present level, Harold Boeschenstein of the War Production Board's forest products division said today to the Senate War Investigating Committee.

LONDON, June 19 -- The first official details of the robot planes with which German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels proposes to win the war were released tonight together with accounts of the measures taken to combat them, which indicate that the antidotes are proving steadily more successful.

Fifty new graduates of the Salvation Army's Officers Training School will join the "long column of 27,000 commanding officers serving in ninety-seven countries and colonies in places of sorrow, destitution and sin," Gen. Evangeline Booth, retired international leader of the Salvation Army, said last night in a commencement address at Carnegie Hall.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended with March a net income of $3,778,505, equivalent to $18.43 a share. In the preceding fiscal year the net income was $3,680,691, or $17.95 a share.

Rained out yesterday, the Yankees hope to begin their uphill climb at the Stadium today at the expense of the Senators. Joe McCarthy's pitching selection will rest between Johnny Johnson and Emerson (Steve) Roser, with the Washington club expected to counter with Johnny Niggeling, veteran butterfly ball hurler.

More than 200 Germans have been killed, over 100 wounded and nearly 400 taken prisoner in a series of battles between Polish underground troops and German Army units in the Wilno and Nowogrodek Provinces in eastern Poland, the Polish Telegraph Agency said yesterday in a London dispatch.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Unanimous consent was given in the House today to a bill increasing rates on special delivery mail and reducing the fees for insured mail, money orders and C.O.D. service. The new charges would take effect on the first day of the second month following enactment of the measure, which now goes to the Senate.

Roderick Stephens, Bronx business and civic leader, who as head of the Willkie forces in the Bronx was credited with increasing the Republican party vote there by 100,000 in 1940, was designated last night as a candidate for the Republican nomination for Congress in the Twenty-fifth Congressional District at a meeting of Republicans in the Hotel Concourse Plaza under the chairmanship of Brig. Gen. Bryce P. Disque.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP) -- Judge John Biggs Jr. of the Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals held today that two patent decisions by former Judge J. Warren Davis, involving millions of dollars, were "tainted with fraud." He set aside both decisions and ordered rehearings.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- A warning to the American people that "the German war machine has plans for survival" and that "when Germany decides upon surrender her choice will be for a negotiated peace in France, in Finland, in Italy -- anywhere except in Germany," was voiced here tonight by Secretary Morgenthau.
ROME, June 19 (AP) -- A communique:

MOSCOW, June 19 -- Eric Johnston, President of the United States Chamber of Commerce, announced to a press conference today that Anastas Mikoyan, Foreign Trade Commissar, had told him that the Soviet Union wished to purchase "many billions of dollars" worth of goods from the United States.
BOSTOIN, June 19 (AP) -- H.H. Polk's Dream Parade won the $2,000 Plum Island purse by three and a half lengths today at Suffolk Downs before a wash-day crowd of 10,526 patrons.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The War Production Board held out some hope to housewives today for the manufacture of aluminum kitchen utensils on a limited scale but warned against expecting increases in the supply of tin cans.

"Attack! The Battle for New Britain," a feature-length fact film dealing with the campaign on that Southwest Pacific bastion, will open this morning at the New York Theatre. The film also will open tomorrow at the Globe, Gotham and Manhattan Theatres.

A UNITED STATES AIR BASE IN YUNNAN, June 17 (Delayed) -- After an entire day of reconnaissance flights over Lungling, where the Chinese troops who are attacking the Japanese were running short of supplies, Major K.C. Burwell Jr. of Charlotte, N.C., was discouraged this afternoon.
The Heritage Club announces a membership ceiling of 30,000, which means that no new members may be accepted this year. The ceiling is the result of limited paper supplies.

Bonds totaling $70,000 for a case of Scotch whisky, $50,000 for a strand of cultured pearls and $30,000 for a red crocodile bag, helped swell the total of sales to $807,000 in the bond auction held by Bonwit Teller yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Plaza.

NEWARK, N.J., June 19 -- Eighteen hundred members of Local 843, Bottled Beer Drivers and Bottlers, American Federation of Labor, voted today to continue their strike at seven major breweries in this area, despite a directive from the National War Labor Board and the pleas of their own officers.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 19 -- The greatest air-sea battle since Midway was fought off the Marianas yesterday, when the American carrier task force supporting the ground attack on Saipan shot down more than 300 out of swarms of Japanese planes, a number of which apparently came from Japanese carriers.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 19 (U.P.) -- Four Red Army columns, pouring through a thirty-one-mile gap in the western side of the Mannerheim Line, converged on Viborg along a narrowing twenty-two-mile front yesterday, and one column advanced to a point ten miles south of the Finnish gateway city by capturing the town of Rokkala on the Gulf of Finland.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- By a vote of 326 to 21, the House today adopted its version of the War Contract Settlement bill. The measure, which sets up procedure for the termination of billions in war contracts, now goes to a joint conference committee.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The War Production Board reported today that it was studying with hotel men possible means of assuring hotel space to essential travelers.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. said today that no commitments binding on the United States could be made at the world monetary conference which would meet July 1 at Bretton Woods, N.H.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Tuesday, June 20 (AP) -- Americans fighting for the control of all Netherlands New Guinea have tightened their defenses of the vitally important Mokmer airstrip and have put into operation another field in the Schouten Islands only 880 miles from the Philippines, headquarters announced today.
ELBA, June 19 -- The white flag was hoisted this morning at Porto Longone to signify the German surrender of this island to French Colonial troops.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, June 20 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Warning that the next three months threaten to be the most critical from the standpoint of production, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told the Senate Truman Committee today that it will be "absolutely essential" for at least 200,000 workers to shift from present locations to areas of greater labor needs, largely in the midwest and on the West Coast.

Children's dress manufacturers were disturbed to learn yesterday morning that the directive which would provide cotton textiles for many thousands of low-end children's dresses and for which they had been waiting for more than four weeks had been canceled.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 19 (AP) -- Communique 27:

ABOARD THE JOHN E. WARD, Off England, June 19 -- Adolf Hitler's newest terrifying weapon, a jet-propelled bomb larger and faster than anything heretofore revealed, passed over this ship last night among twenty-seven similar but smaller pilotless planes that streaked through the skies toward the English coast.

Dr. Lois Coffey Mossman, 66 years old, retired Associate Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, was killed by a ground hog hunter's bullet at her Cherry Hill Farm at Gladstone, N.J., on Sunday, it was disclosed yesterday by the New Jersey State Police.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Office of Price Administration made ten revisions today in its rationing regulations for new 1942 automobiles, all designed to make it more difficult for a non-essential driver to buy one.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A cutback in production of airplane-type .50-caliber machine guns at each of the seven plants making them was confirmed by Army sources and other authorities today.

Announcement was made yesterday of the purchase by investment interests of three large apartment houses in Jersey City. One of the deals involved the four-story structure accommodating thirty-five families at 135-37 Bergen Avenue, opposite Audubon Park, sold by the Carteret Savings Loan Association to Molly Harris.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today a "remarkable" increase in the propertion of married men and women in the United States.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- A group of anti-fourth-term Democrats, meeting under the auspices of the American Democratic National Committee, today beat the Republicans to the "punch" in condemnation of the New Deal and demands that President Roosevelt and Vice President Wallace must not have another term in Washington.

The Indians did not catch Dwight E. Dean of Falls Village, Conn., and at 96 years of age he is president of the National Iron Bank of that place and one of the few persons who ever has outlived the insurance mortality table to become his own beneficiary.

Because more leather has become available for civilian use the shoe repair industry expects to continue to receive 350,000 bends of sole leather, although the percentage set aside for that part of the industry recently was reduced by a War Production Board directive.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The two-party system is so ingrained in the structure of American politics, and considerations of local office-seeking influence its maintenance so strongly, that attempts to coalesce the campaign efforts of one party with a disaffected faction of the other encounter even more obstacles than efforts to set up a third.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 19 -- Warner Brothers will co-star Dennis Morgan and Jane Wyman in "Honeymoon Freight," a romantic comedy to be based on a recently bought short story by Donald Keyhoe. The same company announces that Ann Sheridan's first picture on her return from an overseas camp tour will be "A Night at Toni Pastor's," which has been on the studio schedule under various titles for more than a year.

JOSEPH SEVERN'S chief claim to fame is that he chose to accompany the dying John Keats from England to Rome, where he sat at the bedside while the poet coughed out his life. An able painter of miniatures. Severn spent most of his life trying to be an artist in the grand style. History has been cruel to his pretensions to genius, or even to the idea that he had great talent.

MOSCOW, June 19 -- An influential Soviet journal today criticized post-war proposals for freedom of the air. In an article in War and the Working Class Prof. A. Voskresensky said that such a principle had "real possibilities of harming the security of separate countries" and could not be compared with the age-old freedom of the seas because it was broader.

The "taxpayer" building at 43504354 White Plains Avenue, southeast corner of 237th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York to an investing client of Henry Pleus, attorney. The property, consisting of seven stores on a plot 100 by 73.9 feet, is assessed at $37,000.

Frank Costello, gambler and slot machine king, started legal action yesterday to recover from the city $27,200 which he left in a taxicab last Wednesday by serving a summons and complaint in a replevin action on Col. Maurice Simmons, property clerk of the Police Department, in whose custody the money had been since it was found by Edward Waters of 361 West Fifty-first Street, driver of the cab.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 (AP) --Rigid Government price control should be repealed early in the post-war period "because many products will need higher prices, at least temporarily," Frank D. Newbury, vice president of Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, declared today.

Further new highs in prices of stocks for the last four years were attained yesterday as fresh demand appeared, apparently spurred by continued Allied gains in Europe and in the Pacific and Prime Minister Churchill's statement that victory over the Nazis may come this year.

New York race-goers, 15,608 of them who probably figured that Aqueduct's roof afforded as good a shelter as could be found anywhere, got more than their money's worth at the Queens track yesterday, for they saw, among other things, a 3-to-10 shot beaten by a head, a man on foot catch a horse on all fours, starting gates fail to function, and Jockey Ted Atkinson continue Iris winning streak.
ROME, June 19 -- Gen. George C. Marshall came to another scene of triumph yesterday, straight from the Norman beachhead.

War bond sales to individuals in the Fifth War Loan drive totaled $854,000,000 at the close of the first week of the campaign, which began June 12 and is scheduled to continue through July 8, it was announced yesterday by the Treasury Department in Washington.

An army of working girls, housewives, college and high school girls and boys under 18, with "Keep 'Em Eating" as its slogan, is swarming out of New York in almost daily contingents to help harvest crops and do farm chores.

In your issue of June 16 Prof. Roger Picard contests my conclusion that the Committee of National Liberation represents not only de facto the Government of the French Empire but also de jure the legitimate Government of the French Republic.
WITH AMERICAN TROOPS, Advancing Toward Cherbourg, June 19 -- American troops captured today at least 1,000 German prisoners, whose units had been disorganized by the American break-through.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, June 20 -- The American assault on Cherbourg has started with remarkable speed and success.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A YEAR ago Mel Ott hit a total of eighteen home runs, and by an odd coincidence all of them were smitten at the Polo Grounds. With the present campaign approximately one-third over the perennial Boy Wonder of the Giants has punched out eighteen round trippers, which is a rather astonishing clip for a youth whose best days, sad to relate, are all behind him.

Introducing an admittedly "new legal wrinkle," attorneys for Doris Duke Cromwell, the tobacco heiress, filed yesterday a notice of motion in Reno to amend the divorce decree she obtained Dec. 21, 1943, from James H.R. Cromwell, son of Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, economist, and former United States Minister to Canada.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The American people are well informed of the meaning of their war, of its causes, the issues at stake, and the problems of the peace they toil and fight and die to secure. To this high degree of understanding many agencies have contributed, and one of the foremost of these is the Council of Books in Wartime.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 19 -- Canadian casualties in the Normandy invasion have been "moderate" and "below the figure that had been estimated," Col. J.L. Ralston, Defense Minister, told the House of Commons this afternoon. He refused, however, to disclose the total figure, giving as his reason that any announcement of totals was precluded by agreement until field commanders were sure that it would not prejudice the military situation.

The volume of trading diminished somewhat yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange as traders marked time pending final action on the price-control bill, and as a result prices on active months finished 1 point lower to 4 points higher than on Saturday.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Members of the Supermarket Institute, opening their eighth annual conference here today, were told that price control probably would last longer on consumer durable goods than on foods; that there was no early prospect of a lifting of sugar rationing, and that the post-war period would see keen price competition to win back patronage lost under rationing conditions.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 19 (UP) -- A communique:
LONDON, June 19 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

TORONTO, June 19 (Canadian Press) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and the Newark Bears broke even in their two games tonight, the Bears taking the first, 11 -- 10, and the Leafs winning the second, 5 -- 1.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- J. Russel Sprague, national committeeman from New York, announced at a press conference today that he, Edwin F. Jaeckle, State chairman, and Herbert Brownell Jr., chairman of the law committee of the Republican State Committee, representing the Republican voters and the Republican organization of New York State, had come to Chicago to get the Republican National Convention to draft Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for the nomination for President.

The ancient Norman town of Bayeux became the first town of a European subjugated nation to be liberated by the Allied arms. In the old museum of Bayeux there is a unique relic which provides a fine footnote to this historic event.

Hunter College will hold its eighty-fifth commencement exercises tonight in the college's Assembly Hall at 8 o'clock. Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, will preside and confer degrees upon the 800 candidates presented to him by Dr. Eleanor H. Grady, Dean of Faculty.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 21 -- Soviet tanks and infantry, completing a swift sixty-mile drive up the Karelian Isthmus, yesterday captured the ancient fortress city of Viborg, breaking the "bottleneck" of the coastal route leading 135 miles westward to Helsinki.

Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, had in mind a very definite purpose when he turned a deaf ear to the French Committee of National Liberation's request for recognition as the "Provisional Government of the French Republic."

Corporation executives have leaned over backward in most cases to allow small shareholders the right to be heard at annual meetings. Many of the latter have taken unfair advantage of the leeway granted them, rising to speak on one subject and then launching into tirades on company policy as a whole.

LONDON, June 20 -- Merchant ships flying the Stars and Stripes and manned by American seamen have delivered intact shipload after shipload of British "tommies" with all their equipment to British beachheads on the Normandy coast, it was disclosed today.
A communique, as broadcast from Tokyo yesterday and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Yesterday communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared tonight that an assertion by Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production, today that the United States had provoked Japan to attack Pearl Harbor was "entirely in error as to the facts and fails to state the true attitude of the United States."

A foursome known as the Hippocrates, composed of Columbia medical students, representing Manhattan, won last night the service men's branch of the Tenth Annual American Ballad Contest for Barber Shop Quartets, held in the Central Park Mall before an audience of 4,000.

Mr. Winthrop Parkhurst's letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES asserting that recent on-the-spot reports from Normandy show that sentiment there for de Gaulle is not vigorous appeared on the same day your paper described the reception de Gaulle received in Normandy.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 20 (AP) -- Two teams defending titles won last year were beaten and a third defending champion retained its crown in the National A.A.U. championship relay races which featured the fourth annual track meet of Pope Pius High School in the Passaic High School Stadium tonight.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Several upsets marked today's first round of championship match play in the women's Western open golf tournament, but the two favorites -- Miss Dorothy Germain of Philadelphia and Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias of Beverly Hills, Calif. -- cruised in with easy victories, heading for their expected showdown for the title at thirty-six holes on Saturday.
LONDON, June 20 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
CAIRO, Egypt, June 20 -- Bulgarian and Turkish troops have been concentrating to some degree on either side of the Thracian border in the last few weeks, according to reports received here.
Mel Ott decided yesterday to give Johnny Allen his first outing of the 1944 campaign and, in practically no time at all, the Giant skipper discovered he had made a mistake.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed unanimously yesterday a ruling of Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell holding certain obligations of Associated Gas and Electric Company subordinate to other obligations that are sufficient to exhaust the company's assets.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Gov. Ellis Arnall of Georgia filed today in the Supreme Court a complaint against twenty railroads, asking $60,750,000 damages for his State and its shippers and seeking to force equalization of freight rates between the South and other parts of the country.
The City Council adopted a basic tax rate of $2.74 for 1944-45 in five minutes yesterday after spending a clamorous three hours in wrangling over renewal of the sales tax.

ON THE KARELIAN ISTHMUS, June 20 -- Very strong formations of the Red Air Force were thrown into the battle in yesterday's opera tions for the overthrow of the Mannerheim Line. Hundreds of bombers and Stormoviks, escorted by latest-type fighters, flew from bases in the Leningrad region to attack fortress positions on which the remnants of five severely punished Finnish divisions had been falling back since they were driven from their strong second defense zone.

DETROIT, June 20 (AP) -- Ray Mack, who flew from his Cleveland war job to participate in a twilight game, drove in the winning run in the ninth inning tonight as the Indians defeated the Tigers, 3 to 1, in the opener of a three-game series.

A contribution of $100,000 for the general benefit and cultural advancement of the legitimate theatre has been made by John Golden, veteran Broadway producer, it was announced yesterday by Richard Rodgers, chairman of the recently formed Foundation Advisory Committee of the Theatre.

ALGIERS, June 20 -- The French Committee of National Liberation expects to move to France as soon as a town large enough to accommodate it is available. It also expects to be accepted by both the French and the Allies as the de facto Provisional Government.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 20 -- If President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey were the candidates in a Presidential election today, a majority of voters in Indiana would pick Mr. Dewey.

ROME, June 20 -- A Leftist military organization called "Armata Rossa" -- Red Army -- which claims 58,000 recruits has asked the Allied Command's permission to join in the fight against the Germans in Italy.

How dark, exactly, was the night that descended on this country in November, 1920, when Warren Harding was elected? Specifically, what did happen to organized labor in the Harding era? Were the labor organizations suppressed by violence or law or both?

LONDON, June 20 (U.P.) -- Striking sixty miles from Paris, French patriots have paralyzed the emergency flow of German reinforcements to the Normandy front by attacks on rail and water communications, it was announced today.

Even in wartime some city dwellers will be able to spend the summer or part of it in the country, and many of these people have dogs and cats. It is important to take our pets with us, or else provide for them humanely, not leave them behind to starve. Humane societies gather up what strays they can, but their manpower is depleted and they need the cooperation of individual owners.

The first thirteen carloads of 3,048,000 pounds of commercial grade beef released to the civilian trade from its stocks by the War Food Administration still had no takers last night. Local WFA attaches at 150 Broadway explained that wholesale meat dealers and other prospective customers who went to inspect the beef were out so early in the morning that the beef was not ready for inspection.
The cotton futures market yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange had a steady close, 3 to 8 points higher on active months, following an early decline.

CHUNGKING, China, Wednesday, June 21 (AP) -- Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province and for five years a symbol of successful Chinese resistance, has fallen to the Japanese, the Chinese High Command announced today.

The Stadium concert season of 1944 opened last night with Sir Thomas Beecham conducting the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the first time at these concerts and with Fritz Kreisler also making his first appearance on that stage in the performance of his highly individual version of Tchaikovsky's violin concerto.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 21 (AP) -- British morning newspapers expressed dismay today at the reaction in the United States to a statement attributed to Minister Lyttelton that American lend-lease to this country was Japan's "provocation" to attack Pearl Harbor.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 20 (AP) -- Battered by German fighters and anti-aircraft fire over the Baltic, twenty-one American heavy bombers crashed or made forced landings in Sweden today in the greatest such influx to this neutral country in a single day.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- In a whirl of activity, the House today considered, debated and acted on three conference reports on as many major appropriation bills, involving the expenditure of nearly three quarters of a billion dollars.

All ships that have played their part in the invasion have done their work so well that it may seem unjust to single out any one for particular praise. We do so only because of the compensation, retribution or poetic justice illustrated. On the morning of Dec. 7, 1941, the battleship Nevada was smoking from the fires lighted in her by the Japanese, declaring war in their well-known manner.

Maj. Kathleen Atto, director of the New York City Nurse Corps, Second Service Command, called on "each citizen" to be an "individual nurse procurement committee" at a luncheon given yesterday by the New York City Nursing Council for War Service at headquarters of the Visiting Nurses Service, 262 Madison Avenue.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 20 (AP) -- Communique 29:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, June 21 (U.P.) -- The first high-ranking casualty of the invasion was announced today by Supreme Allied Headquarters, which said that Brig. Gen. Don F. Pratt, 51 years of age, of Brookfield, Mo., was killed on D-day when his glider crashed in France.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company sold yesterday to a score of municipal bond dealers twenty-one blocks of municipal bonds aggregating $10,309,000. The bonds had been held in the investment portfolio of the Metropolitan Life.

People around Times Square these days, unless they are more than slightly deaf, cannot fail to learn that the United States Government is offering its constituents a good bargain in Fifth War Loan bonds. Much the same sort of thing is going on in urban centers all over the country.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- In a move hailed by some as a temporary solution of the whisky drought and a curb on black market dealings, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, opened the way today to the production of upward of 50,000,000 gallons of beverage alcohol by relieving distillers of the need to make industrial alcohol during August.

At least a small share of the vast amounts collected in taxes by local, State and Federal agencies from the liquor business should be appropriated for the study and prevention of alcoholic addiction, Professor Anton J. Carlson, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, declared last night.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan made public yesterday a forty-one-page report on the workings of his office in 1943. He commented that, despite his revelations last fall on the manner in which Frank Costello, racketeer, promoted the Tammany nomination of Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio to the Supreme Court bench, nothing had been done officially to prevent a recurrence.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Senate, after a third day for explosive debate over the Fair Employment Practice Committee, which President Roosevelt established by executive order, passed the $1,030,000,000 War Agencies Appropriation Bill this evening, allowing $500,000 for continuing that agency but setting up restrictions which FEPC spokesmen said might materially limit its functions and authority.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Shortages of many chemicals used widely in civilian production have grown markedly more critical under the pressure of military requirements, the War Production Board disclosed today on the basis of its Chemical Bureau's report for June.

The Office of Price Administration is preparing to set specific export premiums on processed foods, pine lumber, flour and paper and revised premiums on textiles, Charles J. Walsh, price executive of the agency's export-import price branch, disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill partially unveiled one of the war's greatest secrets today when he told the House of Commons that a German attempt to invade Britain in 1940 was smashed in continental ports before a "very heavy concentration of troops and ships" could put to sea.

Secretary Morgenthau assures the country that no binding commitments will be made at the world monetary conference which meets on July 1. Whatever agreements are made for stabilizing currencies and establishing a world bank, he declares, will be subject to Congressional approval as far as this country is concerned.

SOME folks collect stamps for a hobby. Others prefer coins and still others gather all sorts of odds and ends. But the strangest hobby of them all is that of Dr. L.H. Baker, a medical specialist of New York and New Haven, who collects information on football. He has assembled what undoubtedly is the most complete set of data on gridiron doings in the world.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The question of newspaper ownership of radio stations was dismissed but was not decided by the Federal Communications Commission when it voted in January to adopt no general rule on the subject, James Lawrence Fly, FCC chairman, said today before the special House Committee investigating his agency.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 14: Increases of $232,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $244,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $130,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $350,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $114,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and $304,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.
CHUNGKING, China, June 20 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The fall of Cherbourg, expected soon, will be but a brief stopping point for our combat troops, who will move on to capture more vital ports and strategic centers in France, military observers here predicted today.
CHUNGKING, China, June 20 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Teachers must become active in community life if they are to be an effective group in developing educational programs for children, Prof. Ernest G. Osborne of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday in urging them to take renewed interest in civic organizations and local politics and pressures.

A long line of service men waited in Forty-fourth Street west of Broadway yesterday for the reopening of a streamlined Stage Door Canteen. Long before the little red door admitted the first man at 5 P.M. the single file stretched almost to Broadway.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Hiland G. Batcheller, president of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, told the Steel Panel of the National War Labor Board today that the board should abolish its custom of ordering maintenance of membership and the check-off in the steel industry because it did not further prosecution of the war.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20 -- Forty scholars in the field of international relations, who have been collaborating on a study of the problems of the Pacific area, made public here today eight recommendations for the post-war treatment of Japan.

PEARL HARBOR, June 20 -- Powerful Japanese naval units -- perhaps the entire fleet -- are somewhere in the sea area between the Marianas Islands and the Philippines. They were sighted yesterday by American forces and the possibility of a major naval engagement is indicated, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, June 21 (U.P.) -- The occupation of the two airdromes near the captured Mokmer airfield virtually completed the twenty-five-day-old invasion of Biak Island, which gives American forces three air strips within 800 miles of the southern tip of the Philippines.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 20 (AP) -- British Imperial troops in a swift seventeen-mile advance have driven the Japanese from Mao Songsang on the Kohima-Imphal road of eastern India in the greatest thrust since the start of the Allied counter-offensive, a communique announced today.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY NURSE CORPS, in Italy, May 31 (Delayed) -- This is the moment for which we have all been waiting these past twenty-four hours. We have arrived at our new location, five hours by truck convoy over the road to Rome.

The outdoor reading room that has been operated in Bryant Park for the last eight summers by the New York Public Library will not be opened this year because of a staff shortage at the library, Esther Johnston, acting chief of the library's circulation department, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The war economy has about reached the point at which aggregate production indices are static or downward, the Department of Commerce reported today.

A GREAT many bored young men with tommy guns and itching fingers could do irreparable damage to the wild life of a small Pacific island. If there were no Japanese to shoot, what would be more likely than that animals would be shot instead until entire species were exterminated? A group of scientists meeting together informally in New York City more than a year ago contemplated this prospect with alarm.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Although Roy D. Moore, campaign manager for Governor Bricker of Ohio, characterized the claims of Governor Dewey's delegate strength today as "fantastic" and declared that it was far short of a majority, supporters of the New York Governor continued to have complete confidence in his nomination for President by the Republican convention.
ROME, June 20 -- The British Eighth Army was cleaning up Perugia today after having entered the city yesterday.
With invasion under way, we come closer than ever to the realities involved in financing this war. That is why the Fifth War Loan is so significant.

ALBANY, June 20 -- Supreme Court Justice William H. Murray held today that John (Sonny) Jones, Negro of this city, was entitled to know the identity of State troopers and other persons who were on the twenty-ninth floor of the State Office Building, Feb. 25, the day on which he says he was beaten and suspended, head-down, from a window.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes' proposed Arabian pipeline had definitely been abandoned as a Government project, in favor of private construction, it was learned in official circles today.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 21 (AP) -- In the greatest heavy bomber assault in history, the United States Army Air Forces hurled more than 2,000 Flying Fortresses and Liberators against Hitler's Europe yesterday to smash once at twelve German oil and aircraft plants and twice at the rocket-bomber coast of France, which also was attacked throughout the day by other Allied planes.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Miss Marion E. Martin, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee and director of the women's division, cited today the history-making record of women membership on the important resolutions committee as significant of the part which they will play in the national convention.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 21 (AP) -- The German Transocean News Agency, in a Berlin broadcast, quoted a Japanese naval spokesman today as saying that Japanese air and naval forces "have successfully engaged an American fleet" in the waters off the Marianas Islands.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace has taken with him to the Far East nearly a hundred packages containing scientific instruments, books, educational films and agricultural seed as gifts to China, the State Department announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -- John E. Dwyer, Chicago, trustee for Inland Power and Light Corporation, today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission's approval of the sale of 2,400 shares of Missouri Edison Company's common stock to Central States Edison, Inc., Newark, N.J., for a base price of $290,481.

Unable to continue with the job of assembling, editing and staging the sketches for Billy Rose's elaborate revue, "The Seven Lively Arts," George S. Kaufman has resigned from that triple assignment. Mr. Kaufman said yesterday his withdrawal was brought about by the postponement of rehearsals from August until six weeks later.

As New York City, as a result of one of the best bond-buying days of the campaign, passed the $100,000,000 mark yesterday in purchases by individual investors in the Fifth War Loan drive, Governor Dewey gave the drive here and throughout the State added impetus by announcing plans for the investment of $100,000,000 of the State's surplus in the loan.

The regional War Labor Board moved yesterday to end the two-week old strike in North Jersey breweries as the beer shortage in Jersey City, Newark and other near-by communities threatened to assume acute form. Many hotels, restaurants, bars and taverns were importing their beer from cities as far as Philadelphia in an effort to meet their normal demand.

MOSCOW, June 20 -- The Soviet Navy periodical Red Fleet published to day a long commentary on the United States Presidential campaign in which it was said that while the decisive state of the campaign lay ahead, "wide circles of the American public already have with sufficient clarity stated that their attitude is in favor of President Roosevelt."

The report of the National Radiator Company for the fiscal year ended with March disclosed yesterday a net profit of $333,969 after setting aside $250,000 for postwar rehabilitation and other contingencies and $400,000 for Federal and State taxes on income.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 20 (UP) -- A communique:

ROME, June 20 (AP) -- Amid the marble magnificence of the unfinished Mussolini Stadium which the Fascists built for 1944's now forgotten Olympic Games and where the Germans were billeted a scant fortnight ago Allied fighting men competed today in the Fifth Army track and field meet.

Somewhere in the grim reaches of last evening's second act, one of the folks remarked, "I came to this metropolis because this is where the theatre is." That may have been true of the old days, but if many more things like "Love on Leave" find their way to Broadway, the theatre will be like Annie, not living here any more.

NINTH AIR FORCE ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, Normandy, June 20 -- American air power over this battle peninsula has reached such an advanced stage that liaison officers are complaining they have more planes available than work laid out for them.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A threatened deadlock over renewal of wage, price and rent controls was averted today when Senate and House conferees accepted an Administration-sponsored substitute for the Bankhead "cotton amendments" in the Senate bill.

MONTREAL, June 20 (AP) -- Jersey City and Montreal split a double-header tonight, the Giants taking a 1-0 verdict in the twilight opener, while the Royals were extended to 10 innings for a 2-1 victory in the nightcap.

The Board of Estimate at a special meeting yesterday morning authorized the immediate condemnation of 1,350 acres to be added to the 3,150-acre site of the Idlewild Airport on Jamaica Bay, Queens, and voted $5,054,000 for costs of acquisition and development work. Already the largest airfield site in the world, Idlewild, the city's major post-war project, by the new addition will become seven and a half times bigger than La Guardia Airport.

Since fresh mushrooms are expensive and none too plentiful at present, the ration-free canned varieties that are available should prove popular substitutes. A kind that is hardly distinguishable from the fresh ones in flavor and texture is King brand.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- A group of anti-fourth-term Democrats, meeting under the designation of the American National Democratic Committee, wound up a two-day session today with a demand for an end to the New Deal, but with obvious uncertainty as to how best to attain it.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Elimination of the Pace amendment from the Price-Control bill, reported from Washington, had a bearish effect today on prices of wheat on the Board of Trade here and the market was weak. Favorable crop reports and the increasing movement of wheat in the Southwest induced free selling in the absence of political developments to bolster prices. Closing quotations showed net losses of 1 3/4 cents to 2 1/8 cents a bushel.

CHUNGKING, China, June 20 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace, arriving here today to confer with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek,, predicted that the common boundary between Russia and China would in the future be like the border between the United States and Canada.

Any city fireman who can show how the city can properly be protected without resort to extra tours of duty in the present manpower shortage will be entitled to the Fire Department's Administration Medal, awarded only occasionally for outstanding administration work, Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- The Buffalo, Niagara Eastern Power Corporation was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to undertake a partial re-capitalization by substituting a single class of common stock for the $1.60 preferred, Class A and common stocks outstanding.

The Allied armies have now liberated a large part of Italy and a small segment of France. The Norman beachhead is no more typical of all of France than Sicily or Calabria is typical of Italy. But it is strange to hear of the population of Normandy the word repeated so often in the description of the Italian population.

When the Allies failed immediately to recognize the new Bonomi Cabinet in Italy, following its establishment a week or so ago, a familiar chorus of criticism arose on the part of those in this country who are always ready to suspect the worst of the diplomacy of the American and British Governments.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- A Senate-House committee agreed tonight on a compromise version of a bill setting up machinery to implement the termination of war contracts amounting to billions.

The odd sight of form players making one trip after another to the pay-off windows presented itself yesterday at Aqueduct when seven out of eight favorites came home first, one of them in the feature of an ordinary program, the Amagansett Hurdle Handicap.
LONDON, June 20 -- The stock markets here opened today cheerfully and the turnover showed some expansion. Investment buying strengthened gilt-edge issues and industrials showed a firmer trend.
The text of an Allied spokesman's warning yesterday to German troops trapped on the Cherbourg peninsula, as reported to the United States Office of War Information, follows:
LONDON, June 20 -- A slow, bitter and difficult campaign in western Europe is presaged by the last two weeks of fighting in the Bocage country of Normandy.
LONDON, June 20 -- A prominent Polish democrat, who, it is reported, is still in Poland, has been chosen to replace Gen. Kazimierz Sosnkowski as successor-designate to the Polish Presidency.

Over-all possibilities for industry and trade are now much brighter since the recent decision by the War Production Board to authorize vital reconversion preparations and the clarification by the Office of Price Administration of its flexible policy on future controls, C.F. Hughes, business news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, last night told the conference of Apparel credit men in the assembly room of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- The Republican resolutions committee will hold an informal session tomorrow to begin the draft of the platform which, many of its members hope, will remove war and post-war foreign policies as controversial issues from the national campaign.

STOCKHOLM, June 19 (Delayed) -- "American Flying Fortress Makes Forced Landing in Skaane" has become a familiar headline in Swedish newspapers. The Bulltofta airfield in this southern Swedish province has increasingly taken on the character of an American field and the Swedish air fleet has received some very valuable additions.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration is already assuming some of the great responsibilities it must undertake in caring for war-stricken millions of Europe, former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Director General, said tonight.

Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch reserved decision yesterday after a stormy three-hour hearing on an application for a writ of habeas corpus brought by the Society for the Prevention of Crime to test the legality of detaining juvenile delinquents in the City Prison pending their transfer to the New York State Training School for Boys at Warwick.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 20 (AP) -- The first women's Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship opened today with an upset when Miss Marilyn Barnett, unseeded player from Hood College, Frederick, Md., defeated Miss Judy Atterbury of Wellesley, seeded No. 4, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2.

Harpers is announcing the publication of "Approaches to World Peace," the fourth symposium of the Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion. It includes! fifty-nine approaches to peace by leadlnl men in the field of anthropology, psychiatry, sociology, history, arts and letters, government, philosophy and theology.

On the basis of reservations now on hand, railroad and bus officials predicted yesterday that summer vacation travel would set new records this year, despite Government appeals to avoid unnecessary travel and the inconveniences caused by wartime demands on carriers.

A pair of anglers from Brooklyn, Vincent Traina and George Siegel, are leading the parade of entries in the George Ruppert contest for fish taken off Long Island, while another New Yorker, Ludwig Geide of the Bronx, is first with a specimen taken in Florida.

A million dollar per year cooperative promotional campaign for the shoe repair and findings industry, to begin early in 1945, is practically assured, officials of the National Leather and Shoe Finders Association, in convention at the Hotel New Yorker, stated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, deputy chief of staff, will not predict when the war will end. And, although this country will have an overseas fighting force of 5,000,000 men by the end of the year, "the movement will likely continue at a high rate during 1945," he says.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The United States submarine Grayback, under command of Comdr. John Anderson Moore, one of the heroes of our submarine warfare against the enemy in Pacific waters, is overdue from patrol and must be presumed lost, the Navy announced in a communique today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- "Aghast" is the only word to describe the effects on two Washington groups of the remarks that were reportorially attributed today to Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production, at a London luncheon, and later officially amended by the Minister.
LONDON, June 20 -- Hitler's flying bombs got hit today in the air and on the ground. Allied air power threw the book at them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 20 -- Paramount has acquired the screen rights to Clarence Morrow Wilson's "Ambassadors in White," a factual account of disease-control work by American doctors in Central America. The book will be used as a basis for a picture to star Brian Donlevy.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Federal Government is now teaching women to wash windows. Although women have been washing windows for several centuries, it has now become known that in the hundreds of years they have been performing this mundane household task they have lacked the correct technique of removing excess real estate from a pane in the window.

Your editorial concerning the planned vacations of our well-paid Congressmen is very much to the point. A more shameful group of men would be difficult to find anywhere in this nation. The ghastly fact of the bloody beaches of Normandy, Anzio, the southwest Pacific and Africa must seem not to have affected them any more than the black-market patrons.

Those slot machines Frank Costello allegedly operated in New Orleans in the late Twenties paid off in reverse yesterday, when the Federal Government stepped in and filed copies of tax liens as an attachment against the $27,200 he was so careless as to leave lying in a taxicab.

LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- Nazi propagandists told the German people today that watchful waiting for new Allied landings from Britain and North Africa was the guiding principle of the High Command in combating the Normandy invasion.

"Home in Indiana," a Technicolor drama about trotting horses, produced by Twentieth Century-Fox from George Agnew Chamberlain's story, "The Phantom Filly," will have its local premiere this morning at the Roxy. Walter Brennan, Jeanne Crain, Lon McCallister, Charlotte Greenwood, Ward Bond and June Haver are among the featured players.

Fall lines of costume jewelry opened in the last few days have attracted heavy buyer attendance, with new records set in some instances, manufacturers here reported yesterday. Style and color trends in women's and misses' apparel for the coming season presage further gains in the use of costume accessories, limited only by the inability of producers to turn out wanted items, it was said.

Unusual embroideries, silver and weaving are featured in the exhibition of Bolivian and Chilean native arts and crafts that opened yesterday afternoon at the American Museum of Natural History. The collection was brought to the United States by Senorita Mabel MacCrimmon, a native Chilean, to show the finest of the native work produced both in the past and today in the Bolivian Highlands and in southern Chile.

It has often been said that Hitler's biggest mistake in the war was in not trying to invade England after the fall of France. Now Winston Churchill erases that error at least from the Fuehrer's record of bad guesses. He did try and failed.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, June 21 (UP) -- A communique:

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 20 -- Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City will appear personally to defend the $2,000,000 libel suit brought against him in the Monmouth court by his Hudson County foe, John Warren, it was learned today.

Arrangements have been quietly made for a testimonial dinner for James A. Farley, retiring chairman of the Democratic State Committee, it was disclosed yesterday. The move is being backed by both friends and political supporters of Mr. Farley and by the New Deal wing of the party in the State. Mr. Farley's resignation as State Chairman, after fourteen years of service, becomes effective July 11. The dinner will be at the Waldorf-Astoria on July 10.

A posthumous award of the Navy and Marine Corp Medal for the heroic part he had played in the rescue of survivors from a torpedoed transport in the Atlantic last year, was presented yesterday to the family of Coast Guardsman Charles W. David Jr., 26-year-old Negro mess attendant, at Coast Guard headquarters, 42 Broadway.

The three-cornered baseball game, in which the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers will participate Monday night at the Polo Grounds, one of the main sports features in the Fifth War Loan drive, will start at 8:45 P.M., it was announced yesterday. However, the actual show is scheduled to begin promptly at 6 o'clock.

A one-man filibuster by an owner of ten shares of stock made an all-day affair yesterday of the annual meeting of Paramount Pictures, Inc., but that gathering approved the incentive compensation plan for Barney Balaban, president, and transacted the other business on its calendar.

An old Maroon from Old Rose Hill dropped into the Stadium, where the Yankees were tackling the Senators yesterday, watched Hank Borowy set down the opposition, 3 -- 1, with what seemed to be a minimum of effort, and promptly remarked: "Borowy has regained his Fordham form."

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -- The Athletics slowed down the pennant spurt of the Red Sox tonight by defeating Joe Cronin's men in both ends of a twilight-night double-header at Shibe Park before 18,500 fans. Philadelphia won the first game, 5 -- 4, in eleven innings, and then took the second, 2 -- 0.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday were 1,917, compared with 2,086 in the preceding week and 1,172 in the similar period of 1943, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 788, against 1,047 last Tuesday.

Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U., at a meeting of the Track Writers Association at the New York Athletic Club yesterday, disclosed that he will recommend to the national convention next winter that the 100-meter race at Randalls Island last Sunday be regarded only as an exhibition.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 (AP) -- The league-leading Browns stretched their narrow first-place margin to a game and a half tonight by splitting a twilight-night doubleheader with the White Sox. Chicago won the opener, 4 to 3, in 10 innings and the Browns won the second contest, 5 to 0.

Three naval officers and myself took a hike in the mountains this morning and followed a narrow trail for miles. We saw many things left behind by the Japanese. While going through a Japanese foxhole I found an issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 27, 1944. So I tore the heading off and decided to mail it back to you.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A defense motion for a directed acquittal for the 29 defendants in the mass sedition trial was overruled today by Justice Edward C. Eicher.

ALBANY, June 20 -- Capitol legal experts are trying to decide who will be Acting Governor of New York State on Wednesday and Thursday of next week if Governor Dewey goes to Chicago to accept a Republican nomination for President.

WITH BRITISH FORCES in France before Caen, June 19 (Delayed) -- Civilian refugees reaching our lines from Caen have brought stories of great suffering among the civilian population caused by the shortage of food and by the ferocity of air and artillery activity in the area of the ancient town.

At ceremonies for the awarding of citations to 256 public, Catholic and Hebrew schools that have made outstanding contributions to the paper salvage drive, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had ordered all city departments to make a 30 per cent reduction from their normal paper consumption.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, June 21 -- After turning the enemy left flank in a combination infantry and tank attack, American troops have poured into the two remaining enemy airdromes on Biak Island against lessening enemy resistance.

Simon W. Straus, banker and head of the mortgage bond investment house of S.W. Straus Co., who died on Sept. 7, 1930, left a gross estate of $7,531,478, which was reduced by debts and administration expenses to $4,738,091. This was disclosed in a transfer tax appraisal approved yesterday by David Krakaur, appraiser for the metropolitan district.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Representative Margaret Smith of Maine, who as a member of the House Naval Affairs Committee, has long been pressing to have Waves and women Marines in overseas service as the Wacs are, introduced a bill today to permit them such foreign service.

Because they have not been able to set aside sufficient reserves under the present Governmental renegotiation policies, several war plants have written that they will have to close shortly after the Government stops placing war contracts with them, William S. Jack, president of Jack Heintz, Clevland, told 800 members of the Sales Executive Club yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore.

Miss Altha C. Hammann, a Red Cross staff assistant club director, was killed in an airplane accident in England on June 10, it was learned yesterday from Brooklyn Red Cross headquarters, 57 Willoughby Street. She was believed to be the first Brooklyn woman killed in the war and one of the first Red Cross workers from New York City to have died in line of duty.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 20 (U.P.) -- Reports from Helsinki said tonight that a "peace Cabinet" headed by the present Foreign Minister, Dr. Henrik Ramsay, was being formed in a last-minute effort to bring an end to the Russo-Finnish war.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Senate passed the War Agencies Appropriation Bill including $500,000 to continue the Fair Employment Practice Committee, and recessed at 7:33 P.M. until noon tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP) -- Bucky Walters allowed Pittsburgh only two hits tonight as the Reds shut out the Pirates, 3 -- 0. Max Butcher was reached for nine safeties before he retired at the beginning of the ninth in favor of Xavier Rescigno.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- The Cardinals supported Al Jurisich's five-hit pitching with a series of dazzling catches today as they downed the Cubs for the ninth time in as many meetings this season. The score was 2 to 1, and the margin of victory was an unearned run scored when Roy Hughes, Chicago third baseman, let a grounder seep through him.

The stock market experience yesterday the first corrective interlude of the post-invasion advance but the adjustment proved much less drastic than financial circles had anticipated, with the result that firmness prevailed at the close.

Under the supervision of the United States Office of Education, community counsel services for war veterans and displaced war workers have been established in fifty towns and cities in seven States, it became known yesterday. Existing guidance, social, welfare and educational agencies within the different communities have been coordinated into one single organization to operate in the post-war period.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, June 21 -- American infantrymen, closely supported by withering artillery fire, have broken through the outer perimeter of the Cherbourg defenses and established themselves in positions four to seven miles from the center of the great Atlantic port.

WITH THE UNITED STATES TROOPS BEFORE CHERBOURG, June 21 -- There has been no cessation of our military activity. Our artillery thundered away all day today at German defenses, although our airplanes were unable to bomb them because of a thick overcast.

A wave of isolationist sentiment threatens to reappear in the United States during the post-war period, impairing this country's effective and necessary participation in international organizations, Dr. Vera Micheles Dean, research director of the Foreign Policy Association, declared yesterday.

MOSCOW, June 21 -- Scores of United States heavy bombers from bases in Britain landed in the Soviet Union today after blasting Berlin and other strategic targets in the eastern part of Nazi-held Europe. Some American fighter escorts from Britain flew to Russia and Red Air Force fighters accompanied them in to the bases of the Eastern Command, United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe.
Lieut. Comdr. John Bell Huhn, USN, and Mrs. Huhn, accompanied by Mrs. William G. Costin Jr., wife of Lieutenant Costin of the Naval Reserve, have come to the Weylin from Bryn Mawr, Pa.

Sir Douglas Alexander, president of the Singer Manufacturing Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday that manufacturing facilities have been and are continuously occupied with war work and as yet there is no indication as to when the company will resume unhampered manufacturing of sewing machines.
