LONDON, June 21 -- A factor that has helped to compensate the Allies for the period of bad weather that followed D-day, it was learned today, has been the effective sabotage carried on by the French underground behind the German lines.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Opposition led by Representatives Edouard V. Izac, Democrat, of California, and Joseph P. O'Hara, Republican, of Minnesota, defeated today the proposal to absorb the Women's Air Force Service Pilots into the Army, made in the bill submitted by Representative John M. Costello, Democrat, of California.

DETROIT, June 21 (AP) -- The Indians smashed out fourteen hits today to make it two straight over the Tigers with a 9-to-7 victory. The Tigers used five pitchers, Johnny Gorsica submitting to his sixth defeat, while Ed Klieman, second of three Cleveland pitchers, notched his fourth victory.

When the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers engage in the novel three-cornered game at the Polo Grounds Monday night, when admission will be exclusively by the purchase of war bonds, some 500 wounded service men will be honored guests. The injured soldiers, sailors, marines and coast guardsmen, veterans of action in virtually every theatre of war, will be brought to the Polo Grounds from Halloran Hospital, St. Albans Naval Hospital and the Brooklyn Naval Hospital.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A list of 203 articles of civilian "hard goods" which are in short supply but are essential in various degrees to the maintenance of the civilian economy was made public today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

ROME, June 21 -- Col. Charles Poletti, former Governor of New York, arrived here today to take over his new duties as Commissioner of the Rome region, which consists of Rome itself, its suburbs and the so-called "Agro Romano," which is all the flat land around the capital.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee, in a highly unusual action, called on Hungary today to halt the mistreatment of Jews, reminding the German satellite that the perpetrators of "inhumane conduct" would be punished.

The railroads are experimenting with radiophones to facilitate communication between the engineer and the crew in the caboose of a mile-long freight train. Even if railway managers decide that hand and lantern signaling are not to be abandoned, there is no doubt that the radiotelephone is here to stay and that it will play its part in industrial and home life.

Delphiniums were the highlights of the monthly flower show held yesterday by the Horticultural Society of New York at its headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue. A gold medal certificate was awarded to Miss Anne Morgan of Mount Kisco, N.Y., for three vases of this flower.
LONDON, June 21 -- The stock markets here opened quietly today but the undertone was firm. Movements were somewhat irregular and some industrials eased.

CHUNGKING, China, June 21 (AP) -- Japanese troops, bent on splitting China in two, have pressed southward from fallen Changsha along a sweeping eighty-mile arc and in a ten-mile advance have fought to within fifty-five miles of the big rail junction of Hengyang, the Chinese High Command said tonight.

Capt. Oliver Lyttelton has made a personal apology in the House of Commons for the remarks which (needlessly, we think) so disturbed Secretary Hull, and accordingly this incident may now be regarded officially as closed. But for the sake of the record it is interesting to examine the statement which stirred such a tempest in the Washington teapots.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A flexible policy of competitive bidding and cash payment for surplus Government property sold abroad was urged on the Foreign Economic Administration by a committee of four business men today in response to a request for a "preliminary report" by Leo Crowley, Administrator of the FEA.

THE face of conquered Europe has been a blank to most of us for four long years. But now, bit by bit, we are getting glimpses of what it really looks like. The eyewitness account provided in "Gallic Charter: Foundations of Tomorrow's France,"* by J.C. Fernand-Laurent, is especially revealing. M. Fernan-Laurent, a member of the Chamber of Deputies,

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Werner W. Schroeder, Republican National Committeeman from Illinois, told the committee today that for their entertainment tickets would be provided for the Arlington Park race track, a Friday night baseball game and the Chicago Institute of Art.

ALBANY, June 21 -- Governor Dewey and newspaper correspondents at the Capitol engaged in a one-hour press conference today, featured by a single brief reference to developments at Chicago, where the Governor may be nominated next week as the Republican candidate for President.
ST. LOUIS, June 21 (AP) -- Collecting seven runs in the last two innings, the Browns trounced the White Sox, 11 to 2, tonight and now top the American League field by two and a half games.

The Mayor, in a recent address, spoke strongly in favor of social security and remarked, incidentally, "persons on old-age assistance should not take employment," and "teachers should retire at 65, not 70."

Their sunsuits and playshoes packed, their dolls and stuffed animals under their arms, a bevy of three-year-olds starts today for camp. They are the first contingent of sixty-five youngsters, aged three to ten, who will go to camp for three or four weeks this summer from the Eisman Day Nursery, Inc., one of the nurseries sponsored by the Mayor's Committee for the Care of Children in Wartime.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 21 (AP) -- A pension plan for employes of long service was announced by Justin R. Whiting, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, at the company's annual stockholders meeting here today.

The retail advertising course sponsored jointly by the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association will be mailed between Aug. 15 and Sept. 1, it was learned yesterday. Thus far, about fifty cities have applied for the course and it will be sponsored by a newspaper, department store and radio station in each of the cities selected.

A tantalizing look into the future was provided recently by H.F. Willkie, vice president of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., who spoke at a meeting of the Institute of Food Technologists on the food products that we may expect to see after the war.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Roosevelt today appointed Miss Frieda S. Miller to be director of the women's bureau of the Labor Department. The appointment must be confirmed by the Senate.
LONDON, Thursday, June 22 (UP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by The Unites Press:

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- The defending champion, Lieut. Patty Berg, absent from competitive golf since enlisting in the Marines last fall, today advanced to the quarter-final round of the women's Western open along with such pre-tournament favorites as Miss Dorothy Germain and Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias.

William Shenkel, associate editor and war correspondent for Newsweek, is missing in action on the B-29 raid over Japan, according to a report received by the editors of Newsweek from the War Department. As an observer, he was aboard one of the four Superfortresses that failed to return.

The six-story apartment house at 2878 Claflin Avenue and 2865 University Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the trustees of the Lawyers Mortgage Company to an investing client of Levy, Kornblum Katz, attorneys. The property, containing ninety-four apartments, is assessed at $395,000.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Conflicting advice as to the Republican position on post-war international problems developed as soon as the party's policy writers sat down today to begin consideration of the platform on which it will ask for defeat of the Democratic Administration.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 21 (AP) -- Communique 31:

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Marshall Field, publisher of PM and The Chicago Sun, said tonight more attention should be given by newspapers, radio and films to the contribution Negroes were making in the war effort.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The American Utilities Service Corporation was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to reduce its preferred and common stock capitalization to a single class of new common stock and to strip itself of all interest in two of its eight subsidiary companies.

A second and more severe reaction than on Tuesday was encountered yesterday by the stock market, and although a come-back ensued, prices failed to even up on the rebound. Despite the lower closing level, the list showed considerable resistance to the profit-taking which was induced more by violent swings in isolated spots rather than by acute sales pressure.

CHUNGKING, China, June 21 (U.P.) -- After forty days of fighting in the world's "most difficult" terrain, American-trained Chinese troops have won complete control of the towering Kaolikung range in Western Yunnan Province, routing the Japanese from a 4,000-square-mile area the enemy had converted into a fortress guarding Burma's eastern border, a Chinese communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- personnel strength of the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard stood at 3,400,646 men and women May 1, Senator Walsh reported today in a Senate document entitled "The Decline and Rennaissance of the Navy, 1922-1944."

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 21 (AP) -- The Misses Doris Hart, Betty Rosenquest and Lillian Lopaus, Florida college stars seeded in the first three places of the women's Eastern intercollegiate tennis tournament, breezed through their opposition in today's second-round matches at the Elizabeth Town and Country Club and moved into the quarter-finals.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- The high-flying Cardinals continued their subjugation of the Cubs today by sweeping through both ends of a double-header, 6 to 4 and 7 to 2, before 16,823 fans. This gave them eleven out of eleven over the cellar-dwelling Chicagoans this season, and nineteen of twenty-one over them in a streak dating back to last June 27.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY IN NORMANDY, June 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- The story of the green-bereted daredevils who scorn battle helmets and fight German armor with small arms was told today by their leader, Lord Lovat, a 32-year-old brigadier.

A warning that "a semblance of surrender," coupled with an "overthrow of Hitler and his gangster government" to give it verisimilitude, will be offered to the United Nations was sounded yesterday by Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, at ceremonies marking the dedication of Fifth Avenue as the "Avenue of the Allies" for the duration of the Fifth War Loan.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Both houses of Congress adopted a conference committee report today on legislation for extension of wartime price, rent and wage controls and the finished bill was sent to the White House for signature.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 21 -- Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal declared today at a convocation of Princeton University that there was no reason to assume that the American system of government and economics could not "wage peace" as successfully as it was waging war, but there were at least seven steps the nation must take to give our democracy the health and vigor to meet the great problems of peace.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- An attempt to build up a coalition to prevent the nomination of Governor Dewey for President at the Republican National Convention by multiplying the number of "favorite-son" candidates failed to make much progress today, as supporters of the New York Governor received word that the fifty votes of California would be cast for him on the first ballot.

Because they have accomplished "twice as big a job" in this war as they did in World War I with only one-fourth the accident fatality rate to passengers and employes, American railroads will receive a special Harriman Safety Award, the American Museum of Safety disclosed yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 21 -- New Soviet armistice terms have been presented to Finland, according to persons close to the Helsinki government. These terms are being discussed in Helsinki.

LONDON, Thursday, June 22 (U.P.) -- The Red Amy has killed or captured 7,800,000 Germans in the last three years of fighting on the Eastern Front and the Nazis are now faced "with complete rout," Moscow announced today on the third anniversary of the Russo-German war.
A supplement to Tuesday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland yesterday and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Beyond the fact that the winged rockets launched by the Germans from the French Channel coast against England have a wing-spread of about sixteen feet, that they are presumably jet-propelled and that they carry a metric ton of high explosives, the official statements are vague. More is being learned, however, from bombs brought down before exploding and at captured launching platforms in Normandy.

NEWARK, N.J., June 21 -- A post-war national income of $100,000,000,000 a year, compared with a pre-war level of sixty-five to seventy billion, was envisioned today by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of directors of the General Motors Corporation, in an address before 800 members of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce at a luncheon in the Essex House here.

The report in THE NEW YORK TIMES on June 11 on the fine work being done for consumers under the leadership of CDVO was most enlightening. To this should be added some word of the work being done by consumers through the thirty-five consumer councils now operating in Brooklyn.

Domestic whiskies yesterday began making a cautious reappearance on the shelves of local liquor package stores, and some even found their way into window displays as the War Production Board's order permitting the distilling of beverage alcohol during the month of August cut sharply into buying pressure.

LONDON, June 21 -- Thousands of German soldiers trapped in the Cherbourg Peninsula received some reading matter today from Allied planes. They were reminded that the famous 716th German Infantry, the Kreml Division, was cornered near Arromanches and "writen off" in the first three days of the French invasion.

The Associated Hospital Service of New York, non-profit hospital-sponsored Blue Cross Plan, has paid 750,000 hospital bills totaling $48,000,000 during the nine years of its existence, it was reported yesterday by Louis H. Pink, president of the service, in his annual report to the members, who totaled 1,500,000 on May 1.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Dr. Theodore Schultz of the Department of Economics of the University of Chicago, predicted today that advances in nutrition were "not likely to provide us with a solution of the farm problem," but might aggravate the difficulties of agriculture after the war.

There were two schools of thought yesterday at Ebbets Field on the question whether the Giants and the Dodgers should play baseball. What with the rain, Frenchy Bordagaray coming down with a touch of flu and his pitching staff being what it is, Manager Leo Durocher took the negative on the issue.

Waste paper collected by Sanitation Department trucks yesterday totaled 387 tons -- fifteen tons less than the total picked up on the previous Wednesday -- but the RKO circuit of motion picture theatres announced that it will make up for nearly half of this week's deficit with a contribution tomorrow of seven tons of obsolete tickets that can be converted by paper mills into urgently needed containers for war material.
LOS ANGELES, June 21 -- Convalescing soldiers, some of them bedridden, are helping to fabricate parts for the P-61 Black Widow fighter plane at the Army's new Birmingham General Hospital at Van Nuys.

Mario Amato, 41 years old, a son of the late opera baritone, Pasquale Amato, was sentenced to three months in the workhouse yesterday in Special Sessions after pleading guilty to a charge of passing a worthless check. Presiding Justice Frederick L. Hackenburg and Associate Justice Gustav W.M. Wieboldt expressed doubt that the man "could tell the truth."

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A bristling letter from Robert P. Patterson, Undersecretary of War, defending the Army's $134,000,000 Canol oil development in Canada as an essential link in Allied strategy brought quick Senate approval today of a $16,439,688 appropriation to continue its operation.

Warning against over-optimism due to improvement in the war situation, Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commanding general of the Second Service Command, declared last night that any faltering now in the production of war supplies "will mean days, weeks, possibly months delay in the ultimate conclusion of the war."

Jacobson Co., manufacturers of acoustical instruments, have leased two floors in 211-25 West Sixty-first Street. The lease was negotiated by Daniel W. Blumenthal, Supreme Court trustee, who owns the building as trustee for the benefit of certificate holders of New York Title and Mortgage Company, Series N-80.
BUFFALO, June 21 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis, only Negro general in the United States Army, called today for an end to "hayphenated Americanism."

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Thursday, June 22 (AP) -- Liberator bombers from the New Guinea sector made a record-breaking attack on Truk Monday, coordinated with the American invasion of Saipan in the Marianas.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Twenty-five more industrial plants and construction projects have been named to receive the joint Army-Navy "E" award for outstanding performance on war work. Their names and addresses are:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- Ann Dvorak, whose last three pictures were produced in England, has been signed by Republic to a term contract. The first film, "Flame of the Barbary Coast," a story with an early San Francisco political background, will have John Wayne in the lead.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Pressurized cabins -- air-conditioned compartments in which superchargers maintain near-normal air pressure -- make it possible for crews of the new B-29 Superfortresses to operate without oxygen masks at altitudes of 40,000 feet and higher, the War Department revealed today.

CHUNGKING, China, June 21 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace told a State banquet tonight that there was reason to hope the next twelve months "will be the final year of Japanese aggression in China," and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek declared that his nation and the three other great powers "must shoulder the responsibility of maintaining international peace."

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The art treasures and household furnishings of Joseph E. Widener went under the auctioneer's gavel today at Lynnewood Hall, his home in Elkins Park. Receipts from some 300 items sold yesterday were said to total about $60,000.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Detroit will have a serious unemployment crisis in sixty days if cutbacks are carried out on the scale now planned, says R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers Union (CIO).

WITH THE BRITISH SIXTH AIRBORNE DIVISION, France, June 21 (U.P.) -- When British paratroopers holding a vital sector of the Orne Valley in Normandy the other morning saw a Tiger tank and two self-propelling guns rolling down the road toward them they thought they were done for.

Although the Baltimore Ohio Railroad has arranged for meeting the maturity of $42,191,000 on Aug. 1, it probably will not complete plans for taking care of the $71,000,000 of notes held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for another month or two.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., June 21 (U.P.) -- Walter R. Suppes, Republican convention delegate, telegraphed today to the editors of Harpers Magazine demanding the name of the purchaser of reprints of an article which the magazine published last month concerning Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Action on the bill to permit overseas service for Waves and Women Marines, was delayed today by a demand from Representative Michael J. Bradley, Democrat of Pennsylvania, for an explanation by Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, Surgeon General of the Navy, of his remarks on Waves' foreign service in a recent Chicago speech.

The Pangborn Corporation, manufacturer of blast cleaning and dust control equipment, of Hagerstown, Md., has announced an upward revision of its group insurance program without additional cost to the employes affected. The plan will continue to be underwritten by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on a cooperative basis, the employes contributing fixed amounts and the employer bearing the remainder of the net cost.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, June 22 -- Hacking their way through the barbed-wire, machinegun and mortar positions that make up the inner defenses of Cherbourg, American infantrymen have advanced to within three and five miles of the port to the south and southwest of the city in a battle raging around the first great prize for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's armies.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (U.P.) -- Senator Scott W. Lucas, Democrat, of Illinois, a strong New Dealer who sometimes speaks for the Administration, demanded today that the British Government request Mr. Lyttelton's resignation for his "miserable" statement that the United States had provoked Japan into attacking Pearl Harbor.

Casualties on their way back from the Normandy beachhead in France were disclosed yesterday to have presented for the nation's railroads a further emergency in an already acute transportation situation.

Many American soldiers in Italy heard their first news of D-day in France from Marlene Dietrich, the blonde motion picture star said yesterday at USO-Camp Shows headquarters, 8 East Fortieth Street. Newly returned from a ten-week tour of entertaining service men in Africa and Italy, Miss Dietrich described hearing the invasion news as she was preparing for a 2 P.M. performance.
ROME, June 21 (AP) -- A communique:

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 21 (U.P.) -- British imperial troops have scored new gains at both ends of the Manipur Road in India, narrowing the Japanese-held gap to less than twenty-four miles, a southeast Asia Command communique announced today. In the face of half-hearted enemy opposition, it is anticipated that the important supply line will be cleared much ahead of schedule.

The Government, while consenting yesterday to the dismissal of denaturalization proceedings against four persons who had been accused of un-American utterances and activities subsequent to their receipt of United States citizenship, disclosed that it would press for the denaturalization of those shown to have had the same sort of view prior to naturalization.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- An exploding Japanese ship in the Pacific, by a freak accident, delivered its log and papers to one of the attacking planes, the Army reported today.
Arthur Upham Pope's letter concerning Finland in today's TIMES reminded me of the following passage in one of G.K. Chesterton's writings:

LONDON, June 21 -- The battle of Cherbourg was opening tonight as American troops, spearheaded by the hard-fighting, hard-marching doughboys of the Ninth Division, drove through the outer defenses of the important port.

LENINGRAD, June 21 -- Leningrad has taken up the task of reconstruction with the same frenzied energy shown during the city's historic siege. The first sight greeting a traveler's eye upon emerging on the Nevsky Prospect consists of gangs of girls shifting masonry from an unsightly ruin.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- One thousand railroad mechanics and helpers now employed on the National Railways of Mexico soon will begin to come to the United States under an arrangement for training recently completed by the Office of Coordinator of Inter-American affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Representative Charles Halleck, Republican of Indiana, this afternoon characterized the recent ruling of the United States Supreme Court, that insurance companies are transacting interstate commerce and are thus subject to the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, as usurpation of the legislative powers of Congress.
PRINCET0N, N.J., June 21 -- The text of the address delivered by James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, at a special convocation of Princeton University today follows:

PEARL HARBOR, June 21 -- American carrier planes attacked the Japanese fleet in the middle of the western Pacific area between Saipan and the Philippines on Monday, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet and Pacific Ocean Areas, announced today.

Disposal of Government-owned surplus materials must be accomplished in a manner which will help "backward areas of the country -- the West and South" -- to become industrialized, Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, Montana, declared yesterday.

I.J. Fox filed suit yesterday in the State Supreme Court for $1,000,000 damages against Gus Getsos and Benjamin Dranow as individuals and Getsos Dranow, Inc., a corporation, alleging illegal conspiracy and unfair competition by infringing on the complainant's trade name and representing themselves as a branch of the I.J. Fox organization.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 21 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Henley called upon the American people tonight to tackle public problems themselves instead of entrusting them entirely to politicians.

Plans to establish in Palestine a new agricultural setttlement to perpetuate the memory of Lord Josiah Wedgewood, British Labor leader and life-long champion of a Jewish national home in Palestine as a dominion of the British Commonwealth, were begun at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore last night under the auspices of the Labor department of the Jewish National Fund.

SANDS POINT, L.I., June 21 (AP) -- Frank Costello, the slot machine operator, who recently lost $27,200 in a New York taxicab, has acquired a new home in this exclusive residential community on the North Shore of Long Island.
CINCINNATI, June 21 (AP) -- Favorites continued their advance through the fifth round of the Tri-State tennis tournament today to move into tomorrow's quarter-finals in the men's singles matches.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 58:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
New York City sold yesterday by allotment $29,000,000 revenue bills dated June 23, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced. Interest is payable at maturity at the rate of 0.75 per cent.

The Army needs 22,000 women immediately to serve as medical technicians in hospitals, Maj. Gen. Norman T. Kirk, the Surgeon General, declared yesterday in a nation-wide call from the War Department in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Senate passed by a voice vote today, the War Department military establishment bill making available to the Army on July 1 $49,107, 735,795, of which $15,434,814,795 will be new money and $33,672, 971,000 will represent reappropriated savings from the $59,034,839, 673 appropriated for the present fiscal year.

IF all the big league catchers ever banded together and formed a union, the first article of the constitution would outlaw knuckle-ball pitching as a menace to society -- and the Catchers Union. The flutter-ball heavers annoy the batters most dreadfully but they grieve their receivers even more.
The United States Plywood Corporation reported yesterday that in the fiscal year ended on April 30 sales, earnings and assets made new high records.

LONDON, Thursday, June 22 -- At least two Nazi robot plane-launching platforms on the Cherbourg Peninsula have been captured intact by Allied troops, it was reported to London last night. Others may have been taken.

STANTON, Del., June 21 (AP) -- Rouge Dragon, carrying the silks of M.A. Cushman, was a driving winner of the Georgetown Steeplechase Handicap, a half length ahead of Lieut. Bayard Sharp's Knight's Quest, at Delaware Park today.

Leading Southern cotton mills were credited yesterday with fixing the price on fairly large quantities of cotton following the agreement on the price control bill by House-Senate conferees, with the result that futures advanced 9 to 16 points on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Mayor La Guardia continued yesterday his efforts to persuade the Uniformed Firemen's Association and its individual members to drop pending litigation contesting the validity of the order issued several months ago by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh, imposing extra tours of duty without additional pay.

LONDON, June 21 (U.P.) -- The Belgian radio here told patriots at home tonight to be on the lookout for signs of a new Allied invasion, while unconfirmed Swedish dispatches said that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had sent Brig. Gen. Jacques Leclerc, French desert raider, behind the lines to take command of patriot forces disrupting German reinforcements and supplies.

The August Book-of-the-Month Club selection will be "The Time for Decision" by Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, to be published on July 19 by Harper's "Cluny Brown," by Margery Sharp (Little, Brown) and "Pastoral" by Nevil Shute (Morrow) have been selected by the club for distribution in September.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP) -- Athletics, led by Dick Siebert's slugging, scored their third straight victory over the Red Sox today as they pushed over two runs in the sixth to break a 2-to-2 tie and then went on to win, 5 to 2. Siebert drove in three of the Mackmen's runs, with a single in the first and a double with two on in the sixth.

The United States is well prepared to care for its badly disabled veterans of the present war, Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, announced last night. He disclosed that large numbers of World War II veterans already have been placed on Government pension rolls and that his agency expects to have 300,000 hospital beds for veterans when the war is over.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 21 -- With one exception, French resistance groups are observing the general rules laid down by the Allies -- to wait for the moment when they can lend active aid to the best effect.

"Hats Off to Ice," the Center Theatre's fifth ice spectacle, will be unveiled tonight by Sonja Henie and Arthur M. Wirtz, specialists in that form of entertainment. Four of their shows (two editions of "It Happens On Ice" and the same number for "Stars On Ice") fared rather well at the Center in Radio City, achieving an aggregate of 1,576 performances.

Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch declared invalid yesterday a section of the city's Sanitary Code that prohibits the sale of horseflesh for animal consumption unles the meat is changed by harmless coloring or otherwise in a manner satisfactory to the Department of Health.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Admiral Ernest J. King, making his first public report today on his inspection of the European invasion operations, declared that it had been "a puzzle to everyone" why the Germans had not attempted to block the Allies by either air or sea.

For the woman who knows what miracles can be worked with the clever use of accessories there is a new collection, designed by Arpad, teeming with ideas for transforming last season's clothes. They are now appearing in leading department stores.

LONDON, Thursday, June 22 -- Russian troops opened a new twin offensive against Finland north and southwest of Lake Onega yesterday in a drive to clear a 223-mile enemy-held stretch of the vital Leningrad-Murmansk railroad, while Marshal Leonid A. Govoroff's tanks and infantry pursued the retreating Finns northwest from captured Viborg.
VATICAN CITY, June 21 -- Further details of the art collections, libraries and documents saved through the intervention of the Vatican were divulged today, and some of the material was displayed.

Mills working on denims, chambrays, flannels, sheets and pillowcases are awaiting with interest developments on the "compromise" cotton pricing amendment to the OPA extension bill. Spokesmen for the mills stated that in their opinion present ceilings on these items would have to be raised on an average of one cent per yard to bring them in line with cotton parity.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- When 20,300 persons from all parts of the country, including 1,057 delegates, enter the Stadium Monday for the opening session of the Republican National Convention they will find the amphitheatre ready for the big show.

Kipling could have had his mind on fillies when he penned those immortal words about the female of the species being deadlier than the male. So far as the 1944 crop is concerned, they may not be deadlier but they definitely have more up and go.

WITH THE JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, to the Marianas Islands, June 10 (Delayed) -- Successful American seizure of the Marianas Islands would complete the nullification of all Japan's military activities on a score of islands in the vast tropical sea called the Central Pacific.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 21 -- Seventy-three sick and wounded soldiers, most of them battle-weary infantrymen and all of them just back from the Italian battlefields, arrived by Army ambulance planes yesterday at England General Hospital here, it was announced today.

Nursery schools must be incorporated into the public school system if children below the age of 6 are to receive adequate health, recreation and guidance services, Dr. Ruth Andrus, director of the Child Development and Parent Education Bureau of the New York State Department of Education, declared yesterday.

Distribution of $18,000,000,000 of consumer durable goods annually to maintain national prosperity and employment can be achieved only through a "broader and better use of installment credit than ever was dreamed of in pre-war years." Nathan S. Sachs, retiring president of the Retail Credit Institute and treasurer of Sachs Quality Furniture, Inc., said yesterday at the annual meeting of the institute in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Mr. Frank Costello forgot $27,200 in a taxicab and Mayor La Guardia wants to confiscate the money on the ground that they are gambling funds. We trust it is not against public morals if we here suggest that there is one convincing reply which Mr. Costello can make in court.

LONDON, Thursday, June 22 -- Berlin was heavily attacked yesterday forenoon by an armada of American bombers and fighters exceeding 2,200 in number in the greatest assault of the war on the German capital.

CHICAGO, June 21 - Washington developments did not spur much buying of wheat futures today. The market was affected more by increased receipts in the Southwest and broadened hedge selling, which was of fair volume.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 21 (UP) -- A communique:
TORONTO, June 21 (AP) -- Newark and Toronto split a double-header tonight, the Bears shutting out the Leafs, 6-0, in the first game and losing, 4-2, in the other.

LONDON, June 21 -- Obviously very much embarrassed that he had rekindled an old quarrel in the United States, Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, made an abject apology in the House of Commons today for a side remark in a public speech yesterday suggesting that American aid to Great Britain had provoked the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

ROME, June 21 (U.P.) -- British Eighth Army troops on the Adriatic coast have captured Grottammare, ninety-eight miles southeast of Rimini, bringing the eastern end of the Italian front level with the Allies' positions on the Tyrrhenian coast above Rome, it was announced today.

Support of City Planning Commission's proposed rezoning of land use in Manhattan north of West Tenth Street and East Fourteenth Street by the public and the City Administration is urged by the committee on civic design and development of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects in a report made public yesterday.

The position of Australia has become stategically impossible in a future world, without new strength and firm friends, Sir Keith Murdoch, Australian publisher said last night at a Foreign Press Association dinner to welcome him, at the Netherlands Club 10 Rockefeller Plaza.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Proceedings were instituted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine whether the registration of M.S. Wien Co., of 25 Broad Street, New York, as a broker and dealer should be revoked or suspended and the company ousted from membership in the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., for allegedly raising artificially the market price of a series of debentures late last year.

One hundred and forty Protestant, Catholic and Jewish religious leaders representing all sections of the United States have signed a joint statement calling for the early establishment of a permanent International Office for Education, it was learned yesterday.

The thirty-six dancing Rockettes of Radio City Music Hall have received a hand-engraved plaque from thirty-six United States Navy admirers somewhere in the South Pacific, it was made known yesterday by the music hall. The plaque is made of wood and metal fragments of a wrecked Japanese plane and bears the engraved words: "The Fighter Direction Center, South Pacific, Has Selected as Our Sponsor and Ideal the Radio City Rockettes, New York."

WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY BEFORE CHERBOURG, 5 P.M. , June 21 -- German prisoners indicate a general belief among the men of the enemy garrison that they have been abandoned to their fate. It is doubtful if the German command ever intended to reinforce the city even if it had been able to.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Mayme Jones-Jason of Philadelphia, a Negro mother, told an Army judge advocate's review board today that her son's conviction on a mutiny charge was based on illegal grounds and pleaded "not for clemency, but for justice."

A tale of hunting broadbill swordfish and sharks off Montauk Point came from the United States Naval Torpedo Testing Range there yesterday and provided a refreshing deep-sea tang that has been missed since the war began.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The battle between the United States Pacific Fleet and the Japanese Navy, elusive for many months, may now be joined, Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal indicated at his press conference this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- With most office buildings in the nation at least fifteen years old, and with repairs and equipment replacements held to a minimum under wartime restrictions, a vast backlog of structural improvements is being built up to help cushion the shock of peace and to provide quick employment in the early post-war period, the National Association of Building Owners and Managers was informed today.

News that the Hartley amendment barring the highest place line limitation stays in the new price control bill so far as retailers only are concerned led manufacturers yesterday to charge that the Congressional action was "unfair" and will result in further diminishing the supply of low price garments.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, June 22 (AP) -- A communique:

The United Artists Corporation is considering acquiring theatre properties in this country and abroad as well as new studio facilities in Hollywood, it was announced yesterday. These and other plans for expansion in the future win be studied by board members before their next monthly meeting on July 11 in the U.A. offices at 729 Seventh Avenue.

For five years Changsha has been a rock of resistance to Japanese conquest, a symbol of physical and moral endurance. It would be idle to deny that its fall marks a decline in China's fortunes. The enemy has moved a long way forward in his plan to split China in two.

VIBORG, Finland, June 21 -- This Finnish seaport fell today because the Russians knew exactly how to attack the Mannerheim Line. Ignoring the Lake Ladoga side, the Red Army attacked right along the gulf coast. They picked the weak section of each part of the Finnish line and concentrated everything they had on it.
LONDON, June 21 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

After a hearing attended by representatives of the strikers and brewers the regional War Labor Board yesterday ordered the employes of eight breweries in and around Newark, N.J., to return to work immediately and leave the questions in dispute involving terms for a new contract to the decision of the board.

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the first three months of this year, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $2,340,386, after operating expenses and other charges, compared with a net of $1,247,957 in the first quarter of 1943.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 21 (AP) -- Assessed valuation of taxable real property in New York was reported by the State Tax Commission today as $25,053,936,754, a decrease of $78,303,512 in the fourth successive year of decline.
PITTSBURGH, June 21 (AP) -- Pittsburgh emerged from its batting slump in the last half of the ninth inning today and rang up three hits and two runs to beat Cincinnati, 2 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Both houses of Congress approved the conference report on the OPA extension bill, and the measure was sent to the White House for the President's signature.

The first joint commencement exercise of Yeshiva College and the Teachers Institute will take place at 3:30 P.M. today in the Lamport Auditorium, Amsterdam Avenue and 187th Street. Fifty-four bachelor of Arts degrees and thirteen teachers' diplomas will go to graduates of the respective schools.
CHUNGKING, China, June 21 (AP) -- A communique:

The thirteen carloads of Government beef that arrived here a few days ago to relieve the meat scarcity for civilians remained unsold yesterday, although there were several willing buyers, because the complexities of the mark-up system of fixing ceiling prices stumped the War Food Administration as well as the local meat industry.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 21 -- Ray Hendley of Shore View, a member of the Brooklyn police force, turned in par 71, the low gross score, in the M.G.A. one-day 18-hole handicap golf tournament today at the Bonnie Briar Country Club.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt made yesterday her first visit to an American Red Cross Prisoners of War Packaging Service, 39 Chambers Street. She congratulated the New York center on the 4,170,114 food boxes sent to Allied military and civilian prisoners, but at the same time urged women volunteers further to serve the men who fight by answering the political, economic and racial questions that are in their hearts as they go into battle.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, June 22 (AP) -- "If you do not stop the fight now you will never see your homeland again," an Allied ultimatum told German soldiers in Cherbourg this morning. The broadcast ultimatum said:

Both production of petroleum and refinery operations last week reached new peaks, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The country's output of crude oil averaged 4,568,250 barrels daily, an increase of 45,750 over the 4,522,500 in the preceding week, although 17,350 barrels less than the recommendation of 4,585,600 daily for June by the Petroleum Administration for War.

Holders of B gasoline ration books who find that their automobiles do not get the fifteen miles a gallon the Office of Price Administration figures they should get and consequently use their fuel in less than the 325 miles a month allowed in the East, can expect little relief, Charles F. Phillips, rationing chief of the OPA, said yesterday.

More than 50,000 consumer service establishments in the city -- among them shoe repair shops, tailoring and cleaning and dyeing places, laundries, auto repair stations and radio and household appliance repair shops -- are due to come within the next few weeks under strict price controls by means of which the Office of Price Administration hopes to roll back prices of "cost of living" services an average of 10 to 15 per cent.

After an ownership of two weeks, the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 425 Riverside Drive, southeast corner of 115th Street, has been resold by Samuel Knepper, operator, to Philip Simkowitz. It is assessed at $1,550,000 and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $1,433,000 held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and extended for five years.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Republicans can effect a coalition with the "genuine American" Democrats and swing 10,000,000 to 15,000,000 votes and some doubtful States into the Republican column in November if they nominate the right man next week, Dr. Gleason L. Archer said today.

Meteorologists said yesterday would be the longest day of the year and the 2,980 fans who paid their way into the Stadium agreed. For the Yankees and Senators, following long delays before each game, caused by rain, battled through 4 hours and 15 minutes of actual diamond combat only to wind up even.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- In a session lasting until evening, the Republican National Committee today dismissed contests for recognition as delegates to the Republican National Convention in Alaska and Florida on recommendation of its subcommittee on contests on the ground that protests were not filed with the committee within the required time.

With the opening of the Britain-Berlin-Russia air route yesterday, supplementing the Italy-Hungary-Rumania-Russia route or routes set up three weeks ago, Germany's Maginot Line of the air ceases to exist. There is now no spot in Fortress Europe which the Allies cannot ring with fire.
Do not gamble! Take no gamble with the lives of our sons and daughters who are fighting for us.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Ten fundamental principles to serve in framing a lasting peace, endorsed by fifty-five leaders, including Senators, Representatives, Governors, judges and leaders in public life, were issued at a press conference in the Capitol Building this afternoon with the sponsorship of Senator Elbert D. Thomas, Democrat of Utah and a member of the Foreign Relations Committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- A petition by the city of San Francisco asking the Federal District Court to defer the effective date of an injunction prohibiting the sale of Hetch Hetchy electric power to a private corporation for resale was opposed today in an answer filed on behalf of the Department of the Interior by Frank J. Hennessy, Federal attorney here.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 22 -- Twenty-two ringleaders from among the first group of seventy-six Greek officers and men, charged with fomenting mutiny in the First Greek Brigade, today continued listening to their original brigade commander, Col. Evangelos Pappas, witness for the crown, being cross-examined by their defense lawyers. It was the fourth day of the court-martial.

A SUPERFORTRESS BASE, in India, June 20 (Delayed) -- One salient fact that has emerged from last week's first Superfortress attack against the Japanese homeland is that huge new bombers are capable of carrying an even bigger bomb load than that hauled to Yawata.

For the third successive year net sales of United States Industrial Chemicals, Inc., established a new high record with a volume of $37,486,342 for the fiscal year ended with March, an increase of 26 per cent over the $29,727,966 sales for the previous year, Glenn L. Haskell, president, and Charles E. Adams, chairman, declare in the annual report issued for publication today.

Highly elated but obviously shy, eight public school pupils received yesterday certificates and cash prizes totaling $1,530 for exceptional scholarship and their ability to overcome social and physical handicaps. Immediately, all declared that they would utilize them in the continuation of their education.

The Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal was presented yesterday to Lieut. Russell O. Wirtz, USMS, at a luncheon of the Propeller Club at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, for his part in the rescue of shipmates from the torpedoed Standard Oil Company of New Jersey tanker Esso Baton Rouge.

LONDON, June 22 -- Since Germany started dispatching robot planes against this country neither American nor British propagandists have threatened retalation against a form of attack effective only against civilians, it was learned here today.

Persons who insist that you can't believe what you read in the papers -- and it is an opinion often voiced in the most exalted quarters -- may have derived much satisfaction from a couple of adjacent news columns on our front page yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 (AP) -- The Browns' defense fell apart long enough today to give the White Sox an opportunity to score seven unearned runs in the eighth to notch a 10-to-3 victory and an even break in their four-game series.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Wheat reversed an early trend today and closed strong and sharply higher on the Board of Trade here. Mill buying on a fairly pretentious scale cushioned the early selling and started considerable short covering.
PEARL HARBOR, June 22 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 59:

ATLANTA, June 22 -- In addition to naming Gov. Ellis Arnall to head the Georgia delegation to the Democratic National Convention, the State Committee today ratified a subcommittee report limiting the July 4 primary to whites only and provided that Presidential electors should be required to sign a personal pledge of party regularity.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- All quota restrictions on shipments of cane spirits to the United States from Cuba and other Caribbean sources of supply will be removed by the War Production Board soon, according to reports circulating among liquor importers.

ROME, June 22 (AP) -- Banned from singing in an Army concert tonight on the ground that the time was not propitious for his appearance in embittered Rome, Beniamino Gigli, former Metropolitan Opera Company tenor, laid the opposition to him to "jealousy of mean people," and declared that he would "never sing for the Italians again."

The stock market underwent little change yesterday as many more traders retired to the sidelines to await developments. In the narrowest and slowest trading in two weeks, the list made scant headway as prices fluctuated fractionally either from slight selling pressure or modest demand.

The American Navy has scored another smashing victory over the Japanese Navy, comparable to the victories of the Coral Sea, of Midway and of Guadalcanal. It was not that decisive victory which the early enthusiasm of our admirals had painted as a possibility. Regarding discretion as the better part of valor, the Japanese continue to hide their main fleet for the last defense of their islands, and send into battle only substantial task forces.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 22 (UP) -- A communique:

An outstanding example of how a consumer product introduced in wartime has reached a sales volume of more than $4,000,000 annually in the short space of thirteen months is described in the monthly bulletin of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

In the future women will no longer be bothered removing the caps of bottles and jars, pouring or scooping out their cosmetics, and replacing the tops again if the designs for pressure containers for cosmetics becomes a reality.
In your issue of Monday, June 19, on the editorial page under the heading "Removing Wage Controls" the following statement appears:

Further increases in excess reserves by the member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City and for the nation as a whole, in the fiscal week ended Wednesday, were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The Associated Press disclosed yesterday that it had received a message from "the crew of the U.S.S. Coos Bay," a seaplane tender, which appealed to war workers not to interrupt the production of fighting weapons through strikes and enclosed $412 in cash to help pay the demands of "money-hungry" strikers.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 22 -- The Pacific Fleet crippled a formidable Japanese sea force in a smothering attack last Monday afternoon that cost the enemy at least four ships sunk and ten badly damaged.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 22 -- The Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board has outlawed in Pennsylvania the whisky "dividend" declared by Park Tilford, Inc.

Nearly 300,000 pounds of Government beef, brought to this city by the War Food Administration early this week to relieve a shortage in civilian supply, was sold yesterday to local wholesalers and should be in the retail butcher shops for week-end shoppers.

In all this discussion of "dual employment" of city workers, which has Mayor La Guardia out gunning for them, there is one aspect to the controversy which the long-suffering taxpayer fails to appreciate.

An apartment in the Hotel Marguery, 270 Park Avenue, designed by Eleanor Johnstone, a young woman who moves around town decorating as she goes, was exhibited to the press at a cocktail party yesterday afternoon. Miss Johnstone, who has never studied decorating, ignores the credo shared by most professionals -- that a home must be designed to suit the personality of a particular client.

Fresh green vegetables of all kinds are in the market in profusion today and no matter what one is looking for it should be found without difficulty, the War Food Administration tells us. Broccoli, which is not too plentiful, is the only exception.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 17 were 879,161 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 4,968 cars, or 0.6 per cent more than for the preceding week; 10,875 cars, or 1.3 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 34,248 cars, or 4.1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Thirty-two of the 100 watercolors William Blake made in 1827 upon the commission of his patron, John Linnell, as illustrations for "The Divine Comedy" have been selected for reproduction in the Heritage Club edition of Dante's work, to be distributed to members this month.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The "most powerful and destructive naval unit in the history of sea warfare" met and defeated the Japanese off the Philippines Monday, the Navy revealed tonight in disclosing for the first time the organization of "Task Force 58."

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, commenting today on the third anniversary of the German assault on the Soviet Union, looked forward with assurance to the part the Red Army will play in the decisive battles in Europe this summer.

The city's many retail stores are being urged to contribute their old sales slips and tax records to the paper salvage drive in letters mailed yesterday by the Newspaper Publishers Waste Paper Salvage Committee and the salvage division of the War Production Board.

TRENTON, N.J., June 22 (AP) -- New Jersey's 1941 and 1942 railroad tax compromise legislation, which waived interest payments totaling $24,000,000 and permitted the payment of $34,000,000 of principal amount in installments, was set aside today by the Court of Errors and Appeals.

ROME, June 22 (AP) -- American troops driving up the west coast of Italy have overcome stiff German resistance and captured the town of Paganico, fourteen miles Northeast of Grosseto and less than sixty miles from the Pisa-Florence-Rimini defense line along which the Nazis are expected to make their final stand below the Alps, allied headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- While Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson called attention today to the "very strong fashion" in which we have built up our armies on the beachhead in France, military observers here noted that the final Allied assault to force the capitulation of the stubborn German defenders of Cherbourg apparently had begun.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Adhering to the arguments advanced in a hearing on last Thursday, the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a brief in support of the contention that it should have until late August to prepare a voluntary plan for compliance with the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -Chairman Mary T. Norton of the House Labor Committee introduced today a bill that would provide that wage determinations under the War Labor Disputes Act, the Fair Labor Standards Act and other statutes "shall apply to workers without regard to sex."
DETROIT, June 22 (AP) -- The Tigers kept the Indians from a sweep of the three-game series by winning today, 4 to 3, on Joe Orengo's double in the eighth inning.
CHICAGO, June 22 ((AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

THE NEW YORK TIMES of today carries a strong editorial expressing doubt as to whether Congress would approve of the plan for monetary stabilization which Secretary Morgenthau proposes to advance at the forthcoming conference at Bretton Woods. We fully share that doubt.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 22 -- Following the warning issued by the German High Command in France that partisans cannot be recognized as combatants and when caught will be shot as francstireurs, the resistance movement in the east of France has posted a placard in many towns and villages pledging that for every partisan shot the life of a German civilian will be exacted.

WASHINGTON, D.C., June 22 -- Cartoons of salmon leaning lazy-eyed against a lamp-post, a bewildered rabbit surveying a plate of cheese-covered toast, a spinach leaf fanning itself wearily beneath a blazing sun, liven up, recipes for salmon loaf, welsh "rabbit," and wilted spinach in the new Prisoner of War Cooking Guide just published by the American Red Cross.

The Army's Mason General Hospital at Brentwood, L.I., was turned over formally to the Medical Corps by the Corps of Engineers yesterday afternoon and was dedicated to the recovery of psychoneurotic casualties from both battle and training areas by Maj. Gen. Norman T. Kirk, the Surgeon General.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WHEN Tim Healy was a young engineering student in Australia he stepped between two open terminals in a powerhouse wearing a wet raincoat. Enough thousands of Volts of electricity crashed through his body to kill a herd of elephants. But Tim Healy did not die. For four months he lay unconscious in a hospital in Sidney, confounding medical science and providing a sensation for the press.

VATICAN CITY, June 22 -- The Vatican's stocks of rosaries were almost exhausted this afternoon after Pope Pins XII gave away more than 18,000 pairs in the past four days to Allied soldiers and officers. In all, the Pontiff probably has given as many as 50,000 rosaries and medals to troops.

ALGIERS, June 22 -- It was understood on high authority here tonight that an agreement between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gen. Charles de Gaulle for the use of some 230 French administrative liaison officers, now in England, had been virtually completed and that, as a result, these officers would go to France on the staff of Brig. Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig, Algiers liaison officer in London.

The three-cornered baseball game involving the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers at the Polo Grounds Monday night for the Fifth War Loan will be broadcast over Station WINS, it was announced yesterday by J.P. Spang Jr. president of the Gillette Safety Razor Company.

Councilmen Benjamin J. Davis Jr. of Manhattan and Peter V. Cacchione of Brooklyn, both elected as Communists, apologized yesterday to readers of The Daily Worker, mouthpiece of the Communist Political Association, for not voting on the first roll-call for Mayor La Guardia's emergency sales tax bill at the City Council meeting on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The German-American Bund sought to put a "more American" face upon its propaganda activities as war clouds thickened in Europe, but still urged its members to retain their essential Nazi German ideology, the jury in the mass sedition trial was told today.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- A pledge for prosecuting the war to a victorious end "in full cooperation with the United Nations" and for an international organization to preserve peace short of "a world state," was being circulated among Republican leaders tonight as the model foreign policy declaration for the Republican National Convention which assembles here next week.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The House Naval Affairs Committee approved today by a vote of 17 to 4 the bill to permit Navy women to serve overseas but Chairman David I. Walsh of the Senate Naval Affairs Committee blasted hope of its enactment prior to the recess.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- With a celerity almost unmatched even in the press of business in these last few days before the Congressional recess the House adopted today by a roll-call vote of 283 to 54, legislation controverting the recent four-to-three decision of the Supreme Court of the United States that fire insurance companies were dealing in interstate commerce and were thus subject to the anti-trust laws.

A reorganized American Chamber of Commerce for Trade with Italy, Inc., has laid plans to work with the Department of Commerce to collate information released by the Allied Military Government in Italy and help formulate plans for resumption of private trade with that country, E.L. Sozzi, president of the group, and of the Fontana Hollywood Corporation, said yesterday.

The Office of Price Administration took steps yesterday to prevent black marketeering in used cars when ceiling prices become effective on July 10. A major aim was to make it difficult for "fly-by-nights" and other unscrupulous dealers to shine up old cars and sell them to war workers and other motorists as reconditioned at the higher prices permitted for such automobiles.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the President's Committee on the Cost of Living, made public today a report by an advisory committee of statistical experts who declared that their investigation confirmed confidence in "the accuracy and representativeness of the price changes shown by the Bureau of Labor Statistics index."

CHICAGO, June 22 -- The convention of American Home Economics Association, in a series of resolutions passed today, urged that the production, distribution and use of food be determined by nutritional needs.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Nearly 100,000 tickets to the Republican National Convention will be distributed at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow to State leaders at the Blackstone Hotel. These do not include "season passes" of delegates, alternates and convention officials.

An idea that may be worth cultivating was presented last night at the meeting of the Metropolitan Rod and Gun Club, Brooklyn. It wasn't a new idea by any means, but perhaps the oldest form of trade-barter. This time the trading was done in fishing tackle, which is rapidly becoming non-existent as far as new gear is concerned.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 22 -- When the systematic organization of the peace finally takes form at the conclusion of the present carnage, it must be the result of an habitual exercise of collective responsibility, not for the purpose of coercion of this nation or that but on behalf of the welfare of each, President Charles Seymour of Yale declared today in his baccalaureate address at the university's 243d commencement exercises.
If all of us could have perpetuated the feelings which were in our hearts on D-day, the Fifth War Loan drive would be oversubscribed already.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A joint arrangement prepared by the United States War Shipping Administration and the British Ministry of War Transportation which will enable shippers of commercial cargoes to South and East Africa to apply directly to American and British steamship lines for cargo space, following acquisition of necessary licenses, was announced today by the WSA.

The initial step here toward a world meeting of national organizations of Christians and Jews soon after the end of the war was taken at the semi-annual meeting of trustees of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, Inc., yesterday in the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Substantial declines in primary market prices for important agricultural commodities such as grains, live stock and poultry and fruits and vegetables brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of nearly 900 price series down 0.3 per cent during the week ended last Saturday.

LONDON, June 22 -- From American and other sources today came testimony that resistance by the French underground was surpassing in effectiveness some of the most optimistic predictions made for it. The German Army in France is reported to have been caught virtually between two fires and as a result the movement of Nazi troops from southern France to the battle zones is being seriously hampered.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 (AP) -- The Pirates cast off the "hitless wonders" appellation today and blasted twenty-six safeties to take both ends of a double-header from Cincinnati. Coming from behind both times, they won, 9 -- 4 and 7 -- 4.
By way of demonstrating to a somewhat skeptical gathering of 4,706 that the thing still can be done the Yankees turned in one of their neatest jobs of the season at the Stadium yesterday.

BOSTON, June 22 -- Working at top speed, 300 workmen at the Neponset Shipyard of the George Lawley Sons Corporation assembled and launched a 150-foot infantry landing craft today in the record time of seven hours. The usual time required is five to seven days.

First Lieut. Michael A. Stramiello, who completed fifty missions as a navigator on a bomber in the Mediterranean theatre, was the guest of honor yesterday as the Minneford Yacht Yards, Inc., City Island, the Bronx, launched the sixty-fourth tug it has built for the Army Transportation Corps.
It was one of those "man bites dog" days out at Aqueduct yesterday, for Ted Atkinson, who has been booting in winners left and right, top and bottom, since the meeting opened, was blanked.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Federal controls over the distribution of lumber so strict that they may slash the use of that material by some non-military consumers as much as 50 per cent below even present restrictions will go into effect on Aug. 1, the result of a survey of the nation's lumber needs made earlier this year, the War Production Board announced today.

Worth printing as a reminder, if not exactly as news, are reports from Italy that Allied investigators are uncovering evidence of widespread corruption in the Fascist regime. Of course fascism was corrupt. No one should have expected it to be otherwise. Its essence was irresponsible power, exercised without the consent of the governed.
LONDON, June 22 -- Allied defensive measures gradually seem to be meeting the menace of the war's newest weapon, the Germans pilotless aircraft.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 22 (AP) -- On Saipan, Japan's virtually abandoned defenders fell back before a gathering assault, while the Tokyo radio conceded that American reinforcements were pouring ashore.

Yielding to a directive of the regional War Labor Board to return to their jobs, striking brewery workers in northern New Jersey voted yesterday to end a two-week walkout that had threatened a beer drought and brought complaints from Army and Navy installations along the Eastern seaboard.

LONDON, June 22 -- Reports from the underground in Germany said today that Adolf Hitler established headquarters at or near Le Mans the day after the Allies landed in Normandy 100 miles to the north, but soon withdrew to Troyes beyond Paris and finally returned to Berchtesgaden.

LONDON, Friday, June 23 -- Powerful Soviet forces, driving ahead on three Finnish fronts, yesterday cleared a further stretch of the Murmansk railroad north of Lake Onega, deepened a bridgehead on the north bank of the Svir River northeast of Leningrad and surged forward against stiffening Finnish resistance northeast of Viborg. Lake Osterozero and to Velikaya Guba, northwest of Vanzhozero.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Miss Betty Jane Haemerle, 18-year-old St. Louis lassie, pulled one of the biggest upsets in the fifteen-year history of the women's Western open golf tournament today by beating the defending champion, Lieut.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull reacted coldly today to suggestions that the Foreign Misters of the American Republics meet to consider anew their policy toward the revolutionary government in Argentina, which most of their countries have refused to recognize.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Cutback in the manufacture of premium gasoline for civilian use was ordered today and the card rationing of coal next winter was predicted as a possibility by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, solid fuels administrator and petroleum administrator for war.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Following is the text of a statement President Roosevelt read today as he signed the "G.I. Bill of Rights" for veterans' benefits:

A syndicate headed by Leo J. Margolin has purchased the twelve-story loft building at 338-40 West Thirty-ninth Street from Henry Goelet, operator, who bought it recently. The property is assessed at $165,000 and is 50 by 100 feet.

Few manufacturers will be able to take any appreciable advantage of special allocations made last Tuesday by the War Production Board for the production of low-end cotton garments during the third quarter of this year, Max J. Lovell stated yesterday.

Kevin Patrick O'Sheel, 22 years old, of 44 West Sixtieth Street, will continue to be known by that name and not as Henri Marie Patrice Hubert de Pineo because Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch would not permit him to change it.

Asserting that the Government is prepared to handle the avalanche of paperwork accompanying terminated contracts, Col. Curtis G. Pratt, deputy director of the readjustment division of the Army Service Forces, declared yesterday that industry as a whole is not ready to accomplish "its part of the job."

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- The New Orleans Public Service, Inc., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan to sell $34,500,000 of first mortgage bonds and 77,798 shares of $100 par value preferred stock to obtain funds with which to finance a bond and stock redemption program.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 22 -- Post-war prosperity for rural banking institutions was forecast tonight by Charles W. Bailey, president of the First National Bank of Clarksville, Tenn., and chairman of the Food for Freedom Committee of the American Bankers Association, in a talk at the seminar dinner of the Graduate School of Banking in Cooper Hall, Rutgers University, here.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 22 -- Saying that the initial successes of the Reich's pilotless planes marked only the first step in Germany's war of retaliation, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the German Propaganda Minister, in the current issue of the Reich said today that new and more powerful weapons were now in readiness for Germany's foes.

Increasing evidence that Congressmen from the cotton States had won a signal victory with the passage of a price-control bill that lifted ceilings for cotton loans and cotton goods brought about yesterday one of the most buoyant cotton markets in months, and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 12 to 34 points to the highest levels in sixteen years.

LONDON, June 22 (U.P.) -- The French "Army of the Interior," in a series of rapier-like thrusts, has isolated a "starving" Paris, has snarled German military traffic throughout France and has flanked Naiz forces in Normandy with blows behind the battle line and in Brittany, it was reported officially tonight.

DEPARTMENT of Utter Confusion: When Arthur Mann, the magazine writer, sits down at a typewriter, he frequently sticks tongue in cheek and lets his fancies roam. Apparently one item on the dramatic page of this newspaper caught his eye just before his gaze strayed to the racing chart. His puckish mind instantly connected the two and the following nonsense was the result:

AUSTIN, Tex., June 22 -- Only the anti-Roosevelt forces' Presidential electors will appear on the Texas ballot in November under a ruling handed down today by the State Supreme Court. The court rejected an application by the pro-Roosevelt wing of the party for a mandamus to compel the Secretary of State to put the names of its own electors on the ballot for the Democratic State primary July 22.
Yesterday's communique, as broad cast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, June 22 -- At a press interview today in the New York State headquarters, J. Russel Sprague, national committeeman from New York, today presented twenty-nine Republican leaders from twenty-three States and Territories who have joined the movement to "draft" Governor Dewey for the Republican nomination for President.

Herman G. Brock, 53 years old, for twenty-five years recognized in banking circles as an authority on Latin-American financial affairs, got off with a suspended sentence yesterday in General Sessions on his recent guilty plea to passing two worthless checks for $9,800 last December on the Guaranty Trust Company when he was a vice president in charge of its foreign department at a yearly $25,000 salary.
Young apprentice cooks studying under the chefs at ten of the city's leading hotels served their first "practice" dinner last night at the Food Trades Vocational High School.

The National Shawmut Bank of Boston was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $500,000 New Bedford, Mass., temporary loan notes, due on Nov. 24. Award was made on an 0.438 per cent basis.

The value of a specialized education in wartime was stressed last night by Dr. Clarence C. Stoughton, president of Wagner Memorial College, at commencement exercises of the New York School of Printing. The ceremony, at which Dr. Frederic W. Goudy, noted type designer, awarded diplomas to 121 graduates, was held at the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.
CANTON, N.Y., June 22 -- Owen D. Young told the graduates of St. Lawrence University here today that the United States would emerge from this war as the most powerful country on earth and declared:

WITH THE NINTH AIR FORCE COMMAND, Somewhere in Normandy, June 22 -- German military transport, always one of the brightest plumes in the Teutons' war bonnet, has suffered the most crippling blow in its history in the present campaign in France.

LONDON, June 22 -- Within forty-five minutes after the first troops landed on the shores of France a medical unit was on the beachhead picking up casualties despite withering machine-gun fire, while in the background a damaged landing craft was being converted into an operating theatre.

Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein had members of the "Robins" and the "Beavers," rival gangs in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn, present yesterday when he sentenced Joseph Parker, 16-year-old Negro member of the "Robins," to ten to twenty years in Sing Sing Prison for first-degree assault.
LONDON, June 22 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for week ended June 21 reported a decrease of 4,071,000 in note circulation.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Roosevelt signed today, in a semi-public ceremony, the "G.I. Bill of Rights," which authorizes a broad program of benefits for veterans of this war.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Congress shuttled appropriations and legislative measures at high speed between the Senate and the House today in the final push for the convention recess scheduled to start almost certainly tomorrow afternoon and end on Aug. 1.

Should Boris Karloff agree with Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, look for the bogeyman's next stage appearance in "Who Sups With a Devil." It will be recalled that Mr. Karloff had no small part in the tremendous success of "Arsenic and Old Lace," having starred for Mr. Lindsay and Mr. Crouse in that lethal melodama by Joseph Kesselring.

Under ideal weather conditions for outdoor music the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Sir Thomas Beecham, was heard in an all-Russian program last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, with Artur Rubinstein as soloist. The concert was attended by an audience of 18,000 persons, the largest gathering of the current Stadium season.

Speaking at the joint commencement of Yeshiva College and the Teachers Institute, Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of Yeshiva College, declared yesterday that the United States must lead the way for the rest of the world politically and spiritually by becoming "the center of resurrection of all the lofty ideals which were transmitted to us from generation to generation."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, ALLIED EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, Friday, June 23 -- Germany is now entirely blanketed by the Allied pattern for strategic bombing, it was said here yesterday by a senior officer of the United States Eighth Air Force in commenting on the successful flight of American bombers from this country to Russia Wednesday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, June 23 (U.P.) -- With the Biak Island campaign virtually completed and its three airdromes now in American hands, heavy bombers of the Fifth Air Force concentrated their attacks on other Japanese installations Wednesday, with a heavy raid on Numfor Island.

CHUNGKING, June 22 (AP) -- Japanese troops driving swiftly southward along the Siang River have reached a point only thirty-three miles north of Hengyang, a Chinese communique said tonight, and the High Command admitted that the threat to that strategic rail junction was becoming graver by the hour.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The President's ability to form a popular and Congressional majority of separate and even dissident groups of voters has been responsible for the long series of victories under the Democratic label and has been the envy of Republican politicians.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Gov. Ellis Arnall of Georgia walked out of President Roosevelt's office today and told newspaper men that Mr. Roosevelt would run for a fourth term if the Democratic national convention tenders the nomination to him.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Department store sales for the week ended June 17 were 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following table shows percentage changes from like periods of last year:
ROME, June 22 (AP) -- A translation of the agreement issued here said:
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- A fourteen-member Georgia delegation headed by Wilson Williams and instructed to vote for Governor Dewey was approved by the Republican National Committee today.

In the warm sunshine at Ebbets Field yesterday Whit Wyatt's sixth start of the campaign was spun into his first complete game and his second triumph as the Dodgers, almost reversing the previous day's score, beat the Giants, 10 -- 3, before a ladies' day crowd of 13,674.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Friday, June 23 (AP) --Allied forces, pressing a counter-offensive to drive the Japanese invaders from northeastern India, have cleared enemy troops from the Imphal-Kohima road in Manipur State, reports from the front said today.
