ELIZABETH, N.J., June 22 (AP) -- Florida's entries, Miss Doris Hart of Barry College, and Miss Lilian Lopaus of Rollins, seeded first and third, respectively, in the women's Eastern intercollegiate tennis tournament, moved through their quarter-finals today to face each other in a semi-final match tomorrow.

ROME, June 22 (U.P.) -- Taking advantage of better flying weather, a force estimated at 750 American heavy bombers attacked railway and industrial targets in northern Italy today for the first time since June 16. While these heavies of the strategic air force weakened the German ability to resist at the Riminic-Florence-Pisa line, the fighters and fighter-bombers of the tactical force resumed full-scale attacks in the fighting zones and the enemy's immediate rear.
LONDON, June 22 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 22 -- Prospective changes and progress in the widely divergent fields of chemical research, taxation and insurance may have a broad effect on future operation and income of office buildings, the National Association of Building Owners and Managers was told today by experts in these fields.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, June 23 -- After an eighty-minute bombardment by well over 1,000 medium bombers and light fighter-bombers, the sweaty, hard-bitten infantrymen of Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley's First American Army arose from their foxholes and plunged into the fire of the last and strongest German defense line outside of Cherbourg.
ROME, June 22 (UP) -- A communique:

The three-story dwelling at 174 East Ninety-third Street has been purchased by Mr. and Mrs. William Roos, writers, from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank through Hardy, Brauneis Naumann, Inc., and Jacob F. Liebler. It is assessed at $18,000 and was sold for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $6,000 for ten years at 4 per cent.

CHUNGKING, China, June 22 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace asserted today that the end of the war would mark "the beginning of a century of the common man" and that the Chinese would "find the American people marching by their side" at every step forward.

PATERSON, N.J., June 22 -- Employes of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation paraded before the company's Plant 1, here, today in protest against a company move which they said resulted in laying off 350 skilled workers.
CHUNGKING, China, June 22 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
LONDON, June 22 (U.P.) -- German "revenge" bombardment rose sharply today after a night of desultory attacks on southern England.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 22 (U.P.) -- Helsinki's attempts to form a new Finnish "peace" government have reached a standstill, late information said tonight, while Swedish newspapers speculated that the Germans might establish a quisling government in northern Finland if the Finns capitulated to Russia.

LONDON, June 22 -- Efforts to create an atmosphere in which a reconciliation can be obtained between Poland and Russia continued today when Prime Minister Churchill received Polish Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk for an hour's conversation.

Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch in a decision yesterday upheld the right of justices of the Children's Court to remand juvenile delinquents to the city prison pending their transfer to State Training Schools.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 22 (AP) -- Communique 33:

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of Government securities to have increased $178,578,000 during the week to a new high record, while note circulation for the system as a whole decreased $22,289,000. Ratio of reserve declined still further.

A new aircraft carrier, which will be named the Lake Champlain in commemoration of the brilliant naval victory scored by an American naval squadron under Commodore Thomas MacDonough in the War of 1812, will be purchased with the $100,000,000 subscription made to the Fifth War Loan by New York State.

Our Canadian friends have made an impressive record in all phases of their all-out war effort -- particularly in the hold-the-line program. An important feature of their program has been the large volume of war bonds sold to individuals, with the consequent need to have only minor recourse for funds from the banking system.

A goal of $2,670,000 for overseas relief and reconstruction-has been set for Protestant churches in this country to raise in the next twelve months, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Leslie Bates Moss, executive director of the Church Committee on Overseas Relief and Reconstruction, 297 Fourth Avenue.
JERSEY CITY, June 22 -- A statement issued late this afternoon at the Mayor's office, Jersey City, read:
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Friday, June 23 (AP) -- A communique:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, June 23 -- At least 6,000 Allied warplanes scorched German-held France from Cherbourg to Paris with bombs, rockets and bullets Thursday in dawn-to-dusk attacks, giving the closest support to the invasion armies since the liberation of France began.

A task committee to foster close cooperation between installment credit retailers and manufacturers of durable goods for the post-war period will be named soon, it was announced yesterday at the meeting of the Retail Credit Institute at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The war on all fronts has brought 178,677 casualties to the Army and 46,705 to the Navy.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal today hailed the "magnificent job" done by the Pacific Fleet in the victory of its carrier-based planes over units of the Japanese fleets, but declared the Navy "is not going to be satisfied until the Japanese Fleet is wiped out."

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs, the only announced anti-Dewey member of the New York State delegation to the Republican National Convention, suffered a heart attack Wednesday, night, it was disclosed yesterday, and will be unable to attend the convention.

ROME, June 22 -- Col. Charles Poletti, the Allied Military Government's new broom in Rome, swept the Fascist heads of every Government agency out into the street today as one part of the most vigorous twenty-four hours' of administration that the Eternal City has probably ever seen.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 22 -- Governor Dewey appointed today Noah C.A. Walter of St. Albans, co-manager of the Laundry Workers Joint Board of Greater New York, Amalgamated Clothing Workers of New York (CIO), as a member of the Industrial Board. This completes the membership of the board, which, under a law enacted last winter, was increased from five to ten members.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has borrowed John Hodiak from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the lead with Ann Baxter in "Sunday Dinner for a Soldier." He replaces William Eythe, who instead will have the lead in "Czarina," the Tallulah Bankhead film.

The Harlem Savings Bank has sold the seven-story apartment house for fourteen families at 55-57 East Sixty-fifth Street to Frederick Brown, the operator, for altering into small suites after the war. It took back a ten-year first mortgage of $100,000 and has agreed to advance to the new owner an additional $20,000 after the alterations have been made and to increase the mount of the mortgage to $120,000.

Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida, suggested last night that the move to withhold the electoral votes of certain States from President Roosevelt, should he be the Democratic party's nominee, was part of a grandiose plot to keep the United States out of any future world organization to keep the peace.

BOSTON, June 22 (AP) -- Knuckle-Baller Jim Tobin of the Braves turned in his second no-hitter of the season, a 7-0 affair halted by darkness after the fifth inning, today after his forces had dropped a fifteen-inning opener to the Phillies by a 1-0 margin.

ABOARD JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE FLAGSHIP off Saipan, June 22 (June 21, U.S. Time) (AP) -- The Aslito airdrome on Saipan, most valuable in Marianas and only 1,500 miles from Japan and the Philippines, was ready for operation today after seabees had repaired and extended its 3,600-foot main runway.

In recent years the local connotation of the word ice has been less the second tray in the refrigerator and more the Center Theatre. Sonja Henie and Arthur M. Wirtz did nothing to change that last evening, when they put on another of their excellent shows, this one called 'Hats Off to Ice."

JERUSALEM, June 21 (Delayed) -- What is possibly the first wartime assurance given to any country under a British protectorate or mandate concerning its post-war political status is contained in a note addressed by the British Government to the Emir Abdullah's Government of Trans-Jordan, it was revealed today at Amman, Trans-Jordan's mountain capital.
LONDON, June 22 -- Quiet again ruled in today's stock markets here, but prices generally kept steady.

" The Mask of Dimitrios," a mystery melodrama produced by Warner Brothers, will open this morning at the Strand. Based on the Eric Ambler novel, "Coffin for Dimitrios," the film features Sydney Greenstreet, Peter Lorre, Faye Emerson, Zachary Scott, Broadway actor who makes his screen debut in the title role, and Victor Francen.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- Bobby Estalella beat out a single with the bases felled and two out in the ninth to drive in the winning run as the Athletics took the second half of a double-header, 3 to 2, after bowing to the Red Sox, 5 to 4, in twelve innings of the opener before 10,540.

MOSCOW, June 22 -- The Moscow newspapers today published a full-page map of the front that is chiefly notable because it reveals that German counter-attacks at the southern end of Marshal Gregory K. Zhukoff's front have forced a Soviet withdrawal to the northeast from the Czechoslovak boundary, a distance ranging from twenty to twenty-five miles.

With victories to his credit over Sammy Angott, Slugger White and Joey Peralta, whom he knocked out, Ike Williams, Negro lightweight from Trenton, will make his first appearance in a main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.
TORONTO, June 22 (AP) -- Toronto and Jersey City broke even in their double-header tonight, the visitors winning the first game, 4 -- 2, and Toronto taking the second, 3 -- 1.

Just how far the present battle will go between the United Corporation and the management of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation over the latter's management policy with respect to integration proceedings before the Securities and Exchange Commission remains to be seen.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 22 (U.P.) -- At the southern end of the gap, Imperial troops repulsed three determined enemy attempts to check their drive north of Kanglatongbi and then counter-attacked with artillery support, inflicting severe casualties and capturing many rifles and equipment.

Frederick J. Chapey, assistant manager in charge of protective service in the Hotel New Yorker for thirteen years, who appeared at Police Headquarters last Saturday in behalf of Frank Costello, slot-machine claimant of the $27,200 found in a taxicab, has resigned his position at the hotel, it became known yesterday.

Officials at the State Motor Vehicle Bureau, 320 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, voiced surprise yesterday when 82-year-old Barnett Steinfeld of 1,035 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, passed easily the visual and hearing requirements for a driver's license.
Sir Howard and Lady Trott of Hamilton, Bermuda, are at the St. Regis.

MOSCOW, June 22 -- The Soviet Union began the fourth year of the war with Hitlerite Germany today with all signs pointing to the early launching of the biggest offensive drive the Germans have yet faced on this front, and indications are mounting that Finland, and perhaps some other satellites, may soon be knocked out of the war by either the military or the diplomatic route.

The new Sinclair Refining Company of Venezuela, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, announced yesterday that it contemplates the construction of a 35,000-barrel refinery on a site already owned near the Puerta de la Cruz, Venezuela, terminal of the Venezuelan Petroleum Corporation.

Seven officers in the German Army have been executed on a number of charges including "breach of their oath of allegiance to the Fuehrer by slandering, mocking and insulting his person," it was disclosed in a captured German High Command document reported yesterday by the Office of War Information.
Sir William and Lady Glasgow of Ottawa are visiting Dr. and Mrs. Wallace P. Cohoe of Stoneycrest, Riverdale-on-Hudson.

The one-story business building at 524 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased by an investor from the Devon Associates, Inc., which acquired the property about two years ago from the United States Trust Company. Halford Realty Company was the broker.

While encouraging reports have come from some areas regarding consumer acceptance of the 20 per cent fur tax, the industry feels that the August sales results will afford a more comprehensive picture of its effect upon volume, it was reported here yesterday.

BALTIMORE, June 23 (AP) -- The James Gibbons Company of Relay, Md., a contracting firm engaged in work on airports and highways, filed suit for $500,000 damages today against an American Federation of Labor union, charging a strike of employes had interfered with essential war work.

LONDON, Saturday, June 24 -- The Red Army opened its summer offensive on the main Eastern Front yesterday, attacking northwest and southeast of the White Russian fortress city of Vitebsk in a drive that began the third phase of the Allied master plan to destroy Nazi Germany by simultaneous blows from the east, west and south.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 23 -- With the Republican Party National Convention due to convene Monday, Republican voters in the Mountain, Pacific Coast and Southern sections of the country continue to name Governor Dewey their first choice for the Presidential nomination.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- The women's Western open golf tournament today reached the point to which it appeared headed all week -- a championship showdown between two of the game's longest hitters, Miss Dorothy Germain of Philadelphia and Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias of Beverly Hills, Calif.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Roosevelt indicated at his press conference today that he was not particularly impressed by the action of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, head of the French Committee of National Liberation, in appointing prefects and sub-prefects for the civil administration of the liberated areas in Normandy.
ROME, June 23 (AP) -- A communique:

ROME, June 23 -- The Germans have called a halt in central Italy to the galloping Allied advance and while steady smashing progress is still being made in most sectors, it is clear today that the Germans are making their first stand north of Rome.

Courtesy and use of polite language may prove to be the downfall of two young, armed thugs who Brooklyn police believe escaped with $5,000 from two hold-ups yesterday. Both were carried out before noon in Kings County under similar circummstances with the same methods being employed in each case.

PITTSBURGH, Saturday, June 24 (AP) -- The Pirates and Cardinals battled through fourteen innings, the last six scoreless, to a 5-5 tie. The game was called at the end of the fourteenth by the league rule ending night games at 1 o'clock this morning.

Charging that the Southern New York Baptist Association has been ruled during recent years by "liberal-minded" persons who deny fundamentalist doctrines, parishioners of the First Baptist Church at Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street voted last night at a business meeting to withdraw their membership in that organization.

Most 16-year-olds with big league ambitions would feel pretty low at having fumbled a fly, but not George "Red" Williams of 514 West Forty-eighth Street. George, who hopes to attain baseball fame as "the Red Williams of New York, has become the happy possessor of a $500 diamond ring as a result of a fumble three months ago.

AT A COMMAND POST ON SAIPAN, June 22 (Delayed) -- As the battle for Saipan enters its second week, it begins to appear that lack of drinking water may turn out to be the fatal weakness of this island's strong defenses.

LONDON, June 23 (AP) -- The Ministry of Home Security's routine evening announcement that "during the day there was enemy activity over southern England -- damage and casualties were reported" included such incidents as these:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23 -- Protests by the Hudson River Day Line and the village of Buchanan against pollution of the Hudson River at Indian Point, south of Peekskill, left the State and Westchester County Health Departments at loggerheads today as to which should take remedial action.

PITTSBURGH, Saturday, June 24 (AP) -- At least eighty-six persons were reported killed and hundreds injured last night when a violent windstorm of tornadic force twisted through southwestern Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia.

Individual sales of bonds on Thursday were reported yesterday to have established Fifth War Loan drive records for both New York City and the State, while the Treasury Department announced in Washington that sales of that day had boosted national purchases close to one-fourth of the individual sales quota.

Lieut. Col. William H. Combs, a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1929, died June 15 in Burma of wounds suffered in action, according to word received from the War Department last night by his wife, Mrs. Anthonette M. Combs of 45 Oxford Road, New Rochelle.

Members of the National Association of Securities Dealers have been warned that there are now two types of "when issued" contracts in the new securities of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company -- those drawn under the first plan of reorganization and those drawn under the plan approved yesterday by the Federal District Court in Chicago.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, June 22 (Delayed) -- After capturing Chiangtso yesterday the Chinese troops of the Twentieth Group Army under command of Gen. Huo Kuei-chang advanced toward Tengyueh today, one unit being less than ten miles north of the Japanese base.

Revision of the rules of the Court of Appeals to meet the new conditions for admission to the bar by young men returning from the armed forces was advocated yesterday by Chief Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The appointment by President Roosevelt of Col. William O'Dwyer, District Attorney of Kings County, New York, was announced today as the ranking American official of the Economic Section of the Allied Control Commission for Italy.

In order to prevent business failures and widespread unemployment when war contracts are canceled, industry must adjust its financial problems now, according to Norman W. Wilson, chairman of the corporation peacetime planning committee of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Services from the individual to the State, to compensate for the benefits granted to him under a democracy, must receive greater emphasis if the American way of life is to become a dynamic force, Dr. Jay B. Nash, chairman of the physical education and health department of New York University, old members of the Camp Fire Girls Council of Greater New York yesterday.

A flood of job opportunities in New York City hotels is aiding in the resettlement of about a hundred Japanese a month in the New York area, the War Relocation Authority reported yesterday in revealing that this district already had absorbed more than half of the 2,000 Japanese cleared to the Middle Atlantic and New England States in the last year and a half.

ABOARD THE FLAGSHIP, UNITED STATES FIFTH FLEET, June 21 (Delayed) (AP via Naval Radio) -- This huge force today completed the rout of the Japanese grand fleet from waters east of the Philippine Islands -- without firing a salvo from its formidable battle line or losing a ship.

Congressman James C. Auchincloss of New Jersey is a man who never stops trying. He's been active in the movement to lift offshore fishing restrictions, which has succeeded, and in the fight to get party boat owners more gasoline, which has failed so far.

CHUNGKING, China, June 23 (AP) -- Thousands of Chinese civilians are fleeing the rail junction of Hengyang, the Chinese announced tonight, making no attempt to minimize the city's peril as the Japanese closed to within twenty-five miles of their goal in a drive that may become a virtual battle for China.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Saturday, June 24 (U.P.) -- Allied medium bombers sank or damaged a 3,000-ton Japanese ship, five coastal vessels and three barges in the Sorong area at the northwestern tip of Netherland New Guinea on Thursday, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

LONDON, June 23 -- Business in today's stock markets was quiet because of the week-end influence but the undertone was steady. Some profit-taking was evident particularly in the entertainment section, but other industrial shares generally remained at yesterday's prices.

BOSTON, June 23 (AP) -- Policies concerning disposal of some $75,000,000,000 worth of surplus Government property at the end of the war must be "scrupulously fair to every business," and small business must be protected, Senator James E. Murray (Dem., Mont.) declared tonight.

NINTH AMERICAN AIR FORCE WING HEADQUARTERS, in France, June 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- Two American fliers, tired but elated, arrived here yesterday after days in hiding behind the German lines in the Cherbourg area.

RICHMOND, Va., June 23 -- Two patents aimed at increasing safety in transportation, one directed at improving the quality of meat before slaughter and one covering the use of soy-bean oil in printing ink were among the 578 listed as granted in the current issue of The Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

Operations at recruiting and induction stations in the Army's Second Service Command will be suspended, as far as the receipt and processing of selectees is concerned, from Monday until July 10 in New York State, and from July 1 to July 17 in New Jersey, it was announced late yesterday. Officials

BOSTON, June 23 (AP) -- Pennant hopes of the Red Sox, given a severe jolt in Philadelphia where they lost four games out of five, took another bump today in a 7-to-l setback at the hands of the Senators.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Arguments in the South's long fight for equality of freight rates on manufactured goods with the Official Territory of the North came to an end today to await a decision from the Interstate Commerce Commission.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 23 (AP) -- Special communique No. 2 from Supreme Allied Headquarters:

AN EIGHTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER STATION, England, June 23 (U.P.) -- Capt. Don S. Gentile of Piqua, Ohio, Eagle Squadron ace who has thirty German planes to his credit, has been awarded the Oak Leaf Cluster to the Distinguished Service Cross.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle assured the Senate judiciary subcommittee today the Department of Justice had no intention of prosecuting cases against insurance companies under a recent decision of the United States Supreme Court until after Congress, the States and insurance companies had had opportunity to study the decision.

A customer questionnaire to find out what women think of grocery stores so that grocers may plan their stores accordingly after the war was issued yesterday by the New York State Food Merchants' Association, A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the association, announced, as the opening attack in the independent food retailers' fight for their share of business in the keen competition expected when hostilities cease.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania was accused by Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia on the Senate floor today of making "a cowardly, vindictive, malicious and unwarranted" attack upon Senator Josiah W. Bailey of North Carolina, and of selecting a time for this assault when Senator Bailey lay ill at home in North Carolina.

The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, awarded diplomas to sixteen seniors at the thirty-first annual commencement exercises of the university's College of Pharmacy last night in Keating Hall, on the campus.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 23 (U.P.) -- British forces are retaining control of the Kohima-Imphal highway after re-opening land communications between Manipur State and the rest of India and relieving the long-isolated imperial garrison in Imphal, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (U.P.) -- The armed forces totaled 10,080,000 officers and enlisted personnel June 1 and requirements for young, able-bodied men were being met successfully, Selective Service said today in announcing that 159,000 of the 185,000 men inducted in May were between 18 and 25.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 23 (UP) -- Communique 35:

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh proposed to the special steel panel of the National War Labor Board today that a permanent salaried arbitrator be named to enforce the contract between the company and the United Steel Workers of America (CIO) by imposing penalties on those who violate the agreement.

The Columbia University School of Engineering held graduation exercises for forty-one yesterday at the Men's Faculty Club, 400 West 117th Street. Thirteen civilian candidates received engineering awards and twenty-eight members of the Navy V-12 unit at Columbia received certificates of attendance presented jointly by Columbia and the Navy.

George Fine has purchased from Paul S. Hitlin, builder and operator, the five-story apartment house at 1363-1365 Plimpton Avenue, the Bronx. The sale was for cash over a first mortgage held by the Manhattan Life Insurance Company.
Richard Tregaskis, author of "Guadalcanal Diary," has written a first-hand account of the Mediterranean war called "Invasion Diary." Random House will publish it on Aug. 14.

LEWISBURG, Pa., June 23 -- Expediting of the organization of an international agency to keep the peace was called for tonight by President Arnaud C. Marts of Bucknell University in the baccalaureate address to the graduating class.

Complaints of the upgrading of butter have become so numerous in both trade and consumer circles that the Office of Price Administration has just launched a nationwide survey of prices and grades at creameries and at shipping and receiving points.

LONDON, June 23 -- The fruits of five years of economic warfare and bombing may be apparent on the battlefield this summer. An oil shortage is threatening the operational mobility of the German armies to a point where it may well shorten the war.

WITH A CARRIER TASK FORCE OFF THE ANDAMAN ISLANDS, June 21 (delayed) (AP) -- Fighters and bombers of the fast-expanding Allied Eastern Fleet caught the Japanese by surprise early today and delivered a smashing blow at the enemy's installations at Port Blair, capital of the Andaman Islands in the Bay of Bengal and an outpost guardian of Japanese shipping lanes to Rangoon in Burma.
Murray L. Schacter has resigned as sales manager of the National Silver Company.
In response to your suggestion I am writing to present to you the facts concerning the consideration of the Red Cross bill by the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

The first knockout in a career that extends back four years overtook stout-hearted Cleo Shans, Los Angeles Negro, last night in Madison Square Garden. Before a paid attendance of 5,842, Ike Williams, Trenton Negro, knocked out Shans in the tenth and final round of a blazing battle.

Domei, Japanese news agency, has issued a report "for the information of bureau chiefs" in Domei offices in occupied East Asia on the visit of Vice President Henry A. Wallace in Chungking, United States Government monitors reported yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 23 -- Fifty members of the Class of 1945 will be graduated from Princeton University at commencement exercises in front of Nassau Hall tomorrow afternoon. Dr. Henry Pitney Van Dusen, president-elect of Union Theological Seminary, who is a Princeton trustee and member of the class of 1919, will be the commencement speaker.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Roosevelt laughed merrily at his press conference today when again pressed to say something about fourth-term intentions and then brushed the questioning aside with a remark, all in good humor, that it belonged to the boudoir.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Cleveland dropped the White Sox into a tie for third place with the Yankees when southpaw Al Smith, overcoming early wildness, held Chicago to four hits for a 5-to-1 victory before 22,684.

The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 260 West Seventy-second Street has been sold by the Admiral Management Corporation to an investing client of Pearce Mayer for cash over a first mortgage of $155,000 held by the East New York Savings Bank.

The notable increase in absent-minded taxi passengers who leave their valuables behind them may be due to one of several reasons. It may be the mysterious law of nature by which fatal railway accidents and fire disasters seem to come in spurts.

LONDON, June 23 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden promised an approving House of Commons today that the murderers of fifty Royal Air Force prisoners of war in Germany would be brought to "exemplary justice" after the war. His phrasing indicated retaliation rather than trial.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- Hundreds of war plant workers and other commuters in the bay area were left stranded today as Greyhound bus drivers continued their refusal, for the second day, to admit passengers in excess of seating capacity.

Apparently melancholy over the prospect of being committed as a juvenile delinquent to a girls' training school, 15-year-old Margaret Daily was killed after she fell or jumped from a fourth-floor window at the Brooklyn Shelter of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children shortly before 9 A.M. yesterday. She plunged

The Japanese menace will not end with this war, no matter how complete the victory, Sir Keith Murdock, Australian publisher, said in an interview here yesterday. Between visits to Columbia University and Herbert Hoover he paused long enough to point out that Japan's population soon would reach 100,000,000.

The Office of Civilian Requirements' estimate of infants' dress requirements of 42,000 dozen for the third quarter is less than one-third of the actual need, Max H. Zuckerman, executive secretary of the United Infants and Children's Wear Association, declared yesterday.

Sales of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., in its fiscal year ended with March rose 26 per cent to a new high of $177,901,262 from the previous year's volume of $141,046,615, O.H. Chalkley, president, informed stockholders, in the annual report to be released today.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 23 (AP) -- A communique:

Last December Sydenham Hospital decided that it would admit any qualified Negro into the ranks of its internes, resident physicians, surgeons and nurses, and that Negroes would also be represented on its board of trustees. The decision was acclaimed by those who have long been convinced that the color line is an anomaly in any branch of science.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, expressed confidence today that the bill passed by Congress extending the Emergency Price Control Act of 1942 another year would enable the Government to hold the line on both prices and rents.

On June 17 a communique issued under the authority of General Eisenhower said that since D-day the Army of French Forces of the Interior "has increased both in size and in the scope of its activities." Part of its plan of sabotage is the paralyzing of road and rail traffic and the interruption of telephone and telegraph communications.

Thirteen students who received high school diplomas yesterday afternoon at the 113th commencement exercises of the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, 999 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, were urged by the commencement speaker, Roderick Stephens, to have an "abiding interest" in good government and help to make the "new world" better than the present one.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- In a deal involving over $2,000,000, Associated Distributors, Inc., has been organized to take over the cosmetics business of Associated Distributors, and to continue to distribute the products of Dana Perfumes, a former Associated affiliate.

The confidently awaited Russian drive on the east front has begun. The Soviet communique announces that some time yesterday, "supported by massive blows from artillery and aviation," the Red Army "went over to the offensive against the German troops." The initial blows have been struck near Vitebsk, on the shortest possible line that leads through East Prussia into the heart of Nazi Germany.

Today's theme is salad dressings for summer meals -- the commercially prepared kinds that may be bought for quick use and the "makings" for those varieties (such as vinegars and seasonings) that are to be assembled at home.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Roosevelt made public today the personnel of the American delegation to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference, opening July 1 at Bretton Woods, N.H. He admonished the delegates that theirs was "the responsibility for demonstrating to the world that international post-war cooperation is possible."
Bishop William T. Manning made public yesterday a new wartime prayer for use by the clergy and laity of the Episcopal Diocese of New York. It is as follows:

Following the sharp run-up on Thursday, the cotton futures market on the Cotton Exchange reacted yesterday and closed 4 to 12 points net lower. The decline was attributed generally to a weakened technical situation.

Two new films will open today in midtown theatres. "48 Hours," a British topical drama starring Frank Lawton, will begin an engagement at the Little Carnegie Playhouse. The supporting cast includes Leslie Banks, Elizabeth Allan and Basil Sydney. . . .

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 23 (AP) -- Miss Betty Rosenquest of Rollins College, Winter Park, Fla., seeded No. 2 in the Women's Eastern Intercollegiate tennis tournament, breezed through a quarter-final match today to defeat Miss Joan Wheeler of Temple University, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, June 24 -- A strong enemy position on high ground three and a half miles east of Cherbourg and due east of Tourlaville was stormed and captured by American infantry yesterday as Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley continued his assault on the Atlantic port, with hundreds of guns beating out a devil's tattoo on the defenses of the doomed city.
A dividend of 15 cents a share together with an extra of 35 cents, making a total of 50 cents, was declared by the Central Republic Company for payment to common stockholders on July 15.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 23 (U.P.) -- Finnish political leaders, under strong pressure by Germany to remain in the war, sought vainly to reorganize the Cabinet tonight as the advance of the Russian armies made their position more dangerous each hour.

A reduction in industrial accidents in war plants throughout the country of 6 per cent so far this year was reported yesterday by E.G. Quesnel, regional representative of the National Committee for the Conservation of Manpower in War Industries.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 23 -- Mrs. James Travers of Northern Boulevard heard a pawing at the door of her home this morning and opened it to find that the sound had been made by a dog that the family gave away two years ago.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs today at the Midwestern major markets were the lightest for this time of the week since early May and well in line with current demand. Considerable progress has been made this week toward normal marketing conditions as a result of lighter receipts, improved demand, more lenient sorting, stronger prices and better daily distribution.

TAMIMENT Pa., June 23 -- Domestic problems and programs are insignificant as compared with the importance of decisions we shall make on international relations, Dr. Harry Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, declared today at the Tamiment conference.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 23 -- The American people have themselves to blame for the fact that the Federal Government has assumed more and more power over local affairs and Federal power will increase still more unless millions of people in thousands of small towns and cities work harder to make their communities more independent and self-respecting, President Alan Valentine of the University of Rochester told Colgate University's seniors at commencement today.

Thirty-one City College teachers, including Dr. John Roscoe Turner, Professor of Economics and former dean of men at the college, have been dropped from the instructional staff, it was revealed yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president. The reason offered by Dr. Wright was "schedule conditions and financial disability."

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe took under advisement today objections to a reorganization plan for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad and expressed surprise that one group of bondholders did not want to be paid in cash.

" In the Allied invasion of France the Norwegian Merchant Marine, Air Forces and Navy all played important roles; and in England and Scotland, the Norwegian Army stands ready to be called into action," Crown Princess Martha of Norway told an audience of 300 yesterday as she opened an arts and crafts exhibition portraying her country at war and in peace.

SOMEWHERE IN NORMANDY, June 23 -- This is one of the stories I have been aching to tell ever since I landed with the Sixth British Airborne Division by parachute in Normandy -- the story of a small group of daredevil men to whom most of the airborne troops owe their lives and safety today.
A Finnish communique, as broadcast by the Finnish home radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Some Republicans in Congress started a Byrd-for-Vice President boom today, but the Democratic Senator from Virginia told reporters:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 23 -- Dr. Ray M. Bowles and his guest, Frank Graven of Plandome, were co-medalists in the qualifying round of the best-ball invitation golf tournament at the Cherry Valley Club as the final scores were posted today.

Boy Scouts in the five boroughs collected 638,200 pounds of waste paper in May, it was announced yesterday by headquarters of their Greater New York Councils. Troops in Queens salvaged and sold 224,000 pounds; in Brooklyn, 200,000 pounds; Manhattan, 120,000 pounds; the Bronx, 80,000 pounds, and on Staten Island, 14,200 pounds.

LONDON, June 23 -- Reporting to the House of Commons on the first week's bombardment of southern England by German crewless planes, or flying bombs, Herbert Morrison, Minister of Home Security, declared today that there had been "little damage of national importance," and added that thus far public utilities had been "only slightly affected."
PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, PEARL HARBOR, June 23 -- Another of Japan's largest and newest aircraft carriers has probably been sunk and another destroyer definitely went down.

ALGIERS, June 23 -- In official circles here, it was said today that the negotiations with the British in London were going surprisingly well and fast. The British are regarded as being in a very conciliatory mood toward Gen. Ccharles de Gaulle.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 23 (AP) -- Kent Cooper, executive director and general manager of The Associated Press, told Australians in a rebroadcast address tonight he hoped Australians and Americans would work steadily together to remove a basic cause of wars -- perverted presentation of international news.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (U.P.) -- The Navy disclosed today that it was returning to the crew of the seaplane tender Coos Bay the $412 reported raised to "help pay the wage increase money-hungry strikers are demanding" and said it had ordered an investigation of the incident.
President, Douglas Gibbons Co.; Chairman, Professional and Special Services Section, Commerce and Industry Division.

The stock market inched higher yesterday as the corrective movement lost force. The rails spearheaded the mild recovery, but the brand of leadership was disappointing to financial circles as the bulk of trading was centered in stocks selling at less than $10 a share.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 22 (Delayed) -- While an Argentine court was passing sentence of two years' imprisonment yesterday on four confessed German spies, it became known that the Buenos Aires police lately had arrested and questioned a great number of United Nations' citizens.

In your issue of June 20 Count Coudenhove-Kalergi, in trying to prove that General de Gaulle's Committee in the de jure Government of France makes the fantastic statement that General de Gaulle is the legal successor of Marshal Petain, because the latter's authority has passed after his capture on to Admiral Darlan and then on to General Giraud, who succeeded him, to rest finally on de Gaulle, when Giraud was ousted.

Today is War Bond Day at Aqueduct and admission will be by the purchase of war bonds only. Those who want to enter the clubhouse need a $100 bond or more, while a $25 or $50 bond will entitle the buyer to a grandstand seat.

Reflecting the "priority" given the Fifth War Loan drive in the investment market, only $4,040,000 of new municipal bonds will come up for award next week, compared with this week's revised total of $16,964,000. According to the Daily Bond Buyer, the weekly average for the year to date now stands at $20,499,308.

LONDON, June 23 -- Tactical photo-reconnaissance aircraft of the United States Ninth Air Force have completed 4,000 individual sorties without losing one plane to the Lufawaffe in the past six months, Col. George W. Peck, 29-year-old commander of the group, said today.

The Office of Price Administration enforcement division announced yesterday that it would apply to the Appellate Term in Brooklyn to reconsider its unanimous reversal of two decisions of the Brooklyn First District Municipal Court by which Mrs. Betty Traunstein of 2041 Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn, received triple damages of $300, under the Emergency Price Control Act, growing out of the purchase of meat.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Weary of work and anxious to visit the voters and attend the national conventions, Congress recessed today until Aug. 1, after approving two important appropriation bills and winding up a multitude of details. Both houses stopped work at 5 P.M.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Office of Price Administration, acting on the advice of its machine tool industry advisory committee, revised today and extended its price control over sales of new machine tools, attachments and parts and issued a wholly new price regulation to include the alterations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- The Yankees, now backtracking at a furious clip to make up for the ground they lost during their long and harrowing slump, continued to zoom along on all cylinders tonight while a gathering of 20,512, which apparently had expected to see something of an entirely different nature, grunted and groaned.
In the statement of principles for the proposed International Stabilization Fund is this short paragraph:

NO smart horse-player willingly divulges his private and infallible system of beating the races. Not being a smart horse-player in the first place and not knowing any better in the second, this operative is about to reveal one way in which you can go to Aqueduct and be absolutely guaranteed that you won't lose one thin dime.

ADVANCED NINTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER UNIT, Somewhere in France, June 20 (Delayed) -- Air power means airfields as well as airplanes. And this is a brief description of how engineer battalions of the Ninth Air Force have worked night and day since D-day, sometimes only a mile and a half from the front lines and frequently under the heavy guns of the enemy, to provide necessary airfields.

Etsuzo Kurihara, chief of the naval press section of Japanese Imperial Headquarters, issued a formal statement yesterday warning the Japanese people that the "battle situation in the Saipan area is the most critical one since the beginning of the war" and that a major effort upon the part of the Japanese armed forces would be necessary to turn back advancing United States naval elements.

ALBANY, June 23 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today that vitamins, when listed in the official United States Pharmacopoeia or national formulary, were drugs and could be sold at retail only by registered pharmacists, drug stores and registered stores.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, June 24 (AP) -- Royal Air Force heavy bombers in great strength ranged over France last night and early today, continuing the Allied aerial assault that has subjected the Normandy battle zone and Nazi targets beyond to almost continual punishment for more than thirty-six hours.
LONDON, June 23 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast by the Berlin radio:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 23 -- The Axton-Fisher Tobacco Company, in dissolution, offered today to give holders of its Class B shares 141 pounds of tobacco in the form of warehouse receipts as a means of distributing assets. The offer consists of sixty-five pounds of flue-cured leaf, thirty pounds of flue-cured strip tobacco and forty-six pounds of burly leaf for each share.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- James S. Earley of the Office of Economic Adviser, Office of Price Administration, said today that the price control of clothing "was now OPA's number one problem."

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 --The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, a subsidiary of the NY Pa NJ Utilities Company, was permitted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to redeem and cancel 40,000 shares of its outstanding 160,000 shares of $100 par value Series D 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock at the redemption price of 105 a share.

Recommendations that 119 physicians lose the right to handle workmen's compensation cases for periods ranging from fifteen days to one year, were contained in a report submitted yesterday to Edward Corsi, Industrial Commissioner, by the compensation boards of the Queens, Bronx and Westchester County Medical Associations.

Penicillin, the powerful chemical used in the fight against bacterial infections, will be made available without cost to those in New York City who cannot afford to buy it, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday afternoon in an address dedicating the Bedford Health Center, 1,219 Fulton Street, near Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 23 -- The State War Council has authority under the War Emergency Act to provide for direct State operation of care projects for children of war workers, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today.

The new season's first vaudeville presentation, "Take a Bow," featuring Chico Marx, Cross Dunn, Raye Naldi, the Murtah Sisters, Gene Sheldon, Pat Rooney, Think-a-Drink Hoffman and J.C. Flippen, will terminate its Broadway engagement tonight.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Mayor Edward J. Kelly presented today to Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe his plan for settlement of Chicago's seventeen-year-old traction problem through municipal ownership.

Exceedingly sharp gains marked retail trade here this week. Merchants reported department store increases ranged from 25 to 40 per cent or more over last year. The explanation given was that trade now is picking up volume "lost" during the first ten days of this month when the impact of invasion and a drop in advertising cut consumer buying.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. came out flatly today for post-war revision of the Federal tax structure to encourage risk capital.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Ten conditions under which the War Manpower Commission will recruit workers for migration from one area to another under priority referral beginning July 1 were announced today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Buying for millers was a big factor today in giving the wheat market on the Board of Trade a strong tone, while hedge pressure was not especially heavy. Prices reacted from the early tops on profit-taking and a lull in the demand, but closing prices showed net gains of 1/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel.

THE peace books that are currently being written fall generally into two classes. There are the "blueprint" books which sketch the future in terms of "musts" and "oughts." And there are the "obstacle" books which, while usually admitting the desirability of certain of the "musts" and "oughts," still prefer to concentrate on the barriers that stand in the way of universal peace.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A sweeping order permitting railroads after midnight Monday to refuse passengers, cancel reservations and take whatever other actions are necessary to assure space for "invalid troops and their attendants," was issued today by the Office of Defense Transportation.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 23 -- Direct contribution by the French underground army to the success of the Allied campaign in Normandy was reported today in a special Allied communique that said that German armored divisions had been "seriously delayed" in moving up from southwest France to the battlefront.
CHICAHO, June 23 -- The program of the Republican National Convention was made public today by Chairman Harrison E. Spangler as follows:
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Senate Truman committee today praised the Liberty Ship as "the truck horse of the sea, but criticized its use as a troop carrier or hospital ship.
James Amster, interior decorator, has bought from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustee, the property at 213-15 East Forty-ninth Street through Martin Co.
Ed Head knocked hard on the door of baseball's hall of fame under the lights of Ebbets Field last night and was denied admittance by only one man, Charley Letchas, second baseman of the Phils.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The United States resumed diplomatic relations with Bolivia today after a period of six months of non-recognition.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 23 -- Accepting the "challenge of realities" -- a war on three fronts -- the German Propaganda Ministry today broke the news to the German public that the Russians had begun their summer offensive on a large scale in four sectors of the central-eastern front.

TRENTON, June 23 -- Gov. Walter E. Edge, leader of New Jersey's uninstructed delegation to the Republican National Convention, said today on the eve of his departure for Chicago that he would oppose any "wishy-washy" international policy plank in the party platform.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- A demand for a change in the Washington administration as the only possible fundamental corrective for a sprawling Federal bureaucracy was made today in a report of the Republican Committee on Reform of Government Administration, appointed at the Mackinac conference under the chairmanship of Governor Dewey of New York.

Barnet Steinfeld, 82-year-old motorist, proved yesterday his right to retain an operator's license by passing a road test conducted through exceptionally heavy traffic and for a longer time than is usually provided. On the previous day the octogenarian driver had amazed Motor Vehicle Bureau officials by meeting both visual and hearing requirements for a permit.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 61:
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Saturday, June 24 (AP) -- A communique:

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES, Before Cherbourg, June 23 -- Our troops slowly pushed toward Cherbourg today against a desperate enemy, fighting under orders to stand or die. Enemy troops were holding out both from stubbornness and fear. An order of Gen. Dietrich von Schlieben, commander of the fortress of Cherbourg, found on a German prisoner captured last night helps to explain why.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- George Brent has been signed by RKO for a co-starring role with Hedy Lamarr and Paul Lukas in the screen adaptation of Margaret Carpenter's murder mystery novel, "Experiment Perilous," which will be put before cameras in two weeks.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 23 -- Russell W. Davenport, who directed the campaign of Wendell L. Willkie for the 1940 Republican nomination, threatened tonight to bolt the Republican party unless convinced by its platform and candidate that it would crusade to interpret the American idea as a world idea for freedom.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Domestic issues rose today to claim a place with foreign problems in the attention of Republican party policy writers when Governor Dewey of New York sent to Chicago a statement attacking the National Administration as a sprawling, overlapping bureaucracy, "undermined by executive abuse of power."
CHUNGKING, China, June 23 (AP) -- A communique:

Day by day, as our hold in Normandy strengthens, the pattern of our employment of airpower is becoming increasingly clear. Our huge air superiority, amounting practically to domination, has enabled us to continue and expand heavy strategic pounding of the Reich and its satellites even while giving full tactical support to the troops in Normandy and providing a complete umbrella for the Channel supply routes.
CHUNGKING, China, June 23 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Immediate reduction by 300,000 of the Federal Government's more than 3,000,000 civil employes was demanded in a resolution introduced today by Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, on behalf of the Joint Committee on Reduction of Non-Essential Federal Expenditures.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Despite efforts of other candidates to form a combination to keep the nomination for President from going to Governor Dewey on the first or second ballot, it appeared today that agreement of a majority of the delegates to the Republican National Convention would be reached on nominees for President and Vice President and on the foreign policy plank of the platform before the convention opens Monday.

LONDON, June 23 -- A former Belgian Army officer, Pierre Richard Charles Neukermans, who came to Britain in the guise of a loyal Belgian subject to spy for Germany, was executed in a London prison today.

DETROIT, June 23 (U.P.) -- The real causes of war would be exposed and war discouraged by daily publication of news free from influence of self-interest, John S. Knight, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, said tonight in naming a committee of thirteen to seek international agreements on freedom of the press.

The Metropolitan Amateur Golf Association is returning to the game of golf with a vim this year and its handicap committee, under the chairmanship of Shepard Barnes of Baltusrol G.C., yesterday released 600 handicaps for the 1944 season. Under ideal conditions and without a war to worry them, the handicap committee would not consider this list as large, but since the total exceeds that of last season, it augurs wen for the game.

Reports of sales of Government-owned cotton in the South, continued ideal weather for the growth of cotton, and covering of contracts for pre-notice day in July led yesterday to slightly irregular prices for cotton on the New York Cotton Exchange.

RICHMOND, June 24 -- Ways and means by which Kentucky can expand industrially after the war were discussed the other day by Prof. Rodman Sullivan of the University of Kentucky before the Kentucky Pharmaceutical Association. He said that the State should be especially interested in the small manufacturing enterprise and in getting new industries to move there.

With net farm income in the United States at the highest level in history, the stage is certainly set for a land boom in the farming sections, the curtain has gone up on the first act, and whether a repetition of the first World War's post-boom collapse will occur in agriculture depends on whether farmers use surplus income to reduce debts and build up insurance against hard times in war bonds.

The value of an A gasoline ration coupon remains at three gallons because the Office of Price Administration must make allowance, in apportioning the available civilian supply, for the gasoline that is drained off through the black market, it was explained yesterday by Charles F. Phillips, national deputy administrator in charge of rationing.

" WILDERNESS TREK" was one of the manuscripts that Zane Grey left at his death in 1939. Four have since been published, and an indefinite number of others are complete enough so that the flow of adventure under the Zane Grey trade-mark will be unabated for some time to come.

VATICAN CITY, June 24 -- Pope Pius emphasized again today his fundamental conviction that the church must remain neutral during the war. The occasion was his reception of the prelates and priests of the Superior Council of Missionary Works.
As major league baseball starts the tenth week of its campaign Greater New York's three local clubs will pause in their serious pursuit of pennants for the more serious pursuit of war bond dollars.

THE Prairie Rose is a less exacting beauty than many of the modern roses which adorn our gardens. This native American actually has had more popularity across the Atlantic than at home -- a vogue dating back to the Empress Josephine's famous garden at Malmaison.

FILM theatre admission prices, which affect the purses of 95,000,000 persons weekly, according to the industry's own attendance estimate, have come in for some critical discussion recently in the trade press. At least three publications -- Motion Picture Daily, The Exhibitor and Harrison's Reports -- have sounded warnings of possible repercussions after the war as a result of the fluctuating price policies which are becoming increasingly commonplace.

The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration is opening an office here for recruiting persons qualified for overseas service with the relief organization, it was announced yesterday. The office will be in the Federal Building, Christopher and Washington Streets, and will be directed by Mrs. Marion H. Ray, on leave from the United States Civil Service Administration.

At high altitude the tissues of bomber crews freeze rapidly in winter, with the result that medicine is presented with a new problem. All the European victims have been collected at one army hospital in England for intensive study.

Retail trade here last week recovered sharply from the comparative lull noted during the first half of the month. Department store gains ranging from 25 to 40 per cent or more over the like week last year were reported. Increases were marked in many types of soft goods, including seasonal times, sports wear and staple goods.
TORONTO, June 24 (AP) -- Jersey City's Giants broke a 4-4 tie in the ninth inning to defeat Toronto 5-4, and gain an even break in today's double-header. The Leafs won the first game, 8-7.

WITH the official arrival of summer, five group exhibitions opened in the galleries. Two of these were in the nature of selective retrospects. Georgette Passedoit's show is marked by diversity, with, for example, several of the powerful canvases by B.J.O. Nordfeldt (including the one reproduced above) interspersed among sensitive landscapes by Eugene Paul Ullman, romantic vistas by Rudolf Jacobi and examples of the highly personal and suggestive impressionism of Edwin Dickinson.

A QUESTION frequently raised these days is "what has happened to our novels?" Some lay the blame on the war which has deprived us of so many of our potential writers. Others blame the reading public which is too easily satisfied.

Freshmen students entering Michigan State College when the fall quarter opens will be required to enroll in the two-year basic college recently established on the campus. The revised program includes comprehensive courses, such as written and spoken English, biological science, physical science, social science, effective living, origin and development of civilization and literature and fine arts.

LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- Cherbourg is a "fire-spitting hell" and German troops are retreating into its recesses "only after they have fired their last bullet," the Berlin radio said tonight, quoting a frontline report.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Chicago, where eleven Republican Presidential candidates have been nominated since the birth of the party ninety years ago and of whom seven were elected, is prepared tonight to do its best as host under wartime conditions.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Senate Rules Committee has recommended the creation of a special Senate-House committee to see what can be done about streamlining Congress.

Black market charges against sole leather jobbers selling to the shoe repair industry, made by various manufacturing and retail associations, well may fit the foot of those making them, according to C.L. Engstrom of C.V. Engstrom Company, Peoria, Ill., retiring president of the National Leather and Shoe Finders Association, which held its annual convention last week at the Hotel New Yorker.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- A foreign-policy plank for the Republican platform, adhering closely to the Mackinac Charter composed at Mackinac Island last September and differing only as to details and elaborations from the draft which was presented yesterday by Senator Vandenberg, was adopted unanimously today by the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Republican National Convention.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Prices of wheat declined sharply today on the Chicago Board of Trade, with pressure on the July especially heavy. The market was influenced mainly by the favorable weather conditions and the expectation of heavy receipts of wheat in the next few weeks.

Ethelbert Smith said that the history of our own times, as recorded from day to day in the newspapers and weeklies, is bound to be fragmentary and often vague. That is why he finds himself envying our children and grandchildren when they come to read the story in their schoolbooks.

LAST Sunday we glanced back over the local season, finding it to have been unusually productive in the exhibition field. Only now, late in June, is the brisk run of new shows tapering off into a summer schedule full of promise.

MEXICO CITY, June 24 (AP) -- Directors of the Guatemalan Popular Union in Mexico asked President Manuel Avila Camacho today to intercede in behalf of Guatemalans who might be affected by the decree of President Jorge Ubico which, they said, curbs individual rights.

LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- King Peter of Yugoslavia and Marshal Tito of the Yugoslav Partisans will probably meet soon to draft final details for the unification of all anti-German elements into a wartime government for all-out blows against the enemy.

IN virtual demonstration of the art of diplomacy, Dexter Perkins (known for his thoroughgoing studies of the Monroe Doctrine issued in the course of of the last twenty years) has written a retrospective and prospective essay on the meaning of major public events in and between the two world wars.

THE light cruiser Helena was one of the first ships to see action in the Pacific war. She was hit by a torpedo in the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. Repaired, she returned to action in the battle for the Solomons, participating in three of the great night engagements of those stirring days.

Plastic "ghosts," which are mathematically accurate averages of the trim feminine dimensions of the Wasps, are now enabling designers to adjust plane interiors and equipment to girl fliers. Plane quarters have been scaled primarily to the bulkier male dimensions of the United States Army Air Forces.

RECOGNIZING the average player's tendency to put in a defensive overcall when he should not, bridge writers and teachers have devoted much of their efforts to a crusade against unwise overcalls. In so doing they have neglected to emphasize the many cases in which an overcall is so clearly indicated that it would be highly improper to pass.
Chungking, June 24 -- Following is the text of the joint press release issued by the Chinese News Service at the conclusion of Vice President Wallace's visit in Chungking:

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- With Ernie Bonham ready to take his regular turn on the mound, Tuck Stainback almost recovered from the broken bone in his ankle and the newcomer, Herschel Martin, having given clear indication that the outfield situation already may be considered vastly improved, Manager Joe McCarthy today was almost inclined to view the Yankees' pennant prospects in a more optimistic vein than he has been able to reveal in a long time.

A rabbit recipe that stretches a skimpy cheese ration is this one: Place one eleven-ounce tin of condensed tomato soup in a saucepan, add a fourth-pound of grated cheddar cheese and heat over a very low flame, stirring constantly.

MONTREAL, June 24 (AP) -- Tom Sunkel fanned thirteen of the Bears tonight while the Royals were winning the game, 6 to 2. He gave seven hits and walked six, but was strong in the clinches, and the Bears left ten runners stranded.

THIS little volume gives a timely insight into the workings of the French underground, which already, in cooperation with the invading Allied armies, has carried into the open its 4-year-old clandestine struggle against the Boche.

THIS is a historical story of the twelfth century in which a young Welsh girl, Halcyon del Myddrai, a medical student of Salerno, and the great Welsh scholar Giraldus de Barri, known as Giraldus Cambrensis, play the leading parts.

The war is approaching a climax. The end seems in sight. Post-war problems will be numerous and complex. Unemployment is the chief problem. A stable free society depends on its solution. The Twentieth Century Fund lists over one hundred organizations that are studying post-war problems. The mass effect is confusing to the layman.

LONDON, June 24 -- The operations in Normandy are following a plan decided on a year ago. That plan gave the American forces the spectacular role of storming and capturing the vital stronghold of Cherbourg, while to the British forces was assigned the undramatic task of containing all the enemy's armor east of Tilly-sur-Seulles in a dull but important slugging match.

All last week trains feeding into Chicago carried Republicans to the twenty-third national convention of their party. By yesterday most of the 1,057 delegates, many of the 20,300 spectators and the majority of the 1,150 newspaper and radio men who will report and interpret the proceedings had arrived and were crowding the hotels.
