FLOWERING Tobacco or Nicotiana is an invaluable annual for all those busy gardeners whose working time is brief and whose enjoyment is usually limited to a few hours at dusk. It is then that Nicotiana affinis opens its long lovely tubes of bloom and pervades the garden with its fragrance.

AT the moment when British and American armies are again on French soil, an understanding of the problems of France may help to banish the sinister specter of estrangement which once sundered the three great western allies.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, June 25 (U.P.) -- Strong Liberator bomber forces, attacking five Japanese bases in the Caroline Islands Thursday night, destroyed or damaged twenty-two grounded planes when they dropped thirty-three tons of explosives on the Yap Island airdrome, Gen. Douglas MacArthur stated today.
STOCKHOLM, June 24 -- Arne Andersson and Gunder Haegg, two of Sweden's most rapid trackmen, will meet Wednesday in their first 1944 assault on the world record book after months of secret training.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES Before Cherbourg, June 24 (U.P.) -- The captain of an infantry company told today how Corp. John D. Kelly of Grove City, Pa., knocked out a pillbox with concrete and steel walls six feet thick.
ONCE again Henry Kane, in photographs that are rare and lovely and in a simple, beautiful prose, gives us a glimpse of a world close to our own but with the mysterious quality of a fairy tale.

CHUNGKING, China, June 24 (AP) -- The last major barrier in the swift Japanese march on vital Hengyang apparently has fallen, and there were indications that the enemy in this drive would employ encirclement tactics against the Hengyang rail junction similar to those that brought about the fall of Changsha, the Chinese High Command intimated tonight.

There has grown up a disposition to criticize the newspapers for their war news. The most often heard complaint is that the papers publish reports which are too optimistic; that they make war look like roses and posies whereas, in fact, it is mostly blood and mud.

Sponsored by individual banks and bankers' associations throughout the country, the United States Secret Service, a division of the Treasury Department, has conducted during the last five years a campaign on "Know Your Money" and has reduced losses by counterfeit money in the nation to a negligible figure.

LONDON, Sunday, June 25 -- While the war is being waged and won on land and in the air in Russia, Italy and France, the relentless battle between Allied naval forces and German submarines to keep open our supply routes goes on.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Nomination of Governor Dewey for President by the Republican National Convention was definitely assured today when representatives of Illinois with fifty-nine votes and Pennsylvania with seventy votes notified the promoters of Mr. Dewey's candidacy that they would support the New York Governor.

LONDON, June 24 -- Defensive measures have been put into operation against the German flying bomb and they have proved encouragingly efficacious. They consist chiefly in massed bomber attacks on enemy launching apparatus across the Channel and interception along the British coast to destroy the missiles before they get far inland.

" A WALK IN THE SUN" is one of the most honest books to come out of this war. It is a small novel possessing dramatic tension, sustained and skillful progress of narrative, a poetic and realistic speech. It deals with a minute aspect of the war, yet, because of its genuineness, is vaster than the currently popular "vast" books.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, June 25 -- The Allied air forces thrust the power of their heavy and lighter bombers and fighters against the Wehrmacht yesterday to disrupt the flow of enemy reinforcements to Normandy.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 24 (AP) -- Plans for an invasion of France were being studied as early as 1940, when the Germans still were plotting to overrun England, it was disclosed tonight, and at one time the British decided that a single division would suffice to capture the Cherbourg Peninsula.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- With sales of bonds in the Fifth War Loan campaign lagging throughout the country, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that American individuals had more than enough money tucked away in cold cash and bank deposits to oversubscribe by six times their $6,000,000,000 allotment in the $16,000,000,000 drive.

" BRASSEY'S NAVAL ANNUAL," like "Jane's Fighting Ships," has become tradition to those who follow the world's navies. Like Jane's, it is a hardy perennial, with a flavor as British as its origin; like Jane's, it becomes thicker and thicker with each year of war; like Jane's, it suffers in wartime from censorship restrictions and inadequate and dated information.

THE climate of the United States, in comparison with that of western Europe, is nothing short of melodramatic. England, for instance, our traditional mother country, knows neither extreme cold nor extreme heat by American standards.

Residents of New York State have purchased E bonds and other individual issues at a rate of more than $100,000,000 a week since the start of the Fifth War Loan drive on June 12, officials of the War Finance Committee reported yesterday.

CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE HEADQUARTERS, June 24 -- After twenty days of attacks by Chinese ground troops and artillery and occasional bombings by the Fourteenth Air Force, about 150 Japanese still retain small fortified points atop the Sungshan, which towers on the west bank of the Salween River.

ALBANY, June 24 -- Governor Dewey urged today that more women volunteer for nurse training to relieve overcrowded hospitals and called for an increase in blood donations, pointing out that more blood plasma would be needed as the fighting in Europe grows more intense.
CHICAGO, June 24 -- The program of proceedings far the first day of the Republican convention is as follows:

Remember when the Germans talked so much about "encirclement"? For two decades we heard little out of Germany but loud wailings over the "iron ring" that had been drawn around them by a hostile world. They could not breathe because the "strait-jacket of Versailles" held them in a vise.

LONDON, June 24 -- The world strategical picture changed rapidly this week as American armies smashed at the defenses of Cherbourg, the Red Army opened its summer offensive and Marine and Army troops made good their landings on Saipan in the Pacific.

A court test of State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein's ruling that concentrated vitamins may be sold only by pharmacists or in stores registered by the State Board of Pharmacy appeared likely yesterday as grocers protested that the ruling would give drug stores a virtual monopoly in this State on a business that amounts throughout the nation to $250,000,000 a year.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES In Italy, June 24 (AP) -- The possibility that the recent rush of fresh enemy troops into the Italian battle may have been precipitated because the Pisa-Rimini line fortifications to the north have not been completed was voiced in some quarters today as the American forces neared this seaport.

OVER THE CHERBOURG BATTLEFRONT, June 24 -- This Piper Cub spotter plane is ticking along only a few hundred feet above the battlefield on which the Americans are contesting with the German defenders of Cherbourg.

DOCTORS' and dentists' appointments are again on the family calendars; such items as "rubbers," "name-tapes" and "shoelaces" are jotted on mothers' lists. The children are going to camp. This year veteran junior campers have some helpful ideas to offer.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Three big American Army transport planes, including one Stratoliner of the type formerly used in coast-to-coast passenger travel and two of the even bigger Douglas Skymasters, have been shot down by mistaken friendly fire.

UNDER what star, and with what midwifery, was the monster of nazism born? Dr. Brecht -- an estimable civil servant entrusted with missions of great importance under the German Governments of the Weimar period -- replies by putting the emphasis upon principles of government rather than upon personalities.

New courses dealing with the war effort, special workshops for the retraining of teachers and programs stressing post-war economic and social problems characterized the summer session as classes began last week in colleges and universities throughout the country.

Premier Per Albin Hansson of Sweden said yesterday that, although the focal point of the fighting in the west was "relatively far away" from Sweden, its repercussions were being felt in Scandinavia and that "both belligerents are considering active measures in this part of the world also."

A four-way expansion program calling for an expenditure of approximately $7,000,000 is planned by the Frank G. Shattuck Company and its subsidiaries, Gerald Shattuck, president of the company, stated yesterday in an interview at the company's offices, 58 West Twenty-third Street.

In civilian Italy last week Allied officials were encountering problems in politics which indicated the difficulties to be faced as the liberation of Europe continues. Rome had been the first of the European capitals to be freed; it had an immediate heritage of German domination, a longer history under the fascist regime of Benito Mussolini.

Prominent among the items on the long list of supplies shipped from this country aboard American merchant vessels is railroad equipment, with sufficient locomotives, freight cars and other apparatus to operate several large railroads, already delivered, according to the American Merchant Marine Institute.

The 18-year-old Calvin (many names) McLish, aided by the lusty clouting of his teammates, pitched the Dodgers to an 8 -- 3 triumph over the Phillies yesterday at Ebbets Field before a crowd of 10,431, which included 4,000 yelling members of the Knothole Gang.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, called on all war industries and Government agencies today to support "to the hilt" the new war workers recruitment program which goes into effect throughout the country July 1.

The Norwegian Merchant Marine was well equipped for its part in the war of transport, with approximately 7,500,000 deadweight tons of shipping, but more than four years of war has cost that country about one-half of its pre-war tonnage, according to Oivind Lorentzen, director of the Norwegian Shipping and Trade Mission.
CHICAGO, June 24 -- The G.O.P. elephant clumped into this city today with mouselike footfalls.

The world monetary conference opening Saturday at the Mount Washington Hotel, Bretton Woods, and extending through July 15, will bring several hundred people to this resort. Practically all accommodations in the vicinity have been reserved for that fortnight.

So much advance buying has already been done that the traditional after-the-Fourth buying rush probably will not be done this year, according to the market report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Difficulties, however, the report adds, continue to mount in many hard-to-get lines, and for early fall many staple items will be even scarcer.

PERENNIAL and biennial seeds sown between now and mid-August reward the gardener with pleasure that cannot be imagined by the garden owner who buys plants from the florist. The fun of raising one's own is infinitely greater than the plagiaristic joy of having flowers for which the nurseryman really deserves the credit.

The deepening cold-storage crisis soon may represent the most serious threat to the nation's food program. This was conceded yesterday by a representative of the War Food Administration after the American Institute of Food Distribution had advised its members that "the implications of the unholy storage mess go deep" and that, "unless a drastic remedy is found, hundreds of thousands of tons of perishable food are threatened."

ON THE AMERICAN BEACHEAD, Somewhere in France, June 24 (AP) -- American troops advancing on Cherbourg have captured several sites from which the Germans may have intended to launch robot bombs against Britain.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 24 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, urged in an address today that the United States recognize the responsibilities of leadership which its military and economic power confers and thus show the way to a system of law between nations by which each can live in peace under justice.

THE lonely heart in America today is lonely by courtesy only. The art of letting concealment feed on the damask cheek is practically lost. "Dear Dorothy Dix, Dear Doris Blake, Mr. Anthony, my problem is this" -- the demands of the harassed, publicly seeking help, flood the newspapers and jam the air waves.
IF the United States is to win the peace and begin effective world collaboration at the end of World War II it will have to be not by treaty of peace but by executive agreement.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (U.P.) -- The Ball-Burton-Hatch-Hill group in the Senate, which advocated a separate international police force to keep the peace, urged tonight that all candidates for the Presidency and for Congress state "clearly and forthrightly" their positions on foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- While taking a stand in favor of United States cooperation in international currency problems, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States urged today "the most careful examination" of the proposals to be implemented by the United Nations conference convening July 1 at Bretton Woods, N.H.

The Citizens Union has proposed to the Joint Legislative Committee on Legislative Procedures that the Governor receive additional time, both during the session and after adjournment, to consider bills passed by the Legislature, it was announced here yesterday.
ALLIED ADVANCE COMMAND POST in France, June 24 (U.P.) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower returned here today after his second tour of the American beachhead position in France.

ROME, June 24 -- Fifth Army forces battering northward against increasing German opposition have trapped an enemy force in a 225-square-mile pocket above Grosseto on the Tyrrhenian coast, while other spearheads have pushed northeast along Highway 73 beyond Roccastrada, twenty-three miles southwest of the big Siena road junction, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Delegates, alternates, newspaper and radio observers and spectators in general were gathering in Chicago today to take part in and witness the virtually certain nomination of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York for President in the Republican National Convention beginning on Monday.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 24 -- Symptomatic of Vichy's isolation, moral and material, since the invasion began is the announcement today that Joseph Darnand has decided entirely to recast the Forces for the Maintenance of Order, of which he is supreme chief.

PORT BOU, Spain, June 24 (AP) -- Reports reaching Spain from France tonight told of a German victory over French patriot forces in one Jura Mountain town, but said that the battle was only one of many raging between the harassed German and southern French volunteer forces.

Acting deans of two law schools will join the law faculty of the University of Virginia for the summer term beginning July 3 and continuing until Oct. 21. Clayton E. Williams, acting dean, Washington and Lee Law School, will teach two courses in real property, and Dudley W. Williams, acting dean, William and Mary School of Jurisprudence, will teach contracts and negotiable instruments.

IN municipal planning we must decide between revolution and common sense -- between the subsidized lamas in their remote mountain temples and those who must work in the market place. It is a mistake to underestimate the revolutionaries. They do not reach the masses directly, but through familiar subsurface activities.

By Jimminy, Alfred P. Parker's brown colt, took a long stride toward the year's 3-year-old championship when he won yesterday's twenty-seventh running of the $50,000 added Dwyer Stakes in such formidable fashion that practically no one in the War Bond Day crowd at Aqueduct ever had the slightest doubt who would be in front at the end of the mile and a quarter run.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, aspirant for the Republican nomination for the Presidency, urged the United States in a speech here tonight to make "more history at the crossroads" of the country and less in Washington.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 24 -- Allied diplomacy, after a long and unfortunate period of hesitation, having finally resolved to seek a path out of chaos for Greece and rendering firm assistance to that country's Government in an effort to solve its troubles, is now trying to move along the same sort of lines in Yugoslavia.

" HELLO, fighting men in the Pacific! Are you lonely tonight? This is Radio Tokyo bringing you your Sunday evening concert hour. Tonight we feature the magnificent playing of the Boston Pops Orchestra."

Tomorrow there will come together the first of the two great national party conventions. The spectacle has become so familiar to us that we have all but forgotten how anomalous it is. For the Presidential nominating convention is a body unknown to the Constitution. It has, in effect, usurped the functions that the framers of the Constitution intended to confer upon the Electoral College.

WITH the approval of the Office of Defense Transportation, the Jersey Central has added to its schedules two week-day summer trains and twenty-one week-end summer trains to or from the New Jersey shore area.

WHEN the news came that a small American fleet under Commodore George Dewey had gained a decisive victory over the Spanish fleet at Manila Bay on May 1, 1898, the nation was thrilled as it had not been thrilled in a generation.

FEW things are more exasperating than the trials that beset the inexperienced laundress. Between the shortage of help and the delays in getting work back from the laundry, more and more housewives these days are getting their first introduction to the washtub. But with the proper organization and technique the job isn't the drudgery that it is proverbially claimed to be.

ST. LOUIS, June 24 (AP) -- The Browns combined a strong hitting offensive with effective pitching by Bob Muncrief for a 7-to-1 victory over the Tigers today, stretching their American League lead to 3 1/2 games over the second-place Red Sox, who were idle.

FIRST of all this is the tragic story of the love of Julian Day, a young British Army officer, and Daphnis Diamapholus, a beautiful girl of mingled Greek and Italian parentage. It is also the story of the adventures of these two and of their joint fight against a Nazi spy ring.

LONDON, June 24 -- The Germans have started new mass executions in Polish concentration camps, Dr. Emanuel Scherer, a representative of the Jewish labor movement in the Polish National Council, announced tonight.

Ever since the Battle of Midway the American and Japanese naval staffs have been operating with two different strategies in view. The American and British Navies are trained to fight whenever and wherever the enemy can be found. The Japanese, on the other hand, have had few running fights in open water and those experiences have not been happy ones.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 24 (AP) -- Bill Hulse of New York, America's fastest outdoor miler, failed today for the second time this year to set a new record for the three-quarter mile.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 24 -- The Bumble Bee took command again out on Long Island Sound today, defeating thirteen other international sloops in the fifth special regatta of the season, which was held by the Horseshoe Harbor Club.

AS Somerset Maugham remarked in conversation the other day, all novelists whose work has a true basis in human life write, to a greater or less degree, about themselves. This is a fact that holds for the greatest among them as much as it does for the merely competent

There will be 16 per cent more game birds and animals than now in five years and 27 per cent more in twenty years if a survey just completed by the Remington Arms Company is at all accurate. The company hastens to add that the percentages must be considered only in the light of the composite opinion of the best authorities among State and Federal officials, experienced sportsmen and others and cannot be definite.
BERNE, Switzerland, June 24 -- Attacks by Italian patriots are backing a wave of general strikes in northern Italy, according to reports tonight to the Swiss press from the Italian frontier.

CRIME is paying me very well. After four years and some months of writing the "Crime Doctor" series for CBS, I find I have no complaints with the sociological menace. Not that I mean to condone transgression, but it is infinitely more lucrative than any other medium I have put my pen to.

A bright future is assured for our American Merchant Marine in the post-war period if the marine industry takes advantage of the knowledge learned in the laboratory of this war, a knowledge that has been acquired at a rate of speed never before approached, according to Reginald E. Gillmor, president of the Sperry Gyroscope Company, Inc.

Carrying high their hopes of a Dewey victory not only in the convention but in the November election as well, New York City's delegation of 150 men and women left Grand Central Station yesterday Chicago-bound for the Republican National Convention, which opens tomorrow.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 24 -- With the Republican nominating convention opening Monday, the popularity of Gov. John W. Bricker as a Presidential nominee has increased slightly as compared to last month, while that of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has declined, a final survey by the institute shows.

OMAHA, June 24 -- Notwithstanding the repeated pleas of the Office of Defense Transportation to limit travel to necessity the coming of summer and the vacation season has brought a state of super-saturation to the passenger traffic facilities of the Midwest.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- A committee of ten newspaper executives, after conferring with Canadian newsprint manufacturers in Montreal, recommended today that this country abandon the use of the new, lightweight 30-pound newsprint.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Sunday, June 25 (UP) -- A communique:

FOR EX - PRESIDENTS: Former Presidents of the United States frequently enjoy a kind of elder-tatesman position in American pollute and exert some influence on public opinion and national affairs. Last week in Congress Representative Gordon Canfield of New Jersey moved to give them a more official position.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Hope of distillers, law enforcement agencies and thirsty, free-spending Americans soared this week as the War Production Board suddenly ended a twenty-one-month ban on the manufacture of whisky by naming August as the month when distillers could put aside industrial alcohol and make what they choose to do. No one doubted that the choice would be beverage alcohol.

ELIZABETH N.J., June 24 -- Representative Donald H. McLean of Hillside became the first Republican in two decades to assume the office of Union County prosecutor when he was sworn in today by Supreme Court Justice Clarence E. Case before a large gathering of Republican leaders here.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The War Production Board announced today that permits have been issued for the importation of additional quantities of Mexican gin, rum and other beverage cane spirits, which is expected to bring in 325,000 proof gallons of these beverages in addition to the original 1944 importation quota of 1,300,000 proof gallons.

Mikhail Botvinnik, 32, retained the chess title of the Soviet Union on Wednesday when he finished first in the U.S.S.R. championship tournament, held in the auditorium of the House of Trade Unions in Moscow, according to a wireless dispatch from the Soviet correspondent of the magazine Chess Review.
Dr. John Joseph Moorhead of 115 East Sixty-fourth Street will retire as medical director of the New York City Transit System on Aug. 1 after a month's vacation, it was learned yesterday.

Your June 12 editorial "The Case for Airships" would indicate that you have accepted rather unwarily the arguments presented in the article by Rear Admiral C.E. Rosendahl and Kyle Crichton in Collier's magazine. The seemingly persuasive case for the economy and utility of the airship as a commercial carrier is based on data which are either hypothetical or obsolete, and presented solely with a view to selling the perspective of the lighter-than-air craft enthusiasts.

After a Department of Sanitation crane truck and the police of Emergency Squad 11 had raised an automobile that had plunged into Sheepshead Bay at Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, just after 3 A.M. yesterday, they recovered the body of Robert Price, 27 years old, of 285-A Fourteenth Street, a civilian electrical engineer employed by the Government.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Strict rationing of all liquor sales to officers at naval shore establishments operating "wine messes" has been put in effect.

Political prisoners are being forced to work on German fortifications in Norway to compensate for the failure of a German labor-mobilization drive there, the Swedish newspaper Stockholms Tidningen said in an article reported to the Office of War Information last night.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Of the five New Yorkers who have been elected to the Presidency all served as Governor, which means that each gave his party advance proof of vote-getting ability in the State with the most electoral votes; also the State which Presidential candidates must nearly always carry to be elected.

For several hours beginning in the early morning and ending at 3 P.M. yesterday, 100 detectives and fifty patrolmen staged one of the most intensive manhunts in recent years for one of three Negro hold-up men who had shot and critically wounded a plainclothes policeman in Harlem.

A fifty-count criminal information accusing the Equitable Trading Corporation, wholesale liquor dealer, and its president, Hyman Karlin, of 99 Hudson Street, of violating the Office of Price Administration's maximum price regulations, was filed by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally in the Federal court yesterday morning.
LONDON, June 24 -- This is the critical period in the battle of supply in France.

Details of the world's greatest ferry service, which uses 10,000-ton Liberty ships as invasion craft, reached United Seamen's Service headquarters here yesterday. The communication, as relayed by the War Shipping Administration to Douglas P. Falconer, executive director of USS, revealed that it takes these cargo-carrying "ferries" just forty-eight hours to rush into the south England ports, load up and dash back over to the Normandy beachheads with essential supplies.

A BRITISH journalist who witnessed the Republican convention in Chicago which nominated Abraham Lincoln in 1860 sent back a lurid account of the spectacle to his newspaper. He loosed a veritable flood of adjectives to describe the pandemonium which broke when Lincoln's name was placed in nomination, people whooping and yelling and running about like a horde of "Comanches."

LONDON, June 1 (Delayed) AFTER a non-stop run of four years and two months, "Gone With the Wind" pulls out of the Little Ritz in Leicester Square, and goes on the road in a second nation-wide release.

For the first time the conventions at which the two great parties are to nominate their respective candidates are to be brought right into the home -- alas, at second-hand twenty-four hours later in the form of motion pictures transmitted by local stations. Instantaneous, direct transmission is possible but the facilities are not available.

That was an interesting article that Frederick Graham wrote about the air-borne soldiers for the Magazine, but allow me to correct one of Mr. Graham's errors which I am sure irked many glider troopers who read his article.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 24 -- Sons of Bowdoin came home today, in body and in spirit, to mark the 150th anniversary of the rugged New England liberal arts college, whose history and accomplishments parallel the evolution of the United States.
TEANECK, N.J., June 24 -- Champion Warland Warboy, superb Airedale terrier, this afternoon scored his fifth best-in-show victory, repeating his triumph of last Sunday at Westport, Conn.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 (AP) -- The Cardinals, held to a 5-5 tie in fourteen innings by Pittsburgh last night, unlimbered their heavy artillery this afternoon to pound three Pirate hurlers for a 16-to-0 victory.
Saturday's communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press in New York:
GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 24 -- The two low qualifying pairs in the member-guest best-ball golf tournament at the Cherry Valley Club were eliminated in the opening round of match play today.

The Negro pilots of the Ninety-ninth Fighter Squadron, operating in the Mediterranean area since April, 1943, more than proved their qualifications for aerial combat by shooting down seventeen enemy planes, two captains of the Squadron asserted yesterday in an interview at Army Public Relations, 90 Church Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- O.F. Hoskins, conciliator for the Department of Labor, today recommended for certification to the War Labor Board the dispute over "standees" in Greyhound buses and which has caused a deadlock in negotiations for a contract between the bus operators and drivers.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- The White Sox defeated Cleveland, 2 to 1, today when Third Baseman Grey Clarke twice singled in a run to cash Orval Grove's eight-hit pitching effort. The triumph gave the Chicagoans undisputed possession of third place, a half game above the idle Yankees, with whom they had been tied.

ARCHIBALD YELL'S reach does not really exceed his grasp, although in his own eyes it always seems that it does, as he searches for "new roads to glory" on the frontiers of 1812-47, from Tennessee, New Orleans and Arkansas, to Washington, D.C., and Mexico.
Last week Adolf Hitler, who has made no secret of his dread of fighting a two-front war, was fighting on four fronts at the very moment that his Japanese ally was being sorely beset.

Action of the stock market since D-day is being variously interpreted in Wall Street, but analysts agree that the technical position is strong. Disagreement concerns the basic reasons for the advance this month. One group holds that the public, which had been getting into cash since early in the year in expectation of a post-invasion slump, began to buy again, sending prices up.

MRS. HARD'S story of a Protestant child in a Catholic convent school presents none of the problems one might expect from such a situation. Kate Champion's life in the Couvent du Sacre Coeur differs little from that of any schoolgirl at the turn of the century.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- A move to put a labor leader in the second place on the Republican ticket to "win labor back to the party" was started today by friends of William L. Hutcheson, president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, and a vice president of the American Federation of Labor.

STANTON, Del., June 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' Ace Card toyed with a field of nine opposing 2-year-old fillies to coast home six easy lengths ahead of her nearest rival in the five-furlong $5,000 Polly Drummond Stakes at Delaware Park today.
A communique, as broadcast by the Finnish home radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
The regional Office of Price Administration and the City Markets Department started yesterday a two-pronged attack on unscrupulous food purveyors.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- A number of American planes were destroyed in a recent German air raid on two airdromes in the Soviet Union used by the United States Army Air Forces in shuttle-bombing operations over Europe, the War Department announced tonight.

SEATTLE, June 24 (AP) -- Employes of the Lake Washington Shipyards at Houghton, Wash., which built the U.S.S. Coos Bay, addressed a letter to the ship's crew today in care of The Associated Press announcing that they were taking a collection to reimburse the sailors for the $412 the crew contributed to "buy off strikers of the Wright Aeronautical Company, or any other struck war plant."

SETTLING a huge theatrical estate is no humorous matter. Hence Pasadena Playhouse is having to go without its customary summer of mirth for the first time since war impended. Not George M. Cohan but Sidney Howard is to supply the stage fare for the Ninth Midsummer Drama Festival here.

GUNNAR PIHL was Berlin correspondent of the Swedish newspaper Sydsvenska Dagbladet from 1931 through 1934, and from 1938 to Aug. 2, 1943, when he was arrested by the Gestapo for having telephoned to his paper the contents of a widely distributed official leaflet urging women, children and aged people to leave the city because of air raids.

ALBANY, June 24 (AP) -- Members of the armed forces on parole from New York penal institutions totaled 2,097 in 1943. Frederick A. Moran, chairman of the State Parole Board, said today that less than twenty-five were inducted direct from places of detention and the rest by their local selective service boards.

SIDNEY, Neb., June 24 -- A movement to "draft" Governor Warren of California for the Republican Vice Presidential nomination was accelerated today after Southern California delegates joined their colleagues from the northern part of the State at Cheyenne.

Yellow fever was conquered largely with the aid of volunteer soldiers under Walter Reed's direction. They permitted themselves to be bitten by fever-carrying mosquitos. In jail prisoners have volunteered to serve as guinea pigs for the benefit of physicians, who were able with such aid to determine that pellagra is a deficiency disease and to add considerably to our knowledge of influenza, malaria and other diseases.

OPERA returns to the Lewisohn Stadium beginning tomorrow night when Verdi's "Aida" will be presented with an all-Metropolitan Opera cast under the direction of Alexander Smallens. Zinka Milanov, Bruna Castagna, Kurt Baum and Alexander Sved will sing the leading roles and the work will be repeated Tuesday evening.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The firmly established and overwhelming American superiority in the Pacific theatre was strikingly demonstrated this week when the Japanese Fleet, after suffering disastrous air losses and considerable damage to it surface ships, fled from combat with the Pacific Fleet.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Marshal Pietro Badoglio, who was recognized as the head of the provisional authority for Italy until recent Allied recognition of the new Bononi coalition Cabinet, has informed President Roosevelt that his "separation from the Government will not for a single day interfere with my activity as a sponsor of friendship between the United States of America and Italy."

IN commemoration of the capture of Italy's Monte Cassino by Polish troops on May 18 the Polish Ministry of Industry, Commerce and Shipping, with headquarters in London, will on Tuesday release four stamps which will be valid on letters "posted from Polish merchantmen on the high seas and warships wherever they may be."

Reports on the working capital of corporations released recently by the Securities and Exchange Commission have given the public "a dangerously misleading impression,'' according to a statement issued yesterday by Robert Gaylord, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 62:

FAME sometimes catches up with one in the most unexpected ways, as Peter Lorre discovered the other evening while standing in the lobby of a midtown hotel. An anonymous gentleman beaming with good-will and alcohol halted abruptly about ten feet away from Lorre and fixed his happy stare upon the actor.

Retail trade continued active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floor activity was brisk, with dress, sportswear, children's wear and home departments outstanding.

NAVAL AIR HEADQUARFTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 24 -- Japan is nearer defeat this week than ever before in her history. Unless the enemy has lost all touch with reality (which sometimes appears to be the case) it must now be evident to thinking Japanese that they are going to lose, that nothing can stay the superior forces of the United Nations.

Charging that the Securities Exchange Commission has overstepped its functions in declaring that all industry has plenty of working capital to convert to peacetime operations without financial aid, Robert Gaylord, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, denounced the findings yesterday as either "unintelligent" or "done for some other purpose not clear."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- As West Coast delegations entrained for Chicago and the Republican National Convention, this segment of the Union speculated this week on the likelihood of the party's nominating a Coast leader for Vice President for the second successive time.
NEW ORLEANS, June 24 -- Opposition to the renomination of President Roosevelt by Southern Democratic leaders is weakening, owing to the expressed sentiment of an apparent majority of the people.

GEORGE CREEL, now Washington correspondent of Collier's, held in the last war the job corresponding roughly to that held by Elmer Davis today -- though in this war the activities involved have been greatly multiplied and expanded.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Under the impact of the war the prices of diamonds have risen to unprecedented heights in this country, but the market for lesser stones in the jewelry trade has experienced a sharp slump.

" PRIMER DIA DE EMISION" (First Day of Issue) cover from Buenos Aires is prepaid with copies of the 5-centavos sky-blue and white stamp released on June 4 to commemorate Argentina's political revolution on that date in 1943.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- An interdepartmental committee of Government technicians has agreed on a national post-war cartel policy, it was learned today, but final acceptance, rejection or modification of its proposals at a higher level of government awaits recommendations of a committee on international commodity agreements, expected next week.

ABOARD A JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FLAGSHIP, Saipan, June 24 (U.P.) -- American marines and soldiers today fought their way up to the sheer, jungle-covered cliffs guarding Mount Tapotchau, the most savage terrain encountered in the Pacific since the Attu campaign.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 24 (AP) -- Frederick C. Prior, No. 1 man on the Princeton net team this year, won the men's Eastern intercollegiate singles crown today by beating his team-mate, Chadwick Johnson, 6 -- 2, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3. Prior was top-seeded in the tournament and Johnson was unseeded.

This is the story of a Fortress bombardier. It reveals the kind of ordeal that war is for a young American and what, out of that ordeal, he has learned. It consists of excerpts from letters written, without thought of publication, to his parents by a 22-year-old lieutenant who recently completed a tour of missions as a member of the Eighth Air Force.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, June 25 -- Yard by yard Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley's hard-hitting infantrymen have slugged their way through German defenses of Cherbourg until last evening the vanguard from the south was assaulting the fortifications from 2,000 yards south of the center of the city, Allied Headquarters stated last night.

More than 15,000 discharged veterans from all branches of the armed services have been employed by airplane, engine and accessory manufacturers of the East Coast who are members of the Aircraft War Production Council. Many of these veterans have been through bitter combat service and many are suffering serious physical handicaps.

MORE optimism and more money are among factors contributing to the present upswing in travel. This is the opinion of railroad officials who are joining the ODT in persistent appeals to the public not to take trips unless they are necessary. Some people have heeded these pleas, but still the volume of travel increases.

CHUNGKING, China, June 24 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace ended his mission to Chungking today with a joint Chinese-American press release that declared that enduring peace in the Pacific would depend on permanent demilitarization of Japan; understanding, friendship and collaboration among China, Russia, Great Britain and the United States, and recognition of the right of self-government for Asiatic peoples now dependent.

The story of the hidden workings of Rockefeller Center in THE TIMES Magazine was interesting and illuminating to me, even though I am a constant frequenter of its buildings. However, there is a photograph illustrating the story, whose caption seems incorrect.

Dr. W.E.B. DuBois, who recently was honored by the National Institute of Arts and Letters by election to membership as one of the nation's leading scholars, will retire from active service at Atlanta University on June 30, where he has been chairman of the Department of Sociology since 1932 and editor of Phylon, the Atlanta University Review of Race and Culture, since 1940.

CINCINNATI, June 24 (AP) -- The Reds broke out of their losing streak today by grace of a bunt, sacrifice, infield play and single which made for a 1-0 decision over the Cubs for rookie Jim Konstanty.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- A picture of San Francisco's harbor choked with ships laden with vitally needed war materials but unable to move to Pacific bases because of lack of crews was drawn today by the War Shipping Administration.

EVER since they pooled their talents to create "Oklahoma!" the names of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d have been linked with one project or another. The extent and anticipated duration of the union, however, was not guessed until the other day when Mr. Rodgers remarked: "We have no plans that don't include each other."

NOT every little girl who is as strong-minded as Clarinda finds so convenient and fascinating an escape from the rigors of home discipline as did she. LONDON, June 24 (U.P.) -- Many persons were saved by shelters when a flying bomb demolished a number of houses and shops, but three persons were killed today. Near-by residents said the bomb "power-dived" with its engine still going instead of "cutting out" before descending.

THE practice of medicine and surgery in the New World, the first hospitals and the first medical schools was an established institution for several generations in Latin America before its counterpart made its appearance in North America.

NEW lighter shades of lipstick, pale coral and intense pink, form the latest beauty vogue launched by cosmetic manufacturers. After years of wearing lipstick of medium and dark shades of vermilion and purple-red, it is generally agreed that women must readjust their ideas on make-up before the trend toward lighter colors becomes general.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 24 -- Hampered considerably by heavy rainfall throughout the week, 1,500 members of the Sixth and Seventy-fourth Regiments of the New York State Guard completed today a twelve-day field training schedule at Camp Smith here with results that were commended by Cols. George J. Winslow and Alan F. Reif.

ALGIERS, June 24 -- Official circles here today denied knowledge of the "roundabout" information that, President Roosevelt said yesterday, he had received to the effect that Gen. Charles de Gaulle was going to Washington in the second week of July.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 24 -- Bob Wallace of Baltusrol and Al Williams of the home club held first place at the halfway mark in the annual Rock Spring Club member-guest best-ball tournament today. They compiled a 70 to lead forty-six other teams in the thirty-six-hole competition, which will be completed today.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut declared today that the Republicans recognize the strategic importance of the women's vote, then added that no enduring structure will be built when the war ends unless it is founded on "a just peace."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 24 -- The Germans in Copenhagen were subjected to a "rocket-bomb" attack last night.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES BEFORE CHERBOURG, June 24 -- American troops are firmly established 1,000 yards from Cherbourg at two places tonight and are still forging ahead. All day they hammered through one strong point after another until at dusk strong advanced elements were within a mile of the heart of this vitally important port.

Rear Admiral Albert B. Randall, USNR, Commandant of the Maritime Service, yesterday afternoon officially opened its new permanent headquarters in the old Army and Navy Club at 30 West Forty-fourth Street. More than 100 visitors and officers from near-by training stations attended the brief ceremony.

MAGICIENNE BAY, Saipan, June 19 (Delayed) -- Risking their lives to provide the enemy with a chance to surrender, American intelligence officers set up a loudspeaker today on a ledge over a network of caves and broadcast to Japanese garrisons trapped inside a guarantee of safe surrender.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 24 -- Suspended after the 1941 competition, the Metropolitan Amateur Golf Championship, frozen in the possession of Mike Cestone of Branch Brook since, was revived today over the picturesque Sleepy Hollow layout.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 (AP) -- Rescue forces were searching for more victims tonight in the ruins left by a great storm which swept across parts of Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Maryland yesterday evening, taking a toll of 145 lives and injuring hundreds.

One of your correspondents takes Maury Maverick to task for using "none" in a plural ssnse.

IT was Cuthbert S. Kilocycle, who lives in Jackson Heights, sells insurance and listens to the radio, who suggested it. Pulling up a chair, mopping his brow and muttering peevishly about the failure of the electronic industry to air-condition Times Square ("where is that inventive genius they're always talking about?"), he allowed that he had dropped in to have a little chat about revues.

TRAVEL is broadening, they say, but Phil Weintraub begs to disagree. The first baseman of the Giants has been in organized ball for nineteen years and has worn the uniforms of twenty-one different clubs, exclusive of side trips to several semi-pro outfits. If he had owned stock in the various railroad and bus companies he has patronized he could have retired wealthy on his own travels.

Because of the imminent further decrease in the amount of lumber available for civilian furniture production and an expected large increase in demand, record attendance is forecast for the semi-annual New York furniture market, which opens tomorrow at the Furniture Exchange, 206 Lexington Avenue.

IT is more than a little amazing that the most impressive war-news film of the past three weeks has been "Attack! The Battle of New Britain," the War Department's report on a six-month-old event. And the reason it is so amazing is that this fifty-four-minute document arrived almost simultaneously with the first invasion newsreels.

ASPARAGUS is a perennial vegetable crop which yields annually a generous quota of delicious stems for eating. Once established in the garden, the planting will produce for ten to twelve years, and if well cared for it may produce abundantly for fifteen to eighteen consecutive years.
LONDON, Sunday, June 25 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 24 (U.P.) -- British Chindits have seized the strategic trail junction of Sawngching, twelve miles southwest of beleaguered Mogaung, a communique announced today, while Chinese troops three miles west of Mogaung captured the last of the long-range 150-mm. cannon with which the Japanese had plagued the Allies in north Burma.

THE green light for reconversion preparations was turned on by the War Production Board over the last weekend but within forty-eight hours it was changed to the orange cautionary signal by Chairman Nelson in testimony before the Senate Truman Committee.

TAMIMENT, Pa., June 24 -- A capitalist system of free enterprise is capable of greater production than any collectivist system and also makes possible the greatest amount of individual freedom. Henry Hazlitt of THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial staff told the Tamiment Conference on Social and Economic Problems today.

EARLY summer is the time when fresh ducks (as contrasted with the cold-storage variety available in the winter) are most plentiful. This year the Long Island crop, which supplies many sections of the country, is good, practically equal to that of a normal pre-war year. Long Island, by the way, is the biggest duck-raising center in the United States, and most of the industry is concentrated in a small area near Patchogue.

United States Attorney General Francis Biddle filed yesterday in the United States District Court here a complaint against E.I du Pont de Nemours Co., the National Lead Company and its subsidiary, the Titan Company, Inc., in which they were accused of having established a monopoly in the titanium industry through a series of agreements.

SALVIA Selarea, or Clary, is a biennial herb which comes easily from seed, to bring an unusual accent to the garden and a delightful fragrance as well. It is a stout, two to three foot plant, with a look of the mint tribe about it, and loose racemes of small flowers.

American air and sea power last week made new cracks in Japan's ocean defenses and widened earlier ones. The largest Navy in the world -- one of its Pacific task forces alone is credited with being strong enough to rove the Pacific at will -- was on the offensive in the largest ocean in the world, its foe the one remaining Axis navy.

IF you take your literary fare pretty much for granted, just as you eat your breakfast honey without a thought of the blossom it came from or the diligent bees that gathered it, a new volume of Americana may seem to you an event hardly worth noting.

As the initial move in its plan to set up a sales training course for soft floor coverings salesmen in the post-war period, the Carpet Institute of America will send out questionnaires this week to 10,000 retail stores that handle carpets throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (U.P.) -- Chairman Walter F. George of the Senate Finance Committee called on both political parties tonight to write planks calling for post-war tax reductions into their platforms as a means of encouraging business expansion.
Yesterday's Soviet communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The infield at the Polo Grounds yesterday was sprinkled with a sooty coating of coal dust to protect Billy Jurges' eyes from reflected sun glare. But, this was only touching the surface. And, after what the Boston Braves did to Mel Ott's Giants, a gathering of 8,529 fans was unanimous that a first-aid station somewhere handy to the infield would have been a much more practical precautionary measure.

LONDON, Sunday, June 25 -- Two mighty Red Army forces are closing pincers from the north and south on Vitebsk in White Russia, and the German-fortified town already is threatened with encirclement, Moscow said early today.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- A triumvirate of New Yorkers, J. Russel Sprague, national committeeman; Edwin F. Jaeckle, State chairman, and Herbert Brownell Jr., chairman of the law committee of the State committee, is leading the draft-Dewey movement at the Republican National Convention and from all indications is doing it very well.

MOSCOW, June 24 -- As they claw at Vitebsk and heighten the danger to Polotsk, Red Army veterans are using new tactics and improved weapons to such good effect that the long-prepared German defenses have been rent at record speed.

IN World War II the "debunking" of wartime "idealism" is preceding military victory instead of following it, as in World War I. increasing numbers of civilians apparently share the widely publicized desire of soldiers, sailors and airmen to "get it over with and go home."

ROCHESTER, June 24 -- What was said to be the first magnetic motor, operating purely on magnetic current supplied by a permanent magnet, was demonstrated here today before the meeting of the American Physical Society at the University of Rochester by Prof. Felix Ehrenhaft, who recently startled the scientific world with experiments which, he maintains, provide proof for the existence of pure magnetic current.

Specialties-took the lead yesterday in a stock market which was dull and closed mixed. Trading on the Stock Exchange was the smallest since June 3, or 558,110 shares, compared with 1,064,480 a week earlier. Of the 736 issue, traded, 310 rose, 199 fell and 227 were unchanged.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows.

BOSTON, June 24 -- The silks of Mrs. Weston W. Adams, daughter-in-law of Charles F. Adams, former president of Suffolk Downs and now the director of racing, took the laurels in today's feature at Suffolk when Cavatorta captured the $5,000 added Sonstitution Mile before a rain-drenched throng of 17,789.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Amazing recovery shots from traps and rough today gave Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias her second women's Western open golf championship in four years with a 7 and 5 victory over 20-year-old Miss Dorothy Germain.

STOCKHOLM, June 24 -- This week-end Finland is rapidly drifting toward a Nazi-manufactured civil war. The situation is the immediate outcome of the overwhelming successes of the Soviet armies, who in a little more than a week rolled back the Finns from positions they considered extraordinarily strong, if not impregnable, on the Karelian Isthmus as well as in Soviet Karelia.

There are many methods of earning a livelihood in a nation of 135 million people and one of the best is to own a mountain pasture. In thin-soiled regions, high above the rich valley farms which line the river's winding path, the hill farmer can make a living renting pasture grazing to the dairyman who wishes to "put out" his dry cows and young stock for the season.

With the Republican National Convention opening in Chicago tomorrow, Wendell L. Willkie, the party's standard bearer in 1940, has not yet decided on his plans in the forthcoming Presidential campaign.

LIKE everything else in a competitive world, theatrical productions take their places on a sliding scale of success. At the top are the fat and happy hits like "Oklahoma!" and "The Voice of the Turtle." Down a little, but still entered in black upon the ledgers, are the minor successes, those plays which give 150 or so performances on Broadway and then head cheerfully for the subway circuit or the road.

DETROIT, June 24 (AP) -- Little Johnny Adams, the Iola, Kan., veteran who tops American jockeys in winners since 1941, booted home five today before 13,580 fans to equal the riding record at the Detroit track.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 24 (UP) -- A communique:

THE second Viscount Halifax, father of the Ambassador, now Earl, was not interested at all in politics. He collected strange animals, "like deer, yaks, emus and kangaroos," and he also collected authentic ghost stories.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 24 -- Our carrier force, spreading destruction from Rota to the Volcano Islands, has destroyed another seventy-two Japanese planes and sent five more cargo ships to the bottom.

EASTON, Pa., June 24 -- America is confronted with the great opportunity and responsibility to see to it that an order is established among nations based upon the same concepts and faiths on which our own form of Government has been constructed, Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, said today in a commencement address at Lafayette College.
CHUNGKING, China, June 25 (AP) -- A communique:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, June 25 (U.P.) -- The London Sunday Express, published by Lord Beaverbrook, Lord Privy Seal, praised the achievements of American forces in Normandy in an editorial today and said American work had been "superb."

One of the ostensible objects of the proposed International Stabilization Fund is "to promote exchange stability." The more the "statement of principles" for the fund is examined, however, the more difficult it becomes to find exchange stability in it. It provides, indeed, that when any nation enters the fund a par value for its currency shall be fixed or stated; but this can apparently be changed at any time.

NORMANDY, June 25 -- The bells of a local church -- silenced by the Germans for the same reason that Britain's bells were muted -- rang this morning for the first time in four years. And about half a hundred natives of this small village put on Sunday clothes to join eighty dusty khaki-clad G.I.'s in services at the 400-year-old Norman church.

Large increases in the prices of livestock and oranges, and the continued increase in the price of rosin, were the main factors which caused the Irving Fisher index to rise by 0.1 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.84 to 113.00.

An audience of 6,000 persons at the Lewisohn Stadium which heard Sir Thomas Beecham, in his final appearance, conduct last night the program postponed from Saturday night because of rain was favored with an outdoor orchestral concert of unusual excellence, for Sir Thomas was at his best, and his best is very good indeed.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 -- The steel ingot rate for the nation last week remained unchanged at 97.5 per cent of capacity. Indications are that it will be equaled or exceeded this week. Likewise steel order volume was strong, with little or no change on the rate of incoming bookings.
In 1935 the average American consumed 1.9 pounds of canned fruit juice a year; in 1940, 8.5 pounds. Now the rate has dropped but only because civilian supplies have shrunk owing to the war.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Chicago has tried hard to whoop up the Republican National Convention, but the race between Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Gov. John A. Bricker seems so one-sided and the big guns at Cherbourg make so much noise that it just won't whoop.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (U.P.) -- A large fleet of new and deadly attack-transports, each capable of landing 1,000 men with a complement of tanks and heavy guns, is under construction in American shipyards, it was made known tonight.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Gerald L. K. Smith, leader of the America First Crusade, caused a minor diversion today by "seizing" the ballroom of the Stevens Hotel, Republican convention headquarters, and holding a rump meeting in the face of disapproval by the convention management.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The country's railroads, hauling more freight, more civilian passengers, and more members of the armed forces than ever before, may reach their maximum capacity even before the experts had figured, the Office of War Information made known today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, June 26 -- Flying high over the Normandy battle zone and southward another 400 miles to within seventy miles of the Spanish border a powerful force of American heavy bombers yesterday attacked a Nazi fuel dump and airdromes in the Toulouse area.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- The Republican convention committee's subcommittee on housing wishes all room-hunters might approach the scramble for quarters as cheerfully as a woman delegate from Connecticut did.

Despite the pessimistic prophecies of "smart aleck" magazine writers and the bearish attitude of real estate speculators, there is no cause for worry about the city's business and commercial future, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.
